it may take 2 weeks or longer to feel the full benefit. keep taking it even if you feel better. do not stop taking it without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine: your doctor may prescribe this medicine for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking aripiprazole, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to it, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your previous reaction. give your doctor and pharmacist a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. some products, including st. john’s wort, may interact with aripiprazole. do not start or stop any medication, over-the-counter product, or herbal supplement while taking aripiprazole without first discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have severe diarrhea or vomiting or think you may be dehydrated. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had heart disease, heart failure, a heart attack, an irregular heartbeat, high or low blood pressure, a stroke or ministroke, seizures, a low white blood cell count, high cholesterol dyslipidemia, balance problems, or difficulty swallowing. tell your doctor if you or a family member uses or has used street drugs, overuses prescription medications or alcohol, or has or has ever had diabetes, obsessive-compulsive disorder, an impulse-control disorder, bipolar disorder, or a strongly impulsive personality, and if you have ever stopped a mental health medication because of severe side effects. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor. if you become pregnant while taking aripiprazole, call your doctor; taking this medicine during the last months of pregnancy may cause problems in newborns. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking aripiprazole. aripiprazole can cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. alcohol can increase drowsiness; avoid alcohol while taking this medicine. aripiprazole may raise your blood sugar hyperglycemia, even if you do not have diabetes. people with schizophrenia are at higher risk of developing diabetes, and medicines like aripiprazole may further increase this risk. call your doctor right away if you have extreme thirst, frequent urination, extreme hunger, blurred vision, or weakness. untreated high blood sugar can lead to ketoacidosis, a serious condition. call your doctor immediately if you develop dry mouth, nausea and vomiting, shortness of breath, fruity-smelling breath, or decreased alertness. aripiprazole can cause dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting when you stand up too quickly, especially when starting treatment. rise slowly from bed, letting your feet dangle for a few minutes before standing. this medicine may reduce your body’s ability to cool itself in very hot conditions; use caution if you will exercise vigorously or be exposed to extreme heat. if you have phenylketonuria pku, note that the orally disintegrating tablets contain phenylalanine. if you have diabetes, know that the oral solution contains sugar. some people taking medicines like aripiprazole have developed strong, unusual, or compulsive urges such as gambling, increased sexual urges or behaviors, excessive shopping, or binge eating. call your doctor if you develop these urges or cannot control your behaviors. tell family members about this risk so they can contact your doctor if you do not recognize the problem. when aripiprazole is used in children, it should be part of a comprehensive treatment plan that may include counseling and special education; ensure your child follows all treatment recommendations. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor about drinking grapefruit juice or eating grapefruit while taking this medicine. drink plenty of water daily while you are taking aripiprazole. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? aripiprazole may cause side effects. common side effects include: headache; nervousness; restlessness; dizziness, unsteadiness, or balance problems; heartburn; constipation; diarrhea; stomach pain; weight gain; changes in appetite; increased saliva; pain especially in the arms, legs, or joints; and tiredness. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have any of the following, or any symptoms listed in the important warning or special precautions sections: rash; hives; itching; swelling of the eyes, face, mouth, lips, tongue, or throat; trouble breathing or swallowing; seizures; uncontrolled movements of the face, tongue, or other body parts; fever; stiff muscles; sweating; confusion; fast, pounding, or irregular heartbeat; problems with coordination or increased falls; or tightening of the neck muscles or throat. aripiprazole may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: aripiprazole injection
instructions: important warning: older adults with dementia (loss of memory and brain function) have a higher chance of death if treated with antipsychotic medications such as aripiprazole. they may also have an increased risk of stroke or ministroke during treatment with antipsychotics. aripiprazole extended-release (long-acting) injection is not approved by the food and drug administration (fda) for treating behavior problems in older adults with dementia. your doctor or pharmacist will give you a medication guide when you start aripiprazole extended-release injection and each time you receive a dose. read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have any questions. talk with your doctor about the risks of receiving aripiprazole extended-release injection. why is this medication prescribed? aripiprazole extended-release injection is used to treat schizophrenia, a mental illness that affects how a person thinks, feels, and behaves, and bipolar i disorder, a condition that causes depression, mania, and other abnormal moods. aripiprazole is an atypical antipsychotic. it works by changing the activity of certain natural substances in the brain. how should this medicine be used? aripiprazole extended-release injection comes as a powder to be mixed with liquid and as a suspension to be injected into a muscle by a healthcare provider. it is usually given once every 4, 6, or 8 weeks, depending on the specific product. if you have never taken aripiprazole before, your doctor may have you take aripiprazole tablets by mouth for up to 2 weeks before your first injection. you may also need to take aripiprazole tablets or another antipsychotic by mouth for the first several weeks after your first injection. this medication helps control your symptoms but does not cure your condition. keep all appointments to receive your injections even if you feel well. tell your doctor if you do not feel you are improving during treatment. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving aripiprazole extended-release injection, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to aripiprazole, any ingredients in the product, or any other drugs, foods, or substances; describe the allergy and what symptoms you had. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. the herbal product st. john’s wort may interact with aripiprazole; do not start st. john’s wort while taking aripiprazole without talking to your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have severe diarrhea or vomiting or think you may be dehydrated. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had heart disease, heart failure, a heart attack, an irregular heartbeat, high or low blood pressure, a stroke or ministroke, seizures, a low white blood cell count, dyslipidemia (high cholesterol or other lipid problems), balance problems, or any condition that makes it difficult to swallow. tell your doctor if you or anyone in your family uses or has used street drugs, has overused prescription medications or alcohol, or has or has ever had diabetes, obsessive-compulsive disorder, an impulse-control disorder, bipolar disorder, or an impulsive personality. also tell your doctor if you have ever had to stop a medication for mental illness because of severe side effects. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor. if you become pregnant while receiving aripiprazole, call your doctor. aripiprazole may cause problems in newborns if used during the last months of pregnancy. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are being treated with aripiprazole. this medication may make you drowsy and can affect your ability to think clearly, make decisions, and react quickly. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. alcohol can increase the drowsiness caused by this medication; do not drink alcohol during treatment. aripiprazole may cause dizziness, lightheadedness, fast or slow heartbeat, or fainting when you get up too quickly, especially right after an injection. if you feel dizzy or drowsy after your injection, lie down until you feel better. during treatment, get up slowly, letting your feet dangle on the bed’s edge for a few minutes before standing. you may experience high blood sugar (hyperglycemia) while receiving this medication, even if you do not already have diabetes. people with schizophrenia are more likely to develop diabetes, and aripiprazole and similar medicines may increase this risk. call your doctor right away if you have extreme thirst, frequent urination, extreme hunger, blurred vision, or weakness. high blood sugar can cause ketoacidosis, a serious condition that can be life-threatening if not treated early. symptoms of ketoacidosis include dry mouth, nausea and vomiting, shortness of breath, fruity-smelling breath, and decreased consciousness. some people taking medications like aripiprazole extended-release injection have developed gambling problems or other intense urges or compulsive behaviors, including increased sexual urges or behaviors, excessive shopping, and binge eating. call your doctor if you develop strong urges to shop, eat, have sex, or gamble, or if you cannot control your behavior. tell your family members about this risk so they can call the doctor even if you do not realize the behavior has become a problem. aripiprazole may make it harder for your body to cool down in very hot conditions. if you plan vigorous exercise or will be exposed to extreme heat, drink plenty of water and call your doctor if you feel very hot, sweat heavily or stop sweating despite heat, have a dry mouth, excessive thirst, or decreased urination. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor about drinking grapefruit juice or eating grapefruit while receiving this medication. drink plenty of water every day while you are receiving aripiprazole. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment to receive your aripiprazole extended-release injection, call your doctor as soon as possible to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? aripiprazole extended-release injection may cause side effects. if any of these are severe or do not go away, tell your doctor: pain, swelling, or redness at the injection site; weight gain; headache; extreme tiredness; stomach pain; constipation; vomiting; dry mouth; back, muscle, or joint pain; difficulty falling or staying asleep; dizziness, feeling unsteady, or trouble keeping your balance. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following or those listed in the important warning or special precautions sections, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help: rash; itching; hives; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; swollen lymph nodes; difficulty swallowing or breathing; muscle stiffness; excessive sweating; irregular heartbeat; confusion; falls; unusual movements of the face or body that you cannot control; uncontrollable shaking; restlessness or the need to get up and move; slow movements; sore throat, fever, chills, or other signs of infection; or seizures. aripiprazole extended-release injection may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you notice any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: abiraterone
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? abiraterone is used with prednisone to treat certain prostate cancers that have spread to other parts of the body. it belongs to a class of medicines called androgen biosynthesis inhibitors and works by lowering certain hormone levels. how should this medicine be used? take abiraterone tablets by mouth once daily on an empty stomach with water—either at least 1 hour before or 2 hours after any food. take it at the same time each day. swallow tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush. follow your prescription exactly and do not take more or less than prescribed. continue taking abiraterone even if you feel well. do not stop abiraterone or prednisone unless your doctor tells you to. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the patient medication guide. what special precautions should i follow? before taking abiraterone, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to abiraterone or any tablet ingredients, and about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and herbal products you use or plan to use. st. john’s wort can interact with abiraterone—do not use it unless your healthcare provider approves. tell your doctor if you have an infection; low potassium; are under unusual stress; recently had a heart attack; or if you have or have ever had adrenal or pituitary problems, heart failure, an irregular heartbeat (including qt prolongation), high blood pressure, diabetes, high cholesterol or other lipids, osteoporosis, or heart or liver disease. abiraterone is for use in men only; women should not take it, especially if pregnant, may become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if taken during pregnancy, it may harm the fetus. women who are or may become pregnant should not handle abiraterone tablets without protective gloves; if exposure occurs, contact a doctor immediately. men with female partners must use effective contraception during treatment and for 3 weeks after the final dose. this medicine may decrease fertility in men. abiraterone can cause low blood sugar; your doctor may ask you to monitor your glucose. seek medical help if you have symptoms of hypoglycemia such as headache, dizziness, weakness, tiredness, sweating, hunger, rapid or irregular heartbeat, confusion, irritability, or jitteriness. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss one dose, take your usual dose the next day. if you miss more than one dose, call your doctor right away. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include joint swelling or pain, groin pain, hot flashes, diarrhea, constipation, heartburn, cough, sore throat, stuffy or runny nose, and trouble sleeping. serious side effects require immediate medical attention: dizziness; feeling faint or lightheaded; headache; confusion; fast or irregular heartbeat; muscle weakness or aches; leg pain; swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; shortness of breath; rash, hives, itching, trouble breathing or swallowing, or swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat; unusual bruising or bleeding; yellowing of the skin or eyes; nausea; vomiting; loss of appetite; extreme tiredness; lack of energy; dark urine; pain in the upper right abdomen; flu-like symptoms such as fever; blood in the urine; difficult, painful, or frequent urination; or falls and bone fractures. abiraterone may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you have any unusual or persistent symptoms.

name: methotrexate injection
instructions: important warning: methotrexate can cause very serious, potentially life-threatening side effects. discuss the risks and benefits of methotrexate injection with your doctor. severe allergic or infusion-related reactions can occur during or shortly after receiving a dose. seek emergency help immediately if you develop rash, itching, hives, throat tightness, swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat, trouble swallowing, runny or stuffy nose, dizziness or lightheadedness, difficulty breathing, chest pain, wheezing, or feeling faint. methotrexate can harm an unborn baby or cause pregnancy loss. if you could become pregnant, you must have a pregnancy test before treatment and use reliable birth control during treatment and for 6 months after the last dose. if you are male, you and your female partner must use reliable birth control during treatment and for 3 months after the last dose. if pregnancy occurs, contact your doctor right away. certain conditions and medicines increase the risk of severe toxicity, including fluid in the abdomen or around the lungs (ascites or pleural effusion), kidney disease or dialysis, and use of nsaids such as aspirin, ibuprofen (advil, motrin), naproxen (aleve, naprosyn), magnesium salicylate (doan’s), choline magnesium trisalicylate (tricosal, trilisate), or salsalate. your doctor may monitor you more closely, lower your dose, or stop treatment. methotrexate can suppress bone marrow and lower blood cell counts. tell your doctor right away if you have a history of low blood counts or blood disorders, or if you develop sore throat, chills, fever, persistent cough or congestion, signs of infection, unusual bruising or bleeding, unusual tiredness or weakness, pale skin, or shortness of breath. methotrexate may cause liver damage, especially with long-term use, in people who drink or have drunk heavily, or who have liver disease; in such cases, it may be avoided unless treating life-threatening cancer. risk is also higher in older adults, people with obesity, or diabetes. ask about safe alcohol use during treatment. the risk of liver injury is also greater with acitretin (soriatane), azathioprine (imuran), isotretinoin (accutane), sulfasalazine (azulfidine), or tretinoin (vesanoid). seek medical care immediately for nausea, extreme tiredness, lack of energy, loss of appetite, pain in the upper right abdomen, yellowing of the skin or eyes, or flu-like symptoms. methotrexate can injure the lungs; if you have or had lung disease, call your doctor if you develop a dry cough, fever, or shortness of breath. it can damage the lining of the mouth, stomach, and intestines; if you have or had stomach ulcers or ulcerative colitis, call right away for mouth sores, diarrhea, black or bloody stools, or vomiting blood or material that looks like coffee grounds. use of methotrexate has been linked to lymphoma; in some cases, it resolves after stopping the drug, but it may require chemotherapy. serious skin reactions (including blistering and peeling) can occur; call your doctor immediately if you develop fever, rash, blisters, or peeling skin. methotrexate suppresses the immune system and can lead to serious infections; if you have an active infection or an immune system disorder, your doctor may advise against use unless treating life-threatening cancer. report signs of infection such as sore throat, cough, fever, or chills right away. when used with radiation therapy, methotrexate may increase the risk of damage to skin, bone, or other tissues. keep all doctor and lab appointments. your doctor will order tests before, during, and after treatment to monitor your response and manage side effects early. why is this medication prescribed? methotrexate injection is used alone or with other medications to treat certain types of acute lymphocytic leukemia (all) in adults and children; to treat or prevent meningeal leukemia (cancer in the covering of the brain and spinal cord) in adults and children; to treat certain types of non-hodgkin’s lymphoma in adults and children; to treat osteosarcoma after surgery to remove the tumor in adults and children; to treat cutaneous t‑cell lymphoma (ctcl); to treat breast cancer; to treat certain head and neck cancers; to treat gestational trophoblastic tumors; to treat rheumatoid arthritis (ra) in adults; to treat polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (pjia) in children; and to treat severe psoriasis in adults. it belongs to a class of drugs called antimetabolites. it treats cancer by slowing the growth of cancer cells, psoriasis by slowing skin cell growth to reduce scaling, and ra/pjia by decreasing immune system activity. it is also sometimes used with other drugs for bladder cancer, and for crohn’s disease and other autoimmune diseases; ask your doctor about the risks and benefits of these uses. how should this medicine be used? methotrexate injection is supplied as a powder that is mixed with liquid and given by a health professional into a muscle (intramuscular), into a vein (intravenous), just under the skin (subcutaneous), or into the fluid around the spinal cord (intrathecal). your dosing schedule depends on your condition and how you respond. the length of therapy depends on your regimen, response, and diagnosis. your doctor may give additional medicines to prevent or treat methotrexate side effects. ask your doctor or pharmacist for the manufacturer’s patient information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving methotrexate injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to methotrexate, any other medications, benzyl alcohol, or any ingredients in the product. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. be sure to mention the medicines in the important warning and any of the following: certain antibiotics (such as chloramphenicol, penicillins, and tetracyclines), folic acid (alone or in multivitamins), other drugs for rheumatoid arthritis, phenytoin (dilantin), probenecid (benemid), proton pump inhibitors (such as esomeprazole, omeprazole, pantoprazole), sulfonamides (such as co‑trimoxazole [bactrim, septra], sulfadiazine, sulfamethizole, and sulfisoxazole [gantrisin]), and theophylline (theochron, theolair). your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor more closely. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any conditions noted in the important warning, seizures, or low folate levels. do not breastfeed during treatment and for at least 1 week after your final dose. this medicine may reduce fertility in both women and men; discuss concerns with your doctor. methotrexate may cause dizziness or drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, tell the clinician that you are receiving methotrexate. avoid unnecessary or prolonged sun or ultraviolet light exposure; wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen. if you have psoriasis, sunlight exposure may worsen lesions while on methotrexate. do not receive vaccinations during treatment without talking to your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss or cannot keep an appointment for your injection, call your doctor right away to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? methotrexate may cause side effects. common effects include joint or muscle pain, red eyes, swollen gums, and hair loss. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor immediately or seek emergency care if you have any of the following or any symptoms listed in the important warning: vomiting; blurred vision or sudden loss of vision; sudden fever with severe headache and stiff neck; seizures; confusion or memory loss; weakness or difficulty moving one or both sides of the body; trouble walking or unsteady gait; loss of consciousness; impaired or slurred speech; decreased urination; or swelling of the face, arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs. some people who received methotrexate injection developed other cancers; discuss this risk with your doctor. methotrexate may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: abobotulinumtoxina injection
instructions: important warning: abobotulinumtoxina can spread from the injection site and cause botulism-like effects, including severe or life-threatening trouble breathing or swallowing. swallowing problems may last for weeks, may require a feeding tube, and can lead to food or drink entering the lungs. symptoms can begin within hours or up to several weeks after treatment and may occur at any age and for any treated condition, with the highest risk likely in children treated for spasticity. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had swallowing or breathing problems (such as asthma or emphysema) or a disorder affecting muscles or nerves (such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis/als, motor neuropathy, myasthenia gravis, or lambert-eaton syndrome). call your doctor right away if you develop generalized weakness or loss of strength, double or blurred vision, drooping eyelids, difficulty speaking, swallowing, or breathing, or loss of bladder control. you will receive a medication guide when you start and each time you are treated; read it and ask your doctor or pharmacist any questions. why is this medication prescribed? abobotulinumtoxina is used to relieve cervical dystonia (spasmodic torticollis) that causes neck pain and abnormal head positions, to temporarily smooth frown lines between the eyebrows, and to treat muscle spasticity (stiffness and tightness) of the arms and legs in adults and in children 2 years of age and older. it is a neurotoxin that blocks nerve signals that trigger involuntary muscle tightening and movement. how should this medicine be used? abobotulinumtoxina is supplied as a powder that is mixed and injected by a healthcare professional into selected muscles. your doctor will choose the dose and injection sites based on your condition. repeat treatments are typically given every 3 to 4 months depending on your response and how long the effects last. for cervical dystonia, treatment usually starts with a lower dose and is adjusted as needed. do not substitute one botulinum toxin product for another. this medicine controls symptoms but does not cure the underlying condition. when used for cervical dystonia, it may take 2 weeks or longer to see the full benefit. other uses: it is sometimes used to treat blepharospasm (involuntary eyelid muscle tightening) in adults; discuss the potential risks and benefits with your doctor. what special precautions should i follow? before treatment, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to abobotulinumtoxina; to other botulinum toxins such as incobotulinumtoxina (xeomin), onabotulinumtoxina (botox), prabotulinumtoxina‑xvfs (jeuveau), or rimabotulinumtoxinb (myobloc); to cow’s milk protein; or to any ingredient in the product. ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. some nonprescription allergy and cold medicines (including diphenhydramine, loratadine, fexofenadine, chlorpheniramine, or cetirizine) may interact—do not start or stop them without your provider’s advice. do not receive injections into an area with swelling or signs of infection. tell your doctor if you have had eye or facial surgery; any prior side effect from a botulinum toxin; changes in facial appearance; bleeding problems; diabetes; or a slow or irregular heartbeat. if you are receiving treatment for wrinkles, your doctor will examine you to determine if it is likely to work; results may be limited or risks increased if you have drooping eyelids, difficulty raising your eyebrows, excess eyelid skin, thick, oily, or heavily scarred skin, or lines that do not smooth when spread apart with your fingers. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, inform the doctor or dentist that you receive abobotulinumtoxina. this medicine can cause generalized weakness, blurred vision, or drooping eyelids; if these occur, do not drive, operate machinery, or perform dangerous tasks. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor instructs otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an injection appointment, call your doctor to reschedule as soon as possible. do not attempt self-injection and do not receive extra injections to make up for a missed visit. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include pain, bruising, redness, or tenderness at the injection site; headache; dry mouth; bone or muscle pain; arm or leg pain; tiredness; nausea; depression; trouble sleeping; and cold-like symptoms such as cough, sneezing, fever, nasal congestion, or sore throat. serious side effects can include vision changes; sensitivity to light; reduced blinking or eye dryness; eyelid swelling, irritation, or pain; itching; rash; hives; swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; shortness of breath; dizziness; fainting; falls or coordination problems; blood in the urine; or seizures. if you develop these or the symptoms listed in the important warning, contact your doctor immediately. this medication may cause other side effects; ask your doctor for more information.

name: paclitaxel with albumin injection
instructions: important warning: paclitaxel with albumin injection can cause a significant drop in white blood cells, which are needed to fight infection. this increases your risk of serious infection. do not receive paclitaxel with albumin if your white blood cell count is already low. your doctor will order blood tests before and during treatment to monitor your white blood cells and may delay or interrupt treatment if counts are too low. call your doctor right away if you develop a temperature higher than 100.4 f 38 c, a sore throat, cough, chills, painful or frequent urination, or any other signs of infection. keep all appointments for doctor visits and laboratory tests. your doctor will use these tests to check how your body is responding to paclitaxel with albumin. discuss the benefits and risks of treatment with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? paclitaxel with albumin injection is used to treat breast cancer that has spread and has not improved or has worsened after other treatments. it is also used with other chemotherapy medicines to treat non small cell lung cancer nsclc, and with gemcitabine gemzar to treat pancreatic cancer. paclitaxel belongs to a class of medicines called antimicrotubule agents and works by stopping the growth and spread of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? paclitaxel with albumin injection is supplied as a powder that is mixed with liquid and infused into a vein over about 30 minutes by a health care professional in a medical facility. for breast cancer, it is usually given once every 3 weeks. for nsclc, it is usually given on days 1, 8, and 15 of a 3 week cycle. for pancreatic cancer, it is usually given on days 1, 8, and 15 of a 4 week cycle together with gemcitabine. these cycles may be repeated as your doctor recommends. your doctor may pause treatment, lower the dose, or stop treatment based on your response and side effects. tell your health care team how you are feeling during treatment. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer information for patients. other uses for this medicine: paclitaxel injection is sometimes used to treat cancers of the head and neck, esophagus the tube that connects the mouth and stomach, bladder, endometrium lining of the uterus, and cervix opening of the uterus. ask your doctor about the risks and benefits of using this medicine for your condition. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving paclitaxel with albumin injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to paclitaxel, docetaxel, any other medicines, or human albumin. ask your pharmacist if you are unsure whether a product contains human albumin. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver, kidney, or heart disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or plan to father a child. you or your partner should not become pregnant while receiving this medicine. your doctor may perform a pregnancy test before starting treatment. females should use effective birth control during treatment and for at least 6 months after the final dose. males with female partners should use effective birth control during treatment and for 3 months after the final dose. if you or your partner becomes pregnant during treatment, call your doctor; paclitaxel may harm the fetus. do not breastfeed during treatment and for 2 weeks after your final dose. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, tell the doctor or dentist that you are receiving paclitaxel with albumin injection. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given by a health care professional. if you miss an appointment or a dose is missed, contact your doctor or clinic as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to make up a dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? paclitaxel with albumin may cause side effects. common effects include pain, redness, swelling, or sores at the infusion site; unusual tiredness or weakness; nausea; vomiting; diarrhea; mouth or throat sores; hair loss; swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; blurred vision or other vision changes; decreased urination; dry mouth or thirst; muscle pain or cramps; joint pain. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you experience any of the following or the symptoms listed in the important warning section: numbness, burning, or tingling in the hands or feet; a new dry cough that does not go away; shortness of breath; rash; hives; difficulty breathing or swallowing; swelling of the eyes, face, mouth, lips, tongue, or throat; pale skin; excessive tiredness; unusual bruising or bleeding; chest pain; slow or irregular heartbeat; fainting. paclitaxel with albumin may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medicine.

name: adalimumab injection
instructions: notice: adalimumab injection is available as several biologic products made from living organisms. these products are “biosimilar” to adalimumab, meaning they work the same way and are just as safe and effective. in the information below, “adalimumab injection” refers to any of these products. important warning: adalimumab can lower your body’s ability to fight infections and increase the risk of serious infections that may require hospitalization and can be life-threatening. tell your doctor if you get infections often; if you have any current infection (including minor ones like open cuts, sores, or cold sores) or chronic infections that do not go away; if you have any condition that affects your immune system; if you live in or have lived in areas where severe fungal infections are more common (such as the ohio or mississippi river valleys); or if you take other medicines that suppress the immune system. your doctor will monitor you during and after treatment for signs of infection. call your doctor right away if you have weakness, sweating, sore throat, cough, coughing up blood or mucus, fever, weight loss, extreme tiredness, diarrhea, stomach pain, warm/red/painful skin, painful or frequent urination, or any other signs of infection. you may have inactive tuberculosis (tb) or hepatitis b without symptoms; adalimumab can reactivate these infections. your doctor will test you for tb and may test for hepatitis b before you start and may give preventive treatment if needed. tell your doctor if you have ever had tb, lived in or visited a country where tb is common, or were close to someone with tb. call your doctor immediately if you have tb symptoms now or during treatment—cough, weight loss, loss of muscle tone, fever, or night sweats—or symptoms of hepatitis b during or after treatment—unusual tiredness, yellow skin or eyes, loss of appetite, nausea or vomiting, muscle aches, dark urine, pale/clay-colored stools, fever, chills, stomach pain, or rash. some children, teenagers, and young adults taking adalimumab or similar medicines have developed severe or life-threatening cancers. tell your child’s doctor if your child has ever had cancer. call the doctor right away if your child develops stomach pain, fever, unexplained weight loss, swollen glands in the neck, underarms, or groin, or easy bruising or bleeding. discuss the risks and benefits of adalimumab with your doctor. you will receive a medication guide when you start and each time you get the medicine; read it carefully and ask questions as needed. why is this medication prescribed? adalimumab injection is used alone or with other medicines to reduce signs and symptoms of certain autoimmune conditions, including: rheumatoid arthritis in adults; juvenile idiopathic arthritis (jia) in children; crohn’s disease in adults and children who did not improve with other treatments; ulcerative colitis in adults and children when other treatments were not effective or not tolerated; ankylosing spondylitis in adults; psoriatic arthritis in adults; hidradenitis suppurativa in adults and teenagers; uveitis in adults and children; and chronic plaque psoriasis in adults. adalimumab is a tumor necrosis factor (tnf) inhibitor that works by blocking tnf, a substance that causes inflammation. how should this medicine be used? adalimumab injection is a liquid solution supplied in single-dose prefilled syringes, prefilled pens, prefilled automatic injectors, and vials for subcutaneous (under the skin) injection. your doctor will tell you how often to inject based on your condition and age. mark your calendar with your injection days. follow your prescription label, and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. use exactly as directed; do not use more, less, or more often than prescribed. your first dose will be given in your doctor’s office; afterward you or a caregiver can inject at home after proper training. read the written instructions for use before your first self-injection, and have your healthcare provider demonstrate the technique. each syringe, pen, or device is for one use only; inject all the solution in the device, and do not try to reuse any leftover liquid. dispose of used devices in a puncture-resistant sharps container; ask your pharmacist how to dispose of the container. if your dose was refrigerated, let the pen/syringe sit flat at room temperature (with the needle cap on) for 15 to 30 minutes before use; do not warm it with a microwave, hot water, or any heat source. inject into the front of the thighs or abdomen (stomach), avoiding the navel and the 2 inches (5 cm) around it. rotate injection sites; keep injections at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) apart from previous sites, and keep a record of where you inject. do not inject into skin that is tender, bruised, red, hard, scarred, or has stretch marks. always check the solution before use: confirm the expiration date, the correct amount of liquid in the device, and that the appearance matches the instructions for use. do not use if expired, if the amount is incorrect, or if the solution’s appearance is not as described. adalimumab helps control your condition but does not cure it. continue to use it even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine: your doctor may prescribe adalimumab for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using adalimumab, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to adalimumab, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and what symptoms you had. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. in addition to the issues in the important warning, tell your doctor if you have or have ever had numbness or tingling; diseases of the nervous system such as multiple sclerosis, guillain-barré syndrome, or optic neuritis; any type of cancer; diabetes; heart failure or other heart disease; or psoriasis treated with light therapy. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while using adalimumab. if you are having any surgery, including dental procedures, tell the doctor or dentist that you use adalimumab. do not receive any vaccines without talking to your doctor. if your child will receive adalimumab, make sure all routine vaccinations are up to date before starting treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? inject the missed dose as soon as you remember, then take your next dose on your regular scheduled day. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your usual schedule. do not use two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? adalimumab may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: redness, itching, bruising, pain, or swelling at the injection site; nausea; headache; back pain. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have any of the following or the symptoms listed in the important warning: numbness or tingling; vision problems; weakness in the legs; dizziness; shortness of breath; swelling of the feet, ankles, or lower legs; chest pain; new joint pain; rash, especially a sun-sensitive rash on the cheeks or arms; itching; hives; trouble breathing or swallowing; swelling of the face, eyes, lips, or mouth; unusual bruising or bleeding; pale skin; or red, scaly patches or pus-filled bumps on the skin. adults receiving adalimumab may have a higher risk of skin cancer, lymphoma, and other cancers than those not receiving it; discuss these risks with your doctor. adalimumab may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: abrocitinib
instructions: important warning: abrocitinib can weaken your ability to fight infection and increase your risk of serious infections (fungal, bacterial, or viral) that can spread throughout the body, may require hospitalization, and can be fatal. tell your doctor if you frequently get infections or think you have any infection now, including minor infections (such as open cuts or sores), infections that come and go (such as cold sores), or chronic infections that do not go away. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had diabetes; hiv or aids; hepatitis b virus infection (hbv) or hepatitis c virus infection (hcv) or any ongoing liver infection; shingles (herpes zoster); lung disease; or any condition that affects your immune system. tell your doctor if you live in or have ever lived in areas where severe fungal infections are common (such as the ohio or mississippi river valleys); ask if you are not sure. tell your doctor if you are taking medicines that decrease immune system activity. your doctor will monitor you for infection during and after treatment. call your doctor immediately if, before, during, or shortly after treatment, you have fever, sweating, chills, muscle aches, cough, shortness of breath, weight loss, warm, red, or painful skin, sores on the skin or body, frequent or painful urination or burning during urination, diarrhea, or excessive tiredness. you may be infected with tuberculosis (tb) without symptoms; abrocitinib can worsen this infection. your doctor will test you for inactive tb before starting treatment and, if needed, treat tb before you begin abrocitinib. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had tb, have lived in or visited a country where tb is common, or have been around someone with tb. call your doctor right away if you have symptoms of tb now or during treatment, such as cough, coughing up bloody mucus, weight loss, loss of muscle tone, or fever. abrocitinib may increase the risk of lymphoma or other cancers (including skin or lung cancer). tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any type of cancer. avoid unnecessary or prolonged sunlight and wear protective clothing and sunscreen. tell your doctor if you smoke or have ever smoked. abrocitinib may increase the risk of serious heart problems (heart attack, stroke) and serious blood clots in the lungs or legs. tell your doctor if you smoke or have ever smoked, or if you have or have ever had a heart attack or other heart problems, a stroke, blood clots in the legs, arms, lungs, or arteries, high cholesterol, high blood pressure, or diabetes. call your doctor immediately or get emergency help if you have pain in the chest, arms, back, neck, jaw, or stomach; breaking out in a cold sweat; feeling light-headed; dizziness; numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg; slow or difficult speech; sudden shortness of breath or difficulty breathing; swelling of a leg or arm; leg pain; or redness, discoloration, or warmth in the legs or arms. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor may order tests before, during, and after treatment to check your response to abrocitinib. you will receive a medication guide when you start treatment and each time you refill; read it carefully and ask questions. discuss the risks of abrocitinib with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? abrocitinib is used to treat moderate to severe atopic dermatitis (eczema) in adults and in children 12 years of age and older who cannot use other medications for their condition or whose eczema has not responded to other medications. it is a janus kinase (jak) inhibitor that works by decreasing immune system activity. how should this medicine be used? abrocitinib comes as a tablet to take by mouth once a day, with or without food, at the same time each day. follow your prescription label exactly. do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. swallow tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush. your doctor will usually start you on a low dose and may increase your dose after about 12 weeks if you have not responded to the lower dose. your doctor may temporarily or permanently stop treatment if certain severe side effects occur. tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking abrocitinib, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to abrocitinib, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets. check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. some medications should not be taken with abrocitinib; discuss all medicines you take or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist before starting abrocitinib, and consult them before starting, stopping, or changing any medicines while taking abrocitinib. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. nonprescription products such as aspirin may interact; tell your healthcare providers you are taking them, and do not start any without discussing with your doctor. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had low white blood cells; anemia (low red blood cells); low platelet counts; kidney disease; cataracts, retinal detachment, or other eye problems; or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking abrocitinib, call your doctor. this medicine may decrease fertility in women; discuss risks with your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist you are taking abrocitinib. tell your doctor if you have recently received or are scheduled to receive any vaccines. you may need vaccinations before starting abrocitinib and to wait a period before beginning treatment; do not receive vaccines during treatment without your doctor’s approval. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is less than 12 hours until your next dose, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? abrocitinib may cause side effects. common side effects include cold symptoms (stuffy or runny nose, sneezing, sore throat), nausea, headache, dizziness, acne, vomiting, mouth and throat pain, rash, and stomach pain. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of these symptoms or those listed in the important warning section, stop taking abrocitinib and call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment: sudden changes in vision; tiredness, shortness of breath, or pale skin; or unusual bruising or bleeding. abrocitinib may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: rsv (respiratory syncytial virus) vaccine (abrysvo, arexvy)
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? rsv vaccine helps prevent lower respiratory tract disease (lrtd) caused by rsv, a common virus that often causes mild, cold-like symptoms (runny nose, decreased appetite, cough, sneezing, fever, wheezing) but can lead to serious illness in infants and older adults, especially those with chronic heart or lung disease, weakened immune systems, or who live in nursing homes or long-term care. lrtd can cause shortness of breath, low oxygen levels, and can worsen chronic heart or lung conditions, sometimes leading to hospitalization or death. the vaccine does not contain live rsv; it includes components that stimulate an immune response so your body can respond quickly if exposed. how should this medicine be used? a healthcare professional reconstitutes a powder with liquid and gives a single intramuscular injection. it is recommended for: pregnant patients at 32–36 weeks’ gestation to help protect the newborn through 6 months of age; all adults 60 years of age or older; and adults 50–59 years of age who have risk factors for lrtd. what special precautions should i follow? tell your vaccine provider if you have ever had an allergic reaction to this vaccine, any component of it, any other vaccine, or any drug, food, or substance; describe the symptoms you had. inform your provider if you have a history of guillain-barré syndrome (which can cause numbness or tingling in the extremities, muscle pain, difficulty walking or standing, or paralysis), if you have a weakened immune system due to a condition or medications, if you have a fever or are feeling ill, or if you have ever fainted with injections. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits; because some studies have noted higher rates of preterm birth after vaccination during pregnancy, it is recommended only between 32 and 36 weeks of gestation. your provider may postpone vaccination in some situations. tell your provider about all medicines and vaccines you take. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are required unless your healthcare provider gives you specific advice. what should i do if i forget a dose? this vaccine is given as a single scheduled injection. if you miss your appointment, contact your healthcare provider as soon as possible to reschedule; if you are pregnant and miss the 32–36 week window, ask your provider about timing and options. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include pain, bruising, redness, or swelling at the injection site; fever; headache; muscle or joint pain. serious side effects can occur. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you develop symptoms such as numbness or tingling in the extremities, muscle pain, difficulty walking or standing, weakness or paralysis; rash; shortness of breath or difficulty breathing; or swelling of the face or throat. fainting can occur after injections; tell your provider if you feel dizzy, have vision changes, or ringing in the ears. adverse events can be reported to the vaccine adverse event reporting system (vaers); your healthcare provider can file a report, or you can report it yourself.

name: lidocaine transdermal patch
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? prescription lidocaine transdermal (brand names include dermalid, lidoderm, ztlido) is used to relieve the nerve pain of post‑herpetic neuralgia (phn)—burning, stabbing pain, or aching that can persist for months or years after shingles. over‑the‑counter (otc) lidocaine products (such as absorbine jr, aspercreme, lidocare, salonpas, and others) are also used to ease minor aches and pains in the shoulders, arms, neck, and legs in adults and in children 12 years and older. lidocaine is a local anesthetic that numbs by blocking nerve signals that transmit pain. how should this medicine be used? prescription lidocaine transdermal is available as a 5% patch (dermalid, lidoderm) and as a 1.8% topical system (ztlido) applied to the skin. use once daily as needed for pain; do not apply more than three 5% patches or three 1.8% topical systems at the same time, and do not wear them for more than a total of 12 hours in a 24‑hour period (12 hours on, 12 hours off). follow your prescription label exactly; do not use more, less, or more often than directed. otc lidocaine transdermal comes as a 4% patch (e.g., absorbine jr, aspercreme, lidocare, salonpas) applied to the skin up to three times daily, for no longer than 8 hours per application; use exactly as the package directs and do not exceed the labeled dose or duration. your doctor will specify how many prescription patches or topical systems you may apply at once and how long to wear them; applying too many or wearing them too long can cause serious side effects. apply to clean, dry, intact skin in an area that will not be rubbed by tight clothing. do not apply to open wounds, cuts, irritated or reddened skin, or skin with rashes, burns, or other problems. if irritation or a burning sensation occurs, remove the patch/topical system and do not reapply until the irritation resolves. prescription patches and topical systems may be cut to smaller sizes with scissors before removing the release liner. always remove the current patch before applying a new one. avoid contact with the eyes; if contact occurs, rinse immediately with water or saline and protect the eye until normal sensation returns. while wearing any lidocaine patch or topical system, keep the treated area away from direct external heat sources (such as heating pads or electric blankets). the 1.8% topical system may be applied after moderate heat exposure (for example, 15 minutes of heating pad use on a medium setting). do not tightly bandage the area. do not shower, bathe, or swim while wearing the prescription 5% patch. if you are using the 1.8% topical system, you may shower for up to 10 minutes or immerse in water for up to 15 minutes; if it becomes wet, gently pat the skin and system—do not rub. if the 1.8% system lifts at the edges, press firmly to reattach; if it comes off completely more than once and will not adhere, remove it and apply a new system without exceeding a total of 12 hours of wear. wash hands after handling patches/topical systems. stop using otc 4% patches and contact your doctor if pain lasts more than 7 days or improves then returns/worsens. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. what special precautions should i follow? before using lidocaine transdermal, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to lidocaine; to other local anesthetics such as benzocaine, bupivacaine (marcaine), etidocaine (duranest), mepivacaine (carbocaine), prilocaine (citanest), procaine, or tetracaine; or to any ingredients in the product; ask your pharmacist for a full ingredient list. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and herbal products you use or plan to use; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. the nonprescription product acetaminophen (tylenol) may interact with lidocaine; make sure your doctor and pharmacist know you use it, and do not start any new medications while using lidocaine transdermal without consulting your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had glucose‑6‑phosphate dehydrogenase (g‑6‑pd) deficiency, methemoglobinemia, or heart, lung, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while using lidocaine patches/topical systems, call your doctor. before any surgery, including dental procedures, tell the doctor or dentist you use lidocaine patches/topical systems. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is often used as needed. if your doctor has told you to use it on a regular schedule and you miss a dose, apply it as soon as you remember; if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra patches to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? lidocaine patches/topical systems may cause side effects. if you develop local symptoms, remove the patch/topical system and do not reapply until symptoms subside. common effects include burning, discomfort, redness, or swelling at the application site. serious side effects are uncommon but require immediate medical attention, including hives; rash; itching; blisters; bruising; trouble breathing or swallowing; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; hoarseness; rapid pulse or breathing; unusual thirst; nausea; vomiting; confusion; weakness; dizziness; fainting; or signs of methemoglobinemia such as pale, gray, or blue skin, headache, shortness of breath, lightheadedness, or fatigue. lidocaine transdermal may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual or persistent.

name: isotretinoin
instructions: important warning: for all patients: do not take isotretinoin if you are pregnant or could become pregnant. this medicine has a high risk of causing miscarriage, premature birth, newborn death, and severe birth defects. the ipledge program exists to prevent exposure during pregnancy. all patients, including men and women who cannot become pregnant, must be enrolled in ipledge, receive prescriptions only from an ipledge registered prescriber, and fill them at an ipledge registered pharmacy. do not buy isotretinoin over the internet. you will receive risk information and must sign an informed consent before treatment. you must see your doctor every month to review your condition and side effects. at each visit your doctor may prescribe up to a 30 day supply with no refills. if you can become pregnant, you must have a pregnancy test in an approved lab every month and pick up your prescription within 7 days of that test. if you are a man or a woman who cannot become pregnant, you must pick up your prescription within 30 days of your doctor visit. the pharmacy cannot dispense after these time windows. tell your doctor if you do not understand the ipledge requirements or cannot reliably keep appointments or pick up medication on time. you will be given an ipledge identification number and card; you need this to fill prescriptions and to access the website or phone system; keep it safe and request a replacement if lost. do not donate blood while taking isotretinoin and for 1 month after your last dose. do not share your medication. you will be given the medication guide at the start and with each refill; read it and ask questions. discuss the risks of isotretinoin with your doctor. for female patients: if you can become pregnant, you must meet special requirements even if you have not started menstruating or have had tubal ligation. you may be excused only if your doctor confirms you are postmenopausal after 12 months without menses or if you have had surgery to remove your uterus and or both ovaries. otherwise you must use two acceptable forms of birth control for at least 1 month before starting isotretinoin, throughout treatment, and for 1 month after the last dose. your doctor will explain acceptable methods, give written information, and can arrange a free visit with a clinician for contraception counseling. you must use two methods at all times unless you commit to complete abstinence from sexual contact with a male for 1 month before, during, and 1 month after treatment. any birth control can fail; using two methods reduces the risk. do not take isotretinoin if you do not fully understand the contraception instructions or cannot use two methods consistently. if you will use oral contraceptives, provide the exact brand. isotretinoin interferes with micro dosed progestin only minipill products such as ovrette, micronor, and nor qd; do not use these while on isotretinoin. if you use hormonal contraceptives pills, patches, implants, injections, rings, or an intrauterine device, review all medicines, vitamins, and herbal supplements with your clinician because many interact. do not take st. johns wort with any hormonal contraceptive. you must have two negative pregnancy tests before starting. your doctor will tell you when and where to test. you must also have a lab pregnancy test every month during treatment, at your final dose, and 30 days after your last dose. each month you must confirm in ipledge by phone or internet the two birth control methods you are using and answer program questions. you can receive more isotretinoin only if you have completed these steps, seen your doctor, and had a negative pregnancy test within the past 7 days. stop isotretinoin and call your doctor immediately if you think you may be pregnant, miss a period, or have sex without two forms of birth control. if pregnancy occurs during treatment or within 30 days after, your doctor will notify ipledge, the manufacturer, and the fda, and you will speak with a pregnancy specialist to discuss options and care. information about your health and the babys health may be used to improve understanding of isotretinoins effects in pregnancy. for male patients: small amounts of isotretinoin may be present in semen at prescribed doses. it is unknown whether this could harm a fetus if your partner is or becomes pregnant. tell your doctor if your partner is pregnant, planning pregnancy, or becomes pregnant during your treatment. why is this medication prescribed? isotretinoin is used for severe recalcitrant nodular acne that has not improved with other treatments such as antibiotics. it is a retinoid that reduces production of skin substances that contribute to acne. how should this medicine be used? take isotretinoin capsules by mouth, usually twice daily with meals, for a typical course of 4 to 5 months. follow the prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. take only as directed. swallow capsules whole with a full glass of liquid; do not chew, crush, or suck them. your doctor may adjust the dose based on your response and side effects. acne may temporarily worsen at the start; full benefit can take several weeks, and improvement may continue after completing therapy. use only isotretinoin obtained through ipledge. other uses for this medicine: isotretinoin is sometimes used for certain skin conditions and some cancers; discuss risks and benefits with your doctor. what special precautions should i follow? before taking isotretinoin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to isotretinoin, vitamin a, any other medicines, or any capsule ingredients; check the medication guide for inactive components. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, herbal products, and supplements you take or plan to take. your doctor may change doses or monitor for interactions. do not take vitamin a supplements or st. johns wort while using isotretinoin. tell your doctor if you or a family member has a history of depression, other mental illness, suicidal thoughts or attempts, diabetes, asthma, osteoporosis, osteomalacia or other bone problems, high triglycerides, lipid metabolism disorders, anorexia nervosa, liver disease, or heart disease; also if you are overweight or drink or have drunk large amounts of alcohol. do not breastfeed during treatment and for 1 month after the last dose. limit sun exposure and wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen because your skin may be more sensitive to sunlight. isotretinoin can cause changes in mood, behavior, and mental health including depression, psychosis, aggression, and suicidal thoughts or actions. you or your family should call your doctor immediately for anxiety, persistent sadness, crying spells, loss of interest, poor performance at school or work, sleeping more or difficulty sleeping, irritability, anger, aggression, appetite or weight changes, trouble concentrating, withdrawing from friends or family, low energy, feelings of worthlessness or guilt, thoughts of self harm, acting on dangerous thoughts, or hallucinations. dry eyes may make contact lenses uncomfortable during and after treatment. night vision may worsen suddenly and can persist; use caution when driving or operating machinery at night. avoid waxing, laser skin treatments, and dermabrasion during treatment and for 6 months after due to increased scarring risk; ask your doctor when these are safe. discuss strenuous sports; isotretinoin can weaken or abnormally thicken bones and may increase the risk of certain bone injuries. if you break a bone, tell all healthcare providers that you are taking isotretinoin. do not donate blood during treatment and for 1 month after. do not share this medicine. keep and protect your ipledge id card; you need it to fill prescriptions and to access ipledge; request a replacement if lost. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include red, cracked, sore lips; dry skin, eyes, mouth, or nose; nosebleeds; skin color changes; peeling skin on the palms or soles; nail changes; delayed healing of cuts or sores; bleeding or swollen gums; hair loss or unwanted hair growth; sweating; flushing; voice changes; tiredness; and cold like symptoms. serious side effects require stopping isotretinoin and urgent medical care: headache, blurred vision, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, seizures, slow or difficult speech, weakness or numbness on one side of the body, stomach pain, chest pain, difficult or painful swallowing or new or worsening heartburn, diarrhea, rectal bleeding, yellow skin or eyes, dark urine, back, bone, joint, or muscle pain, muscle weakness, hearing problems or ringing in the ears, vision problems, severe or constant eye dryness, unusual thirst, frequent urination, trouble breathing, fainting, fast or pounding heartbeat, red swollen itchy or teary eyes, fever, rash, peeling or blistering skin especially on the legs arms or face, sores in the mouth throat nose or eyes, red patches or bruises on the legs, and swelling of the eyes face lips tongue throat arms hands feet ankles or lower legs; difficulty swallowing. in teenagers, isotretinoin may cause bones to stop growing too soon. this medicine may cause other side effects; call your doctor about any unusual problems.

name: fentanyl
instructions: notice: fentanyl buccal and sublingual products have been discontinued in the u.s. because this drug is no longer available in the u.s. market, this monograph is not being updated. if this drug is used outside the u.s., consult the manufacturer’s labeling for the most current information. important warning: fentanyl can be habit forming, especially with prolonged use. use it exactly as prescribed. do not take larger or more frequent doses, and do not use it longer than directed. while using fentanyl, discuss your pain goals, the expected length of therapy, and other pain management options with your healthcare provider. the risk of misuse is higher if you or a family member has a history of heavy alcohol use, substance use, prescription drug misuse, overdose, or mental health conditions such as depression, schizophrenia, or hallucinations. if you think you may have an opioid use disorder, seek help immediately from your healthcare provider or call the samhsa national helpline at 1-800-662-help. fentanyl can cause serious, potentially life-threatening breathing problems, especially during the first 24–72 hours of treatment and after dose increases. your doctor will monitor you closely. do not use fentanyl if you have severe breathing problems, a history of slow breathing, or asthma. use extreme caution and consult your doctor if you have lung disease (such as copd), a head injury, a brain tumor, or any condition that increases intracranial pressure. older, frail, or malnourished patients are at higher risk. seek emergency help if you experience slowed or difficult breathing, long pauses between breaths, or shortness of breath. fentanyl should only be prescribed by clinicians experienced in treating cancer pain and only for breakthrough cancer pain in opioid-tolerant patients who are at least 18 years old (or at least 16 years old if using actiq lozenges) and are taking regular, around-the-clock opioid therapy. do not use fentanyl for non-cancer pain, acute or short-term pain (for example, migraines, injury pain, or post-surgical/dental pain). using fentanyl in people who are not opioid tolerant can cause severe breathing problems or death. accidental use by a child or an adult for whom it was not prescribed can be fatal. keep fentanyl out of reach of children. if using lozenges, ask your doctor about obtaining the manufacturer’s child-safety kit. dispose of partially used lozenges immediately after removal from the mouth as directed by the manufacturer. if a non-prescribed person, including a child, uses fentanyl, attempt to remove it from the mouth and seek emergency medical help right away. combining certain medicines with fentanyl can increase the risk of severe sedation, respiratory depression, coma, or death. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and herbal products you use or plan to use. if you develop unusual dizziness, lightheadedness, extreme sleepiness, slowed or difficult breathing, or unresponsiveness, seek emergency care. ensure caregivers know these symptoms and when to call for help. fentanyl products are not interchangeable; each is absorbed differently. do not substitute one product for another. if you switch products, your doctor will prescribe a new, appropriate dose. each fentanyl product has a safety program to reduce risks. your prescriber and pharmacy must be enrolled. you will receive counseling on risks, safe use, storage, and disposal and will be asked to sign that you understand and will follow these instructions. if you are pregnant or planning to become pregnant, tell your doctor. regular fentanyl use during pregnancy can cause life-threatening withdrawal in newborns. seek immediate care if your baby shows irritability, excessive crying, abnormal sleep, tremors, vomiting, diarrhea, poor feeding, or failure to gain weight. you will receive a medication guide at the start of treatment and with each refill; read it carefully and ask questions as needed. why is this medication prescribed? fentanyl is an opioid analgesic used to treat breakthrough cancer pain—sudden flares that occur despite around-the-clock opioid therapy—in opioid-tolerant patients at least 18 years old, or at least 16 years old if using actiq lozenges. it works by changing how the brain and nervous system respond to pain. use fentanyl in addition to your regular pain medicines; do not stop your other opioids when starting fentanyl. if you stop your scheduled opioids, you must stop using fentanyl. how should this medicine be used? fentanyl is available as a lozenge on a handle (actiq), a sublingual (under the tongue) tablet, and a buccal (between the gum and cheek) tablet. use it as needed for breakthrough pain, but not more than four times in 24 hours. follow your prescription directions exactly. your doctor will start with a low dose and adjust to the dose that controls your breakthrough pain. if pain persists after one dose, your doctor may instruct you to take a second dose: for actiq, 15 minutes after finishing the first lozenge; for fentora or other buccal/sublingual tablets, 30 minutes after starting the first tablet. after treating an episode with 1 or 2 doses as directed, wait at least 4 hours before treating another breakthrough pain episode. do not take more fentanyl than prescribed. if you have more than four breakthrough episodes per day, or if your pain is worsening or you develop increased sensitivity to pain, call your doctor; your around-the-clock opioid may need adjustment. do not stop fentanyl abruptly; your doctor may taper your dose to avoid withdrawal. directions for actiq lozenges: 1) verify the dose on the blister and handle. 2) use scissors to cut open the blister just before use. 3) place the lozenge between your cheek and gum; actively suck without chewing, crushing, or biting. 4) move it from side to side using the handle and twirl the handle often. 5) do not eat or drink while using it. 6) finish over about 15 minutes. 7) if you feel very dizzy, very sleepy, or nauseated before finishing, remove it from your mouth and dispose of it immediately as directed or place it in the temporary storage bottle for later disposal. 8) if fully used, throw away the handle in a childproof trash container. if not fully used, dissolve remaining medication by running the lozenge under hot water, then discard the handle in a child- and pet-safe trash container. directions for buccal/sublingual tablets: 1) separate one blister unit by tearing along perforations. 2) peel back the foil; do not push the tablet through the foil. open only when ready to use. 3) place the tablet above an upper back tooth between cheek and gum or under the tongue as far back as possible. 4) let it dissolve completely (typically 14–25 minutes). do not split, chew, bite, suck vigorously, or swallow whole. 5) if any portion remains after 30 minutes, swallow with water. 6) if you become very dizzy, very sleepy, or nauseated before it dissolves, rinse your mouth with water and spit remaining pieces into a sink or toilet; flush/rinse to remove residue. other uses for this medicine: this medication should not be prescribed for other uses. what special precautions should i follow? before using fentanyl, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to fentanyl or any ingredients in the tablets or lozenges. review the medication guide for a full ingredient list. do not use fentanyl if you are currently taking, or have taken within the past 14 days, an mao inhibitor such as isocarboxazid, linezolid, methylene blue, phenelzine, selegiline, or tranylcypromine. st. john’s wort may interact with fentanyl; tell your doctor if you use it. do not start, stop, or change any medicines while using fentanyl without discussing with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have any of the conditions listed in the important warning section; a blockage or narrowing of the stomach or intestines; or paralytic ileus. your doctor may advise against fentanyl in these cases. tell your doctor if you have a history of seizures; slow heart rate or other heart problems; low blood pressure; adrenal insufficiency; urinary difficulties; diabetes; or disease of the pancreas, gallbladder, thyroid, kidneys, or liver. do not breastfeed while using fentanyl; it can cause shallow or difficult breathing, excessive sleepiness, poor feeding, or limpness in infants. fentanyl may reduce fertility in males and females; discuss risks with your doctor. tell your surgeon or dentist that you use fentanyl before any procedure. fentanyl can cause drowsiness or dizziness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. to reduce the risk of dizziness or fainting when standing, rise slowly from sitting or lying positions. each actiq lozenge contains about 2 grams of sugar; if you have diabetes, account for this. actiq lozenges may increase risk of tooth decay; ask your dentist about preventive dental care during treatment. fentanyl commonly causes constipation; discuss dietary changes and preventive treatments with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your healthcare provider about consuming grapefruit or grapefruit juice while using fentanyl. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medication is used as needed for breakthrough pain according to your prescriber’s directions. do not exceed the prescribed frequency, do not use more than four times per day, and allow at least 4 hours between treated episodes. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include: drowsiness; headache; stomach pain; gas; heartburn; weight loss; difficulty urinating; vision changes; anxiety; depression; unusual thoughts or dreams; insomnia; dry mouth; flushing; tremor; back pain; mouth pain, sores, or irritation at the application site; and
