swelling of the hands, arms, feet, ankles, or lower legs. serious side effects require immediate medical attention: signs of serotonin syndrome (agitation, hallucinations, fever, sweating, confusion, rapid heartbeat, shivering, severe muscle stiffness or twitching, loss of coordination, diarrhea); severe nausea or vomiting; loss of appetite; weakness or dizziness; inability to get or keep an erection; irregular menstruation; decreased sexual desire; seizures; rash, hives, itching, hoarseness, trouble breathing or swallowing, or swelling of the face, mouth, tongue, or throat; chest pain; changes in heartbeat; extreme drowsiness; or any breathing problems mentioned in the important warning section. fentanyl may cause other side effects; contact your healthcare provider if you notice anything unusual.

name: acalabrutinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? acalabrutinib is used to treat mantle cell lymphoma (mcl), a fast-growing cancer of immune system cells. it is also used to treat chronic lymphocytic leukemia (cll) and small lymphocytic lymphoma (sll), cancers that begin in white blood cells. acalabrutinib is a kinase inhibitor that blocks an abnormal protein that signals cancer cells to multiply, helping slow or stop their spread. how should this medicine be used? acalabrutinib comes as a tablet taken by mouth with or without food every 12 hours (twice daily) for as long as your doctor recommends. take it at the same times each day and exactly as prescribed. swallow the tablets whole with a glass of water; do not chew, crush, dissolve, or cut them. your doctor may adjust how you take acalabrutinib based on side effects; tell your doctor how you feel during treatment. do not stop taking acalabrutinib without talking to your doctor. ask your doctor or pharmacist for the manufacturer’s patient information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking acalabrutinib, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to this drug, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your allergy symptoms. some medications should not be taken with acalabrutinib; review all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and herbal products you take or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist before starting, stopping, or changing any medication. tell your doctor if you have an infection, have recently had surgery, or if you have or have ever had liver disease (including hepatitis b), heart rhythm problems, or bleeding problems. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; do not start acalabrutinib until a pregnancy test shows you are not pregnant, and use effective birth control during treatment and for at least 1 week after your final dose. acalabrutinib may harm an unborn baby; if you become pregnant, call your doctor immediately. tell your doctor if you are breastfeeding; you may be told not to breastfeed during treatment and for 2 weeks after the final dose. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist you are taking acalabrutinib; your doctor may advise stopping it for a period before and after the procedure. avoid unnecessary or prolonged sun exposure and wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen; acalabrutinib can make your skin more sensitive to sunlight and may increase your risk of skin cancer. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor about eating grapefruit or drinking grapefruit juice while taking this medication. unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if more than 3 hours have passed since the missed dose, skip it and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? acalabrutinib may cause side effects. common side effects include headache, nausea, vomiting, constipation, diarrhea, abdominal pain, rash, easy bruising or small red or purple skin spots, joint or muscle pain, and extreme tiredness. some side effects can be serious. stop taking acalabrutinib and call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have signs of infection (such as fever, sore throat, or chills); cough, shortness of breath, chest pain when you breathe or cough, or fever; fast or irregular heartbeat, palpitations, feeling lightheaded or dizzy, fainting, or chest pain; unusual or severe bleeding or bruising; blood in your stools or black, tarry stools; pink or brown urine; vomiting blood or material that looks like coffee grounds; coughing up blood; or feeling dizzy, weak, or confused; changes in speech; or a headache that lasts a long time. acalabrutinib may increase your risk of developing other cancers; talk to your doctor about the risks. acalabrutinib may cause other side effects; tell your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: acamprosate
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? acamprosate is used with counseling and social support to help people who have already stopped heavy alcohol use avoid drinking again. long-term alcohol use changes brain function; acamprosate helps the brain work more normally. it does not treat alcohol withdrawal symptoms. it has not been shown to work in people who have not stopped drinking or in those who also misuse other substances such as street drugs or prescription medicines. how should this medicine be used? acamprosate comes as a delayed-release tablet (releases medicine in the intestine) taken by mouth, usually three times daily with or without food. take it at the same times each day; linking doses to breakfast, lunch, and dinner may help you remember. follow your prescription label exactly. do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. swallow tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush. acamprosate helps prevent a return to drinking only while you continue taking it. keep taking it even if you believe you will not drink again. do not stop without talking to your doctor. if you drink alcohol while taking acamprosate, keep taking your doses and call your doctor; acamprosate does not cause an unpleasant alcohol reaction. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking acamprosate, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to acamprosate, any other medicines, sulfites, or any ingredients in the tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take; be sure to mention antidepressants (mood elevators), as your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have ever had thoughts of harming or killing yourself, have ever attempted this, use or have used street drugs, or have overused prescription medications, and if you have or have ever had depression or kidney disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor; if you become pregnant while taking acamprosate, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist you take acamprosate. acamprosate may affect thinking, decision-making, and coordination; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. people who drink heavily often become depressed and may try to harm themselves. acamprosate does not reduce, and may increase, the risk of suicidal thoughts or actions. depression can occur even if you do not resume drinking. you or your family should call your doctor right away for symptoms of depression such as sadness, anxiety, hopelessness, guilt, worthlessness, helplessness, loss of interest, low energy, trouble concentrating, making decisions, or remembering, irritability, sleep problems, appetite or weight changes, restlessness, or thoughts about harming or killing yourself, planning, or attempting to do so. ensure your family knows these serious symptoms so they can seek help if you cannot. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? acamprosate may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: diarrhea, gas, upset stomach, loss of appetite, dry mouth, dizziness, itching, weakness, nausea, anxiety, difficulty falling or staying asleep, sweating. some side effects can be serious. if you experience burning, tingling, or numbness in the hands, feet, arms, or legs, or a rash, or any symptoms listed in the special precautions section, call your doctor immediately. acamprosate may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice any unusual problems while taking it.

name: benzoyl peroxide topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? benzoyl peroxide is used to treat mild to moderate acne. how should this medicine be used? benzoyl peroxide is for use on the skin and comes as a cleansing liquid or bar, lotion, cream, and gel. it is usually applied once or twice daily; begin with once daily to see how your skin tolerates it. follow the package directions or your prescription label exactly; do not use more, less, or more often than directed. when starting for the first time, apply a small amount to one or two affected spots for 3 days; if no irritation occurs, use as directed. use the cleansing liquid or bar to wash the affected area as instructed. for lotions, creams, or gels, gently wash the area, pat dry, then apply a thin layer and rub in gently. avoid irritants such as abrasive cleansers, alcohol-containing products, drying or medicated cosmetics, and unnecessary sun exposure or sunlamps unless your doctor advises otherwise. it may take 4 to 6 weeks to see improvement; if your acne does not improve, contact your doctor. do not get the medication in your eyes, mouth, or nose. do not use on children under 12 years of age without a doctor’s advice. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to benzoyl peroxide, any other medications, or any ingredients in the product; ask your pharmacist or check the label for a full ingredient list. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines you use, including vitamins. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while using benzoyl peroxide, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary changes are needed with topical benzoyl peroxide; continue your normal diet unless your doctor gives you other instructions. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include skin dryness or peeling, warmth, tingling, or mild stinging; contact your doctor if these are severe or do not go away. serious side effects can include burning, blistering, redness, swelling, or rash at the application site—call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if these occur. stop using benzoyl peroxide and get emergency help if you develop hives, itching, throat tightness, trouble breathing, feeling faint, or swelling of the eyes, face, lips, or tongue.

name: clindamycin and benzoyl peroxide topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? the clindamycin and benzoyl peroxide combination is used to treat acne. these topical antibiotics work by killing the bacteria that cause acne. how should this medicine be used? this medicine comes as a gel to apply to the skin and is usually used twice daily, in the morning and evening. apply it at the same times each day to help you remember. follow the directions on your prescription label exactly; do not use more or less, or apply it more often than prescribed. to use: wash the affected area with warm water and gently pat dry. using your fingertips, spread a thin, even layer of gel over the affected skin. avoid the eyes, nose, mouth, and other body openings; if contact occurs, rinse with warm water. check in a mirror—if you see a white film, you applied too much. wash your hands after applying. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to clindamycin (e.g., cleocin, clinda-derm, c/d/s), benzoyl peroxide (e.g., benzac, desquam, panoxyl, triaz, others), lincomycin, or any other medications. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are using; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had stomach problems, ulcerative colitis, or severe diarrhea caused by antibiotics. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while using this medicine, call your doctor. avoid unnecessary or prolonged sun exposure and wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen, as this medicine may make your skin more sensitive to sunlight. ask your doctor or pharmacist to recommend a moisturizer to help keep your skin comfortable during treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? clindamycin and benzoyl peroxide may cause side effects. common effects include dry skin, itching, peeling, and redness; contact your doctor if these are severe or do not go away. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor immediately if you have severe diarrhea, blood or mucus in the stool, severe stomach pain or cramps, or changes in your skin or nails that may be signs of a fungal infection. this medication may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: acarbose
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? acarbose is used with diet alone or with diet plus other medicines to treat type 2 diabetes, a condition in which the body does not use insulin properly and cannot control blood sugar. it works by slowing the activity of enzymes that break down carbohydrates, which reduces how quickly glucose enters the bloodstream after meals. keeping blood glucose in range helps reduce the risk of long term complications such as heart disease, stroke, kidney problems, nerve damage, and eye disease. taking medicines as prescribed, making lifestyle changes such as healthy eating, exercise, quitting smoking, and checking your blood sugar regularly can help manage diabetes and may lower your chances of heart attack, stroke, kidney failure, nerve damage causing numb or cold legs or feet, decreased sexual function, vision changes or loss, and gum disease. your healthcare team will advise you on the best plan to manage your diabetes. how should this medicine be used? acarbose is an oral tablet usually taken three times daily. take each dose with the first bite of each main meal. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. take acarbose exactly as directed. do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. continue taking it even if you feel well and do not stop without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine this medicine is sometimes prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking acarbose, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to acarbose or any medicines. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription drugs you use, especially other diabetes medicines, digoxin (lanoxin), diuretics (water pills), estrogens, isoniazid, medicines for high blood pressure or colds, oral contraceptives, pancreatic enzymes, phenytoin (dilantin), steroids, thyroid medicines, and vitamins. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had diabetic ketoacidosis, cirrhosis, or intestinal disorders such as inflammatory bowel disease or bowel obstruction. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while taking acarbose, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, tell the surgeon or dentist that you are taking acarbose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow the exercise and meal plan recommended by your doctor or dietitian, and aim for a balanced, healthful diet. alcohol can lower blood sugar; ask your doctor about safe alcohol use while taking acarbose. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if you will be having a snack soon, take a dose with the snack. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? when used with insulin or other diabetes medicines, acarbose may cause low blood sugar. if you have symptoms of hypoglycemia, use glucose products such as insta-glucose or b-d glucose tablets and call your doctor. because acarbose blocks the breakdown of table sugar and other complex sugars, fruit juice or other products containing these sugars will not reliably raise blood sugar. make sure you and those around you understand this difference between acarbose and other diabetes medicines. symptoms of low blood sugar include shakiness, dizziness or lightheadedness, sweating, nervousness or irritability, sudden mood or behavior changes, headache, numbness or tingling around the mouth, weakness, pale skin, hunger, and clumsy or jerky movements. if hypoglycemia is not treated, severe symptoms can occur; be sure family, friends, and others know to get medical help immediately if you develop confusion, seizures, or loss of consciousness. call your doctor right away if you have symptoms of high blood sugar such as extreme thirst, frequent urination, extreme hunger, weakness, or blurred vision. if high blood sugar is not treated, diabetic ketoacidosis can develop. call your doctor immediately if you have dry mouth, upset stomach and vomiting, shortness of breath, breath that smells fruity, or decreased consciousness.

name: zafirlukast
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? zafirlukast is prescribed to help prevent asthma symptoms. it belongs to a class of medicines called leukotriene receptor antagonists (ltras) and works by blocking natural substances that cause swelling and tightening of the airways. other uses for this medicine zafirlukast may also be used to treat allergic rhinitis (hay fever) and to help prevent exercise-induced breathing difficulties in people with asthma. how should this medicine be used? zafirlukast is an oral tablet usually taken twice daily on an empty stomach—either at least 1 hour before or 2 hours after meals. take it at the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly; do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. do not use zafirlukast to treat a sudden asthma attack; your doctor will prescribe a short-acting rescue inhaler for acute symptoms and will tell you how to use it. keep taking all other asthma medicines as directed; do not stop or change doses unless your doctor tells you to. zafirlukast helps control symptoms but does not cure asthma; continue taking it even if you feel well, and do not stop without talking to your doctor. what special precautions should i follow? before taking zafirlukast, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to zafirlukast or any other medicines; provide a list of all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use, because your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects; tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver disease; tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, and call your doctor right away if you become pregnant while taking zafirlukast; do not breastfeed while taking this medicine. be aware that mental health changes can occur while taking zafirlukast; call your doctor immediately if you experience agitation, aggressive behavior, anxiety, irritability, unusual dreams, hallucinations, depression, difficulty falling or staying asleep, restlessness, suicidal thoughts or behavior, or tremor. your doctor will decide if you should continue treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you different instructions, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effect: headache (contact your doctor if severe or persistent). some side effects can be serious; call your doctor right away if you have nausea; loss of appetite; pain in the right upper abdomen; excessive tiredness or lack of energy; itching; yellowing of the skin or eyes; flu-like symptoms; rash; swelling of the eyes, face, lips, tongue, or throat; difficulty breathing or swallowing; hoarseness; or pain, burning, numbness, or tingling in the hands or feet. zafirlukast may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you experience any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: somatropin injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? somatropin injection is used to treat growth failure due to growth hormone deficiency and certain other conditions, to increase body weight and endurance in some people with human immunodeficiency virus (hiv), and to treat short bowel syndrome in adults who require specialized nutrition support. somatropin is a human growth hormone (hgh) analog that replaces the hormone normally produced in the body, which can promote growth, increase body weight, and improve absorption of nutrients and fluids from the intestines. how should this medicine be used? somatropin injection is available as a solution in prefilled pens and cartridges, and as a powder in vials or cartridges that must be mixed with a liquid before use. it is injected subcutaneously (under the skin). your doctor will determine how often you should use it based on your condition and age. use it at the same time on each scheduled day. use exactly as directed; do not use more or less or more often than prescribed. your doctor may start with a low dose and increase it gradually. you may receive your first dose in the doctor’s office, or you or a caregiver may be taught to inject at home. before your first dose, read the manufacturer’s patient information and instructions for use. make sure you understand how and where to inject and how to dispose of used needles and syringes. continue to use somatropin even if you feel well. do not stop using it without talking to your doctor. always check the solution before injecting: confirm it has not expired and that it is clear and colorless without visible particles. do not use if expired, cloudy, or containing particles. do not reuse or share syringes, needles, injection pens, or vials. dispose of used items in a puncture-resistant container kept out of the reach of children. ask your doctor or pharmacist how to dispose of the full container. ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medicine may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using somatropin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to somatropin, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your allergy symptoms. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. do not use somatropin if you have recently had heart or stomach surgery, experienced major trauma, have serious breathing problems, have sleep apnea, have cancer, or have diabetic retinopathy; your doctor may advise against treatment in these situations. somatropin should not be used in children whose growth plates have closed and whose bones are no longer growing (usually after puberty). tell your doctor if you have ever had cancer and received radiation therapy to the head or brain; or if you have or have ever had diabetes; adrenal insufficiency; pancreatitis; papilledema; scoliosis; high blood phosphate levels; or thyroid or parathyroid problems. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using somatropin, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are using somatropin. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, call your doctor. your doctor will tell you when to inject the missed dose and when to take your next scheduled dose. do not inject a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? somatropin may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: thickening of the skin at the injection site; injection-site pain, redness, swelling, or itching; headache; muscle or joint pain; sore throat, cough, fever, or other signs of infection; ear pain; excessive gas; or hair loss. some side effects can be serious. stop using the medication and call your doctor immediately or seek emergency medical care if you have: vision changes with headache, nausea, or vomiting; hives; rash; itching; trouble breathing or swallowing; sweating; swelling of the eyes, face, mouth, lips, tongue, or throat; hoarseness; lightheadedness; fainting; fast or pounding heartbeat; chest pain; persistent stomach-area pain that may spread to the back with nausea, vomiting, or loss of appetite; swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; muscle or joint pain; numbness, burning, or tingling in the hands, fingers, arms, legs, or feet; extreme tiredness, weakness, lightheadedness, darkening of the skin, or weight loss; new or persistent knee or hip pain or limping; breathing problems, snoring, or sleep apnea; or enlarged breasts. somatropin may increase the risk of certain cancers, including brain or skin cancer. call your doctor right away if you notice changes in behavior or vision, headaches, or changes in moles, birthmarks, or skin color. somatropin may cause other side effects. if you experience anything unusual, contact your doctor.

name: pseudoephedrine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? pseudoephedrine is used to relieve nasal congestion caused by colds, allergies, and hay fever, and to temporarily ease sinus congestion and pressure. it improves symptoms but does not treat the underlying cause or speed recovery. it is a nasal decongestant that works by narrowing blood vessels in the nasal passages. how should this medicine be used? pseudoephedrine is available as a regular tablet, a 12-hour extended-release tablet, a 24-hour extended-release tablet, and a liquid solution taken by mouth. regular tablets and liquid are usually taken every 4 to 6 hours. the 12-hour extended-release tablets are taken every 12 hours; do not take more than two doses in 24 hours. the 24-hour extended-release tablets are taken once daily; do not take more than one dose in 24 hours. to help prevent trouble sleeping, take your last dose several hours before bedtime. follow the package or prescription label exactly; ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not take more, less, or more often than directed. pseudoephedrine is sold alone and in combination with other ingredients; ask your doctor or pharmacist which product best matches your symptoms. check nonprescription cough and cold labels carefully before using two or more products together, as they may contain the same active ingredients and could lead to an overdose. this is especially important for children. over-the-counter cough and cold combination products, including those with pseudoephedrine, can cause serious side effects or death in young children. do not give nonprescription pseudoephedrine to children younger than 4 years. use caution and follow package directions closely for children 4 to 11 years. do not give pseudoephedrine extended-release tablets to children younger than 12 years. if giving pseudoephedrine or a combination product to a child, check that the product is appropriate for the child’s age and do not use adult formulations for children. before dosing, read the label to find the correct amount for the child’s age and follow the dosing chart; ask the child’s doctor if you are unsure. if taking the liquid, measure with the provided device or a medicine-measuring spoon, not a household spoon. if your symptoms do not improve within 7 days or if you develop a fever, stop taking pseudoephedrine and call your doctor. swallow extended-release tablets whole; do not break, crush, or chew. other uses for this medicine this medication is sometimes used to help prevent ear pain and blockage from pressure changes during air travel or underwater diving. ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask for details. what special precautions should i follow? before taking pseudoephedrine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to pseudoephedrine, any other medications, or any inactive ingredients in the product; check the package label for a full ingredient list. do not use pseudoephedrine if you are taking, or have taken within the past 14 days, a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (maoi) such as isocarboxazid (marplan), phenelzine (nardil), selegiline (eldepryl, emsam, zelapar), or tranylcypromine (parnate). tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had high blood pressure, glaucoma, diabetes, difficulty urinating due to an enlarged prostate, or thyroid or heart disease. if you plan to use the 24-hour extended-release tablets, tell your doctor if you have had a narrowing or blockage of your digestive tract. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking pseudoephedrine, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you take pseudoephedrine. what special dietary instructions should i follow? limit or avoid foods and drinks high in caffeine, which can worsen pseudoephedrine’s side effects. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medication is often taken as needed. if your doctor has told you to take it on a regular schedule and you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? pseudoephedrine may cause side effects. common side effects include restlessness, nausea, vomiting, weakness, and headache. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor right away if you experience nervousness, dizziness, difficulty sleeping, stomach pain, trouble breathing, or a fast, pounding, or irregular heartbeat. pseudoephedrine may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: albuterol oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? albuterol helps prevent and relieve breathing problems such as wheezing, shortness of breath, coughing, and chest tightness caused by asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (copd). the inhalation aerosol (proair hfa, proventil hfa, ventolin hfa) is for adults and children 4 years and older. the dry powder inhaler (proair respiclick) is for children 12 years and older. the nebulizer solution is for adults and children 2 years and older. albuterol is a short-acting bronchodilator that relaxes and opens the airways to make breathing easier. it is also used to prevent exercise-induced bronchospasm. how should this medicine be used? albuterol is inhaled by mouth as a nebulized solution, a metered-dose aerosol, or a dry powder. for symptom relief or prevention in asthma/copd, the aerosol or powder is typically used every 4 to 6 hours as needed. to prevent exercise-induced breathing problems, use it 15 to 30 minutes before activity. nebulizer solution is usually used three or four times daily. follow your prescription exactly; do not use more or less or more often than prescribed. call your doctor if your symptoms worsen, if relief does not last as long as usual, or if you need it more frequently than normal. albuterol controls symptoms but does not cure lung disease; do not stop using it without your doctor’s guidance. each hfa aerosol inhaler delivers 60 or 200 puffs (depending on device); each powder inhaler delivers 200 doses. after the labeled number of doses, the inhaler may not deliver the correct amount. discard an hfa inhaler once its labeled number of doses is reached, even if spray remains. discard a powder inhaler 13 months after opening, on the package expiration date, or after the labeled doses are used, whichever comes first. many inhalers have dose counters; read and follow the manufacturer’s instructions and do not attempt to adjust or remove the counter. if your inhaler has no counter, keep track of doses used; do not float the canister in water. use only the albuterol canister with its matching inhaler; do not use the device for other medications or other canisters for albuterol. avoid getting albuterol in your eyes. do not use the inhaler near an open flame or high heat; the canister can explode. read the device’s instructions before first use, ask your healthcare professional to demonstrate proper technique, and practice under supervision. children should be taught and observed during use to ensure correct technique. to use the hfa aerosol: remove the cap and check the mouthpiece, ensure the canister is fully seated, and prime if new, unused for more than 14 days, or after a drop by shaking and releasing 4 sprays into the air away from your face. shake well before each puff. breathe out fully, place the mouthpiece in your mouth and seal your lips, begin a slow deep inhalation while pressing the canister once, then hold your breath for about 10 seconds and exhale slowly. if 2 puffs are prescribed, wait about 1 minute before the second puff. replace the cap and clean as directed by the manufacturer. to use the dry powder inhaler (respiclick): do not use with a spacer. if new, remove from the foil pouch; confirm the counter shows 200. hold upright with the cap at the bottom, open the cap fully until it clicks to load a dose only when ready to inhale. each cap opening loads one dose; avoid opening and closing unnecessarily. exhale fully away from the device; do not blow into it. place the mouthpiece in your mouth, seal your lips, and inhale deeply and forcefully through your mouth (not your nose), keeping fingers and lips clear of the vent. hold your breath for about 10 seconds, then remove the inhaler and close the cap. if a second puff is prescribed, repeat. keep the device clean and dry; wipe with a dry cloth only, never wash or immerse in water. to use the nebulizer solution: remove one vial from the foil pouch (leave others protected), check that the solution is clear and colorless, and do not use if cloudy or discolored. twist off the vial top and squeeze the entire contents into the nebulizer reservoir. ask your clinician whether other prescribed inhaled medications may be placed in the reservoir with albuterol. connect the reservoir to the mouthpiece or face mask and then to the compressor. sit upright, turn on the compressor, and breathe calmly and deeply for about 5 to 15 minutes until mist stops. clean and maintain the nebulizer as directed by the manufacturer. other uses for this medicine: inhaled albuterol may be used to help improve muscle strength during attacks in certain periodic paralysis conditions. discuss risks and benefits with your doctor. it may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor and pharmacist about all allergies, including to albuterol (including tablets such as vospire er or combinations such as in combivent or duoneb), levalbuterol (xopenex), or any ingredients in your inhaler or nebulizer solution. if you will use the powder inhaler, tell your doctor if you are allergic to milk proteins. provide a complete list of all medicines and supplements you use, especially beta blockers (atenolol, labetalol, metoprolol, nadolol, propranolol), digoxin, diuretics (water pills), epinephrine (e.g., epipen, primatene mist), other inhaled bronchodilators (metaproterenol, levalbuterol), and over-the-counter cold medicines. tell your doctor if you take or have recently stopped (within 2 weeks) tricyclic antidepressants (amitriptyline, amoxapine, clomipramine, desipramine, doxepin, imipramine, nortriptyline, protriptyline, trimipramine) or monoamine oxidase inhibitors (isocarboxazid, phenelzine, selegiline, tranylcypromine). your doctor may adjust doses and monitor for interactions. tell your doctor if you have or have had irregular heartbeat, heart disease, high blood pressure, hyperthyroidism, diabetes, or seizures, and if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. rarely, albuterol can cause paradoxical bronchospasm (sudden worsening wheeze and shortness of breath immediately after inhalation); if this occurs, stop using it and seek medical care right away. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is required. if you are sensitive to stimulants, limiting caffeine may reduce jitteriness or palpitations. if you have diabetes, monitor blood glucose as directed, as albuterol can occasionally affect sugar levels. follow any additional advice from your healthcare provider. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you are using albuterol on a schedule and miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose; if so, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use extra doses to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include tremor or shakiness, nervousness, headache, nausea, vomiting, cough, throat irritation, and muscle, bone, or back pain. serious effects can include fast, pounding, or irregular heartbeat; chest pain; rash; hives; itching; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; worsening breathing difficulty; trouble swallowing; or hoarseness. if serious symptoms or signs of an allergic reaction occur, seek medical attention immediately. other side effects may occur; call your doctor if you experience anything concerning.

name: quinapril
instructions: important warning: do not take quinapril if you are pregnant. if you become pregnant while taking quinapril, call your doctor right away. quinapril may harm the fetus. why is this medication prescribed? quinapril is used alone or with other medications to treat high blood pressure, and with other medications to treat heart failure. quinapril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ace) inhibitor. it lowers levels of substances that tighten blood vessels, helping blood flow more easily and allowing the heart to pump more effectively. untreated high blood pressure can damage the brain, heart, blood vessels, kidneys, and other organs, leading to heart disease, heart attack, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, vision loss, and other problems. in addition to medication, lifestyle changes such as eating a low-fat, low-salt diet, maintaining a healthy weight, exercising at least 30 minutes on most days, not smoking, and using alcohol in moderation help control blood pressure. how should this medicine be used? quinapril comes as an oral tablet, usually taken once or twice daily. take it at the same times each day. follow your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. take exactly as directed; do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. your doctor will likely start you on a low dose and increase it gradually, no more than once every 1 to 2 weeks. quinapril controls high blood pressure and heart failure but does not cure them. continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking quinapril, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to quinapril; any other ace inhibitors such as benazepril (lotensin, in lotrel), captopril (capoten), enalapril (vasotec, in vaseretic), fosinopril (monopril), lisinopril (in prinzide, in zestoretic), moexipril (univasc, in uniretic), perindopril (aceon), ramipril (altace), or trandolapril (mavik, in tarka); any other medications; or any ingredients in quinapril tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are taking valsartan and sacubitril (entresto) or if you have stopped taking it within the last 36 hours; your doctor will likely tell you not to take quinapril with valsartan and sacubitril. if you have diabetes and take aliskiren (tekturna, in amturnide, tekamlo, tekturna hct), your doctor will likely tell you not to take quinapril. some medications should not be taken with quinapril; others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. discuss all medicines you take or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist before starting quinapril, and consult them before starting, stopping, or changing any medicines while taking quinapril. the following nonprescription products may interact with quinapril: aspirin; nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin, others) and naproxen (aleve); and potassium supplements. tell your doctor and pharmacist if you use these and do not start them while on quinapril without medical advice. tell your doctor if you have ever had swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs while taking quinapril; your doctor will likely tell you not to take quinapril. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had heart, liver, or kidney disease; diabetes; lupus; or scleroderma. tell your doctor if you are breastfeeding. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist you are taking quinapril. be aware that diarrhea, vomiting, not drinking enough fluids, or heavy sweating can cause low blood pressure, leading to lightheadedness or fainting. what special dietary instructions should i follow? talk to your doctor before using salt substitutes containing potassium. if your doctor prescribes a low-salt or low-sodium diet, follow these instructions carefully. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember it. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? quinapril may cause side effects. common side effects include dizziness, excessive tiredness, cough, upset stomach, and vomiting. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; hoarseness; trouble breathing or swallowing; yellowing of the skin or eyes; fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection; chest pain; lightheadedness; or fainting. quinapril may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: theophylline
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? theophylline is used to prevent and treat wheezing, shortness of breath, and chest tightness caused by asthma, chronic bronchitis, emphysema, and other lung diseases. it relaxes and opens air passages in the lungs, making it easier to breathe. how should this medicine be used? theophylline comes as an extended-release (long-acting) tablet, extended-release capsule, and an oral solution. it is usually taken every 6, 8, 12, or 24 hours. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. take theophylline exactly as directed; do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. take this medication with a full glass of water on an empty stomach, at least 1 hour before or 2 hours after a meal. extended-release capsules (e.g., theo-dur sprinkles) may be swallowed whole or opened and the contents mixed with soft food and swallowed without chewing. swallow extended-release tablets whole; do not chew or crush them. theophylline controls symptoms of asthma and other lung diseases but does not cure them. continue to take theophylline even if you feel well. do not stop taking it without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine theophylline is sometimes used to treat breathing problems in premature infants. talk to your doctor about the possible risks of using this drug for your baby’s condition. this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking theophylline, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to theophylline, any other medications, or any ingredients in theophylline products; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist what prescription medications you are taking, especially allopurinol (zyloprim), azithromycin (zithromax), carbamazepine (tegretol), cimetidine (tagamet), ciprofloxacin (cipro), clarithromycin (biaxin), diuretics (“water pills”), erythromycin, lithium (eskalith, lithobid), oral contraceptives, phenytoin (dilantin), prednisone (deltasone), propranolol (inderal), rifampin (rifadin), tetracycline (sumycin), and other medications for infections or heart disease. also tell your doctor and pharmacist what prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take while taking theophylline. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. the following nonprescription or herbal products may interact with theophylline: cimetidine (tagamet), ephedrine, pseudoephedrine, and st. john’s wort. do not start any of these while taking theophylline without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had seizures, ulcers, heart disease, an overactive or underactive thyroid gland, high blood pressure, liver disease, or a history of alcohol abuse; if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding; and if you use tobacco products. cigarette smoking may decrease the effectiveness of theophylline. what special dietary instructions should i follow? drinking or eating foods high in caffeine, such as coffee, tea, cocoa, and chocolate, may increase side effects caused by theophylline. avoid large amounts of these substances while you are taking theophylline. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. if you become severely short of breath, call your doctor. what side effects can this medication cause? theophylline may cause side effects. contact your doctor if any of the following are severe or do not go away: upset stomach, stomach pain, diarrhea, headache, restlessness, difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep, irritability. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following, call your doctor immediately: vomiting, increased or rapid heart rate, irregular heartbeat, seizures, or rash.

name: hydrochlorothiazide
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? hydrochlorothiazide is used alone or with other medicines to treat high blood pressure. it is also used to treat edema fluid retention caused by conditions such as heart, kidney, or liver disease, and by certain medicines including estrogens and corticosteroids. hydrochlorothiazide is a diuretic water pill that helps the kidneys remove extra water and salt in the urine. treating high blood pressure helps prevent damage to the brain, heart, blood vessels, kidneys, and other organs, reducing the risk of heart disease, heart attack, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, and vision loss. lifestyle changes such as a low-fat, low-salt diet, maintaining a healthy weight, exercising at least 30 minutes most days, not smoking, and limiting alcohol also help control blood pressure. how should this medicine be used? hydrochlorothiazide comes as tablets, capsules, and an oral solution to take by mouth. it is usually taken once or twice daily. for edema, it may be taken every day or only on certain days as directed. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully. take hydrochlorothiazide exactly as prescribed. do not take more or less or take it more often than directed. hydrochlorothiazide controls high blood pressure but does not cure it. continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop taking it without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine hydrochlorothiazide may also be used to treat diabetes insipidus and to help prevent kidney stones in people with high calcium levels. talk to your doctor about the possible risks and benefits for your condition. this medicine may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking hydrochlorothiazide, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to hydrochlorothiazide, sulfa drugs, penicillin, or any other medicines. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. if you take cholestyramine or colestipol, take them 1 hour before or 4 hours after hydrochlorothiazide. nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs nsaids such as ibuprofen advil, motrin and naproxen aleve may interact; do not start or stop these while taking hydrochlorothiazide without discussing with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have kidney disease your doctor may tell you not to take hydrochlorothiazide or if you have or have ever had diabetes, asthma, gout, systemic lupus erythematosus sle, high cholesterol, or liver or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking hydrochlorothiazide, call your doctor right away. avoid unnecessary or prolonged sun exposure and wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen; hydrochlorothiazide can increase skin sensitivity to sunlight and may raise the risk of certain skin cancers. your doctor may check your skin during treatment. call your doctor if you notice any new skin changes or growths. hydrochlorothiazide may cause dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting when you stand up quickly, especially when starting treatment. to reduce this, get up slowly from sitting or lying positions. alcohol can worsen these effects. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow your doctor’s advice about a low-salt or low-sodium diet. if your doctor tells you to increase potassium intake, include potassium-rich foods such as bananas, prunes, raisins, and orange juice as directed. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include frequent urination, diarrhea, loss of appetite, headache, and hair loss. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have signs of dehydration or electrolyte imbalance such as dry mouth, thirst, nausea, vomiting, weakness, tiredness, drowsiness, restlessness, confusion, muscle weakness, pain or cramps, or a fast heartbeat; blisters or peeling skin; hives, rash, or itching; difficulty breathing or swallowing; fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection; unusual bleeding or bruising; ongoing pain that begins in the stomach area and may spread to the back; joint pain or swelling; or changes in vision, eye pain, or redness or swelling in or around the eye.

name: acebutolol
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? acebutolol is used alone or with other medications to treat high blood pressure and certain irregular heart rhythms. it is a beta blocker that lowers blood pressure by relaxing blood vessels and slowing the heart rate, which improves blood flow. untreated high blood pressure can damage the brain, heart, blood vessels, kidneys, and other organs, leading to heart disease, heart attack, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, vision loss, and other problems. along with medication, lifestyle changes such as eating a low-fat, low-salt diet, maintaining a healthy weight, exercising about 30 minutes most days, not smoking, and limiting alcohol can help control blood pressure. how should this medicine be used? acebutolol is taken by mouth as a capsule, usually once or twice daily. take it at the same times each day to help you remember. follow your prescription label exactly; ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not take more or less than prescribed or take it more often. your doctor may start you on a low dose and increase it gradually so your body can adjust; discuss how you feel and report any symptoms during this time. acebutolol controls your condition but does not cure it. continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop suddenly; stopping abruptly can cause serious heart problems such as chest pain angina, heart attack, or irregular heartbeat. your doctor will usually reduce the dose gradually over about 2 weeks, monitor you closely, and may advise avoiding strenuous activity during this period. other uses for this medicine acebutolol may also be used to treat chest pain angina. talk to your doctor about the possible risks and benefits. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking acebutolol, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to acebutolol, any other medications, or any ingredients in the capsules; your pharmacist can provide a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. some over-the-counter products can interact with acebutolol, including nasal decongestants such as oxymetazoline for example, afrin, neo-synephrine, vicks sinex and cough or cold combination products containing phenylephrine or pseudoephedrine; make sure your doctor and pharmacist know you use these, and do not start them while taking acebutolol without medical advice. tell your doctor if you have a slow or irregular heartbeat or heart failure; you may be advised not to take acebutolol. also inform your doctor if you have or have ever had heart, kidney, or liver disease; asthma or other lung diseases; circulation problems; diabetes; hyperthyroidism overactive thyroid; or a history of severe allergic reactions to foods or other substances. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking acebutolol, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking acebutolol. this medication may cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. acebutolol can increase the risk of low blood sugar and can mask the warning signs and symptoms of hypoglycemia. inform your doctor if you cannot eat or drink normally or are vomiting while taking acebutolol. know the symptoms of low blood sugar and what to do if they occur. if you have allergies, reactions may be more severe while using acebutolol, and usual doses of injectable epinephrine may be less effective. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? acebutolol may cause side effects. common side effects include dizziness, lightheadedness, excessive tiredness, headache, constipation, diarrhea, upset stomach, nausea, muscle or joint pain, and difficulty falling or staying asleep. some side effects can be serious. if you experience shortness of breath or wheezing, a slow heart rate, severe muscle or joint pain, unusual weight gain, swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, or chest pain, call your doctor immediately.

name: aceclidine ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? aceclidine ophthalmic is used to treat presbyopia, the gradual loss of the ability of the eyes to focus on close objects. it is a cholinergic agonist that works by stimulating muscles in the eye to improve depth of focus. how should this medicine be used? aceclidine ophthalmic is a liquid eye drop. instill one drop in each eye, wait 5 minutes, then instill a second drop in each eye. do this once daily. use exactly as directed. do not use more or less of it or use it more often than prescribed. remove contact lenses before use and wait at least 10 minutes after dosing before reinserting them. do not use any other eye drops within 5 minutes of using aceclidine ophthalmic. avoid letting the tip of the vial touch your eye or any surface. each vial is for single use; after opening and using a vial, discard it. what special precautions should i follow? before using aceclidine ophthalmic, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this medication, any of its ingredients, or any other medicines, foods, or substances, and describe the reaction you had. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have a history of iritis, which is inflammation of the iris. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while using aceclidine ophthalmic, call your doctor. this medication may cause temporary blurred, dark, or dim vision. do not drive a car or operate machinery until your vision returns to normal. use caution with night driving. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not use extra eye drops to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? some side effects can be serious. if you experience sudden onset of flashing lights, new floaters, or vision loss, get emergency medical treatment. aceclidine ophthalmic may cause other side effects; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information.

name: perindopril
instructions: important warning: do not take perindopril if you are pregnant. if you become pregnant while taking perindopril, call your doctor immediately. perindopril may harm the fetus. why is this medication prescribed? perindopril is used alone or in combination with other medications to treat high blood pressure. perindopril is in a class of medications called angiotensin-converting enzyme (ace) inhibitors. it helps blood flow more smoothly by preventing the production of certain natural chemicals that tighten the blood vessels. high blood pressure is a common condition and, when not treated, can cause damage to the brain, heart, blood vessels, kidneys, and other parts of the body. damage to these organs may cause heart disease, a heart attack, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, loss of vision, and other problems. in addition to taking medication, lifestyle changes such as eating a diet that is low in fat and salt, maintaining a healthy weight, exercising at least 30 minutes most days, not smoking, and using alcohol in moderation will also help control your blood pressure. how should this medicine be used? perindopril comes as a tablet to take by mouth and is usually taken once or twice a day. take it at the same time(s) each day to help you remember. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. take perindopril exactly as directed. do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed by your doctor. your doctor may start you on a low dose and gradually increase your dose. perindopril controls high blood pressure but does not cure it. continue to take perindopril even if you feel well. do not stop taking it without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking perindopril, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to perindopril; angiotensin-converting enzyme (ace) inhibitors such as benazepril (lotensin, in lotrel), captopril (capoten), enalapril (vasotec, in vaseretic), fosinopril (monopril), lisinopril (in prinzide and in zestoretic), moexipril (univasc, in uniretic), quinapril (accupril, in accuretic and in quinaretic), ramipril (altace), or trandolapril (mavik, in tarka); any other medications; or any of the ingredients in perindopril tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of the ingredients. tell your doctor if you are taking valsartan and sacubitril (entresto) or if you have stopped taking it within the last 36 hours; your doctor will probably tell you not to take perindopril with sacubitril/valsartan. if you have diabetes and are taking aliskiren (tekturna, in amturnide, tekamlo, or tekturna hct), your doctor will probably tell you not to take perindopril. tell your doctor and pharmacist what prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. the following nonprescription products may interact with perindopril: potassium supplements and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin) and naproxen (aleve). be sure to let your doctor and pharmacist know if you are taking these medications before you start perindopril. do not start any of these medications while taking perindopril without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you are on dialysis; and if you have or have ever had heart failure; lupus (sle); scleroderma; diabetes; angioedema (swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs); or kidney or liver disease. if you are breastfeeding, tell your doctor. you should know that diarrhea, vomiting, not drinking enough fluids, and sweating a lot can cause a drop in blood pressure, which may cause lightheadedness and fainting. what special dietary instructions should i follow? talk to your doctor before using salt substitutes containing potassium. if your doctor prescribes a low-salt or low-sodium diet, follow these directions carefully. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember it. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? perindopril may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: cough, headache, weakness, dizziness, diarrhea, stomach pain, upset stomach. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following, call your doctor immediately: swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; hoarseness; difficulty swallowing or breathing; lightheadedness; fainting; fever, sore throat, chills, and other signs of infection; irregular or rapid heartbeats. perindopril may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: acetaminophen rectal
instructions: notice: on september 22, 2025, the u.s. food and drug administration (fda) issued a safety communication indicating that using acetaminophen during pregnancy may be associated with neurodevelopmental conditions such as autism spectrum disorder (asd) or attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (adhd) in children. current evidence has not established that acetaminophen causes these disorders, but some studies have shown an association. talk with your healthcare provider about the risks and benefits of using acetaminophen during pregnancy. important warning: taking or using too much acetaminophen can cause severe liver damage, which may require a liver transplant or lead to death. accidental overdose can occur if you do not follow the prescription or package directions carefully or if you take or use more than one product that contains acetaminophen. to use acetaminophen safely, do not take or use more than one acetaminophen-containing product at the same time. read the labels of all prescription and nonprescription products to see if they contain acetaminophen. be aware that acetaminophen may appear on labels as apap, ac, acetaminophen, acetaminoph, acetaminop, acetamin, or acetam. ask your doctor or pharmacist if you need help identifying products that contain acetaminophen. use acetaminophen exactly as directed on the prescription or package label. do not take or use more acetaminophen or use it more often than directed, even if you still have pain or fever. do not take or receive more than 4,000 mg of acetaminophen in 24 hours from all sources. ask your doctor or pharmacist if you need help determining your total daily amount. do not use acetaminophen if you routinely drink three or more alcoholic beverages per day. talk to your doctor about the safe use of alcohol while taking acetaminophen. if you think you have taken or received too much acetaminophen, stop using it and call your doctor or get emergency help right away, even if you feel well. speak with your pharmacist or doctor if you have any questions about the safe use of acetaminophen or acetaminophen-containing products. why is this medication prescribed? acetaminophen rectal is used to relieve mild to moderate pain and to reduce fever. it belongs to a class of medications called analgesics (pain relievers) and antipyretics (fever reducers). it works by changing how the body senses pain and by helping to lower body temperature. how should this medicine be used? acetaminophen rectal comes as a suppository for use in the rectum. it is available without a prescription, though your doctor may prescribe it for certain conditions. follow the directions on the package or prescription label exactly. do not use more than directed. if giving acetaminophen rectal to a child, check the package label carefully to be sure it is the right product for the child’s age, and do not give children products made for adults. many acetaminophen products are combination products (for example, those for cough and cold). check labels carefully before using two or more products at the same time, because they may contain the same active ingredient, which could result in an overdose. stop giving acetaminophen rectal to your child and call your child’s doctor if new symptoms develop (such as redness or swelling), if pain lasts longer than 5 days, or if fever worsens or lasts longer than 3 days. to insert an acetaminophen suppository: 1) wash your hands. 2) remove the wrapper. 3) lie on your left side and draw your right knee toward your chest. left-handed persons may prefer lying on the right side with the left knee raised. 4) using your finger, gently insert the suppository into the rectum about 1/2 to 1 inch (1.25 to 2.5 cm) for infants and children, and about 1 inch (2.5 cm) for adults. 5) hold it in place for a moment. 6) remain lying down for 5 minutes to help prevent the suppository from coming out. 7) wash your hands thoroughly and resume normal activities. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information if available. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using acetaminophen rectal, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to acetaminophen or any of its ingredients, or if you have had an allergic reaction to any medications, foods, or substances; explain what symptoms you experienced. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver disease. do not use acetaminophen if you drink three or more alcoholic beverages daily. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor; if you become pregnant while using acetaminophen rectal, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medication is usually used as needed. if your doctor has told you to use it on a regular schedule and you miss a dose, use it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? acetaminophen rectal may cause side effects. some side effects can be serious. stop using acetaminophen rectal and call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical care if you have any of the following: red, peeling, or blistering skin; rash; yellowing of the skin or whites of the eyes; upper abdominal pain; dark urine; pale stools. acetaminophen may cause other side effects. if you experience any unusual symptoms, contact your doctor.

name: acetaminophen
instructions: notice: on september 22, 2025, the food and drug administration fda issued a safety warning indicating that using acetaminophen during pregnancy may be associated with the development of neurological conditions such as autism spectrum disorder asd or attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder adhd in children. although no evidence to date has proven that acetaminophen in pregnancy causes these disorders, some studies have shown an association. talk to your doctor about the risks and benefits of using acetaminophen during pregnancy. important warning: taking too much acetaminophen can cause severe liver damage, sometimes serious enough to require liver transplantation or cause death. you might accidentally take too much if you do not follow the prescription or package directions carefully, or if you take more than one product that contains acetaminophen. do not take more than one acetaminophen-containing product at the same time. read the labels of all prescription and nonprescription medications to see if they contain acetaminophen, which may also be listed as apap, ac, acetaminophen, acetaminoph, acetaminop, acetamin, or acetam. ask your doctor or pharmacist to help identify whether a product contains acetaminophen. take acetaminophen exactly as directed on the prescription or package label. do not take more or take it more often than directed, even if you still have fever or pain. do not take more than 4,000 mg of acetaminophen per day from all sources. ask your doctor or pharmacist if you need help determining your total daily amount. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver disease. do not take acetaminophen if you drink three or more alcoholic drinks every day. talk to your doctor about the safe use of alcohol while taking acetaminophen. stop taking your medication and call your doctor right away if you think you have taken too much acetaminophen, even if you feel well. talk to your pharmacist or doctor if you have questions about the safe use of acetaminophen or acetaminophen-containing products. why is this medication prescribed? acetaminophen is used to relieve mild to moderate pain and to reduce fever. it is in a class of medications called analgesics pain relievers and antipyretics fever reducers. it works by changing the way the body senses pain and by lowering body temperature. how should this medicine be used? acetaminophen comes as a tablet, chewable tablet, capsule, suspension or solution liquid, extended-release long-acting tablet, and orally disintegrating tablet that dissolves quickly in the mouth, to take by mouth with or without food. acetaminophen is available without a prescription, but your doctor may prescribe it to treat certain conditions. take acetaminophen exactly as directed. follow the directions on the package or prescription label carefully. do not take more than indicated on the label. if you are giving acetaminophen to your child, read the package label carefully to be sure it is the right product for the child’s age. do not give children acetaminophen products made for adults. check the package label to find the correct dose. if you know your child’s weight, use the dose that matches that weight on the chart; if you do not know the weight, use the dose for your child’s age. ask your child’s doctor if you are unsure how much to give. acetaminophen is also available in combination with other medications to treat cough and cold symptoms. check nonprescription cough and cold product labels carefully before using two or more products at the same time, because they may contain the same active ingredients and using them together could lead to an overdose. swallow extended-release tablets whole; do not split, chew, crush, or dissolve them. place the orally disintegrating tablet meltaways in your mouth and allow it to dissolve, or chew it before swallowing. shake the suspension well before each use to mix the medication evenly. always use the measuring cup or oral syringe provided by the manufacturer to measure doses of the solution or suspension. do not switch dosing devices between products; always use the device that comes with the product. stop taking acetaminophen and call your doctor if your symptoms worsen, you develop new or unexpected symptoms including redness or swelling, your pain lasts for more than 10 days, or your fever worsens or lasts more than 3 days. stop giving acetaminophen to your child and call your child’s doctor if new symptoms develop including redness or swelling, if pain lasts longer than 5 days, or if fever worsens or lasts longer than 3 days. do not give acetaminophen to a child who has a sore throat that is severe or does not go away, or that occurs with fever, headache, rash, nausea, or vomiting; call the child’s doctor right away, as these may be signs of a more serious condition. other uses for this medicine: acetaminophen may also be used in combination with aspirin and caffeine to relieve the pain associated with migraine headache. this medication is sometimes prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking acetaminophen, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this medication, any component of this medication, or any other medications, foods, or substances; describe what symptoms you had. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take while using acetaminophen. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. if you become pregnant while taking acetaminophen, call your doctor. you should know that combination acetaminophen products for coughs and colds that contain nasal decongestants, antihistamines, cough suppressants, or expectorants should not be used in children younger than 2 years of age because use in young children can cause serious and life-threatening effects or death. in children 2 through 11 years of age, use combination cough and cold products carefully and only according to the directions on the label. if you have phenylketonuria pku, an inherited condition requiring a special diet to prevent brain damage that can cause severe intellectual disability, you should know that some brands of acetaminophen chewable tablets may be sweetened with aspartame, a source of phenylalanine. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medication is usually taken as needed. if your doctor has told you to take acetaminophen on a regular schedule, take the missed dose as soon as you remember it. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and
