continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? acetaminophen may cause side effects. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following, stop taking acetaminophen and call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical attention: red, peeling, or blistering skin; rash; hives; itching; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; hoarseness; difficulty breathing or swallowing; yellowing of the skin or whites of the eyes; upper belly pain; dark urine; pale stools. acetaminophen may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: acetaminophen and codeine
instructions: important warning: the combination of acetaminophen and codeine may be habit forming. take it exactly as directed. do not take more or less, take it more often, stop suddenly, or use it differently than your doctor prescribes. the risk of misuse is higher if you or a family member drinks large amounts of alcohol, uses or has used street drugs, has overused prescription medicines, has had an overdose, or has depression or another mental illness. this medicine can cause serious or life-threatening breathing problems, especially during the first 24 to 72 hours of treatment and any time your dose is increased. if you have slowed or shallow breathing, long pauses between breaths, or shortness of breath, call your doctor or get emergency help right away. taking too much acetaminophen can cause severe liver damage, sometimes requiring transplantation or causing death. do not take more than 4,000 mg of acetaminophen per day. if you use more than one product that contains acetaminophen, add up the total and ask your doctor or pharmacist for help. this medicine can harm or be fatal to others who take it, especially children. store it securely so no one else can take it accidentally or on purpose. using alcohol, certain medications, or street drugs while taking this medicine increases the risk of dangerous sedation, breathing problems, or coma. always tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses and monitor you closely. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, regular use can cause life-threatening withdrawal in your newborn. you will receive a medication guide when you start and each time you refill; read it carefully and ask questions. discuss the risks of this medicine with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? the combination of acetaminophen and codeine is used to relieve pain. acetaminophen is an analgesic and antipyretic that changes how the body senses pain and lowers fever. codeine is an opioid analgesic that changes how the brain and nervous system respond to pain. how should this medicine be used? this medicine comes as tablets, capsules, and liquid taken by mouth. take every 4 hours as needed. your doctor may adjust your dose based on pain control and side effects. tell your doctor if your pain is not controlled, worsens, seems new, or if you develop increased sensitivity to pain. do not take more or more often than prescribed. ask your doctor or pharmacist about access to rescue medicines (naloxone or nalmefene), available over the counter or by prescription, and make sure you and people around you know overdose signs, how to use the rescue medicine, and what to do until help arrives. if overdose symptoms occur, someone should give the first dose of naloxone, call 911 immediately, stay with you, and give additional doses every 2 to 3 minutes if symptoms return until emergency help arrives. if you have taken this medicine for several weeks or longer, do not stop without talking to your doctor; your dose may need to be reduced gradually to prevent withdrawal symptoms such as restlessness, enlarged pupils, teary eyes, irritability, anxiety, runny nose, trouble sleeping, yawning, sweating, fast breathing, fast heartbeat, chills, nausea, loss of appetite, vomiting, diarrhea, stomach cramps, or muscle aches. if using the oral solution, use the provided measuring device or a medication-specific spoon or syringe; do not use household spoons. ask your pharmacist if you have questions about measuring your dose. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this drug, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your symptoms. some medicines must not be taken with acetaminophen and codeine; discuss all current and planned medications with your doctor and pharmacist before starting, stopping, or changing anything. do not take this medicine with or within the past 14 days of mao inhibitors such as isocarboxazid, linezolid, methylene blue, phenelzine, selegiline, or tranylcypromine. nonprescription products such as st. john’s wort and tryptophan may interact; tell your doctor and pharmacist if you use them. tell your doctor if you have slowed breathing, asthma, copd, or other lung problems; a blockage or narrowing of the stomach or intestines; or paralytic ileus—your doctor may advise against use. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had a brain tumor or any condition that increases pressure in the brain; seizures; or pancreas, gallbladder, heart, liver, or kidney disease. this medicine may decrease fertility in men and women; discuss risks with your doctor. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant, call your doctor. this medicine may cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. do not drink alcohol while taking it. it may cause dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting when standing; rise slowly. it may cause constipation; ask your doctor about diet changes and medicines to prevent or treat it. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is usually taken as needed. if your doctor has told you to take it on a regular schedule and you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your usual schedule. do not take a double dose. what side effects can this medication cause? this medicine may cause side effects. call your doctor if these are severe or do not go away: nausea, vomiting, sweating, decreased sexual desire, or inability to get or keep an erection. some side effects can be serious. get emergency help or call your doctor immediately if you have any of the symptoms listed in the important warning section, or any of the following: signs of liver problems (nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, weakness, dizziness); symptoms of serotonin syndrome (agitation, hallucinations, fever, sweating, confusion, fast heartbeat, shivering, severe muscle stiffness or twitching, loss of coordination, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea); rash; hives; itching; red, peeling, or blistering skin; trouble breathing or swallowing; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; chest pain; heartbeat changes; seizures; extreme drowsiness; new or unusually intense pain or pain from normal touch or activities; difficulty swallowing, regurgitation of food, or chest-area pain; unusual snoring or long pauses in breathing during sleep. this medication may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: acetaminophen injection
instructions: notice: on september 22, 2025, the food and drug administration (fda) issued a safety warning indicating that taking or receiving acetaminophen while pregnant may be associated with the development of neurological conditions such as autism spectrum disorder (asd) or attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (adhd) in children. although no evidence to date has been able to show that acetaminophen in pregnancy causes these disorders, some studies have shown an association. talk to your doctor about the risks and benefits of using acetaminophen during pregnancy. important warning: receiving too much acetaminophen can cause liver damage, sometimes serious enough to require liver transplantation or cause death. you might accidentally receive too much acetaminophen if you take acetaminophen by mouth or use more than one product that contains acetaminophen while receiving acetaminophen intravenously. do not use multiple acetaminophen-containing products at the same time. why is this medication prescribed? acetaminophen injection is used to relieve mild to moderate pain and to reduce fever. acetaminophen injection is also used in combination with opioid medications to relieve moderate to severe pain. acetaminophen is in a class of medications called analgesics (pain relievers) and antipyretics (fever reducers). it works by changing the way the body senses pain and by cooling the body. how should this medicine be used? acetaminophen injection comes as a liquid solution to be injected into a vein over 15 minutes. it is usually given every 4 to 6 hours as needed to relieve pain or reduce fever. receive it exactly as directed by your healthcare provider. do not take additional acetaminophen products while you are receiving the injection unless your provider tells you to. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving acetaminophen injection, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this medication, any part of this medication, or any other medications, foods, or substances, and describe what symptoms you had. tell your doctor and pharmacist what prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver disease; your doctor will probably tell you not to use acetaminophen injection. tell your doctor if you drink or have ever drunk large amounts of alcohol; if you have had severe vomiting or diarrhea or think you may be dehydrated; if you are not able to eat and drink enough to stay healthy; and if you have or have ever had kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. if you become pregnant while receiving acetaminophen injection, call your doctor. ask your doctor or pharmacist about the safe use of alcoholic beverages while receiving acetaminophen injection. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a scheduled dose or appointment for acetaminophen injection, contact your healthcare provider as soon as possible to reschedule. do not take extra acetaminophen or additional acetaminophen-containing products to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? acetaminophen injection may cause side effects. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of these symptoms, call your doctor immediately: rash; hives; itching; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, or lower legs; hoarseness; difficulty breathing or swallowing; yellowing of the skin or whites of the eyes; upper belly pain; dark urine; or pale stools. acetaminophen injection may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: acetaminophen, butalbital, and caffeine
instructions: important warning: taking too much acetaminophen in this combination can cause severe liver damage, sometimes requiring a liver transplant or causing death. do not take more than 4,000 mg of acetaminophen in 24 hours from all sources. read all labels carefully; many prescription and over-the-counter products contain acetaminophen. if you use more than one acetaminophen-containing product, ask your doctor or pharmacist to help you calculate your total daily amount. do not use if you have liver disease unless directed by your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? acetaminophen, butalbital, and caffeine is used to relieve tension headaches. acetaminophen is an analgesic (pain reliever) that changes how the body senses pain. butalbital is a barbiturate that has a relaxing effect on the brain and central nervous system (cns). caffeine is a cns stimulant that alters the amounts of certain natural substances in the brain. how should this medicine be used? this combination comes as capsules or tablets to take by mouth, usually every 4 hours as needed. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully. take exactly as directed. do not take more than six tablets or capsules in 24 hours. if you think you need more to relieve symptoms, call your doctor. this medication can be habit-forming; do not take larger doses, take it more often, or use it longer than prescribed. what special precautions should i follow? before taking this medicine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to acetaminophen, butalbital, caffeine, or any ingredients in the product. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. do not use if you are taking or have taken in the past 14 days any monoamine oxidase inhibitors (maois) such as isocarboxazid (marplan), phenelzine (nardil), tranylcypromine (parnate), selegiline (emsam, zelapar), or agents with maoi activity such as linezolid (zyvox) or methylene blue. tell your doctor if you have porphyria; your doctor will likely tell you not to take this medication. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver, stomach, or kidney problems. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor; if you become pregnant while taking this medication, call your doctor. this drug may cause drowsiness or dizziness. do not drive a car or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. ask your doctor about the safe use of alcohol while taking this medication; alcohol can worsen side effects and increase the risk of liver damage. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medication is usually taken as needed. if your doctor has told you to take it regularly and you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include drowsiness, nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, lightheadedness, dizziness, and confusion. call your doctor immediately if you experience rash, hives, itching, peeling or blistering skin, difficulty breathing or swallowing, or swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes.

name: acetazolamide
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? acetazolamide is used to lower pressure inside the eye in glaucoma, helping to prevent gradual vision loss. it is also used to lessen the severity and shorten the duration of symptoms of acute mountain (altitude) sickness such as upset stomach, headache, shortness of breath, dizziness, drowsiness, and fatigue. in combination with other medicines, it helps reduce edema (excess fluid retention) and helps control seizures in certain types of epilepsy. it may sometimes be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. how should this medicine be used? acetazolamide is available as oral tablets and capsules. take it exactly as directed on your prescription label; ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. if you are using the extended‑release (long‑acting) capsules (for example, diamox sequels), swallow them whole—do not crush or chew. what special precautions should i follow? before taking acetazolamide, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to acetazolamide, sulfonamides (sulfa drugs), diuretics (“water pills”), or any other medications. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription drugs you use, especially amphetamines, aspirin, cyclosporine (neoral, sandimmune), medicines for depression or for irregular heartbeat, diflunisal (dolobid), digoxin (lanoxin), diuretics, lithium (eskalith, lithobid), phenobarbital, primidone (mysoline), and any vitamins or supplements. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had heart, liver, or kidney disease, or diabetes. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while taking acetazolamide, contact your doctor right away. if you are scheduled for any surgery, including dental procedures, inform the doctor or dentist that you take acetazolamide. this medicine can cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you, and avoid alcohol, which can increase drowsiness. acetazolamide can make your skin more sensitive to sunlight; avoid unnecessary or prolonged sun exposure and wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your normal diet. to minimize stomach upset, you may take doses with food or milk. stay well hydrated, especially if using this medicine for altitude sickness, unless your doctor has advised fluid restriction. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at the same time to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? acetazolamide may cause side effects. common effects include upset stomach, vomiting, and loss of appetite; contact your doctor if these are severe or do not go away. call your doctor right away if you experience numbness or tingling, increased thirst and urination, marked drowsiness, headache, confusion, fever, rash, blood in the urine, painful urination, yellowing of the skin or eyes, seizures, sore throat, or unusual bleeding or bruising.

name: medroxyprogesterone injection
instructions: important warning: medroxyprogesterone injection can lower the amount of calcium in your bones. the longer you use it, the greater the loss may be, and bone calcium may not fully return to normal after stopping. bone loss can lead to osteoporosis (thin, weak bones) and increase fracture risk later in life, especially after menopause. because bone mass normally increases during the teen years, loss during this period may be especially serious. it is not known if starting medroxyprogesterone injection as a teen or young adult raises your future risk of osteoporosis. tell your doctor if you or a family member has osteoporosis, if you have or have had any other bone disease or anorexia nervosa, or if you smoke heavily or drink a lot of alcohol. tell your doctor if you take corticosteroids (for example, dexamethasone, methylprednisolone, prednisone) or seizure medicines (for example, carbamazepine, phenytoin, phenobarbital), as these can also affect bone health. do not use medroxyprogesterone injection long term (for example, more than 2 years) unless no other birth control or treatment option is appropriate for you. your doctor may order bone tests and will monitor you for signs of bone weakening. keep all medical and laboratory appointments and discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? medroxyprogesterone intramuscular (into a muscle) injection and medroxyprogesterone subcutaneous (under the skin) injection are used to prevent pregnancy. the subcutaneous form is also used to treat endometriosis (when tissue like the lining of the uterus grows outside the uterus, causing pain and heavy or irregular periods). medroxyprogesterone is a progestin that helps prevent pregnancy by stopping ovulation (the release of eggs) and by thinning the uterine lining. it does not protect against hiv (the virus that causes aids) or other sexually transmitted infections; use condoms to reduce infection risk. how should this medicine be used? the intramuscular suspension is injected into the buttock or upper arm, usually once every 3 months (13 weeks) by a healthcare professional. the subcutaneous suspension is injected just under the skin, usually once every 12 to 14 weeks by a healthcare professional. your first injection must be given when pregnancy is not possible: during the first 5 days of a normal period; within 5 days after giving birth if you are not breastfeeding; or during the sixth week after giving birth if you are breastfeeding. if you are switching from another birth control method, your doctor will tell you when to receive your first injection. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using medroxyprogesterone injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to medroxyprogesterone (depo-provera, depo-subq provera 104, provera, in prempro, in premphase) or any medication. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. st. johns wort may interact with medroxyprogesterone. your doctor may change doses or monitor you for side effects. do not start or stop interacting medicines while on medroxyprogesterone without medical advice. tell your doctor if you or a family member has had breast cancer or diabetes; and if you have or have ever had breast problems (lumps, nipple bleeding, abnormal mammogram, fibrocystic breast changes), unexplained vaginal bleeding, irregular or very light periods, significant premenstrual weight gain or fluid retention, blood clots in the legs, lungs, brain, or eyes, stroke or mini-stroke, migraine headaches, seizures, depression, high blood pressure, heart attack, asthma, or heart, liver, or kidney disease. if you think you might be pregnant, are pregnant, or plan to become pregnant, tell your doctor; if you become pregnant while using medroxyprogesterone injection, call your doctor right away because it may harm the fetus. if you are breastfeeding, you may receive medroxyprogesterone injection as long as your baby is at least 6 weeks old at the time of your first dose. small amounts pass into breast milk, but studies have not shown harm to infants exposed this way. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, tell the clinician that you use medroxyprogesterone injection. expect changes in your menstrual cycle while using this medication. periods may become irregular with spotting at first and may stop completely with continued use; cycles generally return to normal sometime after stopping. what special dietary instructions should i follow? consume adequate calcium and vitamin d to help reduce bone loss while using medroxyprogesterone injection. your doctor can recommend foods rich in these nutrients, daily amounts you need, and whether you should take calcium or vitamin d supplements. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an injection appointment, call your doctor right away. you may not be protected from pregnancy if injections are delayed. your doctor will advise when to receive the missed dose and may order a pregnancy test before giving it. use a backup birth control method (for example, condoms) until you receive the missed injection. what side effects can this medication cause? medroxyprogesterone may cause side effects. common effects include: changes in menstrual periods; weight gain; weakness or tiredness; nervousness or irritability; depression; difficulty sleeping; hot flashes; breast pain, swelling, or tenderness; stomach cramps or bloating; leg cramps; back or joint pain; acne; hair loss on the scalp; vaginal itching, irritation, redness, burning, or white discharge; changes in sexual desire; cold or flu symptoms; pain, redness, irritation, lumps, or scarring at the injection site. serious side effects are uncommon but require immediate medical attention: sudden shortness of breath; sudden sharp or crushing chest pain; coughing up blood; severe headache; nausea or vomiting; dizziness or fainting; vision change, vision loss, double vision, or bulging eyes; trouble speaking; weakness or numbness in an arm or leg; seizure; yellowing of the skin or eyes; extreme fatigue; pain, swelling, warmth, redness, or tenderness in one leg; menstrual bleeding that is heavier or lasts longer than usual; severe lower abdominal pain or tenderness; rash, hives, or itching; trouble breathing or swallowing; swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; difficult, painful, or frequent urination; constant pain, pus, warmth, swelling, or bleeding at the injection site. if you are younger than 35 years and began medroxyprogesterone injection within the past 4 to 5 years, you may have a slightly increased risk of breast cancer. medroxyprogesterone injection may also increase the risk of blood clots that can travel to the lungs or brain. because it is long acting, return to fertility may be delayed after the last injection; discuss timing if you plan to become pregnant soon. this medication may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using it.

name: medroxyprogesterone
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? medroxyprogesterone is used to treat abnormal menstrual periods or irregular vaginal bleeding. it is also used to restart a normal menstrual cycle in women who previously had regular periods but have not had a period for at least 6 months and are not pregnant or in menopause. in people taking estrogen, medroxyprogesterone helps prevent overgrowth of the uterine lining and may lower the risk of uterine cancer. medroxyprogesterone is a progestin that works by thinning the uterine lining and altering hormonal signals in the uterus. how should this medicine be used? medroxyprogesterone is taken by mouth as a tablet, usually once daily on specific days of your monthly cycle. take it at the same time each day on your scheduled days. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. this medicine manages your condition but does not cure it. continue using it as scheduled even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor. what special precautions should i follow? before taking medroxyprogesterone, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to medroxyprogesterone (provera, depo-provera), any other medicines, or corn. tell them about all prescription and over-the-counter medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had breast or gynecologic cancers; unexplained vaginal bleeding; a missed abortion (fetal demise not yet expelled); blood clots in the legs, lungs, brain, or eyes; stroke or tia; seizures; migraine; depression; asthma; diabetes; or heart, kidney, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant, call your doctor right away. do not use medroxyprogesterone to test for pregnancy or to prevent miscarriage in early pregnancy; it does not prevent miscarriage and may harm the fetus. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, inform the surgeon or dentist that you take medroxyprogesterone. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you different instructions, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? medroxyprogesterone may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: breast tenderness or nipple discharge; changes in menstrual flow; irregular vaginal bleeding or spotting; acne; increased facial hair; scalp hair thinning; trouble sleeping; drowsiness; upset stomach; weight gain or loss. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away if you have: pain, swelling, warmth, redness, or tenderness in one leg; slurred or difficult speech; dizziness or fainting; weakness or numbness of an arm or leg; shortness of breath; coughing up blood; sudden sharp or crushing chest pain; fast or pounding heartbeat; sudden vision changes or vision loss; double or blurred vision; bulging eyes; missed periods; depression; yellowing of the skin or eyes; fever; hives, rash, or itching; trouble breathing or swallowing; swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs. some laboratory animals given medroxyprogesterone developed breast tumors; it is unknown if this occurs in humans. medroxyprogesterone may also increase the risk of blood clots that can travel to the lungs or brain. discuss the benefits and risks with your doctor. medroxyprogesterone may cause other side effects; contact your healthcare provider if you notice anything unusual.

name: aspirin rectal
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? aspirin rectal is used to lower fever and to ease mild to moderate pain from headaches, menstrual cramps, arthritis, toothaches, and muscle aches. aspirin belongs to a class of medicines called salicylates and works by blocking the production of natural substances that cause fever, pain, swelling, and blood clots. how should this medicine be used? aspirin rectal is a suppository used in the rectum. it is available over the counter, though a doctor may also prescribe it for certain conditions. follow the package or prescription directions exactly, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not give aspirin to a child or teenager without talking to a doctor, because aspirin can cause reye’s syndrome—a rare but serious illness that causes fat to build up in the brain, liver, and other organs—especially during viral illnesses such as chickenpox or the flu. many aspirin products are combined with other ingredients (for example, cough and cold remedies). read labels carefully and do not use two products together if they contain the same active ingredients, to avoid an overdose; this is especially important for children. stop using aspirin rectal and contact your doctor if a fever lasts more than 3 days, pain lasts more than 10 days, or the painful area becomes red or swollen. to insert a suppository: wash your hands; remove the wrapper; lie on your left side with your right knee drawn up (left-handed people may lie on the right side with the left knee up); gently insert the suppository with a finger into the rectum—about 1/2 to 1 inch (1.25 to 2.5 centimeters) in infants and children, and about 1 inch (2.5 centimeters) in adults; hold it in place briefly; remain lying down for 5 minutes to help keep it from slipping out; then wash your hands and resume normal activities. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using aspirin rectal, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to aspirin, to any other medicines, or to any ingredient in the product; check the package label or ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. some nonprescription and herbal products can interact with aspirin, including nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as naproxen (aleve, naprosyn). do not start these while using aspirin rectal without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had asthma, frequent nasal congestion or runny nose, or nasal polyps, because these conditions increase the risk of an allergic reaction to aspirin and your doctor may advise against using it. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney or liver disease, or if you regularly consume three or more alcoholic drinks per day. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor. do not use aspirin doses greater than 81 mg (for example, 325 mg) around or after 20 weeks of pregnancy unless your doctor tells you to. if you become pregnant while using aspirin rectal, call your doctor. if you are planning surgery, including dental surgery, tell your surgeon or dentist that you use aspirin. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is often used as needed. if your doctor has told you to use it on a regular schedule and you miss a dose, use it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? aspirin rectal may cause side effects. some side effects can be serious. stop using aspirin rectal and call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have: bloody vomit; vomit that looks like coffee grounds; bright red blood in the stool; black or tarry stools; hives; rash; swelling of the eyes, face, lips, tongue, or throat; wheezing or trouble breathing; ringing in the ears; or hearing loss. aspirin may cause other side effects.

name: aspirin
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? prescription-strength aspirin is used to relieve symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis (inflammation of the joint lining), osteoarthritis (degeneration of the joint lining), systemic lupus erythematosus (an immune condition that affects joints and organs), and certain other rheumatologic conditions. over-the-counter aspirin reduces fever and relieves mild to moderate pain from headaches, menstrual periods, arthritis, toothaches, and muscle aches. nonprescription aspirin is also used to prevent heart attacks in people with a prior heart attack or angina (chest pain from reduced blood flow to the heart), to reduce the risk of death in people who are having or recently had a heart attack, and to prevent ischemic strokes or transient ischemic attacks (mini-strokes) in people with a previous event. it does not prevent hemorrhagic (bleeding) strokes. aspirin is a salicylate that works by blocking the production of natural substances that cause fever, pain, swelling, and blood clots. aspirin is also available in combination products (for example with antacids, other pain relievers, or cough and cold ingredients). this information covers aspirin alone; if you use a combination product, read the package or prescription label or ask your doctor or pharmacist for details. how should this medicine be used? prescription aspirin is supplied as an extended-release (long-acting) tablet. nonprescription aspirin is available as a regular tablet, delayed-release tablet (designed to dissolve in the intestine to reduce stomach irritation), chewable tablet, oral powder, and medicated gum. prescription aspirin is usually taken two or more times daily. nonprescription aspirin is typically taken once daily to lower the risk of heart attack or stroke, or every 4 to 6 hours as needed for fever or pain. follow the package or prescription directions exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not take more, take less, or take it more often than directed. swallow extended-release tablets whole with a full glass of water; do not break, crush, or chew them. swallow delayed-release tablets with a full glass of water. chewable tablets may be chewed, crushed, or swallowed whole; drink a full glass of water immediately after taking them. consult a doctor before giving aspirin to a child or teenager. aspirin can cause reye syndrome, a rare but serious condition involving the brain and liver, especially in children and teens with viral illnesses such as chickenpox or influenza. if you had oral surgery or a tonsillectomy within the last 7 days, ask your doctor which aspirin products are safe for you. delayed-release tablets take longer to start working; do not use them when you need rapid relief of pain or fever. stop aspirin and contact your doctor if fever lasts more than 3 days, pain lasts more than 10 days, or the painful area becomes red or swollen, as you may need medical evaluation. other uses for this medicine aspirin is sometimes used to treat rheumatic fever (a serious complication of strep throat that can inflame heart valves) and kawasaki disease (an illness in children that can affect the heart). it is also used to lower the risk of blood clots in certain people with artificial heart valves or other heart conditions, and to help prevent certain pregnancy complications. what special precautions should i follow? before taking aspirin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to aspirin, other pain or fever medicines, tartrazine dye, or any medications. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you use, especially: acetazolamide (diamox); angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors such as benazepril (lotensin), captopril (capoten), enalapril (vasotec), fosinopril (monopril), lisinopril (prinivil, zestril), moexipril (univasc), perindopril (aceon), quinapril (accupril), ramipril (altace), trandolapril (mavik); anticoagulants (blood thinners) such as warfarin (coumadin) and heparin; beta blockers such as atenolol (tenormin), labetalol (normodyne), metoprolol (lopressor, toprol-xl), nadolol (corgard), propranolol (inderal); diuretics (water pills); medicines for diabetes or arthritis; gout medicines such as probenecid and sulfinpyrazone (anturane); methotrexate (trexall); other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as naproxen (aleve, naprosyn); phenytoin (dilantin); and valproic acid (depakene, depakote). your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. if you take aspirin regularly to prevent heart attack or stroke, do not use ibuprofen (advil, motrin) for pain or fever without medical advice; your doctor will likely instruct you to separate the timing of ibuprofen and your daily aspirin. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had asthma, frequent nasal congestion or runny nose, or nasal polyps, because these increase the risk of an aspirin allergy; you may be advised not to take aspirin. tell your doctor if you often have heartburn, upset stomach, or stomach pain, and if you have or have had stomach ulcers, anemia, bleeding problems such as hemophilia, or kidney or liver disease. if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding, discuss aspirin use with your doctor. low-dose aspirin (81 mg) may be used during pregnancy, but doses above 81 mg can harm the fetus and cause problems with delivery if taken at about 20 weeks of pregnancy or later. do not take more than 81 mg (for example, 325 mg) at or after 20 weeks of pregnancy unless your doctor tells you to. call your doctor if you become pregnant while taking aspirin or aspirin-containing products. if you are scheduled for surgery, including dental procedures, tell the clinician that you take aspirin. if you drink three or more alcoholic beverages daily, ask your doctor whether you should use aspirin or other pain and fever medicines. what special dietary instructions should i follow? continue your usual diet unless your doctor gives you other instructions. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you take aspirin on a regular schedule and miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your usual dosing time. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? aspirin can cause side effects. common effects include nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, and heartburn. some effects are serious; call your doctor right away if you have hives, rash, swelling of the eyes, face, lips, tongue, or throat, wheezing or trouble breathing, hoarseness, fast heartbeat, rapid breathing, cold clammy skin, ringing in the ears, hearing loss, bloody vomit, vomit that looks like coffee grounds, bright red blood in stools, or black tarry stools. aspirin may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice any unusual problems while taking it.

name: tetracycline
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? tetracycline is used to treat infections caused by bacteria, including pneumonia and other respiratory tract infections; certain infections of the skin, eyes, lymphatic, intestinal, genital, and urinary systems; and infections spread by ticks, lice, mites, and infected animals. it is also used with other medications to treat acne. tetracycline is used to treat plague and tularemia—serious infections that may be spread on purpose as part of a bioterror attack. it can also be used in people who cannot take penicillin to treat certain types of food poisoning, and to treat anthrax—another serious infection that may be spread on purpose as part of a bioterror attack. tetracycline belongs to a class of medicines called tetracycline antibiotics and works by preventing the growth and spread of bacteria. antibiotics such as tetracycline do not work for colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when they are not needed increases the risk of getting an infection later that resists antibiotic treatment. how should this medicine be used? tetracycline comes as an oral capsule and is usually taken two to four times daily. take it on an empty stomach, at least 1 hour before or 2 hours after meals or snacks. swallow each dose with a full glass of water. do not take tetracycline with food, especially dairy products such as milk, yogurt, cheese, or ice cream. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. take tetracycline exactly as directed. do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed by your doctor. other uses for this medicine tetracycline is sometimes used to treat lyme disease and malaria, and to prevent plague and tularemia in people who have been exposed. talk to your doctor about the risks of using this medication for your condition. this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking tetracycline, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to tetracycline, minocycline, doxycycline, demeclocycline, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tetracycline capsule; ask your pharmacist for a list of the ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. be aware that antacids containing magnesium, aluminum, calcium, or sodium bicarbonate; calcium supplements; zinc products; iron products; and laxatives containing magnesium can interfere with tetracycline and make it less effective. take tetracycline 2 hours before or 6 hours after antacids, calcium supplements, and magnesium-containing laxatives; take tetracycline 2 hours before or after zinc products; and take tetracycline 2 hours before or 4 hours after iron preparations and vitamin products that contain iron. you should know that tetracycline may decrease the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives (birth control pills, patches, rings, and injections). use another method of contraception to prevent pregnancy while taking tetracycline, and talk to your doctor about options. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had lupus or kidney disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor. if you become pregnant while taking tetracycline, call your doctor immediately; tetracycline can harm the fetus. plan to avoid unnecessary or prolonged exposure to sunlight and wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen; tetracycline may make your skin sensitive to sunlight. call your doctor right away if you get a sunburn. you should know that when tetracycline is used during pregnancy or in babies or children up to age 8, it can cause permanent tooth discoloration. tetracycline should not be used in children under age 8 unless your doctor decides it is needed. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember it. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? tetracycline may cause side effects. if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away, tell your doctor: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, itching of the rectum or vagina, swollen tongue, black or hairy tongue, sore or irritated throat. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following, call your doctor immediately: headache; blurred vision, double vision, or loss of vision; skin rash; hives; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes; difficulty breathing or swallowing; joint stiffness or swelling; unusual bleeding or bruising; chest pain; a return of fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection; watery or bloody stools, stomach cramps, or fever during treatment or for up to two or more months after stopping treatment. tetracycline may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: rabeprazole
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? rabeprazole is used to relieve symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (gerd)—heartburn and possible esophageal injury—from acid backing up from the stomach, in adults and children 12 years and older. in adults, it is used to treat and heal gerd-related esophageal damage and to prevent further damage. it is also used in adults for conditions with excess stomach acid, such as zollinger-ellison syndrome, and to treat ulcers in the stomach or intestine. in adults, it is used with other medicines to eliminate helicobacter pylori (h. pylori), a bacteria that causes ulcers. rabeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor (ppi) that reduces stomach acid production. how should this medicine be used? rabeprazole is taken by mouth as a delayed-release tablet (designed to dissolve in the intestine so stomach acid does not break it down). it is usually taken once daily. for ulcers, take the tablet after the morning meal. for h. pylori, take it twice daily with the morning and evening meals for 7 days, together with the other prescribed antibiotics. follow your prescription label exactly; ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. take rabeprazole exactly as directed; do not take more, take it more often, or take it longer than prescribed. swallow tablets whole with water; do not split, chew, or crush. keep taking rabeprazole even if you feel better; do not stop without talking to your doctor. call your doctor if your symptoms do not improve or worsen. other uses for this medicine your doctor may prescribe this medication for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking rabeprazole, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to rabeprazole; to other ppis such as dexlansoprazole (dexilant), esomeprazole (nexium; also in vimovo), lansoprazole (prevacid), omeprazole (prilosec; also in talicia and zegerid), or pantoprazole (protonix); to any other medications; or to any ingredients in the tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. some medicines should not be taken with rabeprazole; others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. discuss all prescription, nonprescription, and herbal products you use or plan to use with your doctor and pharmacist before starting rabeprazole, and consult them before starting, stopping, or changing any medicine while taking rabeprazole. nonprescription or herbal products that may interact include iron supplements; tell your doctor and pharmacist if you take these, and do not start them while on rabeprazole without medical advice. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had low magnesium, calcium, or potassium; hypoparathyroidism (low parathyroid hormone); low vitamin b12; osteoporosis; an autoimmune disease such as systemic lupus erythematosus; or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while taking rabeprazole, call your doctor. if you are 70 years or older, discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. do not take this medicine longer than your doctor recommends. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? rabeprazole may cause side effects. common side effects include headache, nausea, vomiting, constipation, diarrhea, gas, sore throat, and in men, difficulty achieving or maintaining an erection. call your doctor right away or seek emergency help for serious side effects: severe skin reactions (blistering, peeling, bleeding skin; sores on lips, nose, mouth, or genitals), swollen glands, shortness of breath, fever, or flu-like symptoms; signs of an allergic reaction (rash, hives, itching, swelling of the eyes, face, lips, mouth, throat, or tongue; trouble breathing or swallowing; hoarseness); irregular, fast, or pounding heartbeat; muscle spasms; uncontrollable shaking; unusual tiredness; lightheadedness; dizziness; seizures; severe or persistent diarrhea with watery stools, stomach pain, or fever; new or worsening joint pain or a rash on the cheeks or arms that is sensitive to sunlight; or signs of kidney problems (increased or decreased urination, blood in the urine, fatigue, nausea, loss of appetite, fever, rash, or joint pain). rabeprazole may cause other side effects. people taking ppis like rabeprazole may have a higher risk of fractures of the wrist, hip, or spine, and may develop fundic gland polyps (growths on the stomach lining). these risks are higher with high doses or use for one year or longer. talk with your doctor about the risks and benefits of rabeprazole.

name: acitretin
instructions: important warning: for female patients: do not take acitretin if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant within the next 3 years. this drug can harm an unborn baby. do not start acitretin until you have had two negative pregnancy tests. you must use two acceptable forms of birth control for 1 month before starting, throughout treatment, and for 3 years after your last dose; your doctor will tell you which methods are acceptable. you do not need two methods if you have had a hysterectomy, have completed menopause as confirmed by your doctor, or practice complete sexual abstinence. if you use oral contraceptives, tell your doctor the brand. do not use microdosed progestin “minipill” products while on acitretin because acitretin reduces their effectiveness. if you use hormonal contraceptives (pills, patches, implants, injections, iuds), review all medicines, vitamins, and herbal supplements with your clinician because many can reduce contraceptive effectiveness; do not take st. john’s wort with any hormonal contraceptive. you will need regular pregnancy tests during treatment and for at least 3 years after stopping. stop acitretin and call your doctor immediately if you become pregnant, miss a period, or have sex without two forms of birth control; emergency contraception (“morning after pill”) may be prescribed in some situations. do not consume alcohol in food, drinks, prescription, or nonprescription products while taking acitretin and for 2 months after your last dose; alcohol and acitretin can form a long-lasting substance that can harm a fetus. read labels carefully and ask if you are unsure whether a product contains alcohol. you will receive and must sign a patient agreement/informed consent before starting; read it carefully and ask questions. for male patients: small amounts of acitretin are found in semen; it is unknown if this can harm a fetus. discuss risks with your doctor if your partner is pregnant or planning pregnancy. for all patients: do not donate blood during treatment and for 3 years after stopping. acitretin can cause liver damage; if you have liver disease or develop nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, upper right abdominal pain, yellowing skin or eyes, or dark urine, call your doctor right away. you will receive a medication guide at the start and with each refill; read it and ask questions. why is this medication prescribed? acitretin treats severe psoriasis (abnormal skin cell growth causing red, thickened, or scaly skin). it is a retinoid; its exact mechanism in psoriasis is not known. how should this medicine be used? acitretin is an oral capsule taken once daily with your main meal at about the same time each day. follow your prescription exactly; do not change your dose or schedule without your doctor’s advice. your doctor may start with a low dose and increase it. acitretin controls but does not cure psoriasis; full benefit may take 2 to 3 months or longer. psoriasis may temporarily worsen in the first months; continue treatment unless your doctor tells you otherwise. do not stop without consulting your doctor. symptoms may return after stopping; do not use leftover capsules for a new flare—your treatment plan may need to change. other uses for this medicine: your doctor may prescribe it for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for details. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you have had a serious allergic reaction to acitretin, other retinoids (adapalene, alitretinoin, isotretinoin, tazarotene, tretinoin), or any capsule ingredients. do not take acitretin with methotrexate or with tetracycline antibiotics (demeclocycline, doxycycline, minocycline, tetracycline). tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription, nonprescription, vitamin, nutritional, and herbal products you take, including those noted above, as well as glyburide, phenytoin, vitamin a (including multivitamins), and if you have ever taken etretinate. your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have had liver disease, high cholesterol or triglycerides, a family history of high cholesterol, kidney disease, heavy alcohol use, diabetes or high blood sugar, spinal problems, depression, stroke or tia, or joint, bone, or heart disease; your doctor may advise against acitretin in some cases. do not breastfeed while taking acitretin or if you have recently stopped. acitretin can suddenly reduce night vision; use caution driving at night. avoid unnecessary or prolonged sun exposure; wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen, and do not use sunlamps. if you receive phototherapy, tell your clinician you take acitretin. it can dry your eyes and make contact lenses uncomfortable; remove lenses and call your doctor if this occurs. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include peeling, dry, itchy, scaling, cracked, blistered, sticky, or infected skin; brittle or weak nails; dandruff; sunburn; abnormal skin odor; excessive sweating; hair loss or texture change; dry eyes; loss of eyebrows or eyelashes; hot flashes or flushing; chapped or swollen lips; swollen or bleeding gums; excessive saliva; tongue or mouth pain, swelling, or blisters; stomach pain; diarrhea; increased appetite; insomnia; sinus infection; runny or dry nose; nosebleeds; joint pain; muscle tightness; and taste changes. serious side effects can occur; call your doctor immediately if you have rash; headache; signs of high or low blood sugar or diabetic ketoacidosis (extreme thirst, frequent urination, extreme hunger, blurred vision, weakness, dry mouth, nausea and vomiting, shortness of breath, fruity breath, decreased consciousness); eye pain, redness, swelling of eyes or eyelids, or light sensitivity; swelling of hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; redness or swelling in one leg; depression or suicidal thoughts; bone, muscle, back pain, or difficulty moving; numbness in hands or feet; chest pain; slow or difficult speech; tingling in arms or legs; loss of muscle tone; weakness or heaviness in legs; cold, gray, or pale skin; slow or irregular heartbeat; dizziness; fast heartbeat; weakness; shortness of breath; or ear pain or ringing. acitretin may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: aclidinium oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? aclidinium is used for long-term maintenance to help prevent wheezing, shortness of breath, cough, and chest tightness in people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (copd), including chronic bronchitis and emphysema. it is a bronchodilator that relaxes and opens the airways to make breathing easier. how should this medicine be used? aclidinium comes as a dry powder in an inhaler used by mouth. inhale one dose twice daily, about 12 hours apart, at the same times each day. follow your prescription directions exactly; do not use more or less or more often than prescribed. do not use aclidinium for sudden breathing problems—your doctor will prescribe a rescue medication for sudden symptoms; keep it with you at all times. do not take extra doses of aclidinium if symptoms worsen. call your doctor or seek emergency care if your breathing gets worse, you need your rescue inhaler more often, or it no longer works as well. aclidinium controls symptoms but does not cure copd. you may notice some improvement on the first day, but full benefit may take longer. continue using it even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor. before first use, read the manufacturer’s instructions carefully. ask your doctor or pharmacist to show you how to use the device and practice while being observed. avoid getting the powder in your eyes; it may cause blurred vision and sensitivity to light. the device does not need cleaning; if desired, wipe the outside of the mouthpiece with a dry tissue or paper towel. do not use water, as it can damage the medication. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to aclidinium, atropine (atropen; in lomotil, lonox, motofen), any other medicines, any ingredients in the aclidinium inhalation powder, or milk proteins. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use. be sure to mention antihistamines; atropine; glycopyrrolate (lonhala magnair, seebri; in bevespi aerosphere; in utibron); ipratropium (atrovent); medicines for irritable bowel disease, motion sickness, parkinson’s disease, ulcers, or urinary problems; tiotropium (spiriva); and umeclidinium (incruse ellipta; in anoro ellipta; in trelegy ellipta). your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had glaucoma (high eye pressure), enlarged prostate (bph), a bladder condition, or any problem that makes it hard to empty your bladder completely. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using aclidinium, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and resume your regular dosing schedule. do not inhale a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? aclidinium may cause side effects. common side effects include headache, runny nose or other cold-like symptoms, cough, and diarrhea. some side effects can be serious. stop using aclidinium and call your doctor right away or get emergency help if you have sudden shortness of breath immediately after inhalation; eye pain or redness; blurred vision; seeing halos or bright colors around lights; nausea or vomiting; difficult, painful, or frequent urination; weak urine stream; rash; hives; itching; swelling of the eyes, face, lips, mouth, tongue, or throat; or trouble breathing or swallowing. aclidinium may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice any unusual problems while using it.

name: acoltremon ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? acoltremon ophthalmic solution is used to treat the signs and symptoms of dry eye disease, a condition in which your tears do not provide enough moisture for your eyes. acoltremon is a transient receptor potential melastatin 8 (trpm8) agonist that works by increasing tear production. how should this medicine be used? acoltremon ophthalmic solution is a liquid used in the eyes. instill it in each eye twice daily, about 12 hours apart, and use it at the same times each day. use acoltremon exactly as directed. do not use more or less than prescribed or use it more often than your doctor recommends. remove contact lenses before using the drops and wait 15 minutes before reinserting them. acoltremon comes in single-use containers meant for one dose. use the liquid immediately after opening for both eyes, then discard the container and any remaining liquid; do not save it for the next dose. to use the eye drops: wash your hands with soap and water; remove a strip of single-use containers from the foil pouch; detach one container and return the rest to the pouch; hold the container upright with the twist-off tab at the top; twist off the tab to open; tilt your head back or lie down; hold the tip close to your eye without touching it; pull your lower eyelid down and look up; gently squeeze to release a single drop into the space between your lower eyelid and eye; if the drop misses, try again; close your eye for a few seconds without blinking or squeezing; dispose of the used container out of the reach of children, even if not empty. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using acoltremon eye drops, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to acoltremon, any ingredient in the product, or any other medications, foods, or substances, and describe your allergy and the symptoms you experienced. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take while using acoltremon. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using acoltremon, call your doctor. if you use another topical eye medication, instill it at least 5 minutes before or after acoltremon. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and resume your regular dosing schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? acoltremon eye drops may cause side effects. contact your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: irritation, burning, or stinging when the drops are instilled. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you experience pain, swelling, or redness of the eyes or eyelids, or any eye injury. acoltremon may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: acoramidis
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? acoramidis is used to treat transthyretin amyloid cardiomyopathy (attr-cm), a condition in which the protein transthyretin builds up in the heart wall, making it thicker and making it harder for the heart to pump blood effectively. acoramidis is in a class of medicines called transthyretin stabilizers. it works by preventing abnormal proteins from forming in the heart and causing damage. how should this medicine be used? acoramidis comes as a tablet to take by mouth. take it with or without food twice a day, at about the same times each day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. take acoramidis exactly as directed; do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. swallow the tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush them. acoramidis controls attr-cm but does not cure it. continue to take acoramidis even if you feel well. do not stop taking acoramidis without talking to your doctor. ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking acoramidis, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to acoramidis, any other medications, or any of the ingredients in the tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of the ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. some nonprescription or herbal products may interact with acoramidis, including st. john’s wort. do not start any new medicines, supplements, or herbal products while taking acoramidis without discussing them with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney problems. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking acoramidis, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. however, if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? acoramidis may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: diarrhea; stomach pain. acoramidis may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: fluoride
instructions: important warning: on may 13, 2025, the u.s. food and drug administration (fda) announced it will remove oral fluoride prescription drug products for children from the market. unlike fluoride toothpastes or rinses, these products are swallowed by infants and toddlers and have never been fda-approved. ingested fluoride has been shown to alter the gut microbiome, which is of particular concern during early childhood when the microbiome is developing. some studies have also suggested associations between fluoride and thyroid disorders, weight gain, and possibly decreased iq. the fda set a goal date of october 31 to complete a safety review and public comment period and to take appropriate action regarding removal of these products from the market. why is this medication prescribed? fluoride is used to help prevent tooth decay. it is incorporated into teeth to strengthen them, improve resistance to acid, and reduce the cavity-forming effects of bacteria. fluoride is typically prescribed for children and adults whose household water supply is not fluoridated (does not already have fluoride added). it may sometimes be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? fluoride is available as a liquid, tablet, and chewable tablet to take by mouth, usually once daily. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take fluoride exactly as directed; do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. the liquid may be taken directly or mixed with cereal, fruit juice, or other foods. use a dropper or oral syringe to measure your dose. tablets may be dissolved in the mouth, chewed, or mixed into drinking water or fruit juice. tablets may also be added to water used for infant formula or other foods. fluoride helps strengthen teeth and prevent cavities but does not replace brushing and flossing. what special precautions should i follow? before taking fluoride, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to fluoride, tartrazine (a yellow dye found in some foods and medications), or any other drugs. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. nonprescription products that may interact with fluoride include calcium, magnesium, and iron supplements; be sure your doctor and pharmacist know you are taking these before starting fluoride, and do not start them while taking fluoride without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while taking fluoride, call your doctor. tell your doctor if you are on a low-sodium or sodium-free diet. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not eat or drink dairy products for 1 hour before or 1 hour after taking fluoride. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? fluoride may cause side effects. if this symptom is severe or does not go away: staining of teeth. call your doctor immediately if you experience any of the following: unusual increase in saliva; salty or soapy taste; stomach pain; upset stomach; vomiting; diarrhea; rash; weakness; tremor; seizures.

name: tocilizumab injection
instructions: notice: tocilizumab injection is available as biologic products, including biosimilars. these biosimilars are expected to work just as well and be as safe as the reference tocilizumab. in this document, tocilizumab injection refers to any of these products. important warning: tocilizumab can make it harder for your body to fight infections and can increase the risk of serious or life-threatening infections. tell your doctor if you currently have any infection; if you frequently get infections (including minor ones such as open cuts, sores, or cold sores, or infections that come and go); if you have diabetes, hiv, low white blood cell counts, or any condition that affects your immune system; if you live in, have lived in, or have traveled to areas where severe fungal infections are more common (such as the ohio and mississippi river valleys or the southwest); or if you take medicines that decrease immune system activity. you will be monitored during and after treatment for signs of infection. call your doctor right away if you have fever; chills; sweating; trouble breathing; sore throat; cough; weight loss; diarrhea; stomach pain; blood in your phlegm; extreme tiredness; muscle aches; warm, red, or painful skin; mouth or skin sores; burning with urination; frequent urination; or any other signs of infection. tocilizumab can reactivate tuberculosis (tb) or hepatitis b if these infections are present but inactive. your doctor will test you for tb (such as a skin or blood test) and for hepatitis b before treatment and may treat these infections first. tell your doctor if you have or ever had tb or hepatitis b, have visited countries where tb is common, or have been around someone with tb. call your doctor immediately if you have symptoms of tb (cough, chest pain, coughing up blood or mucus, weakness or tiredness, weight loss, loss of appetite, chills, fever, or night sweats) or symptoms of hepatitis b (extreme tiredness, yellow skin or eyes, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, muscle aches, dark urine, pale or clay-colored stools, fever, chills, stomach pain, or rash). keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor will order tests before and during treatment to check your response. you will receive a medication guide when you start and each time you receive this medicine—read it and ask your doctor or pharmacist any questions. discuss the risks and benefits of tocilizumab with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? tocilizumab injection is used to treat autoimmune disorders in which the immune system attacks healthy tissues and causes pain, swelling, and damage, including: rheumatoid arthritis; giant cell arteritis; polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis (pjia); systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (sjia); and systemic sclerosis–associated interstitial lung disease (ssc‑ild). it is also used to treat cytokine release syndrome (a severe, potentially life-threatening reaction) and to treat coronavirus disease 2019 (covid‑19) in hospitalized adults who require supplemental oxygen or a ventilator. tocilizumab is an interleukin‑6 (il‑6) receptor inhibitor that works by blocking il‑6, a substance in the body that drives inflammation. how should this medicine be used? tocilizumab injection is given as a solution for intravenous (iv) infusion over about 1 hour by a healthcare professional in a medical office or hospital. it also comes as a single‑dose prefilled syringe and an autoinjector for subcutaneous (sc) injection under the skin that you or a caregiver can give at home. your doctor will determine how often you receive doses based on your condition, age, and weight. use tocilizumab exactly as directed; do not use more, less, or more often than prescribed. your first sc dose will be given in your doctor’s office, where you will be shown how to inject. read the instructions for use before your first injection at home and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. if the medicine has been refrigerated, allow the prefilled syringe to reach room temperature for 30 minutes or the autoinjector for 45 minutes on a flat surface before use. do not warm it by microwave, hot water, or any other method. do not remove the cap until after warming and when you are ready to inject. do not use the syringe or device if it has been dropped. always check the expiration date and inspect the solution; it should be clear and colorless to pale yellow—not cloudy, discolored, or containing particles or lumps. if there are problems with the package or device, do not inject; call your pharmacist. inject into the front of the thighs or the abdomen, avoiding the navel and the 2‑inch area around it; if a caregiver injects, the outer area of the upper arms may be used. do not inject into skin that is tender, bruised, red, hard, broken, scarred, or over moles or bruises. rotate injection sites; choose a spot at least 1 inch from the last site. if the full dose is not injected, call your doctor or pharmacist. use each syringe or autoinjector once and inject the entire contents; do not reuse even if some solution remains. do not recap after use. dispose of used devices in a puncture‑resistant sharps container; ask your pharmacist how to discard it. tocilizumab helps control symptoms but does not cure your condition. your doctor will monitor your response and may adjust or delay doses if your lab results change. tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. other uses for this medicine: this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving tocilizumab, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to this drug or any of its ingredients, or to any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your symptoms. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects or interactions. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any of the conditions listed in the important warning; cancer; diverticulitis (inflamed pouches in the colon); stomach or intestinal ulcers; high cholesterol or triglycerides; high blood pressure; any nervous system condition such as multiple sclerosis (ms) or chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (cidp); low platelet counts; or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while receiving tocilizumab, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell your healthcare providers that you are receiving tocilizumab. ask your doctor whether you should receive any vaccines before starting treatment;
