if possible, bring children up to date on all vaccinations before therapy. do not receive vaccinations during treatment without talking to your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment for an iv dose, call your doctor. if you forget to inject a subcutaneous dose, inject it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next scheduled dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not inject a double dose to make up for a missed one. call your doctor or pharmacist if you are unsure when to inject. what side effects can this medication cause? tocilizumab may cause side effects. common side effects include headache; runny nose or sneezing; redness, itching, pain, or swelling at the injection site; constipation; diarrhea; anxiety; and difficulty falling or staying asleep. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have any of the symptoms listed in the important warning or any of the following: rash; flushing; hives; itching; swelling of the eyes, face, lips, tongue, or throat; wheezing; trouble breathing or swallowing; dizziness or fainting; sweating; fast or racing heartbeat; chest pain; swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; fever with ongoing stomach‑area pain or a change in bowel habits; or signs of liver problems such as yellow eyes or skin, right upper abdominal pain, unexplained bruising or bleeding, loss of appetite, confusion, dark yellow or brown urine, or pale stools. tocilizumab may increase the risk of certain cancers; discuss these risks with your doctor. other side effects may occur; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: cosyntropin injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cosyntropin injection is used to help diagnose adrenocortical insufficiency, a condition in which the adrenal glands do not produce enough cortisol. it belongs to a class of medicines called synthetic adrenocorticotropic hormone acth and works by acting like natural acth to stimulate the adrenal glands to produce cortisol. how should this medicine be used? cosyntropin comes as a powder that is mixed with liquid and given by a healthcare professional as a one-time injection either into a vein intravenously or into a muscle intramuscularly. your healthcare provider will measure your cortisol level before the injection and again about 30 minutes and 60 minutes after the injection. some medicines can affect test results. if you take spironolactone, do not take it on the day of the test. if you take corticosteroids for example prednisone, prednisolone, dexamethasone, methylprednisolone, hydrocortisone, or triamcinolone, ask your doctor or pharmacist how long you should stop them before your test. if you take estrogen-containing medicines such as hormonal contraceptives or hormone replacement therapy, you may need to stop them 4 to 6 weeks before your scheduled test. always tell your healthcare provider about all medicines and supplements you use. ask your doctor or pharmacist for the manufacturer information for patients if you need it. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving cosyntropin, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this medication, any of its ingredients, or any other medicines, foods, or substances, and describe what symptoms you had. some medicines can interfere with the results of the cosyntropin test, so make sure you have discussed all medicines and supplements you are taking or plan to take when scheduling your test. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given as a single dose by a healthcare professional for a scheduled test. if you miss your appointment, contact your healthcare provider to reschedule. do not attempt to take this medicine on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? cosyntropin may cause side effects. common effects include swelling in the arms or legs, lightheadedness, and redness of the skin or rash. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have hives, itching or rash; swelling of the face, lips, eyes, or throat; wheezing or trouble breathing; or a weak or rapid pulse with lightheadedness. cosyntropin may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: corticotropin, repository injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? corticotropin repository injection is used to treat: infantile spasms (seizures that begin in the first year of life and may be followed by developmental delays in infants and children younger than 2 years); episodes or flares of multiple sclerosis (ms; a disease that affects nerve function and can cause weakness, numbness, coordination problems, and issues with vision, speech, and bladder control); flares in rheumatoid arthritis; flares in psoriatic arthritis; flares in ankylosing spondylitis; lupus; systemic dermatomyositis (muscle weakness with skin rash) or polymyositis (muscle weakness without skin rash); severe allergic skin reactions including stevens-johnson syndrome; serum sickness; allergic reactions or other conditions that cause swelling of the eyes and the area around them; sarcoidosis; and nephrotic syndrome (protein in the urine, low blood protein, high blood fats, and swelling of the arms, hands, feet, and legs). it belongs to a class of medications called hormones and treats many conditions by decreasing immune system activity to prevent organ damage. how it treats infantile spasms is not fully known. how should this medicine be used? corticotropin repository injection is a long-acting gel given subcutaneously (under the skin) or intramuscularly (into a muscle). for infantile spasms, it is usually injected into a muscle twice daily for 2 weeks, then tapered over another 2 weeks. for multiple sclerosis, it is typically injected once daily for 2 to 3 weeks, then gradually reduced. for other conditions, it is injected once every 24 to 72 hours based on the condition and response. inject at about the same times on each scheduled day. follow your prescription exactly; do not use more or less or more often than prescribed. continue as directed and do not stop without talking to your doctor. stopping suddenly may cause weakness, tiredness, pale skin, skin color changes, weight loss, stomach pain, and loss of appetite; your doctor will taper your dose. you may self-inject or have a caregiver inject after training. read the manufacturer's instructions before your first home injection; your clinician can show you or arrange for a nurse to teach you. the medicine comes in vials (dose withdrawn with a syringe) or as a prefilled autoinjector. ask which needle and syringe to use if drawing from vials. do not share or reuse needles or syringes. dispose of used sharps in a puncture-proof container; ask your pharmacist how to discard it. subcutaneous sites: upper thigh, upper arm, or abdomen (avoid the navel and the 1-inch area around it). intramuscular sites: upper arm or upper outer thigh; for infants, use the upper outer thigh. rotate sites and choose a spot at least 1 inch from prior injections. do not inject into areas that are red, swollen, painful, hard, sensitive, or that have tattoos, warts, scars, or birthmarks. do not inject into the knee or groin. if using a vial: check the label and expiration date; the solution should be clear and colorless without cloudiness, flecks, or particles. do not use if incorrect, expired, or abnormal; call your pharmacist. warm to room temperature before injecting by rolling the vial between your hands or holding it under your arm for a few minutes. if using the autoinjector: remove from the refrigerator and allow 45 minutes at room temperature before subcutaneous injection. the autoinjector is for subcutaneous use only. rotate sites and do not use the same site more than once per week. read and follow the autoinjector instructions. when injecting a child, position and comfort the child; another person may help hold or distract. an ice cube on the site before or after injection can reduce discomfort. if treating infantile spasms, you will receive a medication guide at the start and with each refill; read it and ask questions. what special precautions should i follow? before use, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to corticotropin repository injection, any of its ingredients, any medications, or porcine (pig) proteins. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; dose changes or extra monitoring may be needed. tell your doctor if you have scleroderma; osteoporosis; a fungal infection that has spread throughout the body; herpes infection in the eye; heart failure; high blood pressure; any disorder of the adrenal glands; if you recently had surgery; or if you have or have ever had a stomach ulcer. if the patient is a baby, tell the doctor if the baby had an infection before or during birth. your doctor may advise against use if these conditions are present. tell your doctor if you currently have any infection; if you have fever, cough, vomiting, diarrhea, flu-like symptoms, or live with someone who is sick. also tell your doctor if you have tuberculosis (tb), a severe lung infection, known exposure to tb, or a past positive tb skin test. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had diabetes, an underactive thyroid, neuromuscular conditions such as myasthenia gravis, stomach or intestinal problems, emotional problems, psychosis (difficulty recognizing reality), liver disease, or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant during treatment. before surgery (including dental) or emergency treatment, tell the providers you use corticotropin repository injection; carry a card or wear a medical alert bracelet in case you cannot speak. do not receive vaccinations without talking to your doctor, and tell your doctor if household members are scheduled for vaccinations during your treatment. your blood pressure may increase during therapy; your doctor will monitor it. this medicine increases the risk of infection; wash hands often and avoid people who are ill during treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? your doctor may recommend a low-sodium and/or high-potassium diet and may prescribe a potassium supplement during treatment. ask your doctor for guidance. what should i do if i forget a dose? inject the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not inject a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? corticotropin repository injection may cause side effects. common effects include increased or decreased appetite, weight gain, irritability, mood or personality changes, an abnormally happy or excited mood, and trouble falling or staying asleep. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have sore throat, fever, cough, vomiting, diarrhea, or other signs of infection; open cuts or sores; puffiness or fullness of the face; increased fat around the neck with thinning of the arms or legs; thin skin; stretch marks on the abdomen, thighs, or breasts; easy bruising; muscle weakness; stomach pain; vomit that is bloody or looks like coffee grounds; bright red blood in stools; black or tarry stools; depression; difficulty recognizing reality; vision changes; extreme tiredness; increased thirst; fast heartbeat; rash; swelling of the face, tongue, lips, or throat; difficulty breathing; or new or different seizures. in children, growth and development may slow; your child's doctor will monitor growth. use may increase the risk of osteoporosis; your doctor may order bone density tests and advise ways to lower your risk. this medication may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using it.

name: haemophilus influenzae type b (hib) vaccine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? the haemophilus influenzae type b (hib) vaccine helps prevent infections caused by hib bacteria. hib can cause mild illnesses (such as ear infections or bronchitis) and severe, invasive disease (such as bloodstream infections and bacterial meningitis). before hib vaccination was routine, hib was the leading cause of bacterial meningitis in u.s. children under 5 years, which can lead to brain damage, deafness, or death. hib can also cause pneumonia; severe throat swelling that makes breathing difficult; and infections of the blood, joints, bones, and the covering of the heart. how should this medicine be used? hib vaccine is typically given as a series of 3 or 4 doses, depending on the brand. infants usually receive the first dose at 2 months of age and complete the series at 12-15 months. children 12 months to 5 years who are not fully vaccinated may need 1 or more catch-up doses. children over 5 years and adults usually do not receive hib vaccine, but it may be recommended for people with a damaged or removed spleen (including those with sickle cell disease), before or after splenectomy, after a bone marrow transplant, and for some people 5 through 18 years old with hiv. hib vaccine can be given by itself or as part of a combination vaccine (one shot that includes multiple vaccines) and may be given at the same time as other vaccines. what special precautions should i follow? tell the vaccination provider if the person to be vaccinated has ever had a severe allergic reaction to a previous hib dose or has any severe, life-threatening allergies. people with minor illnesses (such as a cold) can usually be vaccinated. those who are moderately or severely ill should generally wait until they recover. fainting can occur after vaccination; tell your provider right away if you feel dizzy or have vision changes or ringing in the ears. your health care provider may advise postponing vaccination in certain situations. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are needed for this vaccine. what should i do if i forget a dose? if a scheduled dose is missed, contact your health care provider to reschedule as soon as possible. follow your provider’s guidance for catch-up vaccination based on age and health status, and do not take extra doses on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? common reactions include redness, warmth, or swelling where the shot was given. fainting can occur after vaccination. as with any medicine, there is a very small chance of a severe allergic reaction or other serious injury. signs of a severe allergic reaction include hives, swelling of the face or throat, difficulty breathing, a fast heartbeat, dizziness, or weakness; call 9-1-1 and go to the nearest hospital if these occur. report adverse events to the vaccine adverse event reporting system (vaers); vaers is for reporting only and does not provide medical advice. the national vaccine injury compensation program (vicp) is a federal program that may compensate people who believe they were injured by certain vaccines; claims have filing deadlines that may be as short as two years.

name: doxycycline
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? doxycycline treats many infections caused by certain bacteria. it is also used to treat or prevent inhalational anthrax after exposure, and to treat plague and tularemia, which may be spread intentionally. it helps prevent malaria. along with other medications it treats acne and rosacea; the oracea brand is used only for the pimples and bumps of rosacea. doxycycline is a tetracycline antibiotic that stops bacteria from growing; in acne it kills pore-infecting bacteria and reduces oily secretions; in rosacea it lowers inflammation. it does not treat viral illnesses such as colds or flu; using antibiotics when not needed can lead to antibiotic resistance. it may also be used to treat malaria, to treat or prevent lyme disease after certain tick bites, and to help prevent certain sexually transmitted infections in specific circumstances; ask your doctor about risks and appropriateness. how should this medicine be used? doxycycline comes as capsules, tablets, delayed-release tablets, and an oral suspension. it is usually taken once or twice daily with a full glass of water. if it upsets your stomach, you may take it with food or milk; ask your doctor or pharmacist for guidance. follow your prescription label exactly; do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. swallow delayed-release tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush. if you cannot swallow certain delayed-release tablets (doryx and some generics), you may carefully break the tablet and sprinkle the pellets on a spoonful of cool or room-temperature applesauce; do not crush the pellets; swallow right away without chewing; discard if not taken immediately. shake the suspension well before each dose. for malaria prevention, start 1–2 days before you travel to an area with malaria, continue daily while there, and for 4 weeks after leaving; do not use for prevention longer than 4 months. keep taking doxycycline for the full prescribed course even if you feel better. different doxycycline products may not be interchangeable; use only the product prescribed; ask your pharmacist if unsure. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to doxycycline, minocycline (dynacin, minocin, solodyn, ximino), tetracycline (achromycin v; in pylera), demeclocycline, any other medicines, sulfites, or any ingredients in doxycycline products; your pharmacist can provide a list of ingredients. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and herbal products you take or plan to take. important interactions include acitretin; anticoagulants such as warfarin (jantoven); bismuth subsalicylate; carbamazepine (epitol, tegretol); isotretinoin (absorica, claravis, myorisan, zenatane); penicillins; phenobarbital; phenytoin (phenytek); and proton pump inhibitors such as dexlansoprazole (dexilant), esomeprazole (nexium; in vimovo), lansoprazole (prevacid), omeprazole (prilosec, zegerid; in talicia), pantoprazole (protonix), and rabeprazole (aciphex). nonprescription bismuth, omeprazole, and lansoprazole can also interact. do not start or stop interacting products without medical advice. antacids containing magnesium, aluminum, or calcium; calcium supplements; iron products; and magnesium-containing laxatives reduce doxycycline’s effectiveness. take doxycycline 1–2 hours before or 1–2 hours after antacids, calcium supplements, and magnesium-containing laxatives, and 2 hours before or 3 hours after iron products and multivitamins with iron. tell your doctor if you have or have had lupus, intracranial hypertension (pseudotumor cerebri), oral or vaginal yeast infections, stomach surgery, asthma, kidney or liver disease, or diarrhea. doxycycline may reduce the effectiveness of hormonal birth control pills, patches, rings, or injections; discuss an additional nonhormonal method. if you are pregnant or planning pregnancy, tell your doctor; if you become pregnant, call immediately, as doxycycline can harm the fetus. if you are breastfeeding, your doctor may advise not to breastfeed while taking doxycycline. avoid unnecessary or prolonged sunlight; wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen; contact your doctor right away if you get sunburned. for malaria prevention, also use insect repellent, bed nets, body-covering clothing, and stay in well-screened areas, especially from early evening to dawn; doxycycline does not provide complete protection. use in pregnancy or in children younger than 8 years can permanently discolor teeth and affect bone growth; do not use in children under 8 except for inhalational anthrax, rocky mountain spotted fever, or if your doctor decides it is necessary. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember; if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule; do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, loss of appetite, rectal itching, vaginal itching, burning, swelling, redness, irritation, vaginal discharge, painful or difficult urination, sore throat or nose, swollen tongue, dry mouth, anxiety, back pain, and changes in the color of skin, scars, nails, eyes, or mouth. serious side effects require immediate medical attention and include severe headache; blurred, double, or lost vision; rash possibly with fever or swollen glands; hives; skin redness, peeling, or blistering; trouble breathing or swallowing; swelling of the eyes, face, throat, tongue, or lips; unusual bleeding or bruising; watery or bloody stools, stomach cramps, or fever during treatment or up to two or more months after stopping; return of fever, sore throat, chills, or other infection signs; joint pain; and discoloration of permanent adult teeth. other side effects may occur; call your doctor if you experience anything unusual.

name: chlorpheniramine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? chlorpheniramine is an antihistamine used to relieve red, itchy, watery eyes; sneezing; an itchy nose or throat; and a runny nose caused by allergies, hay fever, and the common cold. it helps control these symptoms but does not treat their cause or speed recovery. it works by blocking histamine, a body chemical that triggers allergic symptoms. how should this medicine be used? chlorpheniramine comes as tablets, capsules, extended-release (long-acting) tablets and capsules, chewable tablets, and a liquid taken by mouth. regular tablets/capsules, chewable tablets, and liquid are usually taken every 4 to 6 hours as needed. extended-release tablets and capsules are usually taken twice daily, in the morning and evening, as needed. follow your prescription label carefully. take chlorpheniramine exactly as directed; do not take more or less, or take it more often, than prescribed. chlorpheniramine is available alone and in combination with fever and pain relievers, expectorants, cough suppressants, and decongestants. ask your doctor or pharmacist which product best fits your symptoms. check nonprescription cough and cold product labels carefully before using two or more products at the same time; many contain the same active ingredients, and using them together could cause an overdose. this is especially important for children. nonprescription cough and cold combination products, including those with chlorpheniramine, can cause serious side effects or death in young children. do not give these products to children younger than 4 years of age. if used in children 4 to 11 years of age, use caution and follow the package directions carefully. when giving chlorpheniramine or a combination product to a child, read the package label to be sure it is appropriate for the child’s age, and do not give adult products to children. check the dosing chart on the package to match the child’s age and give only that dose. ask the child’s doctor if you are unsure how much to give. if you are taking the liquid, use the provided measuring spoon or cup, or a medication-measuring device; do not use a household spoon. swallow extended-release tablets and capsules whole; do not break, crush, chew, or open them. other uses for this medicine this medication may sometimes be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking chlorpheniramine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to chlorpheniramine, any other medications, or any of the ingredients in the product you plan to use. check the package label for a complete list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had asthma, emphysema, chronic bronchitis, or other lung disease; glaucoma (increased pressure in the eye that can cause gradual vision loss); ulcers; diabetes; difficulty urinating due to an enlarged prostate gland; heart disease; high blood pressure; seizures; or an overactive thyroid gland. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking chlorpheniramine, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking chlorpheniramine. this medication may cause drowsiness. do not drive a car or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. ask your doctor about the safe use of alcohol while taking chlorpheniramine; alcohol can worsen its side effects. if you are 65 years of age or older, talk to your doctor about the risks and benefits; older adults generally should not take chlorpheniramine because safer and more effective alternatives are available. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? chlorpheniramine is often taken as needed. if your doctor has told you to take it regularly and you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? chlorpheniramine may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of the following are severe or do not go away: drowsiness; dry mouth, nose, or throat; nausea; vomiting; loss of appetite; constipation; headache; increased chest congestion. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you experience: vision problems or difficulty urinating.

name: ursodiol
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ursodiol is prescribed to dissolve certain cholesterol gallstones in people who cannot or prefer not to have surgery, to prevent gallstone formation in people who are losing weight rapidly, and to treat primary biliary cholangitis (pbc), an autoimmune liver disease. it belongs to a class called gallstone dissolution agents and works by reducing cholesterol production, dissolving cholesterol in bile to prevent stone formation, and lowering toxic bile acid levels that build up in pbc. how should this medicine be used? ursodiol is available as capsules and tablets taken by mouth. for gallstones, it is usually taken two or three times daily with or without food; to prevent gallstones during rapid weight loss, it is usually taken twice daily. if you are taking tablets for pbc, they are typically taken 2 to 4 times daily with food. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. if you need to split a scored tablet, place it scored-side up on a flat surface and apply gentle pressure with your thumbs to snap it in half. swallow the half-tablet with water without chewing. because the tablet is very bitter, store the unused half in a separate container from whole tablets and use it within 28 days. ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions about splitting, taking, or storing the tablets. treatment often takes months. if you are taking capsules to dissolve gallstones, therapy may continue for up to 2 years; stones may not fully dissolve, and even after successful treatment, new stones can form within 5 years. continue taking ursodiol even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking ursodiol, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to ursodiol, other bile acids, any medications, or any ingredients in the tablets or capsules. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. nonprescription antacids that contain aluminum may interact with ursodiol; make sure your healthcare providers know you use them, and do not start them while taking ursodiol without discussing it with your provider. tell your doctor if you have a blocked bile duct; you will likely be advised not to take ursodiol. your doctor may also advise against ursodiol if your gallstones will not dissolve or if surgery is a better option. tell your doctor if you have had gastrointestinal surgery, or if you have or have ever had variceal bleeding, crohn’s disease, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while taking ursodiol. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your usual diet. take tablets for pbc with food; doses for gallstones may be taken with or without food. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? ursodiol may cause side effects. if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away, tell your doctor: dizziness, headache, cough, fever, sore throat, runny nose or other signs of infection, frequent urination or pain when you urinate, muscle pain, hair loss. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or get emergency medical help if you have: indigestion, stomach pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, hives, rash, itching, swelling of the face, eyes, mouth, throat, tongue, lips, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, or trouble breathing or swallowing. ursodiol may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: interferon gamma-1b injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? interferon gamma-1b injection is used to reduce how often and how severely serious infections occur in people with chronic granulomatous disease, an inherited immune disorder. it is also used to slow worsening of severe, malignant osteopetrosis, an inherited bone disease. interferon gamma-1b is an immunomodulator; its exact mechanism in these conditions is not fully known. how should this medicine be used? interferon gamma-1b is injected under the skin three times each week (for example, monday, wednesday, and friday) at about the same time of day. follow your prescription directions exactly; do not use more or less or inject more often than prescribed. your first dose will be given in your doctor’s office. after that, you or a caregiver may give the injections. read the patient instructions that come with the medication before your first self-injection, and have your doctor or pharmacist show you the correct technique. inject into the upper arms, abdomen (stomach area), or thighs, rotating sites with each dose. do not inject into skin that is irritated, bruised, red, infected, or scarred. never reuse or share needles, syringes, or vials. dispose of used needles and syringes in a puncture-resistant sharps container and discard used vials in the household trash; ask your pharmacist how to dispose of the sharps container. you will receive a patient information leaflet at the start of treatment and with each refill; read it and ask your healthcare provider any questions. what special precautions should i follow? before using interferon gamma-1b, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to interferon gamma-1b, products made from e. coli, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the product; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; dose adjustments and monitoring may be needed. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had seizures, low red or white blood cell counts, heart failure, irregular heartbeat, or heart or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant during treatment. you may experience flu-like symptoms (headache, fever, chills, muscle aches, tiredness) after injections; your doctor may recommend acetaminophen (tylenol) to help—contact your doctor if symptoms are hard to manage or become severe. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, do not increase your dose and do not give two injections at once. if you are unsure what to do, call your doctor for instructions. what side effects can this medication cause? interferon gamma-1b can cause side effects. common effects include extreme tiredness, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, muscle or joint pain, dizziness, trouble walking, confusion, and bruising, redness, swelling, bleeding, or irritation at the injection site. serious reactions can occur; stop the medication and call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have rash, itching, trouble breathing or swallowing, hives, or swelling of the eyes, face, mouth, tongue, or throat, or if you experience symptoms noted under special precautions. this medication may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: dactinomycin
instructions: important warning: dactinomycin injection must be given in a hospital or medical facility under the supervision of a doctor experienced with chemotherapy. it must be administered into a vein, but if the drug leaks into surrounding tissue it can cause severe irritation or damage. your care team will monitor the injection site. call your doctor immediately if you notice pain, itching, redness, swelling, blisters, or sores at the injection site. why is this medication prescribed? dactinomycin is used with other medications, surgery, and/or radiation therapy to treat wilms tumor (a kidney cancer in children) and rhabdomyosarcoma (a muscle cancer in children). it is also used with other medications to treat certain testicular cancers and ewing sarcoma (a cancer of bone or muscle), and alone or with other medications to treat gestational trophoblastic tumors (tumors that form in the uterus during pregnancy). it may also be used for certain cancers confined to a specific area of the body. dactinomycin is an antibiotic used only in cancer chemotherapy; it works by slowing or stopping the growth of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? dactinomycin is supplied as a powder that is mixed with liquid and injected intravenously by a doctor or nurse in a medical facility. the length and schedule of treatment depend on your cancer type, other drugs you receive, and how you respond to therapy. your doctor may delay or stop treatment if you develop certain side effects. in some cases, dactinomycin may be injected directly into a specific area or organ to treat a localized tumor. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine: dactinomycin is sometimes used to treat certain ovarian cancers. it may also be prescribed for other conditions; discuss the potential risks and benefits with your doctor or pharmacist. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving dactinomycin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to dactinomycin, any other medications, or any ingredients in the injection; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have or recently had chickenpox or shingles (herpes zoster); your doctor will usually not give dactinomycin in this situation. tell your doctor if you have received or are receiving radiation therapy. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor. do not become pregnant or breastfeed while receiving dactinomycin; if you become pregnant, call your doctor immediately because the drug may harm the fetus. do not receive any vaccinations without talking to your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your normal diet. if nausea or mouth sores affect eating or drinking, ask your care team for guidance on fluids and nutrition. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment for a dose, contact your doctor or treatment center as soon as possible to reschedule. do not attempt to take an extra dose to make up for the missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? dactinomycin may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: vomiting, stomach pain, diarrhea, hair loss. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you experience any of the following or those listed in the important warning section: hives; rash; difficulty breathing or swallowing; severe or persistent nausea; extreme tiredness; unusual bleeding or bruising; sores in the mouth or throat; lack of energy; loss of appetite; pain in the upper right part of the abdomen; yellowing of the skin or eyes; fever, sore throat, ongoing cough or congestion, or other signs of infection; black, tarry stools; or red blood in the stools. dactinomycin may increase the risk of developing other cancers; talk to your doctor about these risks. dactinomycin may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice any unusual problems during treatment.

name: alteplase injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? alteplase is used to dissolve blood clots that have formed in blood vessels. it helps reduce the risk of death or heart damage during a heart attack and is used to treat people with symptoms of a stroke or a blood clot in the lungs (pulmonary embolism). alteplase belongs to a class of medications called thrombolytics and works by helping the body break down blood clots. how should this medicine be used? alteplase comes as a powder that is mixed with liquid and given by a healthcare professional as an intravenous infusion over up to 3 hours. it is usually given once, as soon as possible after symptoms begin for a heart attack, pulmonary embolism, or stroke. if more than 3 hours have passed since stroke symptoms began, you may not be able to receive alteplase. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving alteplase, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to alteplase, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the injection; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take when receiving alteplase. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have had a stroke, a serious head injury, or surgery on your spine or brain; or if you have brain problems such as bleeding, a tumor, an arteriovenous malformation (avm), or an aneurysm. also tell your doctor if you have very high blood pressure that is not controlled by medication or any condition that may increase your risk of bleeding or bruising; your doctor will probably not give you alteplase. tell your doctor if you have recently had surgery or a procedure; an injury; bleeding in your brain, stomach or intestines, or urinary tract; a serious infection due to a blood clot in a vein; or an infection of the lining around or inside the heart. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had bleeding in the retina of your eyes, high blood pressure, or liver or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medication is given by healthcare professionals in a medical setting, so missed doses do not apply. if you think a dose was not given as planned, notify your care team right away. what side effects can this medication cause? alteplase may cause side effects. tell your doctor if this symptom is severe or does not go away: bleeding. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have any of the following: itching; rash; hives; swelling of the face, eyelids, lips, mouth, tongue, or throat; trouble breathing; tightness in the throat or chest; feeling faint; vomiting blood or blood in the urine or stool; severe headache, nausea, or vomiting; changes in consciousness or wakefulness; weakness or numbness in the face, arm, or leg (usually on one side); loss of vision; or seizures.

name: estrogen and progestin hormone replacement therapy
instructions: important warning: combination hormone replacement therapy estrogen plus progestin may raise the risk of heart attack, stroke, blood clots in the lungs and legs, and breast cancer. the risk may be higher if you smoke or if you have or have ever had a breast lump, breast cancer, a heart attack, a stroke, blood clots or a clotting disorder, high blood pressure, high cholesterol or high blood fats, lupus, or diabetes. if you are scheduled for surgery or expect prolonged bed rest, talk with your doctor about stopping estrogen and progestin at least 4 to 6 weeks before. seek emergency care right away for sudden severe headache, sudden severe vomiting, sudden partial or complete loss of vision, trouble speaking, dizziness or fainting, weakness or numbness of an arm or a leg, a new breast lump, crushing chest pain or chest heaviness, coughing up blood, sudden shortness of breath, or calf pain. combination hormone replacement therapy may also increase the risk of dementia decreased thinking, memory, and reasoning. discuss the risks and benefits of estrogen and progestin with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? combinations of estrogen and progestin are used to treat certain symptoms of menopause. estrogen also helps prevent thinning of the bones osteoporosis in menopausal women. your doctor will choose the product that fits your condition. estrogen replaces the hormone your body no longer makes after menopause and helps reduce hot flashes, sweating and heat, vaginal itching, burning and dryness, and difficulty with urination. progestin is added to lower the risk of uterine cancer in women who still have a uterus. how should this medicine be used? hormone replacement therapy comes as tablets or capsules to take by mouth, usually once daily. take it at the same time each day to help you remember. follow your prescription label exactly. do not take more, take less, take it more often, or stop it without talking to your doctor. activella, angeliq, femhrt, jinteli, mimvey, and prempro are tablets, and bijuva is a capsule that contains estrogen and progestin. take one tablet or capsule each day. premphase comes as a 28 day dispenser. take one maroon tablet containing only estrogen once daily on days 1 through 14, then one light blue tablet containing estrogen plus progestin once daily on days 15 through 28. start a new dispenser the day after finishing the last one. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer patient information. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking hormone replacement therapy, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to estrogen, progestin, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the tablets or capsules. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use while taking hormone replacement therapy. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. nonprescription or herbal products that may interact include st. johns wort. do not start such products while using estrogen and progestin unless you have discussed it with your healthcare provider. in addition to the conditions in the important warning, tell your doctor if you have had unusual vaginal bleeding, any type of cancer, or liver disease, because your doctor may tell you not to take estrogen and progestin. also tell your doctor if you have had a hysterectomy surgery to remove your uterus, and if you have or have ever had asthma, epilepsy seizures, migraine headaches, endometriosis a condition in which tissue similar to the lining of the uterus grows outside the uterus, high calcium levels in your blood, or gallbladder, thyroid, or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking this medicine, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking hormone replacement therapy. tell your doctor if you use tobacco products, because smoking while taking this medicine may increase the risk of serious side effects such as blood clots and stroke. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? hormone replacement therapy may cause side effects. common effects include headache, upset stomach, vomiting, stomach cramps, pain or bloating, diarrhea, changes in appetite or weight, trouble sleeping, emotional changes or depression, swelling of the hands, feet, or lower legs fluid retention, vaginal bleeding, pain in the back or pelvic area, and breast pain or tenderness. some side effects can be serious. stop the medicine and call your doctor right away for hives, rash, itching, trouble breathing or swallowing, swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes, vision changes, sudden new severe headaches, signs of liver problems such as itchy skin, dark urine, yellowing of the skin or eyes, flu like symptoms, or pain in the upper right part of your abdomen, or unusual vaginal bleeding. also seek emergency help for the symptoms listed in the important warning. hormone replacement therapy may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medicine.

name: risedronate
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? risedronate immediate-release tablets and delayed-release tablets are used to prevent and treat osteoporosis in postmenopausal women. the immediate-release tablets are also used to treat osteoporosis in men and in adults who are taking glucocorticoids. immediate-release tablets are also used to treat paget’s disease of bone. risedronate belongs to a class of medicines called bisphosphonates; it works by slowing bone breakdown and increasing bone density. how should this medicine be used? risedronate is taken by mouth as either an immediate-release tablet or a delayed-release tablet. delayed-release tablets are usually taken once weekly, in the morning, immediately after breakfast. immediate-release tablets are taken on an empty stomach: once daily in the morning, once weekly in the morning, once monthly in the morning, or on two consecutive mornings each month, as prescribed. if you take a weekly or monthly schedule, take it on the same day each week or the same day(s) each month. take exactly as directed and do not change your dose or schedule without your doctor’s advice. to prevent esophageal or mouth irritation and to ensure effectiveness, follow these rules: immediate-release tablets: take immediately after getting out of bed and before eating or drinking anything; swallow whole with a full glass of plain water (6–8 oz/180–240 ml) while sitting or standing; do not eat, drink, or take other medications for at least 30 minutes after; remain upright for at least 30 minutes; never take at bedtime or before getting out of bed. delayed-release tablets: take immediately after breakfast on your scheduled day; swallow whole with at least 4 oz (120 ml) of plain water while sitting or standing; do not split, chew, crush, or suck the tablet; avoid lying down and avoid other medications for at least 30 minutes after the dose. for all forms: use only plain water; do not take with tea, coffee, juice, mineral water, milk, or any liquid other than plain water. risedronate controls but does not cure osteoporosis or paget’s disease; continue as prescribed and talk with your doctor periodically about whether you should keep taking it. you will receive a medication guide when you start and with each refill—read it and ask your pharmacist or doctor if anything is unclear. if you cannot follow these instructions or do not understand them, contact your healthcare provider before using this medicine. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor and pharmacist about any allergy to risedronate or any ingredients in the tablets. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, minerals, and herbal products you take or plan to take. do not take actonel and atelvia together; both contain risedronate. take any other oral medicines, including vitamins, supplements, iron, calcium, magnesium, aluminum-containing antacids, or laxatives at least 30 minutes after your immediate-release risedronate dose. tell your doctor if you use h2 blockers (such as cimetidine, famotidine, ranitidine), proton pump inhibitors (such as esomeprazole, lansoprazole, omeprazole, rabeprazole), aspirin, or other nsaids (such as ibuprofen or naproxen); do not start or stop these without medical advice while on risedronate. do not use risedronate if you have low blood calcium, significant esophageal problems, or cannot sit or stand upright for at least 30 minutes. before use, tell your doctor if you are receiving radiation therapy; have or have had trouble swallowing, heartburn, stomach ulcers or other stomach problems, anemia, cancer, infections (especially in the mouth), mouth/teeth/gum problems, bleeding disorders, or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, planning to become pregnant in the future, or breastfeeding; risedronate can remain in your body for years—call your doctor if you become pregnant during or after treatment. risedronate can cause severe bone, joint, or muscle pain that may start days, months, or years after beginning therapy; call your doctor right away if this occurs—your doctor may stop the medication. risedronate may cause osteonecrosis of the jaw, especially after dental procedures; have a dental exam and complete any needed dental work before starting, maintain good oral hygiene, and tell your dentist you are taking risedronate; consult your doctor before dental procedures. your doctor may also recommend lifestyle measures such as weight-bearing exercise, not smoking, and limiting alcohol. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ensure adequate calcium and vitamin d intake while taking risedronate; your doctor will tell you how much you need and which foods provide these nutrients. if diet alone is insufficient, your doctor may recommend supplements. what should i do if i forget a dose? for once-daily immediate-release: skip the missed dose; take one tablet the next morning as usual—do not take it later that day. for once-weekly schedules: take one dose the morning after you remember (immediate-release before food; delayed-release immediately after breakfast), then resume your regular weekly day. for once-monthly schedules: if you remember more than 7 days before your next scheduled dose, take the missed dose the next morning; if you remember within 7 days of the next scheduled dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose on your usual day. for once-monthly two consecutive mornings: if you miss one or both doses and remember more than 7 days before the next cycle, take the first missed dose the next morning and, if both were missed, take the second missed dose the morning after; if you remember within 7 days of the next scheduled cycle, skip the missed doses and resume on your usual days. never take more than one dose on the same day and never double up to make up a missed dose; when in doubt, call your doctor. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include nausea, belching, dry mouth, stomach pain, diarrhea or constipation, gas, headache, dizziness, weakness, leg cramps, back pain, increased urinary frequency or urgency, or painful urination. serious side effects require immediate medical attention and stopping the medication until you speak with your doctor: trouble or pain when swallowing, new or worsening heartburn, chest pain, itching, rash, hives, skin blisters, swelling of the face, lips, tongue, throat, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, difficulty breathing, hoarseness, muscle spasms or twitching, cramps, tingling or numbness around the mouth or in hands or feet, red, painful, or swollen eyes or sensitivity to light, painful or swollen gums, loose teeth, jaw numbness or heaviness, poor healing of the jaw, or dull aching pain in the hip, groin, or thigh. long-term treatment with bisphosphonates such as risedronate has been associated with rare atypical thigh bone fractures; pain in the hip, groin, or thigh can occur weeks to months before a fracture—contact your doctor if you develop these symptoms. this is not a complete list of side effects; talk to your doctor about the risks and report any unusual symptoms.

name: metformin
instructions: important warning: metformin can rarely cause lactic acidosis, a serious and potentially life-threatening buildup of lactic acid. your risk is higher if you have kidney disease; are 65 years of age or older; have had a heart attack, stroke, diabetic ketoacidosis, coma, heart or liver disease, or heart failure. certain medicines increase this risk, including acetazolamide (diamox), dichlorphenamide (keveyis), methazolamide, topiramate (topamax; also in qsymia), and zonisamide (zonegran). you may need to stop metformin temporarily if you have a serious infection; severe vomiting, diarrhea, or fever; or if you are drinking much less fluid than usual. tell your doctor and dentist that you take metformin if you are having surgery or any major medical procedure. before an x-ray procedure that uses injected contrast dye, you may need to stop metformin and wait at least 48 hours after the procedure to restart it; your doctor will tell you exactly when to stop and start. stop metformin and call your doctor right away if you have symptoms of lactic acidosis, including extreme tiredness or weakness; nausea; vomiting; stomach pain; decreased appetite; deep and rapid breathing or shortness of breath; dizziness; lightheadedness; fast or slow heartbeat; muscle pain; or feeling cold, especially in the hands or feet. alcohol use, including regular drinking or binge drinking, increases the risk of lactic acidosis and can lower blood sugar; ask your doctor how much alcohol, if any, is safe while you take metformin. keep all appointments for checkups and lab tests so your doctor can monitor kidney function and your response to treatment. discuss the risks and benefits of metformin with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? metformin is used alone or with other medicines, including insulin, to treat type 2 diabetes, a condition in which the body does not use insulin normally and cannot control blood sugar. it belongs to a class called biguanides. metformin lowers blood glucose by decreasing the amount of sugar absorbed from food, reducing sugar production by the liver, and improving the body response to insulin. it is not used to treat type 1 diabetes. managing diabetes with medicines, diet, exercise, not smoking, and regular blood sugar checks can improve health and reduce the risk of complications such as heart disease, stroke, kidney problems, nerve damage (including numb or cold legs or feet and decreased sexual ability), eye problems (including vision changes or vision loss), and gum disease. your healthcare team will help you plan the best approach to manage your diabetes. how should this medicine be used? metformin is available as a tablet, an extended-release tablet, and a liquid solution to take by mouth. the liquid is usually taken with meals once or twice daily. the regular tablet is usually taken with meals two or three times daily. the extended-release tablet is usually taken once daily with the evening meal. take it at the same times each day to help you remember. follow your prescription label exactly; do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. swallow extended-release tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush them. your doctor may start with a low dose and increase it gradually, usually no more often than every 1 to 2 weeks. monitor your blood sugar as instructed so your doctor can assess how well metformin is working. metformin controls diabetes but does not cure it, so continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor. ask your doctor or pharmacist for the manufacturer patient information. other uses for this medicine: this medicine may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking metformin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to metformin, any ingredients in the liquid or tablets, or any other medicines. ask your pharmacist or check the manufacturer patient information for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use, because your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had low vitamin b12 levels or any other medical conditions, especially those listed in the important warning section. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while taking metformin. changes in food intake or physical activity can affect blood sugar; if you eat less or exercise more than usual, ask your doctor for instructions. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow the diet and exercise plan recommended by your doctor or dietitian. eat a healthful, balanced diet as advised. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? metformin can change your blood sugar levels; learn the signs and management of low and high blood sugar and what to do if they occur. common side effects may include diarrhea, nausea, stomach discomfort, gas, indigestion, constipation, low energy or weakness, changes in taste, headache, flushing, nail changes, muscle pain, or rash. if any of these are severe, persist, recur, or start after you have been taking metformin for a while, contact your doctor. serious side effects can occur. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have chest pain or any symptoms listed in the important warning section. metformin may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have unusual problems while taking this medicine.

name: pioglitazone
instructions: important warning: pioglitazone and other medicines in its class may cause or worsen heart failure, a condition in which the heart cannot pump enough blood to the body. before starting pioglitazone, tell your doctor if you have or have ever had heart failure (especially if it is so severe that you must limit activity, are only comfortable at rest, or need to remain in a chair or bed), were born with a heart defect, or have or have ever had swelling of the arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; heart disease; high cholesterol or other blood fats; high blood pressure; coronary artery disease (narrowed heart blood vessels); a heart attack; an irregular heartbeat; or sleep apnea. your doctor may advise you not to use pioglitazone or may monitor you closely during treatment. call your doctor right away if you develop symptoms of heart failure, especially when starting treatment or after a dose increase: rapid weight gain in a short time; shortness of breath; swelling of the arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; abdominal swelling or pain; waking at night short of breath; needing extra pillows to breathe when lying down; frequent dry cough or wheezing; confusion or trouble thinking clearly; fast or racing heartbeat; decreased ability to walk or exercise; increased tiredness. you will receive a medication guide when you start pioglitazone and with each refill; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. discuss the risks and benefits of pioglitazone with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? pioglitazone is used along with diet and exercise, and sometimes with other medicines, to treat type 2 diabetes (when the body does not use insulin normally and cannot control blood sugar). it is a thiazolidinedione that works by increasing the body’s sensitivity to insulin. pioglitazone is not for type 1 diabetes (when the body does not produce insulin) or for diabetic ketoacidosis. lowering high blood sugar can help prevent serious complications of diabetes such as heart disease, stroke, kidney problems, nerve damage, and eye problems, and may reduce the risk of heart attack, stroke, kidney failure, nerve problems (including numb, cold legs or feet and decreased sexual ability), eye problems (including vision changes or loss), and gum disease. your healthcare team will help you plan the best way to manage your diabetes. how should this medicine be used? pioglitazone is an oral tablet usually taken once daily, with or without food, at the same time each day. follow your prescription label exactly; do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. your doctor may start at a low dose and increase it gradually. pioglitazone helps control type 2 diabetes but does not cure it. blood sugar may start to improve in about 2 weeks, with full effect in 2 to 3 months. continue taking pioglitazone even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking pioglitazone, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to pioglitazone, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets (check the medication guide for a list). tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. the nonprescription product ranitidine (zantac) may interact with pioglitazone; be sure your doctor and pharmacist know you are taking it, and do not start ranitidine while on pioglitazone without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any conditions listed in the important warning section, or if you have or have ever had bladder cancer, diabetic eye disease, or kidney or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while taking pioglitazone, call your doctor; do not breastfeed while taking this medicine. if you have not yet gone through menopause, be aware that pioglitazone may increase the chance of becoming pregnant even if you do not have regular periods or ovulate; talk to your doctor about effective birth control. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist you take pioglitazone. ask your doctor what to do if you become ill, develop an infection or fever, experience unusual stress, or are injured, as these can affect your blood sugar and your pioglitazone dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow the diet and exercise plan your doctor or dietitian recommends. eat a healthy diet, exercise regularly, and lose weight if needed to help control diabetes and help pioglitazone work better. alcohol can lower blood sugar; ask your doctor about safe alcohol use while taking pioglitazone. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you remember on the same day, take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if you do not remember until the next day, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take more than one dose in a day and do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? pioglitazone may change your blood sugar; know the symptoms of low and high blood sugar and what to do if they occur. common side effects may include headache, muscle pain, pain in the arms or legs, sore throat, or gas; call your doctor if these are severe or do not go away. serious side effects can occur; call your doctor immediately if you have changes in vision or vision loss; frequent, painful, or difficult urination; cloudy, discolored, or bloody urine; or back or stomach pain. pioglitazone can cause liver problems; stop the medicine and call your doctor right away if you have nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, pain in the upper right abdomen, flu-like symptoms, dark urine, yellowing of the skin or eyes, unusual bleeding or bruising, or lack of energy. in clinical studies, more people taking pioglitazone for more than one year developed bladder cancer than those not taking it; discuss this risk with your doctor. in studies, women taking pioglitazone had more fractures (especially of the hands, upper arms, or feet) than women not taking it; this increased risk was not seen in men; if you are a woman, discuss this risk with your doctor. pioglitazone may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: ketorolac ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ophthalmic ketorolac relieves itchy eyes caused by allergies and reduces swelling and redness inflammation after cataract surgery. it is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug nsaid that works by blocking substances that trigger allergy symptoms and inflammation. how should this medicine be used? ketorolac ophthalmic is a liquid eye drop. for allergy symptoms, instill 1 drop in the affected eye or eyes 4 times daily. for inflammation after cataract surgery, instill 1 drop in the affected eye 4 times daily for 2 weeks, starting 24 hours after surgery. follow your prescription directions exactly; do not use more often, use more, or use less than prescribed. your itchy eyes should improve after you use the drops; if symptoms do not improve or worsen, call your doctor. for allergy-related itching, continue use until you are no longer exposed to the allergen, allergy season ends, or your doctor tells you to stop. to instill the drops: wash hands; check the dropper tip for damage; avoid touching the tip to any surface; tilt head back; pull down the lower eyelid to make a pocket; hold the dropper close without touching the eye; look up and squeeze out 1 drop into the pocket; release the eyelid; close the eye for 2 to 3 minutes with your head tipped down and avoid blinking; press gently on the tear duct; wipe excess liquid; if a second drop is needed, wait at least 5 minutes; replace and tighten the cap without rinsing the tip; wash hands. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to ketorolac, aspirin, or any other medicines. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use. aspirin and other nsaids such as ibuprofen advil, ibu-tab, motrin, others and naproxen aleve, others may interact with ketorolac eye drops; do not start these without discussing with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had heart, kidney, or liver disease, or bleeding problems. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you wear soft contact lenses, do not use ketorolac eye drops while the lenses are in; remove lenses before dosing. use caution when driving or operating machinery because your vision may be blurred after instilling the drops. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? instill the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not instill a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include temporary stinging or burning in the eyes and blurry vision. stop using ketorolac eye drops and call your doctor right away if you have redness or swelling of the eyes, lips, tongue, or skin; signs of infection in or around the eye; skin rash, hives, or other skin changes; or difficulty breathing or swallowing.

name: acyclovir topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? acyclovir cream is used to treat cold sores also called fever blisters that are caused by the herpes simplex virus on the lips or face. acyclovir ointment is used for the first episode of genital herpes and for certain herpes simplex sores in people with weakened immune systems. acyclovir is an antiviral medicine called a synthetic nucleoside analogue. it limits the spread of the herpes virus in the body. it does not cure cold sores or genital herpes, does not prevent future outbreaks, and does not prevent transmission to others. how should this medicine be used? topical acyclovir comes as a cream and as an ointment for use on the skin only. acyclovir cream is typically applied 5 times daily for 4 days. it can be used at any point in a cold sore episode but works best when started early at the first signs such as tingling, redness, itching, or a bump before a sore appears. acyclovir ointment is usually applied 6 times daily about every 3 hours for 7 days. begin the ointment as soon as possible after the first symptoms appear. follow your prescription directions exactly. do not use more or less, and do not apply more often than prescribed. call your doctor if symptoms do not improve or worsen. use on skin only. keep the cream and ointment out of the eyes, mouth, and nose, and do not swallow. apply the cream only to areas where a cold sore has appeared or is likely to appear; do not use the cream on unaffected skin or on genital herpes sores. do not apply other skin products such as cosmetics, sunscreen, or lip balm on the treated cold sore area unless your doctor advises it. to use the cream: wash your hands; clean and dry the affected skin; apply a thin layer to cover the area and rub in until it disappears; leave uncovered unless your doctor instructs otherwise; wash your hands with soap and water after application, taking care not to wash the treated area; avoid bathing, showering, or swimming right after application and avoid irritating the area. to use the ointment: put on a clean finger cot or rubber glove; apply enough ointment to cover all sores; remove and safely discard the finger cot or glove out of reach of children; keep the area clean and dry and avoid tight clothing over the area. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information and read it before starting and with each refill. what special precautions should i follow? before using topical acyclovir, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to acyclovir, to valacyclovir brand name valtrex, to any other medicines, or to any ingredients in the cream or ointment. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had conditions that affect the immune system such as human immunodeficiency virus hiv or acquired immunodeficiency syndrome aids. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using acyclovir, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra cream or ointment to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? topical acyclovir can cause side effects. common effects include dry or cracked lips; dry, flaky, or peeling skin; burning or stinging; redness, swelling, or irritation where the medicine is applied. serious reactions can occur. call your doctor right away if you have hives, rash, itching, trouble breathing or swallowing, swelling of the face, throat, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, or hoarseness. topical acyclovir may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: acyclovir
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? acyclovir is prescribed to reduce pain and speed healing of sores or blisters caused by varicella (chickenpox), herpes zoster (shingles) - a rash that can occur in people who have had chickenpox - and first-time or recurrent episodes of genital herpes (a herpes virus infection that periodically causes sores around the genitals and rectum). it is also used to help prevent outbreaks of genital herpes in people infected with the virus. acyclovir belongs to a class of antiviral medicines called synthetic nucleoside analogues; it works by limiting the herpes virus's ability to multiply in the body. it will not cure genital herpes and may not prevent spreading genital herpes to other people. it may also be used for eczema herpeticum; to treat or prevent herpes infections of the skin, eyes, nose, and mouth in people with hiv; and to treat oral hairy leukoplakia. this medicine may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for details. how should this medicine be used? acyclovir comes as tablets, capsules, and an oral suspension to take by mouth, and as a delayed-release buccal tablet that is applied to the upper gum. tablets, capsules, and the suspension are usually taken with or without food 2 to 5 times daily for 5 to 10 days, beginning as soon as possible after symptoms start. for prevention of genital herpes outbreaks, it is typically taken 2 to 5 times daily for up to 12 months. the delayed-release buccal tablet is applied with a dry finger as a single dose within 1 hour of the first cold sore symptoms (itching, redness, burning, or tingling) and before a sore appears. take or use acyclovir at the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. use only as directed; do not take more or less, more often, or longer than prescribed. do not chew, crush, suck, or swallow the delayed-release buccal tablet. if your mouth feels dry while the buccal tablet is in place, drink plenty of liquids. to apply buccal acyclovir: find the area on the upper gum above your left or right incisor teeth (just to either side of the two front teeth); with dry hands remove one tablet; gently place it as high as possible on the upper gum above the incisor on the side with the cold sore (do not place on the inside of the lip or cheek); hold in place for 30 seconds. if it does not adhere or sticks to your cheek or lip, reposition it on the gum. leave it in place until it dissolves and avoid disturbing it. after eating, drinking, or rinsing, check that it remains in place. if it comes off within the first 6 hours, reapply the same tablet; if it still will not stick, apply a new tablet. if you swallow the tablet within the first 6 hours, drink a glass of water and place a new tablet. if it falls off or is swallowed 6 or more hours after application, do not apply another until your next regular time. while the buccal tablet is in place: do not chew gum, touch, or press the tablet; do not wear upper dentures; do not brush your teeth. if cleaning is needed, rinse gently. shake the oral suspension well before each dose. your symptoms should improve during treatment; call your doctor if they do not improve or if they worsen. take or use acyclovir for the full prescribed course even if you feel better; stopping early or skipping doses may leave the infection incompletely treated or harder to treat. the delayed-release buccal tablet is a one-time dose. what special precautions should i follow? before using acyclovir, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to acyclovir, valacyclovir (valtrex), any other medicines, milk proteins, or any ingredients in acyclovir products; your pharmacist can provide a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. be sure to mention: amphotericin b (fungizone); aminoglycoside antibiotics such as amikacin (amikin), gentamicin (garamycin), kanamycin (kantrex), neomycin (neo-fradin, nes-rx), paromomycin (humatin), streptomycin, and tobramycin (nebcin, tobi); aspirin and other nsaids such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin) and naproxen (aleve, naprosyn);
