cyclosporine (gengraf, neoral, sandimmune); medicines for hiv or aids such as zidovudine (azt, retrovir); pentamidine (nebupent); probenecid (benemid); sulfonamides such as sulfamethoxazole and trimethoprim (bactrim); tacrolimus (prograf); and vancomycin. many other medicines may interact with acyclovir, so provide a complete list of everything you take. your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you might be dehydrated from a recent illness or activity, or if you have or have ever had problems with your immune system; hiv infection; aids; or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking acyclovir, call your doctor. if you are taking acyclovir to treat genital herpes, remember it can spread through sexual contact even when you have no blisters or other symptoms and possibly even while taking acyclovir. discuss ways to reduce transmission and whether your partners should receive treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? drink plenty of fluids while you are taking or using acyclovir. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember, then take the remaining doses that day at evenly spaced times. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? acyclovir may cause side effects. common effects include upset stomach, vomiting, diarrhea, dizziness, tiredness, agitation, pain (especially in the joints), hair loss, and changes in vision. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have hives; rash or blisters; itching; trouble breathing or swallowing; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; hoarseness; fast heartbeat; weakness; pale skin; difficulty sleeping; fever, sore throat, chills, cough, or other signs of infection; unusual bruising or bleeding; blood in the urine; stomach pain or cramps; bloody diarrhea; decreased urination; headache; hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that are not there); confusion; aggressive behavior; difficulty speaking; numbness, burning, or tingling in the arms or legs; temporary inability to move parts of your body; uncontrollable shaking; seizures; or loss of consciousness. acyclovir may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you experience unusual problems while using this medication.

name: acyclovir buccal
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? acyclovir buccal is used to treat herpes labialis (cold sores or fever blisters) on the face or lips caused by the herpes simplex virus. it is an antiviral medication in the synthetic nucleoside analogue class that works by stopping the virus from spreading in the body. how should this medicine be used? acyclovir buccal comes as a delayed-release buccal tablet applied to the upper gum. apply with a dry finger within 1 hour after the first cold sore symptoms (itching, redness, burning, or tingling) begin and before a visible sore appears. it is taken as a single one-time dose. follow your prescription label carefully and use exactly as directed. do not use more or less or more often than prescribed. do not chew, crush, suck, or swallow the tablet. you may eat and drink while the tablet is in place. if your mouth feels dry, drink plenty of liquids. to apply: identify the area on the upper gum above the incisor tooth on the side of your mouth with symptoms. with dry hands, remove one tablet. place the flat side of the tablet on your fingertip. gently apply the rounded side to the upper gum as high as it will go above the incisor. do not apply to the inside of the lip or cheek. hold in place for 30 seconds. if the tablet does not stick or sticks to your cheek or lip, reposition it onto the gum. leave the tablet in place until it dissolves and avoid disturbing it. check that it remains in place after eating, drinking, or rinsing your mouth. if it comes off within the first 6 hours, reapply the same tablet; if it still will not stick, apply a new tablet. if you accidentally swallow the tablet within 6 hours of application, drink a glass of water and place a new tablet on your gum. if it falls off or is swallowed 6 or more hours after application, do not apply a new tablet. while using the tablet, avoid touching or pressing it, chewing gum, wearing upper dentures, and brushing your teeth; if you need to clean your mouth, rinse gently. what special precautions should i follow? before using acyclovir buccal, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to acyclovir, valacyclovir (valtrex), milk proteins, any other medications, or any ingredients in this product; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor about all your medical conditions. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using acyclovir buccal, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medication is a single one-time dose used at the first sign of symptoms. if you did not apply it as directed, apply one tablet as soon as you remember at the first sign of symptoms. do not use more than one tablet. if a cold sore has already appeared or you are unsure when to apply it, ask your doctor or pharmacist for advice rather than taking extra doses. what side effects can this medication cause? acyclovir buccal may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: canker sores; irritation of the gums. acyclovir buccal may cause other side effects.

name: acyclovir injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? acyclovir injection is used to treat first-time or recurrent outbreaks of herpes simplex, a herpesvirus infection of the skin and mucous membranes, and to treat herpes zoster (shingles), a rash that can occur in people who have had chickenpox, in people with weak immune systems. it is also used to treat first-time genital herpes outbreaks in people with normal immune systems. in addition, acyclovir injection is used to treat herpes simplex encephalitis (a brain infection with swelling caused by the herpes virus) and herpes infections in newborn infants. acyclovir injection is in a class of antiviral medications called synthetic nucleoside analogues. it works by stopping the spread of the herpes virus in the body. acyclovir injection will not cure genital herpes and may not prevent the spread of genital herpes to other people. how should this medicine be used? acyclovir injection comes as a solution to be infused into a vein. it is usually given over 1 hour every 8 hours. the length of treatment depends on your health, the type of infection, your age, and how you respond to the medication. your doctor will tell you how long to use acyclovir injection. you may receive it in a hospital, or you may be taught to administer it at home. if you will receive acyclovir injection at home, your healthcare provider will show you exactly how to prepare and infuse the medication. make sure you understand these directions and ask your healthcare provider any questions you have. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using acyclovir injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to acyclovir, valacyclovir (valtrex), any other medications, or any ingredients in the product. ask your pharmacist for a list of the ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had problems with your immune system, human immunodeficiency virus (hiv) infection, or acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (aids); or kidney or liver disease. also tell your doctor if there is a possibility you may be dehydrated from recent illness or activity. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while receiving acyclovir injection, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you receive acyclovir injection at a clinic or hospital, call to reschedule any missed appointment. if you are using acyclovir injection at home and you miss a dose, infuse it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not infuse two doses at the same time to make up for a missed dose. if you are unsure what to do, call your healthcare provider for instructions. what side effects can this medication cause? acyclovir injection may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: redness or swelling at the infusion site, nausea, vomiting. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following symptoms, call your doctor immediately: rash, hives, itching, trouble breathing or swallowing, swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes, hoarseness. acyclovir injection may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: acyclovir ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ophthalmic acyclovir is used to treat eye infections caused by herpes simplex virus. it is an antiviral medicine (a synthetic nucleoside analogue) that works by stopping the virus from multiplying and spreading in the eye. how should this medicine be used? ophthalmic acyclovir is an eye ointment. apply it five times daily (about every 3 hours while awake) until the eye heals, then three times daily for 7 more days as directed by your doctor. use it at the same times each day and exactly as prescribed. do not use more or less, or more often, than directed. you should notice improvement during treatment; call your doctor if symptoms worsen, do not improve, or if you develop any new eye problems. to apply: wash your hands with soap and water. use a mirror or have someone help. do not let the tube tip touch your eye, fingers, or any surface. tilt your head slightly forward. hold the tube close to your eyelid without touching it and brace your hand. with the other hand, pull the lower eyelid down to make a pocket. squeeze a ribbon about 1 cm (about 1/2 inch) of ointment into the pocket. gently close your eyes and keep them closed for 1 to 2 minutes. replace and tighten the cap immediately. wipe away excess ointment with a clean tissue and wash your hands again. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to acyclovir, valacyclovir (valtrex), any other medications, or any ingredients in the ointment. provide a list of all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using ophthalmic acyclovir, contact your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives different instructions, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra ointment to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? ophthalmic acyclovir may cause side effects. common effects include mild eye stinging and red, swollen, or itchy eyelids. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have hives, itching, rash, swelling of the eyes, face, lips, mouth, throat, or tongue; new or worsening red, watery eyes; sensitivity to light; blurred vision; or pain around the eye. this medication may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual or bothersome.

name: dapsone topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? dapsone topical is used to treat acne in children, adolescents, and adults. it belongs to the sulfone antibiotic class and helps by slowing or stopping bacterial growth and reducing inflammation. this medicine may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for details. how should this medicine be used? dapsone comes as a gel for use on the skin. apply once daily if using the 7.5 percent gel, or twice daily if using the 5 percent gel, exactly as directed on your prescription label. do not use more gel or apply it more often than prescribed; doing so will not improve results faster and may irritate the skin. it can take up to 12 weeks to see the full benefit; contact your doctor if your acne has not improved after 12 weeks. avoid getting the gel in your eyes, nose, or mouth. steps for use: read the patient information provided by the manufacturer if available; gently wash the affected skin and pat dry, using a gentle cleanser recommended by your health care professional; for the 5 percent gel, apply a pea sized amount in a thin layer to the affected area; for the 7.5 percent gel, apply a pea sized amount in a thin layer to the face and any other affected areas; rub in gently until absorbed. the gel may feel gritty or contain visible particles. replace the cap tightly after use and wash your hands right away. what special precautions should i follow? before using dapsone, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to dapsone, sulfonamide derived medicines often called sulfa drugs, or any ingredient in the gel. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. provide a complete list of all medicines, vitamins, and herbal products you use or plan to use. some products may interact with dapsone, including st johns wort, topical benzoyl peroxide, and acetaminophen tylenol. do not start or stop these without discussing with your health care provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had hemolytic anemia low red blood cell count, glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase g6pd deficiency, or methemoglobinemia a condition where red blood cells cannot carry oxygen well. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breast feeding. if you become pregnant while using dapsone, contact your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, inform the clinician that you use dapsone. if you also use benzoyl peroxide containing skin products such as duac, onexton, or other acne treatments, your skin or facial hair may temporarily turn yellow or orange; this effect is reversible. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is close to the time for your next dose, skip the missed application and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra gel to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? dapsone topical may cause side effects. common effects include redness or burning, dry skin, oiliness, peeling, and itching. call your doctor if these are severe or do not go away. some side effects can be serious. stop using dapsone and seek medical attention right away if you have numbness, burning, or tingling in the hands or feet; muscle weakness; gray blue color of lips, nails, or inside the mouth; back pain; shortness of breath; unusual tiredness or weakness; dark brown urine; fever; yellow or very pale skin; rash; or swelling of the face, lips, or eyes. dapsone topical may cause other side effects. contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: covid-19 vaccine, viral vector janssen [johnson and johnson]
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? the janssen johnson and johnson covid-19 vaccine is used to help prevent coronavirus disease 2019 caused by the sars-cov-2 virus in adults 18 years and older. it is not fda approved but is authorized under an fda emergency use authorization for a single primary dose in adults who are unable or unwilling to receive other fda authorized or approved covid-19 vaccines, and for a single booster dose at least 2 months after a janssen primary dose or after completion of a different covid-19 vaccine in adults who are unable or unwilling to receive other vaccines. covid-19 is primarily a respiratory illness that can affect other organs and may cause symptoms such as fever, chills, cough, shortness of breath, fatigue, muscle or body aches, headache, loss of taste or smell, sore throat, congestion or runny nose, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. discuss the risks and benefits with your healthcare provider. how should this medicine be used? the vaccine is given as a single intramuscular injection. a single booster dose may be given at least 2 months after the janssen primary dose, or after completion of a different covid-19 vaccine in eligible adults who are unable or unwilling to receive other fda authorized or approved covid-19 vaccines. your healthcare provider will determine eligibility and timing. the vaccine does not contain sars-cov-2 and cannot give you covid-19. keep your vaccination card and bring it to any additional dose appointments. your vaccination may be recorded in your state or local immunization information system. what special precautions should i follow? do not receive this vaccine if you previously had blood clots with low platelets after the janssen johnson and johnson vaccine or after the astrazeneca covid-19 vaccine. tell your vaccination provider if you have any allergies; have a fever; have a bleeding disorder or take a blood thinner such as warfarin coumadin or jantoven; are immunocompromised or take medicines that affect the immune system; are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; are breastfeeding; have received another covid-19 vaccine; have ever fainted after an injection; or have had a serious allergic reaction to any ingredient in this vaccine. be aware of rare but potentially life threatening blood clots with low platelets that may occur 1 to 2 weeks after vaccination; symptoms can include shortness of breath, chest pain, leg swelling, persistent abdominal pain, severe or persistent headache, blurred vision, or tiny red or purple spots on the skin petechiae. seek immediate medical attention if these occur. severe allergic reactions can occur within minutes to 1 hour after vaccination; get emergency help if you develop trouble breathing, swelling of the face or throat, a fast heartbeat, a bad rash all over the body, dizziness, or weakness. guillain-barre syndrome has occurred rarely, usually within 6 weeks; seek care right away for worsening weakness or tingling especially in the legs or arms, difficulty walking, problems with facial movements including speaking, chewing, or swallowing, double vision or inability to move the eyes, or problems with bladder or bowel control. you cannot be charged an out-of-pocket vaccine administration fee for receiving only a covid-19 vaccination; providers may seek reimbursement from insurance, medicare, medicaid, or federal programs. report suspected vaccination fraud to the hhs office of inspector general at 1-800-hhs-tips or tips.hhs.gov. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are required. stay hydrated and eat as tolerated. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a scheduled dose or booster, contact your healthcare provider and reschedule as soon as possible. bring your vaccination card to the appointment. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include pain, redness, or swelling at the injection site; headache; feeling very tired; muscle aches; nausea; fever; swollen lymph nodes; unusual skin sensations such as tingling, crawling feelings, or decreased sensitivity; ringing in the ears; diarrhea; and vomiting. serious side effects are rare and include severe allergic reactions anaphylaxis, blood clots with low platelets thrombosis with thrombocytopenia syndrome, and guillain-barre syndrome. serious and unexpected side effects may occur because the vaccine continues to be studied. call 911 or go to the nearest hospital for severe allergic reactions or for symptoms of possible blood clots or guillain-barre syndrome. contact your vaccination provider or healthcare provider if side effects bother you or do not go away. report side effects to the fda cdc vaccine adverse event reporting system vaers at vaers.hhs.gov and include janssen covid-19 vaccine eua in the first line of box 18. you may also report side effects to janssen biotech, inc. at 1-800-565-4008 or jnjvaccineae@its.jnj.com. you may be offered enrollment in cdc v-safe, a voluntary smartphone tool that uses text messages and web surveys to monitor vaccine safety.

name: tetanus, diphtheria, pertussis (tdap) vaccine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? the tdap vaccine helps prevent tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis. diphtheria and pertussis spread from person to person, while tetanus enters the body through cuts or wounds. tetanus causes painful muscle stiffening and can lead to lockjaw, difficulty swallowing or breathing, and death. diphtheria can cause breathing problems, heart failure, paralysis, or death. pertussis (whooping cough) causes intense, uncontrollable coughing that can make it hard to breathe, eat, or drink; it is especially dangerous for infants and young children, causing pneumonia, seizures, brain injury, or death. in teens and adults it can lead to weight loss, loss of bladder control, fainting, and rib fractures from severe coughing. how should this medicine be used? tdap is given as a single intramuscular injection by a healthcare provider to people 7 years and older. adolescents should receive one dose, ideally at age 11 or 12 years. pregnant individuals should receive one tdap during every pregnancy, preferably early in the third trimester, to protect the newborn from pertussis. adults who have never received tdap should get one dose. after that, adults should receive a booster with either tdap or td every 10 years, or after 5 years in the event of a severe or contaminated wound or burn. tdap can be administered at the same time as other vaccines. brand examples include adacel and boostrix. what special precautions should i follow? tell your vaccination provider if you have ever had: a severe allergic reaction to a previous tetanus-, diphtheria-, or pertussis-containing vaccine or to any component of tdap; a coma, decreased level of consciousness, or prolonged seizures within 7 days after a prior pertussis vaccine (dtp, dtap, or tdap); seizures or other nervous system problems; guillain-barré syndrome; or severe pain or swelling after a previous tetanus- or diphtheria-containing vaccine. people with minor illnesses (such as a cold) may be vaccinated; those who are moderately or severely ill should usually wait until they recover. fainting can occur after vaccination—tell your provider if you feel dizzy or have vision changes or ringing in the ears. for more information, ask your healthcare provider, contact your local or state health department, or call the cdc at 1-800-232-4636 or visit the cdc website. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary restrictions are needed with tdap. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a recommended tdap dose or booster, receive it as soon as possible. if you experience a severe or dirty wound or burn and it has been 5 years or more since your last tetanus-containing vaccine, seek medical care promptly for a booster. what side effects can this medication cause? common reactions include pain, redness, or swelling at the injection site; mild fever; headache; tiredness; and nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or stomachache. fainting can occur after vaccination. as with any medicine, there is a very small chance of a severe allergic reaction or other serious injury. seek emergency care or call 9-1-1 if you develop hives, swelling of the face or throat, difficulty breathing, a fast heartbeat, dizziness, or weakness. for other concerns, contact your healthcare provider. adverse events can be reported to the vaccine adverse event reporting system (vaers); vaers accepts reports but does not provide medical advice. the national vaccine injury compensation program (vicp) is a federal program that may compensate people who believe they were injured by certain vaccines; filing deadlines apply and may be as short as two years.

name: adagrasib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? adagrasib is used to treat certain types of non-small cell lung cancer (nsclc) in adults that have spread to nearby tissues or other parts of the body or cannot be removed by surgery after at least one other treatment. it is also used with cetuximab (erbitux) to treat a certain type of colon cancer that has spread after other treatments. adagrasib is a kras inhibitor that blocks an abnormal protein that signals cancer cells to multiply, helping slow or stop their growth and spread. how should this medicine be used? adagrasib comes as an oral tablet and is usually taken with or without food twice a day for as long as your doctor recommends. take it at the same times each day and exactly as directed. swallow the tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush. if you vomit after a dose, do not take another dose; continue with your next scheduled dose. your doctor may lower your dose, treat side effects with other medicines, pause, or permanently stop treatment based on how you respond. tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. continue taking adagrasib even if you feel well, and do not stop without talking to your doctor. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the patient information from the manufacturer. what special precautions should i follow? before taking adagrasib, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to adagrasib or any ingredients in the tablets. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and herbal products you use or plan to use; st. john’s wort can interact with adagrasib. do not start or stop any medicines while taking adagrasib without your healthcare provider’s advice. tell your doctor if you or a family member has or has ever had long qt syndrome or another irregular heartbeat, or if you have heart failure or other heart problems, low potassium or magnesium levels, liver or kidney problems, or lung or breathing problems other than lung cancer. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; call your doctor right away if you become pregnant during treatment. tell your doctor if you are breastfeeding; you should not breastfeed during treatment and for 1 week after your final dose. this medication may decrease fertility in men and women; discuss risks with your doctor. if you are having any surgery, including dental procedures, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking adagrasib. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if more than 4 hours have passed since the missed dose, skip it and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? adagrasib may cause side effects. common side effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, loss of appetite, rash, dry skin, muscle or bone pain, tiredness, and numbness or tingling in the hands or feet. serious side effects can occur; call your doctor immediately or seek emergency medical care if you have bloody vomit or vomit that looks like coffee grounds, black or tarry stools, stomach pain or cramps, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, pale stools, easy bruising or bleeding, loss of appetite, decreased energy, pain on the right side of the abdomen, shortness of breath, cough, fever, dizziness, lightheadedness, fainting, slow or irregular heartbeat, decreased urination, swelling of the face, arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, or unusual tiredness or weakness. adagrasib may cause other side effects; tell your doctor about any symptoms that are severe or do not go away.

name: crizanlizumab-tmca injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? crizanlizumab-tmca injection is prescribed to reduce the number of vaso-occlusive pain crises, which are sudden, severe pain episodes that can last hours to days, in adults and in children 16 years of age and older with sickle cell disease, an inherited blood disorder. it belongs to a class of medicines called monoclonal antibodies and works by blocking certain blood cells from interacting. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? crizanlizumab-tmca is given as an intravenous infusion, a liquid injected into a vein, by a healthcare professional over about 30 minutes. it is usually given once every 2 weeks for the first two doses and then once every 4 weeks. serious infusion reactions can occur during the infusion or within 24 hours after a dose. you will be monitored during and after the infusion. tell your doctor or nurse right away if you develop fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, tiredness, dizziness, sweating, rash, hives, itching, wheezing, or difficulty breathing. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the patient information from the manufacturer. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving crizanlizumab-tmca, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to this medicine, any of its ingredients, or any other medicines. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and nutritional supplements you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while receiving crizanlizumab-tmca, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment for a crizanlizumab-tmca infusion, call your doctor as soon as possible. what side effects can this medication cause? crizanlizumab-tmca may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: nausea; back or joint pain; fever; redness, pain, swelling, or burning at the infusion site. crizanlizumab-tmca may cause other side effects.

name: nifedipine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? nifedipine is prescribed to treat high blood pressure and to help prevent or control angina chest pain. it belongs to a class of medicines called calcium-channel blockers. it lowers blood pressure by relaxing blood vessels so the heart does not have to pump as hard, and it helps angina by improving blood and oxygen flow to the heart. untreated high blood pressure can damage the brain, heart, blood vessels, kidneys, and other organs, leading to heart disease, heart attack, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, and vision loss. along with medication, lifestyle changes such as eating a low-fat, low-salt diet, maintaining a healthy weight, exercising at least 30 minutes most days, not smoking, and limiting alcohol can help control blood pressure. nifedipine is also sometimes used for preterm labor and raynaud’s syndrome; discuss the potential risks and benefits with your doctor. how should this medicine be used? nifedipine is available as capsules and as extended-release long-acting tablets taken by mouth. capsules are usually taken three or four times daily. extended-release tablets are taken once daily on an empty stomach, either 1 hour before or 2 hours after a meal. take your doses at the same times each day. follow your prescription label closely and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take nifedipine exactly as directed; do not take more or less or more often than prescribed. swallow extended-release tablets whole—do not split, chew, or crush them. your doctor will usually start you on a low dose and increase it gradually, typically every 7 to 14 days. when taken regularly, nifedipine helps control chest pain but does not relieve an attack once it starts; your doctor may give you another medicine for acute chest pain. nifedipine controls high blood pressure and angina but does not cure them. keep taking it even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor; your dose will likely be reduced gradually. what special precautions should i follow? before taking nifedipine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to nifedipine, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the product; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. some medicines should not be used with nifedipine, and others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. discuss all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and herbal products you take or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist before starting nifedipine, and do not start, stop, or change any medicine while taking nifedipine without their advice. in particular, st. john’s wort and cimetidine tagamet can interact—tell your healthcare providers if you use them and do not start them without medical guidance. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had narrowing or blockage of the digestive tract or any condition that slows gut movement; heart, liver, or kidney disease; or if you have had a heart attack myocardial infarction within the past 2 weeks. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while taking nifedipine. if you are 65 or older, talk with your doctor about the safer use of nifedipine; immediate-release capsules are generally not preferred in older adults. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, tell the surgeon or dentist you take nifedipine. ask your doctor about alcohol; it can worsen side effects of nifedipine. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not consume grapefruit or grapefruit juice starting 3 days before and during treatment with nifedipine. if your doctor recommends a low-salt or low-sodium diet, follow those instructions carefully. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? nifedipine may cause side effects. common effects include headache; nausea; dizziness or lightheadedness; flushing; heartburn; fast heartbeat; muscle cramps; constipation; cough; and decreased sexual ability. some side effects can be serious—call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have swelling of the face, eyes, lips, tongue, hands, arms, feet, ankles, or lower legs; trouble breathing or swallowing; fainting; rash; yellowing of the skin or eyes jaundice; or an increase in the frequency or severity of chest pain angina.

name: amantadine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? amantadine helps manage symptoms of parkinson's disease (pd)—a nervous system disorder causing problems with movement, muscle control, and balance—and similar conditions. it also helps control movement problems caused by certain pd medicines. the extended-release capsule (gocovri) is used with levodopa/carbidopa (rytary, sinemet) to reduce 'off' episodes (periods of trouble moving, walking, or speaking when other medicines wear off) in people with pd. it can also help prevent and treat respiratory infections caused by influenza a virus. amantadine belongs to the adamantane class; it is thought to ease movement symptoms by increasing dopamine in certain areas of the body and to limit influenza a by stopping the virus from spreading. how should this medicine be used? amantadine is taken by mouth as a capsule, extended-release capsule (gocovri), tablet, or liquid. capsules, tablets, and liquid are usually taken once or twice daily; the extended-release capsule is taken once daily at bedtime. take it at the same times each day, follow your prescription label, and do not change your dose or schedule without your doctor's advice. swallow extended-release capsules whole; do not split, chew, or crush. if you cannot swallow the extended-release capsule, open it and sprinkle the entire contents on a teaspoonful of soft food (such as applesauce), then swallow right away without chewing. if amantadine is being used for pd, your doctor may start with a low dose and increase it gradually. do not stop amantadine suddenly; stopping abruptly can cause fever, confusion, changes in mental state, or severe muscle stiffness. your doctor will lower the dose gradually if needed. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer's patient information. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to amantadine, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the capsules, extended-release capsules, tablets, or liquid; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. nonprescription products that may interact include allergy medicines (diphenhydramine, loratadine, fexofenadine, chlorpheniramine, cetirizine), sleep medicines, motion-sickness medicines, and sodium bicarbonate products (for example, alka-seltzer; in zegerid). be sure your doctor and pharmacist know you are taking these products before you start amantadine, and do not start them while on amantadine without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have kidney disease (you may be told not to take amantadine); if you drink or have drunk large amounts of alcohol; use or have used street drugs; have overused prescription medicines; or if you have or have had depression, unusual mood or behavior changes, mental illness, or thoughts about or attempts at suicide; epilepsy or other seizures; a sleep disorder; urinary tract infections; glaucoma; eczema (atopic dermatitis); heart failure; swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; low blood pressure; or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while taking amantadine, call your doctor right away. amantadine may harm the fetus. amantadine can cause drowsiness or blurred vision; do not drive, use machinery, or do risky activities until you know how it affects you. it can also cause dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting when you stand up quickly, especially when starting or increasing the dose; to reduce this, rise slowly and sit with your feet on the floor before standing. do not receive any vaccinations without talking to your doctor. some people taking amantadine or similar pd medicines develop compulsive urges or behaviors (such as gambling, increased sexual urges, binge eating, or uncontrolled spending); call your doctor if you notice these or cannot control them, and tell family members about this risk so they can contact your doctor if they observe concerning behaviors. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? for capsules, tablets, or liquid, take the missed dose as soon as you remember, unless it is almost time for your next dose; if so, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose. for extended-release capsules, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule; do not take a double dose. if you have missed several days of the extended-release capsule, call your doctor. what side effects can this medication cause? amantadine may cause side effects. common effects include dry mouth; constipation; nausea; vomiting; decreased appetite; trouble falling or staying asleep; abnormal dreams; headache; confusion; drowsiness; tiredness; uncontrollable muscle tightening; changes in normal walking and falls; and a lace-like purple skin pattern. serious effects can include hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that are not there); believing things that are not true, distrust, or feeling others want to harm you; depression; anxiety; suicidal thoughts, plans, or attempts; lack of interest or enthusiasm; dizziness, lightheadedness, fainting, or blurred vision; swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; difficulty urinating; and shortness of breath. amantadine may cause other side effects.

name: adapalene
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? adapalene is used to treat acne in adults and in children 12 years of age and older. it belongs to a class of medications called retinoid-like compounds and works by preventing new pimples from forming under the skin. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? prescription adapalene comes as a gel, solution, lotion, cream, and single-use pledget (medicated swab) for application to the skin; nonprescription (over-the-counter) adapalene comes as a gel for skin application. it is usually applied once daily at bedtime. follow the directions on your prescription or package label exactly. do not use more or apply it more often than directed; overuse will not speed results and may irritate your skin. adapalene controls acne but does not cure it. your acne may worsen during the first few weeks, and full benefit may take 8 to 12 weeks or longer. early in treatment, adapalene may bring previously unseen pimples to the surface. continue using it even if acne seems worse at first. do not apply to sunburned, broken, or eczematous skin; wait until the skin has healed. avoid contact with eyes, nose, mouth, and vagina. if it gets in your eyes, you may experience redness or irritation. dryness or irritation can occur, especially in the first 2 to 4 weeks. if stinging, burning, or irritation develops, talk to your doctor; they may recommend a moisturizer or reduced application frequency. you may request the manufacturer’s patient information from your pharmacist or doctor. to apply: gently wash affected skin with a mild, nonabrasive cleanser and pat dry; avoid harsh cleansers and vigorous scrubbing. for gel or cream, use your fingers to spread a thin film over the entire affected area, not just individual pimples. for a pledget, remove it from the foil pouch and gently wipe the affected area; discard after single use. for solution, apply a thin layer with a clean cotton swab or applicator. for lotion, use the pump to dispense measured amounts (typically press down 3 to 4 times into your palm) and apply a thin film over the affected area. a mild warmth or stinging after application is common and should fade shortly. what special precautions should i follow? before using adapalene, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to adapalene, any other medicines, or any ingredient in the product; ask your pharmacist for an ingredient list. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had eczema or other skin conditions. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, discuss this with your doctor; if you become pregnant while using adapalene, call your doctor. if breastfeeding, use the smallest amount needed and do not apply it to the nipple or areola. avoid unnecessary or prolonged exposure to natural sunlight and artificial uv light (tanning beds and sunlamps); wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen, especially if you sunburn easily, because adapalene can increase sensitivity to sunlight. weather extremes such as wind and cold may be especially irritating. tell your doctor about all skin products you use (soaps, cleansers, moisturizers, cosmetics); many can irritate the skin when combined with adapalene, particularly those that are harsh, drying, or contain alcohol, spices, or lime rind. your doctor may advise waiting before starting adapalene and can recommend nonirritating products. do not use hot wax to remove unwanted hair on treated areas during therapy. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra medication to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects, especially in the first 2 to 4 weeks, may include redness, scaling, dryness, burning or stinging, and pain at the application site; contact your doctor if these are severe or do not improve. serious side effects require immediate medical attention: hives, itching, shortness of breath or difficulty breathing, or swelling of the eyes, face, lips, tongue, or throat. adapalene may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you experience any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: tralokinumab-ldrm injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? tralokinumab-ldrm injection is used to treat atopic dermatitis (eczema), a skin condition that causes dry, itchy skin and may lead to red, scaly rashes. it belongs to a class of medicines called interleukin-13 receptor inhibitors and works by blocking il-13, a substance that drives inflammation. how should this medicine be used? tralokinumab-ldrm injection is a liquid solution supplied in a prefilled syringe or an autoinjector for subcutaneous (under the skin) use. the first dose is given as 2 to 4 injections, followed by 1 to 2 injections every 2 weeks for 16 weeks; after 16 weeks, your doctor may change you to 1 to 2 injections every 4 weeks. follow your prescription label exactly. do not inject more, less, or more often than prescribed. your first dose may be given in your doctor’s office; after training, you or a caregiver may inject at home. read the instructions for use before each dose. use each syringe or autoinjector only once, inject all the solution, and do not recap or reuse. dispose of used devices in a puncture-resistant sharps container; ask your pharmacist how to discard the container. inject into the front of the thighs or abdomen, avoiding the navel and the 2 inches (5 cm) around it; a caregiver may also inject into the outer upper arms. rotate sites: for multiple injections in one session, place each at least 1 inch apart within the same area, and choose a different body area at the next dose. do not inject into damaged, bruised, scarred, or tender skin. if refrigerated, place the syringe or autoinjector flat at room temperature for 30 minutes before use without removing the needle cap. do not warm with heat, hot water, or a microwave. do not shake. inspect before use: check that it is not expired and that the liquid is clear to slightly pearly and colorless to pale yellow; do not use if cloudy, discolored, or if it contains large or colored particles. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to tralokinumab or any of its ingredients, or to any other medicines, foods, or substances, and describe your allergy symptoms. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had a parasitic (helminth) infection or any eye problems. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while using tralokinumab, call your doctor. check with your doctor about any vaccines you may need; do not receive vaccinations without talking to your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, administer the missed dose as soon as you remember and then resume your usual dosing schedule. what side effects can this medication cause? tralokinumab may cause side effects. common side effects include cough; runny nose; sneezing; sore throat; watery, red, or itchy eyes; and pain, swelling, or redness at the injection site. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away if you have trouble breathing; swelling of the mouth, face, or tongue; rash; hives; itching; fainting; dizziness; eye pain; or changes in vision. other side effects may occur; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: brentuximab vedotin injection
instructions: important warning: receiving brentuximab vedotin injection may increase the risk that you will develop progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (pml), a rare brain infection that cannot be treated, prevented, or cured and that usually causes death or severe disability. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had a condition that affects your immune system, and tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are taking any medications that suppress the immune system. if you experience any of the following symptoms, call your doctor immediately: decreased strength or weakness on one side of the body; difficulty walking; loss of coordination; headache; confusion; difficulty thinking clearly; memory loss; changes in mood or usual behavior; difficulty speaking; or vision changes. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor may order certain tests to check your body’s response to brentuximab vedotin injection. talk to your doctor about the risks of receiving brentuximab vedotin injection. why is this medication prescribed? brentuximab vedotin injection is used to treat certain types of hodgkin lymphoma and non-hodgkin lymphoma, types of cancer that begin in a type of white blood cell that normally fights infection. brentuximab vedotin injection is in a class of medications called antibody-drug conjugates. it works by killing cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? brentuximab vedotin injection comes as a powder to be mixed with fluid and infused over 30 minutes intravenously into a vein by a doctor or nurse in a medical office or hospital. brentuximab vedotin is usually given once every 2 to 3 weeks, depending on what you are being treated for, for as long as your doctor recommends. brentuximab vedotin injection may cause serious allergic or infusion reactions, which usually occur during the infusion or within 24 hours of receiving a dose. you may receive certain medications before your infusion to help prevent a reaction if you had one with previous treatment. your doctor will watch you carefully while you are receiving brentuximab vedotin. if you experience any of the following symptoms, tell your healthcare provider immediately: fever, chills, rash, hives, itching, or difficulty breathing. your doctor may delay treatment, adjust your dose, or stop treatment if you experience certain side effects. be sure to tell your doctor how you are feeling during your treatment with brentuximab vedotin injection. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving brentuximab vedotin injection, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this drug, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe what symptoms you had. some medications should not be taken with brentuximab vedotin. other medications may require dosing changes or extra monitoring when taken with brentuximab vedotin. make sure you have discussed any medications you are currently taking or plan to take before starting brentuximab vedotin with your doctor and pharmacist. before starting, stopping, or changing any medications while receiving brentuximab vedotin, get the advice of your doctor or pharmacist. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had diabetes, or liver or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. if you can become pregnant, you must take a pregnancy test before starting treatment and use effective birth control during your treatment and for 2 months after your final dose. if your partner can become pregnant, you must use effective birth control during your treatment and for 4 months after your final dose. if you or your partner become pregnant while receiving brentuximab vedotin injection, call your doctor immediately. brentuximab vedotin injection may harm the fetus. if you are breastfeeding, you should not breastfeed while you are receiving brentuximab vedotin injection. you should know that this medication may decrease fertility in men and women. talk to your doctor about the risks of receiving brentuximab vedotin injection. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medication is given by a healthcare professional. if you miss an appointment for an infusion, call your doctor as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to make up a missed dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? brentuximab vedotin injection may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: constipation; diarrhea; vomiting; nausea; mouth sores or pain; decreased appetite; weight loss; tiredness; dizziness; weakness; difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep; anxiety; dry skin; hair loss; night sweats; joint, bone, muscle, back, arm, or leg pain; muscle spasms. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of these symptoms or those listed in the important warning section, call your doctor immediately: numbness, burning, or tingling in the hands, arms, feet, or legs; muscle weakness; peeling or blistering skin or rash; fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, confusion, shortness of breath, seizures, irregular heartbeat, dark or cloudy urine, unusual tiredness, or muscle or joint pain; new or worsening cough or shortness of breath; decreased urination; swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; fatigue; fever; chills; cough; difficult, painful, or frequent urination; or other signs of infection; ongoing pain that begins in the stomach area but may spread to the back, nausea, or vomiting; pale skin, unusual tiredness or weakness, shortness of breath, or dizziness; yellowing of the skin or eyes, lack of energy, pain or discomfort in the right upper stomach area, dark urine, light-colored bowel movements, nausea, vomiting, or itching; stomach pain, black and tarry stools, blood in stools, or vomit that is bloody or looks like coffee grounds; unusual bleeding or bruising, small red or purple spots on the skin, or blood in the urine. brentuximab vedotin injection may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: tadalafil
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? tadalafil (cialis) is used to treat erectile dysfunction (ed; impotence) and the signs and symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia (bph; enlarged prostate), including difficulty starting urination, dribbling, weak stream, incomplete bladder emptying, painful urination, and increased urinary frequency and urgency in adult men. tadalafil (adcirca) is used to improve exercise ability in people with pulmonary arterial hypertension (pah; high blood pressure in the vessels to the lungs), which can cause shortness of breath, dizziness, and fatigue. tadalafil is a phosphodiesterase (pde) inhibitor. for ed, it increases blood flow to the penis during sexual stimulation to help produce an erection. for pah, it relaxes blood vessels in the lungs to improve blood flow. tadalafil does not cure ed, increase sexual desire, prevent pregnancy, or protect against sexually transmitted infections (including hiv). how should this medicine be used? tadalafil is an oral tablet that may be taken with or without food. for ed, there are two dosing options: as needed or once daily. as needed: take at least 30 minutes before sexual activity; do not take more than once in 24 hours. your doctor will help you choose the timing. once daily: take at about the same time each day without regard to sexual activity; sexual activity may be attempted at any time between doses. if you have certain health conditions or take certain medicines, your doctor may recommend a lower dose or less frequent use. take exactly as prescribed; do not take more or less or more often than directed. for pah or bph, take once daily at about the same time each day. take all tablets needed for your daily dose at once; do not split the dose. if you are already taking another bph medication, your doctor may have you stop it at least one day before starting tadalafil. for ed, your doctor may adjust your dose based on how you respond or if you have side effects. for pah, tadalafil helps control symptoms but does not cure the condition; continue taking it even if you feel well and do not stop without talking to your doctor. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking tadalafil, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to tadalafil or any ingredients in the tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. do not take tadalafil if you are taking or have recently taken riociguat (adempas) or any nitrates such as isosorbide dinitrate (isordil), isosorbide mononitrate (monoket), or nitroglycerin (minitran, nitro-dur, nitromist, nitrostat, and others), including tablets, sublingual tablets, sprays, patches, pastes, or ointments. if you are unsure whether your medicines contain nitrates, ask your doctor. do not take tadalafil if you use street drugs containing nitrates (“poppers”) such as amyl nitrate, butyl nitrate, or nitrite. tadalafil is marketed as adcirca and cialis; use only one tadalafil product at a time. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and supplements you take or plan to take. be sure to mention: alpha blockers such as alfuzosin (uroxatral), doxazosin (cardura), dutasteride (avodart; in jalyn), prazosin (minipress), silodosin (rapaflo), tamsulosin (flomax; in jalyn), and terazosin; amiodarone (cordarone, pacerone); antifungals such as fluconazole (diflucan), griseofulvin (grifulvin, gris-peg), itraconazole (onmel, sporanox), ketoconazole (extina, ketozole, nizoral, xolegel), and voriconazole (vfend); aprepitant (emend); bosentan (tracleer); carbamazepine (carbatrol, epitol, tegretol, teril, others); clarithromycin (biaxin; in prevpac); diltiazem (cardizem, cartia, tiazac, others); efavirenz (sustiva; in atripla); erythromycin (e.e.s., e-mycin, erythrocin); hiv protease inhibitors including indinavir (crixivan), nelfinavir (viracept), and ritonavir (norvir; in kaletra); lovastatin (altocor; in advicor); blood pressure medications; nefazodone; nevirapine (viramune); other ed or pah treatments; phenobarbital; phenytoin (dilantin, phenytek); rifabutin (mycobutin); rifampin (rifadin, rimactane; in rifamate, in rifater); sertraline (zoloft); telithromycin (ketek); and verapamil (calan, covera, verelan; in tarka). your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor about all herbal products you use, especially st. john’s wort. tell your doctor if you smoke; if you have ever had an erection lasting more than 4 hours; or if you have had recent diarrhea, vomiting, inadequate fluid intake, or heavy sweating that could lead to dehydration. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had pulmonary veno-occlusive disease (pvod); any condition affecting the shape of the penis; diabetes; high cholesterol; high or low blood pressure; irregular heartbeat; heart attack or heart failure; angina (chest pain); stroke; stomach ulcers; a bleeding disorder; circulation problems; blood cell disorders such as sickle cell anemia, multiple myeloma, or leukemia; or heart, kidney, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you or family members have an eye disease such as retinitis pigmentosa, or if you have ever had sudden, severe vision loss, especially if caused by reduced blood flow to the optic nerve. if you are a woman taking tadalafil for pah, tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the surgeon or dentist you take tadalafil. ask your doctor about alcohol use; drinking large amounts (more than five glasses of wine or five shots of whiskey) while taking tadalafil increases the chance of dizziness, headache, rapid heartbeat, and low blood pressure. if you take tadalafil for ed and have been advised to avoid sexual activity for medical reasons, or if you have had chest pain during sex, discuss with your doctor. sexual activity can strain the heart, especially if you have heart disease. if you develop chest pain, dizziness, or nausea during sex, stop and seek medical help right away, and avoid sexual activity until your doctor advises otherwise. tell all healthcare providers that you take tadalafil; in an emergency for a heart problem, they need to know when you last took it. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor about consuming grapefruit or grapefruit juice while taking tadalafil. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you take tadalafil for ed on a regular schedule, take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose or more than one dose per day. if you take tadalafil for pah or bph, take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose. what side effects can this medication cause? tadalafil may cause side effects. common effects include headache, indigestion or heartburn, nausea, diarrhea, flushing, pain in the stomach, back, muscles, arms, or legs, and cough. serious side effects require immediate medical attention: sudden decrease or loss of vision; blurred vision; changes in color vision (for example, a blue tinge or difficulty distinguishing blue and green); sudden decrease or loss of hearing; ringing in the ears; an erection lasting longer than 4 hours; dizziness; chest pain; hives; rash; trouble breathing or swallowing; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; and blistering or peeling skin. some people have reported sudden loss of some or all vision after taking tadalafil or similar medicines; in some cases, vision loss was permanent, and the cause is not certain. if you experience sudden vision loss, stop taking tadalafil and similar medicines (such as sildenafil [revatio, viagra] or vardenafil [levitra]) and seek immediate medical care. some people have reported sudden decrease or loss of hearing, sometimes with ringing in the ears or dizziness; if this occurs, stop taking tadalafil and similar medicines and contact your doctor right away. tadalafil may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: ibuprofen
instructions: important warning: nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) other than aspirin, including ibuprofen, can increase the risk of heart attack or stroke, which may occur without warning and can be fatal. the risk can rise with higher doses or longer use. do not take ibuprofen if you recently had a heart attack unless your doctor specifically tells you to. seek emergency care right away for chest pain, shortness of breath, weakness on one side of the body, or slurred speech. do not use ibuprofen right before or right after coronary artery bypass graft (cabg) surgery. nsaids can cause ulcers, bleeding, or perforation in the esophagus, stomach, or intestines at any time, sometimes without symptoms, and these events can be fatal. risk is higher with long-term use, older age, poor health, smoking, heavy alcohol use, certain medicines (anticoagulants/blood thinners; aspirin; other nsaids such as naproxen; oral steroids like dexamethasone, methylprednisolone, prednisone; ssris such as citalopram, fluoxetine, fluvoxamine, paroxetine, sertraline; snris such as desvenlafaxine, duloxetine, venlafaxine), and if you have a history of ulcers, gastrointestinal bleeding, or other bleeding disorders. stop ibuprofen and call your doctor if you have stomach pain, heartburn, vomit that is bloody or looks like coffee grounds, blood in your stool, or black tarry stools. tell your doctor if you or a family member has or has had heart disease, a heart attack, or a stroke; if you smoke; or if you have or have had high cholesterol, high blood pressure, or diabetes. keep all doctor and lab appointments; your doctor will monitor your response and use the lowest effective dose. you will receive a medication guide with prescription ibuprofen at the start and with each refill; read it and ask questions if needed. why is this medication prescribed? prescription ibuprofen relieves pain, tenderness, swelling, and stiffness from osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis, and treats mild to moderate pain, including menstrual cramps. nonprescription ibuprofen reduces fever and relieves minor aches and pains from headaches, muscle aches, arthritis, menstrual periods, the common cold, toothaches, and backaches. ibuprofen is an nsaid that reduces the body’s production of substances that cause pain, fever, and inflammation. how should this medicine be used? prescription ibuprofen is taken by mouth as tablets or liquid suspension, usually three or four times daily for arthritis or every 4 to 6 hours as needed for pain. nonprescription forms include tablets, chewable tablets, capsules, gelcaps, liquid suspension, and concentrated drops. adults and children 12 years and older may take it every 4 to 6 hours as needed for pain or fever; do not exceed 6 doses in 24 hours. infants and children may take it every 6 to 8 hours as needed; do not exceed 4 doses in 24 hours. take with food or milk to reduce stomach upset. if using regularly, take at the same times each day. follow the label or prescription exactly; do not take more, take it more often, or use it longer than directed. ibuprofen is available alone or in combination products (some require a prescription) used for cough/cold and other conditions; avoid taking multiple products with ibuprofen to prevent overdose. swallow tablets whole; do not chew or crush. ask your doctor or pharmacist which cough or cold product is appropriate for you. always check nonprescription labels to avoid duplicating active ingredients, especially when treating children. nonprescription cough/cold combinations, including those with ibuprofen, can cause serious side effects or death in young children; do not give them to children under 4 years. use caution and follow directions closely for children 4 to 11 years. use only products formulated for children, verify that the product is appropriate for the child’s age, and follow the dosing chart; ask your child’s doctor if you are unsure. shake suspensions and drops well before use and measure doses with the provided device. stop nonprescription ibuprofen and call your doctor if symptoms worsen, new or unexpected symptoms appear, the painful area becomes red or swollen, pain lasts more than 10 days, or fever lasts more than 3 days. for children, stop and call the doctor if there is no improvement in the first 24 hours, if new symptoms (including redness or swelling of the painful area) appear, or if pain/fever worsens or lasts more than 3 days. do not give nonprescription ibuprofen to a child with a severe or persistent sore throat, or a sore throat accompanied by fever, headache, nausea, or vomiting; call the child’s doctor. other uses for this medicine: ibuprofen may also be used for ankylosing spondylitis, gouty arthritis, and psoriatic arthritis. discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor; it may also be prescribed for other uses. what special precautions should i follow? before using ibuprofen, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to ibuprofen, aspirin, other nsaids (e.g., ketoprofen, naproxen), any other medicines, or any inactive ingredients in the product; review the label or ask your pharmacist. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. do not take nonprescription ibuprofen with any other pain reliever unless your doctor advises it. tell your doctor if you have any conditions noted in the important warning, or asthma (especially with frequent nasal congestion or nasal polyps), heart failure, swelling in your hands/arms/feet/ankles/lower legs, lupus, liver disease, or kidney disease. if giving ibuprofen to a child, tell the doctor if the child has been drinking poorly or has lost fluids from vomiting or diarrhea. if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding, talk to your doctor. ibuprofen can harm the fetus and affect delivery if taken at or after about 20 weeks of pregnancy; do not use around or after 20 weeks unless your doctor tells you to. call your doctor if you become pregnant while taking ibuprofen. before any surgery, including dental procedures, tell your clinician you take ibuprofen. if you are 75 or older, discuss risks and benefits; do not exceed recommended dose or duration. if you have phenylketonuria (pku), check labels of nonprescription ibuprofen; some contain aspartame (phenylalanine). what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you take ibuprofen on a regular schedule, take the missed dose when you remember. if it is nearly time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? ibuprofen may cause side effects. common effects include constipation, gas or bloating, dizziness, nervousness, and ringing in the ears. serious effects require immediate medical attention and stopping ibuprofen: symptoms listed in the important warning; unexplained weight gain; shortness of breath or difficulty breathing; swelling of the abdomen, feet, ankles, or lower legs; diarrhea; fever, rash, blisters, or peeling skin; itching; hives; swelling of the eyes, face, throat, arms, or hands; trouble breathing or swallowing; hoarseness; unusual tiredness; pain in the upper right abdomen; nausea; loss of appetite; yellowing of the skin or eyes; flu-like symptoms; pale skin; fast heartbeat; cloudy, discolored, or bloody urine; back pain; difficult or painful urination; blurred vision, changes in color vision, or other vision problems; headache with stiff neck and fever. ibuprofen may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: dextroamphetamine and amphetamine
instructions: important warning: the combination of dextroamphetamine and amphetamine can be habit forming. do not take larger doses, take it more often, or use it longer than your doctor prescribed. taking too much can make you feel compelled to keep taking it and can cause unusual behavior changes. you or a caregiver should call your doctor right away or get emergency help immediately if you have any of the following: fast, pounding, or irregular heartbeat; sweating; enlarged pupils; abnormally elevated mood; restlessness; irritability; trouble falling asleep or staying asleep; hostility; aggression; anxiety; loss of appetite; loss of coordination; uncontrolled movements; flushed skin; vomiting; stomach pain; or thoughts about harming or killing yourself or others, or making plans or attempts to do so. misuse or overuse can cause serious heart problems or sudden death. tell your doctor if you or anyone in your family drinks or has ever drunk large amounts of alcohol, uses or has ever used street drugs, or has misused prescription medicines; your doctor may decide not to prescribe this medicine. do not stop taking it without talking to your doctor, especially if you have been overusing it. your doctor will lower your dose gradually and monitor you carefully. stopping suddenly after overuse may cause severe depression and extreme tiredness. do not sell, give away, or share your medication. this can harm others and is against the law. store it in a safe place to prevent accidental or intentional use by others, and keep a pill count so you will know if any are missing. you will receive a medication guide from the manufacturer when you start treatment and with each refill; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist any questions. why is this medication prescribed? the combination of dextroamphetamine and amphetamine (adderall, adderall xr, mydayis) is used as part of a treatment program for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (adhd), a condition with symptoms such as difficulty focusing, controlling actions, and remaining still or quiet compared with others of the same age. adderall is used for adhd in adults and in children 3 years of age and older. adderall xr is used for adhd in adults and in children 6 years of age and older. mydayis is used for adhd in adults and in children 13 years of age and older. dextroamphetamine and amphetamine (adderall) is also used to treat narcolepsy, a sleep disorder that causes excessive daytime sleepiness and sudden sleep attacks, in adults and in children 12 years of age and older. this combination is a central nervous system stimulant that works by changing levels of certain natural substances in the brain. how should this medicine be used? dextroamphetamine and amphetamine is available as an immediate release tablet (adderall) and as extended release capsules (adderall xr, mydayis) taken by mouth. the immediate release tablet is usually taken 2 to 3 times daily, 4 to 6 hours apart, with or without food. adderall xr is usually taken once upon awakening, with or without food. mydayis is usually taken once upon awakening and should be taken consistently either with or without food. avoid taking doses in the late afternoon or evening, because this may cause difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. take this medicine exactly as directed. swallow extended release capsules whole; do not chew or crush them. if you cannot swallow a capsule, you may open it and sprinkle the entire contents on a teaspoon of applesauce; swallow the mixture right away without chewing. do not store the mixture and do not divide the contents of one capsule into multiple doses. your doctor will likely start you on a low dose and increase it gradually, not more than once each week. your doctor may occasionally have you stop the medication to check whether it is still needed; follow these directions carefully. each product is absorbed differently, so do not substitute one dextroamphetamine and amphetamine product for another. if you are switching products, your doctor will choose the appropriate dose. other uses for this medicine: do not use this medication to treat ordinary tiredness that is not caused by narcolepsy. it may be prescribed for other conditions; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking this medicine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to amphetamine, dextroamphetamine, other stimulants such as benzphetamine, lisdexamfetamine (vyvanse), or methamphetamine (desoxyn), any other medications, or any ingredients in the product; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are taking, or have taken within the past 14 days, a monoamine oxidase (mao) inhibitor such as isocarboxazid (marplan), linezolid (zyvox), methylene blue, phenelzine (nardil), selegiline (eldepryl, emsam, zelapar), or tranylcypromine (parnate). some medicines must not be used with dextroamphetamine and amphetamine, and others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. discuss all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and supplements you use or plan to use with your doctor and pharmacist before starting this medicine, and consult them before starting, stopping, or changing any medication while taking it. the following nonprescription or herbal products may interact with dextroamphetamine and amphetamine: st johns wort; nutritional supplements including glutamic acid or l glutamine, and tryptophan; sodium bicarbonate (arm and hammer baking soda, soda mint); sodium phosphate; antacids and other medicines for heartburn or ulcers such as cimetidine (tagamet), esomeprazole (nexium), and omeprazole (prilosec); and allergy medicines such as diphenhydramine, loratadine, fexofenadine, chlorpheniramine, or cetirizine. do not start any of these while taking dextroamphetamine and amphetamine without first talking to your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have glaucoma, hyperthyroidism, or feelings of anxiety, tension, or agitation;
