your doctor will probably advise you not to take this medicine. tell your doctor if anyone in your family has or has had an irregular heartbeat or has died suddenly, and if you have recently had a heart attack or have or have had a heart defect, high blood pressure, an irregular heartbeat, hardening of the arteries, heart or blood vessel disease, or other heart problems. your doctor will examine you to be sure your heart and blood vessels are healthy and will likely advise against this medicine if you have heart disease or a high risk of it. tell your doctor if you or anyone in your family has or has had depression, bipolar disorder (mood swings from depressed to abnormally excited) or mania, motor or verbal tics, tourette syndrome, or suicidal thoughts or attempts. also tell your doctor if you have or have had any mental illness, seizures, an abnormal electroencephalogram (eeg), or liver or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using this medicine, call your doctor. do not breastfeed while taking this medication. if you are 65 years of age or older, discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor; older adults usually should not take this medicine because safer alternatives are available. this medicine may make it harder to perform tasks that require alertness or physical coordination. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. use this medicine only as part of a comprehensive adhd program that may include counseling and special education, and follow all instructions from your healthcare providers. this medicine may cause sudden death in children and teenagers, especially those with heart defects or serious heart problems, and may cause sudden death, heart attack, or stroke in adults, especially in those with heart defects or serious heart problems. call your doctor right away and get emergency help if you or your child has chest pain, shortness of breath, or faints while taking this medicine. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss the morning dose of an extended release capsule, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time the following day. do not take a dose later in the day and do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? dextroamphetamine and amphetamine may cause side effects. call your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: nervousness; headache; changes in sexual desire or ability; painful menstrual cramps; dry mouth; constipation; diarrhea; nausea; weight loss. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have any of the following or those listed in the important warning section: slow or difficult speech; dizziness; weakness or numbness in an arm or leg; seizures; motor or verbal tics; teeth grinding; depression; believing things that are not true; feeling unusually suspicious of others; hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that are not there); signs of serotonin syndrome such as agitation, hallucinations, fever, sweating, confusion, fast heartbeat, shivering, severe muscle stiffness or twitching, loss of coordination, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea; mania (frenzied or abnormally excited mood); changes in vision or blurred vision; pale or blue fingers or toes; pain, numbness, burning, or tingling in the hands or feet; unexplained sores on fingers or toes; blistering or peeling skin; rash; hives; itching; swelling of the eyes, face, tongue, or throat; trouble breathing or swallowing; hoarseness. this medicine may cause sudden death in children and teenagers, especially those with heart defects or serious heart problems, and may cause sudden death, heart attack, or stroke in adults, especially in those with heart defects or serious heart problems. call your doctor right away if you or your child develops chest pain, shortness of breath, or faints. this medicine may slow growth or weight gain in children; the doctor caring for your child will monitor growth carefully. discuss any concerns about growth or weight with the doctor. talk with your doctor about the risks and benefits of using this medication.

name: flibanserin
instructions: important warning: flibanserin can cause very low blood pressure that may lead to dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting. your doctor will probably tell you not to take flibanserin if you have or have ever had liver disease or if you drink or have ever drunk large amounts of alcohol. drinking alcohol near the time of your dose increases the risk of severe low blood pressure. wait at least 2 hours after drinking 1 or 2 alcoholic drinks before taking flibanserin at bedtime. if you drink 3 or more alcoholic drinks in the evening, skip your flibanserin dose that night. after taking flibanserin at bedtime, do not drink any alcohol until the following day. tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are taking any of the following medicines or have taken them within the past 2 weeks: amprenavir (agenerase; no longer available in the u.s.), atazanavir (reyataz, in evotaz), boceprevir (victrelis), ciprofloxacin (cipro), clarithromycin (biaxin, in prevpac), conivaptan (vaprisol), diltiazem (cartia xt, diltzac, tiazac, others), erythromycin (e.e.s., erytab, erythrocin), fluconazole (diflucan), fosamprenavir (lexiva), indinavir (crixivan), itraconazole (onmel, sporanox), ketoconazole (nizoral), nefazodone, nelfinavir (viracept), posaconazole (noxafil), ritonavir (norvir; in kaletra; in viekira pak), saquinavir (invirase), telaprevir (incivek; no longer available in the u.s.), telithromycin (ketek), and verapamil (calan, covera, verelan; in tarka). your doctor may tell you not to take flibanserin, change your other medications during treatment, or monitor you carefully for side effects. do not eat grapefruit or drink grapefruit juice while taking flibanserin. if you develop lightheadedness, fainting, or dizziness, lie down and call your doctor immediately. keep all appointments with your doctor. you will receive a medication guide when you start flibanserin and with each refill; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. why is this medication prescribed? flibanserin is used to treat hypoactive sexual desire disorder (hsdd)—low sexual desire that causes distress or interpersonal difficulty—in premenopausal women. it should not be used to treat hsdd in women who have gone through menopause, in men, or to improve sexual performance. flibanserin is a serotonin 1a receptor agonist and serotonin 2a receptor antagonist that works by changing the activity of serotonin and other natural substances in the brain. how should this medicine be used? flibanserin comes as a tablet to take by mouth once daily at bedtime. take it at bedtime every day exactly as directed. do not take more or less than prescribed or take it more often. if your symptoms do not improve after 8 weeks of treatment, call your doctor. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking flibanserin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to flibanserin or any ingredients in the tablets; check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. the following nonprescription or herbal products may interact with flibanserin: ginkgo, resveratrol, st. john's wort, cimetidine (tagamet), and heartburn medicines such as proton pump inhibitors (dexlansoprazole [dexilant], esomeprazole [nexium, vimovo], lansoprazole [prevacid], omeprazole [prilosec], rabeprazole [aciphex]) and ranitidine (zantac). do not start any of these while taking flibanserin without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking flibanserin, call your doctor. do not breastfeed while taking flibanserin. flibanserin may cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until at least 6 hours after your dose and until you know how this medication affects you. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. do not consume grapefruit or grapefruit juice, and follow the alcohol timing restrictions described above. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss your bedtime dose, take your next dose at bedtime the following day. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? flibanserin may cause side effects. common effects include nausea, tiredness, difficulty falling or staying asleep, dry mouth, and constipation. some side effects can be serious. if you experience excessive sleepiness; hoarseness; difficulty breathing or swallowing; hives; itching; swelling of the face, lips, or mouth; or any symptoms listed in the important warning or special precautions sections, call your doctor immediately. flibanserin may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: riociguat
instructions: important warning: do not take riociguat if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. riociguat can harm an unborn baby. if you are sexually active and able to become pregnant, do not start riociguat until a pregnancy test confirms you are not pregnant. use reliable methods of birth control during treatment and for 1 month after stopping riociguat. do not have unprotected sex. talk to your doctor about birth control methods that are effective and appropriate for you. call your doctor immediately if you miss a menstrual period or think you may be pregnant while taking riociguat. if you are a parent or guardian of a female who has not yet reached puberty, regularly check for signs of puberty (such as breast buds or pubic hair) and tell her doctor about any changes; puberty may begin before the first menstrual period. because of the risk of birth defects, riociguat is available only through a special restricted distribution program. the adempas risk evaluation and mitigation strategies (rems) program requires all female patients to have pregnancy tests every month during treatment and for 1 month after stopping riociguat. female patients can receive riociguat only if enrolled in the adempas rems program. during enrollment you will choose a certified specialty pharmacy that will ship your medication. ask your doctor if you have any questions about how you will receive your medication. your doctor or pharmacist will give you the medication guide when you begin treatment and each time you refill your prescription. read it carefully and ask questions. talk to your doctor about the risks of taking riociguat. why is this medication prescribed? riociguat is used to treat pulmonary arterial hypertension (pah), high blood pressure in the vessels that carry blood to the lungs. it is also used to treat chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (cteph) in adults who cannot have surgery or who continue to have high lung blood pressure after surgery. riociguat may improve exercise ability in pah and cteph and may slow the worsening of symptoms in pah. it is in a class of medications called soluble guanylate cyclase (sgc) stimulators and works by relaxing the blood vessels in the lungs to improve blood flow. how should this medicine be used? riociguat comes as a tablet to take by mouth. take it with or without food 3 times a day, about 6 to 8 hours apart, at the same times each day. follow your prescription label carefully. take riociguat exactly as directed; do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. if you cannot swallow the tablet whole, you may crush it and mix with a small amount of water or a soft food such as applesauce; swallow the mixture right away. your doctor may start you on a low dose and increase your dose no more than once every 2 weeks. your dose may be decreased if you experience side effects. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking riociguat, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to riociguat, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets; check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor if you are taking or have recently taken a nitrate such as isosorbide dinitrate (isordil, in bidil), isosorbide mononitrate (monoket), or nitroglycerin (nitro-dur, nitromist, nitrostat, minitran, rectiv, others); a phosphodiesterase type 5 (pde-5) inhibitor such as avanafil (stendra), sildenafil (revatio, viagra), tadalafil (adcirca, cialis), or vardenafil (levitra, staxyn); or dipyridamole (persantine, in aggrenox) or theophylline (theo-24, theochron, theolair, others). your doctor will probably tell you not to take riociguat with one or more of these medications. do not take riociguat within 24 hours before or after sildenafil or within 24 hours before or 48 hours after tadalafil. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take, including certain antifungals (itraconazole [onmel, sporanox], ketoconazole [extina, nizoral, xolegel]), hiv protease inhibitors (including ritonavir [norvir, in kaletra]), seizure medications (carbamazepine [epitol, equetro, tegretol, others], phenobarbital, phenytoin [dilantin, phenytek]), and medications for high blood pressure. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. if you take antacids containing aluminum hydroxide or magnesium hydroxide (maalox, mylanta, tums, others), take them 1 hour before or 1 hour after riociguat. tell your doctor about any herbal products you are taking, especially st. john’s wort. tell your doctor if you have pulmonary hypertension with idiopathic interstitial pneumonia (ph-iip); your doctor will probably tell you not to take riociguat. tell your doctor if you currently smoke or start or stop smoking during treatment. also tell your doctor if you have recently had diarrhea, vomiting, or heavy sweating that may have caused dehydration; any bleeding from your lungs; if you have had a procedure to stop coughing up blood; if you have low blood pressure; pulmonary veno-occlusive disease (a blockage of veins in the lungs); or heart, kidney, or liver disease. if you are breastfeeding, do not breastfeed while taking riociguat. you should know that riociguat can cause dizziness and lightheadedness. do not drive a car or operate machinery until you know how this medication affects you. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. if you miss taking riociguat for more than 3 days, call your doctor; you may need to restart your medication at a lower dose. what side effects can this medication cause? riociguat may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: headache, constipation, heartburn, upset stomach, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, swelling of your hands, legs, feet, or ankles. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help: coughing up pink, frothy sputum or blood, fainting, chest pain, shortness of breath. riociguat may cause other side effects.

name: methylphenidate
instructions: important warning: methylphenidate can be habit-forming. take it exactly as directed. do not take more or less than prescribed or take it more often than your doctor recommends. taking too much may make the medication less effective, increase the urge to take more, and cause unusual changes in behavior. tell your doctor if you drink or have ever drunk large amounts of alcohol, use or have ever used street drugs, or have overused prescription medications. do not stop methylphenidate without talking to your doctor, especially if you have overused it. your doctor will likely lower your dose gradually and monitor you closely; stopping suddenly after overuse can cause severe depression. your doctor may also monitor you after stopping the medication because symptoms can worsen when treatment ends. do not sell, give away, or allow anyone else to take your medication; doing so can harm others and is against the law. store methylphenidate in a safe place to prevent accidental or intentional use by others, and keep track of how much you have so you notice any missing doses. you will receive a medication guide when you start methylphenidate and each time you refill it. read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist any questions. why is this medication prescribed? methylphenidate is used to control symptoms of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (adhd)—a condition that makes it hard to pay attention, control behavior, and remain still or quiet—and to treat narcolepsy, a condition that causes excessive daytime sleepiness and sudden sleep attacks. it is a central nervous system (cns) stimulant that works by changing the amounts of certain natural substances in the brain. how should this medicine be used? methylphenidate comes as a tablet, chewable tablet, solution (liquid), suspension (liquid), orally disintegrating tablet (dissolves quickly in the mouth), long-acting (extended-release) tablet, and long-acting capsule to take by mouth. your doctor will tell you how and how often to take it based on the specific product. ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. do not push an orally disintegrating tablet through the foil; with dry hands, peel back the foil, remove the tablet, place it on your tongue, and allow it to dissolve; it can be swallowed with saliva without water. swallow long-acting tablets and capsules whole; do not split, chew, or crush them. if you are prescribed the suspension, follow the manufacturer’s instructions provided by your doctor for measuring and taking each dose; ask if anything is unclear. your doctor may start with a low dose and increase it no more often than once each week. your condition should improve during treatment; call your doctor if symptoms worsen at any time or do not improve after 1 month. your doctor may occasionally stop methylphenidate to see if it is still needed; follow those directions carefully. some methylphenidate products are not interchangeable; ask your pharmacist if you have questions about the specific product prescribed. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking methylphenidate, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to methylphenidate, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and what symptoms you experienced. do not take methylphenidate if you are taking or have taken a monoamine oxidase (mao) inhibitor within the past 14 days (such as isocarboxazid, linezolid, methylene blue, phenelzine, rasagiline, selegiline, or tranylcypromine). some medications should not be used with methylphenidate; others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. discuss all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and herbal products you take or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist before starting methylphenidate, and consult them before starting, stopping, or changing any medication while on methylphenidate. tell your doctor if you or anyone in your family has or has ever had: an irregular heartbeat; sudden death; a heart defect or other heart problems; high blood pressure; tourette’s syndrome; facial or motor tics or verbal tics; depression; bipolar disorder; mania; suicidal thoughts or attempts; other mental health problems; glaucoma; circulation problems in fingers or toes; seizures; an abnormal electroencephalogram (eeg); or narrowing or blockage of your digestive tract. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or become pregnant while taking methylphenidate. if you are breastfeeding or plan to breastfeed, discuss the risks and signs to watch for in your infant (unusual agitation, trouble sleeping, poor appetite, or weight loss). if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist you take methylphenidate. ask your doctor about safe use of alcohol; alcohol can worsen side effects. if you have phenylketonuria (pku), know that chewable tablets contain aspartame, which forms phenylalanine. use methylphenidate as part of a total adhd treatment program that may include counseling and special education; follow all instructions from your doctor and/or therapist. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your normal diet. ask your doctor whether to take your specific methylphenidate product with or without food, and avoid alcohol while taking this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. ask your doctor or pharmacist how late in the day you can take a missed dose to avoid trouble falling or staying asleep. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. if you take a nighttime (evening) methylphenidate product, take the missed dose as soon as you remember that night; if you do not remember until the next morning, skip the missed long-acting capsule and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose. what side effects can this medication cause? methylphenidate may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: nervousness; irritability; difficulty falling or staying asleep; dizziness; nausea; vomiting; loss of appetite; weight loss; stomach pain; diarrhea; heartburn; dry mouth; headache; muscle tightness; drowsiness; restlessness; uncontrollable movements; decreased sexual desire; heavy sweating; back pain. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or get emergency help if you have: fast, pounding, or irregular heartbeat; chest pain; shortness of breath; excessive tiredness; fainting; seizures; changes in or blurred vision; agitation; delusions; unusual suspicion; hallucinations; new or worsening motor or verbal tics; depression; mania or mood changes; frequent, painful erections or an erection lasting longer than 4 hours; numbness, pain, temperature sensitivity, or color changes (pale to blue to red) in fingers or toes; unexplained sores on fingers or toes; or signs of an allergic reaction such as hives, rash, itching, blistering or peeling skin, swelling of the eyes, face, lips, mouth, tongue, or throat, trouble breathing or swallowing, or hoarseness. methylphenidate may slow growth or weight gain in children; your child’s doctor will monitor growth. discuss the risks and benefits of methylphenidate for your child with your child’s doctor.

name: phentermine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? phentermine is prescribed for short-term use to help speed weight loss in overweight individuals who are exercising and following a low-calorie diet. it belongs to a class of medications called anorectics and works by decreasing appetite. this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? phentermine comes as tablets and extended-release capsules. it is usually taken either once daily in the morning or three times a day, 30 minutes before meals. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. take phentermine exactly as directed. most people take it for 3 to 6 weeks, depending on response. phentermine can be habit-forming; do not take larger doses, take it more often, or use it longer than prescribed. if you are taking an extended-release formulation, do not split, chew, or crush it. some tablets may be crushed and mixed with food; ask your pharmacist if this applies to your prescription. what special precautions should i follow? before taking phentermine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to phentermine, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of the ingredients. tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are taking, or have taken within the past two weeks, monoamine oxidase (mao) inhibitors such as isocarboxazid (marplan), phenelzine (nardil), selegiline (eldepryl, emsam, zelapar), or tranylcypromine (parnate). some medicines should not be used with phentermine, and others may require dose changes or extra monitoring; review all medications and supplements you take with your doctor and pharmacist before starting phentermine, and get their advice before starting, stopping, or changing any medicines while taking it. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had heart disease, high blood pressure, arteriosclerosis (narrowing of the arteries), hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid), diabetes, glaucoma, or a history of drug abuse. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while taking phentermine, call your doctor. discuss the risks and benefits if you are 65 or older; older adults generally should not take phentermine because it may be less safe than other options. this medication may make you drowsy; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. ask your doctor about alcohol use; alcohol can worsen side effects. if you have diabetes, you may need to lower your insulin dose while taking phentermine; call your doctor if you have questions or problems. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow the diet and exercise plan your doctor provides; phentermine works best when combined with a structured diet program. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? phentermine may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: dry mouth, unpleasant taste, diarrhea, constipation, vomiting. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor immediately if you experience increased blood pressure, heart palpitations, restlessness, dizziness, tremor, insomnia, shortness of breath, chest pain, swelling of the legs or ankles, or difficulty doing exercise you were previously able to do. phentermine may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: lixisenatide injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? lixisenatide injection is used along with diet and exercise to treat type 2 diabetes, a condition in which the body does not use insulin normally and cannot control blood sugar. it is an incretin mimetic that helps the pancreas release the right amount of insulin when blood sugar is high, slows stomach emptying, and can decrease appetite. managing blood sugar with medication, lifestyle changes (diet, exercise, quitting smoking), and regular monitoring may help improve health and may lower the risk of diabetes-related complications such as heart disease, stroke, kidney problems, nerve damage, and eye problems. your healthcare team will help you decide the best plan to manage your diabetes. how should this medicine be used? lixisenatide injection comes as a prefilled pen for subcutaneous (under the skin) injection once daily, within 1 hour (60 minutes) before the first meal of the day. use it at the same time each day. follow your prescription label exactly. do not use more or less or more often than prescribed. your doctor will usually start with a low dose and may increase it after 14 days. lixisenatide controls diabetes but does not cure it. keep using it even if you feel well and do not stop without talking to your doctor. a healthcare professional will show you how to use the pen and provide written instructions for use—read them carefully and ask questions if needed. you must purchase needles separately; ask which type to use. check the solution before each injection: it should be clear, colorless, and free of particles; do not use if colored, cloudy, thickened, contains particles, or if the pen is expired. inject into the thigh, abdomen, or upper arm, rotating sites with each dose. if refrigerated, allow the pen to reach room temperature before use. never reuse or share needles or pens. remove the needle right after injecting and dispose of it in a puncture-resistant container; ask your pharmacist how to discard the container. this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using lixisenatide, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to this medication, any of its ingredients, or any other medicines, foods, or substances, and describe your symptoms. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all medicines, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; dose adjustments and monitoring may be needed. if you take oral contraceptives (birth control pills), take them at least 1 hour before, or 11 hours after, your lixisenatide dose. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had severe stomach problems (including gastroparesis or trouble digesting food), pancreatitis, or other pancreatic problems. if you are having surgery (including dental), tell the clinician you use lixisenatide. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, planning to become pregnant, or breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while using lixisenatide. ask your doctor what to do if you have major changes in diet, exercise, or weight, or if you become ill, have an infection or fever, experience unusual stress, or are injured—these can affect your blood sugar and your lixisenatide dose. this medication can cause low blood sugar; know the signs and what to do if it occurs: dizziness or lightheadedness, irritability, sweating, hunger, confusion or drowsiness, shakiness, weakness, headache, slurred speech, blurred vision, fast heartbeat, or feeling jittery. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow the diet and exercise plan recommended by your doctor or dietitian. eat a healthy, balanced diet as advised. what should i do if i forget a dose? inject the missed dose within 1 hour (60 minutes) before your next meal. if it is almost time for your next scheduled dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not inject a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? lixisenatide can affect your blood sugar. know the symptoms of low and high blood sugar and what actions to take if they occur. common side effects may include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, indigestion, bloating, headache, and pain, itching, or redness at the injection site. serious side effects require immediate medical attention; stop using lixisenatide and call your doctor or get emergency help if you have: ongoing pain starting in the upper left or middle abdomen that may spread to the back (with or without vomiting); hives, rash, itching; pounding heartbeat; fainting or severe dizziness; swelling of the eyes, face, mouth, tongue, throat, feet, ankles, or lower legs; trouble swallowing or breathing; hoarseness; decreased urination, very dry mouth or skin, or extreme thirst; or severe stomach problems. lixisenatide may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have unusual problems while using it.

name: insulin lispro injection
instructions: notice: insulin lispro and insulin lispro-aabc are biologic medicines made from living organisms. the biosimilar insulin lispro-aabc is highly similar to insulin lispro and works the same way in the body. in this guide, the term “insulin lispro products” refers to both. why is this medication prescribed? insulin lispro injection products are used to treat type 1 diabetes, a condition in which the body does not produce insulin, and type 2 diabetes, a condition in which the body does not use insulin normally, in patients who need insulin to control their blood sugar. in type 1 diabetes, insulin lispro injection products are always used with another insulin unless delivered by an external insulin pump. in type 2 diabetes, insulin lispro injection products may be used with another insulin or with oral diabetes medicines. these products are short-acting, manmade versions of human insulin. they replace the insulin your body normally makes, help move sugar from the blood into body tissues for energy, and reduce the liver’s production of sugar. managing high blood sugar over time helps lower the risk of serious complications such as heart disease, stroke, kidney problems, nerve damage, and eye disease. using medications as prescribed, making lifestyle changes (diet, exercise, quitting smoking), and checking your blood sugar regularly can improve your health and lower your chances of heart attack, stroke, kidney failure, nerve damage (numb, cold legs or feet; decreased sexual ability), eye problems (including vision changes or loss), and gum disease. your healthcare team will advise you on the best plan to manage your diabetes. how should this medicine be used? insulin lispro injection products come as a solution (liquid) and as a suspension (liquid with particles that settle) for subcutaneous injection under the skin. insulin lispro solution (admelog, humalog) is usually injected within 15 minutes before a meal or immediately after a meal. insulin lispro suspension (humalog mix 75/25 or humalog mix 50/50) should be injected 15 minutes before a meal. insulin lispro-aabc solution (lyumjev) should be injected at the beginning of a meal or within 20 minutes after you start eating. your doctor will tell you how many times per day to inject insulin lispro products. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not use more or less, or more often, than prescribed. insulin lispro injection products may also be given intravenously by a doctor or nurse in a healthcare setting with careful monitoring. never use insulin lispro injection products if you have symptoms of low blood sugar or your blood sugar reading is low. insulin lispro controls diabetes but does not cure it. continue using it even if you feel well. do not stop, switch brands or types, or change any insulin dose without talking to your doctor. always check the insulin label to be sure you received the correct product. insulin lispro injection products are supplied in vials, cartridges (for use in dosing pens), and prefilled dosing pens. know which container you have and what supplies (needles, syringes, pens) you need. if using vials, inject with the appropriate syringes; ask your healthcare provider to show you how. if using cartridges, purchase a compatible insulin pen; read the pen’s instructions and have your provider teach you how to use it. if using prefilled pens, read and follow the manufacturer’s instructions carefully and always prime the pen before use. never reuse needles or syringes, and never share needles, syringes, cartridges, or pens. if using a pen, remove the needle immediately after injecting. dispose of sharps in a puncture-resistant container and ask your provider how to dispose of the container. your doctor may tell you to mix insulin lispro solution with nph insulin in the same syringe. if so, always draw insulin lispro into the syringe first, use the same brand of syringe each time, and inject immediately after mixing. do not mix insulin lispro injection products with any insulin other than nph. do not mix insulin lispro suspension with any other insulin. your doctor may tell you to dilute insulin lispro to make dosing easier; follow their instructions exactly. inject into the thighs, stomach (abdomen), upper arms, or buttocks. rotate injection sites within the chosen area with each dose. do not inject into skin that is thick, lumpy, tender, bruised, scaly, hard, scarred, or damaged. always check your insulin before use. insulin lispro solution should be clear and colorless; do not use if colored, cloudy, or if it contains particles. insulin lispro suspension should look cloudy or milky after mixing; do not use if there are clumps or solid white particles sticking to the bottom or walls of the container. do not use any insulin past its expiration date. gently roll or shake insulin lispro suspension to mix before use; ask your provider if and how your insulin should be mixed. insulin lispro solution (admelog, humalog u-100, lyumjev u-100) can be used in an external insulin pump. before pump use, confirm the pump is compatible with continuous delivery of rapid-acting insulin, read the pump manual for recommended reservoir and tubing sets, and have your provider show you how to use the pump. do not dilute insulin lispro or mix it with other insulins in the pump. when using an external pump, replace the insulin in the reservoir at least every 7 days (admelog, humalog u-100) or at least every 9 days (lyumjev u-100), and change the infusion set and insertion site at least every 3 days. if the infusion site becomes red, itchy, lumpy, or thickened, move to a different site. high blood sugar can occur quickly if the pump malfunctions, the reservoir is exposed to direct sunlight or temperatures above 98.6°f (37°c), or if tubing leaks, kinks, disconnects, or becomes blocked. if you cannot promptly find and fix the problem, call your doctor right away. you may need to temporarily inject insulin subcutaneously with a syringe or pen. keep back-up insulin and supplies available and know how to use them. this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using an insulin lispro injection product, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to insulin (humulin, novolin, others), insulin lispro, insulin lispro-aabc, any ingredients in these products, or any other medicines. ask your pharmacist or check the manufacturer’s patient information for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. nonprescription products that may interact with insulin lispro include niacin and salicylates (such as aspirin, choline magnesium trisalicylate [trisalate], choline salicylate [arthropan], magnesium salicylate [doan’s and others], and salsalate [argesic, disalcid, salgesic]). do not start these while using insulin lispro without discussing with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had diabetic nerve damage; heart failure; low potassium levels; or any heart, liver, or kidney disease, and if you frequently have hypoglycemia. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while using insulin lispro. if you are having any surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you use an insulin lispro injection product. alcohol can change blood sugar; ask your doctor about safe use of alcoholic beverages and alcohol-containing medications. ask your doctor what to do if you are sick, under unusual stress, or change your diet, exercise, or activity level, as these can affect your insulin needs. when starting insulin lispro or after a large dose increase, you may experience blurry vision or other vision problems, or painful, burning, weak, or numb sensations in your hands, arms, feet, or legs; these usually resolve, but contact your doctor if they persist. ask your doctor how often to check your blood sugar. low blood sugar can impair tasks such as driving; ask whether you should check your blood sugar before driving or operating machinery. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow the dietary plan provided by your doctor or dietitian. eat a healthful diet and aim to consume similar amounts and types of food at consistent times each day. skipping or delaying meals or changing the amount or kind of food you eat can disrupt blood sugar control. what should i do if i forget a dose? insulin lispro injection products must be injected shortly before or after a meal. if you remember before or shortly after your meal, inject the missed dose right away. if more time has passed since your meal, follow your doctor’s specific instructions or call your doctor to ask whether you should take the missed dose. do not inject a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? this medication can change your blood sugar. know the signs of low and high blood sugar and what to do if they occur. insulin lispro injection products may cause side effects. common effects include redness, swelling, or itching at the injection site; changes in the feel of your skin such as thickening, small indentations, or lumps; weight gain; and constipation. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you experience any of the following: rash or itching, hives, wheezing, difficulty breathing, fast heartbeat, sweating, feeling drowsy, dizzy, or confused; swelling of the face, tongue, or throat; weakness, muscle cramps, or an abnormal heartbeat; shortness of breath; large, rapid weight gain; or swelling of the arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs. insulin lispro may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: ado-trastuzumab emtansine injection
instructions: important warning: ado-trastuzumab emtansine can cause serious or life-threatening liver problems. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver disease, including hepatitis. your doctor will order laboratory tests before and during treatment to check your liver. if tests show liver problems, your doctor may advise that you should not receive this medication. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all medicines and supplements you take so they can check for products that may increase the risk of liver damage while you receive ado-trastuzumab emtansine. call your doctor right away if you have nausea, vomiting, extreme tiredness, lack of energy, loss of appetite, pain in the upper right abdomen, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, flu-like symptoms, confusion, drowsiness, or slurred or unclear speech. ado-trastuzumab emtansine can also cause serious or life-threatening heart problems. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had heart disease, a heart attack, chest pain, or irregular heartbeats. your doctor will perform tests before and during treatment to make sure your heart is working well enough for you to receive this medication, and may tell you not to continue if your heart function decreases. call your doctor immediately if you develop cough, shortness of breath, swelling of the arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, weight gain of more than 5 pounds [about 2.3 kilograms] in 24 hours, dizziness, fainting or loss of consciousness, or a fast, irregular, or pounding heartbeat. do not use this medication if you are pregnant or if you or your partner plan to become pregnant. ado-trastuzumab emtansine may harm an unborn baby. if you can become pregnant, you will need a negative pregnancy test before starting treatment. use effective birth control during treatment and for 7 months after the final dose. if you are a male and your partner can become pregnant, use birth control during treatment and for 4 months after the final dose. talk to your doctor about birth control methods that are right for you. if you or your partner becomes pregnant during treatment, call your doctor immediately. talk to your doctor about the risks of receiving ado-trastuzumab emtansine injection. why is this medication prescribed? ado-trastuzumab emtansine injection is used to treat a certain type of breast cancer that has spread to other parts of the body and has not improved or has worsened after treatment with other medicines. it is also used after surgery for a certain type of breast cancer in people who received chemotherapy before surgery but still had cancer remaining in the removed tissue. ado-trastuzumab emtansine is an antibody-drug conjugate that works by killing cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? ado-trastuzumab emtansine injection comes as a powder that is mixed with liquid and infused slowly into a vein by a doctor or nurse in a hospital or clinic. it is usually given once every 3 weeks. the length of treatment depends on how you respond and what side effects you experience. serious infusion-related reactions can happen during or shortly after the infusion. your first dose is usually infused over 90 minutes, and you will be monitored closely. if you do not have serious problems with the first dose, later doses are usually infused over 30 minutes. call for help immediately if you develop flushing, fever, chills, dizziness, lightheadedness, fainting, shortness of breath, difficulty breathing, or a fast, irregular, or pounding heartbeat during or soon after the infusion. your doctor may delay treatment, slow the infusion, or stop treatment if certain side effects occur. be sure to tell your care team how you are feeling during treatment. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving ado-trastuzumab emtansine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to ado-trastuzumab emtansine, trastuzumab, any other medicines, or any ingredient in the injection. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. some nonprescription products, including aspirin, may interact with ado-trastuzumab emtansine. do not start any new medicine while receiving this medication without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you are of asian descent, or if you have or have ever had any of the conditions listed in the important warning section, trouble breathing even when resting, prior radiation therapy, or any other medical conditions. do not breastfeed while receiving ado-trastuzumab emtansine and for 7 months after the final dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor about eating grapefruit or drinking grapefruit juice while receiving this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an infusion appointment, contact your doctor or clinic as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to self-administer this medication, and do not receive extra doses to make up for a missed dose unless your doctor tells you to do so. what side effects can this medication cause? ado-trastuzumab emtansine may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: constipation, diarrhea, upset stomach, sores in the mouth and throat, dry mouth, changes in ability to taste, joint or muscle pain, headache, dry red or teary eyes, blurry vision, or trouble falling asleep or staying asleep. some side effects can be serious. if you have any of the following or symptoms listed in the important warning section, call your doctor immediately: pain, itching, redness, swelling, blisters, or sores near the infusion site; fever, sore throat, chills, difficulty urinating, pain when urinating, or other signs of infection; nosebleeds or other unusual bleeding or bruising; bloody or black tarry stools; vomiting blood or material that looks like coffee grounds; pain, burning, or tingling in the hands or feet, muscle weakness, or trouble moving; hives, rash, or itching; difficulty breathing or swallowing; nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, fatigue, rapid heartbeat, dark urine, decreased urine, stomach pain, seizures, hallucinations, or muscle cramps and spasms; shortness of breath, cough, or extreme tiredness. ado-trastuzumab emtansine may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you notice any unusual problems during treatment.

name: pamidronate injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? pamidronate is used to treat high levels of calcium in the blood caused by certain cancers. it is also used with cancer chemotherapy to treat bone damage from multiple myeloma cancer that begins in plasma cells, or from breast cancer that has spread to the bones. pamidronate is also used to treat paget disease, in which bones are soft, weak, painful, deformed, or break easily. pamidronate is a bisphosphonate that slows bone breakdown, increases bone density, and reduces the release of calcium from bone into the blood. how should this medicine be used? pamidronate injection is a liquid given into a vein slowly over 2 to 24 hours. a healthcare professional administers it in a hospital, clinic, or medical office. it may be given once every 3 to 4 weeks, once daily for 3 days in a row, or as a single dose that may be repeated after 1 week or longer, depending on your condition. your doctor may recommend daily calcium and a multivitamin with vitamin d during treatment; take these exactly as directed. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving pamidronate, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to pamidronate, alendronate fosamax, etidronate didronel, risedronate actonel, tiludronate skelid, zoledronic acid zometa, any other medicines, or any ingredients in pamidronate injection. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you are receiving radiation therapy and if you have or have ever had thyroid surgery, seizures, or liver or kidney disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, discuss this with your doctor. use reliable birth control while receiving pamidronate; if you become pregnant, call your doctor right away. pamidronate can remain in the body for years after stopping, so talk to your doctor if you plan future pregnancy. pamidronate may cause serious jaw problems, especially with dental surgery or treatment. have a dental exam and complete any needed dental work before starting pamidronate, maintain good oral hygiene, and talk to your doctor before any dental procedures during treatment. pamidronate can cause severe bone, muscle, or joint pain that may start days, months, or years after beginning treatment. call your doctor immediately if you develop severe pain; your doctor may stop the medication and the pain may resolve after stopping. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? call your doctor if you miss a dose or an appointment for pamidronate. what side effects can this medication cause? pamidronate injection may cause side effects. common effects include redness, swelling, or pain at the injection site; stomach pain; loss of appetite; constipation; nausea; vomiting; heartburn; changes in taste; mouth sores; fever; headache; dizziness; unusual tiredness; trouble falling or staying asleep; cough; difficult or painful urination; and swelling of the hands, arms, feet, ankles, or lower legs. serious side effects may include painful or swollen gums; loose teeth; numbness or a heavy feeling in the jaw; poor healing of the jaw; vomit that is bloody or looks like coffee grounds; bloody or black tarry stools; shortness of breath; fast heartbeat; fainting; sudden muscle tightening; numbness or tingling around the mouth; and eye pain or tearing. pamidronate injection may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: epinephrine injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? epinephrine injection is used with emergency medical care to treat life-threatening allergic reactions (anaphylaxis) caused by insect stings or bites, foods, medications, latex, and other triggers. in hospitalized adults, it is also used to treat life-threatening low blood pressure due to septic shock. epinephrine is an alpha- and beta-adrenergic agonist (sympathomimetic) that relaxes the muscles of the airways and tightens blood vessels. how should this medicine be used? epinephrine injection comes as prefilled automatic injection devices and as vials. for anaphylaxis, inject subcutaneously or intramuscularly into the middle of the outer thigh at the first signs of a serious allergic reaction; it may be given through clothing in an emergency. for septic shock, it is injected into a vein by a healthcare professional in a medical facility. use exactly as directed; do not inject more often or more or less than prescribed. have your doctor or pharmacist teach you and your caregivers to use the auto-injector; practice with a trainer device that contains no medicine or needle. read the patient information before first use and ask questions if anything is unclear. know the signs of a serious allergic reaction (such as airway closing, wheezing, sneezing, hoarseness, rash, hives, itching, swelling of the face, eyes, mouth, throat, or hands, skin redness, fast heartbeat, weak pulse, anxiety, confusion, stomach pain, vomiting, diarrhea, loss of bladder or bowel control, faintness, seizures, or loss of consciousness) and inject immediately if you suspect anaphylaxis. always keep two auto-injectors with you or available at all times; one dose may not be enough. check expiration dates and replace expired devices. periodically inspect the solution; if it is discolored or contains particles, contact your doctor for a new device. most auto-injectors deliver a single dose. if symptoms continue or return after the first injection, your doctor may instruct you to give a second dose using a new device. do not give more than two injections for a single episode unless directed by a healthcare professional. epinephrine treats anaphylaxis but does not replace medical care—call 911 and seek emergency help immediately after injecting, and rest quietly while waiting. inject only into the middle of the outer thigh; do not inject into the buttocks, fingers, hands, feet, or into a vein. do not place your thumb, fingers, or hand over the needle end of the device. if epinephrine is accidentally injected into the wrong area, seek emergency care right away. after use, some liquid will remain in the device—this is normal; do not attempt to use the remainder. ask how to dispose of used devices safely and take the used device with you to the emergency department. this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using epinephrine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to epinephrine, sulfites, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the product. your doctor may still tell you to use it in an emergency because it is life-saving. the auto-injector does not contain latex and is safe if you have a latex allergy. tell your healthcare provider about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; you may need careful monitoring for side effects. nonprescription antihistamines such as chlorpheniramine (chlor-trimeton) and diphenhydramine (benadryl) may interact—do not start them while using epinephrine without discussing with your provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had chest pain, irregular heartbeat, high blood pressure, heart disease, asthma, diabetes, hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid), depression, or parkinson’s disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, ask your doctor about when and how to use epinephrine. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary changes are required. ask your doctor if you have questions about foods that may trigger your allergies. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is used as needed for emergencies; a missed dose does not apply. inject immediately at the first signs of a serious allergic reaction and seek emergency care. always carry two auto-injectors. what side effects can this medication cause? epinephrine may cause side effects. after using it, seek emergency medical care and tell providers if you have any of the following: redness, swelling, warmth, or tenderness at the injection site; difficulty breathing; pounding, fast, or irregular heartbeat; nausea; vomiting; sweating; dizziness; nervousness, anxiety, or restlessness; weakness; pale skin; headache; or uncontrollable shaking of a part of your body.

name: doxorubicin
instructions: important warning: doxorubicin must be administered only into a vein. it can leak into surrounding tissue and cause severe irritation or damage; your healthcare team will monitor the injection site. call your doctor right away if you notice pain, itching, redness, swelling, blisters, or sores where the medication was injected. doxorubicin may cause serious or life-threatening heart problems during treatment or months to years afterward. your doctor will perform tests before and during therapy to ensure your heart is functioning well enough, such as an electrocardiogram (ecg) and an echocardiogram to assess rhythm and pumping function, and may advise against treatment if you have an abnormal heart rate or reduced heart function. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had heart disease, a heart attack, or radiation therapy to the chest, and tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are taking or have ever received medicines such as cyclophosphamide (cytoxan), daunorubicin (cerubidine, daunoxome), epirubicin (ellence), idarubicin (idamycin), mitoxantrone (novantrone), paclitaxel (abraxane, onxol), trastuzumab (herceptin), or verapamil (calan, isoptin). call your doctor immediately if you develop shortness of breath, difficulty breathing, swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, or a fast, irregular, or pounding heartbeat. doxorubicin can cause a severe decrease in bone marrow blood cells; your doctor will order regular lab tests before and during treatment. low blood cell counts can cause symptoms and raise your risk of serious infection or bleeding. tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are taking or have received azathioprine (imuran), cyclosporine (neoral, sandimmune), methotrexate (rheumatrex), or progesterone (provera, depo-provera). call your doctor right away if you have fever, sore throat, persistent cough or congestion, or other signs of infection; unusual bleeding or bruising; black or bloody stools; bloody vomit; or vomit that looks like coffee grounds. doxorubicin may increase the risk of leukemia (cancer of the white blood cells), especially at high doses or when given with certain chemotherapy medicines and radiation therapy. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver disease; your doctor may advise against treatment or adjust your dose. doxorubicin should be given only under the supervision of a doctor experienced in chemotherapy. why is this medication prescribed? doxorubicin is used with other medicines to treat certain cancers of the bladder, breast, lung, stomach, and ovary; hodgkin’s lymphoma (hodgkin’s disease) and non-hodgkin’s lymphoma; and certain leukemias, including acute lymphoblastic leukemia (all) and acute myeloid leukemia (aml, anll). it is also used alone or with other medicines to treat some thyroid cancers and certain soft tissue or bone sarcomas, and to treat neuroblastoma and wilms’ tumor in children. doxorubicin is an anthracycline that works by slowing or stopping the growth of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? doxorubicin is supplied as a solution or as a powder to be mixed with liquid and is injected into a vein by a doctor or nurse in a medical facility. it is usually given once every 21 to 28 days. the length of treatment depends on the drug regimen, how well your body responds, and the type of cancer. ask your doctor or pharmacist for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine doxorubicin is sometimes used to treat cancers of the uterus (endometrium and cervix), prostate, pancreas, adrenal cortex, and liver; kaposi’s sarcoma related to aids; ewing’s sarcoma; mesothelioma; multiple myeloma; and chronic lymphocytic leukemia (cll). discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving doxorubicin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to doxorubicin, daunorubicin (cerubidine, daunoxome), epirubicin (ellence), idarubicin (idamycin), any other medicines, or any ingredients in the product; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you closely for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any other medical conditions. know that doxorubicin may interfere with menstrual periods in women and may stop sperm production in men; however, do not assume you cannot become pregnant or cause a pregnancy. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or breastfeeding; you should not become pregnant or breastfeed while receiving doxorubicin. if you become pregnant during treatment, call your doctor. use a reliable method of birth control to prevent pregnancy; doxorubicin may harm an unborn baby. do not receive any vaccinations without talking to your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a scheduled doxorubicin appointment, contact your doctor or clinic as soon as possible to reschedule. do not attempt to self-administer or take an extra dose to make up for the missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? doxorubicin may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: nausea; vomiting; sores in the mouth and throat; loss of appetite and weight loss; weight gain; stomach pain; diarrhea; increased thirst; unusual tiredness or weakness; dizziness; hair loss; separation of a fingernail or toenail from the nail bed; itchy, red, watery, or irritated eyes; eye pain; pain, burning, or tingling in the hands or feet; red discoloration of urine for 1 to 2 days after a dose. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the symptoms listed in the important warning section, or hives, skin rash, itching, difficulty breathing or swallowing, or seizures, call your doctor immediately. doxorubicin may cause other side effects; tell your doctor about any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: fluorouracil injection
instructions: important warning: fluorouracil injection should be given in a hospital or medical facility under the supervision of a doctor who is experienced in administering chemotherapy for cancer. treatment with fluorouracil injection may cause serious side effects. why is this medication prescribed? fluorouracil is an antimetabolite used, usually with other medicines, to treat colon or rectal cancer that has worsened or spread to other parts of the body. it is also used with other medicines to treat certain types of breast cancer after surgery or radiation therapy, and to treat pancreatic and stomach cancers. it works by slowing or stopping the growth of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? fluorouracil injection is a liquid solution given intravenously by a doctor or nurse in a medical facility. your doctor will determine how often you receive it based on your condition and response. your doctor may delay treatment or change your dose if certain side effects occur. it is important to tell your doctor how you feel during treatment. your doctor may perform a genetic test before starting to assess how well you may tolerate this medication. other uses for this medicine: fluorouracil is sometimes used to treat cervical and esophageal cancer; head and neck cancers including cancers of the mouth, lip, cheek, tongue, palate, throat, tonsils, and sinuses; ovarian cancer; and renal cell carcinoma. discuss the risks of using this medication for your condition with your doctor. this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving fluorouracil, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to fluorouracil or any ingredients in the injection; provide a list of all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use, as your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you closely; tell your doctor if you have an infection, if you have previously received radiation therapy or chemotherapy, or if you have or have ever had kidney or liver disease; tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. do not become pregnant or breastfeed while receiving fluorouracil. if you become pregnant, call your doctor. fluorouracil may harm the fetus. avoid unnecessary or prolonged sun exposure and wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen, because fluorouracil may make your skin sensitive to sunlight. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss or cannot keep an infusion appointment, contact your doctor or treatment center right away to reschedule. do not attempt to make up a dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? fluorouracil may cause side effects. common effects include loss of appetite, nausea, unusual tiredness or weakness, dizziness, headache, hair loss, dry or cracked skin, vision changes, watery eyes or sensitivity to light, redness, pain, swelling, or burning at the injection site, and confusion. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you experience sores in the mouth and throat; diarrhea; vomiting; swelling, pain, redness, or peeling of the skin on the palms and soles; fever, chills, sore throat, or other signs of infection; hives, rash, or itching; difficulty breathing or swallowing; nosebleeds; coughing up or vomiting blood or material that looks like coffee grounds; unusual bleeding or bruising; pink, red, or dark brown urine; red or tarry black stools; or chest pain. fluorouracil may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: nadofaragene firadenovec-vncg intravesical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? nadofaragene firadenovec-vncg is used to treat a certain type of bladder cancer that did not respond adequately to bacillus calmette-guerin (bcg) therapy. it is a gene therapy that helps your body produce interferon alfa-2b, a natural protein that fights cancer cells in the bladder. how should this medicine be used? nadofaragene firadenovec-vncg is a liquid suspension that is slowly infused through a catheter into your bladder while you are lying down. a healthcare professional gives it in a doctor’s office, hospital, or clinic, usually once every 3 months. you should keep the medicine in your bladder for 1 hour or as long as you can. during that hour, you will rotate positions—stomach, back, and each side—for about 15 minutes each. tell your healthcare provider if you cannot hold the medication for the full hour. after 1 hour, you will empty your bladder. for the first 2 days after treatment, disinfect your urine by pouring about one half cup (120 ml) of undiluted bleach into the toilet before urinating; after you urinate, wait 15 minutes before flushing. you may experience an irritable bladder during or shortly after treatment, such as sudden urgency to urinate, urine leakage, or bladder cramping; tell your healthcare provider if any of the medication leaks from your bladder. your doctor will monitor your response; if you do not respond fully after 3 months or if the cancer returns, surgery will likely be recommended. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more details. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving nadofaragene firadenovec-vncg, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to nadofaragene firadenovec-vncg, interferon alfa-2b, any other medications, or any ingredients in this product; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you are immunocompromised (have a weakened immune system) due to a medical condition or medicines that affect immune responses, or if you have or have ever had any other medical conditions. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or plan to father a child, discuss this with your doctor. if you are female, you will need a pregnancy test before starting and must use effective birth control during treatment and for 6 months after the final dose. if you are male, you and your female partner should use effective birth control during treatment and for 3 months after the final dose. call your doctor if you or your partner becomes pregnant during treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? continue your usual diet unless your doctor gives you other instructions. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment for a dose, call your doctor right away to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? nadofaragene firadenovec-vncg may cause side effects. common effects include urine leakage, bladder spasms, frequent, urgent, or painful urination, tiredness, chills, and fever. serious side effects can occur; call your doctor immediately if you notice blood in your urine. this medication may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving it.

name: aducanumab-avwa injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? aducanumab-avwa injection is used to reduce amyloid beta plaque, a protein found in the brain of people with alzheimer disease, a condition that slowly destroys memory and the ability to think, learn, communicate, and handle daily activities. it is used to treat people with mild cognitive impairment (mci) or mild dementia. aducanumab-avwa injection is in a class of medications called monoclonal antibodies. it works by blocking the formation of amyloid beta in the brain. how should this medicine be used? aducanumab-avwa injection comes as a liquid solution that is given into a vein by a doctor or nurse in a hospital or clinic. it is usually infused over about 1 hour once every 4 weeks. your doctor may pause or stop treatment depending on your response to the medication and any side effects you experience. be sure to tell your healthcare provider how you are feeling during treatment. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving aducanumab-avwa injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to aducanumab-avwa, any other medications, or any of the ingredients in the injection. ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any medical conditions. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while receiving aducanumab-avwa injection, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment to receive aducanumab-avwa injection, call your healthcare provider as soon as possible. doses should be given at least 21 days apart. what side effects can this medication cause? aducanumab-avwa injection may cause side effects. common side effects include diarrhea and falls. some side effects can be serious. if you experience headache, confusion, dizziness, vision changes, or nausea; swelling of the face, lips, mouth, or tongue; or hives, call your doctor immediately or seek emergency medical care. aducanumab-avwa injection may cause other side effects.

name: guaifenesin
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? guaifenesin is used to relieve chest congestion. it helps control symptoms but does not treat the cause of symptoms or speed recovery. as an expectorant, it thins mucus in the air passages to make it easier to cough up and clear the airways. how should this medicine be used? guaifenesin is available as tablets, capsules, extended-release long-acting tablets, dissolving granules, and liquid syrup taken by mouth. regular tablets, capsules, dissolving granules, and syrup are usually taken every 4 hours as needed, with or without food. the extended-release tablet is usually taken every 12 hours, with or without food. follow the directions on the package or your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. take guaifenesin exactly as directed; do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. guaifenesin is sold alone and in combination with antihistamines, cough suppressants, and decongestants. ask your doctor or pharmacist which product is best for your symptoms. check nonprescription cough and cold product labels carefully before using two or more products at the same time, because they may contain the same active ingredients and using them together could cause an overdose. this is especially important for children. do not give nonprescription cough and cold combination products, including those that contain guaifenesin, to children younger than 4 years of age. if you give these products to children 4 to 11 years of age, use caution and follow the package directions carefully. if you are giving guaifenesin or a combination product containing guaifenesin to a child, read the package label carefully to be sure that it is the right product for that age. do not give guaifenesin products made for adults to children. before dosing a child, check the package label for the correct amount and give the dose that matches the child age on the chart. ask the child doctor if you do not know how much to give. if you are taking the liquid, do not use a household spoon to measure your dose; use the measuring spoon or cup that came with the medication or a device made for measuring medicine. swallow extended-release tablets whole with a full glass of water; do not break, crush, or chew them. if you are taking the dissolving granules, empty the entire contents of the packet onto your tongue and swallow. if your symptoms do not improve within 7 days or if you also have a high fever, a rash, or a headache that does not go away, call your doctor. other uses for this medicine this medication is sometimes prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking guaifenesin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to guaifenesin, any other medications, or any of the ingredients in the product you plan to take. check the package label for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you smoke and if you have a cough with a large amount of phlegm mucus, or if you have or have ever had a breathing problem such as asthma, emphysema, or chronic bronchitis. if you will be taking the dissolving granules, tell your doctor if you are on a low magnesium diet or if you have kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. if you become pregnant while taking guaifenesin, call your doctor. if you have phenylketonuria pku, an inherited condition requiring a special diet to prevent brain damage and severe intellectual disability, you should know that some dissolving granules may be sweetened with aspartame, a source of phenylalanine. what special dietary instructions should i follow? drink plenty of fluids while you are taking this medication. unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? guaifenesin is usually taken as needed. if your doctor has told you to take guaifenesin on a regular schedule and you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? guaifenesin may cause side effects. if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: headache, nausea, vomiting. guaifenesin may cause other side effects.

name: fluticasone and salmeterol oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? the combination of fluticasone and salmeterol (advair diskus, advair hfa, airduo respiclick) is used to treat difficulty breathing, wheezing, shortness of breath, coughing, and chest tightness caused by asthma. advair diskus is also used to prevent and treat these symptoms caused by chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (copd), including chronic bronchitis and emphysema. advair diskus is used in adults and children 4 years and older;
