advair hfa and airduo respiclick are used in adults and children 12 years and older. fluticasone is a corticosteroid that reduces swelling in the airways. salmeterol is a long-acting beta-agonist (laba) that relaxes and opens the air passages to make breathing easier. how should this medicine be used? fluticasone and salmeterol comes as an inhaled powder and as an inhalation solution used by mouth with a specially designed inhaler. it is usually used twice a day, in the morning and evening, about 12 hours apart. use it at the same times every day. follow your prescription label carefully and use exactly as directed. do not use more or less, or more often, than prescribed. ask your doctor how to take your other oral or inhaled asthma medications while using this medicine. if you regularly used a short-acting beta-agonist such as albuterol (proventil, ventolin), your doctor will likely tell you to stop routine use but to keep using it to treat sudden asthma symptoms; follow these directions carefully. do not use fluticasone and salmeterol during an asthma or copd attack; your doctor will prescribe a short-acting rescue inhaler for attacks. this medicine controls symptoms but does not cure your condition, and it may take a week or longer to feel the full benefit. continue to use it even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor, or your symptoms may return. before first use of advair diskus, advair hfa, or airduo respiclick, read the package instructions and study the diagrams. ask your doctor, pharmacist, or respiratory therapist to show you how to use the inhaler, and practice while they watch. if your child uses it, ensure they know how and watch them each time to confirm correct technique. never exhale into the inhaler, take it apart, or wash the mouthpiece or any part of the device. keep the inhaler dry. do not use with a spacer. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to fluticasone (flonase, flovent), salmeterol (serevent), any other medications, milk protein, any foods, or any ingredients in fluticasone/salmeterol products; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. do not use this medicine with another laba such as formoterol (perforomist; in dulera; in symbicort) or salmeterol (serevent; in advair). your doctor will tell you which medication to use and which to stop. tell your doctor if you are taking, or have stopped within the past two weeks, antidepressants such as amitriptyline, amoxapine, clomipramine (anafranil), desipramine (norpramin), doxepin (silenor), imipramine (tofranil), nortriptyline (pamelor), protriptyline (vivactil), or trimipramine (surmontil); or monoamine oxidase (mao) inhibitors such as isocarboxazid (marplan), linezolid (zyvox), methylene blue, phenelzine (nardil), selegiline (eldepryl, emsam, zelapar), or tranylcypromine (parnate). tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you or a family member has or has ever had osteoporosis, and if you have or have ever had high blood pressure, irregular heartbeat, seizures, hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid), diabetes, tuberculosis (tb), cataracts, glaucoma, any condition that affects your immune system, or liver or heart disease. also tell your doctor if you have a herpes eye infection or any other infection, and if you smoke or use tobacco products. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor; if you become pregnant while using this medicine, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you use fluticasone and salmeterol. if you have never had chickenpox or measles and have not been vaccinated, avoid people who are sick, especially those with chickenpox or measles. if you are exposed to these infections or develop symptoms, call your doctor immediately; you may need a vaccine shot. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor about eating grapefruit or drinking grapefruit juice while taking this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not inhale a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? fluticasone and salmeterol may cause side effects. if any of these are severe or do not go away, tell your doctor: runny nose, sneezing, sore throat, throat irritation, sinus pain, headache, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, stomach pain, muscle and bone pain, dizziness, weakness, tiredness, sweating, tooth pain, shaking (tremor), or sleep problems. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have: coughing, wheezing, or chest tightness that begins soon after you inhale the medicine; hives; rash; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; choking or difficulty swallowing; hoarseness; noisy, high-pitched breathing; pounding, fast, or irregular heartbeat; fainting; chest pain; cough; burning or tingling in the hands or feet; white patches in the mouth; fever, chills, or other signs of infection. fluticasone and salmeterol may slow growth in children; your child’s doctor will monitor growth—discuss the risks with your child’s doctor. this medicine may increase the risk of glaucoma or cataracts; you will probably need regular eye exams. call your doctor if you have eye pain, redness, discomfort, blurred vision, halos or bright colors around lights, or any other changes in vision. this medicine may increase your risk of developing osteoporosis. fluticasone and salmeterol may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: diphenhydramine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? diphenhydramine is an antihistamine used to relieve red, irritated, itchy, watery eyes; sneezing; runny nose; and cough caused by allergies or the common cold. it is also used in adults to treat insomnia (difficulty falling or staying asleep) but should not be used to make a child sleepy. it works by blocking histamine, a substance in the body that triggers allergic symptoms. how should this medicine be used? diphenhydramine comes as a tablet, chewable tablet, capsule, and liquid to take by mouth. for allergy, cold, and cough symptoms, take every 4 to 6 hours as directed on the label or by your doctor. do not take more, take less, or take it more often than directed. diphenhydramine is available alone or in combination with pain relievers, fever reducers, and decongestants; ask your doctor or pharmacist which product best matches your symptoms. carefully check labels before using two or more nonprescription cough and cold products at the same time; they may contain the same active ingredients and taking them together could result in too much medication. nonprescription cough and cold combination products, including those containing diphenhydramine, can cause serious side effects or death in young children. do not give these products to children younger than 2 years of age. do not use in children 2 to 5 years of age unless directed by a doctor. use caution when giving to children 6 to 11 years of age. do not give diphenhydramine products made for adults to children. check the package label for the correct dose based on the child’s age, and ask the child’s doctor if you are unsure. if using the liquid, measure each dose with the provided measuring device or a medication-measuring spoon or cup; do not use a household spoon. other uses for this medicine diphenhydramine is used to prevent and treat motion sickness. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking diphenhydramine, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to diphenhydramine, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your allergy symptoms. tell your doctor or pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had emphysema, chronic bronchitis, or other lung disease; glaucoma (increased pressure in the eye); or difficulty urinating due to an enlarged prostate gland. if you have been told to follow a low-sodium diet, ask your doctor before using the liquid product. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking diphenhydramine, call your doctor. in general, diphenhydramine should not be used in older adults, except to manage serious allergic reactions, because it is not as safe or effective as other options. if you are 65 years of age or older, discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. this medication may cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. alcohol can increase drowsiness; avoid alcoholic beverages while taking this medication. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? diphenhydramine is usually taken as needed. if your doctor has told you to take it on a regular schedule and you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? diphenhydramine may cause side effects. common effects include dry mouth, nose, and throat; drowsiness; dizziness; muscle weakness; and excitement (especially in children). some side effects may be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have vision problems or difficulty or painful urination. diphenhydramine may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you experience any unusual problems while you are taking this medication.

name: amphetamine
instructions: . important warning: amphetamine can be habit-forming. do not take a larger dose, take it more often, or use it longer than prescribed by your doctor. taking too much amphetamine can create a strong urge to continue using large amounts and can cause unusual behavior changes. you or your caregiver should seek immediate medical help if you experience any of the following: fast, pounding, or irregular heartbeat; sweating; dilated pupils; abnormally elevated mood; restlessness; irritability; trouble falling or staying asleep; hostility; aggression; anxiety; loss of appetite; loss of coordination; uncontrollable movements; flushed skin; vomiting; stomach pain; or thoughts of harming or killing yourself or others, including plans or attempts. misuse or overuse may cause serious heart problems or sudden death. tell your doctor if you or anyone in your family drinks or has ever drunk large amounts of alcohol, uses or has ever used street drugs, or has misused prescription medicines; your doctor will likely not prescribe amphetamine. do not stop amphetamine without talking to your doctor, especially if you have been overusing it; your dose will likely be tapered and you will be monitored. suddenly stopping after overuse may cause depression and extreme tiredness. do not sell, give away, or let anyone else take your medicine; this can harm others and is illegal. store amphetamine securely, preferably locked, and track the amount so you will know if any is missing. your doctor or pharmacist will give you a medication guide when you start treatment and with each refill; read it carefully and ask questions. why is this medication prescribed? amphetamine (adzenys er, adzenys xr, dyanavel xr, evekeo, evekeo odt, others) is used as part of a treatment program to help manage attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (adhd) symptoms in adults and children, such as difficulty focusing, controlling actions, and staying still or quiet compared with others the same age. amphetamine (evekeo, others) is also used to treat narcolepsy, a sleep disorder that causes excessive daytime sleepiness and sudden sleep attacks. amphetamine (evekeo, others) may also be used short term (a few weeks), together with a reduced-calorie diet and exercise, to aid weight loss in people with obesity who have not been able to lose weight. it is a central nervous system stimulant that works by changing the amounts of certain natural chemicals in the brain. how should this medicine be used? amphetamine comes as an immediate-release tablet (evekeo), an orally disintegrating tablet (evekeo odt), an extended-release orally disintegrating tablet (adzenys xr), and an extended-release suspension (adzenys er, dyanavel xr) to take by mouth. the extended-release suspension is usually taken once daily in the morning with or without food. the orally disintegrating tablet is usually taken once daily in the morning with or without food or liquid. the extended-release orally disintegrating tablet is usually taken once daily in the morning with or without food. for adhd or narcolepsy, the immediate-release tablet is usually taken 1 to 3 times daily, 4 to 6 hours apart, with or without food, with the first dose in the morning. for weight loss, the immediate-release tablet is usually taken 30 to 60 minutes before meals. do not take doses in the late afternoon or evening because this may cause difficulty sleeping. follow your prescription label closely and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. take amphetamine exactly as directed. swallow extended-release tablets whole; do not chew or crush. do not try to push evekeo odt or adzenys xr through the blister foil. use dry hands to peel back the foil, remove the tablet, and place it on your tongue; it will dissolve and can be swallowed with saliva, without water. shake the extended-release suspension well before each use to mix the medication evenly. do not add the extended-release suspension to food or mix it with other liquids. use an oral dosing syringe to measure doses accurately; ask your pharmacist for one if needed, and wash it thoroughly after each use. for adhd, your doctor will usually start with a low dose and increase it gradually, every 4 to 7 days depending on the product, and may have you pause treatment occasionally to see if it is still needed. for narcolepsy, your doctor will usually start with a low dose and increase it no more often than weekly. because products are absorbed differently, do not substitute one amphetamine product for another; if switching, your doctor will select the appropriate dose. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking amphetamine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to amphetamine; other stimulants such as benzphetamine, dextroamphetamine (dexedrine, in adderall), lisdexamfetamine (vyvanse), or methamphetamine (desoxyn); any other medications; or any ingredients in amphetamine products. ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor or pharmacist if you take or have taken within the last 14 days any of these monoamine oxidase inhibitors: isocarboxazid (marplan), linezolid (zyvox), methylene blue, phenelzine (nardil), selegiline (eldepryl, emsam, zelapar), or tranylcypromine (parnate). some medicines must not be combined with amphetamine, and others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. discuss all prescription and nonprescription medicines and supplements you take or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist before starting amphetamine, and consult them before starting, stopping, or changing any medicine while using amphetamine. the following nonprescription or herbal products may interact: st. john’s wort; tryptophan; amino acid supplements such as glutamic acid (l-glutamine); sodium acid phosphate; sodium bicarbonate (baking soda, antacids); medicines for heartburn or ulcers such as cimetidine (tagamet), esomeprazole (nexium), omeprazole (prilosec, in zegerid); and allergy medicines such as diphenhydramine, loratadine, fexofenadine, chlorpheniramine, or cetirizine. do not start any of these while taking amphetamine without medical advice. tell your doctor if you have hyperthyroidism, or strong feelings of anxiety, tension, or agitation; you will likely be told not to take amphetamine. tell your doctor if anyone in your family has or has ever had an irregular heartbeat or died suddenly, and if you have recently had a heart attack, or have or have ever had a heart defect, arteriosclerosis, coronary artery disease, high blood pressure, an irregular heartbeat, cardiomyopathy, heart or blood vessel disease, or other heart problems. your doctor will examine your heart and blood vessels and may advise against amphetamine if you have a heart condition or a high risk of one. tell your doctor if you or anyone in your family has or has ever had depression, bipolar disorder, mania, psychosis, motor or verbal tics, tourette’s syndrome, or suicidal thoughts or attempts, and if you have or have ever had seizures, an abnormal eeg, or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; if you become pregnant while taking amphetamine, call your doctor. do not breastfeed while taking amphetamine. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how this medicine affects you. do not drink alcohol while taking amphetamine, as it can worsen side effects. use amphetamine only as part of a comprehensive adhd treatment plan that may include counseling and special education; follow all instructions from your doctor and therapist. be aware that amphetamine may cause sudden death in children and teenagers, especially those with heart defects or serious heart problems, and may cause sudden death, heart attack, or stroke in adults, especially those with heart defects or serious heart problems. call your or your child’s doctor right away if chest pain, shortness of breath, or fainting occurs while taking this medicine. what special dietary instructions should i follow? talk to your doctor about drinking fruit juice while taking this medicine. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? amphetamine may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: dry mouth; nausea; diarrhea; constipation; unpleasant taste; stomach cramps; weight loss; nosebleeds; headache; teeth grinding or clenching during sleep; nervousness; changes in sex drive or ability; painful menstruation; pain or burning when urinating. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following or any symptoms listed in the important warning section, stop taking amphetamine and call your doctor immediately: dizziness; weakness or numbness of an arm or leg; motor or verbal tics; believing things that are not true; unusual suspicion of others; hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that are not there); mania (frenzied, abnormally excited mood); agitation; signs of serotonin syndrome such as hallucinations, fever, sweating, confusion, fast heartbeat, shivering, severe muscle stiffness or twitching, loss of coordination, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea; seizures; changes in vision or blurred vision; blistering or peeling skin; rash; hives; itching; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes; difficulty breathing or swallowing; numbness, pain, or sensitivity to temperature in the fingers or toes; color changes in the fingers or toes from pale to blue to red; unexplained wounds on the fingers or toes. amphetamine may cause sudden death in children and teenagers, especially those with heart defects or serious heart problems, and may cause sudden death, heart attack, or stroke in adults, especially those with heart defects or serious heart problems. call your doctor right away if you or your child has chest pain, shortness of breath, or faints while taking this medicine. amphetamine may slow growth or weight gain in children; your child’s doctor will monitor growth carefully. talk to your child’s doctor if you have concerns about growth or weight while your child is taking this medicine. amphetamine may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it. discuss the risks and benefits of this medicine with your doctor.

name: rifamycin
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? rifamycin is used to treat travelers' diarrhea caused by certain bacteria. it belongs to a class of antibiotics and works by stopping the growth of the bacteria that cause diarrhea. it will not treat colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when they are not needed increases the risk of developing infections that resist antibiotic treatment. how should this medicine be used? rifamycin comes as a delayed-release tablet that releases medicine in the intestine, where its effects are needed, and is taken by mouth. it is usually taken twice daily, in the morning and evening, with or without food, for 3 days. take rifamycin at about the same times each day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully. take it exactly as directed; do not take more or less or more often than prescribed. take each dose with a full glass of liquid (6–8 ounces [177–240 milliliters]); do not take it with alcohol. swallow the tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush them. you should begin to feel better during the first few days of treatment. if your symptoms do not improve within 48 hours, get worse, or you develop a fever or bloody diarrhea, call your doctor right away. take rifamycin until you finish the prescription, even if you feel better. stopping too soon or skipping doses can prevent complete treatment and may promote antibiotic resistance. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking rifamycin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to rifamycin; other rifamycins such as rifaximin (xifaxan), rifabutin (mycobutin), rifampin (rifadin, rimactane; in rifamate, rifater), or rifapentine (priftin); any other medications; or any of the ingredients in rifamycin tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of the ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, and nutritional supplements you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any other medical conditions. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking rifamycin, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? rifamycin may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: constipation; headache. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have watery or bloody diarrhea with stomach cramps and fever during treatment or for up to 2 months afterward. rifamycin may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: flunisolide oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? flunisolide oral inhalation is prescribed to prevent asthma symptoms such as shortness of breath, chest tightness, wheezing, and cough in adults and in children 6 years and older. it is a corticosteroid that reduces swelling and irritation in the airways to make breathing easier. how should this medicine be used? flunisolide comes as an aerosol for oral inhalation and is usually used twice daily at about the same times each day. follow your prescription label and your clinician’s instructions exactly. do not use more or less or more often than directed. ask your doctor how to coordinate flunisolide with your other asthma medicines, both inhaled and oral, and whether other inhalers should be taken a set amount of time before or after flunisolide. if you have been taking an oral steroid such as dexamethasone, methylprednisolone (medrol), or prednisone (rayos), your doctor may begin to slowly reduce your oral steroid dose starting at least one week after you begin flunisolide inhalation. flunisolide helps prevent attacks but will not treat an asthma attack that has already started; do not use it for sudden symptoms. use your prescribed fast acting rescue inhaler for acute attacks. your doctor will usually start you on a standard dose, increase it if your symptoms are not better after at least 4 weeks, and later decrease it once control is achieved. it may take 2 to 4 weeks or longer to feel the full benefit. keep using it even if you feel well, and do not stop without talking to your doctor. call your doctor if your asthma worsens, if an attack does not improve with your rescue inhaler, or if you need your rescue medicine more often than usual. each canister is designed to deliver a labeled number of puffs (for example, 60 or 120). after that number is reached, later sprays may not contain the correct dose. track your daily actuations so you know how many remain. discard the canister after the labeled number of puffs, even if liquid remains and a spray still comes out. if the inhaler is dropped, do not rely on the counter to estimate remaining doses. before first use, read all written instructions and review diagrams. ask a health professional to show you how to use it. keep the inhaler away from open flame and heat; exposure to very high temperatures may cause the device to burst. to use: ensure the inhaler is at room temperature. if using for the first time or if unused for more than 14 days, prime by releasing 2 test sprays into the air away from your face; avoid spraying into eyes or face. make sure the canister is properly seated in the actuator; do not attach any additional spacers. hold the inhaler, shake it, breathe out fully, place the mouthpiece in your mouth with lips sealed, then inhale slowly and deeply through your mouth while pressing down firmly on the canister to release one spray; remove your finger as soon as the dose is released. when your lungs are full (after at least 3 seconds of inhaling), remove the inhaler, close your mouth, hold your breath for about 10 seconds, then exhale gently and breathe normally. if more than one puff is prescribed, repeat these steps. close the actuator if applicable. rinse your mouth with water and spit it out; do not swallow. what special precautions should i follow? before using flunisolide, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to flunisolide or any of its ingredients, and provide a full list of all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; dose adjustments or monitoring may be needed. do not use flunisolide to treat an acute asthma attack; use your fast acting rescue inhaler and call your doctor if an attack does not resolve or if you require your rescue medication more often than usual. tell your doctor if you have been on prolonged bed rest or limited mobility; if you or family members have osteoporosis; if you have or have had tuberculosis, cataracts, glaucoma, any untreated infection, or an eye herpes infection. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while using flunisolide. inform all clinicians and dentists that you use flunisolide before any surgery, including dental procedures. when your oral steroid is being reduced, other conditions such as asthma, arthritis, or eczema may worsen, and you may develop symptoms of low adrenal hormones such as severe fatigue, muscle weakness or pain, sudden pain in the abdomen, lower body, or legs, loss of appetite, weight loss, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, dizziness, fainting, mood changes such as depression or irritability, and skin darkening. your body may be less able to handle stress such as illness, severe asthma attack, surgery, or injury; call your doctor right away if you become ill, and make sure all healthcare providers know you recently switched from an oral steroid to flunisolide. carry a medical id card or wear a bracelet indicating you may need steroid treatment in an emergency. if you have never had chickenpox or measles and are not vaccinated, avoid people who are ill, especially with chickenpox or measles; if you are exposed or develop symptoms, contact your doctor promptly as you may need preventive treatment. be aware that flunisolide can rarely cause wheezing or breathing difficulty immediately after inhalation (paradoxical bronchospasm); if this occurs, use your rescue inhaler right away and call your doctor. do not use flunisolide again unless your doctor tells you to. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not use two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? flunisolide inhalation may cause side effects. common effects include painful white patches in the mouth or throat (thrush), headache, sore throat, nasal congestion or runny nose, swelling of the nose, throat, or sinuses, cough, nosebleeds, and pain or burning with urination. serious effects can occur; call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have hives, rash, itching, swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, hoarseness, trouble breathing or swallowing, chest pain or tightness, vision changes, or fever, aches, or chills. flunisolide may slow growth in children; your child’s growth will be monitored. long term use has rarely been associated with glaucoma or cataracts; ask your doctor about eye exams during treatment. use may increase the risk of osteoporosis. flunisolide can cause other side effects; call your doctor if you experience anything unusual or severe.

name: afamitresgene autoleucel injection
instructions: important warning: afamitresgene autoleucel can trigger a serious or life-threatening reaction called cytokine release syndrome (crs). you will be closely monitored by medical staff during the infusion, throughout your stay at the healthcare facility (at least 7 days), and for at least 4 weeks afterward. you will receive medicines 30 to 60 minutes before the infusion to help prevent reactions. seek immediate medical help and tell your care team right away if you develop any of the following during or after the infusion: fever, chills or shivering, trouble breathing, rapid or irregular heartbeat, dizziness or lightheadedness, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, or rash. because of the risk of crs, afamitresgene autoleucel is available only through a restricted distribution program and can be given only by a doctor and facility enrolled in the program. your doctor or pharmacist will provide the medication guide when you start treatment; read it carefully and ask questions. discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? afamitresgene autoleucel is prescribed for adults to treat certain synovial sarcomas that cannot be removed by surgery or have not responded to other treatments. it belongs to a class called autologous cellular immunotherapy, made from your own blood cells, and helps your immune system recognize and attack cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? afamitresgene autoleucel is given as an intravenous suspension by a doctor or nurse in a hospital, usually as a single dose infused over about an hour or less. you will receive other chemotherapy medicines beforehand to prepare your body. before dosing, your white blood cells are collected by leukapheresis (a procedure that removes white blood cells at a collection center). because the treatment is made from your cells, it must be given only to you. it is critical not to miss your cell collection or treatment appointments. your healthcare provider will evaluate you daily for at least 7 days after your dose and you should remain near the treatment center for at least 4 weeks so you can be monitored and to check how well the therapy is working and for possible side effects. ask your doctor how to prepare for leukapheresis and what to expect. other uses for this medicine: afamitresgene autoleucel may sometimes be used for other conditions; discuss potential risks and benefits with your doctor. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving afamitresgene autoleucel, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to this medication, to any other drugs, to dimethyl sulfoxide (dmso), or to any ingredient in the injection (review the medication guide for a full list). provide a list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for interactions. inform your doctor if you have or have ever had seizures, stroke, confusion, memory problems, low blood pressure, any current infection, hepatitis b or c (hbv or hcv), other viral infections such as cytomegalovirus or hiv, lung or breathing issues, or kidney, heart, or liver disease. if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding, tell your doctor. you will need a pregnancy test before starting; do not become pregnant during treatment. if you become pregnant, call your doctor right away. this medicine may cause drowsiness, confusion, weakness, dizziness, seizures, and coordination problems. do not drive or operate machinery for at least 4 weeks after your dose. do not donate blood, organs, tissues, or cells after receiving this therapy. what special dietary instructions should i follow? continue your usual diet unless your doctor advises otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss your cell collection appointment, contact your doctor and the collection center immediately. if you miss your treatment appointment, call your doctor right away. what side effects can this medication cause? afamitresgene autoleucel may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, constipation, stomach pain, loss of appetite, back pain, or swelling. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or seek emergency care if you develop any of the symptoms listed in the important warning section or any of the following: pale skin or shortness of breath; fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection; unusual bruising or bleeding; disorientation, drowsiness, trouble concentrating, seizures, difficulty thinking or speaking, or weakness. this therapy may increase the risk of certain cancers; discuss this risk with your doctor. other side effects may occur; contact your healthcare provider if you notice anything concerning.

name: afatinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? afatinib is used to treat certain types of non-small cell lung cancer that have spread locally or to other parts of the body. it is a kinase inhibitor that works by blocking natural signals that help cancer cells grow and divide. how should this medicine be used? afatinib is an oral tablet taken once daily on an empty stomach—at least 1 hour before eating or 2 hours after a meal or snack. take it at the same time each day. follow your prescription label closely, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take exactly as directed; do not take more, take it more often, or change your dose unless your doctor tells you to. your doctor may pause treatment, reduce the dose, or stop afatinib if serious side effects occur; keep your care team informed about how you feel. continue taking afatinib even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medicine may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more details. what special precautions should i follow? before taking afatinib, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to afatinib, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use. your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. some products can interact with afatinib, including st. john’s wort; make sure your healthcare team knows if you take it, and do not start new medicines or supplements while on afatinib without medical advice. tell your doctor if you are of asian descent; have or have ever had lung or breathing problems other than lung cancer; eye problems (including dry eyes); heart issues; liver or kidney disease; any other medical conditions; or if you wear contact lenses. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, do not become pregnant during treatment and for at least 2 weeks after your last dose. discuss effective birth control with your doctor and call right away if you become pregnant; afatinib may harm an unborn baby. do not breast-feed while taking afatinib. limit unnecessary or prolonged sun exposure and use protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen; afatinib can make your skin more sensitive to sunlight and raise the risk of rash or acne. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you different instructions, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is less than 12 hours until your next scheduled dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? afatinib may cause side effects. common effects include cracked or swollen lips; sores at the corners of the mouth; dry or itchy skin; decreased appetite; nail infection; acne; and nosebleeds. some side effects can be serious. if you have any of the following—or symptoms listed in the important warning section—stop taking afatinib and call your doctor right away or seek emergency care: diarrhea; signs of dehydration (such as dry mouth, dark urine, decreased sweating, dry skin); decreased urination; swelling of the arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; rash; skin pain, redness, peeling, or blistering; trouble breathing or shortness of breath; rapid, irregular, or pounding heartbeat; sudden weight gain; cough; fever; unusual tiredness; pain in the right upper abdomen; unusual bruising or bleeding; nausea or vomiting; yellowing of the skin or eyes; dark urine; red, swollen, painful, or watery eyes; sudden vision changes (including blurred vision) or sensitivity to light. afatinib may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: everolimus
instructions: important warning: everolimus can weaken your immune system and raise your risk of serious or life‑threatening infections caused by bacteria, viruses, or fungi. past hepatitis b infection can reactivate during treatment. tell your doctor if you have or ever had hepatitis b, if you currently have or think you may have any infection, or if you take other immune‑suppressing drugs (for example, azathioprine, cyclosporine, dexamethasone, methotrexate, prednisolone, prednisone, sirolimus, tacrolimus). call your doctor right away for symptoms of infection or liver problems, including extreme tiredness; yellow skin or eyes; loss of appetite; nausea; joint pain; dark urine; pale stools; upper‑right abdominal pain; rash; painful, difficult, or frequent urination; ear pain or drainage; sinus pain/pressure; sore throat; cough; fever; chills; or feeling unwell. keep all doctor and lab appointments; your doctor will monitor your response to everolimus. you will receive a medication guide or patient information leaflet (zortress for transplant; afinitor/afinitor disperz for oncology/tsc) at the start and with each refill; read it and ask questions. for transplant prevention: use only under a transplant specialist’s supervision. your risk of cancer, especially lymphoma and skin cancer, is increased. tell your doctor if you or family members have had skin cancer or if you have fair skin. to lower skin‑cancer risk, limit sun/uv exposure (tanning beds/sunlamps), wear protective clothing and sunglasses, and use sunscreen. call your doctor right away for possible cancer signs: red, raised, or waxy skin areas; new sores, bumps, discolorations, nonhealing sores; new lumps/masses; skin changes; night sweats; swollen glands (neck, armpits, groin); trouble breathing; chest pain; or persistent weakness/tiredness. everolimus may rarely cause bk virus kidney infection (which can damage a transplanted kidney) and progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (pml), a serious brain infection that cannot be treated or cured and can cause death or severe disability. call your doctor immediately for signs of pml: one‑sided weakness that worsens; clumsiness; changes in thinking, walking, balance, speech, vision, or strength lasting several days; headaches; seizures; confusion; or personality changes. blood clots can form in the blood vessels of a transplanted kidney, especially within the first 30 days after transplant, and may cause graft loss. call your doctor right away for pain in the groin, lower back, side, or abdomen; decreased or no urination; blood or dark urine; fever; nausea; or vomiting. combined use with cyclosporine can harm the kidneys; your doctor will adjust cyclosporine dosing and monitor drug levels and kidney function. call your doctor immediately for decreased urination or swelling of the arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs. after heart transplant, more deaths occurred in the first few months among people who received everolimus than among those who did not; discuss risks with your doctor if you have a heart transplant. why is this medication prescribed? everolimus (afinitor) treats advanced renal cell carcinoma (rcc) after other medicines have failed; certain advanced breast cancers previously treated with at least one medicine; certain advanced cancers of the pancreas, stomach, intestines, or lungs that have spread or progressed and cannot be removed by surgery; kidney tumors in people with tuberous sclerosis complex (tsc); and subependymal giant cell astrocytoma (sega) in adults and children 1 year and older with tsc. everolimus (afinitor disperz) is also used with other medicines to treat certain seizures in adults and children 2 years and older with tsc. everolimus (zortress) is used with other medicines to prevent organ rejection in certain adults who receive a kidney transplant. everolimus is a kinase inhibitor that treats cancer by slowing cancer cell growth and reducing their blood supply, and prevents transplant rejection by lowering immune system activity. how should this medicine be used? everolimus is taken by mouth as standard tablets or as tablets for oral suspension (to be mixed with water). for rcc; tsc kidney tumors, sega, or seizures; or breast, pancreatic, stomach, intestine, or lung cancers: take once daily. for transplant rejection prevention: take twice daily, every 12 hours, at the same time as cyclosporine. always take with food or always without food—be consistent. take at the same times every day. follow your prescription exactly; do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. tablets are packaged in individual blisters you open with scissors; open just before use. use only one dosage form: either standard tablets or tablets for oral suspension—do not combine them. swallow standard tablets whole with a full glass of water; do not split, crush, or chew; do not take tablets that are broken or crushed. if you cannot swallow tablets, ask your doctor or pharmacist about alternatives. for tablets for oral suspension (afinitor disperz): mix only with water, not juice or other liquids; do not swallow tablets whole. prepare and use within 60 minutes; discard any unused mixture after 60 minutes. do not prepare on food‑prep or eating surfaces. if preparing for someone else, wear gloves; if you are pregnant or may become pregnant, avoid preparing the medication for others because contact may harm an unborn baby. to mix in an oral syringe: remove the plunger from a 10‑ml syringe, place the prescribed number of tablets in the barrel (up to 10 mg per syringe; use a second syringe for higher doses), replace plunger, draw about 5 ml of water and 4 ml of air, and stand the syringe tip‑up in a container for 3 minutes to allow suspension to form. gently invert (turn up and down) 5 times, then place the tip in the mouth and push the plunger to give the dose. refill the same syringe with 5 ml water and 4 ml air, gently swirl to rinse any remaining particles, and give this to ensure the full dose. to mix in a glass: place the prescribed number of tablets (up to 10 mg per glass; use a second glass for higher doses) into a small drinking glass (≤100 ml capacity) without crushing; add 25 ml of water, wait 3 minutes, then gently stir with a spoon and have the patient drink immediately. add another 25 ml water, stir with the same spoon to rinse any remaining particles, and have the patient drink to ensure the full dose. your doctor may adjust your dose based on blood tests, response, side effects, and other medicines. for sega or seizures, dose adjustments are typically no more often than every 1–2 weeks; for transplant prevention, no more often than every 4–5 days. treatment may be paused for severe side effects; tell your doctor how you are feeling throughout therapy. what special precautions should i follow? before taking everolimus, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to everolimus, sirolimus (rapamune), temsirolimus (torisel), any other medicines, or any ingredients in everolimus; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. provide a complete list of all medicines, vitamins, and supplements you take or plan to take; dosing changes and additional monitoring may be needed. st. john’s wort can interact with everolimus—do not start it while taking everolimus and tell your doctor if you use it. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had diabetes or high blood sugar; high cholesterol or triglycerides; kidney or liver disease; or problems digesting sugars, starch, or dairy products. pregnancy and contraception: everolimus may harm an unborn baby. if you can become pregnant, use effective birth control during treatment and for 8 weeks after your final dose. if you are male with a partner who can become pregnant, use effective birth control during treatment and for 4 weeks after your final dose. call your doctor if pregnancy occurs. do not breastfeed during treatment and for 2 weeks after your final dose. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, tell your clinician you take everolimus. do not receive any vaccines without your doctor’s approval, and avoid close contact with people who have recently received live vaccines. ask your child’s doctor about needed vaccinations before starting everolimus. mouth sores are common, especially in the first 8 weeks; your doctor may prescribe a preventive mouthwash. use it as directed. if you develop mouth pain or sores, do not use mouthwashes containing alcohol, peroxide, iodine, or thyme unless your doctor approves, as they may worsen symptoms. wound healing may be delayed; call your doctor right away if a surgical incision (including a kidney‑transplant incision) or any wound becomes warm, red, painful, or swollen; fills with blood, fluid, or pus; or starts to open. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not eat grapefruit or drink grapefruit juice while taking everolimus. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you remember within 6 hours of your scheduled time, take the missed dose right away. if more than 6 hours have passed, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? everolimus can cause side effects. common effects include diarrhea; constipation; changes in taste; weight loss; dry mouth; weakness; headache; trouble sleeping; nosebleeds; dry skin; acne; nail problems; hair loss; pain in the arms, legs, back, or joints; muscle cramps; missed or irregular periods; heavy menstrual bleeding; trouble getting or keeping an erection; anxiety; or aggression or other behavior changes. serious side effects require immediate medical attention and include signs of an allergic reaction (hives; itching; swelling of the hands, feet, arms, legs, eyes, face, mouth, lips, tongue, or throat; hoarseness; trouble breathing or swallowing; wheezing), flushing, chest pain, extreme thirst or hunger, unusual bleeding or bruising, pale skin, fast or irregular heartbeat, dizziness, or seizures. also seek urgent care for any symptoms listed in the important warning section (signs of infection or liver problems; symptoms of pml; signs of bk virus kidney problems; signs of kidney blood clots; or symptoms suggesting lymphoma or skin cancer). everolimus may reduce fertility in men and women; discuss risks with your doctor. other side effects may occur; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking everolimus.

name: ethinyl estradiol and levonorgestrel oral contraceptives
instructions: important warning: ethinyl estradiol and levonorgestrel combination birth-control pills can increase the risk of blood clots, heart attack, and stroke. do not use if you smoke or are older than 35 years, or if you have or have ever had blood clots in the legs, lungs, or eyes; conditions that make your blood clot easily; coronary artery disease; cerebrovascular disease; a stroke or tia (mini-stroke); an irregular heartbeat; heart or heart valve disease; a prior heart attack; or angina (chest pain). seek urgent medical care if you develop shortness of breath, leg pain or swelling, sudden chest pain, a sudden severe headache, sudden vision changes, weakness or numbness on one side of the body, or trouble speaking. why is this medication prescribed? these combined oral contraceptives prevent pregnancy by supplying an estrogen (ethinyl estradiol) and a progestin (levonorgestrel) that work together to stop ovulation. they do not protect against hiv (the virus that causes aids) or other sexually transmitted infections. how should this medicine be used? take the tablets by mouth once daily at the same time each day, exactly as directed. different brands contain different doses and schedules, and some include inactive or iron tablets. know your specific product and follow its instructions; read the patient information that comes with your pack. your doctor will tell you when to start—commonly on the first day of your period or the first sunday after bleeding starts—and you will usually need a backup birth-control method for the first 7 days. expect withdrawal bleeding during inactive pills or a pill-free interval; with all-active or extended-cycle packs, you may have no scheduled bleeding but may experience spotting, especially early in treatment. start each new pack on time even if you are still bleeding. vomiting or diarrhea can reduce effectiveness; contact your doctor for advice—backup contraception is often recommended for 7 days. continue taking pills as prescribed even if you have spotting, nausea, or think pregnancy is unlikely. do not stop without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine: these pills may also be used for heavy or irregular periods, endometriosis, and acne in selected patients by lowering hormones that contribute to these conditions. discuss risks and benefits with your doctor; they may be used for other purposes as determined by your clinician. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor and pharmacist about any allergies to this medication or its ingredients and what reactions you have had. review all prescription, over-the-counter, and herbal products you use; some medicines should not be used with this contraceptive, and others can lower its effectiveness and require backup birth control. do not start, stop, or change any medication while taking this pill without medical advice. st. john’s wort can reduce pill effectiveness—avoid unless approved by your clinician. do not use if you have diabetes with vascular complications; migraines with neurologic symptoms (such as aura, vision changes, weakness, or dizziness); severe or uncontrolled high blood pressure; current or past breast cancer; liver cancer, liver tumors, or active liver disease; or unexplained vaginal bleeding. tell your doctor if you are overweight or have ever had high cholesterol or triglycerides, diabetes, depression, gallbladder disease, or swelling/edema. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding. if you miss a period while on pills, pregnancy is possible—ask your doctor what to do; take a pregnancy test and call if you have pregnancy symptoms (nausea, vomiting, breast tenderness) or suspect pregnancy. inform all healthcare providers, including dentists, that you take this medication before surgery or procedures. these pills can cause dark facial skin patches (melasma); if you have had this during pregnancy or with prior pills, limit sun and tanning bed exposure and use protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen. if you wear contact lenses and notice vision changes or discomfort, see an eye care professional. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? missing pills can reduce pregnancy protection. you may need backup contraception for 7 days or until the end of the cycle, depending on how many pills you missed and when. follow the missed-dose instructions specific to your brand in the patient information, and call your doctor or pharmacist if you are unsure. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include headache; nausea or vomiting; weight changes; spotting or irregular bleeding; vaginal irritation, burning, itching, redness, or discharge; breast tenderness, enlargement, or discharge; swelling of the hands, arms, feet, or legs; trouble sleeping; weakness, fatigue, low energy, or mood changes. serious side effects require stopping the pills and immediate medical care: yellowing of the skin or eyes; abdominal pain or tenderness; a new breast lump; or unusual bleeding, including very heavy or prolonged menstrual bleeding (more than 7 days). these contraceptives may increase the risk of benign liver tumors that can rupture and cause internal bleeding, and may increase the risk of breast or liver cancer; discuss these risks with your doctor. other side effects can occur; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual while taking this medication.

name: aflibercept injection
instructions: notice: aflibercept injection, aflibercept-yszy injection, and aflibercept-jbvf injection are biologic medicines made from living cells. the biosimilars aflibercept-yszy and aflibercept-jbvf are highly similar to aflibercept injection and act the same way in the body; therefore, the term “aflibercept injection products” will be used to refer to these medicines here. why is this medication prescribed? aflibercept injection products are used to treat wet age-related macular degeneration (amd), an eye disease that impairs central vision and can make reading, driving, and other daily activities difficult; diabetic macular edema, an eye condition from diabetes that can lead to vision loss; and diabetic retinopathy, diabetes-related damage to the eyes. they are also used for macular edema following retinal vein occlusion, which is blockage of blood flow from the eye that causes blurry vision and vision loss. in addition, aflibercept injection is used to treat retinopathy of prematurity (rop), an eye disease in premature infants that can cause vision loss and blindness. aflibercept injection products are vascular endothelial growth factor-a (vegf-a) and placental growth factor (plgf) antagonists that help prevent abnormal eye blood vessel growth and leakage that can lead to vision loss. how should this medicine be used? aflibercept injection products come as a liquid solution injected into the eye by a doctor, typically in a doctor’s office or clinic. your injections will follow a schedule tailored to you and your condition. before each injection, your doctor will clean the eye to lower infection risk and numb it to reduce discomfort; after the injection, your eyes will be checked before you leave. these medicines control certain eye conditions but do not cure them, so your doctor will monitor how well they are working and discuss how long you should continue treatment. other uses for this medicine: this medication may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving aflibercept injection products, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to aflibercept, any other medicines, or any ingredients in these products; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. inform your doctor if you have an infection or swelling in or around the eye; you will likely be advised not to receive an injection until it resolves. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor. do not become pregnant right before starting treatment, during treatment, or for 3 to 4 months after your last dose. use effective birth control before and during treatment and for 3 to 4 months after your final injection; ask your doctor how long you should continue contraception. if you become pregnant during treatment, call your doctor. be aware that your vision may be temporarily affected shortly after an injection; do not drive or operate machinery until your vision returns to normal. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment for an aflibercept injection product, contact your doctor as soon as possible to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? aflibercept injection products may cause side effects. call your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: feeling like something is in your eye; watery or teary eyes. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have: eye redness or pain; sensitivity to light; blurred vision; decreased or changes in vision; bleeding in or around the eye; seeing “floaters” or small specks; injection-site pain; seeing flashes of light; chest pain; shortness of breath; sweating; slow or difficult speech; dizziness or fainting; weakness or numbness of an arm or a leg; rash; itching; hives; or trouble breathing or swallowing. aflibercept injection products may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice any unusual problems while receiving this medicine.

name: influenza vaccine, inactivated or recombinant
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? influenza vaccine, inactivated or recombinant, helps prevent influenza (flu) caused by influenza viruses. flu spreads each year in the united states, typically from october through may. anyone can get the flu, but some people are at higher risk of severe illness. symptoms can include fever and chills, sore throat, muscle aches, fatigue, cough, headache, and runny or stuffy nose; complications can include sinus infections, pneumonia, hospitalization, and death. this vaccine does not contain live influenza virus; it works by prompting your immune system to build protection. because influenza viruses change over time, the vaccine is periodically reformulated to match circulating variants. how should this medicine be used? this vaccine is given as an intramuscular injection (a shot into the muscle) by a healthcare provider. it is usually given as a single dose each flu season. some people may be advised to receive two doses based on age and prior vaccination history; if two doses are recommended, they should be given at least 4 weeks apart. what special precautions should i follow? tell your vaccine provider if you have ever had an allergic reaction to this vaccine, any component of this vaccine, any other vaccine, or any drug, food, or substance, and describe the symptoms you experienced; if you have a history of guillain-barré syndrome or a weakened immune system due to a condition or medication; if you have a fever or are feeling unwell; if you have ever fainted after an injection; or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. this vaccine has not been shown to pose a risk to pregnant women or the fetus, but flu during pregnancy has been linked to adverse outcomes such as early labor and delivery. discuss the best timing of vaccination with your doctor. in some cases, your healthcare provider may postpone vaccination to a future visit. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are required. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a scheduled vaccination, or if you were advised to receive two doses and miss the second dose, contact your healthcare provider to reschedule as soon as possible. if two doses are recommended for you, they should be administered at least 4 weeks apart. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include pain, bruising, swelling, or redness at the injection site; muscle aches; chills or general ill feeling; headache; and nausea. serious side effects can include numbness in the extremities, muscle pain, difficulty walking or standing, paralysis; rash; shortness of breath or difficulty breathing; and swelling of the face or throat. seek medical attention immediately if you develop serious symptoms. fainting can occur after vaccination; tell your provider if you feel dizzy or have vision changes or ringing in the ears. adverse reactions should be reported to the vaccine adverse event reporting system (vaers). your healthcare provider will usually file this report, or you can do it yourself. how can i learn more? call your local or state health department. brand names afluria, fluad, fluarix, flublok, flucelvax, flulaval, fluzone. other names flu vaccine.

name: insulin human inhalation
instructions: important warning: inhaled insulin can reduce lung function and may trigger bronchospasm and breathing difficulties. do not use inhaled insulin if you have asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (copd). your doctor will test your lung function before starting therapy, again at 6 months, and then yearly while you continue treatment. call your doctor right away if you develop wheezing or trouble breathing. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. you will receive a medication guide when you start inhaled insulin and each time you refill; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist any questions, or visit the manufacturer’s website to obtain the medication guide. discuss the risks of inhaled insulin with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? inhaled human insulin is used with a long-acting insulin to treat type 1 diabetes. it is also used with other medications to treat people with type 2 diabetes who need insulin to control their blood sugar. it is not for the treatment of diabetic ketoacidosis. this rapid-acting, man-made insulin replaces the insulin your body normally makes, helps move sugar from the blood into body tissues for energy, and decreases sugar production by the liver. managing diabetes with medications, lifestyle changes (diet, exercise, quitting smoking), and regular blood sugar monitoring helps improve health and may reduce the risk of heart attack, stroke, kidney failure, nerve damage (including numb, cold legs or feet), decreased sexual ability, eye problems (including vision changes or loss), and gum disease. your healthcare team will work with you to choose the best plan. how should this medicine be used? inhaled insulin is a dry powder used only with the inhaler provided. use it at the start of each meal exactly as prescribed. do not use more or less or more often than directed. it controls diabetes but does not cure it; continue using it even if you feel well. do not stop or switch insulin types without talking to your doctor. before first use, read the written instructions and review the diagrams; ask your doctor or pharmacist to show you how to use the inhaler and to answer any questions. cartridges are single-use and must be used only with the supplied inhaler. do not open or swallow the cartridge, and do not attempt to inhale the powder without the device. remove cartridges from the refrigerator and allow them to sit at room temperature for 10 minutes before loading. after inserting a cartridge, keep the inhaler level with the white mouthpiece on top and the purple base on the bottom. if the inhaler is turned upside down, the mouthpiece is pointed down, or the device is shaken or dropped, the dose may be lost; replace the cartridge before using the inhaler. follow your doctor’s instructions for how many cartridges to use each day. when you begin using inhaled insulin, your doctor may adjust the doses of your long-acting insulin and your oral diabetes medicines, and may adjust your inhaled insulin dose over time. do not change the dose of inhaled insulin or any other diabetes medication without medical advice. other uses for this medicine this medicine may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using inhaled insulin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to any insulin (for example, apidra, humulin, lantus, levemir, novolog) or any ingredients in the product; check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use, especially other inhaled medicines. your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. aspirin can interact with insulin; do not start aspirin while using inhaled insulin without discussing it with your healthcare provider. do not use inhaled insulin if you have low blood sugar. tell your doctor if you have an infection; if you smoke; or if you quit smoking within the past 6 months. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had low potassium, lung cancer, diabetic nerve damage, heart failure, kidney disease, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using inhaled insulin, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you use inhaled insulin. ask your doctor how often you should check your blood sugar. low blood sugar can affect your ability to drive or operate machinery; ask if you should check your blood sugar before these activities. alcohol can change blood sugar; ask your doctor about safe use while using inhaled insulin. ask your doctor what to do if you become ill, gain or lose weight, experience unusual stress, travel across time zones, or change your exercise or activity level, as these changes can affect your dosing schedule and insulin needs. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow the exercise and meal plan recommended by your doctor or dietitian. eat a healthy diet and try to consume similar amounts and types of food at consistent times each day. skipping or delaying meals or changing what or how much you eat can disrupt your blood sugar control. what should i do if i forget a dose? when you start inhaled insulin, ask your doctor what to do if you forget to inhale a dose at the correct time and write down those instructions so you can refer to them later. what side effects can this medication cause? this medicine can cause changes in blood sugar; know the symptoms of low and high blood sugar and what to do if they occur. inhaled insulin may cause side effects. common side effects include cough, sore or irritated throat, tiredness, diarrhea, nausea, headache, painful or burning urination, and weight gain. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any serious symptoms or those listed in the important warning section—such as rash, itching, hives, fast heartbeat, sweating, difficulty breathing or swallowing, shortness of breath, swelling of the arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, sudden weight gain, extreme drowsiness, confusion, or dizziness—call your doctor immediately or seek emergency medical care. inhaled insulin may increase the risk of lung cancer; talk with your doctor about this risk. this medication may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using it.

name: oxymetazoline nasal spray
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? oxymetazoline nasal spray relieves nasal discomfort from colds, allergies, and hay fever, and helps reduce sinus congestion and pressure. do not use it in children under 6 years old unless a doctor recommends it. children 6 to 12 years should use it carefully under adult supervision. oxymetazoline is a nasal decongestant that works by narrowing blood vessels in the nasal passages. how should this medicine be used? oxymetazoline is a liquid solution sprayed into the nose. use it every 10 to 12 hours as needed, but no more than twice in a 24-hour period. follow the package or prescription directions exactly. do not use more, more often, or longer than directed. using it too often or for longer than recommended can worsen congestion or cause it to return (rebound). do not use for more than 3 days. if your symptoms do not improve after 3 days, stop using it and call your doctor. for use in the nose only; do not swallow. to prevent spreading infection, do not share your spray dispenser. rinse the tip with hot water or wipe it clean after each use. follow the instructions on the label for proper use. if the product has a pump, prime it before the first dose as directed. to apply, keep your head upright, place the tip in your nostril, and for squeeze bottles press quickly and firmly; for pump sprays, press down with a firm, even stroke while breathing in deeply. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to oxymetazoline or any other medications. tell them if you are taking or have taken within the past 2 weeks a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (maoi) such as isocarboxazid (marplan), phenelzine (nardil), selegiline (eldepryl, emsam, zelapar), or tranylcypromine (parnate). tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are using or plan to use; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had high blood pressure, diabetes, difficulty urinating due to an enlarged prostate, thyroid disease, or heart disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using oxymetazoline, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medication is usually used as needed. if your doctor has told you to use it regularly and you miss a dose, use it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not use a double dose. what side effects can this medication cause? oxymetazoline may cause burning, stinging, increased nasal discharge, dryness inside the nose, sneezing, nervousness, nausea, dizziness, headache, and trouble falling or staying asleep. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor right away if you have a fast or slow heartbeat. oxymetazoline nasal spray may cause other side effects.

name: tolnaftate
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? tolnaftate stops the growth of fungi that cause skin infections, including athlete's foot, jock itch, and ringworm. this medication is sometimes prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? tolnaftate comes as a cream, liquid (solution), powder, gel, spray powder, and spray liquid for application to the skin. it is usually applied twice a day. follow the directions on the package or on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain any part you do not understand. use tolnaftate exactly as directed. do not use more or less of it or use it more often than directed by your doctor. the burning and soreness of athlete's foot or the itching of jock itch should decrease within 2 to 3 days. continue treatment for at least 2 weeks after symptoms disappear. a total of 4 to 6 weeks of treatment may be necessary. thoroughly clean the infected area, allow it to dry, and then gently rub a thin layer of medication in until most of it disappears, using just enough to cover the affected area. wash your hands after applying the medication. spray and powder forms should be applied between the toes; socks and shoes should be treated lightly. shake sprays well before each use and spray from a distance of at least 6 inches. what special precautions should i follow? before using tolnaftate, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to tolnaftate or any other drugs. tell your doctor and pharmacist what prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. if you become pregnant while using tolnaftate, call your doctor. for external use only; avoid contact with the eyes, mouth, nose, and genital areas, and do not apply to broken or severely irritated skin. keep spray products away from heat or flame and keep out of the reach of children. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are needed while using tolnaftate unless your doctor gives you other directions. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember it. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not apply a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? tolnaftate may cause side effects. if you experience the following symptom, call your doctor: skin irritation.

name: diphenhydramine topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? diphenhydramine topical is used to relieve itching from insect bites, sunburns, bee stings, poison ivy, poison oak, and minor skin irritation. it is an antihistamine that works by blocking histamine, a substance in the body that causes allergic symptoms. how should this medicine be used? diphenhydramine topical comes as a cream, lotion, gel, and spray to be applied to the skin up to three or four times a day. clean and dry the affected area, then apply a thin layer—just enough to cover it. do not use on large areas of the body, and wash your hands after applying. use exactly as directed; do not use more, less, or more often than prescribed. do not use on a child younger than 2 years of age unless directed by a doctor. talk to your doctor before using this medication to treat chickenpox or measles. contact your doctor if symptoms worsen, last more than 7 days, or improve and then return within a few days. what special precautions should i follow? before using diphenhydramine, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this drug, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe the symptoms you had. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using diphenhydramine, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not apply extra medication to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? diphenhydramine topical may cause side effects. if side effects are severe or do not go away, call your doctor. rash may occur.

name: agalsidase beta
instructions: important warning: agalsidase beta has been associated with hypersensitivity reactions, including severe allergic reactions (anaphylaxis), and may cause infusion-related reactions during the infusion and within 24 hours afterward. you will be monitored very closely during each infusion. tell your healthcare provider immediately or seek emergency medical care if you experience any of the following: headache; nausea; vomiting; diarrhea; stomach pain; swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat; rash; hives; itching; fever; chills; dizziness; weakness; difficulty breathing; fast or irregular heartbeat; or chest pain. your medicine will be given in a hospital or clinic, where you will be observed closely. your doctor may give you medicines before each infusion to reduce the chance of these reactions occurring. why is this medication prescribed?
