agalsidase beta injection is used to treat fabry disease, an inherited condition in which a type of fatty substance builds up in the body, causing nerve and organ damage in adults and in children 2 years of age and older. agalsidase beta is an enzyme replacement therapy that substitutes for the enzyme normally produced by the body to help prevent buildup of this fatty substance. how should this medicine be used? agalsidase beta comes as a powder that is mixed with a liquid and infused intravenously into a vein by a healthcare professional in a hospital or clinic. it is usually infused slowly over at least 90 minutes once every 2 weeks. serious allergic and infusion-related reactions can occur during an infusion and for 24 hours afterward. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving agalsidase beta, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to agalsidase beta, any other medications, or any of the ingredients in the injection; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had heart or kidney problems. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while receiving agalsidase beta, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment to receive a dose of agalsidase beta, call your doctor right away. what side effects can this medication cause? agalsidase beta may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: cough; sore throat; runny nose; other signs of infection; fatigue; back pain; ringing in the ears; hearing loss; repeatedly picking or scratching the skin; anxiety; depression; hot flashes; or falls. agalsidase beta may cause other side effects. if the person has collapsed, had a seizure, has trouble breathing, or cannot be awakened, call emergency services at 911 immediately. what other information should i know? keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. keep a written list of all the prescription and nonprescription (over-the-counter) medicines, vitamins, minerals, and dietary supplements you are taking. bring this list to each doctor visit or if you are admitted to the hospital, and carry it with you in case of emergencies. brand names: fabrazyme.

name: vamorolone
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? vamorolone is used to treat duchenne muscular dystrophy (dmd), a progressive muscle disease, in adults and in children 2 years of age and older. vamorolone is a corticosteroid that works by reducing inflammation and altering immune system activity. how should this medicine be used? vamorolone comes as an oral suspension (liquid) to take by mouth. it is usually taken once daily with a meal at about the same time each day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. take vamorolone exactly as prescribed; do not take more or less or take it more often than directed. shake the suspension well for about 30 seconds before each dose. measure the dose only with the oral syringe provided. your doctor may adjust your dose based on how well the medicine works for you, and may change your dose if you experience unusual physical stress (such as surgery, illness, or infection) or other changes in your health, or if your symptoms improve or worsen. do not stop taking vamorolone without talking to your doctor. stopping suddenly may cause loss of appetite, upset stomach, vomiting, drowsiness, confusion, headache, fever, joint and muscle pain, peeling skin, and weight loss. your doctor will reduce your dose gradually to allow your body to adjust. watch for these symptoms while tapering and after stopping; if they occur, call your doctor immediately. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking vamorolone, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to vamorolone, any other medications, or any ingredients in the oral suspension. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you for side effects. nonprescription or herbal products that may interact include aspirin or other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin) and naproxen (aleve, naprosyn). tell your doctor and pharmacist if you take these before starting vamorolone, and do not start them while taking vamorolone without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had hepatitis b (hbv); a herpes eye infection; cataracts; glaucoma; high blood pressure; heart failure; a recent heart attack; diabetes; emotional problems, depression, or other mental illness; myasthenia gravis; osteoporosis; pheochromocytoma; ulcers; diverticulitis; any surgery on your stomach or intestines or any other gastrointestinal problem; blood clots in your legs, lungs, or eyes; or liver, kidney, heart, adrenal, or thyroid disease. also tell your doctor if you have any untreated bacterial, fungal, parasitic, or viral infection anywhere in your body. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. if you become pregnant while taking vamorolone, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking vamorolone. ask your doctor whether you need any vaccinations. it is important to be up to date on age-appropriate vaccines before starting treatment. do not receive any vaccinations during treatment without talking to your doctor. you should know that vamorolone may reduce your ability to fight infections and may mask infection symptoms. avoid people who are sick and wash your hands often. avoid people with chickenpox or measles. if you think you were exposed to chickenpox or measles, call your doctor immediately. what special dietary instructions should i follow? talk to your doctor about eating grapefruit or drinking grapefruit juice while taking this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember it. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? vamorolone may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: headache, vomiting, diarrhea, increased appetite, runny nose, difficulty falling or staying asleep. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have sore throat, fever, chills, cough, or other signs of infection; rash; hives; itching; swelling of the face, eyes, lips, or throat; trouble swallowing or breathing; confusion; extreme mood changes; personality changes; inappropriate happiness; depression; changes in weight (gain or loss); stomach pain; shortness of breath; sudden weight gain; swelling of the feet, ankles, or lower legs; or changes in vision. vamorolone may slow growth and development in children; your child’s doctor will monitor growth. long-term use may cause glaucoma or cataracts; ask your doctor about the risks and how often you should have eye exams. vamorolone may increase the risk of osteoporosis. vamorolone may cause other side effects.

name: aspirin and extended-release dipyridamole
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? the aspirin and extended-release dipyridamole combination is an antiplatelet medicine that helps prevent excessive blood clotting. it is used to lower the risk of stroke in people who have had a stroke or are at increased risk of one. how should this medicine be used? this medicine comes as an oral capsule. take one capsule twice daily—one in the morning and one in the evening. swallow the capsules whole; do not open, crush, break, or chew them. follow your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. take it exactly as directed; do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. this medicine reduces but does not eliminate your risk of stroke. continue taking it even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking this medicine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to aspirin; dipyridamole; any salicylate or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (nsaid), including celecoxib (celebrex), choline salicylate (arthropan), diclofenac (cataflam), diflunisal (dolobid), etodolac (lodine), fenoprofen (nalfon), flurbiprofen (ansaid), ibuprofen (advil, motrin, nuprin), indomethacin (indocin), ketoprofen (orudis, oruvail), ketorolac (toradol), magnesium salicylate (nuprin backache, doan’s), meclofenamate, mefenamic acid (ponstel), meloxicam (mobic), nabumetone (relafen), naproxen (aleve, naprosyn), oxaprozin (daypro), piroxicam (feldene), rofecoxib (vioxx—no longer available in the us), sulindac (clinoril), or tolmetin (tolectin), or if you are allergic to any other medicines. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. be sure to mention: acetazolamide (diamox); ambenonium (mytelase); ace inhibitors such as benazepril (lotensin), captopril (capoten), enalapril (vasotec), fosinopril (monopril), lisinopril (prinivil, zestril), moexipril (univasc), quinapril (accupril), ramipril (altace), and trandolapril (mavik); anticoagulants (blood thinners) such as warfarin (coumadin) and heparin; beta-blockers such as acebutolol (sectral), atenolol (tenormin), betaxolol (kerlone), bisoprolol (zebeta), carteolol (cartrol), carvedilol (coreg), labetalol (normodyne), metoprolol (lopressor), nadolol (corgard), penbutolol (levatol), pindolol (visken), propranolol (inderal), sotalol (betapace), and timolol (blocadren); diabetes medicines such as acetohexamide (dymelor), chlorpropamide (diabinese), glimepiride (amaryl), glipizide (glucotrol), glyburide (diabeta, micronase, glynase), repaglinide (prandin), tolazamide (tolinase), and tolbutamide (orinase); diuretics (water pills) such as amiloride (midamor), bumetanide (bumex), chlorothiazide (diuril), chlorthalidone (hygroton), ethacrynic acid (edecrin), furosemide (lasix), hydrochlorothiazide (hydrodiuril), indapamide (lozol), metolazone (zaroxolyn), spironolactone (aldactone), torsemide (demadex), and triamterene (dyrenium); methotrexate (folex, mexate, rheumatrex); neostigmine (prostigmin); nsaids (see list above); phenytoin (dilantin); probenecid (benemid); pyridostigmine (mestinon); sulfinpyrazone (anturane); and valproic acid and related drugs (depakene, depakote). tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver, kidney, or heart disease; a recent heart attack; a bleeding disorder; low blood pressure; vitamin k deficiency; stomach or intestinal ulcers; the syndrome of asthma, rhinitis, and nasal polyps; or if you regularly drink three or more alcoholic beverages a day. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor. aspirin may harm the fetus and cause problems with delivery if taken around 20 weeks of pregnancy or later. do not take aspirin and extended-release dipyridamole at or after 20 weeks of pregnancy unless your doctor tells you to. call your doctor if you become pregnant while taking this medicine. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, tell the doctor or dentist that you take this medication; your doctor may tell you to stop it before surgery. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your normal diet while taking this medicine. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? side effects can occur. common ones that may be bothersome or persistent include headache, heartburn, stomach pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, muscle and joint pain, and tiredness. call your doctor right away if you have any of the following: bleeding; severe rash; swelling of the lips, tongue, or mouth; difficulty breathing; a warm feeling, flushing, sweating, restlessness, weakness, or dizziness; chest pain; rapid heartbeat; or ringing in the ears.

name: anagrelide
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? anagrelide is prescribed to reduce the number of platelets—blood cells needed for clotting—in people with bone marrow disorders that produce too many blood cells, such as essential thrombocythemia (too many platelets) or polycythemia vera (too many red blood cells and sometimes platelets). it is a platelet-reducing agent that works by slowing platelet production. how should this medicine be used? anagrelide is taken by mouth as a capsule, with or without food, usually two to four times daily. take it at the same times each day. follow your prescription exactly; do not take more, less, or more often than directed. your doctor will typically start with a low dose and increase it gradually, no more than once a week, based on your response. your dose may be adjusted during treatment. anagrelide controls the condition but does not cure it; continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop without consulting your doctor, as stopping suddenly can raise your platelet count and cause symptoms. other uses for this medicine this medication may be used for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking anagrelide, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to anagrelide or any other medications. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. nonprescription products that may interact include aspirin, nsaids (such as ibuprofen [advil, motrin] and naproxen [aleve, naprosyn]), and cimetidine (tagamet); inform your healthcare providers if you take these and do not start them while on anagrelide without medical advice. tell your doctor if you have or have had bleeding problems; high or low blood pressure; lactose intolerance; or heart, kidney, or liver disease. do not take anagrelide if you are pregnant or planning pregnancy. use effective birth control during treatment; if you become pregnant, call your doctor immediately. do not breast-feed while taking anagrelide. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, tell the clinician you are taking anagrelide. anagrelide may cause dizziness, especially when starting treatment; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. it may cause dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting when you rise quickly; to reduce this, get up slowly and rest your feet on the floor before standing. it may also increase sensitivity to sunlight; avoid unnecessary or prolonged sun exposure and wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor about eating grapefruit or drinking grapefruit juice while taking this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? anagrelide may cause side effects. common side effects include headache; gas; nausea; vomiting; diarrhea; constipation; stomach pain; heartburn; belching; loss of appetite; runny nose; nosebleeds; sore throat; mouth sores; dizziness; depression; nervousness; forgetfulness; confusion; trouble falling or staying asleep; low energy or sleepiness; weakness; muscle, joint, or back pain; leg cramps; hair loss; fever; flu-like symptoms; painful urination; ringing in the ears; and itching. call your doctor immediately if you experience rash; hives; unusual bleeding or bruising; blood in the urine or stool; black or tarry stools; chest pain; a fluttering sensation in the chest; fast, forceful, or irregular heartbeat; swelling of the arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; difficulty breathing; cough; slow or difficult speech; fainting; weakness or numbness of an arm or leg; pain, burning, or tingling in the hands or feet; seizure; or changes in vision.

name: erenumab-aooe injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? erenumab-aooe injection is used to help prevent migraine headaches, which are severe, throbbing headaches that may cause nausea and sensitivity to light or sound. erenumab-aooe is a monoclonal antibody that works by blocking the action of a natural substance in the body that can trigger migraine headaches. how should this medicine be used? erenumab-aooe injection is supplied as a liquid solution in a prefilled syringe or a prefilled autoinjector for subcutaneous injection under the skin. it is given once each month, on or about the same day every month. use erenumab-aooe exactly as directed. do not use more or less than prescribed and do not use it more often than instructed by your doctor. you may be able to inject the medication yourself at home or have a caregiver give the injections. ask your doctor to show you or your caregiver how to inject the medication. use each syringe or autoinjector only once and inject all of the solution in the device. dispose of used syringes and devices in a puncture resistant container and ask your doctor or pharmacist how to dispose of the full container. remove the syringe or autoinjector from the refrigerator and place it on a flat surface away from direct sunlight. do not remove the needle cover or device cap while it warms. allow it to reach room temperature for 30 minutes before injecting. do not try to warm the medication with a microwave, hot water, sunlight, or any other heating method. do not shake a prefilled syringe or autoinjector that contains erenumab-aooe. do not use it if it has been dropped. always inspect the medication before injecting. the liquid should be clear and colorless. do not use the syringe or device if it is damaged, expired, frozen, or if the liquid is colored, cloudy, or contains flakes or particles. inject into the thigh or stomach abdomen area. if a caregiver is giving the injection, it may also be given in the upper arm. do not inject into skin that is tender, thick, bruised, red, scaly, hard, or has scars or stretch marks. erenumab-aooe helps prevent migraines but does not cure them. continue monthly injections even if you feel well. do not stop using erenumab-aooe without talking to your doctor. ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturers information for patients. what special precautions should i follow? before using erenumab-aooe, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to this medication, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe any allergic symptoms you have had. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take, because your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had high blood pressure or circulation problems in your fingers or toes such as raynaud disease fingers and toes may feel numb and turn white or blue with cold or stress. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using erenumab-aooe, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, inject it as soon as you remember, then continue with monthly dosing from the date you last injected. what side effects can this medication cause? erenumab-aooe may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: pain, redness, swelling, or itching at the injection site; constipation; cramps; muscle spasms; mouth sores; hair loss. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or get emergency medical help if you have any of the following: rash; hives; itching; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes; trouble swallowing or breathing; constipation with persistent stomach pain or tenderness, vomiting, or stomach bloating; numb, cold, painful, or discolored fingers or toes. erenumab-aooe may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: budesonide and albuterol oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? the combination of budesonide and albuterol is used in adults to prevent and treat breathing problems such as wheezing, shortness of breath, coughing, and chest tightness. budesonide is a corticosteroid that reduces swelling in the airways. albuterol is a bronchodilator that relaxes and opens the air passages in the lungs to make breathing easier. how should this medicine be used? budesonide and albuterol comes as an oral inhalation aerosol to be inhaled by mouth using an inhaler. the usual dose is 2 puffs as needed to prevent or relieve symptoms. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. use exactly as directed. do not use more or less than prescribed, and do not use it more often than directed. do not use more than 12 puffs in 24 hours. this medicine controls asthma symptoms but does not cure them. do not stop using it without talking to your doctor. before first use, read the manufacturer instructions that come with the inhaler. ask your doctor, pharmacist, or respiratory therapist to show you the correct technique and practice in their presence. discontinue use of the device and throw it away when the dose counter shows 0. to use the inhaler: 1) remove the protective cap from the mouthpiece and check the mouthpiece for dirt or objects. make sure the canister is fully and firmly inserted. 2) prime the inhaler if you are using it for the first time or if it has not been used for more than 7 days: shake well and press down on the canister 4 times to release 4 test sprays into the air, away from your face. re-prime with 2 test sprays if the inhaler has been dropped or cleaned. avoid spraying into the eyes. shake before each test spray. 3) shake the inhaler well before each use. 4) breathe out as completely as possible through your mouth. 5) hold the inhaler upright with the mouthpiece on the bottom facing you and the canister pointing upward. place the open end of the mouthpiece into your mouth and close your lips tightly around it. 6) begin to inhale slowly and deeply through your mouth, and at the same time press down once on the canister to release the medication. 7) when you have inhaled fully, remove the inhaler from your mouth, close your mouth, and hold your breath for about 10 seconds, then breathe out gently. 8) if 2 puffs are needed, repeat steps 3 through 7 right away. 9) replace the protective cap. 10) rinse your mouth with water and spit the water out; do not swallow. clean the inhaler once a week according to the manufacturer instructions; ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer patient information. what special precautions should i follow? before using budesonide and albuterol oral inhalation, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to budesonide (pulmicort, rhinocort, in symbicort), albuterol (proair, proventil, ventolin), any other medications, or any ingredients in this inhaler; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you or a family member has or has ever had osteoporosis, and if you have or have ever had an irregular heartbeat, heart disease, high blood pressure, low potassium levels, hyperthyroidism, diabetes, seizures, tuberculosis or exposure to tb, cataracts, glaucoma or high eye pressure, or liver disease. also tell your doctor if you have any untreated infection anywhere in your body or a herpes eye infection; if you smoke or use tobacco; or if you are on bedrest or unable to move around. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using this medicine, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you use this medicine. if you have never had chickenpox or measles and are not vaccinated, avoid people who are sick, especially those with chickenpox or measles. if you are exposed or develop symptoms, call your doctor right away. you should know that budesonide and albuterol inhalation can sometimes cause wheezing or trouble breathing immediately after use. if this happens, call your doctor right away and do not use the inhaler again unless your doctor tells you to do so. avoid getting the spray in your eyes. rinse your mouth after each use to lower the risk of oral thrush. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is usually used as needed for symptoms, so there may be no scheduled dose to make up. if your doctor has told you to use it on a schedule and you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. do not take extra puffs to make up for a missed dose, and do not exceed 12 puffs in 24 hours. what side effects can this medication cause? budesonide and albuterol may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: headache, cough, white patches in the mouth, hoarseness. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have: increased difficulty breathing; fast, pounding, or irregular heartbeat; chest pain; rash, hives, or itching; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; trouble swallowing; fever, chills, or other signs of infection; tiredness; nausea; vomiting; weakness; or changes in vision. with long-term use of budesonide, glaucoma or cataracts have occurred rarely; ask your doctor about the risks and how often your eyes should be examined during treatment. this medicine may increase the risk of osteoporosis. budesonide and albuterol may cause growth retardation in children; this product should not be used in children. this medicine may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using it.

name: fremanezumab-vfrm injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? fremanezumab-vfrm injection is used to help prevent migraine headaches, which are severe, throbbing headaches that may cause nausea and sensitivity to light or sound. it is a monoclonal antibody that works by blocking a natural substance involved in migraine attacks. how should this medicine be used? fremanezumab-vfrm injection is a liquid solution in a prefilled syringe or autoinjector for subcutaneous injection under the skin. it is given either once each month as 1 injection or once every 3 months as 3 separate injections given one right after the other. use it on about the same day every 1 or 3 months, depending on your regimen. use exactly as directed. do not use more or less or more often than prescribed. you may inject it yourself at home or have a caregiver do so; get training from your health care provider. before injecting, remove the syringe or autoinjector from the refrigerator, place it on a flat surface away from direct sunlight, and allow it to reach room temperature for 30 minutes. do not remove the needle or device cap until you are ready to inject. do not warm the medication using a microwave, hot water, sunlight, or any other method. use each syringe or autoinjector only once and inject all the solution in the device. dispose of used syringes or devices in a puncture resistant container; ask your health care provider how to dispose of the container. inject into the thigh, upper arm, or abdomen. do not inject into skin that is tender, thick, bruised, red, scaly, hard, or scarred, or that has stretch marks. inspect the solution before use; it should be clear and colorless. do not use if it is colored, cloudy, or contains flakes or particles. do not shake. if instructed to give three injections one after another, use a new syringe or autoinjector for each injection and, if using the same body area, choose a different exact spot each time. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer patient information. what special precautions should i follow? before using fremanezumab-vfrm injection, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this drug, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances; describe what symptoms you had. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had high blood pressure or circulation problems in your fingers or toes, such as raynaud disease, in which fingers or toes feel numb or cold, are painful, and may turn white or blue with cold temperatures or stress. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using fremanezumab-vfrm injection, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, inject it as soon as you remember. then continue your dosing schedule from the date of your last dose. what side effects can this medication cause? fremanezumab-vfrm injection may cause side effects. common effects include pain, swelling, or redness at the injection site. some side effects can be serious and may occur up to 1 month after an injection. call your doctor right away or get emergency medical help if you have hives, itching, flushing of the face, trouble breathing, or swelling of your face, mouth, tongue, or throat; or if your fingers or toes become numb, cold, painful, or discolored. this medication may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using it.

name: prednisolone ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ophthalmic prednisolone reduces irritation, redness, burning, and swelling from eye inflammation caused by chemicals, heat, radiation, infection, allergy, or foreign material in the eye. it is also sometimes used after eye surgery. prednisolone is a corticosteroid that lessens swelling and redness by modifying immune activity. how should this medicine be used? ophthalmic prednisolone comes as a solution or suspension (eye drops) to instill in the eye and as an eye ointment to apply to the eye. follow your prescription label exactly. do not use more, use less, or use it more often than directed. continue using it even if you feel better; do not stop without talking to your doctor. to use the eye drops: 1) wash your hands with soap and water. 2) check the label to see if the bottle should be shaken; shake well if directed. 3) inspect the dropper tip; do not use if chipped or cracked. 4) do not touch the dropper tip to your eye or any surface. 5) tilt your head back and pull down the lower eyelid to form a pocket. 6) hold the dropper above the eye without touching it, brace your hand, look up, and squeeze one drop into the pocket. 7) release the lower lid, close your eye for 2–3 minutes, tip your head downward as if looking at the floor, and avoid blinking or squeezing. 8) apply gentle pressure with a finger to the tear duct. 9) wipe excess liquid from your face with a tissue. 10) if more than one drop is prescribed for the same eye, wait at least 5 minutes before the next drop. 11) replace and tighten the cap; do not wipe or rinse the tip. 12) wash your hands to remove any medication. to apply the eye ointment: 1) wash your hands. 2) use a mirror or have someone assist you. 3) do not touch the tube tip to your eye or any surface. 4) tilt your head forward slightly. 5) hold the tube close to the eyelid without touching it and brace your hand. 6) with the other hand, pull the lower lid down to form a pocket. 7) squeeze a small amount of ointment into the pocket (about a 1/2‑inch [1.25 cm] strip unless your doctor instructs otherwise). 8) gently close your eyes and keep them closed for 1–2 minutes to allow absorption. 9) replace and tighten the cap right away. 10) wipe off any excess ointment with a clean tissue and wash your hands again. your vision may be blurry briefly after using the ointment; wait until your vision clears before driving or doing tasks that require clear vision. other uses for this medicine this medication may sometimes be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using prednisolone eye drops or ointment, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to prednisolone or any other medicines; provide a list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; tell your doctor if you have or have ever had glaucoma or diabetes; and tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using prednisolone eye drops or ointment, call your doctor immediately. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are needed with ophthalmic prednisolone unless your doctor gives you specific advice; continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? instill or apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. take any remaining doses that day at evenly spaced intervals. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and use only the next regularly scheduled dose. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? prednisolone eye drops and eye ointment may cause side effects. if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: temporary eye burning or stinging, temporary blurred vision. some side effects can be serious. if you experience eye pain, call your doctor immediately.

name: sulfacetamide ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ophthalmic sulfacetamide is a topical antibiotic that stops the growth of bacteria that cause certain eye infections. it is used to treat bacterial eye infections and to help prevent infection after eye injuries. how should this medicine be used? ophthalmic sulfacetamide comes as an eye drop solution and as an eye ointment. in general, the drops are used every 2 to 3 hours during the day and less often at night; the ointment is usually applied four times daily and at bedtime. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully. use exactly as directed. do not use more, less, or more often than prescribed. to instill the eye drops: 1) wash your hands with soap and water. 2) check the dropper tip to be sure it is not chipped or cracked. 3) do not let the tip touch your eye or any surface; keep the bottle and tip clean. 4) tilt your head back and pull down the lower eyelid to form a pocket. 5) hold the dropper close to the eye without touching it and brace your hand. 6) while looking up, gently squeeze one drop into the pocket. 7) release the eyelid, close your eye for 2 to 3 minutes, and tip your head down as if looking at the floor; try not to blink or squeeze your eyelids. 8) place a finger over the tear duct at the inner corner of the eye and apply gentle pressure. 9) wipe away any excess liquid with a tissue. 10) if more than one drop is prescribed for the same eye, wait at least 5 minutes before the next drop. 11) replace and tighten the cap on the bottle; do not wipe or rinse the dropper tip. 12) wash your hands. to apply the eye ointment: 1) wash your hands. 2) do not let the tube tip touch your eye or any surface; keep the tip clean. 3) hold the tube near your eyelid without touching it and brace your hand. 4) tilt your head back slightly and pull down the lower eyelid to form a pocket. 5) squeeze a 1/4 to 1/2 inch (0.6 to 1.25 centimeter) ribbon of ointment into the pocket. 6) release the eyelid, blink slowly, then gently close your eye for 1 to 2 minutes. 7) wipe excess ointment from the eyelids and lashes with a tissue. 8) wipe the tube tip with a clean tissue, replace and tighten the cap, and wash your hands. other uses for this medicine this medication may sometimes be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using sulfacetamide eye drops or ointment, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to sulfacetamide, other sulfa drugs, sulfites, or any other medicines. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using sulfacetamide, call your doctor right away. you should know that the ointment can blur vision; avoid rubbing your eyes. do not drive or operate machinery until you can see clearly. if you wear soft contact lenses and the product you use contains benzalkonium chloride, remove the lenses and wait at least 15 minutes after using the medicine before reinserting them. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember it. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? sulfacetamide may cause side effects. a common effect is brief stinging or burning of the eye. contact your doctor if you have increased redness, itching, or swelling of the eye that persists for more than 48 hours or worsens.

name: tobramycin ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ophthalmic tobramycin is prescribed to treat bacterial eye infections. it is an antibiotic that works by killing the bacteria causing the infection. how should this medicine be used? tobramycin ophthalmic comes as eye drops (solution) and an eye ointment. the drops are usually applied every 4 to 8 hours, and the ointment is usually applied two to four times daily. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not use more, less, or more often than prescribed. to use the eye drops: wash hands with soap and water; check the dropper tip to ensure it isn’t damaged; avoid touching the tip to your eye or any surface; tilt your head back and pull down the lower eyelid to create a pocket; hold the dropper close without touching the eye and brace your hand; look up and squeeze one drop into the pocket; release the lid; close your eye for 2 to 3 minutes and tip your head down as if looking at the floor; try not to blink; press a finger gently on the tear duct at the inner corner; wipe excess liquid with a tissue; if more than one drop is prescribed, wait at least 5 minutes before the next drop; replace and tighten the cap without wiping or rinsing the tip; wash your hands. to use the eye ointment: wash hands; use a mirror or have someone help; do not touch the tube tip to your eye or any surface; tilt your head slightly forward; hold the tube close to the eyelid without touching; brace your hand; pull the lower lid down to make a pocket; apply about a 1/2‑inch (1.25‑cm) ribbon of ointment unless your doctor directs otherwise; look downward, then gently close your eyes for 1 to 2 minutes to allow absorption; recap right away; wipe excess ointment from lids and lashes with a clean tissue; wash your hands. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to tobramycin, other antibiotics, or any medications. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, discuss this with your doctor; if you become pregnant while using this medicine, call your doctor. your vision may be blurred with the ointment—avoid rubbing your eyes and do not drive or operate machinery until you can see clearly. if you wear soft contact lenses, do not wear contact lenses while you have any eye infection. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? tobramycin eye drops or ointment may cause eye tearing; itching, stinging, or burning of the eye; swelling of the eye; and temporary blurred vision with the ointment. if these effects are severe or do not go away, contact your doctor.

name: levobunolol ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? levobunolol ophthalmic solution is used to lower high pressure inside the eye in glaucoma, helping to prevent gradual vision loss. it is a beta blocker that reduces intraocular pressure. how should this medicine be used? levobunolol comes as an eye drop solution. it is usually used once or twice daily. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. use only as directed; do not use more or less or more often than prescribed. levobunolol controls glaucoma but does not cure it, so keep using it even if you feel well and do not stop without talking to your doctor. to put in the drops: wash your hands with soap and water; check the dropper tip to be sure it is not cracked or chipped; do not let the tip touch your eye or any surface; tilt your head back and pull down the lower eyelid to create a pocket; hold the dropper close to the eye without touching it and brace your hand; look up and gently squeeze out one drop into the pocket; release the eyelid; close your eye for 2 to 3 minutes and tip your head down as if looking at the floor; try not to blink or squeeze your eyelids; press a finger gently on the tear duct; wipe away excess fluid; if more than one drop is prescribed in the same eye, wait at least 5 minutes before the next drop; replace and tighten the cap; do not wipe or rinse the dropper tip; wash your hands after use. other uses for this medicine levobunolol may sometimes be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for details. what special precautions should i follow? before using levobunolol eye drops, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to levobunolol, other beta blockers, sulfites, or any medication. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take, as your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. inform your doctor if you have or have ever had thyroid disease, heart or lung disease, congestive heart failure, or diabetes. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while using levobunolol, call your doctor. if you are having any surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you use levobunolol eye drops. if you use another topical eye medication, instill it at least 10 minutes before or after levobunolol. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are required unless your doctor gives you other instructions. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? levobunolol eye drops may cause side effects. contact your doctor if these are severe or do not go away: stinging or burning, eye discomfort, redness or itching, swelling of the eyelids, or decreased vision. some side effects can be serious. stop using the drops and call your doctor right away if you have difficulty breathing, wheezing, a slow or irregular heartbeat, faintness, swelling of the feet or legs, or sudden weight gain.

name: niraparib and abiraterone
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? niraparib and abiraterone is used with prednisone to treat a certain type of prostate cancer that has already been treated with other medications and has spread to other parts of the body. niraparib is a poly adp-ribose polymerase (parp) inhibitor that works by killing cancer cells. abiraterone is an androgen biosynthesis inhibitor that works by decreasing the amount of certain hormones in the body. this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? niraparib and abiraterone comes as a tablet to take by mouth. take it on an empty stomach once a day, at least 1 hour before or 2 hours after a meal, for as long as your doctor recommends. take it at about the same time every day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. take niraparib and abiraterone exactly as directed. do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed. swallow the tablets whole with water; do not split, chew, or crush them. continue to take niraparib and abiraterone even if you feel well. do not stop taking niraparib and abiraterone or prednisone without talking to your doctor. your doctor may stop, delay, or decrease your dose if you experience certain severe side effects. be sure to tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer’s patient information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking niraparib and abiraterone, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to niraparib, abiraterone, any other medications, or any of the ingredients in the tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of the ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. st. john’s wort may interact with niraparib and abiraterone. do not start, stop, or change any medications, including herbal products such as st. john’s wort, while taking niraparib and abiraterone without discussing this with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have an infection, a low level of potassium in your blood, are experiencing unusual stress, or have had a recent heart attack. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had adrenal problems such as cushing’s syndrome or addison’s disease, adrenal or pituitary tumors, diabetes, heart failure, an irregular heartbeat including qt prolongation (an irregular heart rhythm that can lead to fainting, loss of consciousness, seizures, or sudden death), high blood pressure, or heart, kidney, or liver disease. you should know that niraparib and abiraterone is only for use in men. women should not take this medication, especially if they are or may become pregnant or are breastfeeding. if taken by pregnant women, this medication may harm the fetus. women who are, could become, or may be pregnant should not touch the tablets without protective gloves. if a pregnant woman takes or touches the tablets, she should call her doctor immediately. men taking abiraterone must use effective contraception during treatment and for 4 months after the final dose when having sexual activity with a female partner. talk to your doctor about the types of birth control that are right for you. you should know that this medication may decrease fertility in men. talk to your doctor about the risks of taking niraparib and abiraterone. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking niraparib and abiraterone. you should know that this medication may increase blood glucose. if you have diabetes or high blood sugar, check your blood sugar as often as directed by your doctor. if your blood sugar is higher than usual, call your doctor. call your doctor immediately if you have any of the following symptoms while taking niraparib and abiraterone: headache, drowsiness, dizziness, feeling jittery, extreme hunger, irritability, fast heartbeat, sweating, confusion, or weakness. your doctor may need to change your diet or medication to help control your blood sugar while you are taking this medication. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember it on the same day. however, if it is the next day, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? niraparib and abiraterone may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: muscle or bone pain; difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep; nausea; vomiting; constipation; loss of appetite; rash. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of these symptoms, or those listed in the special precautions section, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment: pale skin; shortness of breath; weakness; tiredness; weight loss; bruising or bleeding easily; blood in urine or stool; burning feeling when you urinate; frequent or urgent need to urinate; fever, cough, runny nose, or other signs of infection; dizziness; feeling faint or lightheaded; headache; confusion; fast or irregular heartbeats; muscle weakness; leg pain; swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; lack of energy; nausea; vomiting; loss of appetite; pain in the upper right part of the stomach; yellowing of the skin or eyes; bone fracture; headache, vision changes, confusion, or seizure. niraparib and abiraterone may increase the risk that you will develop other cancers. talk to your doctor about this risk. niraparib and abiraterone may cause other side effects.

name: trifarotene topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? trifarotene topical is used to treat acne in adults and in children 9 years of age and older. it belongs to a class of medications called retinoids. it works by increasing skin cell turnover, promoting gentle peeling of affected areas, unclogging pores, and helping prevent new pimples from forming under the skin. how should this medicine be used? trifarotene comes as a cream to apply to the skin. it is usually applied once daily at bedtime. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. use trifarotene exactly as directed. do not use more or less of it or use it more often than prescribed. trifarotene cream is only for use on the skin of the face forehead, nose, each cheek, and chin or the upper trunk upper back, shoulders, and chest. do not allow the medication to get into your eyes, ears, mouth, corners of your nose, or the vaginal area. do not apply to areas of sunburn, cuts, abrasions, or eczema. the cream comes in a pump bottle with instructions for use; read and follow them carefully. gently clean the affected area and pat it dry before application. apply a thin layer to the affected skin on the face, chest, shoulders, or back. ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have any questions about how to use trifarotene cream. do not use trifarotene cream along with nonmedicated or medicated cosmetics, abrasive products, or alcohol based cleansers and products for example shaving lotions, astringents, and perfumes. your skin may become dry or irritated during the first 4 weeks of treatment. if your skin stings, burns, or becomes irritated at any time, talk to your doctor. your doctor may recommend a moisturizer to help with dryness or may tell you to apply it less often. ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer information for patients. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using trifarotene, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to trifarotene, to any other medications, or to any of the ingredients in the cream. ask your pharmacist for a list of the ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had eczema or other skin disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using trifarotene, call your doctor. if you are breastfeeding while using trifarotene, apply the smallest amount needed and do not apply it directly to the nipple or the areola the colored area around each nipple. plan to avoid unnecessary or prolonged exposure to sunlight or ultraviolet light tanning beds and sunlamps and wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen with an spf of 15 or higher. trifarotene may make your skin sensitive to sunlight or ultraviolet light. do not use hot wax to remove unwanted hair from areas you are treating with trifarotene during your treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not apply extra cream to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? trifarotene may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: dryness, pain, burning, stinging, peeling, redness, itching, or flaky skin at the treatment area. trifarotene may cause other side effects.

name: cyclopentolate ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cyclopentolate ophthalmic is used to dilate the pupil (mydriasis) and temporarily paralyze the ciliary muscle (cycloplegia) before an eye exam. it is a mydriatic that blocks specific eye receptors to briefly relax or paralyze eye muscles. how should this medicine be used? cyclopentolate is an eye drop solution given just before an eye examination, usually by your healthcare provider. it may take about 30 minutes or longer to reach full effect. the effects generally last up to 24 hours, but can persist for several days in some people. individuals with darker irises may need higher doses. if used in children, observe them closely for at least 30 minutes after dosing; do not feed infants for 4 hours after administration. for ophthalmic use only—do not swallow. avoid touching the dropper tip to the eye, fingers, face, or any surface. if contamination occurs, germs can enter the bottle. to instill the drops: 1) wash hands with soap and water; 2) tilt head back and pull down the lower eyelid to form a pocket; 3) hold the dropper close to the eye without touching it and brace your hand; 4) while looking up, gently squeeze drops into the lower-lid pocket; 5) release the lower eyelid; 6) close the eye and tilt the head downward as if looking at the floor; 7) press a finger gently on the inner corner of the eye (tear duct) for 2–3 minutes; 8) if a second dose in the same eye is needed, wait 5–10 minutes and repeat steps; 9) replace and tighten the cap; 10) wash your hands (and the child’s hands if applicable) after use. other uses for this medicine: cyclopentolate may also be used to help manage uveitis (eye inflammation). discuss potential risks and benefits with your doctor; it may be prescribed for other purposes—ask your doctor or pharmacist for details. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cyclopentolate, any other medicines, or any ingredient in the solution (your pharmacist can provide a list). provide a list of all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and herbal products you use or plan to use. do not use if you have narrow-angle glaucoma. tell your doctor if you have down syndrome or a history of angle-closure glaucoma. if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding, discuss use with your doctor; notify your doctor if you become pregnant while using it. your vision may be blurred; do not drive or operate machinery until you can see clearly. limit unnecessary or prolonged sunlight exposure and protect your eyes (for example, wear sunglasses), as cyclopentolate can increase light sensitivity. this product contains benzalkonium chloride, which soft contact lenses can absorb; remove contact lenses before instillation and follow your eye care professional’s guidance on when to reinsert. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose and are unsure what to do, call your doctor for guidance. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include mild stinging, burning, discomfort, itching, or redness of the eye. call your doctor right away if you develop any serious symptoms, including signs of conjunctivitis (pink eye) such as redness or swelling; problems with coordination (usually in children); slurred speech (usually in children); restlessness (usually in children); drowsiness; hallucinations (usually in children); hyperactivity or other behavioral changes (usually in children); seizures (usually in children); confusion (usually in children); failure to recognize familiar people (usually in children); rash; abdominal bloating in infants; fever; difficulty urinating; decreased sweating; or dry mouth. other side effects may occur; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: dipivefrin ophthalmic
instructions: notice: dipivefrin ophthalmic is no longer available in the united states. why is this medication prescribed? ophthalmic dipivefrin is used to treat glaucoma, a condition in which increased pressure within the eye can lead to gradual vision loss. it works by lowering intraocular pressure. how should this medicine be used? dipivefrin comes as an ophthalmic solution (eye drops). it is usually instilled every 12 hours. use exactly as directed on your prescription label. do not use more, less, or more often than prescribed. dipivefrin controls glaucoma but does not cure it. continue use even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor. to instill the drops: wash your hands; check the dropper tip to be sure it is not chipped or cracked; avoid touching the tip to any surface, including your eye; tilt your head back and pull down the lower eyelid to create a pocket; hold the dropper close to the eye without touching it and brace your hand; look up and gently squeeze out one drop into the pocket; release the lower lid; close your eye for 2 to 3 minutes and tip your head down as if looking at the floor; try not to blink or squeeze your eyelids; place a finger on the inner corner of the eye (tear duct) and apply gentle pressure; wipe away excess fluid with a tissue. if more than one drop is prescribed for the same eye, wait at least 5 minutes between drops. replace and tighten the cap; do not wipe or rinse the tip. wash your hands after use. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using dipivefrin eye drops, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to dipivefrin, epinephrine, sulfites, or any other medications. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had high blood pressure, heart or blood vessel disease, irregular heartbeat, or asthma. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using dipivefrin, call your doctor right away. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are using dipivefrin eye drops. if you use another topical eye medication, instill it at least 10 minutes before or after dipivefrin. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other directions, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? instill the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not instill a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? dipivefrin eye drops may cause side effects. common effects include eye irritation or discomfort, swelling or pain in the eye, blurred vision, and increased sensitivity to light and glare. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you experience fast or irregular heartbeat, chest pain, wheezing, or difficulty breathing.

name: salicylic acid topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? topical salicylic acid is used to treat and help prevent pimples and blemishes in acne. it is also used for skin conditions with scaling or excess skin growth, such as psoriasis (red, scaly patches), ichthyoses (inherited dry, scaly skin), dandruff, corns, calluses, and hand or foot warts. do not use it for genital warts, facial warts, warts with hair, warts inside the nose or mouth, moles, or birthmarks. salicylic acid belongs to a class of medicines called keratolytics. for acne, it reduces swelling and redness and clears clogged pores so pimples shrink. for other conditions, it softens and loosens dry, thickened, or scaly skin so it sheds or can be removed more easily. how should this medicine be used? topical salicylic acid is available as cloth pads or cleansing wipes, creams, lotions, liquids, gels, ointments, shampoos, wipes/pads, and medicated patches for use on the skin or scalp. it is sold in various strengths, and some products are prescription-only. depending on the product and condition, it may be used several times daily or only a few times weekly. follow the package or prescription directions exactly; ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not use more or less or more often than directed. if using it for acne, dryness or irritation can occur at first; you may start with less frequent application and increase as your skin tolerates it. if dryness or irritation occurs at any time, reduce how often you apply it and consult your doctor or the product label. when starting for the first time, apply a small amount to one or two small areas for 3 days. if no reaction occurs, continue as directed. do not swallow. avoid contact with eyes, nose, and mouth; if contact occurs, flush with water for 15 minutes. do not apply to broken, red, swollen, irritated, or infected skin. apply only to affected areas. do not treat large areas unless your doctor advises it. do not cover treated skin with a bandage or dressing unless directed by your doctor. when treating acne or certain other conditions, full benefit may take several weeks or longer, and your skin may appear to worsen in the first few days as it adjusts. read your product’s label carefully for how to prepare the skin and how to apply the medication, and follow those instructions closely. other uses for this medicine this medicine may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using topical salicylic acid, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to salicylic acid, any other medicines, or any ingredients in your product. check the package label or ask your pharmacist for a full ingredient list. do not apply the following to the same skin areas you are treating unless your doctor tells you to: abrasive soaps or cleansers; alcohol-containing skin products; other topical medicines such as benzoyl peroxide (benzaclin, benzamycin, others), resorcinol (ra lotion), sulfur (cuticura, finac, others), tretinoin (retin-a, renova, others); or medicated cosmetics. using these together on the same area can cause significant irritation. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use while on topical salicylic acid. your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. some nonprescription or herbal products may interact, including methyl salicylate in muscle rubs (such as bengay) and aspirin. inform your healthcare providers if you use these before starting topical salicylic acid, and do not start them without discussing with your provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had diabetes or disease of the blood vessels, kidneys, or liver. children and teenagers with chicken pox or flu should not use topical salicylic acid unless specifically directed by a doctor due to the risk of reye’s syndrome, a rare but serious condition affecting the brain, liver, and other organs. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, talk to your doctor; if you become pregnant while using this medicine, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose when you remember. if it is almost time for your next application, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? topical salicylic acid may cause side effects. if these symptoms are severe or do not go away, tell your doctor: skin irritation or stinging at the application site. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have any of the following: confusion, dizziness, extreme tiredness or weakness, headache, rapid breathing, ringing or buzzing in the ears, hearing loss, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. stop using salicylic acid and call your doctor right away or seek emergency help if you develop signs of an allergic reaction: hives, itching, tightness in the throat, trouble breathing, feeling faint, or swelling of the eyes, face, lips, or tongue. topical salicylic acid may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using it.

name: netupitant and palonosetron
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? the combination of netupitant and palonosetron is used to prevent nausea and vomiting caused by cancer chemotherapy. netupitant is in a class of medications called neurokinin nk1 receptor antagonists; it works by blocking neurokinin, a natural substance in the brain that triggers nausea and vomiting. palonosetron is in a class of medications called 5-ht3 receptor antagonists; it works by blocking serotonin, a natural substance in the body that can cause nausea and vomiting. how should this medicine be used? the combination of netupitant and palonosetron comes as a capsule to take by mouth. it is usually taken about 1 hour before the start of chemotherapy, with or without food. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. take netupitant and palonosetron exactly as directed. do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed by your doctor. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking netupitant and palonosetron, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to netupitant, palonosetron, alosetron (lotronex), dolasetron (anzemet), granisetron (sancuso), ondansetron (zofran, zuplenz), any other medications, or any of the ingredients in netupitant and palonosetron capsules. ask your pharmacist for a list of the ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. if you become pregnant while taking netupitant and palonosetron, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? netupitant and palonosetron should only be taken before chemotherapy as instructed by your doctor. it should not be taken on a regularly scheduled basis. what side effects can this medication cause? netupitant and palonosetron may cause side effects. if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: headache, stomach pain, heartburn, constipation, weakness, redness of the skin. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following symptoms, call your doctor immediately or seek emergency medical treatment: hives, rash, itching, difficulty breathing or swallowing, shortness of breath, dizziness, lightheadedness, fainting, fast, slow, or irregular heartbeat, agitation, hallucinations, fever, flushing, excessive sweating, confusion, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, loss of coordination, stiff or twitching muscles, seizures, coma, or loss of consciousness. netupitant and palonosetron may cause other side effects.

name: hydrocortisone topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? hydrocortisone topical is used to relieve redness, swelling, itching, and discomfort from various skin conditions. it belongs to a class of drugs called corticosteroids and works by activating natural substances in the skin to reduce inflammation. how should this medicine be used? hydrocortisone comes as an ointment, cream, solution, spray, or lotion for use on the skin. it is usually applied one to four times daily at about the same times each day. follow the directions on your prescription or product label exactly, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. use only as directed; do not use more, use it more often, or apply it to other areas unless your doctor tells you to. if prescribed, call your doctor if your symptoms do not improve within 2 weeks. if using an over-the-counter product, stop after 7 days if there is no improvement and contact your doctor. to apply, use a small amount to cover the affected area with a thin, even film and rub in gently. for external use only; avoid contact with eyes and mouth and do not swallow. do not wrap or bandage the treated area unless instructed by your doctor. if you have psoriasis, your doctor may recommend an occlusive dressing. if treating a child’s diaper area, do not use tight-fitting diapers or plastic pants. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to hydrocortisone, any other medicines, or any ingredients in hydrocortisone products; ask your pharmacist for a full ingredient list. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had diabetes or cushing’s syndrome (a condition caused by excess corticosteroid exposure). tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while using hydrocortisone topical, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? hydrocortisone topical may cause burning, itching, irritation, redness, or dryness of the skin; acne; unwanted hair growth; changes in skin color; tiny red bumps or a rash around the mouth; or small white or red bumps on the skin. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor right away if you develop a severe rash or signs of skin infection (such as increased redness, swelling, warmth, or pus) where you applied the medication. children using hydrocortisone topical may have an increased risk of side effects, including slowed growth and delayed weight gain; discuss the risks with your child’s doctor. hydrocortisone topical may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using it.

name: brompheniramine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? brompheniramine is an antihistamine used to relieve red, irritated, itchy, watery eyes, sneezing, and runny nose caused by allergies, hay fever, and the common cold. it helps control symptoms but does not treat the underlying cause or speed recovery. do not use brompheniramine to make children sleepy. it works by blocking histamine, a natural substance that triggers allergic symptoms. how should this medicine be used? brompheniramine is available in combination with other cough and cold medicines as chewable tablets, extended-release long-acting capsules or tablets, and a liquid taken by mouth. chewable tablets and liquid are usually taken every 4 to 6 hours as needed. extended-release tablets and capsules are usually taken every 8 or 12 hours as needed. follow the directions on the package or prescription label exactly, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. do not take more, take it more often, or take it longer than directed. many cough and cold products contain the same or similar active ingredients; read labels carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist which product is best for your symptoms to avoid accidental overdose. this is especially important for children. nonprescription cough and cold combination products, including those with brompheniramine, can cause serious side effects or death in young children. do not give these products to children younger than 6 years of age. if you give these products to children 6 to 11 years old, use caution and follow the package directions carefully. if giving a product that contains brompheniramine to a child, make sure it is the right product for that age group, do not give adult products to children, and use the dosing chart on the package to determine the correct amount. ask the pediatrician if you are not sure how much to give. if you are taking the liquid, measure each dose with the supplied device or a medicine measuring spoon or cup, not a household spoon. swallow extended-release tablets and capsules whole; do not crush, break, or chew. stop taking brompheniramine and call your doctor if your symptoms last longer than 7 days or if you develop a fever. other uses for this medicine this medication may sometimes be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking brompheniramine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to brompheniramine, any other medicines, or any ingredients in brompheniramine products; check the package label for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had asthma, emphysema, chronic bronchitis or other breathing problems; glaucoma; ulcers; difficulty urinating due to an enlarged prostate; heart disease; high blood pressure; seizures; or an overactive thyroid. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking brompheniramine, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking brompheniramine. this medicine may cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. ask your doctor about the safe use of alcohol while taking brompheniramine; alcohol can increase side effects. talk to your doctor about the risks and benefits if you are 65 years of age or older; older adults should generally avoid brompheniramine because other medicines may be safer or more effective for these conditions. what special dietary instructions should i follow?
