unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? brompheniramine is usually taken as needed. if your doctor has told you to take it on a regular schedule and you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? brompheniramine may cause side effects. common side effects include drowsiness, dry mouth, nose, and throat, nausea, headache, and chest congestion. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away if you have vision problems or difficulty urinating. brompheniramine may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual symptoms while taking this medication.

name: aluminum hydroxide and magnesium hydroxide
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? aluminum hydroxide and magnesium hydroxide are antacids used together to relieve heartburn, acid indigestion, and upset stomach. they may also be used to treat these symptoms in people with peptic ulcer, gastritis, esophagitis, hiatal hernia, or excessive stomach acid (gastric hyperacidity). they work by neutralizing stomach acid. this combination is available without a prescription. this medication is sometimes prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? this medication is available as chewable tablets and as a liquid taken by mouth. chew the tablets thoroughly; do not swallow them whole. drink a full glass of water after taking the tablets. shake the oral liquid well before each dose to mix the medicine evenly; it may be taken alone or mixed with water or milk. follow the directions on the package or your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. take aluminum hydroxide and magnesium hydroxide exactly as directed. do not take more, take it more often, or take it longer than directed. do not use antacids for more than 1 to 2 weeks unless your doctor tells you to. what special precautions should i follow? before taking aluminum hydroxide and magnesium hydroxide, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to either ingredient or to any other medications. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. nonprescription or herbal products that may interact include aspirin, ferrous sulfate (iron), and multivitamins; be sure to tell your doctor and pharmacist if you use these, and do not start them while taking this antacid without discussing it with your healthcare provider. if your doctor instructs you to use antacids with other medications, separate the doses by 2 hours. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. if you become pregnant while taking this medication, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? if you are taking this medication for an ulcer, follow your doctor’s prescribed diet carefully. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you take this medication on a schedule and miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? side effects are not common. to lessen a chalky taste, take with water or milk. call your doctor if any of the following are severe or do not go away: diarrhea, constipation, loss of appetite, unusual tiredness, or muscle weakness.

name: simethicone
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? simethicone is used to relieve symptoms of excess gas, such as uncomfortable or painful pressure, fullness, and bloating. it may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? simethicone comes as regular tablets, chewable tablets, capsules, and liquid taken by mouth. it is typically taken four times daily—after meals and at bedtime. follow the directions on the package or your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take simethicone exactly as directed. do not take more or less, or take it more often, than prescribed. swallow regular tablets and capsules whole. chew chewable tablets thoroughly before swallowing; do not swallow them whole. do not take more than six simethicone tablets or eight simethicone capsules in one day unless your doctor tells you otherwise. the liquid may be mixed with 1 ounce (30 milliliters) of cool water or infant formula. what special precautions should i follow? before taking simethicone, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to simethicone or any other medicines. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking simethicone, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, no special dietary changes are required while taking simethicone. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you are taking simethicone on a regular schedule and miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? when taken as directed, simethicone is usually not associated with side effects.

name: loratadine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? loratadine is used to temporarily relieve a runny nose, sneezing, and eye redness, itching, and tearing caused by allergies. it is an antihistamine that works by blocking histamine, a substance in the body that triggers allergic symptoms. how should this medicine be used? loratadine comes as a liquid, tablet, chewable tablet, capsule, and rapidly disintegrating tablet to take by mouth. take it once daily with or without food. use loratadine exactly as directed. do not take more or less or take it more often than stated on the package label or recommended by your doctor. if using the rapidly disintegrating tablet, follow the package directions to remove it from the blister without breaking it; do not push the tablet through the foil. once removed, place it on your tongue and close your mouth; it will dissolve quickly and may be swallowed with or without water. do not use this medication if the safety seal is open or torn. other uses for this medicine loratadine may also be used to treat itching and redness caused by hives. it may be recommended for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking loratadine, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to loratadine, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe what symptoms you had. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking loratadine, call your doctor. if you have phenylketonuria (pku), be aware that the chewable tablets may contain aspartame, which forms phenylalanine. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. however, if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? loratadine may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: headache, drowsiness, tiredness. some side effects may be serious. if you experience any of the following, stop taking loratadine and call your doctor immediately: rash; hives; itching; swelling of the eyes, face, lips, tongue, or throat; difficulty breathing or swallowing.

name: ketotifen ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ophthalmic ketotifen is used to relieve the itching of allergic pinkeye (allergic conjunctivitis). it is an antihistamine that works by blocking histamine, a substance in the body that triggers allergy symptoms. how should this medicine be used? ophthalmic ketotifen is a liquid eye drop solution. it is usually instilled in the affected eye(s) twice daily, 8 to 12 hours apart, at about the same times each day. follow the directions on your prescription label and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. use exactly as directed; do not use more, less, or more often than prescribed. to instill the eye drops: 1) wash your hands with soap and water. 2) check the dropper tip to be sure it is not chipped or cracked. 3) do not let the dropper tip touch your eye or any surface; keep the dropper and solution clean. 4) tilt your head back and pull down the lower eyelid with your index finger to form a pocket. 5) with the other hand, hold the bottle tip down close to the eye without touching it and brace your remaining fingers against your face. 6) while looking up, gently squeeze one drop into the lower‑lid pocket. 7) release your lower eyelid. 8) close your eye for 2 to 3 minutes and tip your head downward as if looking at the floor; try not to blink or squeeze your eyelids. 9) place a finger over the inner corner of the eye (tear duct) and apply gentle pressure. 10) wipe away any excess liquid with a tissue. 11) if more than one drop is needed in the same eye, wait at least 5 minutes before instilling the next drop. 12) replace and tighten the cap; do not wipe or rinse the dropper tip. 13) wash your hands to remove any medication. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using ketotifen eye drops, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to ketotifen or any other medications. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor; if you become pregnant while using ketotifen, call your doctor. do not wear contact lenses if your eyes are red. if your eyes are not red and you wear contact lenses, be aware that ketotifen solution contains benzalkonium chloride, which can be absorbed by soft lenses; remove your lenses before using the drops and wait 10 minutes before reinserting them. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? instill the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not instill a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? ketotifen eye drops may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: headache; runny nose; burning or stinging of the eye; eye discharge; dry eyes; eye pain; eyelid problems or irritation; itching; decreased tear production; blurred vision; sensitivity to light; rash; flu-like symptoms; sore throat. ketotifen eye drops may cause other side effects.

name: albendazole
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? albendazole is used to treat neurocysticercosis, an infection caused by the pork tapeworm that can affect the muscles, brain, and eyes and may lead to seizures, brain swelling, and vision problems. it is also used along with surgery to treat cystic hydatid disease, an infection caused by the dog tapeworm that can affect the liver, lungs, and the lining of the abdomen and may damage these organs. albendazole is an anthelmintic; it works by killing the worms. how should this medicine be used? albendazole comes as an oral tablet and is usually taken with food twice a day. for neurocysticercosis, it is typically taken for 8 to 30 days. for cystic hydatid disease, it is usually taken for 28 days, followed by a 14-day break, and repeated for a total of three cycles. take it at the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly; do not take more or less or more often than prescribed. if giving it to a child or if you cannot swallow tablets whole, you may crush or chew them and swallow with water. take albendazole until the prescription is finished, even if you feel better; stopping early or skipping doses may result in incomplete treatment of the infection. other uses for this medicine albendazole is sometimes used to treat infections caused by roundworms, hookworms, threadworm, whipworm, pinworm, flukes, and other parasites. discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking albendazole, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to albendazole, mebendazole, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. the nonprescription product cimetidine (tagamet) may interact with albendazole; make sure your doctor and pharmacist know you are taking it, and do not start it while on albendazole without medical advice. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver disease. if you are pregnant, could be pregnant, or plan to become pregnant, do not start albendazole until a pregnancy test is negative. do not become pregnant while taking albendazole and for 3 days after your final dose; discuss effective birth control methods with your doctor. if you become pregnant, call your doctor immediately; albendazole may harm the fetus. if you are breast-feeding, inform your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking albendazole. if you are being treated for neurocysticercosis, your doctor will likely prescribe other medications to help protect the nervous system during treatment. call your doctor right away if you have seizures, headache, vomiting, extreme tiredness, or changes in behavior. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? albendazole may cause side effects. common side effects include stomach pain, nausea, vomiting, headache, dizziness, and reversible hair loss. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor immediately if you have sore throat, fever, chills, or other signs of infection; unusual bleeding or bruising; weakness; fatigue; pale skin; shortness of breath; rash; or hives. albendazole may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you experience any unusual problems while taking it.

name: albiglutide injection
instructions: notice: albiglutide has been discontinued in the united states. because it is no longer available on the u.s. market, this information is not being updated. if albiglutide is used outside the u.s., consult the manufacturer’s labeling for the most current information. important warning: albiglutide injection may increase the risk of thyroid tumors, including medullary thyroid carcinoma (mtc). tumors were seen in laboratory animals given medicines like albiglutide; it is unknown if this risk applies to humans. do not use albiglutide if you or a family member has or has ever had mtc, or if you have multiple endocrine neoplasia syndrome type 2 (men 2). call your doctor right away if you notice a neck lump or swelling, hoarseness, trouble swallowing, or shortness of breath. keep all appointments with your doctor and the lab; tests may be ordered to monitor your response. you will receive a medication guide at the start of treatment and with each refill—read it carefully and ask questions as needed. discuss the risks and benefits of albiglutide with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? albiglutide injection is used along with diet and exercise to help control blood sugar in adults with type 2 diabetes when other medicines have not controlled levels well enough. it is not for type 1 diabetes or for treating diabetic ketoacidosis. albiglutide is an incretin mimetic that helps the pancreas release insulin when blood sugar is high and slows the movement of food from the stomach. managing blood sugar with medicines, lifestyle changes (diet, exercise, smoking cessation), and regular monitoring can improve health and may reduce the risk of complications such as heart attack, stroke, kidney failure, nerve damage, eye disease, and gum disease. your care team will work with you on a plan to manage your diabetes. how should this medicine be used? albiglutide comes as a powder in a prefilled pen to be mixed with water and injected under the skin (subcutaneously). it is usually given once weekly, with or without food, on the same day each week at any time of day. you may change your dosing day if at least 4 days have passed since your last dose. follow your prescription label and use exactly as directed—do not use more, less, or more often than prescribed. albiglutide controls diabetes but does not cure it; continue to use it unless your doctor tells you to stop. each prefilled pen contains one dose; inject only albiglutide from its own pen and do not mix it with other medications. read the instructions for use that come with the pen for preparation and injection steps, and ask your pharmacist or doctor if you have questions. check the solution before injecting; it should be yellow, clear, and free of particles. inject into the abdomen, thigh, or upper arm; do not inject into a vein or muscle. rotate injection sites within the same body area with each dose. you may use albiglutide and insulin in the same body region, but do not inject them right next to each other. never reuse or share needles or pens. use a new needle for each injection. dispose of used needles in a puncture-resistant container and ask your pharmacist or local authorities how to discard the container. what special precautions should i follow? before using albiglutide, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to albiglutide or any of its ingredients. review the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and over-the-counter medicines, vitamins, and herbal products you use or plan to use. this is especially important for medicines you take by mouth, because albiglutide can affect how your body absorbs them. be sure to mention insulin or other diabetes medicines, particularly sulfonylureas (such as chlorpropamide, glimepiride, glipizide, glyburide, tolazamide, or tolbutamide), as dose adjustments and extra monitoring may be needed. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had pancreatitis; severe stomach problems, including gastroparesis or trouble digesting food; or kidney or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while using albiglutide, call your doctor. ask your doctor what to do if you become ill, develop an infection or fever, or experience unusual stress, as these can affect your blood sugar and may change your dose needs. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow the diet and exercise plan recommended by your doctor or dietitian. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if more than 3 days have passed since the missed dose, skip it and take your next dose on the regularly scheduled day. do not use two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? albiglutide can affect blood sugar. learn the signs of low and high blood sugar and what to do if they occur. common side effects may include diarrhea, nausea, heartburn, redness, swelling, or itching at the injection site, and cough or flu-like symptoms. serious side effects can occur. stop using albiglutide and call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have persistent pain in the upper left or middle abdomen that may spread to the back, vomiting, hives, rash, itching, or trouble breathing. also seek care for any symptoms listed in the important warning. albiglutide may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medicine.

name: albuterol
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? albuterol is used to prevent and relieve wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and coughing caused by asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (copd), a group of lung and airway disorders. it is a bronchodilator that works by relaxing and opening the airways to make breathing easier. how should this medicine be used? albuterol comes as a tablet, a syrup, and an extended-release (long-acting) tablet taken by mouth. the tablets and syrup are usually taken three or four times a day. the extended-release tablets are usually taken every 12 hours. take albuterol at about the same times each day. follow your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. take albuterol exactly as directed; do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. swallow extended-release tablets whole with plenty of water or other liquid—do not split, chew, or crush them. your doctor may start you on a low dose and increase it gradually. albuterol helps control symptoms but does not cure your condition. continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor. call your doctor if your symptoms worsen or if albuterol no longer seems to control them. what special precautions should i follow? before taking albuterol, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to albuterol or any of the ingredients in the tablets, extended-release tablets, or syrup; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. in particular, tell your doctor if you take or have taken within the past two weeks tricyclic antidepressants (such as amitriptyline, amoxapine, clomipramine, desipramine, doxepin, imipramine, nortriptyline, protriptyline, or trimipramine) or monoamine oxidase (mao) inhibitors (such as isocarboxazid, phenelzine, selegiline, or tranylcypromine). tell your doctor if you have or have ever had an irregular heartbeat, heart disease, high blood pressure, hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid), diabetes, or seizures. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor; if you become pregnant while taking albuterol, call your doctor. be aware that albuterol can rarely cause worsening wheezing or trouble breathing (paradoxical bronchospasm). if this happens, call your doctor right away and do not use albuterol again unless your doctor tells you to. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? albuterol may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: nervousness, shakiness, dizziness, headache, uncontrollable trembling, muscle cramps, excessive movement or activity, sudden mood changes, nosebleed, nausea, increased or decreased appetite, trouble falling or staying asleep, pale skin. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away if you have: fast, pounding, or irregular heartbeat; chest pain; fever; blisters or rash; hives; itching; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; worsening trouble breathing; difficulty swallowing; or hoarseness. albuterol may cause other side effects; ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions or notice anything unusual.

name: albuterol and ipratropium oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? the albuterol and ipratropium combination is used to prevent wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and coughing in people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (copd), including chronic bronchitis (swelling of the air passages to the lungs) and emphysema (damage to the air sacs). it is intended for people whose symptoms are not adequately controlled with a single inhaled medicine. both drugs are bronchodilators that relax and open the airways to make breathing easier. how should this medicine be used? this medicine comes as a liquid solution for inhalation by mouth with a nebulizer and as an oral inhalation spray used with an inhaler. it is usually used four times daily. follow your prescription label closely and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. use exactly as directed—do not use more or less or more often than prescribed. your doctor may advise extra doses if you develop symptoms (such as wheeze, shortness of breath, chest tightness); follow these instructions carefully and do not take extra doses unless told to do so. do not use more than 2 extra nebulizer solution doses in a day, and do not use the inhalation spray more than six times in 24 hours. call your doctor if symptoms worsen, if control decreases, or if you need extra doses more often. if you use the inhaler, your medicine comes in cartridges; each cartridge provides 120 inhalations (about one month at 1 inhalation four times daily). after 120 doses, the inhaler locks and will not release more medication. check the dose indicator; when the pointer enters the red zone, about 7 days of medicine remain—refill your prescription so you do not run out. avoid getting the spray in your eyes; accidental exposure can trigger narrow-angle glaucoma or worsen existing glaucoma, causing dilated pupils, eye pain or redness, blurred vision, halos around lights, or seeing unusual colors. if eye exposure occurs or these symptoms develop, call your doctor. use only the inhaler provided with the albuterol/ipratropium cartridge and do not use it for other medicines; do not use other inhalers with this cartridge. read the manufacturer’s instructions before first use and ask your healthcare professional to demonstrate proper technique; practice under supervision. to prepare (prime) the inhaler before first use: 1) assemble the inhaler with the orange cap closed. press the safety catch and remove the clear base (do not touch the piercing element). write down the discard date—three months after assembly. 2) insert the narrow end of the cartridge into the inhaler; press against a hard surface to seat it. 3) replace the clear base. 4) hold the device upright with the orange cap closed; turn the clear base in the direction of the white arrows until it clicks. 5) flip open the orange cap. 6) point the inhaler toward the ground and press the dose-release button. 7) close the orange cap. repeat steps 4–6 until you see a spray, then repeat these steps three additional times. the inhaler is now primed. if unused for more than 3 days, release 1 spray toward the ground before use; if unused for more than 21 days, repeat the full priming steps above. to use the inhaler for a dose: hold upright with the orange cap closed; turn the clear base in the direction of the white arrows until it clicks; open the orange cap; breathe out fully; place the mouthpiece in your mouth with lips sealed, keeping air vents uncovered; point toward the back of your throat and inhale slowly and deeply while pressing the dose-release button; continue to inhale as the spray is released; hold your breath for up to 10 seconds or as long as comfortable; remove from mouth and close the orange cap until the next dose. to use the nebulizer solution: remove one vial from the foil pouch and return the rest to the pouch; twist off the vial top and squeeze all liquid into the nebulizer reservoir; connect the reservoir to the mouthpiece or face mask and then to the compressor; place the mouthpiece or mask; sit upright, turn on the compressor, and breathe calmly and deeply through your mouth for about 5 to 15 minutes until mist stops forming. clean the inhaler or nebulizer regularly, following the manufacturer’s directions; ask your pharmacist or doctor if you have questions. other uses for this medicine: your doctor may prescribe this medication for other uses; ask your healthcare provider for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to albuterol, ipratropium, atropine, levalbuterol, or any ingredients in the solution or spray (ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients), and provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and herbal products you take or plan to take. your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. in particular, tell your doctor if you currently take or have taken in the last 2 weeks any tricyclic antidepressants (such as amitriptyline, amoxapine, clomipramine, desipramine, doxepin, imipramine, nortriptyline, protriptyline, trimipramine) or monoamine oxidase (mao) inhibitors (such as isocarboxazid, phenelzine, tranylcypromine, selegiline), and discuss use of nonprescription cold medicines, which may interact. do not start these medicines while using this inhalation product without consulting your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had glaucoma; difficulty urinating; bladder blockage; prostate problems; seizures; hyperthyroidism; high blood pressure; irregular heartbeat; diabetes; or heart, liver, or kidney disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits; if you become pregnant, call your doctor. before any surgery, including dental procedures, tell the clinician you use this inhalation medication. be aware that paradoxical bronchospasm (worsening wheeze or trouble breathing immediately after use) can occur; if this happens, stop using it and call your doctor right away. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember; if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? side effects may occur. common effects include headache, tremor, and nervousness; contact your doctor if these are severe or persistent. serious side effects require immediate medical attention and include fast or pounding heartbeat, chest pain, hives, rash, itching, swelling of the eyes, face, lips, tongue, throat, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, trouble breathing or swallowing, signs of infection (such as sore throat, fever, chills), or difficulty urinating. albuterol and ipratropium may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: alcaftadine ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ophthalmic alcaftadine is used to relieve itching caused by allergic conjunctivitis (allergic pinkeye). it is an antihistamine that works by blocking histamine, a chemical that triggers allergy symptoms. how should this medicine be used? alcaftadine ophthalmic solution is an eye-drop liquid used once daily in the affected eye(s). use it at the same time each day to help you remember. follow your prescription label exactly; do not use more or less or more often than directed. to apply the drops: 1) wash your hands with soap and water. 2) check that the dropper tip is not cracked or chipped. 3) do not let the tip touch your eye or any surface to keep it clean. 4) tilt your head back and pull down the lower eyelid to create a pocket. 5) hold the dropper close to the eye without touching it and brace your hand against your face. 6) look up and gently squeeze out one drop into the pocket. 7) release the lower lid. 8) close your eye for 2–3 minutes and tilt your head downward as if looking at the floor; avoid blinking or squeezing your eyelids. 9) apply gentle pressure with a finger to the inner corner of the eye (tear duct). 10) wipe away any excess liquid. 11) if you need more than one drop in the same eye, wait at least 5 minutes between drops. 12) replace and tighten the cap; do not rinse the dropper tip. 13) wash your hands to remove any medication. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using alcaftadine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to alcaftadine or any other medicines, or to any ingredient in the solution; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and over-the-counter medicines, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you are using. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while using alcaftadine, contact your doctor. do not wear contact lenses if your eyes are red. if your eyes are not red and you wear contact lenses, be aware that the solution contains benzalkonium chloride, which can be absorbed by soft lenses; remove lenses before using the drops and wait 10 minutes before reinserting them. what special dietary instructions should i follow? continue your normal diet unless your doctor advises otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use extra drops to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? alcaftadine eye drops may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: eye irritation; itching, burning, or stinging of the eye; eye redness; runny nose; headache. alcaftadine eye drops may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you experience any unusual symptoms.

name: spironolactone and hydrochlorothiazide
instructions: important warning: spironolactone has caused tumors in laboratory animals. discuss the risks and benefits of this medicine with your doctor. do not start this combination product at the beginning of therapy; use it only after your doctor has individually established appropriate doses of spironolactone and hydrochlorothiazide. why is this medication prescribed? the spironolactone and hydrochlorothiazide combination is used to treat high blood pressure and to manage edema (fluid retention) caused by conditions such as heart, liver, or kidney disease. spironolactone is an aldosterone receptor antagonist that helps the kidneys eliminate excess water and sodium while minimizing potassium loss. hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic (water pill) that increases the removal of salt and water in the urine. treating high blood pressure helps prevent damage to the brain, heart, blood vessels, kidneys, and eyes, reducing the risk of heart disease, heart attack, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, vision loss, and other problems. lifestyle changes—such as a low-fat, low-salt diet, maintaining a healthy weight, exercising at least 30 minutes most days, not smoking, and limiting alcohol—also help control blood pressure. how should this medicine be used? this medicine comes as an oral tablet, usually taken once or twice daily at the same times each day. if taken once daily, take it in the morning; if twice daily, take it in the morning and late afternoon to reduce nighttime urination. follow your prescription label closely. take exactly as directed; do not take more or less or more often than prescribed. this medication controls but does not cure high blood pressure and edema. continue taking it even if you feel well, and do not stop without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine: it may sometimes be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking this medicine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to spironolactone, hydrochlorothiazide, thiazide diuretics, sulfonamide (sulfa) medications, penicillin, any other drugs, or any ingredients in the tablets. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use. nonprescription products that may interact include aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin) and naproxen (naprosyn), and potassium supplements; do not start or continue these while taking this medicine without discussing with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have high blood levels of calcium or potassium, addison’s disease, other conditions that may increase potassium, or kidney or liver disease—your doctor may advise you not to take this medicine. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had asthma, systemic lupus erythematosus (sle), diabetes, or gout. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits; call your doctor if you become pregnant while taking this medicine. before surgery, including dental procedures, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking it. this medication may cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. alcohol can increase drowsiness. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow your doctor’s recommendations for a low-salt or low-sodium diet and a regular exercise program. avoid potassium-containing salt substitutes. limit high-potassium foods (for example, bananas, prunes, raisins, and orange juice) and ask your doctor how much is appropriate for you. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? this medicine may cause side effects. common effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, loss of appetite, stomach pain, frequent urination, dizziness, headache, enlarged or painful breasts, irregular menstrual periods, difficulty achieving or maintaining an erection, vaginal bleeding in postmenopausal women, and drowsiness. serious effects can include muscle weakness or cramps, vision changes or eye pain, rapid or excessive weight loss, fatigue, slow or irregular heartbeat, unusual bruising or bleeding, yellowing of the skin or eyes, skin rash, itching, fever, or confusion; call your doctor immediately if you experience any of these.

name: spironolactone
instructions: important warning: spironolactone has caused tumors in laboratory animals. discuss the potential risks and benefits of this medicine with your doctor before use. why is this medication prescribed? spironolactone is used to treat certain patients with hyperaldosteronism (the body makes too much aldosterone), low potassium levels, heart failure, and edema (fluid retention) from conditions such as liver or kidney disease. it is also used alone or with other medicines to treat high blood pressure. spironolactone is an aldosterone receptor antagonist that helps the kidneys remove extra water and sodium into the urine while reducing potassium loss. untreated high blood pressure can damage the brain, heart, blood vessels, kidneys, and other organs, potentially leading to heart disease, heart attack, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, vision loss, and other problems. in addition to medication, lifestyle changes such as a low-fat, low-salt diet, maintaining a healthy weight, exercising at least 30 minutes most days, not smoking, and limiting alcohol can help control blood pressure. how should this medicine be used? spironolactone comes as tablets and as an oral suspension (carospir) to take by mouth, usually once or twice daily. take the suspension consistently with food or without food each time, and take your doses at about the same times every day. follow your prescription label exactly; do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. shake the suspension well before each dose. your doctor may start you on a low dose and gradually increase it. the tablet and suspension forms release the drug differently and are not interchangeable; take only the spironolactone product your doctor prescribed and do not switch unless your doctor tells you to. spironolactone controls high blood pressure, edema, heart failure, and hyperaldosteronism but does not cure them; it may take about 2 weeks or longer to see the full effect. continue taking it even if you feel well and do not stop without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine spironolactone may be used with other medicines to treat precocious puberty or myasthenia gravis (mg), and it may be used to treat certain female patients with abnormal facial hair. ask your doctor about the potential risks of using this medication for your condition. it is sometimes prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking spironolactone, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to spironolactone, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets or suspension. if you are taking eplerenone (inspra), your doctor may tell you not to take spironolactone. some medicines should not be used with spironolactone, and others may require dose changes or extra monitoring; review all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and herbal products you take or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist before starting spironolactone. do not start, stop, or change any medicine while taking spironolactone without your doctor’s or pharmacist’s advice. nonprescription products that may interact include potassium supplements; nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin, others) and naproxen (aleve); and acetylsalicylic acid. tell your healthcare providers if you use these, and do not start them while on spironolactone without discussing it. tell your doctor if you have addison’s disease or other conditions that can cause high potassium levels, or kidney disease; your doctor may advise against spironolactone. tell your doctor if you have liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while taking this medicine. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist you take spironolactone. drinking alcohol while taking spironolactone may cause dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting when standing up quickly; ask your doctor about alcohol use. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow your doctor’s advice on meals, including a reduced-salt diet and daily exercise plan. avoid potassium-containing salt substitutes. ask your doctor how much potassium-rich food (for example, bananas, prunes, raisins, orange juice) you may include in your diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? spironolactone may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of the following are severe or do not go away: vomiting; diarrhea; stomach pain or cramps; enlarged or painful breasts in men or women; irregular menstrual periods; vaginal bleeding after menopause; difficulty achieving or maintaining an erection; deepening of the voice; increased body hair growth; drowsiness; tiredness; restlessness. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away if you have: muscle weakness, pain, or cramps; pain, burning, numbness, or tingling in the hands or feet; inability to move arms or legs; heartbeat changes; confusion; nausea; extreme tiredness; dry mouth, thirst, dizziness, unsteadiness, headache, or other signs of dehydration; unusual bleeding or bruising; lack of energy; loss of appetite; pain in the upper right abdomen; yellowing of the skin or eyes; flu-like symptoms; rash, hives, or itching; trouble breathing or swallowing; vomiting blood; blood in stools; decreased urination; fainting.

name: imiquimod topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? imiquimod cream is used to treat certain actinic keratoses (flat, scaly skin growths from sun exposure), superficial basal cell carcinoma (a type of skin cancer), and external genital and anal warts. it belongs to a class of drugs called immune response modifiers and likely works by boosting the body’s immune activity. imiquimod cream does not cure warts; new warts may appear during treatment, and it is unknown whether it prevents spreading warts to others. how should this medicine be used? imiquimod is a skin cream used exactly as directed by your doctor. apply it at the same scheduled times on treatment days. do not use more or less, or more often, than prescribed. do not tightly cover the treated area unless your doctor tells you to; cotton gauze may be used if needed, and cotton underwear may be worn after treating the genital or anal area. if treating genital or anal warts, avoid sexual (oral, anal, genital) contact while the cream is on your skin. imiquimod may weaken condoms and vaginal diaphragms. uncircumcised men treating warts under the foreskin should retract the foreskin and clean daily and before each dose. for skin use only; do not apply in or near the eyes, lips, nostrils, vagina, or inside the anus. if it gets in the eyes or mouth, rinse well with water right away. the cream comes in single-use packets; discard any opened packet with leftover cream. to apply: wash hands; wash and dry the treatment area; apply a thin layer at bedtime and rub in until it disappears; wash hands again; leave on for the time your doctor instructs (usually about 8 hours, typically 6 to 10 hours) without bathing, showering, or swimming; then wash the area with mild soap and water to remove the cream. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to imiquimod, any of its ingredients, or any drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your allergy symptoms. tell your doctor or pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have a sunburn; have or have ever had unusual sensitivity to sunlight; any skin disease or condition; graft-versus-host disease; recent surgery on the affected area; or any immune system condition such as hiv or aids. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while using imiquimod, call your doctor. avoid applying imiquimod to areas that an infant might contact during breastfeeding. limit sunlight exposure and wear protective clothing, a hat, sunglasses, and sunscreen when outdoors; do not use tanning beds or sunlamps. imiquimod may increase sun sensitivity. be aware that skin color may lighten with use and may not fully return to normal; tell your doctor if you notice any change in skin color. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor instructs otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next scheduled dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra cream to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? imiquimod cream may cause side effects. common effects include redness, itching, burning, or bleeding of the treated area; flaking, scaling, dryness, or thickening of the skin; swelling, stinging, or pain at the site; blisters, scabs, or bumps; and headache. serious effects include skin breakdown or sores with drainage (especially during the first week) and flu-like symptoms such as nausea, fever, chills, tiredness, muscle weakness, or muscle pain; call your doctor right away if these occur. imiquimod may cause other side effects.

name: aldesleukin
instructions: important warning: aldesleukin injection must be administered in a hospital or specialized medical facility under the supervision of a physician experienced in cancer chemotherapy. keep all clinic and lab appointments. your doctor will order tests before and during treatment to ensure it is safe for you to receive aldesleukin and to monitor how your body responds. aldesleukin can cause a severe, life‑threatening condition called capillary leak syndrome, in which fluid shifts out of the blood vessels, causing fluid retention, low blood pressure, and low albumin; this can damage the heart, lungs, kidneys, and gastrointestinal tract and may occur soon after a dose. seek immediate medical help if you develop swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; sudden weight gain; shortness of breath; fainting; dizziness or lightheadedness; confusion; black, tarry, or bloody stools; chest pain; or a fast or irregular heartbeat. aldesleukin can lower white blood cell counts, raising the risk of serious infection; call your doctor right away if you have fever, chills, sore throat, cough, painful or frequent urination, or other infection signs. aldesleukin can affect the nervous system and may lead to coma; get urgent help for extreme sleepiness or profound fatigue. why is this medication prescribed? aldesleukin is used to treat advanced renal cell carcinoma (rcc), a kidney cancer that has spread, and metastatic melanoma, a skin cancer that has spread. it is a cytokine (a laboratory‑made form of a natural protein) that stimulates the immune system to release substances that help the body fight cancer. how should this medicine be used? aldesleukin is supplied as a powder that is mixed with liquid and infused into a vein by a healthcare professional over about 15 minutes. it is typically given every 8 hours for 5 consecutive days (up to a total of 14 doses), followed by a 9‑day rest period; a second cycle may then be given. the duration and number of doses depend on your response and side effects; your doctor may delay or stop treatment if needed. you will be closely monitored during therapy, and it is important to promptly tell your care team how you are feeling while receiving aldesleukin. other uses for this medicine: your doctor may prescribe this medication for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving aldesleukin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to aldesleukin, any other medicines, or any ingredient in the injection; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use. in particular, mention beta blockers such as atenolol (tenormin), labetalol (normodyne), metoprolol (lopressor, toprol xl), nadolol (corgard), and propranolol (inderal); cancer drugs such as asparaginase (elspar), cisplatin (platinol), dacarbazine (dtic‑dome), doxorubicin (doxil), interferon alfa (pegasys, peg‑intron), methotrexate (rheumatrex, trexall), and tamoxifen (nolvadex); blood pressure medicines; anti‑nausea medicines; narcotic and other pain medicines; sedatives, sleeping pills, and tranquilizers; systemic steroids such as dexamethasone (decadron, dexone), methylprednisolone (medrol), and prednisone (deltasone); and steroid creams, lotions, or ointments such as hydrocortisone (cortizone, westcort). also tell your doctor and pharmacist about all medicines you take that might increase the risk of kidney or liver injury during aldesleukin therapy. tell your doctor if you have ever had seizures, gastrointestinal bleeding that required surgery, or other serious gastrointestinal, heart, nervous system, or kidney problems after receiving aldesleukin, or if you have ever had an organ transplant; your doctor may decide that aldesleukin is not appropriate. also inform your doctor if you have or have had seizures, crohn’s disease, scleroderma, thyroid disease, arthritis, diabetes, myasthenia gravis, or cholecystitis. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant during treatment, call your doctor; do not breast‑feed while receiving aldesleukin. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you different instructions, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? aldesleukin is given by healthcare professionals on a strict schedule in a medical setting, so missed doses are uncommon; if you miss an appointment or think a dose was missed, contact your doctor or treatment center immediately. do not attempt to self‑administer or make up a dose. what side effects can this medication cause? aldesleukin can cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, decreased appetite, mouth or throat sores, tiredness, weakness, dizziness, feeling unwell, or pain/redness at the injection site. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away if you have any of the symptoms listed in the important warning section or any of the following: seizures; chest pain; severe anxiety, agitation, or new/worsening depression; hallucinations; changes in vision or speech; loss of coordination; decreased alertness; unusual bruising or bleeding; extreme sleepiness; trouble breathing or wheezing; abdominal pain; yellowing of the skin or eyes; decreased urination; rash, hives, itching; or difficulty breathing or swallowing. aldesleukin may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: doxylamine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? doxylamine is used for short-term relief of insomnia (trouble falling asleep or staying asleep). it is also combined with decongestants and other medicines to ease sneezing, runny nose, and nasal stuffiness from the common cold. do not use doxylamine to make children sleepy. doxylamine is an antihistamine that works by blocking histamine, a body chemical that triggers allergy symptoms. how should this medicine be used? doxylamine is available as an oral tablet for sleep and, in combination products, as a liquid or liquid‑filled capsule for cold symptoms. for sleep, take it about 30 minutes before bedtime. for cold symptoms, it is usually taken every 4 to 6 hours. follow the directions on the package or your prescription exactly; do not take more, take it more often, or use it longer than directed. doxylamine is sold alone or with pain relievers, fever reducers, and cough suppressants. ask your doctor or pharmacist which product best matches your symptoms. check labels carefully before using more than one cough/cold product at the same time; many contain the same active ingredients and taking them together can lead to an overdose. over‑the‑counter cough and cold combinations, including those with doxylamine, can cause serious side effects or death in young children. do not give products containing doxylamine to children under 4 years; consult a doctor before giving them to children 4 to 12 years old. worsening or persistent cough/cold symptoms may signal a more serious condition; if your symptoms worsen or last more than 7 days when using a combination product, call your doctor. if you take doxylamine for insomnia, expect drowsiness soon after dosing and lasting for some time; plan for 7 to 8 hours of sleep. getting up too soon may leave you drowsy. use doxylamine for insomnia only short term; call your doctor if you feel you need it for longer than 2 weeks. if using the liquid, measure doses with the supplied device or a medication‑measuring spoon, not a household spoon. what special precautions should i follow? before taking doxylamine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to doxylamine, any other medicines, or any ingredient in the product; check the package label for a full ingredient list. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had asthma, emphysema, chronic bronchitis, other breathing problems, glaucoma, ulcers, difficulty urinating due to an enlarged prostate, heart disease, high blood pressure, seizures, or an overactive thyroid. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, talk to your doctor; if you become pregnant while taking doxylamine, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the surgeon or dentist you take doxylamine. this medicine may cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. alcohol can increase drowsiness; avoid alcoholic beverages while taking this medication. if you are 65 or older, discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor; older adults usually should not take doxylamine because other treatments may be safer or more effective. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? doxylamine is often taken as needed. if your doctor has told you to take it on a regular schedule and you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your usual schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? doxylamine may cause side effects. common effects include dry mouth, nose, or throat; drowsiness; nausea; increased chest congestion; headache; excitement; and nervousness. serious side effects can occur; call your doctor right away if you have vision problems or difficulty urinating. doxylamine may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: methyldopa
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? methyldopa is prescribed to treat high blood pressure. it belongs to a class of medicines called antihypertensives and lowers blood pressure by relaxing blood vessels so blood flows more easily. untreated high blood pressure can damage the brain, heart, blood vessels, kidneys, and other organs, increasing the risk of heart disease, heart attack, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, loss of vision, and other problems. along with medication, lifestyle changes can help control blood pressure: eat a low-fat, low-salt diet, maintain a healthy weight, exercise at least 30 minutes most days, avoid smoking, and use alcohol in moderation. how should this medicine be used? methyldopa comes as tablets and a liquid to take by mouth, usually 2 to 4 times daily. take it at the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly; ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. shake the liquid well before each dose and measure with a dosing spoon or medicine cup, not a household spoon. methyldopa controls but does not cure high blood pressure. keep taking it even if you feel well. do not stop suddenly; your doctor will taper your dose to prevent a rebound increase in blood pressure and other side effects. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses. ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking methyldopa, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to methyldopa, any other medications, sulfites, or any ingredients in the tablets or liquid; ask for a list of ingredients. some medicines should not be used with methyldopa, and others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. discuss all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and supplements you take or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist, and consult them before starting, stopping, or changing any medication while on methyldopa. nonprescription iron supplements and multivitamins containing iron can interact with methyldopa; tell your doctor and pharmacist if you use them before starting methyldopa, and do not start them while taking methyldopa without your healthcare provider’s advice. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney or liver disease, including hepatitis or cirrhosis. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while taking methyldopa. if you are 65 or older, discuss the risks and alternatives; methyldopa is generally not preferred for older adults. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist you take methyldopa. this medication may cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery for 48–72 hours after starting methyldopa or after any dose increase. what special dietary instructions should i follow? your doctor may recommend a low-salt or low-sodium diet; follow these instructions carefully. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? methyldopa may cause side effects. common effects include headache, muscle weakness, swollen ankles or feet, upset stomach, vomiting, diarrhea, gas, dry mouth, and rash. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor right away if you have an unexplained fever, extreme tiredness, or yellowing of the skin or eyes. methyldopa may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you experience anything unusual.

name: chlorothiazide
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? chlorothiazide is used alone or with other medicines to treat high blood pressure and to reduce edema fluid retention caused by conditions such as heart, kidney, or liver disease, and by certain medicines including estrogens and corticosteroids. it belongs to a class called diuretics, also known as water pills. it helps the kidneys remove extra water and salt in the urine. treating high blood pressure helps prevent damage to the brain, heart, blood vessels, kidneys, and eyes that can lead to heart disease, heart attack, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, and vision loss. in addition to medication, lifestyle changes such as a low salt, low fat diet, maintaining a healthy weight, exercising at least 30 minutes most days, not smoking, and using alcohol in moderation help control blood pressure. chlorothiazide may also be prescribed for diabetes insipidus, certain electrolyte disturbances, and to help prevent kidney stones in people with high calcium levels; discuss risks and benefits with your doctor, and ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information about other possible uses. how should this medicine be used? chlorothiazide comes as an oral tablet and as an oral suspension. it is usually taken once or twice daily. for high blood pressure, take it at the same times each day. for edema, it may be taken every day or only on selected days of the week. take doses with meals or a snack. follow your prescription label exactly; ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take chlorothiazide exactly as directed. do not take more or less, or take it more often, than prescribed. chlorothiazide controls high blood pressure and edema but does not cure them. continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop without consulting your doctor. what special precautions should i follow? before taking chlorothiazide, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to chlorothiazide, sulfonamide antibiotics, penicillins, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the tablets or suspension. ask your pharmacist or review the patient information for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. if you take cholestyramine or colestipol, take them 1 hour before or 4 hours after chlorothiazide. nonprescription nsaids such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin) and naproxen (aleve) may interact; inform your doctor and pharmacist if you use them, and do not start them while on chlorothiazide without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have kidney disease; you may be advised not to take chlorothiazide. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had asthma, diabetes, high cholesterol, systemic lupus erythematosus, gout, liver disease, or parathyroid disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, inform your doctor. if you become pregnant while taking chlorothiazide, call your doctor right away. limit unnecessary or prolonged sun exposure and use protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen because chlorothiazide can increase sun sensitivity. chlorothiazide may cause dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting, especially when you first start it or when you stand up quickly. to reduce this risk, rise slowly from bed and sit with your feet on the floor for a few minutes before standing. alcohol can worsen these effects. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow your doctor’s advice if you are told to follow a low salt or low sodium diet, or to increase potassium rich foods such as bananas, prunes, raisins, and orange juice. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects that often improve with time include frequent urination, muscle spasms, blurred vision, constipation, diarrhea, vomiting, loss of appetite, headache, and hair loss. serious side effects require immediate medical attention. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have signs of dehydration or electrolyte imbalance such as dry mouth, intense thirst, nausea, vomiting, weakness, unusual tiredness, drowsiness, restlessness, confusion, muscle weakness, pain or cramps, or a fast heartbeat; fever; blisters or peeling skin; trouble breathing or swallowing; hives; rash; itching; or yellowing of the skin or eyes.

name: methyldopa and hydrochlorothiazide
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? the combination of methyldopa and hydrochlorothiazide is prescribed to treat high blood pressure. methyldopa relaxes blood vessels to improve blood flow, while hydrochlorothiazide helps lower blood pressure by removing excess water and salt. untreated high blood pressure can damage the brain, heart, blood vessels, kidneys, and other organs, leading to heart disease, heart attack, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, vision loss, and other complications. along with medication, lifestyle changes such as eating a low-fat, low-salt diet, maintaining a healthy weight, exercising at least 30 minutes most days, avoiding smoking, and limiting alcohol can help control blood pressure. how should this medicine be used? this medicine is taken by mouth as a tablet, usually two or three times daily. take it at the same times each day to help you remember. follow your prescription label exactly; ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. this medicine controls but does not cure high blood pressure, so keep taking it even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor. what special precautions should i follow? before taking methyldopa and hydrochlorothiazide, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to methyldopa, hydrochlorothiazide, sulfa drugs, any other medicines, or any tablet ingredients; ask for a list of ingredients. some medicines should not be used with this combination, and others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. review all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and herbal products you take or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist before starting, stopping, or changing any medication. if you take iron supplements or multivitamins containing iron, do not take them at the same time as methyldopa and hydrochlorothiazide; ask your doctor how long to separate the doses. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney or liver disease, diabetes, gout, or high cholesterol. if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding, discuss the risks and benefits; call your doctor if you become pregnant while taking this medicine. if you are 65 or older, talk with your doctor; this combination is generally not preferred in older adults because safer alternatives are available. if you are having any surgery, including dental procedures, tell the doctor or dentist you take this medication. this medicine may cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery for 48–72 hours after starting or after a dose increase. ask your doctor about alcohol use, as alcohol can worsen side effects. what special dietary instructions should i follow? your doctor may recommend a low-salt or low-sodium diet; follow these instructions carefully. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? methyldopa and hydrochlorothiazide may cause side effects. common effects include dark urine, frequent urination, dry mouth, headache, upset stomach, vomiting, loss of appetite, diarrhea, gas, and rash. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor right away if you have extreme tiredness, muscle weakness or cramps, unexplained fever, yellowing of the skin or eyes, trouble breathing, or swelling of the ankles or feet. this medication may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: alectinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? alectinib is used to treat a specific type of non-small-cell lung cancer (nsclc) that has spread to other parts of the body. it belongs to a class of medicines called kinase inhibitors and works by blocking an abnormal protein that signals cancer cells to multiply, helping to slow or stop their spread. how should this medicine be used? alectinib comes as capsules taken by mouth and is usually taken with food twice daily. take it at the same times every day. follow your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. take it exactly as directed; do not take more or less or more often than prescribed. swallow the capsules whole; do not open or dissolve them. if you vomit after a dose, do not take an extra dose; continue your regular dosing schedule. your doctor may temporarily pause, reduce, or permanently stop your treatment if certain side effects occur and will monitor how you are feeling during treatment. continue taking alectinib even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking alectinib, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to alectinib, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the capsules; your pharmacist can provide a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you closely for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver disease, lung or breathing problems, or a slow or irregular heartbeat. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or plan to father a child, you should not become pregnant while taking alectinib. females should use reliable birth control during treatment and for at least 1 week after the final dose. males should use effective birth control with their female partner during treatment and for 3 months after the final dose. if you or your partner becomes pregnant while taking alectinib, call your doctor immediately; alectinib may harm the fetus. if you are breast-feeding, do not breast-feed while taking alectinib and for 1 week after your last dose. avoid unnecessary or prolonged exposure to sunlight, including sunlamps and tanning beds, and wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and a sunscreen with a sun protection factor (spf) of at least 50 while taking alectinib and for at least 7 days after your last dose; alectinib may make your skin more sensitive to sunlight. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? alectinib may cause side effects. common side effects include constipation, diarrhea, swelling in your hands, face, or eyelids, headache, weight gain, and rash. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following or those listed in the special precautions section, call your doctor immediately: new or worsening shortness of breath, difficulty breathing, or cough; fever; sudden chest pain; dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting; vision changes; sudden muscle pain, tenderness, or weakness; back pain; tiredness; rash; itchy skin; loss of appetite; nausea; vomiting; yellowing of the skin or the whites of your eyes; pain on the right side of your stomach area; change in the amount or color of your urine; new or worsening swelling in your legs or feet; or bleeding or bruising more easily than normal. alectinib may cause other side effects.

name: alemtuzumab injection chronic lymphocytic leukemia
instructions: notice: alemtuzumab injection (campath) is supplied only through a restricted program called the campath distribution program. your prescriber must be enrolled and follow program requirements. the program ships the medicine directly to your doctor, hospital, or pharmacy. important warning: alemtuzumab can sharply reduce the blood cells made by your bone marrow. call your doctor right away if you have unusual bruising or bleeding, small red or purple skin spots, pale skin, weakness, or severe tiredness. because minor injuries can lead to heavy bleeding, use a soft toothbrush, shave with an electric razor, and avoid contact sports or activities that could cause injury. this medicine also lowers your ability to fight infections and raises the risk of serious or life threatening infection. call your doctor immediately if you get a fever, cough, sore throat, or a wound that is red, draining pus, or slow to heal. you will be given medicines to prevent infection during treatment and for at least 2 months after the last dose; take them exactly as directed. wash your hands often and avoid close contact with people who have contagious illnesses. if you need a blood transfusion while on this medicine, you must receive irradiated blood products. serious and sometimes fatal infusion reactions may occur during or after a dose. each dose is given in a medical facility with close monitoring, and you will receive medicines beforehand to reduce reactions. your doctor will start with a low dose and increase it gradually. seek immediate medical help during or after an infusion if you have fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, hives, rash, itching, trouble breathing or swallowing, slowed breathing, throat tightness, swelling of the eyes, face, mouth, lips, tongue, or throat, hoarseness, dizziness, lightheadedness, fainting, fast or irregular heartbeat, or chest pain. keep all appointments for doctor visits and lab tests so your response and safety can be checked. discuss the risks and benefits of alemtuzumab with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? alemtuzumab injection is used to treat b cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia (b cll), a slow growing cancer in which too many b lymphocytes build up in the body. it is a monoclonal antibody that helps the immune system destroy cancer cells. another alemtuzumab product (lemtrada) treats multiple sclerosis; this information applies only to campath for b cll. if you are receiving alemtuzumab for multiple sclerosis, read the alemtuzumab injection (multiple sclerosis) monograph. how should this medicine be used? alemtuzumab is given as an intravenous infusion over at least 2 hours by a health care professional in a clinic or hospital. doses are increased gradually over the first 3 to 7 days to help your body adjust. after you reach the target dose, it is usually given 3 times per week on alternating days (for example, monday, wednesday, friday) for up to 12 weeks. premedications may make you drowsy, so arrange for someone to accompany you and drive you home. you may feel improvement after 4 to 6 weeks, but treatment generally continues for 12 weeks. your doctor may adjust the dose or schedule based on how you respond and any side effects. this medicine may also be prescribed for other uses;
