ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving alemtuzumab, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to alemtuzumab or to any medicines, provide a list of all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use, and report all current and past medical conditions. do not become pregnant during treatment. you will have a pregnancy test before starting and must use effective birth control during treatment and for 3 months after the final dose. if you become pregnant, call your doctor immediately, as this medicine can harm an unborn baby. do not breastfeed during treatment and for 3 months after the final dose. do not receive live vaccines during treatment or shortly after unless approved by your doctor. women who receive alemtuzumab during pregnancy should speak with their pediatrician, because the infant may need to delay live vaccines for a period of time. this medicine may reduce fertility in both men and women; discuss risks with your doctor. if you need any surgery, including dental procedures, tell the surgeon or dentist that you are receiving alemtuzumab. follow infection prevention advice and take all prescribed preventive antibiotics or antivirals during treatment and for at least 2 months afterward. if a transfusion is needed, ensure irradiated blood products are used. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor instructs otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is administered by health care professionals on a set schedule. if you miss an appointment, contact your doctor or clinic as soon as possible to reschedule. do not attempt to self administer. what side effects can this medication cause? alemtuzumab can cause side effects. common effects include nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, diarrhea, loss of appetite, mouth sores, headache, anxiety, difficulty falling or staying asleep, tremor, and muscle pain. serious side effects may occur. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care for any symptoms listed under important warning or for sudden drooping on one side of the face, sudden weakness or numbness of an arm or leg (especially on one side), or trouble speaking or understanding. swelling in the legs or ankles, weight gain, fatigue, or foamy urine can occur months or years after the final dose. other side effects may occur; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: alemtuzumab injection multiple sclerosis
instructions: important warning: alemtuzumab injection can cause serious or life-threatening autoimmune problems, including immune thrombocytopenia (a dangerously low platelet count) and kidney damage. call your doctor right away if you notice unusual bleeding; easy bruising; red, pink, or purple spots on the skin; bleeding from the gums or nose; heavy or irregular menstrual bleeding; bleeding that is hard to stop; blood in the urine; coughing up blood; swelling of the legs or feet; chest pain; shortness of breath; decreased urine; or severe fatigue. serious infusion reactions may occur during a dose and for up to 3 days afterward. you will receive each dose in a medical facility, be monitored during the infusion, and must stay at the infusion center for at least 2 hours after completion. seek immediate medical care if you develop fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, headache, hives, rash, itching, flushing of the face/neck/upper chest, heartburn, shortness of breath, trouble breathing or swallowing, slowed breathing, throat tightness, swelling of the eyes, face, mouth, lips, tongue, or throat, hoarseness, dizziness, lightheadedness, fainting, fast or irregular heartbeat, or chest pain. alemtuzumab may cause stroke or tears in the neck arteries that supply blood to the brain, often within 3 days of treatment; get emergency help for facial drooping on one side, a sudden severe headache or neck pain, sudden weakness or numbness of an arm or leg (especially on one side), or difficulty speaking or understanding. alemtuzumab may increase the risk of certain cancers, including thyroid cancer, melanoma (a skin cancer), and some blood cancers. have your skin checked by a doctor before treatment and yearly thereafter, and call your doctor if you notice any of the following that may indicate thyroid or skin cancer: a new lump or swelling in the neck; pain at the front of the neck; unexplained weight loss; bone or joint pain; lumps or swellings in the skin, head, groin, or abdomen; a change in a mole’s shape, size, or color or bleeding; a small lesion with an irregular border and areas that look red, white, blue, or blue-black; persistent hoarseness or voice changes; difficulty swallowing or breathing; or cough. because of these risks, alemtuzumab is available only through a special restricted program called the lemtrada risk evaluation and mitigation strategy (rems) program. ask your doctor if you have questions about how you will receive your medication. keep all doctor and laboratory appointments. your doctor will order tests before and during treatment and every month for 4 years after your final dose to monitor for side effects. discuss the risks and benefits of alemtuzumab with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? alemtuzumab injection is used in adults to treat relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis (ms), including relapsing-remitting disease and active secondary progressive disease, typically in people who have not improved with at least two other ms medicines. it is a monoclonal antibody that lowers the activity of immune cells that can damage nerves. alemtuzumab is also available as an injection (campath) for chronic lymphocytic leukemia (cll); this information covers alemtuzumab (lemtrada) for ms only. if you are receiving alemtuzumab for cll, see alemtuzumab injection (chronic lymphocytic leukemia). how should this medicine be used? alemtuzumab is given as an intravenous infusion over about 4 hours by a healthcare professional. it is usually given once daily for 5 days for the first course, then once daily for 3 days 12 months after the first course. an additional 3-day course may be given at least 12 months after the previous course if your doctor decides you need more treatment. alemtuzumab helps control ms symptoms but does not cure the disease. other uses for this medicine: your doctor may prescribe this medicine for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to alemtuzumab or any ingredients in the injection. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and supplements you take or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you more closely for side effects. tell your doctor if you have hiv; any current infection; a history of shingles (herpes zoster), genital herpes, or chickenpox (varicella); liver disease including hepatitis b or c; thyroid, heart, lung, or gallbladder disease; tuberculosis (tb) now or in the past or close contact with someone who has had tb; or if you have ever had a positive tb skin test. you may need testing for tb before treatment. tell your doctor if you have bleeding problems or kidney disease. do not receive alemtuzumab if you have an active serious infection. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor. you may need a pregnancy test before starting treatment. do not become pregnant during treatment and for 4 months after your last dose; use effective birth control and call your doctor right away if you become pregnant, because alemtuzumab may harm the fetus. ask whether you need any vaccines before treatment. do not receive vaccines without talking to your doctor during treatment; avoid live vaccines within 6 weeks before starting alemtuzumab, during treatment, and until your doctor says it is safe. what special dietary instructions should i follow? to reduce infection risk, avoid the following starting at least 1 month before your first infusion and throughout treatment: deli meats; dairy products made with unpasteurized milk; soft cheeses; and undercooked meat, seafood, or poultry. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss or must delay an infusion appointment, contact your doctor as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to self-administer alemtuzumab or change the dosing schedule on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? alemtuzumab can cause side effects. common effects include difficulty falling or staying asleep; pain in the legs, arms, toes, or hands; mouth or throat pain; tingling, prickling, chills, burning, or numbness of the skin; red, itchy, or scaly skin; heartburn; dizziness; changes in taste; and hair loss. serious side effects can occur. call your doctor right away or get emergency help if you have any of the following, or any symptoms listed in the important warning section: shortness of breath, chest pain or tightness, cough, wheezing, or coughing up blood; fever, chills, or other signs of infection; easy bruising or bleeding, blood in the urine or stool, nosebleeds, bloody vomit, or painful and/or swollen joints; diarrhea, red or black tarry stools, or severe stomach pain; excessive sweating, eye swelling, weight loss, nervousness, or fast heartbeat; unexplained weight gain, tiredness, feeling cold, or constipation; depression or thoughts of harming yourself; genital sores, pins-and-needles sensation, or a rash on the penis or in the vaginal area; cold sores or fever blisters on or around the mouth; a painful rash with blisters, itching, or tingling on one side of the face or body; in women, vaginal odor, white or yellowish discharge that may be lumpy like cottage cheese, or vaginal itching; white patches on the tongue or inner cheeks; stomach pain or tenderness with fever, nausea, or vomiting; yellowing of the eyes or skin, loss of appetite, extreme tiredness, or dark urine; decreased strength or weakness on one side of the body that worsens over time, clumsiness of the arms or legs, new or worsening unsteadiness, or difficulty walking; vision changes; small purple spots on the skin, pale skin, tiredness, weakness, or fast heartbeat; agitation, confusion, memory loss, mood or personality changes, changes in thinking or alertness, or hallucinations; seizures; rash; swollen glands; or a high fever lasting more than 1 week. alemtuzumab may increase the risk of cervical human papillomavirus (hpv) infection; women should have a pap test every year. alemtuzumab may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: alendronate
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? alendronate is prescribed to treat and prevent osteoporosis—a condition where bones become thin, weak, and more likely to fracture—in postmenopausal women and in men. it is also used to treat osteoporosis in adults who take corticosteroids, and to treat paget’s disease of bone, in which bones are soft, weak, painful, deformed, or break easily. alendronate belongs to a class of drugs called bisphosphonates; it works by slowing bone breakdown and increasing bone mineral density. how should this medicine be used? alendronate is taken by mouth as a tablet, an effervescent tablet, or an oral solution. the solution is usually taken once weekly on an empty stomach in the morning. the 5-mg and 10-mg tablets are usually taken once daily on an empty stomach in the morning; the 35-mg and 70-mg tablets are usually taken once weekly on an empty stomach in the morning. for paget’s disease, the 40-mg tablet is typically taken once daily in the morning for six months. effervescent tablets are generally taken once weekly on an empty stomach in the morning. follow your prescription label exactly; ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take alendronate exactly as directed; do not change your dose or schedule without your doctor’s advice. improper use can reduce effectiveness and may injure the esophagus or cause mouth sores. take alendronate immediately after getting out of bed for the day, before eating or drinking anything. do not take it at bedtime or before you get up for the day. after taking it, wait at least 30 minutes before eating, drinking, or taking any other medicines (including vitamins or antacids). remain upright—sitting or standing—for at least 30 minutes after dosing and until after you have eaten the first meal of the day. if you take the tablet, swallow it whole with a full glass (6 to 8 ounces [180 to 240 ml]) of plain water only; do not split, chew, crush, or suck the tablet. do not take it with tea, coffee, juice, milk, mineral water, sparkling water, or any liquid other than plain water. if you take the oral solution, follow it with at least 2 ounces (60 ml; 1/4 cup) of plain water; do not take it with any beverage other than plain water. if you take the effervescent tablet, dissolve one tablet in a full glass (4 ounces [120 ml]) of plain, non-carbonated drinking water only. wait at least 5 minutes after the fizzing stops, stir for 10 seconds, and then drink. do not swallow, suck, or chew the effervescent tablet. alendronate manages osteoporosis and paget’s disease but does not cure them; it may take 3 months or longer to see increases in bone density. keep taking it regularly to maintain benefit. do not stop without consulting your doctor, and periodically review with your doctor whether you should continue therapy. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medicine may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for details. what special precautions should i follow? before taking alendronate, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to alendronate or any other medications. provide a complete list of all prescription and over-the-counter medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. nonprescription products that may interact include aspirin and other nsaids (such as ibuprofen and naproxen), mineral oil, calcium supplements, and heartburn/indigestion medicines; tell your doctor and pharmacist if you use these, and do not start them while on alendronate without medical advice. take any other oral medications at least 30 minutes after alendronate. tell your doctor if you cannot sit or stand upright for at least 30 minutes, if you have or have ever had low blood calcium, aspiration risk, or any esophageal problems—your doctor may advise against alendronate. tell your doctor if you are receiving radiation therapy; if you follow a sodium-restricted diet (important with effervescent tablets); and if you have or have had anemia, low vitamin d, trouble swallowing, heartburn, ulcers or other stomach issues, cancer, any infection (especially oral), problems with your mouth, teeth, or gums, bleeding disorders, or dental or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant (alendronate may remain in the body for years), or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant during or after treatment. alendronate can cause osteonecrosis of the jaw (onj), particularly with dental surgery or procedures. have a dental exam and complete needed dental care (including adjusting ill-fitting dentures) before starting. maintain good oral hygiene and discuss any planned dental work with your doctor while taking this medicine. alendronate may cause severe bone, muscle, or joint pain that can start days to years after beginning treatment; call your doctor right away if this occurs—your doctor may stop the medication and the pain may resolve. ask your doctor about other ways to prevent or slow osteoporosis, including not smoking, limiting alcohol, and doing regular weight-bearing exercise. what special dietary instructions should i follow? consume adequate calcium and vitamin d through food and beverages while taking alendronate. your doctor will recommend good sources and how much you need daily. if you cannot meet your needs through diet, your doctor may prescribe or recommend a supplement. what should i do if i forget a dose? for once-daily dosing: if you miss a dose, skip it for that day; take your next dose the following morning as usual. do not take a double dose. for once-weekly dosing: if you miss a dose, take one dose the morning after you remember; then return to your regular once-weekly schedule on your usual day. do not take two doses on the same day or double up. what side effects can this medication cause? alendronate can cause side effects. contact your doctor if any of the following are severe or persistent: nausea; stomach pain; constipation; diarrhea; gas; bloating or a feeling of fullness; changes in taste; headache; dizziness; swelling of joints, hands, or legs; muscle spasms, twitches, or cramps. some side effects are serious. stop taking alendronate and call your doctor immediately if you have new or worsening heartburn; trouble or pain with swallowing; chest pain; bloody vomit or vomit that looks like coffee grounds; black, tarry, or bloody stools; fever; blisters or peeling skin; rash that may worsen with sunlight; itching; hives; swelling of the eyes, face, lips, tongue, or throat; difficulty breathing; hoarseness; painful or swollen gums; loose teeth; numbness or heavy feeling in the jaw; poor jaw healing; eye pain; or dull, aching pain in the hips, groin, or thighs. use of bisphosphonates like alendronate for osteoporosis may increase the risk of unusual thigh bone fractures; you may have hip, groin, or thigh pain for weeks or months before a fracture, and breaks can occur without a fall or trauma. people with osteoporosis can also break this bone even without taking alendronate. discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. alendronate may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: naproxen
instructions: important warning: people who use nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) other than aspirin, such as naproxen, may have a higher risk of heart attack or stroke than those who do not take these medicines. these events can occur without warning and can be fatal. the risk can arise at any time during treatment and is greater with higher doses or long-term use. do not take an nsaid like naproxen if you have recently had a heart attack unless your doctor specifically tells you to do so. your risk may be higher if you or a family member has or has had heart disease, a prior heart attack or stroke, if you smoke, or if you have high cholesterol, high blood pressure, or diabetes. seek emergency medical care right away if you have chest pain, shortness of breath, weakness on one side of the body, or slurred speech. do not take naproxen right before or right after coronary artery bypass graft (cabg) surgery. nsaids, including naproxen, can cause ulcers, bleeding, or perforation in the esophagus, stomach, or intestines. these problems can happen at any time, may occur without warning symptoms, and can be fatal. the risk is higher with long-term or high-dose use, in older adults, in people with poor overall health, and in those who smoke or drink large amounts of alcohol while taking naproxen. tell your doctor if you take any of the following: anticoagulants (blood thinners) such as warfarin (coumadin, jantoven); aspirin; other nsaids such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin) or ketoprofen; oral steroids such as dexamethasone, methylprednisolone (medrol), or prednisone (rayos); salicylates such as diflunisal, magnesium salicylate (doan’s), or salsalate; selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (ssris) such as citalopram (celexa), fluoxetine (prozac, in symbyax), fluvoxamine (luvox), paroxetine (brisdelle, paxil, pexeva), or sertraline (zoloft); or serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (snris) such as desvenlafaxine (pristiq), duloxetine (cymbalta), or venlafaxine (effexor xr). also tell your doctor if you currently have or have ever had ulcers, bleeding in your stomach or intestines, other bleeding problems, or liver disease. stop naproxen and call your doctor if you develop stomach pain, heartburn, vomit that is bloody or looks like coffee grounds, blood in your stool, or black, tarry stools. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor will monitor your symptoms, may order tests to check your response to naproxen, and will aim to use the lowest effective dose. be sure to tell your doctor how you are feeling so your treatment can be adjusted for safety. you will receive a medication guide when you start prescription naproxen and with each refill; read it carefully and ask questions if needed. why is this medication prescribed? prescription naproxen relieves pain, tenderness, swelling, and stiffness due to osteoarthritis (joint lining breakdown), rheumatoid arthritis (inflammation of the joint lining), juvenile arthritis, and ankylosing spondylitis (arthritis mainly affecting the spine). prescription tablets, extended-release tablets, and suspension are also used for shoulder pain from bursitis (inflamed fluid-filled sac) or tendinitis (inflamed tendon), for gout flares (joint pain from crystal buildup), and for other pain, including menstrual cramps. nonprescription naproxen reduces fever and relieves mild pain from headaches, muscle aches, arthritis, menstrual periods, the common cold, toothaches, and backaches. naproxen is an nsaid that works by blocking substances that cause pain, fever, and inflammation. how should this medicine be used? prescription naproxen is available as a regular tablet, a delayed-release (enteric-coated) tablet that dissolves in the intestine, an extended-release tablet, and an oral suspension. extended-release tablets are usually taken once daily. regular tablets, delayed-release tablets, and suspension are typically taken twice daily for arthritis. tablets and suspension are generally taken every 8 hours for gout and every 6 to 8 hours as needed for pain. if you use naproxen on a regular schedule, take it at the same times each day. nonprescription naproxen comes as a tablet, capsule, or gel capsule and is usually taken with a full glass of water every 8 to 12 hours as needed; it may be taken with food or milk to lessen nausea. follow the directions on your prescription or the product label exactly. do not take more, more often, or longer than directed. shake the suspension gently before each dose and measure with an oral syringe or dosing cup. swallow delayed-release and extended-release tablets whole; do not split, crush, or chew. for arthritis, some improvement may be seen within 1 week, with full benefit taking 2 weeks or longer. stop nonprescription naproxen and contact your doctor if symptoms worsen, new or unexpected symptoms occur, the painful area becomes red or swollen, pain lasts more than 10 days, or fever lasts more than 3 days. other uses for this medicine naproxen is sometimes used for paget’s disease of bone (abnormally thick, fragile, misshapen bones) and bartter syndrome (a condition causing low potassium with muscle cramps and weakness). discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. it may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for details. what special precautions should i follow? before taking naproxen, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to naproxen, aspirin or other nsaids (such as ibuprofen or ketoprofen), other pain or fever medications, any other medicines, or any ingredients in naproxen products. provide your doctor and pharmacist with a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. do not take otc naproxen with any other pain medicine unless your doctor advises it; common otc interactions include aspirin and other nsaids (e.g., ibuprofen). do not start these while on naproxen without consulting your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you are on a low-sodium diet and if you have or have ever had any conditions noted in the important warning, or asthma (especially with frequent nasal congestion or nasal polyps), heart failure, swelling of the hands, arms, feet, ankles, or lower legs, anemia, or kidney disease. if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding, discuss use with your doctor. naproxen may harm the fetus and cause delivery problems if taken around 20 weeks or later in pregnancy; do not use at or after 20 weeks unless your doctor tells you to. call your doctor if you become pregnant while taking naproxen. this medicine may temporarily reduce fertility in women. adults 65 years and older should generally use the lowest effective dose for the shortest time because higher, regular doses raise the risk of serious side effects. if you are having any surgery, including dental procedures, tell the surgeon or dentist you take naproxen. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor instructs you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is nearly time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? naproxen may cause side effects. common effects include constipation, gas, increased thirst, headache, dizziness, lightheadedness, drowsiness, trouble falling or staying asleep, burning or tingling sensations in the arms or legs, cold-like symptoms, ringing in the ears, or hearing problems. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away and stop taking naproxen if you have any of the following or any symptoms listed in the important warning: vision changes; a feeling that a tablet is stuck in your throat; unexplained weight gain; shortness of breath or trouble breathing; swelling of the abdomen, ankles, feet, or legs; sore throat, fever, chills, or other signs of infection; blisters; rash; skin redness; itching; hives; swelling of the eyes, face, lips, tongue, throat, arms, or hands; difficulty breathing or swallowing; hoarseness; unusual tiredness; pain in the upper right abdomen; nausea; diarrhea; yellowing of the skin or eyes; flu-like symptoms; easy bruising or purple spots under the skin; fast heartbeat; cloudy, discolored, or bloody urine; back pain; difficult or painful urination; reduced urination; loss of appetite; or confusion. naproxen may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: alfuzosin
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? alfuzosin is used in men to relieve symptoms of an enlarged prostate (benign prostatic hyperplasia, bph), such as difficulty starting urination, dribbling, weak urine stream, incomplete bladder emptying, painful urination, and frequent or urgent urination. it belongs to a class of drugs called alpha blockers and works by relaxing muscles in the prostate and bladder to improve urine flow. how should this medicine be used? alfuzosin is an extended-release tablet taken by mouth once daily, immediately after a meal. do not take it on an empty stomach. to help you remember, take it after the same meal each day. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take it exactly as directed; do not take more or less, or more often, than prescribed. swallow tablets whole—do not split, chew, or crush. alfuzosin controls bph symptoms but does not cure the condition, so continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking alfuzosin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to alfuzosin, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor if you have liver disease—your doctor may advise you not to take alfuzosin. some medicines should not be used with alfuzosin; others may need dose changes or extra monitoring. discuss all medications you take or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist before starting alfuzosin, and always seek their advice before starting, stopping, or changing any medication while on alfuzosin. the nonprescription product cimetidine (tagamet) may interact with alfuzosin; be sure your doctor and pharmacist know you use it, and do not start it while taking alfuzosin without medical advice. tell your doctor if you or a family member has an irregular heartbeat; and if you have or have ever had prostate cancer, angina (chest pain), low blood pressure, heart or kidney disease, or if you have ever become dizzy, fainted, or had low blood pressure after taking any medication. alfuzosin is for use in men only; women should not take it, especially if pregnant or breastfeeding. if a pregnant woman takes alfuzosin, she should contact her doctor. if you are having any surgery, including dental procedures, tell the doctor or dentist that you take alfuzosin. if you need eye surgery during or after treatment, be sure to tell the eye surgeon that you take or have taken alfuzosin. alfuzosin may cause dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting, especially when standing up quickly, and particularly when you first start the medication. to reduce this risk, rise slowly from bed and sit with your feet on the floor for a few minutes before standing. if these symptoms persist, call your doctor. avoid driving, operating machinery, or doing hazardous tasks until you know how alfuzosin affects you. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor about eating grapefruit or drinking grapefruit juice while taking alfuzosin. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? alfuzosin may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of the following are severe or do not go away: tiredness, headache, runny or stuffy nose, general pain, stomach pain, heartburn, constipation, nausea, decreased sexual ability, sore throat, fever, chills, cough, or other signs of infection. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor immediately if you have: rash; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; hoarseness; difficulty swallowing or breathing; chest pain; or fainting. alfuzosin may cause other side effects.

name: concizumab-mtci injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? concizumab-mtci is used to reduce or prevent bleeding episodes in people with certain types of hemophilia. it is a monoclonal antibody that helps the blood clot more effectively. how should this medicine be used? concizumab-mtci is supplied as a solution in a prefilled dosing pen for subcutaneous (under the skin) injection. inject it once daily at the same time each day. use it exactly as prescribed; do not use more or less, and do not use it more often than directed. it helps control bleeding but does not cure hemophilia. keep using it even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor. your first dose will be larger, followed by a smaller daily dose for 4 weeks. after 4 weeks, your doctor will check labs and adjust to a maintenance dose if needed. your healthcare provider will show you or your caregiver how to inject it; also read the manufacturer’s instructions for use and ask your pharmacist or doctor if you have questions. inspect the solution before injecting; it should be clear and colorless to slightly yellow and may contain some clear or white particles. do not use it if it is discolored or if the pen is past its expiration date. never reuse needles and never share needles or pens. remove the needle right after injecting and dispose of it in a puncture-resistant sharps container; ask your healthcare provider how to dispose of the container. inject into the thigh or abdomen at least 2 inches from the belly button. rotate injection sites with each dose. do not inject into skin that is tender, bruised, red, hard, or into areas with moles, scars, or stretch marks. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medicine may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using concizumab-mtci, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to this medication, any of its ingredients, or to any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe any allergy symptoms you have had. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have a serious injury or infection, or if you have or have ever had cancer or blood vessel disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor. you may need a pregnancy test before starting treatment; use effective birth control during treatment and for 7 weeks after your last dose. discuss which birth control is right for you. call your doctor if you become pregnant while using concizumab-mtci. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, tell the doctor or dentist that you are using concizumab-mtci. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose during the first 4 weeks of treatment, contact your doctor for instructions. for maintenance dosing: if you miss 1 dose, continue your regular dosing schedule. if you miss 2 to 6 doses, use 2 doses as soon as you remember, then resume your usual dose and schedule starting the next day. if you miss 7 or more maintenance doses, contact your doctor right away for instructions about your next doses. what side effects can this medication cause? concizumab-mtci may cause side effects. common: redness, bruising, or bleeding at the injection site. serious: signs of an allergic reaction such as itching, redness, rash, hives; chest tightness or wheezing; swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or hands; difficulty swallowing or breathing; fast heartbeat; dizziness. other serious symptoms may include swelling, warmth, pain, or redness of the skin; shortness of breath or chest pain; headache, confusion, difficulty with speech or movement, numbness of the face, eye pain or swelling, or vision problems; sudden pain in the stomach or back area. if you experience serious symptoms, call your doctor immediately or seek emergency medical care. concizumab-mtci may cause other side effects.

name: pemetrexed injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? pemetrexed injection is used with other chemotherapy medicines as an initial treatment for certain types of non-small cell lung cancer (nsclc) that have spread locally or to other parts of the body. it is also used alone as ongoing (maintenance) therapy in people whose nsclc has not worsened after prior chemotherapy, and in those whose disease could not be successfully treated with other chemotherapy drugs. in addition, pemetrexed is combined with another chemotherapy medicine as first-line treatment for malignant pleural mesothelioma in patients who cannot undergo surgery. pemetrexed is an antifolate anticancer agent that slows tumor growth by blocking folate-dependent processes cancer cells need to multiply. how should this medicine be used? pemetrexed injection is available as a solution and as a powder that is mixed with liquid and infused into a vein over about 10 minutes. it is administered by a healthcare professional in a clinic or infusion center. your dosing schedule depends on your condition and response, but it is typically given once every 21 days. your doctor will usually prescribe folic acid, vitamin b12, and a corticosteroid such as dexamethasone to help lower the risk of side effects; follow the instructions for these medicines carefully and call your doctor if you miss a dose. you will have blood tests before and during treatment; your doctor may change your dose, delay a cycle, or stop treatment based on your results. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be used for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving pemetrexed, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to pemetrexed, mannitol (osmitrol), any other medications, or any ingredient in the injection; ask your pharmacist or check the patient leaflet for a full ingredient list. provide a complete list of all prescription and over-the-counter medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; some products, including ibuprofen (advil, motrin), may interact with pemetrexed. do not start any new medication, including nonprescription products, while receiving pemetrexed without first discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have received radiation therapy, or if you have or have ever had kidney disease. if you are pregnant, could become pregnant, or plan to father a child, discuss risks with your doctor; females who can become pregnant need a pregnancy test before starting and must use effective birth control during treatment and for at least 6 months after the final dose; males should use reliable contraception with their partners during treatment and for 3 months after the last dose. call your doctor right away if a pregnancy occurs; pemetrexed can harm an unborn baby. do not breastfeed during treatment and for 1 week after the final dose. pemetrexed may cause fertility problems in males; it is not known if these effects are reversible; talk with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? continue your normal diet unless your doctor gives you different instructions. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment for a pemetrexed infusion, contact your doctor as soon as possible to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? pemetrexed may cause side effects. common effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, decreased appetite, altered taste, hair loss, rash, itching, tiredness, and joint pain. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor immediately or seek emergency care if you have: blisters, sores, peeling, or painful ulcers of the mouth, lips, nose, throat, genitals, or skin; redness, blistering, or a sunburn-like rash in an area previously treated with radiation; unusual bleeding or bruising; sore throat, fever, chills, cough, or other signs of infection; chest pain; fast heartbeat; persistent cough or shortness of breath; extreme fatigue or weakness; dizziness or fainting; weakness or numbness of an arm or leg; pain, burning, numbness, or tingling in the hands or feet; pale skin; severe headache; hives; or decreased urination. other side effects may occur. if someone collapses, has a seizure, has trouble breathing, or cannot be awakened, call 911 immediately. what other information should i know? keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory; tests will be done to monitor your response to treatment. keep a written list of all prescription and over-the-counter medicines, vitamins, minerals, and dietary supplements you use; bring it to every medical visit or if you are admitted to the hospital, and carry it with you for emergencies. brand names alimta; pemfexy.

name: bacillus calmette-guerin (bcg) vaccine
instructions: why is this medicine prescribed? the bcg vaccine helps the body develop immunity or protection against tuberculosis (tb) and may be given to people at high risk of developing tb. it is also used to treat certain bladder tumors or bladder cancer. this medication may sometimes be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? a healthcare professional will administer this medicine. for tb protection, it is injected into the skin. keep the vaccination area dry for 24 hours after the shot, and keep it clean until it looks the same as the surrounding skin. for bladder cancer, the medicine is instilled into your bladder through a tube (catheter). avoid drinking fluids for 4 hours before treatment, and empty your bladder just before the procedure. during the first hour after the medicine is instilled, lie on your stomach, back, and each side for 15 minutes. then stand, but try to keep the medicine in your bladder for another hour. tell your healthcare provider if you cannot retain the medicine for the full 2 hours. after 2 hours, empty your bladder while seated for safety. for the next 6 hours, disinfect your urine by pouring an equal amount of undiluted bleach into the toilet after you urinate and let it stand for 15 minutes before flushing. various dosing schedules may be used; your doctor will schedule your treatment. ask your doctor to explain any directions you do not understand. when the vaccine is given to protect against tb, it is usually given only once, but may be repeated in 2–3 months if there is not a good response on a tb skin test. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving bcg, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bcg or any other drugs; what prescription and nonprescription medications you are taking, especially antibiotics, cancer chemotherapy drugs, steroids, tuberculosis medicines, and vitamins; if you have had a recent smallpox vaccination or have had a positive tb test; and if you have an immune disorder, cancer, fever, an infection, or an area of severe burns. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while receiving bcg, call your doctor immediately. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary restrictions are needed unless your doctor gives you specific instructions. if you are receiving bcg for bladder cancer, avoid drinking fluids for 4 hours before each treatment as directed. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given by a healthcare professional. if you miss an appointment or treatment, contact your doctor or clinic as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to administer this medicine yourself. what side effects can this medicine cause? bcg may cause side effects. call your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: swollen lymph nodes; small red areas at the injection site that usually appear 10–14 days after injection, slowly decrease in size, and typically disappear after about 6 months; fever; blood in the urine; frequent or painful urination; upset stomach; vomiting. call your doctor immediately if you experience any of the following: severe skin rash; difficulty breathing or swallowing; wheezing. what should i do in case of overdose? in case of overdose, call the poison control helpline at 1-800-222-1222. if the person has collapsed, had a seizure, has trouble breathing, or cannot be awakened, call emergency services at 911 right away. what other information should i know? keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. brand names: theracys bcg; tice bcg. other names: bcg live; bcg vaccine. also referred to as bacillus calmette-guerin (bcg) vaccine.

name: bacitracin ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ophthalmic bacitracin is used to treat bacterial infections of the eye. it belongs to a class of drugs called antibiotics and works by killing bacteria that cause infection. how should this medicine be used? ophthalmic bacitracin is an eye ointment typically applied one to three times daily. follow the directions on your prescription label exactly, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not use more, less, or more often than prescribed. your symptoms should improve during treatment; call your doctor if they worsen, do not improve, or if you develop new eye problems. use ophthalmic bacitracin for the full prescribed course, even if you feel better; stopping too soon may fail to cure the infection and may promote antibiotic resistance. to apply: wash your hands with soap and water. use a mirror or have someone assist. do not let the tube tip touch your eye or any surface; keep it clean. tilt your head slightly forward. hold the tube between your thumb and index finger close to, but not touching, your eyelid, and brace your remaining fingers against your cheek or nose. with the other hand, gently pull the lower eyelid down to form a pocket. place a small ribbon of ointment into the pocket; about a 1/2‑inch (1.25 cm) strip is usually sufficient unless your doctor instructs otherwise. look downward, then gently close your eyes and keep them closed for 1 to 2 minutes to allow absorption. replace and tighten the cap immediately. wipe away any excess ointment from your eyelids and lashes with a clean tissue. do not rub your eyes, even if your vision is blurry. wash your hands again. if your doctor has directed you to use bacitracin ointment for an eyelid infection, gently cleanse your eyelids with water to remove scales and crusts, then apply a thin, even layer over the affected eyelid areas. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bacitracin, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the ointment; your pharmacist can provide a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take, especially any other eye medicines. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding; if you become pregnant while using the ointment, call your doctor. your vision may be temporarily blurry after application; wait until you can see clearly before driving or doing tasks that require good vision. if you wear soft contact lenses, do not wear contact lenses while you have an eye infection. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not apply extra ointment to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? bacitracin eye ointment may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of the following are severe or do not go away: itching, stinging, or burning of the eye. bacitracin eye ointment may cause other side effects.

name: bacitracin topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bacitracin topical is used to help prevent minor skin injuries such as cuts, scrapes, and burns from becoming infected. it is an antibiotic that works by stopping the growth of bacteria. how should this medicine be used? bacitracin comes as an ointment to apply to the skin, usually one to three times a day. it is available without a prescription, but your doctor may give you specific directions for your condition. follow the package instructions or your doctor or pharmacist carefully, and ask if anything is unclear. use bacitracin exactly as directed. do not use more or less, and do not apply it more often than directed. for external use only. do not let it get into your eyes, nose, or mouth, and do not swallow it. use it only for minor skin injuries. do not use it for deep cuts, puncture wounds, animal bites, serious burns, or injuries that affect large areas; call your doctor or get emergency medical help for these. stop using and call your doctor if a minor injury does not improve within 1 week. do not apply to a child’s diaper area, especially if the skin is broken or raw, unless a doctor tells you to; if directed to use it there, do not use tightly fitting diapers or plastic pants. to use the ointment: wash your hands well with soap and water. clean the injured area with soap and water and pat dry with a clean towel. apply a small amount about the size of a fingertip in a thin layer to the affected skin. do not touch the tip of the tube to your skin, hands, or any surface. replace and tighten the cap right away. you may cover the area with a sterile bandage. wash your hands again. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using bacitracin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bacitracin, zinc, any other medications, or any ingredients in the ointment. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using bacitracin, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not apply a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? bacitracin may cause side effects. stop using the ointment and call your doctor right away or get emergency medical help if you have itching, rash, hives, or difficulty breathing or swallowing. bacitracin may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using it.

name: baclofen
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? baclofen is prescribed to relieve pain and reduce spasticity (muscle stiffness and tightness) caused by multiple sclerosis, spinal cord injury, or other spinal cord diseases. it is a skeletal muscle relaxant that acts on nerves in the spinal cord to lessen the number and severity of muscle spasms, ease pain, and improve movement. how should this medicine be used? baclofen is available as tablets and as an oral solution to be taken by mouth, usually three times daily at evenly spaced intervals. follow your prescription label exactly. do not take more, take less, or take it more often than directed. use an oral dosing syringe to measure the liquid accurately; ask your pharmacist for one if it is not provided. keep taking baclofen even if you feel better. do not stop suddenly, especially if you have been taking high doses for a long time, as abrupt discontinuation can cause seizures, fever, confusion, muscle rigidity, or hallucinations. your doctor will guide you in gradually lowering the dose if needed. what special precautions should i follow? before using baclofen, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to baclofen or any ingredients in the tablets or oral solution, and ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell them about all medicines and supplements you take, including antidepressants, anti-anxiety medicines, antipsychotics, seizure medications, sedatives, sleep aids, and tranquilizers; dose adjustments or monitoring may be needed. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had epilepsy or seizures, stroke, rheumatic disease, cerebral palsy, parkinson’s disease, psychiatric conditions (such as schizophrenia or episodes of confusion), or kidney disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, inform your doctor; call right away if you become pregnant while taking baclofen. baclofen can cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. ask your doctor about alcohol use; alcohol can intensify baclofen’s side effects. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your normal diet. avoid or limit alcohol because it can increase drowsiness and other side effects. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include dizziness, weakness, confusion, headache, nausea, constipation, trouble falling or staying asleep, tiredness, and frequent urination. serious side effects can occur; call your doctor immediately if you experience hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that are not there) or seizures.

name: baloxavir marboxil
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? baloxavir marboxil is used to treat certain types of influenza (flu) in adults and in children 5 years of age and older who have had flu symptoms for no more than 2 days and are otherwise healthy or are at increased risk for flu-related complications. it is also used to treat some types of flu in adults and children 12 years and older who have had symptoms for no more than 2 days and are at high risk for influenza complications. in addition, it is used to prevent certain types of flu in adults and children 5 years and older after close contact with someone who has the flu. baloxavir marboxil is a polymerase acidic endonuclease (cap-dependent endonuclease) inhibitor that works by stopping the flu virus from multiplying and spreading in the body, which can shorten how long symptoms such as a stuffy or runny nose, sore throat, cough, muscle or joint aches, tiredness, headache, fever, and chills last. it does not prevent bacterial infections that can occur as complications of the flu. how should this medicine be used? baloxavir marboxil comes as tablets and as an oral suspension (liquid) to take by mouth. it is taken as a single dose, with or without food. follow the directions on your prescription label exactly, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not take baloxavir marboxil together with dairy products (such as milk or yogurt) or with calcium-fortified beverages. if using the suspension, gently swirl the bottle to mix; do not shake. use the provided oral syringe to measure your dose accurately. your total dose may require less than one bottle, one full bottle, or two bottles of the suspension. do not take more or less than prescribed. do not mix the suspension with other liquids or with soft foods. if you feel worse, develop new symptoms, or if your flu symptoms do not start to improve, call your doctor. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking baloxavir marboxil, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to baloxavir marboxil, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets or suspension; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and nutritional or herbal supplements you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you for side effects. do not take antacids or laxatives containing magnesium, aluminum, or calcium; calcium supplements; iron products; or vitamin or mineral supplements containing calcium, iron, zinc, or selenium at the same time as baloxavir marboxil. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. tell your doctor if you have recently received or are scheduled to receive any vaccines. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet; however, do not take this medicine together with dairy products or calcium-fortified drinks. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss your single dose, take it as soon as you remember. if it is close to 48 hours after your flu symptoms began, or if you are taking it to prevent flu after exposure and are unsure when to take it, call your doctor or pharmacist for advice. do not take more than the prescribed amount to make up for a missed dose, and avoid taking it at the same time as dairy products, calcium-fortified beverages, or supplements and antacids containing calcium, magnesium, aluminum, iron, zinc, or selenium. what side effects can this medication cause? baloxavir marboxil may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: vomiting, diarrhea, or nausea. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or get emergency medical help if you have difficulty breathing; swelling of the face or throat; swelling of the arms, hands, feet, or legs; hives or itching; or a new red skin lesion or bump. baloxavir marboxil may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: balsalazide
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? balsalazide is used to treat ulcerative colitis, a condition that causes swelling and sores in the lining of the colon and rectum, in adults and in children 5 years of age and older. it is an anti-inflammatory medicine that is converted in the body to mesalamine and helps decrease bowel inflammation, diarrhea, rectal bleeding, and stomach pain. this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? balsalazide comes as capsules taken by mouth. it is usually taken three times a day, with or without food. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. take balsalazide exactly as directed. do not take more or less, or take it more often, than prescribed. treatment is usually 8 weeks but may last up to 12 weeks. continue taking balsalazide even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor. swallow the capsules whole; do not split, chew, or crush them. if you cannot swallow capsules or you are giving this medicine to a child, you may open the capsules and sprinkle the contents over 2 teaspoonfuls (about 10 ml) of applesauce. eat the mixture right away and swallow; you may chew if needed. if you take capsules mixed with applesauce, your teeth and tongue may become stained. drink plenty of fluids while taking balsalazide. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses. ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking balsalazide, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to balsalazide; salicylates such as aspirin, choline magnesium trisalicylate, choline salicylate, diflunisal, or magnesium salicylate; mesalamine products such as apriso or pentasa; salsalate; sulfasalazine (azulfidine); any other medications; or any ingredients in the capsules. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. nonprescription products that may interact include aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin) and naproxen (aleve, naprosyn). do not start these while taking balsalazide without discussing with your health care provider, and make sure your providers know if you already take them. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had eczema or other atopic dermatitis; kidney stones; liver or kidney disease; or pyloric stenosis (slow stomach emptying). tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking balsalazide, call your doctor. avoid unnecessary or prolonged exposure to sunlight and wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen, because balsalazide can make your skin more sensitive to sunlight. do not take balsalazide if you received the varicella virus (chickenpox) vaccine in the past six weeks because of the risk of reye syndrome, a serious condition that affects the brain, liver, and other organs. be aware that balsalazide can cause a serious reaction with symptoms that can resemble a flare of ulcerative colitis; call your doctor if you develop stomach pain or cramping, bloody diarrhea, fever, headache, or a rash. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you different instructions, continue your usual diet. you may take balsalazide with or without food. drink plenty of fluids while taking this medicine. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? side effects can occur. common effects that are usually mild include headache, abdominal pain, upset stomach, diarrhea, vomiting, joint or muscle pain, difficulty falling or staying asleep, tiredness, gas, runny nose, cough, fever, sore throat or flu-like symptoms, loss of appetite, constipation, dry mouth, mouth sores, and painful menstrual periods. call your doctor right away or get emergency medical help if you have any of the following, or the symptoms listed in the special precautions section: rash, hives, itching, or peeling or blistering skin; swelling of the eyes, face, lips, tongue, mouth, or throat; trouble breathing or swallowing; new or worsening cough; shortness of breath; chest pain; extreme tiredness; yellowing of the skin or eyes; pain in the right upper part of the abdomen; pale stools; difficult or painful urination or cloudy, discolored, or bloody urine; side or back pain; bloating or swelling of the abdomen; increased diarrhea; or increased rectal bleeding. balsalazide may cause your urine to appear discolored or reddish brown when it contacts water or other surfaces, such as in the toilet; call your doctor if your urine is discolored.

name: bamlanivimab and etesevimab injection
instructions: notice: on january 24, 2022, the fda reissued the emergency use authorization (eua) stating that the bamlanivimab and etesevimab combination is not authorized to treat mild to moderate covid-19 in regions where infection is likely caused by a sars-cov-2 variant not susceptible to these drugs, based on available susceptibility data and regional variant frequency. given the widespread omicron variant in the united states, bamlanivimab and etesevimab are not recommended for mild to moderate disease anywhere in the u.s. at this time. important warning: bamlanivimab and etesevimab injection is still being studied for the treatment and prevention of covid-19 caused by sars-cov-2. clinical information is limited; more data are needed on how well it works and the possible adverse events. this medicine has not undergone the standard fda approval process; however, under an eua it may be used in certain non-hospitalized adults and children, and in hospitalized or non-hospitalized children and infants younger than 2 years of age who have mild to moderate covid-19 symptoms. why is this medication prescribed? bamlanivimab and etesevimab injection is used in certain non-hospitalized adults, children, and infants (including newborns) who have medical conditions that put them at higher risk for progressing to severe covid-19 (including hospitalization or death) to treat mild to moderate covid-19. it may also be used to prevent covid-19 after exposure in people who are not fully vaccinated or who are vaccinated but are immunocompromised or taking medicines that weaken the immune system and who have had close contact with, or are at high risk of close contact with, someone infected with sars-cov-2 (for example, residents of nursing homes or people in prisons). it is also used to treat mild to moderate covid-19 in hospitalized children and in infants younger than 2 years, including newborns. bamlanivimab and etesevimab are monoclonal antibodies that work by attaching to the virus to block its ability to infect cells and limit its spread. how should this medicine be used? bamlanivimab and etesevimab come as solutions that are mixed together with additional liquid and then infused slowly into a vein by a healthcare professional. for treatment, the two medicines are given together as a single dose as soon as possible after a positive covid-19 test and within 10 days of symptom onset (for example, fever, cough, shortness of breath). for post-exposure prevention, give as soon as possible after exposure to someone infected with sars-cov-2. serious or life-threatening infusion reactions may occur during or after the infusion. you will be monitored during the infusion and for at least 1 hour afterward. tell your doctor or nurse right away if you develop fever, trouble breathing, chills, fatigue, chest pain or discomfort, weakness, confusion, nausea, headache, shortness of breath, wheezing, throat irritation, rash, hives, itching, flushing, muscle pain, dizziness (especially when standing), sweating, or swelling of your face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes. your doctor may slow or stop the infusion if these occur. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving bamlanivimab and etesevimab, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bamlanivimab, etesevimab, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the injection; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. be sure to mention immunosuppressive medicines such as cyclosporine (gengraf, neoral, sandimmune), prednisone, and tacrolimus (astagraf, envarsus, prograf); your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have received a covid-19 vaccine, and if you have or have ever had any medical conditions. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while receiving bamlanivimab and etesevimab, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given as a one-time intravenous infusion by a healthcare professional. if you miss or delay a scheduled appointment or did not receive the infusion within the recommended time window, contact your healthcare provider right away to discuss next steps. do not try to self-administer and do not receive extra doses. what side effects can this medication cause? bamlanivimab and etesevimab injection may cause side effects. mild effects may include bleeding, bruising, pain, soreness, or swelling at the infusion site. some side effects can be serious. if you experience fever, trouble breathing, changes in heart rate, tiredness, weakness, or confusion, or any symptoms listed in the how section above during or after the infusion, call your doctor immediately or seek emergency medical care. bamlanivimab and etesevimab injection may cause other side effects; talk to your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: bamlanivimab injection
instructions: notice: on april 16, 2021, the us food and drug administration fda revoked the emergency use authorization eua for bamlanivimab when used alone to treat covid-19 because many circulating sars-cov-2 variants are resistant to bamlanivimab monotherapy. bamlanivimab used together with etesevimab remains authorized under an eua for the treatment of covid-19 in certain patients. important warning: bamlanivimab is still being studied for the treatment of covid-19. current clinical data are limited regarding how well it works and its potential adverse effects. it has not undergone full fda approval. an eua had allowed certain non-hospitalized adults and children 12 years of age and older who weigh at least 88 pounds 40 kg and have mild to moderate covid-19 symptoms to receive bamlanivimab. discuss the potential risks and benefits of this medicine with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? bamlanivimab is a monoclonal antibody used to treat covid-19 in certain non-hospitalized adults and children 12 years of age and older who weigh at least 88 pounds 40 kg and have mild to moderate symptoms. it is intended for people with medical conditions that raise the risk of developing severe covid-19 or needing hospitalization. it works by binding to and blocking a viral target to limit the spread of the virus in the body. how should this medicine be used? bamlanivimab is provided as a solution that is diluted and infused slowly into a vein over about 60 minutes by a doctor or nurse. it is given as a single dose as soon as possible after a positive covid-19 test and within 10 days of symptom onset for example fever, cough, or shortness of breath. serious or life-threatening reactions can occur during or after the infusion. you will be monitored during the infusion and for at least 1 hour afterward. tell a doctor or nurse immediately if you have fever; chills; nausea; headache; shortness of breath; high or low blood pressure; slow or fast heartbeat; chest pain or discomfort; weakness; confusion; tiredness; wheezing; rash, hives, or itching; muscle aches or pain; dizziness; sweating; or swelling of the face, throat, tongue, or lips. your doctor may slow or stop the infusion if needed. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer information for patients. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving bamlanivimab, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bamlanivimab, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the injection; your pharmacist can provide a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. be sure to mention immunosuppressive medicines such as cyclosporine gengraf, neoral, sandimmune, prednisone, or tacrolimus astagraf, envarsus, prograf, as your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any medical conditions. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while receiving bamlanivimab, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given as a one-time intravenous infusion by a healthcare professional. if you miss your appointment or do not receive the infusion as scheduled, contact your doctor or infusion center as soon as possible to reschedule. do not attempt to administer it yourself and do not take extra doses. what side effects can this medication cause? bamlanivimab may cause side effects. common side effects include diarrhea and bleeding, bruising, pain, soreness, or swelling at the infusion site. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the symptoms listed above in the how section or develop fever, difficulty breathing, changes in heart rate, marked tiredness or weakness, or confusion, call your doctor immediately or seek emergency medical care. bamlanivimab injection may cause other side effects; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information and report any symptoms that are severe or do not go away.

name: baricitinib
instructions: important warning: taking baricitinib can weaken your ability to fight infections and increase the risk of serious infections, including severe fungal, bacterial, or viral infections that can spread throughout the body. these infections may require hospital treatment and can be life threatening. tell your doctor if you get infections often or think you currently have any infection, including minor infections such as open cuts or sores, recurrent infections such as cold sores, or chronic infections that do not go away. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had diabetes; hiv or aids; hepatitis b infection; an ongoing liver infection; hepatitis c infection; herpes zoster (shingles); a lung disease; or any other condition that affects your immune system. tell your doctor if you live or have ever lived in areas where severe fungal infections are more common, such as the ohio or mississippi river valleys. tell your doctor if you are taking medicines that reduce immune system activity. your doctor will monitor you for signs of infection during and after treatment. call your doctor right away if you have fever, sweating, chills, muscle aches, cough, shortness of breath, weight loss, warm, red, or painful skin, skin sores, frequent or painful urination, diarrhea, or extreme tiredness. you may already have inactive tuberculosis (tb) without symptoms. baricitinib can worsen tb and cause symptoms to develop. your doctor will perform a skin test for tb before and during treatment and may treat tb before you start baricitinib. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had tb, if you have lived in or visited a country where tb is common, or if you have been around someone with tb. call your doctor immediately if you have symptoms of tb such as cough, coughing up bloody mucus, weight loss, loss of muscle tone, or fever. baricitinib may increase the risk of lymphoma and other cancers, including lung and skin cancer. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any type of cancer, and if you smoke or have ever smoked. baricitinib may cause serious or life threatening heart problems (such as heart attack or stroke) or serious or life threatening blood clots in the lungs or legs. tell your doctor if you smoke or have ever smoked, and if you have or have ever had a heart attack or other heart problems, a stroke, a blood clot in your legs, arms, lungs, or arteries, high cholesterol, high blood pressure, or diabetes. seek emergency care or call your doctor right away if you develop crushing chest pain or heaviness; pain in the arms, back, neck, jaw, or stomach; breaking out in a cold sweat; feeling light headed; numbness or weakness in the face, arm, or leg; slow or difficult speech; shortness of breath or trouble breathing; cough; or pain, warmth, redness, swelling, or tenderness in a leg. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor may order tests to check your response to baricitinib. you will receive a medication guide when you begin treatment and each time you refill your prescription; read it and ask questions. discuss the risks of baricitinib with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? baricitinib is used alone or with other medications to treat rheumatoid arthritis in adults who have not responded well to one or more tumor necrosis factor (tnf) inhibitors. it is also used to treat coronavirus disease 2019 (covid-19) in hospitalized adults who require supplemental oxygen, a ventilator, or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ecmo). baricitinib is also used to treat alopecia areata in adults. it is a janus kinase (jak) inhibitor that works by decreasing immune system activity. how should this medicine be used? baricitinib comes as an oral tablet taken once daily, with or without food, at about the same time each day. follow the directions on your prescription label and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. take baricitinib exactly as directed. do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. if you cannot swallow the tablets, place the tablet in a small glass with about 10 ml (2 teaspoonfuls) of room temperature water, swirl a few times, and swallow the mixture immediately. then add another 10 ml of water to the glass, swirl, and swallow to ensure you receive the full dose. your doctor may temporarily or permanently stop treatment if you develop certain severe side effects. be sure to tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking baricitinib, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to baricitinib or any ingredients in the tablets. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have unexplained stomach pain or if you have or have ever had stomach or intestinal ulcers, diverticulitis, a low white blood cell count, anemia, liver disease, or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; call your doctor if you become pregnant while taking baricitinib. do not breastfeed while taking baricitinib and for 4 days after your final dose. tell your doctor if you have recently received or are scheduled to receive any vaccinations. do not receive any vaccinations during treatment without talking to your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? baricitinib may cause side effects. common side effects include nausea, headache, acne, and red bumps or pimples around hair follicles. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following or any effects listed in the important warning section, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical care: hives; swelling of the face, eyes, lips, or throat; difficulty swallowing or breathing; stomach pain, especially with fever and diarrhea or constipation; shortness of breath, tiredness, or pale skin. baricitinib may increase blood cholesterol levels; your doctor will order tests to monitor this during treatment. talk to your doctor about the risks of taking this medication. baricitinib may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: barium sulfate
