instructions: why is this medication prescribed? barium sulfate helps doctors visualize the esophagus, stomach, and intestines during x-ray or computed tomography (ct) scans. it is a radiopaque contrast agent that coats the lining of the gastrointestinal tract without being absorbed, allowing damaged or diseased areas to be seen clearly on imaging. how should this medicine be used? barium sulfate is available as a powder to mix with water, an oral suspension, a paste, and tablets. the mixture or suspension may be swallowed or given as an enema into the rectum; the paste and tablets are taken by mouth. it is usually taken once or more shortly before the x-ray or ct scan. enemas are administered by medical staff at the testing center. if you are taking it by mouth, you may receive it at the testing center or be instructed to take it at home at specific times the night before and/or the day of your test. if taking it at home, use exactly as directed; do not take more or less or at different times than prescribed. swallow tablets whole—do not split, crush, or chew. shake liquids well before use. if mixing powder with water at home, follow the provided mixing instructions and ask questions if anything is unclear. you will receive specific directions for preparation and aftercare, which may include switching to clear liquids after a certain time the day before, not eating or drinking after a specified time, and using laxatives or enemas before the test; you may also be told to use a laxative afterward to help clear the barium. follow all instructions carefully and ask your doctor or testing staff if anything is unclear. what special precautions should i follow? before using barium sulfate, tell your doctor and the testing-center staff if you are allergic to barium sulfate, other radiopaque contrast media, simethicone (gas-x, phazyme, others), any other medications, foods, latex, or any ingredients in the product; ask for an ingredient list. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. your doctor will advise whether to take your regular medicines on the day of your test and how to time them relative to barium sulfate. tell your doctor if you recently had a rectal biopsy; if you have any blockage, ulcers, or perforation (holes) in the esophagus, stomach, or intestines; swelling or cancer of the rectum; or if an infant or young child has gastrointestinal disease or prior intestinal surgery—your doctor may advise against barium sulfate. also inform your doctor if you recently had any surgery, especially of the colon or rectum; have a colostomy; have intracranial hypertension (pseudotumor cerebri); or have ever aspirated food into the lungs. mention if you or family members have allergies, and if you have or have had asthma, hay fever, hives, eczema, constipation, cystic fibrosis, hirschsprung’s disease, high blood pressure, or heart disease. if you are pregnant, might be pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor; the radiation used in x-rays and ct scans may harm the fetus. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow the testing center’s instructions about eating and drinking the day before your test. after your test, drink plenty of fluids. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you were told to take barium sulfate at home and missed a dose, take it as soon as you remember and inform the testing-center staff if you did not take it at the scheduled time. what side effects can this medication cause? barium sulfate may cause side effects. common effects include stomach cramps, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, constipation, weakness, pale skin, sweating, and ringing in the ears. some side effects can be serious. tell the testing staff or call your doctor right away if you develop hives, itching, red skin, swelling or tightness of the throat, difficulty breathing or swallowing, hoarseness, agitation, confusion, fast heartbeat, or a bluish skin color. barium sulfate may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: basiliximab injection
instructions: important warning: basiliximab injection must be administered only in a hospital or clinic by a doctor experienced in caring for transplant recipients and in using medicines that suppress the immune system. why is this medication prescribed? basiliximab injection is used with other medicines to prevent the immune system from immediately rejecting a transplanted organ in people receiving kidney transplants. it is an immunosuppressant that works by lowering immune activity so the body does not attack the transplanted kidney. how should this medicine be used? basiliximab injection is supplied as a powder that is mixed with sterile water and given intravenously by a healthcare professional in a medical facility. it is typically given as 2 doses: the first dose about 2 hours before transplant surgery and the second dose 4 days after surgery. other uses for this medicine this medicine may sometimes be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving basiliximab, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to basiliximab, any other medications, or any components of the product; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have ever been treated with basiliximab before and if you have or have ever had any medical conditions. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; you should not become pregnant while receiving basiliximab. discuss effective birth control to use before treatment, during treatment, and for 4 months after your last dose. tell your doctor if you are breastfeeding. do not receive any vaccines without talking with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you different instructions, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? basiliximab is given by healthcare professionals on a set schedule around your transplant. if a dose is missed or delayed, contact your transplant team immediately; they will determine the next appropriate time to receive it. do not attempt to self-administer a replacement dose. what side effects can this medication cause? basiliximab may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, stomach pain, heartburn, swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, runny nose, headache, uncontrollable shaking (tremor), trouble falling or staying asleep, pain at the injection site. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have hives, rash, itching, sneezing, cough, wheezing, trouble breathing or swallowing, fast heartbeat, muscle aches, unusual tiredness, lightheadedness, dizziness, fainting, sudden weight gain with swelling throughout the body, sore throat, fever, chills, or other signs of infection, painful or difficult urination, or decreased urination. basiliximab may increase the risk of infections or cancer; discuss these risks with your doctor. basiliximab may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you experience anything unusual.

name: becaplermin topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? becaplermin gel is used as part of a comprehensive treatment plan to help heal certain diabetic ulcers (sores) on the foot, ankle, or leg. it must be used together with proper ulcer care, including professional removal of dead tissue; offloading with special shoes, walkers, crutches, or wheelchairs; and treatment of any infections. do not use becaplermin on ulcers that have been stitched or stapled. becaplermin is a human platelet-derived growth factor that supports wound healing by helping replace damaged skin and tissue, attracting repair cells, and promoting closure of the ulcer. how should this medicine be used? becaplermin is a skin-applied gel, typically used once daily on the ulcer. follow your prescription directions exactly; do not use more, less, or more often than prescribed—extra gel will not speed healing. your doctor will show you how to measure the correct amount based on ulcer size, will reassess the ulcer every 1 to 2 weeks, and may reduce the dose as the ulcer shrinks. for skin use only. do not swallow, and apply only to the prescribed ulcer. to apply: 1) wash your hands thoroughly. 2) gently rinse the wound with water. 3) wash your hands again. 4) squeeze the prescribed length of gel onto a clean, nonabsorbent surface (such as wax paper). do not let the tube tip touch any surface, the ulcer, or the wax paper. recap tightly. 5) using a clean applicator (e.g., cotton swab or tongue depressor), spread the gel evenly over the ulcer in a layer about 1/16 inch (0.2 cm) thick—about the thickness of a penny. 6) moisten a piece of gauze with saline and place it over the wound, covering only the wound and not the surrounding skin. 7) place a small, dry pad over the wound, then wrap with a soft, dry gauze bandage and secure with adhesive tape; avoid attaching the tape to your skin. after about 12 hours, remove the dressings and gently rinse the ulcer with saline or water to remove any remaining gel. re-cover the ulcer with fresh supplies as above (moistened saline gauze over the wound, then a dry pad, then a soft gauze bandage secured with tape). do not reuse any gauze, dressings, or bandages. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using becaplermin gel, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to becaplermin, parabens, any other medications, or any ingredients in the gel. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional products, and herbal supplements you use or plan to use, especially any products applied to the ulcer. tell your doctor if you have a skin tumor or cancer near the application site; your doctor will likely advise against using becaplermin gel. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had poor blood flow to your legs or feet, or cancer; discuss the risks and benefits of using this medication. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor; if you become pregnant while using the gel, contact your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor instructs otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed application and resume your normal schedule. do not apply extra gel to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? becaplermin gel may cause side effects. contact your doctor if a side effect is severe or does not go away. possible effects include: rash; a burning sensation at or near the application site. this medication may cause other side effects; if you notice any unusual problems while using it, contact your doctor.

name: beclomethasone nasal spray
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? beclomethasone nasal spray is used to relieve sneezing and a runny, stuffy, or itchy nose due to hay fever, other allergies, or vasomotor (nonallergic) rhinitis. it is also used to help prevent swelling of the nasal lining and the return of nasal polyps after polyp-removal surgery. it should not be used to treat symptoms caused by the common cold. beclomethasone is a corticosteroid that works by reducing inflammation and blocking the release of substances that trigger allergy symptoms. how should this medicine be used? beclomethasone comes as a liquid suspension sprayed into the nose, usually into each nostril twice a day. use exactly as directed and follow your prescription label. do not use more, use less, or use it more often than prescribed. an adult should help children younger than 12 use the spray; children younger than 6 should not use it. for intranasal use only; do not swallow and avoid spraying into your eyes or mouth. use one bottle per person and do not share. this medicine controls allergy symptoms but does not cure them. symptom relief may start in a few days, with full benefit in 1 to 2 weeks. for best results, use it regularly unless your doctor tells you otherwise. call your doctor if symptoms worsen or do not improve after 3 weeks. if you are using it to help prevent nasal polyps from returning after surgery, you may need to continue for several weeks as directed. each bottle delivers a set number of sprays; track your sprays and discard the bottle after the labeled number is reached, even if liquid remains. before first use, read the manufacturer’s instructions. to use: 1) shake gently. 2) remove the dust cap. 3) prime the pump: if first use, press and release 6 times while pointing away from your face; if not used for a week or after cleaning, press and release until a fine mist appears. 4) gently blow your nose. 5) close one nostril, tilt your head slightly forward, and insert the applicator tip into the open nostril with the bottle upright. 6) begin to breathe in through your nose and press firmly to release a spray. 7) breathe in gently through your nose and out through your mouth. 8) if prescribed two sprays, repeat in the same nostril. 9) repeat in the other nostril. 10) wipe the tip and replace the dust cover. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to beclomethasone or any of its ingredients, and provide a list of all medicines, vitamins, and herbal products you use. tell your doctor if you have recently had nose surgery or injury, have nasal sores, or have ever had cataracts, glaucoma, asthma, any infection, or herpes infection of the eye. tell your doctor if you have or have been exposed to chickenpox, measles, or tuberculosis. inform your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. use with caution as directed by your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, you may continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include headache; nasal irritation, stuffiness, or dryness; sneezing; nosebleeds; joint or muscle pain; nausea; lightheadedness; unpleasant taste or smell; muscle weakness; easy bruising; menstrual changes; acne; and white patches in the mouth, throat, or nose (thrush). serious side effects can include wheezing; hives; rash; itching; trouble breathing or swallowing; swelling of the face, lower legs, or ankles; and vision changes. stop using the spray and seek medical care right away if serious symptoms occur. this medication may cause children to grow more slowly; discuss duration of use and growth monitoring with your child’s doctor. beclomethasone nasal spray may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you experience anything unusual or severe.

name: beclomethasone oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? beclomethasone is an inhaled corticosteroid used to prevent asthma symptoms—such as shortness of breath, chest tightness, wheezing, and cough—in adults and in children 5 years and older. it reduces inflammation and irritation in the airways to make breathing easier. how should this medicine be used? beclomethasone is an oral inhalation aerosol used with an inhaler, typically taken twice daily. follow your prescription label exactly; do not use more, less, or more often than prescribed. ask your doctor how to adjust your other oral or inhaled asthma medicines while on beclomethasone. if you are switching from an oral steroid (for example, dexamethasone, methylprednisolone/medrol, or prednisone/rayos), your doctor will usually taper the oral dose after you start beclomethasone. this medicine controls asthma but does not cure it. some improvement can occur within 24 hours, but the full benefit may take 1 to 4 weeks of regular use. keep using it even if you feel well; do not stop without consulting your doctor. call your doctor if your symptoms (or your child’s) do not improve within 4 weeks or if they worsen. beclomethasone helps prevent, but does not treat, sudden asthma attacks. your doctor will give you a short-acting rescue inhaler for acute symptoms. do not use the beclomethasone inhaler near open flames or high heat; it can explode at very high temperatures. inhalers supply 50, 100, or 120 actuations depending on size. track the number of puffs used; after the labeled number has been used, doses may be inaccurate. discard the inhaler once the labeled actuations are reached, even if liquid and spray remain. read the written instructions before first use, review the diagrams, and have your doctor, pharmacist, or respiratory therapist demonstrate correct technique; practice under their supervision. to use the aerosol inhaler: keep it clean and dry with the cover on; wipe with a dry tissue or cloth only—do not wash or immerse in water. remove the cap. if using for the first time or after more than 10 days without use, prime by releasing 2 test sprays into the air away from your face; avoid spraying your eyes. breathe out fully through your mouth. hold the inhaler upright (mouthpiece up) or horizontal. place the mouthpiece well into your mouth, tilt your head slightly back, close your lips around it with your tongue below the mouthpiece. begin to inhale slowly and deeply through the mouthpiece and press down once on the canister to release the medicine. when your lungs are full, remove the inhaler, close your mouth, and hold your breath about 5 to 10 seconds, then exhale gently. if more than one puff is prescribed, repeat these steps. replace the cap. after each dose, rinse your mouth with water and spit it out; do not swallow. other uses for this medicine beclomethasone may sometimes be prescribed for other indications; ask your doctor or pharmacist for details. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to beclomethasone or any of its ingredients, or to other medicines. provide a complete list of all prescription and over-the-counter drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or recently took; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for interactions. many medicines can interact with beclomethasone, so list everything you use. do not use beclomethasone to treat an active asthma attack; use your short-acting rescue inhaler instead. seek medical care if an attack does not improve with your fast-acting inhaler or if you need it more often than usual. tell your doctor if you have or have had tuberculosis, serious lung infections, cataracts, glaucoma or elevated eye pressure, any untreated infection, or an eye herpes infection. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, planning to become pregnant, or breastfeeding; call if you become pregnant while using it. if you are tapering off an oral steroid, conditions like asthma, arthritis, or eczema may flare; watch for adrenal insufficiency symptoms such as extreme fatigue, muscle weakness or pain, sudden pain in the abdomen, lower body, or legs, loss of appetite, weight loss, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, dizziness, fainting, depression, irritability, or darkening of the skin. during this period your body may handle stress (surgery, illness, severe asthma attack, injury) less well—call your doctor promptly if you become ill and inform all healthcare providers that you recently switched from an oral steroid to beclomethasone inhalation. consider carrying a medical id stating you may need steroids in an emergency. if you have never had chickenpox or measles and are not vaccinated, avoid people who are ill—especially those with chickenpox or measles. if exposed or if symptoms develop, contact your doctor immediately; you may need preventive treatment. be aware that beclomethasone can rarely cause immediate wheezing or breathing difficulty right after inhalation (paradoxical bronchospasm). if this occurs, use your rescue inhaler at once and call your doctor; do not use beclomethasone again unless your doctor advises it. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives other advice, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects may include headache, sore throat, runny or stuffy nose, back pain, nausea, cough, and hoarseness or painful/difficult speech. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care for serious effects such as rash, hives, itching, swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, hoarseness that is severe or worsening, trouble breathing or swallowing, or any changes in vision. in children, growth may slow while using beclomethasone; your child’s doctor will monitor growth and discuss risks and benefits. rarely, long-term use has been associated with glaucoma or cataracts; ask your doctor about your individual risk and how often you should have eye exams. other side effects may occur; contact your doctor if you have unusual problems while using this medicine.

name: bedaquiline
instructions: important warning: bedaquiline can cause serious or life-threatening changes in heart rhythm. you will need an electrocardiogram (ecg), a test that measures the heart’s electrical activity, before starting and several times during treatment to monitor your heart rhythm. tell your doctor if you or a family member has prolonged qt syndrome, and if you have or have ever had a slow or irregular heartbeat, an underactive thyroid, low blood levels of calcium, magnesium, or potassium, heart failure, or a recent heart attack. call your doctor right away if you experience fast or irregular heartbeat, dizziness, or fainting. certain medicines can interact with bedaquiline and affect your heart rhythm—review all current and planned medications with your doctor and pharmacist. keep all medical and lab appointments. your doctor will order tests before and during treatment to check your response. you will receive a medication guide at the start of therapy and with each refill; read it carefully and ask questions. discuss the risks and benefits of bedaquiline with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? bedaquiline is used with at least three other medicines to treat multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (mdr-tb) that affects the lungs in adults and in children 5 years and older who weigh at least 33 lb (15 kg) when the infection cannot be treated with usual tb medicines. it should not be used to treat tb that primarily affects body parts other than the lungs. bedaquiline is an anti-mycobacterial that works by killing the bacteria causing mdr-tb. how should this medicine be used? bedaquiline is a tablet taken by mouth with food and water. it is usually taken once daily for 2 weeks, then three times a week (with at least 48 hours between doses) for at least 22 more weeks. take it at the same time of day and on the same days each week. follow your prescription exactly; do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. if you or your child cannot swallow 20 mg tablets whole, they may be split on the score line. if still unable to swallow, dissolve up to five 20 mg tablets in 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of water in a cup; drink immediately, or add at least 1 teaspoon (5 ml) more of water, milk product, apple, orange, or cranberry juice, or a carbonated beverage, or mix with a soft food to aid swallowing, then take immediately. rinse the cup with a small amount of the same liquid or soft food and take immediately to ensure the full dose. if more than five 20 mg tablets are needed, repeat these steps until the full dose is taken. alternatively, crush 20 mg tablets, mix with a soft food such as yogurt, applesauce, mashed banana, or oatmeal, and take immediately; then take a small additional amount of soft food to capture any remaining medicine. if you have a nasogastric (ng) tube, your healthcare provider will instruct you on ng administration. continue bedaquiline for the full course and do not miss doses, even if you feel better. stopping early or skipping doses may lead to incomplete treatment and antibiotic resistance. you may be offered directly observed therapy (dot), where a healthcare worker gives and observes doses, to help you complete treatment as prescribed. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking bedaquiline, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bedaquiline or any ingredients in the tablets (check the medication guide for a list of ingredients). tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and supplements you take or plan to take. st. john’s wort and other products may interact with bedaquiline; do not start any new medicines or supplements while on bedaquiline without consulting your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had hiv, or liver or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; call your doctor if you become pregnant during treatment. if you are breastfeeding or plan to breastfeed, you should not breastfeed while taking bedaquiline and for 27.5 months (2 years, 3 months, and 2 weeks) after your final dose, unless formula is not available. if you must breastfeed because formula is not available, contact your child’s doctor if your infant develops yellowing of the eyes or skin or changes in urine or stool color. avoid alcoholic beverages during treatment, as alcohol increases the risk of serious side effects. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor about eating grapefruit or drinking grapefruit juice while taking this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose during the first 2 weeks, skip it and take your next dose at the regular time; do not take a double dose. from week 3 onward, take the missed dose with food as soon as you remember, then continue your three-times-per-week schedule, ensuring at least 24 hours between the missed dose and the next scheduled dose. do not take a double dose or exceed your total weekly dose within any 7-day period. what side effects can this medication cause? bedaquiline may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these persist or are severe: muscle or joint pain, stomach pain, headache, rash, itching, dry skin, trouble falling or staying asleep, numbness or tingling in the arms, hands, legs, or feet. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or seek emergency care if you have any of the following (or the symptoms listed in the important warning above): unusual tiredness or weakness, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, pale stools, pain in the upper right abdomen, fever, coughing up blood, or chest pain. bedaquiline may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: belantamab mafodotin-blmf injection
instructions: important warning: belantamab mafodotin-blmf injection can cause serious eye or vision problems, including vision loss. tell your doctor if you currently have or have ever had eye or vision issues. call your doctor right away if you develop blurred vision, any vision changes or loss, or dry eyes. because of the risk of eye problems, belantamab mafodotin-blmf is available only through a special program called blenrep rems. you, your doctor, and your healthcare facility must be enrolled before you can receive it; ask your doctor for details. do not wear contact lenses during treatment unless your doctor or eye doctor tells you to do so. use preservative-free lubricating eye drops as directed by your doctor during treatment. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how this medicine affects your vision. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor will order tests before and during treatment, including an eye exam before and at intervals during therapy, especially if your vision changes. your doctor or pharmacist will give you the medication guide when you start treatment and each time you receive a dose; read it carefully and ask questions. discuss the risks of treatment with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? belantamab mafodotin-blmf injection is used to treat adults with multiple myeloma, a cancer of the bone marrow, that has returned or has not improved after at least four other treatments. belantamab mafodotin-blmf belongs to a class of drugs called antibody-drug conjugates and works by killing cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? belantamab mafodotin-blmf is supplied as a powder that is mixed with liquid and infused into a vein over about 30 minutes by a doctor or nurse in a hospital or clinic. it is usually given once every 3 weeks. treatment cycles may be repeated as your doctor recommends. the length of therapy depends on your response and any side effects. you will be monitored closely during the infusion to make sure you are not having a serious reaction. tell your nurse immediately if you develop chills, flushing, itching or rash, shortness of breath, cough, wheezing, tiredness, fever, dizziness or lightheadedness, or swelling of your lips, tongue, throat, or face. your doctor may reduce the dose, delay, or permanently stop treatment depending on how well the medicine works and what side effects you experience. be sure to tell your care team how you are feeling during treatment with belantamab mafodotin-blmf. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving belantamab mafodotin-blmf injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to belantamab mafodotin-blmf, any other medications, or any ingredients in the injection; check the medication guide for a full ingredient list. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had bleeding problems. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or plan to father a child, do not start treatment until a pregnancy test confirms you are not pregnant. women who can become pregnant must use effective birth control during treatment and for 4 months after the last dose. men with partners who can become pregnant must use effective birth control during treatment and for 6 months after the last dose. if you or your partner becomes pregnant during therapy, call your doctor; belantamab mafodotin-blmf may harm the unborn baby. if you are breastfeeding, do not breastfeed during treatment and for 3 months after the final dose. you should know this medication may reduce fertility in both women and men; discuss risks with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment to receive a dose, contact your doctor immediately to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? belantamab mafodotin-blmf may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: nausea, constipation, diarrhea, loss of appetite, joint or back pain, tiredness. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following—or any symptoms listed in the important warning—call your doctor immediately or seek emergency care: unusual bleeding or bruising; shortness of breath, chest pain, or cough. belantamab mafodotin-blmf may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: belatacept injection
instructions: important warning: receiving belatacept injection can increase your risk of post-transplant lymphoproliferative disorder (ptld), a serious condition involving rapid growth of certain white blood cells that can become cancer. the risk is higher if you have never been exposed to epstein-barr virus (ebv, the virus that causes mononucleosis), if you have cytomegalovirus (cmv), or if you have received other treatments that reduce t lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell). your doctor will order lab tests to check for these conditions before treatment. if you are ebv-negative, your doctor will likely not prescribe belatacept injection. call your doctor right away after receiving belatacept if you have confusion, trouble thinking, memory problems, mood or behavior changes, changes in how you walk or talk, decreased strength or weakness on one side of the body, or vision changes. belatacept can also increase the risk of cancers (including skin cancer) and serious infections, such as tuberculosis (tb) and progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (pml), a rare, serious brain infection. seek medical attention immediately if you notice a new skin lesion or bump, a change in the size or color of a mole, fever, sore throat, chills, cough, other signs of infection, night sweats, tiredness that does not improve, weight loss, swollen lymph nodes, flu-like symptoms, stomach-area pain, vomiting, diarrhea, tenderness over the transplanted kidney, frequent or painful urination, blood in the urine, clumsiness, increasing weakness, personality changes, or changes in vision or speech. belatacept injection must be given only in a medical facility under the supervision of a doctor experienced in caring for kidney transplant recipients and using immunosuppressants. in people who have had liver transplants, belatacept has been linked to rejection of the new liver and death; it should not be used to prevent rejection of liver transplants. you will receive a medication guide when you start belatacept and with each refill; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. discuss the risks of belatacept with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? belatacept injection is used with other medicines to prevent rejection of a transplanted kidney by reducing the activity of your immune system. it belongs to a class of drugs called immunosuppressants and helps prevent your body from attacking the new kidney. how should this medicine be used? belatacept is given as an intravenous infusion over about 30 minutes by a healthcare professional in a hospital or clinic. it is usually administered on the day of transplant, 5 days after transplant, at the end of weeks 2 and 4, and then once every 4 weeks. your doctor will monitor you closely; tell your doctor how you feel during treatment. other uses for this medicine this medicine may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving belatacept, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to belatacept or any of its ingredients. ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor about all your medical conditions. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant during treatment. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, inform the surgeon or dentist that you are receiving belatacept. avoid unnecessary or prolonged sun exposure, tanning beds, and sun lamps; belatacept may make your skin more sensitive to sunlight. wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and use a high-spf sunscreen when outdoors. do not receive any vaccinations without talking to your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment for a belatacept infusion, call your doctor as soon as possible to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? belatacept may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: headache, excessive tiredness, pale skin, fast heartbeat, weakness, swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, or constipation. some side effects can be serious. if you experience shortness of breath, or any of the symptoms listed in the important warning section above, call your doctor immediately. belatacept may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: belimumab injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? belimumab injection is used to treat certain types of lupus, including systemic lupus erythematosus (sle) and lupus nephritis (a form of kidney involvement). belimumab is a monoclonal antibody that blocks a protein involved in the immune response, helping reduce the immune system’s attack on healthy tissues. how should this medicine be used? belimumab injection comes as a liquid solution in an autoinjector or prefilled syringe for subcutaneous (under the skin) injection, which may be given in a doctor’s office or at home by you or a caregiver. it also comes as a powder that is mixed with water and given intravenously (into a vein) over about 1 hour by a healthcare professional in a medical facility. your doctor will determine how often you receive belimumab based on your age and how you respond. use exactly as directed; do not use more, use less, or use it more often than prescribed. your first dose will be given in your doctor’s office. if you will inject at home, your doctor will train you (or your caregiver), and you should read the instructions for use that come with the product. when preparing a subcutaneous dose, remove the autoinjector or prefilled syringe from the refrigerator and place it on a flat surface away from direct sunlight; do not remove the needle cover. let it reach room temperature for 30 minutes before injection. do not warm it by microwave, warm water, sunlight, or any other heat source. inspect the solution before use; it should be clear and colorless to pale yellow. do not use if cloudy, discolored, or if you see particles, and do not shake. inject into the front of the thighs or the abdomen, avoiding the navel and the 2-inch area around it. do not inject into skin that is tender, bruised, red, hard, or broken. rotate injection sites with each dose. intravenous belimumab can cause serious reactions during the infusion and for up to a week after. you will be monitored during and after the infusion, and you may receive medicines to help prevent or treat reactions. tell your doctor or nurse right away if you have rash; itching; hives; swelling of the face, eyes, mouth, throat, tongue, or lips; trouble breathing or swallowing; wheezing or shortness of breath; anxiety; flushing; dizziness; fainting; headache; nausea; fever; chills; seizures; muscle aches; or a slow heartbeat. belimumab helps control lupus but does not cure it. it may take time to feel the full benefit. your doctor will monitor your progress; tell them how you are feeling during treatment. you will receive a medication guide—read it carefully and ask questions if anything is unclear. what special precautions should i follow? before using belimumab, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to belimumab, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe what reactions you had. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have a current infection or a history of infections that keep coming back; if you have or have ever had depression or thoughts of harming or killing yourself; or if you have had cancer. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. it is not known if belimumab can harm an unborn baby. your doctor may advise effective birth control during treatment and for 4 months after your final dose; discuss options and call your doctor if you become pregnant. if you are breastfeeding, talk with your doctor. do not receive any vaccinations without talking to your doctor, and tell your doctor if you have received a vaccine within the past 30 days. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor instructs otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment for an intravenous infusion, call your doctor as soon as possible. if you miss a subcutaneous dose, inject it as soon as you remember. then either take your next dose at the regularly scheduled time or continue weekly dosing based on the new day you injected. do not inject a double dose to make up for a missed dose. call your doctor or pharmacist if you need help deciding when to inject your next dose. what side effects can this medication cause? belimumab may cause side effects. common side effects include nausea; diarrhea; headache or migraine; redness, itching, swelling, pain, discoloration, or irritation at the injection site; pain in the arms or legs; and runny nose. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have signs of infection such as fever, sore throat, chills; coughing up mucus; frequent, painful, or difficult urination; or warm, red, or painful skin or sores on your body; mental health changes such as thoughts of harming or killing yourself or others, plans or attempts to do so, new or worsening depression or anxiety, trouble falling or staying asleep, unusual changes in mood or behavior, or acting on dangerous impulses; or neurologic symptoms such as vision changes, memory loss, trouble thinking clearly, difficulty talking or walking, dizziness, or loss of balance. also seek immediate help for any infusion reaction symptoms listed in the how section. belimumab may increase the risk of certain cancers; discuss risks with your doctor. belimumab may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: belinostat injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? belinostat is used to treat peripheral t-cell lymphoma (ptcl), a type of cancer that starts in certain immune cells, when the disease has not improved or has returned after other treatments. it is a histone deacetylase inhibitor that works by killing cancer cells. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? belinostat comes as a powder that is mixed with liquid and given by a healthcare professional as an intravenous (iv) infusion in a hospital or clinic. it is usually infused over 30 to 45 minutes once daily on days 1 through 5 of a 21-day treatment cycle. the length of treatment depends on your response and any side effects. your doctor may adjust your dose or stop treatment if certain side effects occur. tell your doctor how you are feeling throughout treatment. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving belinostat, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to belinostat or any of its ingredients. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may change doses or monitor you closely for side effects. tell your doctor if you have received prior chemotherapy; if you have or think you may have any infection; if you have nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea; and if you have or have ever had kidney or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or plan to father a child. you or your partner should not become pregnant while receiving belinostat. if you can become pregnant, you will need a pregnancy test before starting, and you should use effective birth control during treatment and for 6 months after the final dose. if your partner can become pregnant, use effective birth control during treatment and for 3 months after the final dose. if you or your partner becomes pregnant, call your doctor immediately; belinostat may harm the fetus. do not breastfeed during treatment and for 2 weeks after the final dose. this medication may decrease fertility in men; discuss risks with your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are receiving belinostat. this medication may cause nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea; if these occur, tell your doctor—other medicines can help prevent or treat these symptoms. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? belinostat is given by a healthcare professional. if you miss an appointment for a dose, contact your doctor or clinic as soon as possible to reschedule. do not attempt to administer this medication yourself. what side effects can this medication cause? belinostat may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: constipation, headache, tiredness, decreased appetite, pain at the injection site, swelling of the hands, feet, or ankles, rash. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you experience any of the following or those listed in the special precautions section: fever, cough, chills, muscle aches, worsening skin problems, flu-like symptoms, or other signs of infection; painful, frequent, burning, or difficult urination; unusual bleeding or bruising; dizziness, weakness, excessive tiredness, pale skin, or shortness of breath; yellowing of the skin or eyes, pain in the right upper abdomen, dark urine, or itching; nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, fainting, seizures, irregular heartbeat, dark or cloudy urine, unusual tiredness, or muscle or joint pain. belinostat may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: belladonna alkaloid combinations and phenobarbital
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? belladonna alkaloid combinations and phenobarbital are used to relieve cramping pain in conditions such as irritable bowel syndrome and spastic colon. they are also used with other medicines to treat ulcers. these medicines decrease the movement of the stomach and intestines and reduce the secretion of stomach fluids, including acid. this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? belladonna alkaloid combinations and phenobarbital come as a regular tablet, a slow-acting tablet, a capsule, and a liquid to take by mouth. the regular tablet, capsule, and liquid are usually taken three or four times a day, 30 minutes before meals and at bedtime. the slow-acting tablet is usually taken two or three times a day at evenly spaced intervals. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. take belladonna alkaloid combinations and phenobarbital exactly as directed. do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed by your doctor. phenobarbital can be habit forming. do not take a larger dose, take it more often, or use it for a longer period than your doctor tells you to. signs of overdose include headache, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, blurred vision, dilated pupils, hot and dry skin, dry mouth, agitation, and difficulty swallowing. if you have any of these symptoms, stop taking belladonna alkaloids and phenobarbital and call your doctor immediately. what special precautions should i follow? before taking this medication, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to belladonna, any barbiturate medicine, tartrazine (a yellow dye in some foods and drugs), or any medication. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had glaucoma; an enlarged prostate; intestinal blockage; myasthenia gravis; a hiatal hernia; ulcerative colitis; kidney, heart, or liver disease; diseases of the urinary tract; or high blood pressure. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding, tell your doctor; if you become pregnant while taking this medication, call your doctor. if you are 65 years of age or older, talk to your doctor about the risks and benefits; older adults should receive low doses because higher doses do not work better and can cause serious side effects. this drug may make you drowsy; do not drive a car or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. alcohol can add to the drowsiness caused by this drug. belladonna alkaloids may decrease sweating and cause heatstroke; avoid overheating during exercise and in hot weather. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. avoid alcohol, as it can increase drowsiness caused by this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember it. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? to help prevent dry mouth or throat, chew gum or suck sugarless hard candies. to reduce increased sensitivity to light, wear sunglasses. if any of the following symptoms are severe or do not go away, tell your doctor: confusion, constipation, blurred vision, dizziness, drowsiness, nervousness, or flushing. if you experience any of the following, call your doctor immediately: eye pain, rapid heartbeat, skin rash, difficulty urinating, or lack of sweating in hot weather.

name: belumosudil
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? belumosudil is used to treat graft-versus-host disease (gvhd), a complication of hematopoietic stem-cell transplant (hsct), in adults and children 12 years of age and older whose gvhd did not respond to at least two other treatments. it is a kinase inhibitor that works by blocking signals in cells that drive gvhd. how should this medicine be used? belumosudil comes as an oral tablet and is usually taken once daily with a meal, at about the same time each day. follow your prescription label exactly; do not take more or less or more often than prescribed. swallow tablets whole; do not split, crush, or chew. your doctor will order blood tests before and during treatment and may adjust your dose or pause treatment based on your response, lab results, and any side effects. continue taking belumosudil even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor. ask your doctor or pharmacist for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medicine may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking belumosudil, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to it or any ingredients in the tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and supplements you take or plan to take, especially phenobarbital; phenytoin (dilantin, phenytek); proton pump inhibitors such as dexlansoprazole (dexilant), esomeprazole (nexium, in vimovo), lansoprazole (prevacid, in prevpac), omeprazole (prilosec, in yosprala, zegerid), pantoprazole (protonix), and rabeprazole (aciphex); rifampin (rifadin, rimactane); and corticosteroids such as dexamethasone, methylprednisolone (medrol), or prednisone (rayos). tell your doctor about any herbal products, especially st. john’s wort. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver or kidney disease. if you are pregnant, may become pregnant, or plan to father a child, use effective birth control during treatment and for 1 week after the final dose; females will need a pregnancy test before starting. belumosudil may reduce fertility in men and women and can harm an unborn baby. if you or your partner becomes pregnant during treatment, call your doctor. do not breastfeed during treatment and for at least 1 week after the final dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? belumosudil may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: tiredness or weakness; nausea; difficulty swallowing; shortness of breath; diarrhea; muscle or joint pain; headache; swelling of the hands, feet, or face; rash or itching. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have fever, sore throat, chills, cough, or other signs of infection; or unusual bleeding or bruising. belumosudil may cause other side effects; talk to your doctor if you notice anything concerning.

name: belzutifan
instructions: important warning: do not become pregnant or father a child while taking belzutifan. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or plan to father a child, talk to your doctor. you may be required to have a pregnancy test before starting treatment. you and/or your partner should use birth control during treatment and for 1 week after your final dose. belzutifan may decrease the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives (birth control pills, patches, rings, implants, or injections); you will need to use another method of birth control during treatment. ask your doctor to help you choose a method that will work for you or your partner. if you or your partner becomes pregnant while taking belzutifan, call your doctor immediately. belzutifan may harm the fetus. you will receive a medication guide when you begin treatment and with each refill; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. why is this medication prescribed? belzutifan is used to treat renal cell carcinoma (rcc; kidney cancer), central nervous system (cns) hemangioblastomas (tumors in the brain and spinal cord), and a certain type of pancreatic cancer in adults with von hippel-lindau disease (vhl; a rare disease that causes tumors and cysts). belzutifan is also used to treat certain types of rcc and pheochromocytoma or paraganglioma (tumors on or around a small gland near the kidneys). belzutifan is in a class of medications called hypoxia-inducible factor inhibitors. it works by blocking the activity of a certain protein in people with vhl. how should this medicine be used? belzutifan comes as a tablet to take by mouth once daily, with or without food. take it at around the same time each day. take belzutifan exactly as directed; do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. swallow tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush. if you vomit after taking a dose, do not take another dose; take your next scheduled dose the following day. your doctor may temporarily or permanently stop treatment or decrease your dose if you experience certain side effects. your doctor will monitor how you are feeling during treatment. continue to take belzutifan even if you feel well. do not stop taking belzutifan without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking belzutifan, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this drug, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your symptoms. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had anemia (a lower-than-normal number of red blood cells) or kidney or liver problems. if you are breastfeeding, do not breast-feed while taking belzutifan and for 1 week after your final dose. you should know that this medication may decrease fertility in men and women; talk to your doctor about the risks. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember on the same day, then continue your regular dosing schedule the next day. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? belzutifan may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: dizziness; tiredness; headache; nausea; stomach pain; diarrhea; constipation; joint, muscle, or bone pain; muscle spasms or weakness; vision changes; weight gain; fever; cough or other signs of infection; swelling of the arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; numbness or tingling in the hands, legs, or feet. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help: extreme tiredness, feeling cold, pale skin, shortness of breath, chest pain, or fast heartbeat; unusual bleeding or bruising; slow, fast, or irregular heartbeat. belzutifan may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: bempedoic acid
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bempedoic acid is used along with lifestyle changes (such as diet, weight loss, and exercise) and certain cholesterol-lowering medicines called hmg-coa reductase inhibitors (statins) to further lower low-density lipoprotein (ldl, 'bad' cholesterol) in adults with heterozygous familial hypercholesterolemia (hefh), an inherited condition that impairs normal cholesterol removal, or with heart disease. it is also used to reduce the risk of heart attack and to lower the chance that heart surgery will be needed in people who have heart disease or are at risk for heart disease and who are not taking or cannot take statins. bempedoic acid belongs to a class of drugs called adenosine triphosphate-citrate lyase (acl) inhibitors and works by blocking cholesterol production in the liver. how should this medicine be used? bempedoic acid comes as an oral tablet and is usually taken once daily with or without food. take it at the same time each day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. take bempedoic acid exactly as prescribed; do not take more, take less, or take it more often than directed. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking bempedoic acid, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bempedoic acid, any other medications, or any of the ingredients in the tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had gout, tendon problems (tendons are the tough fibers that connect muscle to bone), gallbladder problems, or kidney or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking bempedoic acid, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? bempedoic acid may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: muscle spasms, back pain, pain in the hands or feet. some side effects can be serious. stop taking bempedoic acid and call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have any of the following: rash, flushing, hives, itching, swelling of the eyes, face, lips, tongue, or throat, trouble breathing or swallowing, dizziness or fainting, fast or pounding heartbeat; severe pain, redness, warmth, tenderness, or swelling of the joints (especially the big toe); a snap or pop in a tendon area, bruising after a tendon injury, or inability to move or bear weight on the affected area; nausea, vomiting, or pain in the upper right part of the abdomen; unusual tiredness, pale skin, dizziness, or shortness of breath. bempedoic acid may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: benazepril
instructions: important warning: do not take benazepril if you are pregnant. if you become pregnant while taking benazepril, call your doctor immediately. benazepril may harm the fetus. why is this medication prescribed? benazepril is used alone or with other medications to treat high blood pressure. it belongs to a class of drugs called angiotensin-converting enzyme (ace) inhibitors and works by decreasing chemicals that tighten blood vessels so blood flows more easily. untreated high blood pressure can damage the brain, heart, blood vessels, kidneys, and other organs, causing heart disease, heart attack, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, vision loss, and other problems. in addition to medication, lifestyle changes such as eating a low-fat, low-salt diet, maintaining a healthy weight, exercising at least 30 minutes most days, not smoking, and using alcohol in moderation help control blood pressure. how should this medicine be used? benazepril comes as a tablet to take by mouth. it is usually taken once or twice a day, with or without food. take it at the same times each day to help you remember. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take benazepril exactly as directed; do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. your doctor will probably start you on a low dose and gradually increase it. benazepril controls high blood pressure but does not cure it, so continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop taking benazepril without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking benazepril, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to benazepril; to other ace inhibitors such as captopril (capoten), enalapril (vasotec, in vaseretic), fosinopril (monopril), lisinopril (in prinzide, in zestoretic), moexipril (univasc, in uniretic), perindopril (aceon), quinapril (accupril, in accuretic, in quinaretic), ramipril (altace), or trandolapril (mavik, in tarka); to any other medications; or to any ingredients in benazepril tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor if you are taking sacubitril/valsartan (entresto) or have taken it within the past 36 hours; do not take benazepril with sacubitril/valsartan. if you have diabetes and are taking aliskiren (tekturna, in amturnide, tekamlo, tekturna hct), do not take benazepril. some medications should not be taken with benazepril, and others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. discuss all medications you are taking or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist before starting benazepril, and consult them before starting, stopping, or changing any medication. the following nonprescription products may interact with benazepril: aspirin and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin) and naproxen (aleve), and potassium supplements. tell your doctor and pharmacist if you use these, and do not start them while taking benazepril without medical advice. tell your doctor if you have recently had severe diarrhea or vomiting, and if you have diabetes, heart failure, kidney disease, lupus, or scleroderma. tell your doctor if you are breastfeeding. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking benazepril. be aware that diarrhea, vomiting, not drinking enough fluids, and heavy sweating can lower blood pressure and cause lightheadedness or fainting. what special dietary instructions should i follow? talk to your doctor before using salt substitutes containing potassium. if your doctor prescribes a low-salt or low-sodium diet, follow these directions carefully. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? benazepril may cause side effects. common side effects include cough, headache, dizziness, and drowsiness. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor immediately if you have swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; hoarseness; difficulty breathing or swallowing; severe lightheadedness; fainting; rash; yellowing of the skin or eyes; or fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection. benazepril may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: benazepril and hydrochlorothiazide
instructions: important warning: do not use benazepril and hydrochlorothiazide if you are pregnant. if you become pregnant while taking this medicine, contact your doctor right away. this medication can harm the fetus. why is this medication prescribed? the combination of benazepril and hydrochlorothiazide treats high blood pressure. benazepril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ace) inhibitor that lowers levels of substances that tighten blood vessels, helping blood flow more easily. hydrochlorothiazide is a diuretic (“water pill”) that increases the removal of excess salt and water through the urine. treating high blood pressure helps prevent damage to the brain, heart, blood vessels, kidneys, and other organs, which can otherwise lead to heart disease, heart attack, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, vision loss, and other problems. along with medication, lifestyle changes such as eating a low-fat, low-salt diet, maintaining a healthy weight, exercising at least 30 minutes most days, not smoking, and limiting alcohol can further improve blood pressure control. how should this medicine be used? benazepril and hydrochlorothiazide comes as an oral tablet, usually taken once daily. take it at the same time each day to help you remember. follow your prescription directions exactly; ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not take more or less than prescribed or take it more often. this medicine controls but does not cure high blood pressure, so continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking this medicine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to benazepril (lotensin), hydrochlorothiazide (hctz, microzide, oretic), any other ace inhibitors such as captopril (capoten), enalapril (vasotec, in vaseretic), fosinopril (monopril), lisinopril (in prinzide, in zestoretic), moexipril (univasc, in uniretic), perindopril (aceon), quinapril (accupril, in accuretic, in quinaretic), ramipril (altace), or trandolapril (mavik, in tarka); to sulfa drugs; to any other medications; or to any ingredients in the benazepril and hydrochlorothiazide tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. do not take benazepril and hydrochlorothiazide if you are taking the combination of sacubitril and valsartan (entresto) or if you have taken it within the last 36 hours; your doctor will usually advise against using them together. some medicines should not be used with this combination, and others may need dose changes or extra monitoring. discuss all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and herbal products you use or plan to use with your doctor and pharmacist before starting this medication, and consult them before making any changes while on it. nonprescription products that may interact include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin) and naproxen (aleve, naprosyn), and potassium supplements; inform your healthcare providers if you use these and do not start them while taking this medicine without medical advice. tell your doctor if you have recently had severe vomiting or diarrhea, and if you have or have ever had allergies, asthma, heart failure, diabetes, gout, high cholesterol, lupus, scleroderma, or kidney or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are breastfeeding. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, tell the surgeon or dentist you are taking this medication. be aware that diarrhea, vomiting, inadequate fluid intake, or heavy sweating can lower your blood pressure and cause lightheadedness or fainting. what special dietary instructions should i follow? check with your doctor before using salt substitutes that contain potassium. if your doctor recommends a low-salt or low-sodium diet or an exercise plan, follow these instructions carefully. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? benazepril and hydrochlorothiazide can cause side effects. common effects include cough, dizziness, excessive tiredness, and drowsiness. some effects can be serious; call your doctor right away if you have swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; hoarseness; trouble breathing or swallowing; rash; severe lightheadedness or fainting; fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection; yellowing of the skin or eyes; dry mouth; intense thirst; weakness; lack of energy; restlessness; muscle pain or cramps; infrequent urination; upset stomach; vomiting; or rapid, pounding, or irregular heartbeat. this medication may cause other side effects; talk to your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: bendamustine injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bendamustine injection is used to treat chronic lymphocytic leukemia (cll), a cancer of the white blood cells. it is also used to treat certain slow-growing non-hodgkin lymphoma (nhl) that has continued to worsen during or after treatment with another medication. bendamustine is an alkylating agent that kills existing cancer cells and slows the growth of new cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? bendamustine comes as a solution or as a powder that is mixed with liquid and given intravenously by a healthcare professional. it may be injected over about 10 minutes or infused over 30 or 60 minutes in a medical office or hospital outpatient clinic. for cll, it is usually given once daily for 2 days, followed by 26 days without treatment; this 28-day cycle may be repeated for up to 6 cycles. for nhl, it is usually given once daily for 2 days, followed by 19 days without treatment; this 21-day cycle may be repeated for up to 8 cycles. your doctor may delay treatment and adjust your dose if you experience certain side effects and may prescribe other medicines to prevent or treat side effects. tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving bendamustine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bendamustine, any other medications, or any ingredients in the product. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. be sure to mention ciprofloxacin (cipro), fluvoxamine (luvox), and omeprazole (prilosec). many other medications can interact with bendamustine, so tell your doctor about all the medicines you take, even those not listed here. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had cytomegalovirus (cmv), hepatitis b virus (hbv) infection, tuberculosis (tb), herpes zoster (shingles), or kidney or liver disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or plan to father a child, you or your partner should not become pregnant while receiving bendamustine. use effective birth control during treatment and for 3 months after the last dose. if you or your partner becomes pregnant, call your doctor; bendamustine can harm the fetus. do not breastfeed during treatment. bendamustine may make you tired; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. if you use tobacco, be aware that smoking may reduce this medication’s effectiveness. what special dietary instructions should i follow? continue your normal diet unless your doctor tells you otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you are unable to keep an appointment to receive a dose, call your doctor right away. what side effects can this medication cause? bendamustine may cause side effects. common side effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, heartburn, constipation, stomach pain or swelling, mouth sores or white patches, dry mouth, changes in taste or difficulty tasting food, loss of appetite, weight loss, headache, anxiety, depression, trouble sleeping, back, bone, joint, arm, or leg pain, dry skin, sweating, and night sweats. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have pain at the injection site; hives; rash; itching; blistering or peeling skin; difficulty breathing or swallowing; swelling of the eyes, face, lips, tongue, arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; shortness of breath; chest pain; fast heartbeat; excessive tiredness or weakness; pale skin; fever, chills, cough, or other signs of infection; severe nausea or vomiting; unusual bleeding or bruising; yellowing of the skin or eyes; dark urine; light-colored stools; or tenderness on the right upper side of the abdomen. bendamustine may cause infertility in some men; this may resolve after treatment, last for several years, or be permanent. some people have developed other cancers while using bendamustine; it is not known whether bendamustine caused these cancers. bendamustine may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: benralizumab injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? benralizumab injection is used with other medicines to prevent wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness, and coughing due to asthma in adults and in children 6 years and older whose asthma is not controlled on their current medication. it is also used in adults to treat eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (egpa), a condition involving asthma, high levels of certain white blood cells, and blood vessel inflammation. benralizumab is a monoclonal antibody that lowers a specific type of white blood cell to reduce airway swelling and irritation, making breathing easier. how should this medicine be used? benralizumab injection is a liquid given subcutaneously (under the skin). for asthma, it is usually given every 4 weeks for the first 3 doses, then every 8 weeks. for egpa, it is usually given every 4 weeks. your doctor will determine how long you should receive treatment based on your condition and how you respond. it comes in a prefilled syringe for a healthcare professional to inject into the upper arm, thigh, or abdomen in a clinic. if you are an adult or a child 12 years or older, your doctor may allow you or a caregiver to give it at home using the fasenra pen autoinjector. your healthcare provider will train you; read the manufacturer’s instructions for use and ask if you have questions. before injecting, check the expiration date; look through the autoinjector window—the liquid should be clear and colorless to slightly yellow and may contain small white particles or an air bubble. do not use it if the liquid is cloudy, discolored, or contains large particles. inject into the front of the thighs or the abdomen (not the navel or the 2 inches [5 cm] around it). if a caregiver is injecting, the back of the upper arm may also be used. rotate sites; choose a spot at least 1 inch (2.5 cm) from previous injections. do not inject skin that is tender, bruised, red, hard, or over scars or stretch marks. use each autoinjector only once and inject all the medicine in the device; do not reuse it even if some liquid remains. dispose of used devices in a puncture-resistant (sharps) container; ask your pharmacist or doctor how to dispose of the container. do not decrease or stop your other asthma medicines unless your doctor tells you to; your doctor may reduce them gradually. benralizumab is not for sudden asthma attacks. your doctor will prescribe a quick-relief inhaler for attacks and will tell you how to treat sudden symptoms. call your doctor if your asthma worsens or attacks happen more often. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medicine may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving benralizumab, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to benralizumab, any other medicines, or any ingredient in the injection;
