ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients or review the manufacturer’s information. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have a parasite infection. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while receiving benralizumab, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an injection, call your doctor; they will tell you when to take the missed dose and when to take the next one. if you miss a clinic appointment for a dose, call to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? benralizumab may cause side effects. common side effects include headache and sore throat. some side effects can be serious—call your doctor right away or get emergency medical help if you have wheezing or trouble breathing, hives, rash, swelling of the face, mouth, or tongue, fainting, or dizziness. benralizumab may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: bentoquatam topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bentoquatam lotion is used to help prevent rashes from poison ivy, poison oak, and poison sumac in people who may be exposed to these plants. it belongs to a class of skin protectants and works by forming a barrier on the skin that blocks the plant oils that can cause a rash. it will not soothe, treat, or heal a rash that has already developed from contact with these plants. how should this medicine be used? bentoquatam comes as a lotion for application to the skin. apply it at least 15 minutes before possible exposure to poison ivy, poison oak, or poison sumac, and reapply at least every 4 hours for as long as the risk of contact continues. follow the package directions carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. use bentoquatam exactly as directed. it is available without a prescription, but consult a doctor before using it on a child younger than 6 years. shake the lotion very well before each use to mix it evenly. for external use only. do not swallow or get the lotion in your eyes. if it gets in your eyes, rinse thoroughly with plenty of water. do not apply to an open rash. this product is flammable; stay away from fires and open flames while applying it and while it remains on your skin. what special precautions should i follow? before using bentoquatam, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bentoquatam or any other medications. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. inform your doctor about any medical conditions you have now or have had in the past. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, talk to your doctor. if you become pregnant while using bentoquatam, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medication is usually applied as needed. protection begins about 15 minutes after it is applied. what side effects can this medication cause? bentoquatam can cause side effects.

name: benzgalantamine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? benzgalantamine is used to treat symptoms of alzheimer’s disease (ad), a brain disorder that gradually impairs memory, thinking, learning, communication, and daily functioning. it belongs to a class of drugs called acetylcholinesterase inhibitors and works by increasing levels of a natural brain chemical important for memory and thinking. it may improve or slow the decline of memory and thinking in people with ad, but it will not cure ad or prevent future cognitive loss. how should this medicine be used? benzgalantamine comes as an oral tablet, usually taken twice daily with or without food at about the same times each day. follow your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. take it exactly as directed; do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. swallow tablets whole; do not split, crush, or chew. drink plenty of water while taking benzgalantamine. your doctor will likely start with a low dose and increase it gradually, not more than once every 4 weeks. continue taking it even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor. if you stop for a few days or longer, call your doctor before restarting; you will likely need to resume at the lowest dose and increase gradually to your previous dose. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking benzgalantamine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to benzgalantamine, galantamine, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. some nonprescription medicines and herbal products may interact with benzgalantamine, including diphenhydramine, dimenhydrinate, brompheniramine, doxylamine, loperamide, ibuprofen, and naproxen; do not start any of these while taking benzgalantamine without consulting your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had asthma or other lung disease, an enlarged prostate, ulcers, seizures, irregular heartbeat, or heart, kidney, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while taking benzgalantamine, call your doctor. if you are having any surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you take benzgalantamine. ask your doctor about the safe use of alcohol while taking this medication; alcohol may reduce its effectiveness. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. if you miss more than 3 doses, call your doctor before restarting. what side effects can this medication cause? benzgalantamine may cause side effects. call your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: decreased appetite, depression, dizziness, headache, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, weight loss. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have any of the following: rash; blistering or peeling skin; skin pain; swelling of the lips, mouth, throat, tongue, or face; fever; sore throat; cough; joint pain; fatigue; feeling weak; confusion; fainting; shortness of breath; chest pain; slowed heartbeat; bloody or black, tarry stools; vomiting blood or material that looks like coffee grounds; severe abdominal pain; difficulty urinating or weak urine flow; painful urination; blood in urine; seizures; difficulty breathing or shortness of breath. benzgalantamine may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: benzhydrocodone and acetaminophen
instructions: notice: benzhydrocodone and acetaminophen has been discontinued in the united states. because it is no longer available on the u.s. market, this information is not being updated. if this medicine is used outside the u.s., consult the manufacturer’s labeling for the most current guidance. important warning: benzhydrocodone and acetaminophen can be habit-forming, especially with long-term use. take it exactly as prescribed. do not take larger doses, take it more often, or use it in a different way than directed. while using this medicine, discuss your pain goals, treatment duration, and non-opioid options with your healthcare provider. your risk of misuse, abuse, or addiction is higher if you or a family member drinks heavily, uses or has used street drugs, misuses prescription medicines, has had an overdose, or has a history of depression or other mental illness. if you think you might have an opioid use disorder, contact your healthcare provider right away or call the samhsa national helpline at 1-800-662-help. serious, life-threatening breathing problems can occur, especially during the first 24 to 72 hours of treatment and after dose increases. your doctor will monitor you closely. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had slow breathing, asthma, copd (such as chronic bronchitis or emphysema), a head injury, a brain tumor, or conditions that increase pressure in the skull. older adults and people who are weak or malnourished are at higher risk. call your doctor or seek emergency care immediately if you have slowed breathing, long pauses between breaths, or shortness of breath. do not share your medication. it may seriously harm or kill others, especially children. store it securely and out of the reach of children; track how many tablets remain. flush outdated or unneeded tablets down the toilet to prevent accidental use. concomitant use with certain medicines can increase the risk of dangerous breathing problems, profound sedation, or coma. always tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and herbal products you take or plan to take. seek urgent care if, when taking this medicine with other drugs, you develop unusual dizziness, lightheadedness, extreme sleepiness, slowed or difficult breathing, or unresponsiveness. make sure caregivers know these warning signs. this product contains acetaminophen. taking too much acetaminophen can cause severe liver damage, liver failure, or death. do not exceed 4,000 mg of acetaminophen per day from all sources. carefully follow labels and ask your doctor or pharmacist to help you add up your daily acetaminophen dose, especially if using more than one product. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver disease. do not drink alcohol, use alcohol-containing medicines, or use street drugs while taking this medicine; doing so increases the risk of life-threatening side effects. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, tell your doctor. regular use during pregnancy can cause life-threatening withdrawal in the newborn. call your baby’s doctor right away if your newborn has irritability, hyperactivity, abnormal sleep, high-pitched cry, shaking, vomiting, diarrhea, or poor weight gain. your doctor or pharmacist will give you a medication guide when you start treatment and with each refill. read it carefully and ask questions if anything is unclear. talk to your doctor about the risks and benefits of benzhydrocodone and acetaminophen. why is this medication prescribed? the combination of benzhydrocodone and acetaminophen is used to relieve severe, acute pain (sudden-onset pain with a specific cause that is expected to resolve) in patients who are expected to need an opioid and whose pain is not controlled with non-opioid options. benzhydrocodone is an opioid analgesic that changes how the brain and nervous system respond to pain. acetaminophen is an analgesic and antipyretic that helps the body sense pain differently and reduces fever. how should this medicine be used? benzhydrocodone and acetaminophen is taken by mouth as a tablet, with or without food, usually every 4 to 6 hours as needed for up to 2 weeks. do not take more than 12 tablets in 24 hours. follow your prescription label exactly. your doctor may adjust your dose based on pain control and side effects. tell your doctor if your pain is not well controlled, gets worse, or if you develop new or heightened sensitivity to pain; do not increase your dose or dosing frequency on your own. do not stop this medicine suddenly. if you stop abruptly, you may have withdrawal symptoms such as restlessness, watery eyes, runny nose, yawning, sweating, chills, goose bumps, muscle aches, enlarged pupils, irritability, anxiety, back or joint pain, weakness, stomach cramps, trouble sleeping, nausea, loss of appetite, vomiting, diarrhea, fast breathing, or rapid heartbeat. your doctor will help taper your dose gradually. other uses for this medicine: your doctor may prescribe this medication for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking this medicine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to benzhydrocodone, hydrocodone, acetaminophen, or any ingredients in the tablets. tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are taking or have taken any mao inhibitors in the past 14 days, such as isocarboxazid (marplan), linezolid (zyvox), methylene blue, phenelzine (nardil), selegiline (emsam, zelapar), or tranylcypromine (parnate). herbal supplements such as st. john’s wort and products that affect serotonin (for example, tryptophan) may interact; tell your doctor and pharmacist before starting or stopping them. tell your doctor if you have any condition listed in the important warning above, or if you have a blockage or narrowing of the stomach or intestines, or paralytic ileus; your doctor may advise against use. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had low blood pressure; seizures; difficulty urinating; diabetes; adrenal insufficiency; or disease of the pancreas, gallbladder, thyroid, heart, or kidneys. if you are breastfeeding, monitor the infant for increased sleepiness, trouble breathing, or limpness. if you stop this medicine or stop breastfeeding, watch the infant for withdrawal signs such as restlessness, watery eyes, runny nose, yawning, sweating, chills, or enlarged pupils, and call the doctor immediately if any occur. this medicine may reduce fertility in men and women; discuss risks with your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental work, tell the doctor or dentist you are taking this medication. this drug may cause drowsiness, dizziness, or lightheadedness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. it can cause dizziness or fainting when standing up quickly, especially when starting or after a dose increase; rise slowly from sitting or lying positions. constipation is common; ask your doctor about diet changes or medications to prevent or treat constipation. what special dietary instructions should i follow? continue your usual diet unless your doctor gives you other advice. do not drink alcohol or use alcohol-containing products while taking this medicine. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is usually taken as needed. if your doctor has told you to take it on a regular schedule and you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include nausea, vomiting, itching, headache, abdominal pain or swelling, gas, low energy, feeling faint, or sudden warmth/flushing. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have any serious side effects or symptoms listed in the important warning, including rash; hives; skin peeling or blisters; mouth sores; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes; trouble swallowing or breathing; extreme drowsiness; severe lightheadedness when changing position; agitation, fever, confusion, fast heartbeat, severe muscle stiffness or twitching, loss of coordination, or seizures; or a combination of nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, extreme tiredness, weakness, dizziness, and feeling faint (especially if used for a month or longer). benzhydrocodone and acetaminophen may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you notice anything unusual or bothersome.

name: benznidazole
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? benznidazole is prescribed to treat chagas disease caused by a parasite in children 2 to 12 years old. it belongs to a class of medications called antiprotozoals and works by killing the organism that causes chagas disease. how should this medicine be used? benznidazole comes as a tablet taken by mouth. it is usually taken with or without food twice a day for 60 days. take doses at the same times every day, about 12 hours apart. follow the directions on your prescription label and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. take benznidazole exactly as directed; do not take more or less of it or more often than prescribed. the 100-mg tablets are scored so they can be split into halves or quarters. if your doctor tells you to take only part of a tablet, hold the tablet between your thumb and index finger near the scored line and apply pressure to break off the required portion. use only pieces broken at the scored line. if you cannot swallow tablets whole, you may dissolve them in water: place the prescribed number of tablets or tablet portions into a drinking cup, add the amount of water directed by your doctor or pharmacist, wait 1 to 2 minutes for the tablets to disintegrate, then gently shake the cup to mix. drink the mixture immediately. then rinse the cup with the additional amount of water directed by your doctor and drink the entire amount to be sure you receive the full dose. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine benznidazole is also sometimes used to treat chagas disease in people older than 12 years and adults up to 50 years old who do not have advanced disease. talk to your doctor about the risks of using this medication for your condition. this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking benznidazole, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to benznidazole, metronidazole (for example, flagyl or products that contain metronidazole such as pylera), any other medications, or any of the ingredients in benznidazole tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor if you are taking or have taken disulfiram (antabuse); your doctor may tell you not to take benznidazole if you are currently taking disulfiram or took it within the past 2 weeks. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any blood disorders or liver disease. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, tell your doctor. people who can become pregnant must have a pregnancy test before starting this medication and should use birth control during treatment and for 5 days after the final dose. if you become pregnant while taking benznidazole, call your doctor. benznidazole can cause fetal harm. do not breastfeed while taking benznidazole. you should know that this medication may decrease fertility in men; talk to your doctor about the risks of taking benznidazole. do not drink alcoholic beverages or use products containing alcohol or propylene glycol while taking this medication and for at least 3 days after your treatment is finished. alcohol and propylene glycol may cause nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, headache, sweating, and flushing when taken during treatment with benznidazole. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? benznidazole may cause side effects. if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away, tell your doctor: headache; dizziness; stomach pain; nausea; vomiting; diarrhea; loss of appetite; weight loss; uncontrollable shaking of a part of the body. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following symptoms, stop this medication and call your doctor immediately: rash; swollen, red, peeling, or blistering skin; hives; itching; red- or purple-colored skin spots; fever; swollen lymph nodes; numbness, pain, burning, or tingling in your hands or feet. benznidazole may cause other side effects.

name: benzonatate
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? benzonatate is prescribed to relieve cough. it is an antitussive (cough suppressant) that works by reducing the cough reflex in the lungs and air passages. how should this medicine be used? benzonatate comes as liquid-filled capsules and capsules taken by mouth. it is usually taken three times a day as needed. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. take benzonatate exactly as directed; do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. swallow the capsules whole; do not break, dissolve, cut, crush, suck, or chew them. if the medication is released in the mouth, it can cause numbness and increase the risk of choking. do not eat or drink if you feel numbness or tingling of your mouth, tongue, throat, or face. if these feelings continue or worsen, get medical help right away. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking benzonatate, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to benzonatate, procaine (novocain), tetracaine (in synera), any other medications, or any ingredients in benzonatate capsules. ask your doctor or pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking benzonatate, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking benzonatate. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medication is usually taken as needed. if you take benzonatate on a regular schedule and miss a dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? benzonatate may cause side effects. common effects include nausea, constipation, drowsiness, headache, dizziness, stuffy nose, feeling chilly, and burning in the eyes. some side effects can be serious. if you experience rash or hives, itching, tightening of the throat, difficulty breathing or swallowing, numbness of the chest, confusion, or hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that are not there), call your doctor immediately. benzonatate may cause other side effects.

name: benztropine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? benztropine is used with other medicines to treat the symptoms of parkinson disease (pd), a nervous system disorder that causes difficulties with movement, muscle control, and balance, and to manage tremors caused by other medical problems or medications. benztropine is an anticholinergic that works by blocking the natural substance acetylcholine to help decrease parkinson symptoms. how should this medicine be used? benztropine comes as an oral tablet. it is usually taken at bedtime. it is typically taken once daily but may be taken up to four times a day depending on your symptoms. take benztropine at the same time or times each day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully. take it exactly as prescribed; do not take more or less or take it more often than directed. your doctor may start with a low dose and increase it slowly based on your response. do not stop taking benztropine suddenly without talking with your doctor, especially if you are taking other medications, because symptoms of parkinson disease can return. other uses for this medicine this medication is sometimes prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking benztropine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to benztropine, any other medications, or any ingredients in the product. ask your doctor or pharmacist or check the package label for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. be sure to mention tricyclic antidepressants such as desipramine (norpramin), clomipramine (anafranil), imipramine (tofranil), or trimipramine (surmontil), and haloperidol (haldol). tell your doctor if you have or have ever had tardive dyskinesia (uncontrollable movements of the face, tongue, or other body parts), glaucoma, benign prostatic hypertrophy (bph) or other urinary problems, or heart or blood pressure problems. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking benztropine, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking benztropine. this drug may cause drowsiness; do not drive a car or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. alcohol can add to the drowsiness caused by benztropine. avoid unnecessary or prolonged exposure to sunlight and wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen because benztropine can make your skin sensitive to sunlight. talk to your doctor about the risks and benefits of taking benztropine if you are 65 years of age or older; older adults should not usually take benztropine because it may be less safe or effective than other medications for this condition. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? side effects from benztropine are common. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: dry mouth, difficulty or pain when urinating, constipation, vomiting, nausea, or loss of appetite. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away if you have: rash; fast, irregular, or pounding heartbeat; fever; confusion; depression; delusions or hallucinations; or vision changes. benztropine may cause other side effects.

name: benzyl alcohol topical
instructions: notice: benzyl alcohol topical is no longer available in the united states. if you are currently using benzyl alcohol topical, contact your doctor to discuss switching to another treatment. why is this medication prescribed? benzyl alcohol lotion is used to treat head lice—small insects that attach to the skin—in adults and in children 6 months of age and older. it should not be used in children younger than 6 months. benzyl alcohol is in a class of medications called pediculicides; it kills lice but does not kill lice eggs, so a second application is needed to kill lice that hatch later. how should this medicine be used? topical benzyl alcohol comes as a lotion to apply to the scalp and hair. it is usually used in two treatments, with a possible third if needed; the second treatment must be applied about one week after the first. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. use exactly as directed; do not use more, less, or more often than prescribed. your doctor will prescribe an amount based on your hair length; use enough to cover the entire scalp and all hair. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information and read it carefully. for hair and scalp use only. avoid getting the lotion in your eyes. if it gets in your eyes, flush with water right away; if irritation persists, call your doctor or seek medical help. to use: cover your face and eyes with a towel and keep eyes closed; you may need adult help. apply the lotion to dry hair and scalp, including behind the ears and at the back of the neck, using enough to cover the entire scalp and all hair. leave on for 10 minutes after finishing the application; use a timer. rinse from hair and scalp with water in a sink; do not use a shower or bathtub to avoid spreading the lotion over the rest of your body. you and anyone who helped should wash hands thoroughly after application and rinsing. you may shampoo after rinsing. a lice comb may be used to remove dead lice and empty egg shells (nits), and you may need adult help. repeat the entire process in one week to kill newly hatched lice. after using the lotion, sanitize recently used clothing, underwear, pajamas, hats, sheets, pillowcases, and towels by washing in very hot water or by dry-cleaning. wash combs, brushes, hair clips, and other personal care items in hot water. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to benzyl alcohol, any other medications, or any ingredients in the lotion; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any skin problems or other medical conditions. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while using the lotion, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? a second application is required about one week after the first. if you miss the second treatment, call your doctor. what side effects can this medication cause? benzyl alcohol lotion may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: itching of the scalp, redness of the scalp, numbness or pain of the scalp. some side effects can be serious; if you experience any of the following, call your doctor immediately: scalp irritation or infected or pus-filled areas of skin on the scalp. benzyl alcohol lotion may cause other side effects.

name: bepotastine ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bepotastine ophthalmic is used to relieve eye itching caused by allergic conjunctivitis, a condition in which exposure to airborne allergens makes the eyes itchy, swollen, red, and watery. bepotastine is an antihistamine that blocks the action and release of histamine, a substance that triggers allergy symptoms. how should this medicine be used? bepotastine comes as an ophthalmic solution (eye drops). apply to the affected eye(s) twice daily at about the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly; do not use more, less, or more often than directed. do not let the dropper tip touch your eye, fingers, or any surface. if contamination is suspected, contact your doctor or pharmacist. to use the eye drops: wash your hands. check that the dropper tip is not chipped or cracked. avoid touching the tip. tilt your head back, pull down the lower eyelid to create a small pocket, and hold the dropper above the eye without touching it. while looking up, squeeze one drop into the pocket. release the eyelid, close your eye, tip your head downward, and keep the eye closed for 2 to 3 minutes. try not to blink. gently press a finger on the corner of the eye (near the nose) during this time. wipe away any excess fluid. if you need more than one drop in the same eye, wait at least 5 minutes before the next drop. replace and tighten the cap; do not rinse the tip. wash your hands after use. what special precautions should i follow? before using bepotastine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bepotastine, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the drops; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all medicines, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any medical conditions. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, discuss this with your doctor; call your doctor if you become pregnant while using the drops. if you wear contact lenses: do not wear them if your eyes are red; do not use the drops to treat irritation you think is caused by contact lenses. the drops contain benzalkonium chloride, which can be absorbed by soft lenses. remove lenses before using the drops and wait at least 10 minutes before reinserting; do not instill drops while wearing lenses. what special dietary instructions should i follow? continue your normal diet unless your doctor advises otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? bepotastine eye drops may cause side effects. call your doctor if any symptom is severe or does not go away. common effects include: unusual or bitter taste, eye irritation, headache, and swelling of the inside of the nose and throat. the drops may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice any unusual problems.

name: berdazimer topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? berdazimer topical is used to treat molluscum contagiosum (mc), a viral skin infection that causes small bumps on the skin, in adults and in children 1 year of age and older. berdazimer is in a class of medicines called nitric oxide–releasing agents; how it works for mc is not fully understood. how should this medicine be used? berdazimer is a gel applied to the affected skin. apply to each mc lesion once daily for up to 12 weeks, or as directed. follow your prescription label exactly. do not use more, less, or more often than prescribed. the medication comes as two tubes with a dosing guide. dispense equal amounts from each tube onto the dosing guide as instructed, replace both caps tightly, and mix the contents together on the guide. using the guide, apply a thin layer to all mc lesions. wash your hands after applying (unless treating lesions on the hands) and avoid touching the eyes or transferring gel to unaffected skin. allow the gel to dry for 10 minutes and avoid swimming, bathing, or washing the treated areas for 1 hour after application. do not apply in or around the eyes or place in the mouth or vagina. mix only immediately before use and discard any mixed gel that remains; do not store mixed product. use for as long as your doctor instructs to help ensure complete clearance of lesions. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using berdazimer, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to berdazimer, any other medications, or any ingredient in the gel. ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had skin problems. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. if you become pregnant while using berdazimer, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not apply extra gel to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? berdazimer may cause side effects. call your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: burning, stinging, flaking; lightening or darkening of the skin; blisters or irritation; fever, general unwell feeling, cough, or congestion. some side effects can be serious. if you experience pain, itching, swelling, or redness at the application site, call your doctor immediately.

name: beremagene geperpavec-svdt
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? beremagene geperpavec-svdt is prescribed for certain adults and children 6 months of age or older with dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa, an inherited condition that makes the skin fragile and prone to blisters, wounds, infections, and scarring. it is a gene therapy that helps restore a gene involved in wound healing to strengthen and stabilize the skin. how should this medicine be used? beremagene geperpavec-svdt is a gel applied to the skin by a healthcare professional in a clinic or at home. it is usually applied directly to wounds once a week, and each wound should continue to receive weekly applications until it is fully healed. your doctor may not be able to treat all wounds in a single visit; they will decide which wounds to treat and create a plan to prioritize treatment based on severity. after treatment, avoid contact with the treated wounds and their dressings for about 24 hours. do not touch, rub, or scratch treated wounds or their dressings; if contact occurs, rinse the affected area thoroughly with water. your healthcare provider will instruct you or a caregiver on changing dressings, including washing hands, wearing protective gloves, and disposing of gloves and used dressings as directed. follow all instructions carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist for the manufacturer’s patient information if you have questions. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more details. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving beremagene geperpavec-svdt, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to this medication, any of its ingredients, or any other medicines; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while receiving this medication, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment for a dose of beremagene geperpavec-svdt, contact your doctor right away to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? beremagene geperpavec-svdt may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of the following are severe or do not go away: itching, rash, redness, chills, cough, runny nose. this medication may cause other side effects. if someone collapses, has a seizure, has difficulty breathing, or cannot be awakened, call emergency services (911) immediately. what other information should i know? keep all appointments with your doctor. keep a written, up-to-date list of all prescription and over-the-counter medicines, vitamins, minerals, and dietary supplements you take, and bring it to each doctor’s visit or if you are admitted to the hospital. carry this list with you in case of emergencies. brand names vyjuvek.

name: besifloxacin ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? besifloxacin ophthalmic (eye drops) is used to treat bacterial conjunctivitis (pink eye), an infection of the membrane covering the outside of the eyeballs and the inside of the eyelids. it belongs to a class of antibiotics called fluoroquinolones and works by killing the bacteria that cause the infection. how should this medicine be used? besifloxacin is an ophthalmic suspension (eye drops). apply to the affected eye(s) three times daily, 4 to 12 hours apart, for 7 days. use the drops at about the same times each day. follow your prescription instructions exactly; do not use more, use less, or dose more often than prescribed. your symptoms should improve during treatment; call your doctor if they do not improve, worsen, or if new eye problems develop. use for the full prescribed course even if you feel better. stopping early or skipping doses may leave the infection untreated and promote antibiotic resistance. to avoid contamination, do not let the bottle tip touch your eye, fingers, or any surface; using contaminated drops can cause serious eye injury or vision loss. if you think the drops are contaminated, contact your doctor or pharmacist. to use the eye drops: 1) wash your hands with soap and water. 2) check the dropper tip to be sure it is not chipped or cracked. 3) do not touch the dropper tip to anything. 4) tilt your head back and pull down the lower eyelid with a finger to form a pocket. 5) hold the dropper above the eye without touching it, bracing your hand against your face. 6) look up and squeeze out one drop into the pocket. 7) release the eyelid, close your eye for 2–3 minutes, and tip your head down as if looking at the floor; try not to blink or squeeze your eyelids. 8) press gently on the inner corner of the eye (tear duct). 9) wipe away excess liquid. 10) if more than one drop is prescribed in the same eye, wait at least 5 minutes before the next drop. 11) replace and tighten the cap; do not wipe or rinse the tip. 12) wash your hands. other uses for this medicine besifloxacin may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to besifloxacin; to other quinolone/fluoroquinolone antibiotics such as ciprofloxacin (ciloxan, cipro), gatifloxacin (zymar), gemifloxacin (factive), levofloxacin (levaquin, quixin), lomefloxacin (maxaquin), moxifloxacin (avelox, vigamox), nalidixic acid (neggram), norfloxacin (noroxin), ofloxacin (floxin, ocuflox), or sparfloxacin (zagam); to any other medications; or to any ingredients in besifloxacin eye drops. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor about your medical history. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, discuss this with your doctor; if you become pregnant while using besifloxacin, call your doctor. if you wear contact lenses, do not wear them while you have symptoms of bacterial conjunctivitis or while using besifloxacin. bacterial conjunctivitis spreads easily; wash your hands often, especially after touching your eyes. when the infection resolves, wash or replace any eye makeup, contact lenses, or other items that touched the infected eye(s). what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? instill the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? besifloxacin eye drops may cause side effects. common effects include red, itchy, or irritated eyes; eye pain; blurred vision; and headache. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have rash; hives; itching; trouble breathing or swallowing; or swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs. besifloxacin eye drops may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual or severe.

name: betaine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? betaine is prescribed to treat homocystinuria, an inherited disorder in which the body cannot properly break down certain proteins, leading to a buildup of homocysteine in the blood. high homocysteine can cause extreme tiredness, seizures, dislocation of the lens of the eye, abnormal bone structure, osteoporosis (weak bones), blood clots, decreased weight or slow weight gain, and delayed development in children. betaine is a nutrient that works by lowering homocysteine levels in the blood. how should this medicine be used? betaine comes as an oral powder to mix with food or drink, usually taken twice daily at the same times each day. follow your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. take it exactly as directed; do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. your doctor will likely start with a low dose and increase it based on your response. your doctor may also have you take vitamin b6 (pyridoxine), vitamin b12 (cobalamin), and folic acid with betaine. betaine controls homocystinuria but does not cure it, so continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor. to use the powder: gently shake the bottle before opening. using the provided scoop, measure the prescribed number of level scoops (1 level scoop = 1 gram). mix the measured powder with 4 to 6 ounces (120 to 180 milliliters) of water, juice, milk, or formula until fully dissolved; it may also be mixed with food. drink or eat the mixture immediately. replace the cap tightly after use. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking betaine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to betaine or any other medications. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any medical conditions. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking betaine, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow all dietary recommendations provided by your doctor or dietitian. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? betaine may cause side effects; tell your doctor if nausea is severe or does not go away. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you experience confusion, drowsiness, behavior changes, headache, vomiting, seizures, or loss of consciousness. betaine may cause other side effects.

name: betamethasone topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? betamethasone topical is used to relieve itching, redness, dryness, crusting, scaling, inflammation, and discomfort from various skin conditions, including psoriasis (red, scaly patches) and eczema (dry, itchy skin that may develop red, scaly rashes). it is a corticosteroid that works by activating natural substances in the skin to reduce swelling, redness, and itching. how should this medicine be used? betamethasone is available as an ointment, cream, lotion/solution, gel, and aerosol spray for use on the skin, and as a foam for application to the scalp. it is usually applied once or twice daily. follow your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. use exactly as directed. do not use more or less, do not use more often, and do not apply to other areas or for other conditions unless your doctor tells you to. your skin condition should start improving within the first 2 weeks; call your doctor if it does not. for skin: apply a small amount as a thin, even film to cover the affected area and rub in gently. for scalp foam: part the hair, apply a small amount to the affected area, and rub in gently; you may wash your hair as usual, but not right after applying. the foam is flammable; avoid open flames, heat sources, and do not smoke while applying and for a short time afterward. for external use only. avoid contact with eyes and mouth and do not swallow. do not use on the genital or rectal areas, in skin folds, or in the armpits unless directed by your doctor. if using on a child’s diaper area, do not use tight-fitting diapers or plastic pants. do not apply other products to the treated area or cover with bandages or wraps unless your doctor instructs you, as this can increase side effects. call your doctor if the treated area worsens or if burning, swelling, redness, or pus develops. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to betamethasone, any other medications (including other corticosteroids), or any ingredients in the product; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and supplements you take, especially other corticosteroids and other topical medications. tell your doctor if you have a skin infection or have ever had diabetes, liver disease, or cushing’s syndrome. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while using betamethasone topical, call your doctor right away. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are using this medication. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary changes are usually needed while using topical betamethasone. follow your normal diet unless your doctor gives you other instructions. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not apply a double amount to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? betamethasone may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: burning, itching, irritation, stinging, redness, or dryness at the application site; acne; unwanted hair growth; changes in skin color; bruising or shiny/thinning skin; tiny red bumps or a rash around the mouth; small white or red bumps on the skin. call your doctor immediately if you develop a severe rash or signs of skin infection (such as increasing redness, warmth, swelling, pain, or pus) where you applied the medication. children using betamethasone topical may have an increased risk of side effects, including slowed growth and delayed weight gain. talk to your child’s doctor about the risks. betamethasone topical may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using it.

name: betaxolol
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? betaxolol is used alone or with other medicines to control high blood pressure. it belongs to a class of medications called beta blockers. it works by relaxing blood vessels and slowing the heart rate to improve blood flow and lower blood pressure. untreated high blood pressure can damage the brain, heart, blood vessels, kidneys, and eyes, leading to heart disease, heart attack, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, vision loss, and other problems. along with medication, lifestyle changes help control blood pressure: eat a diet low in fat and salt, maintain a healthy weight, exercise about 30 minutes most days, avoid smoking, and use alcohol in moderation. how should this medicine be used? betaxolol comes as a tablet to take by mouth, usually once a day at the same time each day. follow the directions on your prescription label and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. take betaxolol exactly as directed; do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. your doctor will likely start you on a low dose and may increase your dose after 1-2 weeks if your blood pressure is not controlled. betaxolol controls high blood pressure but does not cure it. it may take 1-2 weeks or longer to see the full benefit. continue to take betaxolol even if you feel well. do not stop taking it without talking to your doctor. stopping suddenly may cause serious heart problems such as chest pain (angina), heart attack, or an irregular heartbeat. your doctor will usually decrease your dose gradually over about 2 weeks and will monitor you during this time, and may tell you to limit physical activity while your dose is being decreased. this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking betaxolol, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to betaxolol, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have heart failure or a slow or irregular heartbeat; your doctor may tell you not to take betaxolol. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had asthma or other lung disease; diabetes; psoriasis; hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid); pheochromocytoma (a tumor near the kidneys); or kidney, liver, or heart disease, and if you have ever had a serious allergic reaction to any food or other substance. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking betaxolol, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental or eye surgery, tell the surgeon, dentist, or eye doctor that you are taking betaxolol. betaxolol may make you drowsy; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. betaxolol may increase the risk of low blood sugar (hypoglycemia) and can mask the warning signs and symptoms of low blood sugar. tell your doctor if you cannot eat or drink normally or if you are vomiting while taking betaxolol. know the symptoms of low blood sugar and what to do if they occur. if you have allergic reactions to different substances, your reactions may be worse while taking betaxolol and may not respond to usual doses of injectable epinephrine. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? betaxolol may cause side effects. common side effects include extreme tiredness, difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep, unusual dreams, heartburn, nausea, diarrhea, joint pain, decreased sexual ability in men, cold hands and feet, numbness, burning, or tingling in the arms, legs, hands, or feet, and rash. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have difficulty breathing (especially during activity or when lying down), swelling of the arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, unexplained weight gain, a fast, slow, pounding, or irregular heartbeat, or chest pain. betaxolol may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: betaxolol ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ophthalmic betaxolol is prescribed to lower elevated pressure inside the eye, such as in glaucoma, to help prevent gradual vision loss. it is a beta blocker that reduces intraocular pressure. how should this medicine be used? ophthalmic betaxolol is available as a solution and as a suspension for use in the eyes and is typically used twice daily. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. do not use more or less than prescribed or use it more often. betaxolol helps control glaucoma but does not cure it, so continue using it even if you feel well. do not stop without discussing it with your doctor. to instill the drops: wash your hands with soap and water. check the bottle label to see if shaking is required; if so, shake well. inspect the dropper tip to ensure it is not damaged. do not let the tip touch your eye or any surface. tilt your head back and gently pull down your lower eyelid to create a small pocket. hold the dropper as close to the eye as possible without touching it, steadying your hand against your face. follow the product’s instructions for dispensing your dose: either gently squeeze the sides of the bottle or press the bottom to release one drop into the pocket. release the lower lid, close your eye for 2 to 3 minutes, and tip your head downward as if looking at the floor. avoid blinking or squeezing your eyelids. press a finger gently over the tear duct at the inner corner of the eye. wipe away any excess liquid. if a second drop is prescribed for the same eye, wait at least 5 minutes before putting in the next drop. replace and tighten the cap without rinsing or wiping the tip. wash your hands after use. other uses for this medicine this medication may be used for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using betaxolol eye drops, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to betaxolol or any other drugs. review all prescription and nonprescription medicines you use, especially other eye medications; beta blockers such as atenolol (tenormin), carteolol (cartrol), labetalol (normodyne, trandate), metoprolol (lopressor), nadolol (corgard), propranolol (inderal), sotalol (betapace), or timolol (blocadren); quinidine (quinidex, quinaglute dura-tabs); verapamil (calan, isoptin); and vitamins or supplements. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had thyroid disease, heart or lung disease, congestive heart failure, or diabetes. if you are pregnant, planning to become pregnant, or breastfeeding, discuss the risks and benefits; call your doctor right away if you become pregnant while using betaxolol. if you are scheduled for surgery, including dental procedures, inform your doctor or dentist that you use betaxolol. if you use another topical eye medication, instill it at least 10 minutes before applying betaxolol. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use extra drops to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? betaxolol eye drops can cause side effects. contact your doctor if these are severe or persistent: eye irritation, increased tearing, headache, dizziness, or trouble sleeping. some effects may be serious; call your doctor immediately if you have difficulty breathing, changes in vision, or eye pain.

name: bethanechol
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bethanechol is used to relieve difficulty urinating caused by surgery, medications, or other factors. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? bethanechol comes as an oral tablet and is usually taken two to four times daily. follow your prescription label exactly, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take it exactly as directed; do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. doses are typically spaced evenly throughout the day. take on an empty stomach at least 1 hour before or 2 hours after meals to help prevent stomach upset. what special precautions should i follow? before taking bethanechol, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bethanechol or any other drugs. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines and supplements you use, especially procainamide (pronestyl), quinidine (quinaglute), cold or nasal congestion medications, and vitamins. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had asthma, a bladder infection, epilepsy, high blood pressure, heart disease, parkinsons disease, an overactive thyroid, or ulcers. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. this drug may cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. alcohol can increase drowsiness. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take bethanechol on an empty stomach, at least 1 hour before or 2 hours after meals, to reduce stomach upset. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose. what side effects can this medication cause? bethanechol may cause side effects. call your doctor if any of the following are severe or do not go away: upset stomach, vomiting, dizziness, sweating, or flushing. call your doctor immediately if you experience shortness of breath, fainting, or a slow heart rate (pulse less than 50 beats per minute).

name: betibeglogene autotemcel injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? betibeglogene autotemcel injection is used to treat anemia (a lower than normal number of red blood cells) in people with transfusion-dependent beta thalassemia (cooley's anemia), an inherited condition that causes reduced red blood cell production. it belongs to a class of medications called autologous gene therapy, which is prepared from your own blood stem cells, and it works by helping your body make enough red blood cells so regular blood transfusions are no longer needed. how should this medicine be used? betibeglogene autotemcel injection is a liquid suspension given by intravenous infusion by a doctor or nurse in a hospital. it is administered as a one-time dose over up to 2 hours. before you receive betibeglogene autotemcel, you will receive chemotherapy medicines to prepare your body. prior to infusion, your blood stem cells are collected at a hospital or treatment center through mobilization and apheresis (a procedure that removes blood stem cells); this process usually takes about 1 week and may need to be repeated. your collected cells are sent to the manufacturer to prepare your personalized dose, which typically takes about 70-90 days. because it is made from your own cells, it must be given only to you. you will need to remain in the hospital for about 3-6 weeks after the infusion so you can be monitored for side effects. infusion reactions may occur within 24 hours of receiving your dose; tell your doctor or nurse right away if you have fast or irregular heartbeat or stomach pain. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer's patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving betibeglogene autotemcel injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to betibeglogene autotemcel, dimethyl sulfoxide (dmso), any other medications, or any ingredients in the product. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had seizures, hepatitis b or c, human immunodeficiency virus (hiv), or kidney or liver disease. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, do not become pregnant while receiving this medication. you will need a pregnancy test before starting, and you should use effective birth control during treatment and for 6 months after receiving the infusion. if you are a male with a partner who can become pregnant, use effective birth control during treatment and for 6 months after your infusion. if you or your partner becomes pregnant, call your doctor immediately; this medication may cause fetal harm. if you are breastfeeding or plan to breastfeed, do not breastfeed while receiving this therapy. do not donate blood, organs, tissues, or cells for transplantation after receiving this medication. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given as a one-time infusion by a healthcare professional. if you miss an appointment or your infusion is delayed, contact your doctor right away to reschedule; do not attempt to receive this medication outside a medical setting. what side effects can this medication cause? betibeglogene autotemcel injection may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: leg or arm pain, mouth or throat sores, hair loss, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, constipation, heartburn, decreased appetite, tiredness, changes in skin color. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have any of the following: unusual bruising or bleeding, nosebleeds, severe headache, blood in urine, stool, or vomit, coughing up blood, or unusual abdominal or back pain; fever, sore throat, ongoing cough and congestion, or other signs of infection; hives, rash, itching, swelling of the lips, tongue, or throat, shortness of breath, or difficulty breathing. this medication may increase the risk of developing blood cancers; your blood will be monitored at least yearly for at least 15 years after treatment. talk to your doctor about the risks of this medication. betibeglogene autotemcel injection may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: betrixaban
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? betrixaban is used to prevent deep vein thrombosis (dvt), a blood clot usually in the leg, and pulmonary embolism (pe), a blood clot in the lung, in people who are hospitalized for serious illnesses and are at increased risk of clots due to reduced mobility or other risk factors. it is a factor xa inhibitor that helps prevent clots by blocking a natural clotting substance. how should this medicine be used? betrixaban comes as an oral capsule and is usually taken with food once daily for 35 to 42 days. take it at the same time each day. follow your prescription label exactly; do not take more or less or more often than prescribed. continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor; stopping suddenly can increase your risk of blood clots. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to betrixaban or any ingredient in the capsules. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and herbal products you take, especially: amiodarone (pacerone, nexterone); anagrelide (agrylin); aspirin and other nsaids such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin), indomethacin (indocin, tivorbex), ketoprofen, and naproxen (aleve, anaprox); azithromycin (zithromax, zmax); cilostazol (pletal); clarithromycin (biaxin; also in prevpac); clopidogrel (plavix); dipyridamole (persantine); eptifibatide (integrilin); heparin; ketoconazole (nizoral, extina); prasugrel (effient); ssris such as citalopram (celexa), escitalopram (lexapro), fluoxetine (prozac, sarafem; in symbyax), fluvoxamine (luvox), paroxetine (brisdelle, paxil, pexeva), and sertraline (zoloft); snris such as duloxetine (cymbalta), desvenlafaxine (khedezla, pristiq), levomilnacipran (fetzima), milnacipran (savella), and venlafaxine (effexor); ticagrelor (brilinta); ticlopidine; tirofiban (aggrastat); verapamil (verelan, calan); warfarin (coumadin, jantoven); as well as carbamazepine (carbatrol, epitol, equetro, tegretol), phenytoin (dilantin, phenytek), and rifampin (rifadin, rimactane; in rifamate, rifater). your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you closely for side effects. many other medicines can interact with betrixaban, so share a complete list of everything you take. tell your doctor about all supplements and herbs; do not use st. john’s wort with betrixaban. do not take betrixaban if you have active bleeding that cannot be controlled. tell your doctor if you have an artificial heart valve; any history of bleeding problems; liver or kidney disease; or if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking betrixaban, call your doctor. before any surgery or dental work, tell the clinician you take betrixaban. if you fall or injure yourself—especially if you hit your head—call your doctor right away. if you receive epidural or spinal anesthesia or a spinal puncture while on a blood thinner such as betrixaban, you may develop a blood clot (hematoma) in or around the spine that can cause paralysis; the risk is higher if you have an epidural catheter, repeated spinal punctures, spinal deformity, or prior spinal surgery. call your doctor immediately if you develop back pain, muscle weakness, numbness or tingling (especially in the legs or feet), loss of bowel or bladder control, or inability to move your legs. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include constipation, diarrhea, nausea, or frequent or painful urination. serious side effects can occur. stop taking betrixaban and call your doctor immediately or seek emergency care if you have any of the following: bleeding gums; frequent nosebleeds; menstrual bleeding that is heavier than normal; red, pink, or brown urine; red or black, tarry stools; coughing up blood or blood clots; vomiting blood or material that looks like coffee grounds; unexpected pain, swelling, or joint pain; headache; dizziness or weakness; or any spinal symptoms listed in the precautions section. because betrixaban reduces your blood’s ability to clot, cuts or injuries may bleed longer than usual, and you may bruise or bleed more easily. call your doctor right away if bleeding or bruising is unusual, severe, or hard to control. betrixaban may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you have any concerns.

name: bevacizumab injection
instructions: notice: bevacizumab injection is available as several biologic products. these biologic products are considered biosimilar to bevacizumab injection, meaning they work just as well and are as safe to use as bevacizumab injection. “bevacizumab injection” below refers to any of these products. why is this medication prescribed? bevacizumab injection products are used to treat various solid tumors, including certain cancers of the lung, kidney, liver, brain, colon, rectum, female reproductive organs, and the peritoneal tissue lining the abdomen. they belong to a class of medications called antiangiogenic agents and work by blocking the formation of blood vessels that supply tumors, which may slow tumor growth and spread. how should this medicine be used? bevacizumab injection products are given as a liquid solution infused slowly into a vein by a doctor or nurse in a hospital or clinic. doses are usually given every 2 or 3 weeks, depending on your condition, other medications, and how you respond to treatment. the first infusion typically takes about 90 minutes, during which you will be closely monitored. if you tolerate the first dose without serious problems, later infusions usually take 30 to 60 minutes. serious infusion reactions can occur. tell your doctor immediately if you have difficulty breathing or shortness of breath, chills, shaking, sweating, headache, chest pain, dizziness, feeling faint, flushing, itching, rash, or hives. your doctor may slow, delay, or stop treatment if these or other side effects occur. other uses for this medicine: bevacizumab injection products are also sometimes used to treat wet age-related macular degeneration (amd) and diabetic macular edema. discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving a bevacizumab injection product, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this drug, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your allergy and symptoms. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; dose changes or extra monitoring may be needed. tell your doctor if you have ever had radiation therapy to your pelvis; and if you have or have ever had bleeding problems, diabetes, high blood pressure, heart failure, chest pain at rest (angina), heart attack, stroke or transient ischemic attack (tia), or blood clots in your lungs or legs, and if you have recently coughed up blood. bevacizumab injection products may cause infertility in women; do not assume you cannot become pregnant. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. use effective birth control during treatment and for at least 6 months after the final dose. if you become pregnant during treatment, call your doctor; bevacizumab may harm the fetus. do not breastfeed during treatment and for at least 6 months after the final dose. this medication may cause ovarian failure and decrease fertility in women; discuss the risks with your doctor. if you have recently had surgery or plan to have surgery, including dental surgery, tell your doctor. treatment should be stopped at least 28 days before planned surgery and not resumed until at least 28 days after surgery and once the area has completely healed. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment for a dose, call your doctor as soon as possible. what side effects can this medication cause? bevacizumab injection products may cause side effects. common side effects include dizziness, loss of appetite, heartburn, changes in taste, diarrhea, weight loss, mouth sores, voice changes, increased or decreased tearing, stuffy or runny nose, muscle, joint, or back pain, trouble sleeping, and dry skin. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have nosebleeds or bleeding from your gums; coughing up or vomiting blood or material that looks like coffee grounds; unusual bleeding or bruising; increased menstrual flow or vaginal bleeding; pink, red, or dark brown urine; or red or black, tarry stools; sudden headache, dizziness, or weakness; slow or difficult speech; sudden weakness or numbness of the face, arm, or leg; chest pain or discomfort; pain in the arms, shoulders, neck, jaw, stomach, or upper back; feeling light-headed or faint; shortness of breath; difficulty breathing; swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; fast, irregular, or pounding heartbeat; seizures; extreme tiredness; confusion; change in vision or loss of vision; sore throat, fever, chills, or other signs of infection; swelling of the face, eyes, stomach, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; unexplained weight gain; foamy urine; pain, tenderness, warmth, redness, or swelling in one leg only; sudden chest pain; shortness of breath; coughing up blood; rash or redness, itching, or scaling of the skin; stomach pain, constipation, nausea, vomiting, shivering, or fever. bevacizumab injection products may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you experience anything unusual.

name: bexagliflozin
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bexagliflozin is used with diet and exercise to help lower blood sugar in adults with type 2 diabetes, a condition where blood sugar is high because the body does not make or use insulin properly. it belongs to a class called sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (sglt2) inhibitors and lowers blood sugar by helping the kidneys remove more glucose in the urine. it is not for type 1 diabetes. managing blood sugar with bexagliflozin, healthy lifestyle changes (such as diet, physical activity, quitting smoking), and regular glucose monitoring can help reduce the risk of serious diabetes complications, including heart disease, stroke, kidney damage, nerve injury, and eye problems; it may also lower the chance of heart attack, stroke, and other diabetes-related issues like kidney failure, neuropathy, vision changes or loss, and gum disease. your healthcare team will help you choose the best plan to manage your diabetes. how should this medicine be used? bexagliflozin is an oral tablet taken once daily, with or without food, at about the same time each day. take exactly as prescribed; do not take more or less or more often than directed. swallow tablets whole; do not split, crush, or chew. bexagliflozin helps control, but does not cure, type 2 diabetes. do not stop taking it without talking to your doctor. you will receive a medication guide at the start of therapy and with each refill;
