read it carefully and ask your healthcare provider any questions. other uses for this medicine this medicine may be used for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking bexagliflozin, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to it, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your allergic symptoms. give your healthcare provider a list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for interactions and side effects. tell your doctor if you regularly drink alcohol or binge drink, are on a low-sodium diet, or have an infection. also inform your doctor if you have a history of amputation; heart disease; peripheral vascular disease; neuropathy; foot ulcers or sores; low blood pressure; urinary tract infections or urinary problems; pancreatic disease (including pancreatitis or pancreatic surgery); genital yeast infections; osteoporosis; or kidney or liver disease. if you are male, tell your doctor if you are uncircumcised. let your doctor know if you are eating less due to illness, surgery, or dietary changes; if you follow a ketogenic (high-fat, low-carbohydrate) diet; or if you have recently had diarrhea, vomiting, excessive sun exposure, or heavy sweating that may cause dehydration. if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding, tell your doctor; do not breastfeed while taking bexagliflozin. if you become pregnant, call your doctor. bexagliflozin may cause dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting when standing up quickly, especially when starting treatment; if this happens, call your doctor. to reduce this risk, rise slowly and sit with your feet on the floor for a few minutes before standing. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, tell the surgeon or dentist you take bexagliflozin; your doctor may have you stop it at least 3 days before surgery. ask your doctor for guidance if you become ill, develop an infection or fever, are under unusual stress, or are injured, as these can change your blood sugar and your medication needs. alcohol can affect blood sugar; ask your doctor about safe use while taking bexagliflozin. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow your usual diet unless your doctor gives you different instructions. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? bexagliflozin may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: urinating more often (including at night) and feeling increased thirst. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away if you have any of the following: symptoms of urinary tract infection such as frequent, urgent, burning, or painful urination; decreased urine; urine that is cloudy, red, pink, or brown; strong-smelling urine; pelvic or rectal pain; or fever, back pain, nausea, or vomiting; signs of vaginal yeast infection such as odor, white or yellowish discharge (often thick or cottage cheese–like), or itching; signs of genital infection in males such as redness, itching, swelling, rash on the penis, foul-smelling discharge, or pain in the surrounding skin; feeling unwell, tired, or weak along with fever and pain, tenderness, redness, or swelling of the genitals or the area between the genitals and rectum. stop bexagliflozin and call your doctor immediately or get emergency help if you have signs of a serious allergic reaction: rash, hives, itching, trouble breathing or swallowing, swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, mouth, or eyes, or hoarseness. stop bexagliflozin and call your doctor immediately or get emergency help if you have symptoms of ketoacidosis (a serious condition that can occur even if blood sugar is below 250 mg/dl): nausea, vomiting, stomach-area pain, unusual tiredness, or difficulty breathing; if possible, check your urine for ketones. bexagliflozin can increase the risk of lower-limb amputation (toe, foot, or leg). your doctor will advise you on proper foot and leg care to prevent infections and complications. follow these instructions carefully and contact your doctor right away if you notice pain, tenderness, sores, ulcers, warmth, swelling, or redness in the leg or foot, fever or chills, or any other signs of infection. this medication can cause dehydration; drink enough fluids while taking it. ask your doctor or pharmacist how much water is right for you. other side effects may occur; call your doctor if you have concerns.

name: bexarotene
instructions: important warning: do not take bexarotene if you are pregnant or could become pregnant. this medicine can cause severe birth defects. discuss the risks with your doctor. for female patients: if you are able to become pregnant, you must avoid pregnancy while taking bexarotene. use two reliable forms of birth control for at least 1 month before starting treatment, throughout therapy, and for 1 month after your last dose. your doctor will advise acceptable methods. because bexarotene can reduce the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives (pills, patches, rings, implants, injections), always use a second non-hormonal method at the same time. start bexarotene on the second or third day of your menstrual period. you must have a negative pregnancy test within 1 week before starting and then monthly during treatment. after each negative test, you will receive only a 1‑month supply. stop bexarotene and call your doctor right away if you think you are pregnant, miss a period, or have sex without using two forms of contraception. for male patients: use a condom every time you have sexual contact with a partner who is pregnant or can become pregnant while you are taking bexarotene and for 1 month after stopping. call your doctor if your partner becomes pregnant during this time. why is this medication prescribed? bexarotene treats cutaneous t‑cell lymphoma (ctcl), a skin‑targeting lymphoma, in people whose disease did not respond to at least one other medicine. it is a retinoid that works by slowing the growth of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? bexarotene is an oral capsule taken once daily with food, at about the same time each day. follow your prescription label exactly; do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. swallow capsules whole; do not chew or dissolve them. if you cannot swallow capsules whole, talk to your doctor. bexarotene can be harmful if it contacts skin: do not handle broken or leaking capsules. if powder from a broken capsule touches your skin, wash the area with soap and water right away and call your doctor. your doctor will start you on a standard dose and may lower it if side effects occur or increase it if your response is inadequate. it may take several months or longer to see full benefit. do not stop taking bexarotene without consulting your doctor. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine: this drug may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for details. what special precautions should i follow? before taking bexarotene, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bexarotene; to other retinoids such as acitretin (soriatane), etretinate (tegison), isotretinoin (accutane), or tretinoin (vesanoid); or to any medicines. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. be sure to mention: amiodarone; antifungals such as ketoconazole (nizoral) and itraconazole (sporanox); cimetidine (tagamet); clarithromycin (biaxin); diltiazem (cardizem); erythromycin (e.e.s., e‑mycin, erythrocin); fluvoxamine; gemfibrozil (lopid); hiv protease inhibitors such as indinavir (crixivan), nelfinavir (viracept), and ritonavir (norvir; also in kaletra); insulin and oral diabetes medicines; nefazodone; phenobarbital; phenytoin (dilantin); rifampin (rifadin, rimactane); tamoxifen (nolvadex); verapamil (calan); and vitamin a. your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you more closely for side effects. many other drugs can interact with bexarotene, so provide a complete medication list. tell your doctor if you drink or have ever drunk large amounts of alcohol, and if you have or have had pancreatitis; high cholesterol or triglycerides; diabetes; cataracts; or gallbladder, thyroid, kidney, or liver disease; and if you are breast‑feeding. ask your doctor about alcohol use while on bexarotene; alcohol can worsen side effects. avoid unnecessary or prolonged sun exposure and wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen, as bexarotene can increase sensitivity to sunlight. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor about eating grapefruit or drinking grapefruit juice while taking this medicine. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose with food as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? bexarotene may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: headache; weakness; tiredness; increased sensitivity to cold; weight gain; depression; joint or muscle pain; thinning or brittleness of hair or nails; constipation; rash; dry skin; redness, scaling, or itching of the skin; hair loss; swelling of the ankles, feet, or legs; trouble falling or staying asleep; nausea; vomiting; diarrhea. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away if you have: sudden or ongoing back or stomach pain; severe and persistent nausea and vomiting; fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection; vision changes. bexarotene can raise cholesterol and other blood fats and can reduce thyroid function. your doctor will monitor you for these effects and may prescribe medicines to manage them while you continue bexarotene. bexarotene may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you have unusual problems while taking it.

name: bexarotene topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? topical bexarotene is used to treat cutaneous t-cell lymphoma (ctcl), a skin-targeting lymphoma that has not responded to other treatments. it belongs to a class of medicines called retinoids and works by slowing or stopping the growth of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? topical bexarotene is a gel applied to the skin. it is typically started once every other day and then increased gradually, up to two to four times daily as tolerated. apply it at about the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. do not use more, use less, or use it more often than prescribed. your doctor will usually start with a low dose and increase no more than once weekly; your dose may be reduced if you have side effects. improvement may be seen in as little as 4 weeks, but it can take several months. continue using it even after improvement unless your doctor tells you to stop. bexarotene gel is flammable; keep it away from heat and open flames (for example, cigarettes). for external use only—do not swallow and avoid contact with eyes, nostrils, mouth, lips, vagina, tip of penis, rectum, and anus. you may bathe, shower, or swim, but use only a mild, non-deodorant soap. wait at least 20 minutes after bathing or showering before applying the gel, and do not bathe, shower, or swim for at least 3 hours after application. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. to use the gel: 1) wash your hands. 2) if using a new tube, remove the cap and confirm the opening is covered by a metal safety seal. do not use if the seal is missing or already punctured. if intact, turn the cap upside down and puncture the seal with the pointed tip. 3) with a clean finger, apply a generous layer of gel only to the affected skin, avoiding healthy surrounding skin. do not rub it in; a thin visible layer should remain. 4) do not cover the treated area with a tight bandage or dressing unless your doctor instructs you to. 5) wipe the application finger with a tissue and discard the tissue, then wash your hands with soap and water. 6) allow the gel to dry for 5–10 minutes before covering with loose clothing, and avoid tight garments over treated areas. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using topical bexarotene, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bexarotene; to other retinoids such as acitretin (soriatane), etretinate (tegison), isotretinoin (accutane), or tretinoin (vesanoid); or to any other medications. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. be sure to mention: certain antifungals (ketoconazole [nizoral], itraconazole [sporanox]); erythromycin (e.e.s., e-mycin, erythrocin); gemfibrozil (lopid); other medicines or products applied to the skin; and vitamin a in multivitamins. your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. many other drugs can interact with topical bexarotene, so tell your doctor about all medicines you use, including those not listed. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney or liver disease. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, do not use this medicine. topical bexarotene can cause severe birth defects. you will begin treatment on day 2 or 3 of your menstrual period and must have negative pregnancy tests within one week before starting and then monthly during treatment. you must use two acceptable forms of birth control during treatment and for one month after the last dose. if you become pregnant while using this medicine, call your doctor right away. if you are breastfeeding, do not use this medicine. if you are male and have a partner who is pregnant or could become pregnant, discuss necessary precautions with your doctor and call your doctor immediately if your partner becomes pregnant during your treatment. avoid unnecessary or prolonged exposure to sunlight and sunlamps; wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen because this medicine can increase sun sensitivity. do not use insect repellents or other products containing deet while using topical bexarotene. do not scratch the treated areas. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor about consuming grapefruit or grapefruit juice while using this medicine. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra gel to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? topical bexarotene may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: itching; redness, burning, irritation, or scaling of the skin; rash; pain; sweating; weakness; headache; swelling of the arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have sore throat, fever, chills, or other signs of infection, or swollen glands. bexarotene may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you experience any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: bezlotoxumab injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bezlotoxumab injection is used to lower the chance that clostridioides (clostridium) difficile infection (c. difficile or cdi)—a bacterial illness that can cause severe or life-threatening diarrhea—will come back in people at high risk of recurrence who are already taking an antibiotic to treat c. difficile. bezlotoxumab is a monoclonal antibody that works by binding to a c. difficile toxin to block its effects. how should this medicine be used? bezlotoxumab comes as a liquid solution given by intravenous (iv) infusion over about 60 minutes. it is administered as a single dose by a healthcare professional. it does not replace antibiotic treatment for c. difficile; continue your prescribed antibiotics exactly as directed by your doctor. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving bezlotoxumab, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bezlotoxumab, any other medications, or any ingredients in the infusion; your pharmacist can provide a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had heart failure. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions with bezlotoxumab unless your doctor gives you special instructions. follow your treatment plan for cdi and stay well hydrated as directed by your healthcare provider. what should i do if i forget a dose? bezlotoxumab is given as a single scheduled infusion. if you miss your appointment, contact your doctor or infusion center as soon as possible to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? bezlotoxumab injection may cause side effects. call your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: nausea; fever. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away if you have shortness of breath or trouble breathing; swelling of the ankles, feet, legs, or abdomen. bezlotoxumab injection may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: bicalutamide
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bicalutamide is used together with a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (gnrh) agonist such as leuprolide or goserelin to treat metastatic prostate cancer (cancer that starts in the prostate and has spread to other parts of the body). it is a nonsteroidal antiandrogen that blocks the effects of androgens (male hormones), helping to stop the growth and spread of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? bicalutamide is an oral tablet taken once daily, with or without food, at about the same time each day in the morning or evening. begin bicalutamide on the same day you start the luteinizing hormone-releasing hormone (lhrh/gnrh) agonist. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take bicalutamide exactly as prescribed; do not take more or less or take it more often than directed. bicalutamide used with an lhrh/gnrh agonist can help control the growth and spread of cancer but does not cure prostate cancer. continue both medicines even if you feel better; do not stop either medication without speaking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking bicalutamide, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bicalutamide, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. be sure to mention: alprazolam (xanax); anticoagulants such as warfarin (coumadin); aripiprazole (abilify); buspirone (buspar); calcium channel blockers such as amlodipine (norvasc), diltiazem (cardizem, dilacor, tiazac), felodipine (plendil), nifedipine (adalat, procardia), nisoldipine (sular), and verapamil (calan, covera, isoptin, verelan); chlorpheniramine; statins such as atorvastatin (lipitor), lovastatin (mevacor), and simvastatin (zocor); clarithromycin (biaxin); cyclosporine (neoral, sandimmune); diazepam (valium); erythromycin; hiv protease inhibitors such as indinavir (crixivan), ritonavir (norvir), and saquinavir (invirase, fortovase); methadone (dolophine); midazolam (versed); pimozide (orap); quinidine (quinidex, quinaglute); quinine; sildenafil (viagra); tacrolimus (prograf); tamoxifen (nolvadex); telithromycin (ketek); trazodone (desyrel); triazolam (halcion); and vincristine (vincasar). many other medications may also interact with bicalutamide, so make sure all your healthcare providers know about everything you take. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver disease. bicalutamide is for use in men only. if taken by a pregnant woman, it can cause fetal harm. women who are pregnant or may become pregnant must not take bicalutamide. if exposure occurs during pregnancy, contact a doctor immediately. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? bicalutamide may cause side effects. common effects include hot flashes or flushing; bone, back, or pelvic pain; muscle weakness; muscle or joint pain; headache; shortness of breath; increased blood pressure; swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; cough; constipation; nausea; vomiting; abdominal pain; diarrhea; gas; weight loss or gain; loss of appetite; dizziness; pain, burning, or tingling in the hands or feet; difficulty sleeping; feelings of uneasiness or dread; rash; sweating; inability to get or keep an erection; frequent urination at night; bloody urine; painful or difficult urination; frequent and urgent need to urinate; difficulty emptying the bladder; and painful or swollen breasts. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have yellowing of the skin or eyes; pain in the upper right part of the abdomen; extreme tiredness; unusual bleeding or bruising; lack of energy; upset stomach; loss of appetite; flu-like symptoms; dull or sharp side pain; or chest pain. bicalutamide may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you experience anything unusual or bothersome.

name: bictegravir, emtricitabine, and tenofovir alafenamide
instructions: important warning: bictegravir, emtricitabine, and tenofovir alafenamide should not be used to treat hepatitis b virus (hbv) infection. if you have or think you may have hbv, your doctor may test you before starting treatment. if you have hbv and take this medicine, your condition may suddenly worsen when you stop. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor will examine you and order lab tests before, during, and for several months after you stop this medicine. talk to your doctor about the risks of taking bictegravir, emtricitabine, and tenofovir alafenamide. why is this medication prescribed? the combination of bictegravir, emtricitabine, and tenofovir alafenamide is used to treat human immunodeficiency virus (hiv) infection. bictegravir is an integrase strand transfer inhibitor (insti). emtricitabine and tenofovir alafenamide are nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (nrtis). together they lower the amount of hiv in the body. although this medicine will not cure hiv, it may reduce your chance of developing acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (aids) and hiv-related illnesses. taking these medications and making other lifestyle changes may also reduce the risk of transmitting hiv to others. how should this medicine be used? this medicine comes as a tablet to take by mouth once daily, with or without food. take it at the same time every day and exactly as directed. do not take more or less, or take it more often than prescribed. if you cannot swallow the tablet whole, you may cut it in half and swallow both halves separately, as long as both halves are taken within 10 minutes of each other. continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor. stopping, even briefly, or skipping doses can allow the virus to become resistant and harder to treat. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking this medicine, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to it, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your allergy symptoms. some medications should not be taken with this medicine. review all medications you take or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist before starting, and consult them before starting, stopping, or changing any medicine while on treatment. nonprescription or herbal products that may interact include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as ibuprofen (advil) and naproxen (aleve, naprosyn), and st. john’s wort. tell your doctor and pharmacist if you take these, and do not start them while on this medicine without discussing it with your healthcare provider. if you take an antacid containing calcium, magnesium, or aluminum (such as maalox, mylanta, tums) or sucralfate (carafate), take this medicine on an empty stomach at least 2 hours before the antacid or sucralfate. if you take an iron or calcium supplement, take it at the same time as this medicine with food. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had hbv or any infection that does not go away or that comes and goes (such as tuberculosis or cytomegalovirus) or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; if you become pregnant while taking this medicine, call your doctor. tell your doctor if you are breastfeeding or plan to breastfeed, as hiv and some of the medicine may pass into breast milk; discuss the risks. be aware that as your immune system strengthens on hiv treatment, it may begin to fight infections already in your body and cause new or worsening symptoms; contact your doctor if this happens. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? this medicine may cause side effects. common side effects include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and headache. if these are severe or do not go away, tell your doctor. if you experience any of the following, or any symptoms mentioned in the important warning, call your doctor immediately or seek emergency medical care: decreased urination; swelling of the feet or ankles; weakness, tiredness, or muscle pain; shortness of breath or fast breathing; stomach pain with nausea and vomiting; cold or blue hands and feet; fast or abnormal heartbeat; dizziness or lightheadedness; dark yellow or brown urine; light-colored bowel movements; yellowing of the skin or eyes; loss of appetite; nausea; abdominal pain. this medicine may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: bimatoprost ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bimatoprost ophthalmic is prescribed to treat glaucoma, a condition in which increased pressure in the eye can gradually lead to vision loss, and ocular hypertension, a condition that causes elevated pressure in the eye. bimatoprost belongs to a class of medications called prostaglandin analogs and lowers eye pressure by increasing the outflow of the eye’s natural fluid. how should this medicine be used? bimatoprost ophthalmic is a liquid solution used as eye drops. instill it in the affected eye(s) once daily in the evening, using it at about the same time each day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully and use exactly as directed. do not use more or less than prescribed, and do not use it more often than prescribed by your doctor. bimatoprost controls glaucoma and ocular hypertension but does not cure them; continue using it even if you feel well, and do not stop without talking to your doctor. to instill the eye drops: wash your hands with soap and water; check the dropper tip to ensure it is not chipped or cracked; avoid touching the dropper tip to your eye or any surface; tilt your head back and pull down the lower eyelid to create a pocket; hold the dropper close to the eye without touching it and brace your hand against your face; while looking up, gently squeeze one drop into the pocket; release the lower lid; close your eye for 2 to 3 minutes and tip your head downward as if looking at the floor, avoiding blinking or squeezing; place a finger on the tear duct and apply gentle pressure; wipe away any excess liquid; if more than one drop is needed in the same eye, wait at least 5 minutes before instilling the next drop; replace and tighten the cap without rinsing the tip; wash your hands. this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using bimatoprost, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bimatoprost or any other medications, and tell them about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take. if you use another topical eye medication, instill it at least 5 minutes before or after bimatoprost. tell your doctor if you have eye inflammation or swelling, if you are missing a lens or have a torn lens, and if you have or have ever had liver or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while using bimatoprost, call your doctor. you should know that the solution contains benzalkonium chloride, which can be absorbed by soft contact lenses; remove lenses before using the drops and reinsert them 15 minutes later. if you injure your eye, develop an eye infection, or have eye surgery while using bimatoprost, ask your doctor whether you should continue using the same eye drop bottle. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? instill the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not instill a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? bimatoprost may cause side effects. call your doctor if any of the following are severe or do not go away: itchy eyes, dry eyes, burning eyes, eye pain or irritation, increased tearing, headaches. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor immediately if you experience sensitivity to light, pink eye (conjunctivitis), or redness or swelling of the eyelid. bimatoprost may gradually change the color of your iris to brown and darken the skin around the eye; it may also cause your eyelashes to grow longer, thicker, and darker. these changes usually occur slowly and may be permanent. if you use bimatoprost in only one eye, differences between your eyes may develop; call your doctor if you notice these changes. bimatoprost eye drops may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you experience any unusual problems.

name: bimatoprost topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? topical bimatoprost is used to treat hypotrichosis (too few eyelashes) by promoting the growth of longer, thicker, and darker eyelashes. it is a prostaglandin analog that works by increasing the number of growing eyelash hairs and the duration of their growth. how should this medicine be used? topical bimatoprost is a liquid solution applied to the skin of the upper eyelids, usually once daily in the evening, at the same time each day. use exactly as directed; do not use more often than once daily, and do not use more or less than prescribed. it may take at least 4 weeks to notice benefits and up to 16 weeks for the full effect; continue regular use to maintain results. eyelash enhancement occurs only while using the medication; stopping will gradually return lashes to their original appearance over weeks to months. do not apply to the lower eyelids or to broken or irritated upper eyelid skin. because hair can grow where the solution repeatedly touches, blot any excess outside the upper eyelid margin with a tissue. if the solution gets into your eye during application, it is not expected to cause harm; do not rinse your eye. the product includes sterile single-use applicators; do not reuse them and do not use cotton swabs or other applicators. application steps: wash hands and face thoroughly and remove makeup; avoid letting the bottle tip or applicator touch your fingers or any surface; hold the applicator horizontally and place 1 drop on the area just before the tip (not on the tip); immediately draw the applicator along the skin of the upper eyelid margin at the base of the lashes from the inner to the outer corner like liquid eyeliner so the skin is lightly moistened without runoff; blot excess with a tissue; discard the applicator; repeat for the other eye with a new sterile applicator. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bimatoprost or any medication. bimatoprost is also available as an eye drop (lumigan) for high eye pressure; using both the topical solution and the eyedrops together may increase exposure—ask your doctor if you use or plan to use both. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and herbal products you take, especially other eye-pressure medicines such as latanoprost (xalatan) and travoprost (travatan), as doses may need adjustment or extra monitoring may be needed. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had eye swelling, a missing or torn lens, or eye pressure problems, and call your doctor if you develop an eye injury or infection or have eye surgery during treatment. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, talk to your doctor; if you become pregnant while using this medicine, call your doctor. this product contains benzalkonium chloride, which can be absorbed by soft contact lenses; remove lenses before application and reinsert them after 15 minutes. differences between eyes in eyelash length, thickness, fullness, color, number, or direction of growth may occur and usually resolve after stopping treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and apply the next dose at the regular time; do not apply extra solution to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include itchy eyes, dry eyes, eye irritation, and redness of the eyes or eyelids; contact your doctor if these are severe or do not go away. serious side effects can include blurred or decreased vision—call your doctor right away if this occurs. the medication may darken the skin of the eyelids (which may be reversible after stopping) and may permanently increase brown eye color; call your doctor if you notice these changes. topical bimatoprost may cause other side effects; talk to your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: bimekizumab-bkzx injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bimekizumab-bkzx injection is used in certain adults to treat moderate to severe plaque psoriasis, a skin condition with red, scaly patches; psoriatic arthritis, which causes joint pain, swelling, and skin scales; ankylosing spondylitis, in which the immune system attacks the spine and nearby joints; and active non-radiographic axial spondyloarthritis, which causes spinal joint pain and signs of inflammation without x-ray changes. bimekizumab-bkzx is a monoclonal antibody that works by blocking a natural substance involved in the symptoms of psoriasis. how should this medicine be used? bimekizumab-bkzx is supplied as a liquid solution in a prefilled syringe or prefilled autoinjector for subcutaneous (under the skin) injection. for plaque psoriasis, it is typically injected once every 4 weeks for the first 5 doses, then once every 8 weeks thereafter. for psoriatic arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, or non-radiographic axial spondyloarthritis, it is usually injected once every 4 weeks. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. do not use more, less, or more often than prescribed. your first dose may be given in your doctor’s office; if you are an adult, you or a caregiver may give injections at home after proper training. have your healthcare professional show you how to prepare and inject the dose. use each syringe or autoinjector only once and inject the entire contents. dispose of used devices in a puncture-resistant sharps container and ask your pharmacist how to discard the container when full. before injecting, remove the prefilled device from the refrigerator, place it on a flat surface with the needle cap on, and let it warm to room temperature for 30–45 minutes. do not heat the medication in a microwave, hot water, or sunlight, and do not shake it. inspect the solution before use: check the expiration date and make sure the liquid is clear to slightly yellow without visible particles. do not use if cracked, broken, expired, frozen, cloudy, or particulate. inject into the front of the thighs or abdomen (stomach), avoiding the navel and the 2 inches (5 cm) around it; if a caregiver gives the dose, the back of the upper arm may also be used. rotate injection sites and do not inject into areas that are tender, bruised, red, hard, scarred, have stretch marks, or are affected by psoriasis. if two syringes are needed for a single dose, use a different site for each injection. you will receive a medication guide and instructions for use at the start of treatment and with each refill; read them carefully and ask questions if anything is unclear. this medicine helps control symptoms but does not cure your condition; continue using it even if you feel well and do not stop without consulting your doctor. what special precautions should i follow? before using bimekizumab-bkzx, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bimekizumab-bkzx, any other medications, or any ingredients in the injection; ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had depression, thoughts of self-harm or suicide, liver problems, or inflammatory bowel disease (ibd) such as crohn’s disease or ulcerative colitis. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while using this medicine. inform your doctor if you recently received any vaccines and ask whether you need any vaccines before starting therapy; do not receive any vaccinations during treatment without consulting your doctor. adults should be up to date on age-appropriate vaccines before starting bimekizumab-bkzx. you should know that bimekizumab-bkzx injection has been associated with suicidal thoughts and behaviors; call your doctor right away if you have new or worsening depression or anxiety, thoughts about suicide, dying, or harming yourself, mood or behavior changes, acting on dangerous impulses, or any suicide attempt. this medicine may lower your ability to fight infections and can increase the risk of serious or life-threatening infections. tell your doctor if you get infections often or think you currently have an infection, including minor, recurrent (such as cold sores), or chronic infections. during or shortly after treatment, call your doctor immediately if you develop signs of infection such as fever, chills, sweats, muscle aches, shortness of breath, warm, red, or painful skin or sores, diarrhea, stomach pain, frequent, urgent, or painful urination, or any other concerning symptoms; your doctor may delay treatment if you have an active infection. this medicine increases the risk of tuberculosis (tb), especially if you already have latent tb. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had tb, have lived in or traveled to areas where tb is common, or have been in close contact with someone with tb. your doctor will test for tb before treatment and, if needed, treat latent tb before you start. call your doctor immediately if you have tb symptoms now or during treatment, such as cough, coughing up blood or mucus, weakness or fatigue, weight loss, loss of appetite, chills, fever, or night sweats. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? inject the missed dose as soon as you remember, then return to your regular dosing schedule. what side effects can this medication cause? bimekizumab-bkzx injection can cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: headache; cold sores (sores around the mouth or lips); small red skin bumps; feeling tired; yeast or fungal infections of the mouth or throat (white patches in or around the mouth, painful or difficult swallowing), skin, nails, feet (scaly, itchy skin or nail thickening), or genitals (white discharge, itching); pain, redness, or swelling at the injection site; stuffy or runny nose, sneezing, or sore throat; stomach pain; diarrhea; acne. some side effects may be serious. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have signs of liver problems such as right-sided lower abdominal pain, fatigue, loss of appetite, nausea and vomiting, itching, dark urine, pale stools, or yellowing of the skin or eyes. bimekizumab-bkzx may cause flare-ups of inflammatory bowel disease (ulcerative colitis or crohn’s disease); if you develop new or worsening abdominal pain or diarrhea, contact your doctor, who may stop treatment. bimekizumab-bkzx may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you experience anything unusual.

name: binimetinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? binimetinib is used with encorafenib (braftovi) to treat certain types of melanoma, a skin cancer that has spread to other parts of the body or cannot be removed by surgery. it is also used with encorafenib to treat certain types of non-small cell lung cancer that have spread to other parts of the body. binimetinib is a kinase inhibitor that blocks an abnormal protein that signals cancer cells to multiply, helping to stop or slow their growth and spread. how should this medicine be used? binimetinib comes as an oral tablet. take it with or without food twice daily, about 12 hours apart, at the same times each day. follow the directions on your prescription label, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. take binimetinib exactly as directed; do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed. if you vomit after taking a dose, do not take another dose; continue your regular dosing schedule. your doctor may decrease your dose or temporarily or permanently stop treatment if you experience side effects. be sure to tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment with binimetinib. ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer information for the patient. this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking binimetinib, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to binimetinib, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, and nutritional supplements you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had heart or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. you will have to take a pregnancy test before starting treatment. use effective birth control during your treatment with binimetinib and for 30 days after your final dose. if you become pregnant while taking binimetinib, call your doctor immediately. binimetinib may harm the fetus. tell your doctor if you are breastfeeding. do not breastfeed while you are taking binimetinib and for 3 days after your final dose. you should know that binimetinib has been associated with new cancers. your doctor will monitor you carefully during treatment. discuss any concerns you have about the risks and benefits of treatment with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. however, if it is within 6 hours of the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? binimetinib may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: fatigue, nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain, constipation, dizziness. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following, call your doctor immediately: vision changes or eye pain, swelling, or redness; fever, sore throat, chills, cough, or other signs of infection; yellow eyes or skin, dark urine, loss of appetite, fatigue, or pain or discomfort in the right upper stomach area; unusual weakness, muscle pain, or dark red or brown urine; unusual bleeding or bruising; black, tarry, or bloody stools; coughing up blood; shortness of breath or cough; sudden onset of difficulty breathing; chest pain; swelling of the feet, ankles, or lower legs; leg pain, warmth, or swelling; fast, pounding heartbeat; shortness of breath; swelling of ankles and feet; or dizziness. binimetinib may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: birch triterpenes topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? birch triterpenes topical is used to treat wounds associated with certain types of epidermolysis bullosa, a condition that causes blistering of the skin, in adults and children 6 months of age or older. it belongs to a class of medications called botanicals. how it helps epidermolysis bullosa is not well understood. how should this medicine be used? birch triterpenes comes as a gel for application to the skin. apply it with every dressing change until the wound heals. wash your hands before and after application or wear gloves. apply a generous layer about 1 mm thick directly to the wound and cover with a clean bandage, or apply the gel to the bandage and then place it on the wound. each tube is for single use only; open immediately before use, apply the gel, and discard the tube and any leftover amount. if a wound becomes infected during treatment, stop using the gel until the infection has resolved. avoid contact with the eyes and mucous membranes (for example, mouth, vagina, or anus). if contact occurs, rinse the area with water. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to birch triterpenes, any other medications, or any ingredients in the gel. ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using birch triterpenes, call your doctor. if you are having any surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are using birch triterpenes. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next application, skip the missed dose and resume your regular dressing-change schedule. do not apply extra gel to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? birch triterpenes may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: itching or pain at the application site. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you experience hives, rash, redness, or intense itching. birch triterpenes may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: bisacodyl
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bisacodyl is used short term to treat constipation and to empty the bowels before surgery or certain medical procedures. it is a stimulant laxative that increases intestinal activity to produce a bowel movement. how should this medicine be used? bisacodyl comes as an oral tablet and is usually taken in the evening before a bowel movement is desired. it typically produces a bowel movement within 6 to 12 hours. do not take bisacodyl more than once daily or for more than 1 week without talking to your doctor. follow the package or prescription directions carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take exactly as directed. frequent or prolonged use may lead to laxative dependence and reduced normal bowel function. if you do not have a regular bowel movement after taking bisacodyl, do not take more and contact your doctor. swallow tablets whole with a glass of water; do not split, chew, or crush. do not take bisacodyl within 1 hour after eating or drinking dairy products. what special precautions should i follow? before taking bisacodyl, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bisacodyl, any other medications, or any ingredients in the product; check the label or ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. if you take antacids, wait at least 1 hour before taking bisacodyl. tell your doctor if you have stomach pain, nausea, vomiting, or a sudden change in bowel habits lasting more than 2 weeks. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking bisacodyl, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow a regular diet and exercise program to support normal bowel function. eat a high-fiber diet and drink plenty of fluids—about eight glasses of liquid daily—as recommended by your doctor. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medication is usually taken as needed. if your doctor has told you to take bisacodyl regularly, take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? bisacodyl may cause side effects. call your doctor if these symptoms are severe or do not go away: stomach cramps, faintness, stomach discomfort. some side effects can be serious; stop taking bisacodyl and call your doctor immediately if you experience rectal bleeding. bisacodyl may cause other side effects; talk to your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: bisacodyl rectal
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? rectal bisacodyl is used short term to relieve constipation. it is also used to empty the bowels before surgery and certain medical procedures. bisacodyl belongs to a class of stimulant laxatives and works by increasing intestinal activity to trigger a bowel movement. how should this medicine be used? rectal bisacodyl is available as a suppository and as an enema for rectal use. use it at the time you want to produce a bowel movement. suppositories usually produce a bowel movement within 15 to 60 minutes; enemas usually work within 5 to 20 minutes. do not use bisacodyl more than once daily or for longer than 1 week unless your doctor tells you to. follow the package directions or your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. use rectal bisacodyl exactly as directed. frequent or prolonged use can lead to dependence and decreased normal bowel function. if you do not have a bowel movement after using bisacodyl, do not use another dose; contact your doctor. if using a suppository: if the suppository is soft, firm it by holding under cold water or refrigerating for a few minutes before unwrapping. remove the wrapper. if instructed to use half, cut it lengthwise with a clean, sharp knife or blade. lie on your left side with your right knee drawn toward your chest. using a finger, insert the pointed end first into the rectum until it passes the rectal sphincter, about 1 inch (2.5 centimeters) in adults; if not past the sphincter, it may come out. hold it in place as long as possible. wash your hands thoroughly. if using an enema: shake the bottle well. remove the protective shield from the tip. lie on your left side with your right knee drawn up, or kneel and lean forward so your head and chest are comfortably supported. gently insert the tip into the rectum with the tip directed toward the navel. squeeze the bottle gently until nearly empty. remove the bottle. hold the enema contents in as long as possible, up to 10 minutes. wash your hands thoroughly. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using rectal bisacodyl, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bisacodyl, any other medications, or any ingredients in these products. check the label or ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have stomach pain, nausea, vomiting, a sudden change in bowel habits lasting more than 2 weeks, anal fissures, or hemorrhoids. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while using rectal bisacodyl, call your doctor. if you are 65 years or older, discuss the risks and benefits; older adults usually should not use rectal bisacodyl because other treatments may be safer or more effective. what special dietary instructions should i follow? maintain a regular diet and exercise program to support normal bowel function. eat a high-fiber diet and drink plenty of fluids, typically about eight glasses of liquid daily, as recommended by your doctor. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medication is generally used as needed. if your doctor has told you to use rectal bisacodyl on a regular schedule and you miss a dose, use it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? rectal bisacodyl may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: stomach cramps, faintness, stomach discomfort, burning in the rectum. some side effects can be serious. stop using bisacodyl and call your doctor immediately if you experience rectal bleeding. rectal bisacodyl may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: bismuth subsalicylate
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bismuth subsalicylate is used to relieve diarrhea, heartburn, and upset stomach in adults and in children 12 years of age and older. it belongs to a class of medicines called antidiarrheals. it works by reducing the movement of fluids and electrolytes into the intestines, easing intestinal inflammation, and may help eliminate organisms that can cause diarrhea. how should this medicine be used? bismuth subsalicylate is available as a liquid, tablet, or chewable tablet taken by mouth, with or without food. follow the package directions carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. take exactly as directed; do not take more, take less, or use it more often than recommended by the manufacturer or your doctor. swallow nonchewable tablets whole; do not crush or chew them. chew chewable tablets thoroughly. shake the liquid well before each dose to mix the medicine evenly. if your symptoms worsen or if diarrhea lasts longer than 48 hours, stop taking this medicine and contact your doctor. what special precautions should i follow? before using bismuth subsalicylate, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to aspirin or other salicylates such as choline salicylate, choline magnesium trisalicylate, diflunisal, magnesium salicylate, or salsalate, or to any other medicine. tell your doctor or pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. be sure to discuss use if you take anticoagulants blood thinners such as warfarin coumadin, a daily aspirin, or medicines for diabetes, arthritis, or gout. if you are taking tetracycline antibiotics such as demeclocycline, doxycycline, minocycline, or tetracycline, take them at least 1 hour before or 3 hours after bismuth subsalicylate. ask your doctor before use if you have ever had an ulcer, a bleeding problem, stools that are bloody or black, or kidney disease, or if you have a fever or mucus in your stool. if you will be giving bismuth subsalicylate to a child or teenager, tell the doctor for the child if the child has any of the following before receiving the medicine: vomiting, listlessness, drowsiness, confusion, aggression, seizures, yellowing of the skin or eyes, weakness, or flu-like symptoms. also tell the doctor if the child is not drinking normally, has had excessive vomiting or diarrhea, or appears dehydrated. ask your doctor before using this medicine if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? drink plenty of water and other fluids to replace losses from diarrhea. unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is usually taken as needed. if your doctor has told you to take it on a regular schedule and you miss a dose, take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take two doses at one time to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? bismuth subsalicylate may cause side effects. some can be serious. if you notice ringing or buzzing in your ears, stop taking this medicine and call your doctor right away. bismuth subsalicylate may cause other side effects.

name: bismuth, metronidazole, and tetracycline
instructions: important warning: metronidazole has caused cancer in laboratory animals. because this combination can be important in healing ulcers, discuss the risks and benefits of using a metronidazole-containing regimen for your ulcers with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? this combination (bismuth, metronidazole, and tetracycline) is used with other ulcer medicines to treat duodenal ulcers. it is an antibacterial regimen that works by stopping the growth and spread of helicobacter pylori, the bacteria commonly associated with ulcers. treating the infection helps prevent ulcers from returning. how should this medicine be used? helidac consists of two chewable bismuth tablets, one metronidazole tablet, and one tetracycline capsule taken together by mouth; pylera is supplied as capsules taken by mouth. it is usually taken four times daily, with meals and at bedtime, for 10 days (pylera) or 14 days (helidac). follow your prescription label exactly. do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. for helidac, chew and swallow the bismuth tablets; swallow the metronidazole tablet and the tetracycline capsule whole with a full glass of water (8 ounces/240 ml). for pylera, swallow the capsules whole with a full glass of water (8 ounces/240 ml). take the bedtime dose with plenty of fluid to reduce irritation of the throat and stomach. take doses at least 1 hour before or 2 hours after consuming calcium-containing foods or drinks (such as dairy products and calcium-fortified foods/juices). continue the full course even if you feel better; stopping early or skipping doses can lead to incomplete treatment and antibiotic resistance. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine: this medication may sometimes be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for details. what special precautions should i follow? before taking this medicine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bismuth; metronidazole (flagyl); aspirin or salicylates; doxycycline (doryx, vibramycin); minocycline (dynacin, minocin); tetracycline (sumycin); tinidazole (tindamax); any other medications; or any ingredients in this combination. provide a full list of your medications. do not take this combination with disulfiram (antabuse) and tell your doctor if you have taken disulfiram within the past 2 weeks. some medicines should not be used with this regimen; others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. discuss all prescription, nonprescription, and herbal products you use or plan to use with your doctor and pharmacist before starting, stopping, or changing any medication. nonprescription products that may interact include: cimetidine (tagamet); aspirin or aspirin-containing products; omeprazole (prilosec); and antacids containing aluminum, calcium, magnesium, iron, zinc, or sodium bicarbonate. do not start these while on therapy without consulting your healthcare provider. if you take antacids with aluminum, calcium, magnesium, zinc supplements, or sodium bicarbonate, take them 1 to 2 hours before or 1 to 2 hours after this medication. if you take iron supplements, take them 3 hours before or 2 hours after this medication. tell your doctor if you have kidney or liver disease (you may be advised not to take this medicine), if you currently have an infection, or if you have or have ever had blood disorders, crohn’s disease, or conditions affecting the central nervous system. if you are pregnant, planning to become pregnant, or breastfeeding, inform your doctor. if pregnancy occurs while taking this medication, call your doctor. tetracycline can cause birth defects and may harm nursing infants. this medication can reduce the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives (pills, patches, rings, implants, injections, intrauterine devices); use an additional nonhormonal birth control method during treatment and as advised by your doctor. do not drink alcohol or use products containing alcohol or propylene glycol while taking this medication and for at least 3 days after finishing; combining these with metronidazole can cause nausea, vomiting, stomach cramps, headache, sweating, and flushing. avoid unnecessary or prolonged sun exposure, tanning beds, and sun lamps; wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen, as your skin may become more sensitive to sunlight. tetracycline taken during pregnancy or by babies or children up to age 8 can cause permanent tooth discoloration, abnormal tooth development, and may affect bone growth; tetracycline should not be used in children under 8 years of age. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take doses at least 1 hour before or 2 hours after eating or drinking calcium-containing foods and beverages (for example, dairy products and calcium-fortified juices/foods). avoid alcohol and propylene glycol during treatment and for at least 3 days after the last dose. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule until the medication is finished. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. if you miss more than four doses, call your doctor. what side effects can this medication cause? this combination may cause side effects. temporary darkening of the tongue and stool can occur and is harmless. call your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: weakness, diarrhea, constipation, dark urine, loss of appetite, stomach pain, heartburn, metallic taste, dry or sore mouth. stop the medication and call your doctor immediately if you have: numbness, pain, burning, or tingling in hands or feet; headache; blurred vision; seizures; dizziness; difficulty speaking; coordination problems; confusion or agitation; ringing in the ears; vaginal itching and/or discharge; fever, cough, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection; bloody or black, tarry stools; nausea; vomiting; hives; rash; or itching.

name: bisoprolol
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bisoprolol is used alone or with other medications to treat high blood pressure. it is a beta blocker that works by relaxing blood vessels and slowing the heart rate to lower blood pressure. treating high blood pressure helps prevent damage to the brain, heart, blood vessels, kidneys, and other organs, which can lead to heart disease, heart attack, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, and loss of vision. along with medication, lifestyle changes such as eating a low-fat, low-salt diet, maintaining a healthy weight, exercising at least 30 minutes most days, not smoking, and using alcohol in moderation help control blood pressure. bisoprolol is also sometimes used to treat heart failure; ask your doctor about the potential risks and benefits for your condition. how should this medicine be used? bisoprolol comes as an oral tablet, usually taken once a day. take it at the same time each day to help you remember. follow your prescription label exactly. do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. your doctor will likely start with a low dose and increase it gradually. tell your doctor how you feel and report any symptoms during this time. bisoprolol controls high blood pressure but does not cure it, and it may take a few weeks to feel the full benefit. continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop taking bisoprolol without talking to your doctor. stopping suddenly may cause serious heart problems such as chest pain (angina), heart attack, or irregular heartbeat. if your doctor advises stopping, the dose will usually be reduced gradually over about 1 week, and you may be told to limit physical activity during this period. what special precautions should i follow? before taking bisoprolol, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bisoprolol, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have a slow or irregular heart rate or certain heart problems; you may be advised not to take bisoprolol. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had asthma or other lung diseases; heart, liver, or kidney disease; diabetes; circulation problems; hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid); or a history of severe allergic reactions to foods or other substances. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking bisoprolol, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you take bisoprolol. bisoprolol may make you drowsy; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. bisoprolol can increase the risk of low blood sugar (hypoglycemia) and can mask the warning signs and symptoms of low blood sugar. let your doctor know if you cannot eat or drink normally or are vomiting while taking bisoprolol. learn the symptoms of low blood sugar and what to do if they occur. if you have allergic reactions to different substances, your reactions may be worse while taking bisoprolol, and usual doses of injectable epinephrine may be less effective. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? bisoprolol may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: headache; dizziness; excessive tiredness; weakness; nausea or vomiting; diarrhea; muscle or joint pain; runny nose, cough, or sore throat; dry mouth; difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following, call your doctor immediately: shortness of breath; swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; unusual weight gain; fainting; chest pain. bisoprolol may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: bleomycin
instructions: important warning: bleomycin can cause severe or life-threatening lung problems, especially at higher doses and in older adults. the risk may be higher if you have a history of lung disease. call your doctor right away if you develop difficulty breathing, shortness of breath, wheezing, fever, or chills. some people receiving bleomycin for lymphomas have had a severe allergic reaction that can occur immediately or several hours after the first or second dose. seek medical help and contact your doctor immediately if you experience difficulty breathing, fever, chills, fainting, dizziness, blurred vision, upset stomach, or confusion. you will receive each dose in a medical facility, and your doctor will monitor you during and after treatment. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory; your doctor will order tests to check how your body responds to bleomycin. why is this medication prescribed? bleomycin injection is used alone or with other medicines to treat head and neck cancers (including cancer of the mouth, lip, cheek, tongue, palate, throat, tonsils, and sinuses) and cancers of the penis, testicles, cervix, and vulva (the outer part of the vagina). it is also used with other medicines to treat hodgkin lymphoma (hodgkin disease) and non-hodgkin lymphoma, and to treat malignant pleural effusions (cancer-related fluid buildup around the lungs). bleomycin is an anti-cancer antibiotic that slows or stops the growth of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? bleomycin comes as a powder that is mixed with liquid and injected by a healthcare professional into a vein (intravenous), into a muscle (intramuscular), or under the skin (subcutaneous) in a clinic or hospital. it is usually given once or twice weekly. when used for pleural effusions, the mixed solution is placed into the chest cavity through a chest tube inserted through the skin. other uses for this medicine bleomycin may also be used to treat kaposi sarcoma related to acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (aids). talk with your doctor about the risks and benefits of using this medication for your condition. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving bleomycin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bleomycin or any ingredients in the injection; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and nutritional supplements you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney or lung disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. do not become pregnant while receiving bleomycin; if you become pregnant, call your doctor because bleomycin may harm the fetus. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, inform the doctor or dentist that you are receiving bleomycin. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment to receive bleomycin, call your doctor as soon as possible to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? bleomycin may cause side effects. common effects include skin redness, blistering, tenderness, or thickening; darkened skin color; rash; hair loss; sores on the mouth or tongue; vomiting; loss of appetite; and weight loss. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the symptoms listed in the important warning section, or any of the following, call your doctor immediately: sudden numbness or weakness of the face, arm, or leg on one side of the body; sudden confusion or trouble speaking or understanding; sudden dizziness, loss of balance or coordination; sudden severe headache; chest pain; or decreased urination. bleomycin may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: blinatumomab injection
instructions: important warning: blinatumomab injection must be given only under the supervision of a doctor experienced with chemotherapy. it can cause a serious, potentially life-threatening reaction called cytokine release syndrome (crs) that may occur during the infusion and after it finishes. you will receive medicines before each dose to help prevent allergic reactions. seek immediate medical help during or after an infusion if you develop fever, fatigue, weakness, dizziness, headache, nausea, vomiting, chills, rash, facial swelling, wheezing, or difficulty breathing. if a severe reaction occurs, your doctor will stop the infusion and treat your symptoms. blinatumomab may also cause serious, life-threatening effects on the central nervous system. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had seizures, confusion, loss of balance, trouble speaking, or if you have down syndrome. get emergency help right away if you experience seizures, uncontrollable shaking, difficulty speaking, slurred speech, loss of consciousness, trouble falling or staying asleep, headache, confusion, or loss of balance. discuss the risks and benefits of blinatumomab with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? blinatumomab is used to treat certain types of acute lymphocytic leukemia (all) that have not improved, have returned after treatment with other medications, or have improved but minimal residual disease remains. it is also used for certain types of all that are in remission. blinatumomab is a bispecific t-cell engager antibody that works by slowing or stopping the growth of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? blinatumomab comes as a powder that is mixed and infused continuously into a vein by a health care professional in a hospital or clinic, and sometimes at home using an infusion pump. it is usually given continuously for 4 weeks followed by a 2 to 8 week break; this is one cycle, and cycles may be repeated as needed based on your response. you may be hospitalized for the first 3 to 9 days of your first cycle and the first 2 days of your second cycle so you can be monitored closely for side effects. for later cycles, your doctor will tell you if hospitalization is needed. your doctor may delay treatment, change your dose, or stop treatment if you develop certain side effects. tell your health care team right away how you are feeling during treatment. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving blinatumomab, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to blinatumomab, benzyl alcohol, any other medications, or any ingredients in the injection. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have a current infection or recurrent infections; if you have ever had radiation therapy to the brain; if you have received chemotherapy; or if you have or have ever had liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; you will need a pregnancy test before starting. do not become pregnant during treatment and for at least 2 days after your final dose; discuss effective birth control with your doctor. if you become pregnant, call your doctor; blinatumomab may harm the fetus. do not breastfeed during treatment and for at least 2 days after your final dose. blinatumomab may cause drowsiness or affect your ability to think clearly; do not drive or operate machinery while receiving it. do not receive any vaccinations without talking to your doctor, and tell your doctor if you received a vaccine within the past 2 weeks. after your final dose, your doctor will tell you when it is safe to receive vaccines. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? blinatumomab is given by continuous infusion. if you miss an infusion appointment or bag change, or if your pump stops or becomes disconnected, call your doctor or nurse immediately. do not try to restart the infusion or make up a missed dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause?
