blinatumomab may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: diarrhea, mouth sores, weight gain, back, joint, or muscle pain, swelling of the arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, or pain at the infusion site. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or get emergency medical help if you have any of the symptoms listed in the important warning or special precautions sections, or any of the following: chest pain; numbness or tingling in the arms, legs, hands, or feet; shortness of breath; persistent abdominal pain that may spread to the back with or without nausea and vomiting; fever, sore throat, cough, or other signs of infection; or unusual bleeding or bruising. blinatumomab may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: boceprevir
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? boceprevir is prescribed together with ribavirin (copegus, rebetol) and peginterferon alfa (pegasys) to treat chronic hepatitis c, a long-term viral infection that harms the liver, in people who have not been treated before or whose condition did not improve with ribavirin and peginterferon alfa alone. boceprevir is a protease inhibitor that lowers the amount of hepatitis c virus (hcv) in the body, but it may not prevent the spread of hepatitis c to others. how should this medicine be used? boceprevir is an oral capsule taken with a meal or light snack three times a day, about every 7 to 9 hours, at the same times daily. follow your prescription label carefully; do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. you will first take peginterferon alfa and ribavirin for 4 weeks, then add boceprevir and take all three medicines for 12 to 44 weeks. after that, you will stop boceprevir and may continue peginterferon alfa and ribavirin for additional weeks. the total duration depends on your condition, how you respond, and whether you develop significant side effects. continue all medicines as directed and do not stop any without consulting your doctor, even if you feel well. you will receive a medication guide when you start treatment and with each refill; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking boceprevir, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to boceprevir, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the capsules; consult the medication guide for a full ingredient list. tell your doctor if you take any of the following medicines or herbal products: alfuzosin (uroxatral); ergot medicines such as dihydroergotamine (d.h.e. 45, migranal), ergonovine, ergotamine (ergomar, in cafergot, in migergot), or methylergonovine; cisapride (propulsid; not available in the u.s.); drospirenone in certain oral contraceptives (beyaz, gianvi, ocella, safyral, yasmin, yaz, zarah); lovastatin (altoprev, mevacor); seizure medicines such as carbamazepine (carbatrol, equetro, tegretol), phenobarbital, or phenytoin (dilantin); oral midazolam; pimozide (orap); rifampin (rifadin, rimactane, in isonarif, in rifamate, in rifater); sildenafil used for lung disease (revatio only); simvastatin (simcor, in vytorin); tadalafil used for lung disease (adcirca only); st. john’s wort; or triazolam (halcion). your doctor will likely tell you not to take boceprevir with one or more of these. also tell your doctor and pharmacist about all other prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and supplements you use or plan to use, especially: alprazolam (niravam, xanax); anticoagulants such as warfarin (coumadin); antifungals such as itraconazole (sporanox), ketoconazole (nizoral), posaconazole (noxafil), and voriconazole (vfend); atorvastatin (lipitor, in caduet); bosentan (tracleer); budesonide (pulmicort, rhinocort, symbicort); buprenorphine (buprenex, butrans, subutex, suboxone); calcium channel blockers such as felodipine (plendil), nicardipine (cardene), and nifedipine (adalat, afeditab, procardia); clarithromycin (biaxin); colchicine (colcrys, in col-probenecid); cyclosporine (gengraf, neoral, sandimmune); desipramine (norpramin); dexamethasone; medicines for erectile dysfunction such as sildenafil (viagra), tadalafil (cialis), and vardenafil (levitra, staxyn); hiv medicines such as atazanavir with ritonavir, darunavir with ritonavir, efavirenz (sustiva, in atripla), lopinavir with ritonavir, and ritonavir (norvir, in kaletra); medicines for irregular heartbeat such as amiodarone (cordarone, pacerone), digoxin (lanoxin), flecainide (tambocor), propafenone (rythmol), and quinidine; methadone (dolophine, methadose); intravenous midazolam; rifabutin (mycobutin); salmeterol (serevent, in advair); sirolimus (rapamune); tacrolimus (prograf); and trazodone. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you closely for side effects. tell your doctor if you have ever had an organ transplant; and if you have or have had anemia (low red blood cell count), hiv, aids, any immune system disorder, hepatitis b, or any liver disease other than hepatitis c. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, tell the surgeon or dentist you are taking boceprevir. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or could become pregnant—or if you are male and your partner is or could become pregnant—know that boceprevir is used with ribavirin, which can seriously harm an unborn baby. use two forms of birth control during treatment and for 6 months after your last dose; hormonal contraceptives may be less effective while taking these medicines. you or your partner must have monthly pregnancy tests during therapy and for 6 months afterward. if pregnancy occurs, call your doctor right away. tell your doctor if you are breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose with food as soon as you remember. if it is 2 hours or less before your next scheduled dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? boceprevir may cause side effects. common effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, changes in taste, loss of appetite, fatigue, trouble sleeping, irritability, hair loss, dry skin, and rash. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor immediately or seek emergency care if you have shortness of breath, dizziness, fainting, weakness, sore throat, fever, chills, or other signs of infection. boceprevir may cause other side effects; tell your doctor if you notice any unusual problems while taking it.

name: bortezomib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bortezomib is used to treat multiple myeloma, a cancer of the bone marrow, and mantle cell lymphoma, a fast-growing cancer of the immune system. it is a proteasome inhibitor that works by killing cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? bortezomib is a liquid given by injection into a vein (intravenous) or under the skin (subcutaneous) by a doctor or nurse in a medical office or clinic. your dosing schedule depends on your condition, the other medications you take, and how you respond. tell your doctor how you feel during treatment; your doctor may pause treatment or lower the dose if side effects occur. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving bortezomib, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bortezomib, mannitol, boron, any other medications, or any ingredients in the product; ask for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, and supplements you take or plan to take. your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you closely. st. john’s wort may interact with bortezomib; do not start it while receiving bortezomib. do not start any new medication while on bortezomib without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had heart failure, a heart attack, irregular heartbeat or other heart problems; herpes infections (cold sores, shingles, or genital sores); diabetes; high cholesterol; low or high blood pressure; peripheral neuropathy (numbness, pain, tingling, burning, weakness, or loss of feeling or reflexes in the hands or feet); or kidney or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. do not become pregnant during treatment and for 7 months after your final dose; you may need a pregnancy test before starting treatment. use effective birth control during treatment and for 7 months after your final dose. if your partner could become pregnant, use birth control during treatment and for 4 months after your final dose. if you or your partner becomes pregnant during treatment or within 7 months after the final dose, call your doctor immediately; bortezomib may harm the fetus. tell your doctor if you are breastfeeding or plan to breastfeed; do not breastfeed during treatment and for 2 months after your final dose. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the provider that you are receiving bortezomib. this medicine may make you drowsy; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. it may also cause dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting when you stand up too quickly, especially if you have fainted in the past, are dehydrated, or take blood pressure medicines. to reduce this risk, rise slowly and sit with your feet on the floor for a few minutes before standing. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor about eating grapefruit or drinking grapefruit juice while using this medication. drink plenty of fluids each day during treatment, especially if you vomit or have diarrhea. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment to receive a dose, call your doctor right away. what side effects can this medication cause? bortezomib may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: unusual tiredness or weakness; nausea; vomiting; diarrhea; constipation; loss of appetite; stomach pain; headache; pain, redness, bruising, bleeding, or hardness at the injection site; trouble falling or staying asleep. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have: weakness in the arms or legs; changes in sense of touch; pain, burning, numbness, or tingling in the hands, arms, legs, or feet; shortness of breath, fast heartbeat, headache, dizziness, pale skin, confusion, or tiredness; hives, rash, itching, hoarseness, difficulty swallowing or breathing, or swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, or hands; fever, sore throat, chills, cough, or other signs of infection; unusual bruising or bleeding, black and tarry stools, red blood in stools, bloody vomit, or vomit that looks like coffee grounds; fainting, blurred vision, dizziness, nausea, or muscle cramps; chest pressure or pain, fast heartbeat, swelling of the ankles or feet, or shortness of breath; cough, shortness of breath, wheezing, or difficulty breathing; headache, confusion, seizures, tiredness, or vision loss or changes; fever, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, unusual tiredness, dizziness, shortness of breath, bruising, confusion, seizures, decreased urination, blood in the urine, or muscle or joint pain; fever, headache, chills, nausea, pain, itching or tingling followed by a rash in the same area with itchy or painful blisters; nausea, extreme tiredness, unusual bleeding or bruising, lack of energy, loss of appetite, pain in the upper right part of the stomach, yellowing of the skin or eyes, or flu-like symptoms. bortezomib may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication. what other information should i know? keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory; your doctor will order tests to check your body’s response to treatment. keep a written list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, minerals, and supplements you take and bring it to each doctor visit or if you are admitted to the hospital; carry the list in case of emergencies. brand names velcade (bortezomib injection).

name: bosentan
instructions: important warning: for male and female patients: bosentan can damage the liver. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver disease. your doctor will check your liver with a blood test before you start bosentan and every month during treatment. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. liver injury can occur before you have symptoms; regular blood tests are the only way to detect it early. call your doctor right away if you develop nausea, vomiting, fever, stomach pain, yellowing of the skin or eyes, or extreme tiredness. your doctor may lower your dose or temporarily or permanently stop bosentan if you have side effects or abnormal test results. for female patients: do not take bosentan if you are pregnant or planning to become pregnant; it can harm an unborn baby. if you can become pregnant, you will need a pregnancy test before starting, every month during treatment, and for 1 month after your last dose. you must use reliable birth control while taking bosentan and for 1 month after you stop. hormonal contraceptives (pills, patches, rings, shots, implants, and intrauterine devices) may not work well with bosentan and should not be used as your only method; most patients will need two forms of contraception. call your doctor right away if you have unprotected sex, think your birth control failed, miss a period, or think you may be pregnant; do not wait for your next visit. if you are a parent or guardian of a female patient who has not reached puberty, check regularly for signs of puberty (breast buds, pubic hair) and report any changes to her doctor. because of the risks of liver injury and birth defects, bosentan is available only through the tracleer risk evaluation and mitigation strategy (tracleer rems) program. you and your doctor must be enrolled and follow program requirements, including monthly liver function tests and pregnancy testing. bosentan is dispensed only by pharmacies registered with tracleer rems. ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions about filling your prescription. you will receive a medication guide when you start bosentan and with each refill; read it every time and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. talk to your doctor about the risks of taking bosentan. why is this medication prescribed? bosentan is used to treat pulmonary arterial hypertension (pah)—high blood pressure in the vessels that carry blood to the lungs—in adults and in children 3 years of age and older. it may improve exercise ability and slow the worsening of pah symptoms. bosentan is an endothelin receptor antagonist; it works by blocking endothelin, a natural substance that narrows blood vessels and restricts normal blood flow in pah. how should this medicine be used? bosentan comes as tablets and as dispersible tablets (to dissolve in liquid) taken by mouth. take it twice daily, morning and evening, with or without food, at the same times each day. follow your prescription label carefully and take exactly as directed. do not take more or less, or take it more often, than prescribed. for dispersible tablets, dissolve the tablet in a small amount of liquid right before taking. if instructed to take a half dispersible tablet, break it along the scored line; take the half as directed and return the other half to the opened blister; use the remaining half within 7 days. do not break dispersible tablets into quarters. your doctor will usually start you on a low dose and increase it after 4 weeks. bosentan controls pah symptoms but does not cure the condition; it may take 1 to 2 months or longer to feel the full benefit. continue taking bosentan even if you feel well. do not stop suddenly; your doctor may lower the dose gradually. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking bosentan, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bosentan, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets or dispersible tablets; check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. some medicines should not be used with bosentan; review all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist before starting bosentan and before starting, stopping, or changing any medicine while on bosentan. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had heart failure or anemia. if you are breastfeeding or plan to breastfeed, you will likely be advised not to breastfeed while taking bosentan. this medication may reduce sperm count and fertility in males; discuss risks with your doctor. if you have phenylketonuria (pku), note that the dispersible tablets contain aspartame (a source of phenylalanine). what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor about drinking grapefruit juice while taking this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? bosentan may cause side effects. common effects include headache, flushing, runny nose, sore throat and other cold-like symptoms, and joint pain. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or get emergency help if you have hives; rash; itching; difficulty breathing or swallowing; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes; hoarseness; fever; swollen lymph nodes; unusual tiredness; swelling of the feet, ankles, or lower legs; sudden weight gain; more trouble breathing than usual; new or worsening shortness of breath; new or worsening cough (with or without blood); chest pain; fast, pounding, or irregular heartbeat; fainting; dizziness; pale skin; shortness of breath; or weakness. bosentan may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: bosutinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bosutinib is used to treat a specific type of chronic myeloid leukemia (cml), a cancer of the white blood cells, in adults who are newly diagnosed or who no longer benefit from other cml treatments or cannot take them due to side effects. it is a kinase inhibitor that blocks an abnormal protein signaling cancer cells to multiply, helping slow or stop their growth and spread. how should this medicine be used? bosutinib is an oral tablet taken once daily with food, at the same time each day. follow your prescription label exactly. do not take more or less or more often than prescribed. swallow tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush. do not handle broken or crushed tablets with bare hands. your doctor may pause treatment or change your dose based on your response and side effects. continue taking bosutinib even if you feel well, and do not stop without talking to your doctor. ask your doctor or pharmacist for the manufacturer’s patient information. this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your healthcare professional for details. what special precautions should i follow? before taking bosutinib, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bosutinib or any tablet ingredients. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use. be sure to mention: antifungals such as ketoconazole and itraconazole (sporanox); aprepitant (emend); hiv medicines such as indinavir (crixivan), nelfinavir (viracept), ritonavir (norvir), and saquinavir (invirase); proton pump inhibitors that reduce stomach acid such as esomeprazole (nexium), lansoprazole (prevacid), omeprazole (prilosec), pantoprazole (protonix), and rabeprazole (aciphex); diltiazem (cardizem, cartia, tiazac); erythromycin (e.e.s., e-mycin, erythrocin); nefazodone; rifabutin (mycobutin); and rifampin (rifadin, rimactane; also in rifamate and rifater). many medicines can interact with bosutinib, so tell your doctor about everything you take. if you use antacids (such as aluminum hydroxide/magnesium hydroxide [maalox], calcium carbonate [tums], or calcium carbonate with magnesium [rolaids]) or h2 blockers/reducers of stomach acid (such as cimetidine [tagamet], famotidine [pepcid], or ranitidine [zantac]), take them 2 hours before or 2 hours after bosutinib. tell your doctor about any herbal products, especially st. john’s wort. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had high blood pressure, diabetes, or kidney, liver, or heart disease. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, you will need a pregnancy test before starting, and you should not become pregnant while taking bosutinib. use effective birth control during treatment and for 2 weeks after your final dose. if you become pregnant, call your doctor; bosutinib may harm the fetus. do not breastfeed during treatment and for 2 weeks after your last dose. this medication may decrease fertility in both men and women; discuss risks with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not eat grapefruit, drink grapefruit juice, or take supplements containing grapefruit extract while using this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose with food as soon as you remember. if more than 12 hours have passed since your last dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? bosutinib may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: headache, loss of appetite, tiredness or weakness, changes in taste, or ringing in the ears. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, sudden stomach (abdominal) pain, unexplained bleeding or bruising, blood in urine or stool, changes in how often you urinate, increases or decreases in urine amount, dizziness, fever, sore throat, chills or other signs of infection, shortness of breath and cough, chest pain, swelling of the face, hands, ankles, feet, or lower legs, sudden weight gain, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark or tea-colored urine, hives, rash, itching, or difficulty breathing or swallowing. bosutinib may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: bremelanotide injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bremelanotide injection is used to treat premenopausal women with hypoactive sexual desire disorder (hsdd)—a low sexual desire that causes distress or relationship difficulties—who have not previously had problems with low sexual desire and whose low desire is not due to a medical or mental health condition, relationship issues, or medication or other drug use. it should not be used to treat hsdd in women who have gone through menopause, in men, or to enhance sexual performance. bremelanotide is a melanocortin receptor agonist; it works by activating certain natural substances in the brain that influence mood and thinking. how should this medicine be used? bremelanotide injection comes as a liquid in a prefilled automatic injection device for subcutaneous (under the skin) use. it is usually injected as needed, at least 45 minutes before anticipated sexual activity. you and your doctor will decide the best timing based on how well it works for you and any side effects. use exactly as directed: do not use more or less, and do not use it more often than prescribed. do not inject more than one dose in 24 hours and do not use more than 8 doses in a month. before your first use, read the manufacturer’s instructions carefully and have your doctor or pharmacist show you how to inject it. use a new prefilled device for each dose; do not reuse or share devices. dispose of used devices in a puncture‑resistant container kept out of the reach of children; ask your pharmacist or doctor how to dispose of the container. inject into the abdomen (stomach area) or front of the thigh, avoiding the 2‑inch area around the belly button. do not inject into skin that is irritated, sore, bruised, red, hard, or scarred, and do not inject through clothing. rotate injection sites with each dose. check the solution before use; it should be clear and free of particles. do not use it if it is cloudy, discolored, or contains particles. if your symptoms do not improve after 8 weeks, call your doctor. what special precautions should i follow? before using bremelanotide, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bremelanotide, any other medications, or any ingredients in the injection; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. be sure to mention oral antibiotics, indomethacin (indocin, tivorbex), and oral naltrexone (in contrave; in embeda). your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. do not use bremelanotide if you have uncontrolled high blood pressure or heart disease. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had high blood pressure, any heart problems, or kidney or liver disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor; use effective birth control while using bremelanotide and call your doctor if you become pregnant. be aware that bremelanotide may cause darkening of the skin on areas such as the face, gums, and breasts; this is more likely in people with darker skin color and in those who used it for eight consecutive days. skin darkening may not resolve after stopping treatment; report any skin changes to your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medication is used as needed and is not taken on a regular schedule. if you planned to use it and forgot, use it when you remember as long as it has been at least 24 hours since your last dose; do not take more than one dose in 24 hours or more than 8 doses in a month. do not take extra doses to make up for a missed planned dose. what side effects can this medication cause? bremelanotide injection may cause side effects. common effects include nausea (most common after the first dose and usually lasting about 2 hours), vomiting, headache, flushing, nasal stuffiness, cough, tiredness, dizziness, and pain, redness, bruising, itching, numbness, or tingling at the injection site. some side effects can be serious: increases in blood pressure and decreases in heart rate may occur and can last up to 12 hours after a dose. if you experience these or any symptoms listed in the special precautions section, call your doctor. bremelanotide may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: brexanolone injection
instructions: important warning: brexanolone injection can cause profound sleepiness or a sudden loss of consciousness during treatment. you will receive this medication only in a medical facility under observation. your healthcare team will check you for signs of sleepiness at least every 2 hours while you are awake. tell your provider right away if you feel extremely tired, cannot stay awake during your usual waking hours, or feel like you might faint. you must have a caregiver or family member help with your children during and after the infusion. do not drive or operate machinery until you are fully alert after receiving brexanolone. because of these risks, brexanolone (zulresso) is available only through a special restricted distribution program, the zulresso risk evaluation and mitigation strategy (rems) program; you, your doctor, and your pharmacy must be enrolled before you can receive it. keep all appointments with your doctor. you will receive a medication guide when you begin treatment and each time you receive brexanolone; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. you can also visit the fda or the manufacturer’s website to obtain the medication guide. why is this medication prescribed? brexanolone injection is used to treat postpartum depression (ppd) in adults. it is a neurosteroid antidepressant that works by changing the activity of certain natural substances in the brain. how should this medicine be used? brexanolone is given as an intravenous infusion in a medical facility. it is typically administered one time over 60 hours (2.5 days). your doctor may temporarily pause, adjust, or stop your infusion depending on your response and any side effects. brexanolone may be habit-forming; discuss your treatment goals with your healthcare provider while receiving this medication. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving brexanolone, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to brexanolone or any of its ingredients; check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. be sure to mention: antidepressants; benzodiazepines such as alprazolam (xanax), diazepam (diastat, valium), midazolam, or triazolam (halcion); medicines for mental illness; pain medicines such as opioids; medicines for seizures; sedatives, sleeping pills, and tranquilizers. your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, think you may be pregnant, or are breastfeeding. do not drink alcohol while receiving brexanolone; alcohol can worsen its side effects. know that your mental health may change unexpectedly when you receive brexanolone or other antidepressants, even if you are over 24. you may become suicidal, especially at the beginning of treatment and when your dose changes. you, your family, or your caregiver should call your doctor right away if you experience any of the following: new or worsening depression; thoughts of harming or killing yourself; planning or trying to do so; extreme worry; agitation; panic attacks; trouble falling or staying asleep; aggressive behavior; irritability; acting without thinking; severe restlessness; or frenzied, abnormal excitement. make sure your family or caregiver knows which symptoms may be serious and how to get help if you cannot. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given as a scheduled infusion in a medical facility. if you miss or need to change an appointment, or if the infusion is interrupted, contact your healthcare provider right away for instructions. what side effects can this medication cause? brexanolone may cause side effects. common side effects include dry mouth, heartburn, mouth or throat pain, flushing or hot flashes, dizziness or a spinning sensation, and fatigue. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the symptoms listed in the important warning section or have a racing heartbeat, call your doctor immediately or seek emergency medical attention. brexanolone may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: brexpiprazole
instructions: important warning: important warning for older adults with dementia: studies have shown that older adults with dementia—a brain disorder that affects memory, clear thinking, communication, daily activities, and may cause mood and personality changes—who take antipsychotic medications such as brexpiprazole have an increased risk of death during treatment. they may also have a higher risk of stroke or ministroke. brexpiprazole is not approved by the food and drug administration (fda) to treat dementia-related psychosis without agitation. talk to the prescribing doctor if you, a family member, or someone you care for has dementia and is taking brexpiprazole. important warning for people who have depression: in clinical studies, a small number of children, teenagers, and young adults up to 24 years old who took medicines for depression became suicidal (thinking about, planning, or attempting to harm or kill themselves). children, teenagers, and young adults who take antidepressants for depression or other mental illnesses may be more likely to become suicidal than those who do not. experts are not sure how great this risk is or how it should influence decisions about using antidepressants in children or teenagers. children younger than 18 years should not usually take brexpiprazole to treat depression, but a doctor may decide it is the best option in some cases. your mental health may change in unexpected ways when you take brexpiprazole or other antidepressants, even if you are older than 24. you may become suicidal, especially at the start of treatment and whenever the dose is increased or decreased. you, your family, or your caregiver should call your doctor right away if you have any of the following: new or worsening depression; new or worsening anxiety; thoughts of harming or killing yourself, plans, or attempts; extreme worry; agitation; panic attacks; trouble falling or staying asleep; aggressive behavior; irritability; acting without thinking; severe restlessness; or mania (a frenzied, abnormally excited mood). make sure your family or caregiver knows which symptoms may be serious so they can call the doctor if you cannot seek help yourself. talk to your doctor about the risks of taking brexpiprazole. why is this medication prescribed? brexpiprazole is used to treat the symptoms of schizophrenia in adults and children 13 years and older. it is also used with an antidepressant to treat depression when symptoms are not controlled by the antidepressant alone. brexpiprazole is also used to treat agitation in people with dementia due to alzheimer’s disease. it is an atypical antipsychotic that works by changing the activity of certain natural substances in the brain. how should this medicine be used? brexpiprazole comes as a tablet to take by mouth. it is usually taken once daily, with or without food, at about the same time each day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. take brexpiprazole exactly as directed—do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. your doctor may start you on a low dose and increase it based on how well it works for you and what side effects you experience. brexpiprazole may control your symptoms but will not cure your condition. continue to take it even if you feel well. do not stop taking it without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking brexpiprazole, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to brexpiprazole, any other medications, or any ingredient in the tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take while using brexpiprazole. some products, including st. john’s wort, may interact with brexpiprazole. do not start, stop, or change the dose of any medication or supplement while taking brexpiprazole without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you or anyone in your family has or has ever had diabetes. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had a stroke or tia (ministroke); chest pain; heart disease, heart attack, irregular heartbeat, or heart failure; trouble keeping your balance; any condition that makes swallowing difficult; high or low blood pressure; seizures; high cholesterol or triglycerides; low white blood cell counts; or kidney or liver disease. also tell your doctor if you currently have severe vomiting or diarrhea or signs of dehydration, or if these develop during treatment. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, especially in the last months of pregnancy, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking brexpiprazole, call your doctor. taking brexpiprazole during the last months of pregnancy may cause problems in newborns after delivery. brexpiprazole may make you drowsy and affect clear thinking and reaction time. do not drive, operate hazardous machinery, and take precautions to avoid falls until you know how it affects you. you may experience increases in blood sugar (hyperglycemia) while taking this medicine, even if you do not already have diabetes. people with schizophrenia are at higher risk of diabetes, and brexpiprazole or similar medicines may increase this risk. call your doctor right away if you have extreme thirst, frequent urination, extreme hunger, blurred vision, or weakness. high blood sugar can lead to ketoacidosis, a serious condition that can be life-threatening if not treated early. symptoms include dry mouth, nausea and vomiting, shortness of breath, fruity-smelling breath, and decreased consciousness. brexpiprazole may cause dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting when you get up too quickly, especially when starting treatment. to help avoid this problem, rise slowly and sit with your feet on the floor for a few minutes before standing. some people taking medicines like brexpiprazole have developed gambling problems or other intense urges or behaviors that were unusual for them, such as increased sexual urges or behaviors, excessive shopping, or binge eating. call your doctor if you have strong urges to shop, eat, have sex, or gamble, or if you cannot control your behavior. tell family members about this risk so they can call the doctor if you do not realize these urges or behaviors have become a problem. brexpiprazole may make it harder for your body to cool down in very hot conditions; use caution if you plan to exercise or be exposed to extreme heat. brexpiprazole may cause weight gain; your weight should be checked periodically while you are taking this medication. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? brexpiprazole may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: headache; constipation; diarrhea; heartburn; increased appetite; tiredness; uncontrollable shaking of a part of the body; dizziness, feeling unsteady, or trouble keeping your balance. some side effects can be serious. if you have any of the following, or those listed in the important warnings and special precautions sections, call your doctor immediately: rash; hives; itching; swelling of the eyes, face, mouth, lips, tongue, throat, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; difficulty breathing or swallowing; seizures; shortness of breath; sore throat, cough, fever, chills, painful or difficult urination, or other signs of infection; fever, sweating, confusion, fast or irregular heartbeat, and severe muscle stiffness; unusual movements of your face or body that you cannot control; falling; tightening of the neck muscles or throat. brexpiprazole may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: brexucabtagene autoleucel injection
instructions: notice: special alert: the food and drug administration has received reports of t-cell malignancies, including chimeric antigen receptor positive lymphoma, in patients treated with bcma- or cd19-directed autologous car t cell therapies such as brexucabtagene autoleucel. at this time the benefits still outweigh the risks, but your doctor will monitor you during and after treatment. discuss any concerns about your therapy with your doctor. important warning: brexucabtagene autoleucel can cause a serious or life-threatening reaction called cytokine release syndrome. you will be monitored closely during your infusion and for at least 4 weeks afterward. tell your doctor if you have an inflammatory disorder or any current or suspected infection. you will receive medicines 30 to 60 minutes before your infusion to help prevent reactions. seek medical help immediately if you develop fever, chills, fast or irregular heartbeat, muscle pain, shaking, diarrhea, tiredness, weakness, trouble breathing, shortness of breath, cough, confusion, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, or lightheadedness during or after your infusion. brexucabtagene autoleucel may also cause severe or life-threatening nervous system reactions that can occur after treatment. tell your doctor if you have a history of seizures, stroke, or memory problems. seek immediate care if you develop headache, dizziness, trouble falling or staying asleep, restlessness, confusion, anxiety, uncontrollable shaking, loss of consciousness, agitation, seizures, loss of balance, or trouble speaking. due to the risks of cytokine release syndrome and neurologic toxicity, this medicine is available only through a special restricted program and can be given only at certified centers. ask your doctor if you have questions about this program. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor will order tests to check how you are responding to treatment. you will receive a medication guide from the manufacturer when you start treatment and each time you receive this medication; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. why is this medication prescribed? brexucabtagene autoleucel is used in adults to treat mantle cell lymphoma that has returned or is unresponsive to other treatments. it is also used in adults to treat certain types of acute lymphoblastic leukemia, also called acute lymphatic leukemia, that have returned or are unresponsive to other treatments. it is an autologous cellular immunotherapy prepared from your own blood cells and works by directing your immune system to attack cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? brexucabtagene autoleucel is a liquid suspension given by intravenous infusion by a healthcare professional in a hospital or infusion center, usually as a single dose over up to 30 minutes. before your infusion, you will receive other chemotherapy medicines to prepare your body. before that, your white blood cells will be collected at a cell collection center using leukapheresis, a process that removes white blood cells from your body. because this medicine is made from your own cells, it must be given only to you. it is very important not to miss or be late to your cell collection and infusion appointments. if you are treated for mantle cell lymphoma, you will be checked daily for at least 7 days after your dose; if treated for acute lymphoblastic leukemia, you will be checked daily for at least 14 days. plan to stay near the treating center for at least 4 weeks after your infusion so your healthcare team can monitor your recovery and side effects. ask your doctor how to prepare for leukapheresis and what to expect during and after the procedure. other uses for this medicine: this medicine may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving brexucabtagene autoleucel, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to this medicine, to any other medicines, or to any of the ingredients; ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or recently had an infection, and if you have or ever had hepatitis b, seizures, a stroke, memory problems, lung or breathing problems, or kidney, heart, or liver disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor. you will need a pregnancy test before starting treatment. if you become pregnant during treatment, call your doctor right away. know that this medicine may cause drowsiness, confusion, weakness, dizziness, seizures, and coordination problems. do not drive or operate machinery for at least 8 weeks after your dose. do not donate blood, organs, tissues, or cells after receiving this therapy. ask your doctor whether you need any vaccinations. do not receive vaccinations for at least 6 weeks before starting chemotherapy, during treatment, and until your doctor says your immune system has recovered. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss the appointment to collect your cells, contact your doctor and the collection center right away. if you miss the appointment to receive your infusion, contact your doctor right away. what side effects can this medication cause? brexucabtagene autoleucel may cause side effects. call your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: constipation, stomach pain, loss of appetite, mouth pain, trouble swallowing, or rash. some side effects can be serious. if you develop any of the following, or any symptoms listed in the important warning section, call your doctor immediately: pale skin or shortness of breath, fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection, unusual bruising or bleeding, decreased urination, or numbness, pain, tingling, or burning in the hands or feet. this treatment may increase the risk of developing certain cancers; discuss these risks with your doctor. other side effects may occur; ask your healthcare provider for medical advice about side effects.

name: brigatinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? brigatinib is used to treat a certain type of non small cell lung cancer nsclc that has spread to other parts of the body. it is a kinase inhibitor that blocks an abnormal protein that signals cancer cells to multiply, helping to slow or stop their growth and spread. how should this medicine be used? brigatinib comes as a tablet to take by mouth once daily, with or without food. take it at the same time each day. follow your prescription label exactly. do not take more or less than prescribed or take it more often. swallow the tablets whole; do not chew or crush them. if you vomit after taking a dose, do not take another dose; continue your regular dosing schedule. your doctor may start you on a lower dose and increase it after 7 days of treatment. depending on side effects, your doctor may temporarily or permanently stop treatment or adjust the dose of brigatinib or other medicines you are taking. tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. do not stop taking brigatinib without talking to your doctor. ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer information for patients. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking brigatinib, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to brigatinib, any other medications, or any ingredients in brigatinib tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. be sure to mention any of the following: antifungals such as itraconazole onmel, sporanox, tolsura and ketoconazole; buprenorphine and naloxone suboxone; carbamazepine equetro, tegretol, teril, others; clarithromycin; cyclosporine gengraf, neoral, sandimmune; diltiazem cardizem, cartia, diltzac, others; efavirenz sustiva, in atripla, symfi; erythromycin e.e.s., eryc, erythrocin; indinavir crixivan; nefazodone; nelfinavir viracept; nevirapine viramune; phenobarbital; phenytoin dilantin, phenytek; pioglitazone actos, in actoplus met, duetact, oseni; rifabutin mycobutin; rifampin rifadin, rimactane, in rifamate, in rifater; ritonavir norvir, in kaletra, technivie, viekira; sirolimus rapamune; tacrolimus astagraf, envarsus, prograf; or verapamil calan, verelan, in tarka. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. many other medications may also interact with brigatinib, so be sure to tell your doctor and pharmacist about all the medicines you take, even those not listed here. tell your doctor what herbal products you use, especially st. johns wort. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had high blood pressure, a slow heartbeat, diabetes or other blood sugar problems, or kidney or liver disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or plan to father a child, know that brigatinib may interfere with hormonal birth control pills, patches, rings, implants, or injections; do not use these as your only method of birth control during treatment. use a non hormonal method such as a barrier method condom or diaphragm. if you are female, use non hormonal birth control during treatment and for 4 months after your final dose. if you are male, you and your female partner should use birth control during treatment and for 3 months after your final dose. brigatinib may harm the fetus. if you are breastfeeding, do not breastfeed during treatment and for up to 1 week after your final dose. you should know that brigatinib may decrease fertility in men; talk to your doctor about the risks. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid eating grapefruit and drinking grapefruit juice while taking brigatinib. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. if you miss taking brigatinib for 14 days or longer, talk to your doctor before restarting; you will probably need to restart at a lower dose. what side effects can this medication cause? brigatinib may cause side effects. call your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, constipation, tiredness, rash, headache, numbness, pain, tingling, or burning feeling in the feet or hands, back or joint pain, loss of appetite, difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help: shortness of breath or difficulty breathing, chest pain, cough with or without mucus, fever, headache, dizziness, lightheadedness, feeling faint, blurred or double vision, seeing flashes of light, light sensitivity, seeing floaters or small specks, extreme thirst, frequent urination, extreme hunger, blurred vision, weakness, upper stomach pain that may spread to the back or worsen with eating with weight loss or nausea, slow or irregular heartbeat, muscle pain, spasms, tenderness, or weakness. brigatinib may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: brimonidine ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ophthalmic brimonidine is used to lower pressure inside the eye in people with glaucoma (eye pressure high enough to damage the optic nerve and cause vision loss) or ocular hypertension (higher-than-normal eye pressure that is not high enough to cause vision loss). it is an alpha-adrenergic agonist that works by decreasing the amount of fluid in the eye. how should this medicine be used? ophthalmic brimonidine comes as an eye-drop solution. instill it in the affected eye(s) 3 times a day, spaced about 8 hours apart, at the same times each day. follow your prescription label carefully and use exactly as directed; do not use more or less, or more often, than prescribed. brimonidine helps control eye pressure but does not cure the condition; continue to use it even if you feel well and do not stop without talking to your doctor. to instill the drops: 1) wash your hands with soap and water. 2) check that the dropper tip is not chipped or cracked. 3) do not touch the tip to your eye or any surface. 4) tilt your head back and pull down the lower eyelid to form a pocket. 5) hold the dropper above the eye without touching it and brace your hand against your face. 6) while looking up, gently squeeze out one drop into the pocket. 7) release the lower eyelid. 8) close your eye for 2–3 minutes, tipping your head downward as if looking at the floor; avoid blinking or squeezing your eyelids. 9) place a finger on the inner corner of the eye (tear duct) and apply gentle pressure during this time. 10) wipe away excess liquid with a tissue. 11) if more than one drop is prescribed in the same eye, wait at least 5 minutes before instilling the next drop. 12) replace and tighten the cap; do not rinse or wipe the dropper tip. 13) wash your hands to remove any medication. what special precautions should i follow? before using brimonidine eye drops, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to brimonidine or any other medications, and tell them about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. if you use other topical eye medications, instill them 5 minutes before or 5 minutes after brimonidine. tell your doctor if you often feel dizzy when standing up, and if you have or have ever had depression; circulation problems (including raynaud’s disease, thromboangiitis obliterans, or reduced blood flow to the heart or brain); or heart, kidney, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; if you become pregnant while using brimonidine, call your doctor. do not breast-feed while using brimonidine eye drops. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the surgeon or dentist that you are using brimonidine eye drops. brimonidine may cause drowsiness and temporary blurred vision after use; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. ask your doctor about alcohol use; alcohol can worsen drowsiness. if you wear soft contact lenses, remove them before using the drops and wait at least 15 minutes before reinserting. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your normal diet. ask your doctor about alcohol and consider limiting or avoiding it because it can increase drowsiness caused by brimonidine. what should i do if i forget a dose? instill the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not instill a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include itchy, irritated, red, stinging, or burning eyes; dry eyes; watery or runny eyes; red or swollen eyelids; sensitivity to light; blurred vision; headache; drowsiness; difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep; dry mouth; runny nose or other cold symptoms; cough; sore throat; flu-like symptoms; facial pain or pressure; and heartburn. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you experience rash; difficulty breathing; seeing specks or flashes of light; blind spots; fainting; severe dizziness; or nausea.

name: brivaracetam
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? brivaracetam is used to treat partial-onset seizures (seizures that involve only one part of the brain). it belongs to a class of medications called anticonvulsants and works by decreasing abnormal electrical activity in the brain. how should this medicine be used? brivaracetam comes as a tablet and as an oral solution to take by mouth. take it with or without food twice daily. take brivaracetam at about the same times each day and exactly as directed. do not take more or less than prescribed or take it more often. swallow the tablets whole with liquid; do not split, chew, or crush them. if you are taking the liquid, do not use a household spoon to measure your dose; use the measuring spoon or cup provided with the medication or another device made for measuring medicine. your doctor may increase or decrease your dose based on your response and any side effects. be sure to tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. brivaracetam may be habit forming; do not take a larger dose, take it more often, or use it for longer than prescribed. brivaracetam helps control your condition but will not cure it. continue to take it even if you feel well. do not stop taking brivaracetam without talking to your doctor, even if you experience side effects such as unusual changes in behavior or mood. stopping suddenly may make your seizures worse; your doctor will probably reduce your dose gradually. you will receive a medication guide when you begin treatment and each time you refill your prescription; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have any questions. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking brivaracetam, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to brivaracetam, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe what symptoms you had. tell your doctor and pharmacist what prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you currently drink or have ever drunk large amounts of alcohol, have used street drugs, or have over-used prescription medications. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had depression, mood problems, suicidal thoughts or behavior, kidney disease treated with dialysis, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking brivaracetam, call your doctor. you should know that brivaracetam may make you dizzy or drowsy and may cause blurred vision or problems with coordination and balance. do not drive, operate machinery, or do activities requiring alertness or coordination until you know how this medication affects you. ask your doctor about the safe use of alcoholic beverages while you are taking brivaracetam; alcohol can worsen side effects. you should know that brivaracetam may cause suicidal thoughts or actions. call your doctor right away if you experience any of the following: panic attacks; agitation or restlessness; new or worsening irritability, anxiety, or depression; acting on dangerous impulses; difficulty falling or staying asleep; aggressive, angry, or violent behavior; mania (a frenzied, abnormally excited mood); talking or thinking about wanting to hurt yourself or end your life; or any other unusual changes in behavior or mood. make sure your family or caregiver knows which symptoms may be serious so they can call the doctor if you cannot seek treatment on your own. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember it. however, if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? brivaracetam may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: constipation; nausea; vomiting; extreme tiredness or lack of energy. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of these symptoms or those listed in the special precautions section, stop taking brivaracetam and call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment: swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes; difficulty swallowing or breathing; hoarseness; rash, hives, blistering or peeling skin, or sores in the mouth; hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that do not exist); delusions (having false beliefs, such as thoughts that people are trying to harm you). brivaracetam may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: brivaracetam injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? brivaracetam injection is used to treat partial-onset seizures (seizures that involve only one part of the brain) in people who cannot take oral medication. brivaracetam is an anticonvulsant that works by decreasing abnormal electrical activity in the brain. how should this medicine be used? brivaracetam injection is a liquid solution given intravenously into a vein over 2 to 15 minutes. it is administered twice a day for as long as you are unable to take brivaracetam tablets or the oral solution. your doctor may adjust your dose based on how well it works for you and any side effects you experience. tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. brivaracetam may be habit forming; do not use a larger dose, use it more often, or use it longer than prescribed. brivaracetam helps control your condition but will not cure it. continue to use brivaracetam even if you feel well. do not stop brivaracetam injection without talking to your doctor, even if you notice unusual changes in behavior or mood. stopping suddenly can worsen seizures; your doctor will likely decrease your dose gradually. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving brivaracetam injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to brivaracetam, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe the symptoms you had. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you closely for side effects. tell your doctor if you currently or have ever drunk large amounts of alcohol, used street drugs, or misused prescription medications, and if you have or have ever had depression, mood problems, suicidal thoughts or behavior, kidney disease treated with dialysis, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while receiving brivaracetam injection. brivaracetam may cause dizziness, drowsiness, blurred vision, and problems with coordination and balance; do not drive, operate machinery, or do activities requiring alertness or coordination until you know how this medication affects you. ask your doctor about the safe use of alcoholic beverages while receiving brivaracetam injection; alcohol can worsen its side effects. brivaracetam injection may cause suicidal thoughts or actions. call your doctor right away if you experience panic attacks; agitation or restlessness; new or worsening irritability, anxiety, or depression; acting on dangerous impulses; difficulty falling or staying asleep; aggressive, angry, or violent behavior; mania (a frenzied, abnormally excited mood); talking or thinking about wanting to hurt yourself or end your life; or any other unusual changes in behavior or mood. make sure your family or caregiver knows which symptoms may be serious so they can call the doctor if you are unable to seek help on your own. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? brivaracetam injection may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: constipation; nausea; vomiting; change in the ability to taste food; extreme tiredness or lack of energy; feeling drunk; pain near the injection site. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of these symptoms or those listed in the special precautions section, stop receiving brivaracetam injection and call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment: swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes; difficulty swallowing or breathing; hoarseness; rash; hives; blistering or peeling skin; sores in the mouth; hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that do not exist); or delusions (strange thoughts or beliefs with no basis in reality, such as thinking people are trying to harm you). brivaracetam injection may cause other side effects.

name: brodalumab injection
instructions: important warning: some people who used brodalumab injection had suicidal thoughts or behavior (thinking about harming or killing oneself, planning, or trying to do so). it is not known whether brodalumab injection causes these thoughts or behaviors. tell your doctor and pharmacist if you have a history of depression or suicidal thoughts. if you experience new or worsening depression or anxiety; thoughts of suicide, dying, or hurting yourself, or planning or trying to do so; changes in your behavior or mood; or acting on dangerous impulses, call your doctor immediately and get medical help. your healthcare provider will give you a patient wallet card listing symptoms; carry it at all times during treatment, show it to all of your healthcare providers, and seek help right away if symptoms occur. because of this risk, brodalumab injection is available only through the siliq rems program. you, your doctor, and your pharmacist must be enrolled before you can receive brodalumab injection. prescriptions must be written by a doctor registered with siliq rems and filled at a pharmacy registered with siliq rems. ask your doctor for more information about this program and how you will receive your medication. you will receive a medication guide when you begin treatment and each time you refill; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. talk to your doctor about the risks of using brodalumab injection. why is this medication prescribed? brodalumab injection is used to treat moderate to severe plaque psoriasis in adults whose psoriasis is too severe for topical medicines alone and who have not been treated successfully with other medications. brodalumab is a monoclonal antibody that works by blocking a natural substance in the body that causes psoriasis symptoms. how should this medicine be used? brodalumab injection is a liquid in a prefilled syringe for subcutaneous (under the skin) injection. it is usually injected once a week for the first 3 doses, then once every 2 weeks. follow the directions on your prescription label exactly. do not inject more or less, or more often, than prescribed. you may inject it yourself or have a caregiver do it after training. before first use, read the manufacturer instructions for use and have your healthcare provider show you how to inject. use each prefilled syringe once and inject all the solution; place used syringes in a puncture-resistant sharps container and ask your healthcare provider how to dispose of it. if using a refrigerated syringe, place it on a flat surface with the needle cap on and allow it to reach room temperature for about 30 minutes before use. do not warm it by microwave, hot water, or any other method. do not return a room-temperature syringe to the refrigerator. do not shake. inspect the solution; it should be clear and colorless to slightly yellow. do not use if cloudy, discolored, or if it contains flakes or particles. do not use a syringe that has been dropped on a hard surface. inject into the front of the thighs, the upper outer arms, or the abdomen (avoid the navel and the 2 inches [5 cm] around it). rotate injection sites with each dose. do not inject into skin that is tender, bruised, red, hard, thick, scaly, affected by psoriasis, or into scars or stretch marks. your healthcare provider may tell you to stop brodalumab if your psoriasis does not improve within 12 to 16 weeks. tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using brodalumab injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to brodalumab, any other medications, or any ingredients in the injection (see the medication guide). tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. mention especially cyclosporine (gengraf, neoral, sandimmune) and warfarin (coumadin, jantoven). your doctor may change doses or monitor you for side effects. many other medications may also interact, so provide a complete list. tell your doctor if you have crohn's disease; your doctor will probably tell you not to use brodalumab. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any medical condition; if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding (call your doctor if you become pregnant while using brodalumab injection); and if you are having surgery, including dental surgery. check with your doctor about vaccinations. it is important to have all age-appropriate vaccines before starting brodalumab. do not receive any vaccinations during treatment without talking to your doctor. you should know that brodalumab injection may decrease your ability to fight infections from bacteria, viruses, and fungi and increase the risk of serious or life-threatening infection. tell your doctor if you often get infections or if you have or think you may have any infection now. this includes minor infections such as open cuts or sores, infections that come and go such as herpes or cold sores, and chronic infections that do not go away. during or shortly after treatment, call your doctor immediately if you develop fever, sweats, or chills; muscle aches; cough; shortness of breath; sore throat or difficulty swallowing; warm, red, or painful skin or sores; diarrhea; stomach pain; frequent, urgent, or painful urination; or other signs of infection. you should know that using brodalumab injection increases the risk of tuberculosis (tb), especially if you are already infected without symptoms. tell your doctor if you have or ever had tb, have lived in a country where tb is common, or have been around someone with tb. your doctor will check you for tb before starting treatment and may treat you for tb if you have a history of tb or have active tb. call your doctor immediately if you have symptoms of tb now or during treatment, such as cough, coughing up blood or mucus, weakness or tiredness, weight loss, loss of appetite, chills, fever, or night sweats. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember and then continue your regular dosing schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? brodalumab injection may cause side effects. common side effects include headache; joint or muscle pain; nausea; and pain, redness, bruising, bleeding, or itching at the injection site. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the symptoms listed in the important warning or special precautions sections, or if you develop painful diarrhea, bloody stools, sudden or uncontrollable bowel movements, stomach pain or cramping, constipation, or weight loss, call your doctor immediately. brodalumab injection may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: brolucizumab-dbll injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? brolucizumab-dbll injection is used to treat wet age-related macular degeneration (amd), an eye disease that causes loss of central vision and can make reading, driving, and daily activities more difficult. it is also used to treat diabetic macular edema (dme), an eye complication of diabetes that can lead to vision loss. brolucizumab-dbll is a vascular endothelial growth factor a (vegf-a) antagonist that works by reducing abnormal blood vessel growth and leakage in the eye to help prevent vision loss. how should this medicine be used? brolucizumab-dbll comes as a liquid solution injected into the eye by a doctor. for wet amd, it is usually given once every 25 to 31 days for the first 3 doses, then once every 8 to 12 weeks. for dme, it is usually given once every 39 to 45 days for the first 5 doses, then once every 8 to 12 weeks. before the injection, your doctor will clean and numb your eye. you may feel pressure during the injection. your doctor will examine your eye after the injection before you leave. brolucizumab-dbll controls amd and dme but does not cure them; your doctor will monitor your response and advise how long to continue treatment. ask your doctor or pharmacist for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving brolucizumab-dbll injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to brolucizumab-dbll, any other medications, or any ingredients in the injection; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have an infection in or around the eye; you will likely be advised not to receive the injection until it resolves. tell your doctor about all your medical conditions. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, do not become pregnant during treatment and for 1 month after your final dose; if you become pregnant, call your doctor. do not breast-feed during treatment and for 1 month after your final dose. this injection may cause temporary vision problems after dosing; do not drive or operate machinery until your vision returns to normal. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment for your injection, call your doctor as soon as possible to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or seek emergency care if you experience eye pain, redness, or sensitivity to light; changes in vision; new floaters (small specks); bleeding in or around the eye; swelling of the eye or eyelid; or rash, hives, itching, or redness. brolucizumab-dbll may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: bromfenac ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bromfenac ophthalmic is used to reduce inflammation, redness, swelling, and pain after cataract surgery. it is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (nsaid) that works by blocking the release of natural substances that cause pain and swelling. how should this medicine be used? bromfenac ophthalmic is a liquid eye-drop solution. it is usually instilled in the affected eye(s) once or twice a day for 14 days after cataract surgery. depending on the brand prescribed, your doctor may also direct you to use it the day before and on the day of surgery. follow your prescription label exactly. do not use more, less, or more often than prescribed. to instill the drops: 1) wash your hands with soap and water. 2) check that the dropper tip is not chipped or cracked. 3) do not let the tip touch your eye or any surface. 4) tilt your head back and pull down the lower eyelid to form a pocket. 5) hold the dropper above the eye without touching it and brace your hand. 6) while looking up, gently squeeze one drop into the pocket. 7) release the lid, close your eye for 2–3 minutes, and tip your head downward; avoid blinking or squeezing. 8) apply gentle pressure with a finger to the tear duct. 9) wipe away excess liquid with a tissue. 10) replace and tighten the cap; do not wipe or rinse the tip. 11) wash your hands again. use one bottle per eye only; if both eyes are treated, use a separate bottle for each eye. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using bromfenac eye drops, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bromfenac, aspirin, other nsaids, sulfites, any other medications, or any ingredients in the drops; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. nonprescription nsaids such as aspirin, ibuprofen (advil, motrin, midol), and naproxen (aleve) may interact; do not start or continue these while using bromfenac without discussing with your healthcare provider. if you use another eye-drop medication, separate doses by at least 5 minutes. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had diabetes, asthma, rheumatoid arthritis, dry eye disease or any eye condition other than cataracts, a bleeding tendency, or recent eye surgery on the same eye. if you wear contact lenses, remove them before use and wait at least 10 minutes after instillation before reinserting. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, discuss with your doctor. bromfenac may slow healing after eye surgery; call your doctor if pain or swelling does not improve. what special dietary instructions should i follow?
