unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? instill the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include stinging or burning of the eyes, red or itchy eyes, a sensation that something is in the eye, and headache. serious side effects require stopping the drops and calling your doctor immediately: redness or swelling of the eyes, lips, tongue, or skin; rash, hives, or other skin changes; difficulty breathing or swallowing; bleeding within the eye; sensitivity to light; eye pain; or blurry, cloudy, or blocked areas of vision.

name: bromocriptine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bromocriptine (parlodel) is used to treat symptoms of hyperprolactinemia (high levels of the hormone prolactin), including absence of menstrual periods, nipple discharge, infertility (difficulty becoming pregnant), and hypogonadism (low levels of hormones needed for normal development and sexual function). it may be used for prolactin-producing tumors and can shrink these tumors. bromocriptine (parlodel) is also used alone or with other therapies to treat acromegaly (too much growth hormone) and parkinson’s disease (pd), a nervous system disorder that affects movement, muscle control, and balance. bromocriptine (cycloset) is used with diet and exercise, and sometimes with other medications, to control blood sugar in people with type 2 diabetes; it is not used for type 1 diabetes or diabetic ketoacidosis. bromocriptine is a dopamine receptor agonist: it lowers prolactin to treat hyperprolactinemia, reduces growth hormone in acromegaly, and stimulates nerves that control movement in pd; how it improves blood sugar in diabetes is not known. how should this medicine be used? bromocriptine (parlodel) comes as capsules and tablets to take by mouth; bromocriptine (cycloset) comes as a tablet to take by mouth. for hyperprolactinemia, parlodel is usually taken once daily with food; for acromegaly, once daily at bedtime with food; for parkinson’s disease, twice daily with food. cycloset is usually taken once daily with food within 2 hours of waking in the morning. take bromocriptine at the same times each day. follow your prescription label carefully; take exactly as directed and do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. your doctor will likely start with a low dose and increase it gradually, no more than once every 2 to 28 days, depending on your condition and response. bromocriptine helps control your condition but does not cure it, and the full benefit may take time. do not stop taking it without talking to your doctor. stopping suddenly may cause loss of interest or concern for usual activities, anxiety, depression, fatigue, insomnia, sweating, or pain; your doctor will taper your dose. if you take bromocriptine (cycloset) for diabetes, ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine bromocriptine should not be used to stop breast milk production in women who have had an abortion or stillbirth or who choose not to breast-feed; it may cause serious or life-threatening side effects in these situations. discuss the risks with your doctor. this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking bromocriptine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bromocriptine; ergot alkaloids such as cabergoline (dostinex), dihydroergotamine (d.h.e. 45, migranal), ergoloid mesylates (germinal, hydergine), ergonovine (ergotrate), ergotamine (bellergal-s, cafergot, ergomar, wigraine), methylergonovine (methergine), methysergide (sansert), or pergolide (permax); any other medications; or any ingredients in bromocriptine tablets or capsules. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have high blood pressure or migraines that cause fainting; you may be advised not to take bromocriptine. also tell your doctor if you recently gave birth, have ever fainted, or have or have ever had a heart attack; a slow, fast, or irregular heartbeat; mental illness; low blood pressure; ulcers; bleeding in the stomach or intestines; raynaud’s syndrome (fingers/toes becoming numb and cool in cold temperatures); heart, kidney, or liver disease; or any condition that prevents normal digestion of sugars, starches, or dairy. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. if you are taking parlodel for lack of menstrual periods and infertility due to hyperprolactinemia, use a nonhormonal birth control method until you have regular periods; then stop birth control. test for pregnancy every 4 weeks while you do not menstruate, and once periods resume, test if your period is 3 days late. if you do not wish to become pregnant, use nonhormonal contraception while taking bromocriptine. if you become pregnant during treatment, stop bromocriptine and call your doctor. do not breast-feed while taking bromocriptine. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking bromocriptine (cycloset). know that bromocriptine may cause drowsiness and sudden sleep; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. ask your doctor about alcohol use; alcohol can worsen side effects. some people taking medicines like bromocriptine have developed strong or unusual urges (such as gambling, increased sexual urges/behaviors, or excessive shopping). call your doctor if these occur, and tell family members about this risk so they can alert your doctor if needed. bromocriptine may cause dizziness, nausea, sweating, or fainting when you stand up quickly, especially when starting or increasing the dose. to reduce this, rise slowly and sit with your feet on the floor for a few minutes before standing. ask your doctor what to do if you become ill, develop an infection or fever, undergo unusual stress, or are injured; these can affect your blood sugar and the cycloset dose you may need. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor about eating grapefruit or drinking grapefruit juice while taking this medicine. follow all diet and exercise recommendations from your doctor or dietitian. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you take bromocriptine (parlodel), take the missed dose as soon as you remember; if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose. if you take bromocriptine (cycloset) once daily and miss your morning dose, wait until the next morning to take it. do not take a double dose. what side effects can this medication cause? this medication may affect your blood sugar; know the symptoms of low and high blood sugar and what to do if they occur. bromocriptine may cause side effects. common side effects include: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, stomach cramps, heartburn, loss of appetite, headache, weakness, tiredness, dizziness or lightheadedness, drowsiness, trouble sleeping, and depression. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor right away if you have: fainting; watery nasal discharge; numbness, tingling, or pain in the fingers (especially in cold weather); black, tarry stools; bloody vomit or vomit that looks like coffee grounds; swelling of the feet, ankles, or lower legs; seizures; severe headache; blurred or impaired vision; slow or difficult speech; weakness or numbness of an arm or leg; chest pain; pain in the arms, back, neck, or jaw; shortness of breath; confusion; or hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that do not exist). bromocriptine may cause other side effects.

name: budesonide
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? budesonide (entocort ec) is used to treat crohn’s disease—a condition in which the immune system attacks the lining of the digestive tract, causing pain, diarrhea, weight loss, and fever—in adults and in children 8 years of age and older. budesonide (tarpeyo) is used to lower protein in the urine in people with primary immunoglobulin a (iga) nephropathy, a kidney disease in which excess iga builds up in the kidneys and causes inflammation. budesonide (uceris) is used to treat ulcerative colitis, which causes swelling and sores in the lining of the colon and rectum. budesonide is a corticosteroid that works by reducing inflammation in the digestive tract or, in people with iga nephropathy, in the kidneys. how should this medicine be used? budesonide comes as capsules (entocort ec, tarpeyo) and as a tablet (uceris) taken by mouth. entocort ec and tarpeyo capsules are usually taken once daily in the morning; tarpeyo should be taken at least 1 hour before a meal. the uceris tablet is taken once daily in the morning with or without food. take budesonide exactly as prescribed; do not take more or less or more often than directed. swallow capsules whole; do not split, crush, or chew them. if you cannot swallow entocort ec capsules whole, you may open the capsule, sprinkle the contents on a tablespoon of applesauce, mix well, and swallow the mixture without chewing within 30 minutes of mixing, followed by a full glass of water. your doctor will tell you how long to take budesonide and will monitor your response. budesonide can help control symptoms but does not cure the condition. if your symptoms are controlled, your doctor may lower your dose of budesonide capsules. tell your doctor how you are feeling throughout treatment. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s medication guide or patient information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking budesonide, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to budesonide, to any other medicines, or to any ingredients in the budesonide capsules or tablet; ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor if you or a family member has diabetes (high blood sugar) or glaucoma, and if you have high blood pressure, osteoporosis (weak, fragile bones), stomach ulcers, cataracts, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you have a current infection, or if you have had tuberculosis (tb) or have been exposed to someone with tb. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, think you may be pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while taking budesonide, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you take budesonide. if you have never had chickenpox or measles and have not been vaccinated against them, avoid close contact with people who are sick, especially those with chickenpox or measles. if you are exposed to one of these infections or develop symptoms, call your doctor right away—you may need treatment to help protect you. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not eat grapefruit or drink grapefruit juice while taking this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at the same time to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? budesonide may cause side effects. common side effects can include headache, dizziness, runny nose, sneezing, cough, nausea, indigestion, abdominal pain, dry or itchy skin, gas, vomiting, fatigue, back pain, joint aches, muscle aches, spasms or cramps, trouble sleeping, swelling of the face or extremities, acne, weight gain, mood changes, and increased facial hair. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor immediately if you have rash, swelling of the throat, trouble breathing, fever, cough, shortness of breath, severe abdominal pain, diarrhea, persistent nausea or vomiting, changes in vision, swelling of the face, a fatty pad or hump between your shoulders, easy bruising, or stretch marks on the skin. budesonide may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems or if your symptoms worsen.

name: budesonide and formoterol oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? the combination of budesonide and formoterol is used to prevent and control asthma symptoms (such as wheezing, shortness of breath, cough, and chest tightness) in adults and in children 6 years of age and older. it is also used in adults to treat chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (copd), including chronic bronchitis and emphysema. budesonide is a corticosteroid that reduces airway inflammation, and formoterol is a long-acting beta agonist (laba) that relaxes and opens the airways to improve breathing. how should this medicine be used? this medicine is an aerosol inhaled by mouth using an inhaler. the usual dose is 2 puffs twice daily, morning and evening, about 12 hours apart. use it at the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly; do not use more or less, or more often, than prescribed. ask your doctor how to use your other asthma or copd medicines while on this treatment. if you regularly used a short-acting beta agonist (such as albuterol: proair, proventil, ventolin), your doctor may tell you to stop using it on a schedule but to keep it for sudden symptoms. do not change or stop any medications without your doctor’s advice. do not use this medicine to treat sudden asthma or copd attacks; your doctor will prescribe a fast-acting rescue inhaler for that. seek medical help if your breathing worsens, you need your rescue inhaler more often, or it does not relieve symptoms. this medicine controls symptoms but does not cure asthma or copd; continue using it even when you feel well. if a child uses the inhaler, ensure they are trained and observed for correct technique. read the patient instructions that come with the inhaler and have your healthcare professional demonstrate proper use; practice until you are confident. after each dose, rinse your mouth with water and spit it out (do not swallow). stop using and replace the inhaler when the dose counter reaches zero. what special precautions should i follow? before use, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to budesonide (e.g., ortikos, pulmicort, rhinocort, tarpeyo), formoterol (e.g., perforomist; also in bevespi, duaklir pressair, dulera), any other medications, or any ingredients in the inhaler. provide a list of all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and herbal products you use; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for interactions. tell your doctor if you or family members have osteoporosis; or if you have or have had heart disease, high blood pressure, irregular heartbeat or qt prolongation, low potassium, diabetes, seizures, tuberculosis (tb), cataracts, glaucoma or elevated eye pressure, thyroid problems, liver disease, any condition affecting the immune system, any untreated infection, or a herpes infection of the eye; and if you smoke or use tobacco, or are on prolonged bedrest. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while using this medicine. before any surgery, including dental procedures, tell the clinician you use this inhaler. if you have never had chickenpox or measles and have not been vaccinated, avoid people who are sick, especially those with these infections; contact your doctor promptly if exposed or if symptoms develop—you may need preventive treatment. this inhaler can occasionally cause sudden wheezing or trouble breathing right after a dose (paradoxical bronchospasm); use your fast-acting rescue inhaler immediately and call your doctor. do not use this inhaler again unless your doctor tells you to. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor instructs otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? for most products, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not inhale two doses at once. if you are using symbicort aerosphere, take the missed dose as soon as you remember, unless it is almost time for the next dose; if so, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not inhale a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include throat irritation or pain, stuffy or runny nose, back pain, headache, muscle spasms, hoarseness, tremor, or nervousness. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care for serious effects such as hives or rash; swelling of the face, lips, tongue, throat, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; burning, tingling, or numbness in the hands or feet; white patches or sores in the mouth or throat (possible oral thrush); pounding, fast, or irregular heartbeat; fainting; chest pain; unusual tiredness, weakness, nausea, or vomiting; cough, trouble breathing, or changes in sputum color; or fever, chills, body aches, or other signs of infection. this medicine may slow growth in children; your child’s growth should be monitored. it may increase the risk of glaucoma or cataracts; you may need regular eye exams—contact your doctor for eye pain, redness, discomfort, blurred vision, seeing halos or bright colors around lights, or any vision changes. long-term use may increase the risk of osteoporosis. this medicine can cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using it.

name: budesonide nasal spray
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? budesonide nasal spray is used to relieve sneezing and a runny, stuffy, or itchy nose due to seasonal or perennial allergies (for example, from pollen, mold, dust, or pets). it should not be used to treat symptoms of the common cold. budesonide is a corticosteroid that works by reducing the release of substances in the body that trigger allergy symptoms. how should this medicine be used? budesonide comes as a prescription and nonprescription liquid suspension for use as a nasal spray, typically once daily in each nostril. adults usually start with a higher dose and then step down once symptoms improve. children start with a lower dose and may increase if symptoms persist, then decrease once controlled. follow the label and your clinician’s instructions exactly; do not use more, less, or more often than directed. an adult should assist children under 12 years of age; children under 6 years should not use this product. for nasal use only; do not swallow or spray into the eyes or mouth. use one bottle per person to prevent spreading germs. budesonide helps control, not cure, allergy symptoms. some relief may occur within 1 to 2 days, but full benefit can take up to 2 weeks. use it regularly unless your clinician advises as-needed use. contact your clinician if symptoms worsen or do not improve after 2 weeks of daily use. each bottle delivers a set number of sprays; track your sprays and discard the bottle when the labeled number is reached, even if liquid remains. before first use, read the patient instructions. to use: 1) gently shake the bottle and remove the cap. 2) prime the pump: if first use, press and release 8 times away from your face until a fine mist appears; if not used for 2 or more days, press and release until you see a fine spray; if not used for more than 14 days, rinse the tip and prime with two or more sprays until a fine mist appears. 3) blow your nose to clear the nostrils. 4) close one nostril, tilt your head slightly forward, keep the bottle upright, and insert the applicator into the other nostril. 5) begin to breathe in through your nose and press down firmly to spray; then lean your head back slightly, breathe in gently through your nose and out through your mouth. 6) use additional sprays in that nostril only if directed. 7) repeat in the other nostril as instructed. 8) do not blow your nose for 15 minutes after use. 9) wipe the tip and replace the cap. ask your pharmacist or clinician for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medicine may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your clinician or pharmacist for details. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your clinician and pharmacist if you are allergic to budesonide or any ingredients in the spray, and review all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and herbal products you use; dose adjustments or monitoring may be needed. tell your clinician if you have had recent nasal surgery, injury, or sores in the nose; if you have or have had cataracts, glaucoma, asthma, any infection, herpes infection of the eye, or liver disease; if you have chickenpox, measles, or tuberculosis (tb), or have been around someone with these; and if you are pregnant, planning to become pregnant, or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary restrictions are required unless your clinician advises otherwise; continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include nasal dryness, stinging, burning, or irritation; tiredness or weakness; nausea or vomiting; joint or muscle pain; and nosebleeds. serious side effects can occur. stop using the spray and call your clinician or seek emergency care if you develop vision changes; signs of infection such as fever, sore throat, chills, or cough; a whistling sound from the nose; hives, rash, itching, or swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; hoarseness, wheezing, chest tightness, or trouble breathing or swallowing; or white patches in the mouth, throat, or nose. this medicine may slow growth in children; discuss long-term use (more than 2 months per year) with your child’s clinician. other side effects may occur; contact your clinician if you notice anything unusual.

name: budesonide oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? budesonide helps prevent breathing difficulty, chest tightness, wheezing, and coughing caused by asthma. the powder for oral inhalation (pulmicort flexhaler) is used in adults and in children 6 years and older; the suspension for oral inhalation (pulmicort respules) is used in children 12 months to 8 years. budesonide is a corticosteroid that reduces airway swelling and irritation to improve breathing. how should this medicine be used? budesonide is available as a dry powder for oral inhalation and as a suspension to inhale with a jet nebulizer that turns the medicine into a mist. the powder is usually inhaled twice daily; the suspension is usually inhaled once or twice daily. use it at the same times each day. follow your prescription label, ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear, and use exactly as directed. do not change your dose or frequency without your doctor’s advice. ask your doctor how to use your other asthma medicines while on budesonide. if you were taking an oral steroid such as dexamethasone, methylprednisolone (medrol), or prednisone (rayos), your doctor may slowly reduce that dose after you start budesonide. budesonide controls asthma symptoms but does not cure asthma. some improvement may occur soon after use, but the full effect may take 1–2 weeks with the powder and 4–6 weeks with the suspension when used regularly. keep using budesonide even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor. call your doctor if your or your child’s symptoms do not improve within 2 weeks (powder) or 6 weeks (suspension) or if they worsen. budesonide helps prevent attacks but will not stop one that has already started; your doctor will prescribe a short-acting rescue inhaler for asthma attacks and if your asthma worsens. each inhaler delivers 60 or 120 inhalations depending on size; doses after the labeled number may not contain the correct amount. track your inhalations and discard the inhaler once you reach the labeled total, even if it still seems to spray. do not swallow the nebulizer suspension. before first use, read the written instructions and diagrams for your inhaler or nebulizer, learn all parts, and have your doctor, pharmacist, or respiratory therapist demonstrate proper technique; practice in front of them. using the powder inhaler: remove the protective cap. prime a new device by holding it upright (mouthpiece up), twisting the brown grip fully to the right and then fully to the left until it clicks; repeat once. you do not need to prime again, even after long periods without use. load a dose while holding upright by turning the grip fully to the right and then fully to the left until it clicks. turn your head away and exhale; do not exhale into or shake the inhaler after loading. hold it upright or horizontal, place the mouthpiece well into your mouth, seal your lips (do not bite), tilt your head slightly back, and inhale deeply and forcefully so the dose is not blocked by your teeth or tongue. remove the inhaler and hold your breath for about 10 seconds; do not exhale through the device. if a second puff is prescribed, reload upright just before the next inhalation and repeat. replace and twist the cap closed. after each dose, rinse your mouth with water and spit it out; do not swallow. keep the inhaler clean and dry with the cover on. using the nebulizer suspension: remove one ampule from the foil pouch and gently swirl it in a circular motion. hold upright, twist off the top, and empty the entire contents into the nebulizer reservoir; do not mix with other medicines. connect the reservoir to the mouthpiece or face mask and to the compressor. sit upright, place the mouthpiece in the mouth or fit the mask, turn on the compressor, and breathe calmly, deeply, and evenly until mist stops. after each treatment, rinse the mouth and spit; do not swallow. discard the empty ampule and top safely. clean the nebulizer regularly per the manufacturer’s directions; ask your clinician if you have questions. what special precautions should i follow? before using budesonide, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to budesonide or any ingredients in the powder or nebulizer solution; if using the powder, also mention any allergy to milk proteins. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; dose adjustments or monitoring may be needed. do not use budesonide to treat an active asthma attack; use your short-acting rescue inhaler. call your doctor if an attack does not stop with your rescue medicine or if you need it more often than usual. tell your doctor if you or a family member has osteoporosis; and if you have or have had tuberculosis, cataracts, glaucoma or high eye pressure, liver disease, any untreated infection, or a herpes infection of the eye. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call if you become pregnant while using budesonide. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, tell the surgeon or dentist that you use budesonide. if your oral steroid dose is reduced, conditions such as asthma, arthritis, or eczema may temporarily worsen, and you may develop symptoms of low adrenal function (extreme tiredness, muscle weakness or pain, sudden pain in the stomach, lower body, or legs, loss of appetite, weight loss, upset stomach, vomiting, diarrhea, dizziness, fainting, depression, irritability, or darkening of the skin); call your doctor if these occur. your body may handle stress (surgery, illness, severe asthma attack, injury) less well during and after a steroid switch; seek medical care right away if you become ill and ensure all healthcare providers know you recently replaced an oral steroid with budesonide; carry a card or wear a medical id stating you may need steroids in an emergency. if you have never had chickenpox or measles and are not vaccinated, avoid people who are sick, especially with these infections; if exposed or symptoms develop, call your doctor promptly because you may need treatment. budesonide can sometimes cause sudden wheezing or breathing difficulty right after inhalation; if this happens, use your rescue inhaler immediately and call your doctor. do not use budesonide again unless your doctor tells you to. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not use extra doses to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include headache, stuffy or runny nose, sore throat, diarrhea, loss of appetite, stomach pain, trouble falling or staying asleep, neck or back pain, ear infections, and nosebleeds. serious side effects may include white patches or sores in the mouth, rash, hives, itching, swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, hoarseness, difficulty breathing or swallowing, wheezing, cough, chest pain, anxiety, fever, chills or other signs of infection, tiredness, nausea, vomiting, weakness, and changes in vision; call your doctor immediately or seek emergency care if these occur. budesonide may slow growth in children; your child’s doctor will monitor growth. rarely, long-term use has been associated with glaucoma or cataracts; discuss how often your eyes should be examined. budesonide may increase the risk of osteoporosis. this medicine may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual while using it.

name: budesonide oral suspension (eosinophilic esophagitis)
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? budesonide oral suspension is prescribed to treat eosinophilic esophagitis (eoe), a condition with high levels of eosinophils (a type of blood cell) in the esophagus that can damage esophageal tissue, in adults and children 11 years of age and older. budesonide is a corticosteroid that reduces inflammation and swelling in the esophagus in people with eoe. how should this medicine be used? budesonide oral suspension is a liquid taken by mouth. it is usually taken without food at least 30 minutes before eating or drinking, twice a day, for up to 12 weeks. take it at the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. the medication comes in single-use stick packs. shake the stick pack for at least 10 seconds before opening. after opening, squeeze from the bottom to the top to dispense the contents directly into your mouth; repeat this 2 to 3 times until the pack is empty. swallow all of the suspension and avoid eating or drinking for 30 minutes. after 30 minutes, rinse your mouth with water and spit it out; do not swallow the rinse. your doctor may adjust your dose if needed. do not change your dose or stop taking budesonide without your doctor’s guidance. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking budesonide oral suspension, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to budesonide, any other medications, or any ingredients in the suspension. ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you or anyone in your family has had diabetes (high blood sugar) or glaucoma, and if you have high blood pressure, osteoporosis (weak, fragile bones), stomach ulcers, cataracts, allergies, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you have or have had tuberculosis or exposure to tuberculosis, hepatitis b, amebiasis (a parasitic intestinal infection) or have spent time in the tropics or have unexplained diarrhea, fungal infections such as recurrent yeast infections or toenail or foot fungus or other chronic fungal infections such as blastomycosis, histoplasmosis, or cryptococcus, strongyloides (threadworm) infection, malaria, or herpes. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while taking budesonide, call your doctor. this medication is generally not recommended for older adults because other medications may be safer or more effective; if you are 65 or older, discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking budesonide. if you have never had chickenpox or measles and have not been vaccinated against these infections, avoid people who are sick, especially those with chickenpox or measles. if you are exposed to these infections or develop symptoms, call your doctor right away; you may need treatment to protect you. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not eat grapefruit or drink grapefruit juice while taking this medication. unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? budesonide oral suspension may cause side effects. common side effects include headache; dry or sore throat; stuffy or runny nose; cough; nasal or chest congestion; dry, itchy skin; sneezing; and watery eyes. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or seek emergency medical care if you experience acne; rounding of the face; ankle swelling; increased body or facial hair; a hump between your shoulders; stretch marks on the skin; tiredness, weakness, nausea, vomiting, or low blood pressure; dizziness when moving from lying or sitting to standing; fever, chills, abdominal pain, aches, diarrhea, or feeling unusually tired; heartburn, chest pain, or trouble swallowing; purple, brown, or red skin lesions that may be flat or raised; rash, throat swelling, or difficulty breathing. budesonide may cause osteoporosis and may slow growth in children. talk to your doctor about the risks of taking this medication. budesonide suspension may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: bumetanide
instructions: important warning: bumetanide is a potent diuretic ('water pill') that can cause dehydration and electrolyte imbalances. take it exactly as directed by your doctor. call your doctor right away if you have any of the following: rapid or excessive weight loss; decreased urination; dry mouth; thirst; nausea; vomiting; weakness; drowsiness; confusion; muscle pain or cramps; or a rapid or pounding heartbeat. why is this medication prescribed? bumetanide treats edema (fluid retention) caused by conditions such as heart, kidney, or liver disease. it belongs to a class of medicines called diuretics and works by helping your kidneys remove excess water and salt in the urine. how should this medicine be used? bumetanide is taken by mouth as a tablet, usually once daily. for edema, a second or third dose may be given every 4 to 5 hours based on your response. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. bumetanide controls edema but does not cure it; continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine: bumetanide may also be used to treat high blood pressure. discuss with your doctor whether this is appropriate for you. it may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking bumetanide, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bumetanide, to sulfonamide medications, to any other medicines, or to any ingredients in the tablets. review the ingredient list with your pharmacist if needed. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you closely for side effects. if you have kidney disease, your doctor may tell you not to take bumetanide. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had diabetes or heart or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. do not breastfeed while taking this medicine. if you become pregnant while taking bumetanide, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the surgeon or dentist that you take bumetanide. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow your doctor’s advice about a low-salt/low-sodium diet and about increasing potassium-rich foods (for example, bananas, prunes, raisins, and orange juice) or potassium supplements if prescribed. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include frequent urination, dizziness, upset stomach, and diarrhea. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have any of the symptoms listed in the important warning section, or if you experience ringing in the ears, hearing loss, unusual bleeding or bruising, a severe rash with peeling skin, difficulty breathing or swallowing, or hives.

name: bupivacaine injection
instructions: important warning: at certain concentrations, bupivacaine used as an epidural for surgery or during labor and delivery has been associated with cardiac arrest (the heart stops). those concentrations are not recommended for these uses. why is this medication prescribed? bupivacaine is used to control pain during surgery or other medical procedures. it belongs to a class of medicines called local anesthetics and works by blocking nerves from sending pain signals. how should this medicine be used? bupivacaine is a sterile liquid solution that a healthcare professional injects, often just before a procedure. ask your doctor or pharmacist for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more details. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving bupivacaine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bupivacaine, any ingredient in the product, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe any reactions you have had. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take; dose adjustments or extra monitoring may be needed. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (g6pd) deficiency; methemoglobinemia; or lung, liver, heart, or blood vessel disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor. you should know that injections in or around the spine can cause temporary loss of feeling and movement (usually of the lower half of the body). after dental use, do not chew solid foods until feeling returns in your mouth; sensation may take up to 7 hours to return. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given by a healthcare professional for procedures, so missed doses are uncommon. if you think you missed an appointment or dose, contact your healthcare provider. what side effects can this medication cause? bupivacaine may cause side effects. common: pain or redness at the injection site. serious—call your doctor right away or get emergency help if you have: signs of an allergic reaction (itching, redness, hives, swelling of the tongue or throat, trouble breathing, fast heartbeat, fainting, excessive sweating, fever); nervous system symptoms (restlessness, anxiety, incoherent speech, lightheadedness, numbness or tingling of the mouth or lips, metallic taste, ringing in the ears, dizziness, blurred vision, tremors, twitching, depression, drowsiness, seizures); fast or irregular heartbeat; signs of methemoglobinemia (pale, gray, or blue skin; headache; rapid heart rate; shortness of breath; lightheadedness; fatigue). bupivacaine may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you experience anything unusual.

name: bupivacaine liposomal injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bupivacaine liposomal injection is used to manage pain after surgery. bupivacaine is a local anesthetic that works by blocking nerves from sending pain signals. how should this medicine be used? bupivacaine liposomal injection is a sterile suspension injected by a healthcare professional. it is typically administered at the time of surgery, either just before the procedure begins or at the end, directly into the surgical area. ask your doctor or pharmacist for the manufacturer's patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving bupivacaine liposomal, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to bupivacaine, any of its ingredients, other local anesthetics, or any foods or substances, and describe the symptoms you had. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (g6pd) deficiency; methemoglobinemia; or lung, liver, heart, or blood vessel disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you will have another procedure within 96 hours, including dental surgery, tell the clinician that you recently received bupivacaine liposomal injection. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medication is administered by a healthcare professional at the time of surgery, so you will not need to remember doses. if you think a dose was missed, ask your surgeon or nurse. what side effects can this medication cause? bupivacaine liposomal may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: nausea, vomiting, constipation. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you experience itching, redness, hives, swelling of the tongue or throat, trouble breathing, fast heartbeat, fainting, excessive sweating, or fever; restlessness, anxiety, incoherent speech, lightheadedness, numbness or tingling of the mouth and lips, metallic taste, ringing in the ears, dizziness, blurred vision, tremors, twitching, depression, drowsiness, or seizures; pale, gray, or blue skin; headache; rapid heart rate; shortness of breath; lightheadedness; or fatigue. bupivacaine liposomal may cause temporary numbness or weakness in the treated area that can last up to 5 days. talk to your doctor about the risks of receiving this medication. bupivacaine liposomal may cause other side effects; contact your healthcare provider if you notice any unusual symptoms.

name: buprenorphine belbuca
instructions: important warning: buprenorphine belbuca can be habit forming, especially with long-term use. use exactly as prescribed—do not apply extra films, use them more often, or change how you use them without your doctor’s direction. while using buprenorphine, discuss your pain goals, expected duration of therapy, and non-opioid options with your healthcare provider. you have a higher risk of misuse or overuse if you or a family member has a history of heavy alcohol use, street drug use, prescription medication overuse, overdose, depression, or other mental illness. if you think you may have an opioid addiction, talk to your healthcare provider right away or call samhsa’s national helpline at 1-800-662-help. serious or life-threatening breathing problems can occur, especially during the first 24 to 72 hours of treatment and any time your dose is increased. your doctor will monitor you closely and adjust your dose carefully to control pain while lowering this risk. tell your doctor if you have breathing difficulties or a history of asthma—your doctor may advise against belbuca. the risk of dangerous breathing problems is higher if you have copd or other lung disease, a head injury, a brain tumor, or increased pressure in the brain, and in older, weakened, or malnourished adults. call your doctor immediately if you have difficulty breathing, shortness of breath, extreme drowsiness, fainting, or loss of consciousness. taking certain medicines with belbuca can increase the risk of severe sedation, respiratory depression, or coma. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and supplements you use. your doctor may change doses and monitor you closely. if you develop unusual dizziness, lightheadedness, extreme sleepiness, slowed or difficult breathing, or unresponsiveness, call your doctor or seek emergency care. make sure caregivers know these symptoms and when to call for help. do not drink alcohol, use alcohol-containing medicines, or use street drugs while taking belbuca; these greatly increase the risk of life-threatening side effects. accidental use by children or anyone for whom it was not prescribed can cause serious harm or death. do not share your medication. store it securely and keep track of how many films you have. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, know that regular use can cause life-threatening withdrawal in your newborn. call your baby’s doctor right away if your baby has irritability, hyperactivity, abnormal sleep, a high-pitched cry, shaking, vomiting, diarrhea, or poor weight gain. you will receive a medication guide when you start belbuca and with each refill—read it carefully and ask questions. discuss the risks of belbuca with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? belbuca is used to relieve severe, persistent pain requiring around-the-clock, long-term opioid treatment when other options are inadequate. it is not for mild or moderate pain, short-term pain, or pain controlled by as-needed medication. buprenorphine is an opioid partial agonist that changes how the brain and nervous system perceive pain. how should this medicine be used? belbuca is a buccal film applied to the inside of the cheek, usually twice daily at the same times. follow your prescription exactly. your doctor will usually start with a low dose once daily or every 12 hours and increase it no more than every 4 days; your dose may be lowered if you have side effects. contact your doctor if your pain is not controlled or if you have side effects—do not change your dose on your own. do not stop belbuca suddenly; your doctor will taper your dose to prevent withdrawal. call your doctor if you develop withdrawal symptoms such as restlessness, teary eyes, runny nose, yawning, sweating, chills, muscle or back aches, enlarged pupils, irritability, anxiety, insomnia, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, decreased appetite, stomach cramps, joint pain, weakness, fast heartbeat, or rapid breathing. films are sealed in foil; do not open until ready to use, and do not use if the seal is broken or the film is cut, damaged, or altered. if your pain worsens or you develop increased sensitivity to pain, especially after using buprenorphine, call your doctor—do not increase your dose or frequency. to apply: 1) fold the foil packet along the dotted line and tear down at the notch (or carefully cut) without damaging the film. 2) moisten the inside of your cheek with your tongue or a sip of water; avoid areas with open sores. 3) with clean, dry fingers, remove the film and hold it yellow side up. 4) immediately place the yellow side against your moistened cheek and press for 5 seconds, then remove your finger; the film should adhere. 5) leave it in place until fully dissolved (about 30 minutes). do not touch, move, chew, or swallow the film, and do not eat or drink until it dissolves completely. after it dissolves, swish a sip of water around your teeth and gums and swallow. do not brush your teeth for at least 1 hour afterward. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using belbuca, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to buprenorphine or any ingredients in the film; check the medication guide for a full list. tell them if you are taking or recently took (within 14 days) mao inhibitors such as isocarboxazid, linezolid, methylene blue, phenelzine, selegiline, or tranylcypromine. st. john’s wort and tryptophan may interact with buprenorphine—tell your healthcare providers about these and do not start them while on belbuca without medical advice. tell your doctor if you have any conditions listed in the important warning section, or if you have paralytic ileus or a blockage in the stomach or intestines—your doctor may advise against belbuca. also tell your doctor if you or an immediate family member has long qt syndrome; if you have low potassium or magnesium; a slow or irregular heartbeat; heart failure; low blood pressure; diabetes; trouble urinating; seizures; dental problems (including cavities) or mouth sores; or gallbladder, pancreas, kidney, thyroid, or liver disease. do not breastfeed while using belbuca; buprenorphine can cause shallow, difficult, or noisy breathing, confusion, excessive sleepiness, feeding problems, or limpness in breastfed infants. this medication may reduce fertility in men and women; discuss risks with your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, tell the provider you use belbuca. belbuca may cause drowsiness—do not drive or use machinery until you know how it affects you. it can cause dizziness or fainting when standing up; rise slowly. constipation is common—ask your doctor about diet changes or medications to prevent or treat it. belbuca may cause serious dental problems (cavities, infections, fractures, tooth loss); get regular dental checkups and call your dentist if you develop tooth or mouth pain. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply a double dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include diarrhea, dry mouth, sleepiness, and headache. serious side effects can include changes in heartbeat; signs of serotonin syndrome (agitation, hallucinations, fever, sweating, confusion, fast heartbeat, shivering, severe muscle stiffness or twitching, loss of coordination, diarrhea); nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, weakness, or dizziness; inability to get or keep an erection; irregular menstruation; decreased sexual desire; chest pain; swelling of the face, tongue, or throat; rash or hives; and worsening pain or increased sensitivity to pain. if you experience serious symptoms or those listed in the important warning or special precautions sections, call your doctor immediately or seek emergency care. belbuca may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: buprenorphine injection (extended-release) for opioid dependence
instructions: important warning: because of the risks with this medication, buprenorphine extended-release injection is only available through special distribution programs called the brixadi rems and the sublocade rems. your doctor and your pharmacy must be enrolled before you can receive this medicine. ask your doctor for more information about how you will receive each dose. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory; your doctor may order tests before and during treatment to monitor your response. you will receive a medication guide when you start and at each dose—read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist any questions. why is this medication prescribed? buprenorphine extended-release injection is used to treat certain people who are dependent on opioids. it belongs to a class of medicines called opioid partial agonists. it helps prevent withdrawal symptoms when stopping opioids by producing similar, controlled effects. how should this medicine be used? buprenorphine extended-release injection is a long-acting solution given by a healthcare professional as a subcutaneous injection (under the skin) in the abdomen, thigh, buttock, or upper arm. it is usually administered once weekly or once monthly, and each dose slowly releases medicine over that period. a firm lump at the injection site may be present for several weeks and should shrink over time. do not rub or massage the area, and avoid pressure from belts, waistbands, or sleeves. your doctor may adjust your dose based on how well it works and any side effects. tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. if treatment is stopped, your doctor will likely taper your dose. withdrawal symptoms can include restlessness, watery eyes, sweating, chills, enlarged pupils, irritability, anxiety, backache, weakness, stomach cramps, insomnia, nausea, loss of appetite, vomiting, diarrhea, rapid breathing, or fast heartbeat; these may occur a month or longer after the last dose. other uses for this medicine: this medicine may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving buprenorphine injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to buprenorphine, any ingredients in the injection, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your reaction. provide a list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you are taking or have stopped taking within the last 14 days any mao inhibitors such as isocarboxazid (marplan), linezolid (zyvox), methylene blue, phenelzine (nardil), selegiline (emsam, zelapar), or tranylcypromine (parnate). some nonprescription or herbal products can interact, including st. john’s wort and tryptophan—do not start them without discussing with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you or a family member drinks or has ever drunk large amounts of alcohol, or if you have or have ever had prolonged qt syndrome; low potassium or magnesium; heart failure; a slow or irregular heartbeat; copd or other lung disease; a head injury; a brain tumor; increased intracranial pressure; adrenal problems such as addison’s disease; enlarged prostate (bph) or trouble urinating; depression or other mental illness; spinal curvature that makes breathing hard; liver disease including hepatitis b or c; thyroid disease; or gallbladder disease. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, tell your doctor; regular use during pregnancy can cause life-threatening withdrawal in your newborn. contact your baby’s doctor right away if your newborn has irritability, hyperactivity, abnormal sleep, high-pitched cry, shaking, vomiting, diarrhea, or poor weight gain. if you are breastfeeding, tell your doctor; seek help immediately if your baby is sleepier than usual or has trouble breathing. this medicine may reduce fertility in men and women. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, tell the surgeon or dentist you receive buprenorphine injection. this medicine may cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. do not drink alcohol or use street drugs; alcohol or alcohol-containing medications can increase the risk of serious, life-threatening breathing problems. buprenorphine may cause dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting when rising quickly; get up slowly and rest your feet on the floor before standing. it may cause constipation; ask your doctor about diet changes or medications to prevent or treat constipation. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a scheduled dose, call your doctor as soon as possible to arrange the next injection. what side effects can this medication cause? buprenorphine injection may cause side effects. call your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: nausea; vomiting; headache; fatigue; insomnia; injection-site pain, itching, swelling, discomfort, redness, bruising, or bumps; painful or difficult urination. some side effects can be serious. get medical help right away if you have slowed, shallow, or difficult breathing; shortness of breath; agitation; hallucinations; fever; sweating; confusion; fast heartbeat; shivering; slurred speech; severe muscle stiffness or twitching; loss of coordination; nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea that may suggest serotonin syndrome; nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, weakness, or dizziness; sexual problems such as erectile dysfunction, irregular menstruation, or decreased sexual desire; rash, hives, itching, trouble breathing or swallowing, lightheadedness, fainting, or swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes; blurred vision; changes in heartbeat; or signs of liver problems such as yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, light-colored stools, loss of appetite, nausea, or pain in the upper right abdomen. buprenorphine injection may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: buprenorphine injection pain relief
instructions: important warning: buprenorphine injection can be habit-forming, especially with long-term use. use it only as prescribed—do not take larger amounts, take it more often, or use it in any way other than directed. while receiving buprenorphine injection, talk with your healthcare provider about your pain goals, how long treatment should last, and other options to manage pain. tell your provider if you or a family member drinks or has drunk heavily, uses or has used street drugs, has misused prescription medicines, has had an overdose, or if you have or have had depression or any other mental health condition, because these increase the risk of misuse or addiction. if you think you may have an opioid use disorder, contact your healthcare provider right away or call the samhsa national helpline at 1-800-662-help. buprenorphine injection can cause serious or life-threatening breathing problems, especially during the first 24–72 hours of treatment and when the dose is raised. your doctor will monitor you closely. do not use this medication if you have or have had slowed breathing or asthma, and tell your doctor if you have lung disease such as copd, sleep apnea, a head injury, a brain tumor, or any condition that raises pressure in the brain. the risk of breathing problems is higher in older adults and in people who are frail or malnourished. call your doctor or seek emergency care immediately if you develop slow or difficult breathing, long pauses between breaths, or shortness of breath. combining buprenorphine injection with certain medicines can increase the risk of severe sedation, life-threatening breathing problems, or coma. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and herbal products you use or plan to use. if you develop unusual dizziness, lightheadedness, extreme sleepiness, slow or difficult breathing, or unresponsiveness, call your doctor or seek emergency care at once. make sure family or caregivers know these warning signs and how to get help. do not drink alcohol, use alcohol-containing products, or use street drugs while on this medication; doing so can cause dangerous side effects. if you are pregnant or planning to become pregnant, discuss the risks; regular use during pregnancy can cause life-threatening withdrawal in your newborn. contact your baby’s doctor immediately if your baby is very irritable, overly active, sleeps abnormally, has a high-pitched cry, tremors, vomiting, diarrhea, or poor weight gain. why is this medication prescribed? buprenorphine injection is used short term to relieve severe pain in people who require an opioid and cannot be adequately treated with other pain medicines. it is an opioid partial agonist that changes the way your body senses pain. how should this medicine be used? buprenorphine injection is a liquid solution given by a healthcare professional as an intramuscular (into a muscle) or intravenous (into a vein) injection, usually every 4 to 6 hours as needed for severe pain. your doctor may adjust the dose based on your pain relief and side effects. tell your doctor if your pain is not controlled, if it worsens, if you have new pain, or if you notice increased sensitivity to pain. do not use more than prescribed or more often than directed. if you have used buprenorphine injection for more than a few days, do not stop suddenly; stopping abruptly may cause withdrawal (restlessness, watery eyes, runny nose, yawning, sweating, chills, muscle/back/joint pain, enlarged pupils, irritability, anxiety, weakness, stomach cramps, insomnia, nausea, loss of appetite, vomiting, diarrhea, rapid breathing, or fast heartbeat). your doctor will taper the dose gradually. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be used for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for details. what special precautions should i follow? before using buprenorphine injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to buprenorphine or any ingredient in the injection (ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients). tell your doctor or pharmacist if you take, or have taken in the past 2 weeks, monoamine oxidase inhibitors (maois) such as isocarboxazid, linezolid, methylene blue, phenelzine, procarbazine, selegiline, or tranylcypromine. some over-the-counter or herbal products—including st. john’s wort and tryptophan—can interact with buprenorphine; tell your healthcare providers if you take these and do not start them without medical advice. tell your doctor if you have any of the conditions noted in the important warning section; a blockage in the stomach or intestines; or paralytic ileus (when the intestines do not move). your doctor may advise against using this medication. also tell your doctor if you have or have had long qt syndrome; low potassium or magnesium; heart failure; a slow or irregular heartbeat; seizures; diabetes; adrenal problems such as addison’s disease; enlarged prostate (bph) or trouble urinating; a spinal curvature that makes breathing difficult; or thyroid, gallbladder, pancreas, kidney, or liver disease. do not breastfeed while using buprenorphine injection; contact your baby’s doctor right away if your baby is more sleepy than usual or has trouble breathing. this medication may reduce fertility in men and women; discuss risks with your doctor. before any surgery or dental procedure, tell the clinician you are using buprenorphine injection. this drug can cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. it can also cause dizziness or fainting when standing up quickly; rise slowly and sit with your feet on the floor before standing. constipation is common; ask your doctor about diet changes or medicines to prevent or treat it. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor whether you should avoid grapefruit or grapefruit juice while using this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? buprenorphine injection is typically administered by a healthcare professional. if you miss a scheduled dose or appointment, contact your doctor or clinic as soon as possible. do not take extra doses or attempt to self-inject to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? buprenorphine injection can cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of the following are severe or do not go away: nausea, vomiting, headache, dizziness, drowsiness, or sweating. serious side effects require immediate medical attention: signs of an allergic reaction (rash, hives, itching, trouble breathing or swallowing, swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes); symptoms of serotonin syndrome (agitation, hallucinations, fever, sweating, confusion, rapid heartbeat, shivering, slurred speech, severe muscle stiffness or twitching, loss of coordination, or diarrhea); nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, weakness, or dizziness; sexual side effects (erectile problems, irregular menstruation, decreased libido); changes in pupil size (narrowing or widening of the black center of the eye); or seizure. buprenorphine injection may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using it.

name: buprenorphine sublingual and buccal (opioid dependence)
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? buprenorphine, alone or combined with naloxone, is used to treat opioid dependence (addiction to heroin or prescription opioid pain medicines). buprenorphine is an opioid partial agonist-antagonist and naloxone is an opioid antagonist. taken as directed, these medicines reduce withdrawal symptoms by producing effects similar to opioids while helping prevent misuse. how should this medicine be used? buprenorphine comes as a sublingual tablet. the buprenorphine/naloxone combination comes as a sublingual tablet (zubsolv) and as a film (suboxone) that is placed under the tongue or against the inside of the cheek. after your clinician sets your dose, it is usually taken once daily at the same time each day. follow the prescription label exactly and ask your clinician or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. your clinician may start therapy with buprenorphine alone in the office at a low dose, increase it for 1–2 days, then switch you to buprenorphine/naloxone; depending on the opioid you were using, you may instead start directly on buprenorphine/naloxone. your dose may be adjusted based on your response. for sublingual tablets: place the tablet(s) under your tongue until fully dissolved. if you need more than two tablets, place them all at once or up to two at a time. do not chew or swallow tablets whole, and do not eat, drink, or talk until dissolved. for buccal film: rinse your mouth with water first, then apply the film with a dry finger to the inside of your cheek and remove your finger so it adheres. if using two films, place one on each cheek at the same time. do not overlap films and do not apply more than two films in the mouth at one time. let the films dissolve completely; do not cut, tear, chew, swallow, touch, or move the film while it dissolves, and do not eat or drink until fully dissolved. for sublingual film: rinse your mouth with water, then place the film with a dry finger under your tongue to the right or left of center and hold for 5 seconds. if using two films, place the second on the opposite side. do not let films touch or overlap and do not use more than two at one time. do not cut, tear, chew, swallow, touch, or move the film while it dissolves, and do not eat or drink until fully dissolved. after the tablet or film dissolves, take a sip of water, swish around your teeth and gums, and swallow; do not brush your teeth for at least 1 hour afterward. if you switch between buprenorphine or buprenorphine/naloxone products, your dose may need adjustment. check each refill to be sure you received the exact product prescribed; ask your pharmacist if you are unsure. do not stop taking this medicine without speaking to your clinician; stopping suddenly can cause withdrawal (hot or cold flashes, restlessness, watery eyes, runny nose, sweating, chills, muscle aches, vomiting, or diarrhea). what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician and pharmacist if you are allergic to buprenorphine, naloxone, or any ingredients in the tablets or films; ask your pharmacist for a full ingredient list. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and herbal products you use; your doses may need adjustment and you may need monitoring for side effects. tell your clinician if you take or recently (within 2 weeks) stopped taking mao inhibitors such as isocarboxazid (marplan), linezolid (zyvox), methylene blue, phenelzine (nardil), selegiline (emsam, zelapar), or tranylcypromine (parnate). st. john’s wort and tryptophan may interact; do not start or stop these without medical advice. tell your clinician if you drink or have ever drunk heavily, or if you have or have had: long qt syndrome; low potassium or magnesium; heart failure; slow or irregular heartbeat; adrenal problems (such as addison’s disease); enlarged prostate (bph) or trouble urinating; head injury; depression or other mental illness; a spinal curvature that affects breathing; gallbladder disease; liver disease (including hepatitis b or c); chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (copd) or other lung disease; or thyroid, kidney, or lung problems. if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or become pregnant, call your clinician. regular use in pregnancy can cause life-threatening withdrawal in newborns; seek care right away if your baby has irritability, seizures, shaking, vomiting, diarrhea, or poor weight gain. if breastfeeding, contact your baby’s clinician immediately if your baby is unusually sleepy or has trouble breathing. tell your surgeon or dentist that you take buprenorphine or buprenorphine/naloxone before any procedure. this medicine may reduce fertility in men and women; discuss risks with your clinician. it can cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. do not drink alcohol or use products containing alcohol while taking this medicine. it can cause dizziness or fainting when standing up, especially when starting treatment; rise slowly from sitting or lying. buprenorphine can cause serious dental problems (cavities, infections, fractures, tooth loss); get regular dental checkups and call your dentist for tooth or mouth pain or any problems with teeth or gums. what special dietary instructions should i follow? continue your usual diet unless your clinician gives you other instructions. what should i do if i forget a dose? take or apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take or apply two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? buprenorphine or buprenorphine/naloxone can cause side effects. common effects include headache, stomach pain, constipation, trouble falling or staying asleep, mouth numbness or redness, tongue pain, blurred vision, and back pain. serious effects require immediate medical attention and include: allergic reactions (hives, rash, itching, trouble breathing or swallowing, swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes); swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; symptoms of serotonin toxicity (agitation, hallucinations, fever, sweating, confusion, fast heartbeat, shivering, severe muscle stiffness or twitching, loss of coordination, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea); symptoms of liver problems (nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, weakness, dizziness, yellowing of skin or eyes, dark urine, light stools, pain in the upper right abdomen); slowed breathing; upset stomach; extreme tiredness; confusion; blurred vision; slurred speech; lack of energy; sexual side effects (decreased libido, erectile problems, irregular periods). this medicine may cause other side effects; contact your clinician if you experience anything unusual or bothersome.

name: buprenorphine transdermal patch
instructions: important warning: buprenorphine patches can be habit-forming, especially with long-term use. use them exactly as prescribed. do not apply extra patches, use them more frequently, or change how you use them without your doctor’s guidance. while using buprenorphine patches, discuss your pain goals, expected duration of therapy, and non-opioid options with your healthcare provider. tell your provider if you or a family member drinks or has drunk heavily, uses or has used street drugs, has misused prescription medicines, has had an overdose, or has or has had depression or another mental illness. these increase the risk of misuse or addiction. if you think you have an opioid use disorder, contact your healthcare provider right away or call samhsa’s national helpline at 1-800-662-help. buprenorphine patches can cause serious or life-threatening breathing problems, especially in the first 24 to 72 hours of treatment and whenever the dose is increased. your doctor will monitor you closely and adjust your dose to relieve pain while reducing the risk of respiratory depression. tell your doctor if you have or have had breathing problems, asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (copd), or other lung disease; your doctor may advise you not to use buprenorphine patches. tell your doctor if you have or have had a head injury, brain tumor, or any condition that raises pressure in the skull. the risk of breathing problems is also higher in older adults and in people who are frail or malnourished. call your doctor immediately if you develop trouble breathing, shortness of breath, extreme sleepiness, fainting, or loss of consciousness. taking certain medicines with buprenorphine increases the risk of dangerous sedation, coma, or breathing problems. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and supplements you use or plan to use. your doctor may change doses and will monitor you carefully. if you take buprenorphine patches with other medicines and develop unusual dizziness, lightheadedness, extreme sleepiness, slow or difficult breathing, or unresponsiveness, call your doctor or seek emergency care immediately. make sure family or caregivers know these warning signs and when to call for help. drinking alcohol or using street drugs while using buprenorphine patches greatly increases the risk of life-threatening side effects. do not drink alcohol, use alcohol-containing medicines, or use street drugs during treatment. accidental exposure to a buprenorphine patch can cause serious harm or death, especially in children and in adults for whom it was not prescribed. never share your medication. store patches safely and out of the reach of children, and track how many patches you have so you will know if any are missing. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, tell your doctor. regular use during pregnancy can cause life-threatening withdrawal in your newborn. contact your baby’s doctor right away if your baby has irritability, hyperactivity, abnormal sleep, a high-pitched cry, uncontrollable shaking, vomiting, diarrhea, or poor weight gain. your doctor or pharmacist will give you a medication guide when you start and each time you refill buprenorphine patches; read it carefully and ask questions as needed. why is this medication prescribed? buprenorphine patches are prescribed to relieve severe, ongoing pain in people who need around-the-clock opioid treatment for an extended period and who cannot be managed with other medications. they should not be used for mild or moderate pain, short-term pain, or pain controlled by as-needed medicines. buprenorphine is an opioid (narcotic) analgesic that works by altering how the brain and nervous system respond to pain. how should this medicine be used? buprenorphine transdermal comes as a skin patch applied once every 7 days. change your patch at about the same time on each change day. follow the prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. your doctor may start with a low-dose patch and increase your dose no more often than every 3 days. if your dose increase requires two patches, remove the old patch and apply the two new patches side by side at a new site at the same time; if instructed to use two patches, always change and apply them together. your doctor may lower your dose if you have side effects. call your doctor if your pain is not controlled; do not change your dose on your own. for skin use only; do not chew, swallow, or place patches in your mouth. do not stop buprenorphine abruptly; your doctor will taper your dose to avoid withdrawal. call your doctor if you develop withdrawal symptoms such as restlessness, watery eyes, runny nose, yawning, sweating, chills, goosebumps, muscle aches, enlarged pupils, irritability, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, anxiety, joint pain, weakness, rapid heartbeat, or fast breathing. do not use a patch that is cut, damaged, or altered; this could release the full dose at once and cause overdose or death. heat can cause the patch to release too much medicine. do not expose the patch or the skin around it to direct heat such as heating pads, electric blankets, heat lamps, saunas, hot tubs, or heated waterbeds. avoid long, hot baths and sunbathing while wearing the patch. you may bathe or shower; if a patch falls off, dispose of it safely, dry your skin completely, and apply a new patch, then leave it in place for 7 full days. apply to the upper outer arm, upper chest, upper back, or side of the chest on clean, flat, hairless skin. do not apply to irritated, broken, cut, damaged, or otherwise altered skin. if needed, clip hair with scissors; do not shave. rotate sites and wait at least 3 weeks before reusing the same area. if your pain worsens or you develop increased sensitivity to pain, especially after applying a patch, do not apply extra patches or change them more
