often; call your doctor. to apply: clean the chosen area with clear water only and pat dry; do not use soaps, lotions, alcohol, or oils. use scissors to open the pouch along the dotted line. remove the patch and peel off the protective liner, avoiding contact with the sticky side. press the patch firmly with the palm for at least 15 seconds, ensuring the edges stick; do not rub. if edges lift, secure edges only with first-aid tape. if it still won’t adhere, you may cover it with a see-through dressing such as bioclusive or tegaderm; do not use other bandages or tapes. talk to your pharmacist or doctor if adhesion problems persist. if a patch falls off early, dispose of it properly and apply a new one at a different site; wear the replacement for 7 days. after applying, wash hands with clear water only. record the date and time of application. when changing patches, remove the old one and apply a new one to a different site. for disposal, use the patch disposal unit provided by the manufacturer: fold sticky sides together, seal completely, and place in the trash. do not throw used patches in the trash without sealing them. alternatively, fold the patch in half with sticky sides together and flush it down the toilet. used patches still contain medicine and can be dangerous to children, pets, or others. other uses for this medicine this medication may sometimes be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using a buprenorphine patch, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to buprenorphine or any ingredients in the patch; check the medication guide or ask for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are taking or have recently taken any monoamine oxidase inhibitors (maois) within the past 14 days, such as isocarboxazid (marplan), linezolid (zyvox), methylene blue, phenelzine (nardil), selegiline (emsam, zelapar), or tranylcypromine (parnate). tell your doctor if you use herbal products such as st. john’s wort. make sure your providers know if you are taking other buprenorphine products (for example, buccal forms like belbuca); do not start this patch while using another buprenorphine product without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have had the conditions noted in the important warning section, or paralytic ileus (a blockage where the intestines stop moving); your doctor may advise you not to use this medicine. tell your doctor if you or an immediate family member has or has had long qt syndrome, or if you have or have had atrial fibrillation, heart failure, seizures, a head injury, brain tumor, stroke or high intracranial pressure, biliary tract disease, diabetes, a slow heart rate, low blood pressure, low potassium levels, urinary problems, or pancreas, thyroid, heart, kidney, or liver disease. if you are breastfeeding, do not breastfeed while using this medicine; buprenorphine can cause shallow, difficult, or noisy breathing, confusion, excessive sleepiness, feeding problems, or limpness in breastfed infants. this medication may reduce fertility in males and females; discuss risks with your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, tell the surgeon or dentist you use a buprenorphine patch. this medicine can make you drowsy; do not drive, use machinery, or do anything requiring alertness until you know how it affects you. it may cause dizziness or fainting when rising from lying down, especially at the start of treatment; get up slowly and sit with your feet on the floor before standing. buprenorphine often causes constipation; ask your doctor about diet changes or medicines to prevent or treat it. fever or becoming very hot after activity can increase drug absorption and risk overdose; avoid activities that cause overheating and call your doctor if you develop a fever, as your dose may need adjustment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you forget to apply or change a patch, put one on as soon as you remember, after removing any used patch. wear the new patch for the full period prescribed (usually 7 days) before replacing it. do not wear two patches at the same time unless your doctor has told you to do so. what side effects can this medication cause? buprenorphine patches can cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of the following are severe or do not go away: trouble falling or staying asleep, headache, dry mouth, stomach pain, or skin redness, itching, swelling, or irritation where the patch was applied. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have any of the following or the symptoms listed in the important warning: difficulty breathing or swallowing, shortness of breath, heartbeat changes, agitation, hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that aren’t there), fever, sweating, confusion, fast heartbeat, shivering, severe muscle stiffness or twitching, loss of coordination, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, weakness, dizziness, inability to get or keep an erection, irregular menstrual periods, decreased sexual desire, chest pain, swelling of the face, tongue, or throat, rash, hives, or itching. buprenorphine patches may cause other side effects. contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual or concerning.

name: bupropion
instructions: important warning: for people taking bupropion wellbutrin for depression: a small number of children, teenagers, and young adults up to 24 years of age who used antidepressants such as bupropion in clinical studies developed suicidal thoughts or behaviors. those taking antidepressants for depression or other mental illnesses may be at greater risk than those who do not. this risk must be weighed against the benefit of treatment when deciding whether a child or teen should take an antidepressant. children younger than 18 years usually should not take bupropion, but a clinician may recommend it when benefits outweigh risks. regardless of age, before starting any antidepressant, you and your parent or caregiver should discuss with your clinician the risks and benefits of treatment and of not treating the condition. having depression or another mental illness itself raises the risk of suicidality, especially early in treatment and whenever the dose is increased or reduced. the risk is higher if you or a family member has current or past bipolar disorder or mania, or a history of suicidal thoughts or attempts. discuss your condition, symptoms, and personal and family history with your clinician to decide on the best treatment. mental health can change unexpectedly while taking bupropion or other antidepressants, even in adults over 24 years old and in people taking bupropion for nonpsychiatric reasons. you may become suicidal, particularly at the start of therapy and during dose changes. you, your family, or your caregiver should call your clinician right away for any of these symptoms: new or worsening depression; thoughts about self harm or killing yourself, or planning or trying to do so; extreme worry; agitation; panic attacks; trouble falling or staying asleep; aggressive behavior; irritability; impulsive actions; severe restlessness; or frenzied, abnormal excitement. make sure family or caregivers know which symptoms are serious so they can seek help if you cannot. for all patients taking bupropion: your clinician will want to see you often while you are taking bupropion, especially early in treatment. keep all appointments. you will receive a medication guide when you start bupropion and with each refill. read it carefully and ask questions. talk with your clinician about the risks and benefits of bupropion. why is this medication prescribed? bupropion aplenzin, wellbutrin, wellbutrin sr, wellbutrin xl treats depression. bupropion aplenzin, wellbutrin xl also prevents and treats seasonal affective disorder sad, depressive episodes that recur at the same time each year usually in fall and winter, but sometimes in spring or summer. bupropion zyban helps people stop smoking. bupropion is an antidepressant that increases certain types of brain activity. how should this medicine be used? bupropion is available as immediate release tablets, sustained release sr tablets, and extended release xl tablets taken by mouth. immediate release wellbutrin is usually taken three times daily at least 6 hours apart, or four times daily at least 4 hours apart. sustained release wellbutrin sr or zyban is taken two times daily at least 8 hours apart. extended release aplenzin or wellbutrin xl is taken once each morning at least 24 hours apart. for sad, take once daily in the morning starting in early fall, continue through winter, and stop in early spring; in some cases the dose is lowered for 2 weeks before stopping. take with food if stomach upset occurs. if you have trouble sleeping, avoid doses near bedtime. take doses at the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly; do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. swallow sr and xl tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush. your clinician will usually start with a low dose and increase gradually. it may take 4 weeks or longer to feel the full benefit. keep taking bupropion even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your clinician, who may lower the dose gradually. other uses for this medicine: bupropion is sometimes used for depressive episodes in bipolar disorder and for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder adhd. ask your clinician about the risks and benefits if it is prescribed for these or other uses. what special precautions should i follow? before using bupropion, tell your clinician and pharmacist about any allergy to bupropion or any ingredient in the tablets. review the medication guide for a full ingredient list. do not take bupropion with or within 14 days of a monoamine oxidase inhibitor maoi such as isocarboxazid marplan, linezolid zyvox, methylene blue, phenelzine nardil, selegiline eldepryl, emsam, zelapar, or tranylcypromine parnate. do not take more than one product containing bupropion at the same time. some medicines cannot be used with bupropion, and others may require dose changes or monitoring. discuss all prescription, nonprescription, and herbal products you use or plan to use with your clinician and pharmacist before starting bupropion, and get their advice before starting, stopping, or changing any medicine while on bupropion. the nonprescription medicine cimetidine tagamet may interact; tell your clinician if you use it and do not start it while on bupropion without medical advice. do not use bupropion if you have or have ever had seizures, anorexia nervosa, or bulimia, or if you drink large amounts of alcohol or take sedatives and expect to stop them suddenly. tell your clinician if you drink heavily, use street drugs, or misuse prescription medicines; and if you have a history of heart attack, head injury, a brain or spinal tumor, high blood pressure, diabetes, or liver, kidney, or heart disease. tell your clinician if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. bupropion may cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. alcohol can worsen side effects; ask about safe use. bupropion can raise blood pressure; your clinician may check it before and during treatment, especially if you also use nicotine replacement. bupropion can trigger angle closure glaucoma in susceptible people; consider an eye exam before starting. seek urgent care for nausea, eye pain, visual changes such as seeing colored halos around lights, or swelling or redness in or around the eye. neuropsychiatric symptoms including behavior changes, hostility, agitation, depressed mood, and suicidal thoughts or actions have been reported during smoking cessation with bupropion; nicotine withdrawal can also cause these changes. these symptoms have occurred in people with and without prior mental illness, sometimes after several weeks of treatment or after stopping. if you have or have ever had depression, bipolar disorder, schizophrenia, or other mental illness, be especially alert for mood or behavior changes. if you develop any of the following while taking bupropion zyban to stop smoking, stop the medicine and call your clinician right away: suicidal thoughts or actions; new or worsening depression, anxiety, or panic attacks; agitation; restlessness; anger or violent behavior; acting dangerously; mania frenzied, abnormally excited or irritable mood; unusual thoughts or sensations; hallucinations; paranoia; confusion; or any other sudden or unusual behavior change. ensure family or caregivers know these warnings and contact your clinician if you cannot. your clinician will monitor you closely until symptoms improve. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your clinician advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. always allow the full prescribed time between bupropion doses. do not take extra doses to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? bupropion can cause side effects. common effects include drowsiness, anxiety, feeling over stimulated or excited, trouble sleeping, dry mouth, dizziness, headache, nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, tremor, decreased appetite, weight loss, constipation, heavy sweating, ringing in the ears, changes in taste, frequent urination, and sore throat. serious effects require immediate medical attention and include seizures; confusion; hallucinations; irrational fears; muscle or joint pain; rapid, pounding, or irregular heartbeat. stop bupropion and seek urgent care if you develop fever; rash or blisters; itching; hives; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; hoarseness; trouble breathing or swallowing; or chest pain. bupropion may cause other side effects. contact your clinician if you have any unusual problems while using it.

name: burosumab-twza injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? burosumab-twza injection is used to treat x-linked hypophosphatemia (xlh), an inherited disorder in which the body does not maintain normal phosphorus levels, leading to weak bones, in adults and in children 6 months of age and older. it is also used to treat tumor-induced osteomalacia (tio), a tumor-related condition that causes phosphorus loss and weak bones, when the tumor cannot be surgically removed, in adults and in children 2 years of age and older. burosumab-twza is a fibroblast growth factor 23 (fgf23)–blocking antibody that works by blocking a natural substance that causes the symptoms of xlh and tio. how should this medicine be used? burosumab-twza injection is a liquid given by subcutaneous (under the skin) injection by a doctor or nurse. for xlh: children 6 months to 17 years are usually treated every 2 weeks; adults are usually treated every 4 weeks. for tio: children 2 to 17 years are usually treated every 2 weeks; adults are usually treated every 4 weeks, and as the dose is increased, injections may be given every 2 weeks. injections are given in the upper arm, upper thigh, buttocks, or abdomen (stomach area), with a different site used each time. if you are taking phosphate supplements or certain active vitamin d products such as calcitriol (rocaltrol) or paricalcitol (zemplar), you must stop them 1 week before starting burosumab-twza. your doctor may increase your dose no more than once every 4 weeks, or may skip a dose, depending on your lab results. this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using burosumab-twza injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to burosumab-twza, any other medications, or any of the ingredients in the injection; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. some medications should not be taken with burosumab-twza; others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. discuss all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist. do not start, stop, or change any medications while using burosumab-twza without your doctor’s advice. tell your doctor if you have kidney disease; your doctor may tell you not to use burosumab-twza. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had restless legs syndrome (rls). tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while receiving burosumab-twza, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment to receive a dose, schedule another appointment as soon as possible. what side effects can this medication cause? burosumab-twza injection may cause side effects. common side effects include headache, vomiting, fever, pain in the arms, legs, or back, muscle pain, constipation, and dizziness. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away if you have redness, rash, hives, itching, swelling, pain, or bruising near or at the injection site; widespread rash or hives; or discomfort in the legs with a strong urge to move the legs, especially at night or when sitting or lying down. burosumab-twza injection may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: buspirone
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? buspirone is prescribed to treat anxiety disorders and for the short-term relief of anxiety symptoms. it belongs to a class of medicines called anxiolytics and works by adjusting levels of certain natural chemicals in the brain. how should this medicine be used? buspirone is an oral tablet usually taken twice daily. take it consistently the same way each time—either always with food or always without food. follow the directions on your prescription label; ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take exactly as directed and do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. your doctor may start with a low dose and increase it gradually, no more often than every 2 to 3 days. it may take several weeks to reach a dose that works for you. other uses for this medicine this medicine may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking buspirone, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to buspirone, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are taking, or have taken within the past two weeks, monoamine oxidase (mao) inhibitors such as isocarboxazid (marplan), linezolid (zyvox), methylene blue, phenelzine (nardil), selegiline (eldepryl, emsam, zelapar), or tranylcypromine (parnate). some medicines should not be used with buspirone, and others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. discuss all prescription, over-the-counter, and herbal products you take or plan to take before starting buspirone, and consult your doctor or pharmacist before starting, stopping, or changing any medications while taking buspirone. the nonprescription product cimetidine (tagamet) may interact with buspirone; tell your doctor and pharmacist if you use it before starting buspirone, and do not start it while taking buspirone without consulting your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney or liver disease, or a history of alcohol or drug abuse. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while taking buspirone, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking buspirone. this medicine may cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. alcohol can increase drowsiness; do not drink alcohol while taking buspirone. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid drinking large amounts of grapefruit juice while taking buspirone. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? buspirone may cause side effects. common side effects include dizziness, nausea, diarrhea, headache, excitement, confusion, fatigue, nervousness, difficulty falling or staying asleep, feelings of anger or irritability, lightheadedness, weakness, numbness or tingling, and increased sweating. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you experience rash, hives, itching, swelling of the face, eyes, mouth, throat, tongue, or lips; fast or irregular heartbeat; blurred vision; uncontrollable shaking of a part of the body; or symptoms such as agitation, fever, sweating, dizziness, flushing, confusion, fast or irregular heartbeat, shivering, severe muscle stiffness or twitching, seizures, hallucinations, loss of coordination, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.

name: busulfan
instructions: important warning: busulfan can cause a severe decrease in the number of blood cells made in your bone marrow. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all the medicines you take. using busulfan with other medicines that lower blood counts can increase the risk and severity of side effects. call your doctor immediately if you have fever, sore throat, persistent cough or congestion, signs of infection, or unusual bleeding or bruising. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor will order blood tests before, during, and after treatment to monitor your response and see if your blood counts are affected. your doctor may change your dose or tell you to stop busulfan temporarily to allow your blood counts to recover. follow your doctor’s instructions carefully and ask if you are unsure how much to take. busulfan may increase the risk of developing other cancers; discuss this risk with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? busulfan is used to treat certain cases of chronic myelogenous leukemia (cml), a cancer of white blood cells. it is an alkylating agent that works by slowing or stopping the growth of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? busulfan comes as a tablet taken by mouth, usually once daily. your treatment length depends on the other drugs you are taking, how well you respond, and your cancer type. take busulfan at the same time each day. follow your prescription label closely, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. take it exactly as directed; do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. your doctor may adjust your dose based on your response and side effects. tell your doctor how you feel during treatment. do not stop taking busulfan without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine busulfan tablets are also used with other drugs to destroy bone marrow and cancer cells in preparation for a bone marrow (stem cell) transplant. it may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking busulfan, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to busulfan, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you closely for side effects. some nonprescription products, including acetaminophen (tylenol), may interact with busulfan; do not start or stop any medication while taking busulfan without checking with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have received radiation therapy or other chemotherapy, have or have ever had seizures or a head injury, or if you previously took busulfan and your cancer did not respond. busulfan may disrupt menstrual periods in women and may stop sperm production in men; infertility can occur. do not assume you cannot get pregnant or make someone pregnant. use reliable birth control during treatment and for a time after; ask your doctor for details. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking busulfan, call your doctor right away; busulfan may harm the fetus. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your normal diet. ask your healthcare team before using over-the-counter products such as acetaminophen, and maintain adequate fluid intake if advised by your doctor. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? busulfan may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: nausea, diarrhea, loss of appetite or weight, constipation, mouth or throat sores, dry mouth, headache, trouble falling or staying asleep, feeling unusually anxious or worried, dizziness, swelling of the face, arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, chest pain, joint, muscle, or back pain, skin rash, itching or dry skin, darkened skin, hair loss. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have any of the following or any symptoms listed in the important warning section: black, tarry stools; red urine; unusual tiredness or weakness; difficulty breathing; changes in vision; vomiting; stomach pain; or seizures. busulfan may cause ovarian failure and may delay puberty in girls. talk to your doctor about the risk of infertility and the risks and benefits of receiving this medication. busulfan may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you experience any unusual problems while taking it.

name: busulfan injection
instructions: important warning: busulfan injection can cause a severe decrease in the number of blood cells made in your bone marrow. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all the medications you are taking. if you receive busulfan with other medicines that may also lower blood counts, side effects can be more severe. call your doctor immediately if you develop fever, sore throat, ongoing cough and congestion, or other signs of infection, or if you notice unusual bleeding or bruising. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory; your doctor will order tests before, during, and after treatment to monitor your response and to see if your blood cells are affected. busulfan may increase the risk of developing other cancers; talk to your doctor about these risks. why is this medication prescribed? busulfan injection is used to treat a certain type of chronic myelogenous leukemia (cml), a cancer of the white blood cells, and in combination with other medications to destroy bone marrow and cancer cells before a bone marrow (stem cell) transplant. busulfan is an alkylating agent that works by slowing or stopping the growth of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? busulfan comes as a liquid solution that is given intravenously over about 2 hours by a doctor or nurse in a medical facility. for transplant conditioning, it is usually given every 6 hours for 4 days, for a total of 16 doses, before the transplant. because busulfan can cause seizures, your doctor will give you another medication to help prevent seizures before and during therapy. other uses for this medicine: busulfan injection is also used with other drugs to destroy bone marrow and cancer cells in preparation for a bone marrow transplant in people with other types of cancer. it may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving busulfan injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to busulfan, any other medications, or any ingredients in busulfan injection. ask your pharmacist for a list of the ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take while receiving busulfan injection; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have previously received radiation therapy or other chemotherapy, or if you have ever had seizures or a head injury. know that busulfan may interfere with normal menstrual periods in women, may stop sperm production in men, and may cause infertility; however, do not assume that you or your partner cannot become pregnant. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor. do not plan to have children while receiving chemotherapy and for a time after treatment; use a reliable method of birth control. if you become pregnant while receiving busulfan, call your doctor immediately, as busulfan may harm the fetus. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other directions, you may continue your usual diet. follow any specific instructions from your transplant team about fluids, meals, or timing around infusions, and stay well hydrated as advised. what should i do if i forget a dose? busulfan injection is administered in a clinic or hospital. if you miss or cannot keep an appointment for a dose, contact your doctor or treatment center immediately to reschedule. do not attempt to make up a dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? busulfan may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: nausea; diarrhea; loss of appetite; weight loss; constipation; sores in the mouth and throat; dry mouth; headache; difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep; feeling unusually anxious or worried; dizziness; swelling of the face, arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; chest pain; joint, muscle, or back pain; rash; itching and dry skin; darkened skin; hair loss. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of these symptoms or those listed in the important warning section, call your doctor immediately: black, tarry stools; red urine; vomiting; stomach pain; unusual tiredness or weakness; difficulty breathing; seizures. busulfan may cause other side effects; if you notice anything unusual, call your doctor.

name: butabarbital
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? butabarbital is prescribed for short-term treatment of insomnia (trouble falling or staying asleep) and to relieve anxiety, including preoperative anxiety. it belongs to the barbiturate class and works by slowing brain activity. it may also be used for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for details. how should this medicine be used? butabarbital is available as an oral tablet and solution. for insomnia, take it at bedtime as needed. for anxiety before surgery, take it 60 to 90 minutes prior to the procedure. for ongoing anxiety, it is usually taken three to four times daily. if you are on a regular dosing schedule, take it at the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. your sleep should improve within 7 to 10 days; contact your doctor if it does not improve, worsens, or if you notice changes in mood, thoughts, or behavior. use butabarbital for short periods only. after about 2 weeks, it may become less effective, and long-term use can lead to dependence. do not take more, take it more often, or use it longer than prescribed. do not stop suddenly; your doctor will guide a gradual dose reduction. abrupt discontinuation can cause withdrawal symptoms such as anxiety, muscle twitching, hand tremors, weakness, dizziness, visual changes, nausea, vomiting, insomnia, and, in severe cases, seizures or extreme confusion. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to butabarbital; other barbiturates (such as amobarbital, pentobarbital, phenobarbital, or secobarbital); tartrazine (a yellow dye); aspirin; or any medication ingredients. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you use; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for interactions. do not take butabarbital if you have porphyria. tell your doctor if you drink or have drunk heavily, use or have used recreational drugs, or have misused medications; if you have ever had suicidal thoughts or attempts; or if you have or have had asthma or other breathing problems, depression, seizures, or kidney or liver disease. if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding, discuss risks; call your doctor right away if you become pregnant. butabarbital can reduce the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives (pills, patches, rings, injections, implants, or iuds); ask about reliable nonhormonal or additional birth control methods, and contact your doctor if you miss a period or think you might be pregnant. adults 65 years and older generally should not use butabarbital because safer or more effective alternatives are available. before any surgery or dental procedure, tell the clinician you take butabarbital. this medication may cause daytime drowsiness, reduced alertness, and increase fall risk; use caution when getting out of bed, and do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. do not drink alcohol while taking butabarbital; it can worsen side effects. some people taking sleep medicines engage in activities (such as driving, preparing and eating food, having sex, or making phone calls) while not fully awake and later do not remember; if this happens, contact your doctor immediately. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you take butabarbital on a regular schedule, take the missed dose when you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. if you use it only as needed for sleep, skip the missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include drowsiness, difficulty sleeping or staying asleep, nightmares, headache, dizziness, depression, nervousness, agitation, excitement, confusion, restlessness, nausea, vomiting, and constipation. call your doctor right away if you have serious effects such as hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that are not there), slow or shallow breathing, slow heartbeat, fainting, hives, rash, itching, swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, trouble breathing or swallowing, or hoarseness. contact your doctor if you experience any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: butoconazole vaginal cream
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? butoconazole is used to treat vaginal yeast infections. it may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? butoconazole is a vaginal cream typically used once daily at bedtime. follow the directions on your prescription label and use exactly as directed; do not use more, less, or more often than prescribed. to apply: fill the supplied applicator to the indicated mark. lie on your back with knees bent and apart. if you are not pregnant, insert the applicator high into the vagina and press the plunger to release the cream. if you are pregnant, insert gently. if you feel resistance or cannot insert comfortably, stop and call your doctor. remove and discard the applicator. wash your hands immediately to avoid spreading the infection. apply at bedtime and remain lying down afterward except to wash your hands. you may wear a sanitary pad to protect clothing. do not use tampons (they can absorb the medication). do not douche unless your doctor tells you to. continue using butoconazole for the full course even if you feel better, including during your menstrual period. do not stop without consulting your doctor. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to butoconazole or any other medicines. provide a list of all prescription and nonprescription drugs and vitamins/supplements you take, especially antibiotics and vitamins. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had diabetes, immune system problems, human immunodeficiency virus (hiv) infection, or acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (aids). tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using butoconazole, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are needed unless your doctor advises otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? insert the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? butoconazole may cause burning or irritation in the vagina when applied, stomach (abdominal) pain, fever, or foul-smelling vaginal discharge. if any of these occur, contact your doctor immediately.

name: butorphanol injection
instructions: important warning: butorphanol injection can be habit forming. use it exactly as directed. do not use more or less than prescribed, do not use it more often, do not stop it suddenly, and do not use it in any way other than your doctor directs. tell your doctor if you or a family member drinks or has drunk large amounts of alcohol, uses or has used street drugs, has overused prescription medicines, has had an overdose, or if you have or have had depression or another mental illness. butorphanol injection can cause serious or life-threatening breathing problems, especially during the first 24 to 72 hours of treatment and any time your dose is increased. call your doctor right away or get emergency help if you have slowed breathing, long pauses between breaths, or shortness of breath. this medicine can harm or cause death to others who use it, especially children. store it securely to prevent accidental or intentional use by others. using certain other medicines, drinking alcohol, or using street drugs with butorphanol increases the risk of dangerous breathing problems. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and supplements you take or plan to take; your doctor may change doses and monitor you closely. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. regular use during pregnancy can cause life-threatening withdrawal in your newborn after birth. your doctor or pharmacist will give you a medication guide; read it carefully and ask questions. discuss the risks and benefits of butorphanol injection with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? butorphanol injection is used to relieve severe pain. it is also used to relieve pain during labor and to prevent pain and decrease awareness before or during surgery. it is an opioid agonist–antagonist that works by changing how the body senses pain. how should this medicine be used? butorphanol injection is a liquid solution given into a muscle or vein. for pain, it is usually given every 3 to 4 hours as needed. for surgery, give a dose 60 to 90 minutes before the procedure and then as needed during surgery. for labor, give once every 4 hours, but not within 4 hours of the expected delivery. you may receive this in a hospital, or you may be instructed to use it at home. if using at home, use exactly as directed. ask your doctor or pharmacist about having rescue medicines (naloxone or nalmefene) available while you use butorphanol; these reverse life-threatening opioid overdose and can be obtained over the counter or by prescription. make sure you and people around you know how to recognize an overdose, how to use the rescue medicine, and what to do until emergency help arrives. your healthcare provider will teach you how to use it. if overdose symptoms occur, a caregiver should give the first dose of naloxone, call 911 immediately, and stay with you, watching closely until help arrives. if symptoms return, they should give another dose; additional doses may be given every 2 to 3 minutes if symptoms recur before help arrives. do not stop butorphanol suddenly without talking to your doctor. stopping abruptly may cause withdrawal (nervousness, agitation, shaking, diarrhea, chills, sweating, trouble sleeping, confusion, loss of coordination, or hallucinations). your doctor will taper your dose gradually. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using butorphanol, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this drug, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your allergy symptoms. some medicines must not be used with butorphanol. discuss all medicines you take or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist before receiving butorphanol, and do not start, stop, or change any medicine while using butorphanol without medical advice. tell your doctor if you are taking or have taken within the past two weeks any monoamine oxidase inhibitor (maoi), including isocarboxazid, linezolid, methylene blue, phenelzine, selegiline, or tranylcypromine. the herbal products st. john’s wort and tryptophan may interact with butorphanol; tell your doctor and pharmacist if you take them, and do not start them while using butorphanol without medical advice. tell your doctor if you have or have had slowed breathing, asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (copd), other lung problems, a blockage or narrowing of the stomach or intestines, or paralytic ileus; your doctor may advise against butorphanol. also tell your doctor if you have or have had a brain tumor or other causes of increased intracranial pressure; seizures; or pancreas, gallbladder, thyroid, heart, kidney, or liver disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding, tell your doctor. if you become pregnant while using butorphanol, call your doctor. this medicine may reduce fertility in men and women; discuss risks with your doctor. butorphanol can cause drowsiness and dizziness. do not drive or operate machinery for at least one hour after a dose, and after one hour do not drive until you are sure you are not dizzy, drowsy, or less alert than usual. do not drink alcohol while using butorphanol; alcohol can worsen side effects. drowsiness, dizziness, or fainting may occur, especially in the first hour after a dose; have a safe place to lie down if needed. butorphanol may cause constipation; ask your doctor about diet changes or medicines to prevent or treat constipation. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is usually used as needed. if your doctor has told you to use it on a regular schedule and you miss a dose, use it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? butorphanol injection may cause side effects. call your doctor if these are severe or do not go away: nausea, vomiting, decreased sexual desire, or trouble getting or keeping an erection. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or get emergency help if you have any of the following, or any symptoms listed in the important warning section: slow or irregular breathing; seizures; agitation; hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that are not there); fever; sweating; confusion; fast heartbeat; shivering; severe muscle stiffness or twitching; loss of coordination; nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, loss of appetite, weakness, or dizziness; rash; hives; trouble breathing or swallowing; swelling of the face, mouth, tongue, or throat; chest pain or heartbeat changes; extreme drowsiness; new pain or pain from light touch or normal activities; trouble swallowing, regurgitation of food into the throat or mouth, or chest area pain; unusual snoring or long pauses in breathing during sleep. butorphanol injection may cause other side effects. contact your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: butorphanol nasal spray
instructions: important warning: butorphanol nasal spray can be habit forming. use exactly as prescribed. do not use more or less, use it more often, stop suddenly, or use it in any way other than directed by your doctor. tell your doctor if you or a family member drinks or has ever drunk large amounts of alcohol, uses or has ever used street drugs, has overused prescription medicines, has had an overdose, or if you have or have ever had depression or another mental illness. serious or life threatening breathing problems can occur, especially during the first 24 to 72 hours of treatment and whenever your dose is increased. if you have slowed breathing, long pauses between breaths, or shortness of breath, call your doctor right away or seek emergency care. this medicine can harm or be fatal to others who take it, especially children. store securely to prevent accidental or intentional use by others. taking certain medicines, drinking alcohol, or using street drugs with butorphanol increases the risk of dangerous breathing problems. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and supplements you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses and will monitor you closely. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, regular use may cause life threatening withdrawal in your newborn. you will receive a medication guide; read it and ask questions as needed. discuss the risks and benefits of butorphanol for your condition with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? butorphanol nasal spray is used to relieve severe pain. it is an opioid agonist antagonist that changes how your body senses pain. how should this medicine be used? butorphanol nasal spray is a liquid sprayed into the nose. use every 3 to 4 hours as needed for pain. pain relief should begin soon after use. your doctor may allow a second dose if pain persists 60 to 90 minutes after the first dose; do not take a second dose unless your doctor has told you to do so. if your pain is not controlled, worsens, you develop new pain, or you feel unusually sensitive to pain, call your doctor. do not use more or more often than prescribed; doing so can cause a dangerous overdose. ask your doctor or pharmacist about access to rescue medicines such as naloxone or nalmefene while using butorphanol. these medicines reverse life threatening opioid overdose and are available over the counter or by prescription. make sure you and people around you know overdose signs, how to use the rescue medicine, and what to do until emergency help arrives. your doctor or pharmacist will teach you how to use it. if overdose symptoms occur, a person should give the first dose of naloxone or nalmefene, call 911 immediately, and stay with you, watching closely until help arrives. if symptoms return, another dose may be given every 2 to 3 minutes until medical help takes over. do not stop butorphanol suddenly. stopping abruptly may cause withdrawal symptoms such as nervousness, agitation, tremor, diarrhea, chills, sweating, trouble sleeping, poor coordination, confusion, or hallucinations. your doctor will taper your dose gradually. before first use, read the manufacturer instructions and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. to use: gently blow your nose. remove the clear cover and protective clip. prime a new pump or one unused for 48 hours or longer by aiming away from yourself, others, and animals and pumping firmly and quickly up to 8 times until a fine spray appears. hold the bottle with the nozzle between your first and second fingers and your thumb on the bottom. insert the tip about 1/2 inch (1 cm) into one nostril, pointing toward the back of your nose. close the other nostril with a finger and tilt your head slightly forward. pump once firmly and quickly and sniff gently with your mouth closed. remove the sprayer, tilt your head back, and sniff gently for a few seconds. replace the protective clip and cover, and return the bottle to the child resistant container. you will receive a medication guide at the start of treatment and with each refill; read it and ask questions. other uses for this medicine this medicine may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to butorphanol, any of its ingredients, or other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your allergy symptoms. some medicines must not be used with butorphanol; discuss all medicines you take or plan to take before starting butorphanol, and consult your doctor before starting, stopping, or changing any medicine while using it. tell your doctor if you are taking or have taken within the past 2 weeks any of the following: isocarboxazid, linezolid, methylene blue, phenelzine, selegiline, or tranylcypromine. st. john’s wort and tryptophan may interact with butorphanol; tell your doctor and pharmacist if you use them, and do not start them without medical advice. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had slowed breathing, asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, other lung problems, or any blockage or narrowing of the stomach or intestines, including paralytic ileus; your doctor may tell you not to use butorphanol. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had a brain tumor or increased intracranial pressure, seizures, or pancreas, gallbladder, thyroid, heart, kidney, or liver disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast feeding, tell your doctor. if you become pregnant, call your doctor. this medicine may reduce fertility in men and women. butorphanol can cause drowsiness or dizziness. do not drive or operate machinery for at least 1 hour after using and until you are sure you are not dizzy, drowsy, or less alert than usual. do not drink alcohol; it can worsen side effects. drowsiness, dizziness, or fainting can occur, especially during the first hour after a dose; have a safe, comfortable place to lie down if needed. butorphanol may cause constipation; ask your doctor about diet changes or medicines to prevent or treat constipation. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor instructs otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is usually used as needed. if your doctor has told you to use it on a schedule and you miss a dose, use it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use a double dose. what side effects can this medication cause? butorphanol nasal spray may cause side effects. call your doctor if common effects are severe or do not go away, including nausea, vomiting, decreased sexual desire, or trouble getting or keeping an erection. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have seizures; slowed or irregular breathing; agitation; hallucinations; signs of serotonin syndrome such as fever, sweating, confusion, fast heartbeat, shivering, severe muscle stiffness or twitching, loss of coordination, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea; extreme drowsiness; nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, weakness, or dizziness; chest pain or irregular or pounding heartbeat; or signs of an allergic reaction such as rash, hives, hoarseness, trouble breathing or swallowing, or swelling of the face, mouth, tongue, or throat. also call if you develop new pain or pain from light touch or routine activities, difficulty swallowing, regurgitation of food, chest area pain, unusual snoring, or long pauses in breathing during sleep. other side effects may occur; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medicine.

name: econazole topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? econazole is used to treat common fungal skin infections such as athlete’s foot, jock itch, and ringworm. it may sometimes be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? econazole comes as a cream to apply to the skin. apply a thin layer to the affected area once or twice daily (morning and/or evening). typical treatment lasts 2 weeks; some infections may require up to 6 weeks. follow the directions on your prescription label exactly. do not use more or less, or more often, than prescribed. clean and dry the area before application, then gently rub in the cream until it is absorbed, using just enough to cover the area. wash your hands after applying (unless treating the hands). continue using econazole even if symptoms improve, and do not stop without talking to your doctor. what special precautions should i follow? before using econazole, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to econazole, other antifungals, or any ingredients in the product. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take while using econazole; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding, talk to your doctor; if you become pregnant while using econazole, call your doctor. avoid contact with the eyes, mouth, inside the nose, vagina, or broken skin; do not use on nails or scalp unless directed by your doctor. do not cover treated areas with airtight dressings unless instructed. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not apply extra cream to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? econazole may cause side effects. if you experience itching, burning, irritation, stinging, redness, or a rash at the application site, call your doctor promptly.

name: eculizumab injection
instructions: notice: eculizumab injection, eculizumab-aeeb injection, and eculizumab-aagh injection are biologic medicines made from living organisms. eculizumab-aeeb and eculizumab-aagh are biosimilars to eculizumab injection, meaning they work as well and are as safe as the reference product. in this document, eculizumab injection refers to any of these three products. important warning: treatment with eculizumab increases the risk of meningococcal infection during therapy and for some time afterward, which can rapidly lead to death. you must receive a meningococcal vaccine at least 2 weeks before starting eculizumab. if you have been vaccinated before, you may need a booster. if treatment must begin right away, you will receive the vaccine as soon as possible and take an antibiotic for as long as your doctor recommends. even after vaccination, you can still develop meningococcal disease during or after treatment. call your doctor immediately or seek emergency care if you have any of the following: headache with nausea or vomiting; fever; stiff neck or stiff back; fever with rash; fever with a fast heart rate; confusion; muscle aches or other flu-like symptoms; or eyes that are sensitive to light. tell your doctor if you have a fever or other signs of infection before starting treatment. you will not receive eculizumab if you currently have a meningococcal infection. your doctor will give you a patient safety card about the risk of meningococcal disease; carry it with you at all times during treatment and for 3 months after your last dose, and show it to all health care providers. eculizumab can only be prescribed through the soliris rems, bkemv, or epysqli rems programs by a certified prescriber who has counseled you on meningococcal risk, given you a safety card, and ensured you received a meningococcal vaccine. you will receive the manufacturer medication guide when you start and each time you receive a dose; read it and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. why is this medication prescribed? eculizumab injection is used to treat paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria pnh, a type of anemia caused by destruction of red blood cells; atypical hemolytic uremic syndrome ahus, a condition in which small blood clots form and damage blood vessels, blood cells, kidneys, and other organs; a certain type of myasthenia gravis mg that causes muscle weakness; and a certain type of neuromyelitis optica spectrum disorder nmosd that affects the optic nerves and spinal cord. eculizumab is an immunotherapy that blocks part of the immune system that can damage blood cells in pnh, promote clot formation in ahus, harm parts of the central nervous system in nmosd, or interfere with communication between nerves and muscles in mg. how should this medicine be used? eculizumab is given as an intravenous infusion over at least 35 minutes by a health care professional. adults usually receive it once a week for 5 weeks, then once every other week. children receive it on a schedule based on age and body weight. additional doses may be given before or after certain treatments for pnh, ahus, mg, or nmosd. your doctor will likely start with a lower dose and increase it after 4 weeks. you will be monitored during the infusion and for 1 hour afterward for serious reactions. tell your doctor right away if you have chest pain; feeling faint; rash; hives; swelling of the eyes, face, lips, tongue, or throat; hoarseness; or trouble breathing or swallowing. your doctor may slow or stop the infusion if these occur. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving eculizumab, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to eculizumab or any ingredient in its products; ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may change doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant during treatment. if a child will be treated, the child should be vaccinated against streptococcus pneumoniae and haemophilus influenzae type b hib before starting therapy; discuss these and any other needed vaccines with the child’s doctor. if you are treated for pnh, red blood cell destruction may increase after stopping eculizumab; your doctor will monitor you and may order lab tests during the first 8 weeks after the last dose. call your doctor right away if you develop confusion, chest pain, trouble breathing, or any unusual symptoms. if you are treated for ahus, blood clots may form after stopping eculizumab; your doctor will monitor you and may order lab tests during the first 12 weeks after the last dose. call your doctor right away if you have sudden trouble speaking or understanding speech; confusion; sudden weakness or numbness of the face, arm, or leg especially on one side; sudden trouble walking, dizziness, loss of balance or coordination; fainting; seizures; chest pain; trouble breathing; swelling of the arms or legs; or any unusual symptoms. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor instructs otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment for a dose, call your doctor right away. what side effects can this medication cause? eculizumab may cause side effects. contact your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: headache; runny nose; pain or swelling in the nose or throat; cough; trouble falling or staying asleep; unusual tiredness; dizziness; pain in the arms, legs, muscles, or joints; nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea; stomach pain; painful or difficult urination. some side effects can be serious. if you have any of the symptoms listed in the important warning or special precautions sections, or if you develop swelling of the arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; pale skin, weakness, fast heartbeat, or shortness of breath, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical care. eculizumab may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice any unusual problems during treatment.

name: edaravone injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? edaravone injection is used to treat amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (als, lou gehrig's disease), a condition in which the nerves that control muscle movement slowly die, causing the muscles to shrink and weaken. edaravone is in a class of medications called antioxidants and may help slow nerve damage associated with worsening als symptoms. how should this medicine be used? edaravone injection is a liquid solution given by intravenous infusion over 60 minutes by a healthcare professional in a doctor's office or medical facility. it is usually given once daily for the first 14 days of a 28-day cycle. after the first cycle, it is given once daily for the first 10 days of each 28-day cycle. your doctor will determine how often you should receive edaravone based on your response to treatment. edaravone may cause serious reactions during or after an infusion, and your doctor may stop treatment if certain side effects occur. tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment, and call your doctor right away or get emergency medical help if you develop any of the following during or after an infusion: wheezing or difficulty breathing, shortness of breath, cough, fainting, flushing, itching, rash, hives, swelling of the throat, tongue, or face, throat tightness, or difficulty swallowing. ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving edaravone injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to edaravone, any other medications, sodium bisulfite, or any ingredients in the injection. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, and nutritional supplements you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had asthma. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while receiving edaravone, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment to receive edaravone, call your doctor as soon as possible. what side effects can this medication cause? edaravone injection may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: bruising, difficulty walking, headache, red, itchy, or scaly rash. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following or the symptoms listed in the how section, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment: difficulty breathing, chest tightness, wheezing, and coughing (especially in people with asthma). edaravone injection may cause other side effects.

name: edaravone oral
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? edaravone is used to treat amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (als, lou gehrig’s disease), a condition in which the nerves that control movement gradually die, leading to muscle weakness and wasting. it is an antioxidant and is thought to slow the nerve damage that contributes to the progression of als symptoms. how should this medicine be used? edaravone comes as an oral suspension to be swallowed or given through a feeding tube. take it in the morning on an empty stomach. if you ate a high-fat meal (about 800–1000 calories with 50% fat) the night before, wait at least 8 hours before taking it; after a low-fat meal (about 400–500 calories with 25% fat), wait at least 4 hours; after a nutrition supplement such as a 250‑calorie protein drink, wait at least 2 hours. after dosing, wait at least 1 hour before eating or drinking anything other than water. take it at the same time each day. follow the directions on your prescription label exactly; do not take more or less or more often than prescribed. dosing schedule: once daily for the first 14 days of a 28‑day cycle, then once daily for the first 10 days of each subsequent 28‑day cycle. your doctor will decide how long and how often you should continue based on your response. before opening, turn the bottle upside down and shake vigorously for at least 30 seconds. use only the supplied oral syringe to measure each dose. the suspension may be administered through silicone or pvc nasogastric (ng) or percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (peg) tubes. after giving a dose through a feeding tube, flush the tube with at least 1 ounce (30 ml) of water using a catheter-tip syringe. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking edaravone, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to edaravone, sodium bisulfite, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the suspension; your pharmacist can provide a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and nutritional supplements you are taking or plan to take, as your doses may need adjustment or monitoring for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had asthma. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking edaravone, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor instructs otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? edaravone may cause side effects. common effects include bruising, difficulty walking, headache, and a red, itchy, or scaly rash. some side effects can be serious; seek immediate medical attention if you have trouble breathing, chest tightness, wheezing, or coughing (especially if you have asthma). edaravone may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice any unusual symptoms while taking this medication.

name: edoxaban
instructions: important warning: if you have atrial fibrillation (an irregular heartbeat that can lead to blood clots and stroke) and are taking edoxaban to help prevent strokes or serious blood clots, your risk of stroke may increase if you stop this medicine. do not stop taking edoxaban without talking to your doctor. continue taking it even if you feel well, and refill your prescription before you run out so you do not miss doses. if edoxaban must be stopped, your doctor may prescribe another anticoagulant (“blood thinner”) to help prevent clots and lower your risk of stroke. if you receive epidural or spinal anesthesia or have a spinal puncture while taking a blood thinner such as edoxaban, you can develop a blood clot near your spine that may cause long-term or permanent paralysis. your risk is higher if you have an epidural catheter (a tube in your spine), spinal problems, prior spine surgery, or multiple spinal punctures. tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are taking anagrelide; aspirin or other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as ibuprofen, indomethacin, ketoprofen, or naproxen; cilostazol; clopidogrel; dipyridamole; eptifibatide; heparin; prasugrel; ticagrelor; ticlopidine; tirofiban; or warfarin. call your doctor immediately if you have back pain, muscle weakness, numbness or tingling (especially in your legs), trouble controlling your bowels or bladder, or inability to move your legs. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor will check your kidney function before and during treatment. you will receive a medication guide; read it carefully and ask any questions. discuss the risks and benefits of edoxaban with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? edoxaban is used to prevent stroke or blood clots in certain people with atrial fibrillation (irregular heartbeat) and to treat deep vein thrombosis (dvt; a blood clot usually in the leg) and pulmonary embolism (pe; a blood clot in the lung). edoxaban is a factor xa inhibitor that works by blocking a natural clotting factor to reduce clot formation. how should this medicine be used? edoxaban comes as an oral tablet. take it once daily, with or without food, at the same time each day. take edoxaban exactly as directed. do not take more or less, or take it more often than prescribed. if you cannot swallow the tablets, crush them and mix with 2 to 3 ounces (60 to 90 ml) of water or applesauce and take the mixture right away. if you have a gastric tube, the crushed tablet may be mixed with water and given through the tube. ask your doctor or pharmacist how to take the medication and follow those instructions carefully. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking edoxaban, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to edoxaban, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your allergy symptoms. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you closely for side effects. do not take edoxaban if you have heavy bleeding that will not stop. tell your doctor if you weigh 132 pounds (60 kilograms) or less, and if you have or have ever had any bleeding problems, a mechanical heart valve, antiphospholipid syndrome (aps), cancer of the stomach or intestine, or heart, kidney, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking edoxaban, call your doctor. if you are having any surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking edoxaban. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is the next day, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? edoxaban may cause side effects. common side effects include rash, unusual tiredness or weakness, dizziness, and pale skin. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the symptoms listed in the important warning above or any of the following, stop taking edoxaban and call your doctor immediately: bleeding gums; nosebleeds; heavy vaginal bleeding; red, pink, or brown urine; red or black, tarry stools; coughing up or vomiting blood or material that looks like coffee grounds. edoxaban may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: efavirenz
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? efavirenz is used with other antiretroviral medicines to treat human immunodeficiency virus (hiv) infection. it belongs to a class of medications called non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (nnrtis) and works by lowering the amount of hiv in the blood. although it does not cure hiv, it helps reduce the risk of developing acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (aids) and hiv-related illnesses. using these medicines as prescribed, along with safer sex and other lifestyle measures, may lower the risk of transmitting hiv to others. it may also be used with other medications to help prevent hiv infection after accidental exposure; discuss risks and benefits with your doctor. how should this medicine be used? efavirenz comes as capsules or tablets taken by mouth once daily with plenty of water on an empty stomach, at least 1 hour before or 2 hours after a meal. taking it at bedtime may lessen certain side effects. take it at the same time each day and exactly as directed; do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. swallow tablets and capsules whole; do not split, chew, or crush. if you cannot swallow capsules whole, you may open a capsule and mix its contents with 1 to 2 teaspoons of soft food (such as applesauce, grape jelly, or yogurt) in a small container. avoid spilling or spreading the powder into the air. mix until the texture is grainy but not lumpy, and eat the mixture within 30 minutes. then add another 2 teaspoons of the same soft food to the empty container, stir, and eat to ensure the full dose. do not eat for the next 2 hours. for infants who cannot eat solids, you may mix the capsule contents with 2 teaspoons of room-temperature infant formula in a small container, avoiding spills or airborne powder. the mixture should look grainy, not lumpy. use an oral syringe to give the mixture within 30 minutes. then add another 2 teaspoons of formula to the empty container, stir, and give with the oral syringe to ensure the full dose. do not give the mixture in a bottle, and do not feed the baby for the next 2 hours. efavirenz controls hiv but does not cure it; continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop taking efavirenz without talking to your doctor. missing doses or stopping treatment may make your infection harder to treat. what special precautions should i follow? before taking efavirenz, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to it, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your reaction. efavirenz is also available as part of the fixed-dose combination atripla; do not take efavirenz separately if you are already taking atripla to avoid duplication. some medicines must not be used with efavirenz, and many others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and herbal products you use or plan to use; do not start, stop, or change any medicine while taking efavirenz without medical advice. do not take st. john’s wort with efavirenz. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had prolonged qt interval (a rare heart rhythm problem), other heart rhythm issues, significant alcohol use, use of recreational drugs, overuse of prescription medications, depression or other mental illness, seizures, hepatitis or other liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. you should not become pregnant while taking efavirenz and for 12 weeks after your final dose. if you can become pregnant, you will need a negative pregnancy test before starting, and you must use effective birth control during treatment. efavirenz may reduce the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives (pills, patches, rings, implants, injections), so do not rely on them alone; use a barrier method (such as a condom or diaphragm) in addition to any other method you choose. ask your doctor to help you select effective options. call your doctor if you become pregnant. if you are breastfeeding or plan to breastfeed, discuss risks because both the medicine and hiv can pass into breast milk. efavirenz may cause drowsiness, dizziness, or trouble concentrating; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. ask your doctor about safe use of alcohol; alcohol can worsen side effects. as your immune system improves on hiv treatment, it may react to hidden infections (immune reconstitution), causing new or worsening symptoms—contact your doctor if this occurs. changes in body fat may happen (increased fat in the breasts, upper back/neck “buffalo hump,” or abdomen, and loss of fat from the face, legs, or arms). efavirenz can affect mood, thoughts, or mental health; call your doctor right away if you have depression, suicidal thoughts or actions, anger or aggression, hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that are not there), loss of touch with reality, or other unusual thoughts. efavirenz may rarely cause serious nervous system problems months or years after starting; call your doctor immediately if you develop balance or coordination problems, confusion, memory issues, or other changes suggesting abnormal brain function. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor about eating grapefruit or drinking grapefruit juice while taking efavirenz. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? efavirenz may cause side effects. common effects include nausea, vomiting, headache, confusion, forgetfulness, trouble falling or staying asleep, and abnormal or vivid dreams. call your doctor immediately if you have any serious symptoms, including fever; rash; itching; peeling, blistering, or shedding skin; swelling of the face; mouth sores; pink eye; fainting; irregular heartbeat; extreme tiredness; lack of energy; loss of appetite; pain in the upper right abdomen; unusual bleeding or bruising; yellowing of the skin or eyes; flu-like symptoms; or seizures. efavirenz may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: efavirenz, emtricitabine, and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate
