instructions: important warning: efavirenz, emtricitabine, and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (df) should not be used to treat hepatitis b virus (hbv) infection. if you have or think you may have hbv, your doctor may test you before starting treatment. if you have hbv and stop taking this medication, your hepatitis may suddenly worsen. your doctor will examine you and order blood tests regularly for several months after you stop. keep all appointments. discuss the risks and benefits of efavirenz, emtricitabine, and tenofovir df with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? this combination is used to treat human immunodeficiency virus (hiv-1) infection. efavirenz is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (nnrti); emtricitabine and tenofovir are nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (nrtis). together they lower the amount of hiv in the body. they will not cure hiv but can reduce the risk of developing acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (aids) and hiv-related illnesses and, with safer practices, can lower the risk of transmitting hiv to others. how should this medicine be used? efavirenz, emtricitabine, and tenofovir df comes as an oral tablet taken once daily with water on an empty stomach, at least 1 hour before or 2 hours after a meal. take it at the same time each day; taking it at bedtime may lessen certain side effects. take exactly as directed; do not take more or less or more often than prescribed. continue even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor. skipping doses or stopping even briefly may lead to drug resistance and make hiv harder to treat. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine: it may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to this medication or any of its ingredients, or to any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your reaction. some medicines must not be taken with efavirenz, emtricitabine, and tenofovir df; others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. discuss all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and herbal products you take or plan to take, including st. john’s wort. do not start, stop, or change any medicine without your doctor’s advice. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had: a prolonged qt interval (a rare heart rhythm problem), low potassium or magnesium levels, heavy alcohol use, use of street drugs, prescription drug misuse, hbv (see important warning), depression or other mental illness, bone problems including osteoporosis or fractures, seizures, or liver or kidney disease. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, you should not become pregnant during treatment and for 12 weeks after your final dose. if you can become pregnant, you must have a negative pregnancy test before starting and use effective birth control during treatment. because efavirenz can reduce the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives (pills, patches, rings, implants, injections), do not rely on these alone; use a barrier method (such as a condom or diaphragm) with any other method you choose. ask your doctor to help select suitable birth control. call your doctor right away if you become pregnant. if you are breastfeeding or plan to breastfeed, discuss the risks; hiv and some of this medicine can pass into breast milk. you should be aware that body fat may increase or shift to the upper back and neck (“buffalo hump”), breasts, and abdomen, with loss of fat from the face, arms, and legs. while treating hiv, your immune system may get stronger and start to fight infections already in your body (immune reconstitution), causing new or worsening symptoms; report new symptoms to your doctor. this medicine may cause drowsiness, dizziness, or trouble concentrating; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. efavirenz can cause changes in mood, behavior, or mental health; call your doctor right away if you have depression, suicidal thoughts or behavior, aggression, hallucinations, unusual thoughts, or loss of touch with reality; make sure your family knows these symptoms and can seek help if needed. ask your doctor about alcohol use, as alcohol may worsen side effects. efavirenz may rarely cause serious nervous system problems, including encephalopathy, months or years after you start; call your doctor immediately if you develop problems with balance or coordination, confusion, memory problems, or other signs of abnormal brain function at any time during treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor about eating grapefruit or drinking grapefruit juice while taking this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include headache, diarrhea, difficulty falling or staying asleep, feeling agitated, worried, or nervous, unusual dreams, and rash. serious side effects can occur; call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have any of the following: decreased urination or urinating large amounts, increased thirst; ongoing or worsening bone pain or bone fractures; pain in the arms, hands, feet, or legs; muscle pain or weakness; severe rash; skin peeling, blistering, or shedding; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, legs, ankles, or feet; trouble swallowing or breathing; hoarseness; numbness, burning, or tingling in the hands, arms, feet, or legs; seizures; signs of liver problems such as nausea, vomiting, extreme tiredness, flu-like symptoms, yellowing of the skin or eyes, light-colored stools, dark yellow or brown urine, loss of appetite, pain in the upper right abdomen, or unusual bleeding or bruising; signs of lactic acidosis or other serious reactions such as weakness, muscle pain, shortness of breath or rapid breathing, stomach pain with nausea and vomiting, cold or blue hands and feet, dizziness or lightheadedness, or fast or irregular heartbeat. efavirenz, emtricitabine, and tenofovir df may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you experience any unusual symptoms.

name: efavirenz, lamivudine, and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (df)
instructions: important warning: efavirenz, lamivudine, and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (df) is not used to treat hepatitis b virus (hbv). if you have or may have hbv, your doctor may test you for hbv before starting this medicine. if you have hbv and stop taking this medicine, your liver disease may suddenly worsen. your doctor will examine you and order lab tests regularly for several months after you stop treatment. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor will order certain tests before and during treatment to check your response to this medicine. discuss the risks of taking efavirenz, lamivudine, and tenofovir df with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? the combination of efavirenz, lamivudine, and tenofovir df is used to treat hiv. efavirenz is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (nnrti). lamivudine and tenofovir df are nucleoside/nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitors (nrtis). together they reduce the amount of hiv in the body. although not a cure, this medicine may lower your chance of developing aids and hiv-related illnesses, and—along with safer practices—can reduce the risk of transmitting hiv to others. how should this medicine be used? take one tablet by mouth once daily on an empty stomach, at least 1 hour before or 2 hours after a meal. take it at the same time each day; taking it at bedtime may lessen certain side effects. take exactly as directed. do not take more or less or more often than prescribed. continue even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor. interruptions or missed doses can lead to drug resistance and make hiv harder to treat. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to efavirenz, lamivudine, tenofovir df, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your reaction. some medicines must not be taken with this combination; others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all medicines, vitamins, and herbal products you take or plan to take, and do not start, stop, or change any medicine while taking this drug unless your healthcare provider approves. do not take st. john’s wort with this medicine. tell your doctor if you have any condition noted in the important warning section, or if you have or have ever had a prolonged qt interval (a heart rhythm problem), low potassium or magnesium, bone problems (including osteoporosis or fractures), seizures, hepatitis c or other liver disease, or kidney disease; and if you drink or have drunk large amounts of alcohol, use or have used street drugs, have misused prescription medicines, or have depression or other mental illness. for children taking this medicine, tell the doctor if they have or have ever had pancreatitis. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, do not become pregnant during treatment. you may need a negative pregnancy test before starting and must use effective birth control during treatment and for 12 weeks after your final dose. this medicine can reduce the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives (pills, patches, rings, implants, injections); use a barrier method in addition to any other birth control method. if you become pregnant, call your doctor right away. if you are breastfeeding or plan to breastfeed, do not breastfeed because the medicine and hiv can pass into breast milk; discuss risks with your doctor. be aware that body fat may increase or shift to your upper back and neck (“buffalo hump”), breasts, and stomach, with loss of fat from the face, legs, and arms. as your immune system strengthens, it may begin to fight hidden infections (immune reconstitution); tell your doctor about any new or worsening symptoms. this medicine can cause dizziness, drowsiness, trouble concentrating, sleep problems, unusual dreams, or hallucinations, usually improving within 2 to 4 weeks. alcohol and medicines such as antidepressants, anxiety medicines, antipsychotics, seizure medicines, sedatives, sleeping pills, or tranquilizers can worsen these effects. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how you are affected. it may also cause changes in thoughts, behavior, or mental health. call your doctor immediately if you have depression, suicidal thoughts or actions, anger or aggression, hallucinations, strange thoughts, loss of touch with reality, or difficulty moving or talking normally; ensure family members know these warning signs. efavirenz may rarely cause serious nervous system problems months or years after starting; call your doctor right away if you develop problems with balance or coordination, confusion, memory problems, or other signs of abnormal brain function at any time. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? efavirenz, lamivudine, and tenofovir df may cause side effects. common side effects include headache, abdominal pain, diarrhea, heartburn, nausea, vomiting, back, joint, or muscle pain, low energy, and burning, tingling, or painful feelings in the arms or legs. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or get emergency help if you have hives; trouble breathing or swallowing; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes; hoarseness; rash, peeling or blistering skin, itching, fever, facial swelling, mouth sores, red or swollen eyes; unusual muscle pain, trouble breathing, stomach pain, nausea, vomiting, feeling cold (especially in arms or legs), dizziness or lightheadedness, extreme tiredness or weakness, fast or irregular heartbeat; yellow skin or eyes, dark urine, light-colored stools, nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, pain or tenderness in the upper right abdomen, swollen abdomen, extreme tiredness, weakness, confusion; decreased urination, leg swelling; bone pain, arm or leg pain, bone fracture, muscle pain or weakness, joint pain; seizures; fainting, lightheadedness, dizziness, irregular or fast heartbeat; or ongoing pain that begins in the upper left or middle abdomen and may spread to the back with nausea and vomiting (possible pancreatitis). this medicine may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual symptoms.

name: efbemalenograstim alfa-vuxw injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? efbemalenograstim alfa-vuxw injection is used to lower the chance of infection in people with nonmyeloid cancer (cancer that does not involve the bone marrow) who are receiving chemotherapy that may decrease the number of neutrophils (a type of white blood cell needed to fight infection). efbemalenograstim alfa-vuxw is a colony-stimulating factor that helps the body make more neutrophils. how should this medicine be used? efbemalenograstim alfa-vuxw comes as a liquid solution injected subcutaneously (under the skin) by a healthcare provider. it is usually given as a single dose for each chemotherapy cycle, no sooner than 24 hours after the last dose of chemotherapy in the cycle and more than 14 days before the next chemotherapy cycle begins. ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving efbemalenograstim alfa-vuxw injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to efbemalenograstim alfa-vuxw, filgrastim (granix, neupogen, nivestym, releuko, zarxio), pegfilgrastim (fulphila, fylnetra, neulasta, nyvepria, stimufend, udenyca, ziextenzo), any other medications, latex, or any ingredients in efbemalenograstim alfa-vuxw injection. ask your pharmacist for a list of the ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had anemia (a lower than normal number of red blood cells), a low platelet count, or kidney problems. tell your doctor if you have sickle cell disease (a blood disorder that can cause painful crises, anemia, infections, and organ damage). if you have sickle cell disease, you may be more likely to have a crisis during treatment; call your doctor right away if a crisis occurs. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while receiving efbemalenograstim alfa-vuxw injection, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are receiving this medication. you should know that efbemalenograstim alfa-vuxw injection lowers the risk of infection but does not prevent all infections that may occur during or after chemotherapy. call your doctor if you develop signs of infection such as fever; chills; rash; sore throat; diarrhea; or redness, swelling, or pain around a cut or sore. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment to receive efbemalenograstim alfa-vuxw injection, call your doctor right away. what side effects can this medication cause? efbemalenograstim alfa-vuxw injection may cause side effects. if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: nausea. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of these symptoms or those listed in the special precautions section, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help: pain in the left upper part of the stomach or the tip of your left shoulder; fever, shortness of breath, trouble breathing, or rapid breathing; rash, hives, itching, swelling of the face, eyes, or mouth, wheezing, shortness of breath, dizziness, or rapid heartbeat; swelling of your face or ankles, bloody or dark-colored urine, or decreased urination; unusual bleeding or bruising, fever, or tiredness; fever, abdominal pain, back pain, or feeling unwell; swelling of the stomach area or other swelling, decreased urination, trouble breathing, dizziness, or tiredness. some people who received efbemalenograstim alfa-vuxw injection developed other forms of cancer such as leukemia (cancer that begins in the white blood cells) and myelodysplastic syndrome (a condition in which blood cells do not develop normally). talk to your doctor about the risks of receiving this medication. efbemalenograstim alfa-vuxw injection may cause other side effects.

name: efgartigimod alfa and hyaluronidase-qvfc injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? efgartigimod alfa and hyaluronidase-qvfc injection is used to treat certain forms of myasthenia gravis (mg), a nervous system disorder that causes muscle weakness, and to treat chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (cidp), a disorder of the immune and nervous systems. efgartigimod alfa-fcab is a monoclonal antibody that reduces a natural substance in the body that contributes to mg and cidp symptoms. hyaluronidase-qvfc is an endoglycosidase that helps keep efgartigimod alfa in the body longer to increase its effect. how should this medicine be used? efgartigimod alfa and hyaluronidase-qvfc injection is a liquid solution injected subcutaneously (just under the skin) into the abdomen over 30 to 90 seconds by a healthcare provider. for mg, it is usually injected once a week for 4 weeks; this cycle may be repeated as recommended by your doctor, but not sooner than at least 50 days after your last weekly dose. for cidp, it is usually given once a week. the length of treatment depends on your response and any side effects. serious reactions may occur, usually within 1 hour after the injection. your healthcare provider will monitor you during the injection and for at least 30 minutes afterward. seek immediate medical attention if you have chest pain; dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting; rash; hives; swelling of the eyes, face, lips, tongue, or throat; hoarseness; trouble breathing or swallowing; chills; shivering; or stomach or back pain. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer's patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving efgartigimod alfa and hyaluronidase-qvfc injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to efgartigimod alfa, hyaluronidase, any other medications, or any ingredients in the injection. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have an infection, have a history of recurrent infections, or have or have had kidney disease or any other medical conditions. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while receiving this injection, call your doctor. if you received this injection during pregnancy and have given birth, tell your baby's doctor; efgartigimod alfa-fcab may affect your baby's immune response to vaccines. talk to your baby's doctor about vaccinations. check with your doctor to see if you need any vaccinations; it is important to have all age-appropriate vaccines before starting treatment. do not receive any vaccinations without talking to your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment to receive a dose, call your doctor right away. what side effects can this medication cause? efgartigimod alfa and hyaluronidase-qvfc injection may cause side effects. common side effects include headache; pain, burning, numbness, or tingling in the hands, feet, or mouth; muscle pain; and itching, swelling, bruising, or redness at the injection site. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have fever, sore throat, chills, cough, or other signs of infection; pain or burning on urination or frequent urination; rash; hives; trouble breathing or swallowing; or swelling of the eyes, face, lips, tongue, or throat. this medication may cause other side effects.

name: efgartigimod alfa-fcab injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? efgartigimod alfa-fcab injection is used to treat a certain form of myasthenia gravis (mg), a nervous system disorder that causes muscle weakness. efgartigimod alfa-fcab is a monoclonal antibody that works by lowering a natural substance in the body that contributes to mg symptoms. how should this medicine be used? efgartigimod alfa-fcab comes as a liquid solution that is infused slowly into a vein over 60 minutes by a healthcare provider. it is given once weekly for 4 weeks. this cycle may be repeated as advised by your doctor, but not sooner than 50 days after the start of your last cycle. the duration of treatment depends on how well you respond and any side effects you experience. serious infusion reactions can occur during the infusion or within 1 hour after it ends. your healthcare provider will monitor you closely during the infusion and for 1 hour afterward, and may slow or stop the infusion if a reaction occurs. if you experience any of the following symptoms, get emergency help immediately: chest pain; feeling dizzy, lightheaded, or faint; rash; hives; swelling of the eyes, face, lips, tongue, or throat; hoarseness; difficulty breathing or swallowing; chills; shivering; or stomach or back pain. ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving efgartigimod alfa-fcab injection, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this medication, any of its ingredients, or any other medications, foods, or substances, and describe the symptoms of your allergy. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have an active infection, a history of recurrent infections, kidney disease, or any other medical conditions. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while receiving efgartigimod alfa-fcab, call your doctor. if you received this medication during pregnancy and have given birth, inform your baby’s doctor because efgartigimod alfa-fcab may interfere with your baby’s response to vaccines; talk with your baby’s doctor about vaccinations. check with your doctor to see if you need any vaccinations; it is important to receive all age-appropriate vaccines before starting treatment. do not receive any vaccinations without talking to your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment for an efgartigimod alfa-fcab infusion, call your doctor right away. what side effects can this medication cause? efgartigimod alfa-fcab may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: headache; pain, burning, numbness, or tingling in the hands, feet, or mouth; muscle pain. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you experience: fever, sore throat, chills, cough, or other signs of infection; pain or burning on urination or frequent urination; rash; hives; difficulty breathing or swallowing; or swelling of the eyes, face, lips, tongue, or throat. efgartigimod alfa-fcab may cause other side effects; talk to your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: efinaconazole topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? efinaconazole topical solution is prescribed to treat fungal infections of the toenails that can cause discoloration, splitting, or pain. it belongs to a class of medicines called antifungals and works by stopping the growth of nail fungus. how should this medicine be used? efinaconazole comes as a topical solution applied to the affected toenails once daily for 48 weeks. apply it at about the same time each day. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. use only as directed; do not use more, less, or more often than prescribed. efinaconazole topical solution is for toenails only. avoid getting it on skin other than the area right around the affected toenails, and do not get it in your eyes, nose, mouth, or vagina. the solution is flammable; stay away from heat and open flames while applying. do not get pedicures or use nail polish or other cosmetic nail products during treatment. to apply: ensure toenails are clean and dry. wait at least 10 minutes after showering, bathing, or washing your toenails. remove the cap, hold the bottle upside down over the affected toe, and gently squeeze to place one drop on the toenail. for the big toe, squeeze again to place a second drop on the tip of the toenail. use the attached brush to spread the solution over the entire toenail, including the cuticle, the skin folds on both sides, and the skin under the nail; do not squeeze the bottle while spreading. if more than one toenail is affected, repeat these steps for each. replace and tighten the cap. allow nails to dry completely. wash your hands with soap and water. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to efinaconazole, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the solution. ask your pharmacist or check the manufacturer patient information for a full ingredient list. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor about any medical conditions you have or have had. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using efinaconazole, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not apply extra solution to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? efinaconazole topical solution may cause side effects. tell your doctor if symptoms are severe or do not go away. possible side effects include redness, itching, or swelling of the skin around the treated toenails; burning, stinging, or pain around the treated area; blisters near the treated toenails; and ingrown toenail.

name: eflornithine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? eflornithine is used to treat a specific type of neuroblastoma—a cancer that starts in nerve cells—in adults and children who have had a complete or partial response to other treatments. it belongs to a class of drugs called ornithine decarboxylase (odc) inhibitors and works by blocking signals that tell cancer cells to multiply, helping to stop or slow their growth. how should this medicine be used? eflornithine is an oral tablet taken with or without food twice daily at about the same times each day. follow your prescription label closely and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. take it exactly as directed; do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. if you cannot swallow the tablets, you may chew them, or crush them and mix with 2 tablespoons of soft food or liquid. consume the mixture right away or within 1 hour. if crushed tablet pieces remain, mix with another 2 tablespoons of soft food or liquid and take all of it to ensure you receive the full dose. if you vomit after a dose, do not take an extra dose; resume your usual dosing schedule. your doctor may lower your dose, add other medicines, pause, or stop treatment if certain side effects occur. tell your care team how you are feeling during treatment. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more details. what special precautions should i follow? before taking eflornithine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to eflornithine, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had hearing problems; low red or white blood cell counts or low platelets; or liver disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or plan to father a child, you or your partner should not become pregnant while using eflornithine. females who can become pregnant need a pregnancy test before starting and must use effective birth control during treatment and for 1 week after the last dose. males with partners who can become pregnant must use effective birth control during treatment and for 1 week after the last dose. if pregnancy occurs, call your doctor; eflornithine may harm the fetus. if you are breastfeeding or plan to breastfeed, your doctor may advise against breastfeeding during treatment and for 1 week after the final dose. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you take eflornithine. eflornithine can cause serious hearing problems that may be severe and may require hearing aids. you will need a hearing test before starting and at least every 6 months during treatment. call your doctor right away if you notice new or worsening hearing loss or ringing in the ears. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor instructs otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is within 7 hours of your next scheduled dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? eflornithine may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: runny or congested nose, sneezing; diarrhea; vomiting; burning, red, itchy, crusty, or irritated eyes; rash; arm or leg pain; hair loss; ear pain or other signs of ear infection. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have any of the following or those listed under special precautions: fever, chills, cough, sore throat, difficulty urinating, pain with urination, or other signs of infection; warm, red, or painful skin or skin sores; unusual bruising or bleeding; blood in urine or stool; pale skin; unusual tiredness or weakness; shortness of breath; yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark tea-colored urine, light-colored stools, pain in the upper right abdomen, nausea, vomiting, or loss of appetite. eflornithine may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: elacestrant
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? elacestrant is used to treat certain hormone receptor-positive breast cancers in adults whose disease has progressed after at least one prior hormone therapy. it belongs to a class of medicines called estrogen receptor antagonists and works by blocking estrogen from binding to its receptor, which slows or stops the growth of estrogen-dependent cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? elacestrant comes as an oral tablet and is usually taken once daily with food at about the same time each day. follow your prescription label exactly. do not take more or less than prescribed or take it more often. swallow the tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush them. your doctor may adjust your dose or tell you to stop temporarily based on side effects. tell your doctor how you are feeling while taking this medicine. do not stop taking it unless your doctor tells you to. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking elacestrant, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to elacestrant, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets; your pharmacist can provide a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. some medicines should not be used with elacestrant, and your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you closely for side effects. tell your doctor about any herbal products you take, especially st. john’s wort. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver disease or high cholesterol. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or plan to father a child, you should not become pregnant while taking elacestrant. you may need a negative pregnancy test before starting. use effective birth control during treatment and for 1 week after your final dose. if you are male and your partner can become pregnant, use effective birth control during treatment and for 1 week after your last dose. if you or your partner becomes pregnant while taking elacestrant, call your doctor. do not breastfeed during treatment or for 1 week after your final dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. however, if more than 6 hours have passed since the missed dose, or if you vomit after taking a dose, skip it and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? elacestrant may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: muscle or joint pain, tiredness or weakness, vomiting, decreased appetite, diarrhea, constipation, abdominal pain, hot flushes, indigestion or heartburn. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away if you have any of the following: lower abdominal pain; yellowing of the skin or eyes or dark urine; nausea, headache, confusion, or unusual fatigue. elacestrant may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: eladocagene exuparvovec-tneq injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? eladocagene exuparvovec-tneq is used to treat l-amino acid decarboxylase (aadc) deficiency, a genetic condition that disrupts the production of chemical signals that allow nerve cells to communicate. eladocagene exuparvovec-tneq is a gene therapy that works by improving the production of these signals in the nervous system. how should this medicine be used? eladocagene exuparvovec-tneq is supplied as a suspension that is administered intraputaminally (into a specific area of the brain) during a surgical procedure at a hospital that is equipped to perform these procedures. your doctor will explain what to expect before, during, and after receiving eladocagene exuparvovec-tneq. because the procedure can have complications, your healthcare team will monitor you closely in the hospital for a period of time after the surgery. ask your doctor or pharmacist for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving eladocagene exuparvovec-tneq, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to eladocagene exuparvovec-tneq, to any other medications, or to any ingredients in the injection; your pharmacist can provide a list of ingredients. some medications should not be taken with eladocagene exuparvovec-tneq. discuss all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take now or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist before treatment. do not start, stop, or change any medicines without your doctor’s advice while you are being treated. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. your doctor may perform a pregnancy test before you receive eladocagene exuparvovec-tneq. if you become pregnant after receiving this medicine, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given by healthcare professionals during a scheduled surgical procedure, so you will not take doses at home. if you miss or need to reschedule the procedure or a follow-up appointment, contact your doctor as soon as possible. what side effects can this medication cause? eladocagene exuparvovec-tneq may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of the following are severe or do not go away: fever; excessive salivation; trouble falling or staying asleep; dizziness or lightheadedness; feeling tired; signs of anemia such as pale skin, shortness of breath, headache, cold hands or feet, brittle nails, or hair loss; muscle weakness or cramping; muscle spasms or tremors; nausea, vomiting, or loss of appetite; abnormal eye movements. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you experience involuntary movements of the face, arms, legs, or body, such as fidgeting, writhing, wriggling, head bobbing, or body swaying. eladocagene exuparvovec-tneq may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems after receiving this medication.

name: elafibranor
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? elafibranor is used alone or with ursodiol to treat primary biliary cholangitis (pbc), a liver disease that damages the bile ducts and allows bile to build up in the liver, in people who cannot take ursodiol or who did not respond well to ursodiol alone. elafibranor is in a class of medicines called peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor (ppar) agonists. it works by reducing the production of bile acids and increasing their removal from the liver, lowering toxic bile acid levels. how should this medicine be used? elafibranor comes as an oral tablet taken once daily, with or without food. take it at the same time each day. follow your prescription label exactly, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not take more or less than prescribed or take it more often. your doctor or pharmacist will give you the manufacturer’s medication guide when you start treatment with elafibranor. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking elafibranor, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to elafibranor, any other medications, or any ingredient in the tablets. ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you for side effects. if you take a bile acid resin such as cholestyramine, colesevelam, or colestipol, take it at least 4 hours before or 4 hours after elafibranor. tell your doctor if you have liver cirrhosis; your doctor may tell you not to take elafibranor. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had osteoporosis (thin, weak bones), muscle aches or weakness, or liver disease. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, you will need a pregnancy test before starting elafibranor. elafibranor may reduce the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives (pills, patches, rings, implants, injections), so do not use these as your only birth control during treatment. use a nonhormonal method such as a barrier method (for example, a condom or diaphragm) during treatment and for 3 weeks after your final dose. if you become pregnant, call your doctor right away; elafibranor may harm the fetus. do not breastfeed while taking elafibranor and for 3 weeks after the last dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor instructs you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? elafibranor may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: diarrhea; stomach pain; nausea; vomiting; constipation; heartburn; weight loss or gain; dry mouth; joint pain; fever and chills; weakness; lightheadedness. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or seek emergency medical care if you have: yellowing of the skin or eyes; pain in the upper right abdomen; new or worsening fatigue, loss of appetite, or swelling of the legs or feet; swelling in or around the abdomen; black, tarry, or bloody stools; coughing up or vomiting blood; confusion, slurred speech, anxiety, mood swings, or personality changes; rash; itching; swelling of the face, eyes, mouth, throat, tongue, or lips; difficulty breathing or swallowing; dark-colored urine; unexplained muscle pain, tenderness, or weakness; unusual tiredness; bone fracture or severe bone pain. taking elafibranor may increase the risk of bone fractures. talk to your doctor about this risk and about ways to keep your bones healthy during treatment. elafibranor may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: elagolix
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? elagolix is used to manage pain due to endometriosis, a condition in which the type of tissue that lines the uterus [womb] grows outside the uterus and can cause infertility, pain before and during menstrual periods, pain during and after sexual activity, and heavy or irregular bleeding. elagolix is in a class of medications called gonadotropin-releasing hormone (gnrh) receptor antagonists. it works by lowering certain hormone levels in the body. how should this medicine be used? elagolix comes as an oral tablet. it is usually taken with or without food once daily for up to 24 months or twice daily for up to 6 months. take elagolix at the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not take more or less than prescribed or take it more often. your doctor may prescribe calcium and vitamin d supplements during treatment; take them as directed. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking elagolix, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to elagolix, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets; ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor if you are taking cyclosporine (gengraf, neoral, sandimmune) or gemfibrozil (lopid); your doctor will likely tell you not to take elagolix with these. some medicines should not be taken with elagolix, and others may require dose changes or extra monitoring; review all medicines you take or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist before starting elagolix, and consult them before starting, stopping, or changing any medicines while on elagolix. tell your doctor if you have osteoporosis (thin, weak bones) or if you have or have ever had liver disease; your doctor may tell you not to take elagolix. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had broken bones, depression, anxiety, unusual changes in mood or behavior, or thoughts about or attempts at suicide. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor. do not take elagolix if you are pregnant or think you may be pregnant. your doctor will perform a pregnancy test before starting treatment or instruct you to begin within 7 days after your menstrual period starts to ensure you are not pregnant. elagolix may reduce the effectiveness of certain hormonal contraceptives; do not rely on them alone for birth control during treatment. use a reliable non-hormonal birth control method during treatment and for 1 week after your final dose. ask your doctor to help you choose a method that is right for you. if you become pregnant while taking elagolix, call your doctor immediately; elagolix may harm the fetus. be aware that mental health changes can occur while taking elagolix. you, your family, or your caregiver should call your doctor right away if you experience new or worsening irritability, anxiety, or depression; thoughts or talk of wanting to harm yourself or end your life; withdrawal from friends or family; preoccupation with death; or any other unusual changes in behavior or mood. ensure your family or caregiver knows which symptoms are serious so they can seek help if you cannot. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose on the same day as soon as you remember, then continue your regular schedule. do not take more than one dose per day if you take it once daily, or more than two doses per day if you take it twice daily. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? elagolix may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: hot flashes (sudden waves of mild or intense body heat), night sweats, headache, nausea, diarrhea, constipation, stomach pain, weight gain, difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep, changes in menstrual periods (irregular bleeding or spotting, little or no bleeding, shorter periods), joint pain, changes in sexual desire. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, extreme tiredness, nausea and vomiting, right upper abdominal pain, or unusual bleeding or bruising. elagolix may cause or worsen osteoporosis by decreasing bone mineral density, increasing the risk of fractures; talk to your doctor about these risks. elagolix may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: elagolix, estradiol, and norethindrone
instructions: important warning: medicines that contain estradiol and norethindrone can increase the risk of heart attack, stroke, and blood clots in the legs, lungs, or eyes. your risk is higher if you smoke or if you have or have ever had a heart attack; stroke; blood clots in the legs, lungs, or eyes; heart valve disease; a fast or irregular heartbeat; a thrombophilia (a condition that makes blood clot easily); migraine headaches; high blood pressure; high cholesterol or high fats in the blood; or diabetes that has affected your circulation. your doctor may tell you not to take this medicine if you have or have had any of these conditions. if you are scheduled for surgery or expect prolonged bedrest, your doctor may advise stopping this medicine at least 4 to 6 weeks in advance. call your doctor right away if you develop any of the following: sudden, severe headache; sudden partial or complete vision loss; double vision; trouble speaking; dizziness or fainting; weakness or numbness in an arm or leg; crushing chest pain or chest heaviness; coughing up blood; sudden shortness of breath; or pain, tenderness, or redness in one leg. you will receive a medication guide when you start treatment and with each refill; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. discuss the risks and benefits of elagolix, estradiol, and norethindrone with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? this combination is used to treat heavy menstrual bleeding caused by uterine fibroids (noncancerous growths in the uterus). elagolix is a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (gnrh) receptor antagonist that lowers certain hormone levels. estradiol is an estrogen that replaces estrogen your body would otherwise produce. norethindrone is a progestin that helps prevent growth of the uterine lining and influences uterine hormone production. how should this medicine be used? this medicine comes as oral capsules and is usually taken with or without food twice daily for up to 24 months. each 28‑day carton contains weekly dose packs with two capsule types: 7 yellow-and-white capsules containing elagolix/estradiol/norethindrone and 7 blue-and-white capsules containing elagolix alone. take one elagolix/estradiol/norethindrone capsule every morning and one elagolix capsule every evening, at about the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly. do not take more or less, or take it more often, than prescribed. your doctor may recommend calcium and vitamin d during treatment; take them as directed. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking this medicine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to elagolix, estradiol, norethindrone, aspirin, tartrazine (a yellow dye), any other medications, or any ingredients in the capsules; check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor if you take cyclosporine (gengraf, neoral, sandimmune) or gemfibrozil (lopid); you will likely be told not to take this combination with those medicines. some medicines should not be used with elagolix/estradiol/norethindrone; others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. discuss all prescription, over-the-counter, and herbal products you use or plan to use with your doctor and pharmacist before starting this medicine, and consult them before starting, stopping, or changing any medication while taking it. in particular, tell your doctor if you use st. john’s wort or omeprazole (prilosec); do not start these while on therapy without medical advice. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had breast cancer; cancer of the cervix, vagina, or the uterine lining; osteoporosis; unexplained abnormal vaginal bleeding; peripheral vascular disease (poor circulation); heart disease; liver disease or any other liver problems—your doctor may tell you not to take this medicine. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had broken bones; depression, anxiety, unusual mood or behavior changes, or suicidal thoughts or attempts; gallbladder disease; jaundice; thyroid problems; or adrenal insufficiency. do not take this medicine if you are pregnant or think you might be pregnant. your doctor will perform a pregnancy test before starting or instruct you to begin within 7 days of the start of your menstrual period to ensure you are not pregnant. this medicine can interfere with some hormonal contraceptives; do not rely on them alone. use a reliable nonhormonal birth control method during treatment and for 1 week after your final dose. if you become pregnant, stop the medicine and call your doctor right away; it may harm the fetus. your mental health may change in unexpected ways, including suicidal thoughts or actions. you, your family, or your caregiver should call your doctor immediately if you notice new or worsening irritability, anxiety, depression, thoughts or talk of self-harm, withdrawing from friends or family, preoccupation with death, or other unusual mood or behavior changes. make sure family or caregivers know which symptoms are serious so they can seek help if you cannot. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not eat grapefruit or drink grapefruit juice while taking this medicine. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless more than 4 hours have passed since the time you were supposed to take it; if so, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? this medicine may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: hair loss or thinning; hot flashes; changes in menstrual periods (irregular bleeding or spotting, little or no bleeding, shorter periods); headache; weight gain; joint pain; changes in sexual desire; drowsiness or tiredness. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have any of the following or the symptoms listed in the important warning section: yellowing of the skin or eyes; unusual bruising or bleeding; loss of appetite; extreme tiredness, weakness, or lack of energy; dark urine; light-colored stools; pain in the upper right abdomen; nausea; vomiting; swelling of the hands, feet, or lower legs. this medicine can cause or worsen osteoporosis, lowering bone density and increasing the risk of broken bones. discuss these risks with your doctor. other side effects may occur; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medicine.

name: elbasvir and grazoprevir
instructions: important warning: you may already be infected with hepatitis b, a virus that infects the liver and can cause severe liver damage, even if you have no symptoms. in this situation, taking elbasvir and grazoprevir can increase the risk that your hepatitis b will flare and become serious or life-threatening, leading to symptoms. before you start treatment, tell your doctor if you have or have ever had hepatitis b. your doctor will order blood tests to check for current or past hepatitis b infection and will monitor you during treatment and for several months afterward. if needed, you may receive medicines to treat hepatitis b before and during therapy with elbasvir and grazoprevir. call your doctor right away if you develop excessive tiredness, yellowing of the skin or eyes, loss of appetite, nausea or vomiting, pale stools, pain in the upper right side of your abdomen, or dark urine. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor may order tests before, during, and after treatment to check your body’s response. talk to your doctor about the risks and benefits of elbasvir and grazoprevir. why is this medication prescribed? the combination of elbasvir and grazoprevir is used alone or with ribavirin (copegus, rebetol, ribasphere, virazole) to treat certain types of chronic (long-term) hepatitis c infection in adults and in children 12 years of age and older. elbasvir is an hcv ns5a inhibitor that helps stop the virus from multiplying. grazoprevir is a protease inhibitor that lowers the amount of hepatitis c virus (hcv) in the body. it is not known whether this treatment prevents the spread of hepatitis c to others. how should this medicine be used? elbasvir and grazoprevir comes as an oral tablet taken once daily, with or without food, usually for 12 to 16 weeks. take it at the same time each day. follow your prescription label exactly. do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. continue taking it even if you feel well. the length of therapy depends on your condition, how you respond, and whether you have serious side effects. do not stop the medication without talking to your doctor. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking elbasvir and grazoprevir, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to elbasvir, grazoprevir, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the tablets. some medicines should not be used with elbasvir and grazoprevir, and others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. review all prescription, nonprescription, and herbal products you take now or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist before starting therapy, and consult them before starting, stopping, or changing any medicines while on treatment. the herbal product st. john’s wort may interact with elbasvir and grazoprevir; tell your healthcare providers if you use it and do not start it while on treatment without medical advice. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any liver disease other than hepatitis c; your doctor may tell you not to take this medication. also inform your doctor if you have had or are awaiting a liver transplant, if you have human immunodeficiency virus (hiv), or if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking elbasvir and grazoprevir, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? elbasvir and grazoprevir may cause side effects. common effects include diarrhea, headache, and difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have sleepiness, confusion, swelling of the stomach area, vomiting blood or material that looks like coffee grounds, or dark, black, or bloody stools, or any symptoms listed in the important warning section. elbasvir and grazoprevir may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: eletriptan
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? eletriptan is used to relieve the symptoms of migraine headaches, which may include severe throbbing pain, nausea, and sensitivity to light and sound. it belongs to the selective serotonin receptor agonists (triptans). it works by narrowing blood vessels in the brain and blocking pain signals and the release of substances that trigger migraine symptoms. it does not prevent migraines or reduce how often they occur. how should this medicine be used? eletriptan is an oral tablet. take one dose at the first sign of a migraine. if your symptoms improve and then return after at least 2 hours, you may take a second dose. if the first dose does not help at all, do not take a second dose before speaking with your doctor. take exactly as directed; do not take more or more often than prescribed. call your doctor if your headaches do not improve, become more frequent, or if you need to treat more than 3 headaches in a month. to avoid medication-overuse headache, do not use eletriptan or any other acute headache medicine on more than 10 days per month. your doctor will tell you the maximum number of tablets allowed in 24 hours. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to eletriptan, any of its ingredients, or any other medicines, foods, or substances, and describe your reactions. do not take eletriptan within 24 hours of another triptan (almotriptan, frovatriptan, naratriptan, rizatriptan, sumatriptan, zolmitriptan) or any ergot-type medicine (bromocriptine, cabergoline, dihydroergotamine, ergoloid mesylates, ergonovine, ergotamine, methylergonovine, methysergide, pergolide). do not take eletriptan within 72 hours of strong cyp3a4 inhibitors such as clarithromycin, itraconazole, ketoconazole, nefazodone, nelfinavir, ritonavir, or troleandomycin. some medicines should not be combined with eletriptan and others may require dose changes or monitoring; tell your doctor and pharmacist about all medicines and supplements you use, including if you currently take or have taken within the past 2 weeks an mao inhibitor (isocarboxazid, phenelzine, selegiline, tranylcypromine). tell your doctor if you have or have ever had heart disease, heart attack, angina, irregular heartbeats, stroke or tia, circulation problems such as blood clots in the legs, raynaud’s phenomenon, varicose veins, or ischemic bowel disease; you may be advised not to take eletriptan. also tell your doctor if you smoke, are overweight, have high blood pressure, diabetes, high cholesterol, kidney or liver disease, have gone through menopause, or have a family history of heart disease or stroke. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; discuss effective birth control if you could become pregnant. eletriptan may cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. confirm with your doctor that your headaches are migraines; eletriptan should not be used for other headache types. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor whether you should avoid grapefruit or grapefruit juice while taking eletriptan. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is taken only as needed for migraines and has no regular dosing schedule. if you did not take it at the onset of a migraine, take it as soon as you recognize migraine symptoms. do not take extra doses to make up for a missed dose; keep at least 2 hours between doses and do not exceed the maximum daily amount your doctor prescribed. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include weakness or tiredness, dizziness, drowsiness, upset stomach, nausea, heartburn, headache, dry mouth, and feeling unusually warm or cold. serious side effects can occur; call your doctor right away or seek emergency care for tightness, pain, pressure, or heaviness in the chest, throat, neck, or jaw; slow or difficult speech; weakness or numbness of an arm or leg; vomiting; sudden or severe stomach pain; bloody diarrhea; constipation; rapid, pounding, or irregular heartbeat; shortness of breath; lightheadedness; cold sweat; trouble breathing or swallowing; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; hoarseness; hives, rash, or itching; pale or blue fingers or toes; or pain, burning, or tingling in the hands or feet. eletriptan may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: elexacaftor, tezacaftor, and ivacaftor
instructions: important warning: the combination of elexacaftor, tezacaftor, and ivacaftor can cause serious, potentially life-threatening liver damage, especially if you have or have ever had liver disease. stop taking it and call your doctor right away if you have pain, swelling, or discomfort in the upper right abdomen; yellowing of the skin or eyes; confusion; dark urine; nausea; vomiting; or loss of appetite. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor will order tests to check your body’s response before and during treatment. you will receive a medication guide when you start treatment and with each refill; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. why is this medication prescribed? the combination of elexacaftor, tezacaftor, and ivacaftor is used to treat certain types of cystic fibrosis (cf), an inherited disease that affects breathing, digestion, and reproduction. elexacaftor and tezacaftor are cftr correctors, and ivacaftor is a cftr potentiator. together they improve the cftr protein’s function to reduce thick mucus in the lungs and improve cf symptoms. how should this medicine be used? elexacaftor, tezacaftor, and ivacaftor come as tablets and as granules to take by mouth. take with fat-containing food twice a day, about 12 hours apart, at the same times each day. take exactly as directed; do not take more or less or more often than prescribed. tablets: each daily dose includes two different tablets with different ingredients. your doctor will usually tell you to take two orange tablets (elexacaftor/tezacaftor/ivacaftor) every morning and one blue tablet (ivacaftor) every evening. swallow tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush. granules: each daily dose includes two different packets, one of elexacaftor/tezacaftor/ivacaftor granules and one of ivacaftor granules. your doctor will usually tell you to take one packet of the combination granules in the morning and one packet of ivacaftor granules in the evening. to prepare a dose, mix the entire packet with 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of cold or room-temperature soft food or liquid such as pureed fruits or vegetables, yogurt, applesauce, water, milk, or juice, and take the mixture within 1 hour. always take tablets or granules with fat-containing foods such as eggs, butter, nuts, peanut butter, cheese pizza, or whole-milk dairy products (whole milk, cheese, yogurt). ask your doctor about other suitable fatty foods. this medicine helps control cf but does not cure it. continue to take it even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking this combination, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to elexacaftor, tezacaftor, ivacaftor, any ingredient in the product, or any other medicines, foods, or substances, and describe your symptoms. some medicines should not be taken with this combination, and others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. discuss all medicines you take or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist before starting, and consult them before starting, stopping, or changing any medicine while on treatment. nonprescription or herbal products may interact, including st. john’s wort; tell your healthcare provider if you use it, and do not start it while taking this medicine without medical advice. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking this medicine, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not eat grapefruit or drink grapefruit juice while taking this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you remember a missed morning or evening dose within 6 hours of the scheduled time, take it right away with a fat-containing food and then continue your regular schedule. if more than 6 hours have passed since the scheduled morning dose, take the missed morning dose as soon as possible and skip the evening dose; then return to your usual schedule. if more than 6 hours have passed since the scheduled evening dose, skip that dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take the morning and evening doses together to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? this medication may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of the following are severe or do not go away: headache; runny nose, sneezing, stuffiness; fever; cough or other signs of infection; diarrhea; gas; pink eye; dizziness. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or get emergency medical help if you have rash, itching, hives, or difficulty breathing or swallowing. cataracts (clouding of the lens of the eye) have occurred in children and teenagers taking ivacaftor-containing treatments; children and teenagers should have eye exams before and during treatment. talk to your child’s doctor about the risks. this medication may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: eliglustat
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? eliglustat is used to treat gaucher disease type 1 in certain people. it belongs to a class of medicines called enzyme inhibitors and works by reducing the production of a fatty substance that otherwise accumulates in organs and leads to problems involving the liver, spleen, bones, and blood. how should this medicine be used? eliglustat is an oral capsule taken once or twice daily, with or without food, at the same times each day. take it exactly as prescribed; do not take more or less or use it more often than directed. because genetic differences affect how your body processes eliglustat, your doctor will order a blood test to determine the best dose for you. swallow capsules whole with water—do not split, open, dissolve, or crush. eliglustat controls but does not cure gaucher disease; continue taking it even if you feel well, and do not stop unless your doctor tells you to. what special precautions should i follow? before taking eliglustat, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to it, to any other medicines, or to any ingredients in the capsules; check the medication guide for a full ingredient list. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all medicines you use. some medicines should not be taken with eliglustat, and others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. do not start, stop, or change any medication while taking eliglustat without medical advice. if you are receiving enzyme replacement therapy such as imiglucerase (cerezyme), taliglucerase alfa (elelyso), or velaglucerase alfa (vpriv), wait 24 hours after your last dose before starting eliglustat. the herbal product st. john’s wort may interact with eliglustat; tell your healthcare providers if you use it, and do not start it while on eliglustat without discussing it with them. tell your doctor if you have liver disease. based on genetic test results, some people should not take eliglustat—either alone or with certain other medications—particularly if they have liver disease or certain combinations of medical conditions and medicines. also inform your doctor if you have or have ever had long qt syndrome (a condition that increases the risk of an abnormal heartbeat), any other irregular heart rhythm, heart attack, heart failure, or heart or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while taking eliglustat. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not eat grapefruit or drink grapefruit juice while taking eliglustat. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, take the next dose at the usual time and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? eliglustat may cause side effects. common side effects include fatigue, weakness, joint pain, headache, migraine, nausea, heartburn, gas, mouth or throat pain, diarrhea, back pain, pain in the legs or arms, stomach pain, cough, and rash. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor immediately if you experience heart palpitations, dizziness, or fainting. eliglustat may cause other side effects; contact your doctor about any unusual symptoms.

name: elivaldogene autotemcel injection
instructions: important warning: elivaldogene autotemcel injection may increase the risk of life-threatening blood cancer. your blood will be monitored at least every 6 months for at least 15 years after treatment. call your doctor immediately if you have unusual bruising or bleeding, nosebleeds, severe headache, blood in your urine, stool, or vomit, coughing up blood, or unusual abdominal or back pain. talk with your doctor about the risks of this medication. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory; your doctor will order tests to monitor your response. your doctor or pharmacist will give you the manufacturer’s medication guide when you begin treatment; read it carefully and ask questions. why is this medication prescribed? elivaldogene autotemcel injection is used to slow the progression of brain damage and the decline of nerve function in males 4–17 years of age with early, active cerebral adrenoleukodystrophy (cald), an inherited condition in which fatty acids build up in the brain and cause nerve and brain damage. it belongs to a class of medications called autologous cellular immunotherapy, prepared from the patient’s own blood cells. it works by helping your body break down fatty acids and slowing nerve and brain damage. how should this medicine be used? elivaldogene autotemcel injection is a one-time intravenous infusion given in a hospital by a doctor or nurse. the dose is contained in 1 or 2 infusion bags, and each bag is usually infused over no more than 60 minutes. before receiving elivaldogene autotemcel, you will be given chemotherapy medicines to prepare your body. before your dose is made, your blood stem cells will be collected at a hospital or treatment center using mobilization and apheresis (a process that removes blood stem cells from the body); this typically takes about 1 week and may need to be repeated. the collected cells are sent to the manufacturer to prepare your dose, which takes about 51–65 days. because it is made from your own cells, it must be given only to you. nausea and vomiting can occur during treatment; your doctor may prescribe medicines to help. you will need to stay in the hospital for about 2 months after your infusion so you can be closely monitored for side effects. talk to your doctor about how to prepare for mobilization and apheresis and what to expect during and after the procedure. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving elivaldogene autotemcel injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to elivaldogene autotemcel, dimethyl sulfoxide (dmso), any other medications, or any ingredients in the product; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had hiv or kidney or liver problems. this medication is for use in males only. if you are male, you and your female partner should use birth control during treatment and for at least 6 months after you receive elivaldogene autotemcel; if your partner becomes pregnant, call your doctor. this medication may decrease fertility in men; discuss the risks with your doctor. do not donate blood, organs, tissues, or cells for transplantation after receiving this medication. check with your doctor about any vaccinations you may need. do not receive any vaccinations without talking to your doctor for at least 6 weeks before starting chemotherapy, during your elivaldogene autotemcel treatment, and until your doctor tells you your immune system has recovered. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this therapy is a single-dose infusion given in a healthcare setting. if you miss or need to reschedule an appointment for cell collection, conditioning chemotherapy, or the infusion, contact your doctor immediately to arrange new dates. do not attempt to self-administer this medication. what side effects can this medication cause? elivaldogene autotemcel injection may cause side effects. common side effects include nausea, vomiting, constipation, diarrhea, stomach pain, decreased appetite, mouth sores, blurred vision, headache, hair loss, and darkening of the skin. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the symptoms listed in the important warning section or any of the following, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment: rash, itching, hives, swelling of the face, mouth, tongue, or throat, chest pain, fast heartbeat, or difficulty swallowing or breathing; unusual bruising or bleeding, nosebleeds, severe headache, blood in urine, stool, or vomit, coughing up blood, or unusual abdominal or back pain; fever, sore throat, swollen glands, ongoing cough and congestion, or other signs of infection; weakness, feeling very tired, shortness of breath; or seizure. elivaldogene autotemcel injection may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: elotuzumab injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? elotuzumab injection is used with lenalidomide (revlimid) and dexamethasone, or with pomalidomide (pomalyst) and dexamethasone, to treat multiple myeloma (a cancer of the bone marrow) that has not improved with treatment or that improved and later returned. elotuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that helps the body slow or stop the growth of cancer cells. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used?
