elotuzumab comes as a powder that is mixed with sterile fluid and given by intravenous infusion by a doctor or nurse in a healthcare setting. when used with lenalidomide and dexamethasone, it is usually given once weekly during the first 2 cycles (each 28-day cycle), then once every 2 weeks. when used with pomalidomide and dexamethasone, it is usually given once weekly during the first 2 cycles (each 28-day cycle), then once every 4 weeks. you will receive medicines before the infusion to help prevent reactions, and you will be monitored during and after the infusion. tell your doctor or nurse right away if you develop fever, chills, rash, dizziness, lightheadedness, a slow heartbeat, chest pain, trouble breathing, or shortness of breath during the infusion or within 24 hours afterward. your doctor may lower your dose or pause or stop treatment depending on how well it works for you and the side effects you experience. tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment, and ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer's patient information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving elotuzumab injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to elotuzumab, any other medications, or any ingredients in the injection. ask your pharmacist or check the manufacturer's patient information for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have an infection or if you have or have ever had liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while receiving elotuzumab, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given by a healthcare professional. if you miss an appointment or dose, call your doctor or infusion center as soon as possible to reschedule. do not attempt to receive an extra dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? elotuzumab injection may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: diarrhea, constipation, headache, vomiting, mood changes, weight loss, night sweats, numbness or decreased sense of touch, bone pain, muscle spasms, or swelling of the arms or legs. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have any of the symptoms listed above under how should this medicine be used? or any of the following: chills, sore throat, fever, or cough; shortness of breath; pain or burning with urination; a painful rash; other signs of infection; numbness, weakness, tingling, or burning pain in your arms or legs; chest pain; nausea; extreme tiredness or lack of energy; loss of appetite; yellowing of the skin or eyes; dark urine; pale stools; confusion; pain in the upper right part of the stomach; or vision changes. elotuzumab injection may increase the risk of developing certain cancers. talk to your doctor about the risks of receiving this medication. elotuzumab injection may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems during treatment.

name: elranatamab-bcmm
instructions: important warning: elranatamab-bcmm injection may cause a serious or life-threatening reaction called cytokine release syndrome (crs). your doctor may give you certain medications before your injections to help prevent this reaction. tell your doctor if you have an inflammatory condition or if you have or think you may have an infection before receiving treatment. if you experience any of the following symptoms during or after your injection, get medical help immediately: fever, chills, fast or irregular heartbeat, difficulty breathing, shortness of breath, cough, confusion, anxiety, restlessness, headache, dizziness, lightheadedness, muscle pain, shaking, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, tiredness, or weakness. elranatamab-bcmm may also cause severe or life-threatening central nervous system reactions called immune effector cell-associated neurotoxicity syndrome (icans). tell your doctor if you have or have ever had seizures, a stroke, or memory problems. if you experience any of the following symptoms, get medical help immediately: headache, restlessness, confusion, loss of consciousness, seizures, uncontrollable shaking or jerking of a part of the body, hearing loss, double vision, difficulty speaking or writing, difficulty walking, muscle tightening or spasms, muscle weakness, burning, throbbing, or stabbing pain, or numbness and tingling of the skin. you may experience crs or central nervous system reactions during a dose or afterwards. these reactions are more common with the first 3 doses but can occur at any time during treatment. a doctor or nurse will monitor you closely in a hospital or medical facility during your injections and for 48 hours after at least your first 3 doses to be sure you are not having a serious reaction. because of the risks of crs and icans, elranatamab-bcmm is available only through a restricted program called the elrexfio rems. your doctor will register you in this program. elranatamab-bcmm is dispensed only by pharmacies enrolled in elrexfio rems. ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions about how to fill your prescription. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor will order tests to check your body’s response to elranatamab-bcmm. you will receive a medication guide when you start treatment and each time you refill. read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist any questions. talk to your doctor about the risks of receiving elranatamab-bcmm injection. why is this medication prescribed? elranatamab-bcmm is used to treat multiple myeloma, a cancer of the bone marrow, that has returned or did not respond after at least 4 other treatments. elranatamab-bcmm is in a class of medications called bispecific t-cell engager antibodies. it works by helping your immune system target and kill cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? elranatamab-bcmm comes as a liquid solution given by subcutaneous injection (under the skin) by a doctor or nurse in a healthcare facility. it is usually given on days 1, 4, and 8, then once weekly for 24 weeks. if you respond to therapy, it is then given every 2 weeks after week 24. your doctor will start you on a low dose and increase it gradually to make sure you tolerate the medication. your doctor may delay or stop treatment, or give you additional medications, depending on your response and any side effects. tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving elranatamab-bcmm, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to elranatamab-bcmm, any other medications, or any ingredients in the injection. ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have an active infection or if you have or have ever had low blood cell counts (such as leukopenia, neutropenia, or anemia) or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. you must have a pregnancy test before starting treatment. use effective birth control during treatment and for 4 months after your final dose. if you become pregnant, call your doctor; elranatamab-bcmm may harm the fetus. do not breastfeed during treatment and for 4 months after your final dose. elranatamab-bcmm may cause dizziness or confusion. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how this medication affects you. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given by a healthcare professional. if you miss an appointment, contact your doctor as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to receive an extra dose or change your dosing schedule on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? elranatamab-bcmm may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: fatigue or tiredness; pain, bruising, or swelling at the injection site; diarrhea or constipation; nausea or vomiting; muscle or bone pain; rash or dry, peeling skin; decreased appetite; difficulty sleeping. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the symptoms listed in the important warning section or any of the following, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help: fever, chills, weakness, cough, shortness of breath, or sore throat; yellowing of the skin or whites of the eyes, dark urine, or lower abdominal pain. elranatamab-bcmm may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: eltrombopag
instructions: important warning: if you have chronic hepatitis c and you take eltrombopag together with hepatitis c medicines such as interferon (peginterferon, pegintron, others) and ribavirin (copegus, rebetol, ribasphere, others), your risk of serious liver damage increases. call your doctor right away if you develop yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, extreme tiredness, pain in the upper right abdomen, abdominal swelling, or confusion. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory; your doctor will perform certain tests before and during treatment to monitor your response to eltrombopag. you will receive a medication guide when you start eltrombopag and each time you refill; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. discuss the risks and benefits of eltrombopag with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? eltrombopag is used to raise platelet counts to lower the risk of bleeding in adults and children 1 year and older with chronic immune thrombocytopenia (itp) who have not improved with, or cannot receive, other treatments (including surgery to remove the spleen). it is also used to increase platelets in people with hepatitis c so they can start and continue treatment with interferon and ribavirin. eltrombopag is used with other medicines to treat aplastic anemia in adults and children 2 years and older, and is also used in adults with aplastic anemia who have not responded to other medications. it is intended to raise platelets enough to reduce bleeding risk in itp or aplastic anemia, or to allow hepatitis c therapy; it is not used to raise platelets to normal. do not use eltrombopag for low platelets from causes other than itp, hepatitis c, or aplastic anemia. eltrombopag is a thrombopoietin receptor agonist that helps bone marrow make more platelets. how should this medicine be used? eltrombopag comes as tablets and as a powder for oral suspension to take by mouth. it is usually taken once daily on an empty stomach, at least 1 hour before or 2 hours after food, at about the same time each day. take exactly as prescribed; do not take more, take less, or take it more often than directed. take eltrombopag at least 2 hours before or 4 hours after foods or drinks high in calcium (for example, dairy products; calcium-fortified juices, cereals, oatmeal, and breads; trout; clams; leafy greens such as spinach and collard greens; tofu and other soy products). ask your doctor if you are unsure whether a food is high in calcium. you may find it easiest to take eltrombopag at the beginning or end of the day so you can eat these foods during your usual waking hours. swallow tablets whole; do not split, chew, crush, or mix them into food or liquids. if using the powder for oral suspension, read the instructions for use carefully. mix the powder with cool or cold water only (do not use hot water), and swallow immediately after preparation. if not taken within 30 minutes or if liquid remains, throw the mixture in the trash (do not pour it down the sink). avoid contact of the powder with your skin; if contact occurs, wash with soap and water right away and call your doctor if you have a skin reaction or questions. your doctor will usually start you on a low dose and adjust based on your platelet counts. at the start of treatment your platelets will be checked weekly; your dose may be increased if platelets are too low or decreased/temporarily stopped if too high. once a stable dose is found, monitoring is less frequent. after stopping eltrombopag, your platelets will be checked weekly for at least 4 weeks. if you have chronic itp, other medicines for your condition may be reduced if eltrombopag works well. not everyone responds; if your platelet count does not increase enough after adequate time, your doctor may stop eltrombopag. eltrombopag helps control your condition but does not cure it. continue taking it even if you feel well and do not stop without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine: your doctor may prescribe this medication for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking eltrombopag, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to eltrombopag or any ingredients in the tablets or suspension; review the medication guide for a full ingredient list. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may change doses or monitor for side effects. if you take antacids containing calcium, aluminum, or magnesium (such as maalox, mylanta, tums) or vitamin/mineral supplements containing calcium, iron, zinc, or selenium, take eltrombopag 2 hours before or 4 hours after these products. tell your doctor if you are of east asian descent (chinese, japanese, taiwanese, or korean); and if you have or have ever had cataracts, blood clots or conditions that increase clot risk, bleeding problems, myelodysplastic syndrome (mds), liver disease, or if your spleen has been removed. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, do not become pregnant while taking eltrombopag; use effective birth control during treatment and for 7 days after the last dose, and call your doctor if you become pregnant. do not breastfeed while taking eltrombopag. during treatment, continue to avoid activities that could cause injury or bleeding; eltrombopag lowers the chance of severe bleeding but bleeding can still occur. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet while following the timing instructions regarding calcium-containing foods and supplements. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one, and do not take more than one dose in a single day. what side effects can this medication cause? eltrombopag may cause side effects. common effects include back pain; muscle aches or spasms; headache; flu-like symptoms (fever, sore throat, cough, tiredness, chills, body aches); weakness or extreme tiredness; decreased appetite; mouth or throat pain or swelling; hair loss; rash; changes in skin color; tingling, itching, or burning of the skin; swelling of the ankles, feet, or lower legs; and, in children, toothache. serious side effects can occur. call your doctor immediately or seek emergency care if you have any of the following or those listed in the important warning: swelling, pain, tenderness, warmth, or redness in one leg; shortness of breath, coughing up blood, rapid heartbeat or rapid breathing, or pain with deep breaths; pain in the chest, arms, back, neck, jaw, or stomach; breaking out in a cold sweat or feeling lightheaded; slow or difficult speech; sudden weakness or numbness of the face, arm, or leg; sudden severe headache; sudden vision problems; sudden difficulty walking; stomach pain, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea; or cloudy, blurry, or other vision changes. eltrombopag may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: eluxadoline
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? eluxadoline is used in adults to treat irritable bowel syndrome with diarrhea (ibs-d), a condition that causes abdominal pain, cramping, and loose or watery stools. eluxadoline belongs to a class of medicines called mu-opioid receptor agonists and works by slowing bowel activity. how should this medicine be used? eluxadoline is taken by mouth as a tablet, usually with food twice daily. take it at the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not take more or less than prescribed or use it more often. eluxadoline may be habit-forming; do not increase your dose, dosing frequency, or duration without your doctor’s guidance. other uses for this medicine this medicine may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking eluxadoline, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to eluxadoline, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets; check the medication guide or ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. you may use loperamide (imodium a-d) occasionally for severe diarrhea while taking eluxadoline, but stop loperamide right away if you become constipated. tell your doctor if you are currently constipated or often become constipated; if you drink more than 3 alcoholic beverages a day or have a history of heavy alcohol use; or if you do not have a gallbladder. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had bile duct obstruction; sphincter of oddi dysfunction; bowel blockage; pancreatitis; or liver disease—your doctor will likely tell you not to take eluxadoline. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while taking eluxadoline, call your doctor. eluxadoline may cause drowsiness, especially if you have liver disease; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. if you regularly drink alcohol or sometimes drink large amounts in a short time, ask your doctor about safe use while taking eluxadoline, as alcohol may raise your risk of pancreatitis. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other directions, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember, with food. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? eluxadoline may cause side effects. tell your doctor if these symptoms are severe or do not go away: nausea; vomiting. some side effects can be serious. stop taking eluxadoline and call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have: severe upper abdominal pain that may spread to the back or shoulder (with or without nausea and vomiting); severe constipation; rash; hives; swelling of the face or throat; shortness of breath; tightness in the throat; chest pain or tightness; or trouble swallowing or breathing. eluxadoline may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: elvitegravir, cobicistat, emtricitabine, and tenofovir alafenamide af
instructions: important warning: elvitegravir, cobicistat, emtricitabine, and tenofovir alafenamide af are not used to treat hepatitis b virus (hbv). if you have or think you may have hbv, your doctor may test you before starting this medicine. if you have hbv and stop taking this medicine, your hbv may suddenly worsen. your doctor will examine you and order lab tests regularly for several months after you stop. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor will order certain tests before and during treatment. talk to your doctor about the risks of taking this medicine. why is this medication prescribed? the combination of elvitegravir, cobicistat, emtricitabine, and tenofovir alafenamide af is used to treat human immunodeficiency virus (hiv) infection. it is in a class of antiviral medications. elvitegravir, emtricitabine, and tenofovir lower the amount of hiv in the blood. cobicistat helps keep elvitegravir in the body longer so it has a greater effect. although this medicine will not cure hiv, it may decrease your chance of developing acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (aids) and hiv‑related illnesses. taking this medicine and making other lifestyle changes may reduce the risk of passing hiv to others. how should this medicine be used? this medicine comes as a tablet to take by mouth. take it with food once a day at the same time each day. take it exactly as directed. do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed by your doctor. this medicine helps control hiv infection but does not cure it. continue to take it even if you feel well. do not stop taking it without talking to your doctor. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking this medicine, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to it, any of its ingredients, or any other medications, foods, or substances, and describe your allergy symptoms. some medicines should not be taken with this combination, and others may require dosing changes or extra monitoring. discuss all prescription, nonprescription, and herbal products you use or plan to use with your doctor and pharmacist before starting. do not start, stop, or change any medicines while taking this medicine without your doctor’s advice. nonprescription or herbal products that may interact include st. john’s wort, and aspirin or other nonsteroidal anti‑inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as ibuprofen (advil) and naproxen (aleve, naprosyn). tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are taking these medications and do not start them without discussing with your healthcare provider. if you take antacids containing aluminum, magnesium, or calcium (for example, maalox, mylanta), take them 2 hours before or 2 hours after this medicine. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had hbv (see important warning), any infection that does not go away or that comes and goes such as tuberculosis (tb) or cytomegalovirus (cmv), or liver or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; if you become pregnant while taking this medicine, call your doctor right away. tell your doctor if you are breastfeeding or plan to breastfeed. some of this medicine and hiv may be passed to your baby in breast milk; ask your doctor about the risks of breastfeeding while taking this medicine. while you are taking medicines to treat hiv, your immune system may get stronger and begin to fight infections already in your body, which can cause symptoms. if you develop new or worsening symptoms, tell your doctor right away. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? elvitegravir, cobicistat, emtricitabine, and tenofovir alafenamide af may cause side effects. call your doctor if any side effects are severe or do not go away; common side effects may include nausea. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following, or any symptoms listed in the important warning or special precautions sections, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help: rash; hives; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; hoarseness; difficulty swallowing or breathing; decreased urination; pain in the upper right part of your stomach, loss of appetite, flu‑like symptoms, nausea, vomiting, extreme tiredness, unusual bleeding or bruising, dark yellow or brown urine, light‑colored bowel movements, yellowing of the skin or eyes; weakness, dizziness, lightheadedness, fast or irregular heartbeat, trouble breathing, feeling cold (especially in the arms or legs), or muscle pain. this medicine may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: elvitegravir, cobicistat, emtricitabine, and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (df)
instructions: important warning: elvitegravir, cobicistat, emtricitabine, and tenofovir df do not treat hepatitis b virus (hbv). if you have hbv or think you may have it, your doctor may test you before starting treatment. if you have hbv and then stop this medicine, your hepatitis may suddenly worsen. your doctor will examine you and order lab tests regularly for several months after you stop. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor will order certain tests before and during treatment. talk with your doctor about the risks of taking elvitegravir, cobicistat, emtricitabine, and tenofovir df. why is this medication prescribed? the combination of elvitegravir, cobicistat, emtricitabine, and tenofovir df is used to treat human immunodeficiency virus (hiv) infection. it belongs to a class of antiviral medications. elvitegravir, emtricitabine, and tenofovir lower the amount of hiv in the blood, while cobicistat helps keep elvitegravir in the body longer to enhance its effect. this combination does not cure hiv but may reduce the chance of developing acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (aids) and hiv-related illnesses. taking these medicines and making other lifestyle changes may also lower the risk of transmitting hiv to others. how should this medicine be used? elvitegravir, cobicistat, emtricitabine, and tenofovir df come as a tablet taken by mouth. take it with food once daily at the same time each day. take exactly as prescribed; do not take more or less, or more often, than your doctor directs. this medicine helps control hiv but does not cure it. continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop taking it without speaking to your doctor. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking elvitegravir, cobicistat, emtricitabine, and tenofovir df, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to any of its ingredients or to any drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your allergy symptoms. some medicines should not be taken with this combination; others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. review all prescription, nonprescription, and herbal products you use or plan to use with your doctor and pharmacist before starting. do not start, stop, or change any medicines while taking this drug without your doctor’s advice. nonprescription or herbal products that may interact include st. john’s wort and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as aspirin, ibuprofen (advil, motrin), and naproxen (aleve, naprosyn); tell your doctor and pharmacist if you use these, and do not start them without medical guidance. if you take antacids containing aluminum, magnesium, or calcium (such as maalox, mylanta), take them 2 hours before or 2 hours after this medication. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had hbv (see important warning), bone problems including osteoporosis or fractures, any infection that does not go away or recurs (such as tuberculosis [tb] or cytomegalovirus [cmv]), or liver or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; if you become pregnant while taking this medicine, call your doctor right away. if you are breastfeeding or plan to breastfeed, talk to your doctor; hiv and some of the medicine can pass into breast milk. while being treated for hiv, your immune system may get stronger and begin to fight infections already in your body, causing new or worsening symptoms; contact your doctor if this occurs. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember, with food. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? elvitegravir, cobicistat, emtricitabine, and tenofovir df may cause side effects. if these symptoms are severe or do not go away, call your doctor: nausea; diarrhea. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or get emergency help if you have swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; hoarseness; difficulty swallowing or breathing; decreased urination; pain in the arms, hands, feet, or legs; pain in the upper right part of the abdomen; loss of appetite; flu-like symptoms; nausea; vomiting; extreme tiredness; unusual bleeding or bruising; dark yellow or brown urine; light-colored stools; yellowing of the skin or eyes; weakness; dizziness; lightheadedness; fast or irregular heartbeat; trouble breathing; feeling cold, especially in the arms or legs; or muscle pain. this medication may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: emapalumab-lzsg injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? emapalumab-lzsg injection is used to treat primary hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (hlh) and hlh/macrophage activation syndrome (mas), a serious condition that can occur in certain patients with still’s disease, including systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (sjia). it belongs to a class of medicines called monoclonal antibodies and works by blocking a protein in the immune system that drives inflammation. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? emapalumab-lzsg is given as a liquid infusion into a vein over about 1 hour by a doctor or nurse in a hospital or clinic. your doctor will determine how often you receive it based on your condition and how you respond to treatment. serious infusion reactions can occur during or shortly after the dose; you will be monitored closely. tell your doctor or nurse right away if you develop any of the following during or after the infusion: skin redness; itching; fever; rash; excessive sweating; chills; nausea; vomiting; lightheadedness; dizziness; headache; bone pain; burning, numbness, or tingling; feeling cold in your arms, hands, legs, or feet; chest pain; or shortness of breath. you will receive a medication guide at the start of therapy and with each dose; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving emapalumab-lzsg, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to this medicine, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your allergy symptoms. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any medical conditions, and provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant during treatment. this medicine can lower your ability to fight infections and increase the risk of serious or life-threatening infections. tell your doctor if you frequently get infections or if you have or think you may have any infection now, including minor cuts or sores, recurrent infections such as herpes or cold sores, or chronic infections that do not go away, and if you have or have ever had shingles (herpes zoster) or a fungal infection such as histoplasmosis. call your doctor right away if you develop signs of infection during or soon after treatment: fever, sweats, or chills; muscle aches; cough; bloody mucus; shortness of breath; sore throat or trouble swallowing; warm, red, or painful skin or sores; diarrhea; stomach pain; frequent, urgent, or painful urination; or other symptoms of infection. you may have inactive (latent) tuberculosis (tb) without symptoms; this medicine can increase the risk that tb becomes active. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had tb, have lived in places where tb is common, or have been around someone with tb. your doctor will check you for tb before treatment and may treat you for tb if indicated. call your doctor immediately if you have symptoms of tb now or during treatment, such as cough, coughing up blood or mucus, weakness or tiredness, weight loss, loss of appetite, chills, fever, or night sweats. do not receive any vaccinations without talking to your doctor during treatment and for at least 4 weeks after your final dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is administered by a healthcare professional. if you miss an infusion or appointment, contact your doctor or clinic as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to make up a dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? emapalumab-lzsg can cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: constipation; nosebleeds; irritability; swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or get emergency medical help if you have fast, slow, or irregular heartbeat; rapid breathing; bloody or black, tarry stools; or vomit blood or material that looks like coffee grounds. also report any symptoms listed in the how should this medicine be used? and what special precautions should i follow? sections. emapalumab-lzsg may cause other side effects; talk with your doctor about what to expect and report any unusual problems.

name: emicizumab-kxwh injection
instructions: important warning: emicizumab-kxwh can cause thrombotic microangiopathy tma, a condition with blood clots and blood vessel injury that can damage the kidneys, brain, and other organs, and it can cause serious blood clots in the arms, legs, lungs, or head, especially if activated prothrombin complex concentrate apcc is used to treat breakthrough bleeding. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have confusion; weakness; swelling, pain, or redness in an arm or leg; yellowing of the skin or eyes; stomach, chest, or back pain; nausea or vomiting; feeling faint; decreased urination; eye pain, eye swelling, or vision problems; fast heartbeat; facial numbness; headache; shortness of breath; or coughing up blood. discuss with your doctor how and when to treat breakthrough bleeds. keep all appointments for checkups and lab tests so your doctor can monitor your response to emicizumab-kxwh. you will receive a medication guide when you start treatment and with each refill; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. talk with your doctor about the risks of using emicizumab-kxwh injection. why is this medication prescribed? emicizumab-kxwh injection helps prevent or reduce how often bleeding occurs in adults, children, and infants with hemophilia a, a disorder in which blood does not clot normally due to a missing or faulty clotting factor. emicizumab-kxwh is a hemostatic antibody that bridges clotting factors to support blood clotting. how should this medicine be used? emicizumab-kxwh is a liquid solution given by subcutaneous under the skin injection. it is given once weekly for the first 4 weeks. after that, it may be injected once every week, once every 2 weeks, or once every 4 weeks, as directed by your doctor. follow your prescription instructions exactly; do not use more, use less, or inject more often than prescribed. your doctor may allow you or a caregiver to give the injections at home after proper training. read the instructions for use before your first self-injection and ask your healthcare provider or pharmacist any questions. emicizumab-kxwh comes in single-use vials. let the vial sit at room temperature out of direct sunlight for 15 minutes before injection; do not warm it with a microwave, hot water, or any other heat source. throw away used syringes, needles, and vials in a puncture-resistant container; ask your pharmacist how to dispose of the container. check the expiration date on the vial. inspect the solution; it should be clear and colorless to slightly yellow, not cloudy, discolored, or containing large particles. do not use it and call your pharmacist if there are problems with the vial or package. inject into the front of the thighs upper legs or the abdomen stomach, avoiding the navel and the 2 inches 5 centimeters around it. if someone else gives the injection, the outer upper arm can also be used. rotate injection sites and use a spot at least 1 inch away from previous sites. do not inject into areas that are tender, bruised, red, hard, broken, or have scars or moles. emicizumab-kxwh helps control bleeding in hemophilia a but does not cure it; continue using it even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine this medication may be used for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving emicizumab-kxwh, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to emicizumab-kxwh, to any other medicines, or to any ingredient in the injection; check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any other medical conditions. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; you should not become pregnant while using emicizumab-kxwh. discuss effective birth control to use during treatment and call your doctor if you become pregnant. tell your doctor if you are breastfeeding. if you are having any surgery, including dental procedures, tell the doctor or dentist that you are using emicizumab-kxwh. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? inject the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not inject two doses on the same day to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? emicizumab-kxwh may cause side effects. call your doctor if any of the following are severe or do not go away: redness, tenderness, warmth, or itching at the injection site; headache; joint pain. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any symptoms listed in the important warning section, seek emergency care right away. increased bleeding can also occur. emicizumab-kxwh may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: empagliflozin
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? empagliflozin is used to lower blood sugar in adults with type 2 diabetes, a condition in which blood sugar is too high because the body does not make or use insulin normally; to reduce the risk of stroke, heart attack, or death in certain people who have type 2 diabetes; to reduce the risk of being hospitalized for heart failure and death in adults with heart failure; and to reduce the risk of worsening kidney disease, hospitalization for heart failure, and death in certain adults with kidney disease. empagliflozin is in a class of medicines called sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 sglt2 inhibitors and lowers blood sugar by helping the kidneys remove more glucose in the urine. it is not used to treat type 1 diabetes, a condition in which the body does not produce insulin. over time, high blood sugar can lead to serious or life-threatening problems such as heart disease, stroke, kidney damage, nerve damage, and eye disease. taking empagliflozin, making lifestyle changes such as diet, exercise, and quitting smoking, and checking your blood sugar regularly may help manage diabetes and improve health. this treatment may also lower your chance of heart attack, stroke, or other complications such as kidney failure, nerve damage numb, cold legs or feet, decreased sexual ability, eye problems including vision changes or loss, and gum disease. your healthcare team will advise you on the best plan to manage your diabetes. how should this medicine be used? empagliflozin comes as a tablet taken by mouth. it is usually taken once daily in the morning, with or without food. take it at about the same time each day and exactly as directed. do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. your doctor may start with a low dose and increase it as needed. empagliflozin helps control your condition but does not cure it. continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop taking empagliflozin without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine this medicine may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking empagliflozin, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this drug, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your allergy symptoms. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you regularly drink alcohol or sometimes drink large amounts in a short time binge drinking, if you are on a low sodium diet, if you have an infection, or if you have ever had an amputation. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had urinary tract infections or problems with urination, low blood pressure, high cholesterol, pancreatic disease including pancreatitis or pancreas surgery, yeast infections in the genital area, peripheral vascular disease, neuropathy, foot ulcers or sores, or kidney or liver disease. if you are male, tell your doctor if you have not been circumcised. tell your doctor if you are eating or drinking less due to illness, surgery, or a change in your diet; if you follow a ketogenic high fat, low carbohydrate diet; or if you have recently had diarrhea, vomiting, too much sun exposure, or heavy sweating, which can cause dehydration. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. do not breastfeed while taking empagliflozin. if you become pregnant while taking this medicine, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you take empagliflozin; you may be told to stop it at least 3 days before surgery. alcohol can change blood sugar; ask your doctor about safe use of alcoholic beverages while taking this medicine. empagliflozin may cause dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting when you get up too quickly from lying down, especially when you first start it. to help prevent this, rise slowly and rest your feet on the floor for a few minutes before standing. ask your doctor what to do if you get sick, develop an infection or fever, are under unusual stress, or are injured, because these can affect your blood sugar and the dose you may need. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow the exercise and meal plan recommended by your doctor or dietitian. eat a healthy diet and exercise regularly. follow your doctor instructions about drinking enough fluids during the day while you are taking this medicine. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? this medicine may cause changes in your blood sugar. know the symptoms of low and high blood sugar and what to do if they occur. common side effects include urinating a lot including at night and increased thirst. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away if you have any of the following: frequent, urgent, burning, or painful urination; passing less urine; urine that is cloudy, red, pink, or brown; strong smelling urine; pelvic or rectal pain; fever, back pain, nausea, or vomiting; in women, vaginal odor, white or yellowish discharge that may be lumpy like cottage cheese, or vaginal itching; in men, redness, itching, or swelling of the penis; rash on the penis; foul smelling discharge from the penis; or pain in the skin around the penis; feeling tired, weak, or unwell along with fever and pain, tenderness, redness, and swelling of the genitals or the area between the genitals and the rectum. stop taking empagliflozin and call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have signs of an allergic reaction such as rash, hives, itching, trouble breathing or swallowing, swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, mouth, or eyes, or hoarseness. stop taking empagliflozin and call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have symptoms of ketoacidosis; if possible, check your urine for ketones even if your blood sugar is less than 250 mg/dl. symptoms include nausea, vomiting, stomach area pain, tiredness, or trouble breathing. empagliflozin can increase the risk of a lower limb toe, foot, or leg amputation. your doctor will tell you how to care for your legs and feet to help avoid infections and complications that could lead to an amputation. follow these instructions carefully and call your doctor right away if you have pain, tenderness, sores, ulcers, or an area on your leg or foot that is swollen, warm, or red; fever or chills; or other signs of infection. empagliflozin can cause dehydration. drink plenty of water while taking it. ask your doctor or pharmacist how much fluid you should drink to help prevent dehydration. empagliflozin may cause other side effects. contact your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medicine.

name: emtricitabine
instructions: important warning: emtricitabine does not treat hepatitis b virus infection hbv. if you have or think you may have hbv, your doctor may test you before starting emtricitabine. if you have hbv and take emtricitabine, your liver condition may suddenly worsen when you stop the medicine. your doctor will examine you and order lab tests regularly for several months after you stop. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor may order tests to see how your body responds to emtricitabine. talk with your doctor about the risks of taking emtricitabine. why is this medication prescribed? emtricitabine is used to treat human immunodeficiency virus hiv infection. it belongs to a class of medicines called nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors nrtis and works by lowering the amount of hiv in the blood. although emtricitabine does not cure hiv, it can lower your risk of developing acquired immunodeficiency syndrome aids and hiv related illnesses. taking these medicines and making other lifestyle changes may also lower the risk of transmitting hiv to others. how should this medicine be used? emtricitabine is available as a capsule and an oral solution liquid to take by mouth. take it once daily with or without food, at about the same time each day. take emtricitabine exactly as directed. do not take more or less than prescribed, and do not take it more often than directed by your doctor. emtricitabine controls hiv but does not cure it, so continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop taking emtricitabine without talking to your doctor. if you miss doses or stop taking it, your condition may become harder to treat. ask your doctor or pharmacist for a copy of the manufacturer patient information for the patient. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking emtricitabine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to emtricitabine, any ingredients in the product, or any other drugs, foods, or substances; describe the allergy and what symptoms you had. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had hbv or the conditions mentioned in the important warning section; any long lasting or recurrent infections such as tuberculosis tb or cytomegalovirus cmv; or liver or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; if you become pregnant while taking emtricitabine, call your doctor. tell your doctor if you are breastfeeding or plan to breastfeed; some of the medicine and hiv may pass to the baby in breast milk, so discuss the risks of breastfeeding while taking emtricitabine. you should know that while taking hiv medicines, your immune system may get stronger and start to fight infections already in your body, which can cause new or worsening symptoms; if this happens after starting treatment with emtricitabine, contact your doctor right away. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take more than one dose of emtricitabine in one day and do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? emtricitabine may cause side effects. common side effects include headache; weakness or tiredness; dizziness; changes in skin color especially on the palms of the hands or the soles of the feet; abdominal pain; diarrhea; nausea; unusual dreams; depression; difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep; numbness, burning, or tingling in the hands, arms, feet, or legs; runny nose. call your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following, or those mentioned in the important warning section, call your doctor immediately: fever, chills, sore throat, cough, or other signs of infection; rash; nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, pain in the upper right part of the abdomen, dark yellow or brown urine, light colored bowel movements, yellowing of the skin or eyes; weakness, extreme tiredness, fast breathing, shortness of breath, feeling cold especially in the arms or legs, muscle pain, dizziness or lightheadedness, fast or abnormal heartbeat. emtricitabine may cause other side effects. if you notice any unusual symptoms, contact your doctor.

name: emtricitabine and tenofovir alafenamide
instructions: important warning: emtricitabine and tenofovir alafenamide (af) should not be used to treat hepatitis b virus (hbv) infection. if you have or think you may have hbv, your doctor may test you before you begin treatment. if you have hbv and take emtricitabine and tenofovir af, your condition may suddenly worsen when you stop taking it. your doctor will examine you and order lab tests regularly for several months after you stop. if you are taking emtricitabine and tenofovir af to help prevent you from getting hiv, your doctor will test you for hiv before you begin treatment. tell your doctor if you have had any of these symptoms in the last month or if you develop any of the following while taking emtricitabine and tenofovir af for hiv prevention: fever, tiredness, joint or muscle pain, rash, night sweats, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, sore throat, or swollen neck or groin. contact your doctor right away if you think you may have been exposed to hiv. emtricitabine and tenofovir af does not always prevent hiv. your doctor will order hiv tests at least every 3 months while you are taking it. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor will order certain tests before and during treatment to check your response. you will receive a medication guide when you begin treatment and each time you refill; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have any questions. talk to your doctor about the risks of taking emtricitabine and tenofovir af. why is this medication prescribed? the combination of emtricitabine and tenofovir af is used to treat human immunodeficiency virus (hiv) infection. it is also used, along with practicing safer sex (e.g., condom use), to reduce the risk of hiv infection. emtricitabine and tenofovir af are nucleoside and nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitors (nrtis) that work by slowing the spread of hiv in the body. although they will not cure hiv, these medications may decrease your chance of developing acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (aids) and hiv-related illnesses. taking these medications and making other lifestyle changes may reduce the risk of transmitting hiv to others. how should this medicine be used? emtricitabine and tenofovir af comes as a tablet to take by mouth. take it once a day, with or without food, at the same time each day. take it exactly as directed; do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed by your doctor. continue to take it even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor. if you stop even for a short time, or if you skip doses, the virus may become resistant and harder to treat. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking emtricitabine and tenofovir af, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this drug, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe the symptoms you had. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. some nonprescription or herbal products may interact, including st. john’s wort and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications (nsaids) such as aspirin, ibuprofen (advil, motrin), and naproxen (aleve, naprosyn). do not start any of these while taking emtricitabine and tenofovir af without discussing with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had the conditions mentioned in the important warning section; any infection that does not go away or that comes and goes such as tuberculosis (tb) or cytomegalovirus (cmv); or liver or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; if you become pregnant while taking emtricitabine and tenofovir af, call your doctor. tell your doctor if you are breastfeeding or plan to breastfeed. some of the medication and hiv may be passed to your baby in breast milk. you should know that while you are taking medications to treat hiv infection, your immune system may get stronger and begin to fight infections already in your body, which may cause you to develop symptoms of those infections. if you have new or worsening symptoms during treatment, tell your doctor right away. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember it. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? emtricitabine and tenofovir af may cause side effects. common side effects include nausea and diarrhea. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of these symptoms or those listed in the important warning or special precautions sections, call your doctor immediately: decreased urination; nausea, vomiting, pain in the upper right part of the stomach, loss of appetite, flu-like symptoms, unusual bleeding or bruising, dark yellow or brown urine, light-colored bowel movements, or yellowing of the skin or eyes; feeling cold, especially in the arms or legs; fast or irregular heartbeat; dizziness; lightheadedness; or stomach pain with nausea and vomiting. emtricitabine and tenofovir af may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: emtricitabine and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (df)
instructions: important warning: emtricitabine and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (df) should not be used to treat hepatitis b virus (hbv). if you have or think you may have hbv, your doctor may test you for hbv before starting treatment. if you have hbv and you stop taking emtricitabine and tenofovir df, your hepatitis may suddenly worsen; your doctor will examine you and order lab tests regularly for several months after you stop. if you are taking emtricitabine and tenofovir df to help prevent hiv, your doctor will test you for hiv before you start. tell your doctor if you have had any of these symptoms in the last month or if you develop them while taking this medicine to prevent hiv: fever, tiredness, joint or muscle pain, rash, night sweats, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, sore throat, or swollen lymph nodes in the neck or groin. contact your doctor right away if you think you have been exposed to hiv. emtricitabine and tenofovir df does not always prevent hiv; your doctor will order hiv tests at least every 3 months while you are taking it. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor will order certain tests before and during treatment to check your response. your doctor or pharmacist will give you the medication guide when you begin treatment and each time you refill your prescription; read it carefully and ask questions. talk to your doctor about the risks of taking emtricitabine and tenofovir df. why is this medication prescribed? the combination of emtricitabine and tenofovir df is used to treat hiv. it is also used, along with practicing safer sex (for example, condom use), to reduce the risk of hiv infection. emtricitabine and tenofovir df are nucleoside and nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitors (nrtis) that work by slowing the spread of hiv in the body. although they will not cure hiv, these medicines may lower your chance of developing aids and hiv-related illnesses. taking these medicines and making other lifestyle changes may reduce the risk of getting or transmitting hiv to other people. how should this medicine be used? emtricitabine and tenofovir df comes as a tablet to take by mouth, usually once daily with or without food. take it at the same time each day and exactly as directed. do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. if your child is taking this medicine, the tablet should be swallowed whole; if your child cannot swallow tablets, talk to your doctor. continue taking the medicine even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor. if you stop even briefly or skip doses, the virus may become resistant and harder to treat. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking emtricitabine and tenofovir df, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this drug, any of its components, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your allergy symptoms. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and nutritional supplements you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you for side effects. know that certain nonprescription products may interact with this medicine, including aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin) and naproxen (aleve, naprosyn); do not start these without discussing with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had hbv (as noted above), bone problems including osteoporosis or fractures, any infection that does not go away or that comes and goes (such as tuberculosis or cytomegalovirus), or liver or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; if you become pregnant, call your doctor. if you are breastfeeding or plan to breastfeed, talk to your doctor; some of the medication and hiv may pass into breast milk. be aware that as your immune system strengthens during hiv treatment, it may begin to fight infections already in your body (immune reconstitution), causing new or worsening symptoms; report any new or worsening symptoms to your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember it that day. do not take more than one dose in a day, and do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? emtricitabine and tenofovir df may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: depression, anxiety, trouble falling or staying asleep, unusual dreams, pain/burning/tingling in the hands or feet, heartburn, or weight loss. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have any of the following or those listed in the important warning or special precautions sections: swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; hoarseness; difficulty swallowing or breathing; decreased urination or frequent urination; muscle pain; bone pain; drinking more than usual; nausea; vomiting; pain in the upper right part of the stomach; loss of appetite; flu-like symptoms; unusual bleeding or bruising; dark yellow or brown urine; light-colored bowel movements; yellowing of the skin or eyes; feeling cold, especially in the arms or legs; fast or irregular heartbeat; dizziness; lightheadedness; or stomach pain with nausea and vomiting. emtricitabine and tenofovir df may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: emtricitabine, rilpivirine, and tenofovir alafenamide
instructions: important warning: emtricitabine, rilpivirine, and tenofovir alafenamide (taf) does not treat hepatitis b virus infection (hbv). if you have hbv or think you may have hbv, your doctor may test you before starting this medicine. if you have hbv and stop this medicine, your hepatitis may suddenly worsen. your doctor will examine you and order blood tests regularly for several months after you stop treatment. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor will order tests to check your response to this medicine. talk with your doctor about the risks and benefits before starting. why is this medication prescribed? the combination of emtricitabine, rilpivirine, and tenofovir alafenamide is used to treat hiv. emtricitabine and tenofovir alafenamide are nucleoside or nucleotide reverse transcriptase inhibitors (nrtis), and rilpivirine is a nonnucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (nnrti). together they slow the spread of hiv in the body. although this medicine will not cure hiv, it may decrease your chance of developing acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (aids) and hiv related illnesses and, with appropriate precautions, may lower the risk of transmitting hiv to other people. how should this medicine be used? this medicine comes as a tablet to take by mouth once a day with food. take it at the same time every day. swallow the tablet whole. take it exactly as directed. do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed by your doctor. continue to take it even if you feel well. do not stop taking it without talking to your doctor. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer information for patients. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking emtricitabine, rilpivirine, and tenofovir alafenamide, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this medication, any of its ingredients, or any other medications, foods, or substances, and what symptoms you had. some medicines should not be taken with this combination, and others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. discuss all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and herbal products you use or plan to use with your doctor and pharmacist, and do not start, stop, or change any medicine without medical advice. the following nonprescription or herbal products may interact: nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as ibuprofen and naproxen, and st. john s wort. do not start these while taking this medicine without discussing with your healthcare provider. if you take antacids containing calcium, magnesium, or aluminum, take the antacid 2 hours before or at least 4 hours after this medicine. if you take a medicine for indigestion, heartburn, or ulcers such as cimetidine, famotidine, nizatidine, or ranitidine, take it at least 12 hours before or at least 4 hours after this medicine. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had hbv (see important warning), depression or other mental illness, any long lasting or recurrent infections such as tuberculosis or cytomegalovirus, or liver or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. if you become pregnant while taking this medicine, call your doctor. you should not breastfeed if you have hiv or if you are taking this medicine, because both the virus and the medicine can pass into breast milk. this medicine may cause changes in thoughts, behavior, or mental health. call your doctor right away if you develop new or worsening depression; feeling sad, hopeless, anxious, or restless; or thoughts about harming yourself. while taking medicines to treat hiv, your immune system may get stronger and begin to fight infections already in your body, which may cause you to develop new or worsening symptoms. if you have new or worsening symptoms at any time during treatment, contact your doctor promptly. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet; always take this medicine with a meal. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember it. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take two doses at the same time to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? emtricitabine, rilpivirine, and tenofovir alafenamide may cause side effects. common side effects include headache and difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following or those listed in the important warning or special precautions sections, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment: decreased urination; weakness; muscle pain; dizziness; lightheadedness; fast or irregular heartbeat; difficulty breathing; feeling cold, especially in the arms or legs; nausea; vomiting; loss of appetite; extreme tiredness; dark yellow or brown urine; light colored bowel movements; yellowing of the skin or eyes; pain in the upper right part of the stomach; flu like symptoms; unusual bleeding or bruising. if you develop a severe rash with any of the following symptoms, stop taking this medicine and call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment: swollen face, lips, mouth, tongue, or throat; difficulty swallowing or breathing; mouth sores or blisters on your body; pink and swollen eyes; fever; dark urine; pain on the right side of the stomach area; yellowing of the skin or eyes. this medicine may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: emtricitabine, rilpivirine, and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate
instructions: important warning: emtricitabine, rilpivirine, and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (df) should not be used to treat hepatitis b virus (hbv). if you have or think you may have hbv, your doctor may test you before starting treatment. if you have hbv and stop taking this medicine, your hepatitis may suddenly worsen. your doctor will examine you and order lab tests regularly for several months after you stop. keep all appointments. your doctor will order certain tests before and during your treatment to check your body's response. talk to your doctor about the risks of taking this medication. why is this medication prescribed? the combination of emtricitabine, rilpivirine, and tenofovir df is used to treat hiv-1 infection. it combines two nucleos(t)ide reverse transcriptase inhibitors (emtricitabine and tenofovir df) and one non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (rilpivirine) that work by slowing the spread of hiv in the body. although it will not cure hiv, it may decrease your chance of developing acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (aids) and hiv-related illnesses and, with other preventive measures, may lower the risk of transmitting hiv to others. how should this medicine be used? the combination comes as a tablet to take by mouth. take it once a day with a meal (not just a protein drink), at the same time each day. take it exactly as directed. do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed. continue to take it even if you feel well. do not stop taking it without talking to your doctor. ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer's patient information. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this drug, any of its components, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your symptoms. some medications should not be taken with this combination; others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. review all prescription, over-the-counter, and herbal products you use with your doctor and pharmacist before starting, stopping, or changing any medication. nonprescription or herbal products that may interact include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications (nsaids) such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin) and naproxen (aleve, naprosyn) and st. john's wort; do not start these while taking this medicine without discussing with your healthcare provider. if you are taking antacids containing calcium, magnesium, or aluminum (such as maalox, mylanta, tums), take the antacid 2 hours before or at least 4 hours after this medication. if you are taking a medication for indigestion, heartburn, or ulcers such as cimetidine (tagamet), famotidine (pepcid, in duexis), nizatidine (axid), or ranitidine (zantac), take it at least 12 hours before or at least 4 hours after this medication. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had the conditions mentioned in the important warning section; depression or other mental illness; bone problems including osteoporosis or bone fractures; any type of infection that does not go away or that comes and goes (such as tuberculosis or cytomegalovirus); or liver or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. if you become pregnant while taking this medication, call your doctor. you should not breastfeed if you are infected with hiv or if you are taking this medication because hiv and the medicine can pass into breast milk. you should know that this medication may cause changes in thoughts, behavior, or mental health. call your doctor immediately if you develop new or worsening depression; feel sad, hopeless, anxious, or restless; or have thoughts about harming yourself. you should also know that as your immune system gets stronger while taking hiv medicines, it may begin to fight infections already in your body, causing new or worsening symptoms. if you have new or worsening symptoms at any time, tell your doctor right away. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet and always take each dose with a meal. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember it, with food. however, if more than 12 hours have passed since your scheduled dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? this medication may cause side effects. common side effects include difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep, unusual dreams, changes in skin color, pain, burning, or tingling in the hands or feet, headache, diarrhea, and mild rash. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment if you experience ongoing or worsening bone pain; decreased urination; weakness; muscle pain; dizziness; lightheadedness; fast or irregular heartbeat; difficulty breathing; feeling cold, especially in the arms or legs; nausea; vomiting; loss of appetite; extreme tiredness; dark yellow or brown urine; light-colored bowel movements; yellowing of the skin or eyes; pain in the upper right part of the stomach; flu-like symptoms; or unusual bleeding or bruising. if you develop a severe rash with any of the following, stop taking the medication and get emergency help: swollen face, lips, mouth, tongue, or throat; difficulty swallowing or breathing; mouth sores or blisters on your body; pink and swollen eyes; fever; dark urine; pain on the right side of the stomach area; or yellowing of the skin or eyes. this medication may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems.

name: enalapril
instructions: important warning: do not take enalapril if you are pregnant. if you become pregnant while taking enalapril, call your doctor immediately. enalapril may harm the fetus. why is this medication prescribed? enalapril is used alone or with other medications to treat high blood pressure and, with other medicines, to treat heart failure. it is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ace) inhibitor that lowers substances that tighten blood vessels, so blood flows more easily and the heart can pump more effectively. treating high blood pressure helps prevent damage to the brain, heart, blood vessels, kidneys, and other organs that could lead to heart disease, heart attack, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, vision loss, and other problems. lifestyle changes such as a low-fat, low-salt diet, keeping a healthy weight, exercising about 30 minutes most days, not smoking, and limiting alcohol also help control blood pressure. how should this medicine be used? enalapril comes as an immediate- and extended-release (long-acting) tablet to take by mouth. it is usually taken once or twice daily, with or without food. take it at the same times each day to help you remember. follow your prescription label and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. take exactly as directed; do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. your doctor will usually start you on a low dose and increase it gradually. enalapril controls, but does not cure, high blood pressure and heart failure. continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine: enalapril may also be used to treat kidney disease related to diabetes. ask your doctor about the possible risks and benefits. it may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking enalapril, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to enalapril; to other ace inhibitors such as benazepril (lotensin, in lotrel), captopril (capoten), fosinopril (monopril), lisinopril (in prinzide, in zestoretic), moexipril (univasc, in uniretic), perindopril (aceon), quinapril (accupril, in accuretic, in quinaretic), ramipril (altace), or trandolapril (mavik, in tarka); to any other medications; or to any ingredients in enalapril tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are taking sacubitril/valsartan (entresto) or if you stopped it within the last 36 hours; you should not take enalapril with sacubitril/valsartan. if you have diabetes and take aliskiren (tekturna; in amturnide, in tekamlo, in tekturna hct), your doctor will probably tell you not to take enalapril. some medications should not be taken with enalapril; others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. review all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and herbal products you use or plan to use with your doctor and pharmacist before starting enalapril, and always seek their advice before starting, stopping, or changing any medications while taking enalapril. nonprescription products that may interact include aspirin and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin, others) and naproxen (aleve); tell your doctor and pharmacist if you use these, and do not start them while on enalapril without medical advice. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had heart or kidney disease; lupus; scleroderma (a condition in which extra tissue grows on the skin and some organs);
