diabetes; or angioedema (swelling that can cause difficulty swallowing or breathing and painful swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs). tell your doctor if you are breastfeeding. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking enalapril. be aware that diarrhea, vomiting, not drinking enough fluids, or heavy sweating can lower blood pressure and cause lightheadedness or fainting. what special dietary instructions should i follow? talk to your doctor before using potassium-containing salt substitutes. if your doctor prescribes a low-salt or low-sodium diet, follow those directions carefully. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? enalapril may cause side effects. common side effects include cough, dizziness, rash, and weakness. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away if you have swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; hoarseness; trouble breathing or swallowing; yellowing of the skin or eyes; fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection; lightheadedness; or fainting. enalapril may cause other side effects.

name: enalapril and hydrochlorothiazide
instructions: important warning: do not take enalapril and hydrochlorothiazide if you are pregnant. if you become pregnant while taking this medicine, call your doctor immediately. this medicine may harm the fetus. why is this medication prescribed? the combination of enalapril and hydrochlorothiazide is used to treat high blood pressure. enalapril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme ace inhibitor that lowers certain chemicals that tighten blood vessels, helping blood flow more easily. hydrochlorothiazide is a diuretic water pill that helps the kidneys remove excess water and salt in the urine. untreated high blood pressure can damage the brain, heart, blood vessels, kidneys, and other organs, leading to heart disease, heart attack, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, vision loss, and other problems. along with medicines, lifestyle changes such as a low-fat, low-salt diet, maintaining a healthy weight, exercising at least 30 minutes most days, not smoking, and using alcohol in moderation help control blood pressure. how should this medicine be used? enalapril and hydrochlorothiazide comes as a tablet taken by mouth, with or without food, usually once or twice daily. take it at the same times each day to help you remember. follow the prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take it exactly as directed; do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. it controls high blood pressure but does not cure it. keep taking it even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine: your doctor may prescribe this medicine for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking this medicine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to enalapril vasotec, in vaseretic; hydrochlorothiazide hctz, microzide, oretic; ace inhibitors such as benazepril lotensin, in lotrel, captopril capoten, fosinopril monopril, lisinopril in prinzide and zestoretic, moexipril univasc, in uniretic, perindopril aceon, quinapril accupril, in accuretic and quinaretic, ramipril altace, or trandolapril mavik, in tarka; sulfa drugs; any other medicines; or any ingredients in the tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor if you are taking sacubitril and valsartan entresto now or if you stopped it within the last 36 hours; your doctor will usually tell you not to take enalapril and hydrochlorothiazide with sacubitril and valsartan. if you have diabetes and take aliskiren tekturna, in amturnide, tekamlo, tekturna hct, your doctor will usually tell you not to take this combination. some medicines should not be taken with enalapril and hydrochlorothiazide; others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. discuss all prescription, nonprescription, and herbal products you use or plan to use with your doctor and pharmacist before starting this medicine. do not start, stop, or change any medicines while taking it without medical advice. nonprescription products that may interact include nsaids such as ibuprofen advil, motrin and naproxen aleve, naprosyn, and potassium supplements; let your doctor and pharmacist know if you use these and do not start them without discussing with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had heart, parathyroid, liver, or kidney disease; lupus; diabetes; allergies; asthma; gout; or angioedema a condition causing hives, trouble breathing, or painful swelling of the face, lips, throat, tongue, hands, or feet. tell your doctor if you are breast-feeding. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you take this medicine. ask your doctor about safe use of alcohol, as alcohol can worsen side effects. be aware that diarrhea, vomiting, heavy sweating, or not drinking enough fluids can lower blood pressure and cause lightheadedness or fainting. what special dietary instructions should i follow? talk to your doctor before using salt substitutes that contain potassium. if you are prescribed a low-salt or low-sodium diet, follow those directions carefully. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? enalapril and hydrochlorothiazide may cause side effects. common side effects include cough, dizziness, headache, excessive tiredness, muscle cramps, and decreased sexual ability. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor immediately if you have severe lightheadedness; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; hoarseness; trouble breathing or swallowing; fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection; yellowing of the skin or eyes; dry mouth; thirst; weakness; infrequent urination; upset stomach; vomiting; fainting; chest pain; or fast or irregular heartbeat. this medicine may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: enasidenib
instructions: important warning: enasidenib can cause a serious, potentially life-threatening condition called differentiation syndrome. your doctor will monitor you closely. call your doctor right away if you develop any of the following: fever, sudden weight gain, decreased urination, swelling of the arms, legs, neck, groin, or underarm area, shortness of breath, trouble breathing, chest pain, cough, or bone pain. at the first sign of this syndrome, your doctor will start treatment for it and may tell you to pause enasidenib for a period of time. you will receive the manufacturer medication guide when you start enasidenib and with each refill; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. why is this medication prescribed? enasidenib is used to treat a certain type of acute myeloid leukemia (aml) that has worsened or returned after treatment with other chemotherapy medicines. it belongs to a class of medicines called isocitrate dehydrogenase-2 (idh2) inhibitors and works by slowing or stopping the growth of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? enasidenib is taken by mouth as a tablet once daily, with or without food, at about the same time each day. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. swallow the tablets whole with about 8 ounces (240 ml) of water; do not split, chew, or crush them. if you vomit after a dose, take another dose as soon as possible on the same day. your doctor may temporarily or permanently stop treatment, lower your dose, or prescribe other medicines depending on your side effects. do not stop taking enasidenib without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine: your doctor may prescribe this medicine for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking enasidenib, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to enasidenib or any ingredient in the tablets; ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. the following nonprescription products may interact with enasidenib: omeprazole (prilosec), dextromethorphan, and caffeine supplements; make sure your doctor and pharmacist know if you take these, and do not start them while on enasidenib without medical advice. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or plan to father a child. you should not become pregnant while taking enasidenib. you will need a negative pregnancy test before starting. use effective birth control during treatment and for 1 month after your final dose. if you are male and your partner can become pregnant, use effective contraception during treatment and for 1 month after your last dose. enasidenib may reduce the effectiveness of some oral contraceptives; discuss birth control options with your doctor. call your doctor if you or your partner becomes pregnant while taking enasidenib. do not breastfeed during treatment and for 1 month after the final dose. you should know this medicine may decrease fertility in both men and women; talk to your doctor about risks. what special dietary instructions should i follow? drink plenty of water or other fluids each day during treatment unless your doctor tells you otherwise; otherwise continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is already the next day, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? enasidenib may cause side effects. common side effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, decreased appetite, and changes in taste. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have yellowing of the eyes or skin, muscle spasms or twitching, burning, prickling, or tingling sensations on the skin, an irregular heartbeat, seizures, or any symptoms listed in the important warning section. enasidenib may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: encorafenib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? encorafenib is used to treat melanoma (a type of skin cancer), certain types of colon cancer (cancer of the large intestine), and some forms of non-small cell lung cancer (nsclc). it is a kinase inhibitor that blocks an abnormal protein that signals cancer cells to multiply, helping slow or stop their spread. how should this medicine be used? encorafenib comes as an oral capsule taken once daily, with or without food, at about the same time each day. take it exactly as prescribed; do not take more, less, or more often than directed. if you vomit after a dose, do not take another dose—continue with your regular schedule. your doctor may adjust your dose, delay, or stop treatment based on side effects. tell your healthcare provider how you are feeling during treatment. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking encorafenib, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to it, any of its ingredients, or any drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your symptoms. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and supplements you take or plan to take; dose changes or extra monitoring may be needed. st. john’s wort can interact with encorafenib—do not start st. john’s wort while taking encorafenib unless your healthcare provider approves. encorafenib may decrease the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives (birth control pills, patches, rings, injections); use a nonhormonal method to prevent pregnancy while taking encorafenib. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had qt interval prolongation (an irregular heart rhythm that can cause fainting, seizures, or sudden death), heart failure, a heart attack or other heart problems; low potassium, calcium, or magnesium; bleeding problems; eye problems; or liver or kidney disease. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, you should not become pregnant while using encorafenib; if you can become pregnant, you may need a pregnancy test before starting. use effective nonhormonal birth control during treatment and for 2 weeks after your final dose. if you become pregnant, call your doctor right away; encorafenib may harm the fetus. do not breastfeed during treatment and for 2 weeks after the last dose. this medicine may decrease fertility in men; discuss risks with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not eat grapefruit or drink grapefruit juice while taking encorafenib. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is within 12 hours of your next dose; if so, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose. what side effects can this medication cause? encorafenib may cause side effects. common side effects include fatigue, fever, nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, constipation, decreased appetite, headache, dizziness, skin thickening, rash, dry or itchy skin, hair loss, joint or muscle pain, changes in taste, back/arm/leg pain, acne, numbness, burning or tingling in the hands or feet, and trouble sleeping. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have dizziness, fainting, feeling lightheaded, or a fast or irregular heartbeat; blurred vision, loss of vision, other vision changes, or eye pain, swelling, or redness; skin changes such as a new wart, a sore or reddish bump that does not heal, or changes in a mole; unusual bleeding or bruising; black, tarry, or bloody stools; coughing up blood; vomiting blood or material that looks like coffee grounds; or nosebleeds; swelling in your hands, ankles, legs, or feet; shortness of breath; fast or pounding heartbeat; feeling faint; signs of liver problems such as nausea, vomiting, lack of energy, loss of appetite, dark urine, pain in the upper right abdomen, or yellowing of the skin or eyes; or redness, swelling, numbness, and skin peeling of the hands and soles of the feet. encorafenib may increase the risk of developing other cancers, including skin cancer; your doctor will check your skin before treatment, every 2 months during treatment, and for up to 6 months after your final dose. encorafenib may cause other side effects; tell your doctor about any unusual problems.

name: enfortumab vedotin-ejfv injection
instructions: important warning: enfortumab vedotin-ejfv may cause serious or life-threatening skin reactions. your doctor will monitor you closely for skin reactions during treatment. call your doctor immediately if you develop new or worsening rash or itching; blisters or peeling skin; painful sores or ulcers on your skin, lips, nose, or in your mouth; fever or flu-like symptoms; or swollen glands. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory; tests will be ordered to check your response to treatment. discuss the risks of receiving enfortumab vedotin-ejfv injection with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? enfortumab vedotin-ejfv injection is used alone or with pembrolizumab (keytruda) to treat urothelial cancer (cancer of the lining of the bladder and other parts of the urinary tract) that has spread or cannot be removed by surgery and has worsened after other chemotherapy medications or when those medications cannot be used. it belongs to a class of medications called monoclonal antibodies and works by helping your immune system slow or stop the growth of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? enfortumab vedotin-ejfv comes as a powder that is mixed with liquid and infused into a vein over about 30 minutes by a healthcare professional in a hospital or clinic. when given alone, it is usually infused on days 1, 8, and 15 of a 28-day cycle; when given with pembrolizumab, it is usually infused on days 1 and 8 of a 21-day cycle. treatment continues as long as your doctor recommends. your doctor may delay or stop treatment, or add other medications, based on your response and side effects. tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving enfortumab vedotin-ejfv, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to this medication, any other medicines, or any ingredients in enfortumab vedotin-ejfv; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you closely for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had peripheral neuropathy (tingling, numbness, or pain in the hands and feet), diabetes or high blood sugar, abnormal blood levels of sodium, phosphate, potassium, or calcium, lung or pancreas problems, or liver disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or plan to father a child, do not become pregnant while receiving this medication. your doctor may perform a pregnancy test before treatment. females should use effective birth control during treatment and for 2 months after the final dose; males with female partners should use birth control during treatment and for 4 months after the final dose. call your doctor if pregnancy occurs; enfortumab vedotin-ejfv may harm the fetus. do not breast-feed while receiving this medication and for at least 3 weeks after the final dose. this medication may decrease fertility in men and women; discuss risks with your doctor. you may develop high blood sugar during treatment, even if you do not have diabetes. call your doctor immediately if you experience extreme thirst, frequent urination, extreme hunger, blurred vision, or weakness. untreated high blood sugar can lead to ketoacidosis, which can be life-threatening; seek urgent care for dry mouth, nausea and vomiting, shortness of breath, fruity-smelling breath, or decreased consciousness. this medication may cause dry eyes and other eye problems, which can be serious; your doctor may recommend artificial tears or lubricating eye drops during treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given by a healthcare professional; if you miss or cannot keep an infusion appointment, contact your doctor or clinic as soon as possible to reschedule. do not attempt to make up a missed dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? enfortumab vedotin-ejfv may cause side effects. common effects include diarrhea, vomiting, nausea, constipation, loss of appetite, weight loss, taste changes, hair loss, dry skin, unusual tiredness or lack of energy, dizziness, muscle, joint, back, or bone pain, and swelling of the arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have shortness of breath, trouble breathing, cough, pale skin, unusual bleeding or bruising, redness, swelling, fever, or pain at the injection site, blurred vision, loss of vision, eye pain or redness, watery eyes, or other visual changes, numbness, burning, or tingling in the hands or feet, muscle weakness, difficult or painful urination, or cloudy, discolored, or bloody urine. also seek care for the symptoms listed in the important warning and special precautions sections. enfortumab vedotin-ejfv may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you experience any unusual problems.

name: enfuvirtide injection
instructions: notice: enfuvirtide injection has been discontinued in the u.s. because this drug is no longer available in the u.s. market, this monograph is not being updated. if this drug is used outside the u.s., consult the manufacturer’s labeling for the most current information. why is this medication prescribed? enfuvirtide injection is used with other medicines to treat human immunodeficiency virus (hiv) infection in adults and in children who weigh at least 24 pounds (11 kg) who have previously been treated with several hiv medicines and whose hiv is not adequately controlled by other treatments, including their current regimen. enfuvirtide is an hiv entry and fusion inhibitor that lowers the amount of hiv in the blood. it does not cure hiv, but it may reduce the risk of developing acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (aids) and hiv-related illnesses such as serious infections or certain cancers. taking these medications, practicing safer sex, and making other lifestyle changes may lower the chance of transmitting hiv to others. how should this medicine be used? enfuvirtide comes as a powder to be mixed with sterile water and injected subcutaneously (under the skin). it is usually injected twice daily at about the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly. do not use more or less than prescribed or use it more often. enfuvirtide controls hiv but does not cure it. continue using it even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor; missing doses or stopping may make hiv harder to treat. a healthcare provider will show you or a caregiver how to mix and inject doses at home. read and understand the manufacturer’s patient instructions before first use, including how to mix the medication, where to inject, how to inject, and what syringe and needle to use. inject into the front of the thighs or the lower abdomen, avoiding the 2-inch (5-cm) area around the navel. if someone else gives the injection, the outer area of the upper arms can be used. do not inject under a belt or waistband; near the elbow, knee, or groin; in the lower or inner buttocks; or directly over a blood vessel. rotate injection sites to reduce soreness. keep track of sites and do not inject into the same area twice in a row. check the area with your fingertips for hard lumps; do not inject into areas with a tattoo, scar, bruise, mole, burn, or where you had a prior reaction to enfuvirtide. never reuse needles, syringes, vials of medication, or vials of sterile water. dispose of used needles and syringes in a puncture-resistant sharps container; do not put them in household trash. ask your pharmacist or local health department how to dispose of the sharps container, used vials, and alcohol pads. wash your hands with soap and water before preparing a dose, and after washing, touch only the medication, supplies, and the injection site. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s injection instructions and follow them carefully. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using enfuvirtide, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to enfuvirtide, mannitol, any other medications, or any ingredients in the injection; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you smoke; if you use or have used intravenous (iv) street drugs; and if you have or have had hemophilia or other bleeding/clotting disorders, a low cd4 count, or lung disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using enfuvirtide, call your doctor. do not breastfeed if you have hiv or are using enfuvirtide. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how this medicine affects you. you should know that as your immune system improves while on hiv treatment, it may start to fight infections already in your body, and you may develop new or worsening symptoms; report any new or worsening symptoms to your doctor right away. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? inject the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not inject a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? enfuvirtide may cause side effects. common effects include: itching, swelling, pain, tingling, discomfort, tenderness, redness, bruising, hardened skin, or bumps at the injection site; red bumps or pimples around hair follicles; tiredness; muscle pain; nausea; decreased appetite; weight loss; diarrhea; arm or leg pain; stomach pain; flu-like symptoms; nasal congestion; cold sores; dry mouth; painful, itchy, red, or teary eyes. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have: worsening pain, oozing, swelling, warmth, or redness at an injection site; rash, hives, itching, trouble breathing or swallowing, nausea, vomiting, or swelling of the face, eyes, lips, or mouth; fever, chills, cough with fever, fast breathing, or shortness of breath; decreased urination, foamy, pink, or brown urine, or swelling of the hands, face, feet, or abdomen; burning, numbness, or tingling in the feet or legs; ongoing pain that starts in the upper left or middle abdomen and may spread to the back, with or without vomiting; pale or fatty stools; yellowing of the skin or eyes, pain in the upper right abdomen, itching, loss of appetite, dark tea-colored urine, extreme tiredness, nausea, or vomiting. enfuvirtide may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: enoxaparin injection
instructions: important warning: if you receive epidural or spinal anesthesia or undergo a spinal puncture while using a blood thinner such as enoxaparin, you can develop a blood clot in or around the spine (spinal/epidural hematoma) that may cause long-term or permanent paralysis. your risk is higher if you are also taking other anticoagulants or antiplatelet medicines, including warfarin (coumadin), anagrelide (agrylin), aspirin, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (such as ibuprofen or naproxen), cilostazol (pletal), clopidogrel (plavix), dipyridamole (persantine), eptifibatide (integrilin), prasugrel (effient), sulfinpyrazone (anturane), ticlopidine (ticlid), or tirofiban (aggrastat). call your doctor immediately if you have any of the following: numbness or tingling, leg weakness or paralysis, or loss of control of your bladder or bowels. discuss the risks and benefits of enoxaparin with your doctor, and keep all appointments with your healthcare provider. why is this medication prescribed? enoxaparin helps prevent blood clots in the legs in people on bedrest or those having hip replacement, knee replacement, or abdominal (stomach) surgery. with aspirin, it helps prevent complications from angina (chest pain) and heart attacks. with warfarin, it is used to treat blood clots in the leg. enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin that works by blocking clot-forming substances. how should this medicine be used? enoxaparin is injected under the skin (subcutaneously) and must not be injected into a muscle. it is usually given twice daily. you will likely start it in the hospital and continue for a total of about 10 to 14 days. follow your prescription label exactly. do not use more, use less, or use it more often than prescribed. continue even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor. your healthcare provider will teach you how to give the injection or arrange for someone to give it. the usual site is the abdomen (stomach area); rotate to a different spot each time. each prefilled syringe is for one use only; do not reuse needles or syringes. dispose of used needles/syringes in a puncture-proof sharps container as instructed. keep out of reach of children. step-by-step: 1) wash your hands and clean the injection site. 2) check that the solution is clear and colorless or pale yellow. 3) remove the needle cap. do not expel the air bubble unless your provider tells you to. 4) lie down, gently pinch a fold of skin between your thumb and finger, insert the entire needle straight into the skin, and push the plunger to inject. keep holding the skin fold during the injection. 5) withdraw the needle and do not rub the site. other uses for this medicine: your doctor may prescribe enoxaparin for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using enoxaparin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to enoxaparin, heparin, any other medication, or pork products. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you more closely. over-the-counter aspirin and nsaids (such as ibuprofen and naproxen) may interact with enoxaparin; do not start or continue them unless your healthcare provider approves. tell your doctor if you have an artificial heart valve; kidney disease; an infection in your heart; a history of stroke; a bleeding disorder; stomach or intestinal ulcers; or a low platelet count. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while using enoxaparin. if you are having any surgery or dental procedure, tell the surgeon or dentist that you are using enoxaparin. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your normal diet. limit alcohol, as it can increase the risk of bleeding. do not start dietary supplements or herbal products that may affect bleeding (such as high-dose fish oil or ginkgo) without discussing them with your healthcare provider. what should i do if i forget a dose? inject the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not inject a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? enoxaparin may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: upset stomach, fever, irritation or burning at the injection site. call your doctor immediately if you notice any of the following or any symptoms listed in the important warning section: unusual bleeding or bruising, black or bloody stools, blood in your urine, or swelling of the ankles and/or feet.

name: ensartinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ensartinib is used in adults to treat certain types of non small cell lung cancer nsclc that have spread locally or to other parts of the body. it is a kinase inhibitor that blocks signals cancer cells need to grow and multiply. how should this medicine be used? ensartinib is an oral capsule taken once daily with or without food at the same time each day. swallow capsules whole and do not chew, crush, open, or dissolve them. follow your prescription label exactly and do not change your dose or schedule unless your doctor tells you to. if you vomit after a dose, do not take another dose; resume your usual schedule. your doctor may pause treatment, reduce your dose, or stop therapy if serious side effects occur. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer patient information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking ensartinib, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to ensartinib or any ingredients in the capsules and ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. some medicines should not be used with ensartinib; discuss all prescription, nonprescription, and herbal products you use before starting, and consult your doctor or pharmacist before starting, stopping, or changing any medicine while on ensartinib. tell your doctor if you have ever had an allergic reaction to fd&c yellow no. 5 tartrazine or to aspirin; your doctor may advise you not to take ensartinib. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had diabetes, glucose intolerance, lung problems other than lung cancer, a slow heartbeat, vision problems, or liver disease. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, you will need a pregnancy test before treatment. if you can become pregnant, use effective birth control during treatment and for 1 week after the final dose. if your partner can become pregnant, your partner should use effective birth control during your treatment and for 1 week after the final dose. call your doctor right away if you become pregnant; ensartinib can harm an unborn baby. do not breastfeed during treatment and for 1 week after the final dose. ensartinib may cause vision changes, dizziness, and excessive tiredness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how the medicine affects you. limit sun exposure and wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen spf 30 or higher because ensartinib can make your skin more sensitive to sunlight. call your doctor right away if you notice changes in vision, loss of vision, double or blurred vision, light sensitivity, flashes of light, new or increased floaters, or any other vision problems. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor about eating grapefruit or drinking grapefruit juice while taking this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is less than 12 hours until your next scheduled dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? ensartinib can cause side effects. common effects include muscle or joint pain, constipation, tiredness, and swelling of the hands, feet, or legs. serious side effects can occur; call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have any of the following: shortness of breath, chest pain, cough, or fever; severe tiredness, decreased appetite, nausea, vomiting, pain in the right upper part of the abdomen, dark urine, or itching; rash, itching, or swelling of the skin; slow or irregular heartbeat, dizziness, or fainting; feeling very hungry or thirsty, increased urination, nausea, tiredness, or confusion; unexplained muscle pain, tenderness, or weakness; red, hot, tender, or swollen joints especially the big toe, nausea or vomiting, pain in your abdomen or sides, or pink or brown urine. ensartinib may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medicine.

name: ensifentrine oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ensifentrine oral inhalation is used to control wheezing, shortness of breath, cough, and chest tightness in people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (copd), including chronic bronchitis and emphysema. it is a phosphodiesterase inhibitor that blocks certain natural substances that trigger inflammation and airway muscle tightening, relaxing and opening the airways to make breathing easier. how should this medicine be used? ensifentrine is a liquid suspension that is inhaled by mouth using a standard jet nebulizer with a mouthpiece connected to an air compressor. use it twice daily, in the morning and evening, at about the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly; do not use more, use less, or take it more often than prescribed. do not use ensifentrine for sudden copd attacks; your doctor will prescribe a short-acting rescue inhaler for flare-ups. call your doctor or seek emergency care if your breathing worsens, if you need your rescue inhaler more often, or if it no longer relieves your symptoms. ensifentrine helps control copd but does not cure it. continue using it even if you feel well, and do not stop without talking to your doctor, as your symptoms may worsen. read the written instructions before first use. have your doctor, pharmacist, or respiratory therapist show you how to use and clean the nebulizer and compressor, and practice with their guidance. do not swallow or inject the suspension, and do not mix it with other solutions. to use with a jet nebulizer: remove one ampule from the foil pouch; shake well to mix evenly—the suspension should look cloudy and yellow to pale yellow after shaking; twist off the top and squeeze the entire contents into the nebulizer reservoir—do not add other medicines; attach the mouthpiece to the reservoir and connect the nebulizer to the compressor; sit upright and place the mouthpiece in your mouth or put on the face mask; turn on the compressor and breathe calmly, deeply, and evenly for about 5 to 7 minutes until mist no longer forms; discard the empty ampule and top in a trash can out of the reach of children and pets. clean the nebulizer regularly according to the manufacturer’s instructions; ask your healthcare professional if you have questions. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using ensifentrine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to ensifentrine, any other medicines, or any ingredient in the oral inhalation product; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had depression, mood or other mental health problems; thoughts about harming yourself, suicidal thoughts, plans, or attempts; high blood pressure; or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using ensifentrine, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? inhale the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not inhale a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? ensifentrine may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: back pain, diarrhea, or difficult or painful urination. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have any of the following: sudden shortness of breath immediately after inhaling the medication; new or worsening depression; thoughts about harming or killing yourself, plans, or attempts; extreme worry; agitation; panic attacks; new or worsening anxiety; trouble falling or staying asleep; aggressive behavior; irritability; acting without thinking; severe restlessness; or frenzied, abnormal excitement. ensifentrine may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice any unusual problems while using it.

name: entacapone
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? entacapone is a catechol-o-methyltransferase (comt) inhibitor used with levodopa and carbidopa (sinemet) to treat end-of-dose “wearing-off” symptoms of parkinson’s disease. it helps levodopa and carbidopa work better by allowing more levodopa to reach the brain, where it has its effects. this medication is sometimes prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? entacapone comes as a tablet to take by mouth. it is taken with every dose of levodopa and carbidopa, up to 8 times a day. it may be taken with or without food. read your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. take entacapone exactly as directed; do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed. entacapone helps control the symptoms of parkinson’s disease but does not cure it. continue to take it even if you feel well. do not stop taking entacapone without talking to your doctor; stopping suddenly may worsen your parkinson’s disease and could have other dangerous effects. if needed, your doctor will decrease your dose gradually. what special precautions should i follow? before taking entacapone, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to entacapone or any other drugs. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver disease or a history of alcoholism. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding; if you become pregnant while taking entacapone, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking entacapone. this medication may cause drowsiness; do not drive a car or operate heavy machinery until you know how entacapone affects you. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. you may take entacapone with or without food. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember it. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? entacapone may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: dizziness, diarrhea, upset stomach, movements you cannot control, stomach pain, drowsiness. if you experience any of the following symptoms, call your doctor immediately: difficulty breathing, hallucinations, high fever, confusion, muscle stiffness, weakness with or without a fever.

name: entecavir
instructions: important warning: entecavir can cause severe or life threatening liver damage and lactic acidosis, a buildup of acid in the blood. your risk of lactic acidosis may be higher if you are a woman, if you are overweight, if you have taken medicines for hepatitis b virus hbv for a long time, or if you have current or past liver disease. call your doctor right away if you develop any of the following: yellow skin or eyes, dark urine, light or pale stools, trouble breathing, stomach pain or swelling, nausea, vomiting, unusual muscle pain, poor appetite lasting several days, lack of energy, extreme weakness or tiredness, feeling cold especially in the arms or legs, dizziness or lightheadedness, or a fast or irregular heartbeat. do not stop taking entecavir without talking to your doctor. stopping entecavir can cause your hepatitis to worsen, most often within the first several months after you stop. take entecavir exactly as directed and be careful not to miss doses or run out. if you stop entecavir and then develop extreme tiredness, weakness, nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, light colored stools, or muscle or joint pain, contact your doctor immediately. if you have untreated human immunodeficiency virus hiv or acquired immunodeficiency syndrome aids, taking entecavir may make your hiv infection harder to treat. tell your doctor if you have hiv or aids or may have been exposed to hiv. your doctor may test you for hiv before you start entecavir and at any time during treatment if exposure is possible. entecavir does not treat hiv. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory before, during, and for a few months after treatment; your doctor will order tests to monitor your response to entecavir. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer patient information. discuss the risks of taking entecavir with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? entecavir is used to treat chronic long term hepatitis b infection inflammation of the liver caused by a virus in adults and in children 2 years of age and older who have evidence of liver damage. entecavir is a nucleoside analog that lowers the amount of hepatitis b virus hbv in the body. it does not cure hbv and may not prevent complications of chronic hepatitis b such as cirrhosis or liver cancer, and it does not prevent the spread of hbv to others. how should this medicine be used? entecavir is available as tablets and as an oral solution to take by mouth. it is usually taken once daily on an empty stomach, at least 2 hours after a meal and at least 2 hours before the next meal. take it at the same time each day. follow your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. take entecavir exactly as prescribed; do not take more or less or take it more often than directed. to use the oral solution: hold the dosing spoon provided upright and slowly fill it with solution to the mark that matches your dose. keep the marks facing you and confirm the top of the liquid is level with the correct mark. swallow the medicine directly from the measuring spoon. do not mix it with water or other liquids. rinse the spoon with water after each use and let it air dry. store the spoon in a safe place and use it every time. if you lose the dosing spoon, contact your doctor or pharmacist. other uses for this medicine: this medicine may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking entecavir, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to entecavir or any ingredients in the tablets or oral solution. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have had a liver transplant, or if you have or have ever had kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking entecavir, call your doctor. do not breastfeed while using entecavir. if you are having any surgery, including dental procedures, tell the doctor or dentist that you take entecavir. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other directions, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? entecavir may cause side effects. a common side effect is headache, which is usually mild. some side effects can be serious. if you have any of the symptoms listed in the important warning section, call your doctor immediately. entecavir may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: entrectinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? entrectinib is used to treat certain types of non-small cell lung cancer (nsclc) in adults that has spread to other parts of the body. it is also used to treat specific solid tumors in adults and in children 1 month of age and older that cannot be removed by surgery or have spread and have worsened after treatment with other chemotherapy medicines. entrectinib is a kinase inhibitor that blocks abnormal proteins that signal cancer cells to multiply, helping to stop or slow cancer growth and spread. how should this medicine be used? entrectinib comes as capsules, capsules prepared as an oral suspension, or oral pellets taken by mouth. it is usually taken once daily with or without food. capsules may be swallowed whole or opened to prepare an oral suspension for patients who cannot swallow capsules or who need the medicine given through a gastric or nasogastric tube. to prepare a suspension from capsules, open the prescribed number, pour the contents into room-temperature drinking water or milk as directed by your prescriber, let it sit for 15 minutes, then take the prescribed amount and follow with water. if you cannot take the suspension right away, it may be stored at room temperature for up to 2 hours; discard if more than 2 hours have passed. pellets may be placed on one or more spoonfuls of soft food (for example, applesauce, pudding, or yogurt), taken within 20 minutes, and followed with water. use the entire packet of pellets; do not use pellets to make a suspension and do not give pellets through a gastric or nasogastric tube. take entrectinib at the same time each day. follow your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have any questions. take exactly as directed—do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. do not chew or crush capsule contents or pellets. if you vomit immediately after taking a dose, take another dose as soon as possible. your doctor may pause, reduce, or permanently stop treatment if serious side effects occur. tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking entrectinib, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to entrectinib, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the capsules; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. the herbal product st. john’s wort can interact with entrectinib; be sure to tell your doctor and pharmacist if you take it before starting entrectinib, and do not start st. john’s wort while taking entrectinib without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had a nervous system condition; eye or vision problems; a prolonged qt interval (a rare heart rhythm problem), a slow or irregular heartbeat, a heart attack, heart failure, or other heart problems; or kidney or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or plan to father a child. females will need a pregnancy test before starting and should use effective birth control during treatment and for at least 5 weeks after the final dose. males should use effective birth control with their partners during treatment and for 3 months after the last dose. if you or your partner becomes pregnant, call your doctor right away. entrectinib may harm the fetus. do not breastfeed during treatment and for 7 days after the final dose. you should know that entrectinib may cause dizziness or confusion; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not eat grapefruit or drink grapefruit juice while taking this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose by less than 12 hours, take it as soon as you remember and then take the next dose at the scheduled time. if more than 12 hours have passed, skip the missed dose and resume your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? entrectinib may cause side effects. common side effects include tiredness; constipation; diarrhea; nausea; vomiting; stomach (abdominal) pain; changes in taste; numbness, pain, burning, or tingling in the arms, hands, feet, or legs; headache; joint pain; muscle pain or weakness; leg, arm, or back pain; weight gain; rash; and difficulty falling or staying asleep. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have problems with learning, memory, attention, or problem solving; mood changes such as anxiety, depression, confusion, or agitation; feeling unsteady, balance problems, sleepiness, or dizziness; hallucinations; trouble speaking or understanding; bone pain, difficulty moving, or bone abnormalities; double or blurred vision, sensitivity to light, loss of vision, or other vision changes; red, swollen, stiff, or painful joints; pain in the upper right part of the stomach, yellowing of the skin or eyes, nausea or vomiting, loss of appetite, or easy bruising or bleeding; shortness of breath, sudden weight gain, persistent coughing or wheezing, tiredness or weakness, difficulty breathing when lying down, or swelling of the arms, legs, hands, or feet; feeling faint, lightheaded, or dizzy; fast or irregular heartbeat; cough, fever, chills, or other signs of infection; difficult, painful, or bloody urination; or intense low back or side pain. entrectinib may increase the risk of fractures and may cause other side effects; talk to your doctor about the risks of taking this medication.

name: enzalutamide
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? enzalutamide is used to treat certain types of prostate cancer. it is in a class of medications called androgen receptor inhibitors and works by blocking the effects of androgens (male hormones) to slow or stop the growth and spread of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? enzalutamide comes as a tablet or a capsule to take by mouth. take it once a day, with or without food, at about the same time each day. take enzalutamide exactly as directed. do not take more or less of it or more often than prescribed. swallow tablets or capsules whole with water; do not crush, chew, divide, dissolve, or open them. take with enough water to ensure they are swallowed completely, as they can get stuck in your throat and cause choking or gagging. your doctor may pause treatment or lower your dose if you experience serious side effects; tell your doctor how you feel during treatment. if you are also receiving another prostate cancer medication such as degarelix (firmagon), goserelin (zoladex), histrelin (supprelin la, vantas), leuprolide (eligard, lupron), or triptorelin (trelstar, triptodur), continue that medication while taking enzalutamide. continue to take enzalutamide even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer's patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking enzalutamide, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to enzalutamide, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe any allergy symptoms you have had. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, and nutritional supplements you take or plan to take. the herbal product st. john's wort may interact with enzalutamide; do not use it. do not start any new medications or supplements while taking enzalutamide without discussing them with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have trouble swallowing; or if you have or have ever had seizures; a brain injury; a brain tumor; a brain arteriovenous malformation (an abnormal connection between arteries and veins in the brain present at birth that may bleed); broken bones; osteoporosis (weak, brittle bones); diabetes; high cholesterol; high blood pressure; heart disease; or a stroke or ministroke. enzalutamide is for use in men. women should not take this medication, especially if they are or may become pregnant or are breastfeeding. women who are or may become pregnant should not handle enzalutamide capsules. if a pregnant woman takes or is exposed to enzalutamide, she should contact a doctor immediately. this medication may decrease fertility in men. do not assume your partner cannot become pregnant: if your partner is pregnant, use a condom during treatment and for 3 months after your final dose; if your partner could become pregnant, use effective birth control during treatment and for 3 months after your final dose. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking enzalutamide. enzalutamide may cause seizures. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how this medication affects you. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember on the same day. if you do not remember until the next day, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take more than one dose in a day and do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? enzalutamide may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: unusual tiredness or weakness; joint pain; muscle pain, weakness, or stiffness; fever, cough, sore throat, or other signs of infection; weight loss; loss of appetite; headache; dizziness; burning, numbness, or tingling in the arms, hands, or feet; decreased sense of touch or ability to feel sensation; hot flashes; difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep; anxiety; trouble remembering, thinking, or paying attention; diarrhea; constipation; itching or dry skin; nosebleeds; frequent urination; taste changes. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have: loss of consciousness or seizures; headache, confusion, or vision changes; swelling of the face, tongue, lips, throat, arms, legs, hands, or feet; chest pain or shortness of breath; pain in the back, muscles, and/or legs; numbness or tingling in the buttocks or legs; difficulty controlling urination or bowel movements; falls; broken bones or fractures; breast enlargement in men; or pink or red urine. enzalutamide may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: epcoritamab-bysp injection
instructions: important warning: epcoritamab-bysp injection may cause a serious or life-threatening reaction called cytokine release syndrome (crs). tell your doctor if you have an inflammatory disorder or if you have, or think you may have, any type of infection. your doctor may give you certain medicines before each dose to help prevent crs. get medical help immediately if you develop any of the following symptoms during or after an injection: fever, chills, fast or irregular heartbeat, difficulty breathing, shortness of breath, cough, confusion, anxiety, restlessness, headache, dizziness, lightheadedness, trouble walking, loss of balance, muscle pain, shaking, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, tiredness, or weakness. epcoritamab-bysp injection may also cause severe or life-threatening central nervous system reactions called immune effector cell-associated neurotoxicity syndrome (icans). tell your doctor if you have or have ever had seizures, a stroke, or memory loss. get medical help immediately if you develop any of the following symptoms: headache; restlessness; confusion; loss of consciousness; seizures; uncontrollable shaking or jerking of part of the body; hearing loss; double vision; difficulty speaking or writing; difficulty walking; muscle tightening or spasms; muscle weakness; burning, throbbing, or stabbing pain; or numbness and tingling of the skin. crs and nervous system reactions can occur during a dose or afterwards. these reactions are more common with the first 3 doses but can occur at any time during treatment. a doctor or nurse will monitor you closely in a hospital or medical facility during and after your injections to ensure you are not having a serious reaction. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how this medication affects you. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor will order tests to check your body’s response to epcoritamab-bysp. your doctor or pharmacist will give you the manufacturer’s medication guide when you start treatment and each time you receive a dose; read it carefully and ask questions if anything is unclear. discuss the risks of epcoritamab-bysp with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? epcoritamab-bysp is used to treat adults with diffuse large b-cell lymphoma (dlbcl)—a cancer of the lymphatic (infection-fighting) system—that has returned or did not respond to at least 2 other treatments. it is also used to treat adults with follicular lymphoma (fl)—a slow-growing blood cancer—that has returned or did not respond to at least 2 other treatments. epcoritamab-bysp is a bispecific t-cell engager antibody that works by helping your immune system target and kill cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? epcoritamab-bysp is given as a subcutaneous (under the skin) injection, usually in the thigh or lower abdomen, by a doctor or nurse in a hospital or medical facility. it is usually given on days 1, 8, 15, and 22 of a 28-day cycle for the first 3 cycles, then once every 2 weeks for cycles 4 through 9, and then once every 4 weeks thereafter. your healthcare provider will determine how many cycles you need. your doctor may delay or stop treatment, or give additional medicines, based on your response and any side effects. tell your doctor how you feel during treatment. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving epcoritamab-bysp, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to epcoritamab-bysp, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the injection. ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had herpes zoster (shingles) or low blood cell counts (leukopenia, neutropenia, anemia), and if you currently have or suspect an infection or have an inflammatory disorder. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. you must have a pregnancy test before starting treatment. use effective birth control during treatment and for 4 months after your final dose. if you become pregnant, call your doctor; epcoritamab-bysp may harm the fetus. do not breastfeed during treatment and for 4 months after your final dose. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are receiving epcoritamab-bysp. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor instructs otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given by a healthcare professional. if you miss or need to change an appointment for an injection, contact your doctor as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to administer this medication yourself. follow your provider’s instructions about any premedications for the rescheduled dose. what side effects can this medication cause? epcoritamab-bysp may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: tiredness; muscle or bone pain; bruising, redness, or pain at the injection site; stomach pain; nausea; diarrhea. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following or any symptoms listed in the important warning section, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help: fever; cough; chest pain; painful rash; sore throat; difficult or painful urination; feeling weak or unwell; unusual tiredness or shortness of breath; unusual bruising or bleeding. epcoritamab-bysp may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: epinastine ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ophthalmic epinastine is used to prevent itchy eyes caused by allergic conjunctivitis, a condition in which exposure to airborne allergens makes the eyes itchy, swollen, red, and watery. epinastine is an antihistamine that works by blocking the release of natural substances that trigger allergic eye reactions. how should this medicine be used? ophthalmic epinastine is a liquid eye drop solution. it is usually used twice daily, in the morning and evening, at about the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. use only as directed; do not use more, use less, or use it more often than prescribed. for ophthalmic use only; do not swallow. epinastine controls allergic eye itching only with regular use and will not help if used only when symptoms occur. keep using it even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor. avoid letting the dropper tip touch your eye, fingers, face, or any surface to prevent contamination. if you think the drops are contaminated, contact your doctor or pharmacist. to instill the drops: wash hands thoroughly; check that the dropper tip is intact; avoid touching the tip; tilt your head back; use a finger to pull the lower eyelid down to create a pocket; hold the dropper close to the eye without touching it and brace your hand; look up and gently squeeze one drop into the pocket; release the eyelid; close the eye for 2 to 3 minutes with your head tipped downward; avoid blinking or squeezing; press gently on the tear duct; wipe away excess liquid with a tissue; if you need more than one drop in the same eye, wait at least 5 minutes before the next drop; replace and tighten the cap without wiping or rinsing the tip; wash your hands afterward. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using epinastine eye drops, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to epinastine or any other medications. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while using epinastine, call your doctor. if you wear contact lenses, do not wear them when your eyes are red or irritated, and do not use epinastine to treat irritation you think is caused by contact lenses. do not instill the drops while wearing contacts; remove lenses before use and wait at least 10 minutes before reinserting. many people find it convenient to use the drops before putting lenses in the morning and after removing them in the evening. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use extra drops to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? epinastine eye drops may cause side effects, and it can be difficult to tell whether symptoms are from the medicine or from allergies. contact your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: burning or itching of the eyes, swollen eyelids, eye redness, headache, runny nose, cough. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor immediately if you develop a sore throat or fever, chills, or other signs of infection. epinastine eye drops may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: epinephrine nasal spray
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? epinephrine nasal spray is used to treat symptoms of an anaphylactic reaction, a severe, life-threatening allergic reaction with signs such as swelling of the face, mouth, or throat; rash or hives; and difficulty breathing in adults and some children. it belongs to a class of medicines called alpha- and beta-adrenergic agonists (sympathomimetic agents) and works by relaxing the muscles in the airways and tightening the blood vessels. how should this medicine be used? epinephrine nasal spray comes as a liquid solution to spray into the nose. use one spray in one nostril at the first sign of an anaphylactic reaction. if symptoms do not improve after 5 minutes or worsen, give a second spray in the same nostril. seek emergency medical care immediately after using epinephrine nasal spray to determine if additional treatment is needed. each nasal spray device is single-use; replace it right away after use. it is recommended to always carry epinephrine nasal spray and to have two doses available at all times. to give a dose, fully insert the nozzle straight into one nostril and press the plunger down firmly. avoid sniffing during administration. review the instructions for use that come with the product and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have any questions. ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer’s patient information. what special precautions should i follow? before using epinephrine nasal spray, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to epinephrine, sulfites, any other medications, or any ingredients in the product. ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. use of epinephrine nasal spray may increase the systemic absorption of other nasal spray medications and raise the risk of side effects for up to 2 weeks after use. ask your doctor or pharmacist about using nasal sprays such as fluticasone (flonase), azelastine (astepro), triamcinolone (nasacort), budesonide (rhinocort), or oxymetazoline (afrin) if you have used a dose of epinephrine nasal spray. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had nasal polyps (noncancerous growths), prior nose surgery or procedures, or a history of nasal injury or fracture; your doctor may advise against use. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had chest pain, irregular heartbeat, high blood pressure, or other heart disease; asthma; diabetes; hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid); depression; parkinson’s disease; kidney disease; or if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is used as needed for allergic emergencies and is not taken on a regular schedule. if you have symptoms of anaphylaxis and have not yet used a dose, use it immediately. if symptoms do not improve or return after 5 minutes, give a second spray in the same nostril and seek emergency care. do not take extra doses to make up for a forgotten dose in the absence of symptoms. always carry two doses with you. what side effects can this medication cause? epinephrine nasal spray may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: throat irritation; tingling in the nose; nasal discomfort; sneezing; itchy nose; nasal congestion or runny nose; headache; feeling jittery, excited, nervous, or anxious; shakiness; dizziness; stomach pain; nausea or vomiting. epinephrine nasal spray may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual symptoms or concerns.

name: epinephrine oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? epinephrine oral inhalation is used to relieve occasional asthma symptoms—such as wheezing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath—in adults and children 12 years of age and older. it is a sympathomimetic agent (alpha- and beta-adrenergic agonist) that relaxes and opens the airways to make breathing easier. how should this medicine be used? epinephrine oral inhalation is an aerosol inhaled by mouth and is used as needed for symptom relief. follow the product label exactly, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. use only as directed; do not use more or less or more often than recommended. this medicine is available over the counter but should be used only if a doctor has told you that you have asthma. seek medical care right away if your symptoms do not improve within 20 minutes of use, if your asthma worsens, if you need more than 8 inhalations in 24 hours, or if you have more than 2 asthma attacks in a week. to use the inhaler: 1) remove the cap. 2) if using for the first time, prime by shaking well and pressing down to release a spray into the air away from your face; repeat for a total of 4 shakes and sprays. 3) before each subsequent use, shake and release 1 spray into the air. 4) place the inhaler in your mouth; inhale deeply while pressing down on the top of the inhaler and continue your breath as long as possible. 5) exhale and wait 1 minute. 6) if symptoms do not improve, repeat for a second inhalation. use no more than 2 sprays per dose, wait at least 4 hours before another dose, and do not exceed 8 inhalations in 24 hours. clean the inhaler daily after use by running water through the mouthpiece for 30 seconds. follow the manufacturer’s instructions and ask your pharmacist or doctor for the patient information leaflet if needed. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to epinephrine or any ingredient in the product; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell them about all medicines and supplements you take or plan to take, including if you currently use or have used in the past 2 weeks any monoamine oxidase inhibitors (maois) such as isocarboxazid (marplan), phenelzine (nardil), rasagiline (azilect), or selegiline (eldepryl, emsam); other asthma medicines; caffeine; medicines for depression, psychiatric or emotional conditions; medicines for obesity or weight control; phenylephrine (sudafed pe); or pseudoephedrine (sudafed, in some combination products such as clarinex-d). nonprescription stimulants and herbal products used for energy or to reduce tiredness may also interact. do not start any of these while using epinephrine oral inhalation without discussing with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have ever been hospitalized for asthma, and if you have or have ever had high blood pressure, diabetes, difficulty urinating due to an enlarged prostate, seizures, narrow-angle glaucoma, thyroid disease, or heart disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, talk to your doctor; call your doctor if you become pregnant while using this medicine. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor about using foods or beverages that contain caffeine while taking this medicine. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is used as needed for symptoms, so missed doses usually do not apply. if your provider has told you to use it on a schedule and you miss a dose, use it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. do not use more than directed, do not use doses closer than every 4 hours, and do not double the dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? stop using your inhaler and call your doctor right away if you have fast, pounding, or irregular heartbeat; tremors; nervousness; seizures; or trouble falling or staying asleep. epinephrine oral inhalation may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: epirubicin
instructions: important warning: epirubicin must be administered only into a vein. if the drug leaks into surrounding tissue, it can cause severe irritation or damage. your healthcare team will monitor the injection site during treatment. call your doctor immediately if you notice pain, itching, redness, swelling, blisters, or sores at the injection site. epirubicin can cause serious or life-threatening heart problems during treatment or months to years afterward. your doctor will check your heart function before and during therapy, for example with an electrocardiogram (ecg) and an echocardiogram to see how well your heart pumps. you may be advised not to receive epirubicin if these tests show reduced heart function, if you have or have had heart disease, or if you have received radiation to the chest. tell your doctor and pharmacist if you currently take or have ever received certain cancer medicines that can affect the heart, such as daunorubicin (cerubidine), doxorubicin (including doxil), idarubicin (idamycin), mitoxantrone (novantrone), cyclophosphamide (cytoxan), or trastuzumab (herceptin). seek medical care right away if you develop shortness of breath; trouble breathing; swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; or a fast, irregular, or pounding heartbeat. epirubicin may increase the risk of leukemia (a cancer of white blood cells), particularly at high doses or when combined with certain other chemotherapy drugs. it can also cause a marked drop in blood counts from bone marrow suppression, raising the risk of serious infection or bleeding. call your doctor immediately if you have fever, sore throat, persistent cough and congestion, other signs of infection, or unusual bleeding or bruising. epirubicin should be given only under the supervision of a clinician experienced in chemotherapy. discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed?
