epirubicin is used with other medicines to treat breast cancer in patients who have had surgery to remove the tumor. it is an anthracycline that works by slowing or stopping the growth of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? epirubicin is a liquid solution given by intravenous injection or infusion by a doctor or nurse in a medical facility, usually with other chemotherapy drugs. common schedules include once every 21 days for 6 treatment cycles, or on days 1 and 8 of a 28-day cycle for 6 cycles. your dosing schedule depends on your condition and how you respond. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine: your doctor may prescribe epirubicin for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving epirubicin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to epirubicin; other anthracyclines such as daunorubicin (cerubidine, daunoxome), doxorubicin (including doxil), or idarubicin (idamycin); any other medications; or any ingredients in the epirubicin injection. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for interactions. the nonprescription drug cimetidine can interact with epirubicin; do not start or stop it without medical advice. tell your doctor if you have had radiation therapy, or if you have or have ever had liver or kidney disease. epirubicin may disrupt menstrual periods in women and reduce or stop sperm production in men; however, you may still be able to become pregnant or father a child. do not become pregnant or breast-feed while receiving epirubicin. inform your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, are breast-feeding, or become pregnant during treatment. ask about reliable birth control to use during therapy. do not receive any vaccinations without talking to your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other guidance, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? epirubicin is given by healthcare professionals. if you miss or cannot keep an appointment, contact your doctor as soon as possible to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? epirubicin may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: nausea; vomiting; mouth or throat sores; stomach pain; diarrhea; loss of appetite or weight; unusual tiredness or weakness; hair loss; hot flashes; red urine for 1 to 2 days after a dose; sore or red eyes; eye pain; darkening of the skin or nails. some side effects can be serious. get medical help right away if you have pale skin, fainting, dizziness, rash, hives, itching, difficulty breathing or swallowing, or any symptoms listed in the important warning section. epirubicin may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you notice any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: eplerenone
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? eplerenone is used alone or with other medicines to treat high blood pressure. it belongs to a class called mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists and works by blocking aldosterone, a natural hormone that raises blood pressure. untreated high blood pressure can damage the brain, heart, blood vessels, kidneys, and other organs, leading to heart disease, heart attack, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, vision loss, and other problems. along with medication, lifestyle changes—such as eating a low-fat, low-salt diet, keeping a healthy weight, exercising about 30 minutes most days, not smoking, and limiting alcohol—help control blood pressure. how should this medicine be used? eplerenone is taken by mouth as a tablet once or twice daily, with or without food. take it at the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. your doctor may start you on a low dose and adjust it after about 4 weeks. eplerenone controls but does not cure high blood pressure; full benefits may take 4 weeks or longer. keep taking it even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor. what special precautions should i follow? before taking eplerenone, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to eplerenone or any tablet ingredients. some medicines should not be used with eplerenone, and others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. review all prescription, over-the-counter, and herbal products you use or plan to use with your healthcare providers before starting eplerenone and before starting, stopping, or changing any medicine while taking it. the following nonprescription or herbal products may interact: st. john’s wort; aspirin and other nsaids such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin) and naproxen (aleve, naprosyn); and potassium supplements. do not start these while on eplerenone without medical advice. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had high potassium levels, diabetes, gout, or liver or kidney disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor; call your doctor if you become pregnant while taking eplerenone. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor about drinking grapefruit juice while taking this medicine. do not use salt substitutes containing potassium while taking eplerenone. if your doctor prescribes a low-salt or low-sodium diet, follow it carefully. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? eplerenone may cause side effects. common effects include headache, dizziness, diarrhea, stomach pain, cough, excessive tiredness, flu-like symptoms, breast enlargement or tenderness, and abnormal vaginal bleeding. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor right away if you have chest pain, tingling in the arms or legs, loss of muscle tone, weakness or heaviness in the legs, confusion, lack of energy, cold gray skin, or an irregular heartbeat. eplerenone may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: eplontersen injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? eplontersen is used in adults to treat polyneuropathy caused by hereditary transthyretin-mediated amyloidosis, an inherited disorder in which abnormal proteins build up in tissues and damage nerves. it is an antisense oligonucleotide that lowers the amount of abnormal protein and its deposits in the body, helping reduce nerve damage. how should this medicine be used? eplontersen comes as a liquid solution in a prefilled autoinjector for subcutaneous injection (under the skin). it is usually given once a month at home by the patient or a caregiver. have your doctor or pharmacist show you or your caregiver how to prepare and inject it. take the autoinjector out of the refrigerator 30 minutes before the planned injection and let it reach room temperature in its original carton. do not warm it using a microwave, hot water, sunlight, or any other heating method. inspect the solution before use: check the expiration date and ensure the liquid is clear or slightly yellow, without visible particles. do not use the autoinjector if it is cracked, broken, expired, frozen, or if the liquid is cloudy or contains particles. inject into the front of the thighs or the abdomen (stomach), avoiding the navel and the 2 inches (5 centimeters) around it; if a caregiver is giving the dose, the back of the upper arm may also be used. rotate injection sites to reduce soreness or redness. do not inject into skin that is tender, bruised, red, hard, scarred, or has stretch marks. wash hands thoroughly and clean the injection site with an alcohol swab. remove the clear cap while holding the autoinjector. place the orange end of the autoinjector at a 90-degree angle to the skin with the viewing window visible. push firmly and hold it against the skin; you will hear a click when the injection starts. keep holding it in place for 10 seconds until the full dose is delivered. ensure the orange plunger fully fills the viewing window to confirm the dose is complete. lift the autoinjector straight up; the orange needle shield will lock to cover the needle. dispose of the used autoinjector in a sharps container or a heavy-duty household plastic container (such as a milk jug or detergent bottle). when the container is mostly full, follow your local community guidelines for disposal. do not place used needles in regular trash. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using eplontersen, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to eplontersen, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the injection. ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney or liver disease or vitamin a deficiency. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using eplontersen, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? continue your normal diet unless your doctor gives you other instructions. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, inject it as soon as you remember, then give the next dose 1 month after that injection to set a new monthly schedule. what side effects can this medication cause? eplontersen may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: bruising, pain, or redness at the injection site; vomiting; blurred vision. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have: difficulty seeing at night or in low-light conditions; dry eyes. eplontersen can lower vitamin a levels, which can be serious and may damage the eyes. your doctor will have you take a vitamin a supplement during treatment; take it exactly as directed and do not take more than recommended. talk to your doctor about the risks of eplontersen. eplontersen may cause other side effects.

name: epoetin alfa, injection
instructions: notice: epoetin alfa injection and its biosimilar epoetin alfa-epbx are biologic medicines made from living cells. because epoetin alfa-epbx is highly similar to epoetin alfa and works the same way in the body, the term epoetin injection products is used for both in this guide. important warning: all patients: epoetin injection products increase the risk of blood clots in the legs (deep vein thrombosis), lungs (pulmonary embolism), or brain (stroke), and the risk may be higher if you have heart disease, a history of clots, or if you are having surgery. tell every doctor and dentist before any surgery that you use an epoetin injection product, especially if you are having coronary artery bypass graft (cabg) or orthopedic surgery; your doctor may prescribe a blood thinner to reduce clot risk. call your doctor or get emergency help right away for pain, tenderness, redness, warmth, or swelling in a leg; a pale or cool arm or leg; sudden shortness of breath; chest pain; sudden trouble speaking or understanding; sudden confusion; sudden weakness or numbness of the face, arm, or leg (especially on one side); sudden trouble walking, dizziness, loss of balance or coordination; or fainting. if you receive hemodialysis, clots can form in your vascular access; call your doctor if your access is not working normally. your dose will be adjusted so your hemoglobin is just high enough to avoid red blood cell transfusions; targeting normal or near‑normal hemoglobin increases the risk of stroke, heart attack, heart failure, and death. seek emergency care for chest pain, pressure, or tightness; shortness of breath; nausea, lightheadedness, sweating; pain in the arms, shoulder, neck, jaw, or back; or swelling of the hands, feet, or ankles. keep all doctor and lab appointments; your dose may be lowered or temporarily stopped based on test results. you will receive a medication guide at the start of therapy and with each refill; read it and ask questions as needed. discuss the risks and benefits of epoetin injection products with your doctor. cancer patients: in studies, some people with certain cancers who received epoetin had earlier death, tumor growth, or cancer recurrence/spread compared with those who did not receive it. use epoetin injection products for chemotherapy‑induced anemia only if your chemotherapy is expected to continue for at least 2 months after starting epoetin and if there is not a high chance of curing your cancer. stop epoetin when chemotherapy ends. surgical patients: epoetin may be used to lower the chance of transfusion due to blood loss with certain surgeries, but use before and after surgery can increase the risk of dangerous clots; your doctor will likely prescribe blood thinners to reduce this risk. why is this medication prescribed? epoetin injection products treat anemia (low red blood cells) due to chronic kidney disease, chemotherapy in certain cancers, or zidovudine (azt) used for hiv. they may also be used before and after certain surgeries to reduce the need for transfusions; they should not be used for people having heart or blood vessel surgery, or for people who can donate their own blood before surgery. epoetin cannot replace transfusions for severe anemia and has not been shown to improve tiredness or well‑being caused by anemia. epoetin products are erythropoiesis‑stimulating agents (esas) that help bone marrow make more red blood cells. how should this medicine be used? epoetin injection products are given as a liquid by subcutaneous (under the skin) or intravenous (into a vein) injection, usually 1 to 3 times per week. for surgical use to lower transfusion risk, dosing may be once daily for 10 days before surgery, on the day of surgery, and for 4 days after, or once weekly starting 3 weeks before surgery and on the day of surgery. your doctor will start with a low dose and adjust based on your labs and symptoms, typically no more than once a month; therapy may be paused if needed. epoetin works only while you keep using it; it can take 2 to 6 weeks or longer to feel the full benefit. do not stop without talking to your doctor. epoetin may be given by a healthcare professional or at home. if injecting at home, follow the prescription label and training exactly. use it only as directed; do not change your dose or schedule without your doctor’s advice. mark a calendar to track doses. a healthcare provider will teach you how to inject and dispose of needles and syringes; keep a spare syringe and needle. do not shake; if shaken and foamy, do not use. inject under the skin on the outer upper arms, front middle thighs, abdomen (avoid the 2‑inch/5‑cm area around the navel), or outer buttocks; avoid areas that are tender, red, bruised, hardened, scarred, or with stretch marks; rotate sites as directed. if you are on dialysis, your doctor may direct injection into the venous access port. always check the vial before use to confirm the correct drug and strength, that the expiration date has not passed, and that the solution is clear and colorless without lumps, flakes, or particles; if there is any problem, do not inject and call your pharmacist. other uses for this medicine: your doctor may prescribe this medicine for other reasons; discuss the potential risks and benefits with your doctor. what special precautions should i follow? before using epoetin injection products, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to epoetin alfa, epoetin alfa‑epbx, darbepoetin alfa, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the product (check the medication guide). tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you take; dose changes or extra monitoring may be needed. tell your doctor if you have or have had high blood pressure; pure red cell aplasia (prca) after esa treatment (you may be told not to use epoetin); seizures; chronic kidney disease; or cancer. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while using epoetin. before any surgery, including dental procedures, tell the clinician you use an epoetin injection product. what special dietary instructions should i follow? your doctor may recommend a diet to help control blood pressure and increase iron stores so epoetin works effectively; follow these instructions closely and ask your doctor or dietitian if you have questions. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, call your doctor for instructions; do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? epoetin injection products may cause side effects. call your doctor if these are severe or do not go away: headache; joint or muscle pain, aches, or soreness; nausea; vomiting; weight loss; mouth sores; trouble falling or staying asleep; depression; muscle spasms; runny nose, sneezing, congestion; fever, cough, or chills; redness, swelling, pain, or itching at the injection site. some side effects can be serious. get medical help right away for rash; hives; itching; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes; blisters or peeling skin; wheezing; trouble breathing or swallowing; unusual tiredness; lack of energy; dizziness; fainting; or seizures. this medicine may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: epoprostenol
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? epoprostenol injection is used to treat certain types of pulmonary arterial hypertension (pah), a condition of high blood pressure in the vessels that carry blood to the lungs that can cause shortness of breath, dizziness, and tiredness. it may improve exercise capacity and slow the worsening of pah symptoms. epoprostenol is a vasodilator and platelet aggregation inhibitor that relaxes blood vessels, including in the lungs, to improve blood flow. it is also sometimes used for acute respiratory distress syndrome (ards); discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor and ask about any other uses. how should this medicine be used? epoprostenol comes as a powder that is mixed with a liquid and given as a continuous intravenous infusion through a vein using an infusion pump. treatment is usually started and doses are adjusted under medical supervision. use exactly as directed; do not use more or less or more often than prescribed. before using it at home, your healthcare team will show you how to prepare the medication and operate the pump; read all instructions and ask questions if anything is unclear. your doctor will usually start at a low dose and increase it gradually; the infusion may be slowed or temporarily interrupted if certain side effects occur. monitor and report how you feel during treatment. epoprostenol can lower blood pressure, so your blood pressure will be checked when therapy begins and when doses change; if you develop flushing, dizziness, feeling faint, headache, or a pounding heartbeat after receiving the medication, contact your doctor immediately. epoprostenol helps control pah symptoms but does not cure the condition. do not stop the infusion abruptly; your doctor will advise a gradual reduction. always keep a backup infusion pump and know what to do if the pump malfunctions. epoprostenol is obtained through a specialty pharmacy; ask your healthcare provider about obtaining your medication and request the manufacturer patient information. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to epoprostenol or any of its ingredients, and provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use, especially anticoagulants such as warfarin and heparin; digoxin (lanoxin); diuretics; medicines for high blood pressure; and platelet inhibitors such as clopidogrel (plavix), dipyridamole (persantine or in aggrenox), prasugrel (effient), and ticlopidine (ticlid). your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you closely for side effects. tell your doctor if you have heart failure, as you may be advised not to use epoprostenol. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had bleeding problems, pulmonary edema (excess fluid in the lungs), or liver problems. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, inform your doctor; call your doctor if you become pregnant during treatment. before any surgery, including dental procedures, tell the clinician that you use epoprostenol. long-term continuous use may increase the risk of blood clots; your doctor may prescribe an anticoagulant to help prevent clots. seek medical care right away if you develop chest pain; shortness of breath; coughing up blood; or lower leg pain, swelling, warmth, or redness. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? your healthcare provider will tell you how to store your medication. store it only as directed, and make sure you understand the proper storage conditions for your supply. what side effects can this medication cause? epoprostenol may cause side effects. common effects include dizziness, jaw pain, muscle and bone pain, headache, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, flushing, anxiety, nervousness, agitation, and rash. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have shortness of breath, wheezing, trouble breathing, or cough up blood; unusual bleeding or bruising; fever, chills, or other signs of infection; or severe dizziness or fainting. epoprostenol injection may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual or persistent.

name: clindamycin topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? topical clindamycin is used to treat acne. it belongs to a class of medicines called lincomycin antibiotics. it works by slowing or stopping the growth of acne-causing bacteria and by reducing swelling and inflammation. how should this medicine be used? topical clindamycin comes as a foam, gel, solution (liquid), lotion, and pledget (pre-moistened swab) to apply to the skin. the foam and one brand of gel (clindagel) are usually applied once daily. the solution, lotion, pledgets, and most other gel brands are applied twice daily. apply topical clindamycin at about the same times each day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. use topical clindamycin exactly as directed. do not apply more or less of it or use it more often than prescribed. for external use only. do not swallow, and do not get the medication in your eyes, nose, mouth, or vagina. if it gets in your eyes, nose, or mouth, or on broken skin, rinse thoroughly with plenty of cool water. your medication will likely include specific directions for use; read them and follow them carefully. ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have any questions about how to apply topical clindamycin. shake the lotion well before each use to mix the medication evenly. pledgets are single-use only; do not remove a pledget from its foil pouch until you are ready to use it, and dispose of it after one use. the foam is flammable; stay away from open flames and do not smoke while applying the foam and for a short time afterward. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using topical clindamycin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to clindamycin, lincomycin (lincocin), or any other medications. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take while using topical clindamycin. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had inflammatory bowel disease (ibd)—a condition in which part or all of the intestinal lining is swollen, irritated, or has sores—or if you have had severe diarrhea caused by an antibiotic. your doctor may tell you not to use topical clindamycin. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had asthma, eczema or sensitive skin that often becomes itchy or irritated, or any allergies. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using topical clindamycin, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are using topical clindamycin. you should know that abrasive or medicated soaps and skin products that contain alcohol may worsen the side effects of topical clindamycin. talk to your doctor about the skin-care products you plan to use during treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not apply extra medication to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? topical clindamycin may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: dry or peeling skin; itching or burning; redness of the skin; oily skin; new pimples or blemishes; headache. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you experience: diarrhea; watery or bloody stools; stomach cramps. topical clindamycin may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: c1-esterase inhibitor recombinant injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? c1-esterase inhibitor (recombinant) is used to treat acute attacks of hereditary angioedema (hae), an inherited condition that causes episodes of swelling in the hands, feet, face, airway, or intestines, in adults and adolescents 13 years of age or older. it belongs to a class of medications called complement inhibitors and works by replacing the c1-esterase inhibitor normally produced by the body to help control inflammation and swelling. how should this medicine be used? c1-esterase inhibitor (recombinant) comes as a powder in a vial to be mixed with a liquid and injected intravenously over about 5 minutes. it is usually used as needed at the start of an hae attack according to your doctor’s directions. if your symptoms do not respond to the first dose, your doctor may tell you to inject a second dose. if symptoms do not improve after the second dose, call your doctor. do not use more than 2 doses in a 24-hour period. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully. use exactly as directed; do not use more or less, or more often, than prescribed. your doctor or nurse will show you or a caregiver how to mix and inject doses at home. before first use, you and the person giving injections should read the manufacturer’s patient information. ask your healthcare provider if you have questions about when to use the medication, where to inject, how to give the injection, what type of syringe to use, or how to dispose of used needles and syringes. always keep a spare syringe and needle on hand. mix the medication right before you plan to inject it; alternatively, you may mix it in advance, store it in the refrigerator, and use within 8 hours. allow refrigerated mixed solution to come to room temperature before injecting. always inspect the solution before use: check that the expiration date has not passed and that the liquid is clear and colorless with no visible particles. do not use if expired, discolored, cloudy, or if particles are present. ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using c1-esterase inhibitor (recombinant) injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to c1-esterase inhibitor (recombinant), other c1-esterase inhibitor products, any other medications, or any ingredients in this product. ask your pharmacist for a list of the ingredients. also tell your doctor if you are allergic to rabbits or rabbit-derived products. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. be sure to mention androgens such as danazol, methyltestosterone (android 25), or testosterone (androderm, jatenzo, natesto, others), and medications that contain estrogen, including birth control pills. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have an indwelling catheter, have been on bedrest or unable to move around for a long time, or if you have or have ever had atherosclerosis (narrowing of blood vessels from fatty deposits) or blood clots in the legs, lungs, eyes, brain, or elsewhere. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using this medicine, call your doctor. if you are having surgery or will be on bedrest, tell the doctor that you are using c1-esterase inhibitor (recombinant) injection. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is used as needed at the start of an hae attack and does not have a regular dosing schedule. if your doctor has told you to use it on a schedule and you miss a dose, inject it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. do not use extra doses to make up for a missed dose and do not use more than 2 doses in 24 hours. call your doctor if your symptoms do not improve. what side effects can this medication cause? c1-esterase inhibitor (recombinant) injection may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: headache, nausea, diarrhea. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you experience hives; rash; itching; difficulty breathing or swallowing; blue lips or skin; swelling of your face, tongue, or throat; sweating; hoarseness; lightheadedness; fainting; warmth, pain, tenderness, or redness in one leg; coughing up blood; chest pain; or shortness of breath. c1-esterase inhibitor (recombinant) may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: cabazitaxel injection
instructions: important warning: cabazitaxel injection can cause a serious or life threatening decrease in white blood cells, which increases your risk of severe infection. your risk is higher if you are 65 years or older, have ever had a low white blood cell count with fever, have received radiation therapy, or are unable to maintain good nutrition. your doctor will check your blood counts before and during treatment and may reduce your dose, delay, or stop treatment if counts are low. your doctor may also prescribe medicine to help prevent complications from low white blood cells. call your doctor right away if you develop signs of infection such as sore throat, fever, chills, muscle aches, cough, burning with urination, or any other signs of infection. severe or life threatening allergic reactions can occur, especially during the first two infusions. you will receive medicines to help prevent allergy reactions at least 30 minutes before each infusion, and the infusion should be given in a medical facility where you can be treated quickly if a reaction occurs. do not receive cabazitaxel if you are allergic to cabazitaxel or polysorbate 80. ask your doctor if any food or medicine you are allergic to contains polysorbate 80. allergic reactions may begin within minutes of the infusion and can include rash, skin redness, itching, dizziness, fainting, swelling of the face, trouble breathing, or tightness in the chest or throat. tell your doctor or nurse immediately if any of these occur. keep all appointments for doctor visits and laboratory tests so your response and safety can be monitored. discuss the risks and benefits of cabazitaxel injection with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? cabazitaxel injection is used with prednisone to treat prostate cancer that has already been treated with other medicines. it belongs to a class called microtubule inhibitors and works by slowing or stopping the growth of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? cabazitaxel injection is given by a healthcare professional as an intravenous infusion over about 1 hour, usually once every 3 weeks. you must take prednisone by mouth every day during cabazitaxel treatment exactly as prescribed. tell your doctor if you miss prednisone doses or do not take it as directed. your doctor may delay, stop, or change your dose based on side effects and test results. tell your care team how you are feeling throughout treatment. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer patient information. other uses for this medicine: your doctor may prescribe this medicine for other uses. ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before treatment, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cabazitaxel, polysorbate 80, or any ingredient in the product, and provide a list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and herbal supplements you use or plan to use. your doctor may change doses or monitor you closely for interactions. the following can interact with cabazitaxel: aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen or naproxen, and st johns wort. do not start these while receiving cabazitaxel without talking with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver or kidney disease, anemia, bleeding stomach or intestinal ulcers, lung problems, or prior pelvic radiation; you may be advised not to receive cabazitaxel if you have significant liver disease. cabazitaxel is for use only in men. if your partner can become pregnant, use effective birth control during treatment and for 4 months after the last dose. call your doctor if your partner becomes pregnant, as cabazitaxel may harm the fetus. this medicine may reduce male fertility. if you are 65 years or older, discuss the higher risk of side effects with your doctor. if you are having any surgery, including dental procedures, tell the surgeon or dentist you are receiving cabazitaxel. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor whether you should avoid grapefruit or grapefruit juice while receiving this medicine. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given by appointment in a clinic. if you miss or cannot keep an infusion appointment, or if you miss prednisone doses, contact your doctor as soon as possible for instructions and to reschedule. do not take extra doses to make up for missed doses. what side effects can this medication cause? cabazitaxel may cause side effects. common effects include heartburn, changes in taste, decreased appetite, weight loss, mouth sores or swelling, headache, joint, back, bone, arm, or leg pain, muscle pain or spasms, numbness, burning, or tingling in hands or feet, and hair loss. serious effects can occur. call your doctor right away if you have nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, or stomach pain; swelling of the face, arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; decreased urination; blood in the urine; frequent, burning, or painful urination; blood in the stool or black stools; changes in stool color; signs of dehydration such as dry mouth, dark urine, decreased sweating, or dry skin; slow, fast, or irregular heartbeat; chest pain; new or worsening cough; shortness of breath; pale skin; unusual tiredness or weakness; dizziness or lightheadedness; unusual bruising or bleeding; or a bone fracture. cabazitaxel can cause other side effects. call your healthcare provider if you notice anything concerning.

name: cabergoline
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cabergoline is prescribed to treat hyperprolactinemia (high prolactin levels). excess prolactin can cause infertility, sexual problems, and bone loss in women who are not breast-feeding and in men. cabergoline is a dopamine receptor agonist that works by lowering prolactin levels. how should this medicine be used? cabergoline is taken by mouth as a tablet, with or without food, usually twice a week. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take it exactly as directed; do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. your doctor will usually start with a low dose and increase it gradually, no more often than every 4 weeks. do not stop taking cabergoline without consulting your doctor; your dose will likely be tapered. other uses for this medicine cabergoline is sometimes used to treat parkinson’s disease (a movement disorder). discuss the potential risks and benefits with your doctor. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cabergoline, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cabergoline, to ergot medications such as bromocriptine (parlodel), dihydroergotamine (d.h.e. 45, migranal), ergoloid mesylates (hydergine), ergotamine (in cafergot, in ergomar), methylergonovine (methergine), methysergide (sansert), or pergolide (permax), to any other medications, or to any ingredients in cabergoline tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you use or have used street drugs; if you have or have ever had high blood pressure; any condition that causes thickening or scarring (fibrosis) in the lungs, heart, or abdomen; or heart valve disease. your doctor will examine you and may order tests to check your heart valves and may advise against cabergoline if there are signs of valve disease or any of these conditions. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; if you become pregnant while taking cabergoline, call your doctor. if you are breast-feeding or plan to breast-feed, know that cabergoline may reduce or stop milk production. cabergoline may cause dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting when rising quickly from lying down, especially when starting treatment. to minimize this, rise slowly and sit with your feet on the floor for a few minutes before standing. some people taking cabergoline have developed gambling problems or other intense or compulsive urges (such as increased sexual urges or behaviors). it is unclear if the medication is the cause. call your doctor if you develop difficult-to-control gambling or other intense urges, or if you cannot control your behavior. inform family members about this risk so they can contact the doctor if you do not recognize these behaviors. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor instructs otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cabergoline may cause side effects. common effects include nausea, vomiting, heartburn, constipation, tiredness, dizziness, breast pain, painful menstrual periods, and burning, numbness, or tingling in the arms, hands, legs, or feet. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor right away or seek emergency help if you have shortness of breath, difficulty breathing when lying down, cough, chest pain, swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, decreased urination, pain in the back, side, or groin, lumps or pain in the abdomen, or abnormal vision. cabergoline may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you experience any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: cabotegravir
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cabotegravir is used to treat human immunodeficiency virus type 1 (hiv-1) infection. cabotegravir is also used for certain periods to help prevent hiv-1 infection. it belongs to a class of medications called hiv integrase inhibitors and works by lowering the amount of hiv in the blood. although cabotegravir does not cure hiv, it may reduce your risk of developing acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (aids) and hiv-related illnesses. taking this medication as directed, along with other lifestyle measures, may decrease the risk of transmitting hiv to others. how should this medicine be used? cabotegravir comes as a tablet to take by mouth. take cabotegravir once daily with food for the number of doses your doctor prescribes. take it at the same time every day and exactly as directed. do not take more or less, or take it more often than prescribed. before receiving cabotegravir to prevent hiv infection, your doctor will order a test to check for hiv-1; you must have a negative test before receiving cabotegravir. continue to take cabotegravir even if you feel well. do not stop taking it without talking to your doctor. if you stop or skip doses, your condition may worsen and the virus may become resistant to treatment. ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cabotegravir, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this medication, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe what symptoms you had. some medications should not be taken with cabotegravir, or their doses may need to be adjusted, or additional monitoring may be needed. discuss all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist before starting cabotegravir. consult your doctor or pharmacist before starting, stopping, or changing any medications while taking cabotegravir. if you take antacids containing calcium, magnesium, or aluminum (such as maalox, mylanta, tums), take them 2 hours before or 4 hours after taking cabotegravir. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had depression or other mental illness, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; if you become pregnant while taking cabotegravir, call your doctor. tell your doctor if you are breastfeeding or plan to breastfeed; some of the medication and hiv may pass to your baby in breast milk. you should know that cabotegravir may cause changes in thoughts, behavior, or mental health. call your doctor immediately if you develop new or worsening depression, or if you think about harming yourself or planning or trying to do so. make sure your family knows which symptoms may be serious so they can call your doctor if you are unable to seek treatment. you should also know that some hiv tests can miss an infection in people recently infected. if you experience tiredness, fever, joint or muscle aches, headache, sore throat, vomiting or diarrhea, rash, night sweats, or swollen lymph nodes in the neck or groin, call your doctor immediately. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember, with a meal. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cabotegravir may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: headache, nausea, abnormal dreams, anxiety, or difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of these symptoms or those listed in the special precautions section, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help: rash with or without fever, extreme tiredness, muscle or joint aches, blisters, mouth sores, swelling of the eyes, lips, tongue, or mouth, or difficulty breathing; yellowing of the eyes or skin, pain in the upper right abdomen, unusual bruising or bleeding, loss of appetite, confusion, dark yellow or brown urine, or pale stools. cabotegravir may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: cabozantinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cabozantinib is used to treat certain types of renal cell carcinoma (rcc; kidney cancer), hepatocellular carcinoma (hcc; liver cancer), thyroid cancer, pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (tumors that begin in certain pancreatic cells), and other neuroendocrine tumors (tumors that arise from certain cells in the body). it is a kinase inhibitor that blocks abnormal signaling proteins that drive cancer cell growth, helping slow or stop the spread of cancer. how should this medicine be used? cabozantinib is taken by mouth as tablets or capsules once daily on an empty stomach, at least 1 hour before or 2 hours after eating. take it at the same time each day. swallow tablets or capsules whole with a full glass of water (8 oz/240 ml); do not split, chew, crush, or open them. use exactly as prescribed; do not take more, less, or more often than directed. treatment length depends on your response and side effects. your doctor may lower your dose or temporarily or permanently stop treatment if serious side effects occur. tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer information for patients. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cabozantinib, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cabozantinib, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your allergy symptoms. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and supplements you use or plan to use; the herbal product st. johns wort can interact with cabozantinib. do not start or stop any medication or supplement, including st. johns wort, while taking cabozantinib without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have had recent unusual or severe bleeding (such as coughing up blood, vomiting blood, or red or black tarry stools); if you have an open or healing wound; or if you have or have ever had low blood calcium, thyroid problems, high blood pressure, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; you will need a pregnancy test before starting cabozantinib. do not become pregnant during treatment and for 4 months after your final dose; discuss effective birth control options with your doctor. if you become pregnant, call your doctor right away; cabozantinib may harm the fetus. do not breastfeed during treatment and for 4 months after your last dose. this medicine may reduce fertility in males and females; discuss risks with your doctor. if you are having surgery, tell your surgeon you take cabozantinib; you will likely be told to stop it at least 21 days before surgery. if you recently had surgery, you may be told not to restart cabozantinib until at least 14 days have passed and the wound has fully healed. cabozantinib may cause serious jaw problems; see a dentist before starting and regularly during treatment, maintain good oral hygiene, and talk to your doctor before any dental procedures; you may be told to stop cabozantinib at least 21 days before dental surgery. your blood pressure may increase on this medication; your doctor will check it before and during treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not eat grapefruit, drink grapefruit juice, or take foods or supplements that contain grapefruit while using this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is less than 12 hours until your next scheduled dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at the same time to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? cabozantinib can cause side effects. common effects include constipation; nausea; vomiting; heartburn or indigestion; trouble swallowing; changes in taste; hemorrhoids; redness, swelling, sores, or pain in the mouth or throat; dry mouth; decreased appetite; weight loss; anxiety; tiredness or weakness; pale skin; dry skin; patchy thickening of the skin; pain in joints, arms, or legs; voice changes or hoarseness; hair loss; hair lightening or graying; and slowed wound healing. some side effects are serious—call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have: coughing up blood or blood clots; vomit that is bloody or looks like coffee grounds; menstrual bleeding heavier than usual; red or black tarry stools; or unusual or heavy bleeding or bruising; diarrhea; tenderness or pain in the stomach area; swelling around the eyes, arms, hands, legs, feet, or ankles; foamy urine; chest pain, pressure, or tightness; shortness of breath or cough; unusual sweating; swelling or pain in an arm or leg; fast, pounding, or irregular heartbeat; trouble breathing; chest pain; sudden severe headache; nosebleed; vision changes; tiredness; confusion; or blood in the urine; lightheadedness or fainting; dizziness; loss of balance or coordination; numbness or weakness of the face, arm, or leg on one side; sudden trouble walking; sudden difficulty thinking, speaking, or understanding; or sudden vision problems; vision changes, confusion, headache, seizures, or trouble thinking; jaw pain, toothache, loose teeth, or swollen or painful gums; rash; redness, pain, swelling, or blistering on the palms or soles; extreme tiredness, dizziness, fainting, weakness, nausea, or vomiting; yellowing of the skin or eyes, extreme tiredness, easy bleeding or bruising, nausea or vomiting, right-sided stomach pain, dark urine, or decreased appetite; muscle stiffness or spasms; numbness, burning, or tingling in the hands, arms, feet, legs, or around the mouth; sudden weight gain; seizures; or swelling of the arms, hands, legs, or ankles. cabozantinib may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: calaspargase pegol-mknl injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? calaspargase pegol-mknl is used with other chemotherapy drugs to treat acute lymphocytic leukemia (all), a cancer of white blood cells, in infants, children, and young adults 1 month to 21 years old. it is an enzyme that interferes with natural substances cancer cells need, slowing or stopping their growth and causing cell death. how should this medicine be used? calaspargase pegol-mknl is given as an intravenous infusion over about 1 hour by a healthcare professional in a medical office or hospital, usually once every 3 weeks for as long as your doctor recommends. your doctor may slow, delay, or stop an infusion, or give other medications, if certain side effects occur. tell your care team how you feel during treatment. serious allergic reactions can happen during the infusion or within 1 hour after it ends. you will be monitored during the infusion and for 1 hour afterward. get help immediately if you have swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes; flushing; hives; itching; rash; or trouble swallowing or breathing. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving calaspargase pegol-mknl, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to calaspargase pegol-mknl, pegaspargase (oncaspar), any asparaginase products (such as asparaginase [elspar] or asparaginase erwinia chrysanthemi [erwinaze]), any other medications, or any of the ingredients in calaspargase pegol-mknl injection. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had pancreatitis, blood clots, or severe bleeding, especially if these occurred during prior asparaginase therapy, or if you have liver disease; your doctor may decide this medication is not right for you. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. you must have a pregnancy test before starting treatment and use effective birth control during treatment and for 3 months after the final dose; calaspargase pegol-mknl may decrease the effectiveness of oral contraceptives, so use an additional non-hormonal method. if you become pregnant, call your doctor immediately; this medication may harm the fetus. do not breast-feed during treatment and for 3 months after the final dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given in a medical setting. if you miss an appointment for an infusion, contact your doctor as soon as possible to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? calaspargase pegol-mknl injection may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any symptom is severe or does not go away, including diarrhea. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away if you have unusual or severe bleeding or bruising; ongoing abdominal pain that may spread to the back; increased thirst or urination; yellowing of the skin or eyes, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, extreme tiredness, pale stools, or dark urine; severe headache; redness, swelling, pain in an arm or leg, chest pain, or shortness of breath; irregular or fast heartbeat; fever, chills, cough, or other signs of infection; shortness of breath especially with activity; extreme tiredness; swelling of the legs, ankles, or feet. calaspargase pegol-mknl may cause other side effects; talk to your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: calcipotriene topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? calcipotriene topical is used to treat plaque psoriasis, a skin condition in which red, scaly patches form due to increased skin cell production. it is a synthetic vitamin d3 analog that works by slowing excessive skin cell growth. how should this medicine be used? calcipotriene comes as a cream for the skin and a solution for the scalp. apply a thin layer to affected areas twice daily at about the same times each day, exactly as directed. do not use more or less or more often than prescribed. do not apply the cream to the face and avoid contact with the eyes, mouth, and inside the nose. the solution is flammable; keep away from heat, sparks, and open flames, and do not smoke while applying or until it has dried. you may see improvement within 2 weeks; full benefit may take up to 8 weeks. to use the cream: wash your hands, apply a thin layer to affected skin, rub in until absorbed, then wash your hands again. to use the solution: wash your hands, comb out loose scales, part the hair to expose lesions, apply a small amount to affected scalp areas, rub in gently, avoid getting it on the face (especially eyes, nose, and mouth), then wash your hands. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to calcipotriene or any medications, and about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use. inform your doctor about any medical conditions you have or have had. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while using calcipotriene, call your doctor. avoid unnecessary or prolonged sunlight exposure and wear protective clothing and sunscreen, as calcipotriene may increase sensitivity to sunlight. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra cream or solution to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? calcipotriene may cause itching, redness, burning, stinging or tingling, dry skin, or temporary worsening of psoriasis at the application site. serious side effects can include rash or significant irritation of the treated or nearby skin; if these occur, call your doctor immediately. calcipotriene may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you have unusual symptoms or if your condition worsens.

name: calcitonin salmon injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? calcitonin salmon injection is used to treat osteoporosis in postmenopausal women, a condition that weakens bones and increases the risk of fractures. it is also used to treat paget’s disease of bone and to rapidly lower high calcium levels in the blood when needed. calcitonin is a hormone found in humans and also in salmon; it helps by slowing bone breakdown and increasing bone density. how should this medicine be used? calcitonin salmon comes as a solution for injection under the skin (subcutaneous) or into a muscle (intramuscular). it is usually given once daily or every other day. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. use calcitonin salmon injection exactly as directed; do not use more, use less, or use it more often than prescribed. your healthcare provider will show you how to prepare and inject the dose; follow all instructions carefully. dispose of used syringes and vials as directed by your healthcare provider. inspect the vial before use; if the solution is discolored or contains particles, do not use it and contact your pharmacist. calcitonin salmon helps manage osteoporosis and paget’s disease but does not cure them. continue using it even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine calcitonin salmon injection is sometimes used to treat osteogenesis imperfecta. discuss potential risks and benefits with your doctor. it may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using calcitonin salmon injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to calcitonin salmon or any other medications. your doctor may perform a skin test before starting treatment to check for an allergic reaction. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using calcitonin salmon, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? if you are using calcitonin salmon for osteoporosis, ensure adequate calcium and vitamin d intake; your doctor may recommend supplements if your diet is insufficient. what should i do if i forget a dose? do not use a double dose to make up for a missed dose. follow these guidelines: if you usually inject two times per day, use the missed dose if remembered within 2 hours of the scheduled time; otherwise skip it and resume your regular schedule. if you usually inject once daily, use the missed dose if you remember the same day; otherwise skip it and resume the next day. if you usually inject every other day, use the missed dose as soon as you remember (on the scheduled day or the next day), then continue every other day from that point. if you usually inject three times a week, give the missed dose the next day, continue every other day thereafter, and resume your regular weekly schedule the following week. what side effects can this medication cause? calcitonin salmon may cause side effects. call your doctor if these are severe or do not go away: upset stomach, vomiting, redness/swelling/irritation at the injection site, flushing, a warm feeling in the face or hands, increased urination at night, itching of the earlobes, a feverish feeling, eye pain, decreased appetite, stomach pain, swelling of the feet, or a salty taste. some side effects can be serious; if you experience hives, skin rash, itching, difficulty breathing or swallowing, or swelling of the tongue or throat, call your doctor immediately. calcitonin salmon may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: calcitonin salmon nasal spray
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? calcitonin salmon is prescribed to treat osteoporosis in women who are at least 5 years past menopause and who cannot or do not want to use estrogen therapy. osteoporosis weakens bones and makes fractures more likely. calcitonin is a human hormone that is also found in salmon; it works by slowing bone breakdown and helping increase bone density. how should this medicine be used? calcitonin salmon is a nasal spray used once daily, alternating nostrils each day. use it at the same time each day. follow the directions on your prescription label exactly; do not use more or less or more often than prescribed. it helps manage but does not cure osteoporosis; continue using it even if you feel well and do not stop without talking with your doctor. before first use, read the written instructions. ask your doctor or pharmacist to show you how to use it and practice while they watch. to assemble, remove the rubber stopper from the bottle, remove the plastic protective cap from the bottom of the spray unit, insert the spray pump into the bottle and tighten, then remove the top protective cap. prime a new bottle before the first dose: allow the bottle to reach room temperature, hold it upright, and press the two white side arms at least 5 times until a full spray is produced. to use: keep your head upright, place the nozzle in one nostril, and press the pump to release the dose; use the opposite nostril the next day. each bottle contains 30 doses. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using calcitonin salmon, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to calcitonin salmon or any medications. your doctor may perform a skin test before you start to make sure you do not have an allergic reaction. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. if you become pregnant while using calcitonin salmon, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? make sure you get enough calcium and vitamin d while using calcitonin salmon; your doctor may recommend supplements if your diet is not sufficient. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not use two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? calcitonin salmon may cause side effects. call your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: runny nose, nosebleed, sinus pain, nasal crusts, dryness, redness, or swelling, back pain, joint pain, upset stomach, flushing, or a feeling of warmth. some side effects can be serious. although uncommon, call your doctor immediately if you have hives, rash, itching, trouble breathing or swallowing, or swelling of the tongue or throat. calcitonin salmon may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: calcitriol
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? calcitriol is used to treat and prevent low calcium levels and bone disease in people whose kidneys or parathyroid glands are not working normally. it is also used to treat secondary hyperparathyroidism and metabolic bone disease in people with kidney disease. calcitriol is a vitamin d analog that helps the body use more of the calcium from foods or supplements and regulates parathyroid hormone production. it may also be used for rickets and osteomalacia caused by lack of vitamin d, familial hypophosphatemia, and to raise calcium levels in some premature infants; ask your doctor about the risks and benefits of these uses. how should this medicine be used? calcitriol comes as capsules and an oral solution to take by mouth. it is usually taken once daily or once every other day in the morning, with or without food. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. take calcitriol exactly as prescribed. do not take more or less, or take it more often, than your doctor directs. your doctor will likely start with a low dose and adjust based on your response. what special precautions should i follow? before taking calcitriol, tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use. some nonprescription products can interact with calcitriol, including other vitamin d supplements, calcium supplements, antacids that contain magnesium, magnesium supplements, and magnesium-containing laxatives; do not start or stop these without discussing with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have high calcium levels, as you may be told not to take calcitriol. also tell your doctor if you recently had surgery, are unable to move around, or if you have or have ever had kidney or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking calcitriol, call your doctor. you should not breastfeed while taking calcitriol. what special dietary instructions should i follow? calcitriol works only if you get the right amount of calcium in your diet. too much calcium can cause serious side effects, and too little can make the medicine less effective. your doctor will tell you which foods are good sources and how many servings you need each day, and may recommend or prescribe a supplement if needed. if you are receiving dialysis, your doctor may also prescribe a low-phosphate diet; follow these directions carefully. if you do not have kidney disease, drink plenty of fluids while taking calcitriol. if you have kidney disease, ask your doctor how much fluid you should drink each day. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you experience any of the following: feeling unusually tired, difficulty thinking clearly, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, constipation, increased thirst, increased urination, weight loss, weakness, headache, upset stomach, dry mouth, muscle pain, bone pain, metallic taste in the mouth, difficult or painful urination, changes in vision, lack of interest in usual activities, hallucinations, fever or chills, stomach pain, pale fatty stools, yellowing of the skin or eyes, runny nose, decreased sexual desire, irregular heartbeat, rash, hives, itching, or difficulty breathing or swallowing.

name: calcium acetate
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? calcium acetate is prescribed to control high phosphorus levels in people with kidney disease who are on dialysis. it belongs to a class of medications called phosphate binders. it binds the phosphorus from foods you eat and prevents it from being absorbed into your bloodstream. how should this medicine be used? calcium acetate comes as capsules, tablets, and an oral solution to take by mouth. it is usually taken with each meal (for example, three times daily if you eat three meals), exactly as directed by your doctor. take it at about the same times each day. follow the directions on your prescription label, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have any questions. do not take more or less than prescribed, and do not take it more often. if you use the oral solution, do not measure your dose with a household spoon; use the dosing cup provided with the medication. ask your pharmacist if you are unsure about your dose or how to use the dosing cup. your doctor will likely adjust your dose based on your blood phosphorus levels, no more often than every 2 to 3 weeks. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking calcium acetate, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to calcium acetate, any other medications, or any ingredients in calcium acetate products. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. take a fluoroquinolone antibiotic such as ciprofloxacin (cipro), gemifloxacin (factive), levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin (avelox) at least 2 hours before or 6 hours after taking calcium acetate. take levothyroxine (euthyrox, synthroid, tirosint) at least 4 hours before or 4 hours after taking calcium acetate. take a tetracycline antibiotic such as demeclocycline, doxycycline (monodox, oracea, vibramycin), minocycline (dynacin, minocin, solodyn), or tetracycline (achromycin v, in pylera) at least 1 hour before taking calcium acetate. if you are using calcium supplements or calcium-containing antacids (such as tums), do not take them while you are taking calcium acetate. if you have high calcium levels in your blood, your doctor will probably tell you not to take calcium acetate. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any other medical conditions. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking calcium acetate, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and take your next dose with your next meal. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? calcium acetate may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: nausea, vomiting, constipation, loss of appetite, itching. some side effects can be serious. if you experience confusion, feeling disoriented, feeling faint, or loss of consciousness, call your doctor immediately or seek emergency medical care. calcium acetate may cause other side effects.

name: calcium carbonate
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? calcium carbonate is a dietary supplement used when the amount of calcium in the diet is not enough. calcium is needed for healthy bones, muscles, the nervous system, and the heart. calcium carbonate is also used as an antacid to relieve heartburn, acid indigestion, and upset stomach. it is available with or without a prescription. this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? calcium carbonate comes as a tablet, chewable tablet, capsule, and liquid to take by mouth. it is usually taken three or four times a day. follow the directions on your prescription or package label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain any part you do not understand. take calcium carbonate exactly as directed. do not take more or less of it or take it more often than directed by your doctor. when using this medicine as a dietary supplement, take it with food or right after meals. chewable tablets should be chewed thoroughly; do not swallow them whole. drink a full glass of water after taking regular or chewable tablets or capsules. some liquid forms must be shaken well before use. do not take calcium carbonate as an antacid for more than 2 weeks unless your doctor tells you to. what special precautions should i follow? before taking calcium carbonate, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to calcium carbonate or any other drugs. tell your doctor and pharmacist what prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. do not take calcium carbonate within 1 to 2 hours of taking other medicines, as calcium may decrease their effectiveness. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney disease, kidney stones, or stomach or intestinal conditions. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. if you become pregnant while taking calcium carbonate, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. when using calcium carbonate as a supplement, take it with meals to improve absorption. follow your doctor’s advice about how much calcium and vitamin d you should get each day. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you are taking calcium carbonate on a regular schedule, take the missed dose as soon as you remember it. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? calcium carbonate may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: upset stomach, vomiting, stomach pain, belching, constipation, dry mouth, increased urination, loss of appetite, or a metallic taste.

name: canagliflozin
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? canagliflozin is used to: lower blood sugar in people with type 2 diabetes (a condition in which blood sugar is too high because the body does not make or use insulin normally); reduce the risk of stroke, heart attack, or death in certain people who have type 2 diabetes; and reduce the risk of worsening kidney disease, hospitalization for heart failure, and death in certain adults with type 2 diabetes and kidney disease. canagliflozin is a sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (sglt2) inhibitor that lowers blood sugar by helping the kidneys remove more glucose in the urine. it is not used to treat type 1 diabetes (a condition in which the body does not produce insulin). over time, high blood sugar can cause serious problems such as heart disease, stroke, kidney damage, nerve damage, and eye disease. taking medication as prescribed, making lifestyle changes (diet, exercise, quitting smoking), and checking your blood sugar regularly can help manage diabetes and may lower your risk of heart attack, stroke, and other complications (such as kidney failure, nerve damage causing numb or cold legs or feet, decreased sexual ability, eye problems including vision changes or loss, and gum disease). your healthcare team will advise you on the best plan to manage your diabetes. how should this medicine be used? canagliflozin comes as an oral tablet taken once daily before breakfast or your first main meal. take it at the same time each day, exactly as directed. do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. your doctor may start you on a low dose and increase it gradually. canagliflozin controls but does not cure type 2 diabetes; continue taking it even if you feel well and do not stop without talking to your doctor. you will receive a medication guide when you start treatment and with each refill; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking canagliflozin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to it, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and explain what symptoms you had. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. inform your doctor if you regularly drink alcohol or sometimes drink large amounts in a short time (binge drinking); if you have an infection; or if you follow a low-sodium diet. also tell your doctor if you have ever had an amputation; heart disease; peripheral vascular disease; neuropathy; foot ulcers or sores; low blood pressure; urinary tract infections or urinary problems; pancreatic disease (including pancreatitis) or pancreatic surgery; infections in the genital area; osteoporosis; or kidney or liver disease. if you are male, tell your doctor if you have not been circumcised. tell your doctor if you are eating less due to illness, surgery, or dietary changes; if you are on a ketogenic (high-fat, low-carbohydrate) diet; if you cannot eat or drink normally due to nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea; or if you become dehydrated (for example, from being in the sun too long). if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor;
