do not breastfeed while taking canagliflozin. if you become pregnant, call your doctor—canagliflozin may harm the fetus. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist you take canagliflozin. your doctor may tell you to stop canagliflozin at least 3 days before scheduled surgery if you will not be able to eat or drink normally for a long time, and will tell you when to restart after surgery. alcohol can affect blood sugar; ask your doctor about safe alcohol use while taking canagliflozin. canagliflozin may cause dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting when you stand up quickly; this is more common when starting treatment. to help prevent this, rise slowly and sit with your feet on the floor for a few minutes before standing; call your doctor if this continues. ask your doctor what to do if you become ill, develop an infection or fever, experience unusual stress, or are injured, as these can affect your blood sugar and your canagliflozin dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow the diet and exercise plan recommended by your doctor or dietitian. eat a healthful diet, exercise regularly, and follow your doctor’s instructions about drinking enough fluids while taking this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? this medication can change your blood sugar. know the symptoms of low and high blood sugar and what to do if they occur. common side effects include urinating a lot (including at night), increased thirst, constipation, and dry mouth. serious side effects may occur; call your doctor right away if you have any of the following: frequent, urgent, burning, or painful urination; decreased urine amount; urine that is cloudy, red, pink, or brown; strong-smelling urine; pelvic or rectal pain; fever, back pain, nausea, or vomiting. women: vaginal odor, white or yellowish discharge (which may be lumpy like cottage cheese), or vaginal itching. men: redness, itching, or swelling of the penis; rash on the penis; foul-smelling discharge; or pain in the skin around the penis. symptoms such as feeling tired, weak, or unwell with fever and pain, tenderness, redness, and swelling of the genitals or the area between the genitals and rectum require immediate medical attention. falls may occur. stop canagliflozin and call your doctor immediately or get emergency help if you have signs of an allergic reaction: rash, hives, itching, trouble breathing or swallowing, hoarseness, or swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, mouth, or eyes. stop canagliflozin and call your doctor immediately or get emergency help if you have symptoms of ketoacidosis (a serious condition that can occur even if blood sugar is less than 250 mg/dl): nausea, vomiting, stomach-area pain, tiredness, or difficulty breathing; if possible, check your urine ketones. canagliflozin can increase the risk of lower-limb amputation (toe, foot, or leg). follow your doctor’s instructions for foot and leg care and call right away if you have pain, tenderness, sores, ulcers, or a swollen, warm, reddened area in your leg or foot; fever or chills; or other signs of infection. canagliflozin may increase the risk of fractures (broken bones), especially in the arms, wrists, hands, lower legs, ankles, or feet; talk to your doctor about risks. canagliflozin may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: canakinumab injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? canakinumab injection is used to treat certain inherited periodic fever syndromes in which the body attacks its own tissues and organs, causing fever, inflammation, joint and muscle pain, eye redness or pain, stomach pain, rash, and fatigue. these conditions include familial cold autoinflammatory syndrome (fcas) and muckle-wells syndrome (mws) in adults and in children 4 years of age or older, and tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated periodic syndrome (traps), mevalonate kinase deficiency (mkd)/hyperimmunoglobulin d syndrome (hids), and familial mediterranean fever (fmf) in adults and children. canakinumab is also used to treat still's disease, including adult-onset still's disease (aosd) and systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis (sjia), in patients 2 years of age or older. it is also used for gout flares—sudden attacks of redness, swelling, pain, and heat in one or more joints—in adults who were not treated successfully with, cannot take, or cannot tolerate other treatments. canakinumab belongs to a class of medicines called interleukin antagonists; it works by blocking interleukin activity that causes inflammation. how should this medicine be used? canakinumab comes as a solution that is injected subcutaneously (under the skin) by a doctor or nurse. for periodic fever syndromes, it is usually given once every 4 or 8 weeks, depending on the specific syndrome being treated. for still's disease, it is usually given once every 4 weeks. for gout flares, it is given as a single dose at the time of a flare; if new flares occur, additional doses may be given at least 12 weeks after a previous dose. your doctor may start you on a low dose and increase it gradually. your doctor or pharmacist will give you the medication guide when you begin treatment; read it carefully and ask any questions you have. this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving canakinumab, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to canakinumab, to any other medicines, or to any ingredient in the injection; ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take, especially medicines that affect the immune system, because your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you closely for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had low white blood cell counts or any condition that affects your immune system. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while receiving canakinumab, call your doctor. if you received canakinumab during pregnancy and have given birth, tell the baby's doctor that you received canakinumab; this medicine may interfere with the infant immune response to vaccines. discuss vaccinations for the baby with the baby's doctor. you should know that canakinumab may decrease your ability to fight infections caused by bacteria, viruses, and fungi and may increase your risk of serious infection. tell your doctor if you often get infections or if you have or think you may have an infection now. this includes minor infections such as open cuts or sores, infections that come and go such as herpes or cold sores, and chronic infections that do not go away. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had human immunodeficiency virus (hiv), hepatitis b virus infection (hbv), hepatitis c virus infection (hcv), or another ongoing liver infection. call your doctor immediately if you develop any signs of infection during or shortly after treatment, such as fever, sweats, or chills; sore throat; cough; warm, red, or painful skin or sores on your body; frequent, urgent, or painful urination; or other symptoms of infection. you should know that using canakinumab increases the risk of tuberculosis (tb), especially if you have latent tb (infection without symptoms). tell your doctor if you have or have ever had tb, if you have lived in a country where tb is common, or if you have been around someone with tb. your doctor may perform a skin test to check for inactive tb. call your doctor right away if you have symptoms of tb now or during treatment, such as cough, coughing up blood or mucus, weakness or tiredness, weight loss, loss of appetite, chills, fever, or night sweats. you should know that macrophage activation syndrome (mas), a serious or life-threatening condition, may occur in patients with stills disease (aosd or sjia) or other autoinflammatory conditions. call your doctor immediately if you have new or worsening symptoms of aosd or sjia or if you have a cough or fever that does not go away; redness, warmth, or swelling of the skin; or any other signs of infection. do not receive any vaccinations without talking to your doctor. check with your doctor to see if you or your child need any vaccinations. it is important that adults and children receive all age-appropriate vaccines before beginning treatment with canakinumab. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment to receive canakinumab injection, call your doctor right away. what side effects can this medication cause? canakinumab may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: pain, bruising, bleeding, swelling, redness, warmth, or itching at the injection site; nausea; vomiting; diarrhea; stomach pain; stuffy nose; headache; weight gain; dizziness; back, muscle, or joint pain. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or seek emergency medical care if you experience any of the following, or any symptoms listed in the special precautions section: hives; rash; itching; difficulty breathing or swallowing; lightheadedness; fainting; fast or irregular heartbeat. canakinumab may increase the risk of developing certain types of cancer. this medicine may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving canakinumab.

name: candesartan
instructions: important warning: do not take candesartan if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. if you become pregnant while taking candesartan, stop taking it and call your doctor immediately. taking candesartan during the last 6 months of pregnancy may cause serious injury or death to the fetus. why is this medication prescribed? candesartan is used alone or with other medications to treat high blood pressure. it is also used alone or with other medications to treat congestive heart failure, a condition in which your heart cannot pump enough blood to the rest of the body. candesartan is an angiotensin ii receptor blocker (arb). it works by blocking natural substances that tighten blood vessels, allowing blood to flow more easily and helping the heart pump more efficiently. untreated high blood pressure can damage the brain, heart, blood vessels, kidneys, and other parts of the body, leading to heart disease, heart attack, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, loss of vision, and other problems. in addition to taking medication, lifestyle changes such as eating a low-fat, low-salt diet, maintaining a healthy weight, exercising at least 30 minutes most days, not smoking, and limiting alcohol can help control blood pressure. how should this medicine be used? candesartan comes as an oral tablet. it is usually taken once or twice daily, with or without food. take it at the same times each day to help you remember. follow the directions on your prescription label and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take candesartan exactly as directed; do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. your doctor will likely start you on a low dose and increase it no more than once every 2 weeks. candesartan controls high blood pressure but does not cure it. your blood pressure may start to decrease within 2 weeks, but full benefit may take 4 to 6 weeks. continue to take candesartan even if you feel well. do not stop taking it without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine: candesartan is sometimes used to treat diabetic nephropathy (kidney disease) in people with diabetes and high blood pressure. talk to your doctor about the risks and benefits of using this medication for your condition. this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking candesartan, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to candesartan, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. if you have diabetes and are taking aliskiren (tekturna) or combination products containing aliskiren (amturnide, tekamlo, tekturna hct), your doctor will probably tell you not to take candesartan. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. nonprescription products that may interact with candesartan include aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin) and naproxen (aleve, naprosyn), and potassium supplements or salt substitutes containing potassium. do not start any of these while taking candesartan without discussing it with your healthcare provider, and be sure your doctor and pharmacist know if you are taking them. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had heart, kidney, or liver disease, and if you are breastfeeding. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking candesartan. candesartan may cause dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting when you get up too quickly, especially when you first start the medication. to help prevent this, rise slowly from lying or sitting, and place your feet on the floor for a few minutes before standing. diarrhea, vomiting, not drinking enough fluids, or heavy sweating can lower blood pressure and cause lightheadedness or fainting; tell your doctor if you have or develop any of these problems during treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not use salt substitutes containing potassium without talking to your doctor. if your doctor prescribes a low-salt or low-sodium diet, follow these instructions carefully. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? candesartan may cause side effects. common side effects include headache, back pain, and sore throat. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you experience swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; hoarseness; difficulty breathing or swallowing; or decreased urination. if you experience any symptoms listed in the special precautions section or any unusual problems while taking candesartan, contact your doctor.

name: cannabidiol
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cannabidiol is prescribed to help control seizures in adults and in children 1 year of age and older with lennox-gastaut syndrome (a childhood-onset disorder that causes seizures, developmental delays, and behavioral problems), dravet syndrome (a childhood-onset seizure disorder that can later lead to developmental delays and changes in eating, balance, and walking), or tuberous sclerosis complex (tsc; a genetic condition that causes tumors to grow in many organs). cannabidiol belongs to a class of medicines called cannabinoids. the exact way it reduces seizure activity is not fully known. how should this medicine be used? cannabidiol is an oral solution taken by mouth, usually twice daily. you may take it with or without food, but take it the same way every time. take your doses at about the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly; do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. measure each dose only with the provided oral syringe, and use a dry syringe each time; do not use a household spoon. if water gets into the bottle or syringe, the solution may look cloudy, but this does not change its safety or effectiveness. the solution may be given through a feeding tube; if you use a tube, ask your doctor for specific instructions and follow them carefully. your doctor will start with a low dose and increase it gradually, usually no more than once each week. cannabidiol helps control your condition but does not cure it. continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop suddenly; stopping abruptly can cause new or worsening seizures. your doctor will guide a gradual dose reduction if needed. you will receive a medication guide when you start treatment and with each refill; read it and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. other uses for this medicine this medicine may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cannabidiol, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cannabidiol, sesame seed oil, any of the ingredients in the solution, or any other medications. review the medication guide for a full list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. in particular, st. john’s wort and caffeine supplements may interact with cannabidiol—do not start or stop these without discussing them with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you drink or have drunk large amounts of alcohol; use or have used street drugs; or have misused prescription medicines. also tell your doctor if you have or have had depression, mood problems, suicidal thoughts or behavior, or liver disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, discuss this with your doctor; call your doctor if you become pregnant while taking cannabidiol. cannabidiol may cause drowsiness or difficulty concentrating. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. ask your doctor about using alcoholic beverages; alcohol can worsen certain side effects. anticonvulsants, including cannabidiol, may rarely cause new or worsening depression, suicidal thoughts, or other unexpected mood or behavior changes. you and your doctor should weigh these risks against the risks of not treating your condition. you, your family, or your caregiver should call your doctor right away if you experience panic attacks; agitation or restlessness; new or worsening irritability, anxiety, or depression; acting on dangerous impulses; trouble falling or staying asleep; aggressive, angry, or violent behavior; mania (an abnormally excited, frenzied mood); talking or thinking about wanting to hurt yourself or end your life; withdrawing from friends or family; preoccupation with death; giving away prized possessions; or any other unusual changes in mood or behavior. make sure your family or caregiver knows these warning signs so they can seek help if you cannot. what special dietary instructions should i follow? talk to your doctor before eating grapefruit or drinking grapefruit juice while taking this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cannabidiol may cause side effects. common side effects include diarrhea, tiredness, trouble falling or staying asleep, decreased appetite, weight loss, stomach pain or discomfort, drooling or excessive saliva, and problems with walking. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have rash, hives, or redness; signs of liver problems such as loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, yellowing of the skin or eyes, itching, unusually dark urine, or pain/discomfort in the right upper abdomen; or signs of infection such as fever or cough. cannabidiol may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: cantharidin topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cantharidin topical is used to treat molluscum contagiosum (pearl like skin bumps) in adults and in children 2 years of age and older. it belongs to a class of medicines called vesicants; its exact mechanism for molluscum is not known. how should this medicine be used? cantharidin topical is a liquid that is applied only by a healthcare professional in a clinic or doctor office. it is placed directly on molluscum bumps, usually once every 3 weeks as needed. after application, let it dry completely (up to 5 minutes) before leaving the office. keep treated skin dry and do not touch the treated areas. wash the treated skin with mild soap and water 24 hours after application; do not scrub or use washcloths or other abrasive materials. apply only to skin; do not use on the mouth, nose, eyes, or genital areas. do not allow the medicine to contact the eyes or mouth for 24 hours after application or until it has been washed off. if it gets in the eyes, flush with water for at least 15 minutes and get emergency medical care; severe eye injury, including scarring, corneal ulcers, and permanent vision loss, can occur. do not apply other topical products (creams, lotions, sunscreen, steroids) to the treatment areas on the day of treatment before application or for 24 hours after, or until the medicine has been washed off. do not wrap or bandage treated areas. if you have a severe reaction such as intense pain or blistering before 24 hours have passed, wash the medication off with soap and water and call your doctor. your doctor may recommend an over the counter pain reliever such as acetaminophen for discomfort. cantharidin topical is flammable, even when dry; keep treated skin away from fire, flames, heat sources, and do not smoke until it is washed off. talk to your doctor if you have questions, and ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer patient information. other uses for this medicine this medicine may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before treatment, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cantharidin, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the cantharidin topical solution; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had other skin problems. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; if you become pregnant during treatment, call your doctor. tell your doctor if you are breast feeding or plan to breast feed; if you are breast feeding, your doctor will avoid applying medicine to areas your baby could contact. because the product is flammable, do not smoke after treatment until the medication has been washed off. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a treatment or appointment, contact your healthcare provider to reschedule. do not attempt to apply cantharidin yourself. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects at the application site include lightening or darkening of the skin, redness, itching, dryness, or scabbing. serious effects can include pain, swelling, or blistering at the application site; skin breakdown or sores. eye exposure can cause painful, irritated, or red eyes and loss of vision; seek emergency care. if the medicine contacts the mouth or is swallowed, get emergency medical help. symptoms requiring urgent care include decreased urination; discolored or bloody urine; swelling of the face, arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; unusual tiredness or weakness; nausea; vomiting; diarrhea; black, tarry, sticky stools or stools with blood or mucus; abdominal pain and cramping; unusual bleeding or bruising; seizures; sudden weakness in the arms, legs, or neck; drooping eyelids; difficulty swallowing; or slurred speech. other side effects may occur; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems.

name: capecitabine
instructions: important warning: capecitabine may cause serious or life-threatening bleeding when taken with anticoagulants (blood thinners) such as warfarin (coumadin). if you are taking warfarin, your doctor will order laboratory tests to monitor how fast your blood clots and may need to change your dose of warfarin. call your doctor immediately if you experience unusual bleeding; vomiting or spitting up blood or brown material that looks like coffee grounds; bloody or black, tarry stools; blood in the urine; red or dark-brown urine; or easy bruising. why is this medication prescribed? capecitabine is used in combination with other medications to treat breast cancer that has returned after treatment with other drugs. it is also used alone to treat breast cancer that has not improved after other treatments. capecitabine is also used to treat colon or rectal cancer that has worsened or spread to other parts of the body, and to help prevent colon cancer from spreading after surgery to remove the tumor. capecitabine is in a class of medications called antimetabolites and works by stopping or slowing the growth of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? capecitabine comes as an oral tablet. it is usually taken twice a day, in the morning and evening, for 2 weeks, followed by a 1-week break before repeating the cycle. take it within 30 minutes after breakfast and dinner with a glass of water. take capecitabine at the same times each day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully. take capecitabine exactly as directed; do not take more or less, or take it more often than prescribed. your doctor may adjust your dose or pause treatment depending on your response and any side effects; tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. swallow the tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush them. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine: capecitabine is sometimes used to treat advanced gastric (stomach) cancer. talk to your doctor about the risks and benefits of using this medication for your condition. this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking capecitabine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to capecitabine, fluorouracil (adrucil, 5-fu), any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take while using capecitabine; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. ask your doctor whether testing for dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase (dpd) enzyme deficiency should be done before starting treatment. if you have been told you have, or have ever had, dpd enzyme deficiency, your doctor will likely tell you not to take capecitabine. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney, liver, or heart disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; you should not plan to conceive while taking capecitabine. use a reliable method of birth control to prevent pregnancy in yourself or your partner during treatment, because capecitabine may harm the fetus. tell your doctor if you are breastfeeding; do not breast-feed during treatment with capecitabine. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? capecitabine may cause side effects. if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away, tell your doctor: stomach pain or upset stomach; constipation; loss of appetite; change in ability to taste food; increased thirst; unusual tiredness or weakness; dizziness; headache; hair loss; skin rash; back, joint, or muscle pain; red, swollen, itchy, or teary eyes; trouble falling asleep or staying asleep. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following or any symptoms listed in the important warning section, call your doctor immediately: diarrhea; nausea; vomiting; sores in the mouth; swelling, pain, redness, or peeling of skin on the palms and soles of the feet; fever, chills, sore throat, or other signs of an infection; swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; chest pain or pressure; fast heartbeat; dark urine; yellowing of the skin or eyes. capecitabine may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: capivasertib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? capivasertib is used with fulvestrant (faslodex) to treat certain hormone receptor-positive advanced or metastatic breast cancers in adults whose disease has worsened during or after other treatments. it is also used with fulvestrant and another medication to treat certain hormone receptor-positive advanced breast cancers that have spread in women who are premenopausal, nearing menopause, or postmenopausal. capivasertib is a kinase inhibitor that blocks an abnormal protein that signals cancer cells to grow, helping to slow or stop their spread. this medicine may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? capivasertib is an oral tablet taken with or without food twice daily, about 12 hours apart, for the first 4 days of each 7-day cycle; cycles are repeated as directed by your doctor. take it at the same times each day (morning and evening). follow your prescription label carefully and take exactly as directed; do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. swallow tablets whole with water; do not split, chew, or crush. do not use tablets that are broken, cracked, or damaged. if you vomit after a dose, do not take an extra dose; resume your regular schedule the next day. your doctor may pause treatment or adjust your dose based on your response and any side effects; tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. continue taking capivasertib even if you feel well, and do not stop without talking to your doctor. if you have not gone through menopause or are just entering menopause, your doctor will likely prescribe another medication such as goserelin (zoladex) or leuprolide (eligard, lupron) to take with capivasertib and fulvestrant. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking capivasertib, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to capivasertib, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; some products, including st. john’s wort, may interact with capivasertib. do not start or stop any of these while taking capivasertib without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have a rash or other skin problem, high triglycerides, or kidney or liver problems. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or plan to father a child, you or your partner should not become pregnant while taking capivasertib. females need a pregnancy test before starting and must use birth control during treatment and for 1 month after the last dose. males and their partners must use birth control during treatment and for 4 months after the last dose. if pregnancy occurs, call your doctor; capivasertib may harm the fetus. do not breastfeed while taking capivasertib. capivasertib may increase blood glucose. if you have diabetes or high blood sugar, monitor as directed by your doctor and call if your readings are higher than usual. call immediately if you develop extreme thirst, frequent urination, extreme hunger, blurred vision, confusion, or weakness. untreated high blood sugar can cause ketoacidosis, which can be life-threatening; symptoms include dry mouth, nausea and vomiting, shortness of breath, fruity-smelling breath, and decreased consciousness. call your doctor if you cannot eat or drink normally due to nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea while taking capivasertib; your doctor may adjust your diet or medicines to help control your blood sugar. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not eat grapefruit or drink grapefruit juice while taking this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. however, if more than 4 hours have passed since the scheduled time, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? capivasertib may cause side effects. common side effects include nausea, vomiting, mouth sores, tiredness, decreased appetite, and headache. some side effects can be serious. stop taking the medication and call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have any of the following, or any symptoms listed in the special precautions section: rash; blistering, peeling, dry, or reddened skin; blistering of the lips, eyes, or mouth; fever; flu-like symptoms; diarrhea (loose, watery, or more frequent stools); stomach cramps; dry mouth; weakness; decreased urination; swelling of the legs or ankles; or frequent, painful, or urgent urination. capivasertib may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: caplacizumab-yhdp injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? caplacizumab-yhdp injection is used with plasma exchange therapy and immunosuppressant medications to treat acquired thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura attp, a condition in which the immune system causes blood clots and low levels of platelets and red blood cells that can lead to serious complications. caplacizumab-yhdp is an antithrombotic agent that works by blocking a substance that contributes to the symptoms of attp. how should this medicine be used? caplacizumab-yhdp comes as a powder that is mixed with liquid and given either intravenously into a vein or by subcutaneous injection under the skin. on the first day, it is given as an intravenous injection at least 15 minutes before plasma exchange, and again as a subcutaneous injection after plasma exchange is finished. after day 1, it is usually given once daily as a subcutaneous injection after each plasma exchange for as long as you receive plasma exchange therapy, and then once daily for an additional 30 to 58 days after plasma exchange has stopped. use caplacizumab-yhdp at about the same time each day. follow your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. use exactly as directed and do not use more, use less, or use it more often than prescribed. your doctor may allow you or a caregiver to give the injections at home. ask your doctor or pharmacist to show you how to prepare and inject the dose and read the written instructions for use before your first self injection. inject subcutaneously into the abdomen, avoiding the navel and the 2 inches 5 centimeters around it. do not inject into the same spot two days in a row; rotate injection sites. dispose of used needles, syringes, and vials in a puncture resistant container and ask your doctor or pharmacist how to dispose of the filled container. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving caplacizumab-yhdp, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to caplacizumab-yhdp, to any other medications, or to any ingredient in the injection; your pharmacist can provide a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had hemophilia a genetic disorder in which the body cannot stop bleeding properly, any other bleeding problems, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while receiving caplacizumab-yhdp, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are using caplacizumab-yhdp; you may be told not to use it for 7 days before the procedure. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. however, if you are no longer receiving plasma exchange therapy and more than 12 hours have passed since the missed dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular dosing schedule. do not use two doses at the same time to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? caplacizumab-yhdp may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of the following are severe or do not go away: headache; extreme tiredness; back pain; muscle pain; tingling, prickling, or numb skin sensations; itching near the injection site; shortness of breath; fever. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you experience any of the following: hives; heavy bleeding that does not stop, including bleeding from the rectum, vagina, nose, gums, or the injection site; vomiting blood; red or black tarry stools; blood in the urine; sudden severe headache with nausea or vomiting; sudden sharp abdominal pain with nausea or vomiting; frequent, painful, or urgent urination. caplacizumab-yhdp injection may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: capmatinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? capmatinib is used to treat a certain type of non-small cell lung cancer (nsclc) that has spread to other parts of the body. it is a kinase inhibitor that blocks an abnormal protein that signals cancer cells to multiply, helping slow or stop the spread of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? capmatinib comes as a tablet to take by mouth and is usually taken twice daily with or without food. take it at about the same times every day. follow your prescription label exactly, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not take more or less than prescribed or take it more often. swallow the tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush them. if you vomit after taking a dose, do not take another dose; take your next dose at the regular time. your doctor may temporarily pause treatment, reduce your dose, or permanently stop capmatinib depending on how well it works for you and any side effects. be sure to tell your healthcare provider how you are feeling during treatment. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking capmatinib, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to capmatinib, any other medications, or any ingredient in the tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. the following nonprescription or herbal products may interact with capmatinib: st. john’s wort. do not start these while taking capmatinib without discussing with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had lung disease or breathing problems not caused by lung cancer, pancreatitis (swelling of the pancreas), or liver disease. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, you should not become pregnant while taking capmatinib. you will need a pregnancy test before starting treatment and should use birth control during treatment and for at least 1 week after your final dose. if you are a male with a female partner who may become pregnant, use birth control during treatment and for at least 1 week after the last dose. capmatinib may harm your unborn baby; if you or your partner becomes pregnant during treatment, call your doctor immediately. if you are breastfeeding, do not breastfeed while taking capmatinib and for at least 1 week after your final dose. avoid unnecessary or prolonged sun exposure and wear a hat, protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? capmatinib may cause side effects. common side effects include: vomiting, nausea, diarrhea, constipation, muscle, bone, or back pain, loss of appetite, tiredness or weakness, dizziness, swelling in the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, and rash. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have: shortness of breath or trouble breathing, cough, fever, or other signs of infection; chest pain; pain in the right upper part of the stomach; swelling in your stomach area; unusual bruising or bleeding; dark urine; yellowing of the skin or eyes; nausea or vomiting; light-colored stools; loss of appetite; ongoing pain that begins in the stomach area and may spread to the back, with nausea, vomiting, or weight loss. capmatinib may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: capsaicin topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? topical capsaicin is used to relieve minor muscle and joint pain from arthritis, backaches, strains, bruises, cramps, and sprains. capsaicin, a compound found in chili peppers, reduces pain by decreasing the activity of pain-sensing nerve cells in the skin. how should this medicine be used? capsaicin comes as an ointment, cream, gel, oil, and topical solution in various strengths for application to the skin. use as needed per the product label or exactly as directed by your doctor. read and follow the package directions carefully; ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not use more, use it more often, or for longer than directed. apply a thin layer to cover the affected area and rub in gently. avoid applying to skin folds. do not apply to broken, cut, damaged, infected, or rash-covered skin. do not wrap or bandage the treated area. for external use only; do not swallow or get it in your eyes, nose, or mouth. wash hands with soap and water after use. if applying to the hands, wait 30 minutes before washing. do not touch your eyes, nose, or mouth until after washing your hands. protect the treated area from direct heat (for example, heating pads, electric blankets, hair dryers, heat lamps). do not apply immediately before or after showering, bathing, swimming, or vigorous exercise. stop use and call your doctor if your pain worsens, improves and then worsens, or lasts longer than 7 days. other uses for this medicine your doctor may prescribe this medicine for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to capsaicin, chili peppers, any medications, or any ingredients in the product; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor; if you become pregnant while using topical capsaicin, call your doctor. avoid unnecessary or prolonged sun exposure and use protective clothing and sunscreen, as topical capsaicin may increase sun sensitivity. be aware that a burning sensation at the application site is common and usually lessens after several days; stop use and call your doctor right away if severe burning occurs. avoid inhaling dried residue from the treated area; inhalation may cause coughing, sneezing, tearing, and throat or respiratory irritation. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is usually used as needed. if your doctor has told you to use it regularly, apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply a double dose. what side effects can this medication cause? topical capsaicin may cause a burning sensation, redness, itching, or irritation at the application site, as well as cough, sneezing, or throat irritation. serious side effects may include pain, swelling, or blistering at the application site and eye irritation or pain; call your doctor immediately if these occur. topical capsaicin may cause other side effects.

name: captopril
instructions: important warning: do not take captopril if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. if you become pregnant while taking captopril, call your doctor immediately. captopril may harm the fetus. why is this medication prescribed? captopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ace) inhibitor used alone or with other medicines to treat high blood pressure and heart failure. it also improves survival and lowers the risk of heart failure after a heart attack, particularly in people with left ventricular hypertrophy (thickening of the left side of the heart). captopril is also used to treat diabetic kidney disease (diabetic nephropathy) in people with type 1 diabetes, especially when eye disease (retinopathy) is present. it lowers substances that tighten blood vessels so blood flows more easily and the heart pumps more efficiently. treating high blood pressure helps prevent damage to the brain, heart, blood vessels, kidneys, and other organs, which can lead to heart disease, heart attack, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, and vision loss. in addition to taking medication, lifestyle changes such as a low-fat, low-salt diet, maintaining a healthy weight, exercising at least 30 minutes most days, not smoking, and limiting alcohol help control blood pressure. how should this medicine be used? captopril comes as a tablet taken by mouth, usually two or three times daily on an empty stomach, about 1 hour before meals. take it at the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you do not understand any part. do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. captopril controls high blood pressure and heart failure but does not cure them. continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop taking captopril without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine this medication may sometimes be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking captopril, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to captopril; other ace inhibitors such as benazepril, enalapril, fosinopril, lisinopril, moexipril, perindopril, quinapril, or trandolapril; any other medications; or any ingredients in captopril tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor if you are taking valsartan and sacubitril or if you have stopped taking it within the past 36 hours; you should not take captopril with this medicine. if you have diabetes and take aliskiren (alone or in combination products), you should not take captopril. some medicines should not be taken with captopril, and others may need dose changes or extra monitoring. review all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and herbal products you use now or plan to use with your doctor and pharmacist before starting captopril, and get their advice before starting, stopping, or changing any medicines while taking captopril. the following nonprescription products may interact with captopril: aspirin and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as ibuprofen and naproxen, and potassium supplements or salt substitutes containing potassium. be sure your doctor and pharmacist know you are taking these before you start captopril, and do not start them while taking captopril without medical guidance. tell your doctor if you have diabetes, or heart or kidney disease, and if you are breastfeeding. if you are having any surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking captopril. know that diarrhea, vomiting, not drinking enough fluids, and heavy sweating can cause low blood pressure, which may lead to lightheadedness or fainting. what special dietary instructions should i follow? talk to your doctor before using salt substitutes that contain potassium. if your doctor prescribes a low-salt or low-sodium diet, follow these instructions carefully. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember it. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? captopril may cause side effects. call your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: dizziness or lightheadedness, salty or metallic taste or decreased ability to taste, cough, fast heartbeat, or excessive tiredness. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following, call your doctor immediately: chest pain; swelling of the face, eyes, lips, tongue, arms, or legs; hives; hoarseness; difficulty breathing or swallowing; stomach pain; fainting; rash; itching; mouth sores; fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection.

name: carbamazepine
instructions: important warning: carbamazepine can cause rare but life-threatening allergic skin reactions called stevens-johnson syndrome (sjs) or toxic epidermal necrolysis (ten), which can severely damage the skin and internal organs. the risk is higher in some people of asian ancestry who carry a specific inherited risk factor; if you are of asian descent, your doctor will usually test for this gene before prescribing carbamazepine. even without the risk gene, there remains a small chance of sjs or ten. call your doctor right away if you develop a painful rash, hives, blisters or skin peeling, easy bruising, mouth sores, or fever, especially within the first few months of treatment. carbamazepine can also lower your blood cell counts; in rare cases this can be serious or life-threatening. if you have ever had bone marrow suppression or other blood disorders, particularly due to another medication, your doctor may advise against carbamazepine. contact your doctor immediately if you have sore throat, fever, chills, infections that come and go or do not resolve, shortness of breath, unusual fatigue, heavy menstrual bleeding, nosebleeds, bleeding gums, other unusual bleeding or bruising, or tiny red or purple skin spots. keep all appointments for doctor visits and lab tests; your doctor will check certain labs before and during treatment to monitor your response. you will receive a medication guide when you start carbamazepine and with each refill—read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. why is this medication prescribed? carbamazepine is used alone or with other medicines to control certain types of seizures in people with epilepsy and to treat trigeminal neuralgia (facial nerve pain). extended-release carbamazepine capsules (equetro brand only) are also used to treat episodes of mania (abnormally elevated or irritable mood) or mixed episodes in patients with bipolar i disorder. carbamazepine is an anticonvulsant that works by reducing abnormal electrical activity in the brain. how should this medicine be used? carbamazepine is taken by mouth as a tablet, chewable tablet, extended-release tablet, extended-release capsule, or liquid suspension. regular tablets, chewable tablets, and the suspension are usually taken two to four times daily with meals. the extended-release tablet (tegretol xr) is typically taken twice daily with meals. extended-release capsules (carbatrol, equetro) are usually taken twice daily, with or without food. take doses at the same times each day. follow your prescription label closely and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take carbamazepine exactly as directed; do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. swallow extended-release tablets whole—do not split, crush, or chew. you may open extended-release capsules and sprinkle the beads on a small amount of soft food (such as a teaspoon of applesauce); swallow without crushing or chewing the beads. shake the suspension well before each dose. your doctor will start with a low dose and increase it gradually. carbamazepine helps control your condition but does not cure it; full benefit may take several weeks or longer. continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop taking carbamazepine without talking to your doctor; if you have a seizure disorder, stopping suddenly can worsen seizures. your doctor will likely reduce the dose gradually. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking carbamazepine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic (rash, wheezing, hives, trouble swallowing or breathing, swelling of the face, eyes, eyelids, lips, or tongue) to carbamazepine; tricyclic antidepressants such as amitriptyline, amoxapine, clomipramine (anafranil), desipramine (norpramin), doxepin (silenor, zonalon), imipramine (tofranil), nortriptyline (pamelor), or protriptyline; oxcarbazepine (trileptal, oxtellar xr); other seizure medicines including phenobarbital, phenytoin (dilantin, phenytek), or primidone (mysoline); any other medicines; or any ingredients in carbamazepine products. some medicines should not be used with carbamazepine. review all medications you take or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist before starting carbamazepine, and get medical advice before starting, stopping, or changing any medication while taking carbamazepine. do not take carbamazepine if you are using or have used within the past 14 days: isocarboxazid (marplan), linezolid (zyvox), methylene blue, phenelzine (nardil), selegiline (emsam, zelapar), or tranylcypromine (parnate). tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and supplements you use. the following over-the-counter or herbal products may interact: acetaminophen (tylenol), cimetidine (tagamet hb), ibuprofen (advil, motrin), loratadine (claritin), omeprazole (prilosec otc, zegerid otc), and st. john’s wort. do not start any of these while taking carbamazepine unless your healthcare provider agrees. if you take other liquid medicines, do not take them at the same time as the carbamazepine suspension. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had glaucoma; depression, mood problems, or suicidal thoughts or actions; an abnormal electrocardiogram (ecg); a slow, fast, or irregular heartbeat or other heart disease; or kidney, thyroid, or liver disease. carbamazepine may reduce the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives (pills, patches, rings, injections, implants, intrauterine devices); use an additional nonhormonal birth control method while taking it and contact your doctor if you have unexpected vaginal bleeding or think you may be pregnant. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; carbamazepine may harm the fetus. if you become pregnant, call your doctor right away. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, tell the clinician you take carbamazepine. carbamazepine can cause drowsiness or dizziness; do not drive or use machinery until you know how it affects you. alcohol can increase these effects. anticonvulsants including carbamazepine have been linked to new or worsening depression or suicidal thoughts or actions in a small number of people (about 1 in 500) during studies, sometimes as early as the first week. you and your doctor will decide whether the benefits outweigh the risks of not treating your condition. you, your family, or your caregiver should call your doctor right away if you have panic attacks; agitation or restlessness; new or worsening irritability, anxiety, or depression; acting on dangerous impulses; trouble falling or staying asleep; aggressive, angry, or violent behavior; mania (unusually excited or irritable mood); thoughts or talk of self-harm; withdrawing from friends and family; preoccupation with death; giving away prized possessions; or any other unusual changes in mood or behavior. if you have hereditary fructose intolerance, note that the oral suspension contains sorbitol and discuss this with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor about eating grapefruit or drinking grapefruit juice while taking this medicine. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? carbamazepine may cause side effects. common effects include dizziness, drowsiness, unusual thinking, difficulty speaking, uncontrollable shaking, constipation, dry mouth, and problems with walking or coordination. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have any of the following or the symptoms listed in the important warning and special precautions sections: confusion; rash; fast, slow, or pounding heartbeat; shortness of breath, dizziness, or fainting; yellowing of the skin or eyes; dark urine; pain on the right side of your abdomen; loss of appetite; nausea or vomiting; vision changes; fatigue; swelling of the face, eyes, eyelids, lips, or tongue; trouble swallowing or breathing; swollen glands; headache; new or increased seizures; difficulty concentrating; weakness; unsteadiness; or a severe rash with one or more of the following: fever, muscle or joint aches, red or swollen eyes, blisters or peeling skin, mouth sores, or swelling of the face or neck. carbamazepine may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual while taking it.

name: carboplatin injection
instructions: important warning: carboplatin injection must be administered in a hospital or clinic under the supervision of a doctor experienced with chemotherapy. carboplatin can markedly lower the number of blood cells made by your bone marrow, increasing the risk of serious infection and bleeding. call your doctor right away if you develop fever, sore throat, chills, persistent cough or congestion, or other signs of infection; unusual bleeding or bruising; black, tarry stools; red blood in your stools; bloody vomit; or vomit that looks like coffee grounds. severe allergic reactions can occur, often within minutes of starting the infusion. tell your healthcare team immediately if you develop hives, rash, itching, skin redness, trouble breathing or swallowing, dizziness, feeling faint, or a rapid heartbeat. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor will order tests before, during, and after treatment to monitor your response and may pause or adjust treatment if certain side effects occur. why is this medication prescribed? carboplatin is used alone or with other medicines to treat ovarian cancer that has spread, not improved, or worsened after prior medications or radiation therapy. carboplatin belongs to a class of platinum-containing compounds and works by stopping or slowing the growth of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? carboplatin injection is a liquid solution given intravenously by a healthcare professional over at least 15 minutes. it is typically administered once every 4 weeks. other uses for this medicine carboplatin may also be used to treat cancers of the lung, bladder, breast, endometrium, head and neck, cervix, and testicles; wilms’ tumor; some brain tumors; neuroblastoma; and retinoblastoma. ask your doctor about the potential risks and benefits for your condition. this medication may be prescribed for other uses; consult your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving carboplatin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to carboplatin, cisplatin (platinol), any other medications, or any ingredients in the carboplatin injection. provide a complete list of all prescription and over-the-counter medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for interactions and side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney disease or bleeding problems. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, inform your doctor. do not become pregnant or breastfeed while receiving carboplatin. if you become pregnant during treatment, call your doctor immediately; carboplatin may harm the fetus. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions for carboplatin unless your doctor gives you special instructions. if you experience nausea, small frequent meals and adequate hydration may help. ask your healthcare team about individualized advice. what should i do if i forget a dose? carboplatin is given on a set schedule by healthcare professionals. if you miss an appointment, contact your doctor or clinic as soon as possible to reschedule. do not attempt to administer this medication yourself. what side effects can this medication cause? carboplatin may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, sores in the mouth or throat, pain/burning/tingling in the hands or feet, redness, itching, swelling, blisters, or sores at the infusion site, hair loss, pain, weakness, or changes in taste. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you experience pale skin; unusual tiredness or weakness; fainting; dizziness; sudden changes in vision, including color vision; decreased urination; swelling of the face, arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; shortness of breath during everyday activity or when lying flat; or ringing in the ears and difficulty hearing. carboplatin may increase the risk of developing other cancers; discuss this risk with your doctor. carboplatin may cause other side effects; contact your healthcare provider if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: carfilzomib injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? carfilzomib injection is used alone or with other medications to treat multiple myeloma (a cancer of the bone marrow) in people who have already received other treatments. it is a proteasome inhibitor that works by stopping or slowing the growth of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? carfilzomib comes as a powder that is mixed with liquid and given by intravenous (iv) infusion by a healthcare professional in a medical office or clinic, usually over 10 or 30 minutes. it may be given on 2 consecutive days each week for 3 weeks followed by a 12-day rest period, or once weekly for 3 weeks followed by a 13-day rest period. your treatment schedule and duration depend on how you respond and tolerate therapy. because severe or life-threatening infusion reactions can occur for up to 24 hours after a dose, you will receive medications before each dose to help prevent reactions. call your doctor immediately if you develop fever, chills, joint or muscle pain, flushing or swelling of the face, swelling or tightening of the throat, vomiting, weakness, shortness of breath, dizziness or fainting, or chest tightness or pain after treatment. tell your doctor how you are feeling throughout treatment; your dose may be paused or adjusted if you have side effects. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving carfilzomib, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to carfilzomib, any other medications, or any ingredients in the injection; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for interactions and side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had heart failure, a heart attack, irregular heartbeat, or other heart problems; high blood pressure; herpes infections (cold sores, shingles, or genital sores); seizures or other neurologic disorders; liver or kidney disease; or if you are on dialysis. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or plan to father a child, use effective birth control: if you are female, have a pregnancy test before starting and use birth control during treatment and for 6 months after the final dose; if you are male, you and your partner should use birth control during treatment and for 3 months after the final dose. call your doctor if pregnancy occurs; carfilzomib may harm the fetus. do not breastfeed during treatment and for 2 weeks after the final dose. carfilzomib may cause drowsiness, dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. what special dietary instructions should i follow? drink plenty of fluids before and every day during treatment, especially if you vomit or have diarrhea. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment or dose, contact your doctor right away to reschedule. do not try to make up a dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? carfilzomib injection may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: headache, diarrhea, constipation, muscle spasms, pain in the arms, legs, or back, trouble falling or staying asleep. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you experience any of the following or those listed under how should this medicine be used? or what special precautions should i follow?: cough; signs of dehydration (dry mouth, dark urine, decreased sweating, dry skin); swelling of the feet or legs; pain, tenderness, or redness in one leg; shortness of breath or difficulty breathing; chest pain; pain, burning, numbness, or tingling in the hands or feet; nausea; unusual tiredness or weakness; unusual bleeding or bruising; lack of energy; loss of appetite; pain in the upper right abdomen; yellowing of the skin or eyes; flu-like symptoms; bloody or black, tarry stools; a pinpoint reddish-purple rash (often on the lower legs); blood in the urine; decreased urination; seizures; vision changes or loss of vision; confusion, memory loss, dizziness, loss of balance, trouble speaking or walking, changes in vision, or weakness on one side of the body. carfilzomib injection may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems during treatment.

name: cariprazine
instructions: important warning: important warning for older adults with dementia: studies show that older adults with dementia who take antipsychotic medicines such as cariprazine have a higher risk of death during treatment. they may also have an increased risk of stroke or mini-stroke. cariprazine is not approved by the u.s. food and drug administration (fda) for treating behavior problems in older adults with dementia. if you or someone you care for has dementia and is being treated with cariprazine, talk to the prescribing doctor. important warning for people with episodes of depression: in clinical studies, a small number of children, teenagers, and young adults up to 24 years of age who took antidepressants (including cariprazine when used for depression) developed suicidal thoughts or behaviors. children, teenagers, and young adults taking antidepressants for depression or other mental illnesses may have a higher risk of becoming suicidal than those not taking these medicines. however, untreated depression also has risks. discuss these risks and benefits with your child’s doctor. cariprazine has not been studied in children younger than 18 years of age. your mental health may change in unexpected ways when you take cariprazine or other antidepressants, even if you are over 24. you may become suicidal, especially at the start of treatment or when your dose is increased or decreased. you, your family, or your caregiver should call your doctor right away if you have any of these symptoms: new or worsening depression; thoughts about harming or killing yourself, or planning or trying to do so; extreme worry; agitation; panic attacks; trouble falling or staying asleep; irritability; acting without thinking; aggressive behavior; severe restlessness; or frenzied, abnormal excitement. make sure your family or caregiver knows which symptoms may be serious so they can call the doctor if you cannot seek help yourself. your healthcare provider will want to see you often while you are taking cariprazine, especially early in treatment, so keep all appointments. you will receive a medication guide when you start cariprazine; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. no matter your age, talk with your doctor about the risks and benefits of treating your condition with an antidepressant or other treatments, as well as the risks of not treating it. having depression or another mental illness increases the risk of becoming suicidal, especially if you or a family member has or has ever had bipolar disorder, mania, or suicidal thoughts or attempts. you and your doctor will decide which treatment is right for you. discuss the risks of taking cariprazine with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? cariprazine is used to treat schizophrenia (a mental illness that causes disturbed or unusual thinking, loss of interest in life, and strong or inappropriate emotions). it is also used to treat depressive episodes in people with bipolar i disorder, and as short-term treatment for manic or mixed episodes (symptoms of mania and depression together) in bipolar i disorder. in adults with major depressive disorder (mdd), cariprazine is used along with other medications to treat depressive symptoms. cariprazine is an atypical antipsychotic that works by changing the activity of certain natural substances in the brain. how should this medicine be used? cariprazine comes as a capsule taken by mouth once daily, with or without food, at the same time each day. follow the directions on your prescription label exactly; ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. do not take more or less than prescribed, or take it more often. your doctor will likely start you on a low dose and increase it gradually based on your response and any side effects. cariprazine helps control symptoms but does not cure your condition; it may take several weeks or longer to feel the full benefit. continue to take it even if you feel well, and do not stop without talking to your doctor. tell your doctor if you do not feel you are improving during treatment. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cariprazine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cariprazine or any ingredients in the capsules; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and herbal or nutritional supplements you take or plan to take. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. st. john’s wort and other products may interact with cariprazine. do not start or stop any medication, including st. john’s wort, while taking cariprazine unless your healthcare provider approves. tell your doctor if you or anyone in your family has or has ever had impaired fasting glucose (pre-diabetes) or diabetes; if you have a low white blood cell count now or have ever developed a low white blood cell count from a medicine; or if you have or have ever had seizures; a stroke or mini-stroke; a heart attack; heart failure; an irregular heartbeat; low or high blood pressure; high cholesterol or other blood lipids; balance problems; trouble swallowing; or heart, liver, or kidney disease. also tell your doctor if you have severe vomiting, diarrhea, or signs of dehydration now, or if these occur during treatment. tell your doctor if you are pregnant (especially in the last months), plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking cariprazine, call your doctor. taking cariprazine in the last months of pregnancy may cause problems in newborns after delivery. cariprazine may make you drowsy and may impair thinking, decision-making, and reaction time; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. cariprazine can raise blood sugar (hyperglycemia), even if you do not already have diabetes, and people with schizophrenia are at higher risk of developing diabetes. call your doctor right away if you have extreme thirst, frequent urination, extreme hunger, blurred vision, or weakness. high blood sugar can lead to ketoacidosis, a serious condition that can be life-threatening if not treated early; symptoms include dry mouth, nausea and vomiting, shortness of breath, fruity-smelling breath, and decreased alertness. cariprazine may cause dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting when you get up too quickly from lying down (especially when starting treatment). to reduce this risk, rise slowly and sit with your feet on the floor before standing. cariprazine may make it harder for your body to cool itself in hot conditions. if you plan vigorous exercise or expect heat exposure, drink plenty of water and call your doctor if you feel very hot, sweat heavily or stop sweating in the heat, or develop dry mouth, excessive thirst, or decreased urination. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? cariprazine may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: extreme tiredness; restlessness; anxiety; agitation; trouble falling or staying asleep; dizziness or feeling unsteady; problems with balance; increased appetite; weight gain; constipation; indigestion; nausea; increased saliva or drooling; blurred vision. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or get emergency help if you have any of the following (or the symptoms listed in the important warning or special precautions sections): seizures; unusual or uncontrolled movements of the face or body; slow movements or a shuffling walk; loss of ability to move; falls; fever, sweating, confusion, rapid breathing, fast or irregular heartbeat, and severe muscle stiffness (possible neuroleptic malignant syndrome); muscle weakness or aching; a blank or mask-like facial expression; difficulty swallowing or breathing; tightness in the throat; tongue sticking out; rash, itching, or hives; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes; dark or cola-colored urine; swelling of the legs or feet; or decreased urination. cariprazine may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: carisoprodol
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? carisoprodol is used along with rest, physical therapy, and other measures to relax muscles and relieve pain and discomfort from strains, sprains, and other muscle injuries. it is a skeletal muscle relaxant that works on the brain and nervous system to help muscles relax. how should this medicine be used? carisoprodol is an oral tablet usually taken three times daily and at bedtime, with or without food. do not use it for longer than 3 weeks unless your doctor instructs you to. follow your prescription label closely. take carisoprodol exactly as directed; do not take more or less, or take it more often or for longer than prescribed. carisoprodol can be habit-forming; do not increase your dose or duration without your doctor’s approval. other uses for this medicine this medicine may sometimes be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more details. what special precautions should i follow?
