before taking carisoprodol, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to carisoprodol, meprobamate, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and supplements you take or plan to take. some nonprescription or herbal products may interact with carisoprodol, including st. john’s wort, aspirin, and omeprazole (prilosec, zegerid). inform your healthcare providers that you take these before starting carisoprodol, and do not start them while taking carisoprodol without discussing it with your provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had porphyria; your doctor will likely advise you not to take carisoprodol. also inform your doctor if you drink or have drunk large amounts of alcohol, use or have used street drugs, or have misused prescription medicines, and if you have or have ever had seizures or kidney or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking carisoprodol, call your doctor. discuss the risks and benefits if you are 65 years or older; older adults generally should not take carisoprodol because safer or more effective alternatives are available. this medication may cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. ask your doctor about alcohol use while taking carisoprodol; alcohol can worsen side effects. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? carisoprodol may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: drowsiness, dizziness, headache, fast heart rate, upset stomach, vomiting. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you experience seizures or difficulty breathing.

name: carmustine
instructions: important warning: carmustine can cause a severe decrease in bone marrow blood cells, which raises the risk of serious infection and bleeding. call your doctor right away if you have fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection; unusual bleeding or bruising; black, tarry stools; red blood in the stools; bloody vomit; or vomit that looks like coffee grounds. carmustine can also cause lung damage that may occur months to years after treatment; this damage can be fatal, especially in people treated as children. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had lung disease. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory for tests to monitor your response and safety while receiving carmustine. why is this medication prescribed? carmustine injection is used to treat certain types of brain tumors. it is also used with prednisone to treat multiple myeloma, and with other medicines to treat hodgkin lymphoma and non-hodgkin lymphoma that has not improved or has worsened after other treatments. carmustine is an alkylating agent that works by slowing or stopping the growth of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? carmustine injection is supplied as a powder that is mixed with fluid and given by a doctor or nurse as an intravenous infusion over at least 2 hours in a medical office, hospital, or clinic. it is usually given once every 6 weeks, or as smaller doses once daily for 2 consecutive days every 6 weeks. your doctor may delay treatment or adjust your dose based on side effects or lab results. tell your healthcare team how you are feeling during treatment. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving carmustine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to carmustine or any ingredient in the product. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and herbal or nutritional supplements you take or plan to take. your doctor may change doses or monitor you closely for interactions. the nonprescription medicine cimetidine (tagamet) may interact with carmustine; tell your doctor and pharmacist if you use it. do not start, stop, or change the dose of any medicine while receiving carmustine without talking with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney or liver disease or lung disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. you should not become pregnant while receiving carmustine; if pregnancy occurs, call your doctor. carmustine may harm the fetus. do not breastfeed while receiving this medicine. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your normal diet. if you have nausea, small frequent meals and adequate fluid intake may help. limit or avoid alcohol to reduce the risk of liver problems. what should i do if i forget a dose? carmustine is given by a healthcare professional on a scheduled day. if you miss an appointment, call your doctor or clinic as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to make up a missed dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? carmustine may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: nausea, vomiting, headache, loss of balance or coordination, pale skin, fainting, dizziness, fast or irregular heartbeat, chest pain, darkening of the skin. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have any of the following or any symptoms listed in the important warning section: swelling, pain, redness, or burning at the injection site; upset stomach; extreme tiredness or weakness; lack of energy; loss of appetite; pain in the upper right abdomen; yellowing of the skin or eyes; decreased urination; swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs. carmustine may increase the risk of developing other cancers. talk with your doctor about the risks and benefits of treatment.

name: carvedilol
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? carvedilol is used alone or with other medicines to treat heart failure and high blood pressure, and to improve survival after a heart attack. it is a beta-blocker that relaxes blood vessels and slows the heart rate to improve blood flow and lower blood pressure. untreated high blood pressure can damage the brain, heart, blood vessels, kidneys, and other organs, leading to heart disease, heart attack, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, and vision loss. in addition to taking medication, lifestyle changes such as eating a low-fat, low-salt diet, maintaining a healthy weight, exercising at least 30 minutes most days, not smoking, and using alcohol in moderation help control blood pressure. this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? carvedilol is available as an immediate-release tablet and as an extended-release (long-acting) capsule taken by mouth. the tablet is usually taken twice daily with food. the extended-release capsule is usually taken once daily in the morning with food. take doses at the same times each day and follow your prescription label exactly. do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. swallow extended-release capsules whole; do not crush or chew them, and do not divide the beads inside a capsule into more than one dose. if you cannot swallow the capsule, you may open it and sprinkle all of the beads on a spoonful of cool or room-temperature applesauce and swallow the mixture right away without chewing. your doctor will likely start you on a low dose and increase it gradually as your body adjusts. carvedilol helps control your condition but does not cure it; continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop carvedilol suddenly. stopping abruptly may cause serious heart problems such as severe chest pain, heart attack, or an irregular heartbeat. your doctor will usually reduce the dose gradually over 1 to 2 weeks, monitor you closely, and may tell you to avoid physical activity during this time. what special precautions should i follow? before taking carvedilol, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to carvedilol or any ingredients in the tablets or extended-release capsules. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, herbal products, and supplements you use or plan to use. st. john’s wort can interact with carvedilol; do not start it without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had asthma or other breathing problems, a slow or irregular heartbeat, heart failure, or liver disease, as your doctor may advise you not to use carvedilol. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had poor circulation in your feet or legs, diabetes or other causes of low blood sugar, hyperthyroidism, low blood pressure, prinzmetal’s angina, pheochromocytoma, or heart, kidney, or liver disease, and if you have ever had a serious allergic reaction to a food or other substance. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while using carvedilol. if you are having surgery, including dental or eye surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you take carvedilol. this medicine may cause tiredness, dizziness, or lightheadedness, especially when you start it or after a dose increase. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you, and be especially careful during the first hour after a dose. carvedilol can cause dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting when you stand up too quickly; to reduce this, rise slowly and sit with your feet on the floor for a few minutes before standing. carvedilol may increase the risk of low blood sugar and can mask the warning signs of hypoglycemia. tell your doctor if you cannot eat or drink normally or are vomiting while taking carvedilol. know the symptoms of low blood sugar and what to do if they occur. if you have allergies, reactions may be more severe while taking carvedilol, and usual doses of injectable epinephrine may be less effective. if you wear contact lenses, your eyes may feel dry during treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? carvedilol may cause side effects. common effects include tiredness, weakness, lightheadedness, dizziness, headache, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, vision changes, joint pain, trouble falling asleep or staying asleep, stuffy or runny nose, cough, dry eyes, and numbness, burning, or tingling in the arms or legs. serious side effects can include fainting, shortness of breath, weight gain, swelling of the arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, chest pain, slow or irregular heartbeat, rash, hives, itching, swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat, and trouble breathing or swallowing. carvedilol may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: caspofungin injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? caspofungin injection is used in adults and in children 3 months of age and older to treat yeast infections in the blood, stomach, lungs, and the esophagus (the tube that connects the throat to the stomach), as well as certain fungal infections that did not respond to other medicines. it is also used for serious fungal infections in people with weakened immune systems. caspofungin belongs to a class of antifungal medicines called echinocandins and works by slowing the growth of the fungi causing the infection. how should this medicine be used? caspofungin injection is supplied as a powder that is mixed with liquid and given into a vein (intravenously) over about 1 hour once daily. the length of treatment depends on your overall health, the type of infection, and how you respond to therapy. you may receive it in the hospital or at home; if used at home, your healthcare provider will teach you exactly how to prepare and infuse it. follow all instructions and ask questions if anything is unclear. your doctor may start with a standard dose and adjust it based on your response and any side effects. you should begin to feel better within the first few days. if your symptoms do not improve or get worse, contact your doctor. if you still have symptoms after finishing caspofungin, let your doctor know. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving caspofungin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to caspofungin, to any other medicines, or to any ingredients in the product; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. the herbal product st. john’s wort may interact with caspofungin; do not start or stop st. john’s wort or any new medication while receiving caspofungin without talking to your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while receiving caspofungin, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you different instructions, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, contact your doctor or infusion service as soon as possible to reschedule. do not give yourself two doses at the same time to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? caspofungin injection may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; pain, redness, or swelling of a vein; diarrhea; nausea; vomiting; stomach pain; back pain; headache. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have: swelling of the face, throat, tongue, or lips; hoarseness; trouble swallowing or breathing; shortness of breath or wheezing; a sensation of warmth; fever, chills, cough, or other signs of infection; blisters or peeling skin; hives, rash, or itching; fast heartbeat; extreme tiredness; unusual bleeding or bruising; lack of energy; loss of appetite; pain in the upper right side of the abdomen; yellowing of the skin or eyes; or flu-like symptoms. caspofungin injection may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: cefaclor
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cefaclor is used to treat certain bacterial infections, including pneumonia and other lower respiratory tract infections, and infections of the skin, ears, throat, tonsils, and urinary tract. it is a cephalosporin antibiotic that stops the growth of bacteria. it will not work for colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when they are not needed increases the risk of later infections that resist antibiotic treatment. how should this medicine be used? cefaclor is taken by mouth as capsules, an oral suspension, or an extended-release (long-acting) tablet. capsules and suspension are usually taken every 8 or 12 hours, with or without food. the extended-release tablet is taken within 1 hour of a meal every 12 hours (twice daily) for 7 to 10 days. take cefaclor at the same times each day. follow the directions on your prescription label exactly; do not take more or less or more often than prescribed. shake the suspension well before each dose. swallow extended-release tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush. you should begin to feel better in the first few days. if your symptoms do not improve or get worse, call your doctor. take cefaclor until you finish the prescription, even if you feel better. stopping too soon or skipping doses may leave the infection untreated and promote antibiotic resistance. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cefaclor, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cefaclor; other cephalosporins such as cefadroxil, cefazolin (ancef, kefzol), cefdinir, cefditoren (spectracef), cefepime (maxipime), cefixime (suprax), cefotaxime (claforan), cefotetan, cefoxitin (mefoxin), cefpodoxime, cefprozil (cefzil), ceftaroline (teflaro), ceftazidime (fortaz, tazicef, in avycaz), ceftibuten (cedax), ceftriaxone (rocephin), cefuroxime (ceftin, kefurox, zinacef), or cephalexin (keflex); to penicillin antibiotics; or to any other medications. also tell your doctor if you are allergic to any ingredients in cefaclor capsules, extended-release tablets, or suspension. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. know that cefaclor may decrease the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives (birth control pills, patches, rings, injections). use another method of contraception to prevent pregnancy while taking cefaclor and ask your doctor about options. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any allergies, gastrointestinal disease (especially colitis), or kidney disease. if you take antacids that contain magnesium or aluminum, take them 1 hour before or 1 hour after cefaclor extended-release tablets. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking cefaclor, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cefaclor may cause side effects. common effects include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, headache, and genital itching. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have rash; itching, prickling, burning, or stinging of the skin; hives; difficulty breathing or swallowing; wheezing; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, arms, or legs; lack of energy or feeling faint; joint pain; watery or bloody stools, stomach cramps, or fever during treatment or for up to two or more months after stopping; or a return of fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection. cefaclor may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: cefadroxil
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cefadroxil is used to treat certain bacterial infections, including infections of the skin, throat, tonsils, and urinary tract. it belongs to a class of medications called cephalosporin antibiotics and works by killing bacteria. antibiotics like cefadroxil do not treat colds, flu, or other viral illnesses. using antibiotics when they are not needed increases the risk of developing infections that resist antibiotic treatment. how should this medicine be used? cefadroxil is available as capsules, tablets, and an oral suspension. it is typically taken by mouth every 12 or 24 hours, with or without food, as directed. take it at the same times each day. follow your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. take cefadroxil exactly as prescribed; do not take more, less, or more often than directed. taking it with food may help reduce nausea and stomach upset. shake the suspension well before each dose to mix it evenly. you should start to feel better within the first few days of treatment. if your symptoms do not improve or worsen, contact your doctor. continue taking cefadroxil for the full course prescribed, even if you feel better. stopping too soon or skipping doses may result in incomplete treatment and antibiotic resistance. other uses for this medicine cefadroxil may be used in certain penicillin-allergic patients with specific heart conditions who are undergoing dental or upper respiratory tract procedures (nose, mouth, throat, or voice box) to help prevent heart valve infection. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cefadroxil, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cefadroxil; any other cephalosporin antibiotics such as cefaclor, cefazolin (ancef, kefzol), cefdinir, cefditoren (spectracef), cefepime (maxipime), cefixime (suprax), cefotaxime (claforan), cefotetan, cefoxitin (mefoxin), cefpodoxime, cefprozil, ceftaroline (teflaro), ceftazidime (fortaz, tazicef, in avycaz), ceftibuten (cedax), ceftriaxone (rocephin), or cefuroxime (zinacef); penicillin antibiotics; any other medications; or any ingredients in cefadroxil capsules, tablets, or suspension. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had gastrointestinal disease (especially colitis) or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking cefadroxil, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? cefadroxil may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: diarrhea, vomiting, genital itching. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or seek emergency care if you experience: watery or bloody stools, stomach cramps, or fever during treatment or for up to two or more months after stopping; rash, itching, hives; trouble breathing or swallowing; wheezing; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes; return of sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection; yellowing of the skin or eyes; pain in the upper right abdomen; dark urine; or pale/clay-colored stools.

name: cefazolin injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cefazolin injection is used to treat certain bacterial infections and may be given around the time of surgery to help prevent infection. it is a cephalosporin antibiotic that works by killing bacteria. it does not treat colds, flu, or other viral infections; using antibiotics when they are not needed can make them less effective later. how should this medicine be used? cefazolin injection comes as a powder to be mixed with liquid or as a premixed solution and is given intravenously over about 30 minutes or as an intramuscular injection. it is typically administered every 6, 8, or 12 hours. the length of treatment depends on your infection and how you respond. you may receive it in the hospital or at home; if at home, your healthcare provider will teach you how to use it. you should start to feel better within a few days; if your symptoms do not improve or get worse, contact your doctor. use cefazolin for the full prescribed course even if you feel better; stopping early or skipping doses may lead to incomplete treatment and antibiotic resistance. other uses for this medicine cefazolin injection may be used in certain penicillin-allergic patients with heart conditions who are undergoing dental or upper respiratory tract procedures to help prevent heart valve infection, and in some penicillin-allergic women in labor to help prevent newborn infection. ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using cefazolin injection, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this drug, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your reactions. some medications should not be taken with cefazolin; review all medicines you use or plan to use with your doctor and pharmacist, and do not start, stop, or change any medication while receiving cefazolin without their advice. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had gastrointestinal disease (especially colitis), or kidney or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using cefazolin, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not use two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? cefazolin injection may cause side effects. common effects include white patches in the mouth, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and pain, redness, swelling, or bleeding at the injection site. some side effects can be serious. stop cefazolin and call your doctor immediately or get emergency help if you have watery or bloody stools, stomach cramps, or fever during treatment or for up to two or more months after stopping; rash, hives, itching, trouble breathing or swallowing, or blistering, peeling, or shedding skin; swelling in the legs or feet; decreased urination; dark urine, yellowing of the skin or eyes, or pain in the upper right part of the abdomen; fainting; a return of fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection; or seizures. cefazolin injection may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using it.

name: cefdinir
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cefdinir is used to treat certain bacterial infections, including bronchitis (infection of the airway tubes leading to the lungs), pneumonia, and infections of the skin, ears, sinuses, throat, and tonsils. it is a cephalosporin antibiotic that works by killing bacteria. it does not treat colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when they are not needed increases the risk of developing infections that resist antibiotic treatment. how should this medicine be used? cefdinir is taken by mouth as capsules or an oral suspension. it is usually taken with or without food every 12 or 24 hours for 5 to 10 days, depending on the condition being treated. take it at the same times each day. follow your prescription label closely and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take exactly as directed; do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. shake the suspension well before each dose. you should start to feel better within the first few days. if your symptoms do not improve or worsen, call your doctor. continue the full course even if you feel better; stopping early or skipping doses may leave the infection untreated and promote antibiotic resistance. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cefdinir, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cefdinir; other cephalosporins such as cefaclor; cefadroxil; cefazolin (ancef, kefzol); cefditoren (spectracef); cefepime (maxipime); cefixime (suprax); cefotaxime (claforan); cefotetan; cefoxitin (mefoxin); cefpodoxime; cefprozil; ceftaroline (teflaro); ceftazidime (fortaz, tazicef; in avycaz); ceftibuten (cedax); ceftriaxone (rocephin); cefuroxime (zinacef); or cephalexin (keflex); to penicillin antibiotics; or to any other medications. also tell your doctor if you are allergic to any ingredients in the capsules or suspension; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. inform your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. if you take antacids containing magnesium or aluminum, iron supplements, or multivitamins with iron, take them 2 hours before or 2 hours after cefdinir. cefdinir may decrease the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives (birth control pills, patches, rings, and injections); use an additional method of contraception while taking cefdinir and talk to your doctor about options. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had gastrointestinal disease (especially colitis) or kidney disease; if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you have diabetes, note that the suspension contains sucrose (sugar). what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor about eating iron-fortified foods (such as fortified breakfast cereals) while taking cefdinir. infants may continue to receive iron-fortified formula during treatment. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cefdinir may cause side effects. common effects include vomiting, nausea, stomach pain, diarrhea, headache, vaginal itching, and reddish-colored stools. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or seek emergency care if you experience rash; hives; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes; difficulty breathing or swallowing; watery or bloody stools, stomach cramps, or fever during treatment or for up to two or more months after stopping; or a return of fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection.

name: cefditoren
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cefditoren is used to treat certain bacterial infections, including bronchitis (infection of the airway tubes leading to the lungs), pneumonia, and infections of the skin, throat, and tonsils. it belongs to a class of medicines called cephalosporin antibiotics and works by killing bacteria. antibiotics like cefditoren do not treat colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when they are not needed increases the risk of future infections that resist antibiotic treatment. how should this medicine be used? cefditoren comes as an oral tablet. take it every 12 hours with the morning and evening meals for 10 to 14 days, depending on your condition. take cefditoren at the same times each day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take it exactly as prescribed; do not take more, less, or more often than directed. you should start to feel better within the first few days. if your symptoms do not improve or worsen, call your doctor. take cefditoren for the full prescribed course even if you feel better. stopping early or skipping doses may result in incomplete treatment and promote antibiotic resistance. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cefditoren, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cefditoren; any cephalosporin antibiotic such as cefaclor, cefadroxil, cefazolin (ancef, kefzol), cefdinir, cefepime (maxipime), cefixime (suprax), cefotaxime (claforan), cefotetan, cefoxitin (mefoxin), cefpodoxime, cefprozil, ceftaroline (teflaro), ceftazidime (fortaz, tazicef, in avycaz), ceftibuten (cedax), ceftriaxone (rocephin), cefuroxime (zinacef), or cephalexin (keflex); penicillin antibiotics; milk protein; or any ingredient in cefditoren tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. the following nonprescription products may interact with cefditoren: antacids (maalox, mylanta, tums, others); medicines that reduce stomach acid such as cimetidine (tagamet), famotidine (pepcid), nizatidine (axid), ranitidine (zantac); and proton pump inhibitors such as esomeprazole (nexium), lansoprazole (prevacid), omeprazole (prilosec), and rabeprazole (aciphex). be sure to tell your doctor and pharmacist if you use these medicines before starting cefditoren, and do not start them while taking cefditoren without discussing with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have carnitine deficiency (a rare condition in which the body does not have enough of a substance needed for energy production); your doctor will likely tell you not to take cefditoren. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney or liver disease, and if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking cefditoren, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cefditoren may cause side effects. common side effects include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, heartburn, headache, vaginal swelling, redness, irritation, burning or itching, and white vaginal discharge. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help: watery or bloody stools, stomach cramps, or fever during treatment or for up to two or more months after stopping treatment; hives, rash, itching, trouble breathing or swallowing, or throat tightness; or a return of fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection. cefditoren may cause other side effects.

name: cefepime injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cefepime injection is used to treat certain bacterial infections, including pneumonia and infections of the skin, urinary tract, and kidneys. it is also used with metronidazole (flagyl) to treat infections within the abdominal area. in patients with fever who are at high risk for infection because of a low white blood cell count, cefepime may be used to prevent or treat infection. cefepime is a cephalosporin antibiotic that kills bacteria. it does not work for colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when not needed can increase the risk of future infections that resist antibiotic treatment. how should this medicine be used? cefepime injection is supplied as a powder to be mixed with liquid or as a premixed solution. it is given by intravenous infusion over about 30 minutes, or by intramuscular injection. it is usually administered every 8 or 12 hours for 7 to 10 days, as directed by your healthcare provider. you may receive cefepime in the hospital, or you may use it at home after proper instruction. make sure you understand how to prepare and administer it and ask your healthcare provider any questions you have. you should start to feel better within the first few days. if your symptoms do not improve or worsen, call your doctor. use cefepime for the full prescribed course even if you feel better. stopping early or skipping doses can result in incomplete treatment and antibiotic resistance. other uses for this medicine cefepime injection may also be used to treat endocarditis, meningitis, and bloodstream infections. talk with your doctor about the risks and benefits for your condition. it may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving cefepime, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cefepime; carbapenem antibiotics; penicillin antibiotics; or other cephalosporins such as cefaclor, cefadroxil, cefazolin (ancef, kefzol), cefdinir, cefditoren (spectracef), cefixime (suprax), cefotaxime (claforan), cefotetan, cefoxitin (mefoxin), cefpodoxime, cefprozil, ceftaroline (teflaro), ceftazidime (fortaz, tazicef, in avycaz), ceftibuten (cedax), ceftriaxone (rocephin), or cefuroxime (zinacef), or to any ingredients in the product. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. cefepime may reduce the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives such as birth control pills, patches, rings, and injections; use an additional nonhormonal method to prevent pregnancy while using cefepime and discuss options with your doctor. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had gastrointestinal disease, especially colitis, or kidney or liver disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, inform your doctor. if you become pregnant while using cefepime injection, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? continue your normal diet unless your doctor gives you other instructions. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? cefepime injection may cause side effects. common effects include headache, diarrhea, and pain, redness, swelling, or bleeding at the injection site. some side effects can be serious. stop using cefepime injection and call your doctor immediately or seek emergency care if you experience watery or bloody stools, stomach cramps, or fever during treatment or for up to two months or longer after stopping treatment; rash; nausea; vomiting; itching; difficulty swallowing or breathing; swelling of the throat or tongue; seizures; confusion; hallucinations; coma; or a return of fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection. cefepime injection may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice any unusual problems while using it.

name: cefiderocol injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cefiderocol injection is used to treat certain complicated urinary tract infections in adults who have limited or no alternative treatment options. it is also used to treat pneumonia that develops in the hospital or while on a ventilator in adults. cefiderocol is a cephalosporin antibiotic that works by killing bacteria. it does not treat colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when they are not needed increases the risk of antibiotic-resistant infections. how should this medicine be used? cefiderocol injection comes as a powder that is mixed with liquid and infused into a vein. it is usually given over 3 hours every 8 hours for 7 to 14 days. your treatment length depends on your overall health, the type of infection, and how well you respond. you may receive it in a hospital or at home. if you will receive it at home, your healthcare provider will show you exactly how to prepare and infuse the medication; ask questions if anything is unclear. you should begin to feel better in the first few days. if your symptoms do not improve or get worse, call your doctor. if you still have symptoms after you finish treatment, call your doctor. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving cefiderocol injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cefiderocol; carbapenem antibiotics such as imipenem and cilastatin (primaxin) or meropenem (merrem); other cephalosporins such as cefaclor, cefadroxil, cefdinir, cefepime (maxipime), cefixime (suprax), cefotaxime, cefotetan, cefoxitin (mefoxin), cefpodoxime, cefprozil, ceftaroline (teflaro), ceftazidime (fortaz, tazicef, in avycaz), ceftriaxone, cefuroxime (zinacef), or cephalexin (keflex); penicillin antibiotics; or any other medications. ask your pharmacist for a list of the ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had epilepsy or seizures or kidney disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor; if you become pregnant while receiving cefiderocol, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you are receiving cefiderocol at home and miss a dose, infuse it as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not infuse two doses at once. contact your healthcare provider or home infusion service for specific instructions. if you are receiving doses in a clinic or hospital, call to reschedule as soon as possible. what side effects can this medication cause? cefiderocol injection may cause side effects. common side effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, swelling, pain, or redness at the infusion site, genital itching, and white patches in the mouth. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or get emergency help if you have seizures; rash, itching, hives; trouble breathing or swallowing; wheezing; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes; or severe diarrhea or watery or bloody stools with or without fever and stomach cramps, which may occur during treatment or up to 2 months or more after treatment. cefiderocol injection may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: cefixime
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cefixime is used to treat certain bacterial infections such as bronchitis (infection of the airways leading to the lungs), gonorrhea (a sexually transmitted infection), and infections of the ears, throat, tonsils, and urinary tract. it belongs to a class of medicines called cephalosporin antibiotics and works by killing bacteria. it does not treat colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when they are not needed increases the risk of developing infections that resist antibiotic treatment. how should this medicine be used? cefixime comes as a tablet, chewable tablet, capsule, and oral suspension. it is usually taken every 12 or 24 hours, with or without food. for gonorrhea, it may be given as a single dose. take cefixime at the same times each day and follow your prescription label exactly. do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. shake the suspension well before each dose. chew chewable tablets completely before swallowing; if you have difficulty chewing, you may crush them before swallowing. tablets with a score line can be split if your doctor tells you to take half a tablet; take the half as directed and save the other half for your next dose. different cefixime products are absorbed differently and are not interchangeable; if you switch products, your doctor may need to adjust your dose. you should begin to feel better within the first few days. if your symptoms do not improve or worsen, call your doctor. keep taking cefixime for the full prescribed course even if you feel better. stopping early or skipping doses may result in incomplete treatment and promote antibiotic resistance. other uses for this medicine cefixime is sometimes used for sinus infections in people allergic to penicillin, pneumonia, shigella or salmonella infections (which can cause severe diarrhea), and typhoid fever. discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. it may also be prescribed for other conditions; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cefixime, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cefixime; other cephalosporins such as cefaclor (ceclor), cefadroxil, cefazolin (ancef, kefzol), cefdinir, cefditoren (spectracef), cefepime (maxipime), cefotaxime (claforan), cefotetan, cefoxitin (mefoxin), cefpodoxime, cefprozil, ceftaroline (teflaro), ceftazidime (fortaz, tazicef; in avycaz), ceftibuten (cedax), ceftriaxone (rocephin), cefuroxime (zinacef), or cephalexin (keflex); to penicillin antibiotics; or to any other medications. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take while using cefixime; dose adjustments or monitoring may be needed. cefixime may reduce the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives (birth control pills, patches, rings, and injections); use an additional method of contraception to prevent pregnancy while taking cefixime and ask your doctor about options. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had gastrointestinal disease (especially colitis), or kidney or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while taking cefixime, call your doctor. if you have phenylketonuria (pku), know that the chewable tablets contain aspartame, which forms phenylalanine. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? cefixime may cause side effects. common side effects include diarrhea, stomach pain, gas, heartburn, nausea, and vomiting. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or seek emergency care if you have watery or bloody stools, stomach cramps, or fever during treatment or for two months or more after stopping treatment; rash, itching, or hives; difficulty breathing or swallowing; wheezing; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes; or a return of sore throat, fever, chills, or other signs of infection.

name: cefotaxime injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cefotaxime injection is used to treat certain bacterial infections, including pneumonia and other lower respiratory tract infections; gonorrhea (a sexually transmitted disease); meningitis and other infections of the brain and spinal cord; and infections of the abdomen, female reproductive organs, skin, blood, bones, joints, and urinary tract. it may also be given before surgery and during or after a cesarean section to help prevent infection. cefotaxime is a cephalosporin antibiotic that kills bacteria. it will not treat colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when they are not needed increases the risk of future infections that resist antibiotic treatment. how should this medicine be used? cefotaxime injection comes as a powder that is mixed with liquid for intravenous (iv) or intramuscular (im) injection. it is also available as a premixed iv product. the dosing schedule and length of treatment depend on your infection and how you respond. you may receive doses in the hospital, or you may be taught to administer them at home. if you will use it at home, your healthcare provider will show you exactly how to prepare and inject the medication; make sure you understand and ask questions if anything is unclear. you should start to feel better within the first few days. if your symptoms do not improve or worsen, call your doctor. use cefotaxime for the full prescribed course, even if you feel better. stopping early or skipping doses may result in incomplete treatment and antibiotic resistance. other uses for this medicine cefotaxime injection is sometimes used to treat typhoid fever, salmonella and other infectious diarrheas, food poisoning, lyme disease after a tick bite, and certain infections from dog bites. discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving cefotaxime, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cefotaxime; other cephalosporins such as cefaclor, cefadroxil, cefazolin (ancef, kefzol), cefdinir, cefditoren (spectracef), cefepime (maxipime), cefixime (suprax), cefotetan, cefoxitin (mefoxin), cefpodoxime, cefprozil, ceftaroline (teflaro), ceftazidime (fortaz, tazicef, in avycaz), ceftibuten (cedax), ceftriaxone (rocephin), cefuroxime (zinacef), or cephalexin (keflex); penicillin antibiotics; or any other medications. also tell your pharmacist if you are allergic to any ingredient in the cefotaxime product; ask for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are using or plan to use while receiving cefotaxime. your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. certain nonprescription products, including nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin) and naproxen (aleve), may interact with cefotaxime; make sure your doctor and pharmacist know you take these medicines before starting cefotaxime, and do not start them while on cefotaxime without medical advice. cefotaxime may decrease the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives (birth control pills, patches, rings, injections). use another method of contraception to prevent pregnancy while using cefotaxime; talk to your doctor about options. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any allergies; recent surgery or trauma; diabetes; cancer; heart failure; gastrointestinal disease (especially colitis); or kidney disease, and if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while receiving cefotaxime, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cefotaxime injection may cause side effects. common effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and pain, redness, swelling, or bleeding at the injection site. some side effects can be serious. stop using cefotaxime and call your doctor right away or get emergency medical help if you have watery or bloody stools, stomach cramps, or fever during treatment or for two or more months after stopping; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes; trouble swallowing or breathing; hoarseness; hives; rash; itching; peeling, blistering, or shedding skin; or a return of fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection. cefotaxime may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you experience any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: cefotetan injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cefotetan injection is used to treat infections of the lungs, skin, bones, joints, abdomen (stomach area), bloodstream, female reproductive organs, and urinary tract. it is also given before surgery to prevent infections. cefotetan is a cephalosporin antibiotic that kills bacteria. it does not treat colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when they are not needed can increase your risk of future infections that resist antibiotic treatment. how should this medicine be used? cefotetan injection comes as a powder that is mixed with fluid and injected into a vein (iv) or a large muscle (im). it is also available as a premixed iv product. it is usually given every 12 or 24 hours. you may receive cefotetan in a hospital or at home after your healthcare provider shows you how to use it. make sure you understand the instructions and ask your provider any questions. you should begin to feel better in the first few days of treatment. if your symptoms do not improve or get worse, call your doctor. use cefotetan for the full prescribed course, even if you feel better. stopping too soon or skipping doses may result in incomplete treatment and antibiotic resistance. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using cefotetan injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cefotetan; other cephalosporin antibiotics such as cefaclor, cefadroxil (duricef), cefazolin (ancef), cefdinir (omnicef), cefditoren (spectracef), cefepime (maxipime), cefixime (suprax), cefotaxime (claforan), cefoxitin, cefpodoxime (vantin), cefprozil (cefzil), ceftaroline (teflaro), ceftazidime (fortaz), ceftibuten (cedax), ceftriaxone (rocephin), cefuroxime (ceftin, zinacef), or cephalexin (keflex); penicillins; or any other medications. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. know that cefotetan may decrease the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives (birth control pills, patches, rings, injections). use an additional nonhormonal method to prevent pregnancy while using cefotetan; talk to your doctor about options. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had hemolytic anemia (a condition where red blood cells are destroyed); your doctor may tell you not to use cefotetan. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had cancer; gastrointestinal disease (especially colitis); or gallbladder, kidney, or liver disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor. if you become pregnant while using cefotetan, call your doctor. do not drink alcoholic beverages while using cefotetan and for 3 days after your last dose; alcohol during this time may cause headache, fast heartbeat, sweating, and flushing (redness of the face). what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cefotetan injection may cause side effects. if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away, tell your doctor: nausea; redness, pain, or swelling at the injection site; diarrhea. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you experience shortness of breath; fast heartbeat; headache; dizziness; pale skin; confusion; extreme tiredness; watery or bloody stools, stomach cramps, or fever during treatment or for two or more months after stopping treatment; unusual bleeding or bruising; hives; skin rash; itching; trouble breathing or swallowing; swelling of the throat or tongue; or a return of fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection. cefotetan injection may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: cefoxitin injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cefoxitin injection is used to treat bacterial infections including pneumonia and other lower respiratory tract infections, as well as infections of the urinary tract, abdomen (stomach area), female reproductive organs, blood, bones, joints, and skin. it may also be given before and during surgery to help prevent infection. cefoxitin is a cephamycin antibiotic that works by killing bacteria. it will not treat colds, flu, or other viral infections; using antibiotics when they are not needed increases the risk of antibiotic-resistant infections. it is also sometimes used to treat gonorrhea; talk to your doctor about the risks of this use. your doctor may prescribe it for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? cefoxitin injection comes as a powder to be mixed with liquid for intravenous (iv) use, and as a premixed iv solution. it is usually given every 6 or 8 hours. the length of treatment depends on your infection and how you respond. you may receive it in the hospital or at home; if at home, your healthcare provider will teach you how to prepare and give the doses. you should begin to feel better in the first few days; if you do not improve or you get worse, call your doctor. use it for the full prescribed course, even if you feel better. stopping early or skipping doses may result in incomplete treatment and antibiotic resistance. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving cefoxitin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cefoxitin; to other cephalosporins (such as cefaclor, cefadroxil, cefazolin, cefdinir, cefditoren, cefepime, cefixime, cefotaxime, cefotetan, cefpodoxime, cefprozil, ceftaroline, ceftazidime, ceftibuten, ceftriaxone, or cefuroxime, and cephalexin); to penicillin antibiotics; or to any ingredient in the formulation. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may change doses or monitor for side effects. cefoxitin may decrease the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives (birth control pills, patches, rings, injections); use another method of contraception to prevent pregnancy while receiving cefoxitin. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any allergies, myasthenia gravis, gastrointestinal disease (especially colitis), or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using cefoxitin, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cefoxitin injection may cause side effects. common effects include pain, redness, swelling, or bleeding at the injection site and diarrhea; pale skin, weakness, or shortness of breath with exertion may also occur. some side effects can be serious. stop using cefoxitin and call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have watery or bloody stools, stomach cramps, or fever during treatment or for two or more months after stopping; flushing; rash; peeling, blistering, or shedding skin; itching; hives; yellowing of the skin or eyes; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes; difficulty swallowing or breathing; hoarseness; decreased urination; swelling in the legs or feet; or a return of fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection. cefoxitin injection may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: cefpodoxime
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cefpodoxime is used to treat certain bacterial infections, including bronchitis, pneumonia, gonorrhea, and infections of the skin, ear, sinuses, throat, tonsils, and urinary tract. it is a cephalosporin antibiotic that works by stopping the growth of bacteria. it does not treat colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when they are not needed increases the risk of future antibiotic-resistant infections. how should this medicine be used? cefpodoxime comes as oral tablets and an oral suspension. it is usually taken every 12 hours for 5 to 14 days, depending on the condition being treated; a single dose is used for gonorrhea. take tablets with food; the suspension may be taken with or without food. take doses at the same times each day and follow the directions on your prescription label exactly. do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. shake the suspension well before each dose. you should begin to feel better within the first few days; if your symptoms do not improve or worsen, call your doctor. continue to take cefpodoxime for the full prescribed time even if you feel better. stopping early or skipping doses may result in incomplete treatment and antibiotic resistance. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cefpodoxime, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cefpodoxime; other cephalosporins (such as cefaclor, cefadroxil, cefazolin, cefdinir, cefditoren, cefepime, cefixime, cefotaxime, cefotetan, cefoxitin, cefprozil, ceftaroline, ceftazidime, ceftibuten, ceftriaxone, or cefuroxime); penicillins; or any other medications, and if you are allergic to any ingredients in the tablets or suspension. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. know that cefpodoxime may decrease the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives (birth control pills, patches, rings, injections); use an additional nonhormonal method to prevent pregnancy while taking it and discuss options with your doctor. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had gastrointestinal disease (especially colitis) or kidney disease, and if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking cefpodoxime, call your doctor. if you have phenylketonuria (pku), be aware that the suspension contains aspartame (a source of phenylalanine). what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cefpodoxime may cause side effects. common effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, stomach pain, vaginal irritation (swelling, redness, burning, or itching) or white vaginal discharge, and headache. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or seek emergency care if you experience watery or bloody stools, stomach cramps, or fever during treatment or for up to two months after stopping treatment; rash, itching, hives; difficulty breathing or swallowing; wheezing; or a return of fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection.

name: cefprozil
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cefprozil is used to treat certain bacterial infections, including bronchitis and infections of the skin, ears, sinuses, throat, and tonsils. it is a cephalosporin antibiotic that stops the growth of bacteria. it does not treat colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when they are not needed increases the risk of developing antibiotic-resistant infections. how should this medicine be used? cefprozil is taken by mouth as tablets or an oral suspension. it is usually taken with or without food every 12 or 24 hours for about 10 days. take it at the same time each day and follow the directions on your prescription label exactly. do not take more or less than prescribed or take it more often. shake the suspension well before each dose. you should begin to feel better within a few days. if your symptoms do not improve or get worse, call your doctor. take cefprozil for the full prescribed length of time, even if you feel better, to prevent incomplete treatment and antibiotic resistance. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cefprozil, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cefprozil, other cephalosporins, penicillins, or any ingredients in the tablets or suspension. provide a list of all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use, because your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. cefprozil may decrease the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives such as birth control pills, patches, rings, and injections; use an additional nonhormonal method to prevent pregnancy while taking it. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had gastrointestinal disease (especially colitis) or kidney disease, and if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking cefprozil, call your doctor. if you have phenylketonuria (pku), ask your pharmacist about the phenylalanine/aspartame content of the oral suspension. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cefprozil may cause side effects. common side effects include nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, stomach pain, dizziness, and genital itching. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have rash, itching, hives, trouble breathing or swallowing, wheezing, swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes, watery or bloody stools, stomach cramps, or fever during treatment or for up to two months after stopping, or a return of fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection. cefprozil may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: ceftaroline injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ceftaroline injection is used to treat certain bacterial skin infections in adults, children, and infants, including newborns. it is also used to treat certain bacterial pneumonia in adults, children, and infants 2 months of age and older. ceftaroline is a cephalosporin antibiotic that works by killing bacteria. it does not treat colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when they are not needed increases the risk of future infections that are resistant to antibiotic treatment. how should this medicine be used? ceftaroline injection comes as a powder that is mixed with fluid and infused into a vein through a needle or catheter. it is usually given over 5 to 60 minutes every 12 hours for adults, every 8 or 12 hours for children, and every 8 hours for infants and newborns. the length of treatment depends on the type of infection and your response to therapy. you may receive ceftaroline in the hospital or at home. if you are using it at home, your healthcare provider will show you exactly how to prepare and give the medication—ask questions until you are comfortable with the process. you should begin to feel better within the first few days. if your symptoms do not improve or get worse, call your doctor. use ceftaroline for the full prescribed course even if you feel better; stopping too soon or skipping doses may result in incomplete treatment and antibiotic resistance. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using ceftaroline, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to ceftaroline; to other cephalosporin antibiotics such as cefaclor, cefadroxil, cefazolin (ancef, kefzol), cefdinir, cefditoren (spectracef), cefepime (maxipime), cefixime (suprax), cefotaxime (claforan), cefotetan, cefoxitin (mefoxin), cefpodoxime, cefprozil, ceftazidime (fortaz, tazicef, in avycaz), ceftibuten (cedax), ceftriaxone (rocephin), cefuroxime (zinacef), or cephalexin (keflex); to penicillin antibiotics; to carbapenem antibiotics; or to any ingredient in ceftaroline injection. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients and whether a medication you reacted to belongs to one of these groups. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using ceftaroline, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? ceftaroline injection may cause side effects. common side effects include diarrhea, constipation, nausea, vomiting, and redness or irritation at the injection site. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you experience watery or bloody stools, stomach cramps, or fever during treatment or for up to two or more months after stopping treatment; hives, rash, itching, difficulty breathing or swallowing, or swelling of the tongue or throat; extreme tiredness, pale skin, fast or irregular heartbeat, shortness of breath, chest pain, or cold hands and feet; dizziness, drowsiness, confusion, slow thinking; or seizures. ceftaroline may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: ceftazidime and avibactam injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? the combination of ceftazidime and avibactam injection is used with metronidazole flagyl to treat infections in the abdominal stomach area. it is also used to treat pneumonia that develops in people who are on ventilators or who were in a hospital, and to treat kidney and urinary tract infections. ceftazidime is a cephalosporin antibiotic that kills bacteria. avibactam is a beta-lactamase inhibitor that helps prevent bacteria from breaking down ceftazidime. antibiotics such as ceftazidime and avibactam do not treat colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when they are not needed increases the risk of developing infections that resist antibiotic treatment. how should this medicine be used? ceftazidime and avibactam injection comes as a powder that is mixed with fluid and infused intravenously into a vein. it is usually infused slowly over 2 hours every 8 hours. the length of treatment depends on your overall health, the type of infection, and how well you respond. your doctor will tell you how long to continue therapy. you may receive this medication in a hospital or at home. if you will receive it at home, your healthcare provider will show you exactly how to prepare, infuse, and dispose of supplies. make sure you understand the instructions and ask any questions you have. you should start to feel better within the first few days. if your symptoms do not improve or get worse, contact your doctor. if you still have symptoms after finishing treatment, contact your doctor. take the medication for the full prescribed time, even if you feel better. what special precautions should i follow? before using ceftazidime and avibactam injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to ceftazidime, avibactam, other cephalosporins, penicillins, carbapenem antibiotics such as doripenem, imipenem and cilastatin, or meropenem, or any ingredients in the product. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using this medication, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, call your healthcare provider as soon as possible to receive instructions. if you administer this medication at home and you miss a dose, infuse it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not infuse two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? ceftazidime and avibactam injection may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, stomach pain, dizziness, headache. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or get emergency medical help if you experience any of the following: rash, itching, hives, difficulty breathing or swallowing; severe diarrhea with watery or bloody stools that may occur during treatment or up to 2 months after treatment; seizures; confusion; sudden muscle twitching or jerking that you cannot control; hand tremor; seeing or hearing things that are not there hallucinations; loss of consciousness or coma. ceftazidime and avibactam injection may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: ceftazidime injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ceftazidime injection treats certain bacterial infections, including pneumonia and other lower respiratory tract infections; meningitis and other infections of the brain and spinal cord; and infections of the abdomen (stomach area), skin, blood, bones, joints, female genital tract, and urinary tract. it is a cephalosporin antibiotic that kills bacteria. it does not work for colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when not needed increases the risk of future infections that resist antibiotic treatment. how should this medicine be used? ceftazidime injection comes as a powder to be mixed with liquid and given intravenously (into a vein) or intramuscularly (into a muscle). it is also available as a premixed product for intravenous use. it is usually given every 8 or 12 hours until 2 days after all signs and symptoms of the infection have resolved. you may receive it in a hospital or at home. if using it at home, your healthcare provider will show you exactly how to prepare and administer it—follow these directions carefully and ask questions if anything is unclear. you should begin to feel better within the first few days. if your symptoms do not improve or worsen, call your doctor. use ceftazidime for the full prescribed course, even if you feel better; stopping too soon or skipping doses may prevent full recovery and promote antibiotic resistance. other uses for this medicine ceftazidime injection is sometimes used for fever in patients at high risk for infection due to low white blood cell counts, melioidosis (a serious infection common in tropical regions), certain wound infections, and food poisoning. discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving ceftazidime injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to ceftazidime; any cephalosporin antibiotics such as cefaclor, cefadroxil, cefazolin (ancef, kefzol), cefdinir, cefditoren (spectracef), cefepime (maxipime), cefixime (suprax), cefotaxime (claforan), cefotetan, cefoxitin (mefoxin), cefpodoxime, cefprozil, ceftaroline (teflaro), ceftibuten (cedax), ceftriaxone (rocephin), cefuroxime (zinacef), or cephalexin (keflex); penicillin antibiotics; or any other medications. also mention if you are allergic to any ingredients in the ceftazidime injection product; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take while receiving ceftazidime; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have had recent surgery or trauma; or if you have or have ever had diabetes, cancer, heart failure, gastrointestinal disease (especially colitis, which causes inflammation of the colon), or liver or kidney disease. know that ceftazidime injection may decrease the effectiveness of some oral contraceptives (birth control pills). use an additional nonhormonal form of birth control while taking this medicine and discuss options with your doctor. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while receiving ceftazidime, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow?
