unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? ceftazidime injection may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: pain, redness, swelling, or bleeding at the injection site; diarrhea. some side effects can be serious. stop using ceftazidime and call your doctor immediately or seek emergency care if you have: watery or bloody stools, stomach cramps, or fever during treatment or for up to two or more months after stopping treatment; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes; trouble swallowing or breathing; hoarseness; rash; itching; peeling, blistering, or shedding skin; seizures; or a return of fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection. ceftazidime injection may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: ceftibuten
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ceftibuten is used to treat certain bacterial infections, including bronchitis (infection of the airways leading to the lungs) and infections of the ears, throat, and tonsils. it belongs to a class of antibiotics called cephalosporins and works by killing bacteria. antibiotics like ceftibuten do not treat colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when not needed increases the risk of antibiotic-resistant infections. how should this medicine be used? ceftibuten comes as capsules and as an oral suspension (liquid) to take by mouth. it is usually taken once daily for 10 days. take the suspension on an empty stomach, at least 2 hours before or 1 hour after a meal; the capsules may be taken with or without food. take your dose at the same time each day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have any questions. take ceftibuten exactly as prescribed; do not take more or less, or take it more often, than directed. shake the suspension well before each dose. you should start to feel better within the first few days. if your symptoms do not improve or worsen, call your doctor. keep taking ceftibuten for the full prescribed length of time even if you feel better. stopping early or skipping doses may result in incomplete treatment and promote antibiotic resistance. other uses for this medicine ceftibuten may also be used to treat urinary tract infections. talk to your doctor about the risks and benefits for your condition. it may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking ceftibuten, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to ceftibuten; any other cephalosporin antibiotics (such as cefaclor, cefadroxil, cefazolin, cefdinir, cefditoren, cefepime, cefixime, cefotaxime, cefotetan, cefoxitin, cefpodoxime, cefprozil, ceftaroline, ceftazidime, ceftriaxone, cefuroxime, or cephalexin); penicillin antibiotics; or any ingredient in the capsules or suspension. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had gastrointestinal disease (especially colitis) or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while taking ceftibuten, call your doctor. if you have diabetes, be aware that the oral suspension contains sucrose (sugar). what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? ceftibuten may cause side effects. common side effects include diarrhea, stomach pain, nausea, vomiting, heartburn, headache, and dizziness. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have watery or bloody stools with stomach cramps or fever during treatment or up to two or more months after stopping; rash, itching, or hives; trouble breathing or swallowing; wheezing; or a return of fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection.

name: ceftolozane and tazobactam injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? the combination of ceftolozane and tazobactam is used to treat certain infections, including urinary tract infections, abdominal infections, and specific types of hospital-acquired or ventilator-associated pneumonia. ceftolozane is a cephalosporin antibiotic that kills bacteria, and tazobactam is a beta-lactamase inhibitor that helps protect ceftolozane from bacterial enzymes. antibiotics do not work for colds, flu, or other viral infections. how should this medicine be used? ceftolozane and tazobactam comes as a powder that is mixed with liquid and given by intravenous infusion over about 1 hour every 8 hours for 4 to 14 days. your treatment length depends on the infection type and your response. you may receive doses in the hospital or at home. if using it at home, your healthcare provider will teach you how to prepare and infuse it; ask questions until you are confident with the steps. you should start to feel better within the first few days. if your symptoms do not improve or worsen, contact your doctor. if you still have symptoms after finishing the full course, call your doctor. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving ceftolozane and tazobactam, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to ceftolozane; tazobactam; piperacillin and tazobactam (zosyn); cephalosporin antibiotics such as cefaclor, cefadroxil, cefazolin (ancef, kefzol), cefditoren (spectracef), cefepime (maxipime), cefixime (suprax), cefotaxime (claforan), cefoxitin, cefpodoxime, cefprozil, ceftazidime (fortaz, tazicef), ceftibuten (cedax), ceftriaxone (rocephin), cefuroxime (ceftin, zinacef), or cephalexin (keflex); penicillin antibiotics; any other medicines; or any ingredients in the product. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant during treatment, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you different instructions, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at the same time. if you receive infusions at home and are unsure what to do, call your healthcare provider for instructions. what side effects can this medication cause? ceftolozane and tazobactam may cause side effects. common effects include nausea, headache, constipation, vomiting, trouble falling or staying asleep, stomach pain, and anxiety. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have severe diarrhea; watery or bloody stools with stomach cramps that may begin during treatment or up to 2 months or more after treatment; rash; itching; hives; trouble breathing or swallowing; fever; or other signs of a new or worsening infection. this medication may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: ceftriaxone injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ceftriaxone injection is used to treat certain bacterial infections, including gonorrhea (a sexually transmitted infection), pelvic inflammatory disease (infection of the female reproductive organs that may cause infertility), meningitis (infection of the membranes around the brain and spinal cord), and infections of the lungs, ears, skin, urinary tract, blood, bones, joints, and abdomen. it is also sometimes given before certain surgeries to help prevent postoperative infections. ceftriaxone is a cephalosporin antibiotic that works by killing bacteria. it does not treat colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when they are not needed increases the risk of developing infections that resist antibiotic treatment. how should this medicine be used? ceftriaxone injection is supplied as a powder to be mixed with liquid or as a premixed product, and is given intravenously (into a vein) over 30 to 60 minutes, or intramuscularly (into a muscle). it may be given as a single dose or once or twice daily for 4 to 14 days, depending on the infection. you may receive it in a hospital or clinic, or at home if your healthcare provider teaches you how to prepare and inject it. follow the instructions exactly and ask your provider any questions. you should start to feel better within the first few days. if your symptoms do not improve or worsen, contact your doctor. if you are prescribed more than one dose, complete the full course even if you feel better. stopping early or skipping doses may lead to incomplete treatment and antibiotic resistance. other uses for this medicine ceftriaxone injection is also sometimes used to treat sinus infections, endocarditis (infection of the heart lining and valves), chancroid (genital sores), lyme disease (tick-borne infection that can affect the heart, joints, and nervous system), relapsing fever (tick-borne infection with recurrent fevers), shigella, typhoid fever, salmonella, and whipple’s disease (a rare infection causing serious digestive problems). it may also be used to prevent infection in certain penicillin-allergic patients with specific heart conditions undergoing dental or upper respiratory tract procedures; in patients with fever and very low white blood cell counts who are at high risk for infection; for close contacts of someone with meningitis; and in people who have been sexually assaulted or bitten by humans or animals. talk to your doctor about the risks and benefits for your condition. this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using ceftriaxone injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to ceftriaxone; to carbapenem antibiotics; to other cephalosporins (such as cefaclor, cefadroxil, cefazolin, cefdinir, cefditoren, cefepime, cefixime, cefotaxime, cefotetan, cefoxitin, cefpodoxime, cefprozil, ceftaroline, ceftazidime, ceftibuten, cefuroxime, or cephalexin); to penicillin antibiotics; or to any ingredients in the product. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your child’s doctor if your child was born prematurely or is younger than 4 weeks old; ceftriaxone may not be appropriate. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any allergies; digestive problems (especially colitis), malnutrition, problems with vitamin k levels, or kidney or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using ceftriaxone, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? ceftriaxone injection may cause side effects. common effects include pain, tenderness, firmness, or warmth at the injection site; pale skin, weakness, or shortness of breath with exertion; and diarrhea. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have rash; bloody or watery stools, stomach cramps, or fever during treatment or for up to two or more months after stopping treatment; stomach tenderness, pain, or bloating; nausea and vomiting; heartburn; chest pain; severe pain in the side or back below the ribs; painful urination; decreased urination; urinating more often than usual; pink, brown, red, cloudy, or foul-smelling urine; swelling in the legs or feet; return of fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection; peeling, blistering, or shedding skin; difficulty swallowing or breathing; swelling of the throat or tongue; or seizures. ceftriaxone injection may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you experience anything unusual.

name: cefuroxime
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cefuroxime is used to treat certain bacterial infections, including bronchitis (infection of the airway tubes leading to the lungs), gonorrhea (a sexually transmitted disease), lyme disease (an infection that may develop after a tick bite), and infections of the skin, ears, sinuses, throat, tonsils, and urinary tract. it belongs to a class of medications called cephalosporin antibiotics and works by stopping the growth of bacteria. it does not treat colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when they are not needed increases the risk of developing infections that resist antibiotic treatment. cefuroxime is also sometimes used to treat pneumonia; talk to your doctor about the risks and benefits. this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? cefuroxime comes as a tablet and as an oral suspension to take by mouth. it is usually taken every 12 hours for 5 to 10 days, depending on your condition. for gonorrhea, it is taken as a single dose. for lyme disease, it is taken every 12 hours for 20 days. take the suspension with food; the tablet may be taken with or without food. take cefuroxime at the same times each day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully. take it exactly as directed; do not take more or less, or take it more often than prescribed. different cefuroxime products are absorbed differently and cannot be substituted for one another; if you switch products, your doctor may need to adjust your dose. shake the suspension well before each use. swallow tablets whole; do not crush them because they have a strong bitter taste. children who cannot swallow tablets should use the liquid. you should begin to feel better during the first few days of treatment. if your symptoms do not improve or get worse, call your doctor. take cefuroxime until you finish the prescription, even if you feel better; stopping too soon or skipping doses may result in incomplete treatment and antibiotic resistance. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cefuroxime, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cefuroxime; other cephalosporins such as cefaclor, cefadroxil, cefazolin (ancef, kefzol), cefdinir, cefditoren (spectracef), cefepime (maxipime), cefixime, cefotaxime (claforan), cefotetan, cefoxitin (mefoxin), cefpodoxime, cefprozil, ceftaroline (teflaro), ceftazidime (fortaz, tazicef, and in avycaz), ceftibuten (cedax), ceftriaxone (rocephin), or cephalexin (keflex); penicillin antibiotics; or any other medications, and if you are allergic to any ingredients in the tablets or suspension (ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients). tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. certain nonprescription acid-reducing medicines may interact with cefuroxime, including cimetidine, famotidine (pepcid), omeprazole (prilosec), and ranitidine (zantac); let your doctor and pharmacist know if you use these, and do not start them while taking cefuroxime without medical advice. if you take antacids that contain magnesium or aluminum, take them at least 1 hour before or 2 hours after cefuroxime. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had gastrointestinal disease (especially colitis), kidney disease, or liver disease. cefuroxime may decrease the effectiveness of some oral contraceptives (birth control pills); use another form of birth control while taking this medication and talk to your doctor about options. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor; if you become pregnant while taking cefuroxime, call your doctor. if you have phenylketonuria (pku), know that the suspension is sweetened with aspartame, which provides phenylalanine. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cefuroxime may cause side effects. common effects include nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea; if these are severe or do not go away, contact your doctor. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help for rash, itching, hives, trouble breathing or swallowing, wheezing, swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes; watery or bloody stools, stomach cramps, or fever during treatment or for up to two or more months after stopping treatment; or a return of fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection. cefuroxime may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you experience any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: cefuroxime injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cefuroxime injection is used to treat certain bacterial infections, including pneumonia and other lower respiratory tract infections; meningitis; gonorrhea; and infections of the skin, blood, bones, joints, and urinary tract. it may also be given before, during, and briefly after surgery to help prevent infection. cefuroxime is a cephalosporin antibiotic that works by killing bacteria. it does not treat colds, flu, or other viral infections, and using antibiotics when not needed can increase the risk of antibiotic-resistant infections. how should this medicine be used? cefuroxime injection is supplied as a powder that is mixed with liquid for intravenous (iv) or intramuscular (im) injection, and as a premixed iv product. it is usually given every 6 or 8 hours for 5 to 10 days. you may receive it in a hospital or at home after your healthcare provider shows you how to prepare and administer it. make sure you understand the instructions and ask any questions you have. you should start to feel better within the first few days; if your symptoms do not improve or worsen, contact your doctor. use cefuroxime injection for the full prescribed course even if you feel better. stopping early or skipping doses can result in incomplete treatment and antibiotic resistance. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving cefuroxime injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cefuroxime; to other cephalosporin antibiotics such as cefaclor, cefadroxil, cefazolin (ancef, kefzol), cefdinir, cefditoren (spectracef), cefepime (maxipime), cefixime (suprax), cefotaxime (claforan), cefotetan, cefoxitin (mefoxin), cefpodoxime, cefprozil, ceftaroline (teflaro), ceftazidime (fortaz, tazicef, in avycaz), ceftibuten (cedax), ceftriaxone (rocephin), or cephalexin (keflex); to penicillin antibiotics; or to any ingredients in the product. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any allergies; gastrointestinal disease (especially ulcerative colitis); or kidney or liver disease. know that cefuroxime injection can reduce the effectiveness of some oral contraceptives (birth control pills); use an additional form of birth control while receiving this medication and ask your doctor about other options to prevent pregnancy. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant during treatment, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? cefuroxime injection may cause side effects. common effects include vaginal itching, diarrhea, and pain, redness, swelling, or bleeding at the injection site. some side effects can be serious. stop the medication and call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have watery or bloody stools, stomach cramps, or fever during treatment or for two or more months after stopping; seizures; rash; hives; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes; trouble swallowing or breathing; hoarseness; decreased urination; swelling in the legs and feet; peeling, blistering, or shedding skin; a return of fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection; or hearing loss if you are being treated for meningitis. cefuroxime injection may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: celecoxib
instructions: important warning: people who take nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) other than aspirin, including celecoxib, may have a higher risk of heart attack or stroke than people who do not take these medicines. these events can happen without warning and may be fatal. this risk may be greater with long-term use. do not take celecoxib if you have recently had a heart attack unless your doctor tells you to. tell your doctor if you or a family member has or has ever had heart disease, a prior heart attack, or a stroke; if you smoke; or if you have or have ever had high cholesterol, high blood pressure, or diabetes. get emergency medical help right away if you have chest pain, shortness of breath, weakness on one side of the body, or slurred speech. if you will undergo coronary artery bypass graft (cabg) surgery, do not take celecoxib right before or right after the procedure. nsaids like celecoxib can cause ulcers, bleeding, or holes in the stomach or intestines at any time during treatment, sometimes without warning, and these can be fatal. risk is higher with long-term use, older age, poor health, heavy alcohol use, or when taken with certain medicines (anticoagulants such as warfarin [coumadin, jantoven]; aspirin; other nsaids such as ibuprofen [advil, motrin] or naproxen [aleve, naprosyn]; oral steroids such as dexamethasone, methylprednisolone [medrol], prednisone [rayos]; ssris such as citalopram [celexa], fluoxetine [prozac, sarafem, in symbyax], fluvoxamine [luvox], paroxetine [brisdelle, paxil, pexeva], sertraline [zoloft]; or snris such as desvenlafaxine [pristiq], duloxetine [cymbalta], venlafaxine [effexor xr]). also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had stomach or intestinal ulcers or bleeding or other bleeding disorders. stop celecoxib and call your doctor if you have stomach pain, heartburn, vomit blood or material that looks like coffee grounds, blood in the stool, or black, tarry stools. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory; your doctor will monitor your symptoms and may order tests to check your response, aiming to use the lowest effective dose to reduce serious risks. you will receive a medication guide when you start celecoxib and with each refill; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. why is this medication prescribed? celecoxib relieves pain, tenderness, swelling, and stiffness caused by osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and ankylosing spondylitis. it is also used to treat juvenile rheumatoid arthritis in children 2 years and older. celecoxib treats painful menstrual periods and other short-term pain, including pain from injuries, surgery, and other medical or dental procedures or conditions that last a limited time. it is a cox-2 selective nsaid that works by reducing the body's production of substances that cause pain and inflammation. how should this medicine be used? celecoxib is an oral capsule usually taken once or twice a day. if you take up to 200 mg at a time, you may take it with or without food. if you take more than 200 mg at a time, take it with food. ask your doctor or pharmacist if you are unsure whether to take it with food. take it at the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly; do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. if you cannot swallow the capsules, or if giving to a child, you may open the capsule and sprinkle the contents over a teaspoon of cold or room-temperature applesauce. you may prepare this mixture ahead and refrigerate it for up to 6 hours. when ready, swallow all of the mixture, then drink water to ensure you have taken the full dose. other uses for this medicine: celecoxib is sometimes used with surgery and other treatments to reduce the number of polyps in the colon and rectum in people with familial adenomatous polyposis. discuss the risks and benefits of this use with your doctor. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking celecoxib, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to celecoxib; aspirin or other nsaids such as ibuprofen or naproxen; sulfa medicines; any other medicines; or any inactive ingredients in celecoxib capsules. ask your pharmacist for a list of inactive ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you closely for side effects. nonprescription products that can interact include aspirin; other nsaids (ibuprofen, naproxen, others); and salicylates such as choline magnesium trisalicylate, choline salicylate (arthropan), magnesium salicylate (doans), or salsalate (argesic, disalcid, salgesic). do not start any of these while taking celecoxib without discussing them with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any condition listed in the important warning section; asthma (especially if you also have frequent nasal congestion, runny nose, or nasal polyps); swelling of the hands, arms, feet, ankles, or lower legs; heart failure; or liver or kidney disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor. celecoxib may harm the fetus and cause problems with delivery if taken at about 20 weeks of pregnancy or later. do not take celecoxib around or after 20 weeks of pregnancy unless your doctor tells you to. if you become pregnant while taking celecoxib, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking celecoxib. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? celecoxib may cause side effects. common effects include gas or bloating, sore throat, cold symptoms, constipation, dizziness, and changes in taste. some side effects can be serious. if you have any of the following or the symptoms listed in the important warning section, call your doctor right away and do not take more celecoxib: unexplained weight gain; shortness of breath or difficulty breathing; swelling of the abdomen, feet, ankles, or lower legs; diarrhea; nausea; excessive tiredness; unusual bleeding or bruising; itching; lack of energy; loss of appetite; pain in the upper right part of the stomach; yellowing of the skin or eyes; flu-like symptoms; blisters; fever; rash; hives; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, or hands; hoarseness; difficulty swallowing or breathing; pale skin; fast heartbeat; cloudy, discolored, or bloody urine; back pain; difficult or painful urination; or frequent urination, especially at night. celecoxib may cause other side effects. if you notice anything unusual, call your doctor.

name: cemiplimab-rwlc injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cemiplimab-rwlc injection is used to treat certain types of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cscc) that have spread to nearby tissues or to other parts of the body and cannot be treated effectively with surgery or radiation therapy. it is also used to treat basal cell carcinoma that has spread to nearby tissues or to other parts of the body after treatment with another medication, or when that medication cannot be used. cemiplimab-rwlc injection is also used alone or with platinum-containing chemotherapy to treat a certain type of non-small cell lung cancer (nsclc) that has spread to nearby tissues and cannot be removed by surgery or treated with chemotherapy or radiation, or that has spread to other parts of the body. cemiplimab-rwlc injection is in a class of medications called monoclonal antibodies. it helps your immune system attack cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? cemiplimab-rwlc injection comes as a solution to be infused into a vein over 30 minutes by a doctor or nurse in a medical facility or infusion center. it is usually given every 3 weeks. your doctor may slow, interrupt, or stop your infusion if you have certain side effects. tell your healthcare team immediately during or after your infusion if you have chills or shaking, fever, itching, rash, feeling faint, flushing, nausea, vomiting, back or neck pain, shortness of breath, dizziness, wheezing, or swelling of the face. your doctor may delay or stop treatment depending on your response and any side effects you experience. you will receive a medication guide when you begin treatment and each time you receive a dose; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have any questions. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving cemiplimab-rwlc injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cemiplimab-rwlc, any other medications, or any ingredients in the injection; ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have received or plan to receive a stem cell transplant that uses donor stem cells (allogeneic) or if you have ever had an organ transplant. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had radiation therapy to your chest; diabetes; crohn’s disease; ulcerative colitis; lupus; a nervous system disease such as myasthenia gravis or guillain-barré syndrome (gbs); a lung disease or breathing problems; or thyroid, liver, or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. you should not become pregnant while you are receiving cemiplimab-rwlc injection. you will need a pregnancy test before you begin treatment. use effective birth control during treatment and for 4 months after your final dose. if you become pregnant while receiving cemiplimab-rwlc injection, call your doctor; cemiplimab-rwlc may harm the fetus. if you are breastfeeding, do not breastfeed during treatment and for 4 months after your final dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment for cemiplimab-rwlc, call your doctor or infusion center as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to make up the dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? cemiplimab-rwlc injection may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: constipation; hair loss; muscle, joint, bone, or back pain. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of these symptoms, or symptoms of an infusion reaction such as those listed in the how should this medicine be used? section, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment: cough; irregular heartbeat; chest pain; shortness of breath; diarrhea; stools that are black, tarry, sticky, or have blood or mucus; abdominal pain or tenderness; yellow eyes or skin; severe nausea or vomiting; dark urine; loss of appetite; unusual bleeding or bruising; pain or discomfort in the right upper stomach area; rash; blistering skin; itching; swollen lymph nodes; fever or flu-like symptoms; painful sores or ulcers in the mouth or nose, throat, or genital area; decreased urine amount; swelling in your ankles; blood in urine; loss of appetite; headaches that will not go away or unusual headaches; feeling more hungry or thirsty than usual; increased sweating; extreme tiredness; frequent urination; weight changes; double vision, blurry vision, sensitivity to light, eye pain, or changes in vision; feeling cold; deepening of the voice or hoarseness; hair loss; irritability; dizziness or fainting; fast heartbeat; forgetfulness; changes in sexual desire; confusion; sleepiness; memory problems; changes in mood or behavior; stiff neck; balance problems; tingling or numbness of arms or legs; persistent muscle pain or weakness; or muscle cramps. cemiplimab-rwlc injection may cause other side effects.

name: cenegermin-bkbj ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ophthalmic cenegermin-bkbj is used to treat neurotrophic keratitis, a degenerative eye disease that can damage the cornea (the outermost layer of the eye). cenegermin-bkbj belongs to a class of medications called recombinant human nerve growth factors and helps heal the cornea. how should this medicine be used? ophthalmic cenegermin-bkbj is a liquid eye drop solution. instill it in the affected eye(s) six times a day, about every 2 hours, for 8 weeks. use it at the same times each day. follow your prescription directions exactly; do not use more, less, or more often than prescribed. do not shake the vial. use a new single-use pipette for each application in each eye; do not reuse pipettes. discard the vial at the end of each day, even if liquid remains, and also discard it if more than 12 hours have passed since attaching the adapter. read the manufacturer’s instructions for use before your first dose and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using cenegermin-bkbj, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cenegermin-bkbj, any other medications, or any ingredients in the eye drops; your pharmacist can provide a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. talk to your doctor before using any other eye medications. if you use another eye drop, apply it at least 15 minutes before or after cenegermin-bkbj. if you use an eye ointment, gel, or other thick (viscous) eye medication, apply it at least 15 minutes after cenegermin-bkbj. tell your doctor if you have an eye infection or develop one during treatment. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, discuss this with your doctor; call your doctor if you become pregnant while using cenegermin-bkbj. your vision may be blurry for a short time after use; do not drive or operate machinery until your vision clears. do not instill these drops while wearing contact lenses; remove lenses before use and reinsert them 15 minutes later. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cenegermin-bkbj may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of the following are severe or do not go away: eye pain; redness or swelling of the eye; increased tearing; feeling that something is in the eye. cenegermin-bkbj may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: cenobamate
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cenobamate is used to treat partial-onset seizures (seizures that begin in one part of the brain). it is an anticonvulsant that works by reducing abnormal electrical activity in the brain. how should this medicine be used? cenobamate comes as an oral tablet taken once daily with or without food, at the same time each day. take it exactly as prescribed; do not take more, take it more often, or take it longer than directed. if you cannot swallow the tablet whole, you may crush it and mix it with water to take by mouth or through a nasogastric (ng) tube: place the crushed tablet in 25 ml of water in a cup and swirl to mix; then drink the mixture or draw it into a syringe to administer through the ng tube. if taking by mouth, add another 25 ml of water to the same cup, swirl, and drink to ensure the full dose is taken; repeat if tablet pieces remain. if giving through an ng tube, add 10 ml more water to the syringe and administer through the tube again. administer the mixture immediately after preparation; do not store for later use. your doctor will usually start with a low dose and increase it no more than once every 2 weeks. cenobamate may be habit forming; do not increase your dose, dosing frequency, or duration without your doctor’s guidance. cenobamate helps control seizures but does not cure them. do not stop taking it without talking to your doctor; stopping suddenly can worsen seizures. your doctor will lower your dose gradually if needed. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cenobamate, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to cenobamate, any of its ingredients, or any other medications, foods, or substances, and describe your allergy symptoms. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. cenobamate may decrease the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives (birth control pills, patches, rings, or implants); ask your doctor about effective contraception while taking cenobamate. do not take cenobamate if you have familial short qt syndrome. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while taking cenobamate. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you take cenobamate. cenobamate can cause dizziness, drowsiness, and problems with coordination and balance; do not drive, use machinery, or do activities requiring alertness until you know how it affects you. ask your doctor about alcohol use; alcohol can worsen side effects. your mental health may change in unexpected ways, including suicidal thoughts or actions; you, your family, or your caregiver should call your doctor right away if you have panic attacks; agitation or restlessness; new or worsening irritability, anxiety, or depression; acting on dangerous impulses; trouble sleeping; aggressive, angry, or violent behavior; mania (abnormally excited mood); talking or thinking about harming yourself; or other unusual mood or behavior changes. cenobamate has caused liver damage; call your doctor right away if you have nausea, vomiting, upper right-sided stomach pain, tiredness or weakness, loss of appetite, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, or pale stools. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cenobamate may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: headache; tiredness; nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or constipation; dry mouth; taste changes; heartburn; stomach pain; loss of appetite; weight loss; back pain; difficulty reading, writing, or speaking; confusion; hallucinations, paranoia, hostility, or aggression. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or seek emergency help if you have double or blurred vision; rash; hives; swelling of the face or legs; trouble swallowing or breathing; fever, sore throat, or swollen glands; sores in the mouth or around the eyes; unusual bruising or bleeding; marked fatigue or weakness; muscle pain; yellowing of the skin or eyes; dark urine; shortness of breath; irregular heartbeat; or fainting. cenobamate may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: cephalexin
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cephalexin is used to treat bacterial infections such as pneumonia and other respiratory tract infections, and infections of the skin, bone, ears, genital tract, and urinary tract. it is a cephalosporin antibiotic that kills bacteria. it does not work for colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when not needed increases the risk of antibiotic-resistant infections. it is also sometimes used in certain penicillin-allergic patients with specific heart conditions who are undergoing dental or upper respiratory procedures to help prevent a heart valve infection. ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? cephalexin is taken by mouth as capsules, tablets, or an oral suspension. it is usually taken every 6 or 12 hours, with or without food, for 7 to 14 days depending on the condition being treated. take it at the same times each day and exactly as directed. do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. shake the liquid well before each dose. you should begin to feel better within the first few days; if symptoms do not improve or worsen, call your doctor. continue taking cephalexin until you finish the full prescription even if you feel better; stopping too soon or skipping doses may result in incomplete treatment and antibiotic resistance. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cephalexin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cephalexin; to other cephalosporins such as cefaclor, cefadroxil, cefazolin (ancef, kefzol), cefdinir, cefditoren (spectracef), cefepime (maxipime), cefixime (suprax), cefotaxime (claforan), cefotetan, cefoxitin (mefoxin), cefpodoxime, cefprozil, ceftaroline (teflaro), ceftazidime (fortaz, tazicef; in avycaz), ceftibuten (cedax), ceftriaxone (rocephin), or cefuroxime (zinacef); to penicillin antibiotics; or to any ingredients in the capsules, tablets, or suspension. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. know that cephalexin may decrease the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives (birth control pills, patches, rings, injections); use another method to prevent pregnancy while taking it and discuss options with your doctor. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any allergies; gastrointestinal disease (especially colitis); kidney or liver disease; or if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking cephalexin, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cephalexin may cause side effects. common effects include nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, heartburn, stomach pain, rectal or genital itching, dizziness, extreme tiredness, agitation, confusion, headache, and joint pain. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor immediately or seek emergency care if you have watery or bloody stools, stomach cramps, or fever during treatment or for two months or more after stopping; rash, itching, hives; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes; difficulty breathing or swallowing; wheezing; a return of fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection; or hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that do not exist).

name: ceritinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ceritinib is used to treat a specific type of non-small cell lung cancer (nsclc) that has spread to other parts of the body. it is a kinase inhibitor that blocks an abnormal protein that signals cancer cells to multiply, helping slow or stop their spread. how should this medicine be used? ceritinib comes as capsules and tablets to take by mouth. take it once daily with food, at about the same time each day. follow your prescription label exactly, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not take more or less than prescribed or take it more often. if you vomit after taking a dose, do not take another dose; continue your regular schedule. your doctor may adjust your dose, add other medications, or pause treatment based on how well it works for you and any side effects. tell your doctor how you are feeling throughout treatment. what special precautions should i follow? before taking ceritinib, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to ceritinib, any other medication, or any ingredient in the capsules or tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. some products may interact with ceritinib, including st. john’s wort and heartburn medicines such as omeprazole (prilosec), esomeprazole (nexium), and rabeprazole (aciphex). do not start any of these while taking ceritinib without talking with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had diabetes or high blood sugar, heart failure, an irregular heartbeat, qt prolongation, low potassium or magnesium levels, pancreatitis, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. do not become pregnant while taking ceritinib. you will need a pregnancy test before starting, and you must use effective birth control during treatment and for at least 6 months after your final dose. if you are a male with a partner who can become pregnant, use effective birth control during treatment and for at least 3 months after your final dose. ceritinib may harm an unborn baby. if you or your partner becomes pregnant, call your doctor immediately. do not breast-feed while taking ceritinib and for at least 2 weeks after your final dose. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist you are taking ceritinib. you should know that ceritinib can increase blood sugar. call your doctor right away if you have extreme thirst, frequent urination, extreme hunger, blurred vision, headache, trouble thinking or concentrating, fruity-smelling breath, or unusual tiredness. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not eat grapefruit or drink grapefruit juice while taking ceritinib. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is within 12 hours of your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? ceritinib may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, constipation, stomach pain, heartburn, difficulty swallowing, loss of appetite, weight loss, fatigue, rash, itching, changes in vision, muscle, bone, back, arm, or leg pain, headache. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have any of the following or any symptoms listed in the special precautions section: pain in the right upper abdomen; unusual bruising or bleeding; dark urine; yellowing of the skin or eyes; decreased appetite; flu-like symptoms; itching; shortness of breath; fever, chills, sore throat, ongoing cough or congestion, or other signs of infection; chest pain or discomfort; changes in heartbeat, heart palpitations, dizziness, lightheadedness, fainting; persistent pain that begins in the upper left or middle abdomen and may spread to the back; or seizures. ceritinib may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: cerliponase alfa injection
instructions: important warning: cerliponase alfa may cause serious hypersensitivity reactions, including life-threatening anaphylaxis, during the infusion and for up to 24 hours afterward. your doctor or nurse will monitor you closely during each infusion. these reactions can occur early in treatment or after many doses. seek emergency medical care if you develop any of the following after receiving cerliponase alfa: rash, itching, hives, swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes, difficulty breathing or swallowing, or wheezing. your doctor may give you medicines 30 to 60 minutes before each infusion to reduce the chance of these reactions. why is this medication prescribed? cerliponase alfa is used to slow the loss of the ability to crawl or walk in children with neuronal ceroid lipofuscinosis type 2 (cln2 disease), an inherited nervous system disorder also known as tripeptidyl peptidase 1 (tpp1) deficiency. it belongs to a class of medicines called enzymes and works by replacing the missing tpp1 in the nervous system. how should this medicine be used? cerliponase alfa is provided as a solution that is diluted and infused slowly over several hours through an access device that was surgically placed into the brain. it is usually given every 2 weeks in a doctor’s office or healthcare facility. ask your doctor or pharmacist for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving cerliponase alfa, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cerliponase alfa, any other medications, or any ingredients in the injection; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have signs of infection near your access device (such as redness, tenderness, or discharge) or if there is leaking from the device site; your doctor will likely tell you not to receive cerliponase alfa. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had an irregular heartbeat or other heart problems, and if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss your appointment to receive cerliponase alfa, call your doctor right away. if one or more doses are missed, treatment should be restarted as soon as possible, then return to the every-2-week schedule. what side effects can this medication cause? cerliponase alfa may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of the following are severe or do not go away: vomiting, bruising, headache, irritability, feeling jittery. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you experience fever, seizures, slow or irregular heartbeat, dizziness, fainting, or any symptoms listed in the important warning or precautions above. cerliponase alfa may cause other side effects.

name: certolizumab injection
instructions: important warning: certolizumab injection can lower your ability to fight infection and increase the risk of serious or life threatening infections, including severe fungal, bacterial, and viral infections that can spread throughout the body, may require hospital treatment, and may cause death. tell your doctor if you frequently get infections or if you have or think you have any infection now, including minor infections such as open cuts or sores, infections that come and go such as cold sores, and chronic infections that do not go away. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had diabetes, hepatitis b, hiv, any condition that affects your immune system, or if you live or have lived in areas such as the ohio and mississippi river valleys where severe fungal infections are more common; ask your doctor if you are unsure whether these infections are common in your area. tell your doctor if you are taking medicines that decrease immune activity. your doctor will monitor you for signs of infection during and after treatment. call your doctor right away if before starting or during or shortly after treatment you have sore throat, cough, coughing up bloody mucus, fever, stomach pain, diarrhea, flu like symptoms, open cuts or sores, weight loss, weakness, sweating, trouble breathing, difficult, frequent, or painful urination, or other signs of infection. you may already be infected with inactive tuberculosis tb or hepatitis b without symptoms; certolizumab can make these infections worse and cause symptoms. your doctor will test you for inactive tb and hepatitis b and may give you medicine to treat these infections before starting certolizumab. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had tb, if you have lived in or visited a country where tb is common, or if you have been around someone with tb. call your doctor immediately if you have symptoms of tb now or develop them during treatment, such as cough, weight loss, loss of muscle tone, or fever. also call your doctor immediately if you have symptoms of hepatitis b during or after treatment, such as excessive tiredness, yellowing of the skin or eyes, loss of appetite, nausea or vomiting, muscle aches, dark urine, clay colored stools, fever, chills, stomach pain, or rash. some children and teenagers who received medicines similar to certolizumab developed severe or life threatening cancers including lymphoma. some teenage and young adult males taking certolizumab or similar medicines developed hepatosplenic t cell lymphoma hstcl, a very serious cancer that often causes death within a short period. most people who developed hstcl were being treated for crohns disease or ulcerative colitis with certolizumab or a similar medicine along with azathioprine or 6 mercaptopurine. adults using certolizumab may also have a higher risk of certain cancers, including skin cancer. tell your doctor if you or your child have ever had any type of cancer. call your doctor right away if during treatment you have unexplained weight loss; swollen glands in the neck, underarms, or groin; easy bruising or bleeding; a new skin lesion or bump; or a change in the size or color of a mole. your doctor will also check your skin for any changes during treatment. your doctor or pharmacist will give you the medication guide when you begin treatment and each time you refill your prescription. read it carefully and ask questions. discuss the risks of using certolizumab with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? certolizumab injection is used in adults to treat crohns disease that has not improved with other medicines; rheumatoid arthritis; psoriatic arthritis; active ankylosing spondylitis with changes seen on x ray; active non radiographic axial spondyloarthritis with signs of inflammation but without changes on x ray; and plaque psoriasis in people who may benefit from medicines or phototherapy. it is also used to treat polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis pjia in children 2 years of age or older. certolizumab is a tumor necrosis factor tnf inhibitor that works by blocking tnf, a substance in the body that causes inflammation. how should this medicine be used? certolizumab comes as a powder to be mixed with sterile water and injected under the skin by a health care professional, and as a prefilled syringe for subcutaneous injection that you can use at home after training. for crohns disease, it is usually given every 2 weeks for the first 3 doses, then every 4 weeks. for rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, or axial spondyloarthritis, it is usually given every 2 weeks for the first 3 doses, then every 2 or 4 weeks. for plaque psoriasis or pjia, it is usually given every 2 weeks. if you are self injecting, follow your prescription directions exactly; do not use more or less than prescribed. have your doctor show you or your caregiver how to inject, and read the instructions for use. if using a refrigerated prefilled syringe, place it on a flat surface and allow it to warm to room temperature for about 30 minutes; do not warm it by microwave, hot water, or any other method, and do not shake. before opening, check that the package is intact, tamper evident seals are not missing or broken, and the expiration date has not passed. after opening, inspect the liquid; it should be clear to pale yellow without large or colored particles. if there are any problems with the package or syringe, call your pharmacist and do not inject. inject into the abdomen or thighs, avoiding the navel and the 2 inch area around it. do not inject into skin that is tender, bruised, red, hard, scarred, or with stretch marks. rotate sites and do not inject in the same spot more than once; choose a new spot at least 1 inch from a previous site. if your dose requires two syringes, use different spots. do not reuse or recap prefilled syringes. discard used syringes in a puncture resistant container and ask your pharmacist how to dispose of the container. certolizumab may help control your symptoms but will not cure your condition. do not stop using it without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using certolizumab, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to certolizumab, any other medicines, latex or rubber, or any ingredients in the product; ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. if you will be using the prefilled syringe, tell your doctor if you or the person who will inject the medicine is allergic to latex. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had a disease that affects the nervous system such as multiple sclerosis, guillain barre syndrome, or optic neuritis; numbness, burning, or tingling anywhere in your body; seizures; heart failure; any type of cancer; bleeding problems; or blood disorders. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while using certolizumab, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you use certolizumab. ask your doctor whether you should receive any vaccinations before you begin treatment. if possible, bring all vaccinations for children up to date before starting treatment. do not receive any vaccinations without talking to your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? inject the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not inject a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? certolizumab may cause side effects. common effects include redness, itching, pain, or swelling at the injection site, headache, and back pain. some side effects can be serious. if you have any of the symptoms listed in the important warning section or any of the following, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help: swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; hoarseness; shortness of breath; difficulty swallowing or breathing; chest pain; sudden weight gain; hives; hot flashes; dizziness or fainting; rash especially on the cheeks or arms that worsens in the sun; unusual bruising or bleeding; pale skin; blistering skin; extreme tiredness; numbness or tingling; vision problems; weakness in the arms or legs; joint pain; loss of appetite; red scaly patches and or pus filled bumps on the skin. certolizumab may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: cetirizine
instructions: important warning: on may 16, 2025, the u.s. food and drug administration (fda) issued a safety communication about a rare risk of severe itching that can occur after stopping long-term use of oral allergy medicines such as cetirizine. most people who experienced itching had taken the medicine for 3 months or longer, though some had used it for less than 1 month. contact your healthcare provider if you develop severe itching after stopping cetirizine. why is this medication prescribed? cetirizine is used to relieve sneezing; runny nose; itchy, red, watery eyes; and an itchy nose or throat due to allergies. it is also used to treat itching and redness from hives. cetirizine is an antihistamine that blocks histamine, a body chemical that causes allergy symptoms. cetirizine is also available with pseudoephedrine; this information covers cetirizine alone. if you are taking a cetirizine–pseudoephedrine combination, read the package label or ask your doctor or pharmacist for details. how should this medicine be used? cetirizine comes as a tablet, chewable tablet, capsule, orally disintegrating tablet (dissolves in the mouth), and a syrup, all taken by mouth. take it once daily, with or without food, at the same time each day. take cetirizine exactly as directed; do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. for the orally disintegrating tablet, with dry hands peel back the foil, immediately remove the tablet, place it on your tongue, and let it dissolve; it can be swallowed with saliva and may be taken with or without water. do not use cetirizine to treat hives that are bruised or blistered, an unusual color, or that do not itch—call your doctor if you have these types of hives. stop cetirizine and call your doctor if your hives do not improve within the first 3 days of treatment or if they last longer than 6 weeks. if you do not know the cause of your hives, call your doctor. if you develop any of the following while treating hives, get emergency help right away: trouble swallowing, speaking, or breathing; swelling in or around the mouth or of the tongue; wheezing; drooling; dizziness; or loss of consciousness—these may be signs of anaphylaxis, a life-threatening allergic reaction. if your doctor believes you may be at risk for anaphylaxis, an epinephrine injector (epipen) may be prescribed. do not use cetirizine in place of the epinephrine injector. other uses for this medicine cetirizine may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cetirizine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cetirizine, any of its ingredients, or any other medicines, foods, or substances, and describe the symptoms you experienced. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while taking cetirizine. cetirizine can cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. alcohol can increase drowsiness; avoid alcoholic beverages while taking this medicine. be aware that severe itching can develop within a few days after stopping cetirizine, especially after regular use for months or years; talk to your doctor if you have questions about risks with long-term use. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? cetirizine may cause side effects. common effects include drowsiness, excessive tiredness, and dry mouth. a less common but serious effect is rash or difficulty breathing or swallowing; if this occurs, call your doctor immediately. cetirizine may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice any unusual problems while taking it.

name: cetirizine injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cetirizine injection is used to treat acute urticaria, the sudden appearance of hives. it is an antihistamine that works by blocking histamine, a substance in the body that causes allergic symptoms. how should this medicine be used? cetirizine injection is a liquid solution given intravenously by a healthcare professional. it is typically administered once every 24 hours as needed. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving cetirizine, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to cetirizine, any component of the product, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe the symptoms you experienced. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take, as your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while receiving cetirizine, call your doctor. cetirizine may cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. alcohol can increase drowsiness; avoid alcoholic beverages while receiving this medication. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medication is given by a healthcare professional. if you miss an appointment or a dose, contact your doctor or clinic to reschedule as soon as possible. what side effects can this medication cause? cetirizine may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: indigestion, feeling hot, unusual taste, feeling faint, headache, sweating, or numbness, tingling, prickling, or burning sensations of the skin. some side effects can be serious. if you experience difficulty breathing or swallowing, seek medical attention immediately. cetirizine may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: cetirizine ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cetirizine ophthalmic is used to relieve the itching of allergic pink eye (allergic conjunctivitis). cetirizine is an antihistamine that works by blocking histamine, a substance in the body that causes allergy symptoms. how should this medicine be used? cetirizine ophthalmic is an eye drop solution. instill in the affected eye or eyes twice daily, approximately 8 hours apart, and use it at the same times each day. use cetirizine ophthalmic exactly as directed. do not use more or less of it or use it more often than prescribed by your doctor. cetirizine ophthalmic comes in single-use containers and in a multi-dose bottle (a bottle that can be used more than once). use a single-use container immediately after opening for one or both eyes, then dispose of the container and any remaining solution after one use. to use the eye drops, follow these steps: wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water. check the dropper tip to ensure it is not chipped or cracked. avoid touching the dropper tip to your eye or any surface to keep it clean. tilt your head back and pull down the lower eyelid with your index finger to form a pocket. hold the dropper tip down close to the eye without touching it, bracing your hand against your face. while looking up, gently squeeze one drop into the pocket formed by the lower eyelid. release the lower eyelid. close your eye for 2 to 3 minutes and tip your head downward as though looking at the floor. try not to blink or squeeze your eyelids. place a finger over the tear duct at the inner corner of the eye and apply gentle pressure. wipe any excess liquid from your face with a tissue. if using another eye product, wait at least 5 minutes after using cetirizine eye drops before using the other eye medication. replace and tighten the cap on the dropper bottle. do not wipe or rinse the dropper tip. discard the single-dose container out of the reach of children or pets. replace and tighten the cap on the multi-dose bottle. wash your hands to remove any medication. ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer information for the patient. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using cetirizine ophthalmic, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to cetirizine, any ingredient in the product, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe what symptoms you had. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. if you become pregnant while using cetirizine eye drops, call your doctor. do not wear contact lenses if your eyes are red. if your eye is not red and you wear contact lenses, be aware that cetirizine solution contains benzalkonium chloride, which can be absorbed by soft contact lenses. remove your contact lenses before instilling cetirizine and wait 10 minutes before reinserting them. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember it. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cetirizine eye drops may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: eye redness, eye pain, blurred vision. cetirizine may cause other side effects.

name: cetuximab injection
instructions: important warning: cetuximab can cause severe or life-threatening infusion reactions. these are more common with the first dose but can occur at any time during treatment. your doctor will monitor you closely during each infusion and for at least 1 hour afterward. tell your doctor if you are allergic to red meat or have ever been bitten by a tick. seek immediate medical help during or after an infusion if you have sudden trouble breathing, shortness of breath, wheezing or noisy breathing, swelling of the eyes, face, mouth, lips, or throat, hoarseness, hives, fainting, dizziness, nausea, fever, chills, or chest pain or pressure. if a reaction occurs, your doctor may slow or stop the infusion and treat the symptoms, and you may not be able to receive cetuximab again. people with head and neck cancer treated with both radiation therapy and cetuximab may have a higher risk of cardiopulmonary arrest and sudden death during or after treatment. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had coronary artery disease, heart failure, irregular heartbeat, other heart disease, or low magnesium, potassium, or calcium levels. keep all appointments for medical and lab visits so your doctor can check your response and monitor for side effects. discuss the risks and benefits of cetuximab with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? cetuximab is used with or without radiation therapy to treat certain head and neck cancers that have spread locally or to other parts of the body. it can be combined with other medicines to treat head and neck cancer that has spread or has returned after prior treatment. cetuximab is also used alone or with other medicines to treat certain colorectal cancers that have spread. it is a monoclonal antibody that works by slowing or stopping the growth of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? cetuximab is a liquid solution given by slow infusion into a vein by a doctor or nurse in a clinic or infusion center. the first dose is infused over about 2 hours; later doses are usually infused over about 1 hour. it is typically given every 1 to 2 weeks for as long as your doctor recommends. your doctor may slow the infusion rate, reduce your dose, delay or stop treatment, or give other medicines if you develop certain side effects. be sure to tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. other uses for this medicine: this medicine may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving cetuximab, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cetuximab, any other medicines, red meat, or galactose, or to any ingredient in the product. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor if you have ever had tick bites. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had heart disease. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, you will need a pregnancy test before starting treatment. do not become pregnant during treatment and for at least 2 months after your final dose; ask your doctor about effective birth control. if you become pregnant during treatment, call your doctor. if you are breastfeeding, your doctor may tell you not to breastfeed during treatment and for 2 months after the final dose. this medicine may decrease fertility in women; discuss risks with your doctor. avoid unnecessary or prolonged sun exposure and use protective clothing, a hat, sunglasses, and sunscreen during treatment and for 2 months after your last dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment for a dose, call your doctor right away. what side effects can this medication cause? cetuximab may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: acne-like rash; dry or cracking skin; itching; swelling, pain, or changes in fingernails or toenails; red, watery, or itchy eyes; red or swollen eyelids; eye pain or burning; sensitivity to light; hair loss; increased hair growth on the head, face, eyelashes, or chest; chapped lips; headache; tiredness; weakness; confusion; numbness, tingling, pain, or burning in arms or legs; dry mouth; sores on the lips, mouth, or throat; sore throat; nausea; vomiting; change in taste; loss of appetite; weight loss; constipation; diarrhea; heartburn; joint pain; bone pain; pain, redness, or swelling at the infusion site. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have any of the symptoms above in the important warning section or any of the following: loss of vision; blistering, peeling, or shedding skin; red, swollen, or infected skin; new or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or chest pain. cetuximab may cause other side effects. talk to your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: cevimeline
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cevimeline is prescribed to relieve dry mouth in people with sjogren’s syndrome, an autoimmune condition that causes dryness in areas such as the eyes and mouth. it belongs to a class of medicines called cholinergic agonists and works by increasing saliva production. how should this medicine be used?
