cevimeline comes as an oral capsule and is usually taken 3 times a day. take it at the same times each day. follow your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take cevimeline exactly as directed; do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cevimeline, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cevimeline or any other medicines. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and supplements you use or plan to use; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. the herbal product st. john’s wort may interact with cevimeline. do not start or stop any medication, including herbal products, while taking cevimeline without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have asthma, acute iritis/uveitis (inflammation inside the eye), or glaucoma; you may be advised not to take cevimeline. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had chest pain or a heart attack, chronic bronchitis, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (copd), kidney stones, gallstones, or heart disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while taking cevimeline, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you take cevimeline. know that cevimeline may cause vision changes, especially at night or in low light; use caution when driving at night or doing hazardous activities in reduced lighting. cevimeline may also cause excessive sweating and dehydration; drink plenty of fluids and ask your doctor about ways to prevent dehydration while taking this medicine. what special dietary instructions should i follow? talk to your doctor about eating grapefruit or drinking grapefruit juice while taking this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cevimeline may cause side effects. common side effects include sweating, nausea, and a runny nose. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor right away if you have severe headache, vision changes, tearing of the eyes, excessive sweating, trouble breathing, abdominal cramping, changes in heartbeat, changes in blood pressure, confusion, or uncontrollable shaking/tremor. cevimeline may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual symptoms.

name: chenodiol
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? chenodiol is used to dissolve certain cholesterol gallstones and to treat cerebrotendinous xanthomatosis (ctx), a condition that causes high levels of cholesterol in the body. it is a bile acid that works by dissolving the cholesterol that forms gallstones and by reducing cholesterol production in the liver. how should this medicine be used? chenodiol comes as a tablet taken by mouth. take it with or without food 2 or 3 times a day, at the same times each day. take chenodiol exactly as directed. do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. swallow the tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush them. you will likely start on a low dose that is increased gradually, typically weekly, as directed by your doctor. ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer information for patients. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking chenodiol, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this medication, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe the allergy and your symptoms. some medicines should not be taken with chenodiol, and others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. discuss all medicines you take now or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist before starting chenodiol. get medical advice before starting, stopping, or changing any medicine while taking chenodiol. tell your doctor if you have liver disease; your doctor may tell you not to take chenodiol. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any other medical conditions. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking chenodiol, call your doctor right away. chenodiol may harm the fetus. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? chenodiol may cause side effects. common side effects include diarrhea, constipation, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, heartburn, gas, muscle weakness, and headache. some side effects can be serious. stop taking chenodiol and call your doctor immediately if you have abdominal pain, bruising, dark-colored urine, fatigue, bleeding, nausea, itching (pruritus), yellowing of the eyes or skin, or sudden, worsening pain in the upper right part of the abdomen if you are being treated for gallstones. chenodiol may cause other side effects. if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication, contact your doctor.

name: chloral hydrate
instructions: notice: chloral hydrate is no longer available in the united states. why is this medication prescribed? chloral hydrate is a sedative used short term to treat insomnia (to help you fall asleep and stay asleep) and to relieve anxiety and induce sleep before surgery. it is also used after surgery for pain and to treat alcohol withdrawal. this medication may sometimes be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? chloral hydrate comes as oral capsules and liquid, and as rectal suppositories. follow your prescription label exactly, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take chloral hydrate exactly as directed; do not take more, take it more often, or use it longer than prescribed. for the liquid, mix the dose with half a glass of water, fruit juice, or ginger ale and drink it right away. swallow capsules whole with a full glass of water or fruit juice; do not chew them. for the suppository: 1) remove the wrapper. 2) moisten the tip with water. 3) lie on your left side with your right knee drawn up (left-handed people may lie on the right side with the left knee drawn up). 4) using your finger, insert the suppository into the rectum: about 1/2 to 1 inch (1.25 to 2.5 cm) in infants and children and about 1 inch (2.5 cm) in adults. 5) hold it in place briefly. 6) stand up after about 15 minutes. 7) wash your hands thoroughly and resume normal activities. chloral hydrate can be habit-forming. continue taking it exactly as prescribed. do not stop suddenly, especially after large doses or long-term use; your doctor will likely taper your dose. what special precautions should i follow? before taking chloral hydrate, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to chloral hydrate, aspirin, tartrazine (a yellow dye in some processed foods and drugs), or any other medications. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are using or plan to use; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney or liver disease, heart or stomach problems, asthma, or a history of alcohol or drug abuse. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor; if you become pregnant while taking chloral hydrate, call your doctor. if you are having any surgery, including dental procedures, inform the doctor or dentist that you are taking chloral hydrate. this medicine may cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. alcohol can increase drowsiness. what special dietary instructions should i follow? chloral hydrate may upset your stomach; take it with food or milk. what should i do if i forget a dose? do not take the missed dose; skip it and take your next dose at the regularly scheduled time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include drowsiness, upset stomach, vomiting, or diarrhea. call your doctor immediately if you have a skin rash, itching, confusion, difficulty breathing, a slow heartbeat, or extreme tiredness.

name: chlorambucil
instructions: important warning: chlorambucil can reduce the number of blood cells produced by your bone marrow. your doctor will order blood tests before, during, and after treatment to monitor this—keep all laboratory appointments. chlorambucil may increase the risk of developing other cancers; discuss this risk with your doctor. it can disrupt menstrual periods in women and reduce or stop sperm production in men, and may cause permanent infertility; however, do not assume you cannot become pregnant or cause a pregnancy. if you are pregnant, tell your doctor before starting this medicine. do not plan to conceive or father a child while receiving chemotherapy and for some time after finishing; ask your doctor for guidance. use reliable birth control to prevent pregnancy. if you become pregnant while taking chlorambucil, call your doctor immediately; chlorambucil may harm the fetus. why is this medication prescribed? chlorambucil treats certain cases of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (cll) and is also used for non-hodgkin lymphoma (nhl) and hodgkin disease, cancers that begin in white blood cells. it is an alkylating agent that slows or stops cancer cell growth. how should this medicine be used? chlorambucil is an oral tablet. it is usually taken once daily for 3 to 6 weeks, but may be given intermittently as a single dose every 2 weeks or once a month. treatment length depends on your regimen, your response, and your cancer type. take it at the same time each day. follow your prescription exactly; do not take more or less, or take it more often than prescribed. your doctor may adjust your dose based on response and side effects; tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. do not stop taking chlorambucil without talking to your doctor. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be used for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking chlorambucil, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to chlorambucil; to other alkylating agents such as bendamustine (treanda), busulfan (myleran, busulfex), carmustine (bicnu, gliadel wafer), cyclophosphamide (cytoxan), ifosfamide (ifex), lomustine (ceenu), melphalan (alkeran), procarbazine (mutalane), or temozolomide (temodar); to any other medications; or to any ingredients in chlorambucil. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. if you previously took chlorambucil and your cancer did not respond, your doctor will likely advise you not to take it again. tell your doctor if you received radiation therapy or other chemotherapy within the past 4 weeks; if you have ever had seizures or a head injury; and if you are breastfeeding. do not receive any vaccinations without talking to your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? chlorambucil may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: nausea, vomiting, sores in the mouth and throat, tiredness, missed menstrual periods in girls and women. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor immediately if you have: skin rash; unusual bruising or bleeding; black, tarry stools; red urine; cough; sore throat; congestion; fever; difficulty breathing; seizures; yellowing of the skin or eyes; pain in the upper right part of the abdomen; dark urine; frequent urination; or unusual lumps or masses. chlorambucil may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you experience any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: chloramphenicol injection
instructions: important warning: chloramphenicol injection can reduce the number of certain blood cells. in some people who had this reduction, leukemia, a cancer of white blood cells, later developed. this decrease can occur with short or long courses. call your doctor right away if you develop pale skin, unusual tiredness, shortness of breath, dizziness, rapid heartbeat, easy bruising or bleeding, or signs of infection such as sore throat, fever, cough, or chills. your doctor will order regular blood tests during treatment to check your blood counts, but these tests may not always detect changes that can lead to lasting decreases. it is best to receive chloramphenicol injection in a hospital so you can be closely monitored. chloramphenicol injection should not be used if another antibiotic can treat your infection. it must not be used for minor infections, colds, flu, routine sore throats, or to prevent infection. discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? chloramphenicol injection is used to treat certain serious bacterial infections when other antibiotics cannot be used. it belongs to a class of antibiotics that stop bacteria from growing. it does not treat colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when they are not needed increases the risk of future infections that resist treatment. how should this medicine be used? chloramphenicol injection is a liquid given by a healthcare professional into a vein, usually every 6 hours. the length of therapy depends on the type of infection. after you improve, your doctor may switch you to an antibiotic taken by mouth to complete treatment. you should start to feel better in the first few days. if you do not improve or if your symptoms worsen, call your doctor. use chloramphenicol injection for the full time prescribed, even if you feel better. stopping early or skipping doses may result in incomplete treatment and promote antibiotic resistance. other uses for this medicine: in the event of biological warfare, chloramphenicol injection may be used to treat or prevent serious illnesses such as plague, tularemia, and anthrax of the skin or mouth. ask your doctor about the risks of using this medicine for your condition. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving chloramphenicol injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to chloramphenicol or any other medicines. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take while receiving chloramphenicol; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you closely for side effects. tell your doctor if you have received chloramphenicol before, especially if you had severe side effects; you may be advised not to use it. tell your doctor if you have or have had liver or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while receiving chloramphenicol, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, tell the doctor or dentist that you are receiving chloramphenicol injection. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given on a schedule by healthcare professionals. if a dose is missed or delayed, contact your doctor or the treating facility as soon as possible. do not try to make up a dose yourself. what side effects can this medication cause? chloramphenicol injection may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, sores of the tongue or mouth, headache, depression, confusion. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you experience any of the following or the symptoms listed in the important warning: hives; rash; itching; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; hoarseness; trouble swallowing or breathing; watery or bloody stools up to 2 months after treatment; stomach cramps; muscle aches or weakness; sweating; numbness, pain, or tingling in an arm or leg; sudden changes in vision; pain with eye movement. chloramphenicol injection can cause a condition called gray syndrome in premature and newborn infants; it has also been reported in children up to age 2 and in newborns whose mothers were treated with chloramphenicol during labor. symptoms, usually after 3 to 4 days of treatment, may include abdominal bloating, vomiting, bluish lips or skin due to low blood oxygen, low blood pressure, breathing difficulty, and death. if treatment is stopped at the first sign of symptoms, they may resolve and the infant may recover fully. discuss the risks of using this medicine during labor or in infants and young children with your doctor. chloramphenicol injection may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: chlordiazepoxide and clidinium
instructions: important warning: chlordiazepoxide may increase the risk of serious or life-threatening breathing problems, profound sedation, or coma when used with certain opioid medications. tell your doctor if you take or plan to take opioid cough medicines such as codeine in triacin-c or tuzistra xr, or hydrocodone in anexsia, norco, or zyfrel, and opioid pain medicines such as codeine in fiorinal, fentanyl actiq, duragesic, or subsys, hydromorphone dilaudid or exalgo, meperidine demerol, methadone dolophine or methadose, morphine astramorph, duramorph pf, or kadian, oxycodone in oxycet, percocet, or roxicet, and tramadol conzip, ultram, or ultracet. your doctor may need to adjust doses and will monitor you carefully. if you take chlordiazepoxide and clidinium with any of these medicines and develop unusual dizziness, lightheadedness, extreme sleepiness, slowed or difficult breathing, or unresponsiveness, call your doctor or seek emergency medical care right away. make sure caregivers or family members know these serious symptoms so they can get help if you cannot. chlordiazepoxide may be habit forming. do not take larger doses, take it more often, or use it longer than prescribed, especially if you have ever drunk large amounts of alcohol, used street drugs, or misused prescription medications. do not drink alcohol or use street drugs during treatment, as this increases the risk of serious, life-threatening side effects. if you have or have ever had depression or another mental illness, tell your doctor. chlordiazepoxide can cause physical dependence, and unpleasant symptoms can occur if it is stopped suddenly or the dose is reduced, especially after several days to several weeks of use. do not stop this medication or reduce your dose without talking to your doctor. stopping suddenly can worsen your condition and cause withdrawal symptoms that may last for several weeks to more than 12 months. your doctor will decrease your dose gradually. call your doctor or get emergency help if you experience any of the following: unusual movements; ringing in the ears; anxiety; memory problems; difficulty concentrating; sleep problems; seizures; shaking; muscle twitching; changes in mental health; depression; burning or prickling in hands, arms, legs, or feet; seeing or hearing things others do not; thoughts of harming or killing yourself or others; overexcitement; or losing touch with reality. why is this medication prescribed? the combination of chlordiazepoxide and clidinium is used with other medications to treat peptic ulcers, irritable bowel syndrome ibs, and enterocolitis swelling in the intestines. chlordiazepoxide is a benzodiazepine that decreases abnormal electrical activity in the brain. clidinium is an anticholinergic that helps decrease stomach spasms and cramps. how should this medicine be used? chlordiazepoxide and clidinium comes as a capsule to take by mouth, usually three or four times a day, before meals and at bedtime. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully. ask your doctor or pharmacist if you do not understand anything. take this medicine exactly as directed. your doctor or pharmacist will give you the medication guide when you begin treatment and each time you refill. read it carefully and ask questions if needed. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking chlordiazepoxide and clidinium, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to chlordiazepoxide, clidinium, any other medications, or any ingredients in the capsules. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you for side effects. do not take this medicine if you are taking or have taken within the past 14 days any monoamine oxidase inhibitors maois such as isocarboxazid marplan, linezolid zyvox, methylene blue, phenelzine nardil, selegiline eldepryl, emsam, zelapar, or tranylcypromine parnate. tell your doctor if you have glaucoma, prostatic hypertrophy enlarged prostate, or bladder neck obstruction, as your doctor will probably tell you not to take this medicine. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had vision problems, urinary problems, or kidney or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. if you become pregnant while taking this medication, call your doctor immediately. clidinium-containing medications may cause fetal harm. tell your doctor if you are breastfeeding, as clidinium-containing medications may decrease breast milk production. if you are 65 years of age or older, talk with your doctor about the risks and benefits. older adults should not usually take this combination because it may not be as safe or effective as other options. this medication may make you drowsy. do not drive a car or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your normal diet. do not drink alcohol while taking this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you take several doses per day and miss a dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? chlordiazepoxide and clidinium may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: weakness or tiredness, excitement, anger, dry mouth, blurred vision or other vision changes, constipation, nausea, difficulty urinating, changes in sex drive or ability, irregular menstrual cycles, coordination problems, or confusion. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following or any symptoms listed in the important warning section, call your doctor immediately: slow or difficult speech, shuffling walk, persistent fine tremor or inability to sit still, difficulty breathing or swallowing, rash, swelling of the arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, or yellowing of the skin or eyes.

name: chlorhexidine topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? chlorhexidine topical is used to reduce the number of bacteria on the skin. it is commonly used as needed to cleanse the skin or superficial wounds, and as a handwash for healthcare providers, especially before surgery or procedures. it belongs to a class of antiseptic/anti-infective agents and works by lowering skin bacteria. how should this medicine be used? chlorhexidine comes as a solution to apply to the skin and is also available in chlorhexidine-containing wipes and sponges. use it only on the skin exactly as directed on the product label or by your healthcare provider. do not use more, use less, or use it more often than recommended. ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain any instructions you do not understand and for the manufacturer’s patient information. what special precautions should i follow? before using chlorhexidine topical, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to chlorhexidine, to any other medicines, or to any ingredients in the product; check the package for a full ingredient list. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, discuss use with your healthcare provider. use with particular care in premature infants and infants under 2 years of age, as irritation or burns may occur. keep the product out of the eyes, ears, and mouth; if contact occurs, rinse immediately with plenty of cold water. do not use in the genital area, on the meninges (membranes around the brain and spinal cord), or on deep or puncture wounds. do not repeatedly clean large areas of the body unless directed by your doctor. chlorhexidine can cause stains on fabrics when used with chlorine-releasing laundry products; rinse fabrics thoroughly and use non-chlorine detergents. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you use chlorhexidine on a regular schedule and miss a dose, apply it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next scheduled application, skip the missed dose and resume your usual schedule. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. if you use it only as needed, apply when needed. what side effects can this medication cause? chlorhexidine may cause side effects such as mild skin irritation or redness. some effects can be serious. stop using chlorhexidine and call your doctor right away or get emergency medical care if you develop hives, rash, wheezing, difficulty breathing, dizziness, or swelling of the face. chlorhexidine may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice any unusual or bothersome problems.

name: chloroquine phosphate
instructions: notice: chloroquine has been studied for the treatment and prevention of covid-19. the fda issued an emergency use authorization (eua) on march 28, 2020 to allow distribution of chloroquine for hospitalized adults and adolescents who weigh at least 110 pounds (50 kg) and could not participate in a clinical study, but the fda revoked this eua on june 15, 2020 because clinical studies showed chloroquine is unlikely to be effective for covid-19 in these patients and serious side effects, including dangerous irregular heartbeats, were reported. the fda and nih state chloroquine should only be used for covid-19 under a doctor’s direction in a clinical study. do not buy this medication online without a prescription. if you experience irregular heartbeats, dizziness, or fainting while taking chloroquine, call 911. for other side effects or concerns, contact your doctor. do not use chloroquine products intended for veterinary or aquarium use to treat or prevent covid-19; serious injury and death have occurred from misuse. why is this medication prescribed? chloroquine phosphate is used to prevent and treat malaria and to treat amebiasis. it belongs to a class of drugs called antimalarials and amebicides and works by killing the organisms that cause malaria and amebiasis. how should this medicine be used? chloroquine phosphate is taken by mouth as tablets. for prevention of malaria in adults, take one dose once a week on the same day each week. begin 2 weeks before travel to an area where malaria is common, continue weekly while in the area, and for 8 weeks after leaving. if you cannot start 2 weeks before travel, your doctor may direct you to take a double first dose right away. for treatment of sudden, severe malaria attacks in adults, take one dose immediately, then one-half of that dose 6 to 8 hours later, followed by one-half of the original dose once daily for the next 2 days. for prevention and treatment of malaria in infants and children, dosing is based on body weight; your doctor will calculate and direct the correct amount. for treatment of amebiasis, take one dose daily for 2 days, then one-half of that dose daily for 2 to 3 weeks, usually combined with other amebicides. chloroquine phosphate can upset the stomach; take with food. follow your prescription label exactly. do not take more or less, or more often, than prescribed. other uses for this medicine: chloroquine phosphate is sometimes used to reduce symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis and to treat systemic and discoid lupus erythematosus, sarcoidosis, and porphyria cutanea tarda. discuss the potential risks and benefits with your doctor. this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for details. what special precautions should i follow? before taking chloroquine phosphate, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to chloroquine phosphate, chloroquine hydrochloride, hydroxychloroquine (plaquenil), or any other medications. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. if you take antacids, take them 4 hours before or 4 hours after chloroquine. if you take ampicillin, take it at least 2 hours before or 2 hours after chloroquine. the nonprescription product cimetidine (tagamet) may interact with chloroquine; inform your doctor and pharmacist before starting it, and do not begin it while on chloroquine without your healthcare provider’s guidance. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver disease, heart disease, prolonged qt interval, irregular heartbeat, low blood magnesium or potassium, g-6-pd deficiency, hearing problems, porphyria or other blood disorders, psoriasis, seizures, vision problems, diabetes, weakness in your knees or ankles, or if you drink large amounts of alcohol. tell your doctor if you have ever had vision changes while taking chloroquine phosphate, chloroquine hydrochloride, or hydroxychloroquine. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or become pregnant while taking chloroquine. if you are breastfeeding or plan to breastfeed, discuss the risks, as chloroquine can harm a nursing infant. do not receive any vaccinations without talking to your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet while taking chloroquine phosphate. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? side effects can occur. common effects include headache, nausea, loss of appetite, diarrhea, upset stomach, stomach pain, rash, itching, and hair loss. call your doctor immediately if you experience any of the following: flashes or streaks of light, blurred vision, difficulty reading or seeing (such as words disappearing, seeing only half an object, misty or foggy vision), trouble hearing, ringing in the ears, muscle weakness, drowsiness, vomiting, irregular heartbeats, convulsions, difficulty breathing, mood or mental changes, decreased consciousness or loss of consciousness, or thoughts of harming yourself or suicide.

name: chlorpromazine
instructions: important warning: studies show that older adults with dementia who take antipsychotic medications, including chlorpromazine, have an increased risk of death during treatment. chlorpromazine is not approved by the u.s. food and drug administration (fda) for treating behavior problems in older adults with dementia. if you or someone you care for has dementia and is taking chlorpromazine, talk with the prescribing doctor. why is this medication prescribed? chlorpromazine is used to treat the symptoms of schizophrenia (disturbed or unusual thinking, loss of interest in life, strong or inappropriate emotions) and other psychotic disorders (difficulty distinguishing what is real from what is not). it is also used to treat the symptoms of mania (frenzied, abnormally excited mood) in people with bipolar disorder (manic-depressive illness). chlorpromazine is used to treat severe behavior problems (such as explosive, aggressive behavior and hyperactivity) in children 1 to 12 years of age; to control nausea and vomiting; to relieve hiccups that have lasted one month or longer; and to relieve restlessness and nervousness before surgery. it is also used to treat acute intermittent porphyria (a condition in which certain natural substances build up and cause stomach pain, and changes in thinking and behavior) and, along with other medications, to treat tetanus (a serious infection that may cause muscle tightening, especially of the jaw). chlorpromazine is a conventional antipsychotic. it works by changing the activity of certain natural substances in the brain and other parts of the body. how should this medicine be used? chlorpromazine comes as a tablet to take by mouth and is usually taken 2 to 4 times a day. for nausea and vomiting, take every 4 to 6 hours as needed. for nervousness before surgery, take 2 to 3 hours before surgery. for hiccups, take 3 to 4 times a day for up to 3 days or until the hiccups stop; if they do not stop after 3 days, a different medication should be used. if you take chlorpromazine on a regular schedule, take it at the same times each day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully. take chlorpromazine exactly as directed. do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed. your doctor may start you on a low dose and gradually increase it; once your condition is controlled, your dose may be decreased. be sure to tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. if you are taking chlorpromazine for schizophrenia or another psychotic disorder, it may control symptoms but will not cure the condition. continue to take it even if you feel well. do not stop taking chlorpromazine without talking to your doctor. your dose will probably be decreased gradually. suddenly stopping may cause withdrawal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, dizziness, and shakiness. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking chlorpromazine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to chlorpromazine; other phenothiazines such as fluphenazine, perphenazine, prochlorperazine (compazine), promethazine (phenergan), thioridazine, or trifluoperazine; or any other medications. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had asthma; emphysema (a lung disease that causes shortness of breath); an infection in your lungs or bronchial tubes; trouble keeping your balance; glaucoma (increased pressure in the eye); breast cancer; pheochromocytoma (a tumor on a small gland near the kidneys); seizures; an abnormal electroencephalogram (eeg); any condition that affects bone marrow or blood cell production; or heart, liver, or kidney disease. also tell your doctor if you have ever had to stop taking a medication for mental illness due to severe side effects or if you plan to work with organophosphorus insecticides. if you will be using chlorpromazine to treat nausea and vomiting, tell your doctor about any other symptoms you are experiencing, especially listlessness; drowsiness; confusion; aggression; seizures; headaches; problems with vision, hearing, speech, or balance; stomach pain or cramps; or constipation. nausea and vomiting with these symptoms may be a sign of a more serious condition that should not be treated with chlorpromazine. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, especially in the last months of pregnancy, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking chlorpromazine, call your doctor. taking chlorpromazine during the last months of pregnancy may cause problems in newborns after delivery. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking chlorpromazine. if you are having a myelogram (an x-ray examination of the spine), tell the radiology staff that you are taking chlorpromazine. your doctor will probably tell you not to take chlorpromazine for 2 days before and for 1 day after the myelogram. you should know that this medication may make you drowsy and may affect your thinking and movements. do not drive a car or operate machinery until you know how chlorpromazine affects you. ask your doctor about the safe use of alcohol; alcohol can make the side effects of chlorpromazine worse. avoid unnecessary or prolonged exposure to sunlight and wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen; chlorpromazine may make your skin sensitive to sunlight. you should know that chlorpromazine may cause dizziness, lightheadedness, fast heartbeat, and fainting, especially when you get up too quickly from a lying position. this is most common at the beginning of treatment, especially after the first dose. to help prevent this, get out of bed slowly, letting your feet rest on the floor for a few minutes before standing. you should also know that chlorpromazine may make it harder for your body to cool down in very hot weather; use caution if you plan vigorous exercise or exposure to extreme heat. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you take chlorpromazine on a regular schedule and miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. however, if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? chlorpromazine may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: dizziness, feeling unsteady, or trouble keeping your balance; blank facial expression; shuffling walk; restlessness; agitation; nervousness; unusual, slowed, or uncontrollable movements of any part of the body; difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep; increased appetite; weight gain; breast milk production; breast enlargement; missed menstrual periods; decreased sexual ability; changes in skin color; dry mouth; stuffy nose; difficulty urinating; widening or narrowing of the pupils; black circles in the middle of the eyes. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following, call your doctor immediately: fever; muscle stiffness; falling; confusion; fast or irregular heartbeat; sweating; yellowing of the skin or eyes; flu-like symptoms; sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection; unusual bleeding or bruising; neck cramps; tongue that sticks out of the mouth; tightness in the throat; difficulty breathing or swallowing; fine, worm-like tongue movements; uncontrollable, rhythmic face, mouth, or jaw movements; seizures; blisters; rash; hives; itching; swelling of the eyes, face, mouth, lips, tongue, throat, arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; vision loss (especially at night); or seeing everything with a brown tint.

name: chlorpropamide
instructions: notice: chlorpropamide is no longer available in the united states. why is this medication prescribed? chlorpropamide is used along with diet and exercise, and sometimes with other medications, to treat type 2 diabetes, a condition in which the body does not use insulin normally and cannot control blood sugar. it is a sulfonylurea that lowers blood sugar by causing the pancreas to release insulin and by helping the body use insulin more effectively. it only helps people whose bodies naturally produce insulin. it is not used to treat type 1 diabetes or diabetic ketoacidosis. managing high blood sugar can reduce the risk of serious complications such as heart disease, stroke, kidney problems, nerve damage, and eye problems. medications, lifestyle changes such as diet, exercise, and quitting smoking, and routine blood sugar monitoring can help manage diabetes and lower the risk of heart attack, stroke, and other diabetes-related complications. your healthcare team will advise you on the best plan for your diabetes. how should this medicine be used? chlorpropamide comes as an oral tablet. it is usually taken once daily with breakfast. if it upsets your stomach, your doctor may instruct you to take smaller doses twice daily with meals. take it at the same time each day. follow the prescription label and your provider’s directions exactly. do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. your doctor will likely start with a low dose and increase it as needed. over time, it may not control blood sugar as well, and your doctor may adjust the dose. tell your doctor how you are feeling and whether your blood sugar results have been higher or lower than usual at any time. chlorpropamide helps control blood sugar but does not cure diabetes. continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine this medication is sometimes prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking chlorpropamide, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to chlorpropamide, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. some nonprescription products can interact with chlorpropamide, including salicylate pain relievers such as choline magnesium trisalicylate, choline salicylate arthropan, diflunisal dolobid, magnesium salicylate doan’s and others, salsalate argesic, disalcid, salgesic, niacin, aspirin, and other nsaids such as ibuprofen advil, motrin and naproxen aleve. do not start these while taking chlorpropamide without discussing with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had g6pd deficiency or hemolytic anemia, hormone disorders involving the adrenal, pituitary, or thyroid glands, or heart, kidney, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking chlorpropamide, call your doctor. adults 65 years and older should generally not take chlorpropamide because it is not as safe or effective as other options. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you take chlorpropamide. ask your doctor about alcohol use while on this medication; alcohol can worsen side effects and may cause flushing, headache, nausea, vomiting, chest pain, weakness, blurred vision, confusion, sweating, choking, breathing difficulty, and anxiety. avoid unnecessary or prolonged sunlight exposure and wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen because chlorpropamide may increase sun sensitivity. ask your doctor what to do if you get sick, develop an infection or fever, experience unusual stress, or are injured, as these can affect blood sugar and the dose you need. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow the exercise and dietary plan recommended by your doctor or dietitian. eat a healthy diet, exercise regularly, and lose weight if advised. what should i do if i forget a dose? before starting chlorpropamide, ask your doctor what to do if you miss a dose and write down the instructions. in general, take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose. what side effects can this medication cause? this medication may change your blood sugar. know the signs of low and high blood sugar and what to do if they occur. chlorpropamide may cause side effects. common side effects include nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, hunger, dizziness, headache, and itching. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have yellowing of the skin or eyes, light-colored stools, dark urine, pain in the upper right abdomen, unusual bruising or bleeding, diarrhea, fever, sore throat, or rash. chlorpropamide may cause other side effects. contact your doctor if you experience anything unusual.

name: chlorthalidone
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? chlorthalidone is a diuretic ('water pill') used to lower high blood pressure and to treat fluid retention (edema) from conditions such as heart disease. it helps the kidneys remove extra water and salt in the urine. it may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? chlorthalidone comes as an oral tablet. it is usually taken once daily or every other day after a meal, preferably breakfast. take it in the morning to avoid nighttime urination. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully. take chlorthalidone exactly as directed; do not take more or less, or take it more often, than prescribed. chlorthalidone controls high blood pressure but does not cure it. continue to take it even if you feel well, and do not stop without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine chlorthalidone may also be used to treat diabetes insipidus and certain electrolyte disturbances, and to help prevent kidney stones in people with high calcium levels. discuss the possible risks and benefits with your doctor. what special precautions should i follow? before taking chlorthalidone, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to chlorthalidone, sulfa (sulfonamide) drugs, or any other medicines. if you are taking cholestyramine or colestipol, take those at least 1 hour after chlorthalidone. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. the following nonprescription products may interact with chlorthalidone: nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin) and naproxen (aleve, naprosyn). make sure your doctor and pharmacist know if you take these medicines, and do not start them while taking chlorthalidone without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had diabetes, gout, or kidney, liver, thyroid, or parathyroid disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking chlorthalidone, call your doctor right away. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking chlorthalidone. this drug may cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. alcohol can increase drowsiness. avoid unnecessary or prolonged sun exposure and wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen, because chlorthalidone can make your skin more sensitive to sunlight. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow your doctor's directions. these may include a daily exercise program, a low-salt or low-sodium diet, potassium supplements, and increasing potassium-rich foods (for example, bananas, prunes, raisins, and orange juice). what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? increased urination is common and usually improves after a few weeks. if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away, contact your doctor: muscle weakness, dizziness, cramps, thirst, stomach pain, upset stomach, vomiting, diarrhea, loss of appetite, headache, or hair loss. call your doctor immediately if you experience any of the following: sore throat with fever, unusual bleeding or bruising, severe skin rash with peeling skin, or difficulty breathing or swallowing. for the drug chlorthalidone

name: chlorzoxazone
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? chlorzoxazone is used to relieve muscle pain and stiffness from strains and sprains. it is typically used along with rest, physical therapy, and pain relievers such as aspirin or acetaminophen. how should this medicine be used? chlorzoxazone comes as an oral tablet usually taken three or four times daily. follow the directions on your prescription label exactly, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not take more or less than prescribed, and do not take it more often than directed. what special precautions should i follow? before taking chlorzoxazone, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to chlorzoxazone or any other medications. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, discuss the risks and benefits; call your doctor if you become pregnant while taking chlorzoxazone. if you are 65 years of age or older, talk with your doctor; older adults usually should not take chlorzoxazone because it may be less safe or effective than other options. this medicine can cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. ask your doctor about alcohol use while taking chlorzoxazone, as alcohol can worsen side effects. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? chlorzoxazone may cause side effects. your urine may turn red or purple; this is not harmful. common effects include upset stomach, drowsiness, dizziness, lightheadedness, and weakness. call your doctor right away if you develop a skin rash or itching, yellowing of the skin or eyes, or stomach pain.

name: cholecalciferol (vitamin d3)
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cholecalciferol (vitamin d3) is used as a dietary supplement when vitamin d from diet and sun exposure is not sufficient. people at higher risk of deficiency include older adults, breastfed infants, people with dark skin, those with obesity, those with limited sun exposure, and people with gastrointestinal diseases (such as crohn’s disease or celiac disease). cholecalciferol is also used with calcium to prevent and treat bone diseases such as rickets (softening/weakening of bones in children due to lack of vitamin d), osteomalacia (softening/weakening of bones in adults due to lack of vitamin d), and osteoporosis (thin, weak bones that break easily). it belongs to a class of medications called vitamin d analogs and supports healthy bones, muscles, nerves, and the immune system by helping the body absorb and use calcium. how should this medicine be used? cholecalciferol (vitamin d3) comes as a capsule, softgel, chewable gummy, tablet, and liquid drops to take by mouth. it is usually taken once or twice daily depending on the product, your age, and your medical condition. it is available without a prescription, but your doctor may prescribe it for certain conditions. check with your doctor or pharmacist before taking a vitamin d3 supplement. take it at the same time each day. follow the directions on your product label or your doctor’s instructions carefully. do not take more or less or take it more often than directed. liquid drops may be added to a child’s food or drink. cholecalciferol is available alone, in combination with other vitamins, and in combination with medications. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cholecalciferol, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cholecalciferol, any other medications, or any ingredients in the product; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had hyperparathyroidism (too much parathyroid hormone), kidney disease, or high blood calcium levels. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking cholecalciferol, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? when cholecalciferol is used to prevent or treat bone disease, consume adequate amounts of calcium-rich foods and drinks. if you cannot meet calcium needs through diet, your doctor may recommend a calcium supplement. unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular dosing schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? cholecalciferol may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of the following are severe or do not go away: loss of appetite, weight loss, nausea, vomiting, constipation. cholecalciferol may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: cholera vaccine (vaxchora)
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? the cholera vaccine helps reduce the risk of illness from cholera, a bacterial disease that can cause severe diarrhea and vomiting leading to dehydration and death if untreated. it is mainly recommended for adults 18 through 64 years old who are traveling to areas with active cholera transmission (for example, haiti and parts of africa, asia, and the pacific). cholera is rare among u.s. residents but has occurred after eating raw or undercooked gulf coast seafood. the vaccine was very effective in studies at preventing severe or life-threatening cholera, but it is not 100% effective and does not protect against other food- or water-borne diseases. how should this medicine be used? the u.s. cholera vaccine is an oral (swallowed) single-dose vaccine; booster doses are not currently recommended. most travelers do not need cholera vaccine; your healthcare provider may recommend it if you are traveling to an area where people are becoming infected with cholera. follow your provider’s instructions exactly. what special precautions should i follow? do not receive this vaccine if you have had a life-threatening allergic reaction to a previous cholera vaccine dose or to any component of this vaccine. tell your healthcare provider about any severe allergies. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, the risks are not well known; if you are vaccinated and later learn you were pregnant at the time, you may contact the pregnancy registry at 1-800-533-5899. tell your provider if you took antibiotics in the 14 days before vaccination, as they can make the vaccine less effective. do not take the antimalarial chloroquine (aralen) with this vaccine; wait at least 10 days after vaccination before taking antimalarial drugs. if you have a mild illness (such as a cold), you can usually be vaccinated; if you are moderately or severely ill, wait until you recover. wash your hands thoroughly after using the bathroom and before preparing or handling food, because the vaccine strain can be shed in stool for at least 7 days. what special dietary instructions should i follow? practice careful food and water hygiene when traveling; the vaccine is not a substitute for being careful about what you eat and drink, and safe practices help prevent cholera and other waterborne or foodborne illnesses. what should i do if i forget a dose? this vaccine is a single dose. if you planned to receive it before travel and missed it, contact your healthcare provider as soon as possible to discuss timing and whether vaccination is still recommended for your trip. what side effects can this medication cause? mild side effects can include abdominal pain, tiredness or fatigue, headache, decreased appetite, nausea, or diarrhea; these usually go away on their own within a few days. no serious problems in studies were considered related to the vaccine. however, any medication can rarely cause a severe allergic reaction (about 1 in a million doses), typically within minutes to hours. seek emergency care (call 9-1-1) for hives, swelling of the face or throat, difficulty breathing, fast heartbeat, dizziness, weakness, very high fever, or unusual behavior. afterward, report reactions to the vaccine adverse event reporting system (vaers) at vaers.hhs.gov or 1-800-822-7967; vaers does not provide medical advice. vaccine safety is continually monitored.

name: cholestyramine resin
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cholestyramine is used along with dietary changes that limit cholesterol and fat to reduce the amount of cholesterol and certain fatty substances in your blood. buildup of cholesterol and fats along artery walls (atherosclerosis) reduces blood flow and oxygen to the heart, brain, and other organs. lowering blood cholesterol and fats may help prevent heart disease, angina (chest pain), strokes, and heart attacks. this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? cholestyramine comes as a chewable bar and as a powder to be mixed with fluids or food. it is usually taken two to four times daily. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take cholestyramine exactly as directed; do not take more or less or more often than prescribed. take it before a meal and/or at bedtime, and take other medications at least 1 hour before or 4 hours after cholestyramine because it can interfere with their absorption. continue taking cholestyramine even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor. do not take the powder dry. to take the powder: stir it into a glass of water, milk, heavy or pulpy fruit juice (such as orange juice), or another beverage. if using a carbonated beverage, mix slowly in a large glass to avoid foaming. drink the mixture slowly, then rinse the glass with more beverage and drink to ensure you receive the full dose. the powder may also be mixed with applesauce, crushed pineapple, pureed fruit, or soup. although it may be mixed into hot foods, do not heat the powder itself. for taste and convenience, you may prepare an entire day’s doses the night before and refrigerate them. for chewable bars, chew each bite thoroughly before swallowing. drink plenty of fluids while taking this medication. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cholestyramine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cholestyramine or any other drugs. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had heart disease (especially angina), stomach, intestinal, or gallbladder disease, or phenylketonuria. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding; if you become pregnant while taking cholestyramine, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking cholestyramine. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow a low-fat, low-cholesterol diet and adhere to all exercise and dietary recommendations provided by your doctor or dietitian. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cholestyramine may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of the following are severe or do not go away: constipation, bloating, stomach pain, gas, upset stomach, vomiting, diarrhea, loss of appetite, heartburn, or indigestion. if you experience unusual bleeding (such as from the gums or rectum), call your doctor immediately.

name: choline magnesium trisalicylate
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? choline magnesium trisalicylate is used to relieve pain, tenderness, swelling, inflammation, and stiffness caused by arthritis and painful shoulder. it is also used to reduce fever and relieve general pain. it belongs to the salicylate class of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) and works by blocking the body’s production of substances that cause pain, fever, and inflammation. how should this medicine be used? choline magnesium trisalicylate comes as tablets and a liquid taken by mouth, usually one to three times a day. take it at the same times each day to help you remember. follow your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. take exactly as directed; do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. what special precautions should i follow? before taking choline magnesium trisalicylate, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to choline magnesium trisalicylate; aspirin; choline salicylate (arthropan); diflunisal (dolobid); magnesium salicylate (doan’s, others); salsalate (argesic, disalcid, salgesic); or any other medications. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. nonprescription salicylate pain relievers—including aspirin, choline salicylate (arthropan), diflunisal (dolobid), magnesium salicylate (doan’s, others), and salsalate (argesic, disalcid, salgesic)—may interact with this medication; do not start any of these while taking choline magnesium trisalicylate without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had stomach problems such as ulcers, or kidney or liver disease. children and teenagers with chickenpox or the flu should not take this medication because of the risk of reye syndrome, a rare but serious illness. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while taking this medicine, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking choline magnesium trisalicylate. ask your doctor about safe use of alcohol while taking this medication; alcohol can worsen side effects. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? choline magnesium trisalicylate may cause side effects. common side effects include upset stomach, vomiting, heartburn, diarrhea, constipation, stomach pain, headache, lightheadedness, dizziness, drowsiness, and lack of energy. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor immediately if you experience ringing in the ears, hearing loss, black or tarry stools, bright red blood in stools, bloody vomit, or vomit that looks like coffee grounds. this medication may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: ciclesonide nasal spray
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ciclesonide nasal spray is used to relieve symptoms of seasonal (occurring at certain times of the year) and perennial (occurring year-round) allergic rhinitis, including sneezing and a stuffy, runny, or itchy nose. it is a corticosteroid that works by preventing and reducing inflammation in the nasal passages. how should this medicine be used? ciclesonide comes as a liquid solution to spray into the nose. it is usually used once daily in each nostril at about the same time each day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully and use exactly as directed. do not use more, less, or more often than prescribed. for intranasal use only; do not swallow the spray and avoid spraying it into your eyes or directly onto the nasal septum (the wall between the nostrils). ciclesonide controls symptoms but does not cure rhinitis; improvement may begin after 24–48 hours, with full benefit possibly taking longer. continue to use it even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor. each bottle delivers 120 sprays after initial priming and must be discarded 4 months after the bottle is removed from the foil pouch; write the discard date on the provided sticker and place it on the bottle. keep track of sprays used and discard after 120 sprays even if liquid remains. to use the spray: 1) shake gently and remove the dust cover. 2) before first use, prime by pointing away from your body and pressing down and releasing the pump 8 times; if not used for 4 days or more, press down and release once or until a fine mist appears. 3) blow your nose to clear your nostrils. 4) close one nostril with a finger. 5) hold the bottle with your forefinger and middle finger on either side of the spray tip and your thumb on the base. 6) tilt your head slightly forward, keep the bottle upright, and gently insert the tip into the open nostril. 7) begin to breathe in through your nose; while inhaling, press down quickly and firmly to release a spray. 8) repeat in the other nostril unless your doctor tells you otherwise. 9) wipe the applicator tip with a clean tissue and replace the dust cover. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using ciclesonide nasal spray, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to ciclesonide; to other nasal corticosteroids such as beclomethasone, budesonide, fluticasone, mometasone, or triamcinolone; or to any medications. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had tuberculosis, cataracts, glaucoma; if you have sores in your nose; any untreated infection; or a herpes infection of the eye; and if you have recently had nasal surgery or injury. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while using ciclesonide. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are using ciclesonide. if you have been taking oral steroids (such as dexamethasone, methylprednisolone, prednisolone, or prednisone), your doctor may gradually reduce your oral steroid dose after you start ciclesonide. special caution is needed for several months as your body adjusts. conditions such as asthma, arthritis, or eczema may worsen when the oral steroid dose is reduced; contact your doctor if this happens or if you develop any of the following: extreme tiredness; muscle weakness or pain; sudden pain in the stomach, lower body, or legs; loss of appetite; weight loss; nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea; dizziness; fainting; depression; irritability; or darkening of the skin. during this time your body may be less able to cope with stress such as illness, severe asthma attack, surgery, or injury; call your doctor right away if you become ill and make sure all healthcare providers know you recently switched from an oral steroid to ciclesonide nasal spray. carry a card or wear a medical identification bracelet stating that you may need steroids in an emergency. ciclesonide may decrease your ability to fight infection; avoid close contact with people who are sick and wash your hands often. be especially careful to avoid exposure to chickenpox or measles; contact your doctor right away if you are exposed. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? ciclesonide may cause side effects. common effects include headache, nosebleeds, and burning or irritation in the nose, and earache. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor immediately if you have painful white patches in the nose or throat, flu-like symptoms, vision problems, injury to the nose, new or increased acne, easy bruising, a rounded or enlarged face or neck, extreme tiredness, muscle weakness, irregular menstrual periods, hives, rash, itching, swelling of the face, throat, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, hoarseness, difficulty breathing or swallowing, or wheezing. ciclesonide may cause children to grow more slowly; it is not known whether this affects final adult height; talk to your doctor about the risks. ciclesonide may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: ciclesonide oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ciclesonide oral inhalation is used to help prevent breathing problems such as shortness of breath, chest tightness, wheezing, and coughing caused by asthma in adults and in children 12 years and older. it is a corticosteroid that reduces inflammation and irritation in the airways to make breathing easier. how should this medicine be used? ciclesonide is an aerosol inhaled by mouth using its specific inhaler, typically twice daily at about the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly; do not use more, use less, or use it more often than prescribed. ask your doctor how to use your other asthma medicines (both oral and inhaled) while you are using ciclesonide, including whether to separate them by a certain amount of time. if you are on an oral steroid (such as dexamethasone, methylprednisolone [medrol], or prednisone [rayos]), your doctor may begin slowly reducing that dose starting at least 1 week after you begin ciclesonide. ciclesonide helps prevent asthma attacks but will not treat an attack that has already started; do not use it for sudden symptoms. your doctor will give you a quick-relief (short-acting) inhaler for asthma attacks. your doctor will usually start with a standard dose, may increase it if your symptoms are not better after at least 4 weeks, and may lower it once your asthma is controlled. it can take 4 weeks or longer to feel the full benefit. keep using it even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor. call your doctor if your asthma gets worse, if an attack does not improve with your rescue inhaler, or if you need your rescue medicine more often than usual. use only the inhaler that comes with the ciclesonide canister, and do not use that inhaler with any other medicine. each canister provides 60 inhalations. after the labeled number of doses, sprays may not deliver the correct amount. the attached counter changes every 10 sprays; when it shows 20, contact your doctor or pharmacist for a refill; when it shows 0, stop using that canister. track your daily inhalations to know how many sprays remain. discard the canister once you have used the labeled number of inhalations, even if liquid remains and it still sprays. if the inhaler is dropped, do not rely on the counter to estimate remaining doses. before first use, read the written instructions and review the diagrams; ask your doctor, pharmacist, or respiratory therapist to demonstrate proper technique. do not use the inhaler near open flames or heat sources; exposure to very high temperatures can cause it to explode. to use: make sure the inhaler is at room temperature. remove the mouthpiece cap and confirm the canister is fully seated in the actuator. you do not need to shake the inhaler. if this is the first use or if it has not been used for more than 10 days, prime it by releasing 3 sprays into the air away from your face and eyes. breathe out through your mouth. hold the inhaler upright with the mouthpiece at the bottom, place your thumb beneath the mouthpiece and your index finger on the center of the dose indicator at the top of the canister. place the mouthpiece in your mouth, close your lips around it with your tongue below it. breathe in slowly and deeply through your mouth while pressing down firmly on the top of the canister to release the dose. when your lungs are full, hold your breath for about 10 seconds, remove the inhaler, then exhale gently. replace the cap. rinse your mouth with water and spit it out; do not swallow. clean the inhaler weekly with a clean, dry tissue or cloth; do not wash any part of the inhaler in water. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to ciclesonide, other medications, or any ingredients in the inhaler (ask your pharmacist for a list). tell them about all prescription and over-the-counter medicines, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; your doses may need adjustment or you may need monitoring for side effects. do not use ciclesonide to treat an active asthma attack; use your fast-acting rescue inhaler instead. call your doctor if an attack does not improve after rescue medication or if you need your rescue inhaler more often than usual. tell your doctor if you have been on prolonged bedrest or are unable to be active, or if you or a family member has osteoporosis; and if you have or have ever had tuberculosis, seizures, cataracts, glaucoma, any untreated infection, or herpes infection of the eye. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call if you become pregnant while using ciclesonide. before any surgery, including dental procedures, tell the clinician you use ciclesonide. if your oral steroid dose is being reduced, conditions such as asthma, arthritis, or eczema may flare. during this period, watch for symptoms of adrenal insufficiency such as extreme fatigue, muscle weakness or pain, sudden pain in the stomach, lower body, or legs, loss of appetite, weight loss, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, dizziness, fainting, mood changes such as depression or irritability, or skin darkening; your body may handle stress (illness, surgery, severe asthma attack, or injury) less well. call your doctor right away if you become ill, and make sure all healthcare providers know you recently switched from an oral steroid; consider carrying a medical id noting you may need steroids in an emergency. if you have never had chickenpox or measles and are not vaccinated, avoid people who are ill, especially with those infections; if exposed or if symptoms develop, call your doctor promptly—preventive treatment may be needed. be aware that ciclesonide can rarely cause immediate wheezing or breathing difficulty right after inhalation; if this occurs, use your rescue inhaler right away and call your doctor. do not use ciclesonide again unless your doctor advises you to do so. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you different instructions, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? ciclesonide may cause side effects. common effects include headache, stuffy or runny nose, sore or irritated throat, swelling or irritation of the nose, throat, or sinuses, painful white patches in the mouth or throat (oral thrush), hoarseness, joint pain, and pain in the arms, back, or legs. serious reactions can occur. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have hives, rash, itching, swelling of the face, throat, tongue, or lips, trouble breathing or swallowing, or chest pain or tightness. in children, ciclesonide may slow growth; your child’s doctor will monitor growth—discuss risks and benefits. this medicine may increase the risk of glaucoma or cataracts; regular eye exams may be recommended. contact your doctor if you notice eye pain, redness, discomfort, blurred vision, halos or bright colors around lights, or any vision changes. ciclesonide may increase the risk of osteoporosis. other side effects may occur; talk to your doctor if you experience anything unusual or bothersome.

name: ciclopirox topical
