instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ciclopirox topical solution is prescribed, together with regular nail trimming, to treat fungal infections of the fingernails and toenails that can cause discoloration, splitting, and pain. it belongs to a class of antifungal medicines and works by inhibiting the growth of the fungus in the nail. how should this medicine be used? ciclopirox comes as a solution applied to affected nails and the surrounding and underlying skin. apply it once daily, ideally at the same time each day, usually at bedtime. use exactly as directed on your prescription label; do not use more or less or more often than prescribed. this treatment improves nail appearance and health but may not completely cure the fungus; visible improvement can take 6 months or longer. continue daily use as instructed and do not stop without talking to your doctor. keep nails trimmed throughout treatment. before starting and then weekly, remove loose or damaged nail material with clippers or a file as your doctor shows you; your doctor may also trim your nails about once monthly. apply only to the nails and the skin immediately around and under them; avoid contact with other skin areas and especially the eyes, nose, mouth, and vagina. do not use nail polish or other nail cosmetics on treated nails. do not bathe, shower, or swim for at least 8 hours after application. the solution is flammable; keep away from heat and open flames, including cigarettes. to apply: ensure nails are properly trimmed; use the brush in the cap to coat all affected nails evenly, including undersides and adjacent skin if accessible; wipe the bottle cap and neck and replace the cap tightly; allow to dry about 30 seconds before putting on socks or stockings. for each new daily dose, apply over the existing layer. once weekly, remove all layers with rubbing alcohol on a cotton pad or tissue, then trim or file away as much damaged nail as possible. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to ciclopirox or any medication, and provide a list of all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have ever had an organ transplant; recently had chickenpox; or have disorders that affect the immune system such as hiv, aids, or scid; cancer; cold sores; diabetes; flaky, itchy, or crusty skin conditions; genital herpes; shingles; fungal skin infections such as athlete’s foot or ringworm; peripheral vascular disease; or seizures. if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits; if you become pregnant during treatment, contact your doctor. keep nails clean and dry during treatment. do not share nail care tools. use separate tools for infected and healthy nails. if toenails are involved, wear well-fitting, low-heeled shoes, change socks frequently, and avoid going barefoot in public areas. wear protective shoes and gloves for sports, harsh cleaners, or tasks that may injure or irritate nails. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next application, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? ciclopirox topical solution may cause side effects. tell your doctor if redness at the application site is severe or does not go away. call your doctor immediately if you experience any of the following uncommon but serious effects: irritation, itching, burning, blistering, swelling, or oozing at the application site; pain in the affected nails or surrounding area; nail discoloration or changes in nail shape; or ingrown nails. ciclopirox topical solution may also cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual or bothersome.

name: cidofovir injection
instructions: important warning: cidofovir injection can cause kidney damage. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney disease, or if you are taking or recently took other medicines that may harm the kidneys, including amikacin; amphotericin b (abelcet, ambisome); foscarnet (foscavir); gentamicin; pentamidine (pentam 300); tobramycin; vancomycin (vancocin); and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin) and naproxen (naprosyn, aleve). your doctor will probably tell you not to use cidofovir injection if you are taking one or more of these medications. keep all appointments with your doctor and laboratory; tests will be done before, during, and after treatment to monitor your response. cidofovir has caused birth defects and problems with sperm production in animals; although not studied in humans, it could cause birth defects if used during pregnancy. do not use cidofovir injection while pregnant unless your doctor decides it is the best option. cidofovir has caused tumors in laboratory animals; discuss the potential risks with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? cidofovir injection is used with another medication, probenecid, to treat cytomegaloviral retinitis (cmv retinitis) in people with aids. cidofovir is an antiviral that slows the growth of cmv. how should this medicine be used? cidofovir injection is a liquid given intravenously by a doctor or nurse in a medical facility, usually once every 2 weeks. the length of treatment depends on your response. you must take probenecid tablets by mouth with each cidofovir dose: take one dose 3 hours before receiving cidofovir, and again 2 hours and 8 hours after the infusion is completed. take probenecid with food to reduce nausea and stomach upset. ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions about taking these medicines together. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using cidofovir injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cidofovir, probenecid (probalan, in col-probenecid), sulfa-containing medicines, any other medications, or any ingredients in the injection. some medicines should not be taken with cidofovir; others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. review all prescription, over-the-counter, and herbal products you use now or plan to use with your doctor and pharmacist before starting cidofovir, and consult them before starting, stopping, or changing any medication while using cidofovir. the following nonprescription products may interact with cidofovir: nsaids such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin) and naproxen (aleve). do not start these while using cidofovir without talking to your healthcare provider. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, use effective birth control during treatment and for 1 month after your final dose. if you are a male and your partner can become pregnant, use a barrier method (condom or diaphragm with spermicide) during treatment and for 3 months after your final dose. if you or your partner becomes pregnant while receiving cidofovir, call your doctor immediately. do not breastfeed if you have hiv/aids or while using cidofovir. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment for a cidofovir infusion or a scheduled probenecid dose, contact your doctor immediately for instructions. do not take extra probenecid or try to make up a missed infusion without medical guidance. what side effects can this medication cause? cidofovir injection may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: vomiting, nausea, diarrhea, loss of appetite, headache, hair loss, sores on the lips, mouth, or throat. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away if you have: rash; eye pain or redness; vision changes such as light sensitivity or blurred vision; fever, chills, or cough; shortness of breath; pale skin. cidofovir injection may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: cilostazol
instructions: important warning: medications similar to cilostazol have been associated with an increased risk of death in people with congestive heart failure (a condition in which the heart cannot pump enough blood to the body). if you have or have ever had congestive heart failure, your doctor will probably tell you not to take cilostazol. talk with your doctor about the risks and benefits of cilostazol. why is this medication prescribed? cilostazol is used to reduce the symptoms of intermittent claudication—leg pain that worsens with walking and improves with rest—caused by narrowing of the blood vessels that supply the legs. it is in a class of medicines called platelet-aggregation inhibitors (antiplatelet agents) and works by improving blood flow to the legs. how should this medicine be used? cilostazol comes as an oral tablet and is usually taken twice daily, at least 30 minutes before or 2 hours after breakfast and dinner. take it at the same times each day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully; ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take cilostazol exactly as prescribed—do not take more, less, or more often than directed. cilostazol controls symptoms but does not cure the condition. you may notice improvement within 2 to 4 weeks, but it can take up to 12 weeks to experience the full benefit (increased walking distance). continue taking cilostazol even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine this medication may sometimes be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cilostazol, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cilostazol, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you closely for side effects. the nonprescription medicine omeprazole (prilosec) may interact with cilostazol; do not start omeprazole while taking cilostazol without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have bleeding ulcers, bleeding in the brain, bleeding from any other site, a low platelet count, or any condition that causes severe bleeding—your doctor will probably tell you not to take cilostazol. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had heart, kidney, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking cilostazol, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take cilostazol on an empty stomach (at least 30 minutes before or 2 hours after meals). avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice unless your doctor tells you otherwise. unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? cilostazol may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: headache, diarrhea, dizziness, heartburn, nausea, stomach pain, muscle pain. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following, call your doctor immediately: fast or irregular heartbeat, unusual bleeding or bruising, or swelling of the arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs.

name: ciltacabtagene autoleucel injection
instructions: notice: special alert: the food and drug administration has received reports of t cell malignancies, including chimeric antigen receptor positive lymphoma, in patients treated with bcma or cd19 directed autologous car t cell therapies such as ciltacabtagene autoleucel. at this time, benefits still outweigh risks, but your doctor will monitor you during and after treatment. discuss any concerns with your healthcare provider. important warning: ciltacabtagene autoleucel can cause a serious or life threatening reaction called cytokine release syndrome. you will be monitored closely during the infusion and for at least 10 days afterward. tell your doctor if you have an inflammatory condition or if you have or suspect an infection. you will receive medications 30 to 60 minutes before the infusion to help prevent reactions. seek immediate medical attention during or after the infusion if you develop fever, chills, headache, fast or irregular heartbeat, muscle pain, shaking, diarrhea, tiredness, weakness, difficulty breathing, shortness of breath, cough, confusion, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, or lightheadedness. ciltacabtagene autoleucel may cause severe, life threatening, or fatal central nervous system reactions that can occur days, weeks, or months after treatment. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had seizures, a stroke, or memory loss. get medical help right away if you have dizziness, trouble falling or staying asleep, restlessness, confusion, anxiety, uncontrollable shaking, loss of consciousness, difficulty with handwriting, agitation, seizures, slow movements, personality change or loss of interest in usual activities, loss of coordination or balance, weakness, trouble speaking, or facial numbness. this medicine can cause severe decreases in certain blood cells, increasing the risk of serious infection or bleeding. tell your doctor if you have or recently had an infection. seek care right away if you develop fever, chills, other signs of infection, feel unusually tired, or have bruising or bleeding. ciltacabtagene autoleucel is available only through the carvykti rems risk evaluation and mitigation strategy due to the risks of cytokine release syndrome, central nervous system effects, and blood cell problems. you can receive it only from a certified doctor and healthcare facility that participates in the program. your doctor or pharmacist will give you the medication guide when you begin treatment and each time you receive the medication; read it carefully and ask questions. why is this medication prescribed? ciltacabtagene autoleucel is used to treat adults with multiple myeloma that has returned or did not respond after at least four other treatments. it is an autologous cellular immunotherapy made from your own blood cells and works by helping your immune system identify and attack cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? ciltacabtagene autoleucel is given as an intravenous suspension by a doctor or nurse in a hospital or infusion center, usually over 30 to 60 minutes as a one time dose. before your infusion, you will receive other chemotherapy medicines to prepare your body. before dosing, your white blood cells are collected at a cell collection center using leukapheresis. because this medicine is made from your own cells, it must be given only to you. be on time for all cell collection and treatment appointments. your healthcare provider will check you daily for at least 10 days after your dose to monitor for side effects, and you should plan to stay near the treating center for at least 4 weeks. your healthcare provider will assess how well the treatment is working and monitor for possible side effects. ask your doctor how to prepare for leukapheresis and what to expect during and after the procedure. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving ciltacabtagene autoleucel, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to ciltacabtagene autoleucel, any other medicines, dimethyl sulfoxide dmso, or any ingredient in the injection; ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had hepatitis b or c hbv or hcv, other viral infections such as cytomegalovirus or human immunodeficiency virus hiv, lung or breathing problems, or kidney, heart, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. you will need a pregnancy test before starting treatment, and you or your partner should not become pregnant while receiving ciltacabtagene autoleucel. if you become pregnant, call your doctor immediately; this medicine may harm the fetus. know that ciltacabtagene autoleucel can cause drowsiness, confusion, weakness, dizziness, seizures, and coordination problems; do not drive or operate machinery for at least 8 weeks after your dose. do not donate blood, organs, tissues, or cells for transplantation after receiving this therapy. ask your doctor if you need any vaccinations; do not receive any vaccines for at least 6 weeks before starting chemotherapy, during ciltacabtagene autoleucel treatment, and until your doctor tells you that your immune system has recovered. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss the appointment to collect your cells, call your doctor and the collection center right away. if you miss the appointment to receive your ciltacabtagene autoleucel dose, call your doctor immediately. what side effects can this medication cause? ciltacabtagene autoleucel may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: diarrhea, loss of appetite, joint, muscle, or bone pain, swelling, constipation. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment if you have any of the symptoms listed in the important warning section or develop rash, itching, hives, swelling of the face, mouth, tongue, or throat, chest pain, rapid heartbeat, or difficulty swallowing or breathing. ciltacabtagene autoleucel may increase your risk of certain cancers. talk to your doctor about these risks. this medicine may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving it.

name: cimetidine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cimetidine is used to treat ulcers; gastroesophageal reflux disease (gerd), a condition in which stomach acid flows backward and causes heartburn and injury to the esophagus; and conditions that cause excess stomach acid, such as zollinger-ellison syndrome. over-the-counter cimetidine is used to prevent and relieve heartburn associated with acid indigestion and sour stomach. cimetidine is in a class of medications called h2 blockers and works by reducing the amount of acid produced in the stomach. how should this medicine be used? cimetidine comes as a tablet and a liquid to take by mouth. it is usually taken once daily at bedtime or two to four times daily with meals and at bedtime. over-the-counter cimetidine is typically taken once or twice a day with a glass of water. to prevent symptoms, take it within 30 minutes before eating or drinking items that trigger heartburn. follow the directions on your prescription or the package label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. take cimetidine exactly as directed; do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. do not use over-the-counter cimetidine for longer than 2 weeks unless your doctor tells you to. if heartburn, acid indigestion, or sour stomach lasts longer than 2 weeks, stop taking cimetidine and call your doctor. other uses for this medicine cimetidine is sometimes used to treat stress ulcers, hives and itching, and viral warts, and to help prevent aspiration pneumonia during anesthesia. discuss the potential risks and benefits with your doctor. this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cimetidine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cimetidine or any other medications. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. if you take antacids (such as maalox, mylanta, tums), digoxin (lanoxin), ketoconazole (nizoral), or iron salts, take them 2 hours before cimetidine. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had human immunodeficiency virus (hiv), acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (aids), or kidney or liver disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, talk to your doctor; if you become pregnant while taking cimetidine, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cimetidine may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: headache, diarrhea, dizziness, drowsiness, breast enlargement. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following, call your doctor immediately: confusion, unusual excitement, depression, nervousness, or hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that are not there). cimetidine may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: cinacalcet
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cinacalcet is used alone or with other medicines to treat secondary hyperparathyroidism, a condition in which the body makes too much parathyroid hormone that can cause serious problems with the bones, heart, blood vessels, and lungs, in patients with chronic kidney disease who are receiving dialysis. cinacalcet is also used to treat high levels of calcium in the blood in patients with parathyroid cancer. cinacalcet belongs to a class of medicines called calcimimetics. it works by signaling the body to produce less parathyroid hormone, which lowers the amount of calcium in the blood. how should this medicine be used? cinacalcet comes as a tablet to take by mouth. it is usually taken once a day with food or shortly after a meal. to help you remember, take it at about the same time each day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. take cinacalcet exactly as directed. do not take more or less than prescribed, and do not take it more often than your doctor recommends. swallow the tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush them. your doctor will likely start you on a low dose and increase it gradually, not more than once every 2 to 4 weeks. cinacalcet helps control your condition but will not cure it. continue to take it even if you feel well. do not stop taking cinacalcet without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cinacalcet, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cinacalcet or any other medicines. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had seizures or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. if you become pregnant while taking cinacalcet, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? talk to your doctor about drinking grapefruit juice while taking this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember it. however, if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cinacalcet may cause side effects. if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away, tell your doctor: upset stomach, vomiting, diarrhea, dizziness, weakness, chest pain. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following, call your doctor immediately: burning, tingling, or unusual feelings of the lips, tongue, fingers, or feet; muscle aches or cramps; sudden tightening of the muscles in the hands, feet, face, or throat; seizures; infection of the dialysis access, the surgically created blood vessel where blood leaves and enters the body during dialysis. cinacalcet may cause other side effects.

name: cipaglucosidase alfa-atga
instructions: important warning: cipaglucosidase alfa-atga may cause severe hypersensitivity reactions, infusion-related reactions, or cardiorespiratory failure. tell your doctor if you currently feel ill, have any infection, or have or have had any cardiovascular or respiratory disease. seek medical help right away if you develop hives, itching, flushing, a weak and rapid heartbeat, swelling of the tongue or throat, difficulty breathing, dizziness or fainting, or loss of consciousness. your doctor may give you medicines before your infusion and will monitor you closely during and after treatment. cipaglucosidase alfa-atga must be administered by a healthcare provider in a monitored setting. why is this medication prescribed? cipaglucosidase alfa-atga is used with miglustat (opfolda) to treat late-onset pompe disease, a genetic condition that causes deficiency of lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase and can lead to muscle weakness and wasting, in adults who weigh 92 pounds (40 kg) or more and who have not been improving on their enzyme therapy. cipaglucosidase alfa-atga is a recombinant lysosomal enzyme that helps break glycogen down to glucose to prevent glycogen buildup in tissues. how should this medicine be used? cipaglucosidase alfa-atga comes as a powder that is mixed with water and given intravenously by a doctor or nurse in a hospital or clinic. it is usually infused over about 4 hours every other week. the infusion must be started 1 hour, and no later than 3 days, after you take a dose of miglustat by mouth. if you do not take your miglustat dose, you cannot receive your cipaglucosidase alfa-atga infusion. your doctor may recommend or give other medicines before each dose to help you tolerate treatment. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving cipaglucosidase alfa-atga, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cipaglucosidase alfa-atga, any other medications, or any ingredients in the product; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had heart or lung disease, if you currently feel unwell, or if you have any infection. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, do not become pregnant while receiving cipaglucosidase alfa-atga and for 60 days after your last dose; ask your doctor about effective birth control. if you become pregnant, call your doctor immediately; cipaglucosidase alfa-atga may harm the fetus. if you are able to become pregnant, your doctor will perform a pregnancy test before starting treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given by appointment. if you miss or cannot keep an infusion appointment, call your doctor right away to reschedule. do not attempt to receive cipaglucosidase alfa-atga unless you have taken the required dose of miglustat within the specified time window (start the infusion 1 hour to no later than 3 days after miglustat); your healthcare provider will tell you when to take miglustat and when to reschedule your infusion. what side effects can this medication cause? cipaglucosidase alfa-atga may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: headache, diarrhea, fever, bloating. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or get emergency medical help if you have difficulty breathing, rash, swelling of the legs or arms, swelling or tightness of the throat, tongue swelling, itching, flushing, or chills. cipaglucosidase alfa-atga may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: ciprofloxacin and dexamethasone otic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ciprofloxacin and dexamethasone otic is prescribed to treat outer ear infections in adults and children, and sudden middle ear infections in children with ear tubes. ciprofloxacin is a quinolone antibiotic, and dexamethasone is a corticosteroid. together they kill the bacteria causing the infection and reduce swelling in the ear. how should this medicine be used? this medicine is an ear-drop suspension. use it in the affected ear(s) twice daily—morning and evening—for 7 days, at about the same times each day. follow the directions on your prescription label; ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. use exactly as directed; do not use more, less, or more often than prescribed. for ears only; do not use in the eyes. you should start to feel better within the first few days. if symptoms do not improve after one week or get worse, call your doctor. continue until you finish the full prescription, even if you feel better; stopping early or skipping doses may result in incomplete treatment and antibiotic resistance. to apply the drops: 1) warm the bottle in your hand for 1–2 minutes. 2) shake well. 3) lie down with the affected ear facing up. 4) place the prescribed number of drops into the ear without touching the dropper tip to the ear, fingers, or any surface. 5) for middle ear infections, press the tragus (the small cartilage flap in front of the ear canal) inward four times to help the drops reach the middle ear. 6) remain lying with the affected ear up for 60 seconds. 7) repeat for the other ear if directed. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to ciprofloxacin (cipro), dexamethasone (decadron), or other quinolone antibiotics such as cinoxacin, enoxacin, gatifloxacin, gemifloxacin, levofloxacin, lomefloxacin, moxifloxacin, nalidixic acid, norfloxacin, ofloxacin, sparfloxacin, or trovafloxacin/alatrofloxacin, or to any other medications. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding; if you become pregnant while using this medicine, call your doctor. keep infected ears clean and dry during treatment. avoid getting the affected ears wet while bathing, and do not swim unless your doctor tells you it is okay. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use extra drops to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? possible side effects include ear discomfort, pain, or itching. some side effects can be serious. stop using the medication and call your doctor immediately if you develop rash; hives; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; hoarseness; or difficulty swallowing or breathing. this medication may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using it.

name: ciprofloxacin injection
instructions: important warning: using ciprofloxacin injection increases the risk of tendinitis (inflammation of the tendon that connects muscle to bone) and tendon rupture during treatment or for several months afterward. this can affect the shoulder, hand, achilles tendon, or other tendons. risk is higher in adults over 60 years, in people with kidney, heart, or lung transplants; kidney disease; prior joint or tendon problems (such as rheumatoid arthritis); and those who do regular physical activity. the risk also increases with oral or injectable steroids (for example, dexamethasone, methylprednisolone, prednisone). stop the medicine, rest the area, and call your doctor right away if you develop tendon pain, swelling, tenderness, stiffness, or trouble moving a muscle. get emergency care if you hear or feel a snap or pop, develop bruising after a tendon injury, or cannot move or bear weight on the area. ciprofloxacin injection can also cause peripheral neuropathy (nerve damage) that may begin soon after the first dose and may be permanent. do not use it if you have ever had peripheral neuropathy. stop the drug and call your doctor immediately for numbness, tingling, pain, burning, weakness in the arms or legs, or new trouble sensing light touch, vibration, pain, heat, or cold. ciprofloxacin injection can affect the brain and nervous system, sometimes after the first dose. tell your doctor if you have a history of seizures, epilepsy, cerebral arteriosclerosis, stroke or ministroke, structural brain changes, or kidney disease. stop the drug and call your doctor right away for seizures, tremors, dizziness, lightheadedness, persistent headache (with or without blurred vision), difficulty falling or staying asleep, nightmares, paranoia, hallucinations, suicidal thoughts or actions, restlessness, anxiety, nervousness, depression, memory problems, confusion, or other sudden mood or behavior changes. ciprofloxacin can worsen muscle weakness in people with myasthenia gravis and may cause severe breathing problems or death; if you have myasthenia gravis, your doctor may advise against this medicine. if prescribed despite myasthenia gravis, seek medical help immediately for new or worsening muscle weakness or breathing trouble. discuss the risks of ciprofloxacin with your doctor. you will receive a medication guide when you begin treatment; read it carefully and ask questions. why is this medication prescribed? ciprofloxacin injection is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic used to treat certain bacterial infections, including pneumonia; infections of the skin, bone, joint, abdomen, urinary tract, and prostate; and fever in patients at high risk of infection because of very low white blood cells. it is also used to prevent or treat plague and inhalational anthrax, including in bioterror exposure. it may be used for bronchitis or sinus infections only when no other treatment options are appropriate. it works by killing bacteria. it does not treat colds, flu, or other viral infections; unnecessary use increases the risk of antibiotic resistance. other uses for this medicine in events of biological warfare, ciprofloxacin may be used to prevent or treat deliberately spread illnesses such as tularemia and cutaneous or oropharyngeal anthrax. it is also sometimes used for cat scratch disease, legionnaires’ disease, certain outer ear infections that spread to nearby bone, and to help prevent infection around some types of surgery. ask your doctor about the risks and benefits if prescribed for these uses. how should this medicine be used? ciprofloxacin injection is a liquid infused into a vein over about 60 minutes, usually once every 8 to 12 hours. treatment length depends on your infection; your doctor will tell you how long to continue. it may be given in the hospital or at home. if using at home, your healthcare provider will show you how to infuse it and what to do if problems occur; follow instructions and ask questions if anything is unclear. you should start to feel better in the first few days. if symptoms do not improve or worsen, call your doctor. use it for the full prescribed course unless you develop serious side effects described in the important warning or side effects sections. stopping early or skipping doses can result in incomplete treatment and antibiotic resistance. what special precautions should i follow? do not use ciprofloxacin injection if you are allergic to ciprofloxacin, other quinolone or fluoroquinolone antibiotics (such as gemifloxacin, levofloxacin, moxifloxacin, or ofloxacin), any of its ingredients, or if you take tizanidine; your doctor will usually avoid this combination. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all medicines you take, including oral or injectable steroids (dexamethasone, methylprednisolone, prednisone), nsaids (ibuprofen, naproxen), and all prescription, nonprescription, and herbal products; some must not be combined with ciprofloxacin and others may require dose changes or monitoring. do not start, stop, or change medicines while using ciprofloxacin without medical advice. tell your doctor if you or family members have prolonged qt interval, or if you have a slow or irregular heartbeat, heart failure, prior heart attack, aortic aneurysm, high blood pressure, peripheral vascular disease, marfan or ehlers-danlos syndrome, or low potassium or magnesium. also tell your doctor if you have diabetes or a history of low blood sugar, liver disease, kidney disease, a kidney, heart, or lung transplant, joint or tendon problems (including rheumatoid arthritis), or if you do regular vigorous physical activity. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant during treatment. until you know how ciprofloxacin affects you, do not drive, operate machinery, or do activities requiring alertness or coordination. avoid unnecessary or prolonged sun or uv exposure (tanning beds, sunlamps); wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen. call your doctor if you develop a severe sunburn-like reaction. what special dietary instructions should i follow? limit caffeine from coffee, tea, energy drinks, cola, and chocolate, as ciprofloxacin can intensify caffeine-related nervousness, insomnia, palpitations, and anxiety. drink plenty of water and other fluids daily while using ciprofloxacin. what should i do if i forget a dose? infuse the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not infuse two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, heartburn, diarrhea, unusual tiredness, sleepiness, and irritation, pain, tenderness, redness, warmth, or swelling at the infusion site. stop the drug and call your doctor right away, or seek emergency care, for severe diarrhea (watery or bloody stools with or without fever and cramps) that can occur during or up to 2 months or more after treatment; rash; hives; itching; skin peeling or blistering; fever; swelling of the eyes, face, mouth, lips, tongue, throat, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; hoarseness or throat tightness; trouble breathing or swallowing; persistent or worsening cough; yellowing of the skin or eyes, pale skin, dark urine, or light-colored stools; symptoms of blood sugar changes such as extreme thirst or hunger, pallor, shakiness or trembling, rapid or fluttering heartbeat, sweating, frequent urination, blurred vision, or unusual anxiety; fainting or loss of consciousness; decreased urination; unusual bruising or bleeding; or sudden pain in the chest, abdomen, or back. in children and adolescents, ciprofloxacin can cause problems with bones, joints, and surrounding tissues; it is generally avoided under age 18 unless no alternatives are suitable for serious infections or for exposure to plague or inhalational anthrax. tell your child’s doctor about any past joint problems and report any joint pain or swelling during treatment or after it ends. ciprofloxacin injection may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using it.

name: ciprofloxacin ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ciprofloxacin eye drops are used to treat bacterial eye infections such as conjunctivitis (pinkeye) and corneal ulcers (infection and tissue loss in the clear front part of the eye). ciprofloxacin eye ointment treats conjunctivitis. ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic that works by killing the bacteria causing the infection. how should this medicine be used? ciprofloxacin ophthalmic comes as a liquid solution and as an eye ointment. eye drops: typically used frequently—ranging from once every 15 minutes to once every 4 hours while awake—for 7 to 14 days or longer as directed. ointment: usually applied 3 times daily for 2 days, then twice daily for 5 more days. use at the same times each day and exactly as prescribed; do not use more, less, or more often than directed. you should notice improvement during treatment; call your doctor if symptoms do not improve, worsen, or if new eye problems develop. finish the full course even if you feel better to prevent incomplete cure and antibiotic resistance. to instill eye drops: 1) wash hands with soap and water. 2) check the dropper tip; do not use if chipped or cracked. 3) do not let the tip touch your eye or any surface. 4) tilt your head back and pull down the lower eyelid to form a pocket. 5) hold the dropper close (without touching), brace your hand on your face, look up, and squeeze out one drop into the pocket. 6) release the lid, close your eye for 2–3 minutes, and tip your head down as if looking at the floor; avoid blinking or squeezing. 7) press a finger gently on the tear duct at the inner corner of the eye. 8) wipe away excess liquid with a tissue. 9) if more than one drop is needed in the same eye, wait at least 5 minutes before the next drop. 10) replace and tighten the cap; do not wipe or rinse the tip. 11) wash hands to remove any medication. to apply eye ointment: 1) wash hands. 2) avoid touching the tube tip to the eye or any surface. 3) hold the tube near the eyelid without touching; brace your hand. 4) tilt your head back slightly and pull down the lower eyelid to form a pocket. 5) squeeze a 1/2‑inch (about 1.25 cm) ribbon of ointment into the pocket. 6) release the lid, blink slowly, then keep the eye gently closed for 1–2 minutes. 7) wipe excess ointment from lids and lashes with a tissue. 8) wipe the tube tip with a clean tissue, cap tightly right away, and wash hands. other uses for this medicine this medicine may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before use, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to ciprofloxacin (cipro, ciloxan), any quinolone/fluoroquinolone antibiotic (for example ofloxacin, levofloxacin, moxifloxacin, gatifloxacin, lomefloxacin, norfloxacin, nalidixic acid, cinoxacin, enoxacin, sparfloxacin), any other medication, or benzalkonium chloride. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. share your medical history and any current conditions. if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding, discuss risks and call your doctor if you become pregnant while using this medicine. your vision may blur with the ointment; avoid rubbing your eyes and do not drive or operate machinery until your vision is clear. do not wear contact lenses while you have symptoms of bacterial conjunctivitis or while using the drops or ointment. bacterial conjunctivitis spreads easily: wash your hands often, especially after touching your eyes. when the infection resolves, wash or replace eye makeup, contact lenses, and any items that touched the infected eye. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor about drinking coffee or other caffeinated beverages while using this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use a double dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include burning, redness, itching, crusting, irritation, eye pain, a feeling that something is in the eye, or an unpleasant taste. serious side effects can occur; call your doctor immediately if you have rash, hives, itching, tingling, swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, difficulty breathing or swallowing, or hoarseness. this medicine may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice any unusual problems.

name: ciprofloxacin otic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ciprofloxacin otic solution (cetraxal) and ciprofloxacin otic suspension (otiprio) are used to treat outer ear infections in adults and children. ciprofloxacin otic suspension (otiprio) is also used in children during ear tube placement surgery to help prevent infection or ear drainage. ciprofloxacin otic belongs to a class of antibiotics called quinolones and works by killing the bacteria that cause infection. how should this medicine be used? ciprofloxacin otic solution (cetraxal) is a liquid placed into the ear and is usually used twice a day for 7 days. use the solution at about the same times each day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully. use exactly as directed; do not use more, less, or more often than prescribed. ciprofloxacin otic suspension (otiprio) is a liquid placed into the ear by a healthcare professional in a clinic or surgical setting and is usually given as a single dose. ciprofloxacin otic is for use in the ears only; do not use in the eyes. you should start to feel better within the first few days of treatment for outer ear infections; if your symptoms do not improve after one week or get worse, call your doctor. after use during ear tube surgery, call your doctor if you have ear pain, persistent ear discharge, or fever. cetraxal ear drops come in single-use containers; open a container immediately before use, instill the dose, and discard the container after use. use the drops for the full prescribed course even if you feel better; stopping early or skipping doses may result in incomplete treatment and bacterial resistance. to use the ear drops: wash your hands thoroughly. warm the container in your hand for at least 1 minute. twist off the top. lie down with the affected ear facing up. place the entire contents of the container into the ear. remain lying with the affected ear up for at least 60 seconds. repeat for the other ear if directed. throw away the empty container. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using ciprofloxacin otic, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to ciprofloxacin (cipro), gemifloxacin (factive), levofloxacin (levaquin), lomefloxacin (maxaquin), moxifloxacin (avelox), nalidixic acid (neggram), norfloxacin (noroxin), ofloxacin (floxin), any other medications, or any ingredients in ciprofloxacin otic; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using ciprofloxacin otic, call your doctor. keep infected ears clean and dry while using this medicine; avoid getting the ears wet while bathing and avoid swimming unless your doctor tells you otherwise. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not use extra drops to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? ciprofloxacin otic may cause side effects. common effects include ear discomfort, pain, or itching. some side effects can be serious; stop using ciprofloxacin otic and call your doctor right away if you have a rash; hives; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; hoarseness; or trouble swallowing or breathing. ciprofloxacin otic may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice any unusual symptoms.

name: cisapride
instructions: important warning: in the united states, cisapride is available only through a restricted access program for certain patients enrolled by their prescribers. discuss with your doctor or pharmacist whether cisapride is appropriate for you. cisapride can cause serious abnormal heart rhythms that may be life-threatening. tell your doctor if you have a family history of heart problems and if you have or have ever had irregular heartbeats, heart disease, severe dehydration, persistent vomiting, an eating disorder, or kidney or lung failure. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and over-the-counter medicines you take. do not use cisapride if you are taking any of the following: bepridil (vascor); chlorpromazine (thorazine); clarithromycin (biaxin); erythromycin (e.e.s., e-mycin, ery-tab); fluconazole (diflucan); fluphenazine (prolixin); itraconazole (sporanox); ketoconazole (nizoral); antidepressants such as amitriptyline (elavil), amoxapine (asendin), clomipramine (anafranil), desipramine (norpramin), doxepin (adapin, sinequan), imipramine (tofranil), maprotiline (ludiomil), nefazodone (serzone), nortriptyline (pamelor), protriptyline (vivactil), or trimipramine (surmontil); antiarrhythmics such as amiodarone (cordarone), disopyramide (norpace), quinidine (quinidex), procainamide (procanbid, pronestyl), or sotalol (betapace); mesoridazine (serentil); perphenazine (trilafon); prochlorperazine (compazine); promethazine (phenergan); protease inhibitors such as indinavir (crixivan) or ritonavir (norvir); sertindole (serlect); sparfloxacin (zagam); thioridazine (mellaril); thiothixene (navane); trifluoperazine (stelazine); or troleandomycin (tao). do not drink grapefruit juice while taking cisapride. do not take more than prescribed or take it more often than directed. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory; your doctor may order tests to monitor how your body responds to cisapride. call your doctor right away if you faint or develop irregular or fast heartbeats. why is this medication prescribed? cisapride is prescribed to relieve nighttime heartburn symptoms in people who have not improved with other treatments. how should this medicine be used? cisapride is available as tablets and oral liquid. it is typically taken four times daily, 15 minutes before each meal and at bedtime. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take cisapride precisely as directed; do not take more or less or take it more frequently than prescribed. other uses for this medicine this medication should not be used for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cisapride, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cisapride or any other medication. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had intestinal disorders or bleeding ulcers. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while taking cisapride, contact your doctor. this medicine may cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. alcohol can increase drowsiness caused by this drug. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice while taking cisapride. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular dosing schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? cisapride may cause side effects. common effects include diarrhea, upset stomach, abdominal discomfort, headache, stuffy nose, constipation, and coughing. call your doctor immediately if you have vision changes, chest pain, or any symptoms listed in the important warning section such as fainting or irregular or rapid heartbeats.

name: cisplatin injection
instructions: important warning: cisplatin injection must be given in a hospital or medical facility under the supervision of a doctor experienced in giving chemotherapy. cisplatin may cause serious kidney problems, which can occur more often in older adults. your doctor will order laboratory tests before and during treatment to monitor your kidneys. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney disease, and tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are taking aminoglycoside antibiotics such as amikacin, gentamicin, or tobramycin. call your doctor immediately if you have decreased urination; swelling of the face, arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; or unusual tiredness or weakness. cisplatin may cause serious hearing problems, especially in children, and hearing loss may be permanent. your doctor will order tests to monitor your hearing before and during treatment. tell your doctor if you have ever had radiation therapy to your head and if you are taking aminoglycoside antibiotics. call your doctor immediately if you experience hearing loss, ringing in the ears, or dizziness. cisplatin may cause severe allergic reactions, especially if you have received more than one dose. an allergic reaction may begin within minutes after the infusion starts and may include hives, rash, itching, reddening of the skin, difficulty breathing or swallowing, swelling of the face, throat, tongue, or lips, dizziness, fainting, or a fast heartbeat. seek immediate medical help if you experience any of these symptoms. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor will order tests before, during, and after treatment to check your body’s response to cisplatin and may stop or delay treatment if certain side effects occur. why is this medication prescribed? cisplatin is used in combination with other medications to treat testicular cancer that has not improved or has worsened after treatment with other medications or radiation therapy. cisplatin is used alone or with other medications to treat ovarian cancer that has not improved or has worsened after treatment with other medications or radiation therapy. cisplatin is also used alone or with other medications to treat bladder cancer that cannot be treated with surgery or radiation therapy alone. cisplatin is in a class of medications known as platinum-containing compounds. it works by stopping or slowing the growth of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? cisplatin injection comes as a solution to be infused intravenously over 6 to 8 hours by a doctor or nurse in a medical facility. it is usually given once every 3 to 4 weeks. other uses for this medicine cisplatin is also sometimes used to treat head and neck cancer (including cancer of the mouth, lip, cheek, tongue, palate, throat, tonsils, and sinuses), lung cancer, cancer of the cervix and esophagus, brain tumors, malignant pleural mesothelioma (cancer in the lining of the chest or abdomen), and neuroblastoma (a cancer that begins in nerve cells and occurs mainly in children). talk to your doctor about the risks and benefits of using this medication for your condition. this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving cisplatin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cisplatin, carboplatin, any other medications, or any of the ingredients in cisplatin injection. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take while receiving cisplatin, especially aminoglycoside antibiotics such as amikacin, gentamicin, or tobramycin. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have kidney disease or hearing problems; your doctor may not want you to receive cisplatin. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. you should not become pregnant or breastfeed while receiving cisplatin. if you become pregnant during treatment, call your doctor. cisplatin may harm the fetus. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your normal diet. drink plenty of fluids as directed by your care team before and after treatment to help protect your kidneys. what should i do if i forget a dose? cisplatin is given in a medical facility. if you miss an appointment for a dose, call your doctor as soon as possible to reschedule. do not receive two doses at the same time to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? cisplatin may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, hair loss, loss of the ability to taste food, hiccups, dry mouth, dark urine, decreased sweating, dry skin, or other signs of dehydration. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following symptoms or those listed in the important warning section, call your doctor immediately: swelling, pain, redness, or burning at the injection site; pain, burning, or tingling in the hands or feet; muscle cramps; difficulty walking; a feeling of an electric-like shock when you bend your neck forward; seizures; sudden changes in vision (including color vision), loss of vision, or eye pain; chest pain or pressure; fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection; unusual bleeding or bruising; black, tarry stools; red blood in stools; bloody vomit; or vomited material that looks like coffee grounds. cisplatin may increase the risk that you will develop other cancers. cisplatin may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: citalopram
instructions: important warning: a small number of children, teenagers, and young adults up to 24 who took antidepressants such as citalopram during clinical studies developed suicidal thoughts or behaviors. young people taking antidepressants for depression or other mental illnesses may be at higher risk than those not taking them, although the exact size of this risk and how to weigh it in treatment decisions is uncertain. children under 18 generally should not take citalopram, but a doctor may determine it is the best option in some cases. adults over 24 can also experience unexpected changes in mental health while taking citalopram or other antidepressants. suicidal thoughts or behavior may occur, especially when starting treatment or when doses are increased or decreased. you, your family, or your caregiver should call your doctor right away if you have any of the following: new or worsening depression; thoughts about harming or killing yourself or plans or attempts to do so; extreme worry; agitation; panic attacks; trouble falling or staying asleep; aggressive behavior; irritability; acting without thinking; severe restlessness; or frenzied, abnormally excited mood. make sure your family or caregiver knows which symptoms are serious so they can seek help if you cannot. your healthcare provider will want to see you often, especially at the beginning of treatment; keep all appointments. you will receive a medication guide when you start citalopram; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. no matter your age, discuss with your doctor the risks and benefits of antidepressants versus other treatments, as well as the risks of not treating your condition. having depression or another mental illness increases suicide risk, particularly if you or a family member has or has had bipolar disorder, mania, or suicidal thoughts or attempts. review your condition, symptoms, and medical and family history with your doctor to choose appropriate treatment. why is this medication prescribed? citalopram is used to treat depression. it is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (ssri) that increases serotonin, a natural brain chemical that helps maintain mental balance. how should this medicine be used? citalopram is taken by mouth as a tablet or oral solution once daily, in the morning or evening, with or without food. take it at the same time each day. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not take more or less, or take it more often, than prescribed. your doctor may start you on a low dose and increase it no more than once a week. it may take 1 to 4 weeks to feel the full benefit. continue taking citalopram even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor; your dose will likely be decreased gradually. stopping suddenly may cause withdrawal symptoms such as mood changes, irritability, agitation, dizziness, numbness, tingling or electric shock-like sensations in the hands or feet, anxiety, confusion, headache, tiredness, nausea, sweating, shaking, frenzied or abnormally excited mood, and trouble sleeping. call your doctor if you experience these while tapering or after stopping. other uses for this medicine citalopram is sometimes used to treat obsessive-compulsive disorder, eating disorders, alcoholism, panic disorder, premenstrual dysphoric disorder, social anxiety disorder, posttraumatic stress disorder, tingling in the hands and feet caused by diabetes, and certain male sexual problems. talk to your doctor about the possible risks and benefits for these conditions. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking citalopram, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to citalopram, escitalopram (lexapro), any other medications, or any ingredients in your product; check the medication guide for a full list. do not take citalopram with pimozide (orap) or if you are taking or have taken a monoamine oxidase (mao) inhibitor such as isocarboxazid (marplan), linezolid (zyvox), methylene blue, phenelzine (nardil), selegiline (emsam, zelapar), or tranylcypromine (parnate) within the past 14 days. citalopram is very similar to escitalopram; do not take them together. tell your doctor about nonprescription or herbal products that may interact, including st. john's wort, tryptophan, cimetidine (tagamet), aspirin, and nsaids such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin) and naproxen (aleve). do not start any of these while on citalopram without medical advice. tell your doctor if you drink or have drunk large amounts of alcohol, use or have used street drugs, or have overused prescription medicines. also tell your doctor if you or a family member has long qt syndrome; if you recently had a heart attack; or if you have or have had a slow or irregular heartbeat, heart failure or other heart conditions, high blood pressure, bleeding problems, stroke, low magnesium, potassium, or sodium levels, seizures, or kidney or liver disease. if you are pregnant (especially in the last months), plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor; call your doctor if you become pregnant. citalopram may cause problems in newborns if taken late in pregnancy. citalopram may make you drowsy and affect judgment, thinking, and movement; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. alcohol can worsen side effects; ask your doctor about safe use. citalopram may cause angle-closure glaucoma. ask about an eye exam before starting. if you develop nausea, eye pain, changes in vision such as seeing colored rings around lights, or swelling or redness in or around the eye, call your doctor or seek emergency care right away. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? citalopram may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: nausea; diarrhea; constipation; vomiting; stomach pain; heartburn; decreased appetite; weight loss; increased sweating; increased thirst; frequent urination; trouble falling or staying asleep; drowsiness; excessive tiredness; yawning; weakness; uncontrollable shaking; muscle or joint pain; dry mouth; sexual problems in males (decreased sex drive, inability to get or keep an erection, delayed or absent ejaculation); sexual problems in females (decreased sex drive, delayed orgasm, or inability to have an orgasm); heavy menstrual periods; runny nose. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have any of the following, or those listed in the important warning or special precautions sections: chest pain; shortness of breath; dizziness; fainting; signs of serotonin syndrome such as fever, sweating, confusion, fast or irregular heartbeat, severe muscle stiffness or twitching, agitation, hallucinations, loss of coordination, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea; coma; loss of consciousness; hives or blisters; rash; itching; difficulty breathing or swallowing; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; hoarseness; unusual bleeding or bruising, including nosebleeds; headache; unsteadiness; problems with thinking, concentration, or memory; seizures. in children, citalopram may decrease appetite and cause weight loss; their growth will be monitored. discuss any concerns with your child's doctor. citalopram may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: cladribine
instructions: important warning: cladribine can increase the risk of cancer. if you have cancer now or have had it in the past, your doctor may advise you not to take cladribine. discuss with your doctor how to monitor for cancer, including self-exams and screening tests, and review the risks of treatment. do not take cladribine if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. if you become pregnant while taking cladribine, stop the medication and call your doctor immediately. cladribine can cause pregnancy loss or birth defects. your doctor will check for pregnancy before each treatment course. use effective birth control during each treatment course and for at least 6 months after the last dose of each course. if you use hormonal estrogen contraceptives such as pills, patches, rings, implants, or injections, also use another method of birth control during each treatment course and for at least 4 weeks after the last dose of that course. if you are a male with a partner who could become pregnant, use birth control during each treatment course and for at least 6 months after the last dose of each course. talk to your doctor about suitable birth control options. you will receive a medication guide from the manufacturer when you start treatment and with each refill; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. why is this medication prescribed? cladribine is used to treat adults with relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis, including relapsing remitting disease and active secondary progressive disease, and is generally used in patients who have already tried another ms therapy. cladribine is in a class of medications called purine antimetabolites and works by limiting certain immune cells that cause nerve damage. how should this medicine be used? cladribine is an oral tablet taken with water, with or without food. take it once daily for 4 or 5 consecutive days for one treatment cycle, then repeat a second cycle 23 to 27 days later to complete one treatment course. a second course consisting of 2 treatment cycles is usually given at least 43 weeks after the last dose of the second cycle. take cladribine at the same time each day. follow your prescription exactly; do not take more or less or more often than directed. your doctor will order laboratory tests before and during treatment to ensure you are tolerating the medicine. swallow tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush. with dry hands, remove a tablet from the blister and swallow it right away. minimize skin contact; avoid touching your eyes, nose, and other body parts. wash your hands well with water after taking the medication. if the tablet contacts your skin or any surface, wash the area or surface with water immediately. other uses for this medicine cladribine may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cladribine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cladribine or any ingredients in the tablets. provide a list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and supplements you take or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. if you take other oral medicines, take them at least 3 hours before or 3 hours after cladribine. tell your doctor about any nonprescription or herbal products you use, especially curcumin and st. johns wort; do not start these while on cladribine without medical advice. tell your doctor if you have human immunodeficiency virus, hepatitis, tuberculosis, or other ongoing infections; your doctor will likely tell you not to take cladribine. also tell your doctor if you have or have had shingles or liver, kidney, or heart disease. if you have never had chickenpox and have not been vaccinated, your doctor may recommend chickenpox or shingles vaccination before or during treatment. do not breast-feed during a treatment cycle and for 10 days after the last dose of that cycle. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, inform the clinician that you are taking cladribine. do not receive any vaccinations from 4 to 6 weeks before, during, or after treatment without talking to your doctor. ask your doctor whether any vaccinations are recommended before you begin therapy. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember on the same day. if you miss the entire scheduled day, take the dose the next day and add one extra day to that treatment cycle. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cladribine may cause side effects. common effects include headache, nausea, back pain, joint pain and stiffness, trouble sleeping, depression, hair loss, tingling, itching, or burning sensations, and sores on the gums, lips, or mouth. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or seek emergency help if you have any of the following: fever, sore throat, chills, muscle aches, cough, or other signs of infection; cough, chest pain, coughing up blood or mucus, weakness or tiredness, weight loss, loss of appetite, chills, fever, or night sweats; a painful rash with blisters; burning, tingling, numbness, or itchiness of the skin; rash, trouble breathing or swallowing, or swelling or itching of the face, lips, tongue, or throat; chills, fever, nausea, vomiting, pain in the back, side, or groin, or frequent and painful urination; unusual bleeding or bruising; weakness on one side of the body, loss of coordination in the arms or legs, decreased strength, balance problems, confusion, or changes in vision, thinking, memory, or personality; shortness of breath, fast heartbeat, headache, dizziness, pale skin, or confusion; nausea, vomiting, extreme tiredness, loss of appetite, pain in the upper right abdomen, yellowing of the skin or eyes, or dark urine; shortness of breath, fast or irregular heartbeat, or swelling in any part of the body. cladribine may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: cladribine injection
instructions: important warning: cladribine injection must be given in a hospital or medical facility under the supervision of a doctor experienced in administering chemotherapy for cancer. cladribine can cause a severe decrease in all types of blood cells, increasing the risk of serious infection or bleeding. call your doctor immediately if you have fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection; unusual bleeding or bruising; black, tarry stools; red blood in your stools; bloody vomit; or vomit that looks like coffee grounds. cladribine may cause severe nerve damage that can occur more than one month after treatment. call your doctor right away if you experience pain, burning, numbness, or tingling in the hands or feet; weakness in the arms or legs; or loss of ability to move your arms or legs. cladribine can also cause serious kidney problems. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney disease, and tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are taking medicines that can affect the kidneys such as aminoglycoside antibiotics (amikacin, gentamicin, tobramycin), amphotericin b, angiotensin-converting enzyme (ace) inhibitors (benazepril, captopril, enalapril, fosinopril, lisinopril, moexipril, perindopril, quinapril, ramipril, trandolapril), or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as diclofenac, naproxen, or sulindac. call your doctor immediately if you develop decreased urination; swelling of the face, arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; or unusual tiredness or weakness. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor will order tests before, during, and after treatment to check how your body is responding to cladribine. why is this medication prescribed? cladribine is used to treat hairy cell leukemia, a cancer of a certain type of white blood cell. it belongs to a class of medications called purine analogs and works by stopping or slowing the growth of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? cladribine injection is a liquid solution given intravenously by a doctor or nurse in a medical facility. it is usually administered as a continuous intravenous infusion over 7 days. do not attempt to use this medication on your own. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving cladribine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cladribine, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the cladribine injection; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take while receiving cladribine; your doctor will need to monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. you should not become pregnant while receiving cladribine. if you become pregnant during treatment, call your doctor immediately; cladribine may harm the fetus. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment or think you missed a dose of cladribine, contact your doctor or treatment center right away to reschedule. do not try to make up a dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? cladribine may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, stomach pain, constipation, loss of appetite, skin rash, headache, excessive sweating, or pain, redness, swelling, or sores at the injection site. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following, or any symptoms listed in the important warning section, call your doctor immediately: pale skin, excessive tiredness, shortness of breath, dizziness, or a fast heartbeat. cladribine may cause other side effects. if the person collapses, has a seizure, has trouble breathing, or cannot be awakened, call emergency services (911) immediately. symptoms of overdose may include: decreased urination; swelling of the face, arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; unusual tiredness or weakness; unusual bleeding or bruising; black and tarry or bloody stools; bloody vomit or vomit that looks like coffee grounds; fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection; pain, burning, numbness, or tingling in the hands or feet; weakness in the arms or legs; or loss of ability to move the arms or legs. what other information should i know? keep a written list of all prescription and nonprescription (over-the-counter) medicines, vitamins, minerals, and dietary supplements you take, and bring it with you each time you visit a doctor or are admitted to a hospital. carry this list with you in case of emergencies. brand names: leustatin. other names: 2-cda; 2-chloro-2'-deoxyadenosine; cda; chlorodeoxyadenosine.

name: clarithromycin
