instructions: why is this medication prescribed? clarithromycin is used to treat certain bacterial infections, such as pneumonia (a lung infection), bronchitis (infection of the tubes leading to the lungs), and infections of the ears, sinuses, skin, and throat. it is also used to treat and prevent disseminated mycobacterium avium complex (mac), a type of infection that often affects people with human immunodeficiency virus (hiv). in combination with other medications, it is used to eradicate h. pylori, a bacterium that causes ulcers. clarithromycin belongs to a class of medications called macrolide antibiotics and works by stopping the growth of bacteria. antibiotics like clarithromycin do not treat colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when they are not needed increases the risk of developing infections that resist antibiotic treatment. how should this medicine be used? clarithromycin comes as a tablet, an extended-release (long-acting) tablet, and a suspension (liquid) to take by mouth. the regular tablet and liquid are usually taken with or without food every 8 to 12 hours (two to three times daily) for 7 to 14 days. the extended-release tablet is usually taken with food once every 24 hours for 7 to 14 days. your doctor may prescribe a longer course depending on your condition. take clarithromycin at the same times each day and exactly as directed. do not take more or less than prescribed or take it more often than instructed. shake the suspension well before each dose to mix it evenly. swallow the extended-release tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush them. you should start to feel better in the first few days of treatment; if your symptoms do not improve or worsen, call your doctor. take clarithromycin until you finish the entire prescription, even if you feel better. stopping too soon or skipping doses may lead to incomplete treatment and antibiotic resistance. other uses for this medicine clarithromycin is sometimes used to treat other infections, including lyme disease (an infection that may develop after a tick bite), cryptosporidiosis (an infection that causes diarrhea), cat scratch disease (an infection that may develop after a cat bite or scratch), legionnaires’ disease (a type of lung infection), and pertussis (whooping cough). it is also sometimes used to prevent heart infection in patients undergoing dental or other procedures. talk to your doctor about the potential risks and benefits of using this medication for your condition. this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking clarithromycin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to clarithromycin, azithromycin (zithromax, zmax), erythromycin (e.e.s., eryc, erythrocin, pce, others), telithromycin (ketek; not available in the u.s.), any other medications, or any ingredients in clarithromycin products. ask your pharmacist for a list of the ingredients. some medications should not be taken with clarithromycin, and others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. review all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and herbal products you use or plan to use with your doctor and pharmacist before starting clarithromycin. do not start, stop, or change any medications while taking clarithromycin without medical advice. if you have or have ever had jaundice (yellowing of the skin or eyes) or other liver problems while taking clarithromycin, your doctor will likely tell you not to take it. the following nonprescription or herbal products may interact with clarithromycin: st. john’s wort; omeprazole (prilosec). tell your doctor and pharmacist if you use these and do not start them while on clarithromycin without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had a prolonged qt interval (a heart rhythm problem that may cause fainting or irregular heartbeat), ventricular arrhythmia (abnormal heart rhythms), low blood magnesium or potassium, myasthenia gravis (a disorder causing muscle weakness), any irregular heartbeat, coronary artery disease, or kidney or liver disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor; clarithromycin may harm the fetus. if you become pregnant while taking it, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking clarithromycin. clarithromycin may cause dizziness, confusion, or disorientation; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? clarithromycin may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, heartburn, gas, change in taste, headache. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have any of the following: chest pain; shortness of breath; trouble breathing; pain or weakness on one side of the body; slurred speech; severe diarrhea with watery or bloody stools (which may occur up to 2 months after treatment); rash; hives; itching; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; difficulty breathing or swallowing; hoarseness; peeling or blistering skin; fever; yellowing of the skin or eyes; extreme tiredness; unusual bleeding or bruising; lack of energy; loss of appetite; pain in the upper right abdomen; dark-colored urine; flu-like symptoms; fast, pounding, or irregular heartbeat; muscle weakness (such as difficulty chewing, talking, or performing daily activities); double vision. clarithromycin may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you experience any unusual problems while taking it.

name: clemastine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? clemastine is used to relieve symptoms of hay fever and allergies, such as sneezing, runny nose, and red, itchy, watery eyes. prescription-strength clemastine may also help reduce the itching and swelling of hives. it controls allergy and cold symptoms but does not treat their cause or speed recovery. clemastine is an antihistamine that works by blocking histamine, a body chemical that triggers allergic symptoms. how should this medicine be used? clemastine is available as an oral tablet and liquid. it is typically taken two or three times daily. follow the directions on your prescription or product label exactly, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not take more, less, or more often than directed. if using the liquid, measure doses with the supplied device or a medication-measuring spoon or cup, not a household spoon. other uses: this medication may be prescribed for additional purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking clemastine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to clemastine, other antihistamines, any medications, or any ingredients in the product; check the label for a full ingredient list. some medicines should not be taken with clemastine, and others may require dose changes or monitoring. review all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and herbal products you use or plan to use with your doctor and pharmacist, and seek their advice before starting, stopping, or changing any medication while taking clemastine. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had asthma or other lung disease; glaucoma; stomach or intestinal ulcers; difficulty urinating due to an enlarged prostate; blockage between the stomach and intestine; bladder outlet blockage; heart disease; high blood pressure; seizures; or an overactive thyroid. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking clemastine, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, tell the clinician you are taking clemastine. this medicine may cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. ask your doctor about alcohol use, as alcohol can intensify side effects. discuss the risks and benefits if you are 65 or older; older adults generally should avoid clemastine because safer and more effective alternatives are available. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medication is often used as needed. if your doctor has directed you to take it on a regular schedule and you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose. what side effects can this medication cause? clemastine may cause side effects. common effects include drowsiness; dry mouth, nose, and throat; dizziness; decreased coordination; nausea; chest congestion; headache; and, especially in children, excitement or nervousness. serious effects can include difficulty urinating; vision changes; fast, pounding, or irregular heartbeat; hives; rash; itching; or trouble breathing or swallowing. call your doctor right away if you experience serious symptoms. contact your doctor if you notice any unusual problems while taking clemastine.

name: clindamycin
instructions: important warning: many antibiotics, including clindamycin, can cause an overgrowth of harmful bacteria in the large intestine. this can lead to mild diarrhea or a life-threatening colitis (inflammation of the colon). clindamycin is more likely to cause this than many other antibiotics and should be used only for serious infections that cannot be treated with other antibiotics. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had colitis or other conditions affecting your stomach or intestines. these problems can appear during treatment or up to several months after treatment ends. call your doctor if you develop watery or bloody stools, diarrhea, stomach cramps, or fever during treatment or in the months after finishing clindamycin. discuss the risks of clindamycin with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? clindamycin is used to treat certain bacterial infections, including infections of the lungs, skin, blood, female reproductive organs, and internal organs. it belongs to a class of medicines called lincomycin antibiotics and works by slowing or stopping bacterial growth. it does not treat colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when not needed increases the risk of future infections that resist antibiotic treatment. how should this medicine be used? clindamycin comes as capsules and an oral solution. it is usually taken three to four times daily. the length of treatment depends on your infection and response. take clindamycin at the same times each day and follow your prescription label carefully. take it exactly as directed; do not take more or less, or more often, than prescribed. swallow capsules whole; do not split, chew, or crush. take capsules with a full glass of water (6 to 8 ounces [180 to 240 ml]) to prevent throat irritation. do not lie down for at least 30 minutes after taking a capsule; remain sitting or standing during that time. you should begin to feel better within a few days. if your symptoms do not improve or get worse, call your doctor. take clindamycin for the full prescribed course even if you feel better. stopping early or skipping doses may result in incomplete treatment and antibiotic resistance. other uses for this medicine clindamycin is sometimes used to treat acne and, in combination with other medications, to treat anthrax and malaria. it is also sometimes used for ear infections, tonsillitis, pharyngitis, and toxoplasmosis when other treatments are not suitable; to treat bacterial vaginosis; and to prevent endocarditis in certain at-risk people undergoing dental procedures. talk to your doctor about the risks and benefits of these uses. this medication may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking clindamycin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to clindamycin, lincomycin (lincocin), any other medications, or any ingredients in the capsules or solution; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. if you will be taking the capsule, tell your doctor if you are allergic to aspirin or tartrazine (a yellow dye found in some medicines). tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had asthma, allergies, eczema, kidney disease, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking clindamycin, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? clindamycin may cause side effects. common effects include nausea, vomiting, an unpleasant or metallic taste, joint pain, thick white vaginal discharge, and burning, itching, or swelling of the vagina. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the symptoms listed in the important warning section or any of the following, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help: peeling or blistering skin, rash, hives, itching, trouble breathing or swallowing, hoarseness, swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, yellowing of the skin or eyes, decreased urination, new or worsening heartburn, difficulty swallowing, or pain when swallowing. clindamycin may cause other side effects.

name: clindamycin injection
instructions: important warning: many antibiotics, including clindamycin, can allow harmful bacteria to overgrow in the large intestine. this can cause mild diarrhea or a life-threatening inflammation of the colon (colitis). clindamycin is more likely to cause this than many other antibiotics, so it should be reserved for serious infections that cannot be treated with other antibiotics. these problems can occur during treatment or up to several months after you finish. call your doctor right away if you develop watery or bloody stools, persistent diarrhea, stomach cramps, or fever while receiving clindamycin injection or within the first several months afterward. discuss the benefits and risks of clindamycin injection with your doctor, especially if you have a history of colitis or other stomach or intestinal problems. why is this medication prescribed? clindamycin injection treats certain bacterial infections, including infections of the lungs, skin and soft tissue, blood, bones and joints, female reproductive organs, and internal organs within the abdomen. it is a lincomycin antibiotic that works by slowing or stopping the growth of bacteria. it does not treat colds, flu, or other viral illnesses. using antibiotics when they are not needed increases the chance of future infections that resist antibiotic treatment. how should this medicine be used? clindamycin injection is given as a liquid either into a vein over 10 to 40 minutes or into a muscle. it is usually administered two to four times daily. the length of treatment depends on your infection and how you respond. you may receive it in a hospital or at home. if you are instructed to use it at home, use it exactly as directed and at about the same times each day. follow all instructions from your doctor, pharmacist, or nurse, and ask if anything is unclear. do not use more or less, and do not use it more often, than prescribed. you should begin to feel better within the first few days. if you do not improve or if symptoms worsen, call your doctor. use clindamycin injection for the full prescribed course even if you feel better. stopping early or skipping doses may lead to incomplete treatment and antibiotic resistance. other uses for this medicine: clindamycin injection may also be used to treat malaria, to prevent infections in certain surgical patients, to treat anthrax, and to treat toxoplasmosis, particularly in people with weakened immune systems and in fetuses when the mother is infected. in some pregnant patients, it is used to help prevent passing an infection to the baby during birth. this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using clindamycin injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to clindamycin, lincomycin, any other medications, or any ingredients in the product. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take, because your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for interactions and side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had colitis or other stomach or intestinal disease, asthma, allergies, eczema, liver disease, or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using clindamycin injection, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are using clindamycin injection. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not use two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? clindamycin injection can cause side effects. common effects include pain, hardness, or a tender lump where the medicine was injected; an unpleasant or metallic taste; nausea; vomiting; joint pain; white patches in the mouth; or thick white vaginal discharge with burning, itching, or swelling. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or get emergency medical help if you have severe skin reactions such as peeling or blistering, rash, hives, itching, trouble breathing or swallowing, hoarseness, swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, yellowing of the skin or eyes, or decreased urination. clindamycin injection may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: clioquinol topical
instructions: notice: clioquinol topical is no longer available in the united states. if you are currently using clioquinol, contact your doctor to discuss switching to another treatment. why is this medication prescribed? clioquinol is used to treat skin infections such as eczema, athlete’s foot, jock itch, and ringworm. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? clioquinol comes as a cream, lotion, or ointment to apply to the skin. it is usually applied two to four times a day for up to 4 weeks, and for up to 2 weeks for jock itch. follow the directions on the label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. use clioquinol exactly as directed. do not use more or less of it or use it more often than indicated. thoroughly clean and dry the infected area, then apply a thin layer and gently rub it in until most of it disappears. use just enough to cover the affected area. wash your hands after applying unless you are treating your hands. avoid contact with the eyes, mouth, or mucous membranes. what special precautions should i follow? before using clioquinol, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to clioquinol or any other drugs. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you are scheduled for a thyroid function test. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using clioquinol, call your doctor. for external use only; do not apply to broken skin or large areas unless directed by your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not apply a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? clioquinol may cause side effects. if you experience any of the following symptoms, call your doctor: itching, burning, irritation or stinging, redness, or swelling at the application site.

name: clobazam
instructions: notice: special alert: the u.s. food and drug administration warns that the antiseizure medicines levetiracetam keppra, keppra xr, elepsia xr, spritam and clobazam onfi, sympazan can rarely cause a severe, potentially life-threatening reaction called drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms dress. it may begin as a rash and quickly progress to involve internal organs such as the liver, kidneys, lungs, heart, or pancreas, and may require hospitalization or lead to death. seek medical care immediately if you develop fever, rash, swollen lymph nodes, or other signs of illness. this risk is now included in prescribing information and medication guides. important warning: clobazam can cause profound sedation, breathing problems, coma, or death when used with certain medicines. tell your doctor if you take or plan to take antidepressants; medicines for anxiety, mental illness, or seizures; sedatives; sleeping pills; opioids such as codeine, fentanyl duragesic, subsys, morphine astramorph, kadian, or oxycodone in percocet, in roxicet, others; or tranquilizers. your doctor may adjust doses and will monitor you closely. if you use clobazam with these medicines and develop unusual dizziness, lightheadedness, extreme sleepiness, slowed or difficult breathing, or unresponsiveness, call your doctor or seek emergency care right away. ensure caregivers know these warning signs. clobazam may be habit forming. do not take a larger dose, take it more often, or use it longer than prescribed, especially if you have a history of heavy alcohol use, substance use, or medication misuse. do not drink alcohol or use street drugs while taking clobazam, as this raises the risk of serious, life-threatening side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had depression or another mental illness. clobazam can cause physical dependence. do not stop or reduce the dose abruptly; stopping suddenly can worsen seizures and cause withdrawal that may last for weeks to more than 12 months. your doctor will taper your dose gradually. call your doctor or get emergency help if you have withdrawal or mental health symptoms such as unusual movements; ringing in the ears; anxiety; memory problems; trouble concentrating; sleep problems; seizures; shaking; muscle twitching; mood or behavior changes; depression; burning or prickling in the hands, arms, legs, or feet; seeing or hearing things others do not; thoughts of harming yourself or others; overexcitement; or loss of touch with reality. why is this medication prescribed? clobazam is used with other medications to help control seizures in adults and children 2 years of age and older with lennox-gastaut syndrome, a condition that causes seizures and often developmental delays. clobazam is a benzodiazepine that works by reducing abnormal electrical activity in the brain. how should this medicine be used? clobazam is available as tablets and an oral suspension taken by mouth, and as an oral film placed on the tongue. it is usually taken once or twice daily, with or without food, at the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. if you cannot swallow tablets whole, you may split them on the score line or crush and mix with a small amount of applesauce. oral suspension: the bottle includes an adapter and two oral syringes; use one syringe for dosing and keep the second as a spare. before first use, uncap the bottle and press the adapter firmly into the neck until it is level with the top; do not remove the adapter while using the bottle. shake well before each dose. to measure a dose, push the syringe plunger down, insert the syringe into the adapter of the upright bottle, turn the bottle upside down, and slowly pull the plunger until the black ring aligns with your prescribed dose. remove the syringe and slowly dispense the liquid into the corner of the mouth. cap the bottle over the adapter after each use. wash the syringe after each dose by removing the plunger, washing barrel and plunger with soap and water, rinsing, and air-drying; do not place syringe parts in a dishwasher. oral film: with clean, dry hands, open the foil pouch and remove the film. place the film on the top of your tongue, close your mouth, and swallow normally as it dissolves. do not chew, spit, talk, or take with liquids while the film dissolves. wash your hands after. if more than one film is prescribed per dose, allow the first to dissolve completely before placing the next. your doctor will usually start with a low dose and increase it no more than once weekly. some people metabolize clobazam differently based on genetics; your doctor may order a blood test to help determine the best dose. clobazam helps control seizures but does not cure the condition. continue taking it even if you feel well, and do not stop without consulting your doctor. you will receive a medication guide at the start of therapy and with each refill; read it and ask questions as needed. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to clobazam or any ingredients in the tablets, suspension, or film. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. in particular, mention the medicines in the important warning section and any of the following: antihistamines; dextromethorphan delsym, in nuedexta, in robitussin dm; fluconazole diflucan; fluvoxamine luvox; omeprazole prilosec, in zegerid; or ticlopidine. many other medicines can interact with clobazam, so inform your healthcare providers about everything you take. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had thoughts about harming yourself or others, or lung, kidney, or liver disease, or depression or another mental illness. pregnancy: regular use in the last months of pregnancy can cause withdrawal in the newborn. call your babys doctor if your newborn has irritability, hyperactivity, abnormal sleep, high-pitched crying, shaking, vomiting, or diarrhea. if you become pregnant while taking clobazam, call your doctor. contraception: hormonal birth control pills, patches, rings, implants, injections, or intrauterine devices may be less effective with clobazam. do not rely on hormonal methods alone while taking clobazam and for 28 days after the final dose; discuss effective nonhormonal options. breastfeeding: if you are breastfeeding while taking clobazam, contact your doctor if your baby is very sleepy or feeding poorly; discuss risks and benefits. older adults 65 years and older should usually receive lower doses because higher doses may not work better and may increase side effects. clobazam can cause drowsiness, impair thinking and decision-making, and affect coordination. do not drive, operate machinery, or do dangerous activities until you know how it affects you. mental health risk: anticonvulsants including clobazam may increase the risk of suicidal thoughts or behavior in a small number of adults and children 5 years and older about 1 in 500, sometimes as early as one week after starting. call your doctor right away for panic attacks; agitation or restlessness; new or worsening irritability, anxiety, or depression; acting on dangerous impulses; trouble sleeping; aggressive, angry, or violent behavior; mania unusually excited mood; thoughts of harming yourself or others; or other unusual mood or behavior changes. ensure family or caregivers know these warning signs. hypersensitivity and dress: stop clobazam and get immediate medical care if you develop fever, rash, swollen lymph nodes, facial swelling, unexplained tiredness, or signs of organ involvement such as dark urine, abdominal pain, persistent cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, or yellowing of the skin or eyes. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include tiredness, problems with coordination, difficulty speaking or swallowing, drooling, changes in appetite, vomiting, constipation, cough, and joint pain. serious side effects can occur. call your doctor immediately or seek emergency care if you have difficult, painful, or frequent urination; cough, trouble breathing, or fever; mouth sores; rash, hives, skin peeling or blistering; fever; signs of dress or other severe allergic reactions; or any symptoms listed in the important warning or special precautions sections. clobazam may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual or bothersome.

name: clobetasol topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? clobetasol topical is used to relieve itching, redness, dryness, crusting, scaling, inflammation, and discomfort from certain scalp and skin conditions such as psoriasis (red, scaly patches) and eczema (dry, itchy skin that may develop red, scaly rashes). clobetasol is a corticosteroid that reduces swelling, redness, and itching by activating natural substances in the skin. how should this medicine be used? clobetasol topical is available as a cream, gel, ointment, lotion, foam, and spray for the skin and as a foam, spray, solution (liquid), and shampoo for the scalp. the cream, gel, ointment, lotion, foam, solution, and spray are usually applied twice daily; the shampoo is typically used once daily. follow your prescription label exactly; ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. use only as directed—do not use more, use more often, or use on other body areas or conditions unless your doctor instructs you to do so. most skin problems should begin to improve within 2 weeks; call your doctor if they do not. for skin: apply a thin, even film of cream, gel, ointment, lotion, foam, or spray to the affected area and rub in gently. for scalp foam, spray, or solution: part the hair, apply a small amount to the affected area, and rub in gently; avoid washing or rubbing the area until it dries. read the product’s written instructions (especially for foam) before first use and ask your pharmacist if you have questions. for shampoo: part the hair, apply a small amount to the affected scalp, and rub in gently; after 15 minutes, wet hair, lather with your fingers, then rinse the shampoo from your hair and skin thoroughly with plenty of water. do not cover your head with a cap or towel while the shampoo is on the scalp. you may wash your hair as usual after rinsing. clobetasol foam is flammable; keep away from heat, open flames, and do not smoke while applying and for a short time afterward. for external use only. avoid contact with eyes or mouth and do not swallow. avoid the genital and rectal areas, skin folds, and armpits unless your doctor tells you otherwise. do not apply other products to treated areas unless your doctor says it is okay. do not cover or bandage treated skin unless instructed by your doctor, as this can increase side effects. wash your hands after applying clobetasol. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for details. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to clobetasol, other medicines, or any ingredients in clobetasol products; ask your pharmacist for an ingredient list. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for interactions. tell your doctor if you have any skin infections or other skin problems, or if you have or have ever had diabetes, cushing’s syndrome (from excess corticosteroid hormones), or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while using this medicine. if you are having any surgery, including dental procedures, tell the doctor or dentist that you use clobetasol topical. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary changes are typically needed while using clobetasol topical unless your doctor gives you specific instructions; continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? clobetasol may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: burning, itching, irritation, redness, or dryness at the application site; acne; small red bumps or a rash around the mouth; small white or red bumps; bruising or shiny skin; red or purple lines or blotches under the skin; thinning, fragile, or very dry skin; or changes in skin color. call your doctor right away if you have any of the following: redness, swelling, pus, or other signs of skin infection where applied; severe rash; skin sores; changes in body fat distribution; sudden weight gain; unusual tiredness; muscle weakness; depression or irritability. children using clobetasol topical may be at greater risk for side effects, including slowed growth and delayed weight gain; discuss risks with your child’s doctor. clobetasol topical may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: clofarabine injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? clofarabine is used to treat acute lymphoblastic leukemia (all), a cancer of white blood cells, in children and young adults 1 to 21 years old who have already received at least two prior treatments. it belongs to a class called purine nucleoside antimetabolites and works by killing existing cancer cells and slowing the growth of new ones. how should this medicine be used? clofarabine is given as an intravenous infusion by a healthcare professional. it is usually administered once daily for 5 consecutive days; this cycle may be repeated every 2 to 6 weeks depending on your response and recovery. each dose is infused over at least 2 hours. tell your doctor or nurse right away if you feel anxious, restless, or unwell during the infusion. other uses for this medicine clofarabine may also be used for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving clofarabine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to clofarabine or any other medicines; provide a list of all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use, as your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you closely for side effects; tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney or liver disease; tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or could become pregnant—clofarabine can harm an unborn baby, so use effective birth control during treatment and call your doctor right away if you become pregnant; do not breastfeed during treatment; if you are scheduled for any surgery, including dental procedures, inform the surgeon or dentist that you are receiving clofarabine. be aware that clofarabine can cause hand-foot syndrome (tingling followed by redness, dryness, and peeling of the hands and feet); ask your doctor to recommend a gentle lotion and apply it lightly without vigorous rubbing, and your doctor may prescribe additional treatments to relieve symptoms. what special dietary instructions should i follow? drink plenty of fluids every day during treatment, especially if you are vomiting or have diarrhea. what should i do if i forget a dose? clofarabine infusions are typically given in a clinic or hospital; if you miss an appointment, contact your doctor or treatment center as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to make up a missed dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? clofarabine may cause side effects. common effects include nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, diarrhea, constipation, loss of appetite, weight loss, swelling or soreness of the mouth and nose, painful white patches in the mouth, headache, anxiety, depression, irritability, pain in the back, joints, arms, or legs, drowsiness, dry or itchy or irritated skin, and flushing. some side effects can be serious—call your doctor immediately if you have a fast heartbeat, fast breathing, shortness of breath, dizziness, lightheadedness, fainting, decreased urination, sore throat, cough, fever, chills or other signs of infection, pale skin, unusual tiredness or weakness, confusion, unusual bruising or bleeding, nosebleeds, bleeding gums, blood in the urine, small red or purple spots under the skin, yellowing of the skin or eyes, itching, red warm swollen tender skin, or uncontrollable shaking of a part of the body. clofarabine may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice any unusual symptoms.

name: clomiphene
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? clomiphene is used to stimulate ovulation in women who do not regularly release eggs and wish to become pregnant. it is an ovulatory stimulant that acts similarly to estrogen to help eggs mature in the ovaries and be released. how should this medicine be used? clomiphene is taken by mouth as a tablet. it is usually taken once daily for 5 days, beginning on or about day 5 of your menstrual cycle. take it at the same time each day. follow your prescription directions exactly; do not change your dose or schedule unless your doctor tells you to. ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have any questions. other uses for this medicine: clomiphene may also be used for male infertility, menstrual irregularities, fibrocystic breast changes, and persistent breast milk production. talk with your doctor about the potential risks and benefits. it may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking clomiphene, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to clomiphene or any medicines; list all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you use; and inform them if you have or have ever had liver disease, ovarian cysts not due to polycystic ovary syndrome, uterine fibroids, unexplained vaginal bleeding, a pituitary tumor, or thyroid or adrenal disorders. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using clomiphene, contact your doctor right away. clomiphene may cause visual disturbances such as blurred vision; do not drive or operate machinery, especially in low light, until you know how it affects you. clomiphene increases the chance of multiple pregnancy (twins or more); discuss this risk with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, call your doctor for guidance. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include flushing or a feeling of warmth, nausea, vomiting, breast discomfort, headache, and abnormal vaginal bleeding. serious side effects are uncommon but require immediate medical attention and may include blurred vision, visual spots or flashes, double vision, pain in the lower abdomen, abdominal swelling, rapid weight gain, or shortness of breath. long-term use may increase the risk of ovarian cancer; treatment is generally limited to about six cycles. other side effects may occur; contact your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking clomiphene.

name: clomipramine
instructions: important warning: a small number of children, teenagers, and young adults up to 24 years of age who took antidepressants such as clomipramine in clinical studies developed suicidal thoughts or behaviors. young people taking antidepressants for depression or other mental illnesses may be at higher risk of suicidality than those not taking these medicines, though the exact size of the risk is uncertain and must be weighed when deciding on treatment. children under 18 should usually not take clomipramine, but a doctor may judge it appropriate in certain cases. mental health can change unexpectedly when starting clomipramine or other antidepressants at any age. suicidal thoughts or behaviors may be more likely early in treatment or when the dose is increased or decreased. you, your family, or your caregiver should contact your doctor right away if you notice new or worsening depression; thoughts of self-harm; plans or attempts to harm yourself; extreme anxiety; agitation; panic attacks; trouble falling or staying asleep; aggressive behavior; irritability; acting without thinking; severe restlessness; or unusually elevated, frenzied mood. make sure your family or caregiver knows which symptoms are serious so they can seek help if you cannot. your healthcare provider will want to see you regularly while you are taking clomipramine, especially early in treatment. keep all appointments. you will receive a medication guide from the manufacturer when you start clomipramine; read it carefully and ask your healthcare professional any questions. before starting any antidepressant, discuss with your doctor the risks and benefits of treatment compared with other options and with no treatment at all. having depression or another mental illness itself increases the risk of suicidality, particularly if you or a family member has or has had bipolar disorder, episodes of mania, or suicidal thoughts or attempts. review your symptoms and personal and family history with your doctor to choose the right treatment. why is this medication prescribed? clomipramine is used to treat obsessive-compulsive disorder, a condition marked by repeated unwanted thoughts and the urge to perform certain actions repeatedly. it is a tricyclic antidepressant that works in part by increasing serotonin, a brain chemical that helps maintain mental balance. how should this medicine be used? clomipramine is an oral capsule. it is often started three times daily with meals to help your body adjust, then after several weeks usually taken once daily at bedtime. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. take it exactly as directed; do not take more, take less, or take it more often. your doctor may begin with a low dose and raise it gradually. it may take several weeks or longer to feel the full effect. keep taking clomipramine even if you feel well. do not stop suddenly; stopping abruptly can cause withdrawal symptoms such as dizziness, nausea, vomiting, headache, weakness, sleep problems, fever, and irritability. your doctor will taper the dose gradually if discontinuation is needed. what special precautions should i follow? before taking clomipramine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to clomipramine; to other tricyclic antidepressants such as amitriptyline (elavil), amoxapine (asendin), desipramine (norpramin), doxepin (adapin, sinequan), imipramine (tofranil), nortriptyline (aventyl, pamelor), protriptyline (vivactil), or trimipramine (surmontil); to any other medications; or to any inactive ingredients in the capsules. ask for a list of inactive ingredients if needed. do not take clomipramine with or within 14 days of a monoamine oxidase inhibitor such as isocarboxazid (marplan), linezolid (zyvox), methylene blue, phenelzine (nardil), selegiline (eldepryl, emsam, zelapar), or tranylcypromine (parnate). some drugs must not be used with clomipramine, and many others may require dosage changes or extra monitoring. review all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and herbal products you use or plan to use with your doctor and pharmacist before starting clomipramine, and consult them before starting, stopping, or changing any medicine while taking it. the nonprescription medicine cimetidine (tagamet) can interact with clomipramine; tell your doctor and pharmacist if you take it, and do not start it while on clomipramine without medical advice. tell your doctor if you have had a recent heart attack, as you may be advised not to take clomipramine. inform your doctor if you receive electroconvulsive therapy; if you currently drink or previously drank large amounts of alcohol; and if you have or have had seizures, brain injury, urinary or prostate problems, irregular heartbeat, blood pressure problems, thyroid disease, or heart, kidney, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while taking clomipramine. discuss risks and benefits if you are 65 or older, as safer or more effective alternatives may be available. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, tell the provider you take clomipramine. this medicine can cause drowsiness and can raise seizure risk. do not drive, operate machinery, swim, or climb until you know how it affects you. alcohol can increase drowsiness. if you use tobacco, be aware that cigarette smoking may reduce the effectiveness of clomipramine. clomipramine can precipitate angle-closure glaucoma in susceptible individuals. ask about an eye exam before you start. if you develop nausea, eye pain, vision changes such as seeing colored rings around lights, or swelling or redness in or around the eye, seek urgent medical care. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other advice, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? clomipramine may cause side effects. common effects include drowsiness, dry mouth, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, nervousness, decreased sexual ability, reduced memory or concentration, headache, nasal congestion, and changes in appetite or weight. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have any of the following or any symptoms listed in the important warning or special precautions sections: uncontrollable shaking, seizures, fast or irregular or pounding heartbeat, trouble urinating or loss of bladder control, believing things that are not true, seeing or hearing things that are not there, marked shakiness, trouble breathing or rapid breathing, severe muscle stiffness, unusual tiredness or weakness, sore throat, fever, or other signs of infection.

name: clonazepam
instructions: important warning: clonazepam can increase the risk of serious or life-threatening breathing problems, profound sedation, or coma when used with certain medicines. if you take or plan to take opioid medications for cough (for example, codeine in triacin-c or tuzistra xr; hydrocodone in anexsia, norco, zyfrel) or for pain (for example, codeine in fiorinal; fentanyl [actiq, duragesic, subsys, and others]; hydromorphone [dilaudid, exalgo]; meperidine [demerol]; methadone [dolophine, methadose]; morphine [astramorph, duramorph pf, kadian]; oxycodone [in oxycet, percocet, roxicet, and others]; tramadol [conzip, ultram, ultracet]), your doctor may need to adjust doses and will monitor you closely. if you use clonazepam with any of these and develop unusual dizziness, lightheadedness, extreme sleepiness, slowed or difficult breathing, or unresponsiveness, call your doctor immediately or seek emergency medical care. ensure that your family or caregivers know these warning signs and can get help if you cannot. clonazepam may be habit forming. do not take larger doses, take it more often, or use it longer than prescribed, especially if you have ever drunk large amounts of alcohol, used street drugs, or misused prescription medications. do not drink alcohol or use street drugs during treatment, as this further increases the risk of serious, life-threatening side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had depression or another mental illness. clonazepam can cause physical dependence, meaning withdrawal symptoms may occur if you stop suddenly or reduce the dose, especially after several days to weeks of use. do not stop or reduce clonazepam without talking to your doctor. sudden discontinuation can worsen your condition and cause withdrawal symptoms that may last for weeks to more than 12 months. your doctor will lower your dose gradually. call your doctor or seek emergency care if you experience any of the following: unusual movements; ringing in your ears; anxiety; memory problems; difficulty concentrating; sleep problems; seizures; shaking; muscle twitching; changes in mental health; depression; burning or prickling sensations in your hands, arms, legs, or feet; seeing or hearing things others do not; thoughts of harming or killing yourself or others; overexcitement; or losing touch with reality. why is this medication prescribed? clonazepam is used alone or with other medications to control certain types of seizures. it is also used to relieve panic attacks (sudden, unexpected episodes of extreme fear and worry about these attacks). clonazepam is a benzodiazepine that works by decreasing abnormal electrical activity in the brain. how should this medicine be used? clonazepam comes as a tablet and as an orally disintegrating tablet (a tablet that dissolves quickly in the mouth) to take by mouth. it is usually taken one to three times daily, with or without food, at the same times each day. follow your prescription label and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. do not push the orally disintegrating tablet through the foil. with dry hands, peel back the foil, remove the tablet, place it in your mouth, allow it to dissolve, and swallow with or without liquid. your doctor will usually start you on a low dose and increase it gradually, no more often than once every 3 days. clonazepam helps control your condition but does not cure it; it may take several weeks or longer to feel the full benefit. continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop clonazepam without talking to your doctor, even if you have mood or behavior changes. stopping suddenly may cause withdrawal symptoms such as new or worsening seizures; hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that do not exist); behavior changes; sweating; uncontrollable shaking; stomach or muscle cramps; anxiety; or difficulty falling or staying asleep. your doctor will taper your dose gradually. other uses for this medicine: clonazepam may also be used to treat akathisia (restlessness with a need for constant movement) that can occur as a side effect of antipsychotic medications, and to treat acute catatonic reactions (states in which a person does not move or speak at all or moves or speaks abnormally). discuss the possible risks and benefits with your doctor. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking clonazepam, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to clonazepam; other benzodiazepines such as alprazolam (xanax), chlordiazepoxide (librium, in librax), clorazepate (gen-xene, tranxene), diazepam (diastat, valium), estazolam, flurazepam, lorazepam (ativan), midazolam (versed), oxazepam, temazepam (restoril), or triazolam (halcion); any other medications; or any ingredients in clonazepam tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, and nutritional or herbal supplements you take or plan to take. your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. st. john’s wort may interact with clonazepam; do not start or stop it without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had glaucoma (increased pressure in the eye) or liver disease—your doctor may tell you not to take clonazepam—and if you have or have ever had lung or kidney disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor; clonazepam may harm the fetus. if you become pregnant while taking clonazepam, call your doctor. if you are 65 years of age or older, discuss risks and benefits with your doctor; older adults should receive lower doses because higher doses may not work better and can cause serious side effects. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking clonazepam. this medication may make you drowsy; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. your mental health may change unexpectedly, and you may become suicidal while taking clonazepam for epilepsy, mental illness, or other conditions. in clinical studies, about 1 in 500 adults and children 5 years and older who took anticonvulsants such as clonazepam became suicidal, sometimes as early as 1 week after starting. there is a risk of mental health changes both with and without treatment; you and your doctor will decide whether the risks of taking an anticonvulsant are greater than the risks of not treating your condition. you, your family, or your caregiver should call your doctor right away if you experience any of the following: panic attacks; agitation or restlessness; new or worsening irritability, anxiety, or depression; acting on dangerous impulses; difficulty falling or staying asleep; aggressive, angry, or violent behavior; mania (frenzied, abnormally excited mood); talking or thinking about wanting to hurt yourself or end your life; withdrawing from friends and family; preoccupation with death and dying; giving away prized possessions; or any other unusual changes in behavior or mood. ensure that your family or caregiver knows which symptoms may be serious so they can seek help if you cannot. what special dietary instructions should i follow? talk to your doctor about eating grapefruit or drinking grapefruit juice while taking clonazepam. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? clonazepam may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: drowsiness; dizziness; unsteadiness; problems with coordination; difficulty thinking or remembering; increased saliva; muscle or joint pain; frequent urination; blurred vision; changes in sex drive or ability. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of these or those listed in the important warning section, call your doctor immediately or seek emergency medical treatment: rash; hives; swelling of the eyes, face, lips, tongue, or throat; difficulty breathing or swallowing; hoarseness; difficulty breathing.

name: clonidine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? clonidine is taken alone or with other medicines to treat high blood pressure. it is also used alone or with other medicines, as part of a treatment plan, to help control symptoms of attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (adhd) in children 6 years of age and older, such as trouble focusing, controlling actions, and staying still or quiet. clonidine belongs to a class of medicines called centrally acting alpha-agonist antihypertensives. it lowers blood pressure by slowing the heart rate and relaxing blood vessels so blood flows more easily. the extended-release tablet may help adhd by affecting brain areas that regulate attention and impulsivity. untreated high blood pressure can damage the brain, heart, blood vessels, kidneys, and eyes, leading to heart disease, heart attack, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, loss of vision, and other problems. along with medication, lifestyle changes—eating a low-fat, low-salt diet, maintaining a healthy weight, exercising at least 30 minutes most days, not smoking, and limiting alcohol—also help control blood pressure. how should this medicine be used? clonidine comes as an immediate-release tablet, an extended-release tablet, and an extended-release oral suspension, taken by mouth with or without food. the immediate-release tablet is usually taken two times a day at evenly spaced intervals. if the extended-release tablet is used for high blood pressure, it is usually taken once daily; if used for adhd, it is taken once or twice daily. the extended-release oral suspension is usually taken once daily at bedtime. take clonidine at the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. swallow extended-release tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush them. to take the extended-release oral suspension: before first use, remove the cap and firmly press the adapter into the bottle neck until its top is even with the bottle top; do not remove the adapter while using the bottle, then recap clockwise. gently shake the bottle up and down for at least 10 seconds before each dose. to measure a dose, push the oral syringe plunger all the way down and insert the syringe into the adapter of the upright bottle. turn the bottle upside down and slowly pull back the plunger to the amount prescribed. if you are unsure how to measure the dose, ask your doctor or pharmacist. if you see air bubbles, move the plunger in and out until most bubbles are gone and tap the syringe barrel to remove any remaining bubbles. remove the syringe from the adapter and slowly squirt the suspension into your mouth or your child’s mouth toward the inside of the cheek, pushing the plunger all the way in to give the full dose; allow time to swallow. place the cap over the adapter after each use. rinse the oral syringe with water after each use and allow it to dry. your doctor may start with a low dose and increase it gradually, no more than once each week. clonidine helps control your condition but does not cure it. keep taking it even if you feel well. do not stop clonidine without talking to your doctor. suddenly stopping can cause a rapid rise in blood pressure and symptoms such as fast heartbeat, nervousness, anxiety, headache, nausea, flushing, lightheadedness, chest tightness, and shaking. your doctor will taper your dose gradually—over at least 2 days for the immediate-release tablet and over 3 to 7 days for the extended-release tablet and oral suspension. other uses for this medicine clonidine is also used to treat dysmenorrhea (painful menstrual cramps), hypertensive crisis (very high blood pressure), menopausal hot flashes, and alcohol and opiate (narcotic) withdrawal. it is also used as an aid in smoking cessation therapy and to help diagnose pheochromocytoma (a tumor near the kidneys that can cause high blood pressure and fast heart rate). ask your doctor about the possible risks of using this medicine for your condition. this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking clonidine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to clonidine, any of its ingredients, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the tablets, extended-release tablets, or extended-release oral suspension; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. also tell your doctor if you have ever had a skin reaction or rash after using clonidine patches. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had a stroke; low or high blood pressure; a heart attack; an irregular heartbeat or other heart rhythm problem; other heart problems; kidney disease; or a history of fainting. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking clonidine, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking clonidine. clonidine may make you drowsy or dizzy; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. ask your doctor about the safe use of alcohol while taking clonidine; alcohol can worsen its side effects. clonidine may cause dizziness, lightheadedness, and fainting when you stand up too quickly, especially when you first start taking it; to reduce this, get out of bed slowly, letting your feet rest on the floor for a few minutes before standing. extended-release clonidine for adhd should be used as part of a comprehensive treatment program that may include counseling and special education; follow all instructions from your doctor and therapist. you may faint if you become dehydrated or overheated during treatment; drink plenty of liquids and stay cool. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? clonidine may cause side effects. if any of the following symptoms, or those listed in the special precautions section, are severe or do not go away, tell your doctor: dry mouth; tiredness; weakness; headache; nervousness; decreased sexual ability; nausea; vomiting; constipation. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have: rash; hives; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; difficulty swallowing or breathing; hoarseness; fainting; fast or irregular heartbeat. clonidine may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: clopidogrel
instructions: important warning: clopidogrel must be converted to an active form in your body to work. some people do not activate clopidogrel as well as others, which can increase the risk of heart attack or stroke. tests are available to identify people who have reduced activation. ask your doctor if testing is right for you. if you are found to have difficulty converting clopidogrel to its active form, your doctor may change your dose or choose a different medicine. your doctor or pharmacist will give you the medication guide when you start clopidogrel and with each refill; read it carefully and ask any questions. discuss the risks and benefits of clopidogrel with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? clopidogrel is used alone or with aspirin to reduce the risk of serious heart and blood vessel problems in people who have had a heart attack, ischemic stroke, or severe chest pain. this includes those undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention (pci; angioplasty) with coronary stent placement, or those who have had coronary artery bypass grafting (cabg). it is also used to help prevent serious cardiovascular problems in people with peripheral arterial disease (poor blood flow to the legs). clopidogrel is an antiplatelet drug that works by stopping platelets from clumping and forming clots that can cause heart attack or stroke. how should this medicine be used? clopidogrel is an oral tablet usually taken once daily, with or without food, at about the same time each day. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. do not take more or less than prescribed or take it more often. clopidogrel helps only while you continue taking it. keep taking it even if you feel well. do not stop clopidogrel without talking to your doctor. stopping can raise your risk of heart attack or stroke; if you have a stent, stopping too soon increases the risk of a clot forming in the stent. other uses for this medicine clopidogrel is sometimes used to help prevent blood clots in people with atrial fibrillation. talk to your doctor about the potential risks of using it for your condition. it may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking clopidogrel, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to clopidogrel, prasugrel (effient), ticlopidine, any other medicines, or any ingredient in the tablets. give your doctor and pharmacist a list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. the following over-the-counter products may interact with clopidogrel: omeprazole (prilosec, prilosec otc, zegerid), esomeprazole (nexium), aspirin, and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin) and naproxen (aleve, naprosyn). tell your doctor and pharmacist if you use these and do not start them while on clopidogrel without medical advice. do not take clopidogrel if you have active bleeding such as bleeding stomach or intestinal ulcers, bleeding in the brain, or other severe bleeding conditions. tell your doctor if you were recently injured; if you have or have ever had liver or kidney disease; or if you have conditions that increase bleeding risk, including stomach problems like ulcers. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor; if you become pregnant while taking clopidogrel, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, tell the doctor or dentist you take clopidogrel. your doctor may advise stopping it at least 5 days before surgery to reduce bleeding risk and will tell you when to restart. know that you may bruise or bleed more easily or for longer while taking clopidogrel; take care to avoid cuts or injuries. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? clopidogrel may cause side effects. common side effects include tiredness, headache, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, diarrhea, and nosebleeds. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away if you have any of the following: hives, rash, itching, trouble breathing or swallowing, swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, hoarseness; black, tarry stools; red blood in stools; bloody vomit or vomit that looks like coffee grounds; unusual bleeding or bruising; pink or brown urine; slow or difficult speech; weakness or numbness of an arm or leg; vision changes; fever; shortness of breath; rapid heartbeat; pale skin; purple patches or bleeding under the skin; confusion; yellowing of the skin or eyes; seizures. clopidogrel may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: clorazepate
instructions: important warning: clorazepate may increase the risk of serious or life-threatening breathing problems, profound sedation, or coma when used with certain opioid medicines. tell your doctor if you are taking or plan to take opioid medicines for cough such as codeine in triacin-c or tuzistra xr, or for pain such as codeine in fiorinal; fentanyl actiq, duragesic, subsys; hydrocodone in anexsia, norco, zyfrel; hydromorphone dilaudid, exalgo; meperidine demerol; methadone dolophine, methadose; morphine astramorph, duramorph pf, kadian; oxycodone in oxycet, percocet, roxicet, and others; or tramadol conzip, ultram, ultracet. your doctor may need to adjust doses and will monitor you closely. if you take clorazepate with any of these medicines and develop unusual dizziness, lightheadedness, extreme sleepiness, slowed or difficult breathing, or unresponsiveness, call your doctor or seek emergency care immediately. make sure your caregiver or family knows these serious symptoms so they can get help if you cannot. clorazepate may be habit forming. do not take larger doses, take it more often, or use it longer than directed. tell your doctor if you currently drink or have ever drunk large amounts of alcohol, have used or ever used street drugs, or have misused prescription medicines. do not drink alcohol or use street drugs during treatment because this increases the risk of serious, life-threatening side effects. clorazepate can cause physical dependence, in which unpleasant symptoms occur if the medicine is suddenly stopped or the dose is reduced, especially after several days to several weeks of use. do not stop clorazepate or reduce your dose without talking to your doctor. stopping suddenly can worsen your condition and cause withdrawal symptoms that may last for several weeks to more than 12 months. your doctor will likely taper your dose gradually. call your doctor or get emergency help if you have any of the following: unusual movements; ringing in the ears; anxiety; memory problems; trouble concentrating; sleep problems; seizures; shaking; muscle twitching; changes in mental health; depression; burning or prickling in the hands, arms, legs, or feet; seeing or hearing things others do not; thoughts of harming or killing yourself or others; overexcitement; or loss of touch with reality. why is this medication prescribed? clorazepate is used to relieve anxiety. it is also used with other medicines to treat certain types of seizures and to relieve symptoms that may occur in people who have stopped heavy, long-term alcohol use. clorazepate is a benzodiazepine. it works by decreasing abnormal electrical activity in the brain. how should this medicine be used? clorazepate comes as an oral tablet and is usually taken one to three times daily. follow your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take clorazepate exactly as directed. for anxiety or seizures, your doctor will usually start with a low dose and increase it gradually. for alcohol withdrawal, your doctor will usually start with a higher dose and decrease it gradually as symptoms are controlled. clorazepate helps control seizures and anxiety but does not cure them. continue to take it even if you feel well. other uses for this medicine: this medicine may be prescribed for other uses. ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking clorazepate, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to clorazepate; to other benzodiazepines such as alprazolam xanax, chlordiazepoxide librium or in librax, clonazepam klonopin, diazepam diastat or valium, estazolam, flurazepam, lorazepam ativan, oxazepam, temazepam restoril, or triazolam halcion; to any other medicines; or to any ingredient in clorazepate tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had glaucoma; your doctor may tell you not to take clorazepate. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking clorazepate, call your doctor. if you are 65 years of age or older, discuss the risks and benefits; older adults should not usually take clorazepate because it may be less safe or effective than other options. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking clorazepate. this medicine may make you drowsy. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. your mental health may change in unexpected ways, and you may become suicidal while taking clorazepate for epilepsy, mental illness, or other conditions. in clinical studies, about 1 in 500 adults and children 5 years and older who took anticonvulsants such as clorazepate became suicidal. some developed suicidal thoughts or behavior as early as one week after starting. there is a risk of mental health changes both with and without treatment, so you and your doctor will weigh these risks. you, your family, or your caregiver should call your doctor right away if you have panic attacks; agitation or restlessness; new or worsening irritability, anxiety, or depression; acting on dangerous impulses; trouble falling or staying asleep; aggressive, angry, or violent behavior; mania abnormally excited mood; talking or thinking about wanting to hurt yourself or end your life; withdrawing from friends and family; preoccupation with death and dying; giving away prized possessions; or any other unusual changes in behavior or mood. make sure your family or caregiver knows which symptoms are serious so they can call the doctor if you cannot seek help on your own. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? clorazepate may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: drowsiness, dizziness, tiredness, headache, nervousness, confusion, dry mouth. some side effects can be serious. if you have any of the following, or any symptoms listed in the important warning section, call your doctor right away or get emergency medical help: blurred or double vision, uncontrollable shaking of a part of the body, slurred speech, trouble keeping your balance, or rash. clorazepate may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: clotrimazole lozenge
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? clotrimazole lozenges are used to treat yeast infections of the mouth in adults and children 3 years of age and older. they can also be used to prevent mouth yeast infections in people at risk who are receiving certain treatments. clotrimazole is an antifungal in the imidazole class that works by stopping the growth of fungi that cause infection. how should this medicine be used? clotrimazole comes as a lozenge that dissolves slowly in the mouth. for treatment of yeast infections, it is usually used five times a day for 14 days. for prevention, it is usually used three times a day; the length of preventive treatment depends on your condition. use clotrimazole lozenges at about the same times each day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully and use clotrimazole exactly as directed. do not use more or less than prescribed or use it more often. to use, place the lozenge in your mouth and allow it to dissolve slowly; do not chew, crush, or swallow it. it should take about 30 minutes to dissolve. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using clotrimazole lozenges, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to clotrimazole, any other medications, or any ingredients in the lozenges; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using clotrimazole lozenges, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? clotrimazole may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: nausea, vomiting, unpleasant mouth sensations, itching. clotrimazole may cause other side effects.

name: clotrimazole topical
