instructions: why is this medication prescribed? topical clotrimazole treats tinea corporis (ringworm), tinea cruris (jock itch), and tinea pedis (athlete’s foot). it belongs to the imidazole class of antifungals and works by stopping the growth of fungi that cause infection. it may also be used for tinea versicolor (light or brown patches on the chest, back, arms, legs, or neck) and yeast infections of the skin; talk to your doctor about the risks and whether it is appropriate for your condition. how should this medicine be used? topical clotrimazole comes as a cream or liquid for use on the skin and is usually applied twice daily (morning and night). follow the package directions exactly, and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. do not use more or less or more often than directed. for external use only; do not swallow or get it in your eyes. clotrimazole is not effective on the scalp or nails. for jock itch, symptoms should improve within 2 weeks; for athlete’s foot or ringworm, within 4 weeks. call your doctor if symptoms do not improve in these time frames or if they worsen at any time. to apply, wash and thoroughly dry the affected area, then apply a thin layer of cream or liquid to cover the area. for athlete’s foot, pay special attention to the spaces between the toes. wear well-fitting, breathable shoes and change shoes and socks at least daily. if using the liquid, do not apply it to severely cracked or irritated skin. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to clotrimazole, other medicines, or any ingredients in the product; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, discuss use with your doctor; if you become pregnant while using clotrimazole, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply a double amount to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? clotrimazole may cause blistering, redness, swelling, itching, burning, stinging, peeling, hives, or skin cracks. stop using clotrimazole and call your doctor if you experience any of these symptoms. clotrimazole may cause other side effects.

name: clotrimazole vaginal
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? vaginal clotrimazole is used to treat vaginal yeast infections in adults and in children 12 years and older. it is an imidazole antifungal that works by stopping the growth of the fungi that cause the infection. how should this medicine be used? vaginal clotrimazole comes as a cream to be inserted into the vagina and may also be applied to the skin around the outside of the vagina. insert the cream into the vagina once daily at bedtime for 3 or 7 consecutive days, depending on the product instructions. apply a small amount to the external area twice daily for up to 7 days. follow the package directions or your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. use clotrimazole exactly as directed; do not use more, less, or more often than recommended. vaginal clotrimazole is available over the counter. if this is your first episode of vaginal itching and discomfort, talk to a doctor before using clotrimazole. if a doctor has previously told you that you had a yeast infection and you have the same symptoms again, use the vaginal cream as directed on the package. do not have vaginal intercourse or use other vaginal products such as tampons, douches, or spermicides during treatment. you should start to feel better within the first 3 days; if your symptoms do not improve or get worse, call your doctor. to treat the skin around the vagina, use your finger to apply a small amount of cream to the affected area. to insert the vaginal dose, read the product instructions and follow these steps: fill the supplied applicator to the indicated level; lie on your back with your knees bent and apart or stand with your feet apart and knees bent; gently insert the applicator into the vagina and press the plunger to release the medication; withdraw the applicator; discard it if disposable, or if reusable, take it apart and clean it with soap and warm water after each use. wash your hands promptly to avoid spreading the infection. apply the dose at bedtime, and avoid getting up again afterward except to wash your hands. you may wear a sanitary pad to protect clothing from stains. continue using clotrimazole vaginal cream even if your period starts during treatment. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using vaginal clotrimazole, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to clotrimazole, any other medicines, or any of the ingredients in the vaginal cream. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have lower stomach, back, or shoulder pain; fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, or foul-smelling vaginal discharge; have been exposed to or have human immunodeficiency virus (hiv) or acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (aids); or have frequent vaginal yeast infections (about once a month or 3 or more infections in 6 months). tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using clotrimazole, call your doctor. you should know that condoms and diaphragms may be weakened during treatment with vaginal clotrimazole; they may be less effective at preventing pregnancy or sexually transmitted diseases if used during treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? clotrimazole may cause side effects. if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away, contact your doctor: increased burning, itching, or irritation of the vagina. some side effects can be serious. stop using clotrimazole and call your doctor immediately if you experience: rash; hives; stomach pain; fever; chills; nausea; vomiting; or foul-smelling vaginal discharge.

name: clozapine
instructions: important warning: clozapine can cause a severe or life-threatening drop in white blood cells. your doctor will order regular blood tests to monitor your white blood cell count. low white blood cells increase the risk of serious infection. call your doctor right away if you have extreme tiredness, weakness, fever, sore throat, chills, flu-like symptoms, unusual vaginal discharge or itching, mouth or throat sores, wounds that heal slowly, pain or burning with urination, sores or pain around the rectal area, or abdominal pain. clozapine may cause seizures. tell your doctor if you have ever had seizures, a head injury, or if you drink large amounts of alcohol. do not drive, operate machinery, swim, or climb while taking clozapine because sudden loss of consciousness could cause harm. if you have a seizure, call your doctor immediately or get emergency help. clozapine may cause serious or life-threatening heart inflammation or swelling, and may enlarge or harden the heart, reducing its ability to pump blood. call your doctor immediately if you have extreme tiredness, flu-like symptoms, swelling of the legs, ankles, or feet, trouble breathing or fast breathing, fever, chest pain, dizziness, or a fast, irregular, or pounding heartbeat. clozapine can cause dangerously low blood pressure and slow heart rates, leading to dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting when standing, especially when starting or increasing the dose. tell your doctor if you have or have had a heart attack, heart failure, or a slow or irregular heartbeat; if you take blood pressure medications; or if you have severe vomiting, diarrhea, or signs of dehydration now or at any time during treatment. your doctor will likely start with a low dose and increase it gradually to help your body adjust and lower this risk. if you do not take clozapine for 2 days or longer, talk to your doctor before restarting; you will likely need to restart at a low dose. call your doctor right away if you faint or have a slow or irregular heartbeat. use in older adults: older adults with dementia who take antipsychotics such as clozapine have an increased risk of death during treatment. clozapine is not approved by the fda for behavior problems in older adults with dementia. talk to the prescribing doctor if you, a family member, or someone you care for has dementia and is taking this medication. why is this medication prescribed? clozapine is used to treat schizophrenia in certain people. it is an atypical antipsychotic that works by changing the activity of certain natural substances in the brain. how should this medicine be used? clozapine is available as a tablet, an orally disintegrating tablet (dissolves on the tongue), and an oral suspension (liquid) taken by mouth. it is usually taken once or twice daily at the same times each day. follow your prescription label carefully. take exactly as directed; do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. for orally disintegrating tablets: do not push the tablet through the foil. with dry hands, peel back the foil, immediately remove the tablet, place it on your tongue, and allow it to dissolve; you can swallow with saliva and do not need water. for oral suspension: 1) ensure the cap is tight by turning clockwise. 2) shake the bottle up and down for 10 seconds. 3) to open, push down and turn counterclockwise. 4) on first use, push the adaptor into the bottle until aligned with the top. 5) use the 1 ml syringe for doses ≤1 ml or the 9 ml syringe for doses >1 ml. 6) draw air into the syringe, insert the tip into the adaptor, and push the air into the bottle. 7) while holding the syringe in place, turn the bottle upside down. 8) pull back to draw medication into the syringe; do not pull the plunger all the way out. 9) you may see a small air bubble; push medication back into the bottle to remove air. 10) pull back again to draw the correct dose. 11) turn the bottle upright and remove the syringe without pressing the plunger. 12) take the dose right away; do not store the filled syringe. 13) place the syringe tip into one side of your mouth, close your lips around it, and press the plunger slowly while swallowing. 14) leave the adaptor in the bottle, replace the cap, and tighten clockwise. 15) rinse the syringe with warm tap water by drawing water in and pushing it out until clean; let air dry and discard any leftover rinse water. clozapine controls but does not cure schizophrenia. it may take several weeks or longer to feel the full benefit. continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop without talking to your doctor; your dose will likely be reduced gradually. other uses for this medicine: this medication should not be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking clozapine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to clozapine, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your allergy symptoms. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor for side effects. st. john’s wort may interact with clozapine; do not start it while taking clozapine without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you or a family member has ever had a prolonged qt interval (a rare heart rhythm problem that can cause fainting or sudden death); and if you have or have ever had low magnesium or potassium levels; diarrhea; constipation; urinary problems; prostate problems; diabetes; high cholesterol (dyslipidemia); paralytic ileus (blocked intestinal movement); glaucoma; high or low blood pressure; balance problems; or heart, kidney, lung, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you have ever had to stop a mental health medication due to severe side effects. if you are pregnant, especially in the last months, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor. if you become pregnant while taking clozapine, call your doctor; use late in pregnancy may cause problems in newborns. ask your doctor about safe use of alcohol; alcohol can worsen clozapine side effects. tell your doctor if you use tobacco; cigarette smoking may decrease clozapine’s effectiveness, and your doctor may advise you not to smoke while taking it. you may develop high blood sugar (hyperglycemia) during treatment, even without preexisting diabetes. people with schizophrenia are at higher risk of diabetes, and clozapine and similar medicines can increase this risk. call your doctor right away if you have extreme thirst, frequent urination, extreme hunger, blurred vision, or weakness. high blood sugar can lead to ketoacidosis, a serious, potentially life-threatening condition. symptoms include dry mouth, nausea and vomiting, shortness of breath, fruity-smelling breath, and decreased consciousness. if you have phenylketonuria (pku), know that orally disintegrating tablets contain aspartame, which forms phenylalanine. you may gain weight while taking clozapine; you and your doctor should monitor your weight regularly. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ask your doctor about consuming caffeinated beverages while taking this medicine. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose. if you miss taking clozapine for more than 2 days, call your doctor before taking more; you may need to restart at a lower dose. what side effects can this medication cause? clozapine may cause side effects. common side effects include: drowsiness; dizziness, unsteadiness, or balance problems; increased salivation; dry mouth; restlessness; and headache. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have any of the following or those listed in the important warning or special precautions sections: constipation; nausea; stomach swelling or pain; vomiting; uncontrolled shaking of the hands; unusual, uncontrollable movements of the face or body; falls; difficulty urinating or loss of bladder control; fever, sweating, confusion, fast or irregular heartbeat, or severe muscle stiffness; vision changes; shakiness; behavior changes; loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, pain in the upper right abdomen, lack of energy, unusual bleeding or bruising, or yellowing of the skin or eyes; chest pain; sudden shortness of breath or trouble breathing; swelling of a leg or arm; leg pain; or redness, discoloration, or warmth in the legs or arms. clozapine may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you notice any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: co-trimoxazole
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? co-trimoxazole, a combination of sulfamethoxazole and trimethoprim, is used to treat certain bacterial infections and is also used for traveler’s diarrhea. it belongs to a class of medications called sulfonamides and works by stopping the growth of bacteria. antibiotics do not treat viral infections. how should this medicine be used? co-trimoxazole comes as tablets and as an oral suspension. it is taken two to four times a day. your doctor will decide how often and how long you should take it based on the infection being treated. take it at the same times each day and exactly as directed. do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. you should begin to feel better in the first few days; if your symptoms do not improve or get worse, call your doctor. shake the liquid well before each dose. take co-trimoxazole until you finish the prescription, even if you feel better. stopping too soon or skipping doses may result in incomplete treatment and antibiotic resistance. other uses for this medicine this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking co-trimoxazole, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this drug, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe the symptoms you had. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had low platelets caused by sulfonamides or trimethoprim; abnormal red blood cells due to low folic acid; phenylketonuria (pku); or liver or kidney disease—your doctor may tell you not to take co-trimoxazole. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had severe allergies; asthma; low folate levels; human immunodeficiency virus (hiv) infection; porphyria; thyroid disease; or glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (g-6-pd) deficiency. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, inform your doctor. if you become pregnant while taking co-trimoxazole, call your doctor immediately, as it can harm the fetus. avoid unnecessary or prolonged sunlight exposure and wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen, because co-trimoxazole may make your skin more sensitive to sunlight. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. drink plenty of fluids while taking co-trimoxazole. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? co-trimoxazole may cause side effects. if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite. if you experience any of the following, call your doctor immediately or seek emergency medical treatment: rash, itching, redness, peeling, or blistering of the skin; sore throat; loss of consciousness; fever or chills; severe diarrhea; watery or bloody stools with or without fever and stomach cramps that may occur up to 2 months or more after treatment; shortness of breath, cough, or difficulty breathing; unusual bruising or bleeding or red or purple skin discolorations; fever; rash; yellowing of the skin and eyes; abdominal tenderness; nausea, vomiting, diarrhea; swollen lymph nodes. other side effects may occur with co-trimoxazole.

name: co-trimoxazole injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? co-trimoxazole (sulfamethoxazole and trimethoprim) injection is an antibiotic in the sulfonamide class used to treat certain bacterial infections by stopping bacterial growth. it does not treat viral infections. how should this medicine be used? co-trimoxazole injection is a solution that is diluted and infused into a vein over 60 to 90 minutes. it is usually given every 6, 8, or 12 hours. the length of treatment depends on the type of infection and your response. you may receive it in the hospital or at home. if at home, your healthcare provider will teach you how to prepare, administer, and store it and how to dispose of supplies. use exactly as directed and finish the full course even if you feel better. call your doctor if your symptoms do not improve or if they worsen. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving co-trimoxazole, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to sulfamethoxazole, trimethoprim, other sulfonamides, or any ingredient of the product, and describe any past reactions. provide a list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and herbal products you use; dose changes or monitoring may be needed. do not use this medicine if you have had low platelets due to sulfonamides or trimethoprim or if you have megaloblastic anemia due to folate deficiency, unless your doctor decides benefits outweigh risks. tell your doctor if you have asthma, severe allergies, low folate levels, glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (g6pd) deficiency, hiv infection, porphyria, or thyroid, liver, or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; co-trimoxazole can harm the fetus. limit sun exposure and use protective clothing and sunscreen, as this medicine can increase sun sensitivity. what special dietary instructions should i follow? continue your usual diet unless your doctor advises otherwise. drink plenty of fluids while receiving this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose; if so, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. if your doses are given at a clinic, call to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, diarrhea, joint or muscle pain, and pain or irritation at the infusion site. serious side effects can include severe skin reactions (rash, itching, hives, blistering or peeling skin), return of fever, sore throat, chills, cough, or other signs of infection, shortness of breath, severe or persistent diarrhea or watery or bloody stools with or without fever and stomach cramps that may occur during treatment or up to 2 months after, fast heartbeat, symptoms of low blood sugar such as hunger, headache, tiredness, sweating, shaking, irritability, blurry vision, difficulty concentrating, or loss of consciousness, yellowing of the skin or eyes, swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs, hoarseness, difficulty breathing or swallowing, unusual bleeding or bruising or red or purple skin spots, paleness, swelling at the injection site, decreased urination, seizures, or a reaction with fever, rash, yellowing of skin and eyes, abdominal tenderness, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and swollen lymph nodes. stop the medication and seek medical help immediately if you develop serious symptoms. this medicine may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: cobicistat
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cobicistat is used to increase the levels of atazanavir or darunavir when these medicines are used to treat human immunodeficiency virus (hiv). it is a pharmacokinetic booster that works by raising the amount of atazanavir or darunavir in the body so they can have a greater effect. how should this medicine be used? cobicistat comes as a tablet to take by mouth. take it with food once a day together with atazanavir or darunavir. always take cobicistat at the same time as atazanavir or darunavir and at about the same time every day. take cobicistat exactly as directed. do not take more or less than prescribed or take it more often than your doctor recommends. ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cobicistat, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to this drug, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe the symptoms you had. some medicines should not be taken with cobicistat; others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. discuss all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and herbal products you use or plan to use with your doctor and pharmacist before starting cobicistat. do not start, stop, or change any medicines while taking cobicistat without your doctor’s advice. st. john’s wort may interact with cobicistat; tell your doctor and pharmacist if you take it, and do not start it while using cobicistat without discussing it with your healthcare provider. if you are taking cobicistat with atazanavir and also take antacids (such as maalox, mylanta, tums), take the antacid 2 hours before or 2 hours after cobicistat and atazanavir. if you are taking cobicistat with atazanavir and also take an h2 blocker for indigestion, heartburn, or ulcers (such as cimetidine, famotidine, nizatidine, or ranitidine), take atazanavir/cobicistat at the same time as the h2 blocker or at least 10 hours after the h2 blocker. if you are taking cobicistat with atazanavir and also take a proton pump inhibitor (such as esomeprazole, lansoprazole, omeprazole, pantoprazole, or rabeprazole), take atazanavir/cobicistat at least 12 hours after the proton pump inhibitor. you should know that cobicistat may decrease the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives (birth control pills, patches, rings, and injections). use another method of contraception to prevent pregnancy while taking cobicistat and talk to your doctor about options. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney or liver disease; if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant (call your doctor if you become pregnant while taking cobicistat); and if you are breastfeeding or plan to breastfeed, because some of the medication and hiv may pass into breast milk—discuss the risks with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. it is important to take cobicistat and all other medicines prescribed for hiv every day on a regular schedule. missed doses may make the medicines less effective. do not stop any of these medicines without talking to your doctor. what side effects can this medication cause? cobicistat may cause side effects. if this symptom is severe or does not go away: nausea. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of these symptoms, call your doctor immediately: yellowing of the skin or eyes, rash, decreased urination. cobicistat may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: cobimetinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cobimetinib is used with vemurafenib (zelboraf) to treat certain types of melanoma that cannot be treated with surgery or have spread to other parts of the body. it is also used to treat histiocytic neoplasms, conditions that cause an overproduction and accumulation of a type of white blood cell. cobimetinib is a kinase inhibitor that blocks an abnormal protein that signals cancer cells to multiply, helping to slow or stop the spread of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? cobimetinib comes as a tablet taken by mouth with or without food. it is usually taken once daily for the first 21 days of a 28-day cycle. take it at the same time each day. follow your prescription label carefully. take it exactly as directed; do not take more or less or more often than prescribed. if you vomit after taking a dose, do not take another dose; continue your regular schedule. your doctor may reduce your dose or temporarily or permanently stop treatment depending on how well it works for you and the side effects you have. tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cobimetinib, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cobimetinib, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, and nutritional supplements you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor about any herbal products, especially st. john’s wort; do not take st. john’s wort while taking cobimetinib. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had skin conditions other than melanoma, bleeding problems, vision problems, any muscle condition, or heart or liver disease. know that cobimetinib may decrease fertility in men and women, but you should not assume that you or your partner cannot become pregnant. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, use reliable birth control during treatment and for 2 weeks after the last dose; talk with your doctor about options. if you become pregnant, call your doctor immediately; cobimetinib may harm the fetus. if you are breastfeeding, do not breastfeed during treatment and for 2 weeks after the last dose. avoid unnecessary or prolonged sunlight exposure and wear protective clothing, sunglasses, lip balm, and sunscreen (spf 30 or higher), as cobimetinib can make your skin more sensitive to sunlight. contact your doctor right away if you get a sunburn. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not eat grapefruit or drink grapefruit juice while taking this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cobimetinib may cause side effects. common side effects include mouth ulcers, hair loss, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, heartburn or indigestion, dry mouth, mouth pain, fever, chills, sore throat, frequent or painful urination or other signs of infection, and falls. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have a rash covering a large area, blisters, or peeling skin; changes in skin appearance; a new wart; a skin sore or red bump that bleeds or does not heal; a change in the size or color of a mole; unusual bleeding or bruising; black, tarry stools; blood in the urine; unusual vaginal bleeding; stomach pain; headache or dizziness; coughing or wheezing; rapid, irregular, or pounding heartbeat; shortness of breath; tiredness; swelling of the face, arms, legs, ankles, or feet; muscle spasms, pain, or weakness; or vision changes such as seeing halos, blurred outlines around objects, blurred vision, or vision loss. signs of liver problems include yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark tea-colored urine, pain in the upper right abdomen, nausea, vomiting, or loss of appetite. cobimetinib may increase the risk of new skin cancers; talk to your doctor about the risks. cobimetinib may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: codeine
instructions: important warning: codeine can be habit-forming. take it exactly as prescribed; do not take more or less, take it more often, change how you take it, or stop it suddenly without your doctor’s guidance. codeine can cause serious or life-threatening breathing problems, especially during the first 24 to 72 hours of treatment and any time your dose is increased. the risk is higher if you or a family member drinks or has ever drunk large amounts of alcohol, uses or has used street drugs, has misused prescription medicines, has had an overdose, or if you have or have had depression or another mental illness. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you have slowed or shallow breathing, long pauses between breaths, or shortness of breath. codeine can harm or cause death in others who take your medicine, especially children. store it securely to prevent accidental or intentional use by others. taking certain medications, drinking alcohol, or using street drugs while on codeine can increase the risk of dangerous breathing problems, excessive sedation, or coma. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses and will monitor you closely. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; regular use during pregnancy can cause life-threatening withdrawal in your newborn. you will receive a medication guide—read it carefully and ask questions. discuss the risks and benefits of codeine with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? codeine is used to relieve pain and to suppress cough. it is an opioid (narcotic) analgesic and an antitussive. for pain, it changes how the brain and nervous system respond to pain; for cough, it decreases activity in the part of the brain that causes coughing. codeine is also available in combination with acetaminophen or aspirin and as an ingredient in many cough and cold products. if you use a combination product, review information about all ingredients and ask your doctor or pharmacist for guidance. how should this medicine be used? codeine is taken by mouth as an immediate-release tablet, extended-release tablet, solution, or syrup. for pain, it is typically taken every 4 hours as needed; your doctor may adjust your dose based on pain control and side effects—do not take more or more often than prescribed. tell your doctor if your pain is not controlled, worsens, you develop new pain, or you notice increased sensitivity to pain. for cough, take the solution or syrup every 4 to 6 hours as needed, or the extended-release tablet every 12 hours as needed. ask your doctor or pharmacist about having a rescue medicine such as naloxone or nalmefene available; these can reverse life-threatening opioid overdose and are available over the counter or with a prescription. ensure that you and those around you know how to recognize an overdose, how to use the rescue medicine, and what to do until emergency help arrives. if overdose symptoms occur, a caregiver should give the first dose, call 911 immediately, stay with you, and give additional doses every 2 to 3 minutes if symptoms return until help arrives. if you have taken codeine for several weeks or longer, do not stop suddenly; your doctor will taper your dose. stopping suddenly can cause withdrawal symptoms such as restlessness, enlarged pupils, tearing, irritability, anxiety, runny nose, insomnia, yawning, sweating, fast breathing, fast heartbeat, chills, goosebumps, nausea, loss of appetite, vomiting, diarrhea, stomach cramps, muscle aches, or backache. if using the oral solution or syrup, measure your dose with the provided device or a medication-measuring spoon or syringe, not a household spoon. ask your pharmacist if you have questions about measuring your dose. other uses for this medicine: this medication is sometimes prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking codeine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to codeine or any ingredients in the product. some medicines should not be taken with codeine. review all medicines you take or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist before starting codeine, and always get their advice before starting, stopping, or changing any medicine while taking codeine. do not take codeine if you are taking or have taken within the past 14 days an mao inhibitor such as isocarboxazid, linezolid, methylene blue, phenelzine, selegiline, or tranylcypromine. nonprescription or herbal products such as st. johns wort and tryptophan may interact with codeine; do not start them without medical advice. tell your doctor if you have slowed breathing, asthma, copd, or other lung problems; a blockage or narrowing of the stomach or intestines; or paralytic ileus—your doctor may tell you not to take codeine. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had a brain tumor or increased intracranial pressure; seizures; or thyroid, pancreatic, gallbladder, heart, liver, or kidney disease. this medication may decrease fertility in both men and women. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while taking codeine, call your doctor. codeine may make you drowsy; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. do not drink alcohol while taking codeine, as it can worsen side effects. codeine may cause dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting when standing up quickly, especially when starting treatment; rise slowly from lying or sitting. constipation is common; ask your doctor about diet changes and medicines to prevent or treat it. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? codeine is usually taken as needed. if you miss a dose, skip it and resume your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? codeine may cause side effects. common effects include nausea, vomiting, sweating, decreased sexual desire, and difficulty getting or keeping an erection. some side effects can be serious. stop taking codeine and call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have any of the breathing problems listed in the important warning; agitation; hallucinations; fever; sweating; confusion; fast heartbeat; shivering; severe muscle stiffness or twitching; loss of coordination; nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea; nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, weakness, or dizziness; chest pain or heartbeat changes; rash, hives, itching, hoarseness, trouble breathing or swallowing, or swelling of the eyes, face, lips, mouth, tongue, or throat; seizures; extreme drowsiness; new pain or pain from light touch or routine activities; difficulty swallowing, regurgitation of food, or chest-area pain; or unusual snoring or long pauses in breathing during sleep. codeine may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: colchicine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? colchicine is used in adults to prevent gout attacks and to relieve pain during gout attacks. it is also used to treat familial mediterranean fever (fmf) in adults and children 4 years of age and older. low-dose colchicine (lodoco) is used to reduce the risk of heart attack, stroke, cardiovascular death, and the need for procedures such as angioplasty or coronary artery bypass grafting (cabg) in patients with atherosclerosis or multiple risk factors for heart and blood vessel disease. colchicine is not a general pain reliever and should not be used for pain unrelated to gout or fmf. it belongs to a class of medications called anti-gout agents and works by reducing the processes that cause inflammation and other symptoms of gout and fmf. how should this medicine be used? colchicine comes as capsules, tablets, and an oral solution (gloperba) to take by mouth with or without food. for preventing gout attacks or for fmf, it is usually taken once or twice daily. for an acute gout attack, the usual regimen is 2 tablets at the first sign of pain, followed by 1 tablet 1 hour later. if you do not get relief, or if another attack occurs within several days, talk to your doctor before taking additional doses. if using the oral solution, measure each dose with an oral syringe, dosing spoon, or dosing cup; do not use a household spoon. for fmf, your doctor may start with a low dose and increase it gradually; your dose may be decreased if side effects occur. if you are taking colchicine to prevent gout attacks and you have an attack, call your doctor right away; you may be told to take an extra dose followed by a smaller dose 1 hour later. if you take extra doses to treat an attack, wait at least 12 hours before your next scheduled dose. take colchicine exactly as directed. do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. continue taking it even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to colchicine or any ingredients in the tablets, capsules, or solution; check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. some medicines should not be taken with colchicine; discuss all prescription and over-the-counter drugs, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take before starting colchicine and before starting, stopping, or changing any medication while on colchicine. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney or liver disease or blood problems; your doctor may advise you not to take colchicine. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking colchicine, call your doctor. colchicine may decrease fertility in men; discuss the risks with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not eat grapefruit or drink grapefruit juice while taking colchicine. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you take colchicine regularly and miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. if you are taking colchicine (colcrys) to treat a gout attack that occurred while you are using colchicine to prevent attacks and you forget the second dose, take it as soon as you remember, then wait at least 12 hours before your next scheduled dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and stomach cramps or pain. serious side effects can occur; stop taking colchicine and call your doctor right away if you have muscle pain or weakness; numbness or tingling in the fingers or toes; unusual bruising or bleeding; sore throat, fever, chills, or other signs of infection; weakness or tiredness; or paleness or grayish color of the lips, tongue, or palms.

name: colesevelam
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? colesevelam is used in adults, along with diet, weight loss, and exercise, to lower cholesterol and certain blood fats, either alone or with hmg‑coa reductase inhibitors (statins). it is also used alone or with statins in certain boys and in girls ages 10 to 17 with heterozygous familial hypercholesterolemia to reduce cholesterol and other blood fats. in adults with type 2 diabetes, it is used with diet and exercise to help control blood sugar. colesevelam is a bile acid sequestrant; it binds bile acids in the intestine so they are removed from the body. because bile acids are made from cholesterol, this helps lower blood cholesterol. reducing cholesterol and fats helps slow atherosclerosis and may reduce the risk of heart disease, angina, stroke, and heart attack. how should this medicine be used? colesevelam comes as tablets, chewable bars, and a powder for oral suspension. tablets are usually taken once or twice daily with meals and a beverage. chewable bars and the powder are usually taken once daily with a meal. follow your prescription label exactly; do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. for the powder, empty one packet into a glass, add 8 ounces (about 240 ml) of water, fruit juice, or a diet soft drink, stir well, and drink all the contents; cloudiness is normal. do not take the powder dry. each chewable bar contains 80 calories. colesevelam controls but does not cure your condition; continue taking it even if you feel well and do not stop without talking to your doctor. it may sometimes be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for details. what special precautions should i follow? before taking colesevelam, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to colesevelam or any medication. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use. your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for interactions. nonprescription vitamins a, d, e, and k can interact with colesevelam; inform your doctor and pharmacist if you take them and do not start them without medical advice. if you take cyclosporine (gengraf, neoral, sandimmune), glipizide (glucotrol), glimepiride (amaryl), glyburide (diabeta), levothyroxine (synthroid), olmesartan (benicar), oral contraceptives (birth control pills), phenytoin (dilantin), or vitamins, take them at least 4 hours before colesevelam. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had a bowel or stomach blockage, very high triglycerides, or pancreatitis due to high triglycerides; you will likely be advised not to take colesevelam. also tell your doctor if you have had gastrointestinal surgery; problems digesting or absorbing nutrients; stomach motility problems such as delayed gastric emptying; or difficulty swallowing. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while taking colesevelam, call your doctor. if you have phenylketonuria (pku), know that the powder for oral suspension contains aspartame (a source of phenylalanine). what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow a low‑fat, low‑cholesterol diet and all eating and exercise recommendations from your doctor or dietitian. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? colesevelam may cause side effects. common effects include gas, constipation, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, heartburn, stomach or back pain, headache, weakness, and muscle pain. serious effects can occur; call your doctor right away if you have severe abdominal pain with or without nausea and vomiting. colesevelam may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: colestipol
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? colestipol is used along with diet changes to lower low-density lipoprotein (ldl, “bad”) cholesterol in certain people with high cholesterol. it belongs to a class of medications called bile acid sequestrants and works by binding bile acids in the intestines to form a complex that is eliminated from the body. how should this medicine be used? colestipol comes as tablets and granules to take by mouth. tablets are usually taken once or twice daily; granules are usually taken one to six times daily. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. take colestipol exactly as directed; do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed. unless otherwise instructed, take all other medications at least 1 hour before or 4 hours after colestipol because it can interfere with their absorption. swallow the tablets whole with a full glass of water or another liquid; do not chew, split, or crush them. your doctor may gradually increase your dose at 1- to 2-month intervals based on your response. continue to take colestipol even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor. do not take the granules dry. add them to at least 3 ounces (90 ml) of a liquid (e.g., fruit juice, water, milk, or a soft drink) and stir until completely mixed. if you use a carbonated beverage, mix it slowly in a large glass to minimize foaming. after taking the dose, rinse the glass with a small amount of additional liquid and drink it to be sure you receive the entire dose. granules may also be mixed with hot or regular breakfast cereals, thin soups (e.g., tomato or chicken noodle), or pulpy fruit (e.g., crushed pineapple, pears, peaches, or fruit cocktail). other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking colestipol, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to colestipol, any other medications, or any of the ingredients in colestipol products; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. the following nonprescription products may interact with colestipol: oral phosphate supplements. be sure to let your doctor and pharmacist know you are taking these before you start colestipol, and do not start them while taking colestipol without medical advice. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had unusual bleeding, an underactive thyroid gland, heart disease, intestinal disease, or hemorrhoids. if you are taking gemfibrozil (lopid), take it 2 hours before or 2 hours after colestipol. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking colestipol, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? eat a low-fat, low-cholesterol diet and follow all diet and exercise recommendations from your doctor or dietitian. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? colestipol may cause side effects. common side effects include constipation, belching, nausea, vomiting, and gas. some side effects can be serious. if you experience unusual bleeding (such as bleeding from the gums or rectum), call your doctor immediately.

name: colistimethate injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? colistimethate injection is an antibiotic used to treat certain bacterial infections by killing the bacteria. it will not treat colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when they are not needed can increase the risk of developing infections that resist antibiotic treatment later. how should this medicine be used? colistimethate injection is supplied as a powder that is mixed with liquid and given by injection. it may be administered intravenously into a vein over 3 to 5 minutes, injected into a muscle (buttocks or thigh), or given as a continuous intravenous infusion over 22 to 23 hours. doses are usually given every 6 to 12 hours. treatment length depends on your health, the type of infection, and how you respond. you may receive it in the hospital or at home; if at home, your healthcare provider will teach you exactly how to prepare and give it. start feeling better within the first few days; call your doctor if you do not improve or if symptoms worsen. use it for the full prescribed course even if you feel better. stopping early or skipping doses may prevent cure and promote antibiotic resistance. other uses for this medicine colistimethate may also be inhaled via a nebulizer to treat certain serious lung infections. discuss the potential risks and benefits with your doctor. it may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to colistimethate, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the product, and provide a full list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use, as doses may need adjustment and you may need monitoring for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney disease; if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding (call your doctor if you become pregnant during treatment); and if you are scheduled for any surgery, including dental procedures. colistimethate can cause dizziness or affect coordination; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. what special dietary instructions should i follow? continue your usual diet unless your doctor gives you other instructions. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose and you self-administer at home, use it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose; if so, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use two doses at once. if your doses are given by a healthcare professional or you are on a continuous infusion, contact your healthcare provider promptly to reschedule or for guidance. what side effects can this medication cause? colistimethate injection may cause side effects. common effects include upset stomach, hives, and rash. call your doctor right away or get emergency help if you have: numbness or tingling of the arms, legs, hands, feet, or tongue; a crawling sensation on the skin; itching; slurred speech; muscle weakness; shallow, slowed, or temporarily stopped breathing; decreased urination; severe diarrhea; or watery or bloody stools with or without fever and stomach cramps, which can occur during treatment or up to 2 months or more after it ends. colistimethate may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: collagenase clostridium histolyticum injection
instructions: important warning: for men receiving collagenase clostridium histolyticum injection (xiaflex) for peyronie’s disease: serious penile injury, including corporal rupture (penile fracture), has occurred with this treatment. surgery may be needed, and some injuries can cause permanent damage. call your doctor right away if you notice a popping sound or sensation in an erect penis; sudden inability to maintain an erection; penile pain; bruising, bleeding, or swelling of the penis; difficulty urinating; or blood in the urine. you will receive a medication guide when you start and each time you receive xiaflex; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. discuss the risks and benefits of xiaflex with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? collagenase clostridium histolyticum injection is an enzyme therapy used to treat: dupuytren’s contracture, a painless thickening and tightening of a cord beneath the skin of the palm that can prevent one or more fingers from straightening when a cord is felt on exam; peyronie’s disease, a thickened plaque inside the penis that causes curvature; and, under the brand qwo, cellulite in the buttocks of adult women. it works by breaking down the thickened collagen in cords or plaques to help straighten the affected finger or penis, and for cellulite by releasing fibrous bands, redistributing fat cells, and promoting new collagen growth. how should this medicine be used? this medicine is supplied as a powder mixed with liquid and injected by a healthcare professional. for dupuytren’s contracture (xiaflex), your doctor injects the medication into the palpable cord in the affected hand. after injection, do not bend or straighten the fingers of the injected hand or press on the area; keep the hand elevated until bedtime. return the next day for an exam; your doctor may move and extend the finger to help break the cord. ask when improvement should occur and report lack of improvement. additional injections may be needed. avoid strenuous activity with the treated hand until your doctor clears you. you will likely wear a splint at bedtime for up to 4 months and perform daily finger exercises as directed. for peyronie’s disease (xiaflex), your doctor injects the plaque, followed by a second injection 1 to 3 days later. return 1 to 3 days after the second injection for gentle penile modeling (stretching) performed by your doctor to help straighten the penis. you will also be instructed to gently stretch and straighten the penis at home for 6 weeks; follow directions carefully. avoid sexual activity from the first injection until your doctor says you may resume it after each treatment cycle. avoid activities that strain the abdominal muscles (for example, straining during bowel movements) during treatment. up to 3 additional treatment cycles may be given based on response. for cellulite (qwo), your doctor injects subcutaneously into each buttock treatment area, with up to 12 injections per area; up to two areas can be treated per visit. treatments are repeated every 21 days for a total of 3 visits. other uses for this medicine: your doctor may prescribe this medication for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving this medicine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to collagenase clostridium histolyticum, collagenase ointment (santyl), any other medications, or any ingredients in the product; review the medication guide for a full ingredient list. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for interactions. tell your doctor if you have an infection at the intended injection site; you will likely be advised not to receive treatment until the infection resolves. inform your doctor if you have a bleeding disorder or take anticoagulants; avoid anticoagulant medicines such as aspirin more than 150 mg/day, warfarin, or enoxaparin during the 7 days before injection unless your doctor tells you otherwise. tell your doctor if you have previously received collagenase clostridium histolyticum for another condition. this medicine can cause dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting, particularly soon after injection or within 1 to 2 days; if you feel dizzy or faint, lie down until symptoms resolve. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant during treatment, contact your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor instructs otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medication is administered by your healthcare provider at scheduled visits. if you miss an appointment, contact your doctor as soon as possible to reschedule; do not attempt to self-inject. what side effects can this medication cause? collagenase clostridium histolyticum can cause side effects. for dupuytren’s contracture (xiaflex): redness, warmth, swelling, tenderness, bruising, or bleeding at the injection site; itching, pain in the treated hand; painful, swollen glands in the elbow or underarm. for peyronie’s disease (xiaflex): tenderness around the injection site along or above the penis; blisters or a lump at the injection site; changes in penile skin color; itching of the penis or scrotum; painful erection; erectile difficulties; painful sexual activity; headache. for cellulite (qwo): redness, warmth, swelling, firmness, skin color changes, or bruising at the injection site; pain in the treated buttock. serious side effects require immediate medical attention: hives; rash; difficulty breathing or swallowing; hoarseness; chest pain; lower back pain that may radiate to the legs, feet, chest, or arms; muscle spasms; swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; fever, sore throat, chills, cough, or other signs of infection; numbness, tingling, or increased pain in the treated finger or hand after injection or after the follow-up visit. when used for dupuytren’s contracture, serious hand injury can occur and may require surgery or be permanent; call your doctor promptly if, after swelling subsides, you cannot bend the injected finger toward the wrist or you have trouble using the treated hand after the follow-up visit. this medication may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving it.

name: copanlisib injection
instructions: important warning: copanlisib is no longer commercially available in the united states. if this medicine is used outside the u.s., consult the local manufacturer labeling for the most current information. why is this medication prescribed? copanlisib injection is used to treat adults with follicular lymphoma (fl), a slow-growing blood cancer that has returned after at least two prior treatments. it is a kinase inhibitor that blocks abnormal signaling proteins that drive cancer cell growth, helping slow or stop the spread of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? copanlisib injection is supplied as a powder that is mixed with liquid and infused into a vein through a needle or catheter. it is usually given over 60 minutes on days 1, 8, and 15 of each 28-day treatment cycle. copanlisib can raise blood pressure for up to 8 hours after the infusion; your care team will check your blood pressure before the dose and for several hours afterward. seek immediate medical attention if you develop dizziness, feeling faint, headache, or a pounding heartbeat after a dose. your doctor may lower the dose, delay or stop treatment, or prescribe additional medicines based on your response and any side effects. tell your doctor how you feel during therapy. ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer patient information. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving copanlisib injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to copanlisib, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the injection; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. be sure to mention: boceprevir (victrelis); carbamazepine (carbatrol, equetro, tegretol, others); clarithromycin (biaxin, in prevpac); cobicistat (tybost, in evotaz, genvoya, prezcobix, stribild); conivaptan (vaprisol); diltiazem (cardizem, cartia xt, diltzac, others); efavirenz (sustiva); enzalutamide (xtandi); idelalisib (zydelig); indinavir (crixivan) with ritonavir; itraconazole (sporanox, onmel) and ketoconazole; lopinavir with ritonavir (in kaletra); mitotane (lysodren); nefazodone; nelfinavir (viracept); nevirapine (viramune); paritaprevir, ritonavir, ombitasvir, and/or dasabuvir (viekira pak); phenobarbital; phenytoin (dilantin, phenytek); posaconazole (noxafil); rifabutin (mycobutin); rifampin (rifadin, in rifamate, rifater); ritonavir (norvir, in kaletra, technivie, viekira pak); saquinavir (invirase) and tipranavir (aptivus) with ritonavir; and voriconazole (vfend). your doctor may change doses or monitor you closely for side effects. many other medicines can interact with copanlisib, so tell your healthcare providers about all medicines you take, even if not listed here. tell your doctor which herbal products you use, especially st. johns wort. tell your doctor if you currently have an infection or if you have or have ever had high blood sugar or diabetes, lung or breathing problems, high blood pressure, or liver disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or plan to father a child, you should not become pregnant while receiving copanlisib. you will need a negative pregnancy test before starting treatment. use effective birth control during treatment and for 1 month after the final dose. if you are male and your partner can become pregnant, use effective birth control during treatment and for 1 month after the final dose. call your doctor if you or your partner becomes pregnant during treatment. do not breastfeed during treatment and for 1 month after the final dose. this medicine may reduce fertility in males and females; discuss risks with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not drink grapefruit juice while receiving copanlisib. unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an infusion appointment, call your doctor as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to make up a dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? copanlisib injection may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: diarrhea; nausea; vomiting; mouth sores, ulcers, or pain; burning, prickling, tingling, or numbness of the skin; pain with touch; swelling of the nose, throat, or mouth; weakness or lack of energy. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have: unusual bleeding or bruising; new or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or trouble breathing; rash or red, itchy, peeling, or swollen skin; fever, sore throat, chills, or other signs of infection; or feeling very hungry or thirsty, headache, or frequent urination. copanlisib injection may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: cosibelimab-ipdl injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cosibelimab-ipdl injection is used to treat certain types of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cscc)—skin cancer that has spread to nearby tissues or to other parts of the body and cannot be treated well with surgery or radiation therapy. cosibelimab-ipdl is in a class of medications called monoclonal antibodies. it works by helping your immune system slow or stop the growth of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? cosibelimab-ipdl comes as a solution (liquid) to be injected into a vein over 60 minutes by a doctor or nurse in a hospital or medical facility. it is usually injected once every 3 weeks. the length of your treatment will be decided by your doctor and depends on how well your body responds to the medication and the side effects that you experience. cosibelimab-ipdl injection may cause serious or life-threatening infusion reactions. a doctor or nurse will watch you closely while you receive the infusion. call your doctor or get emergency help immediately if you experience any of the following symptoms during or after your infusion: chills or shaking, fever, itching, rash, feeling faint, flushing, nausea, back or neck pain, shortness of breath, dizziness, or wheezing. your doctor may need to temporarily or permanently stop your treatment, or treat you with additional medications, depending on your response and the side effects that you experience. it is important to tell your healthcare team how you are feeling during your treatment with cosibelimab-ipdl injection. your doctor or pharmacist will give you the manufacturer’s patient information sheet (medication guide) when you begin treatment and each time you receive a dose. read the information carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have any questions. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving cosibelimab-ipdl injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cosibelimab-ipdl, any other medications, or any of the ingredients in cosibelimab-ipdl injection. ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist what prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have received or plan to receive a stem cell transplant that uses donor stem cells (allogeneic) or have ever had an organ transplant, including a corneal transplant. also tell your doctor if you have received radiation therapy to your chest or if you have or have ever had diabetes; crohn’s disease; ulcerative colitis; lupus; a nervous system disease such as myasthenia gravis or guillain-barré syndrome (gbs); a lung disease or breathing problems; or thyroid, liver, or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant. you should not become pregnant while you are receiving cosibelimab-ipdl injection. you may need to have a pregnancy test before you begin receiving this medication. use effective birth control during your treatment and for 4 months after your final dose. if you become pregnant while receiving cosibelimab-ipdl injection, call your doctor. cosibelimab-ipdl injection may harm the fetus. tell your doctor if you are breastfeeding or plan to breastfeed. do not breastfeed during your treatment with cosibelimab-ipdl injection and for 4 months after your final dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment to receive cosibelimab-ipdl injection, call your doctor as soon as possible to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? cosibelimab-ipdl injection may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: muscle or bone pain; feeling tired or weak; nausea; constipation; swelling of the arms, hands, feet, or lower legs; headache. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of these symptoms or those listed in the how section, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment: cough, irregular heartbeat, chest pain, or shortness of breath; diarrhea; stools that are black, tarry, sticky, or have blood or mucus; or abdominal pain or tenderness; yellow eyes or skin, severe nausea or vomiting, dark urine, loss of appetite, unusual bleeding or bruising, or pain or discomfort in the right upper stomach area; rash; blistering or peeling skin; itching; swollen lymph nodes; fever or flu-like symptoms; or painful sores or ulcers in the mouth or nose, throat, or genital area; decreased urine amount, swelling in your ankles, blood in urine, or loss of appetite; headaches that won’t go away or unusual headaches; feeling more hungry or thirsty than usual, increased sweating, extreme tiredness, frequent urination, or weight changes; double vision, blurry vision, eye sensitivity to light, eye pain, or changes in vision; feeling cold, deepening of the voice or hoarseness, hair loss, irritability; dizziness or fainting, fast heartbeat, forgetfulness, or changes in sexual desire; confusion, sleepiness, memory problems, changes in mood or behavior, stiff neck, balance problems, or tingling or numbness of the arms or legs; persistent muscle pain or weakness or muscle cramps. cosibelimab-ipdl injection may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: covid-19 vaccine, adjuvanted
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? covid-19 vaccine, adjuvanted is used to prevent covid-19 or to lower the risk of serious illness from sars-cov-2 infection. covid-19 can cause fever or chills, cough, shortness of breath or difficulty breathing, sore throat, congestion or runny nose, loss of taste or smell, fatigue, muscle aches or body pains, headache, nausea or vomiting, and diarrhea, and in some people may lead to hospitalization or death. this vaccine includes a protein from the virus with an adjuvant to stimulate your immune system so it can respond quickly and limit the virus if you are exposed. how should this medicine be used? covid-19 vaccine, adjuvanted is a liquid suspension given by a healthcare professional as an intramuscular injection. it is administered as a single dose for the season and should be given at least 2 months after any previous dose of any covid-19 vaccine. what special precautions should i follow? before vaccination, tell your provider if you have ever had an allergic reaction to this vaccine, any of its components, any other vaccine, or any drug, food, or substance, and describe your symptoms; if you have or have had myocarditis (inflammation of the heart muscle) or pericarditis (inflammation of the lining around the heart); if you have a bleeding disorder or are taking a blood thinner; if you have a weakened immune system or take medicines that affect your immune system; if you have a fever or feel unwell; if you have received any other covid-19 vaccine; if you have ever fainted with an injection; or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. the safety of covid-19 vaccination in pregnancy is not fully known, and covid-19 infection during pregnancy can have adverse outcomes; discuss risks and benefits with your clinician. your healthcare provider may choose to delay vaccination in some situations. adverse reactions can be reported to the vaccine adverse event reporting system (vaers); your provider usually files this report, or you can submit it yourself. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are required. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss your appointment, reschedule as soon as possible, ensuring that at least 2 months have passed since your last covid-19 vaccine dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include pain, redness, or swelling at the injection site; tiredness or feeling unwell; headache; muscle or joint pain; nausea or vomiting; and fever. some side effects can be serious. seek immediate medical care if you have trouble breathing, swelling of the face or throat, a fast heartbeat, rash, dizziness, or weakness. you should know that covid-19 mrna vaccines may increase the risk of myocarditis or pericarditis, with symptoms most often occurring within a week after vaccination and reported more often in males 12 to 24 years of age. get emergency medical help if you develop chest pain, shortness of breath, or a fast, fluttering, or pounding heartbeat. some people may faint after vaccination; tell your provider if you feel lightheaded or notice vision changes or ringing in the ears.

name: crinecerfont
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? crinecerfont is used along with glucocorticoid steroids to control androgen (male sex hormone) levels in adults and children with classic congenital adrenal hyperplasia (cah). crinecerfont is in a class of medications called selective corticotropin-releasing factor (crf) type 1 receptor antagonists. it works by reducing the production of androgens. how should this medicine be used? crinecerfont comes as a capsule and as an oral solution (liquid) to take by mouth. take it twice daily with a meal in the morning and evening, at about the same times each day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. take crinecerfont exactly as directed. do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed. continue taking crinecerfont even if you feel well. do not stop taking crinecerfont or glucocorticoid medications without talking to your doctor. do not change the dose of glucocorticoid unless your doctor tells you to do so. swallow the capsules whole; do not open, chew, or crush them. to use the oral solution, follow these steps: 1) use only the bottle adapter and oral syringe provided; if you did not receive these items, ask your pharmacist. 2) when using a new bottle, open it, remove the seal, press the bottle adapter into the bottle, and leave it in place. 3) to prepare a dose, push in the plunger of the oral syringe, insert it into the bottle adapter, turn the bottle upside down, and pull back on the plunger until you have measured the dose prescribed by your doctor. 4) turn the bottle upright and remove the syringe. 5) give the dose by placing the tip of the syringe inside your or your child’s cheek and slowly pushing the plunger until the full dose is given. 6) place the cap over the adapter and store properly for the next dose. rinse both parts of the syringe with water, allow to air-dry, and store in a clean, dry place. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking crinecerfont, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to crinecerfont, any other medications, or any of the ingredients in the capsules or oral solution; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding; if you become pregnant while taking crinecerfont, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking crinecerfont. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? crinecerfont may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: headache; tiredness; dizziness in adults; joint, back, or muscle pain in adults; decreased appetite in adults; abdominal pain in children; stuffy nose or nosebleed in children. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of these symptoms, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical treatment: rash; difficulty swallowing or breathing; swelling of the lips, tongue, eyes, or throat; confusion; dizziness; severe weakness; headache; fever; nausea; vomiting; fast heartbeat; rapid breathing; unusual sweating on the face or palms. crinecerfont may cause other side effects.

name: crisaborole topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? crisaborole topical is used to treat atopic dermatitis (eczema)—a skin condition that causes dryness, itching, and sometimes red, scaly rashes—in adults and children 3 years of age and older. it is a phosphodiesterase-4 (pde-4) inhibitor that helps reduce inflammation by blocking certain natural inflammatory substances. how should this medicine be used?
