crisaborole is an ointment for use on the skin only. apply a thin layer to the affected areas twice daily, at about the same times each day. use exactly as directed; do not use more, use less, or apply it more often than prescribed. avoid contact with your eyes, mouth, and vagina. to apply: wash your hands with soap and water; make sure the affected skin is clean and dry; apply a thin layer to all affected areas and rub in gently and completely; wash your hands after application unless your hands are being treated; if a caregiver applies it, they should wash their hands after application. if you need written patient information, ask your pharmacist or doctor. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to crisaborole, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the ointment; ask your pharmacist for an ingredient list if needed. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal or topical products you use or plan to use; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while using crisaborole, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra ointment to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? crisaborole may cause side effects. common effects include burning or stinging at the application site, which is usually mild. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor right away if you have hives or redness, itching, or swelling where the ointment was applied or anywhere on the body. other side effects may occur; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: crizotinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? crizotinib is used to treat certain types of non-small cell lung cancer (nsclc) that have spread locally or to other parts of the body. it is also used to treat a specific form of anaplastic large cell lymphoma (alcl) that has returned or did not respond to other treatments in certain adults and in children 1 year of age and older. crizotinib is also used for a specific type of inflammatory myofibroblastic tumor (imt)—a cancer that can arise in mucosal tissues, often within the abdomen and involving organs such as the lungs, bladder, stomach, uterus, liver, or intestines—when surgery is not possible or the disease has not improved or has come back after prior treatments, in adults and children 1 year of age and older. crizotinib is a kinase inhibitor that blocks certain natural signals cancer cells use to grow and divide. how should this medicine be used? crizotinib is available as a capsule taken by mouth. it is usually taken twice daily, with or without food, at about the same times each day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully; ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. take crizotinib exactly as prescribed. do not take more or less of it, or take it more often, than directed. swallow the capsules whole; do not split, chew, or crush them. do not handle capsules that are broken or crushed. your doctor may pause treatment, reduce your dose, or change how often you take it if you have serious side effects. crizotinib may cause nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea; your doctor may prescribe medicines to prevent or treat these symptoms. tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. if you vomit after a dose, do not take an extra dose; continue with your regular dosing schedule. continue taking crizotinib even if you feel well. do not stop using it without talking to your doctor. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer's patient information. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking crizotinib, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to crizotinib, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the capsules. ask your pharmacist or check the manufacturer's patient information for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and over-the-counter medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you closely for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had long qt syndrome (a rare heart rhythm problem that can cause irregular heartbeat, fainting, or sudden death), a slow heartbeat, heart failure, vision problems, lung problems other than lung cancer, or liver or kidney disease. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, you will need a pregnancy test before starting crizotinib. if you are female, use effective birth control during treatment and for 45 days after your final dose. if you are male, you and your female partner should use birth control during treatment and for 90 days after your final dose. ask your doctor which birth control methods are appropriate. if you become pregnant while taking crizotinib, call your doctor immediately; crizotinib may harm the fetus. do not breastfeed during treatment and for 45 days after your final dose. this medication may reduce fertility in both men and women; discuss risks with your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking crizotinib. crizotinib can cause vision problems, dizziness, and severe tiredness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. avoid unnecessary or prolonged sunlight exposure and wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen, as crizotinib may increase your skin's sensitivity to sunlight. crizotinib may cause vision problems, including loss of vision; your doctor may have you undergo an eye exam before and during treatment. call your doctor right away if you develop changes in vision, double or blurred vision, sensitivity to light, sudden flashes of light, new or increased floaters (spots in your vision), or any other vision problems. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not eat grapefruit or drink grapefruit juice while taking this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. however, if it is less than 6 hours before your next scheduled dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? crizotinib may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: constipation, stomach pain, mouth sores, changes in the ability to taste food, decreased appetite, heartburn, headache, numbness, burning, or tingling in the hands or feet, rash, muscle, bone, or back pain, and pain in the arms, legs, hands, or feet. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following or those listed under special precautions, call your doctor immediately or seek emergency medical help: trouble breathing or shortness of breath; cough; fever; swelling of the arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; chest pain; slow or irregular heartbeat, dizziness, or fainting; weakness; excessive tiredness; decreased appetite; nausea or vomiting; pain in the right upper part of the abdomen; dark urine; itching; diarrhea; difficulty swallowing; or unusual bleeding or bruising. crizotinib may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you experience any unusual problems while taking it.

name: crofelemer
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? crofelemer is used to control certain types of diarrhea in patients with human immunodeficiency virus (hiv) infection who are being treated with specific medicines. crofelemer is in a class of medicines called botanicals and works by decreasing the amount of fluid that enters the bowel, which helps reduce diarrhea. how should this medicine be used? crofelemer comes as a delayed-release tablet that releases the medicine in the intestine, where its effects are needed, to take by mouth. it is usually taken two times a day, with or without food. take crofelemer at about the same times every day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain any part you do not understand. take crofelemer exactly as directed. do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed by your doctor. swallow the tablets whole; do not chew or crush them. what special precautions should i follow? before taking crofelemer, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to crofelemer, any other medicines, or any of the ingredients in crofelemer tablets. ask your pharmacist for a list of the ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist what other prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. if you become pregnant while taking crofelemer, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember it. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? crofelemer may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: runny nose, sneezing, or cough; tiredness; fever; chills; cough with mucus (sputum) or chest tightness; gas; nausea; swelling of the abdomen; hemorrhoids; back or joint pain; difficult, painful, or frequent urination; urine that is cloudy or discolored; back pain or pressure in the lower abdomen; anxiety. crofelemer may cause other side effects.

name: cromolyn ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cromolyn ophthalmic is used to relieve symptoms of allergic conjunctivitis—itchy, swollen, red, teary eyes—and to treat keratitis, a swelling of the cornea (the front of the eye) that can cause redness, pain, tearing, and changes in vision, in adults and children 4 years of age and older. cromolyn is a mast cell stabilizer; it works by preventing the release of substances that trigger inflammation and eye swelling. how should this medicine be used? cromolyn ophthalmic comes as a liquid solution to place in the eyes and is usually used 4 to 6 times daily in the affected eye(s). use it at the same times each day. follow your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. use the drops exactly as directed; do not use more, use less, or use them more often than prescribed. symptoms such as itching, tearing, redness, and discharge should improve within a few days, though full benefit may take up to 6 weeks. call your doctor if symptoms do not improve or worsen. to instill the eye drops: wash your hands with soap and water; check that the dropper tip is not chipped or cracked; avoid touching the dropper tip to your eye or any surface to keep it clean; tilt your head back and pull down the lower eyelid with your index finger to form a pocket; hold the dropper tip down near the eye without touching it and brace the remaining fingers against your face; while looking up, gently squeeze one drop into the pocket; release the lower eyelid; close your eye for 2 to 3 minutes and tip your head downward as if looking at the floor; try not to blink or squeeze your eyelids; place a finger on the tear duct and apply gentle pressure; wipe away excess liquid with a tissue; if more than one drop is prescribed in the same eye, wait at least 5 minutes before the next drop; replace and tighten the cap immediately and do not wipe or rinse the dropper tip; wash your hands after use. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using cromolyn ophthalmic, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cromolyn, any other medications, or any ingredients in the product; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take, especially any other eye medications; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while using cromolyn ophthalmic, call your doctor. if you wear contact lenses, do not wear them while using cromolyn eye drops. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? instill the missed dose as soon as you remember; if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not instill a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cromolyn ophthalmic may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: stinging or burning of the eyes. some side effects can be serious; if you experience any of the following, call your doctor immediately: shortness of breath, swelling, or rash. cromolyn ophthalmic may cause other side effects.

name: cromolyn oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cromolyn oral inhalation is used to prevent asthma symptoms such as wheezing, shortness of breath, difficulty breathing, coughing, and chest tightness. it also helps prevent bronchospasm triggered by exercise, cold and dry air, or inhaled irritants/allergens such as pet dander, pollen, dust mites, or chemicals (for example, perfume). it works by preventing the release of substances that cause inflammation and swelling in the airways. how should this medicine be used? cromolyn oral inhalation is a liquid solution used with a nebulizer machine that turns the medication into a mist to be inhaled through the mouth. for prevention of asthma symptoms, it is usually used 4 times daily at evenly spaced intervals. to prevent exercise- or trigger-induced breathing problems, use it 10 to 15 minutes before exercise or before exposure to the trigger. follow your prescription label exactly; do not use more or less or more often than prescribed. cromolyn helps control asthma but does not cure it. some improvement may occur soon after starting, but it may take up to 4 weeks to feel the full benefit; use it regularly for best effect. if your symptoms have not improved after 4 weeks, talk to your doctor. continue using cromolyn even if you feel well; do not stop without consulting your doctor. cromolyn helps prevent asthma attacks but will not treat an attack that has already started; your doctor will prescribe a short-acting rescue inhaler for acute attacks. before first use, read the nebulizer’s written instructions and have your doctor, pharmacist, or respiratory therapist show you how to use it; practice while they observe. to use with a nebulizer: remove one vial from the foil pouch (leave the others sealed until use); check that the solution is clear and colorless (do not use if cloudy or discolored); twist off the vial top and squeeze all contents into the nebulizer reservoir; if you use other nebulized medications, ask your doctor or pharmacist whether they can be placed in the reservoir with cromolyn; connect the reservoir to the mouthpiece or face mask and to the compressor; place the mouthpiece in your mouth or put on the mask; sit upright, turn on the compressor, and breathe calmly, deeply, and evenly for about 5 to 10 minutes until mist no longer forms in the chamber; clean the nebulizer regularly as directed by the manufacturer; ask your healthcare professional if you have questions about cleaning or use. what special precautions should i follow? before using cromolyn, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cromolyn, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the cromolyn nebulizer solution; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver or kidney disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, discuss this with your doctor; if you become pregnant while using cromolyn, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular dosing schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cromolyn inhalation may cause side effects. common effects that are usually mild and may go away include: sore throat, unpleasant taste in the mouth, stomach pain, cough, stuffy nose, itching or burning in the nasal passages, and sneezing. call your doctor immediately if you experience: wheezing, difficulty breathing or swallowing, hives, rash, itching, or swelling of the face, tongue, throat, or lips.

name: cromolyn sodium nasal solution
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cromolyn helps prevent and relieve nasal allergy symptoms such as stuffy nose, sneezing, runny nose, and related discomfort by blocking the release of inflammatory substances that cause swelling in the nasal air passages. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? cromolyn comes as a solution used with a special nasal applicator (such as nasalmatic). it is typically inhaled three to six times daily to prevent allergy symptoms and works best when used before exposure to allergens. if you have seasonal allergies, continue use until the season ends. follow the directions on the package or your prescription label exactly; ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. do not use more, use less, or use it more often than directed. it may take up to 4 weeks to see full benefit; if your symptoms do not improve after 4 weeks, contact your doctor. before first use, read the provided instructions and have your doctor, pharmacist, or respiratory therapist demonstrate the proper technique; practice under their supervision. for the nasal spray: blow your nose to clear your nostrils, insert the applicator into one nostril, and sniff gently as you squeeze the sprayer once. to prevent mucus from entering the sprayer, keep squeezing until you remove the sprayer from your nose. repeat in the other nostril as directed. what special precautions should i follow? before using cromolyn, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cromolyn or any other medicines; provide a list of all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; and tell them if you have or have ever had liver or kidney disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding, discuss this with your doctor; if you become pregnant while using cromolyn, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cromolyn may cause side effects. common effects that are usually mild include itching or burning in the nasal passages, sneezing, headache, and stomach pain. if these are severe or do not go away, contact your doctor. call your doctor immediately if you experience wheezing or increased difficulty breathing.

name: crovalimab-akkz injection
instructions: important warning: receiving crovalimab-akkz injection can increase your risk of meningococcal infection—an infection that can affect the lining of the brain and spinal cord and/or the bloodstream—and other serious infections during treatment and for some time afterward. these infections can become life-threatening quickly. you must receive recommended meningococcal vaccines at least 2 weeks before starting crovalimab-akkz; if you were vaccinated in the past, you may need a booster. if treatment must begin right away, you should be vaccinated as soon as possible and take an antibiotic for as long as your doctor recommends. even if vaccinated, you can still develop meningococcal disease. call your doctor immediately or get emergency help if you have headache with nausea or vomiting; fever; stiff neck or back; fever with rash; fever with a fast heartbeat; confusion; muscle aches or flu-like symptoms; or sensitivity to light. tell your doctor if you have a fever or other signs of infection before starting treatment; you should not receive crovalimab-akkz if you currently have a meningococcal infection. you will receive a patient safety card about this risk; carry it at all times during treatment and for 11 months after your final dose and show it to all healthcare providers. piasky rems: you can receive crovalimab-akkz only from a doctor enrolled in this program who has counseled you on meningococcal risks, provided the safety card, and ensured you received a meningococcal vaccine. your doctor or pharmacist will give you a medication guide when you begin treatment and each time you refill; read it carefully and ask questions. talk to your doctor about the risks of crovalimab-akkz. why is this medication prescribed? crovalimab-akkz injection is used to treat paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (pnh), a type of anemia in which too many red blood cells break down. it is a monoclonal antibody that blocks part of the immune system (complement) that can damage red blood cells in pnh. how should this medicine be used? crovalimab-akkz is a liquid given by a healthcare professional intravenously (into a vein) and then subcutaneously (under the skin). the first dose is infused over about 60 to 90 minutes. after the first dose, it is injected under the skin on days 2, 8, 15, and 22, and then once weekly thereafter. serious allergic or infusion reactions can occur; you will be monitored during dosing, and the infusion may be slowed or stopped if needed. seek immediate care for chest pain; dizziness or lightheadedness; rash or hives; trouble breathing or shortness of breath; swelling of the face, tongue, or throat; or fever or chills. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to crovalimab-akkz, any other medicines, or any ingredient in the injection. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any other medical conditions. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; if you become pregnant during treatment, call your doctor. do not breastfeed during treatment and for 9 months after your final dose. after stopping crovalimab-akkz, your condition may worsen due to increased red blood cell breakdown; your doctor will monitor you and may order lab tests during the first 20 weeks after your last dose. call your doctor right away if you develop extreme tiredness; blood in the urine; stomach pain; difficulty swallowing; inability to get or keep an erection; shortness of breath; pain, swelling, warmth, redness, or tenderness in one leg; slow or difficult speech; weakness or numbness of an arm or leg; or any unusual symptoms. serious immune system reactions may occur in the first 30 days of therapy, especially if you have taken certain other medications, including complement inhibitors; your doctor may monitor you closely for about 30 days after starting. if you are receiving or have received any complement inhibitor medications, tell your doctor. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you develop muscle, joint, or bone pain; rash, itching, or other skin problems; fever; numbness or tingling in the hands or feet; unusual tiredness or weakness; headache; or stomach pain. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment for a dose of crovalimab-akkz, call your doctor right away. what side effects can this medication cause? crovalimab-akkz may cause side effects. common side effects include diarrhea; nausea; redness or pain at the subcutaneous injection site; swelling of the arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; and runny nose. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you experience sore throat, cough, fever, chills, burning or pain when urinating, or other signs of infection; nosebleed; or any symptoms listed in the important warning, how should this medicine be used, or what special precautions should i follow sections. crovalimab-akkz may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: cyanocobalamin vitamin b12
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cyanocobalamin is used to treat and prevent vitamin b12 deficiency. it belongs to a class of medications called vitamins and works by supplying vitamin b12 needed to break down proteins, maintain the nervous system, and produce red blood cells. how should this medicine be used? cyanocobalamin comes as an oral tablet. it is usually taken with a meal or as directed by your doctor. take cyanocobalamin exactly as prescribed. if you have questions, ask your doctor or pharmacist. do not take more or less than prescribed or take it more often than directed. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cyanocobalamin, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to cyanocobalamin, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe any allergy symptoms you have had. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. tell your doctor if you have bleeding problems or if you have or have ever had a stroke, diabetes, or heart disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking cyanocobalamin. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? cyanocobalamin may cause side effects. if you have concerns about side effects or experience symptoms that worry you, contact your doctor or pharmacist.

name: cyanocobalamin injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cyanocobalamin injection is used to treat and prevent vitamin b12 deficiency caused by pernicious anemia (lack of intrinsic factor needed to absorb vitamin b12), certain diseases, infections, or medications that reduce b12 absorption from food, and by strict vegan diets that exclude all animal products (including dairy and eggs). vitamin b12 deficiency can lead to anemia and potentially irreversible nerve damage. cyanocobalamin may also be given as a test to see how well your body absorbs vitamin b12. it belongs to the vitamin class and, because it is injected directly into the body, can provide b12 to people who cannot absorb it through the intestine. how should this medicine be used? cyanocobalamin is a liquid solution injected into a muscle or just under the skin, usually administered by a healthcare professional in a clinic or office. a common schedule is once daily for the first 6 to 7 days, then every other day for 2 weeks, then every 3 to 4 days for 2 to 3 weeks. after your anemia has been corrected, you will typically receive a maintenance dose once a month to prevent symptoms from returning. the injections work only as long as they are given regularly; some people may need monthly injections for life. keep all appointments even if you feel well. if you stop receiving injections, anemia can recur and nerve damage may occur. other uses for this medicine cyanocobalamin injection may also be used for inherited conditions that reduce intestinal absorption of vitamin b12, to treat methylmalonic acidemia, and sometimes during pregnancy to help prevent methylmalonic acidemia in the newborn. discuss the potential risks and benefits with your doctor. it may also be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving cyanocobalamin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cyanocobalamin (injection, nasal gel, or tablets), hydroxocobalamin, multivitamins, any other medications or vitamins, or cobalt. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. inform your doctor if you currently drink or have previously drunk large amounts of alcohol, and if you have or have ever had leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy (a slow, painless loss of vision) or kidney disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor. if you become pregnant while using cyanocobalamin, call your doctor. discuss the amount of vitamin b12 you should receive daily during pregnancy or while breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment for a cyanocobalamin injection, contact your doctor as soon as possible to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? cyanocobalamin injection may cause side effects. contact your doctor if these symptoms are severe or do not go away: diarrhea; a feeling that your whole body is swollen. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you experience any of the following: muscle weakness, cramps, or pain; leg pain; extreme thirst; frequent urination; confusion; shortness of breath, especially with exercise or when lying down; coughing or wheezing; fast heartbeat; extreme tiredness; swelling of the arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; pain, warmth, redness, swelling, or tenderness in one leg; headache; dizziness; flushed or red skin (especially on the face); hives; rash; itching; or trouble breathing or swallowing. cyanocobalamin injection may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you notice any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: cyanocobalamin nasal gel
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cyanocobalamin nasal gel is used to prevent vitamin b12 deficiency caused by pernicious anemia (lack of a natural substance needed to absorb vitamin b12 from the intestine), certain diseases, infections, or medications that reduce absorption of vitamin b12 from food, or a vegan diet that excludes all animal products including eggs and dairy. vitamin b12 deficiency can cause anemia (when red blood cells do not carry enough oxygen) and permanent nerve damage. the anemia must first be treated with vitamin b12 injections; once red blood cells return to normal, cyanocobalamin nasal gel can be used to prevent the anemia and other b12 deficiency symptoms from returning. it is also used to provide extra vitamin b12 for people who need higher amounts, such as during pregnancy or with certain diseases. cyanocobalamin nasal gel is a vitamin that enters the bloodstream through the nose and can be used in people who cannot absorb vitamin b12 through the intestine. how should this medicine be used? cyanocobalamin nasal gel is applied inside the nose and is usually used once a week. use it on the same day each week to help you remember. follow the directions on your prescription label, and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. use exactly as directed; do not use more, less, or more often than prescribed. it supplies enough vitamin b12 only while used regularly, and you may need to use it weekly for life. continue even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor, as your anemia may return and nerves may be damaged. hot foods and drinks can increase nasal mucus and wash away the gel; do not eat or drink hot foods or beverages for 1 hour before or 1 hour after using the gel. your doctor or pharmacist will show you how to use it and provide the manufacturer’s instructions—read them carefully and ask questions if needed. to use the nasal gel: 1) blow your nose gently to clear both nostrils; 2) remove the clear cap from the pump; 3) if first use, press down firmly and quickly on the finger grips until a droplet appears at the tip, then press two more times; 4) insert the tip about halfway into one nostril, pointing it toward the back of the nose; 5) hold the pump with one hand and close the other nostril with a finger of your other hand; 6) press down firmly and quickly on the finger grips to release the dose; 7) remove the pump and gently massage the treated nostril for a few seconds; 8) wipe the tip with a clean cloth or alcohol swab and replace the clear cap. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using cyanocobalamin nasal gel, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cyanocobalamin (nasal gel, tablets, or injection), hydroxocobalamin, multivitamins, any other medications or vitamins, or cobalt. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you drink or have ever drunk large amounts of alcohol, if you have any infection, and if you have or have ever had leber’s hereditary optic neuropathy (slow, painless vision loss in one eye followed by the other), nasal allergies that cause congestion, itching, or runny nose, or kidney disease. if you develop a cold or a runny or stuffy nose during treatment, you may need another form of vitamin b12 until your symptoms resolve. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor; if you become pregnant while using the gel, call your doctor. discuss with your doctor how much vitamin b12 you should get daily during pregnancy or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cyanocobalamin nasal gel may cause side effects. call your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: headache, upset stomach, stuffy or runny nose, sore tongue, weakness. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor immediately if you experience: unusual bruising or bleeding; muscle weakness, cramps, or pain; leg pain; extreme thirst; frequent urination; confusion; burning or tingling in the arms, legs, hands, or feet; sore throat, fever, chills, or other signs of infection; rash; hives; itching; difficulty breathing or swallowing. cyanocobalamin nasal gel may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using it.

name: cyclobenzaprine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cyclobenzaprine is used with rest, physical therapy, and other measures to relax muscles and relieve pain and discomfort from strains, sprains, and other muscle injuries. it belongs to a class of medicines called skeletal muscle relaxants and works on the brain and nervous system to help muscles relax. how should this medicine be used? cyclobenzaprine is taken by mouth as a tablet or an extended-release capsule. the tablet is usually taken three times a day, with or without food. the extended-release capsule is usually taken once a day, with or without food. do not use this medicine for more than 3 weeks unless your doctor tells you to. follow your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. take it exactly as directed; do not take more or less, or take it more often than prescribed. swallow extended-release capsules whole; do not chew or crush them. if you cannot swallow the capsule whole, you may open it and sprinkle the contents on applesauce, eat the mixture right away without chewing, then drink and swish to ensure you receive the full dose. other uses for this medicine this medicine may sometimes be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cyclobenzaprine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to it, to any other medicines, or to any ingredients in the tablets or capsules; your pharmacist can provide a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all medicines you take and any you have taken in the past two weeks. do not take cyclobenzaprine if you are using or have recently used a monoamine oxidase (mao) inhibitor such as isocarboxazid (marplan), phenelzine (nardil), rasagiline (azilect), selegiline (eldepryl, emsam, zelapar), or tranylcypromine (parnate). some medicines should not be combined with cyclobenzaprine, and others may require dose changes or extra monitoring; discuss all current and planned medicines with your doctor and pharmacist before starting cyclobenzaprine, and get their advice before starting, stopping, or changing any medicines while taking it. do not take cyclobenzaprine if you are recovering from a recent heart attack; if you have an overactive thyroid; or if you have heart failure, an irregular heartbeat, heart block, or other electrical conduction problems of the heart. tell your doctor if you have glaucoma or increased eye pressure, trouble urinating, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while taking cyclobenzaprine, call your doctor right away. discuss risks and benefits if you are 65 years of age or older, as this medicine is generally not as safe or effective as other options for this condition. this medicine may cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. ask your doctor about the safe use of alcohol while taking cyclobenzaprine, as alcohol can increase its effects. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required unless your doctor advises otherwise. ask your doctor about the safe use of alcoholic beverages while taking cyclobenzaprine, because alcohol can increase drowsiness and other side effects. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include dry mouth, dizziness, nausea, constipation, heartburn, and extreme tiredness. call your doctor right away if you have serious symptoms such as a skin rash, hives, swelling of the face or tongue, trouble breathing or swallowing, a fast or irregular heartbeat, or chest pain.

name: cyclophosphamide
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cyclophosphamide is used alone or with other medications to treat hodgkin lymphoma (hodgkin disease) and non-hodgkin lymphoma (cancers that begin in white blood cells that normally fight infection); mycosis fungoides (a blood cancer that often first appears as skin rashes); multiple myeloma (a cancer of the bone marrow); and certain types of leukemia (cancers of the white blood cells), including chronic lymphocytic leukemia (cll), chronic myelogenous leukemia (cml), acute myeloid leukemia (aml/anll), and acute lymphoblastic leukemia (all). it is also used to treat retinoblastoma (eye cancer), neuroblastoma (a cancer that begins in nerve cells and occurs mainly in children), ovarian cancer, and breast cancer. in certain children, it is used to treat nephrotic syndrome (a kidney disease). cyclophosphamide is an alkylating agent. for cancer, it works by slowing or stopping the growth of cancer cells; for nephrotic syndrome, it works by suppressing the immune system. how should this medicine be used? cyclophosphamide comes as a capsule to take by mouth once a day in the morning. the length of treatment depends on your regimen, how well you respond, and the condition being treated. take it at the same time every day and exactly as directed. do not take more or less than prescribed or take it more often. swallow capsules whole; do not open, chew, or crush them. your doctor may delay treatment or adjust your dose based on your response and any side effects; tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. do not stop taking cyclophosphamide without talking to your doctor. drink plenty of fluids while taking cyclophosphamide. wear rubber or latex gloves when handling the capsules so your skin does not contact the medication. if any capsules are broken or leaking, do not touch them with bare hands and avoid breathing the powder; wear rubber or latex gloves to handle broken or opened capsules. if capsule contents touch your skin, wash the area well with water right away. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cyclophosphamide, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cyclophosphamide, to other alkylating agents (such as bendamustine, busulfan, carmustine, chlorambucil, ifosfamide, lomustine, melphalan, procarbazine, or temozolomide), to any other medications, or to any ingredients in the capsules; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had urinary obstruction (a blockage of urine flow); your doctor may tell you not to take cyclophosphamide. tell your doctor if you have previously received chemotherapy, had radiation therapy to your chest or abdomen, have an open or healing wound, or have or have ever had heart failure, a fast or irregular heartbeat, other heart problems, low sodium levels, or kidney or liver disease. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, know that cyclophosphamide may interfere with menstrual periods in women and may stop sperm production in men; however, do not assume you cannot become pregnant or get someone else pregnant. if you can become pregnant, you must have a pregnancy test before starting treatment and use effective birth control; cyclophosphamide may harm the fetus. if you are breastfeeding, do not breastfeed during treatment and for 1 week after your last dose. this medication may cause permanent infertility in men and women; talk to your doctor about the risks. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking cyclophosphamide. cyclophosphamide may cause dizziness or vision problems; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. cyclophosphamide may cause severe or life-threatening urinary problems; if you have trouble urinating or a bladder infection, call your doctor right away. call your doctor immediately if you have pink or red urine or blood in the urine, or frequent, urgent, or painful urination. drink plenty of fluids and urinate frequently during treatment to help reduce urinary side effects. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cyclophosphamide may cause side effects. if any of these are severe or do not go away, call your doctor: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, weight loss, stomach pain, loss of appetite, hair loss, sores on the mouth or tongue, changes in skin color, or changes in the color or growth of fingernails or toenails. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following or those listed in the special precautions section, call your doctor immediately: sore throat, fever, chills, or other signs of infection; poor or slow wound healing; black, tarry stools; nosebleed or other unusual bruising or bleeding; rash, hives, itching, difficulty breathing or swallowing; shortness of breath; swelling of the legs, ankles, or feet; fast, irregular, or pounding heartbeat; weight gain of more than 5 pounds (about 2.3 kilograms) in 24 hours; dizziness; loss of consciousness; new or worsening cough, chest pain, or shortness of breath; yellowing of the skin or eyes, extreme tiredness, nausea or vomiting, right-sided stomach pain, dark-colored urine, or decreased appetite. cyclophosphamide may increase the risk of developing other cancers; talk to your doctor about the risks. cyclophosphamide may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems.

name: cyclophosphamide injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cyclophosphamide injection is an alkylating agent used to treat hodgkin lymphoma (hodgkin disease) and non-hodgkin lymphoma; mycosis fungoides (a blood cancer that can first appear as skin rashes); multiple myeloma; and certain leukemias including chronic lymphocytic leukemia (cll), chronic myelogenous leukemia (cml), acute myeloid leukemia (aml/anll), and acute lymphoblastic leukemia (all). it is also used to treat retinoblastoma, neuroblastoma, ovarian cancer, and breast cancer, and to manage nephrotic syndrome in certain children. for cancer, it works by slowing or stopping the growth of cancer cells; for nephrotic syndrome, it dampens the immune system. how should this medicine be used? cyclophosphamide injection is supplied as a powder that is mixed with fluid and infused into a vein by a healthcare professional in a medical office, clinic, or hospital. your dosing schedule depends on your condition and response to treatment; your doctor may delay a dose or adjust the amount if side effects occur or your blood counts are low. tell your care team how you are feeling throughout therapy. this medicine may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving cyclophosphamide, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cyclophosphamide; to other alkylating agents such as bendamustine, busulfan, carmustine, chlorambucil, ifosfamide, lomustine, melphalan, procarbazine, or temozolomide; to any other medicines; or to any ingredients in the injection—ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may change doses or monitor you more closely for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had urinary obstruction (blocked urine flow)—you may be advised not to receive this medicine; prior chemotherapy or radiation to your chest or abdomen; an open or healing wound; heart failure, fast or irregular heartbeat, or other heart problems; low blood sodium; or kidney or liver disease. do not become pregnant and do not get someone pregnant while using this medicine. your doctor may order a pregnancy test before treatment. if you can become pregnant, use effective birth control during treatment and for 1 year after your last dose; if your partner can become pregnant, use effective birth control during treatment and for 4 months after your last dose. if pregnancy occurs, contact your doctor immediately—cyclophosphamide can harm an unborn baby. do not breastfeed during therapy and for 1 week after the final dose. this medicine can cause permanent infertility in both men and women; discuss fertility preservation options with your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, tell the provider you are receiving cyclophosphamide. this medicine may cause dizziness or vision changes; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. cyclophosphamide can cause severe, potentially life-threatening urinary (bladder) problems. tell your doctor if you have trouble urinating or a bladder infection, and call immediately if you notice pink or red urine, blood in the urine, or frequent, urgent, or painful urination. drink plenty of fluids and urinate often during treatment to help reduce urinary side effects. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor instructs otherwise, continue your usual diet; drink plenty of fluids as advised during treatment. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment for a dose, contact your doctor or clinic as soon as possible to reschedule; do not try to make up the dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? cyclophosphamide may cause side effects. common effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, loss of appetite or weight, stomach pain, hair loss, mouth or throat sores, skin color changes, and changes in the color or growth of fingernails or toenails. some side effects can be serious—call your doctor immediately if you have sore throat, fever, chills, or other signs of infection; poor or delayed wound healing; black, tarry stools; unusual bruising or bleeding; rash, hives, itching, or trouble breathing or swallowing; shortness of breath; swelling of the legs, ankles, or feet; fast, irregular, or pounding heartbeat; weight gain of more than 5 pounds (about 2.3 kilograms) in 24 hours; new or worsening cough, chest pain, or shortness of breath; or signs of liver problems such as yellowing of the skin or eyes, extreme tiredness, nausea or vomiting, right-sided abdominal pain, dark urine, or decreased appetite. cyclophosphamide may increase the risk of developing other cancers. it may cause additional side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything concerning.

name: cyclosporine
instructions: important warning: cyclosporine is available as the original formulation and as a modified formulation designed for better absorption. these two forms are absorbed differently and are not interchangeable. take only the exact formulation your doctor prescribed. when you receive a prescription, confirm the formulation is specified. at each refill, check the brand name on your label to be sure it matches what you usually take. if the brand looks unfamiliar or you are unsure you received the correct product, speak with your pharmacist. cyclosporine (either formulation) can increase your risk of infections and cancer, especially lymphoma and skin cancer, and this risk is higher if you also take other medicines that suppress the immune system. tell your doctor if you take any immunosuppressants and if you have or have ever had any type of cancer. reduce skin cancer risk by limiting sun exposure and using protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen during treatment. call your doctor right away if you develop any of the following: sore throat, fever, chills, flu-like symptoms, cough, trouble urinating or pain with urination, a red/raised/swollen skin area, new sores or skin discoloration, lumps anywhere in your body, night sweats, swollen glands in the neck/armpits/groin, shortness of breath, persistent weakness or tiredness, or unexplained weight loss. cyclosporine can also cause high blood pressure and kidney damage. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had high blood pressure or kidney disease. seek medical advice immediately if you have dizziness, swelling of the arms/hands/feet/ankles/lower legs, fast shallow breathing, nausea, or an irregular heartbeat. if you have psoriasis, tell your doctor about all psoriasis treatments you use or have used. your skin cancer risk is higher if you have received puva (psoralen plus uva), methotrexate (rheumatrex) or other immunosuppressants, uvb therapy, coal tar, or radiation. do not receive puva, uvb, or other immunosuppressants while taking cyclosporine modified for psoriasis. keep all appointments for doctor visits and lab tests so your response and safety can be monitored. why is this medication prescribed? cyclosporine and cyclosporine modified are used with other medicines to prevent rejection of transplanted kidneys, livers, and hearts. cyclosporine modified is also used, alone or with methotrexate (rheumatrex), to treat the symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis in patients not adequately helped by methotrexate alone, and to treat psoriasis in certain patients who did not improve with other treatments. both products are immunosuppressants that work by decreasing immune system activity. how should this medicine be used? cyclosporine and cyclosporine modified come as oral capsules and oral solutions. cyclosporine is usually taken once daily; cyclosporine modified is usually taken twice daily. take doses on a consistent schedule at the same times every day and keep the same interval between doses and meals. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist about anything you do not understand. do not take more or less or more often than prescribed. your doctor will adjust your dose during treatment. for transplant prevention, you will likely start at a higher dose that is gradually decreased. for rheumatoid arthritis or psoriasis, you will usually start at a lower dose that is gradually increased; your doctor may lower your dose if you develop side effects. cyclosporine modified controls symptoms of psoriasis and rheumatoid arthritis but does not cure them. for psoriasis, improvement may begin after about 2 weeks with full benefit in 12–16 weeks; for rheumatoid arthritis, improvement may take 4–8 weeks. continue taking cyclosporine modified even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor, who may taper the dose. an unusual smell when opening a blister card of cyclosporine capsules is normal. cyclosporine modified oral solution may gel or become lumpy if stored below 68°f (20°c); it can still be used, or allow it to warm to room temperature 77°f (25°c) to return to a liquid. both oral solutions must be mixed with a liquid before use. cyclosporine modified solution may be mixed with room-temperature (about 77°f/25°c) orange juice or apple juice and should not be mixed with milk. cyclosporine (original) solution may be mixed with milk, chocolate milk, or orange juice. choose one compatible drink and use it consistently. to take either solution: fill a glass (not plastic) cup with your chosen drink; remove the protective cap from the provided dosing syringe; insert the syringe into the bottle and draw up the prescribed amount; dispense the solution into the glass, stir well, and drink immediately; add a small amount of the same drink to the glass, swirl to rinse, and drink; wipe the outside of the syringe dry and replace the cap. do not wash the syringe with water; if you must wash it, be sure it is completely dry before measuring another dose. other uses for this medicine cyclosporine and cyclosporine modified are sometimes used to treat crohn’s disease. discuss the potential risks and benefits with your doctor. they may also be prescribed for other conditions; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cyclosporine or cyclosporine modified, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to either product, any other medicines, or any inactive ingredients in the capsules or solutions; your pharmacist can provide a list of inactive ingredients. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and nutritional or herbal supplements you take or plan to take. your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you more closely. if you take sirolimus (rapamune), take it 4 hours after cyclosporine. nonprescription nsaids such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin) and naproxen (aleve, naprosyn), and the herbal product st. john’s wort can interact with cyclosporine; tell your doctor and pharmacist if you use them, and do not start them while taking cyclosporine unless your healthcare provider approves. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had any condition listed in the important warning or any of the following: low cholesterol, low magnesium, high potassium, high uric acid, any condition that impairs nutrient absorption, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; if you become pregnant while taking cyclosporine, call your doctor. both formulations may increase the risk of preterm birth. tell your doctor if you are breastfeeding or plan to breastfeed. cyclosporine may cause drowsiness, dizziness, or confusion; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. the capsules and oral solution contain alcohol; ask your doctor about safe use of alcoholic beverages during treatment. do not receive vaccinations without talking to your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not eat grapefruit or drink grapefruit juice while taking cyclosporine or cyclosporine modified. your doctor may tell you to limit dietary potassium. follow these instructions carefully and discuss how much you may consume of potassium-rich foods such as bananas, prunes, raisins, and orange juice. many salt substitutes contain potassium; consult your doctor before using them. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? cyclosporine and cyclosporine modified may cause side effects. common effects include headache, diarrhea, heartburn, gas, increased hair growth on the face/arms/back, overgrowth of gum tissue, acne, flushing, tremor, burning or tingling in the hands/arms/feet/legs, muscle or joint pain, cramps, facial pain or pressure, ear problems, breast enlargement in men, depression, and trouble sleeping. serious effects require immediate medical attention and include, in addition to those listed in the important warning, unusual bleeding or bruising, pale skin, yellowing of the skin or eyes, nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, extreme tiredness, flu-like symptoms, pain in the upper right abdomen, dark urine, or light-colored stools; seizures; loss of consciousness; behavior or mood changes; trouble controlling body movements; loss of balance or coordination or unsteadiness; weakness or inability to move one side of the body; vision changes; confusion; purple skin blotches; or rash, itching, or hives. cyclosporine may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you experience unusual problems while taking it.

name: cyclosporine injection
instructions: important warning: cyclosporine injection must be given under the supervision of a clinician experienced with transplant care and immunosuppressive therapy. this medicine can raise your risk of serious infections and cancers, especially lymphoma and skin cancer. the risk is higher when used with other immune-suppressing drugs such as azathioprine (imuran), cancer chemotherapy, methotrexate (rheumatrex), sirolimus (rapamune), or tacrolimus (prograf). tell your doctor if you take any of these or if you have or have ever had any cancer. call your doctor right away if you develop sore throat, fever, chills, flu-like symptoms, cough, trouble urinating or pain with urination, a red, raised, or swollen area on the skin, new skin sores or discoloration, lumps or masses, night sweats, swollen glands in the neck, armpits, or groin, difficulty breathing, chest pain, weakness or tiredness that does not go away, or pain, swelling, or fullness in the stomach. discuss the risks and benefits of cyclosporine injection with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? cyclosporine injection is used with other medicines to prevent rejection of a transplanted kidney, liver, or heart. it should be used only in people who cannot take cyclosporine by mouth. cyclosporine belongs to a class of drugs called immunosuppressants and works by lowering the activity of the immune system. how should this medicine be used? cyclosporine injection is an intravenous solution infused over 2 to 6 hours, typically by a doctor or nurse in a hospital or clinic. it is usually administered 4 to 12 hours before transplant surgery and then once daily after surgery until you can switch to oral cyclosporine. you will be closely monitored during the infusion so that any severe allergic reaction can be treated promptly. other uses for this medicine: cyclosporine injection may sometimes be used for crohn’s disease and to prevent rejection in people who have received pancreas or cornea transplants. ask your doctor about the risks and benefits of using it for these conditions. it may also be prescribed for other uses; consult your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving cyclosporine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cyclosporine (gengraf, neoral, sandimmune), any other medicine, or cremophor el. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and supplements you use or plan to use; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you more closely for side effects. some nonprescription or herbal products interact with cyclosporine, including st. john’s wort and nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (nsaids) such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin) and naproxen (aleve); do not start these while receiving cyclosporine without medical advice. tell your doctor if you receive phototherapy for psoriasis and if you have or have ever had low cholesterol, low magnesium, or high blood pressure. tell your doctor if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant; if you become pregnant during treatment, call your doctor, as cyclosporine may increase the risk of preterm birth. tell your doctor if you are breastfeeding or plan to breastfeed. do not receive vaccinations without discussing them with your doctor. cyclosporine can cause gum overgrowth; brush carefully and see a dentist regularly to reduce this risk. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not eat grapefruit or drink grapefruit juice while receiving cyclosporine. your doctor may ask you to limit potassium in your diet; follow instructions carefully. ask about how much potassium-rich food (such as bananas, prunes, raisins, and orange juice) you may have. many salt substitutes contain potassium; discuss their use with your doctor. what should i do if i forget a dose? cyclosporine injection is usually given by a healthcare professional. if you miss an appointment or a dose is not given as scheduled, contact your doctor or clinic immediately to reschedule and receive instructions. what side effects can this medication cause? cyclosporine injection may cause side effects. common effects include headache, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, increased hair growth on the face, arms, and back, swelling or overgrowth of gum tissue, acne, uncontrollable shaking (tremor), pain, burning, numbness, or tingling in the hands, arms, feet, or legs, cramps, and breast enlargement in men. serious side effects can occur. call your doctor immediately if you have flushing of the face or chest, shortness of breath, wheezing, fast heartbeat, rash, hives, itching, difficulty swallowing, loss of consciousness, seizures, mood or behavior changes, difficulty moving, vision problems or sudden blackouts, swelling of the hands, arms, feet, ankles, or lower legs, or any symptoms listed in the important warning above. cyclosporine injection may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: cyclosporine ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ophthalmic cyclosporine is used to increase tear production in people with dry eye disease. it belongs to a class of medicines called immunomodulators and works by reducing inflammation in the eye to help restore natural tear production. how should this medicine be used? ophthalmic cyclosporine comes as a solution (liquid) and as an emulsion (two liquids that do not mix) to be instilled into the eye. the usual dosing is one drop in each eye twice daily, about 12 hours apart. use the drops at the same times every day. follow your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. use exactly as directed; do not use more or less or more often than prescribed. give cyclosporine eye drops at least 15 minutes before or after any other eye drops. use in the eyes only; do not swallow or apply to the skin. the product is supplied as single-use vials (for one dose) and as a multi-dose bottle (for repeated use). if using a single-use vial, use the contents immediately after opening for one or both eyes. do not let the dropper tip touch your eye, fingers, face, or any surface; contamination can occur if it does. to instill: 1) wash your hands with soap and water. 2) if using the multi-dose bottle for the first time, follow the package instructions to prepare it. 3) if using the emulsion, gently turn the vial or bottle over several times until the liquid looks uniformly white and not see-through. 4) open the vial or remove the cap from the multi-dose bottle. 5) avoid touching the dropper tip. 6) tilt your head back and pull down the lower eyelid with your index finger to form a pocket. 7) hold the dropper tip down as close to the eye as possible without touching it and brace your other fingers against your face. 8) while looking up, gently squeeze one drop into the pocket. 9) release the lower eyelid. 10) close your eye for 2 to 3 minutes and tip your head downward as if looking at the floor; try not to blink or squeeze your eyelids. 11) place a finger on the tear duct and apply gentle pressure. 12) wipe away any excess liquid with a tissue. 13) discard the single-use vial out of the reach of children, even if some liquid remains. 14) replace the cap on the multi-dose bottle. 15) wash your hands to remove any medication. what special precautions should i follow? before using cyclosporine eye drops, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cyclosporine (gengraf, neoral, sandimmune), any other medicines, or any ingredients in the drops; your pharmacist can provide a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you for side effects. inform your doctor about any medical conditions you have now or have had in the past. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while using this medication. do not use cyclosporine eye drops while wearing contact lenses. if you wear contact lenses, remove them before using the drops and wait 15 minutes before reinserting them. ask your doctor about contact lens use if you have dry eye disease. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular dosing schedule. do not use two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? cyclosporine eye drops may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of the following are severe or do not go away: burning, itching, stinging, redness, or pain in the eyes; eyelid swelling; eye discharge; blurred vision or other vision changes; feeling that something is in the eye; headache. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or seek emergency care if you have hives; itching; swelling of the face, throat, eyes, or tongue; or shortness of breath. cyclosporine eye drops may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: cyproheptadine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cyproheptadine is used to relieve red, irritated, itchy, watery eyes; sneezing; and runny nose due to allergies, airborne irritants, and hay fever. it can also reduce itching from allergic skin conditions and treat hives, including hives triggered by cold temperatures or by rubbing the skin. it is sometimes used to manage allergic reactions in people who have received blood products and to help treat life-threatening allergic reactions after initial control with other medications. it relieves symptoms but does not treat the underlying cause or speed recovery. cyproheptadine is an antihistamine that works by blocking histamine, a chemical that causes allergic symptoms. how should this medicine be used? cyproheptadine is available as tablets and as an oral solution. it is usually taken two or three times daily, at the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly. do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. if using the liquid, measure each dose with the provided device or a medication-measuring spoon or cup—do not use a household spoon. other uses for this medicine cyproheptadine may also be used to treat cushing’s syndrome (a condition caused by excess corticosteroid hormones) and certain headaches such as migraine. ask your doctor about the potential risks and benefits for your condition. this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking cyproheptadine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cyproheptadine, other antihistamines, or any medications. some medicines should not be taken with cyproheptadine, and others may require dose changes or extra monitoring. discuss all medicines, vitamins, and supplements you take or plan to take with your doctor and pharmacist before starting cyproheptadine, and consult them before starting, stopping, or changing any medicines while on it. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had asthma; glaucoma (increased eye pressure); stomach ulcers; trouble urinating due to an enlarged prostate; heart disease; high blood pressure; seizures; or an overactive thyroid. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while taking cyproheptadine, call your doctor. discuss the risks and benefits if you are 65 or older; older adults generally should not use cyproheptadine because safer or more effective alternatives may be available. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the surgeon or dentist you are taking cyproheptadine. this medication may cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. ask your doctor about alcohol use; alcohol can worsen cyproheptadine’s side effects. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? cyproheptadine may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: dry mouth, nose, or throat; drowsiness; dizziness; nausea; chest congestion; headache; excitement (especially in children); muscle weakness. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away if you have difficulty urinating, vision problems, or nervousness. cyproheptadine may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: cytarabine injection
instructions: important warning: cytarabine injection must be given by a doctor experienced in chemotherapy. cytarabine can cause a severe decrease in blood cells produced by your bone marrow, increasing the risk of serious infection or bleeding. call your doctor right away if you have fever, sore throat, ongoing cough or congestion, or other signs of infection; pale skin, unusual tiredness, fast heartbeat, fainting, or dizziness; unusual bleeding or bruising; black, tarry stools; red blood in stools; bloody vomit; or vomit that looks like coffee grounds. why is this medication prescribed? cytarabine is used to treat certain types of leukemia (cancers of the white blood cells). it is an antimetabolite that slows or stops the growth of cancer cells. other uses for this medicine: cytarabine may also be used to treat certain types of non-hodgkin lymphoma. talk to your doctor about the risks and benefits. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? cytarabine comes as a powder that is mixed with liquid and injected into a vein (iv), under the skin (subcutaneous), or into the fluid-filled space around the spinal cord (intrathecal) by a doctor or nurse in a medical facility. your doctor will tell you how often you will receive cytarabine based on your condition and how you respond to treatment. ask your pharmacist or doctor for a copy of the manufacturer's patient information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving cytarabine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cytarabine, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe what symptoms you had. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you closely for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. you should not become pregnant while receiving cytarabine. if you become pregnant, call your doctor; cytarabine may harm the fetus. do not breastfeed during treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment for a cytarabine injection, call your doctor or treatment center as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to make up a dose without medical advice. what side effects can this medication cause? cytarabine may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, stomach pain, loss of appetite, sores in the mouth and throat, hair loss, tiredness, sore or red eyes. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the symptoms listed in the important warning section, or any of the following, call your doctor immediately or seek emergency medical care: ongoing pain that begins in the stomach area but may spread to the back; redness, pain, swelling, or burning at the injection site; rash, itching, hives, or difficulty breathing or swallowing; fever, muscle or joint pain, tiredness, chest pain, rash, redness and itching of the eyes; shortness of breath or trouble breathing; yellowing of the skin or eyes; dark-colored urine or decreased urination; sudden change or loss of vision; seizures; confusion, sleepiness, changes in personality; numbness, burning, or tingling in the hands, arms, feet, or legs. cytarabine may cause other side effects; tell your doctor about any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: cytarabine lipid complex injection
instructions: notice: cytarabine lipid complex injection has been discontinued in the united states. because it is no longer available on the u.s. market, this information is not being updated. if this drug is used outside the u.s., consult the manufacturer’s labeling for the most current guidance. important warning: cytarabine lipid complex injection must be administered in a hospital or medical facility under the supervision of a doctor experienced in giving cancer chemotherapy. it can cause a serious or life-threatening reaction. you will receive medicine to help prevent this reaction and will be monitored closely after each dose. seek immediate medical help and tell your doctor right away if you develop nausea, vomiting, headache, or fever after a dose. why is this medication prescribed? cytarabine lipid complex is used to treat lymphomatous meningitis, a cancer involving the membranes covering the brain and spinal cord. it belongs to a class of medicines called antimetabolites and works by slowing or stopping the growth of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used?
