cytarabine lipid complex is given as an intrathecal injection into the fluid-filled space of the spinal canal over 1 to 5 minutes by a healthcare professional in a medical facility. the usual schedule is five doses given 2 weeks apart at weeks 1, 3, 5, 7, and 9; then, starting 4 weeks later, five additional doses given 4 weeks apart at weeks 13, 17, 21, 25, and 29. you will need to lie flat for 1 hour after each dose. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving cytarabine lipid complex, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to cytarabine or any ingredient in the product. ask your pharmacist for a list of the ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you currently have meningitis due to infection; your doctor will likely not use cytarabine lipid complex in that situation. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. do not become pregnant while receiving cytarabine lipid complex. if you become pregnant during treatment, call your doctor right away. cytarabine lipid complex may harm the fetus. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is administered by a healthcare professional. if you miss an appointment for a dose, contact your doctor or clinic as soon as possible to reschedule. do not attempt to receive this medicine outside of a medical facility. what side effects can this medication cause? cytarabine lipid complex may cause side effects. common effects include diarrhea, constipation, stomach pain, tiredness, weakness, muscle or joint pain, and trouble falling or staying asleep. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following or any symptoms listed in the important warning section, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help: sudden change or loss of vision or hearing; dizziness; fainting; confusion or memory loss; seizure; numbness, burning, or tingling in the hands, arms, feet, or legs; loss of bowel or bladder control; loss of feeling or movement on one side of the body; difficulty walking or unsteady walking; sudden fever, severe headache, and stiff neck; difficulty breathing or swallowing; rash; hives; itching; unusual bleeding or bruising; fever, sore throat, ongoing cough and congestion, or other signs of infection. cytarabine lipid complex may cause other side effects. contact your doctor if you notice any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: dabigatran
instructions: important warning: if you have atrial fibrillation and are taking dabigatran to reduce the risk of stroke or serious blood clots, stopping the medication can raise your chance of having a stroke. do not stop dabigatran without talking to your doctor. keep taking it even if you feel well, and refill your prescription before you run out so you do not miss doses. if you must stop, your doctor may prescribe another anticoagulant to help prevent clots. receiving epidural or spinal anesthesia or having a spinal puncture while on dabigatran or other blood thinners can lead to a clot in or around the spine (spinal/epidural hematoma) that could cause paralysis. tell your doctor if you have an epidural catheter, have had repeated spinal/epidural punctures, spinal deformity, or prior spinal surgery. tell your doctor and pharmacist if you take medicines that increase bleeding risk, including anagrelide; aspirin and other nsaids (such as ibuprofen, indomethacin, ketoprofen, naproxen); cilostazol; clopidogrel; dipyridamole; eptifibatide; heparin; prasugrel; ticagrelor; ticlopidine; tirofiban; or warfarin. call your doctor right away if you have back pain, muscle weakness (especially in the legs/feet), numbness or tingling (especially in the legs), or loss of bowel or bladder control. keep all doctor and lab appointments. your doctor may order tests to check your response to dabigatran. you will receive a medication guide at the start of treatment and with each refill; read it and ask questions if anything is unclear. why is this medication prescribed? dabigatran is used in adults and in children 3 months and older (after treatment with an injectable anticoagulant) to treat deep vein thrombosis (dvt; blood clot usually in the leg) and pulmonary embolism (pe; blood clot in the lung), and to lower the risk of these clots happening again after initial treatment. it also helps prevent dvt and pe in adults after hip replacement surgery. in adults with atrial fibrillation not caused by a heart valve problem, it helps prevent strokes and serious blood clots. dabigatran is a direct thrombin inhibitor that works by preventing clot formation. how should this medicine be used? dabigatran is taken by mouth as capsules or pellets. for treating or preventing dvt/pe or preventing stroke/clots in atrial fibrillation, it is usually taken twice daily. to prevent dvt/pe after hip replacement surgery, the first dose is typically 1 to 4 hours after surgery, then once daily for 28 to 35 days. take capsules with or without food (with food if stomach upset occurs), at the same times each day. swallow capsules whole with a full glass of water; do not split, chew, crush, or open them, and do not sprinkle capsule contents on food or into drinks. give pellets before meals to help ensure the full dose is taken. pellets must be given with soft food or apple juice only; do not mix with milk or foods containing milk. to give pellets with soft food, sprinkle the entire packet onto soft food such as baby rice cereal prepared with water, mashed carrots, mashed banana, or applesauce, and give the full mixture within 30 minutes. to give with apple juice, spoon pellets into the child’s mouth and offer apple juice to help swallow, or mix pellets in a small amount of apple juice and have the child drink all of it. if pellets stick to the cup, add a small amount of apple juice and give; repeat until all pellets are taken. do not store any mixture; use within 30 minutes. if the entire pellet dose is not taken, do not give another dose; resume the next dose at the regular time. take dabigatran exactly as prescribed; do not take more, less, or more often than directed. do not stop without talking to your doctor, as your stroke or clot risk may increase. other uses for this medicine: your doctor may prescribe this medication for other reasons; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking dabigatran, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to dabigatran or any ingredients in the capsules or pellets. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, and herbal products you take or plan to take, as your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have a mechanical heart valve or have noticed unusual bruising or bleeding; you will likely be advised not to take dabigatran. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had bleeding problems; stomach or intestinal bleeding or ulcers; or kidney disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, inform your doctor; dabigatran can increase the risk of severe bleeding during labor and delivery. discuss the risks and benefits if you are 75 years or older. if you are scheduled for any surgery or dental procedure, tell the doctor or dentist you take dabigatran. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is less than 6 hours until your next scheduled dose, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? dabigatran can cause side effects. common effects include stomach pain, upset stomach, heartburn, and nausea. serious side effects require immediate medical attention and include any signs of unusual bruising or bleeding; pink or brown urine; red or black, tarry stools; coughing up blood; vomiting blood or material that looks like coffee grounds; bleeding from the gums; frequent nosebleeds; heavy menstrual bleeding; bleeding from a cut that takes longer than usual to stop; joint pain or swelling; headache; dizziness or fainting; weakness; hives, rash, or itching; trouble breathing or swallowing; chest pain or tightness; or swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, eyes, arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs. dabigatran may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: dabrafenib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? dabrafenib is used to treat certain types of melanoma (a skin cancer), lung cancer, thyroid cancer, glioma (a cancerous brain tumor), and some other solid tumors. it belongs to a class of drugs called kinase inhibitors and works by blocking an abnormal protein that tells cancer cells to grow, helping to slow or stop their spread. how should this medicine be used? dabrafenib is available as capsules taken by mouth and as tablets that must be mixed in water and swallowed. it is usually taken twice daily on an empty stomach, either 1 hour before or 2 hours after a meal, about 12 hours apart, at the same times each day. take it exactly as prescribed; do not take more or less, take it more often, or stop taking it unless your doctor tells you to. swallow capsules whole—do not open, break, or crush them. tablets for oral suspension must be mixed with water; do not swallow, chew, or crush the tablets. prepare the mixture no more than 30 minutes before use and throw it away if not used within 30 minutes. use the dosing cup provided: for 1 to 4 tablets, add 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of cool drinking water; for 5 to 15 tablets, add 2 teaspoons (10 ml) of water. place the tablets in the water and stir for 3 minutes or until fully dispersed (the mixture will look cloudy). drink right away or within 30 minutes. then add another 1 teaspoon (5 ml) of water to the cup, stir to rinse any remaining particles, and drink all of it; if you are taking 5 to 15 tablets, repeat this rinse step a second time. if you vomit after a dose, do not take another dose; resume your regular schedule. your doctor may change your dose or pause or stop treatment based on how you respond and any side effects. you will receive a medication guide when you start dabrafenib and with each refill; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. what special precautions should i follow? before taking dabrafenib, tell your doctor or pharmacist if you are allergic to it, any of its ingredients, or any other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your allergy symptoms. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you closely for side effects. dabrafenib can make hormonal birth control (pills, patches, rings, injections) less effective; use an effective non-hormonal method while taking dabrafenib. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had diabetes, glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (g6pd) deficiency, bleeding problems, eye problems, heart failure or other heart conditions, liver or kidney disease, or any other medical issues. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or plan to father a child; you may need a pregnancy test before starting, and you should not become pregnant while taking dabrafenib. use effective non-hormonal birth control during treatment and for 2 weeks after your final dose. if your partner can become pregnant, use condoms during treatment and for 2 weeks after the last dose, even if you have had a vasectomy. call your doctor right away if you or your partner becomes pregnant; dabrafenib may harm the fetus. this medicine may make it harder for men and women to have children; discuss risks with your doctor. do not breastfeed during treatment and for 2 weeks after the final dose. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist you are taking dabrafenib. avoid unnecessary or prolonged sun exposure and wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen, as dabrafenib can increase sun sensitivity. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is less than 6 hours until your next scheduled dose, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once to make up for a missed dose. if you vomit after taking a dose, do not take an extra dose; continue with your usual schedule. what side effects can this medication cause? dabrafenib may cause side effects. common effects include headache; joint, muscle, or back pain; nausea; diarrhea; constipation; decreased appetite; cough, runny nose, or sore throat; hair loss; tiredness; thickening of the skin; infection of the skin around the fingernails or toenails; numbness or tingling in the arms, hands, legs, or feet; and dry skin. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have any of the following: changes in the skin such as a new wart, pimple, sore, or red bump that bleeds or does not heal, or a change in a mole; fever, chills, or shaking; dizziness, lightheadedness, weakness, fainting, or decreased urination; increased thirst or more frequent urination; eye pain, red or puffy eyelids, sensitivity to light, blurred vision, or vision changes (such as halos or colored dots); rash; blistering, peeling, or reddened skin; blistering of the lips, eyes, or mouth; flu-like symptoms; swollen glands, with or without fever; fever with swollen glands, bruising, and rash; persistent stomach pain that may spread to the back; unusual bleeding or bruising; black, tarry stools; coughing up or vomiting blood or material that looks like coffee grounds; nosebleeds; headaches, dizziness, or feeling weak; chest pain; rapid, irregular, or pounding heartbeat; lightheadedness; swelling of the hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; shortness of breath; or yellowing of the skin or eyes. dabrafenib may increase the risk of developing new skin cancers or other cancers. this medicine may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: dacarbazine
instructions: important warning: dacarbazine injection must be given in a hospital or medical facility under the supervision of a doctor who is experienced in giving chemotherapy medicines for cancer. dacarbazine can cause a severe decrease in the number of blood cells in your bone marrow, which may increase the risk of serious infection or bleeding; your doctor may stop or delay treatment if your blood counts are low. call your doctor immediately if you have fever, sore throat, ongoing cough and congestion, other signs of infection, or unusual bleeding or bruising. dacarbazine may cause serious or life threatening liver damage, especially when used with other cancer medicines. call your doctor immediately if you have nausea, extreme tiredness, unusual bleeding or bruising, lack of energy, loss of appetite, pain in the upper right part of the stomach, or yellowing of the skin or eyes. dacarbazine injection has caused birth defects in animals and may cause birth defects if used during pregnancy. do not use dacarbazine if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant unless your doctor decides it is the best treatment for your condition. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory so tests can be done to check how your body responds to dacarbazine. talk to your doctor about the risks of using dacarbazine injection. why is this medication prescribed? dacarbazine is used to treat melanoma that has spread to other parts of the body. it is also used in combination with other medicines to treat hodgkin lymphoma, a type of cancer that begins in white blood cells that normally fight infection. dacarbazine is in a class of medicines known as purine analogs and works by slowing or stopping the growth of cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? dacarbazine injection is supplied as a powder that is mixed with liquid and given intravenously by a doctor or nurse, either as an injection into a vein over about 1 minute or as an infusion over 15 to 30 minutes in a medical facility. for melanoma, it may be given once daily for 10 days in a row every 4 weeks or once daily for 5 days in a row every 3 weeks. for hodgkin lymphoma, it may be given once daily for 5 days in a row every 4 weeks or once every 15 days. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer patient information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving dacarbazine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to dacarbazine, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the injection; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you are breastfeeding. avoid unnecessary or prolonged exposure to sunlight and wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen, because dacarbazine may make your skin sensitive to sunlight. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? dacarbazine is given by a health professional on a set schedule. if you miss an appointment or think a dose was missed, contact your doctor or treatment center as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to receive an extra dose without medical advice. what side effects can this medication cause? dacarbazine may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, diarrhea, sores in the mouth and throat, hair loss, burning or tingling on the face, flushing, flu like symptoms. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you have any of the following or the symptoms listed in the important warning section: redness, pain, swelling, or burning at the injection site; hives; skin rash; itching; difficulty breathing or swallowing; fever, muscle aches, and general feeling of pain and tiredness. dacarbazine may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while receiving this medicine.

name: daclatasvir
instructions: notice: daclatasvir is no longer available in the united states. important warning: you may already be infected with hepatitis b (a virus that infects the liver and may cause severe liver damage) without having symptoms. taking daclatasvir may increase the risk that a past or current hepatitis b infection becomes more serious or life-threatening and you develop symptoms. your doctor will order blood tests to check for current or past hepatitis b infection and will monitor you for signs of hepatitis b during treatment and for several months afterward. if needed, your doctor may treat hepatitis b before and during daclatasvir therapy. call your doctor right away during or after treatment if you have excessive tiredness, yellowing of the skin or eyes, loss of appetite, nausea or vomiting, pale stools, stomach pain, or dark urine. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory; tests may be ordered before, during, and after treatment to check your response. talk to your doctor about the risks of taking daclatasvir. why is this medication prescribed? daclatasvir is used with another medication, sofosbuvir (sovaldi), to treat a certain type of chronic hepatitis c, an ongoing viral infection that damages the liver. daclatasvir is an antiviral in the hepatitis c virus (hcv) ns5a inhibitor class. it works by stopping the hepatitis c virus from multiplying in the body. it is not known if daclatasvir prevents the spread of hepatitis c to other people. how should this medicine be used? daclatasvir comes as an oral tablet and is usually taken once daily with or without food. it must be taken in combination with sofosbuvir, typically for 12 weeks. take daclatasvir at the same time each day and exactly as directed on your prescription label. do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. continue taking daclatasvir even if you feel well. do not stop daclatasvir or sofosbuvir without talking to your doctor. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking daclatasvir, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to daclatasvir, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. some medicines should not be taken with daclatasvir; others may require dosing changes or extra monitoring. discuss all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and herbal products you use or plan to use with your doctor and pharmacist before starting daclatasvir. do not start, stop, or change any medicines while taking daclatasvir without your doctor’s or pharmacist’s advice. the herbal product st. john’s wort may interact with daclatasvir; do not take it with daclatasvir. tell your doctor if you have had a liver transplant, any liver disease other than hepatitis c, or heart disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking daclatasvir, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you remember on the same day, take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if you do not remember until the next day, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses on the same day. what side effects can this medication cause? daclatasvir may cause side effects. common effects include headache and diarrhea. some side effects can be serious. if you are also taking amiodarone and you experience near-fainting or fainting, dizziness or lightheadedness, weakness or feeling unwell, shortness of breath, chest pain, memory problems, or confusion, call your doctor immediately. daclatasvir may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: daclizumab injection
instructions: notice: daclizumab injection is no longer available. if you are currently using daclizumab, call your doctor to discuss switching to another treatment. important warning: daclizumab can cause serious or life-threatening liver damage. the risk may be higher if you take other medicines that can harm the liver or if you already have liver disease. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver problems or hepatitis; your doctor may tell you not to use daclizumab. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all medicines you take so they can check for increased liver risk. your doctor will monitor you for signs of liver problems during treatment and for 6 months after your last dose. call your doctor right away if you have nausea, vomiting, extreme tiredness, unusual bleeding or bruising, lack of energy, loss of appetite, pain in the upper right abdomen, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, or flu-like symptoms. daclizumab may cause serious immune system disorders in which the immune system attacks healthy cells. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had skin problems such as eczema or psoriasis. call your doctor immediately if you develop redness, itching, or scaling of the skin; swollen glands in the neck, armpits, or groin; diarrhea; bloody stools; stomach pain; or any new, unexplained symptom affecting any part of your body. because of these risks, daclizumab was available only through a restricted distribution program called the zinbryta risk evaluation and mitigation strategies (rems) program. your doctor and pharmacist had to be registered with the zinbryta rems program. ask your doctor for more information about this program and how you received your medication. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor will order tests before, during, and for 6 months after your final dose to monitor your response to treatment. you will receive a medication guide when you start treatment and each time you refill; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. talk to your doctor about the risks of receiving daclizumab. why is this medication prescribed? daclizumab is used to reduce relapses and slow worsening disability in people with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (ms) who were not helped by at least two other ms medicines. it is an immunomodulator thought to work by decreasing inflammation and the activity of immune cells that may cause nerve damage. this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? daclizumab comes as a liquid solution in a prefilled syringe for subcutaneous (under the skin) injection, usually once a month. receive your first dose in your doctor's office. after that, you may inject it yourself or have a caregiver do it. read the written instructions before your first self-injection, and have your doctor or pharmacist show you how to inject. inject into the back of the upper arms, abdomen (stomach area), or thighs. do not inject into skin that is irritated, bruised, red, infected, scarred, or tattooed. use exactly as directed; do not use more, less, or more often than prescribed. never reuse or share needles or prefilled syringes. dispose of used syringes in a puncture-resistant container and ask your doctor or pharmacist how to discard the container. what special precautions should i follow? before using daclizumab, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to daclizumab or any of its ingredients; ask your pharmacist or check the medication guide for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to change doses or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had liver problems or hepatitis; tuberculosis; any current infection; depression or a history of suicidal thoughts or attempts; or skin conditions such as eczema or psoriasis. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while using daclizumab. you may become depressed or have suicidal thoughts while using daclizumab; you, your family, or your caregiver should call your doctor right away if you have new or worsening depression, thoughts about self-harm, or any unusual changes in mood or behavior. ensure your family or caregiver knows which symptoms are serious so they can seek help if you cannot. do not receive any vaccinations during treatment or for up to 4 months after your final dose without talking to your doctor. because of the risks, daclizumab was dispensed only through the zinbryta rems program with required monitoring. keep all medical and lab appointments during treatment and for 6 months after your last dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? inject the missed dose as soon as you remember. if more than 2 weeks have passed since the missed dose, skip it and resume your regular schedule. do not inject a double dose to make up for a missed dose. call your doctor if you miss a dose and have questions about what to do. what side effects can this medication cause? daclizumab may cause side effects. common effects include acne and mouth pain. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following or any symptoms listed in the important warning, call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help: rash; hives; itching; trouble breathing or swallowing; swelling of the eyes, face, mouth, tongue, or throat; new or worsening depression; changes in mood or behavior; thoughts about harming or killing yourself or planning or trying to do so; signs of infection such as runny nose, cough, sore throat, fever, or chills; difficulty urinating; pain with urination; or seizures. daclizumab may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: dacomitinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? dacomitinib is prescribed to treat certain types of non-small-cell lung cancer (nsclc) that have spread to other parts of the body. it belongs to a class of medicines called kinase inhibitors and works by blocking an abnormal protein that signals cancer cells to grow, helping slow or stop their spread. how should this medicine be used? dacomitinib is taken by mouth as a tablet, usually once daily with or without food, at about the same time each day. follow your prescription label exactly and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. do not take more, less, or more often than prescribed. if you vomit after taking a dose, do not take an extra dose; continue with your regular schedule. your doctor may pause treatment or lower your dose if certain side effects occur. tell your doctor how you feel during treatment. keep taking dacomitinib even if you feel well and do not stop without talking to your doctor. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine this medicine may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more details. what special precautions should i follow? before taking dacomitinib, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to dacomitinib, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell them about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for side effects. if you take an h2 blocker for indigestion, heartburn, or ulcers (such as cimetidine, famotidine, nizatidine, or ranitidine), take dacomitinib at least 6 hours before or at least 10 hours after the h2 blocker. some over-the-counter proton pump inhibitors (such as dexlansoprazole, esomeprazole, or rabeprazole) may interact with dacomitinib; make sure your doctor and pharmacist know you use these and do not start one while on dacomitinib unless you have discussed it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have frequent diarrhea, lung disease or breathing problems other than lung cancer, or liver or kidney disease. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, you must have a pregnancy test before starting treatment. do not become pregnant while taking dacomitinib; use reliable birth control during treatment and for at least 17 days after the final dose. call your doctor right away if you become pregnant; dacomitinib may harm the fetus. do not breastfeed during treatment and for 17 days after the last dose. to reduce skin sensitivity to sunlight, use a moisturizer, avoid unnecessary or prolonged sun exposure, and wear protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? dacomitinib may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of the following are severe or do not go away: weight loss, decreased appetite, mouth sores, infection around fingernails or toenails, hair loss, cough, tiredness, trouble sleeping, red or swollen eyes (pink eye), taste changes, or vomiting. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor right away or seek emergency help if you have: diarrhea; shortness of breath, cough, and fever; dry skin, redness, rash, acne, itching, or skin peeling or blistering; or chest pain. dacomitinib may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you have any unusual symptoms.

name: dalbavancin injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? dalbavancin injection is used to treat skin infections caused by certain types of bacteria. dalbavancin is in a class of medications called lipoglycopeptide antibiotics and works by killing bacteria. antibiotics such as dalbavancin do not kill viruses that cause colds, flu, or other viral infections. using antibiotics when they are not needed increases your risk of developing an infection later that resists antibiotic treatment. how should this medicine be used? dalbavancin injection comes as a powder that is mixed with fluid and given intravenously into a vein over 30 minutes by a doctor or nurse in a hospital or clinic. it is usually given as a single dose or once a week for 2 doses. you may have an infusion-related reaction while receiving dalbavancin. tell your healthcare provider immediately if you develop sudden redness of the face, neck, or upper chest; itching; rash; or hives during the infusion. your doctor may slow or stop the infusion until your symptoms improve. you should begin to feel better after treatment. if your symptoms do not improve or get worse, call your doctor. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving dalbavancin injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to dalbavancin, oritavancin (orbactiv), telavancin (vibativ), vancomycin (vancocin), any other medications, or any of the ingredients in dalbavancin injection. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you closely for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had kidney or liver disease, or if you are receiving hemodialysis. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while receiving dalbavancin, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment to receive dalbavancin, call your doctor right away to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? dalbavancin injection may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or headache. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you experience hives, rash, itching, difficulty breathing or swallowing; or severe diarrhea, including watery or bloody stools, with or without fever and stomach cramps, which may occur up to 2 months or more after treatment. dalbavancin injection may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you experience any unusual problems while receiving this medication.

name: dalfampridine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? dalfampridine is prescribed to improve walking in people with multiple sclerosis (ms), a condition in which nerve function is impaired and can cause weakness, numbness, poor coordination, and problems with vision, speech, and bladder control. it belongs to a class of medicines called potassium channel blockers and works by helping nerve signals travel more effectively through areas damaged by ms. how should this medicine be used? dalfampridine is an extended-release tablet taken by mouth with or without food twice daily, about every 12 hours, at the same times each day. follow your prescription label exactly; do not take more or less or more often than directed. swallow the tablets whole—do not split, crush, chew, or dissolve them. dalfampridine is dispensed through a specialty mail-order pharmacy rather than a retail pharmacy; ask your doctor if you have questions about receiving your medication. walking benefits continue only while you keep taking the medication and may take 6 weeks or longer to be fully noticeable. continue taking it even if you feel well; do not stop without talking to your doctor. you will receive a medication guide when you start dalfampridine and with each refill; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. what special precautions should i follow? before taking dalfampridine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to dalfampridine, 4-aminopyridine (4-ap), compounded fampridine, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets. provide a list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use, and specifically mention any form of 4-aminopyridine (4-ap), as your doctor may need to adjust treatments or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have ever had a seizure or if you have kidney disease; your doctor will probably tell you not to take dalfampridine. also tell your doctor if you have ever had an abnormal electroencephalogram (eeg). inform your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking dalfampridine, call your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take more than two doses in a 24-hour period and do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one; keep doses about 12 hours apart. what side effects can this medication cause? dalfampridine may cause side effects. common effects include trouble falling or staying asleep, dizziness, headache, nausea, heartburn, constipation, weakness, back pain, balance problems, worsening of ms symptoms, burning, tingling, or itching of the skin, and nose or throat pain or irritation. some side effects can be serious; seek medical help right away if you have seizures; painful, difficult, or frequent urination; fever or chills; or pain in the back, side, or abdomen. dalfampridine may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking it.

name: dalteparin injection
instructions: important warning: receiving an epidural or spinal anesthesia or a spinal puncture while using a blood thinner such as dalteparin can lead to a blood clot or hematoma in or around the spine that may cause paralysis. tell your doctor if you have an epidural catheter in place; recently had spinal anesthesia or medicine injected near the spine; have or have ever had repeated epidural or spinal punctures; had problems with these procedures; have a spinal deformity; or had spinal surgery. tell your doctor and pharmacist if you take any of the following: anagrelide (agrylin); apixaban (eliquis); aspirin and other nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen (advil, motrin), indomethacin (indocin, tivorbex), ketoprofen, and naproxen (aleve, anaprox); cilostazol; clopidogrel (plavix); dabigatran (pradaxa); dipyridamole (persantine, in aggrenox); edoxaban (savaysa); heparin; prasugrel (effient); rivaroxaban (xarelto); ticagrelor (brilinta); ticlopidine; and warfarin (coumadin, jantoven). call your doctor right away if you have muscle weakness especially in your legs and feet, numbness or tingling especially in your legs, back pain, or loss of control of your bowels or bladder. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor will order tests to monitor your response to dalteparin. discuss the risks of dalteparin with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? dalteparin is an anticoagulant blood thinner used with aspirin to help prevent serious or life-threatening problems from angina chest pain and heart attacks. it also helps prevent deep vein thrombosis dvt, which can lead to pulmonary embolism pe, in people on bed rest or those having hip replacement or abdominal surgery. it is used to treat dvt or pe and help prevent recurrence in children 1 month of age and older, and in adults with dvt or pe who have cancer. it works by decreasing the ability of the blood to clot. how should this medicine be used? dalteparin is a liquid solution in vials and prefilled syringes for subcutaneous under the skin injection. in adults it is usually given once daily, but some conditions may require twice daily dosing. in children it is usually given twice daily. treatment length depends on your condition and response. for angina and heart attack, treatment is usually 5 to 8 days. to prevent dvt after surgery, it is given on the day of surgery and for 5 to 10 days afterward. to prevent dvt in people on bed rest, it is usually given for 12 to 14 days. for cancer-associated dvt treatment and prevention of recurrence, treatment may continue for up to 6 months. a nurse or other healthcare professional may give your injections, or you may inject at home after training. if injecting at home, have a healthcare provider show you where and how to inject, what syringes to use, and how to dispose of used needles and syringes. inject at the same time or times each day. follow your prescription label carefully. use dalteparin exactly as directed. do not use more or less or use it more often than prescribed. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the patient information from the manufacturer. other uses for this medicine: dalteparin may be used to help prevent strokes or blood clots in people with atrial fibrillation or flutter who are undergoing cardioversion. it may also be used to prevent clots in people with prosthetic heart valves or other conditions when warfarin therapy has just been started or has been interrupted. it may be used to help prevent blood clots in some pregnant people and in those having total knee replacement, hip fracture surgery, or other surgeries. ask your doctor about the risks and benefits of these uses. this medicine may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using dalteparin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to dalteparin, heparin, pork products, any other medicines, or any ingredient in the injection. provide a list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor you closely for side effects. do not use dalteparin if you have heavy bleeding that cannot be stopped or if you have had a reaction to heparin that caused a low platelet count heparin-induced thrombocytopenia. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had a bleeding disorder such as hemophilia, stomach or intestinal ulcers or fragile or swollen blood vessels, high blood pressure, endocarditis an infection in the heart, a stroke or transient ischemic attack tia, eye disease due to high blood pressure or diabetes, or liver or kidney disease, and whether you recently had brain, spine, or eye surgery or recent bleeding from your stomach or intestines. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using dalteparin, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental procedures, tell the clinician that you use dalteparin. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? inject the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not inject a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? dalteparin can cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: nosebleeds, redness, pain, bruising, or sores at the injection site. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency help if you have any of the following, or the symptoms listed in the important warning section: unusual bleeding or bruising, dark red spots under the skin or in the mouth, vomiting or spitting up blood or material that looks like coffee grounds, bloody or black tarry stools, blood in urine or red or dark-brown urine, excessive menstrual bleeding, dizziness or lightheadedness, hives or rash, swelling of the face, throat, tongue, lips, or eyes, or trouble swallowing or breathing. dalteparin may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unexpected problems while using this medicine.

name: halcinonide topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? halcinonide topical is used to relieve itching, redness, dryness, crusting, scaling, inflammation, and discomfort from various skin conditions, including psoriasis and eczema. it is a corticosteroid that activates natural substances in the skin to reduce swelling, redness, and itching. how should this medicine be used? halcinonide comes as an ointment and a cream for use on the skin, usually applied two or three times a day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully. use exactly as directed. do not use more or less or more often than prescribed. do not apply to other areas of your body or to treat other skin conditions unless your doctor tells you to do so. apply a small amount to cover the affected area with a thin film and rub in gently. for external use only. avoid contact with eyes and mouth and do not swallow. avoid use in the genital or rectal areas and in skin creases and armpits unless directed by your doctor. if using on a childs diaper area, do not use tight fitting diapers or plastic pants. do not wrap or bandage the treated area unless your doctor instructs you to do so, as this may increase side effects. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before using halcinonide topical, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to halcinonide, any other medicines, or any ingredients in the product; ask your pharmacist for an ingredient list. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have an infection or any other skin problems, or if you have or have ever had diabetes or cushing syndrome. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while using halcinonide, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are using halcinonide topical. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not apply a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? halcinonide may cause side effects. common effects include burning, itching, irritation, redness, dryness, or cracking of the skin; acne; changes in skin color; tiny red bumps or a rash around the mouth; unwanted hair growth; small white or red bumps on the skin; bruising or shiny skin; and thin, fragile, or dry skin. call your doctor immediately if you have a severe rash or redness, swelling, oozing, pus, or other signs of skin infection where you applied the medication. children using halcinonide topical may have an increased risk of side effects, including slowed growth and delayed weight gain. talk to your doctor about the risks of applying this medication to your childs skin. halcinonide may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: halobetasol topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? halobetasol topical is used to relieve redness, swelling, itching, and discomfort from certain inflammatory skin conditions in adults and in children 12 years and older, including plaque psoriasis (red, scaly patches) and eczema (dry, itchy skin that may develop red, scaly rashes). it is a corticosteroid that activates natural substances in the skin to reduce inflammation and itching. how should this medicine be used? halobetasol is available as a cream, ointment, foam, and lotion for use on the skin. apply a thin, even film to the affected area once or twice daily as directed, and rub in gently. use exactly as prescribed; do not use more often, in larger amounts, or on other areas or conditions unless your doctor tells you to. your skin should start to improve within 2 weeks; contact your doctor if it does not. keep the medicine out of the eyes and mouth and do not swallow. avoid use on the face, groin or genital and rectal areas, skin folds, and armpits unless your doctor instructs you to. do not cover, wrap, or bandage treated skin unless your doctor tells you to, because this can increase side effects. halobetasol foam is flammable; keep away from heat, open flame, and do not smoke during application and for a short time afterward. what special precautions should i follow? before using, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to halobetasol, other corticosteroids, other medicines, or any ingredients in the product. provide a list of all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and herbal products you use, because your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have an active skin infection or a history of cataracts, glaucoma, diabetes, cushing syndrome (excess corticosteroid hormones), or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while using halobetasol. if you are scheduled for any surgery, including dental procedures, tell the doctor or dentist that you are using halobetasol topical. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next application, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra medicine to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects may include burning, itching, irritation, redness, or dryness at the application site; acne; a rash or small red bumps around the mouth; small white or red bumps; unwanted hair growth; changes in skin color; easy bruising or shiny skin; or red or purple streaks or blotches under the skin. serious side effects can occur. call your doctor right away if you notice signs of skin infection at the treated site (redness, swelling, pus), a severe skin rash, skin sores, sudden weight gain, unusual tiredness, muscle weakness, mood changes such as depression or irritability, or blurred vision or other vision changes. children using halobetasol topical may have a higher risk of systemic side effects, including slowed growth and delayed weight gain; discuss risks with your childs doctor. halobetasol may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: haloperidol
instructions: important warning: studies show that older adults with dementia, a brain disorder that affects memory, thinking, communication, daily activities, and mood or personality, who take antipsychotic medicines such as haloperidol have an increased risk of death during treatment. haloperidol is not approved by the food and drug administration (fda) for treating behavior problems in older adults with dementia. talk to the doctor who prescribed this medicine if you, a family member, or someone you care for has dementia and is taking haloperidol. why is this medication prescribed? haloperidol is used to treat psychotic disorders, conditions in which it is hard to tell what is real from what is not. it is also used to control motor tics (uncontrollable repeated body movements) and verbal tics (uncontrollable repeated sounds or words) in adults and children with tourette's disorder. haloperidol is also used to treat severe behavioral problems, such as explosive or aggressive behavior or hyperactivity, in children who cannot be treated with psychotherapy or other medicines. haloperidol is a conventional antipsychotic that works by decreasing abnormal excitement in the brain. how should this medicine be used? haloperidol comes as a tablet and as a concentrated liquid to take by mouth. it is usually taken two or three times a day. take haloperidol at the same times each day. follow the directions on your prescription label exactly, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain anything you do not understand. take haloperidol exactly as directed. do not take more or less of it, and do not take it more often than prescribed by your doctor. your doctor will probably start you on a low dose and increase it gradually. your doctor may decrease your dose once your condition is controlled. be sure to tell your doctor how you are feeling during treatment. haloperidol helps control your condition but does not cure it. continue to take it even if you feel well. do not stop taking haloperidol without talking to your doctor; your doctor will probably decrease your dose gradually. if you suddenly stop taking haloperidol, you may have difficulty controlling your movements. other uses for this medicine haloperidol is also used to treat confusion and difficulty thinking and understanding that are caused by severe physical or mental illness. talk to your doctor about the possible risks of using this medicine for your condition. this medicine may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking haloperidol, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to haloperidol or any other medicines. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take while taking haloperidol. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medicines or monitor you carefully for side effects. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had parkinson's disease; your doctor will probably tell you not to take haloperidol. tell your doctor if you or anyone in your family has or has ever had prolonged qt syndrome, a condition that increases the risk of an irregular heartbeat that may cause loss of consciousness or sudden death. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had breast cancer; bipolar disorder; citrullinemia (a condition that causes a buildup of ammonia in the blood); an abnormal electroencephalogram (eeg); seizures; an irregular heartbeat; low calcium or magnesium levels in your blood; trouble keeping your balance; chest pain; or heart or thyroid disease. also tell your doctor if you have ever had to stop taking a medicine for mental illness because of severe side effects. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, especially in the last few months of pregnancy, if you plan to become pregnant, or if you are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while taking haloperidol, call your doctor. haloperidol may cause problems in newborns after delivery if it is taken during the last months of pregnancy. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking haloperidol. you should know that this medicine may make you drowsy and may affect your thinking and movements. do not drive a car or operate machinery until you know how this medicine affects you. ask your doctor about the safe use of alcohol during treatment with haloperidol; alcohol can make the side effects worse. you should know that haloperidol may cause dizziness, lightheadedness, and fainting when you get up too quickly from a lying position. to help prevent this, get out of bed slowly, letting your feet rest on the floor for a few minutes before standing. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? haloperidol may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: dry mouth; increased saliva; blurred vision; loss of appetite; constipation; diarrhea; heartburn; nausea; vomiting; difficulty falling asleep or staying asleep; blank facial expression; uncontrollable eye movements; unusual, slowed, or uncontrollable movements of any part of the body; restlessness; agitation; nervousness; mood changes; dizziness, feeling unsteady, or trouble keeping your balance; headache; breast enlargement or pain; breast milk production; missed menstrual periods; decreased sexual ability in men; increased sexual desire; difficulty urinating. if you experience any of the following symptoms, call your doctor immediately: fever; muscle stiffness; falling; confusion; fast or irregular heartbeat; sweating; decreased thirst; neck cramps; tongue that sticks out of the mouth; tightness in the throat; difficulty breathing or swallowing; fine, worm-like tongue movements; uncontrollable, rhythmic face, mouth, or jaw movements; seizures; eye pain or discoloration; decreased vision, especially at night; seeing everything with a brown tint; rash; yellowing of the skin or eyes; erection that lasts for hours. haloperidol may cause other side effects. if you have any unusual problems while taking this medicine, call your doctor.

name: haloperidol injection
instructions: important warning: older adults with dementia who are treated with antipsychotic medicines such as haloperidol have a higher risk of death during treatment. haloperidol injection and haloperidol extended-release injection are not approved by the fda for treating behavior problems in older adults with dementia. if you or someone you care for has dementia and is receiving haloperidol injection or haloperidol extended-release injection, speak with the prescriber about the risks and benefits. why is this medication prescribed? haloperidol injection and haloperidol extended-release injection are used to treat schizophrenia, a mental health condition that causes disordered thinking, loss of interest, and inappropriate emotions. haloperidol injection is also used to control motor tics and verbal tics in people with tourette's disorder. haloperidol is a conventional antipsychotic that works by reducing abnormal activity in the brain. how should this medicine be used? haloperidol injection is given by a healthcare professional as a muscle injection, typically as needed for agitation or for motor or verbal tics; if symptoms persist after the first dose, additional doses may be given. haloperidol extended-release injection is given by a healthcare professional as a muscle injection, usually once every 4 weeks. these medicines help control symptoms but do not cure the condition. keep all appointments for injections even if you feel well, and talk to your doctor if you do not think you are improving. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. other uses for this medicine: this medication may be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving haloperidol injection or haloperidol extended-release injection, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to haloperidol, any other medicine, or any ingredient in the injection; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. st. john's wort can interact with haloperidol; tell your doctor if you take it and do not start it while receiving haloperidol unless your doctor approves. tell your doctor if you have parkinson's disease; your doctor will likely advise against haloperidol. also tell your doctor if you have a low white blood cell count or if you have or have ever had qt prolongation (a heart rhythm problem), bipolar disorder, balance problems, an abnormal eeg, seizures, an irregular heartbeat, low potassium or magnesium levels, or heart or thyroid disease. if you are pregnant (especially in the last months), plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor. if you become pregnant while receiving haloperidol, call your doctor; use in late pregnancy may cause problems in newborns after delivery. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you receive haloperidol. this medicine can cause drowsiness and can affect thinking, judgment, and reaction time; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. alcohol can increase drowsiness; do not drink alcohol while being treated. haloperidol may cause dizziness or fainting when standing up quickly; to reduce this, rise slowly and sit with your feet on the floor for a few minutes before standing. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment for your haloperidol extended-release injection, contact your doctor as soon as possible to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? haloperidol injection or haloperidol extended-release injection may cause side effects. call your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: mood changes; trouble falling or staying asleep; restlessness; anxiety; agitation; dizziness or unsteadiness; problems with balance; headache; dry mouth; increased saliva; blurred vision; loss of appetite; constipation; diarrhea; heartburn; nausea; vomiting; breast enlargement or pain; breast milk production; missed menstrual periods; decreased sexual ability in men; increased sexual desire; difficulty urinating. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or get emergency medical help if you have: fever; muscle stiffness; falls; confusion; fast or irregular heartbeat; sweating; decreased thirst; involuntary movements of the tongue, face, mouth, or jaw; uncontrollable eye movements; unusual, slowed, or uncontrolled movements of any body part; throat tightness; fine, worm-like tongue movements; neck cramps; trouble breathing or swallowing; tongue that sticks out; uncontrollable, rhythmic movements of the face, mouth, or jaw; difficulty walking or talking; seizures; seeing or hearing things that are not there; yellowing of the skin or eyes; or an erection that lasts for hours. haloperidol injection or haloperidol extended-release injection may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you notice any unusual symptoms.

name: hepatitis a vaccine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? hepatitis a vaccine helps prevent hepatitis a, a serious liver infection spread by close personal contact or by ingesting contaminated food, drinks, or objects exposed to tiny amounts of stool from an infected person. adults often develop fatigue, low appetite, stomach pain, nausea, and jaundice (yellow skin or eyes), with dark urine and pale stools; most children under 6 have no symptoms. people can transmit the virus even without symptoms. most recover fully within weeks without lasting liver damage, but rare cases cause liver failure and death, especially in people over 50 or with other liver diseases. vaccination has greatly reduced disease in the united states, though outbreaks still occur among unvaccinated people. how should this medicine be used? children need 2 doses: first at 12–23 months of age and a second dose at least 6 months later. infants 6–11 months old traveling outside the united states when protection is recommended should receive 1 dose; they should still receive 2 additional doses at the recommended ages for long-lasting protection. older children and adolescents 2–18 years who were not previously vaccinated should be vaccinated. unvaccinated adults who want protection may also be vaccinated. vaccination is recommended for international travelers; men who have sexual contact with men; people who use injection or non-injection drugs; people with occupational risk for infection; those anticipating close contact with an international adoptee; people experiencing homelessness; people with hiv; and those with chronic liver disease. people with direct contact with someone who has hepatitis a and who have not been vaccinated should receive hepatitis a vaccine as soon as possible and within 2 weeks after exposure. the vaccine may be given at the same time as other vaccines. what special precautions should i follow? tell your vaccination provider if you had an allergic reaction after a previous hepatitis a vaccine dose or have any severe, life-threatening allergies. people with minor illnesses (such as a cold) may be vaccinated; those who are moderately or severely ill should usually wait until they recover. pregnant or breastfeeding people who are at risk should be vaccinated; pregnancy and breastfeeding are not reasons to avoid this vaccine. some people faint after vaccination; tell your provider if you feel dizzy, have vision changes, or ringing in the ears. seek emergency care (call 911) for signs of a severe allergic reaction after leaving the clinic, such as hives, swelling of the face or throat, difficulty breathing, fast heartbeat, dizziness, or weakness. adverse reactions should be reported to the vaccine adverse event reporting system (vaers); vaers is for reporting and does not give medical advice. the national vaccine injury compensation program (vicp) is a federal program that may compensate certain vaccine-related injuries; filing deadlines may be as short as two years. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are required. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your healthcare provider to reschedule and receive the missed dose as soon as possible; the second dose should be given at least 6 months after the first. if travel is planned, get vaccinated as soon as you can. keep your vaccination records and ask your provider about catch-up scheduling. what side effects can this medication cause? soreness or redness where the shot was given, fever, headache, tiredness, and loss of appetite can occur. fainting can happen after vaccination. as with any medicine, there is a very remote chance of a severe allergic reaction or other serious injury, including death; seek emergency care for concerning symptoms. brand names: havrix; vaqta. combination product: twinrix (contains hepatitis a and hepatitis b vaccines). other names: hep.

name: hepatitis b vaccine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? hepatitis b vaccine helps prevent infection with hepatitis b virus, which is spread through contact with blood, semen, or other body fluids from an infected person. hepatitis b can cause short term illness with fever, fatigue, loss of appetite, nausea, vomiting, jaundice yellow skin or eyes, dark urine, pale stools, and muscle, joint, or stomach pain. when infection becomes chronic, people often have no symptoms but can still transmit the virus, and are at risk for serious complications including liver damage cirrhosis, liver cancer, and death. most people who complete vaccination develop long lasting, typically lifelong, protection. how should this medicine be used? this vaccine is given as an intramuscular injection by a healthcare provider in a series of 2, 3, or 4 doses, depending on the product and schedule. infants should receive the first dose at birth and usually complete the series by 6 to 18 months of age. children and adolescents younger than 19 years who are not yet vaccinated should be vaccinated. adults 19 through 59 years who are not yet vaccinated should be vaccinated. adults 60 years and older who are at risk for hepatitis b should be vaccinated; those 60 and older who are not at risk may choose to be vaccinated for protection. the vaccine may be given alone or as part of a combination vaccine and can be administered at the same time as other vaccines. follow the schedule your provider recommends; if the series is interrupted, remaining doses should be given as soon as possible without restarting the series. brand names include engerix-b, heplisav-b, recombivax hb, and prehevbrio. combination products include comvax haemophilus influenzae type b plus hepatitis b, pediarix diphtheria, tetanus, acellular pertussis, hepatitis b, and polio, twinrix hepatitis a plus hepatitis b, and vaxelis diphtheria, tetanus, acellular pertussis, polio, haemophilus influenzae type b, and hepatitis b. other names you may see include dtap-hepb-ipv, dtap-ipv-hib-hepb, hepa-hepb, hepb, and hib-hep. what special precautions should i follow? tell your vaccination provider if you ever had a severe allergic reaction to a previous hepatitis b vaccine dose or to any component for example yeast, or if you have any severe, life threatening allergies. people with minor illnesses such as a cold can usually be vaccinated; those who are moderately or severely ill should typically wait until they recover. pregnancy and breastfeeding are not reasons to avoid hepatitis b vaccination, and people who are pregnant or breastfeeding and not yet vaccinated should receive it. tell your provider if you have a history of fainting after injections or if you feel dizzy, have vision changes, or ringing in the ears during or after the visit. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required for this vaccine. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your healthcare provider to reschedule as soon as possible. you do not need to restart the series; simply complete the remaining doses according to your provider’s guidance. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include soreness, redness, or swelling where the shot was given, fever, headache, and fatigue. nausea may occur. fainting can happen after vaccination; tell your provider if you feel lightheaded or have vision changes or ringing in the ears. serious reactions are very rare, but a severe allergic reaction can occur. seek emergency care or call 911 if you develop hives, swelling of the face or throat, difficulty breathing, a fast heartbeat, dizziness, or weakness. as with any medicine, there is a very remote chance of serious injury or death. report any adverse events to the vaccine adverse event reporting system vaers; vaers is for reporting only and does not provide medical advice. the national vaccine injury compensation program vicp is a federal program that may compensate people who may have been injured by certain vaccines; claims have filing deadlines that may be as short as two years.

name: histrelin implant
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? histrelin implant vantas is used to treat symptoms of advanced prostate cancer. histrelin implant supprelin la is used to treat central precocious puberty (cpp), a condition in which children enter puberty too early, leading to faster than normal bone growth and the development of sexual characteristics in girls usually between 2 and 8 years of age and in boys usually between 2 and 9 years of age. histrelin is a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (gnrh) agonist that works by lowering certain hormone levels in the body. this medication may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? histrelin is supplied as an implant—a small, thin, flexible tube containing medication—that a doctor inserts under the skin on the inside of the upper arm. your doctor will numb the area, make a small cut, insert the implant subcutaneously, then close the cut with stitches or surgical strips and cover it with a bandage. the implant is typically placed every 12 months; after 12 months it should be removed and may be replaced to continue treatment. in children receiving supprelin la for cpp, treatment will likely be stopped by around 11 years of age in girls and 12 years of age in boys. keep the area clean and dry for 24 hours after insertion and do not swim or bathe during this time. leave the bandage on for at least 24 hours. if surgical strips are used, let them fall off on their own. avoid heavy lifting and vigorous activity (including heavy play or exercise for children) with the treated arm for 7 days, and try not to bump the area for a few days. in the first few weeks after insertion, histrelin may temporarily raise certain hormone levels; your doctor will monitor for new or worsening symptoms. the implant can sometimes be hard to feel; ultrasound or mri may be needed to locate it for removal. rarely, the implant may come out through the original insertion site on its own; call your doctor right away if you think this has happened. ask your pharmacist or doctor for the manufacturer’s patient information. what special precautions should i follow? before receiving histrelin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to histrelin; goserelin (zoladex); leuprolide (eligard, lupaneta pack, lupron); nafarelin (synarel); triptorelin (trelstar, triptodur kit); anesthetics such as lidocaine (xylocaine); any other medications; or any ingredients in the implant. ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. tell your doctor if you have low potassium or magnesium levels, or if you have or have ever had diabetes, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, a prolonged qt interval (a rare heart rhythm problem that can cause irregular heartbeat, fainting, or sudden death), cancer that has spread to the spine (backbone), urinary obstruction (difficulty urinating due to blockage), seizures, brain or blood vessel problems or tumors, mental illness, or heart disease. know that histrelin is not for use in women who are pregnant or who can become pregnant. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. if you become pregnant while receiving a histrelin implant, call your doctor immediately; histrelin can harm the fetus. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment to receive an implant or to have an implant removed, call your healthcare provider right away to reschedule. if continuing treatment, the new implant should be inserted within a few weeks. what side effects can this medication cause? histrelin implant may cause side effects. call your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: bruising, soreness, tingling, or itching at the insertion site; scarring at the insertion site; hot flashes; tiredness; light vaginal bleeding in girls; enlarged breasts; decrease in size of testicles; decreased sexual ability or interest; constipation; weight gain; trouble falling or staying asleep; headache; crying, irritability, impatience, anger, or aggressive behavior. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor immediately if you experience: pain, bleeding, swelling, or redness at the insertion site; hives; rash; itching; difficulty breathing or swallowing; bone pain; weakness or numbness in the legs; pain, burning, or tingling in an arm or leg; slow or difficult speech; dizziness or fainting; chest pain; pain in the arms, back, neck, or jaw; loss of ability to move; difficult urination or inability to urinate; blood in the urine; decreased urination; unusual bleeding or bruising; extreme tiredness; loss of appetite; pain in the upper right part of the stomach; yellowing of the skin or eyes; flu-like symptoms; depression or suicidal thoughts, plans, or attempts; seizures. long-term use may affect bone health and increase the risk of fractures; discuss these risks with your doctor. in children receiving supprelin la for cpp, new or worsening signs of sexual development may occur in the first few weeks; in girls, light vaginal bleeding or breast enlargement may occur during the first month. histrelin may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while using this medication.

name: human insulin injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? human insulin is prescribed to control blood sugar in people with type 1 diabetes (when the body makes no insulin) and in people with type 2 diabetes (when the body does not make or use insulin normally) whose blood sugar cannot be controlled with oral medicines alone. it belongs to the hormone class and replaces the insulin your body should produce. it lowers blood sugar by moving glucose from the bloodstream into body tissues for energy and by reducing the liver’s glucose production. all insulins work this way but differ in how quickly they start to act and how long they work. good blood sugar control with medicines, lifestyle changes (diet, exercise, quitting smoking), and regular monitoring can reduce the risk of serious complications such as heart disease, stroke, kidney failure, nerve damage (including numb, cold feet or legs), decreased sexual function in men and women, eye disease and vision loss, and gum disease. your healthcare team will help you plan the best management for your diabetes. how should this medicine be used? human insulin is available as a solution and as a suspension for subcutaneous (under the skin) injection. it is usually injected several times daily, and you may need more than one type of insulin. use exactly the types, doses, and schedule your doctor prescribes; do not use more or less or more often than directed. certain solutions (myxredlin, humulin r u-100, novolin r) may be given intravenously by a healthcare professional with close monitoring. insulin controls high blood sugar but does not cure diabetes;
