continue using it even if you feel well. do not change brands, types, or doses without talking to your doctor. insulin is supplied in vials, prefilled disposable pens, and cartridges for insulin pens. know which container you have and what supplies (needles, syringes, or pens) you need. confirm that the name and letter on your insulin match your prescription. if you use vials, inject with syringes; be sure you know if your insulin is u-100 or u-500 and always use a syringe marked for that strength. use the same brand and model of needle and syringe each time. read the manufacturer’s directions for drawing up and injecting insulin and ask your healthcare provider if you have questions. if using cartridges, you may need to purchase a compatible pen—review the pen’s instructions and have your healthcare provider show you how to use it. if using a disposable pen, read and follow its instructions and get a demonstration from your provider. never reuse needles or syringes, and never share needles, syringes, cartridges, or pens. if using a pen, remove the needle right after the injection. dispose of sharps in a puncture-resistant container and ask your provider how to discard it safely. your doctor may instruct you to mix two insulins in the same syringe; follow the steps exactly and always draw the same type first. do not mix insulins unless told to do so. inspect your insulin before use: regular human insulin (humulin r, novolin r) must be clear, colorless, and as fluid as water—do not use if cloudy, thick, colored, or if particles are present. nph (humulin n, novolin n) and premixed insulins (humulin 70/30, novolin 70/30) should look cloudy or milky after mixing—do not use if clumps or white particles stick to the vial walls or bottom. do not use any insulin past its expiration date. some insulins must be gently mixed (by rolling or inverting); ask your pharmacist how to mix your product if needed. inject into the abdomen, upper arm, thigh, or buttocks; do not inject into muscles, scars, or moles. rotate sites within the same body area, spacing injections at least 1/2 inch (1.25 cm) apart; use all sites in one area before moving to another area. what special precautions should i follow? before using insulin, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to any insulin or any medicines. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may adjust doses or monitor for interactions. nonprescription products such as niacin and salicylates can interact with insulin—do not start them without discussing with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have had diabetic nerve damage; heart failure; or heart, adrenal, pituitary, thyroid, liver, or kidney disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while using insulin. if you are having any surgery, including dental procedures, inform the provider that you use insulin. alcohol can lower blood sugar; ask your doctor about safe alcohol use. ask your doctor what to do if you are ill, under unusual stress, traveling across time zones, or changing your exercise/activity level, as these can alter your insulin needs. ask how often to check your blood sugar. low blood sugar can impair your ability to drive or operate machinery; ask whether you should test before these activities. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow the meal and exercise plan from your doctor or dietitian. eat a healthy diet and try to consume similar amounts and types of foods at consistent times each day. skipping or delaying meals or changing the amount or type of food can disrupt blood sugar control. what should i do if i forget a dose? when you begin insulin therapy, ask your doctor what to do if you miss a dose or inject at the wrong time, and write down those instructions for future reference. what side effects can this medication cause? this medicine affects blood sugar; learn the signs of low and high blood sugar and what actions to take. human insulin may cause side effects. common effects include: redness, swelling, or itching at the injection site; changes in skin texture; skin thickening; fat buildup or small dents from fat loss at injection sites; weight gain; constipation. serious side effects require immediate medical attention and may include: widespread rash or itching; shortness of breath; wheezing; dizziness; blurred vision; rapid heartbeat; sweating; trouble breathing or swallowing; weakness; muscle cramps; abnormal heartbeat; sudden large weight gain; or swelling of the arms, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs.

name: human papillomavirus (hpv) vaccine (gardasil 9)
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? the hpv vaccine helps prevent infection with certain types of human papillomavirus that can cause cancer of the cervix, vagina, and vulva in females; penile cancer in males; anal cancer in both men and women; and cancers of the tonsils, base of tongue, and back of the throat (oropharyngeal cancer) in both men and women. it also helps prevent anogenital warts. the vaccine can prevent over 90% of cancers caused by hpv. hpv spreads through intimate skin-to-skin or sexual contact, and most people will get at least one type of hpv at some point. many infections clear within 2 years, but some persist and can lead to cancer later in life. how should this medicine be used? the hpv vaccine is given as an intramuscular injection. it is routinely recommended at 11 or 12 years of age (it may begin at age 9) to protect before exposure to the virus, and it is recommended for everyone through 26 years of age if not fully vaccinated. adults 27 through 45 years of age may receive the vaccine based on discussions with their health care provider. most people who get the first dose before 15 years of age need 2 doses. people who get the first dose at or after 15 years of age, and younger people with certain immunocompromising conditions, need 3 doses. the hpv vaccine may be given at the same time as other vaccines. what special precautions should i follow? tell your vaccination provider if you have ever had an allergic reaction to a previous dose of hpv vaccine or if you have any severe, life-threatening allergies. tell your provider if you are pregnant; hpv vaccine is not recommended until after pregnancy. people with minor illnesses (such as a cold) may be vaccinated; people who are moderately or severely ill should usually wait until they recover before getting the hpv vaccine. if you have a history of fainting after shots, let your provider know so you can be observed after vaccination. what special dietary instructions should i follow? none; follow your usual diet unless your health care provider gives you different instructions. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, get the next dose as soon as possible. you do not need to restart the series; complete the remaining dose or doses on the updated schedule recommended by your health care provider. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include soreness, redness, or swelling where the shot is given, fever, and headache. some people may feel dizzy or faint after vaccination. rarely, severe allergic reactions can occur, with symptoms such as hives, swelling of the face or throat, difficulty breathing, a fast heartbeat, dizziness, or weakness; call 9-1-1 and seek immediate medical care if these occur. as with any vaccine or medication, there is a very remote chance of other serious injury or death. report concerning reactions to your health care provider and consider reporting them to the vaccine adverse event reporting system (vaers).

name: cervarix (human papillomavirus hpv vaccine)
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cervarix is a vaccine used to help prevent most cases of cervical cancer caused by certain types of human papillomavirus (hpv), especially when given before exposure to the virus. protection is expected to be long-lasting, but vaccination does not treat existing hpv infection and does not replace regular cervical cancer screening; women should continue to get pap tests. this product is no longer marketed in the united states and will not be available once current supplies are gone. how should this medicine be used? cervarix is given as a 3-dose series to females: dose 1 now, dose 2 one to two months after dose 1, and dose 3 six months after dose 1. routine vaccination is recommended for girls 11–12 years old and may start at age 9. catch-up vaccination is recommended for females 13–26 years old who did not complete all 3 doses earlier. it is most effective when given before first sexual contact. additional booster doses are not recommended. it may be given at the same time as other vaccines. what special precautions should i follow? do not receive cervarix if you have had a life-threatening allergic reaction to any component of the vaccine or to a previous dose, or if you have a severe latex allergy. it is not recommended during pregnancy; if you were vaccinated while pregnant, this is not a reason to end the pregnancy. women who are breastfeeding may receive the vaccine. if you are mildly ill, you can usually be vaccinated; people with moderate or severe illness should wait until they recover. because fainting can occur after vaccination, sit or lie down for about 15 minutes afterward and tell your provider if you feel dizzy, light-headed, have vision changes, or ringing in the ears. vaccination does not replace routine cervical cancer screening. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are required. what should i do if i forget a dose? get the missed dose as soon as possible. complete the series without restarting; follow your provider’s guidance to finish any remaining doses on the appropriate intervals. what side effects can this medication cause? common, short-lived reactions include: pain at the injection site (about 9 in 10), redness or swelling (about 1 in 2), fever of 99.5°f or higher (about 1 in 8), headache or fatigue (about 1 in 2), nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or abdominal pain (about 1 in 4), and muscle or joint pain (up to 1 in 2). fainting can occur after vaccination; brief jerking movements may accompany fainting. serious allergic reactions are rare but can include rash, swelling of the hands, feet, face, or lips, and difficulty breathing. seek medical care right away if these occur. report severe reactions to your healthcare provider and ask them to submit a vaers report; concerns about vaccine injuries can be addressed through the national vaccine injury compensation program (1-800-338-2382 or http://www.hrsa.gov/vaccinecompensation).

name: hydralazine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? hydralazine is prescribed to treat high blood pressure. it belongs to a class of medicines called vasodilators and works by relaxing blood vessels so blood can flow more easily. treating high blood pressure helps prevent damage to the brain, heart, blood vessels, kidneys, and other organs, which can lead to heart disease, heart attack, heart failure, stroke, kidney failure, vision loss, and other problems. along with medication, lifestyle changes—such as eating a diet low in fat and salt, maintaining a healthy weight, exercising at least 30 minutes on most days, not smoking, and limiting alcohol—also help control blood pressure. it may also be prescribed after heart valve replacement or for heart failure; discuss risks and benefits with your doctor. this medication may sometimes be used for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. how should this medicine be used? hydralazine comes as an oral tablet and is usually taken 2 to 4 times a day. take it at the same times each day. follow your prescription label carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if anything is unclear. take exactly as directed; do not take more or less or take it more often than prescribed. hydralazine controls, but does not cure, high blood pressure. continue taking it even if you feel well. do not stop taking it without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine hydralazine may be used after heart valve replacement and to treat heart failure. talk to your doctor about the possible risks of using this medication for your condition. what special precautions should i follow? before taking hydralazine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to hydralazine, aspirin, tartrazine (a yellow dye in some foods and medicines), any other medications, or any ingredients in hydralazine tablets; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have ever had a heart attack or if you have coronary artery disease, rheumatic heart disease, or heart, kidney, or liver disease. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; if you become pregnant while taking hydralazine, call your doctor. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the doctor or dentist that you are taking hydralazine. ask your doctor about the safe use of alcohol while taking hydralazine; alcohol can worsen side effects. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take hydralazine with meals or a snack. your doctor may recommend a low-salt (low-sodium) diet; follow these instructions carefully. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? hydralazine may cause side effects. common side effects include flushing, headache, upset stomach, vomiting, loss of appetite, diarrhea, constipation, watery eyes, stuffy nose, and rash. some side effects can be serious; call your doctor immediately if you experience fainting, joint or muscle pain, fever, rapid heartbeat, chest pain, swollen ankles or feet, or numbness or tingling in the hands or feet.

name: hydrocodone
instructions: important warning: hydrocodone can be habit forming and may cause serious or life-threatening breathing problems. take it exactly as prescribed. do not take more, take it more often, use it in any other way, or stop it suddenly unless your doctor tells you to. tell your doctor if you or a family member drinks or has ever drunk large amounts of alcohol, uses or has ever used street drugs, has misused prescription medicines, has had an overdose, or if you have or have ever had depression or another mental illness. hydrocodone can slow or stop breathing, especially during the first 24 to 72 hours of treatment and whenever your dose is increased. call your doctor or get emergency help right away if you have slowed breathing, long pauses between breaths, or shortness of breath. hydrocodone can harm or be fatal to others who take it, especially children. store it securely to prevent accidental or intentional use by others. combining hydrocodone with certain medicines, alcohol, or street drugs increases the risk of dangerous sedation, breathing problems, coma, and death. always tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medicines, vitamins, and supplements you take or plan to take. your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor you closely. swallow extended-release capsules and extended-release tablets whole; do not chew, crush, break, divide, dissolve, or pre-soak them. these forms are designed to resist tampering; breaking or chewing can release too much hydrocodone at once. if you are pregnant or plan to become pregnant, tell your doctor. regular use during pregnancy can cause life-threatening withdrawal in the newborn. you will receive a medication guide when you start and each time you refill; read it and ask questions. discuss the risks and benefits of hydrocodone with your doctor. why is this medication prescribed? hydrocodone is used to relieve severe pain. it is an opioid narcotic analgesic that changes how the brain and nervous system respond to pain. this information covers hydrocodone alone; if you use a combination product, read about all ingredients and ask your doctor or pharmacist. how should this medicine be used? hydrocodone comes as extended-release capsules to take every 12 hours and extended-release tablets to take once daily by mouth. take doses at the same times each day. swallow one capsule or tablet at a time with plenty of water and swallow immediately after placing it in your mouth. do not pre-soak, wet, or lick tablets. your doctor will adjust your dose based on pain control and side effects. if your pain is not controlled, worsens, becomes more sensitive, or new pain appears, call your doctor; do not take extra doses or take it more often. ask your doctor or pharmacist about access to rescue medicines such as naloxone or nalmefene. these can reverse an opioid overdose and are available over the counter or by prescription. make sure you and people around you know the signs of overdose, how to use naloxone or nalmefene, and what to do until help arrives. if overdose symptoms occur, a helper should give the first dose of naloxone, call 911, stay with you, and monitor you; if symptoms return, give another dose every 2 to 3 minutes until medical help arrives. do not stop hydrocodone without talking to your doctor. stopping suddenly can cause withdrawal symptoms such as restlessness, watery eyes, runny nose, yawning, sweating, chills, gooseflesh, muscle aches, enlarged pupils, irritability, anxiety, back or joint pain, weakness, stomach cramps, insomnia, nausea, loss of appetite, vomiting, diarrhea, fast breathing, or fast heartbeat. your doctor will taper your dose gradually. other uses for this medicine this medicine may be prescribed for other purposes; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking hydrocodone, tell your doctor and pharmacist about any allergies to this drug, its ingredients, or other drugs, foods, or substances, and describe your reaction. some medicines must not be used with hydrocodone. discuss all current and planned medicines with your doctor and pharmacist before starting hydrocodone, and always consult them before starting, stopping, or changing any medicine while taking hydrocodone. do not take, and tell your doctor if you are taking or have taken within the past 2 weeks, isocarboxazid, linezolid, methylene blue, phenelzine, selegiline, or tranylcypromine. nonprescription or herbal products that may interact include st. johns wort and tryptophan; tell your doctor and pharmacist if you use them, and do not start them while on hydrocodone without medical advice. tell your doctor if you have slowed breathing, asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease copd, or other lung problems; a blockage or narrowing of the stomach or intestines; or paralytic ileus. your doctor may advise against hydrocodone. also tell your doctor if you have or have ever had a brain tumor or other conditions that increase pressure in the brain; seizures; or thyroid, gallbladder, pancreas, heart, liver, or kidney disease. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor; call your doctor if you become pregnant while taking hydrocodone. this medication may decrease fertility in males and females. do not drink alcohol while taking hydrocodone, as it can worsen side effects. hydrocodone can cause drowsiness; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. it may cause dizziness or fainting when standing up quickly, especially at the start; rise slowly and sit with your feet on the floor before standing. hydrocodone may cause constipation; ask your doctor about diet changes or medicines to prevent or treat constipation. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take more than one dose of extended-release capsules in 12 hours or extended-release tablets in 24 hours. what side effects can this medication cause? hydrocodone may cause side effects. call your doctor if common effects are severe or do not go away: nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, increased sweating, decreased sexual desire, or inability to get or keep an erection. some side effects are serious. call your doctor immediately or get emergency medical help if you have any of the following or the symptoms listed in the important warning: agitation; hallucinations; fever; sweating; confusion; fast heartbeat; shivering; severe muscle stiffness or twitching; loss of coordination; diarrhea; nausea; vomiting; loss of appetite; weakness; dizziness; chest pain; changes in heartbeat; rash; hives; hoarseness; trouble breathing or swallowing; swelling of the face, mouth, tongue, or throat; seizures; extreme drowsiness; new or worsened pain or pain from light touch or routine activities; difficulty swallowing; regurgitation of food; chest pain while swallowing; unusual snoring or long pauses in breathing during sleep. hydrocodone may cause other side effects. call your doctor if you have any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: hydroxychloroquine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? hydroxychloroquine is used to prevent and treat acute attacks of malaria in adults and in children who weigh more than 31 kg (68 lb). it is also used to treat discoid lupus erythematosus (dle), systemic lupus erythematosus (sle, or lupus), and rheumatoid arthritis. hydroxychloroquine belongs to a class of drugs called antimalarials and also acts as an antirheumatic. it works by killing the organisms that cause malaria and may improve rheumatoid arthritis and sle by decreasing overactivity of the immune system. how should this medicine be used? hydroxychloroquine is available as an oral tablet and should be taken with food or milk. for malaria prevention, take one dose once a week on the same day each week; start 1 to 2 weeks before entering a malaria-endemic area, continue weekly while there, and for 4 weeks after leaving. for malaria treatment, take the first dose right away, a second dose 6 hours later, and two more doses 24 and 48 hours after the first dose. for dle, sle, or rheumatoid arthritis, it is usually taken once or twice daily. follow your prescription label exactly. do not take more or less, or take it more often, than prescribed. swallow tablets whole; do not split, chew, or crush. rheumatoid arthritis symptoms may take several weeks to months to improve; contact your doctor if symptoms do not improve or worsen. if the medicine helps, do not stop it without talking to your doctor; symptoms often return if you stop. other uses for this medicine hydroxychloroquine is sometimes used to treat porphyria cutanea tarda (a condition causing sun-sensitive blistering skin). discuss the potential risks and benefits with your doctor. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking hydroxychloroquine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to hydroxychloroquine, chloroquine, primaquine, quinine, any other medications, or any ingredients in the tablets. provide a complete list of all prescription and nonprescription drugs, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you take or plan to take. the nonprescription drug cimetidine (tagamet hb) may interact with hydroxychloroquine; do not start cimetidine while taking hydroxychloroquine without discussing it with your healthcare provider. if you take antacids, take them at least 4 hours before or 4 hours after hydroxychloroquine. tell your doctor if you or a family member has had a prolonged qt interval (a rare heart rhythm problem) or if you are of asian descent; and if you have or have ever had heart failure, a heart attack, an irregular heartbeat, or other heart problems; low magnesium or potassium levels; psoriasis; porphyria; glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (g6pd) deficiency or other blood disorders; dermatitis; seizures; vision problems including macular degeneration; diabetes; kidney or liver disease; or if you drink large amounts of alcohol. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding; call your doctor if you become pregnant while taking hydroxychloroquine. hydroxychloroquine can cause serious, potentially irreversible eye problems; you will likely need regular eye exams during treatment. call your doctor right away if you notice blurred vision, floaters, flashes of light, or other changes in vision. hydroxychloroquine can cause hypoglycemia (low blood sugar); your doctor may ask you to monitor your blood sugar. seek medical help if you develop dizziness, weakness, tiredness, sweating, nausea, fast or irregular heartbeat, confusion, fainting, or loss of consciousness. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take hydroxychloroquine with food or milk to reduce stomach upset. unless your doctor gives you other instructions, continue your usual diet. if you have diabetes, follow your meal plan and monitor your blood sugar as directed. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? hydroxychloroquine may cause side effects. common effects include headache; loss of appetite; nausea; diarrhea; stomach pain; vomiting; difficulty hearing; ringing in the ears; hair loss; and changes in hair color. call your doctor immediately if you have any of the following or those listed in special precautions: hives; rash; swelling of the face, eyes, mouth, throat, tongue, lips, hands, feet, ankles, or lower legs; trouble breathing or swallowing; blisters on the skin, eyes, lips, or in the mouth; itching or burning skin; muscle weakness; burning, numbness, or tingling in the hands or feet; extreme tiredness; loss of appetite; nausea; yellowing of the skin or eyes; dark urine; pain in the upper right abdomen; unusual bleeding or bruising; cough, fever, sore throat, runny nose, or other signs of infection; mood or mental changes; fast or irregular heartbeat; lightheadedness, dizziness, or fainting; unusual tiredness or weakness; seizures; new or worsening depression; mood changes; thoughts of harming yourself; or reduced urination, swelling of the legs, feet, or ankles, shortness of breath, tiredness, confusion, nausea, weakness, belly pain, itching, or loss of appetite. hydroxychloroquine may cause other side effects; call your doctor if you experience any unusual problems while taking this medication.

name: hydroxyurea
instructions: important warning: hydroxyurea can cause a significant drop in the number of blood cells made in your bone marrow, which increases the risk of serious infection and bleeding. call your doctor right away if you develop fever, chills, severe tiredness or weakness, body aches, sore throat, shortness of breath, persistent cough and congestion, or other signs of infection; unusual bruising or bleeding; bloody or black, tarry stools; or vomiting blood or material that looks like coffee grounds. keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. your doctor will order regular tests to monitor your response and to check for low blood counts, and may change your dose or temporarily stop treatment if counts fall too low. hydroxyurea may raise the risk of other cancers, including skin cancer. avoid unnecessary or prolonged sun exposure and use protective clothing, sunglasses, and sunscreen. discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. you will receive a medication guide when you start hydroxyurea and with each refill; read it carefully and ask your doctor or pharmacist if you have questions. why is this medication prescribed? hydroxyurea (hydrea) is used alone or with other medicines or radiation therapy to treat certain cases of chronic myelogenous leukemia (cml), a cancer of the white blood cells, and certain head and neck cancers (including cancers of the mouth, cheek, tongue, throat, tonsils, and sinuses). hydroxyurea (droxia, siklos) reduces the frequency of painful crises and the need for blood transfusions in adults and in children 2 years and older with sickle cell anemia, an inherited condition in which abnormally shaped red blood cells cannot deliver enough oxygen throughout the body. hydroxyurea is an antimetabolite. it treats cancer by slowing or stopping the growth of cancer cells, and treats sickle cell anemia by helping prevent the formation of sickle-shaped red blood cells. how should this medicine be used? hydroxyurea is available as capsules and tablets taken by mouth. it is usually taken once daily with a glass of water; for some cancers, it may be taken once every third day. your doctor will tell you how often to take hydroxyurea based on your condition and how you respond. take it at the same time each day. follow the prescription label exactly; do not take more, take less, or take it more often than prescribed. your doctor may delay treatment or adjust your dose depending on your response and side effects. do not stop taking hydroxyurea without talking to your doctor. your doctor will likely prescribe folic acid to reduce some side effects; take it as directed. swallow capsules whole; do not split, chew, or crush them. siklos 1,000‑mg tablets are scored so they can be split into halves or quarters for smaller doses; do not split the 100‑mg tablets. your doctor will tell you how to split tablets and how many full or partial tablets to take. if you cannot swallow tablets or tablet portions, you may dissolve your dose in water: place the dose in a teaspoon, add a small amount of water, wait about 1 minute for it to dissolve, then swallow immediately. wear rubber or latex gloves when handling capsules or tablets so the medication does not contact your skin. wash your hands with soap and water before and after touching the bottle or medication. if hydroxyurea gets in your eyes, flush with water for at least 15 minutes. if capsule or tablet powder spills, wipe it up immediately with a damp disposable towel, place the towel in a closed container (such as a plastic bag), and discard it in a trash can out of reach of children and pets. clean the spill area with a detergent solution followed by clean water. other uses for this medicine hydroxyurea is sometimes used to treat polycythemia vera, a blood disorder with too many red blood cells. discuss the risks and benefits with your doctor. it may also be prescribed for other uses; ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking hydroxyurea, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to hydroxyurea or any of its ingredients; ask your pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you use or plan to use; your doctor may need to adjust doses or monitor for side effects. tell your doctor if you have hiv, aids, high uric acid levels, or leg ulcers; if you are receiving or have ever received radiation therapy, cancer chemotherapy, or hemodialysis; or if you have or have ever had kidney or liver disease. be aware that in some people using continuous glucose monitoring (cgm), hydroxyurea can make glucose readings appear higher than they are, which may lead to higher insulin dosing and hypoglycemia; if you use cgm, talk to your doctor about alternative ways to monitor glucose during treatment. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding, tell your doctor. do not become pregnant or breastfeed while taking hydroxyurea. you will need a pregnancy test before starting. females should use effective contraception during treatment and for at least 6 months after stopping. males should use effective contraception with female partners during treatment and for at least 6 months after stopping siklos or at least 1 year after stopping droxia or hydrea. discuss appropriate birth control methods and duration. if you become pregnant while taking hydroxyurea, contact your doctor immediately; hydroxyurea may harm the fetus. this medication may decrease fertility in men; discuss risks with your doctor. do not receive any vaccinations without talking to your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor advises otherwise, continue your usual diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? hydroxyurea may cause side effects. tell your doctor if any of these are severe or do not go away: nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, loss of appetite, weight gain, mouth and throat sores, constipation, rash, pale skin, dizziness, headache, hair loss, and changes in skin or nails. some side effects can be serious. call your doctor right away or seek emergency care if you experience any of the following or any symptoms listed in the important warning section: fast heartbeat; persistent pain that starts in the stomach area and may spread to the back; leg wounds or ulcers; skin pain, itching, redness, swelling, or blisters; pain in the upper right side of the abdomen; blood in the urine; yellowing of the skin or eyes; numbness, burning, or tingling in the hands or feet; fever, cough, shortness of breath, or other breathing problems. hydroxyurea may cause other side effects; contact your doctor if you notice anything unusual.

name: hyoscyamine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? hyoscyamine is used to control symptoms associated with disorders of the gastrointestinal gi tract. it works by decreasing the movement of the stomach and intestines and reducing the secretion of stomach fluids, including acid. hyoscyamine is also used to treat bladder spasms, peptic ulcer disease, diverticulitis, colic, irritable bowel syndrome, cystitis, and pancreatitis. it may also be used to treat certain heart conditions, to control the symptoms of parkinsons disease and rhinitis runny nose, and to reduce excess saliva production. how should this medicine be used? hyoscyamine comes as a tablet, an extended-release long-acting capsule, and a liquid taken by mouth. the tablets and liquid are usually taken three or four times a day. the extended-release capsules are usually taken twice a day. follow the directions on your prescription label carefully, and ask your doctor or pharmacist to explain any part you do not understand. take hyoscyamine exactly as directed. do not take more or less of it or take it more often than prescribed by your doctor. swallow extended-release capsules whole; do not split, chew, or crush them. hyoscyamine controls symptoms associated with gi disorders but does not cure them. continue to take hyoscyamine even if you feel well. do not stop taking it without talking to your doctor. other uses for this medicine this medication may be prescribed for other uses. ask your doctor or pharmacist for more information. what special precautions should i follow? before taking hyoscyamine, tell your doctor and pharmacist if you are allergic to hyoscyamine, any other medications, or any of the ingredients in the tablets, capsules, or liquid. ask your doctor or pharmacist for a list of ingredients. tell your doctor and pharmacist about all prescription and nonprescription medications, vitamins, nutritional supplements, and herbal products you are taking or plan to take while using hyoscyamine. your doctor may need to change the doses of your medications or monitor you carefully for side effects. be aware that antacids may interfere with hyoscyamine, making it less effective. take hyoscyamine 1 hour before or 2 hours after antacids. the following nonprescription allergy medications may interact with hyoscyamine: diphenhydramine, loratadine, fexofenadine, chlorpheniramine, or cetirizine. be sure to let your doctor and pharmacist know that you are taking these medications before you start hyoscyamine. do not start any of these medications while taking hyoscyamine without discussing it with your healthcare provider. tell your doctor if you have or have ever had glaucoma; heart, lung, liver, or kidney disease; a urinary tract or intestinal obstruction; an enlarged prostate; ulcerative colitis a condition that causes swelling and sores in the lining of the colon large intestine and rectum; or myasthenia gravis. tell your doctor if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breast-feeding. if you become pregnant while taking hyoscyamine, call your doctor. talk to your doctor about the risks and benefits of taking hyoscyamine if you are 65 years of age or older. older adults should not usually take hyoscyamine because it may be less safe and may not be as effective as other medications for the same condition. if you are having surgery, including dental surgery, tell the surgeon or dentist that you take hyoscyamine. you should know that this medication may make you drowsy. do not drive a car or operate machinery until you know how hyoscyamine affects you. ask your doctor about the safe use of alcohol during your treatment, as alcohol can make the side effects of this medication worse. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, continue your normal diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember it. however, if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular dosing schedule. do not take a double dose to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? hyoscyamine may cause side effects. if any of these symptoms are severe or do not go away: drowsiness, dizziness or lightheadedness, headache, blurred vision, flushing or feeling of warmth, dry mouth, constipation, difficulty urinating, increased sensitivity to light. some side effects can be serious. if you experience any of the following symptoms, call your doctor immediately: diarrhea, skin rash, eye pain, fast or irregular heartbeat. hyoscyamine may cause other side effects.

name: phenylephrine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? phenylephrine is used to relieve nasal and sinus congestion caused by colds, allergies, or sinusitis. a prescription injectable form may be used in medical settings to raise low blood pressure. how should this medicine be used? for over the counter oral use, follow the product label or your prescribers directions. typical adult dosing is 10 milligrams by mouth every 4 hours as needed with a maximum of 60 milligrams in 24 hours. use the lowest effective dose for the shortest time. do not use for more than 7 days unless directed. for children use only products labeled for their age and follow dosing carefully. how should this medicine be used if it is a nasal spray or drops? use exactly as directed, usually 1 to 2 sprays or drops in each nostril every 4 hours as needed for up to 3 days to avoid rebound congestion. do not share the bottle and avoid contaminating the tip. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you are taking or have taken a monoamine oxidase inhibitor within the last 14 days.if you have high blood pressure, heart disease, diabetes, thyroid disease, glaucoma, an enlarged prostate, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. avoid taking other cold or allergy products that also contain decongestants or stimulants. phenylephrine may cause nervousness or trouble sleeping so avoid taking it near bedtime. what special dietary instructions should i follow? limit caffeine and other stimulants which can increase side effects such as jitteriness and rapid heartbeat. drink plenty of fluids if you are congested. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is usually taken as needed. if you are on a schedule, take it when you remember, but skip it if it is almost time for your next dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nervousness, dizziness, headache, increased blood pressure, palpitations, and trouble sleeping. stop use and seek medical help for chest pain, severe or persistent headache, rapid or irregular heartbeat, severe high blood pressure symptoms, or signs of an allergic reaction such as rash, swelling, or trouble breathing.

name: pyrethrin and piperonyl butoxide topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? pyrethrin with piperonyl butoxide is used to treat head lice and their eggs and may also be used for pubic lice when directed. it kills live lice but not all eggs, so retreatment is often needed. how should this medicine be used? for head lice apply to dry hair and scalp enough to thoroughly wet the hair. leave on for 10 minutes, then add a small amount of water, lather, and rinse thoroughly. use a fine tooth nit comb to remove lice and nits while the hair is still damp. repeat in 7 to 10 days to kill newly hatched lice unless your clinician advises otherwise. treat close contacts as recommended and wash or heat dry clothing, hats, bedding, and combs used within the prior 48 hours. avoid contact with eyes, nose, and mouth. do not use on eyelashes or eyebrows. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you are allergic to pyrethrins, chrysanthemums, or ragweed. use with caution if you have asthma or very sensitive skin. for external use only. do not use on broken or inflamed skin. keep away from open flame because the product may be flammable. ask a clinician before use in children under 2 years, during pregnancy, or while breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply as soon as you remember if lice are still present, then continue with the planned retreatment schedule. do not apply more often than directed. what side effects can this medication cause? mild itching, redness, tingling, or burning of the scalp are common and usually temporary. stop use and seek medical help if you develop swelling, hives, trouble breathing, or severe irritation.

name: antipyrine-benzocaine otic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? antipyrine and benzocaine ear drops are used to relieve ear pain and pressure and to help soften earwax, often alongside other treatments for ear conditions. how should this medicine be used? warm the bottle in your hands. lie with the affected ear upward. instill enough drops to fill the ear canal as directed. insert a clean cotton plug if advised and moisten it with a few drops. for pain you may repeat every 1 to 2 hours as needed or as directed. for earwax softening use drops up to 3 times daily for 2 to 3 days before earwax removal as instructed by your clinician. do not use if you have a perforated eardrum or ear tubes unless directed by a clinician. do not touch the dropper tip to the ear or any surface. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you are allergic to benzocaine, other local anesthetics, or antipyrine. seek medical evaluation for severe pain, fever, drainage, trauma, or hearing loss. for ear use only. keep out of reach of children. use with caution in infants and young children because benzocaine can rarely cause methemoglobinemia. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is often used as needed. if on a schedule, use it when you remember unless it is close to the next dose. do not double doses. what side effects can this medication cause? mild local irritation, redness, or itching can occur. stop use and seek immediate medical help if you notice gray or blue colored skin, shortness of breath, extreme fatigue, fast heart rate, or confusion which may indicate methemoglobinemia, or if you have signs of a severe allergic reaction.

name: hydrocortisone injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? hydrocortisone injection is a corticosteroid used to treat adrenal insufficiency, severe allergic reactions, asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease exacerbations, certain autoimmune and inflammatory conditions, and some forms of shock. how should this medicine be used? it is usually given by a healthcare professional into a vein or muscle. dose and duration are individualized. if you have adrenal insufficiency, your clinician may provide an emergency injection kit and instructions for use during illness or injury and will advise you to wear medical identification. do not stop long term corticosteroids suddenly without medical guidance because of the risk of adrenal crisis. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about infections, recent exposure to chickenpox or measles, diabetes, high blood pressure, glaucoma or cataracts, osteoporosis, stomach ulcers, mood disorders, seizure disorder, liver disease, or pregnancy or breastfeeding. hydrocortisone can increase infection risk and may mask signs of infection. avoid live vaccines while on significant immunosuppressive doses. many medicines can interact, including certain antifungals, antibiotics, seizure medicines, and hiv medicines. what special dietary instructions should i follow? your clinician may advise limiting sodium, ensuring enough calcium and vitamin d, and managing carbohydrates if you have diabetes or steroid induced hyperglycemia. maintain adequate hydration. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you are on a scheduled regimen, take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose, then skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. if you have adrenal insufficiency and symptoms of adrenal crisis occur, use your emergency injection as instructed and seek emergency care. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fluid retention, swelling, increased appetite, weight gain, mood changes, anxiety or insomnia, elevated blood pressure, elevated blood sugar, stomach upset, acne, and increased sweating. serious effects include signs of infection, vision changes or eye pain, severe mood or behavior changes, stomach bleeding, pancreatitis, severe muscle or bone pain, hip or shoulder pain suggestive of avascular necrosis, and adrenal suppression. injection site pain or infection can occur.

name: methylprednisolone injection
instructions: important warning: serious neurologic adverse reactions including spinal cord infarction, paraplegia, quadriplegia, cortical blindness, and stroke have occurred with epidural administration of corticosteroids. methylprednisolone injection should not be given by epidural or intrathecal routes. corticosteroids can suppress the immune system, increase the risk of serious infections, and mask signs of infection. do not stop long term therapy suddenly because of the risk of adrenal crisis. why is this medication prescribed? methylprednisolone injection is a corticosteroid used to treat severe allergic reactions, asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease exacerbations, autoimmune and inflammatory disorders, multiple sclerosis exacerbations, and other conditions as determined by your clinician. how should this medicine be used? it is given by a healthcare professional into a vein or muscle. dose and duration are individualized based on the condition and response. do not use by epidural or intrathecal routes. if used for more than a few days, your clinician may taper the dose to prevent adrenal suppression. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have current or recent infection, exposure to chickenpox or measles, diabetes, high blood pressure, glaucoma or cataracts, osteoporosis, stomach ulcers, psychiatric history, seizure disorder, liver or kidney disease, myasthenia gravis, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. avoid live vaccines while receiving immunosuppressive doses. some formulations contain benzyl alcohol which should not be used in newborns. many medicines interact including certain antifungals, antibiotics, seizure medicines, blood thinners, and hiv medicines. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may be advised to limit sodium, ensure adequate calcium and vitamin d, and manage carbohydrate intake to control blood sugar. maintain adequate hydration. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you are on a scheduled regimen, take the missed dose when you remember unless it is close to the next dose. do not take two doses at once. if you are using a taper, contact your clinician for instructions. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fluid retention, swelling, increased appetite, weight gain, mood changes, anxiety or insomnia, elevated blood pressure, elevated blood sugar, stomach upset, acne, and increased sweating. serious effects include severe infection, vision changes or eye pain, stomach bleeding, pancreatitis, severe mood or behavior changes, muscle weakness, bone loss, hip or shoulder pain suggestive of avascular necrosis, and adrenal suppression. injection site reactions can occur.

name: chlordiazepoxide
instructions: important warning: chlordiazepoxide is a benzodiazepine. taking benzodiazepines with opioids can cause profound sedation, severe respiratory depression, coma, and death. use together only when alternatives are inadequate and with close monitoring. benzodiazepines can cause misuse, abuse, and addiction, and can lead to physical dependence. do not stop suddenly after long term use because withdrawal reactions can be severe or life threatening. why is this medication prescribed? chlordiazepoxide is used to treat anxiety disorders and symptoms of acute alcohol withdrawal. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth exactly as prescribed, with or without food. doses for anxiety are usually divided 3 or 4 times daily. doses for alcohol withdrawal may be higher at first and then tapered. use the lowest effective dose for the shortest duration. do not increase the dose or take more often than prescribed. do not stop suddenly. your clinician will guide a gradual taper to reduce withdrawal risk. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you use opioids, alcohol, or other sedatives. avoid alcohol. tell your clinician if you have liver disease, kidney disease, breathing problems, sleep apnea, depression or other mental health conditions, a history of substance use disorder, glaucoma, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. this medicine may cause drowsiness, dizziness, and impaired coordination; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. many medicines can interact including strong inhibitors or inducers of liver enzymes. older adults are at higher risk of confusion, falls, and fractures. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid alcohol. if you are sensitive to grapefruit or grapefruit juice, ask your clinician or pharmacist about potential interactions. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it when you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include drowsiness, dizziness, fatigue, confusion, blurred vision, dry mouth, constipation, or coordination problems. serious effects include severe sedation or breathing problems, agitation, worsening depression, suicidal thoughts, yellowing of the skin or eyes, severe rash, or unusual bleeding. seek emergency help for trouble breathing or unresponsiveness, especially if taken with opioids or alcohol.

name: tetrahydrozoline ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? tetrahydrozoline ophthalmic is used to relieve eye redness due to minor irritation. how should this medicine be used? wash hands before use. remove contact lenses. instill 1 drop in the affected eye every 4 hours as needed. do not use more than 72 hours in a row to avoid rebound redness. do not touch the dropper tip to any surface and recap after use. do not use while wearing contact lenses. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you have narrow angle glaucoma unless directed by a clinician. stop use and seek care for eye pain, changes in vision, continued redness, or if redness lasts more than 72 hours. keep out of reach of children because accidental ingestion can cause serious harm such as low heart rate, sleepiness, and low body temperature. ask your clinician before use during pregnancy or breastfeeding or in young children. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? use as needed. if you are on a schedule, use when you remember unless it is close to the next dose. do not use extra drops to make up a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? mild transient stinging or burning, temporary blurred vision, or eye irritation may occur. overuse can cause rebound redness. seek medical help for severe eye pain, persistent vision changes, severe headache with eye pain, or signs of an allergic reaction.

name: abacavir
instructions: important warning: abacavir can cause a serious and sometimes fatal hypersensitivity reaction that is more likely if you have the hla b*5701 gene variant. you must be tested for hla b*5701 before starting abacavir. stop abacavir and seek emergency care if you develop symptoms of hypersensitivity which may include fever, rash, malaise or fatigue, gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or abdominal pain, or respiratory symptoms such as cough, sore throat, or shortness of breath. never restart abacavir if you have had a suspected hypersensitivity reaction. why is this medication prescribed? abacavir is an antiretroviral medicine used with other medicines to treat human immunodeficiency virus infection. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as prescribed, usually 300 milligrams twice daily or 600 milligrams once daily, with or without food. take doses at the same times every day. do not miss doses or stop unless your clinician tells you to. abacavir should always be used in combination with other antiretrovirals. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have liver disease, risk factors for heart disease, or if you drink alcohol. abacavir is not recommended in moderate or severe liver disease. tell your clinician if you are pregnant or planning pregnancy. do not breastfeed if you have hiv. many medicines can interact; review all medicines and supplements with your clinician. be aware of possible immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome when starting therapy. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take abacavir with or without food. limit alcohol because it can increase abacavir levels and liver stress. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. do not take two doses at once. if you have stopped abacavir for any reason and have symptoms suggestive of hypersensitivity or if the cause of prior symptoms is uncertain, do not restart abacavir and contact your clinician immediately. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, vomiting, headache, fatigue, and rash. serious effects include hypersensitivity reaction, liver problems such as jaundice or dark urine, lactic acidosis with severe weakness or unusual muscle pain, and chest pain or shortness of breath. seek medical help right away for signs of hypersensitivity or severe side effects.

name: abacavir, dolutegravir, and lamivudine
instructions: important warning: this medicine contains abacavir which can cause a serious and sometimes fatal hypersensitivity reaction that is more likely if you have the hla b*5701 gene variant. you must be tested for hla b*5701 before starting. stop the medicine and seek emergency care if you develop symptoms such as fever, rash, malaise or fatigue, gastrointestinal symptoms like nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or abdominal pain, or respiratory symptoms like cough, sore throat, or shortness of breath. never restart if you had a suspected hypersensitivity reaction. in people with hepatitis b virus infection, stopping lamivudine can cause a serious flare of hepatitis. why is this medication prescribed? the fixed dose combination of abacavir, dolutegravir, and lamivudine treats human immunodeficiency virus infection and is used as a complete regimen in appropriate patients. how should this medicine be used? take one tablet once daily at the same time each day, with or without food. if you take antacids or iron or calcium supplements, take this medicine at least 2 hours before or 6 hours after those products. do not take with dofetilide. do not miss doses or stop unless directed by your clinician. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have liver disease or hepatitis b infection, kidney problems, or if you are pregnant or planning pregnancy. your clinician may check hepatitis b status and liver tests and may prescribe additional hepatitis b treatment if needed. dolutegravir can interact with many medicines including metformin, multivitamins or supplements containing polyvalent cations, certain anticonvulsants, rifampin, and st johns wort. this product is not recommended if your creatinine clearance is less than 50 milliliters per minute. watch for depression or insomnia and report new or worsening mood symptoms. do not breastfeed if you have hiv. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take with or without food. separate dosing from antacids or iron or calcium supplements as described. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember if it is within about 12 hours of your usual time. if it is close to the time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. if you vomit within 1 hour after taking a dose, take another dose. do not restart the medicine after a break if you had any signs of abacavir hypersensitivity without first speaking to your clinician. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, nausea, diarrhea, and insomnia. weight gain can occur. serious effects include hypersensitivity reaction, liver problems including hepatitis flares after stopping in people with hepatitis b, lactic acidosis with severe weakness or unusual muscle pain, depression or suicidal thoughts, and severe skin reactions. immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome can occur when starting therapy.

name: abacavir, lamivudine, and zidovudine
instructions: important warning: this medicine contains abacavir which can cause a serious and sometimes fatal hypersensitivity reaction that is more likely if you have the hla b*5701 gene variant. you must be tested for hla b*5701 before starting. stop the medicine and seek emergency care if you develop symptoms such as fever, rash, malaise or fatigue, gastrointestinal symptoms like nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or abdominal pain, or respiratory symptoms like cough, sore throat, or shortness of breath. never restart if you had a suspected hypersensitivity reaction. this medicine also carries a risk of lactic acidosis and severe liver enlargement with fatty liver. zidovudine can cause bone marrow suppression leading to anemia and neutropenia, and long term use can cause muscle weakness. in people with hepatitis b infection, stopping lamivudine can cause a serious flare of hepatitis. why is this medication prescribed? the fixed dose combination of abacavir, lamivudine, and zidovudine is used with or without other antiretroviral agents to treat human immunodeficiency virus infection. how should this medicine be used? take one tablet by mouth twice daily with or without food. take doses at the same times every day. do not miss doses or stop unless directed by your clinician. this product may not be suitable if you have significant kidney impairment because lamivudine requires dose adjustment. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have liver disease, hepatitis b or c infection, kidney disease, low blood counts, anemia, or neutropenia, or if you are pregnant or planning pregnancy. your clinician will check blood counts regularly. many medicines can interact including ribavirin, doxorubicin, other medicines that affect bone marrow, and alcohol. do not breastfeed if you have hiv. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take with or without food and should limit alcohol to reduce liver stress. ensure adequate nutrition to support blood counts as advised by your clinician. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose, then skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. if you vomit within 1 hour after a dose, take another dose. do not restart the medicine after a break if you had any signs of abacavir hypersensitivity without first speaking to your clinician. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, headache, fatigue, and trouble sleeping. serious effects include hypersensitivity reaction, anemia, neutropenia, lactic acidosis with severe weakness or unusual muscle pain, liver problems with jaundice or dark urine, pancreatitis, and muscle pain or weakness. skin or nail discoloration can occur. seek medical help for shortness of breath, chest pain, severe fatigue, or signs of infection such as fever or persistent sore throat.

name: abaloparatide injection
instructions: important warning: in animal studies abaloparatide caused an increase in bone cancer called osteosarcoma. because of this potential risk, do not use it if you have conditions that increase your baseline risk for osteosarcoma such as paget disease of bone, unexplained elevations of alkaline phosphatase, bone metastases or a history of skeletal radiation therapy, or in patients with open epiphyses. do not use abaloparatide or other parathyroid hormone analogs for more than a total of 2 years during your lifetime. why is this medication prescribed? abaloparatide is used to treat osteoporosis in postmenopausal women and in men who are at high risk for fracture, to increase bone density and reduce the risk of fractures. how should this medicine be used? it is given as a subcutaneous injection once daily, usually 80 micrograms, into the abdomen. use at the same time each day, rotate injection sites, and follow pen preparation instructions. your clinician will show you how to inject properly. store and handle the pen exactly as directed on the product label. after completing abaloparatide therapy, your clinician may start an antiresorptive medicine to maintain bone density. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have or had bone cancer, metabolic bone diseases other than osteoporosis, kidney stones, high calcium, severe kidney disease, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. abaloparatide may cause transient low blood pressure, dizziness, or fast heartbeat after injection, especially at the beginning. sit or lie down after your dose if you feel lightheaded. use caution if you take digoxin because high calcium can increase digoxin toxicity. limit lifetime use of abaloparatide and teriparatide combined to 2 years. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take calcium and vitamin d as directed to ensure adequate intake. avoid excessive calcium supplementation if you have a history of kidney stones and maintain good hydration. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, skip it and take your next dose at the usual time the following day. do not take two doses on the same day. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include dizziness, fast heartbeat, nausea, headache, fatigue, upper abdominal pain, and redness or pain at the injection site. it can raise urine calcium and rarely cause kidney stones. serious effects include persistent high calcium symptoms such as confusion or severe constipation, allergic reactions like rash, swelling, or trouble breathing, and very rarely a potential risk of osteosarcoma.

name: abatacept injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? abatacept is used to treat moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, and polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis by modulating the immune response to reduce joint inflammation and damage. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion at weeks 0, 2, and 4, then every 4 weeks, or as a subcutaneous injection once weekly after possible intravenous loading. a healthcare professional will administer infusions. if you self inject, your clinician will teach you proper technique, site rotation, and storage. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have current or recurrent infections, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, tuberculosis exposure, or hepatitis b. you will be screened for latent tuberculosis and hepatitis b before treatment. do not receive live vaccines during therapy and for a period after stopping. use caution with other immunosuppressants. inform your clinician about pregnancy or breastfeeding plans. seek medical care promptly for fever, cough, shortness of breath, painful urination, or other infection signs. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. if you also take methotrexate or other hepatotoxic drugs, limit alcohol as advised. what should i do if i forget a dose? for subcutaneous dosing, inject as soon as you remember if it is within a few days, then resume your regular schedule. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue as scheduled. do not double doses. for infusions, contact your clinic to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, nausea, runny or stuffy nose, sore throat, and injection site reactions. serious effects include serious infections such as pneumonia or sepsis, hypersensitivity or infusion reactions, and possible increased risk of certain cancers. call your clinician for signs of infection or allergic reaction.

name: idecabtagene vicleucel injection
instructions: important warning: this chimeric antigen receptor t cell therapy can cause life threatening cytokine release syndrome and neurologic toxicities. it can also cause hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis or macrophage activation syndrome and prolonged or recurrent low blood counts. it must be given at a certified center with tocilizumab and intensive care support immediately available. seek emergency care for fever, chills, confusion, severe headache, seizure, difficulty speaking, severe weakness, shortness of breath, chest pain, or low blood pressure. why is this medication prescribed? idecabtagene vicleucel is used to treat adults with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma who have received prior therapies and meet specific criteria. how should this medicine be used? it is given once as an intravenous infusion after a short course of lymphodepleting chemotherapy. you will be monitored closely in the hospital or clinic and must remain near the treating center for at least 4 weeks. do not drive or operate heavy machinery for at least 8 weeks after infusion due to the risk of neurologic events. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all infections, vaccination history, and if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. you will be screened for hepatitis and other infections. avoid live vaccines for at least 6 weeks before lymphodepletion and until your clinician says it is safe afterward. idecabtagene vicleucel can cause prolonged low blood counts, serious infections, low immunoglobulins, and secondary cancers, so you will need frequent blood tests and may receive antimicrobials or immunoglobulin replacement. some patients may have a false positive test for hiv due to the lentiviral vector. do not donate blood, organs, tissues, or cells. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific food restrictions. if your white blood cells are low, follow food safety guidance to reduce infection risk and stay well hydrated. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is administered by professionals. if you miss a scheduled visit or premedication, contact your treatment center immediately for instructions. what side effects can this medication cause? very common effects include fever, chills, low blood pressure, rapid heart rate, low oxygen levels, fatigue, headache, confusion, tremor, speech difficulty, or sleepiness. laboratory abnormalities include low white cells, red cells, and platelets, elevated liver enzymes, and electrolyte changes. serious risks include cytokine release syndrome, severe neurologic events including seizures and encephalopathy, hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis, severe infections, tumor lysis syndrome, and prolonged cytopenias.

name: amphotericin b lipid complex injection
instructions: important warning: different formulations of amphotericin b are not interchangeable and the dosing is not the same. verify the product name and dose carefully to avoid fatal overdoses. use only for treatment of invasive or potentially life threatening fungal infections. why is this medication prescribed? amphotericin b lipid complex treats severe invasive fungal infections such as aspergillosis, candidiasis, and other susceptible mycoses, especially in patients who cannot tolerate or did not respond to conventional amphotericin b. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion, usually once daily, prepared and diluted exactly as directed, typically in dextrose 5 percent solution, and infused over about 2 hours. it must not be interchanged dose for dose with other amphotericin products. premedication may reduce infusion reactions. kidney function, electrolytes, liver tests, and blood counts will be monitored regularly. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about kidney disease, electrolyte problems, liver disease, anemia, pregnancy, or prior reactions to amphotericin. avoid or minimize other nephrotoxic drugs such as certain nsaids, aminoglycosides, and contrast dye. infusion reactions such as fever, chills, chest or back pain, shortness of breath, and low blood pressure can occur and require monitoring. severe allergic reactions can occur. what special dietary instructions should i follow? maintain good hydration as advised. you may need potassium and magnesium supplementation if your levels fall. limit alcohol and avoid over the counter nephrotoxic medicines unless approved. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given by healthcare professionals. if a dose or appointment is missed, contact your clinician to reschedule as soon as possible. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, headache, infusion site reactions, and low potassium or magnesium. kidney function may worsen. anemia and abnormal liver tests can occur. serious reactions include severe infusion reactions, anaphylaxis, severe kidney injury, breathing problems, and low blood pressure.

name: abemaciclib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? abemaciclib is a cyclin dependent kinase 4 and 6 inhibitor used for hormone receptor positive, human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 negative breast cancer in metastatic or advanced disease and in some high risk early breast cancer settings, alone or with endocrine therapy. how should this medicine be used? take the tablets by mouth twice daily at about the same times each day with or without food. swallow tablets whole. if you vomit after a dose, do not retake the dose and take the next dose at the scheduled time. your dose may be adjusted based on side effects. start antidiarrheal medicine at the first sign of loose stools and increase fluids. your clinician will monitor blood counts and liver tests regularly. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about liver disease, clotting history, lung disease, infections, and all medicines and supplements. abemaciclib can cause diarrhea, neutropenia, liver injury, blood clots, and interstitial lung disease or pneumonitis. seek care for shortness of breath, chest pain, or severe diarrhea. avoid strong cyp3a inhibitors or inducers including certain antifungals, anticonvulsants, and st johns wort, or follow dose adjustments. use effective contraception during treatment and for a period after the last dose. do not breastfeed during treatment and for a period after the last dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and seville oranges as they can increase drug levels. maintain good hydration, especially if you have diarrhea. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, skip it and take your next dose at the usual time. do not take extra tablets to make up a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include diarrhea, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, decreased appetite, abdominal pain, infections, low white blood cells, anemia, low platelets, and elevated liver enzymes. serious effects include dehydration, blood clots, liver injury, and interstitial lung disease or pneumonitis.

name: aripiprazole
instructions: important warning: elderly patients with dementia related psychosis treated with antipsychotic drugs are at increased risk of death. aripiprazole is not approved for dementia related psychosis. antidepressants, including aripiprazole when used as an adjunct for depression, increase the risk of suicidal thoughts and behaviors in children, adolescents, and young adults. monitor closely for worsening depression or suicidality. why is this medication prescribed? aripiprazole is used to treat schizophrenia, bipolar i disorder, irritability associated with autistic disorder, tourette disorder, and as an adjunctive treatment for major depressive disorder. how should this medicine be used? take aripiprazole by mouth once daily with or without food, at the same time each day. follow your clinician’s dosing instructions. do not stop suddenly without medical advice. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about heart disease, stroke risk, diabetes or risk factors, seizures, low white blood cell counts, liver problems, pregnancy, and breastfeeding. aripiprazole can cause neuroleptic malignant syndrome, tardive dyskinesia, high blood sugar and diabetes, weight gain and lipid changes, orthostatic hypotension, low white cells, seizures, impulse control problems such as compulsive gambling, temperature regulation problems, and difficulty swallowing. avoid alcohol and use caution driving until you know how it affects you. interactions with cyp2d6 and cyp3a4 inhibitors or inducers may require dose changes. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific food restrictions, but limit alcohol. maintain healthy nutrition and exercise to reduce metabolic side effects. discuss grapefruit products with your clinician if you consume them regularly. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time for your next dose. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include akathisia or restlessness, anxiety, insomnia or sleepiness, headache, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, constipation, and blurred vision. serious effects include neuroleptic malignant syndrome, tardive dyskinesia, high blood sugar or ketoacidosis, stroke in elderly patients with dementia, seizures, low blood pressure or fainting, and allergic reactions.

name: aripiprazole injection
instructions: important warning: elderly patients with dementia related psychosis treated with antipsychotic drugs are at increased risk of death. aripiprazole is not approved for dementia related psychosis. antidepressants, including aripiprazole when used as an adjunct for depression, increase the risk of suicidal thoughts and behaviors in children, adolescents, and young adults. monitor closely for worsening mood or suicidality. why is this medication prescribed? intramuscular aripiprazole is used for acute agitation associated with schizophrenia or bipolar i disorder, and long acting formulations are used for maintenance treatment of schizophrenia and for maintenance monotherapy or adjunct in bipolar i disorder. how should this medicine be used? short acting aripiprazole is given as intramuscular injections by a healthcare professional. long acting injections are given into the gluteal or deltoid muscle at intervals such as monthly or every 6 to 8 weeks depending on the product, with a specific initiation plan and in some cases oral overlap. do not inject intravenously and do not self inject unless specifically trained for a particular product. attend all scheduled injection appointments. what special precautions should i follow? the same precautions as oral aripiprazole apply including risk of neuroleptic malignant syndrome, tardive dyskinesia, metabolic changes, orthostatic hypotension, leukopenia, seizures, and impulse control disorders. tell your clinician about all medicines including cyp2d6 and cyp3a4 inhibitors or inducers which may require dose adjustments. use caution with other central nervous system depressants. avoid alcohol. pregnancy in the third trimester can cause symptoms in the newborn. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific food restrictions. maintain healthy diet and limit alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your clinician as soon as possible to arrange a catch up injection. the timing of the next dose depends on how long it has been since your last injection and the product used. do not try to self inject to make up a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include injection site pain, akathisia, restlessness, sleepiness, dizziness, headache, nausea, constipation, and anxiety. serious effects include neuroleptic malignant syndrome, tardive dyskinesia, high blood sugar, stroke in elderly patients with dementia, orthostatic hypotension or fainting, seizures, and allergic reactions.

name: abiraterone
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? abiraterone is used with prednisone and androgen deprivation therapy to treat metastatic castration resistant prostate cancer and metastatic high risk castration sensitive prostate cancer. it lowers androgen production that fuels prostate cancer. how should this medicine be used?
