for erectile dysfunction it may be taken as needed or once daily. for as needed use, the common starting dose is ten milligrams taken at least thirty minutes before sexual activity and not more than once daily. for daily use, two and a half to five milligrams is taken at about the same time each day. for benign prostatic hyperplasia, five milligrams is taken once daily. swallow tablets with water and take with or without food. your doctor may adjust the dose based on response and other medicines. what special precautions should i follow? do not take tadalafil with any nitrates or with riociguat as this combination can cause a dangerous drop in blood pressure.about heart disease, recent heart attack or stroke, low blood pressure or uncontrolled high blood pressure, liver or kidney disease, eye problems such as retinitis pigmentosa or prior vision loss due to nonarteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy, hearing problems, stomach ulcers or bleeding risk, blood cell disorders, penile deformity, or conditions that predispose to prolonged erections. it can cause sudden vision or hearing loss and prolonged erection. limit alcohol because it can increase dizziness and blood pressure lowering. many medicines interact including strong cyp3a inhibitors such as ketoconazole or ritonavir and inducers such as rifampin. use with alpha blocker medicines requires careful dose timing and monitoring. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take it with or without food but avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you take tadalafil daily, take the missed dose when you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. do not take extra to make up for a missed dose. if you use it as needed there is no scheduled dose. what side effects can this medication cause? headache, flushing, nasal congestion, indigestion or heartburn, back pain, muscle aches, and dizziness are common. rare but serious effects include a severe drop in blood pressure, chest pain, allergic reaction, sudden hearing loss or vision loss, and an erection lasting more than four hours which requires emergency care.

name: ibuprofen
instructions: important warning: this medicine can increase the risk of serious heart and blood vessel problems including heart attack and stroke, and the risk may increase with longer use or at higher doses. it can also cause serious and sometimes fatal stomach or intestinal bleeding or ulcers without warning. do not use right before or after coronary artery bypass graft surgery. use the lowest effective dose for the shortest time needed. why is this medication prescribed? ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti inflammatory medicine used to relieve pain, reduce fever, and decrease inflammation from conditions such as arthritis, muscle aches, dental pain, and menstrual cramps. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as directed on the label or by your doctor. swallow with a full glass of water, and taking it with food or milk may reduce stomach upset. do not take more often or for longer than directed. do not use multiple products that contain ibuprofen or other nonsteroidal anti inflammatory medicines at the same time. what special precautions should i follow?about all allergies to aspirin or other nonsteroidal anti inflammatory medicines, any history of stomach or intestinal ulcers or bleeding, heart disease, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, diabetes, kidney or liver disease, asthma, fluid retention, or if you smoke. many medicines interact with ibuprofen including blood thinners, antiplatelets, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, serotonin norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, steroids, other pain relievers, ace inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, diuretics, lithium, and methotrexate. avoid use after twenty weeks of pregnancy unless your doctor tells you to, and do not use in the last trimester. ask about use while breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take with food or milk if your stomach is sensitive. limit or avoid alcohol because it raises the risk of stomach bleeding. stay well hydrated, especially if you have kidney disease risks. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you take it on a schedule, take the missed dose when you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include upset stomach, heartburn, nausea, dizziness, or drowsiness. serious effects that need urgent care include chest pain, shortness of breath, weakness on one side of the body, slurred speech, black or bloody stools, vomit that looks like coffee grounds, severe stomach pain, swelling of the legs, sudden weight gain, little or no urine, severe rash, swelling of the face or throat, or wheezing.

name: dextroamphetamine and amphetamine
instructions: important warning: this medicine has a high risk for abuse and dependence. misuse can cause sudden death and serious heart or blood vessel problems. keep it in a safe place and never share it. your doctor will monitor for misuse, blood pressure, heart rate, and mental health changes. why is this medication prescribed? it is used to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and may be used for narcolepsy depending on the product. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as prescribed, usually once each morning for extended release products or as directed for immediate release products. take at the same time each day. swallow extended release capsules whole and do not crush or chew. avoid taking late in the day to reduce trouble sleeping. do not stop suddenly if you have been taking it regularly without your doctor’s advice. what special precautions should i follow?about heart disease, high blood pressure, structural heart problems, a history of stroke, seizures, overactive thyroid, glaucoma, mental health conditions such as anxiety, bipolar disorder, or psychosis, tics or tourette syndrome, kidney problems, or a history of substance use disorder. do not use within fourteen days of a monoamine oxidase inhibitor. many medicines can interact, including other stimulants, decongestants, antacids or acidifying agents, and medicines that increase serotonin such as certain antidepressants, migraine medicines, linezolid, and st johns wort. call your doctor if you have chest pain, fainting, shortness of breath, hallucinations, new or worsening aggression, mania, or signs of serotonin syndrome such as agitation, sweating, fast heart rate, fever, muscle stiffness, or confusion. growth should be monitored in children. pregnancy and breastfeeding require careful discussion. what special dietary instructions should i follow? limit caffeine to reduce nervousness and trouble sleeping. acidic foods or juices may lower absorption and effect; take consistently with regard to such foods. avoid alcohol, especially with extended release products. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it when you remember the same day, but if it is late afternoon or evening, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the usual time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include decreased appetite, weight loss, dry mouth, insomnia, nervousness, headache, stomach pain, nausea, and fast heartbeat. serious effects include chest pain, fainting, shortness of breath, hallucinations, mania, seizures, new or worsening tics, prolonged or painful erections, circulation problems in fingers or toes such as color changes and pain, and symptoms of serotonin syndrome.

name: flibanserin
instructions: important warning: flibanserin can cause severely low blood pressure and fainting, especially when taken with alcohol, certain other medicines, or in people with liver problems. do not use with alcohol, with moderate or strong cyp3a4 inhibitors, or if you have liver impairment. take only at bedtime to reduce the risk of fainting. why is this medication prescribed? flibanserin is used to treat acquired generalized hypoactive sexual desire disorder in premenopausal women. it does not treat sexual pain or improve performance. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once daily at bedtime. if your symptoms do not improve after eight weeks, stop taking it and talk with your doctor. what special precautions should i follow?about all medicines you take, especially antifungals, certain antibiotics, antivirals, and other cyp3a4 inhibitors or inducers, and any medicines that cause drowsiness. do not take if you drink alcohol. do not take if you have liver disease. use caution when getting out of bed at night. avoid driving or activities that require full alertness until you know how it affects you the next day. discuss use in pregnancy and breastfeeding with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not drink alcohol while taking flibanserin. avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice because they can increase medicine levels. you may take it with or without food at bedtime. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and take your next dose at bedtime the following day. do not take it in the morning or take extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include dizziness, sleepiness, nausea, fatigue, dry mouth, and trouble sleeping. serious effects include very low blood pressure, fainting, and accidental injury from passing out.

name: riociguat
instructions: important warning: riociguat can harm an unborn baby. do not take if you are pregnant. a negative pregnancy test is required before starting, during treatment, and for one month after stopping, and effective birth control is required. do not use with nitrates or phosphodiesterase type five inhibitors because of the risk of dangerously low blood pressure. why is this medication prescribed? riociguat is used to treat adults with pulmonary arterial hypertension and chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension to improve exercise capacity and delay clinical worsening. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth as directed, usually three times daily about six to eight hours apart, with or without food. your doctor will start with a low dose and adjust based on response and blood pressure. if you smoke and you stop or start,because your dose may need to change. what special precautions should i follow?about low blood pressure, bleeding problems, kidney or liver disease, and if you cough up blood. do not take if you are pregnant and do not breastfeed while using this medicine. many medicines interact, including nitrates, phosphodiesterase type five inhibitors for erectile dysfunction or pulmonary hypertension, strong inhibitors or inducers of cyp3a and p glycoprotein, and antacids which should be taken at least one hour apart. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice. limit alcohol because it can increase dizziness and lower blood pressure. maintain adequate hydration. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it when you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose, in which case skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, dizziness, indigestion, nausea, diarrhea, low blood pressure, swelling of the legs, and anemia. serious effects include fainting, coughing up blood, severe bleeding, and signs of pregnancy.

name: methylphenidate
instructions: important warning: this medicine has a high risk for abuse and dependence. misuse can cause sudden death and serious heart or blood vessel problems. keep it in a safe place and never share it. your doctor will monitor blood pressure, heart rate, growth in children, and mental health changes. why is this medication prescribed? methylphenidate is used to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and some forms may be used for narcolepsy. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as prescribed. immediate release tablets are usually taken two to three times daily, and extended release forms are taken once daily in the morning. swallow extended release products whole. avoid taking late in the day to reduce trouble sleeping. do not stop suddenly if you have taken it regularly without talking to your doctor. what special precautions should i follow?if you have heart disease, high blood pressure, structural heart problems, a history of stroke, seizures, glaucoma, overactive thyroid, mental health conditions such as anxiety, bipolar disorder, or psychosis, or tics or tourette syndrome. do not use within fourteen days of a monoamine oxidase inhibitor. many medicines interact, including other stimulants, blood pressure medicines, some antidepressants, antipsychotics, and medicines that increase serotonin. call your doctor if you have chest pain, fainting, shortness of breath, hallucinations, mania, seizures, or symptoms of serotonin syndrome such as agitation, sweating, fever, fast heart rate, muscle stiffness, or confusion. pregnancy and breastfeeding require discussion. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take extended release products consistently with or without food as directed. limit caffeine to reduce nervousness and insomnia. do not drink alcohol with certain extended release products because it can change the release of the medicine. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it when you remember the same day, but if it is late afternoon or evening skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the usual time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include decreased appetite, weight loss, dry mouth, trouble sleeping, nervousness, headache, nausea, stomach pain, and fast heartbeat. serious effects include chest pain, fainting, shortness of breath, hallucinations, mania, seizures, painful or prolonged erections, circulation problems in fingers or toes, and symptoms of serotonin syndrome.

name: phentermine
instructions: important warning: phentermine is a stimulant with a risk of abuse and dependence and is approved only for short term use as part of a weight reduction plan. serious heart and lung side effects including pulmonary hypertension and heart valve problems have occurred, especially with combination use with other weight loss medicines. do not use with a monoamine oxidase inhibitor or if you have certain heart conditions, uncontrolled high blood pressure, overactive thyroid, glaucoma, or agitation. why is this medication prescribed? it is used as a short term adjunct to diet and exercise to help with weight loss in adults with obesity or overweight with risk factors. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as prescribed, usually once daily in the morning before breakfast or one to two hours after breakfast. avoid taking late in the day to prevent trouble sleeping. do not take for longer than directed. what special precautions should i follow?if you have heart disease, high blood pressure, diabetes, kidney disease, a history of drug misuse, or mental health conditions. do not use during pregnancy or while breastfeeding. many medicines can interact including other stimulants, some antidepressants, and blood pressure medicines. your diabetes medicines may need adjustment as you lose weight. stop and seek care if you develop chest pain, fainting, shortness of breath, swelling in the legs, severe headache, or vision changes. what special dietary instructions should i follow? use phentermine only as part of a reduced calorie meal plan and increased physical activity recommended by your clinician. limit alcohol and excess caffeine. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it when you remember if it is still morning. if it is afternoon or evening, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the usual time. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include dry mouth, insomnia, restlessness, constipation or diarrhea, increased heart rate, and increased blood pressure. serious effects include chest pain, shortness of breath, fainting, swelling in the legs, mood changes, and symptoms of pulmonary hypertension such as severe shortness of breath or reduced ability to exercise.

name: lixisenatide injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? lixisenatide is a glucagon like peptide one receptor agonist used with diet and exercise to improve blood sugar control in adults with type two diabetes and may be used with basal insulin. it is not for type one diabetes or diabetic ketoacidosis. how should this medicine be used? inject under the skin once daily within one hour before the first meal of the day, as instructed by your healthcare provider. rotate injection sites on the abdomen, thigh, or upper arm. do not mix with insulin in the same syringe and if used with insulin, inject separately. follow the pen priming and storage instructions and never share pens or needles. your dose may start low and increase after two weeks. what special precautions should i follow?if you have a history of pancreatitis, gallstones, high triglycerides, severe stomach disease including gastroparesis, kidney disease, or dehydration. lixisenatide can cause low blood sugar especially when used with insulin or sulfonylureas, so your other medicines may need dose changes. it can cause kidney problems especially if you have severe vomiting or diarrhea. serious allergic reactions including swelling of the face or throat can occur. because it delays stomach emptying, it can affect the absorption of oral medicines. ask how to time oral medicines that need careful blood levels.if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow a diabetes meal plan, eat regularly, and stay well hydrated. if you have nausea, smaller more frequent meals may help. ask how to time birth control pills and antibiotics in relation to your injection. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, take your next dose within one hour before your next meal and then resume your usual schedule. do not take two doses on the same day. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, decreased appetite, headache, and dizziness. low blood sugar can occur, especially with insulin or sulfonylureas, with symptoms such as shakiness, sweating, fast heartbeat, and confusion. serious effects include severe stomach pain that may spread to the back which can signal pancreatitis, kidney problems with reduced urination or swelling, and severe allergic reactions.

name: insulin lispro injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? insulin lispro is a rapid acting insulin used to improve blood sugar control in adults and children with type one or type two diabetes. how should this medicine be used? inject under the skin shortly before a meal or immediately after starting a meal, following your personalized dose plan. rotate injection sites on the abdomen, thigh, buttock, or upper arm. if using an insulin pump, follow your device instructions and do not mix with other insulins in the pump reservoir. use only the correct insulin and concentration your doctor prescribed. do not share pens, cartridges, or syringes. store unopened insulin as directed and keep in use pens or vials at the recommended room temperature time frame. check your blood sugar regularly and follow your sick day plan. what special precautions should i follow? the most common risk is low blood sugar. know the symptoms such as sweating, shakiness, fast heartbeat, hunger, headache, and confusion, and how to treat it. your insulin needs may change with illness, stress, changes in diet or activity, kidney or liver problems, pregnancy, or when taking other medicines. some medicines can increase or decrease insulin effect or mask low blood sugar symptoms, including beta blockers, steroids, thiazolidinediones which may cause fluid retention, and others. use caution to avoid medication mix ups. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow your meal plan and coordinate insulin timing with carbohydrate intake. carry a fast acting sugar source at all times. limit alcohol and always take food with alcohol to reduce the risk of low blood sugar. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you forgot your mealtime insulin, take it as soon as you remember based on what you are eating and check your blood sugar more often. if you are unsure what to do or if your blood sugar is very high, follow your sick day plan or contact your diabetes care team. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? low blood sugar is common. other effects include injection site redness or itching, lipodystrophy or skin thickening at injection sites, weight gain, and swelling. severe allergic reactions are rare but need urgent care with rash, trouble breathing, or swelling of the face or throat.

name: ado-trastuzumab emtansine injection
instructions: important warning: ado trastuzumab emtansine can cause serious and sometimes fatal liver injury, heart failure due to reduced left ventricular function, and harm to an unborn baby. liver function and heart function will be checked during treatment. confirm her2 positivity before starting. do not substitute with or for trastuzumab products. avoid pregnancy during treatment and for at least seven months after the last dose. why is this medication prescribed? it is used to treat certain her2 positive breast cancers, including metastatic disease and residual invasive disease after neoadjuvant therapy. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion by a healthcare professional, usually every three weeks. the dose is based on body weight. you will be monitored during and after infusion for reactions and for lab changes, heart function, and platelet counts. do not miss appointments and do not change the dose yourself. what special precautions should i follow?about any liver disease, heart problems, shortness of breath, bleeding problems, or nerve issues. this medicine can cause liver toxicity including rare nodular regenerative hyperplasia, heart failure, infusion reactions, interstitial lung disease, lung inflammation, thrombocytopenia and serious bleeding, and peripheral neuropathy. many medicines interact, including strong inhibitors or inducers of cyp3a which can change drug levels. do not receive live vaccines during treatment. have a pregnancy test before starting and use effective birth control during treatment and for seven months after the last dose. do not breastfeed during treatment and for seven months after the final dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific diet requirements, but avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice and limit alcohol to reduce liver risk. maintain good hydration and nutrition. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your oncology team as soon as possible to reschedule. do not attempt to make up a dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fatigue, nausea, constipation, muscle or joint pain, headache, nosebleeds, and elevated liver enzymes. serious effects include liver failure, heart failure with shortness of breath or swelling, lung inflammation with cough or breathing trouble, severe bleeding, infusion reactions with fever or chills, and peripheral neuropathy such as numbness or tingling.

name: pamidronate injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? pamidronate is a bisphosphonate used to treat high blood calcium caused by cancer, bone damage from multiple myeloma or bone metastases, and paget disease of bone. how should this medicine be used? it is given by slow intravenous infusion by a healthcare professional, often over several hours to reduce kidney risks. your schedule and dose depend on your condition and lab results. you may receive fluids before or during treatment. dental evaluation before therapy is recommended. what special precautions should i follow?about kidney disease, dehydration, low calcium or vitamin d, mineral or electrolyte problems, dental problems, plans for dental surgery or extractions, aspirin sensitive asthma, and pregnancy or breastfeeding. this medicine can cause kidney injury, low calcium, osteonecrosis of the jaw especially after dental procedures, severe bone joint or muscle pain, eye inflammation, and rare atypical thigh fractures with long term use. avoid other medicines that can harm the kidneys when possible andabout all medicines you take, including diuretics and nonsteroidal anti inflammatory medicines. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless you are being treated for high calcium, ensure adequate calcium and vitamin d intake as advised by your clinician. stay well hydrated. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your healthcare provider to reschedule as soon as possible. do not try to receive extra medicine to make up a missed appointment. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fever or flu like symptoms after infusion, fatigue, bone or muscle pain, nausea, vomiting, and low calcium. serious effects include signs of kidney problems such as little urine or swelling, jaw pain or swelling, severe bone or muscle pain, eye pain or vision changes, and allergic reactions with rash, itching, or trouble breathing.

name: epinephrine injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? epinephrine injection is used for the immediate treatment of severe allergic reactions called anaphylaxis caused by foods, medicines, insect stings, and other triggers. it rapidly opens the airways, raises blood pressure, and reduces swelling. how should this medicine be used? use the auto injector at the first sign of a severe allergic reaction such as trouble breathing, swelling of the tongue or throat, widespread hives, or feeling faint. inject into the middle of the outer thigh only, through clothing if needed. hold the device in place for several seconds as directed by your product instructions, then massage the area for a few seconds. if symptoms persist or return, a second dose may be given after five to fifteen minutes if available and if instructed by your clinician. call emergency services immediately after using epinephrine and lie down with legs raised if you feel faint. do not inject into the hands, feet, buttocks, or veins. learn and practice the injection technique, and check the viewing window and expiration date regularly. store at room temperature in the carrier tube and protect from light. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have heart disease, high blood pressure, an abnormal heart rhythm, hyperthyroidism, diabetes, or parkinson disease, and list all medicines you take including beta blockers, tricyclic antidepressants, and monoamine oxidase inhibitors because interactions may change how epinephrine works. use caution in pregnancy and while breastfeeding and carry the device with you at all times. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. drink fluids as tolerated during a reaction. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is used only when needed for an allergic emergency. keep a non expired device available and obtain a replacement before it expires. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fast or pounding heartbeat, palpitations, anxiety, tremor, sweating, headache, dizziness, nausea, and pallor. serious effects can include chest pain, difficulty breathing, fainting, seizures, and tissue damage if injected into fingers or toes. seek emergency medical care after every use and for any severe or persistent symptoms.

name: doxorubicin
instructions: important warning: doxorubicin can cause serious and sometimes fatal heart damage including heart failure and can damage the bone marrow leading to severe low blood counts and infections. the risk of heart injury increases with higher total lifetime dose or when combined with other medicines that affect the heart or after chest radiation. this medicine can cause severe local tissue injury if it leaks outside the vein and can increase the risk of a second blood cancer. doxorubicin must be given only under the supervision of a clinician experienced in cancer drugs with appropriate monitoring. why is this medication prescribed? doxorubicin is an anthracycline chemotherapy used to treat many cancers including breast cancer, ovarian cancer, bladder cancer, lymphomas, leukemias, and soft tissue sarcomas. how should this medicine be used? it is given by slow intravenous injection or infusion in repeating treatment cycles at a clinic or infusion center. a central venous catheter may be used to reduce the risk of vein irritation. follow your treatment schedule and have regular blood tests and heart monitoring as directed. your urine may appear reddish for one to two days after a dose. report any burning or pain at the infusion site right away. what special precautions should i follow? tell your oncology team about any heart disease, prior anthracycline exposure, prior chest radiation, liver problems, or infections. provide a complete list of all medicines and supplements, especially trastuzumab and other targeted therapies, cyclophosphamide, paclitaxel, and live vaccines. use effective contraception during treatment and for the recommended time after the last dose because doxorubicin can harm an unborn baby. do not receive live vaccines during treatment. doxorubicin may impair fertility in both males and females. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions, but maintain good hydration and nutrition. if you develop mouth sores or diarrhea, choose soft bland foods and avoid alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your oncology clinic as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to make up a missed infusion on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include low white blood cells, anemia, low platelets, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, mouth sores, diarrhea, hair loss, and temporary red discoloration of urine. serious effects include fever or signs of infection, unusual bleeding or bruising, severe mouth pain, chest pain, shortness of breath, swelling of the ankles, fast or irregular heartbeat, severe abdominal pain, and severe pain or blisters at the infusion site. seek urgent care for signs of infection or heart problems.

name: fluorouracil injection
instructions: important warning: fluorouracil can cause severe and sometimes life threatening adverse effects including bone marrow suppression, infection, mouth and gastrointestinal ulceration, diarrhea, and neurologic toxicity. people with dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase deficiency are at greatly increased risk of severe or fatal toxicity. fluorouracil must be administered under the supervision of a clinician experienced in cancer chemotherapy with appropriate monitoring. why is this medication prescribed? fluorouracil is a chemotherapy medicine used to treat cancers such as colorectal, breast, stomach, pancreatic, and head and neck cancers. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous injection or continuous infusion at a clinic or through a home infusion pump as part of a treatment cycle. laboratory tests will be done regularly to monitor blood counts and organ function. report chest pain immediately because fluorouracil can sometimes cause coronary artery spasm. what special precautions should i follow? before starting, tell your clinician about all medical conditions including any history of heart disease, infections, kidney or liver problems, or neurologic symptoms. ask about testing for dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase deficiency. provide a complete list of medicines, especially warfarin which may require closer monitoring of clotting, and seizure medicines such as phenytoin. avoid live vaccines during treatment. use effective contraception because fluorouracil can harm an unborn baby. what special dietary instructions should i follow? maintain good hydration. if you develop mouth sores or diarrhea, choose soft bland foods and avoid spicy or high fiber foods and alcohol until symptoms improve. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your oncology clinic promptly to adjust or reschedule your infusion. do not change your schedule without medical advice. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include low blood counts, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, mouth sores, loss of appetite, diarrhea, and skin changes including hand foot syndrome with redness, swelling, and tenderness of the palms and soles. other effects can include increased sensitivity to sunlight and nail changes. serious effects include fever or signs of infection, severe or persistent diarrhea, severe mouth pain preventing eating or drinking, chest pain, confusion, unsteady gait, and severe abdominal pain. seek urgent care for severe symptoms.

name: nadofaragene firadenovec-vncg intravesical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? nadofaragene firadenovec intravesical is a gene therapy used to treat adults with non muscle invasive bladder cancer that no longer responds to bacillus calmette guerin, including carcinoma in situ with or without papillary tumors. it delivers a gene that helps the bladder make interferon to fight cancer locally. how should this medicine be used? a trained clinician places the medicine into your bladder through a catheter once every three months. you will be asked to retain it in the bladder for a set period and then to void. your care team will give you written instructions for hygiene and handling of urine after each treatment to reduce the chance of exposing others, which may include disinfecting toilet contents and surfaces with household bleach for a period after the dose, frequent handwashing, and cleaning the genital area after urinating. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have a urinary tract infection, urinary retention, a weakened immune system, a latex sensitivity related to catheter supplies, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. follow all instructions to avoid exposing caregivers or household contacts to the medicine after dosing. report fever, chills, flank pain, severe urinary urgency, or difficulty urinating. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. stay well hydrated before and after treatment unless you were given different instructions. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given by your clinician. if you miss an appointment, contact the clinic to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include urinary urgency, frequency, burning with urination, bladder spasm, pelvic discomfort, fatigue, and mild fever or flu like symptoms. possible side effects include urinary tract infection, blood in the urine, and temporary difficulty urinating. seek medical care for high fever, severe bladder pain, or urinary retention.

name: aducanumab-avwa injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? aducanumab avwa is a monoclonal antibody used for the treatment of alzheimer disease to reduce amyloid plaques in the brain. how should this medicine be used? it is given as an intravenous infusion in a healthcare setting, typically once every four weeks with a gradual increase in dose to a maintenance dose, and requires magnetic resonance imaging scans before and during treatment to monitor for brain swelling or small bleeds. if imaging shows changes, dosing may be delayed or adjusted. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about any history of stroke, brain bleeding, seizures, or use of blood thinners, and if you carry the apolipoprotein e epsilon four genotype you may have a higher risk of certain brain side effects. report new or worsening headache, confusion, dizziness, visual changes, nausea, or difficulty walking which could be signs of amyloid related imaging abnormalities. inform your clinician about all medicines you take. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your infusion center to reschedule. your clinician will advise how to adjust the schedule. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, falls, diarrhea, and infusion related reactions such as flushing, fever, chills, and nausea. serious effects include amyloid related imaging abnormalities which may present with headache, confusion, dizziness, vision changes, nausea, or seizures, and rarely serious brain swelling or bleeding. seek urgent care if severe neurologic symptoms occur.

name: guaifenesin
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? guaifenesin is an expectorant used to loosen and thin mucus in the airways to help relieve chest congestion and make coughs more productive in colds and similar illnesses. it does not treat the cause of infection. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth exactly as directed on the label or by your clinician. use a dosing device for liquids. take each dose with a full glass of water and drink plenty of fluids during the day. if using an extended release tablet, swallow it whole without crushing or chewing. do not use more often than directed. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have a persistent cough lasting more than a few days, cough with a lot of mucus, fever, rash, or headache, or if you have kidney stones. check the active ingredients of cough and cold products to avoid taking duplicate medicines. ask before using in young children or during pregnancy or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? increase fluid intake unless your clinician has told you to restrict fluids. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you take it on a schedule, take the missed dose when you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? guaifenesin is usually well tolerated. possible effects include nausea, vomiting, stomach upset, dizziness, headache, rash, or drowsiness. very rarely kidney stones may occur with prolonged high dose use.

name: fluticasone and salmeterol oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? the combination of fluticasone and salmeterol is used on a regular schedule to control and prevent symptoms of asthma and to improve breathing in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. it is not a rescue medicine for sudden breathing problems. how should this medicine be used? inhale by mouth as directed usually one inhalation twice daily about twelve hours apart using the specific device you were prescribed. learn and follow the device instructions, prime when needed, and use a spacer if directed for the pressurized inhaler. rinse your mouth with water and spit after each dose to reduce the risk of oral thrush. keep a fast acting rescue inhaler with you for sudden symptoms. do not stop this medicine abruptly without talking to your clinician. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have heart disease, high blood pressure, seizures, thyroid problems, diabetes, glaucoma or cataracts, osteoporosis, immune system problems, infections, or a history of paradoxical bronchospasm. list all medicines you take including other inhalers and strong inhibitors of cyp3a4 such as ritonavir or ketoconazole, which can increase steroid side effects. watch for hoarseness, oral thrush, tremor, palpitations, and signs of worsening breathing. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time for your next dose. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not use extra doses to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include throat irritation, hoarseness, cough, headache, tremor, and fast heartbeat. oral thrush can occur. in people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease there is an increased risk of pneumonia. rarely systemic steroid effects can occur including vision changes, increased blood sugar, and adrenal suppression.

name: diphenhydramine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? diphenhydramine is an antihistamine used to relieve allergy symptoms such as sneezing, runny nose, itchy or watery eyes, and itching or hives. it is also used to prevent or treat motion sickness, to help with short term trouble sleeping, and to treat certain movement symptoms. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth exactly as directed on the label or by your clinician. for motion sickness take the first dose thirty minutes before exposure and then as directed. for sleep take the dose at bedtime. do not exceed the recommended dose and do not use to make a child sleepy. do not use the topical form together with oral forms. what special precautions should i follow? this medicine can cause drowsiness and impair thinking or movement. do not drive or perform tasks that require alertness until you know how it affects you and avoid alcohol and other sedatives. tell your clinician if you have glaucoma, enlarged prostate, urinary retention, asthma, chronic bronchitis, emphysema, heart disease, high blood pressure, or if you take monoamine oxidase inhibitors. older adults are at higher risk of confusion, constipation, and falls and safer alternatives may be preferred. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions, but avoid alcohol while taking this medicine. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you use it as needed take it when you need symptom relief. if you take it on a schedule and miss a dose, take it when you remember unless it is close to the next dose. do not take extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include drowsiness, dizziness, blurred vision, dry mouth, constipation, urinary retention, and thickened bronchial secretions. in some children it may cause excitement or irritability. serious effects can include confusion, hallucinations, fast or irregular heartbeat, and severe allergic reaction.

name: amphetamine
instructions: important warning: amphetamines have a high potential for abuse and dependence. misuse may cause sudden death and serious heart problems. serious cardiovascular adverse events including sudden death have occurred in children, adolescents, and adults with structural heart abnormalities or other serious heart problems. assess the risk of abuse, monitor for signs of misuse, and store securely. why is this medication prescribed? amphetamine medicines are used to treat attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and narcolepsy. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as prescribed. immediate release forms are usually taken one to three times daily and extended release forms are taken once each morning. swallow extended release capsules or tablets whole and do not crush or chew them. avoid taking doses late in the day to reduce insomnia. do not share this medicine with anyone. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have heart disease, high blood pressure, hyperthyroidism, glaucoma, anxiety or agitation, tics or tourette syndrome, seizures, or a history of drug or alcohol misuse. do not use within fourteen days of taking a monoamine oxidase inhibitor. provide a complete list of your medicines including antidepressants and other drugs that can increase serotonin because a dangerous condition called serotonin syndrome can occur. your clinician may check blood pressure, heart rate, and growth in children regularly. stop and seek care for chest pain, fainting, shortness of breath, new psychosis or mania, or unexplained wounds or color changes in fingers or toes. use caution during pregnancy and while breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid alcohol. acidic foods and drinks such as citrus juices can reduce absorption of amphetamines and may make them less effective, so take doses with water and be consistent with meals. limit caffeine to reduce jitteriness. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember if it is early in the day. if it is late in the day or close to the next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take extra doses to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include decreased appetite, weight loss, dry mouth, insomnia, irritability, anxiety, increased heart rate, increased blood pressure, stomach pain, nausea, and headache. other effects can include tics, mood swings, and sexual side effects. serious effects include chest pain, fainting, shortness of breath, seizures, hallucinations, new mania, and prolonged or painful erections. contact your clinician if troublesome or severe effects occur.

name: rifamycin
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? rifamycin is an antibiotic used to treat travelers diarrhea caused by certain strains of escherichia coli in adults without fever or blood in the stool. it is not effective for infections caused by other bacteria or for diarrhea with fever or blood. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth exactly as prescribed usually for a short course. swallow the tablets whole and do not crush or chew them. take doses at evenly spaced times and finish the full course even if you feel better. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have a fever, blood in the stool, diarrhea lasting more than two days, liver disease, or a history of allergy to rifamycins. provide a list of all medicines and supplements. although systemic absorption is low with this product, discuss potential interactions before starting a new medicine. do not use in pregnancy or while breastfeeding unless your clinician decides the benefits outweigh risks. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take it with or without food. drink plenty of fluids to prevent dehydration from diarrhea and avoid alcohol until you have recovered. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, constipation, abdominal pain, nausea, and increased gas. other effects can include rash or hypersensitivity. severe or persistent diarrhea may indicate clostridioides difficile infection which needs medical attention.

name: flunisolide oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? flunisolide is an inhaled corticosteroid used for long term control and prevention of asthma symptoms. it helps reduce airway inflammation and is not a rescue medicine for sudden breathing problems. how should this medicine be used? use exactly as prescribed, usually twice daily. prime the inhaler before first use and if it has not been used for several days. exhale fully, place the mouthpiece in your mouth, press the inhaler, and inhale slowly and deeply, then hold your breath for about ten seconds. if more than one inhalation is prescribed, wait about one minute between inhalations. rinse your mouth and spit after each use to reduce the risk of oral thrush. do not use to treat acute wheezing. do not stop this medicine abruptly without medical advice. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have current or past infections including tuberculosis, herpes infection of the eye, glaucoma, cataracts, osteoporosis, liver disease, or if you are taking oral or injected steroids or medicines that affect the immune system. this medicine may lower your ability to fight infections and can increase the risk of oral thrush. avoid exposure to chickenpox or measles. it may slow growth in children. seek medical help if you have worsening breathing immediately after use. tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements you use. if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding, discuss the risks and benefits. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. maintain good oral hygiene and rinse your mouth after each use. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not use extra inhalations to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include hoarseness, sore throat, cough, dry mouth, and oral thrush. less common but serious effects include worsening breathing right after use, signs of infection, vision changes from glaucoma or cataracts, adrenal suppression with fatigue or dizziness, and allergic reactions with rash or swelling. contact your clinician if symptoms are severe or do not go away.

name: afamitresgene autoleucel injection
instructions: important warning: afamitresgene autoleucel can cause life threatening cytokine release syndrome and serious neurologic toxicities. you will be closely monitored in a facility experienced in cellular therapy and medicines to treat these reactions must be available. seek immediate care for fever, chills, rapid heartbeat, dizziness, shortness of breath, confusion, severe headache, tremor, slurred speech, seizures, or difficulty staying awake. do not drive or operate machinery for several weeks after infusion until your team says it is safe. why is this medication prescribed? afamitresgene autoleucel is an autologous t cell therapy engineered to target the mage a4 protein for treatment of certain cancers such as synovial sarcoma in patients with specific hla types. it is used when the cancer expresses the target and other criteria are met. how should this medicine be used? your blood cells are collected and modified, then you receive lymphodepleting chemotherapy followed by a single intravenous infusion of the modified t cells. premedications are given to lower the risk of reactions. you will be monitored in the hospital or clinic for at least several days and must remain near the treating center for at least four weeks. this therapy is not self administered. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medical conditions including infections, lung disease, heart or kidney problems, seizure history, and if you have had a stem cell transplant. do not receive live vaccines for at least six weeks before chemotherapy, during treatment, and until your team says it is safe afterward. avoid pregnancy and use effective contraception during treatment and for at least four months after infusion because this therapy can harm an unborn baby. do not breastfeed during this period. you should not donate blood, organs, tissues, or cells after receiving this therapy. carry the patient wallet card and show it to all healthcare providers. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. if your white blood cell count is low, your team may recommend food safety precautions such as avoiding raw or undercooked foods. stay well hydrated. what should i do if i forget a dose? this therapy is given as a scheduled infusion. if an appointment is missed or delayed, contact your treatment center immediately for instructions. what side effects can this medication cause? very common effects include fever, chills, low blood pressure, rapid heartbeat, low oxygen, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, decreased appetite, and headache. serious risks include cytokine release syndrome, neurologic toxicities including confusion and seizures, hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis, prolonged low blood counts with anemia, bleeding or infection, febrile neutropenia, electrolyte abnormalities, liver test elevations, and allergic infusion reactions. your team will monitor and treat side effects promptly.

name: afatinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? afatinib is a kinase inhibitor used to treat certain types of non small cell lung cancer, including tumors with specific egfr mutations and some squamous cell lung cancers after platinum therapy. how should this medicine be used? take afatinib by mouth once daily on an empty stomach at least one hour before or two hours after food. swallow tablets whole with water. take it at the same time each day. your clinician may adjust the dose based on side effects or kidney or liver function. what special precautions should i follow? severe diarrhea can occur and may lead to dehydration. start antidiarrheal treatment at the first sign of loose stools and contact your clinician promptly. afatinib can cause lung problems such as interstitial lung disease, liver toxicity, severe skin reactions, mouth sores, paronychia, eye irritation including keratitis, and heart problems including decreased left ventricular function. limit sun exposure and use sunscreen and protective clothing. tell your clinician if you have breathing problems, eye pain or vision changes, severe skin blistering, yellowing of the skin, chest pain, swelling, or rapid weight gain. use effective birth control during treatment and for at least two weeks after the last dose. do not breastfeed during treatment and for at least two weeks after the last dose. tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements. strong p glycoprotein inhibitors or inducers can change afatinib levels. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and seville oranges as they may affect drug levels. drink plenty of fluids to reduce the risk of dehydration from diarrhea. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you remember within twelve hours of the usual time, take the dose as soon as you remember. if more than twelve hours have passed, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include diarrhea, rash or acne like skin eruption, dry skin, itching, mouth sores, decreased appetite, nausea, vomiting, nosebleeds, and fatigue. serious effects include severe diarrhea with dehydration, lung inflammation with new or worsening cough or shortness of breath, liver injury, severe skin reactions, eye problems with pain and redness, and heart problems. seek medical help for severe or persistent symptoms.

name: everolimus
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? everolimus is used to treat certain cancers including kidney cancer, breast cancer that is hormone receptor positive and human epidermal growth factor receptor two negative, pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors, and tumors associated with tuberous sclerosis complex. it is also used with other medicines to help prevent organ rejection after transplantation in specific settings. how should this medicine be used? take everolimus by mouth once daily at the same time each day, with or without food, but be consistent with your choice. swallow tablets whole with a glass of water. do not crush or chew. some formulations may be prepared as a suspension as directed by your clinician. your dose may be adjusted for side effects, liver function, or drug interactions. in transplant and tuberous sclerosis complex settings, blood levels may be monitored to guide dosing. what special precautions should i follow? everolimus can increase the risk of serious infections and may cause noninfectious pneumonitis with cough or shortness of breath, mouth ulcers, delayed wound healing, kidney problems, high blood sugar and cholesterol, and angioedema especially with angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors. avoid live vaccines during treatment. tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements, especially those that affect cyp3a4 or p glycoprotein such as certain antifungals, antibiotics, antivirals, and seizure medicines. use effective contraception during treatment and for at least eight weeks after the last dose. do not breastfeed during treatment and for at least two weeks after the last dose. tell your clinician if you are scheduled for surgery or dental work. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit, grapefruit juice, and seville oranges as they can increase everolimus levels. limit alcohol. maintain good oral hygiene to reduce mouth sores. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you remember within six hours of the usual time, take the dose as soon as you remember. if more than six hours have passed, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include mouth sores, rash, itching, diarrhea, nausea, decreased appetite, fatigue, swelling, cough, shortness of breath, infections, anemia, and changes in blood sugar and lipids. serious effects include lung inflammation, kidney failure, severe infections, delayed wound healing, bleeding, and liver problems. contact your clinician if you have fever, persistent cough, painful mouth ulcers, decreased urine, or any severe or unusual symptom.

name: ethinyl estradiol and levonorgestrel oral contraceptive
instructions: important warning: do not use combined oral contraceptives if you smoke cigarettes and are over thirty five years old. smoking greatly increases the risk of serious heart and blood vessel side effects such as blood clots, stroke, and heart attack. why is this medication prescribed? this medicine is used to prevent pregnancy. some formulations are also used to treat acne, regulate menstrual cycles, reduce menstrual cramps, and treat heavy bleeding. how should this medicine be used? take one tablet by mouth every day at the same time. start as directed by your clinician or the package, often on the first day of your period or on the first sunday after your period begins. use a backup method of birth control such as condoms for the first seven days unless instructed otherwise. take the pills in order, including any inactive pills if present. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you have a history of blood clots, stroke, heart attack, certain types of migraine especially with aura, uncontrolled high blood pressure, diabetes with vascular disease, certain liver diseases or tumors, breast cancer, or if you are within three to six weeks after childbirth depending on risk factors. tell your clinician if you have gallbladder disease, high triglycerides, depression, seizures, or if you need surgery or will be immobilized. some medicines and supplements can make birth control pills less effective, such as certain seizure medicines, some antibiotics and antifungals, and st johns wort. use condoms when medicines that interact are taken and for seven days after. this medicine does not protect against sexually transmitted infections. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. avoid tobacco use. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss one active pill, take it as soon as you remember and take the next pill at the usual time even if that means two pills in one day. if you miss two or more active pills, take the most recent missed pill as soon as you remember and discard the other missed pills, then continue one pill daily at the usual time and use backup contraception for seven days. if the missed pills were in the last week of active pills, finish the active pills and start a new pack the next day without taking inactive pills. consider emergency contraception if you missed pills in the first week and had unprotected sex in the previous five days. check your product instructions and contact your clinician for advice specific to your pack. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, breast tenderness, spotting or breakthrough bleeding, headache, mood changes, and bloating. blood pressure may increase. serious risks include blood clots in the legs or lungs, stroke, heart attack, gallbladder disease, liver problems, and vision changes. seek urgent care for chest pain, shortness of breath, severe headache, vision loss, leg swelling or pain, or sudden numbness or weakness.

name: aflibercept injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? intravitreal aflibercept is used to treat eye conditions caused by abnormal blood vessels and swelling, including neovascular age related macular degeneration, diabetic macular edema, diabetic retinopathy, and macular edema following retinal vein occlusion. how should this medicine be used? a trained eye care professional injects aflibercept into the vitreous of the eye at intervals determined by your condition, often more frequently at the beginning and then less often. you may receive anesthetic and antiseptic eye drops before the injection. this medicine is not self administered. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have an eye infection, eye pain, glaucoma, a history of stroke or heart attack, or if you are pregnant or planning pregnancy. temporary vision changes can occur after injection, so do not drive or operate machinery until your vision is clear. report signs of eye infection or inflammation immediately, such as worsening eye pain, redness, light sensitivity, or sudden vision changes. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment, contact your ophthalmologist as soon as possible to reschedule to avoid worsening of your eye condition. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include eye pain or discomfort, small floaters, conjunctival bleeding, increased tear production, blurred vision, and mild increase in eye pressure. serious risks include endophthalmitis, retinal detachment or tear, significant increase in intraocular pressure, intraocular inflammation, and rare arterial thromboembolic events such as stroke. seek urgent care for severe eye pain, marked redness, marked light sensitivity, or sudden loss of vision.

name: influenza vaccine, inactivated or recombinant
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? inactivated and recombinant influenza vaccines help prevent influenza and its complications. annual vaccination is recommended for most people six months of age and older. how should this medicine be used? the vaccine is given as an intramuscular injection by a healthcare professional, once each flu season. children six months through eight years of age who are receiving influenza vaccine for the first time or who have received only one prior dose may need two doses at least four weeks apart. what special precautions should i follow? do not receive this vaccine if you had a severe allergic reaction to a previous influenza vaccine or to a component of the vaccine. people with a history of guillain barre syndrome within six weeks after a flu vaccine should discuss risks and benefits with their clinician. vaccination can be deferred for people with moderate or severe acute illness until recovery, but mild illness is not a reason to delay. it is safe and recommended during pregnancy. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss your annual vaccination, get vaccinated as soon as possible during the flu season. if your child needs two doses and you miss the second dose, schedule it as soon as possible, maintaining at least four weeks between doses. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include soreness, redness, or swelling at the injection site, low fever, chills, fatigue, headache, and muscle aches that usually resolve within a few days. rarely, allergic reactions can occur. fainting may occur after any injection. guillain barre syndrome is very rare. seek medical attention for signs of a severe allergic reaction such as difficulty breathing, hives, or swelling of the face and throat.

name: insulin human inhalation
instructions: important warning: inhaled insulin can cause sudden bronchospasm in patients with chronic lung disease such as asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. it is contraindicated in these conditions. spirometry to measure lung function is required before starting, at six months, and yearly, and more often if respiratory symptoms occur. seek immediate care for wheezing, shortness of breath, or persistent cough. why is this medication prescribed? inhaled human insulin is a rapid acting mealtime insulin used to improve blood sugar control in adults with diabetes. it is used with a long acting basal insulin in type one diabetes. it is not for diabetic ketoacidosis. how should this medicine be used? use the inhaler to take insulin at the start of a meal. cartridges come in fixed unit doses that may be combined in the device as instructed. your clinician will convert your previous rapid acting insulin dose. keep cartridges refrigerated and allow them to reach room temperature before use as directed. do not share the inhaler. check blood glucose regularly and follow your diabetes care plan. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you have chronic lung disease, if you smoke, or if you have recently stopped smoking. tell your clinician about any lung disease, history of lung cancer, kidney or liver problems, and all medicines you take. hypoglycemia is the most common serious side effect and can be severe. learn to recognize and treat low blood sugar. cough and throat irritation are common. inhaled insulin can reduce lung function. it may increase the risk of diabetic ketoacidosis compared with injected rapid acting insulin. use effective contraception if you are of childbearing potential and discuss use during pregnancy and breastfeeding with your clinician. what special dietary instructions should i follow? coordinate insulin dosing with carbohydrate intake and meal timing to reduce the risk of hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia. limit alcohol and monitor blood glucose closely if you drink alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you forget to take insulin with a meal, check your blood glucose and take the missed mealtime dose as soon as you remember if you are still eating or will eat promptly, according to your care plan. do not take extra insulin if you are not going to eat. follow your clinician’s instructions for correcting high blood glucose. what side effects can this medication cause? hypoglycemia is common and can cause shakiness, sweating, confusion, headache, blurred vision, and loss of consciousness. other effects include cough, throat pain or irritation, wheezing, shortness of breath, and decreased lung function. serious effects include bronchospasm, diabetic ketoacidosis, severe allergic reactions, and possible increased risk of lung cancer. contact your clinician if you have persistent cough, breathing problems, or severe or recurrent hypoglycemia.

name: oxymetazoline nasal spray
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? oxymetazoline nasal spray provides short term relief of nasal congestion due to colds or allergies by narrowing blood vessels in the nasal passages. how should this medicine be used? use as directed on the label or by your clinician, commonly two or three sprays into each nostril every ten to twelve hours, no more than two doses in twenty four hours. blow your nose gently before use. keep your head upright, insert the tip into the nostril, spray while breathing in gently, and repeat for the other nostril. do not use for more than three days in a row to avoid rebound congestion. do not share the bottle. what special precautions should i follow? talk to your clinician before use if you have heart disease, high blood pressure, thyroid disease, diabetes, or prostate enlargement, or if you are taking monoamine oxidase inhibitors or other medicines for colds or allergies. use with caution in children and follow age specific directions. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, consult your clinician before use. stop and seek medical advice if you have severe or persistent nasal irritation, dizziness, or worsening congestion after stopping. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. if you experience palpitations, limiting caffeine may help. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is used as needed. if you are using it on a schedule and miss a dose, use it when you remember but do not exceed the maximum frequency. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include temporary burning, stinging, sneezing, and nasal dryness. overuse can cause rebound congestion that is worse than before. less common effects include headache, nervousness, trouble sleeping, increased blood pressure, and fast heartbeat. rarely, severe allergic reactions can occur.

name: tolnaftate
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? tolnaftate is a topical antifungal used to treat and prevent athletes foot, jock itch, and ringworm of the body. how should this medicine be used? for creams, gels, sprays, powders, or solutions, clean and dry the affected skin, then apply a thin layer to the area and about one inch around it once or twice daily as directed. use for the full course, typically two weeks for jock itch and ringworm of the body and four weeks for athletes foot. continue for one to two weeks after symptoms clear to reduce recurrence. keep feet dry, change socks daily, and wear breathable footwear. what special precautions should i follow? for external use only. avoid contact with eyes, mouth, inside the nose, vagina, and broken skin. do not use to treat nail or scalp infections. stop use and contact your clinician if irritation develops, the infection worsens, or there is no improvement after two weeks for jock itch or body ringworm or after four weeks for athletes foot. keep out of reach of children. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, ask your clinician before use. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply it as soon as you remember, then continue your regular schedule. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? mild skin irritation, redness, stinging, or itching may occur. allergic contact dermatitis is uncommon. stop use and seek medical advice if you have severe irritation, swelling, or signs of an allergic reaction.

name: diphenhydramine topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? this medicine is used to relieve itching and minor skin irritation from insect bites, poison ivy or oak, sunburn, and minor rashes. how should this medicine be used? apply a thin layer to the affected skin up to 3 or 4 times daily as directed. use only on intact skin. avoid contact with eyes, mouth, and genitals. do not cover with tight bandages and do not use on large areas unless your doctor tells you to. do not use for more than 7 days unless directed by your doctor. do not use with other products that contain diphenhydramine. what special precautions should i follow?if you are allergic to diphenhydramine or any ingredients in the product, or if you have a history of skin allergies or eczema. do not use on chickenpox or measles rashes. ask a doctor before using on a child under 2 years of age. stop use and seek medical care if itching worsens, if rash spreads, if you have signs of infection, or if you develop swelling or difficulty breathing. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply when you remember if you still need it. if it is almost time for the next application, skip the missed application. do not apply extra to catch up. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include mild burning, stinging, redness, or dryness at the application site. stop use and seek medical care for severe irritation, hives, swelling, or symptoms of drowsiness or confusion which may occur if too much is absorbed.

name: agalsidase beta injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? this medicine is used as enzyme replacement therapy to treat fabry disease by replacing the missing alpha galactosidase a enzyme.how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion by a health care professional, usually every two weeks. infusions are started at a slow rate and may be increased as tolerated. your doctor may give medicines before the infusion to reduce fever, chills, or allergic reactions. keep all infusion appointments.what special precautions should i follow? serious infusion reactions including anaphylaxis can occur.about any past allergic reactions to this medicine or other enzymes. report symptoms during or after infusion right away including fever, chills, flushing, itching, hives, rash, headache, nausea, vomiting, chest pain, shortness of breath, wheezing, dizziness, lightheadedness, or fainting.if you have heart disease, stroke, kidney disease, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. your doctor may check for antibodies to the medicine and monitor kidney and heart function.what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are required unless your care team advises a specific diet for fabry disease or kidney health.what should i do if i forget a dose? call your clinic to reschedule as soon as possible. do not attempt to self administer unless you have been trained and instructed to do so.what side effects can this medication cause? infusion reactions are common and can include fever, chills, flushing, headache, nausea, vomiting, fatigue, itching, hives, rash, and shortness of breath. other effects include cough, nasal symptoms, dizziness, abdominal pain, and back pain. serious reactions can include anaphylaxis, chest pain, low blood pressure or high blood pressure, and breathing problems. seek urgent care for severe symptoms.

name: vamorolone
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? this medicine is a corticosteroid approved to treat duchenne muscular dystrophy by reducing inflammation and helping preserve muscle strength. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth exactly as directed, usually once daily. use the provided oral dosing device to measure each dose. take with food to reduce stomach upset. if you have been taking this medicine for more than a few weeks, do not stop suddenly. your doctor will lower the dose gradually to prevent withdrawal and adrenal problems. what special precautions should i follow?about all infections or recent exposure to chickenpox or measles. this medicine can weaken your immune system and increase the risk of infections. avoid live vaccines while taking this medicine.if you have diabetes, high blood pressure, glaucoma, cataracts, osteoporosis, mood disorders, stomach ulcers, or liver disease. long term use can cause high blood sugar, fluid retention, weight gain, mood changes, high blood pressure, eye problems, bone thinning, slow growth in children, and adrenal suppression. report vision changes, severe stomach pain, black stools, swelling, shortness of breath, severe mood changes, or signs of infection. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take with food. your doctor may recommend limiting salt and ensuring adequate calcium and vitamin d intake to protect bone health. follow any nutrition plan provided by your care team. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at the same time. if you vomit soon after a dose, ask your doctor if you should take another dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include upset stomach, increased appetite, weight gain, mood changes, headache, and trouble sleeping. serious effects can include increased risk of infections, high blood pressure, high blood sugar, thinning bones, glaucoma, cataracts, stomach bleeding, adrenal suppression, and slowed growth in children. call your doctor for concerning symptoms.

name: aspirin and extended-release dipyridamole
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? this medicine helps reduce the risk of stroke in people who have had a stroke or transient ischemic attack caused by blood clots. how should this medicine be used? take one capsule by mouth twice daily, morning and evening, exactly as directed. swallow the capsule whole. do not chew, crush, or open it. if you have bothersome headache when you start, talk with your doctor. do not take other products that contain aspirin, non steroidal anti inflammatory drugs, or blood thinners unless your doctor tells you to. what special precautions should i follow? this medicine increases the risk of bleeding.if you have a history of stomach ulcers, bleeding problems, nosebleeds, kidney or liver disease, asthma, rhinitis with nasal polyps, or aspirin sensitivity. tell all health care providers and dentists that you take this medicine before any procedure. watch for signs of bleeding such as unusual bruising, prolonged bleeding, black stools, or vomiting blood. avoid giving any aspirin containing product to children or teenagers with viral illnesses because of the risk of reye syndrome. if you are pregnant, planning to become pregnant, or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take with a full glass of water and with food if your stomach is upset. limit alcohol because it can increase stomach irritation and bleeding risk. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it when you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, stomach upset, nausea, diarrhea, dizziness, and flushing. serious effects include bleeding, stomach or intestinal ulcer, low blood pressure, fast heartbeat, shortness of breath, severe allergic reactions including swelling or wheezing, and worsening of asthma. seek urgent care for signs of serious bleeding or allergic reaction.

name: anagrelide
