instructions: why is this medication prescribed? this medicine reduces high platelet counts in people with essential thrombocythemia and helps lower the risk of blood clots. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth exactly as directed, usually in divided doses each day. your doctor will start at a low dose and adjust based on your platelet count and tolerance. taking it with food can reduce stomach upset. do not change your dose without talking to your doctor. what special precautions should i follow? this medicine can affect the heart and can cause fast heartbeat, palpitations, fluid retention, and heart failure, especially in people with heart disease.if you have heart problems, a history of fainting, arrhythmias, long qt, low potassium or magnesium, kidney or liver disease, or if you take medicines that affect heart rhythm or increase bleeding risk such as aspirin, anticoagulants, or other antiplatelet drugs. report chest pain, shortness of breath, swelling, fainting, or fast or irregular heartbeat. this medicine can increase bleeding risk.about all medicines and supplements you use. avoid pregnancy. discuss contraception and breastfeeding with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take it with food if you have stomach upset. limit alcohol. there are no specific diet restrictions unless your doctor advises otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it when you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your schedule. do not take extra doses. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, dizziness, diarrhea, nausea, abdominal pain, weakness, and palpitations. serious effects include fast or irregular heartbeat, heart failure, fainting, bleeding, shortness of breath, fluid retention, and liver problems. contact your doctor for concerning symptoms.

name: erenumab-aooe injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? this medicine helps prevent migraine headaches in adults. how should this medicine be used? it is injected under the skin once every month. use it exactly as directed. let the device warm to room temperature before use. inject into the thigh, abdomen, or back of the upper arm. rotate injection sites and do not inject into areas that are tender, bruised, red, or scarred. if you use an autoinjector or prefilled syringe, follow the instructions for use provided with your device. what special precautions should i follow?about constipation, bowel problems, high blood pressure, or latex sensitivity because the needle shield may contain natural rubber latex. this medicine can cause severe constipation sometimes requiring medical treatment, new or worsening high blood pressure, and allergic reactions including rash, swelling, and trouble breathing. seek medical care if you have severe or persistent constipation, chest pain, shortness of breath, severe headache, or allergic reaction symptoms.if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? inject the missed dose as soon as you remember, then take the next dose one month after the date you inject the missed dose. if you are unsure, ask your doctor or pharmacist for guidance. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include injection site pain, redness, or itching, constipation, and muscle cramps or spasms. serious effects can include severe constipation with complications, high blood pressure, and allergic reactions including swelling of the face or mouth and trouble breathing.

name: budesonide and albuterol oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? this medicine is used as a reliever inhaler for asthma symptoms. it combines a fast acting bronchodilator to open the airways and an inhaled corticosteroid to reduce inflammation. how should this medicine be used? use two inhalations by mouth as needed for asthma symptoms as directed by your doctor. do not use more than 6 doses in 24 hours which equals 12 inhalations. prime the inhaler before first use and if it has not been used for more than 7 days. shake well before each use. exhale fully, place the mouthpiece in your mouth, press and inhale deeply, then hold your breath for up to 10 seconds. wait about 30 seconds before the second inhalation. rinse your mouth with water and spit after use to reduce the risk of oral thrush. keep the inhaler clean and dry. this medicine is not for regular daily prevention unless your doctor tells you to. seek medical care if you need it more often than usual. what special precautions should i follow?about heart disease, high blood pressure, seizures, thyroid problems, diabetes, osteoporosis, glaucoma, cataracts, or infections. this medicine can cause paradoxical bronchospasm, high blood pressure, fast heartbeat, tremor, nervousness, and low potassium. the steroid component can cause oral thrush, hoarseness, adrenal suppression, bone loss, and increased risk of infection. do not use if you are allergic to milk proteins if the product contains them. do not use as the only controller medicine for asthma unless directed. seek help right away if breathing suddenly worsens after using the inhaler. what special dietary instructions should i follow? rinse your mouth after use as described. maintain adequate calcium and vitamin d intake if you use inhaled steroids regularly. no specific diet changes are required unless advised by your doctor. what should i do if i forget a dose? this inhaler is used as needed for symptoms. if you are prescribed scheduled use and you miss a dose, use it when you remember unless it is close to the next scheduled use. do not use extra doses at one time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include throat irritation, cough, hoarseness, headache, tremor, nervousness, and fast heartbeat. oral thrush can occur. serious effects include paradoxical bronchospasm, irregular heartbeat, chest pain, severe allergic reactions, vision changes, and signs of infection.

name: fremanezumab-vfrm injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? this medicine helps prevent migraine headaches in adults. how should this medicine be used? it is injected under the skin either once a month or once every 3 months as directed. use the thigh, abdomen, or back of the upper arm and rotate injection sites. allow the medicine to reach room temperature before injection. follow the instructions for use for your device. what special precautions should i follow?about any history of allergic reactions to monoclonal antibodies. this product may contain natural rubber latex in the needle cap. allergic reactions can occur and may be delayed. seek care if you develop rash, hives, swelling of the face or mouth, trouble breathing, or severe injection site reactions.if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? inject the missed dose as soon as possible and then resume your regular monthly or quarterly schedule from the date you give the missed dose. if you are unsure how to adjust your schedule, ask your health care provider. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include injection site pain, redness, or swelling. other effects can include rash, itching, and fatigue. serious allergic reactions are uncommon but can occur.

name: prednisolone ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? this steroid eye medicine is used to treat eye inflammation due to surgery, injury, or certain inflammatory conditions. how should this medicine be used? use exactly as directed. for suspensions, shake well before each use. wash hands, tilt your head back, pull down the lower eyelid to make a small pocket, place the prescribed number of drops into the pocket, then close your eye and press a finger to the inner corner for one to two minutes. avoid touching the dropper tip to any surface. if using other eye medicines, wait at least 5 to 10 minutes between products. do not wear contact lenses while your eyes are inflamed. do not stop suddenly without your doctor’s advice. what special precautions should i follow?if you have glaucoma, cataracts, herpes simplex infection of the eye, or any eye infection. this medicine can increase eye pressure, worsen or cause glaucoma, delay wound healing, and increase the risk of infections. long term use can cause cataracts. report eye pain, vision changes, persistent redness, or signs of infection. use in children for the shortest time needed. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not use two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include temporary blurred vision, mild burning or stinging, and eye irritation. serious effects include increased eye pressure, glaucoma, cataracts, delayed healing, and secondary eye infections. call your doctor for severe or persistent symptoms.

name: sulfacetamide ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? this antibiotic eye medicine treats bacterial eye infections such as conjunctivitis and blepharitis. how should this medicine be used? use exactly as directed for the full course even if symptoms improve. wash hands, tilt your head back, pull down the lower eyelid to form a pocket, place the prescribed number of drops, then close your eye and press a finger to the inner corner for one to two minutes. avoid touching the dropper tip to any surface. if you use other eye medicines, separate them by at least 5 to 10 minutes. do not wear contact lenses during active infection. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you have had an allergic reaction to sulfonamide medicines. stop and seek medical help if you develop rash, hives, itching, swelling, fever, mouth sores, or signs of severe skin reaction.if you have other eye problems or if symptoms do not improve in a few days. use in infants and young children only as directed by a doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it when you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not use extra drops to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include temporary burning or stinging, eye redness, tearing, and blurred vision. allergic reactions can occur. severe skin reactions are rare but serious. seek medical care for severe or persistent symptoms.

name: tobramycin ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? tobramycin eye drops or ointment are antibiotics used to treat bacterial infections of the eye and eyelid such as conjunctivitis and blepharitis. how should this medicine be used? wash hands. if you wear contact lenses, remove them before use and wait at least fifteen minutes after dosing before reinsertion unless your eye care professional tells you otherwise. for drops, tilt your head back, pull the lower eyelid down to form a pocket, place the prescribed number of drops into the pocket, then close your eye and gently press the inner corner of your eye for one to two minutes to limit systemic absorption. try not to touch the dropper tip to your eye or any surface. if you use more than one eye medicine, separate them by at least five to ten minutes and use ointment last. use exactly as directed on the label or by your doctor. complete the full course even if you feel better. how should i follow special precautions?if you are allergic to tobramycin, other aminoglycosides such as gentamicin, or any ingredient in the product.about all medicines and eye products you use. inform your doctor if you have severe eye pain, vision changes, glaucoma, or have had eye surgery. do not wear contact lenses during an active eye infection unless your doctor says you may. do not use if the solution is discolored or contains particles. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use extra doses to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include temporary burning, stinging, tearing, redness, or blurred vision. less common effects include eyelid itching or swelling and light sensitivity. serious effects are rare but can include severe allergic reactions with rash, swelling of the face or throat, trouble breathing, or severe eye irritation, new or worsening pain, or vision changes. prolonged or repeated use may lead to fungal or other non susceptible infections. seek medical care if serious symptoms occur.

name: levobunolol ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? levobunolol eye drops are beta blocker medicines used to lower pressure in the eye in conditions such as open angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension to help prevent vision loss. how should this medicine be used? use exactly as prescribed, often one drop into the affected eye or eyes once daily, sometimes twice daily. wash hands. remove contact lenses before use and wait at least fifteen minutes after dosing before reinserting. tilt head back, pull down the lower eyelid, apply one drop, then close your eye and gently press the inner corner of the eye for one to two minutes to reduce systemic absorption. if using other eye medicines, separate doses by at least five to ten minutes and use gels or ointments last. do not let the dropper tip touch your eye or any surface. how should i follow special precautions?if you are allergic to beta blockers or any ingredient in the product.about all medicines you take, especially other eye drops, oral beta blockers, calcium channel blockers, digoxin, clonidine, antiarrhythmics, and medicines for asthma or chronic lung disease.if you have asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, slow heart rate, heart block, heart failure, low blood pressure, diabetes, overactive thyroid, depression, myasthenia gravis, or severe circulation problems. levobunolol may worsen breathing problems, slow the heart rate, lower blood pressure, mask signs of low blood sugar, and mask symptoms of hyperthyroidism. use caution when driving or performing tasks that require clear vision until you know how you respond. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is required. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it as soon as you remember. if it is near the time of the next dose, skip the missed dose and use the next dose at the regular time. do not use two doses at one time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include mild burning or stinging, blurred vision, eye redness, and dry eyes. systemic effects can occur and may include tiredness, dizziness, slow heart rate, low blood pressure, shortness of breath or wheezing, depression, nightmares, and sexual dysfunction. serious reactions include severe breathing problems, fainting, severe dizziness, new or worsening heart failure symptoms, and severe allergic reactions. seek medical care if serious symptoms occur.

name: niraparib and abiraterone
instructions: important warning: this combination can cause serious side effects, including bone marrow suppression with low blood counts that can lead to infections or bleeding, high blood pressure and heart effects, liver problems, mineralocorticoid excess from abiraterone with fluid retention, low potassium, and worsening of heart failure, and a risk of myelodysplastic syndrome or acute leukemia with niraparib. abiraterone can cause adrenal insufficiency and severe liver injury. this medicine can harm an unborn baby. women who are pregnant or who may become pregnant should not take this medicine or handle broken tablets. men with partners who can become pregnant should use effective contraception during treatment and for the recommended time after the last dose as directed by the prescriber. your doctor will check blood counts, blood pressure, potassium, and liver tests regularly. why is this medication prescribed? niraparib and abiraterone are used together with prednisone to treat certain adults with metastatic castration resistant prostate cancer, often in those with specific gene changes such as brca variants. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as prescribed, usually once daily at about the same time, together with a daily steroid such as prednisone as directed by your doctor, and continue androgen deprivation therapy. swallow tablets whole with water. take on an empty stomach. do not eat for at least two hours before the dose and for at least one hour after the dose. do not crush, chew, or split the tablets. if you vomit after a dose, do not take an extra dose. take the next dose at the regular time. your doctor will monitor your blood pressure, heart rate, electrolytes including potassium, liver tests, and blood counts, and may adjust your dose or pause treatment based on results or side effects. how should i follow special precautions?if you have or have had heart disease, heart failure, recent heart attack, irregular heartbeat, stroke, high blood pressure, low potassium, liver problems, bleeding problems, or a history of myelodysplastic syndrome or leukemia.about all medicines, vitamins, and herbal products you take. important interactions include strong or moderate inhibitors or inducers of cyp3a, certain antifungals, antibiotics such as clarithromycin, antivirals, seizure medicines, rifampin, and st johns wort. this medicine may increase levels of some medicines including certain steroids and some sedatives. women who are pregnant should avoid handling broken tablets. use effective birth control as advised by your doctor. do not donate blood or semen during treatment and for the period your doctor recommends after the last dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take on an empty stomach as directed. avoid grapefruit and seville oranges because they may change medicine levels. maintain adequate fluid intake and a balanced diet. your doctor may recommend limiting excess salt if you have fluid retention or high blood pressure. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember on the same day. if you miss it for the entire day, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the usual time the next day. do not take two doses at one time. if you vomit a dose, do not repeat the dose. take the next dose at the scheduled time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fatigue, nausea, vomiting, decreased appetite, constipation, diarrhea, headache, dizziness, cough, swelling of legs or feet, weight gain from fluid, high blood pressure, low potassium, and elevated liver enzymes. blood count changes can include anemia, low platelets, and low white cells, which can increase the risk of infection or bleeding. serious effects include liver injury with yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, severe abdominal pain, severe hypertension or heart problems including irregular heartbeat or heart failure, adrenal insufficiency with fatigue and low blood pressure, and rare myelodysplastic syndrome or leukemia. seek urgent medical attention for chest pain, severe shortness of breath, fainting, severe headache, confusion, fever or signs of infection, unusual bruising or bleeding, or signs of severe allergic reaction such as rash, swelling of face or throat, or trouble breathing.

name: trifarotene topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? trifarotene is a topical retinoid used to treat acne on the face, chest, shoulders, and back. how should this medicine be used? use once daily in the evening or as directed. wash with a gentle cleanser and dry the skin completely. apply a thin layer to the entire affected area rather than only to visible lesions. use a small pea sized amount for the face and small amounts for other areas as instructed. avoid the eyes, eyelids, lips, and mucous membranes, and avoid application to cuts, sunburned skin, or eczema. wash hands after application. if irritation occurs, your doctor may advise using a moisturizer, reducing the amount, or applying every other night temporarily. use sunscreen daily and protective clothing because retinoids increase sun sensitivity. how should i follow special precautions?if you are allergic to retinoids or any product ingredients, or if you have other skin conditions. use with caution if you use other topical acne products such as benzoyl peroxide or salicylic acid because irritation may increase. avoid waxing or other hair removal on treated skin while using this product. if you are pregnant, planning to become pregnant, or breastfeeding, talk with your doctor before use. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply it when you remember that day. if it is almost time for the next application, skip the missed application and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include redness, dryness, burning or stinging, scaling or peeling, and increased sensitivity to sunlight. less common effects include swelling and temporary worsening of acne during the first few weeks. stop use and contact your doctor if you have severe irritation, severe redness, swelling, crusting, or signs of allergic reaction such as hives, severe itching, or swelling of the face or throat.

name: cyclopentolate ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cyclopentolate eye drops are used to dilate the pupil and temporarily paralyze focusing for eye examinations and to treat certain inflammatory eye conditions as directed by a doctor. how should this medicine be used? this medicine is usually given in the eye clinic before an examination. if your doctor instructs home use, follow directions exactly. wash hands. remove contact lenses. tilt the head back, pull down the lower eyelid, place the prescribed number of drops, then close the eye and press gently on the inner corner of the eye for one to two minutes to reduce systemic absorption. vision may be blurred and you may be sensitive to light for several hours. wear sunglasses until effects wear off. do not drive or operate machinery until vision is clear. how should i follow special precautions?if you have narrow angle glaucoma or are at risk for angle closure, as cyclopentolate can precipitate an acute attack.if you have down syndrome, brain injury, or seizure disorder, or if you are breastfeeding. use with special caution in infants and small children due to risk of serious side effects such as flushing, fever, rapid heartbeat, restlessness, confusion, or hallucinations. use the lowest effective concentration and apply punctal occlusion as instructed to minimize systemic absorption. avoid touching the dropper tip to any surface. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you are using it on a schedule for an inflammatory eye condition and you miss a dose, use it as soon as you remember. if it is near the time of the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not use extra doses to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include stinging, blurred vision, light sensitivity, and dry mouth. serious effects may include increased eye pressure, severe eye pain, halos around lights, fast heartbeat, flushing, confusion, agitation, or seizures, particularly in infants and young children. seek urgent care if serious symptoms occur.

name: dipivefrin ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? dipivefrin eye drops are used to lower pressure in the eye in chronic open angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension. it is a prodrug of epinephrine that reduces fluid production and increases outflow. how should this medicine be used? use exactly as prescribed, often one drop into the affected eye every twelve hours. wash hands. remove contact lenses and wait at least fifteen minutes after dosing to reinsert them. tilt your head back, pull down the lower eyelid, apply one drop, then close your eye and gently press the inner corner of your eye for one to two minutes to reduce systemic absorption. do not touch the dropper tip to your eye or any surface. if you use other eye medicines, separate them by at least five to ten minutes. how should i follow special precautions?if you are allergic to epinephrine, sulfites, or any ingredient in the product.about heart disease, high blood pressure, overactive thyroid, diabetes, and narrow angle glaucoma. dipivefrin can increase the risk of angle closure in susceptible individuals.about all medicines you use, including other glaucoma drops. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use extra drops to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include temporary stinging or burning, eye redness, tearing, and blurred vision. less common effects include eye pain, eyelid retraction, and allergic conjunctivitis. rare systemic effects may include increased heart rate, palpitations, elevated blood pressure, headache, and nervousness. seek medical care if you have severe eye pain, vision changes, or signs of a severe allergic reaction.

name: salicylic acid topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? topical salicylic acid is used to treat acne, dandruff, psoriasis, and to remove warts, corns, and calluses by helping the outer layer of skin to shed. how should this medicine be used? use only on the skin as directed on the label or by your doctor. for acne or psoriasis, apply a thin layer to clean, dry skin once or twice daily as tolerated, avoiding eyes, lips, and mucous membranes. for warts, corns, or calluses, soak the area in warm water, dry, then apply the product only to the affected skin as directed. do not apply to irritated or infected skin, birthmarks, moles, or genital or facial warts unless your doctor tells you to do so. do not use airtight dressings unless directed, because this can increase absorption and irritation. wash hands after use. how should i follow special precautions?if you are allergic to aspirin, salicylates, or any ingredients in the product.if you have diabetes, poor circulation, kidney disease, liver disease, or large areas of damaged skin. children and teenagers who are recovering from flu or chickenpox should avoid salicylate products because of the risk of serious illness. use caution if you are using other topical products that can irritate skin. keep away from eyes and from flames if your product contains flammable solvents. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply it when you remember. if it is almost time for the next application, skip the missed application and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include dryness, redness, stinging, peeling, and skin irritation. stop use and contact your doctor if you develop severe irritation, swelling, hives, or signs of salicylate toxicity such as ringing in the ears, dizziness, confusion, rapid breathing, or vomiting, especially if used on large areas or under occlusion.

name: netupitant and palonosetron
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? netupitant and palonosetron are taken together to prevent nausea and vomiting caused by certain cancer chemotherapy. palonosetron blocks serotonin receptors and netupitant helps prevent both early and delayed nausea by blocking neurokinin receptors. how should this medicine be used? the oral capsule is usually taken as a single dose about one hour before the start of chemotherapy. swallow the capsule whole with water. your doctor may also prescribe dexamethasone with a dose adjustment. do not take more than one dose in a twenty four hour period unless your doctor tells you to do so. how should i follow special precautions?about all medicines you take, especially medicines that affect serotonin such as antidepressants, migraine medicines, tramadol, and linezolid, because serotonin syndrome may occur. netupitant affects liver enzymes and can interact with many medicines including certain chemotherapy agents, antifungals, antibiotics such as clarithromycin, antivirals for hiv or hepatitis, seizure medicines, and some heart rhythm medicines.if you have liver disease, kidney disease, bowel obstruction, a history of heart rhythm problems, low magnesium or potassium, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. do not start or stop any medicine without consulting your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice because they can change medicine levels. maintain good hydration unless your doctor has restricted fluids. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you forget to take the dose before chemotherapy, contact your doctor for instructions. do not take extra doses on the same day unless directed. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, constipation, hiccups, indigestion, fatigue, and weakness. less common effects include elevated liver enzymes and dizziness. serious effects include allergic reactions with rash or difficulty breathing, serotonin syndrome with agitation, sweating, fever, rapid heart rate, or confusion, and heart rhythm changes such as prolonged qt which may present with fainting or palpitations. seek urgent care if serious symptoms occur.

name: hydrocortisone topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? hydrocortisone cream, ointment, lotion, or solution is a low to medium strength topical corticosteroid used to relieve itching, redness, and swelling caused by eczema, dermatitis, insect bites, and other inflammatory skin conditions. how should this medicine be used? apply a thin film to the affected area one to four times daily or as directed. gently rub in. do not apply to broken skin or infected areas unless directed by your doctor. avoid use on the face, groin, or underarms unless told to do so by your doctor. do not cover the area with a bandage or diaper unless directed because occlusion increases absorption and side effects. wash hands after application unless you are treating the hands. use for the shortest time needed to control symptoms. how should i follow special precautions?if you are allergic to corticosteroids or any ingredients in the product, and if you have skin infections, rosacea, acne, poor circulation, diabetes, liver disease, or immune system problems.about all medicines and skin products you use. in children, use the smallest effective amount for the shortest duration because they are more susceptible to side effects. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply it when you remember. if it is almost time for the next application, skip the missed application and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include mild burning or stinging, dryness, and irritation. with prolonged or excessive use, thinning of the skin, stretch marks, acne like eruptions, visible blood vessels, delayed wound healing, and changes in skin color may occur. if a large amount is used or used under occlusion, adrenal suppression can occur with symptoms such as unusual tiredness, weight loss, or dizziness. skin infections may worsen or new infections may occur. seek care for severe irritation or signs of infection such as increased redness, pus, or fever.

name: brompheniramine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? brompheniramine is an antihistamine used to relieve symptoms of allergies and the common cold such as sneezing, runny nose, itchy or watery eyes, and itching of the nose or throat. it may be found alone or in combination with other ingredients such as decongestants or cough suppressants. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as directed on the product label or by your doctor. use the measuring device that comes with liquid products. many cough and cold products are not recommended for young children. do not give to children younger than the age recommended on the label unless a doctor tells you to do so. do not exceed the recommended dose. how should i follow special precautions?if you are allergic to antihistamines or any product ingredients.about all medicines you take. this medicine can cause drowsiness and impair thinking and reaction times. do not drive, operate machinery, or perform tasks that require alertness until you know how it affects you. avoid other medicines that cause drowsiness such as benzodiazepines, opioids, sleep medicines, and alcohol.if you have glaucoma, enlarged prostate or urinary retention, severe high blood pressure, heart disease, asthma, chronic lung disease, overactive thyroid, or liver disease. do not use if you have taken a monoamine oxidase inhibitor in the past fourteen days. pregnant or breastfeeding individuals should consult a doctor before use. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid alcohol. stay well hydrated. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you are taking it on a schedule, take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at one time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include drowsiness, dizziness, dry mouth, nose, or throat, blurred vision, constipation, and difficulty urinating. in some children, paradoxical excitement or irritability may occur. serious effects can include confusion, hallucinations, severe drowsiness, irregular heartbeat, seizures, and severe allergic reactions with rash, swelling, or trouble breathing. seek medical help if serious symptoms occur.

name: aluminum hydroxide and magnesium hydroxide
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? this antacid is used to relieve symptoms of heartburn, acid indigestion, sour stomach, and upset stomach. it neutralizes stomach acid and may provide short term relief of gastritis symptoms. how should this medicine be used? use exactly as directed on the label or by your clinician. shake liquids well before each dose and measure with a proper device. chew chewable tablets thoroughly and drink a full glass of water. many products are taken after meals and at bedtime. do not use for longer than two weeks without medical advice. separate this medicine from other oral medicines by at least two hours because it can reduce their absorption. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have kidney disease, are on a magnesium restricted or phosphate restricted plan, have a history of bowel obstruction, or have symptoms that could indicate a serious condition such as black stools, vomiting blood, or severe abdominal pain. tell your clinician about all medicines you take because antacids can interact with many medicines including tetracyclines, fluoroquinolones, iron, levothyroxine, isoniazid, and digoxin. pregnant or breastfeeding patients should consult a clinician before use. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required, but limiting alcohol, caffeine, and foods that trigger heartburn such as very spicy, fatty, or acidic foods may help. drink adequate water. what should i do if i forget a dose? many antacids are used as needed. if you were told to use it on a schedule, take it when you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include constipation from aluminum salts or diarrhea from magnesium salts, nausea, and a chalky taste. serious effects can include low phosphate levels, high magnesium levels in those with kidney problems with symptoms such as weakness, flushing, or slowed reflexes, and signs of bleeding or severe abdominal pain. seek medical care if serious effects occur.

name: simethicone
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? simethicone is used to relieve painful pressure, fullness, and bloating caused by excess gas in the stomach and intestines. how should this medicine be used? follow the product label or your clinician’s directions. typical adult dosing is after meals and at bedtime. chew chewable tablets thoroughly before swallowing. for drops or liquids, use the supplied dropper or measuring device. do not exceed the maximum daily amount listed on the label. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have a history of intestinal blockage or unexplained abdominal pain. tell your clinician about all medicines you take. simethicone has few interactions but it is best to review your list. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, consult your clinician before use. what special dietary instructions should i follow? limiting gas producing foods such as beans, broccoli, onions, and carbonated beverages may reduce symptoms. eating slowly and avoiding chewing gum can also help. what should i do if i forget a dose? simethicone is often taken as needed. if you are using it on a schedule, take it when you remember unless it is close to your next dose. do not double the dose. what side effects can this medication cause? side effects are uncommon but can include nausea, constipation, diarrhea, or mild stomach upset. severe allergic reactions are rare. seek medical care if you develop rash, swelling, or trouble breathing.

name: loratadine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? loratadine is an antihistamine used to relieve symptoms of seasonal and perennial allergies such as sneezing, runny nose, itchy or watery eyes, and itching. it is also used to treat itchy hives. how should this medicine be used? adults and children over six years often take ten milligrams by mouth once daily. follow the label or your clinician’s instructions for age specific dosing and for liquid or disintegrating tablets. do not take more than directed and do not combine with other antihistamines unless told to do so. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have liver or kidney disease because a lower or less frequent dose may be needed. tell your clinician about all medicines you take. although loratadine is usually non drowsy, it can cause drowsiness in some people, especially with alcohol or other sedating medicines. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, consult your clinician before use. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. limit alcohol since it can increase drowsiness. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it when you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, dry mouth, fatigue, and sleepiness in some people. less common effects include nervousness or rapid heartbeat. severe allergic reactions are rare. seek medical care for chest pain, severe dizziness, fainting, or rash with swelling or trouble breathing.

name: ketotifen ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ketotifen eye drops relieve itchy eyes due to allergic conjunctivitis by blocking histamine and stabilizing mast cells. how should this medicine be used? wash your hands. remove contact lenses before use. instill one drop in the affected eye or eyes every eight to twelve hours and do not use more than twice in a day. do not touch the dropper tip to your eye or any surface. if you use other eye medicines, separate them by at least five minutes. wait at least ten minutes before reinserting contact lenses and do not wear lenses if your eyes are red. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have eye pain, changes in vision, an eye infection, glaucoma, or if symptoms last more than a few days. tell your clinician and pharmacist about all medicines you use. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, ask your clinician before use. keep the bottle clean and tightly closed. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it when you remember unless it is close to the next scheduled dose. do not use extra drops to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include mild burning or stinging, eye irritation, dry eyes, and headache. less common effects include blurred vision or a bad taste in the mouth. stop use and seek medical care for severe eye pain, vision changes, severe redness or swelling, or signs of an allergic reaction such as rash, swelling, or trouble breathing.

name: albendazole
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? albendazole is an antiparasitic medicine used to treat infections caused by worms, including neurocysticercosis, hydatid disease, and certain intestinal worm infections such as roundworm, hookworm, pinworm, and whipworm. how should this medicine be used? dosing and duration depend on the infection. take exactly as prescribed. take each dose with food, preferably a fatty meal, to improve absorption. for prolonged courses, your clinician will order blood tests to monitor your liver and blood counts. if you are being treated for neurocysticercosis, your clinician may prescribe steroids and seizure medicines to manage inflammation. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you are pregnant. a pregnancy test is usually needed before starting, and effective birth control is recommended during treatment and for at least three to four weeks after the last dose. tell your clinician if you have liver disease, bone marrow suppression, or eye disease. tell your clinician and pharmacist about all medicines you take, especially cimetidine, dexamethasone, praziquantel, antiepileptics, and medicines that affect the liver. if signs of liver trouble occur such as dark urine, yellowing of the skin or eyes, or severe fatigue, stop the medicine and contact your clinician. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take with food and preferably with a fatty meal such as milk or a meal containing oils to increase absorption. avoid alcohol to lessen liver irritation. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, headache, dizziness, and elevated liver enzymes. serious effects include low white blood cells or platelets with fever or easy bruising, severe liver injury, and allergic reactions. in neurocysticercosis, symptoms can worsen temporarily due to inflammation such as seizures or increased intracranial pressure, which require prompt medical attention.

name: albiglutide injection
instructions: important warning: this medicine may increase the risk of thyroid c cell tumors. do not use it if you or a family member has a history of medullary thyroid carcinoma or if you have multiple endocrine neoplasia syndrome type two. call your clinician right away if you develop a lump or swelling in the neck, hoarseness, trouble swallowing, or shortness of breath. albiglutide has also been associated with pancreatitis and gallbladder disease. seek care for severe abdominal pain that may radiate to the back, persistent nausea, or vomiting. this product has been discontinued in some regions, so availability may be limited. why is this medication prescribed? albiglutide is a glucagon like peptide one receptor agonist used along with diet and exercise to improve blood sugar control in adults with type two diabetes. it is not for type one diabetes or diabetic ketoacidosis and is not a substitute for insulin. how should this medicine be used? it is injected under the skin once weekly on the same day each week in the abdomen, thigh, or upper arm. rotate injection sites. follow the instructions to mix and prepare the dose before injection. do not share injection pens. your clinician may adjust other diabetes medicines to reduce the risk of low blood sugar. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have a history of thyroid tumors, pancreatitis, gallbladder disease, diabetic retinopathy, kidney problems, severe stomach or intestinal disease such as gastroparesis, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. tell your clinician and pharmacist about all medicines you take, especially insulin or sulfonylureas which increase the risk of low blood sugar, and medicines that can affect the stomach or kidneys. stop and seek care for signs of pancreatitis or an allergic reaction. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow your diabetes meal plan, monitor carbohydrate intake, and limit alcohol to reduce the risk of low blood sugar and pancreatitis. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a weekly dose, take it as soon as you remember if there are at least three days until your next scheduled dose. if fewer than three days remain, skip the missed dose and take your next dose on the regular day. do not take two doses within three days of each other. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, decreased appetite, indigestion, constipation, and injection site reactions. low blood sugar can occur especially if used with insulin or a sulfonylurea and may cause shakiness, sweating, fast heartbeat, and confusion. serious effects include pancreatitis, gallbladder disease, kidney problems from dehydration, and possible thyroid tumors.

name: albuterol
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? albuterol is a short acting bronchodilator used to treat or prevent bronchospasm in asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and to prevent exercise induced bronchospasm. how should this medicine be used? use exactly as directed. for a metered dose inhaler, the usual dose is two inhalations every four to six hours as needed for symptoms. to prevent exercise induced symptoms, use two inhalations about fifteen to thirty minutes before exercise. for nebulizer solution, inhale the prescribed volume using a jet nebulizer. prime new or unused inhalers as directed, use correct technique, and consider a spacer. keep track of doses remaining. do not exceed the maximum number of inhalations recommended by your clinician. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have heart disease, high blood pressure, arrhythmias, seizures, thyroid disease, diabetes, or low potassium. tell your clinician about all medicines you take, especially other inhalers, beta blockers, diuretics, tricyclic antidepressants, and monoamine oxidase inhibitors. stop and seek care if breathing suddenly worsens after use since this may be paradoxical bronchospasm. needing your rescue inhaler more often may mean your condition is worsening and you should contact your clinician. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no special dietary requirements. limiting caffeine and other stimulants may reduce jitteriness and palpitations. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is often used as needed. if you are on a schedule, take it when you remember unless it is nearly time for the next dose. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include tremor, nervousness, headache, throat irritation, cough, and fast heartbeat. serious effects include chest pain, severe palpitations, significant rise in blood pressure, low potassium with muscle cramps or weakness, and allergic reactions with rash, swelling, or trouble breathing.

name: albuterol and ipratropium oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? this combination inhalation medicine is used to treat bronchospasm in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease by relaxing airway muscles through two different mechanisms. how should this medicine be used? use exactly as prescribed. for the respimat inhaler, the usual dose is one inhalation four times daily and some patients may take additional inhalations as needed up to the maximum allowed in twenty four hours. for nebulizer solution, inhale the prescribed unit dose via a jet nebulizer up to four times daily, with extra doses as directed by your clinician. learn and use the correct inhalation technique, prime new or unused devices, and do not spray into the eyes. do not exceed the maximum daily number of doses. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have glaucoma, enlarged prostate, trouble urinating, bladder neck obstruction, heart disease, high blood pressure, arrhythmias, seizures, or thyroid disease. avoid getting the spray in your eyes because it can worsen narrow angle glaucoma with eye pain or blurred vision. tell your clinician about all medicines you take, including other inhalers, anticholinergics, beta blockers, diuretics, tricyclic antidepressants, and monoamine oxidase inhibitors. seek care for paradoxical bronchospasm if breathing worsens immediately after use. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. limit caffeine and stay well hydrated to help manage secretions. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it when you remember unless it is close to your next dose. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include dry mouth, cough, bitter or unusual taste, sore throat, headache, nervousness, tremor, and fast heartbeat. serious effects include eye pain or vision changes if spray gets into the eyes, difficulty urinating, severe palpitations, allergic reactions, and paradoxical bronchospasm.

name: alcaftadine ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? alcaftadine eye drops are used to prevent and relieve itchy eyes due to allergic conjunctivitis. how should this medicine be used? wash your hands. instill one drop in each affected eye once daily. remove contact lenses before use and wait at least ten minutes before reinserting. do not touch the tip of the dropper to your eye or any surface. if you use other eye medicines, separate them by at least five minutes. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have eye infections, glaucoma, or vision changes. discontinue and seek care for severe eye pain, worsening redness, or vision changes. tell your clinician if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. keep the bottle clean and tightly closed. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it when you remember on the same day. if it is nearly the next day, skip the missed dose and resume your usual schedule. do not use extra drops to make up a dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include temporary stinging or burning, eye irritation, redness, and headache. serious allergic reactions are rare but require immediate medical attention.

name: spironolactone and hydrochlorothiazide
instructions: important warning: spironolactone has caused tumors in animal studies. use this medicine only for approved conditions and at the lowest effective dose. this combination can raise potassium levels which can be severe and life threatening, especially in people with kidney problems, diabetes, or those taking other medicines that increase potassium. regular blood tests are needed to monitor electrolytes and kidney function. why is this medication prescribed? this combination diuretic is used to treat high blood pressure and edema related to conditions such as heart failure, liver cirrhosis, or kidney disorders. spironolactone helps conserve potassium, while hydrochlorothiazide promotes salt and water loss. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth exactly as directed, usually once daily in the morning to avoid nighttime urination. take with food if it upsets your stomach. your clinician will adjust the dose based on your blood pressure, swelling, and lab tests. do not stop the medicine without medical advice. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you have anuria, acute kidney failure, addison disease, or high potassium. tell your clinician if you have kidney disease, liver disease, gout, diabetes, lupus, or a history of skin cancer. tell your clinician and pharmacist about all medicines you take, including ace inhibitors, arbs, aliskiren, potassium supplements, salt substitutes containing potassium, nsaids, lithium, digoxin, and other diuretics. use sun protection because hydrochlorothiazide can increase sensitivity to sunlight. if you feel faint, have very low urine output, or notice an irregular heartbeat, seek care right away. if you are pregnant, planning to become pregnant, or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits with your clinician. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid potassium supplements and salt substitutes that contain potassium unless your clinician tells you otherwise. maintain adequate fluid intake and a consistent amount of dietary sodium as advised by your clinician. limit alcohol to reduce the risk of dizziness or fainting. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it when you remember the same day. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include increased urination, dizziness, low blood pressure especially when standing, stomach upset, muscle cramps, and mild rash. spironolactone can cause breast tenderness or enlargement, menstrual changes, and sexual side effects. hydrochlorothiazide can cause photosensitivity and may increase uric acid and blood sugar. serious effects include high potassium with weakness or slow heartbeat, very low sodium, dehydration, kidney problems, severe skin reactions, pancreatitis, and allergic reactions. seek medical care if serious effects occur.

name: spironolactone
instructions: important warning: spironolactone caused tumors in animal studies. use this medicine only for conditions for which it is clearly indicated. spironolactone can raise potassium to dangerous levels, especially in people with kidney problems or those using potassium supplements, potassium containing salt substitutes, or other medicines that increase potassium such as ace inhibitors, arbs, or other potassium sparing diuretics. your doctor will monitor your blood potassium and kidney function regularly. why is this medication prescribed? spironolactone is prescribed to treat high blood pressure, heart failure, swelling from liver or kidney disease, and certain forms of hyperaldosteronism. it is also used off label for acne and unwanted hair growth. how should this medicine be used? take spironolactone exactly as directed, usually once or twice daily, at the same times each day. you may take it with or without food, but be consistent to avoid stomach upset. do not change your dose or stop without talking to your doctor. if you use the oral suspension, use the measuring device provided. because it is a diuretic, taking it earlier in the day may reduce nighttime urination. what special precautions should i follow?about all allergies and all medicines and supplements you take. do not use if you have severe kidney disease, little or no urine, addison disease, or high potassium.if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. use caution with alcohol and medicines that cause drowsiness. avoid nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs unless your doctor approves. have blood tests as directed to check potassium and kidney function. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your doctor tells you otherwise, avoid high potassium foods such as bananas, oranges, potatoes, and leafy greens, and avoid salt substitutes that contain potassium. follow any sodium restriction your doctor recommends. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time for your next dose. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include increased urination, dizziness, headache, stomach upset, and fatigue. hormonal effects such as breast tenderness or enlargement, menstrual changes, and decreased sexual desire can occur. serious effects include high potassium with symptoms such as muscle weakness, tingling, slow or irregular heartbeat, fainting, or confusion, severe dehydration, very low sodium, and severe skin reactions. seek urgent medical help if you have signs of severe dizziness, fainting, severe weakness, chest pain, or trouble breathing.

name: imiquimod topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? imiquimod cream is used to treat external genital and perianal warts, actinic keratoses on the face or scalp, and certain superficial basal cell skin cancers. it works by stimulating your immune system in the skin to clear abnormal cells and viruses. how should this medicine be used? use exactly as directed for your specific condition. typically a thin layer is applied to clean, dry skin before bedtime on the prescribed nights, rubbed in until it disappears, left on the skin for 6 to 10 hours, then washed off with mild soap and water. wash your hands before and after application. do not apply to broken, irritated, or sunburned skin, inside the mouth, nose, rectum, or vagina, or near the eyes or lips. do not cover with airtight dressings. avoid sexual contact while the cream is on your skin because it may irritate your partner and can weaken condoms or diaphragms. what special precautions should i follow?about all skin conditions, immune problems, autoimmune diseases, and if you have had organ transplants.about all medicines you use including other topical products. avoid excessive sun exposure on treated areas and use sun protection. stop use and call your doctor if you have severe local reactions such as intense redness, swelling, weeping, ulceration, severe pain, or if you develop fever, flu like symptoms, or swollen glands. if pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is required. stay well hydrated and maintain good skin care as advised. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the next dose on the next scheduled night. do not apply extra cream or use it more often to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects at the application site include redness, itching, burning, tenderness, swelling, flaking, scabbing, or small open areas. temporary lightening or darkening of skin may occur. some people experience headache, tiredness, body aches, or mild fever. serious reactions include severe skin erosion or ulceration, severe swelling that interferes with urination or bowel movements, eye irritation if contact occurs, and allergic reactions with rash, hives, or difficulty breathing. seek medical care if severe or if you feel very unwell.

name: aldesleukin
instructions: important warning: aldesleukin can cause a capillary leak syndrome that leads to very low blood pressure, fluid in the lungs, reduced kidney function, heart rhythm problems, and other serious or life threatening problems. it can also cause severe infections, bleeding, and mental status changes. treatment should be given only by experienced clinicians in a hospital setting with intensive monitoring and immediate access to life support. why is this medication prescribed? aldesleukin is used to treat adults with metastatic kidney cancer and metastatic melanoma. it is a synthetic form of interleukin two that stimulates the immune system to attack cancer cells. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion in cycles in the hospital. your team will monitor your heart, lungs, kidneys, liver, and mental status frequently. premedications and supportive care will be provided as needed. do not take any new medicines, including over the counter drugs or supplements, without your oncology team’s approval. what special precautions should i follow?about heart disease, lung disease, kidney or liver problems, seizures, infection, stomach ulcers, thyroid disorders, autoimmune disease, and any mental health conditions.about all medicines you take. you should not receive live vaccines during treatment. use effective birth control during treatment and for the time your doctor recommends after the last dose, and do not breastfeed during therapy. seek immediate help for chest pain, shortness of breath, severe dizziness or fainting, confusion, decreased urine, severe swelling, or signs of infection such as fever or chills. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may be advised to limit fluids or salt, or to maintain good hydration depending on your condition and your care team’s instructions. do not drink alcohol without your doctor’s approval. what should i do if i forget a dose? aldesleukin is administered by healthcare professionals. if you miss or need to delay an infusion, contact your oncology team right away for instructions. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fever, chills, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, decreased appetite, mouth sores, rash, itching, low blood pressure, fast heartbeat, swelling, and changes in lab tests. serious effects include capillary leak with fluid in the lungs and very low blood pressure, heart rhythm changes or heart attack, kidney failure, severe infections and sepsis, bleeding, confusion, agitation, hallucinations, stroke like symptoms, and severe electrolyte abnormalities. your team will monitor you closely and treat side effects promptly.

name: doxylamine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? doxylamine is an antihistamine used short term to relieve occasional difficulty falling asleep and to relieve allergy symptoms such as sneezing and runny nose. a specific combination of doxylamine with vitamin b6 is used for nausea and vomiting of pregnancy under a doctor’s direction. how should this medicine be used? for insomnia, take the lowest effective dose about 30 minutes before bedtime and allow a full night for sleep. use for the shortest time needed, generally not more than two weeks, unless your doctor advises otherwise. swallow tablets whole with water. do not drive or perform tasks requiring alertness after taking. for allergy symptoms, follow your doctor’s instructions or the product label. what special precautions should i follow?if you have glaucoma, enlarged prostate, trouble urinating, asthma, chronic lung disease, thyroid disease, heart disease, high blood pressure, or if you are elderly, as you may be more sensitive to side effects. avoid alcohol, cannabis, and other medicines that cause drowsiness. do not combine with other sleep aids. do not use to make a child sleepy. if pregnant or breastfeeding, use only as directed by your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is required. avoid alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you use it for insomnia and miss a dose, skip it and wait for the next night. if you use it for allergy symptoms, take it when you remember unless it is close to the next dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include drowsiness lasting into the next day, dizziness, dry mouth, blurred vision, constipation, and difficulty urinating. in older adults it may cause confusion, unsteadiness, or falls. rarely, excitability or agitation can occur, more often in children. seek urgent help for severe allergic reaction, palpitations, severe confusion, or trouble breathing.

name: methyldopa
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? methyldopa is prescribed to lower high blood pressure and is commonly used during pregnancy when appropriate. it lowers blood pressure by acting on the central nervous system. how should this medicine be used? take methyldopa exactly as directed, usually two to four times daily. you may take it with food if it upsets your stomach. take it at the same times each day and do not stop suddenly without medical advice, as your blood pressure can rise. your doctor may adjust your dose based on your response. what special precautions should i follow?about liver disease, previous hepatitis or jaundice from methyldopa, depression, parkinson disease, and any history of anemia or blood disorders. methyldopa can cause drowsiness or dizziness; avoid driving until you know how it affects you. it can interact with iron supplements, which reduce absorption, so separate methyldopa and iron by at least two hours. tell laboratory personnel you take methyldopa because it can affect certain test results including a positive coombs test. tell your surgeon or dentist before any procedure. avoid alcohol. if you develop fever, sore throat, unusual tiredness, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, or right upper belly pain, contact your doctor right away. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow a heart healthy, low sodium diet if recommended by your doctor. limit alcohol. if taking iron, separate it from methyldopa by at least two hours. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is close to the next dose. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include drowsiness, dizziness especially when standing up, headache, dry mouth, nasal congestion, and mild swelling. serious effects include liver inflammation with jaundice, hemolytic anemia, fever, myocarditis, depression, and severe low blood pressure. seek medical attention if you have yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, persistent fever, severe fatigue, chest pain, fainting, or unusual bleeding or bruising.

name: chlorothiazide
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? chlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic used to treat high blood pressure and fluid retention due to conditions such as heart failure. it helps your body get rid of excess salt and water. how should this medicine be used? take chlorothiazide exactly as directed, usually once or twice daily. take it in the morning to reduce nighttime urination. you may take it with food to reduce stomach upset and drink enough fluids as advised by your doctor. your doctor may adjust the dose based on your response. what special precautions should i follow?if you are allergic to sulfonamide medicines, or if you have kidney or liver disease, gout, diabetes, lupus, high cholesterol, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. stand up slowly to reduce dizziness from low blood pressure. chlorothiazide can affect electrolytes including potassium, sodium, and magnesium, and can raise uric acid and blood sugar.about all medicines you take. nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs can reduce its effect. lithium levels can rise dangerously with thiazides. protect your skin from the sun. what special dietary instructions should i follow? your doctor may advise a low salt diet. you may be told to eat potassium rich foods or take a potassium supplement, depending on your lab results. do not start potassium supplements or use salt substitutes without your doctor’s advice. stay well hydrated unless your doctor gives other instructions. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is late in the day or close to the next dose. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include increased urination, dizziness, lightheadedness when standing, photosensitivity, stomach upset, and headache. it can cause low potassium or sodium with symptoms such as muscle cramps, weakness, confusion, or seizures, increased uric acid leading to gout, and increased blood sugar. rare but serious effects include pancreatitis, severe skin reactions, severe dehydration, or kidney problems. seek care for severe dizziness, fainting, severe abdominal pain, rash with blistering, or signs of electrolyte imbalance.

name: methyldopa and hydrochlorothiazide
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? this combination lowers high blood pressure by combining methyldopa, which acts on the central nervous system, with hydrochlorothiazide, a diuretic that helps remove excess salt and water. how should this medicine be used? take it exactly as directed, usually once or twice daily at the same times each day. you may take it with food if it upsets your stomach. because it contains a diuretic, taking it earlier in the day may reduce nighttime urination. do not stop taking it without talking to your doctor. what special precautions should i follow?about liver disease, a history of methyldopa induced hepatitis or jaundice, kidney disease, gout, diabetes, lupus, depression, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. this medicine can cause drowsiness and dizziness; avoid driving until you know how it affects you. methyldopa can interact with iron supplements, so separate doses by at least two hours. hydrochlorothiazide can lower potassium and raise uric acid and blood sugar.about all medicines you take, including lithium, other blood pressure drugs, and nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs. rise slowly from sitting to reduce lightheadedness. tell laboratory staff you take methyldopa as it may affect certain tests. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow a low sodium diet if recommended. your doctor may advise you about potassium intake based on your blood tests. do not start potassium supplements or use potassium containing salt substitutes unless your doctor tells you to. limit alcohol. if you take iron, separate it from methyldopa by at least two hours. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is close to the next dose. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include drowsiness, dizziness especially when standing, dry mouth, headache, nasal congestion, increased urination, and stomach upset. serious effects include liver inflammation with jaundice, hemolytic anemia, very low blood pressure with fainting, electrolyte abnormalities especially low potassium with muscle cramps or weakness, gout, and severe skin reactions. seek medical care if you have yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, severe dizziness, fainting, unusual bleeding or bruising, severe rash, or signs of electrolyte imbalance such as confusion or seizures.

name: alectinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? alectinib is used to treat adults with non small cell lung cancer that has a change in the alk gene. it helps slow or stop cancer growth. how should this medicine be used? take alectinib exactly as directed, usually two times a day with food. swallow the capsules whole. if you vomit after taking a dose, do not take an extra dose; take your next dose at the usual time. if you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember unless the next dose is due within about six hours; if the next dose is near, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what special precautions should i follow?about all medicines, vitamins, and herbal products you take. avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice which can change drug levels. alectinib can cause liver problems, interstitial lung disease or pneumonitis, slow heart rate, muscle problems with high creatine kinase, and severe sun sensitivity. your doctor will check your liver tests and other labs. report new or worsening cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, severe fatigue, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, severe muscle pain or weakness, swelling, or fainting. use effective birth control during treatment and for the period your doctor advises after the last dose, and do not breastfeed during treatment and for some time after the last dose. protect your skin from the sun and avoid tanning beds. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take each dose with food. avoid grapefruit products. use sun protection including protective clothing and broad spectrum sunscreen. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless the next dose is due within about six hours, in which case skip the missed dose. if you vomit after a dose, do not take an extra dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include tiredness, constipation, swelling, muscle pain, increased liver enzymes, increased bilirubin, anemia, nausea, and rash or sunburn. serious effects include liver injury, severe lung inflammation, severe muscle damage with dark urine, slow or irregular heartbeat, severe anemia, and kidney problems. seek urgent care for chest pain, severe shortness of breath, fainting, or severe muscle symptoms.

name: alemtuzumab injection chronic lymphocytic leukemia
instructions: important warning: alemtuzumab can cause severe and sometimes life threatening infusion reactions, profound lowering of blood cells, and serious infections including reactivation of viruses. it must be administered by experienced healthcare professionals with appropriate monitoring. you will need preventive medicines and frequent blood tests during treatment and for a period after. why is this medication prescribed? alemtuzumab is used to treat b cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia by targeting a protein on certain white blood cells and causing their destruction. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion on a schedule determined by your oncology team, often with dose escalation at the start. you will likely receive premedications such as acetaminophen and an antihistamine to reduce infusion reactions, and preventive antibiotics and antivirals to reduce the risk of certain infections. your blood counts and infection markers such as cytomegalovirus will be monitored regularly. what special precautions should i follow?about all medical conditions and all medicines you take. do not receive live vaccines during treatment or until your doctor says it is safe. report fever, chills, cough, shortness of breath, sore throat, burning with urination, or any signs of infection right away. use effective birth control during treatment and for the time your doctor advises after the last dose, and do not breastfeed during treatment. if you need a blood transfusion, tell your providers you are receiving alemtuzumab because you may need irradiated blood products. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific diet requirements, but maintaining good nutrition and hydration is important. avoid alcohol unless your doctor approves. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss or need to delay an infusion, contact your oncology team immediately for instructions. do not attempt to make up a dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include infusion reactions with fever, chills, rash, low blood pressure, shortness of breath, headache, and nausea, fatigue, and infections. serious effects include severe and prolonged low white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets with increased risk of infection and bleeding, severe infections including pneumonia and sepsis, reactivation of viruses such as cytomegalovirus, autoimmune complications, and rare severe skin reactions. seek urgent care for trouble breathing, chest pain, severe dizziness or fainting, uncontrolled bleeding, or high fever.

name: alemtuzumab injection multiple sclerosis
instructions: important warning: alemtuzumab for multiple sclerosis can cause serious autoimmune disorders including immune thrombocytopenia and kidney problems, severe infusion reactions, increased risk of stroke soon after infusion, and an increased risk of certain cancers. it is available only through a risk evaluation and mitigation strategy program that requires enrollment and regular monitoring. you will need frequent blood, urine, and thyroid tests during treatment and for 48 months after the last infusion. why is this medication prescribed? alemtuzumab is used to treat adults with relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis who have had an inadequate response to two or more other therapies. it reduces disease activity by depleting and resetting certain immune cells. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion in two treatment courses, usually on five consecutive days for the first course and on three consecutive days 12 months later for the second course. premedications such as corticosteroids, antihistamines, and acetaminophen are given to reduce infusion reactions, and antiviral medicine is prescribed to reduce the risk of herpes infections. your care team will monitor you during and after each infusion. what special precautions should i follow?about all medical conditions, especially bleeding problems, kidney disease, thyroid disease, infections, heart disease, and any history of stroke. do not receive live vaccines during treatment or until your doctor says it is safe. use effective birth control during treatment and for the period your doctor advises after the last dose, and do not breastfeed during treatment and for a period afterward. report symptoms immediately including unusual bleeding or bruising, blood in urine, swelling in legs or face, decreased urine, shortness of breath, severe headache, weakness on one side, trouble speaking, chest pain, severe infusion symptoms, or signs of infection such as fever or chills. you will need monthly blood counts and kidney tests and periodic thyroid tests for 48 months after the last infusion. what special dietary instructions should i follow? to reduce the risk of listeria infection, avoid raw or undercooked meats, unpasteurized dairy products, and unheated deli meats around the time of infusion and for a period after your doctor recommends. stay well hydrated and avoid alcohol unless your doctor approves. what should i do if i forget a dose?
