if you miss or need to delay an infusion day, contact your neurology team immediately. do not attempt to adjust the schedule on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include infusion reactions with fever, rash, headache, nausea, fatigue, and flushing, infections of the respiratory or urinary tract, and changes in thyroid function. serious effects include severe autoimmune platelet loss with bleeding, kidney inflammation that can lead to kidney failure, serious infections including herpes and listeria, heart and blood vessel problems including stroke, and increased risk of some cancers such as thyroid cancer and melanoma. your healthcare team will monitor you closely and treat side effects promptly.

name: alendronate
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? alendronate is used to prevent and treat osteoporosis in adults, including after menopause and in men, to treat osteoporosis caused by corticosteroids, and to treat paget disease of bone. it helps increase bone mass and reduce the risk of fractures. how should this medicine be used? take alendronate exactly as directed, either once daily or once weekly. take your dose first thing in the morning before you eat or drink anything, with a full glass of plain water only. swallow the tablet whole. do not chew or suck the tablet. stay fully upright sitting or standing for at least thirty minutes and until after you have eaten your first food of the day. do not take at bedtime or before getting up for the day. if you use an effervescent tablet, dissolve it in plain water only and drink it as directed. what special precautions should i follow? do not take alendronate if you have problems with the esophagus, cannot sit or stand upright for thirty minutes, or have low blood calcium. tell your clinician if you have kidney disease, stomach or esophageal problems such as ulcers or barrett esophagus, or if you will have a dental procedure. report new or unusual thigh or groin pain. tell your dentist you take alendronate. take calcium and vitamin d as advised. separate alendronate from other medicines and supplements that contain calcium, iron, magnesium, or aluminum. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take alendronate only with plain water on an empty stomach. wait at least thirty minutes before eating, drinking anything other than water, or taking other medicines. ensure adequate calcium and vitamin d intake as recommended by your clinician. what should i do if i forget a dose? for once daily dosing, skip the missed dose and take the next dose the following morning. for once weekly dosing, take one tablet the morning after you remember unless it is the day after your next scheduled dose, in which case skip the missed dose. do not take two doses on the same day. what side effects can this medication cause? stomach pain, heartburn, nausea, constipation or diarrhea, gas, and musculoskeletal pain can occur. more serious effects include irritation or ulcers of the esophagus, low blood calcium with muscle cramps or spasms, severe bone joint or muscle pain, jaw bone problems, unusual thigh or groin pain that may signal an atypical femur fracture, eye inflammation, and allergic reactions.

name: naproxen
instructions: important warning: nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs increase the risk of serious cardiovascular thrombotic events including heart attack and stroke, which can be fatal, and the risk may occur early in treatment and increase with duration of use. they also increase the risk of serious gastrointestinal bleeding, ulceration, and perforation of the stomach or intestines at any time and often without warning. naproxen is contraindicated in the setting of coronary artery bypass graft surgery. why is this medication prescribed? naproxen is used to relieve pain, swelling, and stiffness from conditions such as osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, gout, menstrual cramps, and other acute pain. how should this medicine be used? take naproxen exactly as prescribed, using the lowest effective dose for the shortest duration needed. swallow tablets or capsules with a full glass of water and take with food or milk to reduce stomach upset. do not crush or chew extended release forms. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about heart disease, stroke, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, diabetes, smoking, stomach or intestinal ulcers or bleeding, kidney or liver disease, asthma especially with aspirin sensitivity, pregnancy especially in the last trimester, and breastfeeding. naproxen can increase blood pressure and impair kidney function. avoid taking with other nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs, blood thinners, antiplatelet drugs, corticosteroids, selective serotonin or norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, or certain blood pressure medicines unless your clinician approves. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take with food or milk if needed. avoid alcohol because it can increase stomach irritation and bleeding risk. stay well hydrated. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you take naproxen on a regular schedule, take the missed dose when you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? upset stomach, heartburn, nausea, dizziness, drowsiness, headache, and fluid retention may occur. serious side effects include severe stomach pain, black or bloody stools, vomiting blood, chest pain, shortness of breath, weakness on one side, slurred speech, severe skin reactions, kidney problems with decreased urination, and allergic reactions. seek medical attention right away for serious symptoms.

name: alfuzosin
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? alfuzosin is used to improve urinary symptoms of benign prostatic hyperplasia such as difficulty starting urination, weak stream, and frequent urination. it relaxes muscles in the prostate and bladder neck. how should this medicine be used? take the extended release tablet once daily immediately after the same meal each day. swallow the tablet whole. do not crush, chew, or split it. what special precautions should i follow? alfuzosin can cause low blood pressure and dizziness, especially when starting or increasing the dose. rise slowly from sitting or lying. tell your clinician if you have liver disease, kidney disease, heart disease, a history of fainting, or a prolonged qt interval. tell all of your clinicians about all medicines you take, especially other alpha blockers, blood pressure medicines, medicines for erectile dysfunction, azole antifungals, macrolide antibiotics, and hiv protease inhibitors. avoid driving or hazardous tasks until you know how you respond. tell your eye surgeon before cataract or glaucoma surgery because of a risk of intraoperative floppy iris syndrome. seek urgent care for a prolonged painful erection lasting more than four hours. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take alfuzosin after a meal. avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice because they can raise alfuzosin levels. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, skip it and take your next dose after your next meal at the usual time. do not take two doses on the same day. what side effects can this medication cause? dizziness, headache, tiredness, nausea, and upper respiratory symptoms can occur. it may cause low blood pressure or fainting, palpitations, and in susceptible patients changes in heart rhythm. allergic reactions are uncommon but can be serious.

name: concizumab-mtci injection
instructions: important warning: concizumab may increase the risk of serious blood clots in veins and arteries including deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, heart attack, and stroke. the risk can be higher when used with certain other clotting factor products. seek urgent care for chest pain, shortness of breath, swelling or pain in a limb, sudden severe headache, vision changes, or neurologic deficits. why is this medication prescribed? concizumab is used for routine prophylaxis to reduce bleeding episodes in people with hemophilia a or hemophilia b with inhibitors. how should this medicine be used? concizumab is given as a subcutaneous injection after an initial loading period followed by maintenance dosing as directed by your specialist. you or a caregiver will be trained to prepare and inject the dose, rotate injection sites in the abdomen, thigh, or upper arm, and store and handle the medication properly. do not inject into areas that are bruised, tender, scarred, or with broken skin. keep a record of doses and bleeds, and use other hemostatic agents only under guidance from your hemophilia team. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about any history of blood clots, cardiovascular disease, liver disease, smoking, obesity, prolonged immobility, or use of estrogen containing products. do not use this medicine together with high or repeated doses of activated prothrombin complex concentrates or certain other procoagulant agents unless your specialist instructs you, because this can increase clot risk. inform all clinicians before surgery or dental procedures. learn when to hold and restart doses around procedures. report signs of allergic reaction such as hives, swelling, or breathing trouble. this medicine can affect some laboratory coagulation tests. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are required. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and take only the next scheduled dose. do not take two doses on the same day. if you are unsure, contact your hemophilia treatment center. what side effects can this medication cause? injection site redness, swelling, or pain, headache, rash, fever, and elevations in liver enzymes can occur. serious adverse events include blood clots in veins or arteries such as deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, heart attack, or stroke, and hypersensitivity reactions.

name: pemetrexed injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? pemetrexed is used to treat non small cell lung cancer that is not squamous and malignant pleural mesothelioma, often in combination with other medicines. how should this medicine be used? pemetrexed is given by a health care professional as an intravenous infusion on a repeating cycle. you will receive folic acid by mouth and vitamin b12 injections starting before the first dose and continuing during treatment, and a corticosteroid such as dexamethasone around each infusion to help reduce side effects. keep all laboratory appointments to monitor blood counts and kidney and liver function. avoid ibuprofen and some other nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs around the time of dosing if you have kidney impairment unless your clinician says it is safe. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about kidney or liver disease, prior chest radiation, fluid around the lungs, active infection, and all medicines and supplements. this medicine can lower blood counts and increase the risk of infection or bleeding. report fever, sore throat, unusual bruising, mouth sores, or shortness of breath. pemetrexed can cause severe skin reactions and lung inflammation. effective contraception is required during treatment and for a period after the last dose. do not receive live vaccines during treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take folic acid exactly as prescribed and stay well hydrated. there are no specific food restrictions, but avoid alcohol excess and consult your clinician before taking vitamins or herbal products. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an infusion appointment, contact your oncology clinic as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to make up a dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? fatigue, nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, constipation or diarrhea, mouth sores, rash or skin peeling, and changes in kidney or liver tests can occur. serious effects include low white blood cells red blood cells or platelets, severe skin reactions, shortness of breath or cough due to lung inflammation, and infusion reactions.

name: bacillus calmette-guerin bcg vaccine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bcg vaccine is used to help prevent tuberculosis in people at increased risk when vaccination is recommended. how should this medicine be used? it is administered by a health care professional as a single intradermal injection. follow your providers instructions for follow up. it is not used to treat active tuberculosis. what special precautions should i follow? do not receive bcg vaccine if you are significantly immunocompromised, have symptomatic hiv infection, are pregnant, have active tuberculosis, have a positive tuberculosis test, or have a severe skin infection at the injection site. tell your clinician about all medical conditions, medicines including immunosuppressants, and recent vaccinations. a small ulcer at the injection site is a common reaction. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no dietary restrictions are required. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a vaccination appointment, contact your clinic to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? injection site redness, swelling, and ulceration, nearby lymph node swelling, low grade fever, and fatigue can occur. very rarely a serious disseminated infection can occur, especially in people with immune system problems.

name: bacitracin ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bacitracin ophthalmic ointment is used to treat bacterial eye infections such as conjunctivitis and blepharitis. how should this medicine be used? wash your hands. tilt your head back, gently pull down the lower eyelid to create a pocket, and apply a thin ribbon of ointment into the pocket as prescribed. close your eye gently for one to two minutes. avoid touching the tip of the tube to the eye or any surface. do not wear contact lenses during treatment unless your clinician says it is safe. use for the full prescribed course. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about any allergy to bacitracin or other antibiotics and any eye conditions. stop and seek care if you have severe eye pain, vision changes, intense redness or swelling, or signs of an allergic reaction. do not use if the ointment is contaminated or discolored. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no dietary restrictions are required. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? mild burning or stinging, brief blurred vision after application, eye redness or irritation, eyelid itching or swelling, and allergic reactions may occur.

name: bacitracin topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bacitracin topical is used to prevent or treat minor skin infections in small cuts, scrapes, or burns. how should this medicine be used? clean the affected area gently and pat dry. apply a thin layer of ointment one to three times daily or as directed. you may cover with a sterile bandage if needed. use only on the skin. do not use in the eyes, inside the nose, or in the mouth. do not use on large areas, deep or puncture wounds, animal bites, or serious burns unless directed by a clinician. what special precautions should i follow? stop use and seek care if irritation, rash, or itching worsens or lasts more than one week, if the area develops swelling or drainage, or if you have signs of an allergic reaction such as hives, wheezing, or swelling of the face or throat. tell your clinician about any history of allergy to topical antibiotics such as neomycin, polymyxin, or bacitracin. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no dietary restrictions are required. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose when you remember. if it is close to the time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue with your regular schedule. what side effects can this medication cause? local redness, itching, or rash can occur. contact dermatitis and rare severe allergic reactions are possible.

name: baclofen
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? baclofen is used to relieve muscle spasticity caused by conditions such as multiple sclerosis or spinal cord injury or disease. an intrathecal form may be used for severe spasticity. how should this medicine be used? take the tablets or liquid by mouth exactly as prescribed, usually several times daily. your clinician may increase the dose gradually. do not stop this medicine suddenly. if you use an implanted pump for intrathecal baclofen, keep all refill appointments and follow pump instructions. what special precautions should i follow? baclofen can cause drowsiness, dizziness, and reduced coordination. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. avoid alcohol and other medicines that cause sedation unless your clinician approves. tell your clinician about kidney disease, seizures, mental health conditions, and pregnancy or breastfeeding. abrupt discontinuation especially of the intrathecal form can cause high fever, severe muscle stiffness, confusion, seizures, and organ failure. always taper under medical supervision. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are required, but avoid alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed oral dose as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time of your next dose. do not take two doses at once. if you miss an intrathecal pump refill or the pump alarms, contact your clinician immediately. what side effects can this medication cause? drowsiness, dizziness, weakness, fatigue, headache, nausea, constipation, and confusion can occur. it may lower blood pressure. rarely mood changes, hallucinations, seizures, respiratory depression, and severe withdrawal reactions can occur if it is stopped suddenly.

name: baloxavir marboxil
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? baloxavir marboxil is used to treat acute uncomplicated influenza in people who have had symptoms for no more than two days, and to prevent influenza after close contact exposure when prescribed. how should this medicine be used? take a single oral dose as prescribed based on body weight. swallow the tablets with water. take as soon as possible after symptoms start or after exposure. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, have a weakened immune system, have chronic medical conditions, or if you received or plan to receive a live attenuated influenza vaccine through the nose. this medicine can interact with products that contain polyvalent cations and this can reduce absorption. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take with or without food, but do not take the dose together with dairy products or with foods or supplements that contain significant amounts of calcium, iron, magnesium, zinc, or aluminum. avoid taking antacids, multivitamins, or laxatives that contain these minerals on the day you take baloxavir. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss the single dose, take it as soon as you remember. if you are unsure what to do or many hours have passed, contact your clinician for advice. do not take more than the prescribed single dose. what side effects can this medication cause? diarrhea, nausea, headache, bronchitis, cough, and common cold symptoms can occur. allergic reactions with rash, itching, or swelling are uncommon but require medical attention.

name: balsalazide
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? balsalazide is used to treat mild to moderate ulcerative colitis by reducing inflammation in the colon. it is a prodrug of mesalamine and helps induce and maintain remission of symptoms such as diarrhea and rectal bleeding. how should this medicine be used? take balsalazide by mouth exactly as directed, usually at the same times each day. swallow the capsules whole with water. if you cannot swallow capsules, your clinician may instruct you on opening the capsule and sprinkling the contents on applesauce, then swallowing right away and drinking water. do not crush or chew the granules. continue taking it even if you feel well and do not stop without talking to your doctor. what special precautions should i follow?if you have ever had an allergy to balsalazide, mesalamine, sulfasalazine, aspirin or other salicylates.if you have kidney disease, liver disease, a history of heart inflammation such as myocarditis or pericarditis, or blockage of the stomach or intestines. report new symptoms such as chest pain, shortness of breath, rash, severe abdominal pain, or bloody diarrhea. your doctor may monitor kidney and liver function.about all medicines you take including nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs and azathioprine or 6 mercaptopurine.if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no special dietary restrictions unless your doctor advises otherwise. take with food if it upsets your stomach and drink plenty of fluids to stay hydrated. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to the time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include headache, abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, joint pain, and fatigue. serious side effects can include kidney problems such as blood in the urine or swelling, liver problems such as yellowing of the skin or eyes, severe allergic reactions with rash or hives, chest pain or shortness of breath, and severe cramping or bloody stools. seek medical attention right away for severe or concerning symptoms.

name: bamlanivimab and etesevimab injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bamlanivimab and etesevimab are monoclonal antibodies that were authorized in some regions to treat mild to moderate covid 19 in non hospitalized patients who are at high risk for progression, or for post exposure prophylaxis when indicated. availability and authorization may vary based on circulating variants and local guidance. how should this medicine be used? this medicine is given by a healthcare professional as a single intravenous infusion. it should be administered as soon as possible after a positive test and within the time window specified by current guidance. you will be observed during and after the infusion for side effects. do not attempt to self administer. what special precautions should i follow? tell your healthcare provider about any history of allergy to monoclonal antibodies or any previous infusion reactions. inform your provider if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. tell your provider about all medicines and vaccines you have received or plan to receive and ask about timing of covid 19 vaccination or boosters. this medicine is not for patients who are hospitalized for covid 19 or require oxygen due to covid 19 unless current guidelines specifically recommend it. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary restrictions are required. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss or cannot attend your infusion appointment, contact your healthcare provider immediately to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? side effects may include nausea, dizziness, rash, itching, and infusion related reactions such as fever, chills, flushing, low or high blood pressure, wheezing, or shortness of breath. serious allergic reactions including anaphylaxis can occur and require immediate medical attention. worsening of covid 19 can still occur despite treatment, so seek medical care if your symptoms progress.

name: bamlanivimab injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bamlanivimab is a monoclonal antibody that was authorized in some regions for the treatment of mild to moderate covid 19 in non hospitalized patients at high risk of progression. authorization and availability have changed over time due to variant resistance and local guidance. how should this medicine be used? bamlanivimab is administered by a healthcare professional as a single intravenous infusion as soon as possible after diagnosis and within the recommended time window. you will be monitored during and after the infusion for side effects. do not self administer. what special precautions should i follow? tell your healthcare provider about any prior allergic reactions to monoclonal antibodies or infusion reactions, and if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. discuss your current medications and vaccines and ask about timing of covid 19 vaccination or boosters. this therapy is not for patients hospitalized due to covid 19 or requiring oxygen for covid 19 unless specifically recommended by current guidelines. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary restrictions are required. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss or cannot attend your infusion appointment, contact your healthcare provider immediately to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? side effects can include nausea, dizziness, rash, itching, and infusion related reactions such as fever, chills, flushing, changes in blood pressure, wheezing, or shortness of breath. serious allergic reactions including anaphylaxis can occur and require immediate medical attention. covid 19 can still worsen despite treatment, so seek care if symptoms progress.

name: baricitinib
instructions: important warning: baricitinib can increase the risk of serious infections that may lead to hospitalization or death, including tuberculosis, bacterial, viral, and fungal infections. you should be tested for latent tuberculosis and treated if needed before starting. it may increase the risk of cancer including lymphoma and lung cancer, major adverse cardiovascular events such as heart attack and stroke, blood clots including deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism, and death. use the lowest effective dose for the shortest duration needed and only in patients who have not responded adequately to other therapies when used for chronic inflammatory conditions.right away if you develop signs of infection such as fever, chills, cough, shortness of breath, weight loss, night sweats, painful skin lesions, or if you have chest pain, sudden weakness, trouble speaking, leg swelling, or sudden shortness of breath. why is this medication prescribed? baricitinib is used to treat adults with moderately to severely active rheumatoid arthritis who have had an inadequate response to other medicines, and to treat severe alopecia areata. it is also used in certain hospitalized adults with covid 19 who require supplemental oxygen or more intensive respiratory support, according to current guidelines. how should this medicine be used? take baricitinib by mouth once daily with or without food at the same time each day, exactly as prescribed. your dose may depend on your condition and kidney function. for rheumatoid arthritis and alopecia areata it is taken long term. for covid 19 it is used for a limited duration as directed in the hospital. do not use baricitinib with other janus kinase inhibitors, biologic disease modifying antirheumatic drugs, or potent immunosuppressants unless your doctor instructs you to do so. what special precautions should i follow? before starting,about current or chronic infections, tuberculosis exposure or testing history, diabetes, hiv, liver disease, kidney problems, blood clots, heart disease, high cholesterol, cancer history, smoking history, stomach or bowel problems, and any recent or planned vaccines. live vaccines should be avoided during treatment. your doctor will check blood counts, liver tests, kidney function, and lipids and will monitor for infection and blood clots.if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. limit alcohol to reduce liver strain and follow any diet plans your doctor recommends for your underlying condition. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember on the same day. if the next day is near or it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include upper respiratory tract infections, nausea, headache, acne, increases in cholesterol and liver enzymes, and mild changes in blood counts. serious side effects include serious infections such as tuberculosis and shingles, blood clots, heart attack, stroke, gastrointestinal perforation, cancers including lymphoma and lung cancer, low white blood cells or hemoglobin, liver problems, and severe allergic reactions. seek medical attention for signs of infection, chest pain, sudden shortness of breath, severe abdominal pain, or symptoms of stroke.

name: barium sulfate
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? barium sulfate is a contrast agent used during x rays or ct scans to help visualize the esophagus, stomach, and intestines. it outlines the digestive tract so your radiologist can see abnormalities. how should this medicine be used? barium sulfate is given by a healthcare professional by mouth or rectally during your imaging test. follow all preparation instructions provided by your radiology team which may include fasting or a specific liquid diet before the test. after the test you will be advised to drink plenty of fluids and may be given a laxative to help pass the barium. what special precautions should i follow?if you have ever had an allergic reaction to barium products or any component of the preparation. tell your clinician if you have difficulty swallowing, a risk of aspiration, severe constipation, bowel obstruction, perforation, severe inflammation of the bowel, recent gastrointestinal surgery, diverticulitis, severe bleeding, or a tracheoesophageal fistula, as barium may be contraindicated. tell your clinician if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. report any severe abdominal pain, inability to pass stool or gas, vomiting, fever, breathing difficulty after swallowing, or rectal bleeding after the procedure. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow the specific pre procedure diet given by your radiology team which may include fasting or clear liquids. after the procedure drink extra fluids and consider high fiber foods if recommended to help prevent constipation. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss your scheduled imaging appointment, contact the radiology department to reschedule. do not attempt to use barium products on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include a feeling of fullness, cramping, nausea, constipation, and pale stools for a day or two. serious complications are rare but can include severe constipation or impaction, bowel obstruction, perforation with peritonitis if leakage occurs, aspiration into the lungs with coughing or pneumonia, infection, and allergic reactions. seek immediate care if you develop severe abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, fever, inability to pass stool or gas, chest pain, or trouble breathing.

name: basiliximab injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? basiliximab is used with other medicines to prevent your body from rejecting a transplanted kidney. it works by blocking interleukin 2 receptors on activated t cells to reduce immune attack on the transplant. how should this medicine be used? basiliximab is given by a healthcare professional as an intravenous infusion. the usual schedule is two doses, the first within two hours before the transplant surgery and the second on day four after the transplant. you will be monitored during and after each infusion. what special precautions should i follow?about any history of allergy to basiliximab or mouse proteins and about all medicines you take. because you will be on multiple immunosuppressants, you have an increased risk of infections and certain cancers, so report fevers, chills, cough, painful urination, unexplained weight loss, new lumps, or night sweats promptly. avoid live vaccines during treatment andif you are pregnant, planning to become pregnant, or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions for basiliximab. follow the diet recommended by your transplant team, including food safety measures to reduce infection risk. what should i do if i forget a dose? dosing is coordinated by your transplant team. if an infusion is missed or delayed, contact your transplant team immediately for instructions. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include constipation, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, swelling, high blood pressure, headache, tremor, anemia, and insomnia. serious side effects can include severe allergic or infusion reactions with rash, wheezing, low blood pressure, or trouble breathing, and increased risk of infections or malignancies due to combined immunosuppression. seek immediate care for signs of an allergic reaction or severe infection.

name: becaplermin topical
instructions: important warning: an increased risk of death from cancer has been observed in patients who used three or more tubes of becaplermin gel. use the smallest amount needed for the shortest time necessary, and only for the approved indication. do not apply to areas where cancer is present and avoid use in patients with active malignancy unless the potential benefits outweigh the risks. why is this medication prescribed? becaplermin is a topical gel used to help heal lower extremity diabetic neuropathic ulcers that extend into the subcutaneous tissue and have adequate blood supply, when used together with good wound care such as offloading and regular debridement. it is not for pressure ulcers, venous stasis ulcers, or infected or ischemic wounds. how should this medicine be used? apply a thin layer once daily to the ulcer surface using the amount calculated by your clinician based on wound size, then cover with a saline moistened dressing followed by a secondary dressing. after about twelve hours remove the dressing, gently rinse to remove remaining gel, and re cover with a moistened dressing without adding more gel. continue daily as directed until the ulcer is closed or treatment is stopped by your clinician, usually not beyond twenty weeks. wash hands before and after use, avoid touching the tip to the wound or other surfaces, and store the gel refrigerated. what special precautions should i follow?if you have or have had any cancer and discuss the risks and benefits. do not apply to areas of known or suspected cancer.if you have signs of infection such as increasing redness, warmth, swelling, pus, or fever. keep the gel away from eyes, mouth, and nose. tell your clinician if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. maintain regular wound care visits and blood sugar control. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow your diabetes meal plan and any nutrition recommendations to support wound healing, including adequate protein and vitamins as advised by your clinician. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply it as soon as you remember that day. if it is almost time for your next scheduled application, skip the missed application and resume your usual schedule. do not apply extra gel to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? side effects can include redness, rash, burning, or pain at the application site, excessive granulation tissue, and wound infection. serious allergic reactions are possible. there is a potential increase in cancer related mortality with high cumulative use. seek medical attention for signs of severe allergy or spreading infection.

name: beclomethasone nasal spray
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? beclomethasone nasal spray is used to treat and prevent symptoms of seasonal or perennial allergic rhinitis and to help reduce nasal polyps by decreasing inflammation in the nasal passages. how should this medicine be used? use the spray exactly as directed, usually once or twice daily. prime the spray before first use and if it has not been used for the period stated in the product instructions. gently blow your nose, shake the bottle, insert the tip into a nostril while aiming slightly outward away from the septum, and press to spray while breathing in gently. repeat as directed for each nostril. clean the nozzle regularly. it may take several days to feel the full benefit, so use it consistently. do not exceed the maximum number of sprays prescribed. what special precautions should i follow?if you have recent nasal ulcers, injury, or surgery, as you may need to wait until healing occurs.if you have glaucoma or cataracts, tuberculosis, or untreated infections. long term or high dose use may rarely suppress adrenal function or slow growth in children, so growth should be monitored. avoid exposure to chickenpox or measles and contact your doctor promptly if exposed.if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are required. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is close to the time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use extra sprays to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include nasal irritation or dryness, sore throat, cough, headache, nosebleeds, and an unpleasant taste or smell. less common but serious effects include nasal septum perforation, slowed wound healing, thrush in the nose or throat, glaucoma, cataracts, and adrenal suppression. seek medical care for vision changes, severe nosebleeds, or signs of infection.

name: beclomethasone oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? beclomethasone oral inhalation is a corticosteroid used as a maintenance treatment to prevent and control asthma symptoms. it is not a rescue medicine for sudden breathing problems. how should this medicine be used? inhale the prescribed dose regularly, usually twice daily, exactly as directed. learn and use the correct inhaler technique and prime the inhaler before first use and if it has not been used for the period stated in the product instructions. after each use, rinse your mouth with water and spit to reduce the risk of thrush. do not exceed the prescribed dose and do not stop suddenly without your doctor’s advice. always keep a fast acting rescue inhaler with you for sudden symptoms. what special precautions should i follow?if you have current or recurrent infections, tuberculosis, glaucoma, cataracts, osteoporosis, adrenal problems, or liver disease. high doses or long term use may increase the risk of thrush, hoarseness, reduced bone mineral density, glaucoma, cataracts, and adrenal suppression. children using inhaled steroids should have growth monitored. seek medical care if you experience worsening breathing or paradoxical bronchospasm immediately after inhalation. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. your doctor may recommend adequate calcium and vitamin d intake to support bone health. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is close to the time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take extra puffs to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include sore throat, hoarseness, cough, headache, and oral thrush. serious effects include worsening breathing right after use, vision changes from glaucoma or cataracts, decreased bone density, adrenal suppression, and allergic reactions such as rash, swelling, or trouble breathing.

name: bedaquiline
instructions: important warning: bedaquiline has been associated with an increased risk of death compared with placebo in clinical trials and can cause qt interval prolongation that may lead to serious and potentially fatal heart rhythm problems. use only when the benefits are judged to outweigh the risks and in combination with other medicines for drug resistant tuberculosis. your doctor will monitor your heart rhythm with electrocardiograms and check electrolytes and liver tests. avoid other medicines that prolong the qt interval if possible and report palpitations, fainting, or dizziness right away. why is this medication prescribed? bedaquiline is used with other medicines to treat pulmonary multidrug resistant or rifampin resistant tuberculosis in appropriate patients. it works by blocking an enzyme needed by the tuberculosis bacteria to produce energy. how should this medicine be used? take bedaquiline by mouth with food exactly as prescribed. it is given on a specific schedule as part of a combination regimen designed by your tuberculosis specialist. do not skip doses and do not stop early even if you feel better. your doctor will perform regular blood tests and heart rhythm monitoring. what special precautions should i follow?if you have heart disease, a history of abnormal heart rhythms, long qt syndrome, low potassium or magnesium, liver disease, or if you drink alcohol. provide a complete list of your medicines including those that can affect heart rhythm or the liver and those that affect cyp3a such as certain antifungals, macrolide antibiotics, hiv medicines, rifamycins, anticonvulsants, and some antidepressants. avoid other qt prolonging drugs if possible.if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? always take bedaquiline with food to improve absorption. avoid grapefruit and seville oranges because they can increase bedaquiline levels. limit alcohol to reduce the risk of liver problems. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time for your next scheduled dose, in which case skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at the same time. because dosing schedules can vary over the course of therapy, contact your tuberculosis team for individualized instructions after any missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include nausea, joint pain, headache, and stomach pain. serious side effects include abnormal heart rhythms with palpitations or fainting, chest pain, dizziness, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, severe fatigue, and increased liver enzymes. seek medical attention right away for symptoms of heart rhythm problems or liver injury.

name: belantamab mafodotin-blmf injection
instructions: important warning: belantamab mafodotin can cause severe eye problems, including corneal changes, blurred vision, dry eyes, and loss of vision which may be permanent. you will need a complete eye examination before each dose and as directed afterward. this medicine is available only through a special safety program. tell your clinician right away if you notice any change in your vision, eye pain, or increased light sensitivity. use effective birth control because this medicine can harm an unborn baby. do not drive or operate machinery if your vision is affected. why is this medication prescribed? belantamab mafodotin is used to treat adults with multiple myeloma that has come back or did not respond to other treatments. how should this medicine be used? it is given by a health care professional as an intravenous infusion, usually once every three weeks. you will be monitored before each dose, including an eye exam, and the dose or schedule may be adjusted based on your test results and side effects. use lubricating eye drops as directed by your clinician, avoid wearing contact lenses unless your eye care professional approves, and keep all appointments for exams and infusions. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have any eye disease, use contact lenses, have bleeding problems, or have had low platelets. tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements you take. do not become pregnant and do not breastfeed during treatment and for the time your clinician advises after the last dose. report symptoms of infection, shortness of breath, unusual bruising or bleeding, or infusion reactions such as fever, chills, or rash. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions for this medicine. stay well hydrated unless your clinician gives you other instructions. what should i do if i forget a dose? call your treatment center as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to make up a missed infusion on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include changes in vision, dry eyes, eye irritation or pain, fatigue, nausea, fever, constipation or diarrhea, and decreased appetite. laboratory changes can include low platelets, anemia, and changes in kidney or liver tests. serious side effects can include severe eye injury with vision loss, severe thrombocytopenia with bleeding, infusion reactions, and serious infections.

name: belatacept injection
instructions: important warning: belatacept increases the risk of serious infections and certain cancers, including post transplant lymphoproliferative disorder, especially in the brain. it should be used only in patients who are epstein barr virus seropositive. it is not recommended for liver transplant patients due to increased risk of graft loss and death. you should be monitored for signs of infection, neurologic symptoms such as confusion or vision changes, and any new lumps or unexplained weight loss. why is this medication prescribed? belatacept helps prevent rejection of a transplanted kidney by lowering the activity of the immune system. how should this medicine be used? a health care professional gives it as an intravenous infusion on a specific schedule, starting at the time of transplant, followed by infusions during the first few months and then every four weeks for maintenance. it is used with other transplant medicines. keep all infusion and lab appointments. what special precautions should i follow? tell your transplant team about all infections you have now or recently had, and if you have tuberculosis, hepatitis b or c, hiv or other chronic infections. you will be tested for epstein barr virus antibodies before starting. avoid live vaccines. call your clinician for fever, cough, burning with urination, severe headache, confusion, weakness on one side, vision changes, new swollen glands, or any skin changes that worry you. use effective birth control and do not breastfeed unless your transplant team says it is safe. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions for belatacept. follow your transplant team’s instructions about food safety and food handling to reduce infection risk. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your transplant clinic right away to arrange a new infusion time. do not skip or delay without medical advice. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include anemia, headache, nausea, diarrhea, swelling in the legs, cough, and urinary tract infections. serious side effects include severe infections, post transplant lymphoproliferative disorder, other cancers, progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy, infusion reactions, and kidney problems related to rejection if doses are missed or other medicines are changed.

name: belimumab injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? belimumab is used with other medicines to treat adults and some children with systemic lupus erythematosus and to treat active lupus nephritis. it helps reduce disease activity by targeting a protein involved in b cell function. how should this medicine be used? belimumab is given either as an intravenous infusion in a clinic at regular intervals or as a subcutaneous injection at home once weekly using a prefilled autoinjector or syringe. your clinician will choose the method and schedule that is right for you. do not use it to treat severe active central nervous system lupus. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have an infection now or get infections often, or if you have tuberculosis, hepatitis b or c, or a history of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy. belimumab can cause infusion or injection reactions and can increase the risk of serious infections. it may also cause depression or suicidal thoughts. seek medical help right away if you have fever, chills, chest tightness, difficulty breathing, confusion, new or worsening depression, or self harm thoughts. avoid live vaccines during treatment. tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements you use. if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions for belimumab. maintain adequate hydration and follow any nutrition guidance provided for lupus or kidney involvement. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you self inject and miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember if it is within a few days, then resume your regular weekly schedule. if it has been more than one week, skip the missed dose and take your next dose on the usual day. if you receive infusions at a clinic, call to reschedule as soon as possible. do not take extra doses. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include nausea, diarrhea, fever, joint or muscle pain, headache, insomnia, and injection site reactions. serious side effects include severe infections, infusion reactions, allergic reactions with rash or swelling, low white blood cell counts, depression or suicidal thoughts, and rare brain infection called progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.

name: belinostat injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? belinostat is used to treat adults with relapsed or refractory peripheral t cell lymphoma. it works by blocking enzymes that affect how cancer cells grow and divide. how should this medicine be used? it is given by a health care professional as an intravenous infusion on days one through five of a 21 day cycle. treatment continues as long as it is effective and tolerated. your doses may be adjusted based on blood counts, liver tests, and side effects. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all your medical conditions, including liver disease, prior strong infections, and any bleeding problems. tell your clinician if you have a known ugt1a1 gene variant. this medicine can lower blood counts and increase the risk of infection and bleeding. report fever, sore throat, easy bruising, or unusual bleeding right away. use effective birth control during treatment and for the time your clinician advises after the last dose. do not breastfeed during treatment. tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements you use. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions, but limit alcohol to reduce stress on the liver unless your clinician tells you otherwise. stay well hydrated. what should i do if i forget a dose? call your clinic as soon as possible to arrange a new infusion time. do not attempt to receive an extra dose without guidance. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include fatigue, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, low appetite, fever, and cough. laboratory changes include low platelets, low white blood cells, anemia, and elevated liver enzymes. serious side effects include severe infections, sepsis, bleeding, liver problems, and allergic or infusion reactions.

name: belladonna alkaloid combinations and phenobarbital
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? this combination of anticholinergic belladonna alkaloids with phenobarbital is used to relieve cramping and pain in conditions such as irritable bowel syndrome and as adjunctive therapy for peptic ulcer disease. it reduces intestinal spasms and helps calm the nervous system. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth exactly as directed, usually several times daily. use the lowest effective dose for the shortest time needed. measure liquid doses carefully if you use an elixir. do not stop long term use suddenly because phenobarbital can cause withdrawal. your clinician may gradually lower your dose if you need to stop. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have glaucoma, urinary retention, enlarged prostate, bowel obstruction, severe colitis, myasthenia gravis, liver disease, lung disease, porphyria, a history of substance use disorder, depression, or seizures. this medicine can cause drowsiness, confusion, and decreased sweating. avoid driving or tasks that require alertness until you know how it affects you and avoid overheating in hot weather. do not drink alcohol and avoid other medicines that cause drowsiness unless approved by your clinician. many medicines can interact with phenobarbital. tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements you take. this medicine can harm an unborn baby and passes into breast milk. discuss risks if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? drink plenty of fluids and include fiber in your diet to help prevent constipation. avoid alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time for your next dose. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include dry mouth, blurred vision, constipation, difficulty urinating, rapid heartbeat, drowsiness, dizziness, and confusion. serious side effects include severe allergic reactions, heat stroke, severe constipation with abdominal swelling, difficulty breathing, fainting, rash or skin peeling, depression, and dependence with withdrawal symptoms if stopped suddenly.

name: belumosudil
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? belumosudil is used to treat chronic graft versus host disease in adults and children aged 12 years and older after failure of previous therapy. it works by blocking a signaling pathway involved in inflammation and fibrosis. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once daily with food at the same time each day. swallow tablets whole with water. if you vomit after a dose, do not take an extra tablet. your clinician may change your dose if you take certain other medicines. keep all lab appointments. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements you take, especially medicines that affect liver enzymes or stomach acid. belumosudil can interact with other medicines. it can cause liver test abnormalities and increase the risk of infections. report fever, chills, cough, shortness of breath, severe diarrhea, or yellowing of the skin or eyes. use effective birth control because this medicine can harm an unborn baby. do not breastfeed during treatment and for the time your clinician advises after the last dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take with food. avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice. do not use herbal products like st johns wort. stay well hydrated unless your clinician gives you other instructions. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you remember within about twelve hours, take it as soon as you remember. if more than twelve hours have passed, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, cough, headache, fatigue, swelling of the legs, and upper respiratory infections. laboratory changes can include increased liver enzymes, low phosphate, and increased blood sugar. serious side effects include severe infections, liver problems, and severe diarrhea or dehydration.

name: belzutifan
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? belzutifan is used to treat adults with von hippel lindau disease who need treatment for kidney cancer, brain or spinal cord hemangioblastomas, or pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors, and to treat some adults with advanced kidney cancer. it works by blocking hypoxia inducible factor 2 alpha, which helps slow tumor growth. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once daily at the same time each day, with or without food. swallow tablets whole. if you vomit after taking a dose, do not take an extra dose. your clinician may adjust the dose based on your blood counts, oxygen levels, and side effects. what special precautions should i follow? belzutifan can cause severe anemia and low oxygen levels. you will need regular blood tests and oxygen checks. tell your clinician right away if you feel very tired, lightheaded, short of breath, or if your lips or fingers look blue. tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements you take, because belzutifan can interact with other medicines and can reduce the effectiveness of hormonal birth control. use a reliable non hormonal birth control method during treatment and for one week after the last dose. this medicine can harm an unborn baby. do not breastfeed during treatment and for one week after the last dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. stay well hydrated unless your clinician gives you other instructions. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you remember on the same day, take the dose when you remember. if you do not remember until the next day, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the usual time. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include anemia, fatigue, shortness of breath, dizziness, headache, nausea, vomiting, constipation, and edema. serious side effects include severe anemia requiring transfusions, severe low oxygen levels, and embryo fetal toxicity.

name: bempedoic acid
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bempedoic acid is used to lower low density lipoprotein cholesterol in adults with cardiovascular disease or heterozygous familial hypercholesterolemia, often when statins are not tolerated or when additional lowering is needed. it may be used alone or with other cholesterol medicines. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once daily with or without food at the same time each day. swallow tablets whole. continue to take it even if you feel well, as high cholesterol usually has no symptoms. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have a history of tendon problems, gout, high uric acid, kidney disease, or liver disease. bempedoic acid can raise uric acid and rarely can cause tendon rupture, especially in older adults or those on steroids or fluoroquinolone antibiotics. report sudden joint pain, swelling, or bruising, or heel pain. tell your clinician about all medicines you take. doses of certain statins may need adjustment. if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding, discuss the benefits and risks. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow a cholesterol lowering diet as advised by your clinician, with reduced saturated fat and increased intake of fruits, vegetables, and whole grains. limit alcohol to help reduce the risk of gout and liver irritation. maintain a healthy weight and exercise as advised. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember on the same day. if you do not remember until the next day, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include upper respiratory symptoms, muscle spasms, back pain, abdominal pain, elevated liver enzymes, increased uric acid, and anemia. serious side effects include tendon rupture or injury, severe gout, and liver problems.

name: benazepril
instructions: important warning: medicines that act on the renin angiotensin system, including benazepril, can harm or cause death to an unborn baby when used during pregnancy. do not take this medicine if you are pregnant, and stop it as soon as possible if you become pregnant. why is this medication prescribed? benazepril is an angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor used to treat high blood pressure and to help protect the kidneys in some people with diabetes or protein in the urine. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once or twice daily as directed, with or without food, at the same times each day. your clinician may adjust your dose based on your blood pressure, kidney function, and blood tests. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have kidney disease, liver disease, diabetes, a history of angioedema, or dehydration. benazepril can cause low blood pressure, high potassium, kidney problems, and rare but serious swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat called angioedema. seek emergency care for swelling or trouble breathing. tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements you take. do not take aliskiren if you have diabetes, and do not use sacubitril valsartan with benazepril. if you are having surgery or dental procedures, tell the clinician you take benazepril. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid salt substitutes containing potassium and potassium supplements unless your clinician tells you to use them. limit high potassium foods if advised. maintain a consistent intake of sodium as instructed for blood pressure control, and limit alcohol. stay well hydrated. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to your next dose, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include cough, dizziness, headache, fatigue, and nausea. serious side effects include angioedema, severe low blood pressure, high potassium with muscle weakness or abnormal heartbeat, worsening kidney function, and liver problems.

name: benazepril and hydrochlorothiazide
instructions: important warning: medicines that act on the renin angiotensin system, including benazepril, can harm or cause death to an unborn baby when used during pregnancy. do not take this medicine if you are pregnant, and stop it as soon as possible if you become pregnant. why is this medication prescribed? this combination medicine contains benazepril, an angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor, and hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic. it is used to treat high blood pressure when one medicine alone is not enough. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once daily, preferably in the morning, with or without food. your clinician may adjust your dose based on your blood pressure, kidney function, electrolytes, and side effects. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have kidney or liver disease, gout, diabetes, lupus, or a history of angioedema. this medicine can cause low blood pressure, changes in electrolytes including potassium and sodium, kidney problems, and sensitivity to sunlight. the benazepril component can cause angioedema. seek emergency care for swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat or trouble breathing. tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements you take. avoid nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs unless approved. if you are having surgery, tell the clinician you take this medicine. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid salt substitutes containing potassium and potassium supplements unless your clinician tells you to use them. maintain a consistent sodium intake as instructed and stay well hydrated. limit alcohol. your clinician may advise specific guidance if you have gout or diabetes. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to your next dose, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the usual time. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include dizziness, cough, headache, increased urination, and weakness. laboratory changes can include low sodium, changes in potassium, increases in uric acid, and changes in kidney function. serious side effects include angioedema, severe low blood pressure, severe electrolyte imbalance with abnormal heartbeat or confusion, worsening kidney function, severe rash, and eye pain that could indicate a sudden increase in eye pressure.

name: bendamustine injection
instructions: important warning: bendamustine can cause severe and sometimes life threatening decreases in white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets, which raises the risk of serious infections and bleeding. serious infusion and allergic reactions including anaphylaxis can occur, sometimes after the second or later cycles. severe skin reactions including stevens johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis have been reported. tumor lysis syndrome can occur early in treatment and may lead to kidney failure and abnormal electrolytes. rare cases of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy have occurred. this medicine can harm an unborn baby and may impair fertility. avoid live vaccines during treatment. you will need close monitoring with blood tests and clinical checks. why is this medication prescribed? bendamustine is a chemotherapy medicine used to treat certain blood cancers such as chronic lymphocytic leukemia and indolent non hodgkin lymphoma and may be used for other cancers as directed by your oncologist. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion by a health care professional on specific days of a treatment cycle, often every three or four weeks, with dose and schedule based on your diagnosis, body size, and other medicines. infusions usually run over thirty to sixty minutes. your team may give premedications and may prescribe medicines and extra fluids to lower the risk of tumor lysis syndrome. attend all appointments and follow your treatment plan exactly. what special precautions should i follow?about all of your medical conditions including infections, low blood counts, liver or kidney disease, heart problems, prior cancer treatments, and any history of severe rash with chemotherapy. list all medicines, vitamins, and herbal products; some medicines can increase side effects or change how bendamustine is processed, including certain antidepressants such as fluvoxamine and other treatments you receive for cancer. avoid live vaccines and close contact with people who recently received a live vaccine. use effective contraception during treatment and for a period after the last dose as directed by your doctor; do not breastfeed. report fever, chills, sore throat, unusual bruising or bleeding, new or worsening cough or shortness of breath, confusion, new rash or peeling skin, or any severe or persistent nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. your doctor may recommend drinking extra fluids around treatment days to reduce the risk of tumor lysis syndrome. limit alcohol because it can worsen liver irritation and dehydration. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given in a clinic. if you miss an infusion appointment, contact your oncology team right away to reschedule and to receive instructions. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include low blood counts, infections, tiredness, fever, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea or constipation, decreased appetite, mouth sores, headache, rash or itching, and infusion related reactions such as chills, flushing, or shortness of breath. it can raise liver enzymes and cause swelling. serious effects include severe allergic reactions, tumor lysis syndrome, severe skin reactions with blistering or peeling, severe infections including pneumonia or sepsis, progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy with neurologic symptoms, and organ problems such as liver failure. seek emergency help for signs of severe reaction, severe rash, chest pain, trouble breathing, confusion, or fainting.

name: benralizumab injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? benralizumab is an add on maintenance treatment for severe eosinophilic asthma to help reduce exacerbations and improve control. it is not a rescue medicine for sudden breathing problems. how should this medicine be used? it is given as a subcutaneous injection, usually thirty milligrams once every four weeks for the first three doses and then once every eight weeks. it may be administered by a health care professional or you may be trained to self inject using a prefilled syringe or autoinjector into the thigh, abdomen, or the back of the upper arm if someone else gives the injection. do not use it to treat an acute asthma attack. if you are on oral or inhaled corticosteroids, do not stop them suddenly; any decrease must be gradual under medical supervision. what special precautions should i follow?about all allergies and if you have a parasitic worm infection; treat any parasitic infection before starting.about all medicines you take and about pregnancy or breastfeeding. watch for signs of allergic reactions such as rash, hives, swelling, dizziness, or trouble breathing; seek help if these occur. if asthma symptoms suddenly worsen, use your rescue inhaler and seek medical care. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. what should i do if i forget a dose? inject a missed dose as soon as you remember and then resume your usual schedule. if you are unsure how to adjust the schedule, contact your prescriber for advice. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, sore throat, fever, and injection site redness or pain. serious effects can include hypersensitivity reactions including anaphylaxis. rarely, parasitic infections may persist or worsen. seek medical help for signs of severe reaction or breathing that is getting worse despite treatment.

name: bentoquatam topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bentoquatam is a barrier lotion used to help prevent allergic skin reactions from poison ivy, poison oak, and poison sumac by blocking contact with urushiol oil. it does not treat an existing rash. how should this medicine be used? apply a generous, even film to clean, dry skin at least fifteen minutes before potential exposure. reapply at least every four hours while exposure continues and after heavy sweating or washing. after you finish outdoor activity, wash the skin with soap and water to remove the lotion and any plant oil. do not apply to broken or oozing skin. what special precautions should i follow? for external use only. avoid contact with eyes, mouth, and inside the nose. do not inhale spray or aerosols if applicable.if you have very sensitive skin or a history of allergic reactions to topical products, and if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. keep out of reach of children. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you have been exposed and more than about four hours have passed since your last application, reapply as soon as possible before further exposure. if the lotion has been washed off, reapply. what side effects can this medication cause? mild and temporary skin dryness, tightness, or irritation may occur. stop use and consult a clinician if you develop significant redness, itching, swelling, blistering, or a rash.

name: benzgalantamine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? benzgalantamine is a cholinesterase inhibitor used to help improve memory, awareness, and ability to perform daily functions in people with mild to moderate alzheimer disease. how should this medicine be used? it is taken by mouth as immediate release tablets or oral solution two times daily with morning and evening meals, or as extended release capsules once daily in the morning with food. doses are started low and increased gradually, usually at minimum four week intervals, to reduce stomach side effects. swallow extended release capsules whole and do not crush or chew them. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about stomach ulcers or bleeding, slow heart rate, heart rhythm problems, fainting, asthma or chronic obstructive lung disease, seizures, urinary obstruction, liver or kidney disease, and any surgery requiring anesthesia. list all medicines including anticholinergics, beta blockers, nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs, and other drugs that can slow heart rate or increase bleeding risk. tell your clinician if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. if you have severe nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, fainting, severe dizziness, black stools, or vomiting blood, seek medical care. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take doses with food and plenty of fluids to reduce stomach upset. limit alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose when you remember unless it is close to the next dose, in which case skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at the same time. if you miss several days in a row, contact your prescriber before restarting because you may need to resume at a lower dose. what side effects can this medication cause? nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, decreased appetite and weight loss, dizziness, headache, tremor, sweating, tiredness, sleep problems, and runny nose are common. serious effects include slow heart rate, fainting, seizures, gastrointestinal bleeding, and severe allergic skin reactions.

name: benzhydrocodone and acetaminophen
instructions: important warning: this medicine contains an opioid. opioids carry risks of addiction, abuse, and misuse that can lead to overdose and death. serious and life threatening breathing problems can occur, especially when starting, after a dose increase, or when used with other medicines that depress the central nervous system such as benzodiazepines, sleep medicines, muscle relaxants, antipsychotics, or alcohol. accidental ingestion, especially by a child, can result in a fatal overdose. use during pregnancy can cause neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome in a newborn. concomitant use with medicines that affect certain liver enzymes can lead to dangerous increases or decreases in opioid levels. this product also contains acetaminophen, which can cause severe liver injury including liver failure and death at high doses. do not exceed the total daily acetaminophen limit from all sources. keep this medicine in a secure place and out of reach of children, and have naloxone available if at risk for overdose. why is this medication prescribed? it is used for the short term management of acute pain severe enough to require an opioid when other pain treatments do not control the pain well enough or cannot be tolerated. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as prescribed, using the lowest effective dose for the shortest possible time. dosing is usually every four to six hours as needed for pain. swallow tablets whole and do not crush, chew, dissolve, or inject them. do not share this medicine with anyone. if your pain is not controlled, contact your prescriber; do not increase your dose on your own. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medical conditions including breathing problems, sleep apnea, head injury, seizures, liver or kidney disease, gallbladder or pancreatic disease, low blood pressure, mental health conditions, constipation, or bowel obstruction. provide a full list of medicines and supplements, especially benzodiazepines, sedatives, sleep medicines, muscle relaxants, antidepressants, antipsychotics, other opioids, and any product that contains acetaminophen. avoid alcohol and recreational drugs. do not drive or perform tasks that require alertness until you know how this medicine affects you. use stool softeners, fiber, fluids, and activity as advised to prevent constipation. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and alternatives. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid alcohol. check all over the counter and prescription products to ensure you do not exceed the daily acetaminophen limit, which is generally no more than four thousand milligrams per day for most adults, and your prescriber may recommend an even lower limit. you may take doses with food if you have stomach upset and drink adequate fluids to help prevent constipation. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you take it on a regular schedule and miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember if there is enough time before the next dose. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. if you take it only as needed, take the next dose when you need pain relief, following the prescribed interval. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include constipation, nausea, vomiting, drowsiness, dizziness, lightheadedness, and itching. serious effects include slow or shallow breathing, extreme sleepiness, confusion, fainting, low blood pressure, adrenal problems, severe allergic reactions, and liver injury manifested by yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, severe nausea, or right upper abdominal pain. seek emergency help for signs of overdose or severe breathing problems.

name: benznidazole
instructions: important warning: benznidazole can cause serious allergic and skin reactions, peripheral neuropathy that may be irreversible, blood problems including low white blood cells and anemia, and liver irritation. it can harm an unborn baby and should not be used during pregnancy. carcinogenicity has been seen in animal studies. do not drink alcohol during treatment and for at least three days after the last dose because a severe reaction can occur. do not breastfeed during treatment and for at least five days after the last dose. why is this medication prescribed? benznidazole treats chagas disease, also called american trypanosomiasis, caused by trypanosoma cruzi. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth two times daily with food. the dose is based on body weight and is usually given for sixty days. swallow tablets with water. if a pediatric dispersible tablet is prescribed, follow the mixing instructions carefully. take the full course even if you feel better. what special precautions should i follow?
