tell your clinician about allergies to benznidazole or other nitroimidazole medicines, any history of peripheral neuropathy, blood disorders, liver or kidney disease, or alcohol use disorder. provide a full list of medicines. avoid alcohol and products containing alcohol during therapy and for at least three days after the last dose. women should have a pregnancy test before starting and use effective contraception during treatment and for a short period after the last dose as directed by the prescriber. stop the medicine and seek medical care if you develop numbness or tingling in hands or feet, severe rash or blistering, fever, sore throat, unusual bruising or bleeding, persistent nausea or vomiting, dark urine, or yellowing of the skin or eyes. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take doses with food to reduce stomach upset. do not drink alcohol during therapy and for at least three days after finishing. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember the same day. if it is close to the time of the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. if you miss more than one dose, contact your prescriber. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include rash, itching, sensitivity to sunlight, headache, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, decreased appetite, weight loss, metallic taste, insomnia, and abdominal pain. serious effects include severe skin reactions, peripheral neuropathy with burning or numbness, low white blood cells or anemia leading to infections or fatigue, and liver injury.

name: benzonatate
instructions: important warning: accidental ingestion, especially by children, can be fatal within a short time. keep this medicine in child resistant packaging and out of reach and sight of children at all times. swallow capsules whole. chewing, sucking, or dissolving the capsules can cause severe mouth and throat numbness, choking, seizures, and life threatening reactions. why is this medication prescribed? benzonatate is used to relieve cough due to colds, bronchitis, pneumonia, or other conditions. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth as directed, usually one hundred to two hundred milligrams three times daily as needed for cough. swallow capsules whole with a full glass of water. do not break, crush, chew, or dissolve the capsules. do not take more often than prescribed. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you are allergic to benzonatate or to related local anesthetics such as tetracaine or procaine. inform your clinician about breathing problems, and all medicines and supplements you take, especially those that make you drowsy such as alcohol, benzodiazepines, sleep medicines, and other sedatives. do not drive or perform tasks that require alertness until you know how it affects you. this medicine is not approved for young children; store it safely. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. avoid alcohol, which can increase drowsiness. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you are taking it on a schedule, take the missed dose when you remember unless it is close to the next dose. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. if you use it only as needed, take it when you need relief, following the prescribed interval. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include drowsiness, dizziness, headache, nausea, constipation, stuffy nose, and mild sedation. serious effects include confusion, hallucinations, restlessness, tremors, seizures, severe allergic reactions, choking, and bronchospasm. seek immediate help if severe symptoms occur.

name: benztropine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? benztropine is used to treat symptoms of parkinson disease and to prevent or treat movement problems such as dystonia or parkinsonism caused by antipsychotic medicines. how should this medicine be used? it is taken by mouth once or twice daily as directed, or given by injection by a health care professional for acute reactions. the dose is individualized. you may take it with or without food; taking with food or milk can reduce stomach upset. do not stop suddenly unless your clinician tells you to do so. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have glaucoma, urinary retention, prostate enlargement, bowel obstruction or severe constipation, myasthenia gravis, heart disease, fast heartbeat, or cognitive problems. this medicine can reduce sweating and raise the risk of heat stroke; avoid overheating, drink fluids, and use caution in hot weather. older adults are more sensitive to confusion and memory problems. alcohol and other sedating medicines can increase drowsiness. provide a full list of your medicines, especially other anticholinergics, antihistamines, tricyclic antidepressants, and antipsychotics. what special dietary instructions should i follow? maintain good hydration and fiber intake to help prevent constipation. limit alcohol. there are no specific food restrictions. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose when you remember unless it is close to your next dose, in which case skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include dry mouth, blurred vision, constipation, nausea, decreased sweating, urinary retention, drowsiness, dizziness, and fast heartbeat. serious effects include confusion, hallucinations, memory difficulties, eye pain or vision changes suggesting glaucoma, severe constipation, inability to urinate, and heat related illness with high body temperature.

name: benzyl alcohol topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? benzyl alcohol topical lotion is used to treat head lice. it works by suffocating lice and does not kill unhatched eggs, so a second treatment is needed. some products containing benzyl alcohol are also used as topical antiseptics. how should this medicine be used? for head lice, apply to dry hair and scalp to completely saturate the hair and scalp, leave on for ten minutes, and then rinse well with water. repeat the treatment in seven days to kill newly hatched lice. use a fine toothed comb to remove nits after each treatment. avoid contact with eyes, mouth, and mucous membranes. for external use only. what special precautions should i follow? do not use on infants younger than six months because serious and potentially fatal toxicity has occurred with benzyl alcohol exposure in very young infants. do not use on irritated or open skin. keep out of reach of children. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, consult your clinician before use. avoid flames and smoking while the hair is wet with product if the formulation contains alcohol. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you forget the second application, apply it as soon as you remember and then contact your clinician for advice about the timing of any further steps. do not apply more often than directed. what side effects can this medication cause? mild scalp irritation, redness, itching, or tingling can occur. eye irritation can occur if the product gets into the eyes. rarely, allergic reactions may occur; stop use and seek care if you have significant swelling, rash, or trouble breathing.

name: bepotastine ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bepotastine eye drops are used to relieve itching of the eyes caused by allergic conjunctivitis. how should this medicine be used? instill one drop into the affected eye or eyes two times daily, about eight to twelve hours apart. wash hands before use. do not touch the dropper tip to your eye or any surface. remove contact lenses before using; you may reinsert them after ten minutes. do not wear contact lenses if your eyes are red. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have eye infections, wear contact lenses, or have had allergic reactions to antihistamines. if you develop eye pain, vision changes, persistent redness, or worsening irritation, stop using the drops and seek medical advice. use in pregnancy or breastfeeding only if clearly needed. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use extra drops to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? mild eye irritation or burning after instillation, headache, and an unusual taste after use can occur. eye redness or discomfort may happen. rarely, allergic reactions can occur; get help if you have swelling of the eyelids, severe redness, or trouble breathing.

name: berdazimer topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? berdazimer topical is used to treat molluscum contagiosum, a viral skin infection that causes small raised lesions, in adults and in children as directed by a clinician. it helps clear individual lesions over time. how should this medicine be used? apply a thin layer to each visible molluscum lesion exactly as prescribed, usually once daily for a treatment course that often lasts up to twelve weeks. treat only the lesions and avoid the surrounding healthy skin. wash hands before and after applying and avoid contact with the eyes, inside the nose or mouth, and genital mucosa. do not cover with airtight dressings unless your clinician tells you to do so. do not use on open wounds that are not molluscum lesions. if severe irritation occurs stop use and contact your clinician. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have ever had an allergic reaction to any topical medicines or skincare products. inform your clinician if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding. do not use on or near the eyes and do not share this medication with others. avoid using other skin products that can irritate, such as harsh cleansers or acids, on the same areas unless approved by your clinician. protect treated skin from excessive sun exposure and use sunscreen as advised. if signs of secondary infection such as increasing pain, pus, fever, or spreading redness occur seek medical care. keep out of reach of children. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply it as soon as you remember that same day. if it is almost time for the next scheduled dose skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include mild to moderate redness, itching, stinging or burning, dryness, swelling, crusting, and flaking at application sites. these are usually temporary. less common effects include skin discoloration or cracking. stop the medicine and seek medical help right away for signs of a severe allergic reaction such as hives, swelling of the face lips tongue or throat, trouble breathing, or severe widespread rash.

name: beremagene geperpavec-svdt
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? beremagene geperpavec svdt is a topical gene therapy used to help heal wounds in people with dystrophic epidermolysis bullosa caused by mutations in the col7a1 gene. it delivers a functional copy of the gene locally to promote production of type seven collagen and improve wound healing. how should this medicine be used? it is applied to eligible wounds by a trained health care professional, typically once weekly. the gel is placed directly on the wound using sterile technique and the area is covered with a suitable dressing as instructed. if you or a caregiver are trained to assist with dressing changes follow all handling, application, and disposal instructions carefully, wash hands and wear gloves, and avoid contact with eyes, nose, and mouth. keep treated wounds covered as instructed. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about any history of allergies, fever, or infection. let your clinician know if you are pregnant, planning to become pregnant, or breastfeeding. because the product uses a modified herpes simplex virus type one vector there may be a risk of viral shedding. caregivers should use universal precautions including gloves, dispose of used materials safely, and avoid direct contact with treated wounds or dressings. do not apply to actively infected wounds until the infection is controlled. contact your clinician if you develop fever, chills, rash, breathing problems, new or worsening wound pain, or signs of infection. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. what should i do if i forget a dose? this therapy is scheduled by your clinic. if you miss an appointment contact your treatment team as soon as possible to reschedule. do not attempt to self apply unless your clinician has trained and instructed you to do so. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include itching at the application site, chills, fever, flu like symptoms, rash, and cough. other effects can include wound pain or infection. serious allergic reactions are uncommon but can occur. seek emergency care if you have hives, swelling of the face lips tongue or throat, wheezing, or trouble breathing.

name: besifloxacin ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? besifloxacin eye drops are prescribed to treat bacterial conjunctivitis, also known as pink eye. how should this medicine be used? instill one drop into the affected eye or eyes three times a day for seven days or as directed. wash your hands before and after use. do not touch the dropper tip to any surface including the eye or eyelids. remove contact lenses before using and do not wear contact lenses while you have signs of eye infection. tilt your head back, pull down the lower eyelid to make a small pocket, place a drop, then gently close your eyes. you may gently press the inner corner of your eye for one to two minutes to reduce drainage into the nose. use for the full prescribed time even if symptoms improve. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have ever had an allergy to quinolone antibiotics or any eye medication. stop the drops and seek care if you develop a rash, severe eye irritation, or signs of an allergic reaction. avoid contaminating the dropper. this medication may cause temporary blurred vision or discomfort after instillation so use caution before driving or operating machinery. prolonged use can lead to overgrowth of non susceptible organisms including fungi so use only as prescribed. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. what should i do if i forget a dose? use the missed dose as soon as you remember that same day. if it is almost time for your next dose skip the missed dose and return to your regular schedule. do not use extra drops to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include temporary eye irritation, redness, itching, tearing, and blurred vision. headache may occur. serious but uncommon effects include severe eye pain, swelling, vision changes, or allergic reactions such as hives or swelling. if these occur stop the medicine and seek medical help.

name: betaine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? betaine anhydrous is used with other treatments to lower high homocysteine levels in people with homocystinuria due to cystathionine beta synthase deficiency, mthfr deficiency, or cobalamin metabolism defects. lowering homocysteine helps reduce the risk of complications such as blood clots, bone problems, and vision issues. how should this medicine be used? betaine is an oral powder. measure each dose using the provided scoop and mix with water, juice, milk, formula, or soft food immediately before taking. it is usually taken twice daily or as directed. take it consistently at the same times each day. your clinician will adjust the dose based on body weight and blood test results. continue other prescribed vitamins or cofactors such as vitamin b six, vitamin b twelve, and folate if directed. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medical conditions and all medicines and supplements you take. betaine can raise methionine levels, which in rare cases has been associated with brain swelling, especially when methionine becomes very high. your clinician will monitor homocysteine and methionine regularly and may adjust your diet or dose. seek medical help right away if you develop severe headache, vomiting, visual changes, confusion, seizures, or sudden neurologic symptoms. if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding discuss risks and benefits with your clinician. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow the prescribed methionine restricted and protein managed diet and any special medical foods provided by your metabolic team. ensure adequate vitamin intake and hydration. do not change your diet without guidance, since diet works together with betaine to control amino acid levels. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember that same day. if it is almost time for the next dose skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take extra doses to make up for a missed one. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include stomach upset, nausea, diarrhea, loss of appetite, and a fishy body or breath odor. lab tests may show increased methionine. serious effects are uncommon but can include signs of brain swelling such as severe headache, vomiting, vision changes, confusion, or seizures. contact your clinician if you have persistent gastrointestinal symptoms or any concerning effects.

name: betamethasone topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? topical betamethasone is a corticosteroid used to reduce redness, swelling, and itching in inflammatory skin conditions that respond to steroids such as eczema, dermatitis, and some forms of psoriasis. how should this medicine be used? apply a thin film to the affected skin once or twice daily or as directed. use the smallest amount needed to control symptoms. gently rub in until it disappears. wash your hands after applying unless you are treating the hands. do not apply to the eyes or eyelids, inside the nose or mouth, or to the groin or underarms unless directed. avoid covering the area with tight or waterproof dressings unless your clinician tells you to do so. limit use on large areas or for long durations, especially in children. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have skin infections, rosacea, acne, or poor circulation in the affected area. do not use on untreated skin infections. prolonged or extensive use can increase absorption and may suppress adrenal gland function, raise blood sugar, thin the skin, or cause stretch marks. children are more susceptible to side effects. tell your clinician if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. if irritation, worsening redness, or signs of infection occur stop using and contact your clinician. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply it as soon as you remember that same day. if it is almost time for your next dose skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include burning, stinging, dryness, itching, and skin thinning with prolonged use. other effects may include acne like eruptions, visible blood vessels, changes in skin color, stretch marks, and excessive hair growth at the application site. rare but serious effects include signs of adrenal suppression such as unusual fatigue, dizziness, or fainting and eye problems if the medicine contacts the eyes.

name: betaxolol
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? betaxolol is a beta blocker used to treat high blood pressure, which helps reduce the risk of stroke, heart attack, and kidney problems. how should this medicine be used? take betaxolol by mouth once daily at the same time each day or as directed. swallow the tablet with water. your clinician will adjust the dose based on your response and heart rate and blood pressure readings. do not stop taking betaxolol suddenly unless your clinician tells you to do so. stopping abruptly can worsen chest pain or cause heart attack in people with heart disease. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have asthma or chronic lung disease, slow heart rate, heart block, heart failure, circulation problems, diabetes, thyroid disease, kidney or liver disease, depression, or a history of severe allergic reactions. betaxolol can slow the heart rate and lower blood pressure. it can mask symptoms of low blood sugar such as fast heartbeat. use caution if you also take other medicines that slow the heart rate or lower blood pressure. if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding discuss risks and benefits with your clinician. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow any blood pressure diet plan recommended by your clinician, such as limiting sodium and alcohol. maintain adequate hydration. check before using over the counter cold medicines or herbal stimulants as some can raise blood pressure or heart rate. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember that same day. if it is almost time for your next dose skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include tiredness, dizziness, lightheadedness, slow heart rate, low blood pressure, and cold hands or feet. other effects can include trouble sleeping, depression, sexual dysfunction, shortness of breath, or wheezing. seek medical help if you faint, have severe dizziness, very slow heartbeat, chest pain that worsens, or trouble breathing.

name: betaxolol ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? betaxolol eye drops lower pressure inside the eye in people with open angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension and help reduce the risk of vision loss. how should this medicine be used? instill one drop into the affected eye or eyes twice daily or as directed. if you use the suspension shake the bottle well before each dose. wash your hands before and after use. do not touch the dropper tip to any surface including the eye. remove contact lenses before using and wait at least fifteen minutes before reinserting them. after placing the drop gently close your eyes and press a finger at the inner corner of the eye for one to two minutes to reduce drainage into the nose. if you use other eye medicines wait at least five minutes between products and use eye drops before eye ointments. use as prescribed every day for best effect. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have asthma or chronic lung disease, slow heart rate, heart block, heart failure, circulation problems, diabetes, thyroid disease, or if you are taking an oral beta blocker or other eye pressure medications. even though betaxolol is relatively selective it can be absorbed and affect the heart and lungs. use caution if you drive or do tasks requiring clear vision until you know how the drops affect you. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it as soon as you remember that same day. if it is almost time for your next dose skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use extra drops to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include eye irritation, burning or stinging, blurred vision, tearing, and light sensitivity. systemic effects can include slow heart rate, low blood pressure, dizziness, fatigue, or shortness of breath. seek medical help if you experience wheezing, fainting, severe eye pain, or sudden changes in vision.

name: bethanechol
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bethanechol is used to treat urinary retention due to bladder atony by stimulating bladder muscle contractions to help empty the bladder. how should this medicine be used? take bethanechol by mouth on an empty stomach, one hour before or two hours after meals to reduce stomach upset. it is usually taken several times a day as directed. your clinician may start with a low dose and increase based on your response. take it at the same times each day. what special precautions should i follow? do not take bethanechol if you have a blockage of the bladder or urinary tract, gastrointestinal obstruction, an active peptic ulcer, recent bladder or intestinal surgery, uncontrolled asthma, slow heart rate or low blood pressure, coronary artery disease, epilepsy, or overactive thyroid unless your clinician has determined it is safe. tell your clinician about all medicines you take, especially other drugs that increase acetylcholine such as cholinesterase inhibitors, as well as blood pressure medications. this medicine can cause drops in blood pressure and heart rate and can trigger bronchospasm. use caution when standing up and avoid driving until you know how it affects you. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding discuss use with your clinician. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take on an empty stomach as directed and maintain adequate hydration unless you have been told to limit fluids. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember that same day. if it is almost time for your next dose skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, stomach cramps, increased salivation, sweating, flushing, headache, dizziness, and a feeling of warmth. it can also cause low blood pressure, slow heart rate, and shortness of breath. signs of too much cholinergic effect include severe abdominal cramping, drooling, sweating, blurred vision, severe dizziness, wheezing, or fainting. seek medical attention if these occur.

name: betibeglogene autotemcel injection
instructions: important warning: serious blood cancers have occurred with gene therapies that use related vectors. there is a potential risk of developing hematologic malignancy after receiving betibeglogene autotemcel. you will need lifelong monitoring with blood counts and evaluations if there are concerning findings. the product contains dimethyl sulfoxide which can cause serious allergic reactions including anaphylaxis. conditioning chemotherapy is required before infusion and carries its own risks including severe low blood counts, infections, liver injury, and infertility. do not donate blood, organs, or tissues after receiving this therapy. why is this medication prescribed? betibeglogene autotemcel is a one time autologous gene therapy for people with transfusion dependent beta thalassemia. the therapy adds a functional gene to your own blood stem cells to increase hemoglobin production and reduce or eliminate the need for red blood cell transfusions. how should this medicine be used? this treatment is given only in specialized centers. your own stem cells are collected, modified in a laboratory, and then infused back into your bloodstream after you receive conditioning chemotherapy to make space in the bone marrow. you will be monitored closely in the hospital and after discharge for side effects, infections, and response to treatment. follow all instructions about vaccinations, infection prevention, and when to call the treatment team. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinicians about all medical conditions and all medicines you take. conditioning chemotherapy can harm an unborn baby and may affect fertility. use effective contraception during treatment and for the period your team recommends. do not receive live vaccines around the time of conditioning and until your immune system has recovered. you will need regular blood tests and long term monitoring for blood cancer and other complications. inform clinicians immediately if you develop fever, unusual bruising or bleeding, persistent fatigue, shortness of breath, chest pain, severe abdominal pain, jaundice, severe headache, or any new lumps or swollen glands. what special dietary instructions should i follow? eat a balanced diet as tolerated during treatment. your care team may recommend food safety precautions to lower infection risk and will guide you on hydration and supplements during recovery. avoid alcohol if your liver is affected and follow any restrictions provided by your center. what should i do if i forget a dose? this therapy is scheduled and administered by your treatment center. if you miss any appointment for cell collection, conditioning, or infusion contact the center immediately to reschedule and receive further instructions. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fever, tiredness, nausea, vomiting, mouth sores, constipation or diarrhea, appetite loss, bone or joint pain, and hair loss related to conditioning chemotherapy. serious effects include severe low blood counts with infection or bleeding, liver problems including veno occlusive disease, allergic or infusion reactions including anaphylaxis, blood clots, and the potential risk of hematologic malignancy. seek urgent care for high fever, uncontrolled bleeding, severe chest pain or shortness of breath, confusion, or other severe symptoms.

name: betrixaban
instructions: important warning: stopping betrixaban early increases the risk of blood clots that can cause stroke or other serious problems. do not stop taking it without talking to your clinician. betrixaban increases the risk of bleeding which can be serious or life threatening. there is a risk of bleeding in or around the spine when this medicine is used in patients who receive spinal or epidural anesthesia or undergo spinal puncture, which can lead to paralysis. tell your clinician right away if you have back pain, tingling, numbness, weakness in the legs, or loss of bladder or bowel control. why is this medication prescribed? betrixaban is an oral anticoagulant that helps prevent blood clots in certain adults who are hospitalized for acute medical illness and at risk of venous thromboembolism during and after their hospital stay. how should this medicine be used? take betrixaban exactly as prescribed, typically as a single larger first dose followed by a smaller dose once daily for a total treatment duration of about five to six weeks. take it at the same time each day with food and swallow the capsules whole with water. your clinician may adjust the dose if you have reduced kidney function or if you are taking certain interacting medicines. do not skip doses. if you need surgery, an invasive procedure, or a spinal or epidural injection tell all clinicians you are taking betrixaban and ask when to stop and restart it. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have kidney or liver disease, a history of bleeding problems or ulcers, recent surgery, spinal or epidural anesthesia, stroke, uncontrolled high blood pressure, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. provide a complete list of all medicines and supplements because many increase bleeding risk, including aspirin, clopidogrel and other antiplatelets, nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs like ibuprofen, other anticoagulants, and certain antibiotics and antiarrhythmics that affect p glycoprotein. seek medical help immediately for signs of bleeding such as unexpected bruising, nosebleeds, bleeding gums, coughing up blood, vomit that looks like coffee grounds, red or black stools, severe headache, dizziness, or weakness on one side. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take with food each day. there are no vitamin k restrictions with betrixaban. limit alcohol, which can increase bleeding risk. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember on the same day, then take your next scheduled dose the following day. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? the most common side effect is bleeding which can range from minor bruising or nosebleeds to serious internal bleeding. other effects can include anemia, upset stomach, and abnormal liver tests. serious effects include spinal or epidural bleeding with numbness or weakness, severe headache, vision changes, coughing or vomiting blood, black stools, and any bleeding that you cannot stop. seek urgent medical attention for signs of serious bleeding or stroke.

name: bevacizumab injection
instructions: important warning: bevacizumab can cause serious or fatal bleeding, holes or abnormal connections in the bowel or other organs, and severe problems with wound healing. do not receive this medicine for at least 28 days after surgery and until wounds are fully healed. it can cause very high blood pressure, blood clots, heart or brain events including stroke, kidney problems with protein in the urine, and a rare brain condition called posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome that can present with severe headache, confusion, seizures, or vision changes. seek urgent medical help for heavy bleeding, severe abdominal pain, chest pain, shortness of breath, severe headache, or neurologic symptoms. why is this medication prescribed? bevacizumab is used with other medications to treat various cancers by blocking vascular endothelial growth factor and reducing blood vessel growth that tumors need to grow and spread. how should this medicine be used? it is given by a health care professional as an intravenous infusion on a repeating schedule that is usually every two or three weeks depending on your cancer regimen. your blood pressure and urine will be monitored regularly and dosing may be delayed for uncontrolled blood pressure, recent surgery, or certain side effects. what special precautions should i follow?about high blood pressure, heart or blood vessel disease, prior strokes or clots, bleeding problems, recent or planned surgery or dental procedures, bowel disease, protein in the urine, headaches or vision problems, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. use effective birth control during treatment and for at least 6 months after the last dose for females and at least 3 months after the last dose for males with partners who can become pregnant. do not start or continue treatment around the time of surgery and avoid invasive procedures unless your oncology team approves. report any bleeding, severe headache, vision changes, confusion, abdominal pain, swelling, shortness of breath, or signs of infection right away. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions for this medicine. stay well hydrated and avoid alcohol excess. your doctor may advise limiting agents that increase bleeding risk. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given in a clinic. if you miss an appointment, contact your oncology team as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to self administer. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include high blood pressure, fatigue, headache, mouth sores, diarrhea or constipation, nosebleeds, and delayed wound healing. serious effects include severe bleeding, gastrointestinal perforation, fistulas, blood clots, heart attack, stroke, kidney problems with protein in the urine or kidney failure, severe hypertension or hypertensive crisis, posterior reversible encephalopathy syndrome with seizures or vision loss, and infusion reactions.

name: bexagliflozin
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bexagliflozin is used with diet and exercise to improve blood sugar control in adults with type 2 diabetes. it helps the kidneys remove glucose through the urine. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once daily in the morning with or without food. take it at the same time each day. your doctor will check kidney function before and during treatment and may adjust therapy based on kidney function. correct dehydration before starting. what special precautions should i follow?about kidney or liver disease, low blood pressure, frequent urinary infections, problems with urination, prior diabetic ketoacidosis, alcohol use, low carbohydrate or ketogenic diets, or planned surgery or fasting. this medicine can cause ketoacidosis even when blood sugar is not very high, especially during illness, reduced food or fluid intake, or after surgery. learn sick day rules and when to temporarily hold the medicine. it can increase the risk of genital yeast infections, urinary infections, and rare serious infection of the tissue around the genitals. it can cause dehydration, dizziness, and acute kidney injury. monitor for hypoglycemia if used with insulin or a sulfonylurea.if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow your diabetes meal plan, stay well hydrated, limit alcohol, and avoid very low carbohydrate or ketogenic diets while taking this medicine to reduce the risk of ketoacidosis. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember that day. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? increased urination, thirst, genital yeast infections, urinary tract infections, nausea, constipation, and dizziness can occur. serious effects include ketoacidosis with nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, trouble breathing, unusual fatigue or sleepiness, severe genital or perineal pain or swelling, fever or malaise which may signal a rare but serious infection, severe dehydration, and acute kidney injury.

name: bexarotene
instructions: important warning: bexarotene can cause severe birth defects. do not use if you are pregnant or may become pregnant. women who can become pregnant must have two negative pregnancy tests before starting, use two reliable forms of birth control at the same time including a non hormonal method, and continue for one month after the last dose. because bexarotene can reduce the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives, use an additional non hormonal method. men with partners who can become pregnant should use effective contraception during treatment and for at least one month after the last dose. why is this medication prescribed? bexarotene is an oral retinoid used to treat cutaneous t cell lymphoma that has not responded to other treatments. how should this medicine be used? take capsules by mouth once daily with a meal, preferably with dietary fat to improve absorption, exactly as directed. the dose is based on body surface area and may be adjusted for side effects. your doctor will monitor fasting lipids, liver tests, thyroid function, and blood counts regularly. what special precautions should i follow?about liver disease, pancreatitis, high cholesterol or triglycerides, thyroid disease, cataracts or other eye problems, diabetes, or infection. this medicine commonly raises triglycerides and cholesterol and can cause pancreatitis and liver injury. you may be started on medicines to control lipids and on thyroid hormone. avoid driving if you develop vision changes. use sunscreen and protective clothing because this medicine increases sensitivity to sunlight. do not donate blood during treatment and for one month after the last dose. review all medicines and supplements. avoid gemfibrozil and strong inhibitors or inducers of cyp3a andif you take warfarin. do not become pregnant and do not breastfeed. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take with food and avoid grapefruit or grapefruit juice. limit alcohol and keep vitamin a intake modest because excess vitamin a can increase toxicity. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses together. if you vomit shortly after a dose, call your doctor for instructions. what side effects can this medication cause? very common effects include high triglycerides and cholesterol, hypothyroidism, headache, fatigue, rash, dry or peeling skin, itching, nausea, abdominal pain, swelling, and infections. serious effects include pancreatitis with severe abdominal pain, liver injury with dark urine or yellowing of skin or eyes, significant decreases in white blood cells, severe lipid abnormalities, vision changes or cataracts, and severe skin reactions.

name: bexarotene topical
instructions: important warning: bexarotene can cause severe birth defects. do not use if you are pregnant or may become pregnant. women who can become pregnant must have a negative pregnancy test before starting, use effective contraception including a non hormonal method during treatment and for one month after the last dose, and avoid becoming pregnant. although applied to the skin, some absorption can occur. why is this medication prescribed? bexarotene topical gel is used to treat skin lesions in early stage cutaneous t cell lymphoma. how should this medicine be used? apply a thin layer to the affected skin exactly as directed, usually once daily and increased gradually as tolerated. avoid applying to unaffected skin, mucous membranes, or near the eyes. allow the area to dry and wash hands after application. do not cover with airtight dressings unless instructed. protect treated areas from sunlight. what special precautions should i follow?if you have skin conditions that may increase irritation or if you are using other topical products. this medicine can cause significant local irritation and photosensitivity. avoid becoming pregnant and do not breastfeed. if the gel contacts eyes or mucous membranes, rinse with plenty of water and seek advice. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are required. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply it as soon as you remember, then apply the next dose at the regular time. if it is close to the next application, skip the missed dose. do not apply extra gel to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? local redness, burning, stinging, pain, itching, dryness, scaling, or blistering are common and often improve with dose adjustment. photosensitivity can occur. rarely, systemic effects such as headache may occur if large areas are treated.

name: bezlotoxumab injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bezlotoxumab is a monoclonal antibody given with standard antibiotics to reduce the risk of recurrence of clostridioides difficile infection in adults at high risk for recurrence. it is not a treatment for an acute infection by itself and does not replace antibiotics. how should this medicine be used? it is given by a health care professional as a single intravenous infusion during your antibiotic course, usually over about one hour. what special precautions should i follow?if you have a history of heart failure because worsening heart failure was observed more often in patients with heart failure. report shortness of breath, rapid weight gain, or swelling of the legs.about any prior infusion reactions, allergies, pregnancy, or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. maintain adequate hydration unless your doctor advises otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss the scheduled infusion, contact your health care provider as soon as possible to discuss whether and when you should receive it during your antibiotic treatment window. what side effects can this medication cause? nausea, headache, fever, and infusion related reactions such as rash, itching, shortness of breath, flushing, or dizziness may occur. heart failure can worsen in patients with a prior history of heart failure.

name: bicalutamide
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bicalutamide is used to treat prostate cancer, most often together with a gonadotropin releasing hormone therapy, by blocking the effects of androgens. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once daily at the same time each day, with or without food. if used with a gonadotropin releasing hormone therapy, start at the time your doctor directs. do not stop taking it unless your doctor tells you to stop. what special precautions should i follow?about liver disease, heart disease, diabetes, lung disease, or if you take warfarin or other medicines. serious liver injury can occur, usually within the first months, so your doctor will monitor liver tests. seek care for yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, severe nausea, or right upper abdominal pain. bicalutamide can interact with warfarin and increase bleeding risk. avoid driving if you feel dizzy. this medicine is not for use in women and can harm a developing baby. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are required. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember on the same day. if you do not remember until the next day, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? hot flashes, breast tenderness or enlargement, decreased libido, erectile dysfunction, nausea, constipation or diarrhea, swelling of the legs, dizziness, weakness, rash, and abnormal liver tests can occur. serious effects include liver injury, shortness of breath or cough that worsens, and increased bleeding if taken with warfarin.

name: bictegravir, emtricitabine, and tenofovir alafenamide
instructions: important warning: if you have hepatitis b and stop this medicine, your hepatitis b can suddenly worsen. do not stop taking it without talking to your doctor. your doctor will test for hepatitis b before starting and will monitor your liver for several months after stopping. severe lactic acidosis and liver enlargement with fat have occurred with medicines like these. seek urgent care for deep rapid breathing, unusual fatigue, nausea and vomiting, stomach pain, or yellowing of the skin or eyes. why is this medication prescribed? this fixed dose combination is a complete regimen to treat human immunodeficiency virus type 1 infection in adults and certain children and adolescents. it reduces the amount of virus in the body and helps the immune system work better. how should this medicine be used? take one tablet by mouth once daily, with or without food, at the same time each day. swallow whole. do not take with other antiretroviral medicines unless your doctor instructs you to do so. if you take products that contain aluminum or magnesium, take them at least 2 hours before or 6 hours after this medicine. if you take iron or calcium supplements without food, separate by at least 2 hours, or you may take them together with this medicine if taken with food. what special precautions should i follow?about liver disease including hepatitis b or c, kidney disease, osteoporosis, depression, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. many medicines interact including certain anticonvulsants, rifamycins, dofetilide, and products containing st johns wort. your doctor will check kidney and liver function and viral load regularly. do not miss doses and do not stop without medical advice. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take it with or without food. follow the instructions above regarding antacids and mineral supplements. limit alcohol to protect your liver. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. if you vomit within one hour after taking a dose, take another dose. if you vomit more than one hour after dosing, do not take an extra dose. what side effects can this medication cause? headache, nausea, diarrhea, fatigue, abnormal dreams, and trouble sleeping can occur. laboratory changes can include increases in creatinine due to an effect on transporters, small changes in lipids, or changes in kidney or liver tests. serious effects include severe exacerbation of hepatitis b after stopping, lactic acidosis, severe liver problems, kidney problems, depression or suicidal thoughts, and severe allergic reactions.

name: bimatoprost ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bimatoprost eye drops are used to lower elevated intraocular pressure in people with open angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension. how should this medicine be used? instill one drop into the affected eye or eyes once daily in the evening. do not use more than once daily. remove contact lenses before use and wait at least 15 minutes before reinserting them. do not touch the dropper tip to any surface. if using other eye drops, separate administration by at least 5 minutes. what special precautions should i follow? this medicine may darken the iris, eyelid skin, and eyelashes. iris color change is usually permanent. it may increase eyelash growth and thickness. use with caution if you have macular edema risk, uveitis, or after certain eye surgeries. using more than one prostaglandin analog may reduce effectiveness.about any eye conditions, surgery, or inflammation. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are required. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and apply the next dose at the regular time. do not use extra drops to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? eye redness, itching, irritation, dry eyes, watery eyes, eyelid redness, and a feeling of something in the eye may occur. eyelash growth and darkening of lashes or eyelid skin are common. less commonly, vision changes, eye pain, or periorbital fat loss with deepening of the eyelid sulcus can occur.

name: bimatoprost topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bimatoprost topical is used to treat inadequate eyelashes by increasing their length, thickness, and darkness. how should this medicine be used? apply once nightly to the skin of the upper eyelid margin using a sterile single use applicator. do not apply to the lower eyelid. blot any excess solution. avoid touching the tip of the bottle to any surface. remove contact lenses before use and wait at least 15 minutes before reinserting. continued use is needed to maintain effect and eyelash growth gradually returns to baseline after discontinuation. what special precautions should i follow? avoid getting the medication into the eye. it may darken the iris, eyelid skin, and eyelashes, and may cause hair growth on skin that is repeatedly exposed. use with caution if you are using glaucoma medications because it may lower intraocular pressure.about eye problems or if you develop eye pain, vision changes, or signs of infection. do not use during pregnancy unless your doctor decides the benefit outweighs the risk and discuss breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are required. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose and apply the next dose at the regular time the following evening. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? eye redness, itching, dryness, eyelid skin darkening, irritation of the eyelid margin, and eyelash changes may occur. rarely, macular edema or intraocular inflammation can occur.

name: bimekizumab-bkzx injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bimekizumab is used to treat moderate to severe plaque psoriasis and may be used for other inflammatory conditions as directed by your doctor. it works by blocking interleukin 17a and 17f to reduce inflammation. how should this medicine be used? it is given as a subcutaneous injection. for plaque psoriasis, the usual dose is 320 milligrams given as two injections at different sites at week 0 and week 4, then every 8 weeks. your doctor will show you how to inject if you will use it at home. allow the syringe or pen to reach room temperature before use, rotate injection sites, and do not inject into areas that are tender, bruised, or affected by psoriasis. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you have a clinically important active infection.about chronic or recurrent infections, tuberculosis exposure or testing, inflammatory bowel disease, and if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. you will be screened for tuberculosis. this medicine can increase the risk of infections including candida infections and can worsen inflammatory bowel disease. avoid live vaccines during treatment and discuss needed vaccines before starting. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are required. what should i do if i forget a dose? inject the missed dose as soon as you remember, then take the next dose on the regular schedule. if you are unsure how to adjust your schedule, contact your doctor or pharmacist. do not take two full doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? upper respiratory infections, oral or genital yeast infections, injection site reactions, headache, and fatigue can occur. serious effects include severe infections, new or worsening inflammatory bowel disease with abdominal pain, diarrhea, or blood in the stool, and allergic reactions with rash, swelling, or trouble breathing.

name: binimetinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? binimetinib is a kinase inhibitor used with encorafenib to treat adults with unresectable or metastatic melanoma that has a braf v600 mutation. your tumor will be tested to confirm the mutation before starting treatment. it is not for cancers without a braf mutation. how should this medicine be used? the usual dose is 45 milligrams by mouth twice daily about 12 hours apart, with or without food. swallow the tablets whole. take it exactly as prescribed and do not change your dose without your clinician’s advice. do not take an extra dose if you vomit after a dose. how should i store it? keep at room temperature in the original container, away from moisture and out of reach of children. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have or have ever had heart problems, high blood pressure, eye or vision problems including retinal conditions, breathing or lung problems, liver problems, bleeding problems, muscle disorders, or kidney problems. you will have heart tests and eye exams before and during treatment. report new or worsening shortness of breath, swelling, rapid weight gain, chest pain, lightheadedness, severe muscle pain or weakness, vision changes such as blurred vision or loss of vision, severe headache, unusual bleeding, or coughing up blood. binimetinib can harm an unborn baby. use effective birth control during treatment and for at least one month after the last dose. do not breastfeed during treatment and for several days after the last dose as advised by your clinician. tell all of your clinicians and your dentist that you are taking binimetinib. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice. stay well hydrated, especially if you have diarrhea or vomiting. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless there are about six hours or less until your next dose. if it is close to your next dose, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at the same time. if you vomit after a dose, do not take an extra dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include tiredness, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, stomach pain, swelling of hands or feet, cough, fever, rash or acne like skin changes, and muscle or joint pain. laboratory tests may show increases in muscle enzymes. serious effects can include heart failure, dangerous bleeding, blood clots, eye problems including retinal vein occlusion and retinal pigment changes, lung inflammation, severe muscle injury, severe skin reactions, liver injury, and severe high blood pressure. contact your clinician right away for severe or unusual symptoms.

name: birch triterpenes topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? birch triterpenes topical gel is used to support wound healing in certain partial thickness wounds, including wounds in people with epidermolysis bullosa, as directed by a clinician. how should this medicine be used? apply a thin layer to clean and dry wound areas as directed by your clinician, usually with each dressing change. it is for skin use only. avoid contact with eyes, inside the mouth, or other mucous membranes. do not use more often than prescribed. how should i store it? store at room temperature with the cap tightly closed and keep out of reach of children. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have had allergies to birch tree products, birch pollen, or any component of the gel. do not use on infected wounds unless your clinician tells you to do so. stop using and seek medical advice if you develop signs of infection such as increased redness, warmth, swelling, foul odor, or drainage, or if you develop a rash or hives. tell your clinician if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions with this medicine. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply it as soon as you remember, then return to your regular schedule with the next dressing change. do not double applications. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include mild burning, stinging, pain, itching, or redness at the application site. less common reactions include allergic reactions such as rash or swelling. stop using and seek medical help if you have severe irritation, hives, trouble breathing, or signs of infection.

name: bisacodyl
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bisacodyl is a stimulant laxative used for short term relief of occasional constipation and, in higher doses, as part of bowel preparation before certain medical procedures. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once daily as needed, usually 5 to 15 milligrams. swallow enteric coated tablets whole with a full glass of water. do not crush or chew. do not take within one hour of milk, dairy, antacids, or acid reducing medicines because they can dissolve the coating and increase stomach irritation. bowel movements usually occur in 6 to 12 hours. use the lowest effective dose for the shortest time needed. how should i store it? store at room temperature, away from moisture, and out of reach of children. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you have severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bowel obstruction, appendicitis, acute surgical abdomen, or unexplained rectal bleeding. tell your clinician if you have a sudden change in bowel habits lasting more than two weeks, if you use other laxatives, or if you have heart, kidney, or electrolyte problems. long term or excessive use may cause dependence, dehydration, and electrolyte imbalance. ask your clinician before use if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? drink plenty of fluids and increase dietary fiber unless your clinician has told you otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it when you remember if you still need it that day. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include cramping, abdominal discomfort, diarrhea, nausea, and dizziness. serious effects include severe diarrhea or dehydration, fainting, rectal bleeding, or no bowel movement after use. stop use and contact a clinician if severe symptoms occur.

name: bisacodyl rectal
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bisacodyl rectal suppositories or enemas are used for short term relief of occasional constipation and for bowel evacuation prior to procedures. how should this medicine be used? for suppositories, unwrap and insert one 10 milligram suppository into the rectum pointed end first as directed, then remain in place until you feel a strong urge to have a bowel movement. a bowel movement usually occurs within 15 to 60 minutes. for the enema, use exactly as instructed on the package or by your clinician. do not use more often than directed and do not use for more than a few days unless directed by a clinician. how should i store it? store at room temperature away from heat and moisture and keep out of reach of children. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you have rectal bleeding, anal fissures, inflammatory bowel disease with active proctitis, bowel obstruction, severe abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting. stop using and contact a clinician if you have no bowel movement after use or if you develop rectal bleeding or severe pain. ask your clinician before use if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? drink plenty of fluids and increase dietary fiber unless your clinician has told you otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it when you remember if you still need it. do not use more than directed and do not use multiple doses close together. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include rectal irritation, burning, cramping, and diarrhea. serious effects include persistent rectal bleeding, severe pain, dizziness, or fainting. stop use and seek medical advice if serious effects occur.

name: bismuth subsalicylate
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bismuth subsalicylate is used to relieve diarrhea, travelers diarrhea, and upset stomach including indigestion, heartburn, and nausea. it is also used with antibiotics to treat helicobacter pylori as part of certain regimens. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth as directed on the label. shake liquids well, and chew chewable tablets thoroughly. typical dosing for diarrhea is every 30 to 60 minutes as needed up to the maximum daily dose on the label. do not use for more than two days for diarrhea unless a clinician tells you to. how should i store it? store at room temperature, keep the cap tightly closed, and keep out of reach of children. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you are allergic to salicylates or aspirin, if you are taking other salicylates, or if you have active bleeding, a bleeding disorder, a stomach ulcer, severe kidney disease, gout, or if you are on anticoagulants or certain diabetes or gout medicines without medical advice. children and teenagers who have or are recovering from chickenpox or flu like illness should not use this product because of the risk of reye syndrome. this medicine can cause a temporary and harmless darkening of the tongue and stools. tell your clinician if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. ask your clinician before using if you have fever, blood or mucus in stools, or diarrhea lasting more than two days. what special dietary instructions should i follow? stay well hydrated with oral rehydration solutions or clear fluids. avoid alcohol and avoid taking other aspirin or salicylate containing products. what should i do if i forget a dose? this product is often used as needed. if you are on a scheduled regimen, take the missed dose when you remember unless it is close to the next dose. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include darkening of the tongue or stools, constipation, and nausea. serious effects include ringing in the ears, hearing changes, severe stomach pain, vomiting, blood or black stools not explained by this medicine, or signs of an allergic reaction. stop use and seek medical care if serious effects occur.

name: bismuth, metronidazole, and tetracycline
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? the combination of bismuth subcitrate potassium, metronidazole, and tetracycline is used with a proton pump inhibitor to eradicate helicobacter pylori and reduce the risk of duodenal ulcer recurrence. how should this medicine be used? the usual regimen is three capsules four times daily after meals and at bedtime for 10 days along with a proton pump inhibitor twice daily. swallow capsules with a full glass of water. remain upright for at least 30 minutes after dosing to reduce the risk of esophageal irritation. take the full course even if you feel better. how should i store it? store at room temperature in the original container and keep out of reach of children. what special precautions should i follow? do not drink alcohol or use products containing propylene glycol during treatment and for at least three days after the last dose because of the risk of a severe reaction with metronidazole. avoid sunlight and use sun protection since tetracycline can increase sun sensitivity. do not use if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding because tetracycline can harm the fetus and infant and can stain teeth and affect bone growth in children. do not give to children younger than 8 years old. tell your clinician about all medicines you take. warfarin effects can be increased by metronidazole. tetracycline absorption is reduced by antacids, iron, calcium, magnesium, zinc, and some supplements, so separate those by several hours. this regimen can reduce the effectiveness of hormonal birth control, so use a reliable backup method during treatment. tell your clinician if you have liver disease, kidney disease, seizures, nerve problems, a history of yeast infections, or a history of colitis. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid alcohol completely during treatment and for at least three days after the last dose. take doses after meals and at bedtime as directed. do not take iron, calcium, magnesium, zinc, or antacids within a few hours of this medicine. stay hydrated. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is close to the next dose. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at the same time. call your clinician if you miss multiple doses. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, metallic taste, darkening of tongue or stool, headache, and vaginal yeast infection. serious effects include severe allergic reactions, severe skin rash, numbness or tingling, seizures, confusion, severe headache, vision changes, severe diarrhea possibly due to clostridioides difficile, liver problems such as yellowing of skin or eyes or dark urine, and severe sunburn. contact your clinician promptly for serious symptoms.

name: bisoprolol
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bisoprolol is a beta blocker used to treat high blood pressure. it may also be used in select patients for chronic heart failure as directed by a clinician. controlling blood pressure helps prevent strokes, heart attacks, and kidney problems. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once daily at the same time each day, with or without food. swallow tablets with water. take exactly as prescribed. do not stop taking bisoprolol suddenly because this can cause chest pain or heart attack in some people. your clinician may lower your dose gradually if it needs to be stopped. how should i store it? store at room temperature and keep out of reach of children. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, slow heart rate, heart block, sick sinus syndrome, heart failure, poor circulation, diabetes, thyroid problems, kidney or liver disease, depression, or a history of severe allergic reactions. bisoprolol can mask signs of low blood sugar and thyroid overactivity. tell your clinician about all medicines you take, including other blood pressure or heart medicines such as certain calcium channel blockers, digoxin, antiarrhythmics, clonidine, and any medicines that can lower heart rate. if you need surgery, tell the anesthesiologist you take a beta blocker. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits with your clinician. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow your clinicians advice on a heart healthy diet and salt restriction. limit alcohol. if you have diabetes, monitor your blood sugar regularly. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember the same day. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include slow heart rate, fatigue, dizziness, headache, cold hands or feet, and stomach upset. serious effects include very slow heartbeat, fainting, shortness of breath or swelling suggesting worsening heart failure, wheezing or bronchospasm, confusion, or depression. contact your clinician if you have severe or persistent symptoms.

name: bleomycin
instructions: important warning: bleomycin can cause severe and potentially fatal lung toxicity including inflammation and scarring of the lungs. the risk increases with higher total doses, older age, impaired kidney function, prior chest radiation, and use of high concentration oxygen. it should be administered under the supervision of a clinician experienced in cancer chemotherapy with close monitoring including lung function and chest imaging. severe hypersensitivity reactions including anaphylaxis can occur. why is this medication prescribed? bleomycin is an anticancer medicine used to treat certain cancers including testicular cancer, hodgkin lymphoma, non hodgkin lymphoma, and certain squamous cell cancers. it is also used in some cases for pleurodesis to reduce fluid around the lungs. how should this medicine be used? bleomycin is given by a clinician as an injection into a vein, muscle, or under the skin, or instilled into the chest cavity for pleurodesis. dosing and schedule depend on the condition being treated, your kidney function, and other treatments. you may receive a small test dose before the first dose to check for hypersensitivity. keep all appointments for dosing and monitoring. how should i store it? if you are not administering it yourself, storage is handled by the clinic or pharmacy. if you are provided with medicine for home use, store as directed by your clinician. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have or have ever had lung disease, kidney disease, liver disease, prior radiation to the chest, or if you smoke. report new or worsening cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, or fever right away. tell all of your clinicians and dentist that you are receiving bleomycin. avoid high concentration oxygen exposure during and after treatment unless absolutely necessary. bleomycin can harm an unborn baby. use effective birth control during treatment and for a period after the last dose as advised by your clinician. do not breastfeed during treatment. avoid live vaccines during treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. maintain good hydration and nutrition as advised by your care team. what should i do if i forget a dose? call your treatment center as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to make up a dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fever, chills, skin changes such as darkening, thickening, rash, nail changes, mouth sores, loss of appetite, weight loss, and hair thinning. serious effects include lung inflammation and scarring, severe allergic reactions with low blood pressure or hives or trouble breathing, severe skin reactions, and rarely effects on blood vessels in the fingers known as raynaud phenomenon. contact your clinician immediately for signs of lung problems, severe rash, or allergic reactions.

name: blinatumomab injection
instructions: important warning: blinatumomab can cause life threatening cytokine release syndrome and serious neurologic problems including confusion, seizures, difficulty speaking, loss of consciousness, coordination problems, and encephalopathy. you will receive premedication and are often admitted or observed closely at the start of treatment and when doses are increased. the infusion may need to be interrupted or stopped for severe reactions. why is this medication prescribed? blinatumomab is used to treat certain types of b cell precursor acute lymphoblastic leukemia in adults and children, including relapsed or refractory disease and minimal residual disease positive disease. how should this medicine be used? it is given as a continuous intravenous infusion through a pump over several days in repeating cycles, usually 28 days on treatment followed by a break. you will receive premedication such as dexamethasone. the pump and infusion bag are changed on a set schedule. follow all handling instructions if you are discharged with the pump. keep all appointments and do not adjust the pump settings yourself. how should i store it? storage and handling are arranged by the infusion center or pharmacy. if you are sent home with supplies, keep them as instructed and out of reach of children. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medicines you take and all medical conditions including prior neurologic problems, seizures, infection, liver problems, pancreatitis, or if you have received a stem cell transplant. report fever, chills, shortness of breath, low blood pressure symptoms such as dizziness or fainting, confusion, severe headache, difficulty speaking, weakness, numbness, seizures, or jaundice right away. this medicine can lower white cells and increase infection risk. avoid live vaccines during treatment. blinatumomab can harm an unborn baby. use effective birth control during treatment and for a period after the last dose as advised by your clinician. do not breastfeed during treatment. do not drive or operate machinery if you have neurologic symptoms or until your clinician says it is safe. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions, but maintain hydration and nutrition. what should i do if i forget a dose? if your infusion is interrupted or a bag change is missed, contact your treatment team immediately for instructions. do not attempt to restart the infusion on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fever, headache, infusion related reactions, swelling, nausea, constipation, diarrhea, cough, tiredness, low blood counts including neutropenia, and infections. serious effects include cytokine release syndrome, severe neurologic events such as seizures and encephalopathy, liver injury, tumor lysis syndrome, pancreatitis, and severe infections. seek urgent care for severe symptoms.

name: boceprevir
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? boceprevir is a protease inhibitor that was used with peginterferon alfa and ribavirin to treat chronic hepatitis c virus genotype 1 infection. it is no longer marketed in many countries and has largely been replaced by newer treatments, but information here reflects prior use. how should this medicine be used? when used, it was started after a four week lead in period with peginterferon alfa and ribavirin. the usual dose was 800 milligrams by mouth three times daily taken with food, approximately every seven to nine hours, together with ongoing peginterferon and ribavirin. take exactly as prescribed and do not stop any component without medical advice. how should i store it? store at room temperature and keep out of reach of children. what special precautions should i follow? serious drug interactions are common. tell your clinician about all medicines you take including prescription drugs, over the counter medicines, and herbal products such as st johns wort which should not be used. boceprevir can interact with many heart rhythm, cholesterol, seizure, sedative, and migraine medicines among others. when used with ribavirin there is a risk of severe birth defects and fetal death. both males and females must use effective birth control during treatment and for a period after the last dose of ribavirin as advised by the clinician. tell your clinician if you have anemia, heart disease, kidney disease, liver disease other than hepatitis c, hiv or hepatitis b coinfection, organ transplant, or any history of depression or psychiatric illness. you will need regular blood tests to monitor for anemia and other side effects. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take each dose with food. avoid alcohol. avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice. do not use herbal supplements without checking with your clinician. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember if it is within a few hours of the scheduled time. if it is nearly time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at the same time. call your clinician if you miss more than one dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fatigue, nausea, altered taste, headache, and anemia. serious effects include severe anemia that may require dose adjustments or transfusion, neutropenia and infections, depression, and serious drug interactions that can cause heart rhythm problems or other toxicities. when used with ribavirin there is a risk of serious birth defects. seek medical attention for chest pain, severe shortness of breath, fainting, or signs of severe anemia such as extreme fatigue and rapid heartbeat.

name: bortezomib injection
instructions: important warning: bortezomib must never be given into the spinal canal. intrathecal administration can be fatal. it must be administered only by trained professionals by the intravenous or subcutaneous route. your care team will monitor you closely for low blood pressure, nerve damage, low blood counts, liver problems, lung problems, and serious infections. why is this medication prescribed?
