bortezomib is used to treat multiple myeloma and mantle cell lymphoma by blocking proteasomes that cancer cells need to grow. how should this medicine be used? it is given as an intravenous injection or a subcutaneous injection in treatment cycles. many regimens use two doses each week for two weeks followed by a rest period, but your exact schedule is individualized. injection sites are rotated if given under the skin. you will have regular blood tests and exams before each dose. your doctor may prescribe antiviral medicine to help prevent shingles reactivation. do not attempt to self inject unless you have been taught and instructed to do so by your oncology team. what special precautions should i follow?about any numbness or tingling, dizziness when standing, heart or lung disease, liver disease, diabetes, infections, shingles history, and all medicines you take. this medicine can cause severe low blood pressure especially when standing. rise slowly and drink fluids. it can cause or worsen nerve damage and may require dose changes. it can lower blood counts and increase infection and bleeding risk. call right away for fever, chills, unusual bruising, or bleeding. avoid pregnancy and use effective contraception during treatment and for a time after your last dose as advised by your doctor. discuss all medicines and supplements. strong enzyme inducers or inhibitors and certain herbal products can interact. avoid live vaccines unless your doctor says it is safe. what special dietary instructions should i follow? stay well hydrated unless your doctor restricts fluids. eat small frequent meals if you have nausea. limit or avoid alcohol. avoid green tea products and concentrated green tea extracts, which can interfere with how bortezomib works. ask your team before taking any new vitamins or supplements. what should i do if i forget a dose? call your cancer clinic as soon as possible for instructions. do not try to make up a missed dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fatigue, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea or constipation, loss of appetite, dizziness, headache, fever, rash, and muscle cramps. laboratory changes and symptoms from low blood counts can occur, including infections, anemia, and bleeding. peripheral neuropathy with tingling, numbness, burning pain, or weakness is common. low blood pressure, swelling, shortness of breath, cough, liver test elevations, and herpes zoster reactivation can occur. serious effects include severe infection, severe nerve problems, sudden shortness of breath or new cough, severe dizziness or fainting, chest pain, confusion or vision changes, seizures, and signs of liver injury such as yellowing of the skin or eyes or dark urine. seek urgent care for severe or concerning symptoms.

name: bosentan
instructions: important warning: bosentan can cause serious liver injury. liver tests are required before starting, monthly during treatment, and as directed after dose changes. bosentan can cause severe birth defects. do not use if you are pregnant. people who can become pregnant must have a negative pregnancy test before starting and monthly during treatment, and must use reliable contraception. because bosentan can make hormonal contraceptives less effective, use two effective forms of contraception while taking it and for a period after stopping as advised by your prescriber. why is this medication prescribed? bosentan is used to treat pulmonary arterial hypertension to improve the ability to exercise and slow worsening of symptoms. how should this medicine be used? take bosentan by mouth usually twice daily as prescribed. you may take it with or without food. swallow the tablets with water. your doctor will monitor your liver function and blood counts regularly and adjust your dose if needed. what special precautions should i follow? do not use bosentan with cyclosporine or glyburide.about all medicines you take because bosentan interacts with many drugs. it can reduce the effectiveness of hormonal birth control. it can cause anemia and fluid retention.if you have liver problems, swelling, shortness of breath that is new or worse, or signs of anemia such as unusual fatigue or shortness of breath. men may experience a decrease in sperm count. do not donate blood during treatment and for a period after stopping as advised. do not use if you are pregnant and do not breastfeed during treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take bosentan with or without food. avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice. limit alcohol because it can increase the risk of liver problems. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your normal schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, flushing, nasal congestion, swelling of the legs or ankles, and upper respiratory infections. anemia can occur. liver enzyme elevations and liver injury may occur and can be serious. other effects include stomach upset, reflux, low blood pressure, and palpitations. serious effects include symptoms of liver injury such as yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, persistent nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain, fainting or worsening shortness of breath with swelling, and signs of severe anemia. seek medical attention for serious or worsening symptoms.

name: bosutinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bosutinib is used to treat adults with philadelphia chromosome positive chronic myeloid leukemia including newly diagnosed patients and those who have been treated with other tyrosine kinase inhibitors. how should this medicine be used? take bosutinib by mouth once daily with food at the same time each day. swallow tablets whole with water. your healthcare provider will check blood counts and liver tests regularly and adjust your dose as needed. if you have diarrhea your doctor may recommend antidiarrheal medicine and fluid replacement. what special precautions should i follow?about liver or kidney problems, heart problems, history of pancreatitis or severe diarrhea, and all medicines you take. bosutinib can cause diarrhea, liver problems, and low blood counts. report signs of infection, bleeding, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, or severe abdominal pain. avoid strong enzyme inducers or inhibitors unless your doctor adjusts your therapy. avoid proton pump inhibitors because they reduce absorption. if you need an antacid or an h two blocker, take bosutinib at least two hours before or after those medicines. avoid pregnancy and use effective birth control during treatment and for at least two weeks after the last dose. do not breastfeed during treatment and for at least two weeks after the last dose. protect your skin from the sun if you develop rash or sensitivity. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take bosutinib with food. avoid grapefruit and seville orange products. limit alcohol. if diarrhea occurs, increase clear fluids and follow your clinician guidance. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you remember within about twelve hours of your usual time, take the dose with food. if more than twelve hours have passed, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at the same time. if you vomit after a dose do not take an extra dose that day. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, decreased appetite, fatigue, fever, headache, and rash or itching. lab changes can include liver enzyme elevations and low platelets, white cells, or red cells, which can lead to bleeding, infection, or anemia. less common but serious effects include severe liver injury, severe diarrhea with dehydration, pancreatitis, kidney problems, fluid retention, chest pain or shortness of breath, and severe skin reactions. call your doctor for severe or persistent symptoms or signs of infection or bleeding.

name: bremelanotide injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bremelanotide is used in premenopausal adult women to treat acquired generalized hypoactive sexual desire disorder that causes marked distress and is not due to a medical or psychiatric condition, problems in the relationship, or medications. how should this medicine be used? it is a subcutaneous self injection given in the abdomen or thigh at least forty five minutes before anticipated sexual activity. do not use more than one dose in twenty four hours and do not exceed eight doses in a month. rotate injection sites. your doctor will reassess after eight weeks and stop treatment if there is no meaningful improvement. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you have uncontrolled high blood pressure or known cardiovascular disease. bremelanotide can cause temporary increases in blood pressure and decreases in heart rate for several hours.about nausea, stomach emptying problems, kidney or liver disease, and all medicines. it can slow stomach emptying and reduce the effect of some oral medicines. taking it with oral naltrexone containing medicines is not recommended. it may cause darkening of the skin and gums that can be long lasting. use caution with alcohol. do not use in pregnancy or while breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific food requirements. if nausea occurs, small light meals may help. avoid alcohol around the time of dosing. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is used as needed. if you forget to inject before sexual activity, inject at least forty five minutes before. never take more than one dose in twenty four hours. what side effects can this medication cause? very common effects are nausea and vomiting, flushing, headache, dizziness, fatigue, and injection site reactions. nasal congestion and cough can occur. darkening of the skin or gums can occur and may be more likely in people with darker skin. serious side effects include severe or persistent nausea or vomiting with dehydration, marked increases in blood pressure, chest pain, shortness of breath, and allergic reactions with swelling or trouble breathing. seek medical attention for severe or concerning symptoms.

name: brexanolone injection
instructions: important warning: brexanolone can cause profound sedation and sudden loss of consciousness. it must be given only in a certified healthcare facility with continuous monitoring under a risk management program. you must be monitored during the infusion and must be supervised when caring for your infant. do not drive or operate machinery until at least the day after the infusion ends and only if you feel fully alert. why is this medication prescribed? brexanolone is used to treat postpartum depression in adults. how should this medicine be used? it is given as a continuous intravenous infusion over about sixty hours following a programmed dosing schedule. you will remain in a certified facility for the entire infusion. your breathing, level of alertness, and vital signs will be monitored frequently. discuss breastfeeding with your provider. small amounts can pass into milk and your infant should be observed for increased sleepiness or poor feeding. what special precautions should i follow?about liver or kidney problems, sleep apnea or other breathing disorders, history of substance use, and all medicines including opioids, benzodiazepines, sleep aids, and antihistamines. using alcohol or other sedatives increases the risk of dangerous sedation or breathing problems. have help with childcare during and after the infusion. tell your provider right away if you feel excessively sleepy, dizzy, or if others notice you are hard to arouse. report any worsening depression or suicidal thoughts immediately. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may eat and drink normally unless your care team advises otherwise. do not drink alcohol during treatment. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is administered by healthcare professionals on a set schedule. if the infusion is interrupted, your team will determine how to manage and whether to restart. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include sleepiness, sedation, dizziness, headache, flushing, dry mouth, and feeling faint when standing. infusion site discomfort may occur. serious effects include loss of consciousness and slowed or shallow breathing. worsening depression or suicidal thoughts can occur. seek urgent help for severe or concerning symptoms.

name: brexpiprazole
instructions: important warning: antipsychotic medicines increase the risk of death in older adults with dementia related psychosis. brexpiprazole is not approved for the treatment of dementia related psychosis. antidepressants can increase the risk of suicidal thoughts and behaviors in children, adolescents, and young adults especially during the first months of treatment and during dose changes. watch closely for worsening depression or unusual behavior changes and contact a healthcare provider immediately if these occur. why is this medication prescribed? brexpiprazole is used to treat schizophrenia in adults, as an add on treatment for major depressive disorder in adults when an antidepressant alone is not enough, and to treat agitation associated with dementia due to alzheimer disease in adults. how should this medicine be used? take brexpiprazole by mouth once daily with or without food at the same time each day. your doctor will increase the dose gradually to reduce side effects. if you are taking it for depression, take it along with your prescribed antidepressant. do not stop taking it without talking to your doctor. it may take several weeks to see the full benefit. what special precautions should i follow?if you have diabetes, high cholesterol, heart disease, stroke, low blood pressure, seizures, liver or kidney problems, low white blood cell count, or trouble swallowing. brexpiprazole can cause weight gain, high blood sugar, and high cholesterol. your provider may check your weight and blood tests. it can cause sleepiness, dizziness, and a drop in blood pressure when standing, so use caution when driving or standing up quickly. serious movement problems called tardive dyskinesia can occur and may be permanent. a rare but life threatening reaction called neuroleptic malignant syndrome can occur with high fever, stiff muscles, confusion, sweating, and fast heart rate. impulse control problems such as compulsive gambling or eating can occur. avoid overheating and dehydration. limit alcohol. if you become pregnant,right away. newborns exposed in the last trimester may have symptoms such as agitation, breathing difficulty, or feeding problems. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific food restrictions. maintain a healthy diet and activity to help reduce weight gain. drink fluids to avoid dehydration. limit alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. if you miss more than one dose, contact your prescriber because you may need dose adjustments. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include weight gain, increased appetite, restlessness or inner sense of restlessness, anxiety, insomnia, sleepiness, dizziness, headache, nausea, constipation, dry mouth, blurred vision, nasal congestion, fatigue, and tremor. serious effects include high blood sugar, high cholesterol, low blood pressure when standing, seizures, signs of stroke, neuroleptic malignant syndrome, tardive dyskinesia, impulse control problems, low white blood cell count with infection, and allergic reactions.

name: brexucabtagene autoleucel injection
instructions: important warning: this therapy can cause cytokine release syndrome and severe neurologic toxicities that can be life threatening or fatal. it must be given in a certified healthcare facility with staff trained to manage these reactions and immediate access to tocilizumab and intensive care. you will be monitored closely for fever, low blood pressure, breathing problems, confusion, and seizures. do not drive or operate heavy machinery for at least eight weeks after infusion or longer if you have signs of neurologic side effects. why is this medication prescribed? brexucabtagene autoleucel is a chimeric antigen receptor t cell therapy used to treat adults with certain relapsed or refractory b cell cancers such as mantle cell lymphoma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia. how should this medicine be used? your t cells are collected by a procedure called leukapheresis, genetically modified, and then infused once through a vein after you receive chemotherapy to reduce your lymphocytes. you will receive premedications before infusion. you will be monitored daily for several days and must remain near the treating center for at least four weeks. always carry your patient wallet card and show it to any healthcare provider. what special precautions should i follow? tell your team about all medical conditions, especially infections, fever, neurologic problems, heart, lung, liver, or kidney disease, and seizure history. do not receive live vaccines for at least six weeks before starting chemotherapy for this therapy, during treatment, and until your doctor says it is safe. this treatment can cause prolonged low blood counts and increase infection and bleeding risk. you may need monitoring of immunoglobulin levels and treatment for low levels. use effective contraception during treatment and for the time your team recommends. call right away for fever, chills, confusion, severe headache, difficulty speaking, tremors, seizures, shortness of breath, rapid heartbeat, severe diarrhea, severe fatigue, or any new or worsening symptoms. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions, but your team may recommend a food safety plan while your blood counts are low. stay well hydrated and avoid alcohol during the acute monitoring period unless your team approves. what should i do if i forget a dose? this therapy is scheduled and administered by your care team. if you miss an appointment, contact the treating center immediately for instructions. what side effects can this medication cause? very common and serious effects include cytokine release syndrome with fever, chills, low blood pressure, low oxygen, rapid heart rate, and organ dysfunction, and neurologic toxicities including headache, confusion, agitation, tremor, difficulty speaking, sleepiness, seizures, and coma. other effects include serious infections, prolonged low blood counts with anemia, bleeding, or infection risk, low immunoglobulin levels with recurrent infections, kidney or liver problems, electrolyte abnormalities, rash, and allergic reactions including anaphylaxis. many side effects require urgent medical attention.

name: brigatinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? brigatinib is used to treat metastatic non small cell lung cancer that has a change in the alk gene. how should this medicine be used? take brigatinib by mouth once daily with or without food at the same time each day. it is usually started at a lower dose for seven days and then increased if tolerated. swallow tablets whole with water. your provider will monitor your lungs, blood pressure, heart rate, blood sugar, muscles, eyes, and liver tests during treatment. what special precautions should i follow?about lung disease, high blood pressure, slow heart rate, diabetes, liver or kidney problems, vision problems, and all medicines and supplements. serious inflammation of the lungs can happen, often within the first week. report new or worsening shortness of breath, cough, or fever right away. brigatinib can raise blood pressure, slow the heart rate, raise blood sugar, elevate muscle enzymes, and cause vision problems. use birth control during treatment and for at least four months after the last dose if you can become pregnant, and for at least three months after the last dose if you have a partner who can become pregnant. avoid strong enzyme inducers or inhibitors unless your doctor adjusts your therapy. do not drive if you develop visual symptoms until they resolve. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take brigatinib with or without food. avoid grapefruit and seville oranges. limit alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose and it has been more than six hours, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. if you vomit after taking brigatinib, do not take another dose that day. take your next dose at the usual time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, stomach pain, decreased appetite, weight loss, fatigue, headache, cough, shortness of breath, rash, and muscle pain. laboratory changes can include high blood pressure, slow heart rate, high blood sugar, and elevated liver or pancreatic enzymes. vision changes such as double vision or light sensitivity can occur. serious effects include lung inflammation, blood clots, severe high blood pressure, severe muscle injury, and serious liver problems. seek medical attention for severe or sudden symptoms.

name: brimonidine ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? brimonidine eye drops lower eye pressure in open angle glaucoma or ocular hypertension. lower strength brimonidine is also used to temporarily relieve eye redness. how should this medicine be used? for glaucoma or ocular hypertension use the strength and schedule prescribed, commonly one drop in the affected eye three times daily. for redness relief use one drop in the affected eye every six to eight hours as needed and do not use more than four times daily. wash your hands before use. remove contact lenses before using the drops and wait fifteen minutes before reinserting them. tilt your head back, pull down the lower eyelid to create a small pocket, and place one drop without touching the tip to your eye or any surface. close your eye gently and press the inner corner by the nose for one to two minutes to reduce absorption. if using other eye medicines wait at least five minutes between products. use ointments last. what special precautions should i follow?about eye problems, low blood pressure, heart disease, depression, circulation problems, kidney or liver disease, and all medicines. do not use with monoamine oxidase inhibitors unless your doctor says it is safe. do not use in infants or very young children because serious side effects can occur. this medicine can cause sleepiness. use caution when driving or doing tasks that require alertness. stop and call a doctor if eye pain, changes in vision, continued redness, or irritation worsen or last more than three days. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is needed. limit alcohol if you feel drowsy. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use extra drops to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include eye redness, burning or stinging, itchy or watery eyes, blurred vision, sensitivity to light, dry mouth or nose, headache, drowsiness, and fatigue. eyelid swelling can occur. serious effects include allergic eye reactions with severe redness or swelling, slow heart rate, fainting, breathing problems especially in children, and severe eye pain or vision changes. seek medical attention for severe or persistent symptoms.

name: brivaracetam
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? brivaracetam is used to treat partial onset seizures in patients four years of age and older. how should this medicine be used? take brivaracetam by mouth as tablets or oral solution usually twice daily, or receive it by intravenous injection if oral dosing is not possible. take it at the same times each day. your doctor may adjust the dose based on response and other medicines. do not stop suddenly because this can increase seizure risk. your doctor will tell you how to taper if needed. what special precautions should i follow?about depression, anxiety, mood or behavior disorders, liver disease, kidney disease, and all medicines including other seizure medicines and sedatives. brivaracetam can cause mood and behavior changes including irritability, aggression, agitation, depression, and suicidal thoughts. report unusual changes right away. it can cause dizziness and drowsiness. do not drive until you know how it affects you. serious allergic reactions including swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat and trouble breathing can occur. alcohol increases sedation and may increase seizure risk. if you become pregnant, contact your doctor and consider enrollment in a pregnancy registry. use reliable contraception. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific food restrictions. avoid alcohol. if using the oral solution, ask about the sodium content if you are on a sodium restricted diet. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is close to the next dose. if you miss more than one dose, contact your doctor for instructions. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include sleepiness, dizziness, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, constipation, coordination problems, and blurred vision. behavior and mood changes including irritability, anxiety, and depression can occur. serious effects include suicidal thoughts or behavior, hallucinations or psychosis, severe allergic reactions including swelling of the face or throat, severe rash, worsening seizures, and liver enzyme elevations. seek medical help for severe or concerning symptoms.

name: brivaracetam injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? brivaracetam injection is used to control partial onset seizures in people with epilepsy. the injection is typically used when the oral form cannot be taken and is intended for short term use until oral therapy is possible. how should this medicine be used? it is given by a health care professional into a vein. the total daily dose is individualized and usually matches the dose used with the oral form when switching between routes. do not stop taking or receiving brivaracetam suddenly without medical advice because seizures may worsen. what special precautions should i follow?about all medicines you take. rifampin can lower brivaracetam levels and carbamazepine may increase side effects such as dizziness. brivaracetam can cause sleepiness, dizziness, and coordination problems. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you and avoid alcohol. antiseizure medicines may increase the risk of suicidal thoughts or behavior. call your doctor right away if you have new or worsening depression, irritability, aggression, panic attacks, or thoughts of self harm. serious allergic reactions including rash, hives, swelling of the face lips tongue or throat and bronchospasm can occur. people with liver impairment may need a lower dose. if you are pregnant or may become pregnant talk with your doctor about the risks and benefits and do not stop seizure treatment without medical advice. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions, but avoid alcohol because it can increase sleepiness and dizziness. what should i do if i forget a dose? because this is given by a health care professional, contact your clinic or prescriber to arrange the next dose. do not attempt to self inject and do not receive extra doses to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include sleepiness, dizziness, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, and irritability. changes in mood or behavior, aggression, anxiety, and difficulty with coordination can occur. serious effects include suicidal thoughts or behavior, severe rash, angioedema with swelling or trouble breathing, and infusion site reactions. seek urgent care for signs of a severe allergic reaction or thoughts of self harm.

name: brodalumab injection
instructions: important warning: brodalumab has been associated with suicidal thoughts and behavior including completed suicide. it is available only through a risk evaluation and mitigation strategy program that requires careful monitoring. tell your prescriber immediately if you have new or worsening depression, anxiety, mood changes, or thoughts of self harm, and seek emergency help if you have thoughts of harming yourself. do not use brodalumab if you cannot be closely followed. why is this medication prescribed? brodalumab is used in adults to treat moderate to severe plaque psoriasis in patients who are candidates for systemic therapy or phototherapy and who have not responded or have lost response to other systemic treatments. how should this medicine be used? it is injected under the skin. the usual schedule is 210 milligrams at weeks zero, one, and two, then every two weeks. a health care professional may give the first doses and can teach you how to inject at home if appropriate. allow the prefilled syringe to reach room temperature, do not shake, and inject into the thigh abdomen or outer upper arm avoiding areas that are tender, bruised, or affected by psoriasis. rotate injection sites. store in a refrigerator in the original carton and do not freeze. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you have crohn disease. brodalumab may lower your ability to fight infections.if you have any infection or symptoms such as fever, chills, cough, or sores before starting or during treatment. you will be tested for tuberculosis and should not receive live vaccines while on therapy. discuss pregnancy and breastfeeding with your doctor. report any new or worsening intestinal symptoms such as abdominal pain or diarrhea. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. what should i do if i forget a dose? inject the missed dose as soon as you remember, then resume your regular every two week schedule. do not inject two doses on the same day. if you are unsure how to adjust your schedule, contact your prescriber. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include joint pain, headache, fatigue, diarrhea, injection site redness or pain, and upper respiratory infections. serious effects include suicidal thoughts or behavior, serious infections, neutropenia, worsening inflammatory bowel disease, and severe allergic reactions. seek urgent care for chest pain, shortness of breath, high fever, severe abdominal pain, confusion, or thoughts of self harm.

name: brolucizumab-dbll injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? brolucizumab is injected into the eye to treat neovascular wet age related macular degeneration and diabetic macular edema to help reduce fluid and maintain or improve vision. how should this medicine be used? an eye care specialist injects brolucizumab into the vitreous of the eye in an office or clinic. treatment often starts with monthly injections for several doses followed by injections every eight to twelve weeks depending on your response. you will be monitored after each injection. what special precautions should i follow? there is a risk of serious eye inflammation including retinal vasculitis and retinal artery occlusion, endophthalmitis, and increases in eye pressure that can lead to severe vision loss. call your ophthalmologist right away if you have eye pain, worsening redness, light sensitivity, new floaters, sudden decrease in vision, or severe headache after an injection.about any eye infections or inflammation before treatment. arrange transportation because your vision may be blurry after the procedure. discuss pregnancy and breastfeeding with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your eye care provider as soon as possible to reschedule. do not attempt to inject yourself. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include eye pain, conjunctival hemorrhage, eye redness, floaters, and blurred vision. serious effects include retinal vasculitis and vascular occlusion, endophthalmitis, significant increases in intraocular pressure, and severe or persistent vision loss. seek urgent ophthalmic care if severe symptoms occur.

name: bromfenac ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bromfenac eye drops are nonsteroidal anti inflammatory medicine used to treat inflammation and pain after cataract surgery. how should this medicine be used? use exactly as directed by your eye surgeon. a common schedule is one drop in the affected eye once daily starting one day before surgery and continuing for about two weeks after surgery. wash your hands, tilt your head back, pull down the lower eyelid to create a small pocket, instill the drop, and close your eye gently. do not touch the dropper tip to any surface. if you use other eye medicines, wait at least five minutes between products. remove contact lenses before use and do not wear lenses after surgery unless your surgeon says it is safe. what special precautions should i follow?if you are allergic to aspirin or other nsaids, have bleeding problems, corneal disorders, dry eye, diabetes, rheumatoid arthritis, or if you use topical steroids, because delayed healing and corneal problems can occur. use caution if you have a history of eye infections. stop and call your doctor if you develop severe eye pain, increased redness, decreased vision, or signs of an allergic reaction such as rash or swelling. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. what should i do if i forget a dose? instill the missed dose when you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use extra drops to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? burning or stinging after instillation, eye irritation, redness, blurred vision, and sensitivity to light may occur. less common but serious effects include increased bleeding, delayed healing, corneal thinning or perforation, and severe allergic reactions. seek urgent care for severe pain or sudden vision changes.

name: bromocriptine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bromocriptine is a dopamine agonist used to treat conditions such as high prolactin levels including prolactin secreting pituitary tumors, missed periods or infertility due to hyperprolactinemia, acromegaly, and as adjunct therapy for parkinson disease. a specific formulation is also used with diet and exercise to improve blood sugar control in adults with type 2 diabetes. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth with food to reduce stomach upset. your doctor will start with a low dose and increase slowly to reduce side effects. the diabetes formulation is usually taken once daily with food within two hours after waking. swallow tablets or capsules whole. do not stop suddenly without medical advice, especially if you have been on higher doses. what special precautions should i follow? bromocriptine can cause low blood pressure, dizziness, fainting, and sudden sleep episodes. until you know how it affects you, do not drive or operate machinery. it can cause or worsen mental health symptoms including hallucinations and impulse control problems such as compulsive gambling or spending.if you have heart valve disease, a history of fibrosis, uncontrolled high blood pressure, liver disease, migraines, or if you are postpartum because serious high blood pressure and stroke have been reported when used to suppress lactation. many medicines can interact, including macrolide antibiotics, azole antifungals, some hiv medicines, some blood pressure medicines, and others that affect liver enzymes. avoid alcohol. discuss pregnancy and breastfeeding with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take with food. if you use the diabetes formulation, eat regular meals to reduce the risk of low blood sugar. avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice which can increase bromocriptine levels. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your schedule. do not take two doses at once. if you miss several doses, contact your prescriber because you may need to restart at a lower dose. what side effects can this medication cause? nausea, vomiting, constipation, abdominal cramps, headache, dizziness, fatigue, and nasal congestion are common. it can cause low blood pressure, fainting, confusion, hallucinations, swelling of the legs, chest pain, and raynaud like symptoms. impulse control problems may occur. in people with diabetes it can contribute to low blood sugar especially with other glucose lowering medicines. rare but serious events include stroke, seizures, heart valve problems, and fibrotic reactions. seek urgent care for severe chest pain, shortness of breath, one sided weakness, or severe headache.

name: budesonide
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? budesonide is a corticosteroid used to reduce inflammation in the digestive tract. oral delayed release capsules are used for mild to moderate crohn disease affecting the ileum and or ascending colon. extended release tablets and rectal foam are used for ulcerative colitis. it may also be used for microscopic colitis as directed by your doctor. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as prescribed, usually in the morning. swallow capsules or tablets whole and do not crush, chew, or open them. rectal foam is used in the rectum as directed. do not stop this medicine suddenly if you have used it for more than a few weeks. your doctor may lower your dose gradually. what special precautions should i follow? budesonide can suppress your immune system and adrenal glands. call your doctor if you have fever, chills, or signs of infection. avoid exposure to chickenpox or measles.before surgery or if you become ill or are under significant stress because your dose may need to be adjusted. long term use can cause increased blood pressure, fluid retention, weight gain, mood changes, changes in blood sugar, bone loss, glaucoma, and cataracts. children may have slower growth. liver disease can increase budesonide levels. many medicines can interact, especially strong inhibitors of liver enzymes such as ketoconazole, clarithromycin, and some hiv medicines. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and seville orange products because they can increase budesonide levels. ensure adequate calcium and vitamin d intake if you use this medicine long term. you can take it with or without food but try to be consistent. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at the same time. if you miss more than one dose, contact your prescriber. what side effects can this medication cause? headache, nausea, abdominal pain, indigestion, acne, and fatigue can occur. mood changes and trouble sleeping may happen. budesonide can increase blood pressure and blood sugar, cause swelling of the legs, easy bruising, and thinning of the skin. serious effects include adrenal suppression, infection, glaucoma, cataracts, and osteoporosis. seek medical care for severe abdominal pain, vision changes, severe infection, or signs of adrenal problems such as severe fatigue and dizziness.

name: budesonide and formoterol oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? this combination inhaler contains an inhaled corticosteroid and a long acting beta agonist and is used for maintenance treatment of asthma that is not adequately controlled on an inhaled corticosteroid alone or for which combination therapy is appropriate, and for maintenance treatment of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. it is not for sudden breathing problems. how should this medicine be used? inhale by mouth as prescribed, typically two puffs twice daily. prime the inhaler before first use and if it has not been used for several days. shake well before each use. exhale fully, place the mouthpiece in your mouth, press the canister and inhale deeply and steadily, then hold your breath for about ten seconds and exhale. rinse your mouth and spit after each use to reduce the risk of thrush. keep a rescue inhaler with you for sudden symptoms. do not exceed the prescribed number of inhalations. if your doctor has given you a written asthma action plan follow it carefully. what special precautions should i follow? do not use this medicine to treat an acute attack. it can cause oral thrush and hoarseness. rarely, paradoxical bronchospasm can occur. systemic steroid effects are possible especially at higher doses, including adrenal suppression, changes in blood sugar, bone loss, glaucoma, and cataracts. the long acting beta agonist component can cause tremor, nervousness, palpitations, low potassium, and increases in heart rate or blood pressure. do not use with another long acting beta agonist.if you have heart disease, high blood pressure, thyroid disease, seizures, diabetes, liver disease, or eye problems, and list all medicines you take including strong inhibitors of liver enzymes. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. rinse your mouth after each dose to reduce the risk of thrush. limit caffeine if palpitations or tremor occur. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your schedule. do not take extra puffs to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? throat irritation, hoarseness, cough, oral thrush, headache, and nausea are common. tremor, palpitations, and nervousness may occur. serious effects include worsening breathing immediately after use, pneumonia in people with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, adrenal suppression, high blood sugar, low potassium, and allergic reactions.

name: budesonide nasal spray
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? budesonide nasal spray is used to relieve nasal allergy symptoms such as congestion, sneezing, and runny nose, and may be used for nasal polyps as directed. how should this medicine be used? use once daily or as prescribed. gently blow your nose. shake and prime the spray before first use and if not used for several days. insert the tip into one nostril, aim slightly outward away from the nasal septum, press to release the spray while breathing in gently, then breathe out through the mouth. repeat in the other nostril as directed. wipe the nozzle after each use. effects may take several days to build. what special precautions should i follow? budesonide can increase the risk of nosebleeds, nasal ulcers, and delayed healing after nasal surgery or injury. rarely, a hole in the nasal septum can occur. long term use may increase the risk of infections, glaucoma, cataracts, and slowed growth in children. avoid contact with people who have chickenpox or measles.if you have tuberculosis, untreated infections, eye problems, or frequent nosebleeds. discuss pregnancy and breastfeeding with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your schedule. do not use extra sprays to make up a dose. what side effects can this medication cause? nasal irritation or burning, sore throat, cough, nosebleeds, headache, and an unpleasant taste or smell may occur. rarely, nasal or oral thrush, vision changes, and severe allergic reactions can occur. seek care if you have persistent nosebleeds, severe pain, or vision problems.

name: budesonide oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? inhaled budesonide is a corticosteroid used as a maintenance treatment to prevent and control asthma symptoms. it does not provide quick relief of sudden breathing problems. how should this medicine be used? use exactly as prescribed, usually twice daily. the device may be a dry powder inhaler or a nebulized suspension. learn and follow the instructions for your specific device. exhale fully, take a deep inhalation of the dose, hold your breath for about ten seconds, and then exhale. rinse your mouth and spit after each dose. if using a face mask for the nebulizer, wash your face after treatment to reduce skin irritation. keep a rescue inhaler with you for sudden symptoms. do not stop inhaled steroids abruptly without medical advice. what special precautions should i follow? inhaled budesonide can cause oral thrush and hoarseness. rarely, paradoxical bronchospasm can occur. systemic steroid effects may occur especially with higher doses, including adrenal suppression, increased risk of infections, glaucoma, cataracts, bone loss, and slowed growth in children.if you have liver disease, osteoporosis, tuberculosis, eye problems, or if you use other steroids. avoid exposure to chickenpox or measles. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. rinse your mouth after each dose. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your schedule. do not take extra doses to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? throat irritation, hoarseness, cough, oral thrush, headache, and nausea are common. serious effects include worsening breathing immediately after use, adrenal suppression, vision changes, severe allergic reactions, and pneumonia in people with chronic lung disease.

name: budesonide oral suspension eosinophilic esoph...
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? budesonide oral suspension is used to treat eosinophilic esophagitis, a condition that causes inflammation of the esophagus and difficulty swallowing. it reduces inflammation to relieve symptoms and help healing. how should this medicine be used? use the oral suspension exactly as directed. swallow the dose slowly to coat the esophagus. do not eat or drink for at least thirty minutes after each dose so the medicine can remain in contact with the esophagus. do not rinse your mouth or brush your teeth immediately after dosing unless your doctor directs otherwise. use for the full course prescribed and do not stop long term therapy without medical advice. what special precautions should i follow? budesonide can increase the risk of infections and may suppress adrenal function, especially with long term use. oral and esophageal thrush can occur.if you have liver disease or if you are using other steroid medicines. avoid live vaccines and contact your doctor if you are exposed to chickenpox or measles. seek care if you develop white patches in the mouth, chest pain, severe sore throat, fever, or worsening trouble swallowing. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not eat or drink for at least thirty minutes after each dose. avoid grapefruit products which can increase budesonide levels. ensure adequate calcium and vitamin d intake if therapy is prolonged. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. if you miss more than one dose, contact your prescriber. what side effects can this medication cause? sore throat, hoarseness, cough, dry mouth, mouth or throat thrush, nausea, abdominal pain, diarrhea, and headache can occur. serious effects include adrenal suppression with fatigue, dizziness, and low blood pressure, increased risk of infections, allergic reactions, and slowed growth in children with prolonged use.

name: bumetanide
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bumetanide is a loop diuretic used to reduce swelling and fluid retention caused by conditions such as heart failure, liver disease, and kidney disease. it helps the body remove excess water and salt through the urine. it may also be used off label for high blood pressure when other options are not adequate. how should this medicine be used? take bumetanide by mouth exactly as directed, usually once or twice daily. take it at the same time each day and preferably earlier in the day to limit nighttime urination. your dose may be adjusted based on your response and lab results. an injectable form may be given by a healthcare professional if needed. do not change your dose without medical advice. what special precautions should i follow?about all allergies including to sulfa medicines, and all medical conditions including kidney disease, liver disease, gout, diabetes, low blood pressure, hearing problems, and dehydration. bumetanide can cause significant fluid and electrolyte loss including low potassium, low sodium, and dehydration. your doctor will check your blood pressure, kidney function, and electrolytes. use caution when standing up as dizziness and fainting can occur.about all medicines you take, especially lithium, digoxin, other diuretics, blood pressure medicines, nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs, and ototoxic medicines such as high dose aminoglycosides. if you are pregnant, planning to become pregnant, or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow your doctor’s advice on salt and fluid intake. you may be told to limit salt and to consume potassium rich foods or take a potassium supplement if needed. avoid alcohol, which can worsen dizziness and low blood pressure. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time for your next dose. if it is late in the day, it may be better to skip to avoid waking at night to urinate. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include increased urination, dizziness, headache, thirst, muscle cramps, and weakness. it can cause low blood pressure, dehydration, and electrolyte imbalances such as low potassium which may lead to irregular heartbeat or muscle cramps. rare but serious effects include hearing changes or ringing in the ears especially with high dose injection or in kidney disease, kidney problems, severe rash, and pancreatitis characterized by severe stomach pain, nausea, and vomiting. seek urgent care for fainting, severe dehydration, confusion, severe abdominal pain, or signs of an allergic reaction such as swelling or trouble breathing.

name: bupivacaine injection
instructions: important warning: bupivacaine can cause severe and sometimes fatal local anesthetic systemic toxicity including seizures, severe low blood pressure, arrhythmias, and cardiac arrest. use only by trained clinicians with continuous monitoring and resuscitation equipment immediately available. the 0.75 percent concentration is not recommended for obstetrical paracervical block due to reports of fetal bradycardia and maternal cardiac arrest. do not use for intravenous regional anesthesia. accidental intravascular injection can be dangerous. why is this medication prescribed? bupivacaine injection is a local anesthetic used to numb an area or provide regional anesthesia or analgesia for surgical procedures, obstetrics, dental or other procedures, and for acute pain control. how should this medicine be used? it is administered by a healthcare professional as an infiltration into tissues, a peripheral nerve block, or an epidural or caudal block depending on the procedure. dose, concentration, and technique are individualized based on the site and patient factors. vital signs and neurologic status are monitored during and after administration. what special precautions should i follow? inform your clinician about heart rhythm problems, conduction abnormalities, severe liver disease, low blood pressure, seizures, or prior reactions to local anesthetics. do not receive bupivacaine for obstetrical paracervical block or for intravenous regional anesthesia. avoid intra articular infusions. tell your clinician about all medicines, especially other local anesthetics, class i antiarrhythmics, beta blockers, and strong cyp 3a4 inhibitors. use caution in pregnancy and breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary requirements. avoid alcohol or sedatives around the time of the procedure unless specifically approved. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given in a clinical setting as needed for procedures. if you believe a scheduled dose or catheter related dose was missed, contact your clinician. what side effects can this medication cause? expected effects include numbness, tingling, and weakness in the numbed area, and temporary inability to move the affected limb. common effects include nausea, vomiting, low blood pressure, dizziness, drowsiness, back pain, or urinary retention with epidural use. serious effects requiring immediate attention include seizures, ringing in the ears, metallic taste, numbness around the mouth, severe dizziness, confusion, slow or fast heartbeat, breathing problems, severe low blood pressure, cardiac arrest, allergic reactions such as rash, itching, swelling, or trouble breathing, and nerve injury or prolonged numbness.

name: bupivacaine liposomal injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? bupivacaine liposomal injection provides long lasting local pain relief after surgery when injected into the surgical site or for specific peripheral nerve blocks such as interscalene brachial plexus block for shoulder surgery. it is not approved for epidural, intrathecal, intravenous, or obstetrical paracervical use and is not for intra articular infusion. how should this medicine be used? a healthcare professional injects the medicine into tissues around the surgical site or performs an approved nerve block. it is given as a single dose. do not mix in the same syringe with other local anesthetics. if lidocaine is used, it should be given at least several minutes before and not mixed. avoid additional local anesthetics for up to 96 hours after administration unless your clinician deems it necessary with close monitoring. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about liver disease, heart rhythm problems, seizures, and any prior reactions to local anesthetics. use only for approved routes. mixing with other local anesthetics can increase toxicity. elderly patients and those with severe liver disease may be at greater risk of toxicity. inform your clinician about all medicines including other anesthetics and antiarrhythmics. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is required. avoid alcohol or sedatives around the time of your surgery unless instructed by your clinician. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is given by a healthcare professional at the time of surgery. if you think a scheduled injection or block was missed, contact your surgical team. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, constipation, vomiting, fever, dizziness, and site tenderness. serious effects include symptoms of local anesthetic toxicity such as ringing in the ears, metallic taste, numbness around the mouth, blurred vision, confusion, seizures, severe low blood pressure, slow or fast heart rate, and breathing problems. severe allergic reactions can occur with rash, itching, swelling, or difficulty breathing. seek urgent care if serious symptoms occur.

name: buprenorphine buccal chronic pain
instructions: important warning: buprenorphine can cause addiction, abuse, and misuse which can lead to overdose and death. serious, life threatening respiratory depression may occur, especially at the start of therapy or when the dose is increased. accidental exposure in children can be fatal. prolonged use during pregnancy can result in neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome which can be life threatening if not recognized and treated. concomitant use with benzodiazepines or other central nervous system depressants including alcohol can result in profound sedation, respiratory depression, coma, and death. why is this medication prescribed? buprenorphine buccal film is used to manage severe chronic pain that requires around the clock opioid treatment when other options are not adequate. it is not for as needed use. how should this medicine be used? use exactly as prescribed. place the film on the inside of the cheek and allow it to dissolve completely without chewing, swallowing, or cutting. do not eat or drink until the film has dissolved. doses are individualized and usually given every 12 hours. do not use more often than prescribed. do not abruptly stop the medicine without medical advice. what special precautions should i follow?about breathing problems, sleep apnea, head injury, liver disease, adrenal insufficiency, low blood pressure, mental health conditions, seizure disorders, and history of substance use disorder.about all medicines, especially benzodiazepines, sleeping pills, muscle relaxants, other opioids, alcohol, serotonergic medicines, and cyp 3a4 inhibitors or inducers such as certain antifungals, antibiotics, antivirals, and seizure medicines. avoid driving or operating machinery until you know how this medicine affects you. keep films in child resistant packaging and out of reach of children and pets. if pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits including the risk of neonatal withdrawal. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not drink alcohol. avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice as they may increase buprenorphine levels. maintain adequate fluid and fiber intake to help prevent constipation. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, use it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not apply two films at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include constipation, nausea, vomiting, headache, dizziness, drowsiness, dry mouth, sweating, and itching. serious effects include slow or shallow breathing, extreme sleepiness, confusion, fainting, severe low blood pressure, adrenal insufficiency with symptoms such as fatigue, loss of appetite, weight loss, dizziness, and nausea, allergic reactions with rash or swelling, serotonin syndrome when combined with serotonergic drugs with symptoms such as agitation, fever, sweating, rapid heartbeat, and muscle stiffness, and liver problems with yellowing of the skin or eyes or dark urine. seek emergency help for trouble breathing or unresponsiveness.

name: buprenorphine injection opioid dependence
instructions: important warning: long acting buprenorphine injection must be administered only as a subcutaneous injection by a healthcare professional. intravenous administration can cause serious harm or death due to occlusion and embolization of solid material. concomitant use with benzodiazepines or other central nervous system depressants including alcohol can lead to profound sedation, respiratory depression, coma, and death. why is this medication prescribed? long acting buprenorphine injection is used for the maintenance treatment of moderate to severe opioid use disorder in patients who have been clinically stabilized on a transmucosal buprenorphine product. how should this medicine be used? a healthcare professional injects the medicine as a subcutaneous depot, usually once monthly or per product schedule. do not self inject. you should be stabilized on a transmucosal buprenorphine dose before receiving the injection to reduce the risk of precipitated withdrawal. injection sites should be rotated. what special precautions should i follow?about liver disease, breathing problems, head injury, mental health conditions, and any allergies. inform your doctor about all medicines, especially benzodiazepines, sleeping pills, alcohol, other opioids, cyp 3a4 inhibitors or inducers, and serotonergic drugs. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how the injection affects you. carry proof of treatment to avoid unexpected testing concerns. if pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits including the risk of neonatal withdrawal. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not drink alcohol. avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice as they may increase buprenorphine levels. maintain hydration and oral hygiene if you also use transmucosal products during induction or bridging. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your provider as soon as possible to receive the missed injection. your provider may adjust the schedule or provide bridging therapy if needed. do not attempt to inject yourself. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include constipation, headache, nausea, vomiting, tiredness, dizziness, and injection site pain, itching, or redness. serious effects include respiratory depression, severe sedation, liver enzyme elevations, allergic reactions including rash or swelling, precipitated withdrawal if not properly induced, and adrenal insufficiency. seek emergency help for severe sleepiness, trouble breathing, or unresponsiveness.

name: buprenorphine injection pain relief
instructions: important warning: buprenorphine can cause addiction, abuse, and misuse which can lead to overdose and death. serious, life threatening respiratory depression may occur. prolonged use during pregnancy can result in neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome. concomitant use with benzodiazepines or other central nervous system depressants including alcohol can result in profound sedation, respiratory depression, coma, and death. why is this medication prescribed? buprenorphine injection is used to manage acute pain severe enough to require an opioid analgesic and for which alternative treatments are inadequate. how should this medicine be used? a healthcare professional administers buprenorphine by intramuscular or slow intravenous injection and adjusts dosing based on pain control, response, and side effects. patients are monitored for breathing, blood pressure, and level of sedation. what special precautions should i follow?about breathing problems, sleep apnea, head injury, liver disease, adrenal insufficiency, low blood pressure, seizure disorders, and history of substance use disorder.about all medicines, especially benzodiazepines, sedatives, other opioids, alcohol, cyp 3a4 inhibitors or inducers, and serotonergic drugs. use caution with driving or operating machinery. if pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not drink alcohol. maintain fluid and fiber intake to help prevent constipation. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is administered by a healthcare professional. if you think a scheduled dose in a clinical setting was missed, notify your care team. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include drowsiness, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, constipation, sweating, and headache. serious effects include slow or shallow breathing, severe low blood pressure, fainting, adrenal insufficiency, allergic reactions with rash or swelling, serotonin syndrome when combined with serotonergic drugs, and liver problems. seek urgent help for trouble breathing or severe sedation.

name: buprenorphine sublingual and buccal opioid dependence
instructions: important warning: buprenorphine can cause addiction, abuse, and misuse which can lead to overdose and death. serious, life threatening respiratory depression may occur, especially with benzodiazepines or other central nervous system depressants including alcohol. accidental exposure in children can be fatal. prolonged use during pregnancy can result in neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome. medicines dissolved in the mouth that contain buprenorphine have been associated with dental problems including cavities, tooth decay, and tooth loss. why is this medication prescribed? sublingual tablets or films and buccal films that contain buprenorphine, with or without naloxone, are used for induction and maintenance treatment of opioid use disorder as part of a comprehensive treatment plan that includes counseling and psychosocial support. how should this medicine be used? use exactly as directed. place the tablet or film under the tongue or against the inside of the cheek and allow it to dissolve completely without chewing or swallowing. do not eat or drink until the dose is fully dissolved. after the medicine dissolves, gently rinse with water and swallow to help reduce the risk of dental problems, and wait at least one hour before brushing your teeth. dosing is individualized and usually once daily. do not inject or share the medication. do not abruptly stop the medicine without medical advice. what special precautions should i follow?about liver disease, breathing problems, head injury, mental health conditions, adrenal insufficiency, gallbladder disease, and history of substance use disorder.about all medicines, especially benzodiazepines, sleeping pills, muscle relaxants, alcohol, cyp 3a4 inhibitors or inducers, and serotonergic drugs. using buprenorphine too soon after a full opioid can precipitate withdrawal. keep all forms out of reach of children and pets and store in child resistant packaging. if pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not drink alcohol. avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice which can increase buprenorphine levels. maintain good oral hygiene as directed and follow the rinse and tooth brushing advice above. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, nausea, vomiting, constipation, sweating, dizziness, drowsiness, mouth numbness or redness, and insomnia. serious effects include slow or shallow breathing, severe sedation, liver problems with yellowing of the skin or eyes or dark urine, allergic reactions with rash or swelling, adrenal insufficiency, and dental problems such as cavities, infections, and tooth loss. seek emergency help for trouble breathing or unresponsiveness.

name: buprenorphine transdermal patch
instructions: important warning: buprenorphine can cause addiction, abuse, and misuse which can lead to overdose and death. serious, life threatening respiratory depression may occur, especially when starting or increasing the dose. accidental exposure, particularly in children, can be fatal. prolonged use during pregnancy can result in neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome. concomitant use with benzodiazepines or other central nervous system depressants including alcohol can result in profound sedation, respiratory depression, coma, and death. why is this medication prescribed? the buprenorphine patch is used to control severe chronic pain that requires continuous, around the clock opioid treatment when other options are not adequate. how should this medicine be used? apply the patch to clean, dry, non irritated skin on the upper outer arm, upper chest, upper back, or side of the chest. press firmly for the time specified in the product instructions to ensure good contact. replace every 7 days unless instructed otherwise. rotate sites and do not apply to the same site within 3 weeks. do not cut or heat the patch. heat sources such as heating pads, hot baths, saunas, or fever can increase absorption and cause overdose. if a patch falls off, dispose of it safely and apply a new patch to a different site, then continue your schedule based on the new application time. keep patches away from children and pets. fold used patches and dispose as instructed, often by flushing. what special precautions should i follow?about breathing problems, sleep apnea, head injury, liver disease, heart rhythm problems including prolonged qt interval, low blood pressure, mental health conditions, and history of substance use disorder.about all medicines, especially benzodiazepines, sedatives, other opioids, alcohol, cyp 3a4 inhibitors or inducers, and serotonergic medicines. avoid driving or operating machinery until you know how you respond. if pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not drink alcohol. avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice. maintain fluid and fiber intake to reduce constipation. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply a new patch as soon as you remember. do not apply extra patches. replace the patch on the regular weekly schedule from the new application time unless your doctor advises otherwise. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include constipation, nausea, vomiting, headache, dizziness, drowsiness, itching, sweating, and skin irritation at the application site. serious effects include slow or shallow breathing, severe sleepiness, fainting, severe low blood pressure, adrenal insufficiency, allergic reactions with rash or swelling, and heart rhythm problems. seek emergency help for trouble breathing or unresponsiveness.

name: bupropion
instructions: important warning: antidepressants may increase the risk of suicidal thoughts and behavior in children, adolescents, and young adults, especially during the first few months of treatment or when the dose is changed. monitor for worsening depression, suicidal thoughts, and unusual changes in behavior, and contact a healthcare professional right away if these occur. bupropion can cause seizures, and the risk increases with higher doses and in people with certain risk factors. why is this medication prescribed? bupropion is used to treat major depressive disorder and seasonal affective disorder. a specific brand is used to help people stop smoking. it may be used off label for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and other conditions. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as prescribed. immediate release is usually taken three times daily at least 6 hours apart. sustained release is usually taken twice daily at least 8 hours apart. extended release is usually taken once daily in the morning. swallow tablets whole and do not crush, split, or chew. it may be taken with food if stomach upset occurs. it may take several weeks to feel the full benefit. do not abruptly stop without medical advice. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you have a seizure disorder, current or past bulimia or anorexia nervosa, are abruptly stopping alcohol, benzodiazepines, barbiturates, or antiepileptic drugs, or if you have used a monoamine oxidase inhibitor within the last 14 days.about head injury, brain tumor, severe liver or kidney disease, bipolar disorder, high blood pressure, glaucoma, diabetes, and all medicines and supplements you take, especially other products that contain bupropion or lower the seizure threshold such as antipsychotics, tricyclics, theophylline, systemic steroids, and stimulants. nicotine replacement with bupropion may increase blood pressure, so monitor blood pressure. limit or avoid alcohol because sudden changes in alcohol intake can increase seizure risk. if pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you can take bupropion with or without food. limit or avoid alcohol. consider moderating caffeine if you experience jitteriness or trouble sleeping. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember if there are several hours before your next dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once because this increases the risk of seizures. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include dry mouth, insomnia, headache, nausea, constipation, sweating, tremor, agitation, and anxiety. it can increase blood pressure. serious effects include seizures, severe allergic reactions with rash, hives, itching, swelling, or trouble breathing, eye pain or vision changes that may be signs of angle closure glaucoma, mood changes such as agitation, irritability, or suicidal thoughts, and confusion. seek urgent care for seizures, chest pain, severe headache, or signs of an allergic reaction.

name: burosumab-twza injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? burosumab is a monoclonal antibody used to treat x linked hypophosphatemia in adults and in children 6 months of age and older, and to treat tumor induced osteomalacia when the tumor cannot be located or removed. it works by blocking excess fibroblast growth factor 23 to increase phosphate levels and improve bone mineralization. how should this medicine be used? a healthcare professional gives burosumab as a subcutaneous injection, usually every 2 or 4 weeks depending on the condition and age. the dose is based on body weight and serum phosphorus levels. fasting serum phosphorus should be measured before starting and before each dose, and dosing should be withheld if the level is above the normal range for age. injection sites should be rotated. what special precautions should i follow? do not use burosumab with oral phosphate or active vitamin d analogs. correct vitamin d deficiency before starting. your doctor will monitor phosphorus, calcium, parathyroid hormone, and may check for ectopic calcifications such as kidney calcifications with imaging.about kidney disease, pregnancy, breastfeeding, and any allergies. report new or worsening bone pain, headaches, or visual changes. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow your doctor’s guidance on phosphate and calcium intake. do not take additional phosphate supplements or active vitamin d products unless your doctor tells you to do so. maintain adequate hydration. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your healthcare provider to reschedule as soon as possible and then continue on your regular schedule. do not take an extra dose to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, injection site reactions such as redness or pain, tooth abscess, cough, back or limb pain, decreased vitamin d levels, and dizziness. serious effects include high phosphate levels that can lead to ectopic calcifications including nephrocalcinosis, low calcium levels, hypersensitivity reactions with rash, hives, or swelling, and severe injection site reactions. seek urgent care for signs of an allergic reaction or severe symptoms.

name: buspirone
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? buspirone is used to treat anxiety disorders or to provide short term relief of symptoms of anxiety. it does not provide immediate relief and may take one to four weeks to show full benefit. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth exactly as directed, usually two or three times daily at the same times each day. take consistently either always with food or always without food. swallow tablets with water. do not start or stop other medicines without checking with your clinician. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements, especially monoamine oxidase inhibitors, linezolid, methylene blue, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors, serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors, triptans, tramadol, and st johns wort due to risk of serotonin syndrome. tell your clinician if you have liver or kidney disease. avoid alcohol. this medicine may cause dizziness or drowsiness, so do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. tell your clinician if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice. take doses consistently with respect to meals. limit alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include dizziness, drowsiness, headache, nausea, nervousness, and lightheadedness. serious effects include signs of serotonin syndrome such as agitation, confusion, sweating, fever, shivering, fast heartbeat, muscle stiffness or twitching, severe nausea or vomiting, fainting, severe rash, or chest pain. seek medical help right away for serious effects.

name: busulfan
instructions: important warning: busulfan can cause severe suppression of bone marrow that may lead to serious infections, anemia, or bleeding. it can also cause seizures, serious liver injury including hepatic veno occlusive disease, lung injury, and secondary cancers. it should be used only under the supervision of clinicians experienced in chemotherapy with frequent blood and organ function monitoring. why is this medication prescribed? busulfan is an alkylating chemotherapy used to treat certain blood cancers such as chronic myelogenous leukemia and as part of conditioning regimens before stem cell or bone marrow transplant. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as directed. doses and schedules vary by protocol. swallow tablets whole with water and do not crush or chew. wash hands after handling. caregivers should wear gloves. you will need regular blood tests and monitoring. your clinician may prescribe medicines to help prevent seizures and nausea. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements. important interactions include antifungals such as itraconazole, metronidazole, phenytoin, and acetaminophen, among others. avoid acetaminophen for seventy two hours before and after busulfan unless your oncology team instructs otherwise. report fever, chills, sore throat, bleeding, unusual bruising, cough, shortness of breath, right upper belly pain, swelling, jaundice, or seizures right away. avoid live vaccines and close contact with people who have received them. use effective contraception during treatment and for the time your clinician recommends after the last dose. do not breastfeed. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions, but stay well hydrated as directed and avoid alcohol to reduce liver strain. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your oncology team immediately for instructions. do not take an extra dose unless they tell you to do so. what side effects can this medication cause?
