name: elvitegravir, cobicistat, emtricitabine, and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate
instructions: important warning: severe acute exacerbations of hepatitis b have been reported in patients who are coinfected with hbv and hiv-1 and who have discontinued this medicine. nucleoside analogs have also been associated with lactic acidosis and severe hepatomegaly with steatosis, including fatal cases. test for hbv infection before starting, monitor hepatic function if the medicine is stopped, and seek urgent care for symptoms such as persistent nausea or vomiting, abdominal pain, unusual fatigue, shortness of breath, or jaundice. why is this medication prescribed? this fixed-dose combination, often known by the brand stribild, is used to treat hiv-1 infection in adults and certain adolescents with adequate renal function. how should this medicine be used? take one tablet by mouth once daily with food. take it at the same time each day. do not use with other antiretrovirals unless directed by your hiv specialist. your clinician will monitor kidney function, liver tests, bone health, and viral load regularly; this regimen should not be started or continued in patients with reduced kidney function as directed by current guidelines. what special precautions should i follow? tell your provider about all medicines and supplements. cobicistat has many drug interactions via cyp3a; certain anticonvulsants, rifamycins, st john’s wort, certain statins, ergot derivatives, and some sedatives are contraindicated. avoid nephrotoxic drugs if possible and tell your clinician if you develop bone pain, fractures, or symptoms of kidney problems such as increased urination or thirst. do not stop this medicine without medical guidance due to risk of viral rebound and hbv flares. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and alternatives. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take with food to ensure proper absorption. ensure adequate calcium and vitamin d intake for bone health as recommended by your clinician. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember that day with food. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. if you vomit within 1 hour of taking a dose, take another tablet; if more than 1 hour has passed, do not take an extra dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, diarrhea, headache, and fatigue. it can cause kidney problems including proximal tubulopathy, decreases in bone mineral density, and increases in liver enzymes. serious side effects include lactic acidosis and severe hepatomegaly with steatosis and severe drug interactions; seek medical help for shortness of breath, rapid breathing, persistent abdominal pain, severe weakness, jaundice, dark urine, or severe rash.

name: emapalumab-lzsg injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? emapalumab-lzsg is a monoclonal antibody that blocks interferon gamma and is used to treat primary hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis in patients with refractory, recurrent, or progressive disease or intolerance to conventional therapy. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion in a clinic or hospital, typically twice weekly, with dose adjustments based on clinical response and drug levels. you will have frequent blood tests to monitor for effectiveness and safety. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements. you are at increased risk for serious infections and reactivation of latent infections including tuberculosis; you will be screened for latent tb and may receive antimicrobial prophylaxis. report fever, cough, shortness of breath, painful urination, severe diarrhea, or other signs of infection right away. do not receive live vaccines during treatment and until your care team says it is safe. if you are pregnant, planning pregnancy, or breastfeeding, discuss risks and the need for effective contraception during treatment and for a period after the last dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions; maintain adequate hydration and follow any nutrition advice from your care team. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is administered in a healthcare setting. if you miss an appointment, contact your clinic promptly to reschedule; do not attempt to self-administer. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include infusion-related reactions such as fever, chills, flushing, or low blood pressure, infections including viral reactivation, diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain, elevated liver enzymes, high blood pressure, low blood counts, and rash. serious infections, hypersensitivity reactions, and liver problems can occur; seek immediate care for severe reactions or signs of infection.

name: emicizumab-kxwh injection
instructions: important warning: emicizumab can cause thrombotic microangiopathy and serious thromboembolic events when used with activated prothrombin complex concentrate, especially if high cumulative doses of apcc are used for more than 24 hours. avoid or limit apcc use and contact your hemophilia team for bleeding management; if apcc is required, use the lowest effective dose and monitor closely. seek immediate medical attention for chest pain, shortness of breath, limb swelling, severe headache, confusion, vision changes, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, or marked fatigue. why is this medication prescribed? emicizumab is used for routine prophylaxis to prevent or reduce bleeding in people with hemophilia a with or without factor viii inhibitors. how should this medicine be used? it is injected under the skin after training by your healthcare provider. a loading dose is given once weekly for four weeks, followed by maintenance dosing once weekly, every two weeks, or every four weeks as prescribed. use only the syringes and vials specified for your dose, follow aseptic technique, rotate injection sites, and store and handle the medicine as directed. what special precautions should i follow? tell all healthcare providers, including emergency personnel, that you are taking emicizumab because it interferes with some laboratory clotting tests; specialized assays must be used to monitor bleeding or factor levels. do not use other bypassing agents or factor products without guidance from your hemophilia treatment center. discuss pregnancy and breastfeeding with your clinician. learn how to recognize and treat bleeds per your care plan and when to seek urgent care. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary restrictions are required. what should i do if i forget a dose? inject the missed dose as soon as you remember and then resume your usual dosing schedule, maintaining the same weekly, every-2-week, or every-4-week interval from the date you administer the missed dose. do not administer two doses on the same day to make up for a missed dose. if you are unsure how to adjust your schedule, contact your clinic. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include injection site reactions such as redness, pain, or swelling, headache, joint pain, and fatigue. serious adverse effects include thrombotic microangiopathy, blood clots, and severe allergic reactions; seek immediate care for symptoms of clotting, severe abdominal pain, swelling, shortness of breath, or signs of severe hypersensitivity.

name: empagliflozin
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? empagliflozin is an sglt2 inhibitor used to improve blood sugar control in adults with type 2 diabetes as an adjunct to diet and exercise, and to reduce the risk of cardiovascular death and hospitalization for heart failure in certain patients with cardiovascular disease or heart failure. it may also be used to reduce the risk of kidney disease progression in eligible patients. how should this medicine be used? take it by mouth once daily in the morning, with or without food, as prescribed. your clinician may adjust the dose based on kidney function and treatment goals. it is not for type 1 diabetes or for treating diabetic ketoacidosis. what special precautions should i follow?about all medicines and supplements and if you have kidney disease, low blood pressure, a history of urinary tract or genital infections, peripheral vascular disease, foot ulcers, or if you are on diuretics. this medicine can increase the risk of ketoacidosis even with normal blood sugars; seek urgent care for nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, trouble breathing, unusual fatigue, or fruity-smelling breath. it can cause dehydration, low blood pressure, acute kidney injury, serious urinary tract infections, genital yeast infections, and rare necrotizing fasciitis of the perineum; maintain hydration and practice good genital hygiene. your clinician may advise temporarily stopping the medicine before major surgery, during severe illness, or when you cannot maintain normal food and fluid intake. if pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and alternatives. check your blood sugar as directed. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow your diabetes meal plan, limit excess alcohol to reduce ketoacidosis risk, and maintain adequate fluid intake unless your clinician has you restrict fluids. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember that day. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include increased urination, thirst, genital yeast infections, urinary tract infections, and mild decreases in blood pressure. other effects include nausea, dizziness, and increases in ldl cholesterol. serious effects include ketoacidosis, severe dehydration or kidney injury, severe urinary infections, fournier’s gangrene, and allergic reactions; seek immediate care for severe symptoms.

name: emtricitabine
instructions: important warning: severe acute exacerbations of hepatitis b have been reported in patients coinfected with hbv and hiv-1 who discontinue emtricitabine. test for hbv before starting and, if you have hbv, monitor hepatic function closely if emtricitabine is stopped. do not stop without medical guidance. why is this medication prescribed? emtricitabine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor used with other antiretrovirals to treat hiv-1 infection, and as part of fixed-dose combinations for hiv treatment or pre-exposure prophylaxis when appropriate. it also has activity against hepatitis b. how should this medicine be used? take it by mouth once daily, with or without food, exactly as prescribed as part of a combination regimen. do not use emtricitabine alone to treat hiv. your clinician will monitor kidney and liver function and viral load. what special precautions should i follow? tell your provider about all medicines and supplements and if you have kidney or liver disease. do not use this product alone for pre-exposure prophylaxis; use only fda-approved combinations and confirm you are hiv-negative before starting and at regular intervals to prevent resistance. do not stop therapy without medical advice. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take it with or without food. maintain adequate hydration unless otherwise instructed. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember that day. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. if you vomit within 1 hour of a dose, take another dose; if more than 1 hour has passed, do not take an extra dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, diarrhea, nausea, rash, and fatigue. skin discoloration of the palms or soles can occur. it can cause increases in liver enzymes and, rarely, lactic acidosis and severe hepatomegaly with steatosis; seek care for persistent nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, rapid breathing, jaundice, or dark urine.

name: emtricitabine and tenofovir alafenamide
instructions: important warning: if you have hepatitis b, this medicine can cause serious flare ups of hepatitis when it is stopped. your clinician will test for hepatitis b before you start and will monitor liver function for several months after stopping. if used for prep to prevent hiv, you must be confirmed hiv negative before starting and be retested regularly, because starting or continuing during undiagnosed hiv infection can lead to drug resistant virus. why is this medication prescribed? it is used with other antiretrovirals to treat hiv 1 infection and is also used for pre exposure prophylaxis to reduce the risk of getting hiv through sexual exposure in certain populations. it is not approved for individuals at risk from receptive vaginal sex. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once daily at the same time each day. swallow tablets whole. it can be taken with or without food. if used for prep, take it every day, get hiv testing before starting and at regular intervals, and use safer sex practices since no medicine is 100 percent protective. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medical conditions especially hepatitis b, kidney disease, bone problems, and pregnancy or breastfeeding plans. provide a full list of medicines and supplements because important interactions can occur with drugs that strongly affect p glycoprotein such as rifampin, carbamazepine, phenytoin, and st johns wort. kidney function and hepatitis tests will be checked before and during treatment. do not stop this medicine without medical advice if you have hepatitis b. seek urgent care for symptoms of lactic acidosis or liver problems such as unusual tiredness, rapid breathing, abdominal pain, nausea, dark urine, or yellowing of eyes or skin. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take it with or without food. stay well hydrated. do not start herbal products like st johns wort without discussing with your clinician. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember the same day. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. for prep, missed doses reduce protection; resume daily dosing as soon as possible and contact your clinician if you have had a high risk exposure. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, nausea, diarrhea, fatigue, and stomach discomfort. it can raise cholesterol and triglycerides. less common but serious effects include kidney problems, decreases in bone mineral density, severe liver problems including flares in people with hepatitis b, and rare lactic acidosis. seek immediate care for signs of allergic reaction, severe abdominal pain, shortness of breath, or yellowing of the skin or eyes.

name: emtricitabine and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate
instructions: important warning: if you have hepatitis b, this medicine can cause serious flare ups of hepatitis when it is stopped. your clinician will test for hepatitis b before you start and will monitor liver function for several months after stopping. if used for prep to prevent hiv, you must be confirmed hiv negative before starting and be retested regularly, because starting or continuing during undiagnosed hiv infection can lead to drug resistant virus. why is this medication prescribed? it is used with other antiretrovirals to treat hiv 1 infection and is also used for pre exposure prophylaxis to reduce the risk of getting hiv through sexual exposure in adults and adolescents at risk. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once daily at the same time each day, with or without food, and swallow tablets whole. if used for prep, take it every day, get hiv testing before starting and at regular intervals, and use safer sex practices. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medical conditions especially kidney disease, bone problems, and hepatitis b, and about all medicines and supplements. important interactions include nephrotoxic drugs such as high dose or multiple nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs, aminoglycosides, and amphotericin, and antiviral agents such as adefovir and didanosine. kidney function and bone health may be monitored. do not stop this medicine without medical advice if you have hepatitis b. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take it with or without food. ensure adequate calcium and vitamin d intake unless your clinician advises otherwise, and stay well hydrated. avoid starting herbal products such as st johns wort without discussing with your clinician. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember the same day. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. for prep, missed doses reduce protection; resume daily dosing as soon as possible and contact your clinician if you have had a high risk exposure. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, diarrhea, headache, and dizziness. it can decrease bone mineral density and cause kidney problems including fanconi syndrome. less common but serious effects include lactic acidosis and severe liver problems including flares in people with hepatitis b. seek immediate care for signs of allergic reaction, severe abdominal pain, muscle weakness, unusual tiredness, shortness of breath, or yellowing of the skin or eyes.

name: emtricitabine, rilpivirine, and tenofovir alafenamide
instructions: important warning: if you have hepatitis b, this medicine can cause serious flare ups of hepatitis when it is stopped. your clinician will test for hepatitis b before you start and will monitor liver function for several months after stopping. why is this medication prescribed? it is a complete regimen to treat hiv 1 infection in people with no known resistance to its components and who meet criteria set by guidelines. how should this medicine be used? take one tablet by mouth once daily with a meal. swallow whole and take at the same time each day. if you vomit within four hours of taking a dose, take another tablet and then resume your regular schedule. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medical conditions especially hepatitis b or liver disease, kidney problems, depression or other mood disorders, and pregnancy or breastfeeding plans. provide a full list of medicines and supplements. do not take proton pump inhibitors such as omeprazole. if you use h two receptor blockers such as famotidine, take them at specific times relative to this medicine as directed by your clinician. separate antacids that contain aluminum, magnesium, or calcium by at least two hours before or at least four hours after this medicine. avoid strong enzyme inducers such as rifampin, carbamazepine, phenytoin, and st johns wort. your clinician will monitor viral load and labs. do not stop this medicine without medical advice if you have hepatitis b. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you must take each dose with a meal that is more than a light snack, not just a protein drink. avoid starting herbal products such as st johns wort without medical advice. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you remember within about twelve hours of your usual time, take the dose with a meal as soon as you remember. if more than twelve hours have passed, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, nausea, diarrhea, dizziness, insomnia, and depression or mood changes. rash can occur. serious effects include worsening depression with suicidal thoughts, liver problems, kidney problems, severe skin reactions, and in people with hepatitis b a serious flare of hepatitis when the medicine is stopped. seek urgent care for signs of allergic reaction, severe rash, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, severe abdominal pain, or thoughts of self harm.

name: emtricitabine, rilpivirine, and tenofovir disoproxil fumarate
instructions: important warning: if you have hepatitis b, this medicine can cause serious flare ups of hepatitis when it is stopped. your clinician will test for hepatitis b before you start and will monitor liver function for several months after stopping. why is this medication prescribed? it is a complete regimen to treat hiv 1 infection in people with no known resistance to its components and who meet criteria set by guidelines. how should this medicine be used? take one tablet by mouth once daily with a meal. swallow whole and take at the same time each day. if you vomit within four hours of taking a dose, take another tablet and then resume your regular schedule. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medical conditions especially kidney disease, liver disease or hepatitis b, depression or other mood disorders, and pregnancy or breastfeeding plans. provide a full list of medicines and supplements. do not take proton pump inhibitors such as omeprazole. if you use h two receptor blockers such as famotidine, take them at specific times relative to this medicine as directed by your clinician. separate antacids that contain aluminum, magnesium, or calcium by at least two hours before or at least four hours after this medicine. avoid strong enzyme inducers such as rifampin, carbamazepine, phenytoin, and st johns wort. kidney function and bone health may be monitored. do not stop this medicine without medical advice if you have hepatitis b. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you must take each dose with a meal that is more than a light snack. ensure adequate calcium and vitamin d intake unless your clinician advises otherwise, and stay well hydrated. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you remember within about twelve hours of your usual time, take the dose with a meal as soon as you remember. if more than twelve hours have passed, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, nausea, diarrhea, dizziness, insomnia, and depression or mood changes. kidney problems and decreases in bone mineral density can occur. serious effects include severe liver problems, severe skin reactions, worsening depression, and in people with hepatitis b a serious flare of hepatitis when the medicine is stopped. seek urgent care for signs of allergic reaction, severe rash, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, severe abdominal pain, or thoughts of self harm.

name: enalapril
instructions: important warning: do not use this medicine if you are pregnant. drugs like enalapril can cause injury and death to an unborn baby. if you become pregnant, stop taking this medicine and contact your clinician right away. why is this medication prescribed? it is used to treat high blood pressure, to treat symptomatic heart failure, and to reduce the risk of hospitalization and death in certain people with left ventricular dysfunction. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once or twice daily as directed, with or without food, and try to take it at the same time each day. your dose may be adjusted based on blood pressure, kidney function, and response. do not stop suddenly without medical advice. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medical conditions especially kidney disease, liver disease, a history of angioedema, dehydration, heart valve disease, and if you are breastfeeding or plan to become pregnant. provide a complete list of medicines and supplements. important interactions include other medicines that affect the renin angiotensin system such as angiotensin receptor blockers or aliskiren, potassium supplements or potassium sparing diuretics, lithium, and nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs. this medicine can cause low blood pressure especially with the first doses, cough, high potassium, and kidney problems. seek emergency care for swelling of face, lips, tongue, or throat, trouble breathing, or fainting. your clinician will monitor blood pressure, kidney function, and potassium. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take it with or without food. do not use salt substitutes that contain potassium or potassium supplements unless your clinician tells you to. limit alcohol, and maintain adequate fluid intake. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include dizziness, lightheadedness, cough, fatigue, and headache. serious effects include swelling of the face or throat called angioedema, very low blood pressure, high potassium which may cause muscle weakness or slow heartbeat, kidney problems with decreased urine, and liver problems. seek urgent care for swelling, trouble breathing, fainting, chest pain, or yellowing of the skin or eyes.

name: enalapril and hydrochlorothiazide
instructions: important warning: do not use this medicine if you are pregnant. drugs that block the renin angiotensin system can cause injury and death to an unborn baby. if you become pregnant, stop taking this medicine and contact your clinician right away. why is this medication prescribed? it is used to treat high blood pressure when treatment with a single medicine has not been sufficient, combining an angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitor with a thiazide diuretic. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once daily, preferably in the morning, with or without food, at the same time each day. your clinician may adjust the dose based on blood pressure, kidney function, and how you respond. do not stop suddenly without medical advice. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medical conditions especially kidney disease, liver disease, gout, diabetes, a history of angioedema, electrolyte disorders, dehydration, and if you are breastfeeding or plan to become pregnant. provide a complete list of medicines and supplements. important interactions include other medicines that affect the renin angiotensin system, potassium supplements or salt substitutes, lithium, nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs, other diuretics, and medicines that prolong the qt interval. this medicine can cause low blood pressure especially when starting, changes in electrolytes including low sodium and magnesium and changes in potassium, kidney problems, photosensitivity, increases in uric acid that can trigger gout, and increases in blood sugar. seek emergency care for swelling of face or throat, trouble breathing, severe dizziness or fainting, or severe rash. your clinician will monitor blood pressure, kidney function, and electrolytes. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take it at the same time daily, preferably in the morning. do not start potassium supplements or salt substitutes that contain potassium unless your clinician tells you to. limit alcohol, maintain adequate fluid intake, and follow a balanced diet with moderate sodium as advised. protect your skin from sunlight to reduce photosensitivity. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember the same day. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include dizziness, lightheadedness, cough, fatigue, increased urination, and headache. other effects can include low blood pressure, electrolyte changes, kidney problems, photosensitivity, rash, high uric acid that may cause gout, increases in blood sugar, and rarely swelling of the face or throat called angioedema. seek urgent care for swelling, trouble breathing, fainting, severe abdominal pain, or yellowing of the skin or eyes.

name: enasidenib
instructions: important warning: this medicine can cause a serious and sometimes life threatening condition called differentiation syndrome. symptoms include fever, cough or trouble breathing, rapid weight gain or swelling, low blood pressure, chest pain, kidney or liver problems, and fluid around the heart or lungs. seek urgent medical care right away if these occur, especially in the first months of treatment. why is this medication prescribed? it treats adults with relapsed or refractory acute myeloid leukemia that has an idh2 mutation confirmed by an approved test. how should this medicine be used? the usual dose is taken by mouth once daily at the same time each day, with or without food, swallowing tablets whole. do not crush, chew, or split. treatment is often continued for at least several months if tolerated to allow response. if you vomit after a dose, do not take an extra dose; take the next dose at the usual time. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medical conditions especially liver problems, a history of pancreatitis, and pregnancy or breastfeeding plans. provide a full list of medicines and supplements. your clinician will check blood counts, chemistries, and liver tests regularly and may give steroids promptly if differentiation syndrome is suspected. this medicine can cause elevations in bilirubin, white blood cell increases, tumor lysis syndrome, and rarely pancreatitis. effective contraception is advised during treatment and for a period after the last dose. do not breastfeed during treatment and for a period after the last dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions with this medicine. take it consistently with or without food, stay well hydrated, and avoid excessive alcohol to protect your liver. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you remember within twelve hours, take the dose as soon as you remember. if more than twelve hours have passed, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, decreased appetite, fatigue, joint or muscle pain, and elevated bilirubin on labs which may not indicate liver injury. serious effects include differentiation syndrome, high white blood cell counts, tumor lysis syndrome, pancreatitis, liver test abnormalities, kidney problems, and infection or bleeding due to low blood counts. seek urgent care for fever, shortness of breath, rapid weight gain, swelling, severe abdominal pain, confusion, or decreased urine output.

name: encorafenib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? it treats certain cancers that have a braf v600 mutation, including unresectable or metastatic melanoma usually with binimetinib, and metastatic colorectal cancer with cetuximab. a tumor test must confirm the mutation before starting. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once daily at the same time each day, with or without food, and swallow capsules whole. if you vomit after a dose, do not take an extra dose; take the next dose at the usual time. take it exactly as prescribed with any companion medicines. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medical conditions especially heart rhythm problems, eye problems, bleeding risk, liver problems, and pregnancy or breastfeeding plans. provide a complete list of medicines and supplements. avoid strong cyp3a inhibitors or inducers because they can change drug levels. this medicine can cause new malignancies including skin cancers, bleeding, eye problems such as uveitis and retinal changes, heart rhythm changes including qt prolongation, liver test abnormalities, muscle breakdown, and serious skin reactions. use effective contraception during treatment and for a period after the last dose, and do not breastfeed during treatment and for a period after the last dose. protect your skin from the sun. your clinician will monitor labs, skin, eyes, and heart rhythm as needed. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and seville oranges and their juices because they can increase drug levels. limit alcohol, stay well hydrated, and practice sun protection including protective clothing and sunscreen. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you remember and there are at least twelve hours before your next dose, take it as soon as you remember. if the next dose is due within twelve hours, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fatigue, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, constipation or diarrhea, joint or muscle pain, rash, and hair thinning. other effects include increased liver enzymes, bleeding, photosensitivity, high blood pressure, eye problems such as blurry vision or eye pain, and heart rhythm changes. seek urgent care for severe rash, shortness of breath, chest pain, severe abdominal pain, vision changes, signs of bleeding, or fainting.

name: enfortumab vedotin-ejfv injection
instructions: important warning: severe and sometimes life threatening skin reactions including stevens johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis can occur and have been fatal. stop treatment and seek emergency care for widespread or worsening rash, blistering, peeling skin, mouth sores, eye irritation, fever, or painful skin. why is this medication prescribed? it is an antibody drug conjugate used to treat adults with locally advanced or metastatic urothelial cancer in specific settings, including after certain prior therapies and in combination with pembrolizumab in some patients who are not candidates for cisplatin. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion in cycles by a trained healthcare professional. dosing and schedule will be determined by your clinician. keep all infusion appointments and lab visits. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medical conditions especially diabetes or high blood sugar, nerve problems, lung disease, liver problems, eye problems, and pregnancy or breastfeeding plans. provide a complete list of medicines and supplements. this medicine can cause severe skin reactions, high blood sugar including diabetic ketoacidosis, peripheral neuropathy, infusion reactions, pneumonitis, liver test abnormalities, eye disorders, and low blood counts. your clinician will check blood sugar and other labs and will examine your skin and nerves regularly. use effective contraception during treatment and for a period after the last dose, and do not breastfeed during treatment and for a period after the last dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no strict dietary restrictions, but stay well hydrated, report poor oral intake, and if you have diabetes follow your clinician’s guidance on diet and glucose monitoring. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss or must delay an infusion, contact your clinic as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to make up a dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fatigue, decreased appetite, nausea, diarrhea, constipation, hair loss, taste changes, dry eyes, and skin rash or itching. serious effects include severe skin reactions as above, high blood sugar that may present with increased thirst or urination, confusion, or nausea, peripheral neuropathy with numbness or burning, pneumonitis with cough or shortness of breath, infusion reactions with chills or breathing difficulty, liver problems, eye pain or vision changes, and infections due to low blood counts. seek urgent care for severe rash, trouble breathing, severe weakness, confusion, or signs of infection such as fever or chills.

name: enfuvirtide injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? it is an antiretroviral used with other medicines to treat hiv 1 infection in people whose virus is resistant to or who are otherwise unable to use standard regimens. it is not used for pre exposure prophylaxis. how should this medicine be used? it is given as a subcutaneous injection usually into the upper arm, abdomen, or front of the thigh, twice daily as directed. you or a caregiver will be taught how to reconstitute the powder with sterile water and inject it. rotate injection sites and avoid areas with moles, scars, bruises, or the navel. do not mix with other medicines in the same syringe. store and handle as instructed. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medical conditions especially bleeding disorders such as hemophilia, lung disease, and any history of allergic reactions, and if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. provide a full list of medicines and supplements. this medicine can cause injection site reactions, bacterial pneumonia, and hypersensitivity reactions characterized by rash, fever, nausea, vomiting, chills, rigors, low blood pressure, elevated liver enzymes, or blood abnormalities. stop the medicine and seek urgent care if a hypersensitivity reaction is suspected and do not restart unless directed by your clinician. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions with this medicine. maintain a healthy diet and stay hydrated. what should i do if i forget a dose? inject the missed dose as soon as you remember on the same day, then take the next dose at the regular time. if it is nearly time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not inject two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? very common effects are injection site reactions including pain, redness, induration, nodules, cysts, bruising, or itching. other effects include nausea, diarrhea, weight loss, insomnia, cough, numbness or tingling, muscle pain, and eosinophilia. serious effects include hypersensitivity reactions and increased risk of bacterial pneumonia. seek urgent care for fever, severe shortness of breath, widespread rash, severe dizziness, or signs of infection at an injection site such as warmth, pus, or spreading redness.

name: enoxaparin injection
instructions: important warning: using enoxaparin with spinal or epidural anesthesia or spinal puncture increases the risk of a spinal or epidural blood clot that can cause long term or permanent paralysis. the risk is higher with indwelling epidural catheters, multiple or traumatic punctures, and use of other medicines that affect bleeding. watch for numbness, weakness, or loss of bowel or bladder control and seek urgent help. enoxaparin can cause serious or fatal bleeding. do not use if you have active major bleeding or a history of immune mediated heparin induced low platelet count. use caution with medicines that increase bleeding risk. why is this medication prescribed? enoxaparin is a blood thinner used to prevent and treat blood clots in the legs and lungs, to prevent clots after certain surgeries or during hospitalization, and for certain heart conditions such as unstable chest pain and heart attack. how should this medicine be used? inject under the skin as directed, usually once or twice daily. a healthcare provider will teach you the injection technique. use the prefilled syringe at room temperature. choose a site on the right or left side of the abdomen at least two inches from the belly button. clean the skin, pinch a skin fold, insert the needle straight in, and inject the full dose. do not inject into muscle, do not expel the air bubble, do not rub the site, and rotate sites. the dose depends on your condition and kidney function. if you are also taking a blood thinner by mouth, your provider will tell you when to start and stop each medicine. what special precautions should i follow? tell your provider about bleeding problems, recent surgery or injury, stroke, stomach or intestinal ulcers, eye problems from diabetes or high blood pressure, liver or kidney disease, low body weight, older age, pregnancy, and any spinal or epidural procedure. tell all providers and your dentist that you take enoxaparin. avoid aspirin, nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs, other blood thinners, or supplements that increase bleeding unless your provider says to use them. do not use if you are allergic to enoxaparin, heparin, or pork products, or if you have had immune mediated heparin induced low platelet count. your provider may check blood counts, kidney function, and potassium. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is required. limit alcohol. you do not need to change vitamin k intake for this medicine. avoid herbal products that increase bleeding risk such as ginkgo, garlic, and high dose fish oil unless approved by your provider. what should i do if i forget a dose? inject as soon as you remember the same day. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose. do not inject two doses at the same time. call your provider if you miss more than one dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include bruising or mild pain at the injection site. serious effects include unusual bleeding, nosebleeds, bleeding gums, blood in urine or stool, coughing or vomiting blood, severe headache, dizziness, weakness, shortness of breath, chest pain, leg swelling or pain, low platelets, allergic reactions, high potassium, bone loss with long term use, skin necrosis at the injection site, and symptoms of a spinal or epidural blood clot such as back pain, numbness or weakness in the legs, or loss of bladder or bowel control. seek emergency care for signs of severe bleeding or spinal cord symptoms.

name: ensartinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ensartinib is a targeted therapy used to treat certain lung cancers that are positive for an anaplastic lymphoma kinase gene change, specifically non small cell lung cancer. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth exactly as prescribed once daily at the same time each day, with or without food. swallow tablets whole and do not crush or chew. if you vomit after taking a dose, do not take an extra dose and take the next dose at the usual time. your provider may change your dose based on side effects. what special precautions should i follow? tell your provider if you have liver disease, lung disease, heart rhythm problems, slow heart rate, or if you take medicines that affect heart rhythm. use sun protection because skin can be more sensitive to sunlight. your provider may check liver tests, electrocardiograms, and electrolytes. tell your provider about all medicines and supplements you take. avoid strong inhibitors or inducers of the enzyme cyp3a unless your provider adjusts therapy. use effective birth control during treatment and for a period after the last dose as directed by your provider, and do not breastfeed during treatment and for a period after the last dose. seek medical help right away for new or worsening cough, shortness of breath, chest pain, severe rash, yellowing of the skin or eyes, or fainting. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice. stay well hydrated unless your provider gives you different instructions. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose and remember within about twelve hours, take it as soon as you remember. if more than about twelve hours have passed or it is close to your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include rash, itching, skin sensitivity to sunlight, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea or constipation, decreased appetite, fatigue, swelling, and changes in liver tests. serious effects can include liver injury, inflammation of the lungs that causes cough and shortness of breath, heart rhythm problems including prolonged qt interval or slow heart rate, severe skin reactions, high blood pressure, and changes in vision. contact your provider for persistent or severe symptoms.

name: ensifentrine oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ensifentrine is an inhaled medicine used as a maintenance treatment to improve breathing in adults with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. it is not a rescue medicine for sudden breathing problems. how should this medicine be used? inhale the prescribed dose using a standard jet nebulizer twice daily as directed. do not use it to treat sudden shortness of breath. do not mix it with other medicines in the nebulizer unless your provider instructs you to do so. use only the device types recommended by your provider, and clean and maintain the nebulizer after each use according to the manufacturer instructions. what special precautions should i follow? tell your provider if you have asthma, heart rhythm problems, severe liver or kidney disease, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. stop using the medicine and get medical help right away if breathing gets worse immediately after inhalation. tell your provider about all medicines you use, including other inhalers and oral therapies for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary changes are required. stay hydrated as advised by your provider. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it as soon as you remember the same day. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use extra doses to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include cough, throat irritation, upper respiratory symptoms, headache, nausea, and diarrhea. less common but serious effects may include paradoxical bronchospasm or allergic reactions such as rash, swelling, or trouble breathing. contact your provider if side effects are severe or do not improve.

name: entacapone
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? entacapone is used with levodopa and carbidopa to treat parkinson disease. it helps levodopa last longer in the body to reduce wearing off and improve symptom control. it is not used by itself. how should this medicine be used? take one tablet by mouth with each dose of levodopa and carbidopa, usually 200 milligrams each time, up to eight times per day or as directed. swallow with water and continue your usual levodopa and carbidopa schedule unless your provider changes it. your provider may adjust your levodopa dose after starting entacapone. do not stop entacapone or levodopa suddenly without medical guidance. what special precautions should i follow? tell your provider about liver disease, low blood pressure, fainting, hallucinations, sleepiness, severe diarrhea, a history of colitis, or muscle breakdown. entacapone may increase uncontrolled movements or cause dizziness, low blood pressure, sleepiness, hallucinations, or impulse control problems such as gambling or increased urges. use caution when driving or operating machinery until you know how it affects you. urine, sweat, or saliva may become brownish orange and this is not harmful. seek help for persistent diarrhea, confusion, fever, severe muscle stiffness, or dark urine with muscle pain. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is required for entacapone. because levodopa can be affected by high protein meals, your provider may advise a consistent protein intake and good hydration. limit alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, take entacapone with your next levodopa and carbidopa dose. do not take two entacapone doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, diarrhea, stomach discomfort, dizziness, drowsiness, dry mouth, urine discoloration, and increased involuntary movements. serious effects can include severe diarrhea with weight loss, hallucinations, confusion, low blood pressure with fainting, severe muscle stiffness or breakdown, and allergic reactions. call your provider for severe or persistent symptoms.

name: entecavir
instructions: important warning: stopping entecavir can cause a severe flare of hepatitis b. do not stop this medicine without talking with your provider and continue close monitoring of liver tests for several months after stopping. entecavir and other medicines for hepatitis b have been associated with lactic acidosis and severe liver enlargement with fat. seek immediate care for unusual muscle pain, trouble breathing, stomach pain with nausea and vomiting, cold or blue hands and feet, dizziness, or fast or irregular heartbeat. if you have human immunodeficiency virus that has not been treated, using entecavir by itself can lead to resistant human immunodeficiency virus. test for human immunodeficiency virus before starting and treat both infections appropriately. why is this medication prescribed? entecavir is an antiviral used to treat chronic hepatitis b virus infection in adults and children with evidence of active viral replication and liver inflammation. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once daily on an empty stomach at least two hours before or after a meal. the dose depends on prior hepatitis b treatment and kidney function. take it regularly as long term therapy as directed. your provider will monitor hepatitis b virus levels and liver tests. what special precautions should i follow? tell your provider if you have kidney disease, liver disease including cirrhosis, a history of human immunodeficiency virus, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. do not miss doses or stop without medical advice because this increases the risk of hepatitis flare. your provider may adjust the dose if you have reduced kidney function and will monitor for lactic acidosis and liver problems. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take on an empty stomach. avoid alcohol and follow a liver healthy diet as advised. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. tell your provider if you miss more than one dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, fatigue, dizziness, nausea, and diarrhea. serious effects include a flare of hepatitis after stopping, lactic acidosis with symptoms such as deep rapid breathing and severe weakness, liver enlargement with fat, severe liver problems with yellowing of the skin or eyes and dark urine, and severe allergic reactions. contact your provider right away for serious symptoms.

name: entrectinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? entrectinib is a targeted therapy used to treat cancers that have a neurotrophic receptor tyrosine kinase gene fusion in adults and certain children, and to treat adults with metastatic lung cancer that has a ros1 gene rearrangement. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once daily as prescribed, with or without food, at the same time each day. swallow capsules whole and do not open or crush. if you vomit after a dose, do not take an extra dose and take the next dose at the usual time. your provider may change the dose for side effects or based on body size in children. what special precautions should i follow? tell your provider if you have heart failure, heart rhythm problems, liver disease, gout or high uric acid, bone problems, fractures, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. entrectinib can cause heart failure, liver injury, dizziness and cognitive changes, fractures, weight gain, high uric acid, and heart rhythm changes. your provider may check heart function, liver tests, uric acid, and electrocardiograms. use effective birth control during treatment and for the period recommended by your provider after the last dose. avoid driving or activities that need alertness if you feel dizzy or confused. tell your provider about all medicines and supplements. avoid strong inhibitors or inducers of the enzyme cyp3a. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice. stay well hydrated, especially if your uric acid is high. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose and remember within about twelve hours, take it as soon as you remember. if it is less than about twelve hours until your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. if you vomit after taking a dose, do not take an extra dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fatigue, swelling, constipation or diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, altered taste, dizziness, cough, shortness of breath, weight gain, and changes in liver tests. serious effects can include heart failure with shortness of breath and swelling, liver problems with yellowing of the skin or eyes, high uric acid that can cause kidney problems, fractures and bone pain, confusion, memory problems, hallucinations, and heart rhythm changes. contact your provider for severe or persistent symptoms.

name: enzalutamide
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? enzalutamide is used to treat prostate cancer, including metastatic and nonmetastatic disease, and is usually given with ongoing androgen deprivation therapy or after surgical removal of the testes. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once daily as prescribed, with or without food, at the same time each day. swallow tablets or capsules whole. continue androgen deprivation therapy while taking enzalutamide unless your provider tells you otherwise. what special precautions should i follow? tell your provider if you have a history of seizures, brain injury, stroke, heart disease, high blood pressure, falls or fractures, liver problems, or if you are taking medicines that interact with enzymes cyp2c8 or cyp3a. enzalutamide can cause dizziness, confusion, sleepiness, falls, fractures, seizures, high blood pressure, and rarely a reversible brain condition with headache, vision changes, and seizures. use caution when driving or operating machinery until you know how it affects you. your provider may monitor blood pressure and other labs. enzalutamide can harm an unborn baby. use effective contraception during treatment and for at least three months after the last dose. do not donate sperm during this time. do not breastfeed. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is required. limit alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember on the same day. if you miss the dose for an entire day, take your usual dose the next day. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fatigue, hot flashes, joint or back pain, diarrhea, swelling, headache, falls, and high blood pressure. serious effects can include seizures, confusion or memory problems, fainting, chest pain, signs of stroke, and severe allergic reactions. contact your provider for severe or persistent symptoms.

name: epcoritamab-bysp injection
instructions: important warning: epcoritamab can cause cytokine release syndrome and serious neurologic toxicity including immune effector cell associated neurotoxicity. these can be life threatening or fatal. you will receive stepwise dose increases and premedication, and you will be monitored closely after injections. seek urgent care for fever, chills, low blood pressure, shortness of breath, fast heart rate, confusion, difficulty speaking, severe headache, tremor, seizures, or weakness. why is this medication prescribed? epcoritamab is an immune therapy used to treat certain relapsed or refractory b cell lymphomas in adults. how should this medicine be used? it is given as a subcutaneous injection by a healthcare professional using a schedule that starts with low doses and increases to a full dose, then continues at regular intervals. you will receive premedications such as steroids, antihistamines, and fever reducers and may need observation after some doses. do not attempt to self inject. keep all appointments for lab tests and monitoring. what special precautions should i follow? tell your provider about infections, fever, low blood counts, liver problems, neurologic conditions, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. epcoritamab can cause low white cells, low platelets, anemia, serious infections, cytokine release syndrome, and neurologic problems. your provider may screen for hepatitis b and other infections and may give preventive medicines. avoid live vaccines during treatment and until your provider says they are safe. use effective birth control during treatment and for the period recommended by your provider after the last dose. do not drive or operate machinery if you have neurologic symptoms. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is required. stay well hydrated unless your provider gives you different instructions. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your healthcare team as soon as possible. the dosing schedule will need to be adjusted by your provider. do not try to make up a dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fever, chills, fatigue, injection site redness or pain, nausea, diarrhea, cough, and swelling. serious effects include cytokine release syndrome with fever, low blood pressure, low oxygen, rapid heart rate, neurologic toxicity with confusion, tremor, headache, seizures, or weakness, severe infections, low white blood cells, low platelets, anemia, and liver test abnormalities. seek urgent care for signs of cytokine release syndrome or neurologic toxicity.

name: epinastine ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? epinastine eye drops are used to prevent itching of the eyes due to allergic conjunctivitis. how should this medicine be used? wash your hands. tilt your head back, pull down the lower eyelid to make a small pocket, and instill one drop in the affected eye or eyes twice daily or as directed. avoid touching the tip of the dropper to the eye or any surface. if you wear contact lenses, remove them before using the drops and wait at least ten minutes before reinserting lenses. if you use other eye medicines, wait at least five minutes between products. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if the solution is discolored or contains particles. tell your provider if you have eye infections, wear contact lenses, or have other eye problems. if you develop eye pain, change in vision, severe redness, or if symptoms worsen or last more than a few days, contact your provider. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary changes are required. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not instill extra drops to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include mild burning or stinging in the eyes, dry eyes, unusual taste, headache, and eye redness or irritation. serious allergic reactions are rare but seek medical help for swelling, severe redness, or trouble breathing.

name: epinephrine nasal spray
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? epinephrine nasal spray is used for the emergency treatment of severe allergic reactions including anaphylaxis. it provides rapid epinephrine delivery through the nose. how should this medicine be used? use at the first signs of a severe allergic reaction such as trouble breathing, throat or tongue swelling, hives with dizziness or fainting, or low blood pressure. remove the device from its packaging, hold it upright with your fingers on the sides, insert the tip into one nostril until your fingers touch the nose, and press the plunger firmly to deliver the dose while breathing normally. do not prime or test spray. after using, call emergency services right away. if symptoms are not improving or return, a second dose may be given with a new device after about five minutes as directed by your provider. always carry two devices. what special precautions should i follow? tell your provider if you have heart disease, irregular heartbeat, high blood pressure, thyroid disease, diabetes, narrow angle glaucoma, or if you take certain medicines such as monoamine oxidase inhibitors, tricyclic antidepressants, or beta blockers. epinephrine can increase heart rate and blood pressure. use only for a severe allergic reaction and seek emergency medical care after use. check expiration dates and replace before expiration. store as directed and avoid extreme temperatures. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid known allergens. no specific diet is otherwise required. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is used as needed for a severe allergic reaction. use it immediately when symptoms begin and then seek emergency care. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fast heart rate, palpitations, sweating, tremor, anxiety, headache, nausea, dizziness, and nasal discomfort. serious effects can include chest pain, severe headache, irregular heartbeat, stroke symptoms, or severe high blood pressure. seek emergency care and tell responders that you used epinephrine.

name: epinephrine oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? epinephrine oral inhalation is used for the temporary relief of mild intermittent asthma symptoms such as shortness of breath and wheezing. it is not a controller medicine and does not replace prescribed inhaled corticosteroids or a rescue prescription inhaler if you have a diagnosis that requires them. how should this medicine be used? use exactly as directed on the label or by your clinician. shake the canister, exhale fully, seal your lips around the mouthpiece, and inhale one puff while pressing the canister, then hold your breath for about ten seconds. if symptoms are not relieved, a second inhalation may be used. typical label directions allow one to two inhalations every four hours as needed and not more than the maximum daily number of inhalations on the product label. if you need to use it more often than directed or symptoms are not relieved, seek medical care promptly. how should i prime and care for the device? prime before first use and if it has not been used for a period of time, and keep the mouthpiece clean and dry following the product instructions. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have heart disease, high blood pressure, irregular heartbeat, thyroid disease, diabetes, glaucoma, prostate enlargement, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. do not use if you are taking or have taken a monoamine oxidase inhibitor within the last two weeks. use caution if you take tricyclic antidepressants, beta blockers, or other stimulants including some cold medicines and caffeine. if you have no formal asthma diagnosis or have frequent symptoms, see a clinician to confirm appropriate therapy. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary requirements, but limit caffeine and other stimulants that may increase side effects such as nervousness or fast heartbeat. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is used as needed for symptoms and is not for a fixed schedule. do not use extra doses to make up for a missed dose. seek medical advice if you feel you need frequent dosing. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fast heartbeat, tremor, nervousness, headache, and trouble sleeping. serious effects that require urgent care include chest pain, severe shortness of breath, fainting, very fast or irregular heartbeat, or no improvement in breathing after use.

name: epirubicin
instructions: important warning: epirubicin can cause serious heart damage including heart failure that may occur during treatment or months to years later, and the risk increases with higher total lifetime dose or when combined with other medicines that affect the heart. it can cause severe bone marrow suppression leading to infection, anemia, and bleeding, and can increase the risk of developing certain leukemias. leakage of the drug outside the vein can cause severe tissue injury. this medicine must be given only under the supervision of clinicians experienced in cancer chemotherapy with access to adequate monitoring and supportive care. why is this medication prescribed? epirubicin is an anthracycline chemotherapy used to treat breast cancer and other cancers as determined by an oncologist. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion in treatment cycles, often with other chemotherapy, by trained staff in a clinic or hospital. the dose and schedule are individualized based on body size, organ function, and prior therapies. it is never given by intramuscular or subcutaneous injection. your care team will monitor blood counts, heart function, and liver tests before and during treatment. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all heart problems, prior chest radiation, prior anthracycline exposure, liver disease, infections, and all medicines and supplements you take. report fever, chills, sore throat, unusual bruising or bleeding, shortness of breath, swelling, chest pain, fast or irregular heartbeat, or pain and redness at the infusion site immediately. avoid live vaccines during and after therapy as advised. effective contraception is needed during treatment and for the recommended period after, because epirubicin can harm an unborn baby. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific food restrictions. eat small frequent meals, maintain hydration, and use anti nausea measures as prescribed. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an infusion appointment, contact your oncology clinic as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to make up a dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, mouth sores, hair loss, fatigue, and temporary reddish discoloration of urine. serious effects include low white blood cell counts with infection, bleeding, heart failure, arrhythmias, severe infusion site reactions including tissue damage if the drug leaks outside the vein, and secondary leukemia.

name: eplerenone
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? eplerenone is used to treat high blood pressure and to improve survival and reduce the risk of heart failure after a heart attack in certain patients. it works by blocking aldosterone to help the body eliminate excess salt and water while retaining potassium. how should this medicine be used? take eplerenone by mouth at the same time each day, with or without food, exactly as prescribed. your clinician will check blood pressure, kidney function, and potassium regularly and adjust the dose accordingly. do not stop taking it without medical advice even if you feel well. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about kidney disease, high potassium, diabetes, dehydration, and all medicines you take. do not use potassium supplements, salt substitutes containing potassium, or other potassium sparing drugs unless directed. dangerous interactions can occur with strong inhibitors of the enzyme that clears eplerenone such as ketoconazole, itraconazole, clarithromycin, nefazodone, and certain antiviral medicines. use caution with angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, trimethoprim, cyclosporine, tacrolimus, and nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs because they can raise potassium or affect kidneys. what special dietary instructions should i follow? limit high potassium foods such as large amounts of bananas, oranges, tomato products, and certain salt substitutes. avoid grapefruit juice. follow any fluid or sodium recommendations your clinician gives you. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is close to the next dose. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? possible effects include high potassium which can cause muscle weakness, numbness, or a slow or irregular heartbeat, dizziness, low blood pressure especially when standing, kidney function changes, cough, and fatigue. seek care for signs of very high potassium such as severe weakness, fainting, or palpitations.

name: eplontersen injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? eplontersen is used to treat adults with polyneuropathy caused by hereditary transthyretin mediated amyloidosis. it reduces production of transthyretin to slow nerve damage. how should this medicine be used? it is given as a subcutaneous injection on a regular schedule as directed by your clinician. you may receive loading doses followed by maintenance dosing. your clinician may administer it or will train you or a caregiver to inject it. rotate injection sites and do not inject into areas of redness, tenderness, or bruising. blood tests will be done regularly to check platelets, kidney function, liver enzymes, and vitamin a levels. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about any bleeding problems, use of blood thinners, kidney disease, liver disease, eye problems, and all medicines and supplements you take. eplontersen can lower platelets and affect kidneys. report unusual bruising, nosebleeds, blood in urine, decreased urination, swelling, or sudden weight gain. it can lower vitamin a and cause eye symptoms such as trouble seeing in low light. pregnancy should be avoided during treatment and for the recommended time after the last dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? your clinician may prescribe vitamin a supplementation. take only the amount recommended by your clinician. do not take extra vitamin a beyond what is prescribed. maintain good hydration. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is close to the time of your next scheduled dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. call your clinician for specific guidance if you are unsure. do not inject extra doses. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include injection site redness or pain, tiredness, headache, nausea, and joint or muscle pain. serious effects include low platelets with bleeding, kidney problems, elevations in liver enzymes, and symptoms of low vitamin a such as night vision changes.

name: epoetin alfa, injection
instructions: important warning: epoetin alfa can increase the risk of death, heart attack, stroke, heart failure, blood clots, and tumor growth or return in some people with cancer. use the lowest dose needed to reduce the need for red blood cell transfusions. do not target a hemoglobin level above the range recommended by your clinician. in people having surgery it can increase the risk of blood clots and blood clot prevention may be required. why is this medication prescribed? epoetin alfa is used to treat anemia due to chronic kidney disease, chemotherapy in certain cancers, and zidovudine treatment in people with hiv, and to reduce the need for transfusions in some surgical patients. how should this medicine be used? it is given by subcutaneous or intravenous injection on an individualized schedule. your clinician will check hemoglobin, blood pressure, and iron status regularly and adjust the dose. do not shake the vial or syringe, do not freeze, store in the refrigerator, and allow to reach room temperature before injection. rotate injection sites as instructed. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you have uncontrolled high blood pressure. tell your clinician if you have a history of seizures, heart disease, stroke, blood clots, or if you develop severe fatigue, shortness of breath, chest pain, leg swelling, severe headache, or sudden weakness or vision changes. rarely, severe anemia due to antibodies to erythropoietin can occur. report loss of effect or sudden drop in hemoglobin. discuss pregnancy and breastfeeding with your clinician. what special dietary instructions should i follow? ensure adequate iron, folate, and vitamin b12 intake. your clinician may prescribe iron supplements. follow any fluid and salt recommendations, especially if you have kidney disease or high blood pressure. what should i do if i forget a dose? inject it as soon as you remember unless it is close to your next dose. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not use extra medicine to make up the missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include high blood pressure, headache, joint or muscle pain, rash, and injection site irritation. serious effects include blood clots, stroke, heart attack, heart failure, seizures, severe allergic reactions, and pure red cell aplasia.

name: epoprostenol
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? epoprostenol is used to treat pulmonary arterial hypertension to improve exercise capacity and symptoms. it relaxes blood vessels in the lungs and inhibits platelet function. how should this medicine be used? it is given as a continuous intravenous infusion through a central venous catheter using a portable infusion pump. treatment is started in the hospital and the dose is carefully adjusted. the medicine is prepared exactly as instructed with its designated diluent. keep backup medication, a spare pump, batteries, and infusion supplies available at all times. do not interrupt the infusion. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about bleeding disorders, low blood pressure, heart disease, kidney or liver problems, and all medicines and supplements you take. epoprostenol can increase the risk of bleeding especially with blood thinners and can cause low blood pressure and dizziness. there is risk of catheter infection. learn pump operation and catheter care and have an emergency plan for pump or catheter issues. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. maintain adequate hydration and avoid alcohol that may worsen dizziness or low blood pressure. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is delivered continuously and should not be stopped. if the infusion is interrupted, restart as instructed immediately and seek urgent medical help. use backup equipment if needed. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, flushing, jaw pain, muscle or bone pain, diarrhea, nausea, and low blood pressure with dizziness. serious effects include bleeding, catheter related infections, catheter complications, and sudden worsening of pulmonary hypertension if the infusion stops.

name: clindamycin topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? topical clindamycin is used to treat acne by reducing the number of acne causing bacteria and skin inflammation. how should this medicine be used? apply a thin layer to the affected skin as directed, usually once or twice daily, on clean and dry skin. avoid contact with eyes, mouth, inside the nose, and broken skin. wash hands after application. continue as prescribed since full benefit may take several weeks. if using pledgets, foam, gel, or lotion, follow the specific product instructions. do not use more than directed. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have a history of colitis or severe diarrhea with antibiotics, or sensitive skin. stop and seek care if you develop severe or persistent diarrhea, abdominal cramps, or blood in stools since serious intestinal inflammation has rarely occurred with topical use. avoid using other products that can irritate skin unless advised. using topical erythromycin with clindamycin is not recommended. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no special dietary requirements. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply it as soon as you remember. if it is close to the time for your next application, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include dry skin, redness, itching, stinging, peeling, and oily skin changes. less common but serious effects include severe diarrhea and colitis and allergic reactions such as rash, hives, or swelling.

name: c1-esterase inhibitor recombinant injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? recombinant c1 esterase inhibitor is used to treat acute attacks of hereditary angioedema by replacing the deficient protein and stopping the attack. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous injection after mixing the powder with the supplied liquid. the dose is based on body weight. it should be given as early as possible at the first sign of an attack. after proper training, some patients may self administer. use aseptic technique and follow all reconstitution and administration instructions provided by your clinician. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you have a known allergy to rabbits or rabbit derived products because serious allergic reactions can occur. tell your clinician about any history of blood clots and all medicines you take. stop the infusion and seek urgent care if you develop hives, chest tightness, trouble breathing, dizziness, or swelling. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no special dietary requirements. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is used to treat an attack. if you delayed treating an attack, administer a dose as soon as possible as directed. do not take repeat doses sooner than advised by your clinician. if you miss a planned training or clinic dose, contact your clinician to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, nausea, diarrhea, and injection site reactions. serious effects include allergic reactions including anaphylaxis and rare blood clots.

name: cabazitaxel injection
instructions: important warning: cabazitaxel can cause severe and sometimes fatal bone marrow suppression with very low white blood cells and infection. severe diarrhea and dehydration can occur. severe allergic reactions can occur even with premedication. use only in patients with adequate baseline blood counts and liver function and with clinicians experienced in chemotherapy. primary prevention with a white blood cell growth factor is recommended in patients at increased risk. why is this medication prescribed?
