cabazitaxel is used with prednisone to treat metastatic castration resistant prostate cancer in patients previously treated with docetaxel. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion, usually over one hour, every three weeks. you will receive premedications such as an antihistamine, a corticosteroid, and an acid reducer before each dose. take oral prednisone as directed every day during treatment. your clinician will monitor blood counts, kidney and liver tests, and adjust the dose for side effects. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements. strong inhibitors or inducers of the enzyme that clears cabazitaxel can change its levels. do not receive live vaccines during treatment. report fever, chills, diarrhea, dehydration, dizziness, fainting, mouth sores, numbness or tingling, shortness of breath, rash, or swelling right away. use caution if you have liver problems, are older, or have poor performance status. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and seville orange products. maintain good hydration. follow antidiarrheal instructions at the first sign of loose stools. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an infusion appointment, contact your oncology clinic immediately to reschedule. if you miss a dose of your prescribed prednisone, take it as soon as you remember unless it is close to the next dose and call your clinician for advice. do not take extra cabazitaxel or extra prednisone without guidance. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include low white and red blood cells, infection, fever, fatigue, weakness, hair loss, taste changes, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and numbness or tingling in hands or feet. serious effects include severe infection and sepsis, severe diarrhea with dehydration and kidney failure, low blood pressure, severe allergic reactions with rash, hives, trouble breathing, and liver problems.

name: cabergoline
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cabergoline is used to treat high prolactin levels and prolactin producing pituitary tumors which can cause irregular periods, infertility, sexual dysfunction, or breast discharge. it is a dopamine agonist that lowers prolactin. how should this medicine be used? take cabergoline by mouth usually twice weekly as prescribed. start with a low dose and increase gradually to minimize side effects. take with food to reduce stomach upset and consider taking at bedtime if dizziness or nausea occur. do not stop taking it without medical advice. your clinician will monitor prolactin levels and clinical response and may periodically assess heart valves. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about heart valve disease, lung or heart lining inflammation, scarring disorders, low blood pressure, liver disease, psychiatric conditions, and all medicines and supplements you take. cabergoline can cause low blood pressure when standing, dizziness, sleepiness, and rarely sudden sleep episodes. it can cause or worsen heart valve problems and fibrotic reactions in the lungs or abdomen with long term use. report shortness of breath, chest pain, swelling in legs, persistent cough, new heart murmur, severe abdominal or back pain, or behavior changes such as compulsive gambling or shopping. avoid driving until you know how it affects you. discuss pregnancy plans before starting or stopping therapy. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take with food. limit alcohol because it can worsen dizziness or low blood pressure. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is close to your next scheduled dose. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. if you miss more than one dose, contact your clinician for instructions. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, constipation, abdominal discomfort, dizziness, headache, fatigue, and nasal congestion. serious effects include valvular heart disease, pleural or pericardial effusion, severe low blood pressure with fainting, hallucinations or behavior changes, and sudden sleep onset.

name: cabotegravir
instructions: important warning: before each dose used for prevention you must have a documented negative test for hiv infection. missing or delaying injections can leave low levels of medicine in the body for many months which can lead to infection with hiv that is resistant to treatment. for treatment in combination with rilpivirine you must already have your virus fully suppressed and be free of resistance to either drug. tell your clinician immediately if you develop symptoms of acute hiv infection such as fever, sore throat, rash, or swollen glands. why is this medication prescribed? cabotegravir is an antiretroviral integrase inhibitor used in combination with rilpivirine as a long acting regimen to maintain suppression of hiv type 1 in certain adults and adolescents. a long acting cabotegravir injection is also used as pre exposure prophylaxis to lower the risk of getting hiv type 1 in at risk adults and adolescents who are confirmed hiv negative. how should this medicine be used? your clinician may prescribe an oral cabotegravir lead in for about one month to check tolerance. injections are given into a muscle by a health professional. for hiv treatment cabotegravir and rilpivirine injections are given as a starting dose followed by maintenance injections monthly or every two months as directed. for prevention cabotegravir injection is given as a starting dose, a second injection one month later, then every two months. keep all injection appointments. if you stop injections discuss alternative hiv prevention or treatment and ongoing testing because the drug remains in your body for a long time. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have ever had liver disease, depression or other mood disorders, or allergies to cabotegravir. tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements. some medicines lower cabotegravir levels and should not be used, including certain seizure medicines such as carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine, phenobarbital, and phenytoin, rifampin and rifapentine, and herbal products such as st. john’s wort. report symptoms of liver problems such as yellowing of skin or eyes, dark urine, or right upper belly pain, and report rash or fever that may suggest a severe reaction. if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding discuss risks and benefits. for prevention continue safer sex practices and regular hiv testing during use and for at least twelve months after the last injection. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific food restrictions for cabotegravir. follow any instructions you are given for the oral lead in. what should i do if i forget a dose? for oral cabotegravir take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time for the next dose. do not take two doses at once. for injections contact your clinic right away to reschedule. you may need an oral bridge or adjusted schedule to maintain protection or viral suppression. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include pain, tenderness, hardness, itching, or swelling at the injection site, fever, fatigue, headache, muscle aches, nausea, sleep changes, and abnormal dreams. serious effects can include depressive symptoms or suicidal thoughts, severe rash or allergic reaction with fever and organ involvement, and liver problems with yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, or severe abdominal pain.

name: cabozantinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cabozantinib is a kinase inhibitor used to treat certain cancers including kidney cancer, liver cancer after prior therapy, and thyroid cancers. how should this medicine be used? take the tablets by mouth once daily exactly as directed, on an empty stomach, at least one hour before or two hours after eating. swallow tablets whole with water and do not crush, chew, or split them. your clinician may change your dose for side effects. do not substitute one cabozantinib formulation for another unless your clinician tells you to. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have high blood pressure, bleeding problems, recent coughing up blood, surgery or planned surgery, mouth or jaw problems, liver disease, or kidney problems, and if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or breastfeeding. use effective birth control during treatment and for the recommended time after the last dose. serious bleeding, wound healing problems, and holes or abnormal connections in the stomach or intestines can occur. stop cabozantinib at least three weeks before planned surgery and do not restart until your clinician says it is safe. have a dental exam and complete any required dental work before starting, and maintain good oral hygiene to lower the risk of jaw bone problems. tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements. strong inhibitors or inducers of the liver enzyme cyp3a can change cabozantinib levels. your blood pressure and urine protein will be monitored regularly. report severe headache, confusion, vision changes, chest pain, shortness of breath, severe belly pain, black or bloody stools, vomiting blood, or sudden swelling or pain in the legs. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take on an empty stomach. do not eat grapefruit or drink grapefruit juice because it can change drug levels. stay well hydrated unless your clinician gives you other instructions. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose and it is more than twelve hours until your next dose, take it when you remember. if it is twelve hours or less until your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include diarrhea, mouth sores, decreased appetite, weight loss, nausea, vomiting, tiredness, voice changes, altered taste, high blood pressure, and hand foot skin reaction with redness and pain. serious effects can include severe bleeding, blood clots, heart attack or stroke, holes or fistulas in the gut, wound healing problems, liver test abnormalities, kidney problems with protein in the urine, jaw bone problems, and a rare brain condition with severe headache, confusion, seizures, and vision changes.

name: calaspargase pegol-mknl injection
instructions: important warning: calaspargase pegol can cause severe or life threatening allergic reactions, inflammation of the pancreas, serious blood clots, bleeding, and liver injury. infusions must be given by trained professionals with emergency care available. tell your care team right away if you have hives, wheezing, trouble breathing, severe stomach pain, persistent vomiting, severe headache, confusion, swelling or pain in an arm or leg, chest pain, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, or unusual bleeding or bruising. why is this medication prescribed? calaspargase pegol is an asparagine depleting enzyme used with other medicines to treat acute lymphoblastic leukemia. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion on a schedule determined by your oncology team. you will have blood tests before and during treatment to monitor liver function, pancreas enzymes, blood clotting, and blood counts. keep all appointments. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about any previous reactions to asparaginase products, any history of pancreatitis, blood clots, bleeding disorders, diabetes, liver disease, or severe infections. provide a full list of all medicines and supplements, including blood thinners, hormonal contraceptives, and steroids. live vaccines should be avoided during and after therapy until your clinician says it is safe. use effective nonhormonal birth control during treatment and for the recommended time after the last dose. seek medical care immediately for signs of infection such as fever or chills. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific food restrictions, but avoid alcohol and follow any nutrition plan from your care team, especially if you develop high blood sugar or pancreatitis. stay well hydrated unless you are told otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your oncology team as soon as possible. do not attempt to make up a dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, diarrhea, fatigue, fever, swelling, and decreased appetite. serious effects include severe allergic reactions, pancreatitis with severe abdominal pain and vomiting, liver injury with yellowing of the skin or eyes, blood clots in the legs or lungs, bleeding, high blood sugar, and changes in mental status due to high ammonia levels.

name: calcipotriene topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? calcipotriene is a vitamin d analog used on the skin to treat plaque psoriasis. it helps slow the rapid growth of skin cells and reduce scaling and redness. how should this medicine be used? apply a thin layer to the affected skin exactly as directed, usually once or twice daily. for scalp products apply to dry scalp and wash hands after application. avoid contact with the face, eyes, mouth, and genital areas. do not apply to areas not affected by psoriasis. do not use more than prescribed and do not use with occlusive dressings unless instructed. wash hands after applying. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have high calcium levels, kidney stones, kidney disease, or are using other products that contain vitamin d or calcium. avoid excessive natural or artificial ultraviolet light while using this medicine. stop use and contact your clinician if you develop signs of high calcium such as nausea, vomiting, constipation, increased thirst or urination, confusion, or muscle weakness, or if you develop severe skin irritation. tell your clinician if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not take extra vitamin d or calcium supplements or eat very high calcium diets unless your clinician tells you to, because of the risk of increased calcium levels. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply it as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects are mild burning or stinging, redness, dryness, peeling, itching, and irritation at the application site. less common effects include rash, worsening of psoriasis, and increased calcium in the blood with overuse, which can cause nausea, vomiting, constipation, weakness, and confusion.

name: calcitonin salmon injection
instructions: important warning: severe allergic reactions including anaphylaxis can occur, especially in people with fish allergy. treatment should be initiated by clinicians prepared to manage severe reactions. a possible increase in the risk of malignancy has been observed with calcitonin salmon products. for osteoporosis it should be used only when other treatments are not suitable. why is this medication prescribed? calcitonin salmon injection is used to treat high calcium in the blood due to cancer and to manage symptoms of paget disease of bone. it may also be used in certain cases of postmenopausal osteoporosis when other therapies are not appropriate. how should this medicine be used? it is given by a health professional as a subcutaneous or intramuscular injection. dosing and frequency depend on the condition being treated. your clinician will monitor your calcium and other labs. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you are allergic to salmon or other fish, if you have low calcium levels, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. report signs of allergic reaction such as hives, trouble breathing, chest tightness, or swelling of the face or throat. tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements you use. what special dietary instructions should i follow? your clinician will advise you about calcium and vitamin d intake based on why you are receiving calcitonin. for osteoporosis you may be told to ensure adequate calcium and vitamin d. for high calcium in the blood you may be told to limit calcium intake. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your clinician for instructions. do not try to administer extra doses on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, flushing, injection site pain or redness, diarrhea, and dizziness. serious effects include severe allergic reactions, very low calcium with muscle cramps or tingling, and rarely a possible increased risk of malignancy with long term use.

name: calcitonin salmon nasal spray
instructions: important warning: a possible increase in the risk of malignancy has been observed with calcitonin salmon products. use for postmenopausal osteoporosis only when other treatments are not suitable. severe allergic reactions can occur, especially in people with fish allergy. why is this medication prescribed? calcitonin salmon nasal spray is used to treat osteoporosis in women who are at least five years past menopause when alternative therapies are not appropriate. how should this medicine be used? use one spray in one nostril once daily, alternating nostrils each day. prime the pump as directed before first use. do not sniff hard during spraying. keep the bottle upright. store unopened bottles in the refrigerator. after opening, store at room temperature as directed and discard after the labeled number of doses. your clinician may recommend calcium and vitamin d if appropriate. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you are allergic to salmon or other fish, if you have low calcium levels, or if you have nasal problems such as chronic nasal irritation, nasal ulcers, or recent nasal surgery. your nose may be examined periodically while you use this medicine. report nasal bleeding, sores, or severe irritation. seek urgent care for signs of severe allergy such as hives, wheezing, or swelling. what special dietary instructions should i follow? if you are being treated for osteoporosis your clinician may recommend adequate calcium and vitamin d intake unless you are told otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it as soon as you remember on the same day. if the next day is near, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use extra sprays to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nasal irritation, runny or stuffy nose, nosebleeds, back pain, joint pain, and headache. serious effects include severe allergic reactions, very low calcium with muscle spasms or tingling, and a possible increased risk of malignancy with long term use.

name: calcitriol
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? calcitriol is an active form of vitamin d used to treat low calcium in people on chronic kidney dialysis, to manage secondary hyperparathyroidism in some people with chronic kidney disease, and to treat low calcium due to hypoparathyroidism. how should this medicine be used? calcitriol is taken by mouth as capsules or liquid or is given by intravenous injection during dialysis. dosing is individualized based on lab results. take it exactly as prescribed. your clinician will check calcium, phosphorus, and parathyroid hormone often and adjust your dose. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have kidney disease, a history of kidney stones, high calcium levels, high phosphorus levels, heart disease, or if you are taking thiazide diuretics, digitalis, magnesium containing antacids, or other vitamin d products. do not take any additional vitamin d or calcium supplements unless your clinician tells you to. report signs of high calcium such as nausea, vomiting, constipation, decreased appetite, increased thirst or urination, confusion, or muscle weakness. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding discuss risks and benefits. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow the diet your clinician or dietitian gives you, which may include limits on phosphorus and specific calcium intake. avoid extra vitamin d fortified foods or supplements unless directed. maintain adequate hydration unless you are told otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed oral dose as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. do not take two doses at once. if you miss an intravenous dose given at dialysis, contact your dialysis center for instructions. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, nausea, vomiting, constipation, and weakness. serious effects are high calcium or high phosphorus which can cause confusion, abnormal heart rhythms especially if you take digitalis, bone or joint pain, and kidney stones.

name: calcium acetate
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? calcium acetate is a phosphate binder used to reduce high blood phosphorus levels in people with end stage kidney disease on dialysis. how should this medicine be used? take calcium acetate by mouth with meals as directed. swallow tablets or capsules with water. your dose will be adjusted based on phosphorus and calcium levels. take other medicines at different times if advised, because calcium acetate can interfere with the absorption of some drugs. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have high calcium levels, a history of kidney stones, constipation, or stomach problems. provide a list of all medicines. calcium acetate can reduce absorption of levothyroxine, certain antibiotics such as tetracyclines and quinolones, and others. do not take additional calcium supplements unless your clinician tells you to. your blood calcium and phosphorus will be monitored. report symptoms of high calcium such as nausea, vomiting, constipation, confusion, or muscle weakness. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow a low phosphorus diet as recommended. avoid high calcium foods or supplements unless your clinician instructs otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? skip the missed dose if you have already finished that meal and take the next dose with your next meal. do not take extra tablets to make up a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea and constipation. serious effects include high calcium with confusion, weakness, or abnormal heart rhythm, and rare kidney stones.

name: calcium carbonate
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? calcium carbonate is used as a calcium supplement to prevent or treat deficiency, as an antacid to relieve heartburn and indigestion, and as a phosphate binder in some people with chronic kidney disease. how should this medicine be used? take calcium carbonate exactly as directed on the label or by your clinician. for supplementation it is best absorbed with food. chew chewable tablets thoroughly before swallowing and shake liquid forms well. if used as an antacid follow the maximum daily dose on the label. separate calcium carbonate from medicines such as levothyroxine, tetracyclines, fluoroquinolones, iron, and bisphosphonates by the interval your clinician recommends. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have kidney disease, a history of kidney stones, high calcium levels, or sarcoidosis. provide a list of all medicines and supplements. do not exceed the recommended total daily calcium intake and avoid taking multiple calcium containing products together unless advised. stop and call your clinician if you develop signs of high calcium such as nausea, vomiting, constipation, increased thirst or urination, confusion, or muscle weakness. what special dietary instructions should i follow? track your total daily calcium intake from diet and supplements and stay within the amount recommended by your clinician. drink adequate fluids unless you are told otherwise to reduce the risk of kidney stones. avoid excessive vitamin d unless instructed. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it when you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include constipation, gas, and bloating. serious effects include high calcium with confusion or abnormal heart rhythm and kidney stones.

name: canagliflozin
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? canagliflozin is a sodium glucose cotransporter two inhibitor used with diet and exercise to improve blood sugar in adults with type 2 diabetes. it also reduces the risk of hospitalization for heart failure, cardiovascular events in certain patients, and slows progression of kidney disease in appropriate patients. how should this medicine be used? take canagliflozin by mouth once daily before the first meal of the day or as directed. your clinician will monitor kidney function and adjust the dose as needed. continue your diabetes meal plan and exercise program. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have kidney disease, liver disease, low blood pressure, dehydration, frequent urinary tract or genital infections, peripheral vascular disease, neuropathy, foot ulcers, or a history of amputation, and if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. tell your clinician about all medicines including diuretics, blood pressure medicines, and insulin or sulfonylureas. canagliflozin may increase the risk of ketoacidosis even if blood sugar is not very high. seek medical care for nausea, vomiting, belly pain, trouble breathing, confusion, or unusual fatigue. it can cause low blood pressure, acute kidney injury, severe genital infections including a rare infection of the area between the genitals and the anus, increased potassium, and low blood sugar when used with insulin or insulin secretagogues. maintain good foot care and report any sores or infections promptly. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow your diabetes meal plan and drink enough fluids to avoid dehydration unless your clinician gives you other instructions. limit alcohol to reduce the risk of low blood sugar and ketoacidosis. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember that day. if it is the next day, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the usual time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include increased urination, thirst, genital yeast infections, urinary tract infections, and constipation. serious effects include ketoacidosis, dehydration with dizziness or fainting, acute kidney injury, severe genital infections, high potassium, bone fractures, and low blood sugar when combined with insulin or certain pills.

name: canakinumab injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? canakinumab is used to treat certain periodic fever and autoinflammatory conditions including cryopyrin associated periodic syndromes, tumor necrosis factor receptor associated periodic syndrome, hyperimmunoglobulin d syndrome or mevalonate kinase deficiency, and familial mediterranean fever. it is also used to treat active systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis and adult onset still disease, and in certain adults to treat gout flares who cannot use or did not respond to other medicines. how should this medicine be used? it is given as a subcutaneous injection. the dose and dosing interval depend on the condition being treated, often every four to eight weeks, and may be based on body weight. a health care professional may administer it or teach you how to inject at home. let the syringe or vial come to room temperature before use, do not shake, inspect the solution, and rotate injection sites. do not use if the solution is discolored or contains particles. what special precautions should i follow?if you have any infection or a history of recurrent infections, tuberculosis exposure, or if you have recently received or plan to receive any vaccines. you will be screened for tuberculosis before starting. do not receive live vaccines during treatment.about all medicines you take including other biologic immunosuppressants.if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. seek medical care for signs of infection such as fever, chills, cough, painful urination, or warm red skin. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions for most patients. stay well hydrated and follow any dietary advice given for your underlying condition. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an injection, take it as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time of your next dose. if you are unsure, contact your doctor to reschedule. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include injection site reactions, upper respiratory tract infections, headache, abdominal pain, and back pain. serious side effects include serious infections, neutropenia, hypersensitivity reactions, and activation of latent tuberculosis. seek urgent care for trouble breathing, swelling of the face or throat, severe dizziness, or high fever.

name: candesartan
instructions: important warning: do not use this medicine during pregnancy. medicines that act on the renin angiotensin system can cause injury and death to an unborn baby. stop this medicine as soon as pregnancy is detected and contact your doctor right away. why is this medication prescribed? candesartan is used to treat high blood pressure and heart failure and can reduce the risk of hospitalization for heart failure. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once daily with or without food. take it at the same time each day. your doctor may adjust the dose to control your blood pressure. continue taking it even if you feel well. what special precautions should i follow?about kidney disease, liver disease, dehydration, heart failure, or narrowing of the kidney arteries.about all medicines you take, especially diuretics, nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs, lithium, aliskiren, other blood pressure medicines, and potassium supplements or salt substitutes. this medicine can cause low blood pressure, high potassium, kidney problems, and rarely swelling of face lips tongue or throat. do not use with aliskiren if you have diabetes. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid potassium salt substitutes and limit high potassium foods unless directed otherwise. limit alcohol and drink adequate fluids. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? dizziness, headache, back pain, and fatigue may occur. serious effects include kidney problems, high potassium which can cause muscle weakness or abnormal heartbeat, very low blood pressure, and angioedema with swelling of the face lips tongue or throat and trouble breathing.

name: cannabidiol
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cannabidiol oral solution is used to treat seizures associated with lennox gastaut syndrome, dravet syndrome, and tuberous sclerosis complex. how should this medicine be used? measure the dose with the provided oral syringe and take by mouth twice daily. a common starting dose is two point five milligrams per kilogram twice daily, which may be increased after one week to five milligrams per kilogram twice daily as directed. take it consistently with or without food and shake the bottle well before each dose. do not stop suddenly without talking to your doctor. what special precautions should i follow?if you have liver disease or a history of depression or suicidal thoughts. liver function tests will be done before starting and during treatment.about all medicines, especially clobazam, valproate, other seizure medicines, warfarin, and medicines that affect liver enzymes. avoid alcohol and other medicines that cause sleepiness. this medicine may cause drowsiness and affect your ability to drive until you know how it affects you.if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take doses consistently with or without food to keep levels steady. avoid grapefruit and seville oranges because they may affect how the medicine is broken down. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember if it is within about four hours of the scheduled time. if more time has passed, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take extra doses. if you vomit a dose, do not take another dose and wait until the next scheduled time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include sleepiness, decreased appetite, diarrhea, fatigue, and rash. it can raise liver enzymes. serious effects include liver injury with yellowing of the skin or eyes or dark urine, suicidal thoughts or behavior, severe drowsiness, and allergic reactions with swelling or trouble breathing.

name: cantharidin topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cantharidin is used for the treatment of molluscum contagiosum and common warts. how should this medicine be used? a trained health care professional applies a small amount to the lesions in the office and you wash it off after the instructed time. a blister will form and the lesion will peel off. do not apply at home unless your health care professional has provided a specific product and directions. keep the treated area dry and do not occlude unless told to do so. what special precautions should i follow? for skin use only. avoid contact with the eyes, mouth, nose, genitals, or open wounds. keep out of reach of children and pets.if you have diabetes, poor circulation, nerve problems, large treatment areas, skin infection at the site, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. pain and blistering are expected but seek medical advice if you have severe pain, excessive blistering, or signs of infection. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you forget to wash off at the instructed time, wash the area with soap and water as soon as possible and contact your health care professional for further guidance. if you miss an application appointment, reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? pain, burning, redness, itching, blistering, swelling, and scabbing at the application site are common. serious effects include severe blistering, tissue damage, and signs of infection such as increasing redness, warmth, pus, or fever.

name: capecitabine
instructions: important warning: capecitabine can increase the effect of warfarin and similar blood thinners which may cause serious or fatal bleeding. if you take warfarin or another coumarin anticoagulant your doctor will monitor your blood more often and adjust the dose.right away about bleeding, bruising, or black stools. some people have a deficiency of an enzyme called dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase which can lead to severe or life threatening toxicity.if you have known deficiency and report severe diarrhea, vomiting, mouth sores, fever, or unusual tiredness promptly. why is this medication prescribed? capecitabine is used to treat cancers such as colon, rectal, and breast cancer and to help prevent cancer from returning after surgery. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth twice daily in treatment cycles as directed. a common schedule is two weeks on treatment followed by one week off. the dose is based on body size and kidney function. take each dose with water within thirty minutes after a meal. swallow tablets whole. if you vomit after a dose, do not take an extra dose. your doctor may adjust the dose based on side effects. what special precautions should i follow?about all medicines, especially warfarin, phenytoin, leucovorin or folinic acid, and allopurinol.if you have kidney or liver problems, heart disease or chest pain, or known or suspected dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase deficiency. use effective birth control during treatment and for an appropriate time after the last dose. do not breastfeed during therapy and for at least two weeks after the last dose. this medicine can lower blood counts and increase risk of infection and bleeding. call your doctor for fever, chills, sore throat, unusual bruising or bleeding, chest pain or shortness of breath, or severe diarrhea. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take doses after meals and drink plenty of fluids. limit alcohol. ask your doctor before using folic acid supplements. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, do not take it later and do not take extra. take your next dose at the regular time. contact your care team if you miss more than one dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, decreased appetite, mouth sores, abdominal pain, hand foot redness pain or swelling, and fatigue. serious effects include severe diarrhea or dehydration, severe skin reactions, chest pain or heart rhythm problems, low blood counts, liver problems, and severe hand foot skin reactions.

name: capivasertib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? capivasertib is used with fulvestrant to treat hormone receptor positive human epidermal growth factor receptor two negative advanced or metastatic breast cancer with certain alterations in pik3ca, akt1, or pten after progression on endocrine therapy. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth twice daily for four days followed by three days off in repeating weekly cycles as prescribed. take doses about twelve hours apart at the same times each day with or without food. swallow tablets whole. if you vomit a dose, do not take an extra dose. what special precautions should i follow?if you have diabetes or prediabetes because this medicine can raise blood sugar and in some cases cause diabetic ketoacidosis. your doctor will check blood sugar at baseline and during treatment.about all medicines you take, especially strong inhibitors or inducers of cyp3a.if you develop rash, severe diarrhea, signs of infection, or liver problems. use effective birth control during treatment and for one month after the last dose. do not breastfeed during treatment and for one month after the last dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take this medicine with or without food. avoid grapefruit and seville oranges and their juices. drink fluids to help prevent dehydration if you have diarrhea. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose or vomit after a dose, do not take an extra dose. take the next dose at the regular time. what side effects can this medication cause? diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, decreased appetite, rash, dry skin, mouth sores, fatigue, taste changes, headache, and joint pain are common. it can cause high blood sugar which may present with thirst, frequent urination, confusion, or fruity breath. serious effects include severe skin reactions, severe diarrhea and dehydration, infections, and changes in kidney or liver tests.

name: caplacizumab-yhdp injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? caplacizumab is used with plasma exchange and immunosuppressive therapy to treat adults with acquired thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura and to reduce blood clotting and organ damage. how should this medicine be used? a health care provider gives the first dose into a vein before the first plasma exchange. after each plasma exchange you receive a dose under the skin. after plasma exchange ends, continue daily under the skin injections for at least thirty days. your provider may teach you or a caregiver to inject at home. inject into the abdomen or thigh and rotate injection sites. what special precautions should i follow? this medicine increases the risk of bleeding.if you take blood thinners, antiplatelet drugs, or nonsteroidal anti inflammatory medicines, or if you have a bleeding disorder, recent surgery, or severe uncontrolled high blood pressure. report bleeding that does not stop, blood in urine or stool, black stools, coughing or vomiting blood, frequent or prolonged nosebleeds, or severe headache or dizziness.about all medicines you take and all vaccines you receive. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. contact your care team for guidance. what side effects can this medication cause? headache, nosebleeds, bleeding gums, bruising, injection site reactions, tiredness, hives, and fever may occur. serious effects include serious bleeding and allergic reactions with swelling of the face lips tongue or throat and trouble breathing.

name: capmatinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? capmatinib is used to treat adults with metastatic non small cell lung cancer that has a mesenchymal epithelial transition exon fourteen skipping alteration. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth twice daily with or without food at the same times each day. swallow tablets whole. your tumor will be tested for the required genetic change before starting treatment. do not take a replacement dose if you vomit after taking a dose. what special precautions should i follow?if you have or had lung or breathing problems or liver problems. this medicine can cause lung inflammation and liver injury. it may make your skin more sensitive to sunlight.about all medicines you take. avoid strong inducers or inhibitors of cyp3a if possible. use sun protection with clothing and a broad spectrum sunscreen while on treatment and for seven days after the last dose. use effective birth control during treatment and for one week after the last dose. do not breastfeed during treatment and for one week after the last dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose and it is less than six hours since the scheduled time, take it as soon as you remember. if it is six hours or more, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the usual time. if you vomit after taking a dose, do not take an extra dose. what side effects can this medication cause? swelling of hands or feet, nausea, vomiting, decreased appetite, fatigue, shortness of breath, cough, abnormal liver tests, kidney problems, photosensitivity, rash, and decreased blood counts may occur. serious effects include lung inflammation with new or worsening cough, fever, or shortness of breath, liver injury with yellowing of skin or eyes, dark urine, or right upper stomach pain, and severe skin reactions.

name: capsaicin topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? capsaicin topical products relieve minor muscle and joint pain from arthritis, strains, sprains, and backaches, and may be used under medical direction for nerve pain after shingles. how should this medicine be used? for creams, gels, and lotions apply a thin film to the affected area and rub in until fully absorbed, usually three to four times daily. wash hands with soap and water after applying unless treating the hands. burning or stinging is common and often lessens with regular use. do not tightly bandage or apply heat to treated areas. for high strength patches, application is done in the clinic by a health care professional. what special precautions should i follow? for skin use only. avoid contact with eyes, mouth, nose, and genitals. do not apply to broken, irritated, or infected skin. stop and ask a doctor if severe burning, swelling, or blistering occurs. keep away from children and pets.about all skin products and medicines you use and if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. avoid hot showers or baths immediately before or after application. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply as soon as you remember, then continue your regular schedule. if it is almost time for the next application, skip the missed one and resume your schedule. for clinic applied patches, follow your rescheduling instructions. what side effects can this medication cause? transient burning, stinging, redness, dryness, and cough or throat irritation from vapors can occur. serious effects include severe burns, blistering, or breathing problems from inhaling vapors.

name: captopril
instructions: important warning: do not use this medicine during pregnancy. medicines that act on the renin angiotensin system can cause injury and death to an unborn baby. stop this medicine as soon as pregnancy is detected and contact your doctor right away. why is this medication prescribed? captopril is used to treat high blood pressure and heart failure, to improve survival after a heart attack, and to protect the kidneys in some patients with diabetes. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth usually two or three times daily. take on an empty stomach one hour before meals because food can reduce absorption. take it as prescribed even if you feel well. your doctor will monitor your blood pressure, kidney function, and potassium. what special precautions should i follow?if you have kidney disease including renal artery narrowing, liver disease, high potassium levels, diabetes, dehydration, recent vomiting or diarrhea, or a history of angioedema which is swelling of the face lips tongue or throat.about all medicines you take, especially diuretics, nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs, potassium supplements or salt substitutes, lithium, and other blood pressure medicines. this medicine can cause cough, high potassium, kidney problems, low blood pressure, and angioedema. stand up slowly to reduce dizziness. do not use with aliskiren if you have diabetes. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid potassium salt substitutes and limit high potassium foods unless your doctor tells you otherwise. limit alcohol and drink adequate fluids. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? dizziness, lightheadedness, cough, taste changes, rash, and fatigue may occur. serious effects include swelling of the face lips tongue or throat, trouble breathing, fainting, signs of high potassium such as muscle weakness or slow or irregular heartbeat, and signs of kidney problems such as decreased urination.

name: carbamazepine
instructions: important warning: carbamazepine can cause rare but serious and sometimes fatal skin reactions including stevens johnson syndrome and toxic epidermal necrolysis. the risk is higher in people of asian ancestry who carry the hla b 1502 allele and in some people with the hla a 3101 allele. it can also cause serious blood problems including aplastic anemia and agranulocytosis. your doctor may do genetic testing before treatment and will monitor blood counts and liver function. carbamazepine can cause suicidal thoughts and behaviors, serious drug interactions, and fetal harm if taken during pregnancy. do not stop taking this medicine suddenly without medical guidance. why is this medication prescribed? carbamazepine is used to treat certain types of seizures, to relieve pain in trigeminal neuralgia, and to treat acute manic or mixed episodes in bipolar disorder and for maintenance therapy in some patients. how should this medicine be used? take carbamazepine exactly as prescribed, usually two to four times daily for immediate release forms or twice daily for extended release forms. swallow extended release tablets whole and do not crush or chew them. take with food to reduce stomach upset. shake the oral suspension well before each dose and measure with a dosing device. your doctor may increase the dose gradually and will monitor blood levels and lab tests. what special precautions should i follow?about all allergies, all medicines and supplements you take, and all medical conditions including liver, kidney, or heart disease, glaucoma, blood disorders, low sodium, thyroid disease, and a history of mental health conditions. do not take carbamazepine with monoamine oxidase inhibitors or within 14 days of taking them. many medicines interact with carbamazepine including certain antibiotics, antifungals, antivirals, seizure medicines, antidepressants, antipsychotics, blood thinners, and birth control pills. use effective non hormonal contraception or add a barrier method because carbamazepine can reduce the effectiveness of hormonal contraceptives. avoid activities that require alertness until you know how the medicine affects you. report rash, fever, mouth sores, easy bruising or bleeding, infection signs, confusion, severe dizziness, vision changes, or mood or behavior changes right away. discuss pregnancy planning and breastfeeding with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice. limit or avoid alcohol because it can increase drowsiness and the risk of side effects. take with food if it upsets your stomach. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is close to your next dose. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at the same time. do not stop this medicine suddenly. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include dizziness, drowsiness, unsteadiness, nausea, vomiting, dry mouth, constipation, blurred or double vision, and headache. serious side effects include severe skin rash or peeling, mouth sores, fever, sore throat, unusual bleeding or bruising, severe fatigue, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, severe confusion, suicidal thoughts, rapid or irregular heartbeat, very low sodium with headache and confusion, or swelling of the face or tongue. seek medical help right away for signs of severe reaction.

name: carboplatin injection
instructions: important warning: carboplatin can cause severe bone marrow suppression leading to low white blood cells, platelets, and red blood cells which can increase the risk of infection, bleeding, and anemia. severe nausea and vomiting and serious allergic reactions can occur, sometimes during infusion. carboplatin should be given only by experienced healthcare professionals with regular blood count and kidney function monitoring. avoid use during pregnancy due to risk of fetal harm. why is this medication prescribed? carboplatin is a chemotherapy medicine used to treat various cancers, including ovarian cancer and others as determined by your oncologist. how should this medicine be used? carboplatin is given by intravenous infusion in a clinic or hospital, often in treatment cycles every three to four weeks. the dose is based on kidney function and body size. you may receive medicines to prevent nausea and allergic reactions and fluids for hydration. follow your treatment schedule and lab monitoring exactly as directed. what special precautions should i follow? tell your healthcare team about all allergies, prior reactions to platinum medicines, all medicines and supplements you use, and all medical conditions, especially kidney or liver problems, hearing problems, bleeding disorders, infections, or prior radiation therapy. avoid live vaccines and people who recently received live vaccines. use effective contraception during treatment and for the recommended time after the last dose. do not breastfeed during treatment and for the recommended time after the last dose. seek urgent care for fever, signs of infection, bleeding, severe or persistent vomiting, rash, shortness of breath, chest tightness, swelling, or severe fatigue. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific food restrictions, but staying well hydrated is important. eat small frequent meals if nauseated and follow your care team advice for managing nausea. limit alcohol because it can worsen dehydration and bleeding risk. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your oncology team as soon as possible to reschedule. do not attempt to receive extra medicine on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, fatigue, changes in taste, temporary hair thinning, and low blood counts with increased infection and bleeding risk. other effects can include kidney function changes, electrolyte abnormalities, numbness or tingling, hearing changes or ringing in the ears, and allergic reactions during infusion such as rash, itching, shortness of breath, or low blood pressure. seek immediate help for fever, uncontrolled vomiting, severe bleeding, new or worsening shortness of breath, chest pain, severe rash, confusion, or fainting.

name: carfilzomib injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? carfilzomib is a proteasome inhibitor used to treat adults with multiple myeloma, often in combination with other medicines. how should this medicine be used? carfilzomib is given by intravenous infusion in a clinic on specific days of a repeating cycle. your dose schedule and infusion duration depend on your treatment regimen. you may receive premedication such as dexamethasone and fluids to reduce infusion reactions and kidney problems. lab tests will be done regularly. what special precautions should i follow? tell your care team about all allergies, all medicines and supplements you take, and all medical conditions, especially heart disease, high blood pressure, prior blood clots, lung disease, liver or kidney problems, and infections. carfilzomib can cause heart failure, heart attack, arrhythmias, high blood pressure, shortness of breath, infusion reactions, tumor lysis syndrome, low platelets, anemia, kidney and liver problems, blood clots, and rare brain infection. report chest pain, sudden shortness of breath, rapid weight gain, swelling in legs, fainting, severe headache, neurologic changes, fever, or signs of infection immediately. your doctor may recommend antiviral medicine to reduce shingles risk and medicines to prevent blood clots in some regimens. use effective contraception during treatment and for the recommended time after the last dose. do not breastfeed during treatment and for the recommended time after the last dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? stay well hydrated as directed by your care team. there are no specific food restrictions. limit alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? call your oncology clinic to receive instructions and reschedule the missed infusion. do not try to make up a dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fatigue, low blood counts, shortness of breath, cough, fever, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea or constipation, decreased appetite, muscle or joint pain, and swelling. serious effects include heart problems, severe high blood pressure, infusion reactions with fever or chills, severe shortness of breath, blood clots, bleeding, kidney or liver problems, and tumor lysis syndrome. seek urgent care for chest pain, severe breathing problems, severe headache, confusion, severe abdominal pain, or sudden swelling.

name: cariprazine
instructions: important warning: elderly patients with dementia related psychosis treated with antipsychotic medicines are at increased risk of death. cariprazine is not approved for these patients. antidepressants increase the risk of suicidal thinking and behavior in children, adolescents, and young adults. monitor closely for worsening mood or unusual behavior. why is this medication prescribed? cariprazine is an atypical antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia in adults, manic or mixed episodes and depressive episodes of bipolar i disorder in adults, and as add on therapy for major depressive disorder in adults. how should this medicine be used? take cariprazine exactly as prescribed once daily with or without food. your doctor will start with a low dose and adjust gradually. because the medicine and its active metabolites have a long half life, dose changes may take one to two weeks to show full effect. do not stop suddenly unless your doctor tells you to. what special precautions should i follow?about all medicines and supplements you take, especially strong inhibitors or inducers of cyp 3a4, and all medical conditions including heart disease, stroke risk, diabetes or risk factors, seizures, low white blood cell count, low blood pressure, liver problems, and a history of involuntary movements. cariprazine can cause movement problems including akathisia and tardive dyskinesia, neuroleptic malignant syndrome, orthostatic hypotension, falls, increased blood sugar and cholesterol, weight gain, difficulty regulating body temperature, trouble swallowing, and impulse control problems. avoid alcohol and do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you.if you are pregnant or planning pregnancy. exposure in the third trimester can cause symptoms in newborns. discuss breastfeeding with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice. follow a heart healthy diet and exercise plan to help manage weight, blood sugar, and cholesterol. limit alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose the same day you remember. if it is the next day, skip the missed dose and take your next scheduled dose. if you miss several days, contact your doctor before restarting because you may need dose guidance. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include restlessness or inner sense of unease, tremor or other movement problems, drowsiness, dizziness, nausea, constipation, indigestion, and weight gain. serious side effects include high fever, muscle stiffness, confusion or sweating, fainting, very fast or irregular heartbeat, severe dizziness, signs of high blood sugar such as increased thirst and urination, uncontrollable movements, trouble swallowing, or signs of stroke. seek medical help right away for serious symptoms or suicidal thoughts.

name: carisoprodol
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? carisoprodol is a muscle relaxant used with rest and physical therapy to relieve discomfort from acute muscle and bone conditions. it is intended for short term use only, generally up to two or three weeks. how should this medicine be used? take carisoprodol by mouth exactly as directed, typically three times daily and at bedtime. you may take it with or without food. do not increase your dose or duration of use. do not stop suddenly after long or high dose use without medical guidance. what special precautions should i follow?about all medicines and supplements you take and all medical conditions, especially a history of substance use disorder, liver or kidney disease, seizures, or porphyria. carisoprodol can cause sedation and dizziness and may be habit forming. avoid alcohol and other medicines that cause drowsiness such as opioids, benzodiazepines, and sleep medicines. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you.if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific food restrictions. avoid alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time for your next dose. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include drowsiness, dizziness, headache, and nausea. serious effects include allergic reactions with rash or swelling, severe sedation or breathing problems, fast or irregular heartbeat, seizures, fainting, and signs of abuse, dependence, or withdrawal such as anxiety, insomnia, tremor, vomiting, or hallucinations. seek immediate help for severe reactions.

name: carmustine
instructions: important warning: carmustine can cause severe and prolonged bone marrow suppression that may lead to serious infections, bleeding, and anemia. the nadir in blood counts may be delayed for several weeks and requires close monitoring. carmustine can cause serious and sometimes fatal lung toxicity including pulmonary fibrosis, particularly with higher cumulative doses or in children. it can also cause liver and kidney toxicity and may increase the risk of secondary cancers. use only under the supervision of experienced cancer specialists. avoid use during pregnancy due to risk of fetal harm and possible infertility. why is this medication prescribed? carmustine is a chemotherapy medicine used to treat certain brain tumors and other cancers such as hodgkin lymphoma, non hodgkin lymphoma, and multiple myeloma, and it is available as an implant placed in the brain during surgery for certain brain tumors. how should this medicine be used? carmustine is given by intravenous infusion in a clinic or hospital, often every six weeks, or as an implant wafer placed by a neurosurgeon. dosing and schedule are individualized. you will have regular lab tests and may have breathing tests to monitor lung function. what special precautions should i follow? tell your care team about all allergies, all medicines and supplements you take, and all medical conditions, especially lung, liver, or kidney disease, prior radiation therapy, and prior chemotherapy. avoid live vaccines and close contact with people who have received live vaccines. use effective contraception during treatment and for the recommended time after the last dose. do not breastfeed during treatment and for the recommended time after the last dose. report fever, signs of infection, unusual bruising or bleeding, shortness of breath, new or worsening cough, chest pain, severe fatigue, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, or decreased urine. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific food restrictions. stay well hydrated and consider small frequent meals if you have nausea. limit alcohol to reduce liver strain. what should i do if i forget a dose? call your oncology clinic to receive instructions and to reschedule any missed infusion or implant follow up. do not try to make up a dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea and vomiting that can be severe, loss of appetite, flushing during infusion, pain or burning at the infusion site, and fatigue. serious effects include severe low blood counts, infections, bleeding, lung problems such as cough or shortness of breath, liver and kidney problems, secondary cancers, and severe allergic reactions. seek urgent care for fever, severe shortness of breath, chest pain, confusion, or uncontrolled bleeding.

name: carvedilol
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? carvedilol is a beta blocker used to treat heart failure, high blood pressure, and to improve survival after a heart attack with left ventricular dysfunction. how should this medicine be used? take carvedilol exactly as prescribed. immediate release tablets are usually taken twice daily with food and extended release capsules are taken once daily with food. swallow extended release capsules whole or open and sprinkle the contents on applesauce and swallow right away without chewing. your doctor will increase the dose gradually. do not stop taking carvedilol suddenly. what special precautions should i follow?about all medicines and supplements you take and all medical conditions, especially asthma or chronic obstructive lung disease, slow heart rate, heart block, heart failure that is not stable, peripheral vascular disease, diabetes, thyroid disease, liver problems, and history of severe allergic reactions. carvedilol can cause dizziness, fatigue, slow heart rate, low blood pressure, and can mask low blood sugar symptoms. stand up slowly to reduce dizziness. check blood sugar more often if you have diabetes. tell surgeons and dentists you take carvedilol. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take doses with food to reduce the risk of dizziness. limit alcohol. follow your doctor’s advice on salt and fluid intake if you have heart failure. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. if you miss more than one dose, contact your doctor because you may need to restart at a lower dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include dizziness, fatigue, lightheadedness, diarrhea, weight gain, slow heart rate, and elevated blood sugar. serious effects include very slow heartbeat, fainting, wheezing or breathing difficulty, swelling of legs or ankles, sudden weight gain, severe allergic reactions, and worsening heart failure. seek medical help for severe dizziness, fainting, breathing problems, or swelling.

name: caspofungin injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? caspofungin is an antifungal medicine used to treat serious fungal infections such as invasive candidiasis including candidemia, esophageal candidiasis, and invasive aspergillosis in patients who do not respond to or cannot tolerate other therapies. it may also be used empirically for suspected fungal infection in certain febrile neutropenic patients. how should this medicine be used? caspofungin is given by intravenous infusion once daily, usually after a loading dose, in a hospital or clinic. the duration of therapy depends on your infection and response to treatment. what special precautions should i follow? tell your care team about all allergies, all medicines and supplements you take, and all medical problems, especially liver disease. dose adjustment may be needed in liver impairment. caspofungin can cause infusion related reactions and rare serious allergic reactions. it may interact with medicines such as cyclosporine and tacrolimus. report rash, swelling of the face or throat, trouble breathing, severe abdominal pain, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, or severe fatigue. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. maintain good hydration unless your doctor advises otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your healthcare provider to reschedule the missed infusion. do not try to make up a dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, infusion site reactions, rash, and abnormal liver tests. serious effects include severe allergic reactions, swelling, difficulty breathing, significant elevation of liver enzymes, low potassium, and rare severe skin reactions. seek urgent care for severe reaction signs.

name: cefaclor
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cefaclor is a cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections such as ear infections, sinusitis, bronchitis, pneumonia, skin infections, and urinary tract infections. it will not work for viral infections. how should this medicine be used? take cefaclor exactly as directed, usually every eight hours for immediate release or as directed for extended release. take extended release tablets with food. shake the oral suspension well before each dose and measure with a dosing device. take for the full prescribed course even if you feel better. what special precautions should i follow?if you are allergic to cephalosporins, penicillins, or any medicine, and about all medicines and supplements you take.if you have kidney disease, a history of colitis, or have had a serum sickness like reaction. antibiotics can cause severe diarrhea due to clostridioides difficile. stop and contact your doctor for severe watery or bloody diarrhea or stomach cramps even weeks after finishing. cefaclor may cause a serum sickness like reaction with rash, fever, and joint pain, especially in children. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take extended release tablets with food. you may take other forms with or without food. if stomach upset occurs, take with food. drink fluids unless your doctor advises otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is near the time for your next dose. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, headache, and rash. serious effects include severe allergic reactions with hives, swelling, or trouble breathing, severe or persistent diarrhea, liver problems with yellowing of the skin or eyes, and serum sickness like reactions with rash, fever, and joint pain. seek medical help for severe reactions.

name: cefadroxil
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cefadroxil is a first generation cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections such as skin and soft tissue infections, streptococcal throat infections, and urinary tract infections. it does not treat viral infections. how should this medicine be used? take cefadroxil exactly as prescribed, usually once or twice daily. you may take it with or without food. shake the oral suspension well before each dose and measure with a dosing device. finish the full course even if you feel better. what special precautions should i follow?if you are allergic to cephalosporins or penicillins and about all medicines and supplements you take.if you have kidney disease or a history of colitis. antibiotics can cause severe diarrhea due to clostridioides difficile. contact your doctor for severe or bloody diarrhea or stomach cramps even weeks after finishing. long use may lead to yeast infections. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take with food if stomach upset occurs and drink adequate fluids unless your doctor advises otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the usual time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, stomach upset, headache, and rash or itching. serious effects include severe allergic reactions with hives, swelling, or trouble breathing, severe or persistent diarrhea, yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, unusual bruising or bleeding, and severe skin reactions. seek medical help for severe reactions.

name: cefazolin injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cefazolin is a cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat susceptible bacterial infections such as skin and soft tissue infections, bone and joint infections, biliary tract infections, urinary tract infections, respiratory tract infections, septicemia, and to prevent infection before and during certain surgeries. how should this medicine be used? cefazolin is given by intravenous or intramuscular injection by a healthcare professional. the dose and frequency depend on the type and severity of infection and kidney function. if you are receiving home infusions, use the medication exactly as instructed, complete the full prescribed course even if you feel better, and learn proper sterile technique and line care. if you have kidney disease your dose may need adjustment. what special precautions should i follow?if you have ever had an allergic reaction to cefazolin, other cephalosporins, or penicillins.if you have kidney disease, are on dialysis, have a history of seizures, or have had severe diarrhea with antibiotics. cefazolin can cause severe allergic reactions and clostridioides difficile associated diarrhea, sometimes after treatment has stopped.about all medicines you take, including probenecid and blood thinners.if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. drink plenty of fluids unless your doctor tells you otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you receive doses at a clinic or by home infusion, contact your healthcare provider or home infusion service as soon as possible to reschedule. do not give two doses at the same time unless your provider tells you to. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include pain, redness, or swelling at the injection site, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and rash. serious side effects include severe allergic reaction with trouble breathing or swelling of the face or throat, severe or persistent diarrhea that may be watery or bloody, seizures especially in people with kidney problems, unusual bruising or bleeding, new fever, and signs of liver or kidney problems. seek medical attention right away for serious reactions.

name: cefdinir
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cefdinir is a cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat community acquired pneumonia, sinus infections, flare ups of chronic bronchitis, strep throat and tonsillitis, skin and soft tissue infections, ear infections in children, and other susceptible infections. how should this medicine be used? take cefdinir by mouth as capsules or oral suspension exactly as directed, usually once or twice daily. shake the suspension well before each dose and measure with a proper device. you may take it with or without food. complete the full course even if you feel better. avoid taking cefdinir at the same time as antacids that contain aluminum or magnesium or iron supplements. if needed, take cefdinir at least two hours before or after these products. if you have reduced kidney function your dose may need adjustment. what special precautions should i follow?if you are allergic to cefdinir, other cephalosporins, or penicillins.if you have kidney disease, a history of colitis, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. cefdinir can cause severe allergic reactions and clostridioides difficile associated diarrhea. it can interact with iron and may reduce iron absorption. the suspension contains sugar, so people with diabetes should account for this. what special dietary instructions should i follow? you may take cefdinir with food if it upsets your stomach. separate iron containing foods or supplements and multivitamins from cefdinir by at least two hours. iron can cause a harmless reddish color to stools when taken with cefdinir. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your usual schedule. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, stomach pain, headache, rash, and vaginal yeast infection. serious side effects include severe allergic reaction with trouble breathing, severe or persistent diarrhea that may be watery or bloody, severe skin reactions, liver problems such as yellowing of the eyes or skin or dark urine, and low blood counts. seek medical care for serious reactions.

name: cefditoren
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cefditoren is a cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat susceptible infections such as community acquired pneumonia, flare ups of chronic bronchitis, strep throat and tonsillitis, and uncomplicated skin infections. how should this medicine be used? take cefditoren tablets by mouth with a meal because food improves absorption. take it exactly as prescribed, usually twice daily for the prescribed duration. swallow tablets whole. do not take with antacids or acid reducing medicines at the same time because they can reduce absorption. probenecid can increase cefditoren levels. if you have reduced kidney function your dose may need adjustment. what special precautions should i follow? do not take cefditoren if you have a known allergy to cefditoren or other cephalosporins, a history of immediate allergic reactions to penicillins, milk protein hypersensitivity, or carnitine deficiency.if you have kidney disease, a history of colitis, are taking antacids, h2 blockers, or proton pump inhibitors, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. cefditoren can cause severe allergic reactions and clostridioides difficile associated diarrhea. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take each dose with a meal. avoid taking antacids, h2 receptor blockers, or proton pump inhibitors close to the time you take cefditoren because they can lower absorption. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your usual schedule. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, headache, and rash. serious side effects include severe allergic reaction with trouble breathing, severe skin reactions, severe or persistent diarrhea that may be watery or bloody, liver problems such as yellowing of the skin or eyes, and changes in blood counts. seek medical care for serious reactions.

name: cefepime injection
instructions: important warning: cefepime can cause serious brain and nervous system side effects including confusion, hallucinations, speech difficulty, twitching, seizures, and decreased consciousness, especially in people with kidney problems or when doses are not adjusted for kidney function. these symptoms can occur within a few days of starting therapy. seek medical help right away if these occur. your dose must be adjusted if you have reduced kidney function. why is this medication prescribed? cefepime is a fourth generation cephalosporin antibiotic used to treat serious infections such as hospital acquired pneumonia, febrile neutropenia, complicated urinary tract infections, complicated intra abdominal infections in combination with metronidazole, and skin and soft tissue infections. how should this medicine be used?
