common effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, stomach cramps, decreased appetite, headache, dizziness, blurred vision, and itching. serious effects include heart rhythm disturbances with fainting or palpitations, seizures, severe mood or behavior changes, low blood sugar with sweating or confusion, muscle weakness, and irreversible retinal damage with vision loss with long term or high dose use. seek medical care for serious symptoms.

name: chlorpromazine
instructions: important warning: elderly patients with dementia related psychosis who are treated with antipsychotic medicines have an increased risk of death. chlorpromazine is not approved for the treatment of dementia related psychosis. why is this medication prescribed? chlorpromazine is an antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia and other psychotic disorders. it is also used to control severe nausea and vomiting, treat intractable hiccups, manage acute intermittent porphyria, and as an adjunct in the treatment of tetanus. how should this medicine be used? chlorpromazine can be taken by mouth as tablets or liquid, or given by injection in a healthcare setting. doses are individualized and may be increased gradually. take it at the same times each day. do not stop suddenly without medical advice. your doctor may order blood tests and heart tests and will monitor for movement side effects. use sun protection because this medicine can cause photosensitivity. avoid overheating and stay hydrated. what special precautions should i follow?if you have heart disease, a history of abnormal heart rhythms or prolonged qt, low potassium or magnesium, liver disease, glaucoma, urinary retention, prostate enlargement, seizure disorder, parkinson disease, myasthenia gravis, blood disorders, breast cancer or other prolactin sensitive tumors, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.about all medicines you take, especially other medicines that can prolong the qt interval, blood pressure medicines, anticholinergics, lithium, antidepressants, and opioids. this medicine can cause drowsiness and dizziness. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. seek immediate care if you develop high fever with stiff muscles and confusion which may indicate neuroleptic malignant syndrome, or if you develop uncontrolled movements which may indicate tardive dyskinesia. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid alcohol. taking doses with food may reduce stomach upset. drink fluids and consume fiber to help prevent constipation. use sun protection to prevent photosensitivity reactions. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time of your next dose. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at the same time. if you miss an injection appointment, contact your clinic to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include drowsiness, dizziness, dry mouth, blurred vision, constipation, low blood pressure when standing, weight gain, swelling, menstrual changes, and breast enlargement or discharge. serious effects include abnormal heart rhythms, seizures, blood disorders with fever or unusual bruising, cholestatic jaundice with yellowing of the skin or eyes, neuroleptic malignant syndrome, and tardive dyskinesia with involuntary movements that may be irreversible. photosensitivity reactions and skin discoloration may occur. seek medical help for serious or persistent symptoms.

name: chlorpropamide
instructions: important warning: chlorpropamide can cause prolonged and severe low blood sugar, especially in older adults, those who skip meals or drink alcohol, and people with kidney or liver problems. know the signs of hypoglycemia and how to treat it promptly. why is this medication prescribed? chlorpropamide is used along with diet and exercise to improve blood sugar control in adults with type 2 diabetes. it helps your pancreas release insulin and your body use insulin more effectively. how should this medicine be used? take chlorpropamide by mouth once daily with breakfast or your first main meal to reduce the risk of low blood sugar. take it at the same time each day. do not crush or split unless directed. your doctor will adjust the dose based on your blood glucose and a1c. check your blood sugar as instructed and do not stop or change the dose without medical advice. what special precautions should i follow?about kidney or liver disease, adrenal or pituitary problems, g6pd deficiency, sulfonylurea or sulfonamide allergies, glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency, and if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. avoid alcohol because it can cause a disulfiram-like reaction with flushing, nausea, and can dangerously lower blood sugar. be cautious when driving or operating machinery until you know how this medicine affects you. learn how to recognize and treat hypoglycemia and carry a source of fast-acting sugar. certain medicines can increase hypoglycemia risk, including other diabetes drugs, beta blockers, salicylates, warfarin, and some antibiotics; others may raise blood sugar. chlorpropamide can cause low sodium; report confusion, headache, or weakness. what special dietary instructions should i follow? eat regular meals with consistent carbohydrate intake and do not skip meals. avoid alcohol. follow your diabetes meal plan and stay hydrated. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose, take it as soon as you remember with food. if it is near the time of your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your normal schedule. do not take two doses at once. check your blood sugar more frequently if you missed a dose and contact your clinician if levels are very high or low. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include low blood sugar with sweating, shakiness, hunger, fast heartbeat, headache, and confusion, weight gain, nausea, and skin rash. serious side effects include severe hypoglycemia, low sodium with confusion or seizures, liver problems with yellowing of the skin or eyes or dark urine, and allergic reactions with swelling or difficulty breathing. seek urgent care for severe reactions.

name: chlorthalidone
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? chlorthalidone is a thiazide-like diuretic used to treat high blood pressure and swelling due to heart failure, liver disease, or kidney disorders. lowering blood pressure helps prevent strokes, heart attacks, and kidney problems. how should this medicine be used? take chlorthalidone by mouth once daily in the morning to limit nighttime urination. it may be taken with food if it upsets your stomach. take it at the same time each day and continue even if you feel well. your doctor may adjust the dose based on your blood pressure, kidney function, and electrolytes. what special precautions should i follow?about kidney or liver disease, gout, lupus, diabetes, high cholesterol or triglycerides, and if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. this medicine can cause low potassium, low sodium, dehydration, and increased uric acid and blood sugar. report dizziness, muscle cramps, extreme thirst, confusion, or irregular heartbeat. rise slowly from sitting to reduce dizziness. use caution with other blood pressure medicines, lithium, digoxin, and nsaids. protect skin from sun due to increased sensitivity. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow your prescribed low-salt diet. your doctor may recommend potassium-rich foods or a supplement if appropriate. stay well hydrated unless otherwise directed and limit alcohol, which can worsen dizziness. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is late in the day; if so, skip the missed dose to avoid nighttime urination and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include increased urination, dizziness, lightheadedness, headache, and mild gastrointestinal upset. it can cause low potassium or sodium, high uric acid leading to gout, higher blood sugar, muscle cramps, photosensitivity rash, and, rarely, pancreatitis or severe electrolyte abnormalities. seek medical attention for fainting, severe weakness, irregular heartbeat, or severe abdominal pain.

name: chlorzoxazone
instructions: important warning: rare but severe liver injury, including liver failure, has occurred with chlorzoxazone. stop the medicine and seek medical care immediately if you develop yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, severe fatigue, abdominal pain, or persistent nausea. why is this medication prescribed? chlorzoxazone is a muscle relaxant used short term with rest and physical therapy to relieve muscle spasms and pain from acute musculoskeletal conditions. how should this medicine be used? take chlorzoxazone by mouth as directed, usually three to four times daily. take with food if it upsets your stomach. use the lowest effective dose for the shortest time needed. do not drive or perform tasks requiring alertness until you know how it affects you. what special precautions should i follow?about any liver disease, alcohol use, and all medicines you take, especially other sedatives, opioids, benzodiazepines, sleep medicines, and antihistamines. avoid alcohol, which increases drowsiness and liver risk. this medicine may discolor urine orange, red, or purple, which is usually harmless. use caution in older adults due to increased sedation and fall risk. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary requirements, but avoid alcohol while taking this medication. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember. if it is near the time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include drowsiness, dizziness, lightheadedness, headache, and stomach upset. serious side effects include liver injury with yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, severe fatigue, allergic reactions, or severe dizziness. seek immediate care for signs of liver injury or severe allergic reactions.

name: cholecalciferol vitamin d3
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? vitamin d3 is used to prevent and treat vitamin d deficiency, support bone health, and as part of treatment for conditions like osteoporosis, osteomalacia, and rickets. how should this medicine be used? take vitamin d3 by mouth exactly as directed. it may be prescribed daily, weekly, or monthly. take it consistently with or without food; taking with a meal that contains some fat can improve absorption. your dose is based on your blood levels and medical condition. do not exceed the recommended dose. what special precautions should i follow?if you have high calcium, kidney disease or stones, hyperparathyroidism, sarcoidosis or other granulomatous diseases, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding.about all medicines and supplements, including thiazide diuretics, steroids, anticonvulsants, orlistat, and bile acid sequestrants, which can affect vitamin d levels or absorption. report symptoms of high calcium such as weakness, confusion, nausea, vomiting, constipation, excessive urination, or bone pain. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow your provider’s advice on calcium intake. avoid taking excessive amounts of calcium or additional vitamin d products unless instructed. maintain adequate hydration. if you use agents that reduce absorption such as orlistat or cholestyramine, separate dosing as directed by your provider. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember. if it is close to your next scheduled dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take extra doses to make up for a missed one. for weekly or monthly dosing, take the missed dose when remembered unless it is very close to the next dose, then skip and resume your normal schedule. what side effects can this medication cause? vitamin d3 is generally well tolerated. possible side effects include nausea, constipation, and headache. high doses or sensitivity can cause high calcium with symptoms such as weakness, confusion, thirst, frequent urination, abdominal pain, bone pain, or kidney stones. seek medical care if these occur.

name: cholera vaccine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? the oral cholera vaccine helps prevent cholera caused by vibrio cholerae o1 in travelers and others at risk. it reduces the risk of illness but does not replace safe food and water practices. how should this medicine be used? it is given as a single oral dose administered by a healthcare provider or according to the product directions at least 10 days before potential exposure. do not eat or drink for 60 minutes before and after vaccination unless the product label directs otherwise. if you have recently taken antibiotics, vaccination may need to be scheduled at least 10 days after finishing antibiotics. what special precautions should i follow? tell your provider if you are immunocompromised, have acute vomiting or diarrhea, are pregnant or breastfeeding, or have taken antibiotics or antimalarials recently. the vaccine organism may be shed in stool for a short time; practice good hand hygiene and dispose of diapers carefully. this vaccine does not protect against all cholera strains and is not 100 percent effective; continue to follow food and water safety measures. what special dietary instructions should i follow? do not eat or drink for one hour before and after the oral dose unless instructed otherwise by the product directions. maintain careful food and water hygiene during travel. what should i do if i forget a dose? if your scheduled vaccination is missed, contact your provider to reschedule as soon as possible to ensure protection before travel. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include tiredness, headache, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and lack of appetite. serious reactions are rare but can include severe allergic reactions with difficulty breathing or swelling. seek urgent care for signs of a severe allergic reaction.

name: cholestyramine resin
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cholestyramine is a bile acid sequestrant used to lower ldl cholesterol and to treat itching associated with partial bile duct obstruction. it is also sometimes used to treat diarrhea due to bile acid malabsorption. how should this medicine be used? mix the powder thoroughly with water or a noncarbonated beverage or soft food and drink or eat the entire mixture. do not take the powder dry. take it one to two times daily with meals or as directed. take other medications at least one hour before or four to six hours after cholestyramine to avoid interactions. what special precautions should i follow?if you have bowel obstruction, severe constipation, difficulty swallowing, phenylketonuria if using products containing phenylalanine, high triglycerides, or vitamin deficiencies. this medicine can raise triglycerides, bind many drugs, and reduce absorption of fat-soluble vitamins a, d, e, k and folate. your provider may recommend vitamin supplementation at a different time of day. use caution with warfarin, digoxin, thyroid hormone, diuretics, and many other drugs due to binding interactions. maintain good dental hygiene because some formulations contain sugar and prolonged contact may affect teeth. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow a cholesterol-lowering diet as prescribed. increase dietary fiber and fluid intake to reduce constipation unless instructed otherwise. take vitamin supplements at a separate time from cholestyramine if advised. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is near the time for your next dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include constipation, bloating, gas, abdominal discomfort, nausea, and heartburn. long-term use can cause fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies leading to easy bruising or bleeding, and it can raise triglycerides. rarely it can cause intestinal obstruction or severe constipation. contact your clinician if you have severe abdominal pain, no bowel movements, or signs of vitamin deficiency.

name: choline magnesium trisalicylate
instructions: important warning: salicylates can cause serious bleeding from the stomach or intestines and should not be used in children or teenagers with viral illnesses due to the risk of reye’s syndrome. avoid use late in pregnancy and use caution with other medicines that increase bleeding risk. why is this medication prescribed? choline magnesium trisalicylate is a nonacetylated salicylate used to relieve pain, fever, and inflammation in conditions such as osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and other musculoskeletal disorders. how should this medicine be used? take it by mouth exactly as directed, usually two to three times daily. take with food or milk to reduce stomach upset and drink plenty of fluids. do not take more than prescribed and avoid taking other salicylates or nsaids unless your clinician instructs you. what special precautions should i follow?if you have a history of stomach ulcers or bleeding, bleeding disorders, aspirin or nsaid allergy, asthma or nasal polyps, kidney or liver disease, high blood pressure, heart failure, gout, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. this medicine may interact with anticoagulants, antiplatelet agents, other nsaids, corticosteroids, methotrexate, sulfonylureas, diuretics, and alcohol. stop and seek care for stomach pain, black stools, vomiting blood, unusual bruising or bleeding, ringing in the ears, confusion, or severe allergic reactions. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take with food or milk to minimize stomach upset and avoid alcohol, which increases stomach bleeding risk. maintain adequate hydration. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is near the time for your next dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include stomach upset, heartburn, nausea, dizziness, and mild ringing in the ears. serious side effects include gastrointestinal bleeding or ulcers, severe allergic reactions, kidney problems with decreased urine, liver problems, and salicylate toxicity with confusion, vomiting, or persistent tinnitus. children and teens recovering from viral infections are at risk of reye’s syndrome and must not use this medication.

name: ciclesonide nasal spray
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ciclesonide nasal spray is a corticosteroid used to treat nasal symptoms of seasonal and perennial allergic rhinitis such as congestion, sneezing, and runny nose. how should this medicine be used? use the spray in the nose once daily as directed. prime the spray before first use and if not used for several days. gently blow your nose, aim slightly away from the nasal septum, and avoid spraying into the eyes. clean the nozzle regularly. use it consistently for best effect; some people notice improvement within hours, but full benefit may take several days. what special precautions should i follow?about recent nasal surgery, ulcers, or trauma, glaucoma or cataracts, infections including tuberculosis or untreated fungal, bacterial, or viral infections, and if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. long-term high-dose use can rarely cause systemic steroid effects including slowed growth in children, adrenal suppression, and increased risk of infection. report persistent nosebleeds, nasal irritation, white patches in the nose or throat, or vision changes. avoid exposure to chickenpox or measles and contact your clinician if exposed. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are required. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it as soon as you remember. if it is close to the time of your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use extra sprays to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include nosebleeds, nasal irritation or dryness, sore throat, cough, and headache. less common effects include fungal infections of the nose or throat, loss or change of taste or smell, and, rarely, perforation of the nasal septum or glaucoma or cataracts with long-term use.

name: ciclesonide oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ciclesonide inhalation is an inhaled corticosteroid used as maintenance therapy to prevent and control asthma symptoms. it is not a rescue medicine for sudden breathing problems. how should this medicine be used? inhale by mouth as directed, usually twice daily. prime the inhaler before first use and if not used for a period specified in the product guide. use proper inhalation technique and rinse your mouth with water and spit after each dose to reduce the risk of oral thrush. do not use this medicine to treat acute asthma attacks; use your quick-relief inhaler as directed for sudden symptoms. do not stop systemic steroids abruptly; taper only under medical supervision. what special precautions should i follow?about glaucoma or cataracts, osteoporosis, adrenal or pituitary problems, active or chronic infections including tuberculosis, liver disease, and all medicines you take, including strong cyp3a4 inhibitors such as ketoconazole or ritonavir. report worsening breathing, paradoxical bronchospasm immediately after inhalation, signs of infection, white patches in the mouth, hoarseness, or vision changes. children on long-term therapy should have growth monitored. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are required. ensure adequate calcium and vitamin d intake if advised by your clinician for bone health. what should i do if i forget a dose? inhale it as soon as you remember unless it is close to the next scheduled dose. if it is near the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume the regular schedule. do not take extra puffs to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include throat irritation, hoarseness, cough, headache, and oral thrush. serious side effects include paradoxical bronchospasm, adrenal suppression, slowed growth in children, increased infection risk, and glaucoma or cataracts with long-term use. seek urgent care if you have sudden worsening wheeze or breathing difficulty after use.

name: ciclopirox topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ciclopirox is an antifungal medicine used topically to treat fungal skin infections such as athlete’s foot, jock itch, and ringworm, seborrheic dermatitis of the scalp with the shampoo, and fungal nail infections with the nail lacquer. how should this medicine be used? for creams, gels, or lotions, apply a thin layer to the affected area and surrounding skin once or twice daily as directed on clean, dry skin and continue for the full course even if symptoms improve. for the shampoo, apply to the scalp, lather, leave on for several minutes, then rinse, using as directed. for the nail lacquer, apply once daily to the affected nails and surrounding skin, remove with alcohol once weekly, and trim nails as directed. avoid contact with eyes, mouth, and inside the nose, and do not use on broken skin unless instructed. what special precautions should i follow? for external use only.about any allergies to topical products and if you have diabetes, immune system problems, or poor circulation, especially when treating nail infections. stop use and seek medical advice if irritation, swelling, or signs of allergic reaction occur or if the infection does not improve after the recommended treatment period. the nail lacquer is flammable; keep away from heat or open flame and avoid using cosmetic nail polish unless directed. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary instructions are required. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply it as soon as you remember. if it is near the time for the next application, skip the missed dose and continue with your regular schedule. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. for nail lacquer, apply the next scheduled coat and continue the usual routine. what side effects can this medication cause? common side effects include mild burning, stinging, redness, itching, or dryness at the application site. less common effects include rash, discoloration of the nail with the lacquer, and allergic contact dermatitis. seek medical attention for severe irritation or signs of an allergic reaction.

name: cidofovir injection
instructions: important warning: cidofovir can cause severe or irreversible kidney damage and low white blood cell counts. it must be administered only by experienced clinicians with mandatory kidney protection measures including intravenous saline hydration and probenecid. use is generally limited to cytomegalovirus retinitis in people with aids when potential benefits outweigh serious risks. why is this medication prescribed? cidofovir is an antiviral used to treat cytomegalovirus retinitis in patients with aids. how should this medicine be used? it is given as an intravenous infusion, usually 5 mg per kilogram once weekly for 2 weeks, then every 2 weeks, infused over about 1 hour. you will receive 1 to 2 liters of intravenous normal saline around each dose and probenecid by mouth before and after each infusion to protect the kidneys. doses are adjusted or stopped based on kidney tests and urine protein. only a healthcare professional should administer it. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about any kidney disease, protein in the urine, prior reactions to probenecid or sulfa medicines, blood disorders, eye inflammation, or pregnancy and breastfeeding. do not receive cidofovir if you have significant kidney impairment or cannot take probenecid. avoid other medicines that can harm the kidneys such as aminoglycosides, amphotericin b, iv contrast, certain antivirals including tenofovir, and high dose nsaids. use reliable contraception during treatment and for at least 1 month after the last dose if you are able to become pregnant, and male patients should use condoms during treatment and for at least 3 months after the last dose. you will need frequent blood and urine tests and eye exams. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific food restrictions, but maintain good hydration as directed by your care team. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an infusion appointment, contact your healthcare team immediately to reschedule. do not attempt to receive the medication outside a clinic setting. what side effects can this medication cause? serious side effects include kidney failure, protein in the urine, low white blood cell counts with increased infection risk, inflammation in the eye including uveitis and iritis, vision changes, and ocular hypotony. other side effects can include fever, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, rash, fatigue, headache, and changes in blood tests. seek urgent care for decreased urination, swelling, shortness of breath, severe eye pain or vision loss, fever, or signs of infection.

name: cilostazol
instructions: important warning: do not take cilostazol if you have heart failure of any severity. drugs in this class increased mortality in patients with heart failure. why is this medication prescribed? cilostazol is used to improve walking distance and reduce leg pain in people with intermittent claudication from peripheral artery disease. how should this medicine be used? the usual dose is 100 mg by mouth twice daily, taken at least 30 minutes before or 2 hours after breakfast and dinner. if you take certain strong inhibitors of cyp3a4 or cyp2c19 your doctor may reduce the dose to 50 mg twice daily. benefits may appear after 2 to 4 weeks and may continue to improve up to 12 weeks. if there is no improvement after about 3 months your doctor may stop it. what special precautions should i follow?about any history of heart failure, heart rhythm problems, stroke, bleeding disorders, stomach ulcers, kidney or liver disease, or planned surgery. use caution if you take other medicines that increase bleeding such as aspirin, clopidogrel, anticoagulants, or nsaids. many drugs interact, including strong cyp3a4 inhibitors like ketoconazole and clarithromycin and cyp2c19 inhibitors like omeprazole, and inducers like rifampin or carbamazepine. discuss pregnancy and breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take on an empty stomach for best absorption. avoid grapefruit or grapefruit juice unless your prescriber approves because it can raise cilostazol levels. limit alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is near the time for your next dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? headache, diarrhea, abnormal stools, palpitations, fast heartbeat, dizziness, low blood pressure, swelling of ankles or feet, and stomach discomfort. it can increase bleeding and rarely can cause low platelets or white blood cells. seek medical care for chest pain, fainting, signs of bleeding, or signs of infection.

name: ciltacabtagene autoleucel injection
instructions: important warning: this car t cell therapy can cause life threatening cytokine release syndrome, neurologic toxicities including confusion, seizures, and movement and speech disorders, hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis or macrophage activation syndrome, prolonged low blood counts with infection and bleeding risk, and serious or fatal infections. it is available only through a restricted program and you will be closely monitored. do not drive or operate hazardous machinery for at least 8 weeks after infusion. why is this medication prescribed? it is used to treat certain adults with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma after specific prior treatments. how should this medicine be used? you receive chemotherapy to reduce your lymphocytes for several days before a one time intravenous infusion of your own genetically modified t cells. you will be premedicated and monitored in a certified center for several days after infusion and must stay within close proximity for at least 4 weeks. carry your patient wallet card at all times and show it to all healthcare providers. what special precautions should i follow? before treatment you will be checked and possibly treated for infections, including hepatitis b, and may receive preventive antimicrobials. avoid live vaccines before treatment, during therapy, and until your immune system recovers. tell your team about prior or current neurologic conditions, heart or lung disease, and all medicines including corticosteroids and immunosuppressants. pregnancy must be avoided; discuss contraception and do not breastfeed. do not donate blood, organs, tissues, or cells after receiving this therapy. seek urgent care if you develop fever, chills, fast heartbeat, low blood pressure, shortness of breath, confusion, severe headache, seizures, or weakness. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are required, but maintain good hydration and nutrition as advised by your team. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss any appointment for chemotherapy, cell infusion, or follow up monitoring, contact your treatment center immediately. do not attempt to reschedule on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fever, fatigue, low blood pressure, low oxygen levels, fast heartbeat, confusion, tremor, difficulty speaking, headache, dizziness, nausea, diarrhea, decreased appetite, cough, and muscle or joint pain. serious effects include cytokine release syndrome, severe neurologic events, severe infections, tumor lysis syndrome, prolonged low blood counts with bleeding or infection, and secondary malignancies.

name: cimetidine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cimetidine reduces stomach acid and is used to treat and prevent gastric and duodenal ulcers, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and heartburn or acid indigestion. it may also be used for conditions with excessive acid production such as zollinger ellison syndrome. how should this medicine be used? it is taken by mouth as tablets, liquid, or injections. over the counter dosing for heartburn is typically 200 mg up to twice daily. prescription doses commonly include 400 mg twice daily or 800 mg at bedtime for ulcers for 4 to 8 weeks, with maintenance dosing as directed. dose adjustments may be needed in kidney impairment. do not use nonprescription cimetidine longer than 14 days without medical advice. what special precautions should i follow?about kidney or liver disease, a history of confusion, unintended weight loss, trouble swallowing, vomiting blood or black stools, and any persistent abdominal pain. cimetidine inhibits several liver enzymes and can interact with many medicines including warfarin, theophylline, phenytoin, certain benzodiazepines, tricyclic antidepressants, and others. it can cause confusion especially in older adults. long term use may reduce vitamin b12 absorption. discuss pregnancy and breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid foods and drinks that worsen heartburn such as large fatty meals, caffeine, alcohol, chocolate, peppermint, and spicy or acidic foods. do not smoke. weight reduction and avoiding late night meals may help. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if you use it as needed for heartburn, take it when symptoms occur. do not double up doses. what side effects can this medication cause? headache, dizziness, diarrhea or constipation, tiredness, and rash. rare but serious effects include confusion or agitation, liver enzyme elevations, breast enlargement or tenderness and sexual dysfunction with high doses or prolonged use, low blood counts, and pneumonia. seek care for mental status changes, signs of bleeding, or severe abdominal pain.

name: cinacalcet
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cinacalcet lowers parathyroid hormone levels and is used in adults on dialysis for secondary hyperparathyroidism and to treat high calcium levels in parathyroid carcinoma or primary hyperparathyroidism when surgery is not appropriate. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth with food or shortly after a meal. swallow tablets whole. for secondary hyperparathyroidism the usual starting dose is 30 mg once daily and is titrated every 2 to 4 weeks based on parathyroid hormone and serum calcium levels. for hypercalcemia the starting dose is often 30 mg twice daily with titration. regular blood tests are required. what special precautions should i follow? do not start if your calcium is low. cinacalcet can cause severe hypocalcemia which may lead to muscle cramps, tingling, seizures, or heart rhythm problems.about seizure disorders, heart rhythm issues, liver impairment, and all medicines you take. cinacalcet is a strong cyp2d6 inhibitor and can increase levels of medicines such as flecainide, propafenone, metoprolol, and certain antidepressants. strong cyp3a4 inhibitors can raise cinacalcet levels and inducers can lower them. discuss pregnancy and breastfeeding. keep out of reach of children. what special dietary instructions should i follow? take with meals consistently. follow your dialysis diet including phosphate, calcium, and vitamin d plans as instructed by your care team. avoid grapefruit products unless your prescriber approves. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember on the same day with food. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. contact your provider if you miss several doses. what side effects can this medication cause? nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, decreased appetite, muscle cramps, weakness, tingling around the mouth or in the hands and feet, headache, and low blood pressure. serious effects include severe hypocalcemia with seizures or arrhythmias and worsening heart failure in susceptible patients. seek care for severe cramping, confusion, seizures, or palpitations.

name: cipaglucosidase alfa-atga
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cipaglucosidase alfa-atga is an enzyme replacement therapy used in adults with late onset pompe disease to improve enzyme activity and reduce disease related symptoms. it is used in combination with miglustat. how should this medicine be used? it is given as an intravenous infusion every 2 weeks under the supervision of a healthcare team. you will take miglustat 65 mg by mouth about 1 hour before each infusion to stabilize the enzyme. you may receive premedications such as antihistamines and antipyretics to reduce infusion reactions. the infusion lasts several hours and you will be monitored during and after treatment. what special precautions should i follow?about any history of infusion reactions, allergies, breathing or heart problems, and all medicines you take. serious hypersensitivity including anaphylaxis can occur at any time, even after prior uneventful infusions. infusion associated reactions including fever, chills, flushing, chest discomfort, shortness of breath, or rash can occur and the infusion may need to be slowed or stopped. dose adjustments or temporary interruption may be needed if you have acute respiratory compromise. discuss pregnancy and breastfeeding. do not substitute other enzyme products without medical guidance. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions for this medicine. maintain good hydration and follow any disease specific nutrition plan recommended by your care team. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an infusion appointment, contact your infusion center promptly to reschedule. if you miss taking miglustat before an infusion, tell your team right away for instructions. what side effects can this medication cause? infusion related reactions such as fever, chills, flushing, chest discomfort, nausea, vomiting, headache, dizziness, rash, and shortness of breath are common. serious allergic reactions can occur. other effects include fatigue and elevated liver enzymes. seek immediate care for trouble breathing, swelling of the face or throat, severe chest pain, or fainting.

name: ciprofloxacin and dexamethasone otic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? this ear drop combination of an antibiotic and a corticosteroid is used to treat acute otitis externa and acute otitis media in patients with tympanostomy tubes. how should this medicine be used? the usual dose is 4 drops into the affected ear twice daily for 7 days or as directed. warm the bottle in your hands, shake well, lie with the affected ear upward, instill the drops without touching the dropper tip to the ear, gently press the tragus several times, and keep the ear upward for about 60 seconds. keep water out of the ear and complete the full course even if symptoms improve. what special precautions should i follow? for ear use only. do not use in the eyes.if you are allergic to quinolones, dexamethasone, or any ingredients, or if you have ear surgery history, a perforated eardrum, or chronic infections. stop and contact your doctor if severe pain, swelling, rash, worsening discharge, or hearing changes occur. prolonged use may lead to overgrowth of non susceptible organisms including fungi. discuss pregnancy and breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary restrictions are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not use extra drops to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? mild ear discomfort, itching, or a bitter taste if drops drain to the throat. rare effects include allergic reactions, dizziness if cold drops are used, worsening infection, or changes in hearing. seek care for rash, facial swelling, severe pain, or signs of severe infection.

name: ciprofloxacin injection
instructions: important warning: systemic fluoroquinolones, including ciprofloxacin, can cause disabling and potentially irreversible serious adverse reactions including tendonitis and tendon rupture, peripheral neuropathy, and central nervous system effects such as seizures and psychosis. ciprofloxacin may exacerbate myasthenia gravis. use for uncomplicated infections only when no alternative treatment options exist. why is this medication prescribed? ciprofloxacin injection is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic used to treat a variety of serious bacterial infections when intravenous therapy is appropriate. how should this medicine be used? it is administered by a healthcare professional as an intravenous infusion over about 60 minutes. dose and frequency depend on the type of infection, body weight, and kidney function. complete the prescribed course. do not receive tizanidine while on ciprofloxacin. stay well hydrated during therapy. what special precautions should i follow?about a history of tendon disorders, aortic aneurysm or vascular disease, ehlers danlos syndrome, transplant, kidney disease, seizures, stroke, psychiatric illness, diabetes, heart rhythm problems, and myasthenia gravis. many drugs interact including antiarrhythmics, theophylline, warfarin, antidiabetic agents, nsaids, and corticosteroids which can increase tendon rupture risk. ciprofloxacin can cause abnormal blood sugars, aortic aneurysm or dissection risk, qt prolongation, photosensitivity, clostridioides difficile associated diarrhea, and liver injury. avoid excessive sunlight and use sun protection. discuss pregnancy and breastfeeding. report tendon pain or swelling, tingling or numbness, confusion, severe diarrhea, palpitations, yellowing of the skin or eyes, or signs of severe allergic reaction immediately. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is required for iv therapy. maintain adequate hydration and avoid excessive sunlight or tanning beds. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an infusion appointment, contact your healthcare team immediately to reschedule. do not try to make up a dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, headache, dizziness, rash, and infusion site reactions. serious effects include tendon pain or rupture, peripheral neuropathy, seizures, hallucinations, severe mood changes, severe allergic reactions including anaphylaxis, abnormal heart rhythms, severe diarrhea due to c difficile, liver injury, and severe blood sugar changes.

name: ciprofloxacin ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ciprofloxacin eye drops or ointment are used to treat bacterial conjunctivitis and corneal ulcers. how should this medicine be used? for conjunctivitis, a common adult regimen is 1 to 2 drops in the affected eye every 2 hours while awake for the first 2 days, then 1 to 2 drops every 4 hours while awake for the next 5 days. for corneal ulcers, your eye specialist will prescribe a more frequent schedule. wash hands before use, avoid touching the dropper tip, remove contact lenses before dosing, and wait at least 15 minutes before reinserting them if your doctor approves. use for the full prescribed course. what special precautions should i follow? for eye use only.about allergies to quinolones. stop and seek care for severe burning, swelling, rash, worsening redness, pain, or vision changes. avoid wearing contact lenses during active infection. separate other eye medications by at least 5 to 10 minutes. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary restrictions are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? instill the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use extra drops to make up a dose. what side effects can this medication cause? temporary eye burning or stinging, bad taste in the mouth, eye redness, discomfort, or a white crystalline precipitate on the surface of the eye. rarely, allergic reactions, corneal damage in severe ulcers, and superinfection can occur.

name: ciprofloxacin otic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? ciprofloxacin ear drops are used to treat acute otitis externa and certain chronic ear infections caused by susceptible bacteria. how should this medicine be used? typical dosing for acute otitis externa is 0.25 milliliters, about 5 drops, into the affected ear twice daily for 7 days or as directed. warm the bottle in your hands, shake if it is a suspension, lie with the affected ear upward, instill the drops without touching the dropper tip to the ear, gently press the tragus several times, and keep the ear upward for about 60 seconds. keep the ear dry during treatment and complete the full course. what special precautions should i follow? for ear use only. do not use in the eyes.if you have allergies to quinolones, a perforated eardrum, ear tubes, chronic ear disease, or recent ear surgery. stop and contact your doctor for severe pain, rash, swelling, or hearing changes. pregnancy and breastfeeding should be discussed. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special dietary restrictions are needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your usual schedule. do not apply extra drops to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? ear discomfort or itching, headache, and an unpleasant taste if drainage reaches the throat. rarely, allergic reactions, dizziness if cold drops are used, and overgrowth of non susceptible organisms including fungi may occur.

name: cisapride
instructions: important warning: cisapride can cause serious and sometimes fatal heart rhythm problems, especially when taken with certain other medicines or in people with underlying heart conditions or low potassium or magnesium. it is restricted in many countries and is available only through special programs for select patients. why is this medication prescribed? cisapride is a prokinetic medicine that increases movement of the stomach and intestines. it may be prescribed for severe gastrointestinal motility disorders that have not responded to other treatments. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as directed by your doctor, usually by mouth before meals and at bedtime. do not change your dose or schedule without medical advice. your doctor may check your heart rhythm and blood electrolytes before and during treatment. what special precautions should i follow?if you have or have ever had heart rhythm problems, long qt syndrome, heart failure, slow heartbeat, kidney or liver disease, or low potassium or magnesium. provide a complete list of all medicines and supplements you take. do not take cisapride with medicines that strongly block the enzyme cyp3a4 or that can prolong the qt interval, including certain antibiotics, antifungals, antidepressants, antipsychotics, antiarrhythmics, and some hiv medicines. avoid grapefruit products. seek urgent care if you feel faint, have palpitations, or pass out. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice. maintain good hydration and a balanced diet to help keep potassium and magnesium in the normal range unless your doctor gives you different instructions. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to your next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects can include abdominal cramps, diarrhea, gas, nausea, and headache. serious effects require immediate medical attention and include fainting, fast or irregular heartbeat, chest pain, severe dizziness, and seizures.

name: cisplatin injection
instructions: important warning: cisplatin can cause serious kidney damage, hearing loss, nerve damage, severe nausea and vomiting, and low blood cell counts that increase the risk of infection and bleeding. it must be given by experienced oncology professionals with appropriate monitoring and supportive care. why is this medication prescribed? cisplatin is a chemotherapy medicine used to treat various cancers including testicular, ovarian, bladder, head and neck, and lung cancers. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion in a clinic or hospital on specific treatment cycles. you will receive medicines to prevent nausea and special fluids before and after to protect the kidneys. keep all appointments for blood tests, hearing checks, and treatments. what special precautions should i follow?about all your medical conditions, including kidney or hearing problems, nerve problems such as numbness or tingling, prior chemotherapy or radiation, infections, and gout or high uric acid. provide a full list of your medicines and supplements. avoid other medicines that can harm the kidneys or ears such as aminoglycoside antibiotics, amphotericin b, and high dose nonsteroidal anti inflammatory medicines, unless your oncology team approves. use effective birth control during treatment and for the time your doctor advises because cisplatin can harm an unborn baby and may affect fertility. do not receive live vaccines during treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? drink fluids as instructed by your care team, especially around treatment days. eat small frequent meals if you have nausea. there are no specific foods you must avoid unless your doctor advises otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? call your oncology team as soon as possible to reschedule. do not try to receive this medicine on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fatigue, nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, changes in taste, and low blood counts. serious effects include kidney problems such as decreased urination or swelling, hearing loss or ringing in the ears, numbness or tingling in the hands or feet, severe or persistent vomiting, fever or signs of infection, allergic reactions with rash or trouble breathing during infusion, and electrolyte problems that can cause muscle cramps or irregular heartbeat.

name: citalopram
instructions: important warning: antidepressants including citalopram may increase the risk of suicidal thoughts and actions in children, adolescents, and young adults, especially during the first months of treatment or when the dose is changed. watch for sudden changes in mood, behavior, thoughts, or feelings and contact a doctor right away if these occur. citalopram can also cause changes in heart rhythm called qt prolongation. why is this medication prescribed? citalopram is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor used to treat depression and sometimes other conditions as determined by your doctor. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth once daily with or without food at the same time each day. your doctor may start at a low dose and adjust gradually. do not stop suddenly without medical guidance. what special precautions should i follow?if you have heart problems, long qt syndrome, low potassium or magnesium, liver disease, seizures, bleeding problems, or a history of bipolar disorder or mania. provide a full list of all medicines and supplements. do not use with monoamine oxidase inhibitors, linezolid, or methylene blue. avoid other medicines that prolong the qt interval or increase serotonin unless approved by your doctor. citalopram can cause low sodium levels, especially in older adults or if you take diuretics. use caution with alcohol and activities requiring alertness. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific foods you must avoid. avoid alcohol if it worsens side effects. do not use st johns wort without discussing with your doctor. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, dry mouth, sleepiness or insomnia, increased sweating, tremor, diarrhea or constipation, and sexual side effects such as decreased libido or difficulty reaching orgasm. serious effects include suicidal thoughts or behavior, serotonin syndrome with agitation, fever, fast heartbeat, or stiff muscles, abnormal heart rhythm with dizziness or fainting, severe low sodium with confusion or seizures, and unusual bleeding or bruising.

name: cladribine
instructions: important warning: cladribine tablets increase the risk of cancer and can cause harm to an unborn baby. do not use if you are pregnant or if you have active cancer. use effective contraception during treatment and for at least six months after the last dose, and men should also use reliable contraception during this time. cladribine lowers lymphocytes and increases the risk of serious infections. why is this medication prescribed? oral cladribine is a disease modifying therapy used to treat adults with relapsing forms of multiple sclerosis when other treatments have not been effective or are not appropriate. how should this medicine be used? it is taken by mouth in short treatment cycles during two annual courses. the dose is based on body weight. swallow tablets whole with water and dry hands before and after handling. follow the exact schedule given by your prescriber. do not take more than the prescribed number of tablets in a day and keep doses separated from other oral medicines as directed by your doctor. what special precautions should i follow? before starting, you will be screened for pregnancy, cancers, and infections such as hepatitis, tuberculosis, and hiv, and for immunity to varicella. do not receive live vaccines during treatment or until your doctor says your immune system has recovered.about all medicines and supplements, especially other medicines that affect the immune system. report signs of infection such as fever, shingles rash, or persistent cough. your blood counts and liver function will be monitored. do not breastfeed during treatment and for the time your doctor advises after the last dose of each treatment cycle. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary requirements. stay well hydrated and avoid excessive alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose during a treatment cycle, contact your prescriber for instructions. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, nausea, fatigue, hair thinning, rash, and decreased lymphocyte counts. serious effects include shingles or other infections, very low white blood cell counts, liver problems with yellowing of the skin or eyes or dark urine, and the development of cancers.

name: cladribine injection
instructions: important warning: cladribine injection can cause severe bone marrow suppression that increases the risk of serious and sometimes fatal infections and bleeding. it can also cause harmful effects to an unborn baby. it must be given by experienced healthcare professionals with careful monitoring. why is this medication prescribed? cladribine injection is used to treat hairy cell leukemia and may be used for certain other blood cancers as directed by a specialist. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion by a healthcare professional, often as a continuous infusion over several days or as daily infusions depending on the regimen. you will have regular blood tests and may receive preventive antibiotics or antivirals. what special precautions should i follow?about all medical conditions, including kidney or liver disease, infections, and any prior chemotherapy or radiation. provide a full list of medicines and supplements. avoid live vaccines during and after treatment until your doctor says it is safe. use effective contraception during treatment and for the time advised after the last dose. call your doctor right away for fever, chills, shortness of breath, unusual bleeding or bruising, or new neurological symptoms. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. maintain adequate fluid intake unless you are told otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your oncology team immediately to arrange the next dose. do not attempt to self administer unless you have been trained and instructed to do so. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include fever, fatigue, nausea, rash, and low blood counts leading to anemia, infection, or bleeding. serious effects include severe infections including opportunistic infections, infusion reactions, kidney or liver problems, and neurological effects such as confusion, drowsiness, or seizures at high exposures.

name: clarithromycin
instructions: important warning: clarithromycin may increase the risk of heart problems or death in people with existing heart disease and can cause abnormal heart rhythms, especially when combined with other medicines that affect the heart or the enzyme cyp3a4. it also has serious and sometimes life threatening interactions with certain medicines. why is this medication prescribed? clarithromycin is an antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections such as pneumonia, bronchitis, sinusitis, skin infections, and in combination therapies for helicobacter pylori related ulcers. it is also used to prevent or treat certain mycobacterial infections. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as directed. immediate release tablets or suspension can be taken with or without food. extended release tablets should be taken with food and swallowed whole. shake suspension well before measuring. take doses at evenly spaced times and complete the full course even if you feel better. what special precautions should i follow?if you have heart rhythm problems, long qt syndrome, low potassium or magnesium, liver disease, kidney disease, or myasthenia gravis. provide a complete list of all medicines and supplements. do not take clarithromycin with certain medicines including cisapride, pimozide, ergot alkaloids, lovastatin, or simvastatin. use caution with blood thinners, colchicine, calcium channel blockers, antiarrhythmics, benzodiazepines, carbamazepine, digoxin, theophylline, and other medicines that can prolong the qt interval. stop and seek care if you develop yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, severe abdominal pain, or fast or irregular heartbeat. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific foods you must avoid. take extended release tablets with food. avoid alcohol if it worsens stomach upset. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, taste changes, and headache. serious effects include liver problems, severe allergic reactions, clostridioides difficile associated diarrhea with watery or bloody stools, hearing changes, and abnormal heart rhythms.

name: clemastine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? clemastine is an antihistamine used to relieve symptoms of allergic rhinitis such as sneezing, runny nose, and itching, and to treat hives. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth exactly as directed, usually once or twice daily. it may be taken with or without food. do not exceed the recommended dose. this medicine can cause drowsiness, so consider taking at bedtime if advised by your doctor. what special precautions should i follow?if you have glaucoma, enlarged prostate, urinary retention, breathing problems such as asthma, thyroid disease, high blood pressure, or if you are older. avoid alcohol and other medicines that cause drowsiness unless your doctor says it is safe. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how this medicine affects you. discuss use during pregnancy or breastfeeding with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. avoid alcohol because it can increase drowsiness. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to your next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include drowsiness, dry mouth, blurred vision, constipation, and difficulty urinating. some people, especially children, may experience restlessness or excitement. serious effects include confusion, fast heartbeat, or trouble urinating that does not improve.

name: clindamycin
instructions: important warning: clindamycin can cause severe diarrhea and colitis due to clostridioides difficile that can occur during treatment or even weeks after it ends. this can be life threatening. stop clindamycin and contact your doctor right away if you develop watery or bloody stools or severe abdominal pain. why is this medication prescribed? clindamycin is an antibiotic used to treat serious bacterial infections of the skin and soft tissue, bone and joints, lungs, abdomen, female reproductive organs, and dental infections. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth exactly as directed and for the full prescribed course. capsules and liquid are usually taken three or four times daily. take each dose with a full glass of water. you may take it with food if it upsets your stomach. what special precautions should i follow?if you have a history of colitis, gastrointestinal disease, liver or kidney problems, or allergies to clindamycin or lincomycin. provide a list of all medicines and supplements.if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. do not use anti diarrhea medicines without medical advice if you develop diarrhea while taking clindamycin. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. stay hydrated and you may take doses with food to reduce stomach upset. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and an unpleasant or metallic taste. serious effects include severe diarrhea or colitis, signs of liver problems such as yellowing of the skin or eyes or dark urine, severe skin reactions, and allergic reactions with rash, swelling, or trouble breathing.

name: clindamycin injection
instructions: important warning: clindamycin can cause severe diarrhea and colitis due to clostridioides difficile that can occur during treatment or weeks after it ends. this can be life threatening. report watery or bloody stools or severe abdominal pain immediately. why is this medication prescribed? clindamycin injection is used to treat serious bacterial infections when oral therapy is not appropriate, including infections of the abdomen, pelvis, skin and soft tissues, bones and joints, and the blood. how should this medicine be used? it is given by a healthcare professional by intravenous infusion or intramuscular injection at prescribed intervals. if you receive home infusions, use only as instructed by your care team and do not mix or change rates without guidance. complete the full course. what special precautions should i follow?if you have a history of colitis, gastrointestinal disease, liver or kidney problems, or allergies to clindamycin or lincomycin. provide a full list of medicines and supplements. rapid intravenous administration can cause low blood pressure, so infusions are given over the recommended time. do not use anti diarrhea medicines without medical advice if you develop diarrhea. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. maintain adequate hydration. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an appointment for an injection or infusion, contact your clinic as soon as possible to reschedule. for home infusions, follow your care teams instructions and do not double doses. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include pain or irritation at the injection site, vein irritation, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and rash. serious effects include severe diarrhea or colitis, allergic reactions with hives or trouble breathing, liver problems, and very low white blood cell counts.

name: clioquinol topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? clioquinol topical is used on the skin to treat certain bacterial and fungal skin infections and eczema with secondary infection. how should this medicine be used? apply a thin layer to the affected area of skin as directed, usually two or three times daily. for external use only. avoid contact with the eyes, mouth, and inside the nose. do not use on large areas, on broken skin, or under occlusive dressings unless your doctor tells you to. wash hands after applying. what special precautions should i follow?if you are allergic to iodine, hydroxyquinolines, or any ingredients in the product, and if you have thyroid problems. this medicine can discolor skin, hair, nails, and clothing. prolonged or excessive use can increase the chance of side effects. do not use on deep or serious skin infections. discuss use during pregnancy or breastfeeding with your doctor. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no dietary restrictions for this topical medicine. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next application, skip the missed one and resume your regular schedule. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include mild burning, stinging, itching, dryness, or redness at the application site, and temporary discoloration of the skin. serious reactions are uncommon but include severe irritation or allergic contact dermatitis. stop using and contact your doctor if severe irritation, swelling, or a rash develops.

name: clobazam
instructions: important warning: clobazam is a benzodiazepine. taking it with opioids can cause extreme sleepiness, slowed or difficult breathing, coma, and death. benzodiazepines can cause misuse, abuse, addiction, physical dependence, and severe withdrawal reactions. do not stop suddenly. why is this medication prescribed? clobazam is used with other medicines to help control seizures associated with lennox gastaut syndrome. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as directed once or twice daily. you may take it with or without food. the oral suspension should be measured with an oral syringe. tablets may be split along the score or crushed and mixed with soft food if needed. do not increase your dose or use more often than prescribed. to stop therapy, your prescriber will taper the dose slowly to reduce the risk of withdrawal and seizures. what special precautions should i follow?about all medicines and medical conditions including lung disease sleep apnea liver problems history of substance use depression or suicidal thoughts. avoid alcohol and other medicines that make you drowsy. risk of serious skin reactions such as stevens johnson syndrome or toxic epidermal necrolysis has been reported. use extra caution if you are a cyp2c19 poor metabolizer or take cyp2c19 inhibitors as clobazam levels may increase. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. if pregnant planning pregnancy or breastfeeding discuss risks and benefits. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary requirements. avoid alcohol. avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice which may increase clobazam levels. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. if it is near the time of the next dose skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. if you miss more than one dose contact your prescriber. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include sleepiness tiredness drooling constipation cough fever poor coordination and irritability. serious effects include slowed or difficult breathing severe drowsiness confusion skin rash or blistering suicidal thoughts unusual changes in mood or behavior withdrawal symptoms with abrupt stopping and allergic reactions. seek urgent care for trouble breathing severe rash or thoughts of self harm.

name: clobetasol topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? clobetasol is a very high potency topical corticosteroid used short term to relieve redness itching and inflammation of steroid responsive skin conditions such as psoriasis and eczema. how should this medicine be used? apply a thin layer to the affected skin twice daily or as directed. gently rub in. do not use on the face groin or underarms unless directed. do not use in the diaper area or under occlusion unless your doctor instructs you. avoid eyes mouth and broken skin. wash hands after application. limit total dose to the smallest amount needed and usually no more than two consecutive weeks. do not exceed about fifty grams per week unless specifically directed. for scalp solution or foam apply the recommended amount to dry scalp and allow to dry. what special precautions should i follow? prolonged use on large areas use under occlusion or use in children increases the risk of adrenal suppression skin thinning stretch marks and systemic effects. stop and contact your doctor if local infection occurs worsening irritation happens or no improvement in two weeks. use cautiously if you have diabetes poor circulation skin infections glaucoma or cataracts. do not use if you are allergic to clobetasol or any ingredient. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are required. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply it when you remember. if it is close to the next application skip the missed one and resume your schedule. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? burning stinging itching dryness skin thinning acne like eruptions folliculitis hypopigmentation and stretch marks. more serious but less common effects include adrenal suppression high blood sugar glaucoma or cataracts if used near the eyes and signs of skin infection.

name: clofarabine injection
instructions: important warning: clofarabine can cause severe and sometimes fatal liver injury including hepatic failure and veno occlusive disease severe kidney toxicity and systemic inflammatory response and capillary leak syndrome with hypotension and organ dysfunction. it causes profound bone marrow suppression which increases the risk of serious infections and bleeding. use only under the supervision of an experienced oncology clinician with close monitoring. why is this medication prescribed? clofarabine is a chemotherapy medicine used for relapsed or refractory acute lymphoblastic leukemia typically in pediatric and young adult patients who have received at least two prior regimens. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion in a medical setting often daily for five consecutive days per cycle. dosing frequency and cycle length depend on response and blood count recovery. you will receive prehydration and medicines to prevent nausea infections and tumor lysis depending on risk. lab tests will be checked frequently. what special precautions should i follow? tell your care team about all conditions and medicines especially liver or kidney disease heart problems recent or ongoing infections and prior stem cell transplant. clofarabine should not be given with uncontrolled infections or if liver or kidney tests are significantly abnormal unless the benefit outweighs the risks. avoid live vaccines during and after treatment until your doctor says it is safe. report fever chills shortness of breath dizziness rapid weight gain swelling decreased urine right upper abdominal pain yellowing of the skin or eyes unusual bleeding confusion severe rash or mouth sores right away. use effective contraception during therapy and for the recommended time after the last dose because clofarabine can harm an unborn baby. what special dietary instructions should i follow? stay well hydrated as instructed. limit or avoid alcohol to reduce liver stress. ask before using herbal or over the counter products. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is administered by your healthcare team. if you miss an appointment contact your clinic immediately to reschedule. do not attempt to self administer. what side effects can this medication cause? nausea vomiting diarrhea abdominal pain mouth sores fatigue fever chills infections low white blood cells low platelets anemia rash itching swelling rapid weight gain low blood pressure elevated liver enzymes jaundice kidney problems capillary leak syndrome and tumor lysis syndrome. seek urgent care for signs of infection bleeding allergic reactions breathing problems severe abdominal pain minimal urine output or yellowing of the skin or eyes.

name: clomiphene
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? clomiphene is used to induce ovulation in women with certain types of infertility such as polycystic ovary syndrome. how should this medicine be used? a common regimen is 50 milligrams once daily for five days starting on about cycle day five or as directed. if ovulation does not occur your doctor may adjust the dose or timing in later cycles typically not exceeding 100 milligrams daily. timed intercourse or insemination is usually recommended five to ten days after the last tablet. do not take more than prescribed and do not use for more than the recommended number of cycles without reevaluation. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you are pregnant have liver disease abnormal uterine bleeding an ovarian cyst not due to polycystic ovary syndrome or uncontrolled thyroid or adrenal disorders. risk of multiple pregnancy ovarian enlargement and rarely ovarian hyperstimulation exists. stop and call your doctor for severe pelvic or abdominal pain rapid weight gain nausea vomiting or vision changes. visual symptoms such as blurred vision or spots can occur and may be prolonged. use caution driving if visual symptoms occur and stop the medicine until you are evaluated.about a history of blood clots uterine fibroids or pituitary tumors. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is required. maintaining a healthy weight and taking prenatal folic acid when trying to conceive are recommended. limit alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? call your prescriber for instructions because timing is important for ovulation. do not double up unless your clinician advises you to do so. what side effects can this medication cause? hot flashes abdominal discomfort bloating breast tenderness nausea headache mood changes and visual disturbances. less common but serious effects include ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome enlarged ovarian cysts blood clots and stroke like symptoms. seek urgent care for severe pelvic pain shortness of breath severe headache or visual loss.

name: clomipramine
instructions: important warning: antidepressants including clomipramine may increase the risk of suicidal thoughts and actions in children adolescents and young adults especially during the first few months of treatment or when the dose is changed. close monitoring is required. families and caregivers should watch for sudden changes in mood behaviors thoughts or feelings. why is this medication prescribed? clomipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant used to treat obsessive compulsive disorder. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as directed usually starting with a low dose at bedtime and increasing gradually based on response and tolerability. it may be given in divided doses or once daily. take with food if it upsets your stomach. do not stop suddenly; your doctor will taper the dose to avoid withdrawal symptoms. what special precautions should i follow?about heart disease arrhythmias prior heart attack seizures glaucoma urinary retention thyroid disease bipolar disorder liver problems and all medicines you take. do not use with or within 14 days of monoamine oxidase inhibitors. risk of serotonin syndrome increases with other serotonergic drugs. it can cause drowsiness dizziness orthostatic hypotension and blurred vision; use caution when driving. it may lower the seizure threshold and prolong the qt interval. avoid alcohol. discuss risks in pregnancy and breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary restrictions. avoid alcohol. if you use caffeine heavily discuss with your prescriber because it may worsen anxiety or insomnia. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it when you remember unless it is close to your next dose. if it is almost time for the next dose skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. if you miss several doses call your prescriber. what side effects can this medication cause? dry mouth constipation blurred vision sweating tremor drowsiness dizziness weight gain nausea sexual dysfunction and difficulty urinating. serious effects include fainting fast or irregular heartbeat seizures serotonin syndrome severe confusion jaundice and suicidal thoughts or behaviors. seek urgent care for chest pain fainting seizures fever stiffness agitation or thoughts of self harm.

name: clonazepam
