instructions: important warning: clonazepam is a benzodiazepine. taking it with opioids can cause extreme sleepiness slowed or difficult breathing coma and death. benzodiazepines can cause misuse abuse addiction physical dependence and severe withdrawal including seizures. do not stop suddenly. why is this medication prescribed? clonazepam is used to treat certain seizure disorders and to treat panic disorder. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as prescribed once or twice daily. orally disintegrating tablets should be allowed to dissolve on the tongue and then swallowed. you may take it with or without food. do not change your dose or use it more often than directed. when discontinuing your prescriber will lower the dose gradually to reduce the risk of withdrawal and seizures. what special precautions should i follow?about lung disease sleep apnea liver problems depression or suicidal thoughts substance use disorder and all medicines you take. avoid alcohol and other sedatives. it may cause drowsiness dizziness and poor coordination; do not drive until you know its effects on you. use caution in pregnancy and breastfeeding because it may harm the fetus and cause sedation or withdrawal in the newborn. grapefruit may increase clonazepam levels. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary requirements. avoid alcohol and grapefruit products. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is near the time of the next dose skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. if you miss several doses contact your prescriber. what side effects can this medication cause? drowsiness dizziness fatigue poor coordination memory or concentration problems depression and irritability. serious effects include slowed or difficult breathing severe sedation suicidal thoughts allergic reactions rash and withdrawal symptoms if stopped suddenly.

name: clonidine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? clonidine is used to treat high blood pressure and certain formulations are used for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. it may also be used for other conditions as directed by your clinician. how should this medicine be used? take oral tablets exactly as directed usually twice daily. extended release tablets are taken once daily at bedtime or as prescribed and should not be substituted milligram for milligram with immediate release. transdermal patches are applied to a hairless area on the upper outer arm or chest and changed every seven days rotating sites. do not stop clonidine suddenly because this can cause a rapid rise in blood pressure headache and agitation. your doctor will taper the dose if it needs to be stopped. what special precautions should i follow?about heart rhythm problems low blood pressure kidney disease stroke history depression and all medicines you take. it can cause drowsiness dizziness slow heart rate and low blood pressure. use caution when driving and when standing up. avoid alcohol and other medicines that cause sedation. heat can increase absorption from patches. remove the patch before an mri if it contains metal. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is required, but a heart healthy diet and consistent salt intake may help blood pressure control. limit alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? for tablets take the missed dose when you remember unless it is close to the next dose then skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. for patches if a patch falls off apply a new one to a different site and continue your regular schedule. if you forget to change the patch apply a new one as soon as you remember and start a new seven day cycle from that time. what side effects can this medication cause? dry mouth drowsiness dizziness constipation fatigue headache and sleep problems. patch related skin irritation or rash can occur. serious effects include very low blood pressure slow heart rate fainting and severe rebound high blood pressure if stopped suddenly.

name: clopidogrel
instructions: important warning: the effectiveness of clopidogrel depends on activation by cyp2c19. people who are cyp2c19 poor metabolizers may have reduced response and higher risk for heart attack stroke or stent thrombosis. your doctor may consider genetic testing or alternative treatment. avoid strong cyp2c19 inhibitors such as omeprazole and esomeprazole unless your prescriber recommends a plan. why is this medication prescribed? clopidogrel is an antiplatelet medicine used to reduce the chance of heart attack and stroke in people with recent heart attack recent stroke or established peripheral arterial disease and with aspirin for certain types of acute coronary syndrome and after stent placement. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as directed usually 75 milligrams once daily. in some situations a loading dose is given at the start by your clinician. take with or without food at the same time each day. do not stop without talking to your doctor, especially after a stent, because stopping early can lead to a blood clot in the stent. what special precautions should i follow?about bleeding disorders ulcers recent surgery liver disease and all medicines including over the counter drugs and supplements. clopidogrel increases bleeding risk. your doctor may tell you to stop it five days before surgery or dental procedures. avoid combining with nonsteroidal anti inflammatory drugs and other blood thinners unless directed. watch for signs of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura such as fever weakness confusion yellowing of skin or eyes and unusual bruising or tiny purple spots. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is required. limit alcohol to reduce bleeding risk. ask your clinician before using herbal products that may affect bleeding. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember on the same day. if you do not remember until the next day skip the missed dose and take your regular dose. do not take two doses at once. if you recently had a stent and missed a dose call your cardiology team for advice. what side effects can this medication cause? easy bruising nosebleeds bleeding gums stomach upset diarrhea rash and itching. serious effects include black or bloody stools vomiting blood coughing up blood severe headache dizziness weakness jaundice pale skin shortness of breath and signs of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. seek urgent care for uncontrolled bleeding or stroke or heart attack symptoms.

name: clorazepate
instructions: important warning: clorazepate is a benzodiazepine. taking it with opioids can cause extreme sleepiness slowed or difficult breathing coma and death. benzodiazepines can cause misuse abuse addiction physical dependence and severe withdrawal. do not stop suddenly. why is this medication prescribed? clorazepate is used to treat anxiety disorders and symptoms of alcohol withdrawal and as an add on for certain seizure disorders. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as prescribed one to several times daily. you may take it with or without food. do not increase your dose or take it more often than directed. when stopping your prescriber will lower the dose gradually to prevent withdrawal and seizures. what special precautions should i follow?about lung disease sleep apnea liver or kidney problems depression or suicidal thoughts substance use disorder and all medicines you take. avoid alcohol and other sedatives. it can cause drowsiness dizziness and impaired coordination; do not drive until you know how it affects you. older adults are more sensitive to side effects. discuss risks in pregnancy and breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? there are no specific dietary requirements. avoid alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. if it is near the time of the next dose skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. if you miss several doses contact your prescriber. what side effects can this medication cause? drowsiness dizziness tiredness confusion blurred vision ataxia and memory problems. serious effects include slowed or difficult breathing severe sedation jaundice allergic reactions paradoxical agitation and withdrawal symptoms if stopped suddenly.

name: clotrimazole lozenge
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? clotrimazole lozenges also called troches are used to treat yeast infections of the mouth and throat known as oropharyngeal candidiasis or thrush. how should this medicine be used? dissolve one 10 milligram lozenge slowly in the mouth five times daily for 14 days or as prescribed. move the lozenge around your mouth periodically to reduce local irritation. do not chew or swallow whole and do not eat or drink while it is dissolving. finish the full course even if symptoms improve. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have liver disease frequent mouth sores diabetes or difficulty swallowing and about all medicines you take. use caution in young children who may choke on lozenges. if symptoms persist or recur after treatment contact your clinician to be evaluated for underlying conditions or need for alternative therapy. maintain good oral hygiene and denture care to prevent reinfection. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific diet is required. limiting sugary foods and drinks and rinsing the mouth after inhaled steroids can help prevent thrush. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose skip the missed dose and resume your schedule. do not take two lozenges at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? temporary nausea vomiting diarrhea altered taste and mild mouth irritation. rarely rash hives or abnormal liver tests may occur. seek medical care for signs of an allergic reaction such as swelling trouble breathing or widespread rash.

name: clotrimazole topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? clotrimazole topical is used to treat fungal skin infections such as athlete foot, jock itch, ringworm, cutaneous candidiasis, and tinea versicolor. how should this medicine be used? clean and dry the affected area. apply a thin layer to the affected skin and surrounding area as directed, usually two times daily for two to four weeks depending on the condition. wash hands before and after use. do not apply in the eyes, mouth, or vagina. use for the full course even if symptoms improve. if treating athlete foot, pay special attention to spaces between toes and keep feet dry. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you are allergic to clotrimazole or other antifungals. do not use on broken or very irritated skin unless directed. avoid occlusive dressings unless told to do so. if there is no improvement after two to four weeks or if the rash worsens, contact your clinician. ask your clinician before use if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. keep out of reach of children. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next application, skip the missed dose. do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? mild burning, stinging, irritation, redness, itching, or dryness at the application site may occur. stop use and seek medical advice for blistering, swelling, oozing, widespread rash, or signs of allergic reaction such as hives or trouble breathing.

name: clotrimazole vaginal
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? clotrimazole vaginal products treat vaginal yeast infections caused by candida. how should this medicine be used? use the applicator to insert the tablet or cream deeply into the vagina, usually once daily at bedtime for the number of days directed by your product, commonly one, three, or seven day regimens. you may also apply a small amount of cream to the external vulvar area for itching if directed. avoid douching and do not use tampons during therapy. you may use during your period but sanitary pads are preferred. complete the full course even if you feel better. what special precautions should i follow? use only if you have been told you have a yeast infection or if you have the typical symptoms you have had before. see a clinician if you have fever, lower abdominal pain, back or shoulder pain, foul smelling discharge, or if symptoms persist or recur frequently. do not use if you are allergic to clotrimazole. ask your clinician before use if pregnant or breastfeeding. clotrimazole can weaken latex condoms and diaphragms during treatment and for a short time after use. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? insert the missed dose when you remember. if it is close to the time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and continue your regular schedule. do not use two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? mild vaginal burning, irritation, or itching, abdominal cramps, or increased urinary frequency may occur. rarely, rash or hives can occur. sexual partners may experience local irritation.

name: clozapine
instructions: important warning: clozapine can cause severe neutropenia which can lead to serious infections. regular blood tests are required through a monitoring program before starting and during treatment, and the pharmacy will only dispense the medicine if tests are current. clozapine increases the risk of death in older adults with dementia related psychosis and is not approved for this use. it can cause low blood pressure with fainting, slow heart rate, and cardiac arrest, especially during initial dosing and dose increases. it can cause seizures, myocarditis and cardiomyopathy, and severe constipation that can lead to bowel blockage. seek immediate help for fever, sore throat, mouth sores, flu like symptoms, chest pain, shortness of breath, palpitations, severe constipation or abdominal swelling, or fainting. why is this medication prescribed? clozapine is used to treat schizophrenia when other treatments have not worked and to reduce the risk of suicidal behavior in schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as directed, at the same times each day. it is usually started at a low dose and increased slowly. if you miss taking clozapine for two days or more, do not restart at the previous dose. contact your prescriber because you may need to restart at a lower dose. do not stop clozapine suddenly unless your prescriber tells you to. you must have regular blood tests as scheduled. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medical conditions, especially heart disease, low blood pressure, seizure disorder, diabetes, bowel problems, liver or kidney disease, glaucoma, enlarged prostate, or history of low white blood cells. many drugs interact with clozapine including fluvoxamine, ciprofloxacin, carbamazepine, benzodiazepines, and others. smoking tobacco can lower clozapine levels, and stopping smoking can raise levels, so inform your clinician about any change in smoking. avoid alcohol and other sedatives. use caution driving until you know how it affects you. tell your clinician if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? maintain good hydration and a diet with adequate fiber to help prevent constipation. avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you remember within about twelve hours, take the dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. if you miss doses for two days or more, contact your prescriber before taking more. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include drowsiness, dizziness, increased saliva, constipation, rapid heartbeat, weight gain, increased blood sugar and lipids, and fever. serious effects include infections due to low white blood cells, seizures, severe constipation or bowel blockage, myocarditis or cardiomyopathy with chest pain or shortness of breath, fainting, and severe high blood sugar.

name: co-trimoxazole
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? co trimoxazole also known as trimethoprim sulfamethoxazole is an antibiotic used to treat bacterial infections such as urinary tract infections, some skin infections including certain community acquired methicillin resistant staphylococcus aureus, bronchitis exacerbations, ear infections, certain gastrointestinal infections, and pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia for treatment and prevention. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth with a full glass of water. it may be taken with food if stomach upset occurs. dosing is usually every twelve hours. shake liquid well before measuring. drink plenty of fluids during therapy. take for the full prescribed course even if you feel better. what special precautions should i follow? do not take if you have had an allergic reaction to sulfonamides or trimethoprim. tell your clinician if you have kidney or liver disease, folate deficiency, porphyria, thyroid disorder, or glucose six phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency. this medicine can increase potassium. tell your clinician about all medicines you take, especially warfarin, ace inhibitors, arbs, spironolactone, potassium supplements, diuretics, methotrexate, and phenytoin. it can make you more sensitive to sunlight. tell your clinician if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? maintain good hydration. unless told otherwise, avoid high potassium salt substitutes while taking medicines that raise potassium. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, and rash are common. it can cause photosensitivity with sunburn. serious reactions can include severe skin reactions such as stevens johnson syndrome, low blood counts including anemia and low white cells, high potassium, kidney problems, liver injury, and aseptic meningitis. seek medical help for widespread rash, peeling skin, mouth sores, yellowing of eyes or skin, dark urine, severe sore throat, unusual bleeding or bruising, or trouble breathing.

name: co-trimoxazole injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? co trimoxazole injection also known as intravenous trimethoprim sulfamethoxazole is used in the hospital to treat serious infections when the oral form cannot be used, including pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia, severe urinary tract infections, nocardiosis, and other susceptible infections. how should this medicine be used? it is given by a healthcare professional as an intravenous infusion, with the dose based on your weight and kidney function. treatment length depends on the infection. adequate hydration is important during therapy. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about any sulfonamide or trimethoprim allergy, kidney or liver disease, folate deficiency, glucose six phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. many drugs interact including warfarin, methotrexate, phenytoin, and medicines that raise potassium. your blood counts, kidney function, liver tests, and electrolytes especially potassium and sodium will be monitored. what special dietary instructions should i follow? maintain good hydration unless your clinician tells you otherwise. avoid high potassium salt substitutes if you are at risk for high potassium. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an infusion appointment, contact your healthcare team as soon as possible to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, and rash may occur. infusion site reactions such as pain or redness can occur. serious reactions include severe skin reactions, low blood counts, high potassium, kidney problems, liver injury, and aseptic meningitis. tell your clinician right away for fever, sore throat, unusual bleeding, yellowing of skin or eyes, dark urine, or trouble breathing.

name: cobicistat
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cobicistat is a pharmacokinetic enhancer used with certain hiv medicines such as elvitegravir, atazanavir, or darunavir to raise their levels and help them work better. it is not an antiviral on its own. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as prescribed with the companion antiretroviral, often once daily. some products must be taken with food. do not take cobicistat by itself. do not start, stop, or change any medicines without checking for interactions. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about kidney or liver problems and all medicines and supplements you take. cobicistat has many interactions because it inhibits cyp3a. some medicines must not be used with cobicistat, including certain heart rhythm medicines, some seizure medicines, rifampin, st john wort, and some cholesterol medicines such as simvastatin and lovastatin. it can increase creatinine by blocking tubular secretion without affecting true kidney filtration, but kidney function and urine protein will still be monitored. if used with tenofovir disoproxil fumarate, your clinician will monitor kidney function closely. tell your clinician if you are pregnant or planning pregnancy. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow product specific food instructions. avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice unless your clinician says it is safe. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time for the next dose, then skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. if you vomit within about one hour, follow the product instructions or ask your clinician whether to repeat the dose. what side effects can this medication cause? nausea, diarrhea, headache, and tiredness may occur. it can increase serum creatinine. rash or yellowing of the skin or eyes can occur, especially when boosting atazanavir. severe skin reactions are rare. seek medical care for severe rash, dark urine, pale stools, or persistent vomiting.

name: cobimetinib
instructions: important warning: cobimetinib can cause heart problems with decreased heart pumping function, bleeding, muscle breakdown with very high muscle enzymes, serious eye problems including serous retinopathy and retinal vein occlusion, liver injury, and severe photosensitivity. your clinician will check your heart function, liver tests, creatine kinase, and eyes as needed. use sun protection and seek care right away for vision changes, chest pain, unusual bleeding, severe muscle pain, dark urine, or shortness of breath. why is this medication prescribed? cobimetinib is used with vemurafenib to treat unresectable or metastatic melanoma that has a braf v600 mutation. how should this medicine be used? the usual dose is 60 mg by mouth once daily for twenty one days followed by seven days off to complete a twenty eight day cycle, with dose adjustments as needed for side effects. take with or without food at the same time each day. swallow tablets whole. if you vomit after a dose, do not take an extra dose. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about heart disease, bleeding problems, eye disease, liver problems, and all medicines you take. avoid strong cyp3a inhibitors and inducers. use effective birth control during treatment and for at least two weeks after the last dose. avoid excessive sun and use protective clothing and sunscreen. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and seville oranges. limit alcohol. maintain good hydration. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose and it is within twelve hours of your usual time, take it. if more than twelve hours have passed, skip the dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses on the same day. what side effects can this medication cause? diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, decreased appetite, rash, photosensitivity, swelling, fatigue, and elevated liver enzymes can occur. serious effects include heart failure with shortness of breath or swelling, severe bleeding, high creatine kinase with muscle pain or dark urine, eye problems with blurred vision or dark spots, and severe skin reactions.

name: codeine
instructions: important warning: codeine can cause addiction, abuse, and misuse, which can lead to overdose and death. serious and life threatening breathing problems can occur, especially when starting or increasing the dose, or when used with other sedatives such as benzodiazepines or alcohol. some children convert codeine to morphine more rapidly than normal due to cyp two d six ultra rapid metabolism, which can cause fatal breathing problems. do not use in children younger than twelve years old or after tonsil or adenoid surgery in anyone younger than eighteen years old. avoid use during breastfeeding. prolonged use during pregnancy can cause neonatal withdrawal. why is this medication prescribed? codeine is an opioid used to relieve mild to moderate pain and to suppress cough. it is often combined with other medicines such as acetaminophen or guaifenesin. how should this medicine be used? take exactly as directed at the lowest effective dose for the shortest possible time. if you use a combination product, check the maximum daily dose of the other ingredients such as acetaminophen. measure liquid with a dosing device. do not drink alcohol or use other sedatives. do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have breathing problems such as asthma or copd, head injury, seizures, liver or kidney disease, low blood pressure, gallbladder disease, stomach or bowel blockage, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. many drugs interact with codeine including other opioids, benzodiazepines, sleep medicines, muscle relaxants, and drugs that affect cyp enzymes. use a bowel regimen if needed to prevent constipation. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid alcohol. drink plenty of fluids and increase dietary fiber to help prevent constipation. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you take codeine on a schedule, take the missed dose as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. for as needed use, take only when needed for symptoms. what side effects can this medication cause? drowsiness, dizziness, constipation, nausea, vomiting, dry mouth, sweating, and itching are common. serious effects include slow or shallow breathing, confusion, fainting, severe sleepiness, low blood pressure, and allergic reactions. long term use can cause dependence and withdrawal if stopped suddenly.

name: colchicine
instructions: important warning: colchicine has a narrow margin between effective and toxic doses. serious and sometimes fatal toxicity can occur with overdose and with certain drug interactions, especially with strong cyp three a four or p glycoprotein inhibitors such as clarithromycin, ketoconazole, certain hiv protease inhibitors, cyclosporine, and verapamil, particularly in people with kidney or liver problems. never take more than prescribed and do not combine with interacting drugs without clinician guidance. why is this medication prescribed? colchicine is used to treat acute gout flares, to prevent gout flares, and to treat familial mediterranean fever. how should this medicine be used? for an acute gout flare, the typical starting regimen is 1.2 mg at the first sign of a flare followed by 0.6 mg one hour later, then your clinician may direct you to continue 0.6 mg once or twice daily until the flare resolves. for prevention of flares, the usual dose is 0.6 mg once or twice daily. doses must be reduced in kidney or liver impairment and when taken with some other medicines. do not repeat treatment courses for a flare too soon and follow your clinician instructions. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about kidney or liver problems, stomach or bowel disease, blood disorders, and all medicines and supplements you take. dangerous interactions occur with certain antibiotics such as clarithromycin and erythromycin, antifungals such as ketoconazole and itraconazole, calcium channel blockers such as verapamil and diltiazem, amiodarone, cyclosporine, and some hiv medicines. using colchicine with statins or fibrates can increase the risk of muscle problems, especially with kidney disease. tell your clinician if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice. drink plenty of water. for gout, follow a low purine diet as advised, including limiting red meat, organ meats, alcohol especially beer, and drinks sweetened with high fructose corn syrup, and consider increasing low fat dairy intake. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it when you remember unless it is close to the next dose, then skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. for the flare regimen, if you miss the dose that is due one hour after the first dose and it has been many hours, skip it and continue as directed. what side effects can this medication cause? diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain are common. serious effects include muscle pain or weakness, numbness or tingling, severe fatigue, signs of infection or unusual bleeding from low blood counts, and liver problems. stop the medicine and seek medical care if severe vomiting or diarrhea occurs as this can be a sign of toxicity.

name: colesevelam
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? colesevelam is a bile acid sequestrant used to lower ldl cholesterol and to improve blood sugar in adults with type two diabetes when added to diet and exercise. it may be used with statins or other lipid medicines. how should this medicine be used? take with meals and a beverage. swallow tablets whole. if using the powder for suspension, mix with water, juice, or diet soda and drink with a meal. this medicine can reduce the absorption of some medicines. take other medicines at least four hours before colesevelam if possible or as directed by your clinician. follow your prescribed cholesterol lowering diet. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have a history of bowel obstruction, swallowing problems, severe constipation, triglycerides above 500 mg per dl, or pancreatitis from high triglycerides. tell your clinician about all medicines you take including levothyroxine, certain seizure medicines, cyclosporine, and fat soluble vitamins. periodic monitoring of lipids is needed because colesevelam can increase triglycerides. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow a heart healthy diet low in saturated fat and cholesterol. increase dietary fiber and fluids to prevent constipation. you may need supplementation of vitamins a, d, e, and k, taken at a different time than colesevelam. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember with food. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? constipation, indigestion, nausea, gas, and abdominal discomfort are common. triglycerides may increase. rarely, bowel obstruction can occur. long term use may reduce absorption of fat soluble vitamins.

name: colestipol
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? colestipol is used with diet and exercise to lower bad cholesterol ldl and reduce the risk of heart disease and stroke when lifestyle changes alone are not enough. how should this medicine be used? take colestipol exactly as directed. it is available as large tablets or as granules for oral suspension. swallow tablets one at a time with a full glass of water and do not crush or chew them. if using granules, mix the dose with plenty of liquid or soft food and swallow without chewing the granules. drink extra fluids to help prevent constipation. because colestipol can reduce the absorption of many other oral medicines, take other medicines at least 1 hour before or 4 hours after colestipol unless your clinician gives you different instructions. keep all lab appointments to monitor cholesterol and vitamins. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have bowel obstruction, constipation, swallowing difficulties, major gastrointestinal disease, or very high triglycerides. tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements you take. colestipol can reduce the absorption of many drugs including warfarin, thyroid hormone, certain blood pressure medicines, and others. long term use can reduce absorption of fat soluble vitamins a d e and k and folate. your clinician may recommend vitamin supplementation and will monitor for bleeding or bone problems. tell your clinician if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. increase fiber and fluids to reduce constipation and contact your clinician for severe abdominal pain, no bowel movement for several days, or rectal bleeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow a cholesterol lowering eating plan, limit saturated fats and trans fats, and increase soluble fiber as advised. drink plenty of fluids. take any recommended vitamin supplements as directed by your clinician. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include constipation, abdominal pain, bloating, gas, nausea, vomiting, and indigestion. it can lower absorption of vitamins a d e and k which may cause easy bruising or bleeding or bone problems. rare but serious effects include severe constipation with fecal impaction, bowel obstruction, and severe abdominal pain. allergic reactions such as rash or itching can occur. contact your clinician for any severe or persistent symptoms.

name: colistimethate injection
instructions: important warning: colistimethate can cause serious kidney and nerve problems, and dose expressions can be confusing because products and references may express dose as colistin base activity or as colistimethate sodium. it can also weaken breathing muscles, especially when used with anesthesia or muscle relaxants. you will be closely monitored for side effects and correct dosing. why is this medication prescribed? colistimethate is used to treat serious infections caused by certain gram negative bacteria when other treatments are not appropriate or effective. how should this medicine be used? a health care professional gives this medicine by intravenous infusion or intramuscular injection. dosing is individualized and adjusted for kidney function. take the full course as prescribed even if you feel better. you will have regular blood and urine tests to monitor for side effects. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have kidney disease, nerve disorders, myasthenia gravis, or breathing problems, and list all medicines you take, especially other medicines that can harm the kidneys or nerves such as aminoglycosides, vancomycin, amphotericin b, or diuretics, and medicines that affect neuromuscular transmission. tell your clinician about planned surgery or anesthesia. report symptoms of nerve toxicity such as tingling, numbness, dizziness, confusion, visual changes, slurred speech, or muscle weakness, and signs of kidney problems such as decreased urine, swelling, or sudden weight gain. tell your clinician if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. stay well hydrated unless your clinician gives you different instructions. what should i do if i forget a dose? this medicine is usually given in a clinic or hospital. if you miss an appointment, contact your care team as soon as possible to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, stomach upset, dizziness, tingling or numbness, headache, and rash can occur. serious effects include kidney injury with decreased urine or swelling, severe nerve toxicity with muscle weakness or trouble breathing, neuromuscular blockade, and severe watery diarrhea which may occur during or after treatment and can signal clostridioides difficile infection. seek urgent care for trouble breathing, severe weakness, or severe allergic reaction such as hives, swelling of the face or throat, or fainting.

name: collagenase clostridium histolyticum injection
instructions: important warning: this medicine can cause tendon or ligament rupture in the hand and can cause sudden injury to the penis including corporal rupture and severe bruising when used for peyronie disease. seek emergency care if you feel a sudden pop, severe pain, loss of function, or severe swelling after treatment. why is this medication prescribed? collagenase clostridium histolyticum is used to treat dupuytren contracture with a palpable cord in the hand and to treat peyronie disease with a palpable plaque causing bothersome curve of the penis. how should this medicine be used? a trained clinician injects the medicine directly into the cord or plaque. for dupuytren contracture, the affected finger is usually straightened by your clinician one to three days after the injection, and you may need splinting and exercises. for peyronie disease, you will receive a series of injections and in office modeling and you must avoid sexual activity and vigorous physical activity for the period your clinician recommends. follow all post procedure instructions carefully. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about bleeding problems, use of blood thinners, prior tendon or ligament injuries, infection in the treatment area, or any allergy to collagenase or other proteins. use only under the care of an experienced clinician. avoid strenuous use of the treated hand until cleared. for peyronie disease, strictly follow all instructions regarding activity restriction and penile modeling. tell your clinician if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an injection or follow up appointment, contact your clinician to reschedule. do not attempt to manipulate the treated area yourself. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include swelling, pain, tenderness, bruising, bleeding, or blisters at the injection site, enlarged lymph nodes in the armpit or elbow, itching, headache, and nausea. serious effects include tendon rupture, ligament injury, nerve injury, complex regional pain, penile fracture with sudden loss of erection, severe bruising of the penis, urethral injury, and allergic reactions such as hives, trouble breathing, or fainting.

name: copanlisib injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? copanlisib is used to treat adults with relapsed follicular lymphoma who have received at least two prior systemic treatments. how should this medicine be used? a health care professional gives copanlisib by intravenous infusion, typically on days 1, 8, and 15 of a 28 day cycle. your care team will check your blood pressure and blood sugar before and after each infusion and will adjust your treatment as needed. keep all lab and clinic appointments. what special precautions should i follow?if you have diabetes, high blood pressure, lung disease, active or chronic infections, liver problems, or bowel problems. copanlisib can raise blood sugar and blood pressure soon after the infusion and can increase the risk of serious infections, lung inflammation, bowel perforation, severe diarrhea, bleeding, and low blood counts.about all medicines and supplements you take, especially those that affect an enzyme called cyp3a such as certain antifungals, antibiotics, anticonvulsants, and herbal products like st john wort. do not receive live vaccines during treatment. use effective birth control during treatment and for the time advised after the last dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? on treatment days limit simple sugars as advised and follow your diabetes plan if applicable. avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice unless your doctor says it is safe. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an infusion appointment, call your clinic to reschedule. do not try to make up a dose on your own. what side effects can this medication cause? high blood sugar, high blood pressure during or soon after the infusion, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, decreased appetite, fatigue, cough, shortness of breath, fever, infections, rash, mouth sores, and abnormal liver tests can occur. low white blood cells or platelets and infusion reactions with chills or flushing may occur. seek urgent care for severe abdominal pain, chest pain, shortness of breath, confusion, or signs of infection such as fever or chills.

name: cosibelimab-ipdl injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cosibelimab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor used to treat adults with metastatic or locally advanced cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma when surgery or radiation would not be curative. how should this medicine be used? a health care professional gives the medicine by intravenous infusion at regular intervals. treatment usually continues until the cancer progresses or side effects require stopping. what special precautions should i follow? this medicine can cause your immune system to attack normal organs and tissues, leading to inflammation of the lungs, intestines, liver, kidneys, hormone glands, heart, nerves, skin, or eyes.if you have an autoimmune disease, have received an organ or stem cell transplant, or take immunosuppressive medicines. report new or worsening cough, shortness of breath, diarrhea, abdominal pain, dark urine, yellowing of the skin or eyes, severe rash, headache, vision changes, extreme tiredness, dizziness, fainting, muscle weakness, or changes in urination.about all medicines you take. this medicine can harm an unborn baby; use effective contraception during treatment and for the advised time after the last dose. breastfeeding is not recommended during treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an infusion appointment, call your clinic as soon as possible to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? fatigue, rash, itching, diarrhea, nausea, decreased appetite, joint or muscle pain, cough, and fever are common. serious effects can include pneumonitis, colitis, hepatitis, endocrinopathies such as thyroid problems or adrenal insufficiency, diabetes, nephritis, severe skin reactions, myocarditis, nerve problems, and infusion reactions.

name: covid-19 vaccine, adjuvanted
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? this vaccine helps prevent coronavirus disease 2019 covid 19. how should this medicine be used? a health care professional gives the vaccine as a shot into a muscle. the number and timing of doses depend on your age, health status, and prior vaccination history. follow current public health guidance to stay up to date. what special precautions should i follow? tell your provider if you ever had a severe allergic reaction to any vaccine or to ingredients in this product such as polysorbate, or to a previous dose of a covid 19 vaccine. tell your provider if you had myocarditis or pericarditis after any vaccine, if you have a bleeding disorder or take blood thinners, if you have a weakened immune system, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. you may be observed for 15 to 30 minutes after vaccination. seek immediate care for chest pain, shortness of breath, or fast or pounding heartbeat after vaccination. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is needed. stay well hydrated. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a scheduled dose, get it as soon as you can. you do not need to restart the series. what side effects can this medication cause? pain, redness, or swelling where the shot was given, tiredness, headache, muscle aches, chills, fever, nausea, and swollen lymph nodes are common and usually go away in a few days. severe allergic reactions are rare. myocarditis and pericarditis have occurred rarely, most often in younger males, usually within a few days after vaccination.

name: crinecerfont
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? crinecerfont is used to help manage classic congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 21 hydroxylase deficiency by lowering excess adrenal androgens, which may allow reduction of glucocorticoid doses while maintaining control of the condition. how should this medicine be used? take crinecerfont by mouth exactly as prescribed, at the same times each day. do not change or stop your other adrenal medicines unless your clinician tells you to. your clinician will adjust your treatment based on symptoms and lab results. keep all appointments for blood tests and checkups. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements you take and about liver or kidney disease and any history of mood disorders. this medicine may interact with other medicines. tell your clinician if you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or are breastfeeding. carry your emergency steroid card or medical alert information and follow your sick day rules. seek urgent care if you have signs of adrenal crisis such as severe weakness, vomiting, abdominal pain, confusion, or fainting. what special dietary instructions should i follow? unless your clinician gives you different instructions, no special diet is needed. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time for your next dose. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? headache, nausea, stomach pain, diarrhea, fatigue, trouble sleeping, and mood changes can occur. if your glucocorticoid dose is reduced too quickly, symptoms of adrenal insufficiency may occur such as dizziness, low blood pressure, and severe tiredness. call your clinician right away for yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, unusual bleeding or bruising, or other concerning symptoms.

name: crisaborole topical
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? crisaborole is used on the skin to treat mild to moderate atopic dermatitis eczema in adults and children. how should this medicine be used? apply a thin layer to affected skin twice daily or as directed. for skin use only. avoid contact with the eyes, mouth, and inside the nose or vagina. wash hands after applying unless treating the hands. do not cover with bandages or tight dressings unless your clinician tells you to. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have ever had a reaction to this medicine or any of its ingredients. stop and seek care if you develop hives, swelling, or trouble breathing. burning or stinging can occur when applied to inflamed skin. tell your clinician if the treated area looks infected or if your condition does not improve. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. what should i do if i forget a dose? apply it when you remember, then return to your regular schedule. do not apply extra to make up for a missed application. what side effects can this medication cause? application site pain, burning, stinging, redness, itching, and allergic reactions such as hives or swelling of the face, lips, tongue, or throat can occur.

name: crizotinib
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? crizotinib is used to treat certain cancers that have changes in the alk or ros1 genes, including some lung cancers and certain rare tumors, as determined by an approved test. how should this medicine be used? take crizotinib by mouth exactly as prescribed, usually twice daily at the same times each day. swallow capsules whole with water and do not crush or open them. if you vomit after a dose, do not take an extra dose and take the next dose at the regular time. what special precautions should i follow?about heart disease, lung disease, liver disease, kidney disease, or eye problems. this medicine can cause liver injury, lung inflammation, slow heart rate, changes in heart rhythm including qt prolongation, and vision changes.about all medicines and supplements you take, especially those that affect an enzyme called cyp3a. avoid driving or operating machinery if you have vision changes or dizziness. use effective birth control during treatment and for the advised time after the last dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice and avoid seville orange products. limit alcohol. you may take crizotinib with or without food but try to be consistent. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss a dose and it is less than 6 hours until your next dose, skip the missed dose and take your next dose at the regular time. if it is more than 6 hours until your next dose, take the missed dose when you remember. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? vision problems such as flashes of light or blurred vision, nausea, diarrhea, vomiting, constipation, swelling of hands or feet, tiredness, dizziness, changes in taste, numbness or tingling, and abdominal pain can occur. serious effects include liver injury with yellowing of the skin or eyes, severe shortness of breath or cough, fainting, fast or irregular heartbeat, severe bradycardia, severe vision loss, and low blood counts with infection or bleeding.

name: crofelemer
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? crofelemer is used to control noninfectious diarrhea in adults with human immunodeficiency virus who are receiving antiretroviral therapy. how should this medicine be used? take the delayed release tablets by mouth as prescribed, usually one tablet twice daily. swallow tablets whole and do not crush, chew, or split them. your doctor should evaluate for infectious causes of diarrhea before starting treatment. what special precautions should i follow?if you have fever, blood in the stool, severe abdominal pain, or signs of dehydration. this medicine is not for acute infectious diarrhea.about all medicines and supplements you take and if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. continue your antiretroviral therapy unless your doctor tells you otherwise. what special dietary instructions should i follow? drink plenty of fluids. your doctor may suggest avoiding foods and drinks that worsen diarrhea such as very fatty foods, spicy foods, caffeine, or alcohol. what should i do if i forget a dose? take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time for your next dose. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at once. what side effects can this medication cause? upper respiratory tract infection, bronchitis, abdominal pain, flatulence, increased bilirubin, and cough can occur. most side effects are mild.

name: cromolyn ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cromolyn ophthalmic is used to prevent and relieve symptoms of allergic conjunctivitis such as itchy, red, and watery eyes. it helps stabilize mast cells to reduce the release of substances that cause allergy symptoms. how should this medicine be used? use the eye drops exactly as directed, commonly one drop in each affected eye four to six times daily at regular intervals. wash your hands, avoid touching the dropper tip, tilt your head back, pull down the lower eyelid to form a pocket, instill the drop, then close your eyes and gently press the corner of your eye near the nose for one to two minutes. remove contact lenses before use and wait at least 15 minutes before reinserting. use regularly for best effect. full benefit may take several days to two weeks. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you are allergic to cromolyn or any ingredient in the product, if you wear contact lenses, or if you have an eye infection or have had eye surgery. do not use if the solution changes color, becomes cloudy, or the dropper tip touches any surface. do not share eye drops with others. if you are pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? temporary burning or stinging, blurred vision, watery eyes, dryness, mild eye irritation, or eyelid swelling can occur. stop use and contact your clinician if you have severe eye pain, worsening redness or swelling, vision changes, discharge, rash, or signs of an allergic reaction.

name: cromolyn oral inhalation
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cromolyn oral inhalation is used to prevent asthma symptoms and exercise induced bronchospasm. it helps reduce airway inflammation by stabilizing mast cells. it is not a rescue medicine for sudden breathing problems. how should this medicine be used? use the nebulizer solution exactly as directed, commonly 20 mg via nebulizer four times daily, and 10 to 15 minutes before exercise or known allergen exposure if advised. use only with a compatible nebulizer. breathe the mist in calmly and fully until the dose is finished. rinse your mouth after use. use regularly to maintain benefit. what special precautions should i follow? do not use for acute attacks. always keep a quick relief inhaler for sudden symptoms. tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements, and if you have heart, liver, or kidney problems, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. seek care if you experience worsening wheeze or breathing trouble after a dose. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. what should i do if i forget a dose? inhale it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and return to your regular schedule. do not use two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? throat irritation, cough, wheeze, chest tightness, nausea, unpleasant taste, or headache can occur. rarely, paradoxical bronchospasm, severe allergic reactions, or swelling can occur and require immediate medical attention.

name: cromolyn sodium nasal solution
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cromolyn sodium nasal solution is used to prevent and relieve symptoms of seasonal or perennial allergic rhinitis such as sneezing, runny or itchy nose, and congestion. how should this medicine be used? use as directed, often one spray in each nostril three to four times daily, and up to six times daily if needed. prime the spray before first use. blow your nose gently, keep your head upright, insert the tip into the nostril, and spray while sniffing gently. use regularly for best effect. full benefit may take one to two weeks. start before allergy season or anticipated exposure if possible. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you are allergic to cromolyn. do not share the bottle. keep the spray tip clean and avoid touching it to any surface. ask your clinician before use if you have recent nasal injury, surgery, nasal polyps, sinus infection, or asthma. if pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not use two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? nose irritation or burning, sneezing, cough, dry throat, or nosebleed can occur. stop use and seek care for severe nosebleed, wheezing, facial swelling, or signs of an allergic reaction.

name: crovalimab-akkz injection
instructions: important warning: crovalimab increases the risk of serious and life threatening infections caused by neisseria meningitidis. you should receive meningococcal vaccines at least two weeks before the first dose. if treatment must start sooner, your clinician may prescribe preventive antibiotics. learn the symptoms of meningococcal infection such as fever, severe headache, stiff neck, confusion, light sensitivity, muscle aches, or a dark purple rash and seek emergency care if they occur. infections with other encapsulated bacteria such as streptococcus pneumoniae and haemophilus influenzae can also occur. do not stop treatment without medical guidance because hemolysis can recur after interruption. why is this medication prescribed? crovalimab is a complement c5 inhibitor used to treat paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria to reduce hemolysis and the need for transfusions. it may be used for other complement mediated conditions as approved. how should this medicine be used? it is given as a subcutaneous injection on a loading schedule followed by maintenance dosing commonly every four weeks. it may be given by a clinician or self administered after training. rotate injection sites on the abdomen, thigh, or upper arm and avoid areas that are tender, bruised, scarred, or infected. follow the dosing schedule exactly and do not discontinue without medical advice. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have not been fully vaccinated against meningococcal disease, if you have a fever or infection, or if you have a history of complement deficiency. report all medicines and vaccines you receive. use effective contraception during treatment and for the recommended period after the last dose. tell your clinician if you have liver or kidney disease, autoimmune disorders, or a history of infusion or injection reactions. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your clinician for instructions. if you self inject and realize the missed dose soon after the scheduled time, take it when remembered and resume your regular schedule. if it is near the time of the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not inject two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? injection site pain, redness, or swelling, headache, tiredness, nausea, diarrhea, and upper respiratory symptoms can occur. serious effects include meningococcal or other serious infections, hypersensitivity or injection reactions, breakthrough hemolysis with dark urine, shortness of breath, chest pain, rapid heart rate, low hemoglobin, and blood clots. seek immediate care for symptoms of severe infection or hemolysis.

name: cyanocobalamin vitamin b12
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cyanocobalamin is used to treat and prevent vitamin b12 deficiency which can lead to anemia and nerve problems. it is used when intake is low, absorption is impaired, or certain medicines reduce b12 levels. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth as tablets or sublingual forms as directed, usually once daily at the same time each day. swallow tablets with water or allow sublingual forms to dissolve under the tongue. severe deficiency or pernicious anemia often requires initial treatment with injections. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have leber optic neuropathy, cobalt allergy, megaloblastic anemia, low potassium, kidney or liver disease, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. tell your clinician about all medicines, especially metformin, proton pump inhibitors, h2 blockers, colchicine, chloramphenicol, and folic acid, which can affect response or lab tests. regular blood tests may be needed to monitor treatment. what special dietary instructions should i follow? include foods rich in vitamin b12 such as meat, fish, dairy, and fortified cereals unless advised otherwise. people who follow a vegan diet usually need ongoing supplementation. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? cyanocobalamin is usually well tolerated. diarrhea, nausea, headache, itching, or rash can occur. rarely, allergic reactions with hives, swelling, or trouble breathing can occur. in people with severe anemia, low potassium can occur when starting therapy which can cause muscle weakness or an irregular heartbeat.

name: cyanocobalamin injection
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cyanocobalamin injection treats vitamin b12 deficiency including pernicious anemia and malabsorption and helps prevent anemia and neurologic damage. how should this medicine be used? it is given by a clinician or by you after training as an intramuscular or deep subcutaneous injection using a schedule that often includes frequent doses at first such as daily or weekly followed by monthly maintenance. lifelong therapy is often needed in pernicious anemia. blood tests guide dosing and response. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have a cobalt allergy, leber optic neuropathy, kidney or liver disease, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements. iron or folate deficiencies may also need treatment. during initial therapy for severe anemia your clinician may monitor potassium levels. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow the diet recommended by your clinician. if deficiency is due to low intake, include foods rich in vitamin b12, but those with pernicious anemia will still require injections. what should i do if i forget a dose? contact your clinic to reschedule the injection as soon as possible. do not administer two injections at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? pain, redness, or swelling at the injection site, diarrhea, nausea, headache, dizziness, itching, or rash can occur. rarely, severe allergic reactions, fluid retention, worsening of heart failure in susceptible individuals, or low potassium during early treatment can occur.

name: cyanocobalamin nasal gel
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cyanocobalamin nasal gel is used for maintenance of vitamin b12 levels in people who have been stabilized with injections and do not have conditions that impair nasal absorption. it is not for initial treatment of severe deficiency or neurologic symptoms. how should this medicine be used? administer as directed, commonly one spray into one nostril once a week at the same time each week. prime the device before the first use. avoid blowing your nose for at least one hour after dosing. do not use within one hour before or after hot food or beverages since heat can increase nasal secretions and reduce absorption. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician if you have nasal congestion, rhinitis, a cold, nasal polyps, or recent nasal surgery since these can reduce absorption. tell your clinician about cobalt allergy, leber optic neuropathy, and all medicines and supplements. regular blood tests are needed to confirm adequate levels. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow your clinician guidance. maintain adequate dietary intake of vitamin b12 if appropriate. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it as soon as you remember unless it is close to the next scheduled dose. if it is near the time of the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular weekly schedule. do not use two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? nasal irritation, runny nose, congestion, sore throat, headache, cough, or nausea can occur. rarely, allergic reactions can occur.

name: cyclobenzaprine
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cyclobenzaprine is used short term to relieve muscle spasm associated with acute musculoskeletal conditions. it reduces muscle spasm, discomfort, and improves mobility. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth exactly as prescribed. immediate release tablets are usually taken three times daily. extended release capsules are usually taken once daily. take at the same time each day. do not crush or chew extended release capsules. use for short periods usually up to two or three weeks. what special precautions should i follow? do not use if you have taken a monoamine oxidase inhibitor in the past 14 days. tell your clinician if you have glaucoma, urinary retention, thyroid disease, heart rhythm problems, heart failure, recent heart attack, liver disease, or if you are an older adult. it may cause drowsiness and dizziness. avoid driving or operating machinery until you know how it affects you and avoid alcohol or other sedatives. serotonin syndrome can occur when combined with certain antidepressants, tramadol, or triptans. tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no special diet is required. avoid alcohol because it increases drowsiness. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at the same time. what side effects can this medication cause? drowsiness, dry mouth, dizziness, fatigue, constipation, blurred vision, and confusion can occur. serious effects are rare but include fast or irregular heartbeat, chest pain, severe dizziness or fainting, signs of serotonin syndrome such as agitation, fever, sweating, tremor, and muscle stiffness, and allergic reactions.

name: cyclophosphamide
instructions: important warning: cyclophosphamide can cause severe bone marrow suppression leading to infection and bleeding. it can damage the bladder and kidneys including hemorrhagic cystitis and it increases the risk of bladder cancer and other cancers later in life. it can cause fetal harm and permanent infertility in males and females. it can cause serious heart and lung toxicity particularly at higher doses. your clinician will monitor blood counts and urine and may prescribe mesna with higher doses along with aggressive hydration and frequent urination to protect the bladder. report fever, chills, sore throat, unusual bleeding or bruising, blood in urine, or painful urination right away. why is this medication prescribed? cyclophosphamide is used to treat various cancers such as lymphomas, leukemias, breast cancer, and others, and to treat some severe autoimmune diseases when other treatments are inadequate. how should this medicine be used? take by mouth exactly as directed as part of a treatment plan. swallow with water. take in the morning if possible and drink plenty of fluids throughout the day. your clinician may instruct you to empty your bladder frequently and at bedtime. do not change your dose or schedule without medical advice. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements. avoid live vaccines during treatment and until your clinician says it is safe. use effective contraception during treatment and for the recommended time after the last dose. do not breastfeed during treatment and for a period after the last dose. tell your clinician if you have liver, kidney, heart, or lung disease, prior chemotherapy or radiation, a history of infections, or prior blood in the urine. discuss fertility preservation before starting. seek care for shortness of breath, chest pain, swelling, sudden weight gain, severe nausea or vomiting, diarrhea, or mouth sores. what special dietary instructions should i follow? drink plenty of fluids as directed. small frequent meals and prescribed anti nausea medicines can help with nausea. limit alcohol especially if you have liver problems. what should i do if i forget a dose? follow your clinician instructions. if you miss a dose take it as soon as you remember on the same day. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose. do not take two doses at the same time. if you vomit shortly after a dose call your clinician for guidance. what side effects can this medication cause? low blood counts with increased risk of infection, anemia, and bleeding, nausea, vomiting, poor appetite, diarrhea, mouth sores, hair loss, darkening of skin or nails, and fatigue are common. serious effects include hemorrhagic cystitis with blood in urine and painful urination, severe infections or sepsis, heart problems such as heart failure or rhythm changes, lung inflammation, liver problems, kidney problems, severe allergic reactions, low sodium, and the development of other cancers such as leukemia or bladder cancer.

name: cyclophosphamide injection
instructions: important warning: cyclophosphamide injection can cause severe bone marrow suppression with risk of serious and sometimes fatal infections, hemorrhagic cystitis and bladder damage, kidney injury, serious heart and lung toxicity at higher doses, infertility, fetal harm, and secondary cancers. mesna, aggressive hydration, and frequent urination may be used to protect the bladder. close monitoring of blood counts, urine, and organ function is required. report fever, chills, sore throat, unusual bruising or bleeding, blood in urine, or painful urination right away. why is this medication prescribed? it is used alone or with other medicines to treat cancers such as lymphomas, leukemias, multiple myeloma, breast cancer, ovarian cancer, and others, and to treat certain severe autoimmune diseases when appropriate. how should this medicine be used? it is given by intravenous infusion in a clinic or hospital on schedules that vary by condition. dosing is individualized. hydration before and after the infusion is often used. you may receive anti nausea medicine and mesna to protect the bladder. follow all instructions about fluid intake and bathroom breaks. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements and any history of liver, kidney, heart, or lung disease, prior chemotherapy or radiation, infections, or bleeding problems. avoid live vaccines during treatment and until your clinician says it is safe. use effective contraception during treatment and for the recommended time after the last dose. do not breastfeed during treatment and for a period after the last dose. discuss fertility preservation before starting. report shortness of breath, chest pain, swelling, sudden weight gain, severe nausea or vomiting, diarrhea, mouth sores, or any signs of infection or bleeding. what special dietary instructions should i follow? follow clinician guidance on hydration and diet. drink plenty of fluids unless told otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? call your clinic as soon as possible to reschedule a missed infusion appointment. what side effects can this medication cause? low blood counts with increased risk of infection, anemia, and bleeding, nausea, vomiting, poor appetite, diarrhea, mouth sores, hair loss, darkening of skin or nails, and fatigue are common. serious effects include hemorrhagic cystitis, severe infections or sepsis, heart problems, lung inflammation, liver and kidney problems, severe allergic reactions, low sodium, and development of other cancers later on.

name: cyclosporine
instructions: important warning: cyclosporine can increase your risk of serious infections and cancers including lymphoma and skin cancer. it can cause kidney damage and high blood pressure. it must be prescribed and monitored by a clinician experienced with immunosuppressive therapy. drug levels, kidney function, and blood pressure require regular monitoring. do not switch between different cyclosporine products unless your prescriber tells you to do so. why is this medication prescribed? cyclosporine is used to prevent organ rejection after kidney, liver, or heart transplant. it is also used to treat severe rheumatoid arthritis and severe plaque psoriasis when other treatments have not worked or are not appropriate. how should this medicine be used? take cyclosporine by mouth at the same times each day and in a consistent way with regard to meals. swallow capsules whole. if using the liquid, measure with the provided device and mix with room temperature orange juice or milk, then drink right away and rinse the cup to ensure the full dose. your dose may be adjusted based on blood tests that measure cyclosporine levels. do not substitute between modified and non modified formulations without medical guidance. what special precautions should i follow?and pharmacist about all medicines and supplements you use, especially azole antifungals, macrolide antibiotics, calcium channel blockers, rifampin, anticonvulsants, hiv or hcv medicines, potassium supplements, and herbal products such as st johns wort. avoid live vaccines while taking cyclosporine.if you have kidney or liver disease, high blood pressure, high potassium, a history of cancer, or if you are pregnant or planning to become pregnant. protect your skin from sunlight. your blood pressure and labs will be checked regularly. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice. do not use potassium rich salt substitutes unless your doctor tells you to. take cyclosporine consistently with or without food. what should i do if i forget a dose? take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for your next dose. if it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose and resume your regular schedule. do not take two doses at once. call your doctor if you miss more than one dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include headache, tremor, increased hair growth, acne, nausea, diarrhea, and high blood pressure. serious effects include signs of infection such as fever or sore throat, decreased urine, swelling of legs, confusion, seizures, vision changes, severe stomach pain, yellowing of the skin or eyes, and severe allergic reactions. contact your clinician right away if serious effects occur.

name: cyclosporine injection
instructions: important warning: cyclosporine can increase the risk of serious infections and cancers, and can cause kidney damage and high blood pressure. intravenous cyclosporine can cause severe allergic infusion reactions. it must be given and monitored by experienced clinicians with regular checks of drug levels, kidney function, and blood pressure. why is this medication prescribed? the injection is used to prevent organ rejection in kidney, liver, or heart transplant recipients who cannot take oral medicine or as initial therapy before switching to oral cyclosporine. how should this medicine be used? it is given by a healthcare professional as an intravenous infusion, usually over several hours, and is switched to oral therapy as soon as possible. your dose is individualized and adjusted based on blood levels and lab results. what special precautions should i follow? tell your care team about all medicines and supplements you take, especially drugs that affect cytochrome p450 3a, p glycoprotein, or kidney function. report any shortness of breath, rash, flushing, chest tightness, or other infusion reactions during administration. avoid live vaccines. tell your clinician if you have kidney or liver disease, high blood pressure, or if you are pregnant or planning pregnancy. what special dietary instructions should i follow? avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice. limit potassium rich salt substitutes unless your clinician advises otherwise. what should i do if i forget a dose? if you miss an infusion appointment, contact your healthcare team as soon as possible to reschedule. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include tremor, headache, nausea, vomiting, high blood pressure, and increased hair growth. serious effects include severe allergic or infusion reactions with trouble breathing or swelling, kidney problems with decreased urine, signs of infection, seizures, confusion, vision changes, and liver problems. seek urgent care for signs of severe reaction or infection.

name: cyclosporine ophthalmic
instructions: why is this medication prescribed? cyclosporine eye drops are used to increase tear production in people with chronic dry eye disease where tear production is presumed to be suppressed due to ocular inflammation. some products may also be used for certain allergic eye conditions as directed by a specialist. how should this medicine be used? instill one drop into the affected eye or eyes twice daily about 12 hours apart or as directed. wash your hands, avoid touching the dropper tip to your eye or any surface, and recap tightly. remove contact lenses before use and wait at least 15 minutes before reinserting them. if you use other eye medicines, separate them by at least 5 to 15 minutes. benefits may take several weeks to a few months. use daily as prescribed to maintain effect. what special precautions should i follow? tell your clinician about any eye infections, recent eye surgery, or allergies. do not use during an active eye infection unless directed. tell your clinician if you are pregnant, planning to become pregnant, or breastfeeding. stop and call your clinician if you develop eye pain, worsening redness, or changes in vision. what special dietary instructions should i follow? no specific dietary restrictions are needed for the eye drops. what should i do if i forget a dose? use it as soon as you remember. if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and use the next dose at the regular time. do not use extra drops to make up for a missed dose. what side effects can this medication cause? common effects include temporary burning or stinging, eye redness, watery eyes, and blurred vision. serious effects include eye pain, swelling, discharge, significant vision changes, or signs of infection. seek medical advice if serious effects occur.

name: cyproheptadine
